column2: IN the course of his new novel, "To Live as We Wish,"* Mark Aldanov has his principal character, a writer, brood about the differences between plays and novels as literary media. Plays are fine in their way, Victor Yatsenko concludes, but their limitations as a form are exasperating. Novels are so various in concept and design that they cannot even be defined.
An unusually large number of shows of painting and sculpture make up this week's busy program. Nor are these exhibitions limited to the present day nor to these two mediums.
The following booklet, of special interest to working wives, was published today :

Both representative of the United States in the women's world chess championship challengers tournament in Moscow were winners, yesterday, in the fourteenth and semi-final round, according to a report received through Soviet news sources.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- The United Textile Workers of Amer ica, A. F. L., demanded tonight that the Government either suspend wage controls in their industry or permit pay increases based on increased productivity.

A vocal group of American business men to whom Brazil owes money is demanding that the United States loan money to Brazil so that our Good Neighbor to the south can remit forthwith. Most recently, THE NEW YORK TIMES reported the earnest recommendation of James B. Herzog that the Export-Import Bank make such a loan.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 (AP) -- United States manufacturing corporations showed about the same profits after taxes but less before taxes in the second quarter of this year compared with the first quarter.

CHICAGO, Nov. 16 -- Drought conditions have prevailed over the major part of the country since September. Because of this there has been gradual improvement in prices for the various grains in spite of bearish statistical conditions and slow export trade. The dry weather threatens not only the winter wheat crop, but feed grains as well.

Now that the heat of the election is over, may I hope that you will devote some space in your great journal to examining ways and means to combat the muggings, household entries and even more serious crimes that are of daily occurrence in the Morningside Heights area, in which the home of General Eisenhower is located?

TEL AVIV, Israel, Nov. 16 -- The United States Embassy here today warned American citizens serving in the Israeli armed forces that they would lose their citizenship on Dec, 24 when the McCarran Immigration and Nationality Act becomes effective.

ATHENS, Monday, Nov. 17 -- Field Marshal Alexander Papagos' Greek Rally won yesterday's national election in a landslide. His conservative party will almost assuredly have at least two-thirds of the membership of the next Parliament.

In a surprise midnight-to-dawn drive on parking violators, thirty-four automobiles were impounded and towed away yesterday. In a few instances those who persistently ignore parking tickets were routed from bed by doormen who alerted the owners to the drastic procedure invoked to get the culprits to pay up or go to jail.
AUGUSTA, Ga., Nov. 16 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower prepared today to come to grips with the major problems confronting him as the new President while his two-week vacation in Georgia neared its end.

AUGUSTA, Ga., Nov. 16 -- Protestant churches here had overflow crowds today and some pastors suggested that many were attracted by the possibility that they might see Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the President-elect. General Eisenhower gave no advance notice of which church he would attend.

The movement of cotton prices in the domestic market was featured last week by a sharp drop in initial dealings occasioned by a larger-than-expected official crop report. At the close of trading on Friday active futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were down 20 to 102 points from levels of the previous week.

Van Pelt Manor House, built by a Dutch farmer in 1686 at what is now Eighteenth Avenue and Eighty-second Street, Brooklyn, lay in ruins yesterday, its stone walls shattered and its oak floors smashed by the Park Department.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 16 -- Settlement of the fourteen-week-old strike by the Screen Writers Guild and the Authors League of America, representing a combined membership of more than 6,000 writers, against the Alliance of Television Film Producers, was announced today together with the release of an incomplete summary of the proposed contract terms.

I object to The Associated Press statement that Governor Stevenson was able to hold together only the "tattered remnants" of the once-Solid South. I do not consider Alabama Arkansas, Georgia, Louisiana, Mississippi, North Carolina and South Carolina the tattered remnants of anything much less the Solid South. Florida and Virginia, Republican before, might more accurately be called the tattered fringe of the Solid South.

Negotiations are under way for the sale of the Fourth Presbyterian Church building, Ninety-first Street and West End Avenue, the Rev. Dr. Benjamin F. Farber, pastor, declared after services yesterday.

Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower has directed the establishment of a special personnel section at his temporary headquarters in the Commodore Hotel to handle the deluge of applications for jobs in the new Administration, now pouring in on him.

The two-day toll of four persons killed and dozens injured on the New Jersey Turnpike in a series of chain-reaction crashes in the foggy North Jersey marshlands has brought new efforts to assess the physical and psychological reasons for the accidents and to provide safeguards.
CLEVELAND, Nov. 16 (AP) -- Cleveland's Browns needed everything they had today to register a 29-28 victory over the Pittsburgh Steelers in a National Football League game before 34,973 fans.

Controller Lazarus Joseph announced yesterday that he opposed a suggestion to increase sewer rents to make possible the financing of the entire cost of future sewage treatment plant construction without reducing the city's borrowing capacity within the constitutional debt limit set by the state.

The Rev. Thomas A. Donnellan, vice chancellor of the Archdiocese of New York, yesterday called upon the Roman Catholics of America to fulfill their "vocation" to "bring Christ to men and men to Christ."

BONN, Germany, Nov. 16 -- The throbbing tempo of life in Germany was slowed today as the German people, for the first time since 1945, solemnly observed the Day of Remembrance honoring more than 6,000,000 Germans who died in two world wars and the unnumbered victims who perished in concentration camps between 1933 and 1945.
BOWIE, Md., Nov. 16 (AP) -- Bowie race track will open an eighteen-day fall meeting tomorrow with the $20,000 added Barbara Fritchie Handicap featuring an eight-race program.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 16 -- Many steel companies were looking to their plans for a more normal market some time next year. Now was the time they believed to review customer relationships, distance of customers from mill shipping points and history of purchases. Not all steel mills were this far along in their preparation for a more competitive market -- but many had begun their reshaping of sales policies.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 (AP) -- George E. Ijams, acting for the Veterans of Foreign Wars, protested today against any disposal of surplus sites for veteran hospitals by the outgoing Administration.

While the country at large was choosing a new National Administration last Nov. 4, voters in all but a dozen states were deciding on issues of taxation, public debt, welfare, civil rights, labor issues, political matters and a host of other subjects.
BRONXVILLE, N. Y., Nov. 16 -- The Saddle Tree Farms horse show today drew an entry of 400 for competition through thirty-five classes involving four championships.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., Nov. 16 -- With practically no breeze and therefore little momentum, the sailing dinghy regatta at the Larchmont Yacht Club wound up today with Jack Sutphen in his Rum Dum the top scorer with 114 points.
By the end of 1953 several million additional workers will be needed to meet defense production requirements and expected levels of civilian output.

With pledges of support from President Truman and Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, President - elect, Resources for the Future, Inc., a Ford Foundation subsidiary, will hold a citizens conference on the conservation and development of the nation's natural resources on March 25-27. The meeting will take place at the Mayflower Hotel in Washington.

New military displays in Moscow and fresh repetition of Soviet boasts of the invincibility of the Red Army again raise the question of the Kremlin's foreign policy. This policy, there is good reason to believe, is more subtle and flexible than is suggested by the naive question as to whether the Soviets want war.

The need for Congressional investigations of Communists in Government offices and other positions of public influence may disappear after Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the President-elect, is installed in the White House, Robert Morris, counsel to Senate Internal Security subcommittees, declared yesterday.

The Philadelphia Nationals triumphed over the New York Americans by 3 -- 1 in a feature game of an American Soccer League double-header at Sterling Oval, the Bronx, yesterday. As a result, the Nationals, with 10 points, maintained the tie with the Philadelphia Americans at the top of the standing.

CHICAGO, Nov. 16 (UP) -- Quarterback Norman Van Brocklin passed for 308 yards and four touchdowns today to spark the Los Angeles Rams to a 40-to-24 victory over the Chicago Bears before 40,737 fans at Wrigley Field.
In the minds of some there is fear, as a result of the Republican victory, that a depression lies ahead.

BELGRADE Nov. 16 -- An unpublicized rapprochement between Yugoslavia and West Germany has gone forward quietly but steadily over the last year and it is clear that geography and the rebirth of German economic power are once again destined to give the Germans an important role in this part of Europe.

I believe reader Gilbert H. Doane of Madison, Wis., was a bit presumptuous when he scored THE TIMES food expert, Jane Nickerson, for suggesting such doughnut recipes as "doughnut strawberry shortcake and a doughnut sandwich with a filling of maraschino cherries, prunes and whipped cream,' in her article of Oct. 30. In his letter to THE TIMES he maintains that the old fashioned doughnut should "be protected" from such recipes.

The season's first "Rigoletto," on Saturday evening at the Metropolitan Opera, presented a Metropolitan "first" -- Robert Merrill in the title role. The popular baritone was backed up by Ferruccio Tagliavini as the Duke, Roberta Peters as Gilda, Jerome Hines as Sparafucile, Jean Madeira as Maddalena and Thelma Votipka as Giovanna. Alberto Erede conducted.

The State Labor Relations Board held yesterday that it had no legal power to disqualify unions from participating in collective bargaining elections because of charges that the unions were set up as instruments of extortion and not as bona fide labor organizations.

The Hundred Year Association of New York has the pleasant habit of presenting a gold medal once a year to some citizen distinguished for services to his fellows. It has made happy choices in the past, but none happier than it did last evening, when it honored Howard S. Cullman.

PRINCETON, N. J., Nov. 16 -- Princeton University's undergraduate radio station, WPRU, will imitate the fund-raising activities of many commercial stations tomorrow evening with a fourteen-hour marathon for the benefit of the university's campus fund drive.

After yesterday afternoon's concert of the New York Philharmonic Symphony at Carnegie Hall, fourteen members of the orchestra hurried down to Town Hall where, under the title of the Philharmonic Chamber Ensemble, they presented the first of the five concerts they are giving there for the New Friends of Music.

One in every seven residents of New York City will seek the help of a voluntary hospital in 1953. In the past the hospitals of New York have offered continuous services for the benefit of everyone in the city. No one -- certainly not the one in every seven -- would want these services to diminish either in quality or quantity.
DETROIT, Nov. 16 (UP) -- Quarterback Bobby Layne ran and passed the Detroit Lions to a 43-to-13 victory over the homeless Dallas Texans today before 33,304 fans at Briggs Stadium.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, Nov. 16 -- Belgium is one of the most prosperous countries in Europe and her military progress reflects her military tradition and present wealth.

The research conducted by your Peter Kihss into restrictions on the distribution of Soviet material based on a recent complaint by us to the Post Office might give the impression that the American Civil Liberties Union is concerned with a picayune matter.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- The story of the American merchant marine in peace and war was unfolded here this week in an exhibit of paintings, photographs, manuscripts, ship models, figureheads and other nautical relics.

Francis the Talking Mule has been the subject of several motion-picture successes, but New York Military Academy at Cornwall-on-Hudson has a donkey that is trying to get into the spotlight, too. He is Skippy III, a moth-eaten gray with oversized ears, who serves as the football team's mascot.

CHICAGO, Nov 16 (AP) -- The inventor of Krebiozen, controversial cancer drug, charged yesterday that Dr. George D. Stoddard, president of the University of Illinois, was "seeking to confuse the public on the Krebiozen issue."
TUNIS, Tunisia, Nov. 16 (AP) -- Terrorist sprayed a military convoy and a barracks with automatic weapons fire today, killing four French soldiers and wounding twenty.

The annual gold medal award of the Hundred Year Association was presented last night at a dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria to Howard S. Cullman for his distinguished service over many years in charitable and public affairs.
ATHENS, Nov. 16 -- In the last thirty centuries or so, Greece, where the system of democratic choice was devised, has experimented with almost every kind of voting system.
LONDON, Nov. 16 -- Several British noblemen have told Queen Elizabeth II they just cannot afford the robes and coronets necessary for her coronation next year, it was reported tonight.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 (AP) -- The Government's top personnel official estimated today a new President could install his own selections in only about one half to one per cent of all Federal jobs.

GENEVA, Nov. 16 -- On the basis of new, although still preliminary, studies of the Italian population problems, Italian authorities believe that about 1965 the population growth in overcrowded Italy will come to an end.

BERLIN, Nov. 16 (UP) -- The East German Interior Ministry, which controls the police, warned the German Evangelical Church today that a planned program of prayer for political prisoners "could have grave consequences."
Ten little girls in Brooklyn, and the more or less willing brothers of one of their number, have started uncommonly young to fulfill an ambition to become journalists.

Like a breath fresh from Paris was the Maud et Nano millinery collection that was presented in the ballroom of the Pierre Hotel on Friday morning. To add to the French spirit was the musical French accent of Mme, Maud, who did the commentary.
Whenever the Japanese Emperor has his customary little talk with a new Premier-designate, he says:

" Trouble in Tahiti," Leonard Bernstein's one-act opera, which was done on the stage for the first time last June at Brandeis University in Waltham, Mass., received its first television performance yesterday afternoon when it was presented as the second work in the season's schedule of the N. B. C. Television Opera Theatre.

Mozart's "Don Giovanni" will be performed for the first time this season at the Metropolitan Opera House on Wednesday evening, Nov. 26. Six of the eight principal roles will be sung by artists who have never sung them before at the Metropolitan.
FORT WAYNE, Ind., Nov. 16 (AP) -- Dick Groat, Fort Wayne's star from Duke University, hit his first four shots tonight and pushed the Pistons to a 112-83 victory over the New York Knicker-bockers.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- President Truman said today a growing, deepening religious faith was "essential to our welfare as a nation" in calling upon religious leaders to "stand together against outbreaks of bigotry."
CHICAGO, Nov. 16 (UP) -- The Chicago Black Hawks trounced the Montreal Canadiens, 4 to 1, tonight and took over undisputed possession of first place in the National Hockey League.

MOSCOW, Nov. 16 -- The expansion of the Soviet Union's Antarctic whaling activity in the post-war period was reported today by the newspaper Red Fleet, which said that Soviet whalers topped 25,000 tons of whale oil in the last season -- more than four times the 1946 level.

Having established themselves at the box-office and with nearly all the critics, the performers in the French repertory company, brought over by Sol Hurok and headed by Madeleine Renaud and Jean-Louis Barrault, will swing into their second bill. "Le Proces" (The Trial), at 8:30 this evening at the Ziegfeld.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 16 -- Columbia Pictures, stepping up its 1953 production program to a total of twenty-two top-budget A films under the direction of its new executive producer, Jerry Wald, yesterday hired three new producers to help in carrying out the extended schedule.
TOKYO, Monday, Nov. 17 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,436, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Monday, Korea time:

The steamship charter market thus far in November has continued the "dull" trend experienced in the latter part of October, with the supply of American and foreign-flag ships of all sizes for time and voyage charter for November-December still far in excess of the limited commercial charterers' demand.
Completion of plans for New York's biggest atom bomb exercise, to be held in mid-December, was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 (AP) -- Secretary of the Treasury John N. Snyder today passed up the final opportunity to pay off $7,986,262,500 in 2 per cent 10-year bonds before they come due on Sept. 15, 1953.

LONDON, Nov. 16 -- Officials of the Iraq Petroleum Company, a joint United States, British, French and Dutch enterprise, are leaving for London this week to attend the formal opening of the world's largest pipeline which will triple the flow of oil from Iraq and make possible vast economic development of that Arab country.

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public, which will mature within twelve months, amount to $54,425,294,434. They consist of Treasury bonds, certificates of indebtedness, bills and notes as follows.

The current session of the General Assembly of the United Nations goes this week into its second month. Thus far there have been a large number of speeches, a spate of resolutions, some rather considerable exchanges of recrimination and a minimum of decisive actions. Korea has held the center of the stage most of the time and the deadlock in respect to truce terms has not been resolved.

The new ore ship Ernest T. Weir, under construction for the National Steel Corporation and described as the largest bulk carrier ever built in the Great Lakes, will be launched Wednesday at the American Ship Building Company yard, Lorain, Ohio. Displacing 21,500 tons, the vessel is 690 feet long and has a beam of seventy feet.

PRINCETON, N. J., Nov. 16 (UP) -- Dr. J. Robert Oppenheimer, one of the nation's leading atomic experts, today acclaimed the hydrogen bomb experiments announced by the Atomic Energy Commission as "very remarkable" and a "really impressive piece of work."

BERKELEY, Calif., Nov. 16 -- A discovery by two University of California scientists has indicated that nature has a high-speed way of producing new virus types ranging from harmless or beneficial ones to those having great virulence or deadliness.

LONDON, Nov. 16 -- The markets in the past few days have turned from their initial apprehensive, in fact rather gloomy, contemplation of the possible economic effects, not only in the United States, but in other countries, of the change of President and Administration in America to events on the home front.

For the first time this season the Giants failed to score a touchdown and it is difficult to say a kind word about their activities before 26,723 fans at the Polo Grounds yesterday. Steve Owen's club dropped a yawn-inducing 17-3 decision to the Green Bay Packers and fell from a first-place tie with the Browns to a second-place deadlock with the Eagles in the American Conference of the National Football League.
TANGIER, Nov. 16(AP) -- Spain has scored a diplomatic victory in getting greater authority in the international administration of Tangier.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 16 (AP) -- Pistol Pete Pihos, a sixty-minute man in this age of platoon football, recovered two fumbles, one resulting in a touchdown and the other in a field goal, to enable the Philadelphia Eagles to gain a 10-7 National Football League victory over the Chicago Cardinals today.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Nov. 16 -- Many Western diplomats in the Middle East believe that Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, when he becomes President, will have an opportunity to bring about a new deal in Arab-Israeli relations that may lead to peace negotiations. They feel that this would be second in importance only to whatever he may succeed in doing in the interests of peace in Korea.

PARIS, Nov. 16 -- Following the sharp attack delivered by Guy Mollet, secretary general of the French Socialist party, against the policies of the Pinay Cabinet, the French Socialist National Council voted a motion today condemning what it called the reactionary trend of the present ministry and proclaiming active opposition to a large number of items on the Pinay program.

Seymour M. Tannenbaum bought the five-story building containing a store and nine apartments at 2500 Eighth Avenue, near West 134th Street, from the estate of Henry Walker in a cash deal in which Curtis Solove was the broker. He resold the property to the 2500 Eighth Realty Corporation, which plans to occupy the now vacant bar and grill in the building.

Although some may regard it as unpatriotic to affirm that one is first a Christian and second an American, "such a priority is, in the long run, the best support for a sound America," the Rev. Dr. James A. Pike declared in a sermon yesterday morning at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, of which he is Dean.

CHICAGO, Nov. 16 -- Trade volume expanded a little last week over the previous period, but fell somewhat below the level of a year ago. On the whole the pit business on the Board of Trade was of moderate volume.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 16 -- India is putting finishing touches on a revised plan that she hopes will be accepted as a satisfactory basis for settlement of the prisoner-of-war phase in the Korean truce talks. She will submit the plan to the Political and Security Committee of the General Assembly by midweek.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 (UP) -- San Francisco's Forty-Niners, played off their feet for two quarters, surged from behind with two last-period touchdowns to beat the Washington Redskins, 23 -- 17, and break their two-game losing streak.

With four minutes of playing time remaining, dozens of the 12,163 customers began to walk unhappily out of Madison Square Garden last night. By that time it was clear to all hands that New York's beloved Rangers had no chance of winning in their National Hockey League match with the Toronto Maple Leafs.

BOSTON, Nov. 16 (UP) -- The Detroit Red Wings scored their first road victory of the season tonight as they defeated the Boston Bruins, 5 to 2, before 10,211 fans who turned out to witness the twenty-fifth anniversary of the Garden's first National Hockey League game.

HINESVILLE, Ga., Nov. 16 (UP) -- Col. Lloyd A. Corkan, acting post commander of Camp Stewart, Ga., was shot to death while hunting on the base reservation today, and a hunting companion admitted late tonight that he had shot the colonel accidentally.

TOKYO, Monday, Nov. 17 -- American planes destroyed yesterday a North Korean hydroelectric plant southwest of Tongchon on the Sea of Japan and north of the fighting front. Ground action dwindled to platoon engagements fought in snow and below freezing temperatures along most of the 155-mile battle line.

ZURICH Nov. 16 -- Gold dealers in Zurich pointed apprehensively last week to significant changes now taking place in the free gold market as a result of the verdict on Aug. 18 of the Swiss Federal Court that private minting of gold coins no longer in circulation as legal tender in countries of issue is not counterfeiting provided the coins are of full weight and fineness.

CAIRO, Nov. 16 -- Members of the new Egyptian regime are beginning to raise the question of what kind of political structure the country should have. Much interest has been aroused here by the public declaration last night by Ali Maher, who was the first Premier after the coup of July 23, in the presence of Maj. Gen. Mohammed Naguib, the Premier.
The oft-delayed plan to speed travel on West End Avenue by retiming signal lights for two-way progressive flow will go into effect at 10 A. M. today.

FOOTBALL'S theme song begins to sound suspiciously like the nursery jingle about the ten little Indians who kept disappearing from sight one by one until there were none. As of last Saturday morning five little Indians kept asking for more. But the Terps played Ole Miss. And then there were four. That's a bit crude but it does give you the idea.

State Controller J. Raymond McGovern denied yesterday as "unfounded and ridiculous" the charge made on Nov. 6 by Welfare Commissioner Henry L. McCarthy that the city was not getting its fair share of an annual "windfall" of $45,000,000 in Federal aid to the state for Welfare purposes.

Marking a comeback in automotive advertising, all year a laggard in linage, Chrysler Corporation, through N. W. Ayer Son, Inc., this week is beginning a teasers campaign for the 1953 Plymouth. The campaign will double that of any similar one in Plymouth's postwar history.

The Russian has -- or had, anyway -- a nice tight system for implying just the right amount of familiarity with the names he uses to address another. The average Russian, as every reader of the pre-Soviet Russian novel well knows, has three names: the last, or family name; the middle name, or patronymic, and the first, or given name.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- Representative Joseph W. Martin Jr. of Massachusetts, prospective Speaker of the House, declared tonight that if Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the President-elect, should name "a good outstanding Southerner" to his Cabinet, it would be "a very good thing for the country."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 (AP) -- Lieut. Gen. James H. Doolittle tonight was declared winner of the annual Wright Brothers Memorial Trophy, a top aviation award.

HANOI, Vietnam, Indo-China, Nov. 16 -- Continued Vietminh concentration in the southern reaches of the Red River delta in the Tonkin theatre of war was indicated by reports today of two new attacks by the Communist-led forces in the south delta sector.

ROCQUENCOURT, France, Nov. 12 -- Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway, the Supreme Allied Commander in Europe, is gradually improving the tactical coordination of his far-flung land, air and sea units through the development of six communications networks ranging from northern Norway to eastern Turkey.
Nine new films, including importations from France, Russia, Italy and Yugoslavia, are slated to arrive in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:

Instead of a tent on a desolate battle-line the meeting place is a glass-walled, thickly carpeted conference room, but as far as the Korean truce issue is concerned New York is Panmunjom all over again. For a month the General Assembly of the United Nations has discussed nothing but the single obstacle to a cease-fire which frustrated the military men on the ground.
HEADQUARTERS? Eighth Army, in Korea, Nov. 15 -- If wars could be won on good health alone, the conflict in Korea would be over.

Tanker construction continues to dominate French shipbuilding activity with the placement last month of an order for a fourth 31,500-deadweight-ton tanker. This new order, the French Shipbuilder's Association reports, raises to eleven the number of tankers under construction or ordered at the Penhoet yards at St. Nazaire.
Spring returned yesterday for a mid-November encore in New York and neighboring states, and thousands of motorists turned out to acclaim its presence.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 16 -- Eleven Southern Governors, including three who turned from Democratic voting traditions this year and urged their followers to support the Republican Presidential candidacy of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, discounted today a view that a two-party system had taken hold in the area.

MANHASSET, L. I., Nov. 16 -- Trustees of the North Shore Hospital, deadlocked in controversies with local physicians over the development and policies of the incomplete $4,000,000 institution, plan to take their story directly to the residents of this area this week through a series of five "town meetings."
Two weeks ago when he was asked if Maryland had challenged Michigan State to a post-season game, Jim Tatum begged off borrowing any trouble.
ALBANY, Nov. 16 (AP) -- A nine-day-old strike of about 1,000 truck drivers ended today with agreement on a new two-year contract providing for a pay increase of 10 cents an hour.

BORDEAUX, France, Nov. 16 -- Relations between the United States military forces in France and their French hosts are officially "correct," but there is neither mutual sympathy nor any concerted effort by either side to create such sympathy.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- The Atomic Energy Commission announced tonight "satisfactory" experiments in hydrogen weapon research amid informed speculation that this meant a super-atomic bomb had been exploded in recent United States tests.

The State Crime Commission is prepared to embark today on the second phase of its four-point inquiry -- the self-perpetuation of political machines through the operations of a "loaded" election law -- at the third of its public hearings in the Supreme Court Building.

OTTAWA, Nov. 16 (by Canadian Press) -- The Canadian dollar's spectacular climb last year has trimmed producers' returns on Canadian wheat and reduced final payments to participants in the 1951-52 wheat pool.
A well - devised program of sonatas, and the downtown premiere of a work by the late Arnold Schoenberg, were played last night in Tom Hall by Abram Loft, violinist, and Alvin Bauman, pianist.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- The recent test explosion at Eniwetok was a devastating blast, according to composite eyewitness reports sent back by service men who evidently believed that a hydrogen bomb had been set off.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- Milestones of the atomic age:

NEWARK, Nov. 16 -- Arley Adorable of Harham, an imported 2 1/2-year-old wire-haired fox terrier owned by Mrs. Harold Florsheim of Deerfield, Ill., gained best-in-show honors at the thirty-fourth annual Newark Kennel Club event in the National Guard Armory today.

SAARBRUECKEN, Saar, Nov. 16 (UP) -- Minister-President Johannes Hoffmann of the Sarr denied today West German charges that he forced the breakdown of Franco-German talks on the future of the Saar. The charges were made recently by the West German Chancellor, Dr. Konrad Adenauer, in a radio interview.
Nuts aplenty are in prospect for the coming holidays, despite smaller crops of some varieties than in 1951.
MADRID, Nov. 16 -- The Spanish press announced today that Spain had won a "great diplomatic victory" by achieving modification of the Tangier statute.

PARIS, Nov. 16 -- Economic circles here are disagreed as to whether or not France has begun to suffer from a real economic crisis or is simply undergoing a phase of readjustment. Those who support the theory of a crisis point to the following facts:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- Mohamed Kamil Abdul Rahim, the Egyptian Ambassador to the United States, said today that Britain could solve "a very important problem" by accepting Egyptian proposals for the self-government of the Sudan.

The international relations commission of the National Association of Manufacturers has added its voice to the growing chorus here and abroad suggesting that current types of American economic aid to foreign countries must be replaced as soon as possible by expanded normal trade.

There can be no cure for the "disease" of moral irresponsibility until individuals set up for themselves standards of personal integrity and honesty, the Rev. Dr. Robert J. McCracken, minister of the Riverside Church, said in his sermon yesterday.
Hollywood's first Television City is still a coast-to-coast secret.

Five men in several fields were honored yesterday by the New York Philanthropic League for their work in behalf of the physically handicapped. The awards were made at the annual fall luncheon of the group at the Commodore Hotel, attended by 2,000 persons.

The British islands in the Caribbean -- Jamaica, Trinidad, Barbados, the Leewards and the Windwards -- have a population only slightly larger than that of Manhattan Island, though they include 6,884 square miles of land, scattered over many thousands of square miles of sea. But they have much historical importance, their economic importance is growing and yearly they become more familiar to American tourists.

Outlining a new plan for the establishment of private enterprise industries in Israel under the sponsorship of the Jewish Agency for Palestine, Victor Avrunin, technical adviser to the agency, emphasized yesterday that these planned projects entailed "American processes and know-how as well as capital."

CINCINNATI, Nov. 16 -- Every type, size and category of speedboat racing was put under the microscope in another full session at the annual meeting of the American Power Boat Association today. And no one was surprised when the most popular class, the so-called "stock outboards," received major attention.

ISLAND BEACH, N. J., Nov. 16 -- The largest single delegation of nature-lovers ever to visit this unspoiled duneland at the tip of the Barnegat Peninsula was warned this morning that private realty interests would fight to the end to prevent its becoming a New Jersey state park.

The Canadian dollar was shaken sharply last week in a selling wave which dropped it to a premium of 1 3/8 cent (on Wednesday), lowest since early May. The rate stiffened moderately near the close with Friday's final of 1 5/8 cent, reflecting a loss of 1 1/8 cent over the previous week.

There's still time to whip up a pretty dress for the coming festivities, particularly if you have a smart Advance pattern, as selected by THE NEW YORK TIMES experts, to assist you. Are you a young sophisticated matron, a junior or a teen-ager? In whichever category you fall, you will find that we show you today a design for you.

Three one-story loft buildings on a plot 95 by 100 feet at 651-65 Lexington Avenue, Brooklyn, were sold for investment by the Montdan Realty Corporation to Apt Products, Inc., which insured title with the Security Title and Guaranty Company. The Kalmon Dolgin Company was the broker in the sale of the property, which is assessed at $57,000.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 16 -- Dr. Pinkhos Churgin, dean of the Teachers Institute at Yeshiva University, New York, was named today president designee of the Bar-Ilan University, which the Mizrachi Organization of America is building in Israel near Tel Aviv.

AMSTERDAM, Nov. 16 -- The stock market here continued inactive with no inclination on the part of public or operators to enter into fresh commitments. This state of affairs now has been ruling for several months and the average for shares of around 135 is near the lowest post-war level.

" Doing as well as listening," a basic principle of progressive education, has been applied to a special religious service presented weekly for thirty youngsters attending the Central Presbyterian Church nursery school, Park Avenue at Sixty-fourth Street. The nursery group, which is interdenominational, includes children two and a half to five years old.
ANCHORAGE, Alaska, Nov. 16 (AP) -- Another C-119 Flying Boxcar, with twenty men aboard, has disappeared in Alaska and was feared to have crashed, the Air Force announced today.

The Canadian dollar was shaken sharply last week in a selling wave which dropped it to a premium of 1 3/8 cent (on Wednesday), lowest since early May. The rate stiffened moderately near the close with Friday's final of 1 5/8 cent, reflecting a loss of 1 1/8 cent over the previous week.
TEHERAN, Iran, Nov. 16 (UP) -- Premier Mohammed Mossadegh today ordered the Supreme Court dissolved within five days.

WORCESTER, Mass., Nov. 16 (UP) -- Charlie Maloy, Holy Cross quarterback, set an Eastern college passing record in a losing cause today as the Crusaders fell before the aerial onslaught of the Quantico Marines, 27 to 18, before 12,000 drizzle-soaked fans at Fitton Field.

MOUNT VERNON, N. Y., Nov. 16 -- The Mt. St. Michael eleven of the Bronx won its seventh football victory in eight games by defeating Archbishop Stepinac High of White Plains, 28 to 0, before a crowd of 7,000 at Memorial Field here today.
Victoria de los Angeles, soprano, sang a recital at Hunter College Assembly Hall Saturday evening as the second event of the school's jubilee subscription series.

LONDON, Nov. 16 -- Preaching in Westminster Abbey, where Queen Elizabeth at the coronation next June will swear "to maintain in the United Kingdom the Protestant reformed religion established by law," Dr. Edwin Morris, Bishop of Monmouth, said today it was not true that the church of England was Protestant or that its ancient churches and cathedrals "once belonged to the Roman Catholics."

The Union of American Hebrew Congregations and the Hebrew Union College-Jewish Institute of Religion, the major national institutions of American Reform Judaism, announced yesterday a drive for $2,265,000 for their support and maintenance this year and in 1953.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- In his annual report to the Congress of Industrial Organizations, issued today, the late Philip Murray voiced a strong call for the end of all wage controls. Mr. Murray, who was president of the C. I. O., died a week ago.

The eastern membership of the Screen Actors Guild, meeting at the Astor Hotel yesterday, unanimously voted to authorize strike action asked by its board of directors against producers of television film commercials and the American Association of Advertising Agencies. According to a spokesman for the group who attended the closed meeting, no date for a strike had been set.

GREENWICH, Conn., Nov. 16 -- Tony Ziluca sailed Hiccup to three triumphs in four races and was second the other time around the harbor today to win the second championship regatta of the Indian Harbor Yacht Club frostbite season. He tallied 47 points under conditions of very light air.

Consolidated net income of the Anaconda Copper Mining Company for the nine months ended with last September amounted to $27,988,193 after all charges and provision of $24,902,000 for taxes, but before deducting depletion of metal mines, according to the report released today.

Two young brothers who fled their Bronx home in fear on Friday night after the older boy had accidentally killed his 11-year-old sister, Marion, with a .22-caliber rifle, were reunited with their tearful parents at 5:15 P. M. yesterday.
SEOUL, Nov. 16 -- A mass meeting of about 10,000 civilians was held in the capitol grounds today to urge an early visit to Korea by Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 16 -- Since Oct. 14, when Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt snipped a red satin ribbon and formally opened the gift bazaar in the basement of the United Nations General Assembly building, its backers have felt like the man who wrote what he thought was a potboiler only to find it topping the best-seller list.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., Nov. 16 -- Six Long Island players, four from West Jersey and one from New York, were first-team selections as the New Atlantic women's sectional field hockey tournament at Adelphi College ended today.

LONDON, Nov. 16 -- A new problem in British-American relations has been created by the presence in Britain of a large United States military force. It is a problem that is not yet serious but one that is worrying both British and United States officials.

Ole Bjorn Kraft, Danish Foreign Minister and, since last month, chairman of the council of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, declared yesterday that the conclusion that a wave of anti-Americanism was sweeping Europe was "too strong."
A federal agency and a New York State department joined hands yesterday to help the small business men get a larger share of work on national defense contracts.

BOWIE, Md., Nov. 17 -- What was to have been Larry MacPhail's most opulent sport promotion turned into a fizzle today when jockeys decided the racing surface of the Bowie track was unsafe, and refused to ride after the second event.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 17 -- Consideration of the proposal to establish an international criminal court was postponed for one year today by the Legal Committee of the United Nations General Assembly on a roll-call vote. Twenty-three nations voted in favor, sixteen against, seven abstained and fourteen were absent.

" Terry and the Pirates," a television film series based on the comic strip, will make its local debut on two stations. The program will begin over WABD on Nov. 25 at 7:30 P. M. and over WPIX on Nov. 30 at 6 P. M. The title role is played by John Baer; William Tracy will portray Hotshot Charlie; Gloria Saunders will be the Dragon Lady and Sandra Spence will be Burma.
LONDON, Nov. 17 (Reuters) -- The Government today gave London sugar brokers permission to resume sugar trading on an international scale, subject to exchange control regulations.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark Nov. 17 (Reuters) -- A yacht that once knew the luxury of Barbara Hutton's moonlit champagne parties is to be restored to her former glory after four years on a Norwegian coastal milk run.
TOKYO, Tuesday, Nov. 18 (AP) -- United Nations Command Headquarters communique for twenty-four hours ended 6 A. M. Tuesday, Korea time:

So far "nothing has been accomplished" in the conferences between city and state fiscal officials seeking a long-range solution of the city's financial program, Controller Lazarus Joseph charged yesterday in a press interview.

The city's first sale of discarded rifles -- 307 in the lot -- brought $9,740 to the municipal treasury, Purchase Commissioner John Splain made known yesterday. Originally intended for police prowl cars and later found unsuited for use in crowded streets, the rifles were disposed of for an average of $31.75 apiece.

A police sergeant caused the arrest yesterday morning of seventeen union members who, he said, were engaging in "subtle picketing." Later, in Mid-Manhattan Court, Magistrate Frederick Strong imposed five-day suspended sentences on them on loitering charges.

In a news story in THE NEW YORK TIMES on Saturday concerning the sale of twenty-five acres on Harrison Avenue in Rye, N. Y., to the Socony-Vacuum Oil Company, it was reported incorrectly that the acreage was occupied by the Kings Ridge Golf Club.

HANOI, Vietnam, Indo-china, Nov. 17 -- French aircraft from bases in Saigon and Hanoi and from the aircraft carrier Arromanches launched round-the-clock bombing today of big Vietminh troop concentrations in the vital Red River delta.
TOKYO, Tuesday, Nov. 18 -- The Chinese Communists sent groups of their Russian-designed MIG jet fighters south of the Yalu River yesterday and lost six to American Sabre jets of the Fifth Air Force.
C. L. Hostetler has been appointed manager of the new Mercury sales department of the Ford Motor Company.

Mrs. James H. Wickersham will give a tea this afternoon in her home at 791 Park Avenue for the mothers and sponsors of the young women who will be introduced at dinners before the Grosvenor House Ball to be held on the night of Nov. 29 in the main ballroom of the Plaza for the benefit of the Grosvenor Neighborhood House.

The great post-war objective of the free world -- expansion of trade with a minimum of restrictions -- has been only half attained with heavy outpourings of aid by this country. This was the sum of observations made yesterday at the opening sessions of the thirty-ninth National Foreign Trade Convention.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- The market value of this nation's production of goods and services, as expressed in current prices, rose to the record high annual rate of $343,400,000,000 in the third quarter of this year, the Department of Commerce reported today.
Increased Federal Social Security coverage was called for yesterday by Robert T. Lansdale, state commissioner of Social Welfare.

CHELVESTON, England, Nov. 17 (AP) -- Maj. Gen. Francis N. Griswold, commander of the United States Third Air Force, asserted today that Communists were trying to wreck British-United States relations by "spreading dirt" against United States airmen in Britain.

ALBANY, Nov. 17 -- The racing season that ended last Saturday saw more people attend the state's running-horse and harness tracks and bet more money than at any time in the thirteen years that that pari-mutual betting has been legal in New York. The figures were announced today.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 17 -- Deceptions permitted by the present tax policies of the Federal Government have produced results that are "cruel, cynical and dishonest," Crawford H. Greenewalt, president to E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., charged here tonight.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- The Treasury announced tonight that tenders for $1,300,000,000 of 91-day Treasury bills to be dated Nov. 20 and to mature on Feb. 19, were opened to the Federal Reserve banks today. The total applied for was $1,905,075,000, of which $1,300,719,000 was accepted, including $231,706,000 entered on a noncompetitive basis and accepted in full at the average price shown below.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- Robert A. Lovett, Secretary of Defense, reported today, after a two-hour luncheon session with Senator Henry Cabot Lodge Jr. that he had been greatly encouraged by Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's moves thus far to prepare for the transfer of Government. Mr. Lodge is the President-elect's personal liaison representative for the change-over.
CHICAGO, Nov. 17 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

Moving the engine forward has increased interior car body room on all models of the 1953 Plymouth line presented yesterday by the Plymouth division of the Chrysler Corporation. Other engineering developments make for easier, safer and more comfortable driving.

LONDON, Nov. 17 -- Continuing firmness was displayed in most sections of the London stock market today despite fairly small turnover. Oil shares were the exception on reports of overproduction in the United States.

Following is the text of a statement that the State Crime Commission refused to allow Carmine G. DeSapio, Tammany Hall leader, to make at yesterday's open hearing and that then was handed out in the Supreme Court corridor by Jacob Markowitz, chairman of the Tammany law committee:

SEOUL, Korea, Nov. 17 -- A soldier and his wife were united here this evening, after nineteen months of separation. Mrs. James A. Van Fleet, wife of the commanding general of the Eighth Army, landed at the city airport in her husband's personal twin-engine transport, which had flown her from Japan.

Known facts make it evident that the tests at Eniwetok just completed involved the explosion of the most powerful atomic (fission) bomb developed so far and that these latest models of fission bombs tested also incorporated certain relatively small amounts of the two types of hydrogen that will serve as the ingredients of the full-fledged hydrogen bomb.

Net operating earnings of the Bank of the Manhattan Company for this year are estimated at $6,300,000, or $2.52 a share, compared with $5,940,000, or $2.37 in 1951, according to the annual report of J. Stewart Baker, chairman of the board.

BONN, Germany, Nov. 17 -- (Reuters) -- A husband-wife writing team contended today that their book on world history, condemned as pro-Communist by the Office of the United States High Commissioner, had met an equally frosty reception in Communist East Germany.

This year will probably be one of the biggest in history for cigarette advertising in newspapers, according to a study by Bruce Robinson, tobacco group supervisor of the Bureau of Advertising, American Newspaper Publishers Association.
NORFOLK, Va., Nov. 17 (AP) -- Tony Trabert, Cincinnati tennis star, will use a twenty-nine-day leave from the Navy to compete in the Davis Cup matches in Australia next month.
Columbia University received yesterday the formal resignation of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower as president and as a trustee.

BERLIN, Nov. 17 -- The East German Government is engaged in what United States authorities described today as a "hysterical" campaign to reduce the number of East Germans who listen to American broadcasts.

FARGO, N. D., Nov. 17 (UP) -- Newell Anderson, former circulation manager of The Tupelo Journal, said today he had decided not to go back to Mississippi to clear himself of charges that his story of being driven from the state by hooded terrorists was a hoax.

The approval of three drama appraisers out of a possible eight apparently has failed to encourage enough trade for the new Moss Hart play, "The Climate of Eden," which opened last Thursday at the Martin Beck Theatre. As a result, its producers, Joseph M. Hyman and Bernard Hart, have decided to close the attraction after Saturday night's performance, the twelfth.

On net sales of $229,499,652, the Ashland Oil and Refining Company and its subsidiaries realized a net income of $14,249,117 in the fiscal year ended on Sept. 30, the preliminary annual report disclosed yesterday.

CHICAGO, Nov. 17 -- A legal battle of monumental proportions will get under way here tomorrow when the United States Government opens its anti-trust suit against the du Pont family and three of the nation's largest corporations.

Comptoir des Textiles Artificiels of Paris, largest French producer of synthetic yarns, has perfected a new rayon that it asserts will recapture many of the textile markets lost to the non-cellulose fibers such as nylon, Orion, Dacron and dynel.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 17 -- Insistence by the Soviet bloc that the Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees was an illegal agency to furnish spies for the West and cheap labor for capitalism was rejected in two votes today by the Administrative and Budgetary Committee of the General Assembly.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- John L. Lewis said today that there would be "unrest and confusion" among the nation's 350,000 soft-coal miners until they got the full $1.90-a-day pay increase agreed to in their new contract.

LONDON, Nov. 17 -- Geoffrey Lloyd, the British Minister of Fuel and Power, reiterated in the House of Commons today that the Anglo-Iranian Oil Company, one of seven companies charged by the United States Department of Justice with operating an international oil cartel, must not give information to the United States authorities without the British Government's permission.

A survey of the effectiveness of city and private efforts to assist slum dwellers forced from their homes to make way for higher- priced housing has been undertaken by the Women's City Club of New York. The project, which has the aid of Prof. Mary Huff Diggs of Hunter College's Sociology Department, was disclosed yesterday at the club, 646 Park Avenue.
The discrimination with which foods have been chosen for six gift packages that are a new, mail-order venture of the Music Inn, Lenox. Mass., suggests them as delightful possibilities for Christmas.

SEOUL, Korea, Nov. 17 -- Thousands of G.I.s walking up and down the main streets of Seoul today were not looking for a good time or a pleasant way to pass the afternoon. They were Christmas shopping for the folks back home.

CHICAGO, Nov. 17 (UP) -- Major league baseball filed answers today to the $12,000,000 damage suit of the Liberty Broadcasting System. It denied that it had violated anti-trust laws or committed an illegal conspiracy to control radio broadcasts of games.

The nation's steel mills are maintaining their high-level production pace. Output this week is scheduled to be 2,203,000 net tons of raw steel, with an operating rate of 106.1 per cent of ingot capacity, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Nov. 17 -- Rabbi Irving Miller, president of the Zionist Organization of America, said today that Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the President-elect, told him on Sept. 30 that if elected he would regard it as one of his "principal functions to bring about peace between Israel and her neighbors."

CHICAGO, Nov. 17 -- Motor vehicle administrators from forty-three states and Canada were warned today that the mounting toll of highway accidents and deaths might result in a demand that the Federal Government take over the problem.

There will be no change in the quarterbacking of the Giants, Coach Steve Owen said yesterday. Despite Chuck Conerly's sub-par showing against the Packers on Sunday, Chuck will start for the Giants against the Redskins at Washington next Sunday.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 17 -- Paramount has in the formative stage a number of projects that hold promise of developing into interesting movie news in the near future.

Average market value of stocks listed on the New York Stock Exchange fell 24 cents in October and aggregate market value fell $481,392,014. The exchange reported yesterday. The average price of $40.44 on Oct. 31 was the lowest since June 30, 1951, when the level was $38.73.

SHUSHAN, N. Y., Nov. 17 -- The opening week-end hunters had no reason to complain about the condition of the woods in these rolling foothills, for occasional rains and heavy fogs provided the "quiet" stalking they wanted. We met few hunters who had failed to see deer.
Widely differing views were expressed at Carnegie Recital Hall yesterday by speakers before the investment class of the Federation of Women, Shareholders in American Business, Inc.

The lack of further selling for tax adjustment accounts, which last week produced a series of cross-currents in the stock market, enabled prices to show selective improvement yesterday. Gains were confined to individual issues in various divisions, each stock operating on its own, and peak additions in some reached 2 points.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 (UP) -- Rear Admiral Lamont Pugh, Navy Surgeon General, said today that many civilian physicians and dentists had refused to enter military service because of greed for "easier, quicker and bigger money."

Following are excerpts from testimony given yesterday in the State Crime Commission's investigation of the links between the underworld and political leaders here. The commission's chairman, Joseph M. Proskauer, is presiding, and the questioning is being conducted by members of the commission's legal staff.

LONDON, Nov. 17 -- Seventy-nine voyages by passenger ships of the major trans-Atlantic lines will bring visitors from North American Atlantic ports to Britain in the two months preceding the coronation next June 2. Of the seventy-nine voyages, forty-eight will start from New York, three from Boston and twenty-eight from Canadian ports.

The Port of New York Authority, operator of combined land, sea and air terminal and transportation facilities in New York and New Jersey, will open bids on an issue of $35,000,000 of first series consolidated bonds on Dec. 10, it was announced yesterday. Maturity date was listed as 1982.

Adequate financial provisions for the city colleges were urged yesterday at a preliminary hearing on the tentative budget request of the Board of Higher Education. The budget request at present is for a total of $22,900,000 for the fiscal year beginning July 1, 1953, an increase of about $2,000,000 over the current operating budget.

In your editorial of Nov. 11 "Hudson Water Vetoed" you made the statement that one of the alternatives to supplementing our supply of water would be "the greater use of metering as a method of conserving water." This unequivocal statement is completely at variance with the experience of every multiple dwelling owner in the City of New York.

Michigan State, with only Marquette left on its schedule, had the mythical national collegiate football championship for 1952 all but clinched yesterday as it retained the No. 1 spot in the United Press ratings for the ninth successive week.

LONDON, Nov. 17 -- Britain's complex Town and Country Planning Act calling for the payment of 300,000,000 ($840,000,000) to property owners for their lands' potential improvement value will be amended by the present Conservative Government to postpone or eliminate such payment.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- The special committee of the House of Representatives investigating the operation of tax-exempt foundations disclosed today that President Truman had failed to act on its request for opportunity to examine the tax statements of these institutions.
VIENNA, Nov. 17 -- Soviet occupation authorities made it obvious today that they intended to interfere in Austria's general elections next February.

Having begun with the leisurely eighteenth century, Jean-Louis Barrault and his company have come up to the neurotic twentieth with considerable eclat in their second production, "Le Proces," which was put on at the Ziegfeld last evening.

DANBURY, Conn., Nov. 17 -- The administration of Danbury Hospital, which has been the target of criticism over its suspension of two staff physicians, was repudiated today when fifteen new trustees were elected at the hospital's annual meeting here.

The three-month-long importation of 30,000 tons of frozen beaf from the Antipodes came to an end yesterday with the arrival here of the British refrigerated vessel Suevic, which brought a shipment of 2,344 tons of chilled meat from Wellington, N. Z.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Nov. 17 -- A Federal judge refused to sentence a former cashier to prison today for embezzling $7,500 and remarked that the bank officials should have been indicted instead for paying the man such a low salary.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- The Baptist Joint Committee on Public Affairs took vigorous exception today to the statement published yesterday by the Roman Catholic Bishops deploring what they termed a movement to separate religion from education in the nation's schools.
A new Navy jet fighter plane that can land on water was disclosed here yesterday.

CHICAGO, Nov. 17 -- Light to heavy rains over the winter wheat belt gave the signal for general selling of wheat, and prices broke as much as three cents a bushel, precipitation was heavy in parts of Kansas, Nebraska and eastward through Illinois, northern Indiana and Michigan, but was too light to give effective relief in Oklahoma and Kansas. However, the forecast was for more showers in most sections.
ATHENS, Nov. 17 -- King Paul gave Field Marshal Alexander Papagos a mandate today to form a new Greek Cabinet.

A comprehensive survey of housing projects and the operating policy and management of the New York City Housing Authority will be recommended to Mayor Impellitteri and the Board of Estimate within a week by the Real Estate Board of New York.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 17 (AP) -- Bobby Shantz, the American League's most valuable player, and General Manager Arthur Ehlers of the Athletics talked contract today, but were unable to reach an agreement.
Jimmy Carter, the lightweight boxing champion, won a decision over a trim heavyweight in the Bronx yesterday without landing a punch.

The inauguration of Chile's new President, General Carlos Ibanez del Campo, seems to extend the fence which is being put up between the United States and Latin America. The growing antagonism between the two Americas cannot be alleviated by conquering American tourists or by the glories of Hollywood movies.

Carmine G. DeSapio, leader of Tammany Hall, brought a public New York State Crime Commission hearing close to uproar yesterday in attempts to put into the record a rebuttal of last week's hearing testimony on alleged gangster domination of his organition.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 17 -- A Bryn Mawr, Pa., couple lost a $50,000 suit against the Philadelphia Phillies and Shortstop Granny Hamner today for damages suffered from a ball they claimed was thrown "negligently" into the stands.

Of great interest concerning the Tuatara, the primitive reptile recently received by the Bronx Zoo from New Zealand, is the presence in this creature of a rudimentary pineal, or third eye. This Cyclopean organ, which was functional in some Permian and Carboniferous amphibians, and can be detected in the human embryo, provides substantive evidence for the validity of the theory of evolution.

SYDNEY, Australia, Tuesday Nov. 18 (AP) -- Vic Seixas, captain of the United States Davis Cup team, gained the quarter-finals of the New South Wales Tennis tournament today by winning the fifth set of his adjourned match with Rex Hartwig of Australia.

PARIS, Nov. 17 -- Jean Monnet, chairman of the High Authority of the European Coal and Steel Community (Schuman plan), proposed today to the British Government and British industrial and labor leaders that they should join with the Community in "a close and lasting association uniting our action and yours through the exchange of information and through rules fixed in common."

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Nov. 17 -- Indonesia's political unrest flared anew today. The Macassar Radio announced that Lieut. Col. Warouw had summarily taken command of the Indonesian Seventh Division from the divisional commander, Col. Gatot Subroto.

" This Star of England: William Shake-speare, Man of the Renaissance," by Dorothy and Charlton Ogburn, will be published next Tuesday by Coward-McCann. The volume presents the author's argument that Shakespeare, the name used by the creator of the "noblest literature in the English language," was the pseudonym of Edward de Vere, seventeenth-century Earl of Oxford.

Most of the metropolitan area was covered yesterday by fog that varied in texture from Army blanket to Salome's last veil, slowed traffic along the Jersey Turnpike to a safe crawl, made puzzles out of air transport schedules and confused man and beast.

The block-by-block housing survey that began in Harlem last month got under way in the Bronx yesterday and housing inspectors found in twenty-one tenements on one block 175 violations ranging from "dangerous" fire escapes to "dungeon-like" cellar apartments.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 17 -- Following is the text of the draft resolution on Korea submitted today by India to the United Nations General Assembly's Political and Security Committee:

LONDON, Nov. 17 -- The Government's bill to restore road transport to private ownership and decentralize the nationalized railways came up for a second reading in the House of Commons today. This is the decisive stage of the proposal, generally known as Operation Unscramble.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 17 -- Proposals by Chile, Brazil and Cuba, aimed to speed up consideration by the United Nations General Assembly of new means of financing development projects in underdeveloped countries, were laid before the Assembly's Economic and Financial Committee today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- E. Preston Sharp, director of the Youth Study Center of Philadelphia, told civic organization leaders meeting with the Children's Bureau of Juvenile Delinquency today that three new trends were more serious than the 20 per cent increase in delinquency since 1948.

Pierre Etchebaster, the "iron man" of the sport, moved to a commanding lead over Alastair Bradley Martin of Glen Head, L. I., as they began their engagement for the world open court tennis championship yesterday at the Racquet and Tennis Club.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- The Federal Maritime Board announced today that it had set its final sales prices to American Export Lines, Inc., for the liners Independence and Constitution at $14,036,751 and $14,436,956.

The owner of a Brooklyn rooming house was arrested on a charge of first-degree manslaughter yesterday after a fire swept through his property in the Bedford section of Brooklyn. The blaze killed two tenants and left six others injured, two critically.

The ever-increasing interest of today's designers in combining a multiplicity of materials in furniture is exemplified in a group by George Nelson, architect, newly introduced at the Herman Miller Company, 1 Park Avenue.

As seventeen elderly persons took their places upon the stage of Stuyvesant High School at 345 East Fifteenth Street yesterday for a dress rehearsal of a play to be presented this evening, a high school boy peeked into the school auditorium.
AUGUSTA, Ga., Nov. 17 -- Job applications "in the hundreds" have flooded the temporary headquarters of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower here, James C. Hagerty, the General's press secretary, said today.

Further evidence of racketeer friendships with officials public was provided in the testimony of two witnesses with police records introduced at yesterday's open hearing of the State Crime Commission.

Women who long have taken an active interest in St. Luke's Home for Aged Women have arranged the annual reception and bazaar in behalf of the institution for tomorrow and Thursday at the home, Broadway and 114th Street. Mrs. Guy Beaver King, honorary president of the board of managers heads the committee in charge of the plans for the bazaar. Miss Muriel W. Ashwell is active president.

WASHINGTON Nov. 17 (AP) -- Dr. Johr. A. Hannah, president of Michigan State College, predicted today that the Big Ten would not renew its Rose Bowl contract after the present agreement expired in 1954.

Rocky Castenani, 155 1/2 pounds, Luzerne, Pa., gained a unanimous decision over Vic Cardell, 153, Hartford, Conn., in the ten-round feature bout at the Eastern Parkway in Brooklyn before 2,500 fans last night.

An audience of 15,000 assembled at Madison Square Garden last night for the Festival of Music, presented at a cost of $40,000 by the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York to celebrate the thirty-fifth anniversary of its founding.

Ernie Durando, Bayonne, N. J., middleweight, who was scheduled to oppose Joe Giardello of Philadelphia in the main bout at Madison Square Garden Nov. 28, has withdrawn from the fight because of a severe cold.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 17 -- It has proved so difficult to obtain the views of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower on Korea and other issues before the United Nations General Assembly that the Assembly probably will recess from just before Christmas until after the President-elect's inauguration on Jan. 20.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- Authorities attempted to disguise their concern today over "leaks" on the recent atomic tests but there were indications that the whole field of security among atomic testing personnel would be closely re-examined.

WASHINGTON,, Nov. 17 (AP) -- An Air Force C-119 Flying Boxcar crashed and burned today in a pasture near Billings, Mont., killing eight men and injuring eight others and raising the death toll of one of the worst week-ends in the nation's aviation history.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 17 -- Three Southern Governors, who had supported the Republican Presidential candidacy of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower as a political safeguard for those adhering to the States Rights philosophy, placed a firm hand today on the proceedings of the annual Southern Governors Conference.

PARIS, Nov. 17 -- In a letter to Director General Jaime Torres Bodet, the Spanish Government has promised that if Spain is admitted to the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization she will allow all documents put out by the organization to enter her territory.

Narcotics agents and detectives yesterday seized 117 ounces of "pure" heroin -- said to be worth $1,500,000 at retail -- and arrested six suspected members of an East Harlem narcotics ring in dawn-to- dusk raids.

Bernard Greenhouse achieved his usual norm of 'cello playing last night in Town Hall. Which is to say that his performances were unanimously well thought out, his technique equal to all demands, his musical taste well-nigh perfect. His tone remains a constant and is not likely to change. It is rather small, capable of much variety in quiet sections, but tending to rasp and become strident when heavy pressure is applied by the bow.

DETROIT, Nov. 17 (AP) -- Mrs. Emily Aitchison apologized tonight as she learned that she and The Associated Press had located a missing son who wanted her telephone number and would call from Seattle.
Two new films will arrive in first-run theatres this morning.

Television was the chief topic at the weekly luncheon-meeting of the Football Writers Association at Toots Shor's yesterday and the two-sided discussion forced into the background Lou Little, Eddie Erdelatz, Steve Owen and the other coaches present.
How do you calculate the cost of an operating room? In the dollars it takes to set one up, or in the lives that are saved and the bodies knit?
KANSAS CITY, Mo., Nov. 17 (AP) -- It looks like the Missouri River will go on flowing through the big loop at Kansas City's doorstep for a long time to come.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 (UP) -- The Department of Agriculture said today no restrictions will be placed on acreage or marketing of next year's corn crop, in order not to discourage increased planting during the defense emergency.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- Tighe Woods, Price Stabilizer, today called on his meat price experts to have ready by next Monday an order rolling back retail meat prices or let him know the reason why it could not be done.

President Truman and General Eisenhower in their meeting today are taking a needed step in improvising machinery to meet what can be a defect in our political practice. There is no provision for the interregnum period between election and inauguration when there is a change in party.

BONN, Germany, Nov. 17 -- Relations between United States servicemen and the German people are better at present than they have been at any time since the end of World War II, according to experienced observers in German city and state governments, the headquarters of the United States Army and the Office of the United States High Commissioner.

Futures on the New York commodity exchanges closed irregular yesterday with the fluctuation generally small. Hides, rubber, tin, cocoa and coffee were up, lead, zinc, potatoes, wool and sugar were down and vegetable oils were mixed.

THE HAGUE, Nov. 17 -- Harold J. Adonis, former executive clerk for Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll of New Jersey, under indictment on charges of bilking a gangster of $228,000 in protection money, has been located in Amsterdam, but whether he can be extradited is puzzling the Ministry of Justice here.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 17 -- The captain of the tanker Washington testified today that he had been unaware that military maneuvers were in progress last Friday in the area where his ship and a Navy transport collided, killing six soldiers.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 17 -- India proposed today that the United Nations General Assembly endorse the principle that all Korean prisoners of war be repatriated after an armistice. The task of repatriation would be entrusted to a four-nation commission, divided equally between Communist and non-Communist Governments, and with an umpire to be named by the General Assembly if, after three weeks, a deadlock developed in the commission.

WILBERT ROBINSON wouldn't have looked at him twice. If he had persisted in remaining, Uncle Robbie would have picked up a baseball bat and chased him off the premises. It's a cinch that the beloved manager of the Brooks would have made short shrift of Robert Clayton Shantz, 5 feet 6 inches and 139 pounds.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- While the Capital prepared to give Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower a warm welcome, President Truman was studying the papers he will use tomorrow in briefing the President-elect on urgent problems that face the nation.

TOKYO, Nov. 17 -- Japanese electric power workers, striking for a 60 per cent wage rise and the right to bargain with employers on a nation-wide basis, launched today the tenth "wave" of the strikes that began more than six weeks ago.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 (AP) -- A Federal judge today dismissed charges of contempt of Congress against Abram Flaxer, president of the United Public Workers Union, a labor organization described by a Senate committee as Communist-dominated.

Current indications are that the autumn rains may be autumn snows this year. The early November skies have a forbidding look and the clouds have that black, humorless air suggestive of blizzards rather than of mere water.

Establishment by the American Chemical Society of the Charles Lathrop Parsons Award was announced yesterday by Dr. Charles Allen Thomas, chairman of the society's board of directors. The award, named for Dr. Parsons, who was secretary of the society from 1907 to 1945, will be given not more than once in every three years to a chemist or chemical engineer chosen solely for public service activities.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- Over the vigorous protest of Justice William O. Douglas, the Supreme Court held in an unsigned opinion today that Robert Woodall, a Negro, must be returned from Ohio to complete a prison sentence in Alabama.

New rate schedules increasing the power bills of the city subway and elevated lines by $2,600,000 a year -- or 37 per cent above their present $7,000,000 -- have been filed by the Consolidated Edison Company with the Public Service Commission.

Last year you were kind enough to print my letter asking for part-time volunteers who speak Spanish to give their services as interpreters for the Puerto Rican patients at the Welfare Island Dispensary, 535 East Eightieth Street. The response was gratifying and immediate and through your good offices we obtained many excellent interpreters.

To me it is of first significance that President-elect Dwight Eisenhower is a professional soldier-statesman who, as of my knowledge, has the civilian mind and the civilian spirit. Equally distinguished in war and post-war leadership, the man who enters the White House on Jan. 20 is more than a "come lately" civilian.

We are encouraged to believe that a change for the better may be under way in the city's attack on the smoke and soot nuisance. Mayor Impellitteri, having obtained the legislation he asked to set up a new and independent Department of Air Pollution Control, has now named a commissioner and deputy commissioner.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 (AP) -- The Air Force today announced that those missing aboard the C-46 transport that dived into the water off the east coast of Korea Saturday included Maj. William P. Windus Jr., the pilot, whose wife, Mrs. Cleste L. Windus, lives at 590 Whittier Street, Westbury, L. I., and whose parents, Mr. and Mrs. William P. Windus Sr., live at 119-32 201st Street, St. Albans, Queens.

Nat Holman was suspended last night as head basketball coach at City College to face charges growing out of an investigation of the bribery scandals last year that had tainted his championship teams. Two of his associates in the college basketball program also were suspended on the same charges.

Fannie Heemskerk of the Netherlands, her condition much improved, was able to undertake two sessions of play yesterday in the women's world chess championship challengers' tournament in Moscow, according to a report received through Soviet news sources.
The re-election of State Senator Thomas C. Desmond of Newburgh, N. Y., as president of Phi Beta Kappa Associates was announced yesterday.

Shipbuilding companies and classification societies are awaiting with interest the debut of Norway's combination ore carrier-tanker that has been ordered in a Swedish shipyard by Skibs A/S Malmtransport, a subsidiary of the Norwegian America Line.

The privately-owned United States-flag merchant fleet decreased in October as did the number of Government-owned ships under bareboat charter and general agency agreement, the National Federation of American Shipping reported yesterday.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 17 -- The six Arab states that last September urged the United Nations to reopen the Arab-Israeli political dispute over Palestine will ask the General Assembly soon to enlarge the membership of the Palestine Conciliation Commission and to give it additional powers.
The cotton futures markets on the New York Cotton Exchange closed barely steady yesterday, 18 to 56 points lower than on last Friday, with old December weakest.

Public offering of 370,000 shares of common stock of Smith-Douglass Company, Inc., fertilizer company, is being made today by an underwriting syndicate headed by F. Eberstadt Co., Inc. The price is $18 a share.

NAIROBI, Kenya, Nov. 17 (Reuters) -- Bearded, British educated Jomo Kenyatta, president of the powerful Kenya African Union, will be accused tomorrow of "managing" the Mau Mau terrorist organization, the Colonial Government announced tonight.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Nov. 17 -- The Eastern States Antiques Fair, a standout in the New York area in reflecting the manner of early American living, opened its fall edition today at the Westchester County Center.

Chief Magistrate John M. Murtagh held hearings in Traffic Court yesterday for ten parking violators, including eight whose automobiles had been impounded in surprise seizures early Sunday. As a result, four offenders went to the workhouse for a total of seventy-six days. Fines amounting to $2,775 were imposed.
Most of college football's unfinished business will be wound up this week on the last full program of the season.

With one of the most impressive performances in the forty-four-year history of the event, Charley Capozzoli of Georgetown yesterday scored a runaway victory in the Intercollegiate A. A. A. A. varsity cross-country championship.

The Copperweld Steel Company of Pittsburgh announced yesterday that it has offered to purchase, for approximately $8,650,000, all the outstanding common stock of the Ohio Seamless Tube Company of Shelby, Ohio.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 17 -- Byelorussia accused the United States and Britain today of "encouraging" South Africa to flout the United Nations by continuing her race-segregation policies.

Billy Rose, owner and operator of the Ziegfeld Theatre, confirmed last night a report that he was working on plans to turn over the playhouse without charge to the Lively Arts Foundation, a non-profit organization. The agreement would cover a seven-year period.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 (UP) -- The Air Force disclosed today that it was testing a "spray on" plastic surgical dressing for use in atomic attack as well as for other wounds and injuries.

BOSTON, Nov. 17 -- The New Bedford, Woods Hole, Martha's Vineyard and Nantucket Steamship Authority was permanently forbidden today to curtail service during the winter.
