The decree was issued by Judge Daniel T. O'Connell in Superior Court here, but he said he was reporting his decision to the State Supreme Judicial Court for adjudication.
Rush-hour traffic moved speedily up West End and Eleventh Avenues last evening as the new signal-light pattern providing progressive flow northbound between 4 and 7 P. M. went into operation.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 17 -- A Saudi Arabian delegate came up today with a new formula called "Fra-Tu-Mor" for settling the dispute concerning France's administration of her two African protectorates, Tunisia and Morocco.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 (AP) -- The Tariff Commission today heard pleas for a 45 per cent duty on imported tuna fish or a Government guarantee that United States fishermen can hold 85 per cent of the market.

PRINCETON, N. J., Nov. 17 -- A complete portable television receiver functioned perfectly here today without radio vacuum tubes. Instead, it utilized thirty-seven bits of laboratory magic known as "transistors," which even now are said to perform nearly all the functions of the ordinary radio tube, and do some of them even better.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Nov. 17 (UP) -- James Francis (Three-Gun) Hill, who tried to act the role of a modern Robin Hood and led two others in a kidnap and robbery spree in the South, was sent to a mental asylum today.

CAMDEN, N. J., Nov. 17 -- Woodrow Wilson High School, one of the city's two public secondary schools, closed for the day after more than half of the faculty had stayed home in what some officials termed a "wildcat strike."

With the skiing season at hand, a review of the town's shops reveals much of interest for devotees of this sport as well as for suburban housewives, whom it has been pointed out, have adopted ski wear as their favorite cold weather outdoor garb.
GRAFTON, Mass., Nov. 17 (AP) -- A giant forging press, capable of crushing an automobile to the thickness of a lead pencil, is being built at the Wyman-Gordon plant here.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- The Supreme Court refused again today to reopen the case of Julius and Ethel Rosenberg, the husband and wife condemned to die for giving atomic secrets to Soviet Russia. The tribunal on Oct. 13 rejected the New York couple's earlier appeal for a review of their trial.

Establishment of an advisory committee consisting of two scientists and an economist, all active in the nation's atomic energy program since the beginning, was announced yesterday by Walter Kidde Nuclear Laboratories, privately financed research organization devoted primarily to development of nuclear power for commercial and industrial purposes.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 17 -- Alvin G. Beaman of Nashville, Tenn., president of the American Bottlers of Carbonated Beverages, said here today that soft drink sales in this country during 1952 will run well over one billion cases, representing a retail dollar volume of $1,500,000,000, largest in the industry's history.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- Mrs. John G. Lee, president of the League of Women Voters, today claimed for women the leading role in getting out the sixty million voters in the last election.

Before a group of about fifty friends and well-wishers at City Hall, Mayor Impellitteri yesterday morning swore in Dr. Leonard Greenburg as first Commissioner of the new Department of Air Pollution Control and Rear Admiral William S. Maxwell, U. S. N., retired, as deputy commissioner.

New Yorkers have been told by Mayor Impellitteri and Newbold Morris, chairman of the board of the New York City Center of Music and Drama, that the nine-year-old organization is in "financial distress" and is likely to be forced to close its doors unless it can raise between $75,000 and $100,000.
CAMP DRUM, N. Y., Nov. 17 -- Plans to use a northern New York ski resort as a training ground for winter warfare specialists were announced here today by the Army.

CAIRO, Nov. 17 -- The possibility that the non-Arabic-speaking and non-Moslem section of the Sudan may boycott the Sudanese elections, on which Britain and Egypt have agreed, cropped up in the British - Egyptian conversations now under way here on a Sudan settlement.

Rent increases were approved last month by the Temporary State Housing Rent Commission on 30,993 dwelling units in the New York metropolitan area and disallowed in 3,745 cases where they had been sought by landlords, Joseph D. McGoldrick, State Rent Administrator, reported yesterday.

DAYTON, Ohio, Nov. 17 (AP) -- Harry Gold, convicted of being a courier in a Soviet atomic spy organization, testified today before a Federal Grand Jury here. He was led into the Federal District Court by two Federal marshals.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 17 -- Trial of the long-pending suit between Howard Hughes, industrialist and film producer, and Paul Jerrico, former screen writer, over screen credits, opened today before Superior Judge Orlando H. Rhodes. At the outset both sides waived trial by jury.
A radical new surgical technique for the treatment of schizophrenia is being explored by scientists affiliated with the National Association for Mental Health, it was reported here yesterday.

DAYTON, Ohio, Nov. 17 (AP) -- Harry Gold, convicted of being a courier in a Soviet atomic spy organization, testified today before a Federal Grand Jury here. He was led into the Federal District Court by two Federal marshals.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 (AP) -- The Government sought today to block a suit by a Swiss holding company for 90 per cent of the stock of General Aniline and Film Corporation.

The Community Service Society announced yesterday a budget of $3,205,644 for the fiscal year to make possible "new and larger ways" of helping troubled families in this city. Bayard F. Pope, chairman of the board of trustees, said the program entailed particular attention to prevention and control of juvenile delinquency and broadening the agency's services to aged persons.

ATHENS, Nov. 17 -- Field Marshal Alexander Papagos, who, as a result of yesterday's sweeping electoral victory, will head the strongest Government to take office here since World War II, intends to push through a drastic program for economic and fiscal reform.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 (AP) -- John B. Dunlap, Commissioner of Internal Revenue, who has been attacked by members of Congress, was appointed today commissioner of the Texas-Oklahoma tax district.

WASHINGTON, Wednesday, Nov. 19 -- The Most Rev. Thomas A. Boland, Bishop of the Paterson, N. J., diocese, was named today the Roman Catholic Archbishop of Newark. He will succeed Archbishop Thomas J. Walsh, who died last June 6.

In your issue of Nov. 9 your editorial "The Arab Refugees" states * * * "There are 850,000 Arab refugees, who once lived in the territory that is now Israel." Again in your issue of Nov. 12 your editorial "Reparations and the Arabs" repeats the same statement as to the number of Arab refugees.

The election of George H. Dayton as president of the board of trustees of Blair Academy, Blairstown, N. J., took place yesterday at the Irving Trust Company here. Mr. Dayton is vice president of the J. H. Monteath Company, 2500 Park Avenue, the Bronx, foreign and domestic hardwood dealers.
JERUSALEM, Nov. 18 -- Prof. Albert Einstein has informed Prime Minister David Ben-Gurion that he is unable to accept the Presidency of Israel.

CHICAGO, Nov. 18 -- The fact that rains in the Southwest, where drought conditions are worse than elsewhere, have been too light to be important encouraged buying of wheat futures here today. But while there was fairly broad buying on small set-backs, buying failed to follow bulges.

A forecast of the 1953 city campaign entered the deliberations of the City Council yesterday when Council President Rudolph Halley took the floor and told his colleagues that "the next city election will be fought on the issue of good government."

SYDNEY, Australia, Nov. 18 (AP) -- A furor over Maureen Connolly's tennis writing appeared to have died down today following a talk between representatives of the Australian and American Lawn Tennis Associations.

The personal effects of Jane Cowl, stage and screen star who died on June 22, 1950, were auctioned yesterday at the storehouse of the public administrator at 238 William Street, and brought $1,499 from several hundred persons who attended the sale.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 18 -- A goal of $2,265,000 was adopted today by leaders in the joint national campaign of the Union of American Hebrew Congregations and the Hebrew Union College-Jewish Institute of Religion, which represent Reform Judaism in America.

Professional students of child psychology "might better take their heads out of their books and get to know children first-hand." That was the observation a police sergeant drew yesterday from a decade of trying to prevent juvenile delinquency.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- The presence of Mrs. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the next First Lady, in this city today called attention to the fact that the problems of the Presidency caused by the Lame Duck Amendment are not limited to weighty questions such as the budget.
TRENTON, Nov. 18 (AP) -- The Fish and Game Council decided today against extension of the small game and woodcock hunting seasons for time lost as a result of dry weather.

ALBANY, Nov. 18 -- The Board of Regents will open a hearing in New York on Dec. 4 to determine whether membership in the Communist party should bar a teacher from employment in the state public school system.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Nov. 19 -- Navy headquarters revealed today details of a clash between four Russian-made MIG jet fighters and three carrier-based Panther jets yesterday over far northeastern Korean waters, possibly close to the Soviet border.

Thoroughbred horse racing is completing the biggest season in the history of the sport, with pari-mutuel wagering up 19.02 per cent over 1951, an unofficial survey of the Nation's twenty-four racing states disclosed yesterday.
The stock market pushed ahead yesterday to the levels of last August as strong buying raised prices well beyond 3 points in some instances and left the composite rate higher by 2.44 points.

CHICAGO, Nov. 18 -- Trial of the biggest anti-trust suit ever filed opened here today when the United States Government began presenting its case against the Du Pont interests and a $5,000,000,000 industrial empire allegedly controlled by the famed munitions and chemical family.

ELIZABETH, N. J., Nov. 18 -- Sixteen Union County draftees who were scheduled to have their Thanksgiving dinners G. I. style will remain at home with their folks for the holiday, their induction postponed by the State Selective Service System as a result of a one-man campaign by a newspaper man here.

BOSTON, Nov. 18 -- The executive committee of the Unitarian Ministers Association asserted today that the statement of the Roman Catholic Bishops of the United States concerning public aid for religious education was "foreign to our tradition." Boston is the headquarters of the American Unitarian Association.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Nov. 18 -- Thomas L. McCullough, 97 years old, a retired cotton planter who spent his last sixteen months on relief because he lasted longer than his money, died yesterday in a hospital after a two-week illness.

SOMERVILLE, N. J., Nov. 18 -- A. Harry Moore, 73 years old, the only person ever elected Governor of New Jersey for three terms, suffered a stroke near here today and died as the car he was driving went off the road and into a ditch.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 18 (UP) -- The National Football League today announced its schedule for the play-off of possible ties in its American and National Conferences at the end of the regular season.
INDIANAPOLIS, Nov. 18 (AP) -- The Indianapolis Olympians hit the century tonight for the first time in the National Basketball Association season, beating the New York Knickerbockers, 100 -- 90.

SYRACUSE, Nov. 18 -- A study of the New York State jury system to determine why more women are not included on jury lists will be on the 1953 program of the New York State Federation of Home Bureaus, which concluded its annual meeting here today.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Nov. 18 -- The recent Belgian reduction of the term of military service from twenty-four to twenty-one months and the Netherlands' revision of her intended contribution to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization from five to three divisions may have considerable reverberations throughout the Atlantic defense community.
BOWIE, Md., Nov. 18 (UP) -- Larry S. MacPhail, president of the weather-plagued Bowie track, said today that racing "positively will be resumed Friday either at Bowie or at another track."

Again the people of New York will have an opportunity to contribute to the Visiting Nurses and assure part-time home nursing care to thousands of sick persons. Last year the hardworking and capable young-women of this organization made 321,340 part-time home nursing visits to, 47,960 persons in Manhattan, the Bronx and Queens.

Members of the Women's League for Christian Service of the West End Collegiate Church will hold their annual "Christmas Tree Shop" bazaar on Friday afternoon and evening, from 3 until 10 o'clock, in the parish house of the church, 245 West Seventy-seventh Street.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 18 -- Bishop G. Bromley Oxnam of Washington called upon the Roman Catholic hierarchy today to declare "in clear and unmistakable language'' that the church does not want and will not accept public support for parochial schools as a prelude to discussion of auxiliary services under public control.
The conduct and character of the current open hearings of the State Crime Commission were defended yesterday by former Supreme Court Justice Joseph M. Proskauer, the commission chairman.

Robert B. Blaikie, an insurgent Tammany district leader, urged yesterday that the election law be changed to provide for the automatic ouster of any political party official who declined to testify at any official inquiry on the ground of possible self-incrimination.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 18 -- The Trusteeship Committee of the United Nations General Assembly adopted today a report listing at least forty factors intended to show whether a territory was self-governing and to what extent.

Substantial increase of imports by this country was pictured yesterday at the National Foreign Trade Convention as a necessity, rather than just a practical substitute for aid grants, or a gesture of goodwill.

The National Broadcasting Company's local radio and television stations here have set up the WNBC-WNBT Music Foundation to provide record libraries and record players for hospitals and other community enters. The equipment will be distributed through various welfare organizations.
The Canadian Province of Quebec is borrowing $25,000,000 in the United States market today to fund short-term Canadian money debt incurred in financing highway and bridge construction.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 (UP) -- The Navy has told the Armed Services Committee of the House of Representatives that almost 5,000 naval officers would lose promotions this year because of the so-called Davis Amendment to the Military Appropriations Law.

A spirited Fordham football squad, fresh from its 33-to-6 trouncing of Temple, ran through a half-hour scrimmage yesterday in preparation for its game on Saturday with Syracuse at Triboro Stadium on Randalls Island.

A 10.75 per cent wage increase for pilots and co-pilots, retroactive to June 1, 1952, is incorporated in an agreement signed by Pan-American World Airways and its pilot group, represented by the Air Line Pilots Association, it was announced yesterday.

KIRKUK, Iraq, Nov. 18 -- King Faisal came to the Kirkuk oil fields today to inaugurate officially the Iraq Petroleum Company's thirty-inch pipeline to Banias in the presence of a large gathering of Iraqi and foreign notables. Chartered planes brought guests from London and Paris.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 18 -- The first of two exploratory flights by the Scandinavian Airlines System to check a proposed commercial airline route for linking California and Europe via the Polar area, is scheduled to leave here at 8:30 A. M. tomorrow.
In 1945, when the war ended, it cost the voluntary general hospitals an average of $8.31 a day to pro vide semi-private care for one patient.

The acid test of a democracy is its treatment of minorities, Dr. Buell G. Gallagher, president of City College, declared last night at the fourth annual symposium of the United Negro College Fund, held in the auditorium of Hunter College.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 18 -- Women have been trooping back to California's factories in increasing numbers since the start of the Korean war and their total now is the greatest since the end of World War II, according to the latest report of the State Department of Industrial Relations.
ATHENS, Nov. 18 (Reuters) -- King Paul approved tonight the Cabinet of Field Marshal Alexander Papagos. The Cabinet will be sworn in tomorrow.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Nov. 18 -- The Indonesian Cabinet held an emergency session last night to discuss the latest split within the Army which took place at Macassar, the capital of Celebes, over the week-end when Lieut. Col. Warouw, and a group of officers seized control of the East Indonesian Seventh Division.

MEXICO CITY, Nov. 18 (AP) -- The top race drivers of the United States, Mexico and Europe, and a few ambitious amateurs, gave final tune-ups to their cars today in preparation for the start tomorrow of Mexico's border-to-border sports and stock car race.

ALBANY, Nov. 18 -- Counsel for Dr. Harold Lenz declared today that the Queens College professor had been removed from his post as dean of students at the New York City municipal college as an "unjust and improper" punishment for "legitimate political activities."
MOSCOW, Nov. 18 (AP) -- The Soviet press indicated today that a widespread crackdown on swindling and corruption was reaping results.

Mother's problem of the right Christmas gift for junior, Uncle Harry or even Grandma may be eased considerably with the release yesterday Of book Suggestions compiled by The New Public Library. "Children's Books Suggested as Holidays Gifts," contains 120 sug, gestions with a description of each book listed.
RICHMOND, R. I., Nov. 18 (AP) -- Ernest O. Dean, 25, of 202 Court Street, Newark, N. J., was killed and three other persons were injured in a highway accident early today.

JERUSALEM, Nov. 18 -- Twenty prominent rabbis and religious leaders in Jerusalem appealed to President Truman today to exercise clemency on behalf of Julius and Ethel Rosenberg. The New York couple is under sentence to die in Sing Sing Prison for passing atomic secrets to the Soviet Union.

There's bad news today. Policemen in St. Louis have been told that they must adopt some of the super-sleuthing methods employed on television and radio programs if they want to impress the modern juror. Take to the hills, folks, the dam has broke.

Three hundred and fourteeen West Point cadets, members of the faculty and staff and some civilian employes of the Military Academy contributed a pint of blood each yesterday to the Red Cross Blood Bank.

BONN, Germany, Nov. 18 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer's personal control of the coalition parties in the Bundestag received a sharp and unexpected check today when some members of the Free Democratic party, second largest of the three supporting the Government, combined with the Opposition to defeat his urgent request for ratification this month of the treaty system linking West Germany with the Western powers.

A recent report on Eastern European agriculture by the Food and Agricultural Organization of the United Nations paints a picture far at variance with the usual claims of Communist propaganda. The data, which cover Yugoslavia as well as the satellites, show that in 1951 the per capita wheat equivalent of crop production dropped to 738 pounds, as against 817 pounds before the war and 879 pounds in 1950.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 (AP) -- Representatives of organized labor and cooperatives today joined fishing boat owners in asking the United States Tariff Commission to limit imports on tuna.
The 1948 International Convention for the Safety of Life at Sea, having been ratified by the United States and seventeen other maritime countries, will go into effect today.

The trustees of the Brooklyn Thoracic Hospital, meeting at the Dime Savings Bank of Brooklyn, presented a gift of $1,000 to Charles L. Knudsen, the hospital's chief engineer, who retired yesterday after sixty-two years in that post. Mrs. Oscar W. Swift, honorary president of the hospital who became a trustee in 1918 and had the longest association of any board member with Mr. Knudsen, made the presentation.

Many reservations have been made for the performance of "The Deep Blue Sea," with Margaret Sullavan in the leading role, tomorrow night at the Morosco Theatre which has been taken over to raise funds for the Berkshire Industrial Farm.

The long-predicted proposal to create a Transit Authority to operate the city's rapid transit system and help the city out of its financial crisis will be put before an executive session of the Board of Estimate today by Mayor Impellitteri.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 19 -- Egypt's Foreign Minister said today that until Israel fulfilled her obligations to carry out past decisions of the United Nations, there was no prospect of peace between the two Middle East neighbors.

RUTHERFORD, N. J., Nov. 18 -- Four heavy drinkers and a tee-totaler visited a sociology class at Fairleigh Dickinson College today to explain how they had developed into hoboes and to return the visit made to the Bowery in New York two weeks ago by four inquiring members the class.

Our soldiers stationed in Europe are not fighting a war, but since they are soldiers they are living under something of war's surrealistic conditions and they are manifesting something of war's exaggerations. Unwelcome reports are currently reaching this country about the ill-will growing up between groups of our soldiers abroad and the townspeople of certain cities where our men are billeted.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- President Truman and Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower discussed important problems today and expressed the belief that their arrangements for cooperation would contribute to the stability of the country and "of international affairs."

The city has moved to increase its $1,143,000 yearly charge against the Consolidated Edison Company for use of city streets for the utility's transformers, Controller Lazarus Joseph disclosed yesterday.

A City College clerical worker who was responsible until last year for administering make-up examinations to college athletes and other students, was dismissed yesterday as an aftermath of an investigation into the recent basketball scandal by the Board of Higher Education.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 18 -- The St. Louis Award for 1951 was presented today to District Judge George H. Moore for "the determined and effective manner in which he went beyond accepted standards of judicial responsibility" in forcing a grand jury investigation of tax fixing and corruption in the Internal Revenue Bureau office here.

An explosion that crumbled walls, buckled apartment doors and resulted in the death of one woman and slight injuries to two others, occurred at 6:50 A. M. yesterday in the thirteen-story apartment building at 319 East Fiftieth Street, known as the Beekman Hill Apartments.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 (AP) -- The Defense Department identified today 225 more Korean war casualties. Of the total, 48 are dead, 138 wounded, 22 missing in action and 17 injured in battle zone accidents. The following casualties were reported for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut:

While the question of the Korean armistice, now entering the decisive phase in the United Nations, was first among the problems brought up at yesterday's dramatic meeting in the White House the widening rift between France and Germany was a close second in the order of urgency.

The Chrysler Airtemp organization reports a survey of twenty-three large-scale builders showing major innovations in many of the 12,000 dwellings in twelve major cities of the East, Midwest and South for 1953 occupancy. Seventeen are including packaged air conditioning.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 (AP) -- The State Department announced today the appointment of seven persons to the 100-member United States National Commission for the United Nations Economic, Scientific and Cultural Organization.
JACKSON, Mich., Nov. 18 (UP) -- Prisoners rioted for an hour in overcrowded Southern Michigan Prison late today before guards forced them to their cells.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 18 -- Columbia has Glenn Ford and Broderick Crawford in mind to share co-star billing in "Rough Company," which has been set as the first assignment for Lewis Rachmil, who joined the studio yesterday as a producer after having severed ties with R. K. O.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 (UP) -- The Government is preparing to crack down on an international wheat racket that may touch off one of the first investigations of the new Republican-led Congress.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- Certificates of necessity for accelerated tax amortization for 100 new or expanded facilities amounting to $105,597,017 were issued by the Defense Production Administration from Nov. 6 through Nov. 12, the Government agency announced today.

Futures were weak yesterday on the New York commodity exchanges with almost all prices off. Lead, zinc, cocoa, potatoes and coffee closed lower. Hides, rubber, wool, sugar and cottonseed oil were mixed. Tin and soybean oil were the only commodities to end the day higher but there were no sales in tin.
LINCOLN, R. I., Nov. 18 (UP) -- Tony DeSpirito, the nation's leading jockey who was hurt last Friday, may not ride again until the end of this week.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- One photographer, winner of a drawing out of a hat, got the privilege of making a photograph on a pool basis of the conference between President Truman and Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower today.

MOSCOW, Nov. 18 -- The Soviet press, which has been criticizing American "beizbol" as "bloody mayhem," shifted its target today to American "futbol," which it declared was designed to brutalize American youth and prepare it to take its place in an "army of bandits and haters of mankind" under the United States policy of militarization.

Zinaida Alvers, contralto, was last night's recitalist at Town Hall. The Ukrainian-born artist, a onetime member of the Vienna State Opera, has appeared here previously in recital and in performances of Michel Kachouk's Russian Opera Company.

Debutantes of this season will distribute Spence-Chapin programs before the performance of "The Time of the Cuckoo" tonight at the Empire Theatre, and the performance of "The Millionairess" next Monday night at the Shubert Theatre, which have been taken over to raise funds for the Spence-Chapin Adoption Service.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 (UP) -- A cotton producers group today urged simplified procedure for putting government loans on cotton and studied a program intended to bring 1953 production into line with anticipated demand.

Many parties were given at the first in a serie sof Knickerbocker after-theatre supper parties held last night in the Terrace Room of the Plaza for the subscribers who had attended earlier in the evening the performance of "An Evening With Beatrice Lillie" at the Booth Theatre.
To finance various improvements, the State of Massachusetts borrowed $11,080,000 yesterday on serial bonds maturing from 1953 to 1982.

SYDNEY, Australia, Wednesday, Nov. 19 (AP) -- Mervy Rose, Australia's left-handed Davis Cup player, crushed Vic Seixas of Philadelphia, 6 -- 2, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 4, today in the quarter-finals of the New South Wales tennis championship, assuring an all-Australian semi-final round in the tournament Seixas won last year.

PARIS, Nov. 18 -- Premier Antoine Pinay postponed today his plan to ask the National Assembly this week for a confidence vote on his financial measures. The finance bill, containing parts of the disputed fiscal reform measure, will be sent to the Assembly for a showdown on Dec. 2, it was decided.

The most rigid international code on sea safety ever written by the maritime Powers becomes effective tomorrow, when the International Convention for the Safety of Life at Sea supersedes the 1929 agreement. It expands procedural controls and tightens the rules on equipment all along the line, from lifeboat bilge pumps to subdivisions and stability in passenger liners.

Young matrons, including Mrs. William W. Field, and Mrs. E. Gayle McGuigan are aiding in the plans for the holiday hockey game between the New York Rangers and Toronto next Wednesday, Thanksgiving eve, at Madison Square Garden.

Today's new film is "The Iron Mistress," Warner Brothers' Technicolor dramatization of the James I. Wellman novel, with Alan Ladd, Virginia Mayo, Joseph Calleia, Phyllis Kirk and Alf Kjellin, at the Paramount. Gordon Douglas directed and Henry Blanke produced the period adventure from a script by James R. Webb.

Former Sgt. John David Provoo boasted that he was working for the Japanese and issued an ultimatum to an American officer who was subsequently killed by the Japanese, according to testimony in Federal Court yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 (AP) -- President Truman today awarded the Harmon International Trophy to Mme. Jacqueline Auriol, daughter-in-law of the President of France, and to two Americans.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 (AP) -- The Government today raised the question of "good faith" in seeking to block a suit by a Swiss holding company to win back 90 per cent of the stock of General Aniline and Film Corporation.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- A special committee of the House of Representatives began public hearings today in what promised to be more of a sympathetic study than a hostile investigation of the country's tax-exempt educational and philanthropic foundations.

Most business men look for an economic recession in 1953 or 1954, Elliott V. Bell, editor and publisher of Business Week, told 1,200 members and guests of the Economic Club of New York last night at a dinner meeting in the Astor Hotel.

A collection of operatic memorabilia owned by Dr. Edwin Franko Goldman has been presented to the Metropolitan Opera Association for display at the opera house, where it will be dedicated early in 1953, the year marking Dr. Goldman's seventy-fifth birthday.

Bobby Shantz, the Athletics' star hurler, won The United Press American League player of the year award yesterday in a close race against Mickey Mantle, the switch-hitting sophomore star of the Yankees.

BONN, Germany, Nov. 18 -- The major parties of West Germany temporarily forgot their differences today and united to support a Bundestag declaration branding the Saar elections on Nov. 30 as illegal and refusing to recognize any Saar government resulting from the ballot.

Firemen battled for nearly an hour yesterday afternoon a stubborn and smoky blaze in a four-story brick loft building on the southeast corner of Thirty-seventh Street and the Avenue of the Americas. Damage to the building and its contents were estimated by Chief Fire Marshal Martin Scott as $100,000. Two firemen suffered minor hand injuries from broken glass and ragged metal.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 18 -- Gov. Herman Talmadge of Georgia, elected to the chairmanship of the Southern Governors Conference today, pledged the region's resources and leadership to "work unremittingly" for national security and general welfare "in this perilous hour."

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Nov. 18 -- South Africa's Opposition leader, J. G. N. Strauss, fired the opening shots tonight in an election campaign to be fought on bitter questions of race relations and the constitutional crisis involving non-white voting rights.

ALBANY, Nov. 18 (AP) -- The sale of the state's "one-plate" motor vehicle registrations for 1953 will start Dec. 1. A record distribution of 4,200,000 registrations to top the high mark of 4,175,000 this year was predicted by the State Motor Vehicle Bureau.
Seven more multiple-parking violators appeared yesterday in Traffic Court and paid $1,336 in fines.

MONTREAL, Nov. 18 (Canadian Press) -- H. A. Stevenson, president of Barclays Bank (Canada) Ltd., said today that Canada will deprive non-dollar countries of power and incentive to buy from her if she continues to confine her purchases to the United States.

Following are excerpts from testimony yesterday in the State Crime Commission's investigation of the links between the underworld and political leaders here. The commission's chairman, Joseph M. Proskauer, is presiding, and the questioning is being conducted by members of the commission's legal staff.

The sixty-six-family apartment house at 1165 West Farms Road, also known as 1144 Vyse Avenue, the Bronx, has been purchased by Henry Altman from Hyman Goldberg and David Mayer. The property is assessed at $165,000 and was sold subject to a mortgage of $85,300.

Only 5 per cent of the public assistance social workers in New York State have enough training to fill their jobs adequately, Alexander Handel, dean of Adelphi College School of Social Work, told 5,000 persons attending the fifty-third annual meeting of the New York State Welfare Conference at the Statler Hotel yesterday.
BEAULIEU, France, Nov. 18 (AP) -- Prince Felix D'Aviano of Habsburg and German Princess Anna-Eugenie D'Arenberg were married today by the Mayor of this French Riviera village.

Mr. Hay helped organize the National Retarded Children's Association in 1950 and was its first secretary. He was named its president at the national convention in Los Angeles last Oct. 11. The group is an outgrowth of the Association for the Health of Retarded Children, 31 Madison Avenue, of which Mr. Hay had been an officer.

Merchant ship construction in this country dropped last month to a new low for the year. Fewer ships were being built than at any time since last December and less deadweight tonnage was on the ways of American yards than at any time since February.

PUSAN, Korea, Nov. 18 (AP) -- The South Korean Government has reversed signals once again and is planning a spectacular welcome for the United States President-elect. Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, whose proposed visit to this war zone is supposed to be shrouded in utmost secrecy.

The New York A. C. squash racquets team scored a 3-to-2 victory over the University Club, the defending champion, as competition started last night in the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association's Class A interclub competition.
Issues of new corporate securities having an aggregate value of more than $36,800,000 will be placed on the market by underwriting syndicates today.

The Southern Production Company, Inc., producer of oil and natural gas, announced yesterday that it has submitted an offer to acquire the assets of the Texas Pacific Coal and Oil Company at a price which would enable Texas Pacific's stockholders to realize about $45 a share in complete liquidation.

The Indian delegation to the United Nations has now submitted its compromise proposal for solving the prisoner-of-war issue in Korea -- the last ostensible obstacle to an armistice intended to end the stalemated war and open the road to a settlement of the Korean problem as a whole.

That the design of the chair is a distinctive achievement of Danish designers became clear yesterday at the opening of a new showroom devoted to furniture imported from Denmark. In the collection of pieces introduced by George Tanier, 521 Madison Avenue, designs for sitting took the spotlight.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 18 -- Contributions of member states of the United Nations for 1952 are being collected a little more rapidly than last year but payment of advances to the working capital fund of $21,239,203 is lagging slightly, according to a collection report issued today.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Nov., 18 -- The New Jersey Turnpike Authority adopted today a four-point program designed to cut the heavy accident toll on the 118-mile superhighway, particularly when fog increases driving hazards.
CHICAGO, Nov. 18 (AP) -- Three persons were killed today in a three-car collision in Lake Shore Drive near Thirty-ninth Street, on the South Side.
PRINCETON, N. J., Nov. 18 (AP) -- Princeton University paid tribute to its champion big three football team with a gigantic bonfire rally tonight.

Following is the statement made yesterday by Joseph M. Proskauer, chairman of the State Crime Commission, in connection with a statement given out Monday by Carmine G. DeSapio, leader of Tammany Hall:

Though fruits packed without sugar are not new on the market, there is a brand of them being introduced at Charles, 340 Madison Avenue, that is outstanding. The texture is excellent, approaching the firmness of fresh fruit, and the syrup, despite the fact no sugar has been used, is thick and non-watery.

Consolidation of St. Luke's Hospital and Woman's Hospital, two of New York City's oldest voluntary institution's, has been approved unanimously by their directors, who announced the union at a dinner last night in the Union Club, Park Avenue at Sixty-ninth Street.

It is unfortunate that the letter entitled "Newsprint From Sugar Cane Waste" appeared in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Oct. 9 in the Letters to THE TIMES part of the editorial page, since that letter is, to say the least, incorrect and misleading.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- Mrs. Dwight D. Eisenhower, wife of the President-elect, underwent a "minor check-up" at Walter Reed Hospital, the Army Medical Center, this afternoon, while her husband conferred with President Truman.

A CLICHE becomes one only when its literary aptness is recognized by too many people. It is a form of snobbery to avoid a choice one just because it is familiar. So I will now make use of one of the most expressive of all cliches and say that the trouble with Bernard DeVoto's "The Course of Empire"* is that you can't see the woods for the trees.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 18 -- The financial strength of American railroads has been weakened to such an extent by "outmoded" regulations that Government ownership has become a definite threat, Joseph A. Fisher, president of the Reading Company, declared here today.

One of the most impressive performances we have heard the Philadelphia, or any other orchestra, give in this city in recent seasons was that of Honeggers "Jeanne d'Arc au Bucher," under the baton of Eugene Ormandy, last night in Carnegie Hall.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 (AP) -- Following are the texts of President-elect Eisenhower's informal remarks after his conference with President Truman and of a joint statement issued later by the two conferees:

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 18 -- Two traveling clinics for Korea -- large gray trucks fitted with everything from hypodermics to movie projectors -- were put on exhibition outside the United Nations skyscraper here today.
The resignation of Young Berryman Smith, for twenty-five years dean of the Columbia University Law School, was announced yesterday by Dr. Grayson Kirk, acting head of the university.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Nov. 18 -- Donald R. Richberg, who in 1935 headed the National Recovery Administration, said here tonight that the "great achievement" of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the President-elect, has been the "unification of the forces of conservative progress."

ROME, Nov. 18 -- The trend of Italian voters away from the Christian Democrats and to a smaller degree also from the three Center parties allied with them has been visible in all local elections held since 1948. This was confirmed by elections held recently in the northern provinces of Trento and Bolzano which between them form the autonomous region of Upper Adige.

LONDON, Nov. 18 -- Prices continue to rise on the stock markets here today. Business increased in volume particularly for British Government securities where fresh gains were made by medium dated issues. Industrial leaders also advanced steadily until near the end of business, when prices reacted slightly.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 18 -- Secretary General Trygve Lie received today an invitation to appear before the Federal Grand Jury in New York investigating subversive activities. He is expected to decline the bid.
The Rangers will be without the services of Edgar Laprade when they meet the Detroit Red Wings at Madison Square Garden tonight, but there will be a new face in the line-up.

The Thirty-fourth Street-Midtown Association is dreaming of a white Christmas with renewal of white vehicular traffic lines at street crossings before the Yuletide shopping season gets under way. In a letter sent to Commissioner T. T. Wiley of the Traffic Department yesterday, the immediate needs cited were at Greeley Square, Herald Square, Thirty-third and Thirty-fourth Streets at Seventh Avenue, Thirty-fifth Street at Broadway, Fifth Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street and Thirty-fourth Street and Madison Avenue.

TORONTO, Nov. 18 (AP) -- Canada won tonight's international jumping competition at the Royal Agricultural Winter Fair with clean performances by Reject and Anchors Aweigh, both ridden by W. R. Ballard.
Cotton futures prices on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday were irregular, closing 5 points lower to 19 points net higher than on Monday.

Optional or discretionary spending power in the hands of consumers can cushion the economy when defense expenditures begin to fall off, provided retailers strive to tempt such money out of hiding by adequate sales promotion.
TRENTON, Nov. 18 -- Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll of New Jersey issued the following statement today upon learning of the death of former Gov. A. Harry Moore:

" Sidney Hillman: Statesman of American Labor," a new biography by Matthew Josephson, has been scheduled for Dec. 4 publication by Doubleday. The work describes the life of the Lithuanian immigrant, particularly his career as a political leader of labor in the years following 1929.

A large group of furniture, additions to the Hastings Square collection introduced earlier this autumn, is now on view at Sloane's. Designed by William Pahlmann, the group includes pieces that might be as suitable for small quarters as the large ones in which they are shown.

THE TIMES reports that the school board of a small town will exact a loyalty oath of the officers of any community organization wishing to use school facilities. A committee formed to oppose the board's directive contends that everything from card parties and garden shows to Boy Scout meetings would be affected.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 18 -- Evidence that it takes time for memories to settle in the human consciousness and become fixed there was reported today at a panel discussion on psychiatry at the opening of the University of Maryland's new Psychiatric Institute.
State Housing Commissioner Herman T. Stichman was temporarily enjoined yesterday from evicting veterans from the Manhattan Beach Houses under terms of a State Supreme Court decision.

A new concept of the responsibilities of the purchasing department has arisen from the extraordinary conditions under which industry must operate today, H. W. Christensen, director of purchases of the Columbia-Geneva Steel division of the United States Steel Corporation, declared here yesterday.
Testimony charging sales of judgeships and offers of judgeships for cash was presented yesterday at the New York State Crime Commission hearings in the Supreme Court Building.

HONOLULU, Nov. 15 -- The Government abruptly ended five days of questioning its first witness in the trial of seven Hawaii residents for conspiracy today and after objections defense attorneys cross-examined him closely to test his memory.

Edward Nelson, owner of a Brooklyn rooming house in which two person were burned to death Monday, waived examination yesterday in Brooklyn Felony Court on a charge of first and second degree manslaughter and was held without bail to await grand jury action.

NORMAN, Okla., Nov. 18 (AP) -- President George L. Cross of the University of Oklahoma told a student demonstration tonight that he would sanction a football bowl trip for the Sooners in defiance of a Big Seven ban if the team wants to go.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 18 -- Yale's bitter disappointment over last Saturday's 27-21 loss to Princeton, an outcome that never will be accepted with full resignation here despite the glowing tributes paid to the finesse and gallantry of Jordan Olivar's team, has not lessened the awareness of the Bulldogs that they still have an important mission to accomplish before they can write finis to their 1952 football campaign.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 (UP) -- House tax scandal investigators announced tonight that they had successfully concluded a year-long effort to obtain transcripts of official telephone conversations that might provide new leads for them.

MOSCOW, Nov. 18 (AP) -- The Moscow correspondent of The New York Daily Worker, writing in The Literary Gazette, reported today that the United States' two-party system had deprived the people of an opportunity of expressing their real point of view in the election.

The New York City Lallet last night began the third week of its season at the City Center with a program consisting entirely of repetitions of works already seen. These were Frederick Ashton's "Picnic at Tintagel," with Melissa Hayden, Jacques d'Amboise, Stanley Zompakos, Irene Larsson and Robert Barnett; and three ballets by George Balanchine.
CHICAGO, Nov. 18 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock market here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
The infants' wear department at Gimbels is showing a collection of newly arrived European imports for young ladies and gentlemen in the "birth-to-three" bracket.

Permanent financing amounting to $4,657,900 has been arranged by J. Halperin Co., brokers, for Dara Gardens, a 536-family apartment project being built by the Carol Management Corporation at Seventy-first Avenue and 150th Street in Flushing, Queens.

LONDON, Wednesday, Nov. 19 (Reuters) -- Bertrand Russell, 80-year-old Nobel Prize-winning philosopher, mathematician and writer, announced today that he was engaged to be married to an American, Miss Edith Finch of London, formerly of Bryn Mawr College, Pa.

George Shuba, the Dodger outfielder, who underwent an operation for the removal of a cartilage from his left knee on Election Day, will be discharged from Long Island College Hospital, Brooklyn this morning and will leave immediately for his home in Youngstown, Ohio.

Elmer Wheeler did it again yesterday. He packed the Henry Hudson Room of the Roosevelt Hotel for the weekly meeting of the Sales Executives Club of New York and left 300 persons standing outside. Elmer, widely known as "Mr. Salesman," was there to make the first showing of "Selling the Sizzle," a sales information film of the receiver division of Allen B. Du Mont Laboratories, Inc.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 (AP) -- Profits by corporations, after payment of taxes, have dropped in relation to sales until they are "well below 1950 and the 1920's," the Department of Commerce reported today.

The State Crime Commission decided yesterday that nothing would be gained by a further examination of Thomas (Three Finger Brown) Luchese and entered into a stipulation with his counsel that he would not be called again to testify either publicly or privately.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Nov. 18 -- As its price for the establishment of a six-nation European political authority, the Dutch Government is preparing to insist on a treaty guaranteeing the creation of a customs union within a specified number of years.

Events tonight: "Carmen," Metropolitan Opera, 8:15 o'clock; Mischa Elman, violinist, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; Lawrence Chelsi, baritone, Town Hall, 8:30; Mannes Orchestra, Mannes Music School, 8:30; Music Lovers' Round Table, Turtle Bay Music School, 8:15; Budapest String Quartet, Lexington Avenue Y. M. and Y. W. H. A., 8:40.

The B. F. Goodrich Company increased its quarterly dividend to 65 cents a share and also declared an extra dividend for the year of 50 cents on the common stock, both payable on Dec. 31. At the same time the company reported sales and earnings below the same nine-month period last year.
There are, undeniably, fortunate people in the world who can claim to have done nearly everything that there is to be done, with the possible exception of writing a novel and composing a symphony.
TOKYO, Wednesday, Nov. 19 (AP) -- United Nations Command headquarters communique for twenty-four hours ended 6 A. M. Wednesday, Korea time:

THE duck hunters in this general area, taking in Connecticut and New Jersey as well as Long Island, are managing a wider smile these days, and according to reports from Great South Bay, Barnegat Bay and eastern Connecticut, the shooting has definitely improved.

Yesterday's meeting between President Truman and General Eisenhower at the White House can be expected to serve two purposes. One of these is to give the President-elect an insider's look at some of the chief problems with which he will be confronted when he takes office two months hence.
DALLAS, Nov. 18 (AP) -- There will be no further effort by Dallas to operate a franchise in the National Football League.
Civilian manufacturers may expect better deliveries on machine tools as a result of a revision by the National Production Authority of its M-41 regulation.

WHEELING, W. VA., Nov. 18 (UP) -- Three jockeys were injured today in the seventh race at Wheeling Downs race track when all eight horses in the race were bunched rounding a turn and Archain cut from the outside and piled up two horses. None of the horses was injured.

In a surprise action the City Council, with Councilman Hugh Quinn, Queens Democrat, absent, yesterday defeated by a vote of 13 to 11 the controversial bill that would have levied $25 fines against parents for vandalism committed by their children against city property.

Professional wrestling returned to Madison Square Garden last night as 18,357 fans, who paid $57,396, watched Antonino Rocca of Argentina score over over Lu Kim of San Francisco. The exhibition ended in 10 minutes 43 seconds.

The National Theatre of Greece, in its first American engagement, will be introduced at 8 o'clock this evening at the Hellinger by Guthrie McClintic, a Broadway producer-director whose devotion to his art isn't circumscribed by any boundaries.
This has reference to the letter to the editor by Dr. Morris Weintrob, who wrote on "V. A. Hospital Policy" and who purports to understand how best to serve the veteran.
LONDON, Nov. 18 -- Flames leaping twenty feet into the air damaged tonight what once were the private apartments of King Henry VIII at Hampton Court Palace, former home of British rulers.

SOUTHAMPTON, England, Nov. 18 -- Mischel Hapalo, 45-year-old Polish refugee turned out of France, Canada and Britain, settled down today to a life on the ocean waves as the unwelcome, free guest of the Cunard steamship line.

Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower arrived at the Marine Terminal in La Guardia Airport at 5:45 o'clock last evening in a chartered plane following his afternoon talk with President Truman at the White House and a meeting with the Joint Chiefs of Staff in the Pentagon.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- The nation's capital cheered and shouted its welcome this afternoon to Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower as the President-elect toured the downtown government and business district for thirty minutes on his way to his appointment at the White House.

The United Fruit Company's new $1,000,000 terminal, which will be the largest mechanical banana-handling facility in the world, will be officially opened on Nov. 28, H. H. Robson, vice president in charge of ships and terminals, said yesterday.

Terry Murray, pianist from Macon, Ga., made his New York debut last night at Carnegie Recital Hall. His program included Beethoven's Sonata Op. 90, Ravel's Sonatine, Chopin's B flat minor Sonata and pieces by Liszt and Samuel Barber.
CHICAGO, Nov. 18 -- Illinois Republican State Senator Charles F. Carpentier of East Moline today was declared elected Secretary of State of Illinois by 9,332 votes.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 (AP) -- Senator John J. Williams. Republican of Delaware, today denounced as "indefensible" the appointment of Mr. Dunlap to a lifetime civil service post.

BONN, Germany, Nov. 18 -- The arrest of two United States business men and of thirty-four German contractors in the French zone and their connection with defense construction projects in West Germany costing more than $100,000,000, has started an investigation of bribery, corruption and the illegal possession of classified military information.

CHARLIE MOORE won the Olympic 400-meter hurdles championship at Helsinki last summer and thereby fulfilled a vow that had been made by Charlie Moore twenty-eight years previously. Or are we going too fast for you? Suppose we start in at the beginning.
The Police Department held its 310th public auction in Brooklyn yesterday with the following results:

Retail sales of television receivers in Canada this year are running well over $100,000,000, Ernest A. Marx, director of the international division of Allen B. Du Mont Laboratories, Inc., reported yesterday. He said almost every important manufacturer in the United States is seeking to tap the expanding Canadian market either through subsidiaries or Dominion licensees.

The face of the displaced person is one that has appeared on magazine covers, newspaper front pages and newsreel screens for quite a while. And whether the face is young or old, whether it is the face of a cherub or a face etched in suffering, the expression is always the same. "Where am I going?" say the eyes.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- Fewer persons were out of work in October than at any other time since the end of World War II. the Bureau of the Census reported today.

Assemblyman Ludwig Teller, Manhattan Democrat-Liberal, urged yesterday that voluntary rent increases be outlawed when the State Rent Control Law is extended for another year at the legislative session which begins in January. Unless extended the law expires automatically on June 30.

HUNTINGTON, W. Va., Nov. 18 (AP) -- Marshall College has decided to go ahead with a series of lectures that was canceled earlier when an American Legion post objected to three scheduled speakers who had been identified with alleged Communist-front groups.

Some good words were said for television yesterday at -- surprisingly -- a conference on "Reading in the Family," arranged by the Children's Book Council and held at the Roosevelt Hotel. Robert Lewis Shayon, a writer and television critic, and Dr. Frances Ilg, a child development specialist at the Gesell Institute in New Haven, presented two different aspects of the possible benefits television can provide.
An Internal Revenue Bureau agent was arrested yesterday in a midtown hotel on a charge of accepting a $2,000 bribe for resolving a taxpayer's liability in the latter's favor.
CHICAGO, Nov. 18 (UP) -- Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson said today that he intended to "start making a living" as an attorney when his term as Governor of Illinois ended.

All but one of the unfinished games in the women's world chess championship challengers' tournament were played off in Moscow yesterday, and as a result Mrs. Elizabeth Bykova led the field by 2 points, according to a report received through Soviet news sources.

Higher sales and earnings in the third quarter this year failed to lift the nine months' profit of Eastman Kodak Company, which was $3,764,478 below the net for the corresponding nine months last year.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- President Truman reported to Congress today that shipments of planes, tanks, guns and other military aid to Western Europe fell "considerably behind" schedule in the first half of 1952, but that "much progress was made in translating defense plans into actual military strength."

RABAT, French Morocco, Nov. 18 (UP) -- Sultan Sidi Mohammed Ben Youssef, .nominal ruler of this French protectorate, said today that while he was "profoundly touched" by the friendship of French officials, he wished they would go home.
The growing importance of research will call for changes in tax structures and adjustment of management viewpoints, the president of Massachusetts Institute of Technology declared yesterday.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 18 -- Britain and Canada agreed tonight to try to work out changes in an Indian compromise resolution on the repatriation of Korean prisoners of war in the hope that it could be made acceptable to both India and the United States.

JERSEY CITY, Nov. 18 -- Action on a proposed municipal ordinance to license business and industries here through the collection of gross receipts and payroll tax was postponed today by members of the City Commission after fourteen persons spoke against the ordinance and only one in favor of it at a two-and-one-half-hour hearing at City Hall.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Nov. 18 -- With $475,000 yet to be raised through fund drives to complete the unfinished $4,000,000 North Shore Hospital, the second of five scheduled public meetings appeared tonight to be as unproductive as was the first, which broke up early this ramming over a dispute concerning the proposed appointment of four "outsiders" as directors of services.

E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., has built a machine for measuring the "comfort" of apparel fabrics, it was revealed yesterday at the second day sessions of the annual meeting of the Textile Research Institute in the Commodore Hotel.

SEOUL, Korea, Nov. 18 -- Civilians in this area will be facing this winter one of the most acute food shortages since the beginning of the Korean war, United Nations food administrators here said today. Food contributions from United Nations countries throughout the world have declined, and the population of the city and surrounding areas has swollen by about 30 per cent since last winter.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- The Senate Elections subcommittee appeared opelessly stymied today in its effort to reach a decision before the end of the year on the charges and counter-charges between Senators William Benton, Democrat of Connecticut, and Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin.
John Ryan, 57 years old, who in 1939 was sentenced to fifteen years to life imprisonment as a fourth felony offender, walked out of Kings County Court yesterday a free man.

JERSEY CITY, Nov. 19 -- This city's first Negro police sergeant, a supporter of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower in the Presdential election, last night started a new assignment. It was patrolling the deserted city park area surrounding the Roosevelt Municipal Stadium between 8 P. M. and 4 A. M.

The editorial "Zenger School" in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Nov. 13 no doubt resulted from releases given out by Public School 18 in the Bronx in relation to dedication ceremonies of the school named for John Peter Zenger.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- Following the recommendations of a panel of its, Finance Bureau officials, the Interstate Commerce Commission today announced that changed conditions necessitated a review of the 1949 plan of reorganization for the Missouri Pacific Railroad Company and its affiliates, with a revision if that is found necessary.

SINGAPORE, Nov. 19 -- Gen. Sir Gerald Templer, British High Commissioner, outlined today far-reaching plans to build a strong Malayan nation. They are designed to improve the Malays' position, allow non-Malay Asians into the Malayan civil service, speed up rural development and make a start on state and settlement council elections for 1954.

A new long-range foreign policy for this country, one supplementing maximum free world military strength with "a dynamic economic strategy so bold and so vigorous that it will more than match the ruthless totalitarian expansion of communism," was advocated last night by Winthrop W. Aldrich, chairman of the Chase National Bank.

TORONTO, Nov. 19 (UP) -- Two first period goals by Real Chevrefils gave the Boston Bruins the necessary margin to defeat the Toronto Maple Leafs, 2 -- 1, in a National Hockey League game at Maple Leaf Gardens tonight.

BONN, Germany, Nov. 19 -- Government sources predicted today that the Bundestag would debate and ratify the Bonn peace contract with the Western Allies and the European Defense Community Treaty during the second week of December.

The Schools Morton Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitble for children between the ages of 8 and 14 a group of motion pictures to be shown tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified

HONOLULU, Nov. 19 -- A Pan American Airways Stratoclipper carrying forty-seven passengers and mail, cut 6 hours 45 minutes off the time for the regular Tokyo-Honolulu run today, completing a 3,950-mile non-stop flight from the Japanese capital in 11 hours 30 minutes.

The American people and their elected officials will do well to study the pertinent remarks regarding scientific research voiced recently by Dr. James R. Killian Jr., president of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. Such research has already brought revolutionary changes in our way of life.
OTTAWA, Nov. 19 -- The Canadian Parliament will reopen tomorrow for what is expected to be its last session before a new general election is called.

Today's new film is "Leonardo da Vinci," a feature-length examination in color of the life and works of the master, at the Guild Theatre. Luciano Emmer and Lauro Venturi directed the Pictura Pictures presentation, which has a commentary by Marcel Brion and a narration by Albert Dekker.

The public has very hazy, dim and contradictory ideas about mental illness, according to a University of Chicago survey reported here yesterday at the second annual meeting of the National Association for Mental Health, Inc., at the Henry Hudson Hotel.
Pierre Etchebaster retained a formidable lead in the match for the world open court tennis title and came within a set of retaining the crown yesterday.

Debutantes of this season are aiding members of the executive committee in furthering the success of the Thanksgiving tea dance for the benefit of the Judson Health Center to be held this afternoon in the main ballroom of the Plaza.

It takes four years at medical school to educate a doctor, three years at nursing school to create a registered nurse. But that's only the beginning. At this moment 6,000 future doctors and nurses are studying in the huge network of New York's voluntary, non-profit hospitals.

Police Commissioner George P. Monaghan announced yesterday the dismissal of Sgt. William L. Apfel, a member of the force for the last twelve years. The 33-year-old sergeant was found guilty in a prolonged trial on four of eight charges of "conduct prejudicial to the interests of the Police Department."

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 19 -- V. K. Krishna Menon, the Indian representative, offered assurances today that a compromise Indian resolution on the repatriation of Korean prisoners of war would not mean an indefinite detention of those unwilling to go home. He said that after an armistice, "if neither side can provide a home for them * * * then it will be the responsibility of the United Nations to look after them."

FORT MEADE, Md., Nov. 19 -- The Army announced today it had decided to press court-martial charges against Lieut. Col. Melvin B. Voorhees, former Tacoma (Washington) newspaper man and Army censor in Korea, for a book he wrote about the fighting there.

STANTON GRIFFIS, diplomatist and financier, accompanied a friend to the Salon d'Automne in Paris one day to see the modern pictures. The friend wanted to buy one or two paintings for his office in Wall Street. But the prices seemed steep. He asked Mr. Griffis whether he thought it would do any good to enter under-bids, in the hope of getting something a modest millionaire could afford.
TOKYO, Thursday, Nov. 20 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,439, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Thursday, Korea time:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (AP) -- Attorney General McGranery today announced a Federal Grand Jury at Shreveport, La., has indicted eight individuals and two companies on charges of illegal diversion of oil well drilling equipment.
Luxurious gift suggestions abounded in Bonwit Teller's showing yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel of gown and peignoir ensembles and at-home costumes.
TORONTO, Nov. 19 (AP) -- The Toronto Telegram has been purchased by a group that includes its general manager and managing editor. The seller was the estate of George McCullagh.

Despite recent world-wide advances in many social welfare fields, half of the world is still inadequately cared for and "the gap between the rich and the poor countries in the general levels of production and consumption is wider" than before World War II, a United Nations official declared yesterday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 19 -- Reports that Ned Depinet would rejoin R. K. O. Radio Pictures as president and a member of the board of directors, effective tomorrow, and that he would bring back into the company other top executives who resigned or were let out recently during a major shift in management control, were current today in Hollywood.

TOKYO, Thursday, Nov. 20 -- The Chinese launched heavy attacks yesterday on the Korean western front, but failed to penetrate the Allied lines. The enemy broke contact and retired after more than eight hours' fighting.

The appointment of Harry G. Nagel as Scout executive of Greater New York Councils, Boy Scouts of America, was announced yesterday. He will assume his duties Dec. 5, replacing Joseph A. Brunton Jr., who will become national director of relationships for the Boy Scouts of America.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- Senator Burnet R. Maybank of South Carolina declined today to say whether he would recognize Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois, the defeated Democratic Presidential nominee, as titular leader of the party for the next four years.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 19 -- British administration in Tanganyika and two other colonies in East Africa was defended today by Sir Alan Burns, British representative on the Trusteeship Council. In reporting to the United Nations General Assembly's Trusteeship Committee, he said:

ATHENS, Nov. 19 -- The new Greek Premier, Field Marshal Alexander Papagos, accepted the resignation today of four top-ranking generals whom he had criticized severely in Parliament during the last year.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- The Supreme Court was asked today to decide whether newspaper publishers must pay union printers for setting "bogus" type and whether theatres must hire "stand-by" union musicians even when their services were declared unnecessary.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 19 (UP) -- Ellis Ryan, president of the Indians, said today that the major leagues' only way to cut expenses would be to schedule all weekday games at night, a proposal he will advocate at next month's winter baseball meetings in Phoenix, Ariz.

The New York State Crime Commission closed its first public hearings in New York County yesterday with a weird picture of extraordinary happenings in the chambers of former Justice (now official referee) Aaron J. Levy in the closing years of Justice Levy's twenty-eight years on the Supreme Court bench.
BALBOA, C. Z., Nov. 19 -- A record number of ships passed through the Panama Canal during October, figures issued by the Panama Canal Company showed yesterday.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 19 -- Secretary General Trygve Lie has decided definitely not to accept an invitation to appear before the Federal grand jury in New York investigating subversive activities.

Although defeated by Eileen Tranmer of England in the fifteenth and final round last night, Mrs. Elizabeth Bykova of Russia, runner-up to the world champion two years ago, emerged as winner of the women's challengers' tournament in Moscow, according to a report received through Soviet news sources.

OAXACA, Mexico, Nov. 19 (AP) -- A highly-tuned Gordini sports car with France's Jean Behra at the wheel won the first stage of the Pan-American road race today with a speed of 88.80 miles an hour over 330 miles of winding mountain highway.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 19 -- The Soviet Union has submitted to the Legal Committee of the United Nations General Assembly a resolution incorporating a detailed definition of aggression, to be used by any international organ called upon to decide whether that offense had been committed.

William White, president of the New York Central Railroad Company, was elected a director of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company yesterday at a meeting of the board of directors. At the same meeting, two new officers were elected -- S. Whitney Landon as secretary, and Alexander L. Stott as treasurer.

Plans to pay a 100 per cent stock dividend, increasing capital stock from $3,000,000 to $6,000,000, were announced yesterday by the Northern Trust Company of Chicago. If approved by stockholders at a special meeting on Dec. 22, a stock dividend on the basis of one share of $100 par would be issued for each of the 30,000 shares out standing.
Pillsbury Mills announced yesterday that it has registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission an issue of $17,000,000 of sinking fund debentures due Dec. 1, 1972.

The Harwood Construction Company sold the six-story apartment building on plot 49 by 100 feet at 49 Willow Street, in the Heights section of Brooklyn, to Issie Weisbrod and Dinah Pode for investment. John McGuire and Schafer Ganz were the brokers in the sale of the building, which contains forty-four suites. Title was insured by the Home Title Guaranty Company.

Roscoe C. Ingalls, senior partner of Ingalls Snyder, was elected president of the Association of Stock Exchange Firms yesterday to succeed Walter Maynard of Shearson, Hammill Co. He has been in the securities business since 1912 and formed his own New York company in 1924.

A knowledge of stenography and typing is the key to jobs in fields where the applicant can offer no specialized ability or is too young to have acquired experience, students at Barnard College were told yesterday.

The "five and dime" stores long ago discovered the impossibility of conducting a profitable business on a flat price basis, but our transit authorities seem obsessed with the idea that it can be done, somehow, if they only can raise fares fast enough to catch up with the deficit.

MADRID, Spain, Nov. 19 (AP) -- Nat Holman, suspended basketball coach of City College of New York, said today he was "infuriated" at the charges of a faculty committee investigating the 1951 basketball "fix" scandals and his suspension as a result.

Ninety-minute flights between New York and Montreal and between New York and Toronto will be scheduled by Trans-Canada Air Lines when delivery of fifteen new airliners with turbo-prop power plants is completed.

DETROIT, Nov. 19 -- The Tilley brothers had the Army and police in a dizzy tizzy today. Here's why: In 1945 William Tilley of suburban Redford Township wanted to join the Army, but was too young. So he took the name of his dead brother, Robert, and enlisted.
CHICAGO, Nov. 19 (AP) -- Today's report on the livestock market here by the Department of Agriculture fellows:
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (UP) -- The Defense Department announced today a total of 126,726 United States battle casualties in Korea, an increase of 839 over last week's report.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 19 (UP) -- Civil defense directors from nineteen states today demanded government appropriations that would build the volunteer army into a "fourth co-partner in the United States Defense Department."

" Younger than Springtime" were the pretty fashions shown yesterday at the luncheon hour in the Cotillion Room of the Pierre Hotel. The apparel was presented by Best Co., which had gathered together about thirty fashions dedicated to the bride, her wedding and the weeks preceding the ceremony.

MONTCLAIR, N. J., Nov. 19 -- Mrs. Homer O. Lichtenwalter of Baltusrol was elected president of the Women's New Jersey Golf Association at the annual meeting today at the Montclair Golf Club. Mrs. Lichtenwalter succeeds Mrs. F. M. Hoffman of Plainfield, who headed the association for the past two years.

The treason trial of John David Provoo, the former Army sergeant who is accused of betraying his fellow Americans on Corregidor to the Japanese, became entangled yesterday in the intricacies of the Japanese language. An early adjournment was necessitated just as a former Japanese Army sergeant was being questioned about the execution of Capt. Burton C. Thomson, who was shot subsequent to a quarrel with Provoo.

CAIRO, Nov. 19 -- Premier Mohammed Naguib said today after a conversation with Sir James Robertson, administrative secretary of the Sudanese Government, that the general principles of the Sudanese settlement had been accepted by all sides but that details were under discussion.

SYDNEY, Australia, Thursday, Nov. 20 (AP) -- Ken McGregor, Australian champion, defeated Mervyn Rose, 6 -- 2, 0 -- 6, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 4, to enter the final round of the New South Wales men's singles tennis championship today.
SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Nov. 19 -- The Presidential candidates of two major parties, the National Union and Democratic party, withdrew their candidacies today.

CHICAGO, Nov. 19 -- The Government's suit against the du Pont interests was described today as an attack on expansion in industry, camouflaged by an anti-trust theory, in Federal District Court here as one of the big guns of the defense staff ripped into Federal charges of conspiracy and monopoly.
NEW HAVEN, Nov. 19 -- A campaign to raise $5,730,000 to enlarge the work of the Yale School of Forestry was announced here today by A. Whitney Griswold, president of Yale University.

We had a talk yesterday with Miss Pauline Murrah, who recently left her post as director of food and nutrition services for the American Red Cross to become the director and nutritionist of the National Dairy Council's Greater New York Program.

The Montauk Chamber of Commerce has leased additional space to double its quarters in the Corn Exchange Bank Building at 1 East Forty-second Street. The chamber now occupies most of the third floor and the personnel has been increased in order to handle the large number of inquiries, according to Alan A. Stevenson, the executive director.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- The Bureau of Labor Statistics today issued its new revised daily index of basic commodities traded on spot markets and organized exchanges. The index base represented by 100, has been changed from the average of commodity prices in 1939 to the average in the post-war years of 1947, 1948 and 1949.

TORONTO, Nov. 19 (Canadian Press) -- Canada again won the international jumping competition at the Royal Agricultural Winter Fair tonight and gained first place in the three-event, low-score competition.

MONTEREY, Calif., Nov. 19 (UP) -- Rear Admiral E. E. Herrmann, 56 years old, superintendent of the Naval Post-Graduate School here, was found dead in his office with a bullet in his head. A service revolver was found by his side. Navy officials listed the death as suicide.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- Though it has been more than one hundred and twenty years since a President of the United states has followed Jefferson's practice of counting his opinion as but one "vote" in a Cabinet meeting, public interest in the Cabinet of an incoming President still is livelier than in the identities of the leaders of the new Congress.

Paul Murray of New York has received the thirty-third fellowship of the Eugene F. Saxton Memorial Trust for the completion of the history of a Negro family in America. The announcement was made yesterday by Harper Brothers, who established the trust in memory of their chief literary editor, who for many years had encouraged writers of distinction.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- President Truman asserted tonight that anyone who interpreted the Republican election victory as a mandate to end programs for "social and economic progress is blind to history."

Cigarette sales at the retail level totaled more than $4,081,000,000 during 1951, an increase of about $211,000,000 over the preceding year, according to a survey released yesterday by the National Association of Tobacco Distributors, Inc. The dollar rise is due to increased consumer usage and to the 1 cent Federal excise tax imposed Nov. 1, 1951.

D. A. Schulte, Inc., retail tobacco chain, has completed more than 40 per cent of its store modernization program, with sales and gross profit in the modernized units already showing substantial gains, it was reported yesterday by N. C. Earl Jr., president.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- The Defense Production Administration today approved plans of Olin Industries, Inc., of East Alton, Ill., for the construction of $170,000,000 of facilities for the production of more than 110,000 tons of primary aluminum annually and the fabrication of products.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Nov 19 (AP) -- Jimmy Haslam, senior tackle and captain of the University of Tennessee football team, was declared ineligible today by Gen. Bob Neyland, Tennessee athletic director and head coach.

Member lines of the Trans-Atlantic Passenger Conference have agreed, at least temporarily, to a proposal of the Immigration and Naturalization Service that inspectors be sent abroad so they can examine crewmen of foreign passenger ships on the return trips to New York, it was learned yesterday.

Rudolph Halley, president of the City Council, has accepted an invitation from WJZ-TV to appear in a new program series entitled "Report to the People," which will be televised weekly beginning Wednesday from 8 to 8:15 P. M.

The last of three arbitration proceedings involving three marine affiliates of the Congress of Industrial Organizations ended yesterday as East and Gulf Coast radio officers were listed for a base pay increase of slightly more than 11 per cent.

A final canvass of votes in three Assembly districts and one Congressional district in Queens was completed yesterday and Board of Elections officials reported that the four Democratic candidates, who had led in the original tally, retained enough strength in the recount to win.
The public schools must counter charges that they are godless, irreligious or totalitarian, Dr. Lawrence A. Cremin of Teachers College, Columbia University, said yesterday.

The interregnum imposed by the American political system pending a change in Administrations from one party to another has inevitably produced some confusion and hesitation in the policies of the free world. This state of affairs will not be wholly eliminated until the new Administration has not only taken office but has also revealed its own policies under its own responsibility, which it cannot now share with the old Administration.

It is encouraging to find the expanded program of the Flight Safety Foundation receiving broad support. This activity, under the able direction of Jerome Lederer, has stimulated safety thinking and practice to a remarkable degree in both commercial and private flying, and its down-to-earth bulletins and case histories of experience have engendered lively interest also in the military air arms.
More bad news piled up yesterday for the seven American League clubs who so fervently hope to derail the Yankees in their bid for a fifth straight pennant next year.
