The first public distribution of common stock of the Duquesne Light Company, one of the nation's top-ranking public utility enterprises, will be made today by an investment banking syndicate headed by Kidder, Peabody Co. and White, Weld Co.

The revelations which have appeared in THE NEW YORK TIMES in recent days as a result of the State Crime Commission's current investigation have served to reaffirm my belief that the interest of the people of New York in their city government has been of such a nature in recent years as to encourage if not perpetuate the evils which are now so evident.

Police Commissioner George P. Monaghan, in a move to enlist the aid of women for the Police Athletic League, yesterday appointed Mrs. Charlotte Baruth a chairman of a women's committee to promote and assist the league.

A recommendation to the Board of Estimate that it approve a $4,275,000 addition to the Queensview Cooperative Housing project in Long Island City, Queens, to be known as Queensview North, was made yesterday by City Construction Coordinator Robert Moses.

A diamond and emerald necklace that the late Mrs. Henry Ford received from her inventor-husband at Christmas time in 1931 was auctioned yesterday for $98,500 at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue.

Anyone who wants to know how Sophocles' "Electra" should be acted is directed to the Mark Hellinger Theatre during the rest of this week. For the National Theatre of Greece has stopped by for a visit and, with Katina Paxinou in the leading part, it knows how to bring a venerable classic to majestic life.

A few days ago something new was learned about those tiny bits of electron magic known as "transistors." A new home television receiver, an automotive radio, an electric record player and other familiar domestic electric appliances had been successfully adapted to use transistors instead of the usual complement of radio tubes.

DOBBS FERRY, N. Y., Nov. 19 -- Spurred to renewed agitation by the molesting of a young girl here last Thursday, village residents circulated today a petition demanding that Westchester District Attorney George M. Fanelli investigate depredations here by escaped pupils of the near-by Dobbs Ferry Children's Village, a school for maladjusted boys from 10 to 18 years old.

Magazine selling crews are doing an excellent job in building good-will for themselves, their publications, and their subscription agencies by exemplary action while on the road, according to a report by Kenneth B. Willson, president of the National Better Business Bureau.

The most serious shortage in the musical life of Israel at present is not a lack of audiences but a lack of space for them to sit, it was asserted here yesterday by Marc Lavry, musical director of Kol-Zion Lagola, the Israeli shortwave broadcasting station in Jerusalem.
Plans for remodeling East Side properties were announced yesterday in connection with sales of the parcels.

NORMAN, Okla., Nov. 19 (AP) -- Oklahoma's bowl-hungry football team, expressing a desire to play in a post-season game, voted today not to accept a bid if it meant suspension from the Big Seven Conference.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 19 (AP) -- Connie Mack -- Mr. Baseball -- received birthday congratulations tonight from President Truman and Attorney General James P. McGranery. Mack will be 90 on Dec. 23.
Bullish forces remained in control of the stock market yesterday.
BOWIE, Md., Nov. 19 (AP) -- The rain came down today and brought the test of whether Larry S. MacPhail spent two million dollars for nothing building a new race track at Bowie.

HEADQUARTERS, Fifth Air Force, in Korea, Nov. 19 -- The dream of every private will come true for one here tomorrow. A four-star general will make a special trip to deliver a package personally to Pfc. N. G. Baldwin of the Marines, whose home is in Minneapolis.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- Roger L. Putnam, Economic Stabilization Administrator, said today he hoped to decide before this week-end whether the country's 350,000 soft coal miners should receive the full $1.90-a-day pay increase provided in a new contract.

HEADQUARTERS Fifth Air Force, in Korea, Nov. 19 -- The United States Air Force is in a position to follow any policy set by the Administration, Gen. Hoyt S. Vandenberg, Air Force Chief of Staff, said today. He made the statement at a press conference here when asked whether the Air Force could attack Communist air bases in Manchuria should such a policy be set in Washington.

Mrs. Sidney C. Borg, founder of the Big Sisters of the Jewish Board of Guardians, and a pioneer in social welfare work, particularly among adolescent girls, was the guest of honor last night at a dinner at the Statler Hotel marking the fortieth anniversary of the founding of the Big Sisters.

The splendid labor relations in the tugboat industry of this port were achieved despite the fact that in the management segment there are many "rugged individualists," James P. McAllister, president of the Foreign Commerce Club of New York, asserted last night.
RICHMOND, Va, Nov. 19 -- A bus company's regulation requiring segregated seating of Negro and white passengers was ruled invalid in interstate commerce by a Federal District Court judge here today.

THERE are two possible answers to the increased success of the bow and arrow deer hunters this year: either there are a lot of new converts to this ancient weapon, or the archers are showing a marked improvement in both stalking and accuracy.

LONDON, Nov. 19 -- A new system of voting, introduced last week by Clement Attlee and carried by the old guard leaders of the Labor party, has blocked Aneurin Bevan's first attempt to gain a voice in the party's policy-making body in the House of Commons.

Former Supreme Court Justice Aaron J. Levy was so free and easy with money that, although he earned about $132,000 in his early career as a lawyer, prior to his becoming a jurist, he "never had a nickel," according to a sworn statement he made to the State Crime Commission on Oct. 27.

No detailed account of the briefing of the President-elect at the White House and the Pentagon has been or will be made public. All the reports agree, however, that domestic questions were not on the agenda. The communique states that the talks between Mr. Truman and General Eisenhower concentrated on "the most important problems affecting our country in the field of international relations."

The Metropolitan Opera Association gave its first "Carmen" of the season last night in the world-famous opera house. This opera was restored to the Metropolitan repertory, from which it had been temporarily absent, last season, in a newly staged version by Tyrone Guthrie. This was again the version used last night.

Things looked much better for the New York Rangers last night, even if they failed to win their National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden. For Bill Cook's skaters engaged in a 2-to-2 tie with the Detroit Red Wings and, the way things have been going, a tie is indeed a welcome result for the local athletes.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., Nov. 19 -- A bond issue of $500,000,000 and increases in gasoline and Diesel fuel taxes were proposed today to a joint Senate-Assembly fact-finding committee to help underwrite a $3,500,000,000 highway construction program in California during a fifteen-year period.
BAR HARBOR, Me., Nov. 19 (AP) -- A step that may shed light on a big cancer problem -- how cancer cells wander off to start new cancers in the body -- was announced today.
Futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were somewhat irregular yesterday, and December closed 4 points lower than on Tuesday but other months were 6 to 20 points higher.
Bus drivers, who are among the worst offenders in "jumping" traffic signal lights, are virtually immune to summonses, top police officials readily conceded yesterday.

There will be two openings on Broadway this evening, George Axelrod's new comedy, "The Seven Year Itch," and the double bill of Moliere plays, "Amphitryon" and "Les Fourberies de Scapin" ("Scapin's Pranks").

PARIS, Nov. 19 -- Spain was admitted today as the sixty-sixth member of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization. The vote was 44 to 4, with seven abstentions. The action was taken speedily after delegates moved to proceed to a vote without debate.

An increase last week of 1,939,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end total supplies were 123,313,000 barrels, compared with 121,374,000 a week earlier and 120,644,000 a year ago.

Bolivia's nationalization of its tin mining industry was described as "confiscation" by Joseph C. Rovensky, chairman of Patino Mines and Enterprises Consolidated, Inc., in a letter to shareholders. He said the Bolivian Government for the last month has been in possession of the Patino tin mines in Bolivia and is reported to be engaged in operating them.

BERLIN, Nov. 19 -- East German authorities revoked today permission granted to an estimated total of 2,000 West Berliners to visit family graves at a cemetery outside the city, according to the West German news agency D. P. A.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- Secretary of State Dean Acheson declared today that United States immigration restrictions provoked resentment among the Government's allies and weakened neighbors "whom we need as strong partners."

Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the President-elect, told Senator Alexander Wiley of Wisconsin in an hour-long interview yesterday that he was in emphatic agreement with the principle that there should be no forcible repatriation of the prisoners of war held by United Nations forces in Korea.

A new drive against graft, embezzlement and similar crimes is under way in the Soviet Union. In recent weeks Pravda and other Kremlin publications have given their readers many examples of such wrongdoing -- of swindlers fleecing peasants, of factory managers padding their production figures, of officials stealing Government property, of favoritism and nepotism in public appointments, and the like.
Improved visibility and increased horsepower are offered in the 1953 Packard line of cars, introduced yesterday by the Packard Motor Car Company. The cars will go on public display here on Nov. 28.

The following excerpts are from testimony given yesterday before the State Crime Commission. Joseph M. Proskauer, chairman of the panel, presided, and the questions were asked by the commission's legal staff.

There appears to be some slight discrepancy between the legends of the lusty career of the Louisiana adventurer. James Bowie, designer of the knife that bears his name, and the story of him that is presented in "The Iron Mistress" on the Paramount's screen.

BOSTON, Nov. 19 -- The Republican party, which has maintained the State of Vermont as an unassailable bastion ever since John C. Fremont ran (unsuccessfully) for President in 1856, faces renewal of a prior claim to much of its "holdings" from the Iroquois tribe of Indians.

LONDON, Nov. 19 -- Prices and business continued to rise on stock markets today. British funds showed new gains. Industrial shares were higher despite tendency to react in late dealings. Dollar stocks rose by as much as four points on the firm advices from Wall Street.

The Board of Estimate voted down yesterday a move by Rudolph Halley, City Council President, to add $2,000,000 to the proposed 1953 capital budget for acquisition of strategic sites for public parking garages. The board also rejected a move by Manhattan Borough President Robert F. Wagner Jr. to increase the proposed budget by $1,780,000 to permit construction of a new Public School 60 in Queens.

Yesterday's drill for the football Giants at the Polo Grounds was devoted exclusively to offensive maneuvers, indicating that Coach Steve Owen, after observing last Sunday's dismal performance against the Green Bay Packers, feels that the attack finally has become more important than the defense.

The New York commodity markets continued generally lower yesterday with lead, tin, zinc, potatoes, coffee, wool and cocoa futures showing declines. Rubber and sugar closed mixed. Hides and vegetable oils were higher.

A meeting of the executive committee o fthe Brooklyn Democratic organization has been called for Monday to discuss the selection of a new state party chairman, Frank J. Sinnott, Kings County Democratic leader, announced yesterday.

Three expeditions this summer in the Southwest and Mexico have enlarged the insect and spider collections of the American Museum of Natural History by 119,000 specimens, the museum reported yesterday.
Raybestos-Manhattan, Inc., and its domestic subsidiaries had a net profit of $2,131,273 after all charges, including $3,660,000 taxes, the report for the first nine months disclosed yesterday.

SOUTH HADLEY, Mass., Nov. 19 -- Formation of the Industrial Associates for Women in Science has been authorized by the Board of Trustees of Mount Holyoke College, President Roswell Gray Ham announced today. The group is being established "to pioneer in the development of new forms of cooperation" between industry and a liberal arts college for women.

Lassie, the 5-year-old mother of at least seventeen collies, came home yesterday after a three-month transcontinental vacation or something in which she crossed the Appalachians, the Mississippi River, the Corn Belt, the Great Plains, the Rocky Mountains and the Western deserts. When asked how she did it she merely put on a look of mystery and said nothing.

Three Olympic champions were among the Winged Foot athletes honored last night at the New York A. C.'s twentieth annual all-sports dinner, attended by more than 1,000, in the club gymnasium. Athletes in seven sports were among the honored guests.

Theodore W. Kheel, impartial chairman of the private transit industry, urged the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., yesterday not to go through with plans for a strike Dec. 1 against eight private bus companies in the city.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- Price ceilings on all types of apparel are to be scrapped by Dec. 1, Tighe E. Woods, head of the Office of Price Stabilization, assured a Congressional committee here today.

The Red Cross announced yesterday that 983 pints of blood were collected Tuesday, with the highest amount of the day, 314 pints, donated by West Point cadets. The second highest amount, 292 pints, was received at the Long Island Agriculture Technical Institute at Farmingdale.

THERE are tragic overtones to the downfall of Nat Holman. Here was a man who had won the respect and admiration of all. He had become Mr. Basketball. Once regarded generally as the game's greatest player, he had gained similar acclaim as a coach. But now the slimy fingers of the fixing scandal have reached out and brushed against him.

American colleges and universities are in serious financial trouble. Unless immediate assistance is obtained from private sources, such as corporations, foundations or business, many institutions may be forced to lean heavily on the Federal Government. This could be the death-knell of the independent liberal arts college in this country.

J. Howard Denny has resigned as president of Franklin Simon Company, effective Jan. 31, it was announced yesterday by Albert M. Greenfield, chairman of the board of the City Stores Company, which controls Franklin Simon.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (UP) -- A rising demand for television sets and equipment for new television stations lifted employment in the communications equipment industry to a post-war high in August, the Bureau of Employment Security reported today.

Ned Irish, vice-president of Madison Square Garden, told Metropolitan basketball coaches and writers yesterday at a luncheon at Leone's that "By no means" would basketball be a minor sport at the Eighth Avenue arena.

DENVER, Nov. 19 (AP) -- Editors here for the thirty-third annual convention of Sigma Delta Chi, national journalistic fraternity, which opened today, expressed opinions that newspapers, radio and television had reached new highs in reporting the news.

At least one of the proposals made by Controller Joseph in the interest of economy -- namely, the elimination of the Department of Traffic and the transfer of its functions to the Police Department -- seems to us unwise. We are glad to note that the Mayor's views are in accordance with this position.

The Missouri-Kansas-Texas Railroad is sounding out its stockholders on the proposed capital modification plan approved by directors at a meeting held in St. Louis on Oct. 17. Under the plan, the dividend accumulations of $147 a share on the 7 per cent preferred stock would be eliminated.

Five multiple-parking violators, including Rosemary Murphy, the actress-daughter of Robert D. Murphy, United States Ambassador to Japan, were fined sums ranging from $60 to $249 yesterday in Traffic Court:
The appointment of Mrs. Clare Boothe Luce as treasurer of the $300,000 memorial fund campaign of the Overseas Press Club of America was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- Charles Preston Blanks, Director of Technical Cooperation for Ecuador, exhibited at a press conference here today swatches of hand-woven woolen cloth and a sports jacket that represents the Point Four modernization of an ancient Indian craft.
A pay increase is not as attractive as formerly for the reason that taxes take a proportionately larger bite out of the added money. The more the increase the greater the tax.
Leading retail executives got up early yesterday morning for a panel meeting with educators from the City College School of Business.
VIENNA, Nov. 19 -- Austria presented her case for a state treaty to the world today by means of a motion picture film entitled "1 April 2000."
Secretary of Defense Robert A. Lovett appealed here last night for a "calm and steady" defense program that would not be influenced by momentary shifts in Soviet propaganda.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 19 -- Four less-developed countries proposed today that the United Nations, the specialized agencies and member Governments of the international organization, take concrete steps for the first time to restore the role of private capital investment in the economic growth of underdeveloped countries.

Edward R. Bress has purchased the one-family dwelling at 88-42 201st Street, Hollis, Queens, from William M. Linder. The sale was negotiated by the Home Sales Agency as broker and title was insured by the Inter-County Title Guaranty and Mortgage Company.
MAYS LANDING, N. J., Nov. 19 -- A jury deliberated only thirty-five minutes here today before acquitting former Atlantic City Patrolman Jack Portock on conspiracy charges.

Elizabeth Gurley Flynn, Communist party national committee member, was cited twice yesterday by Federal Judge Edward Dimock for contempt for refusing to answer questions under cross-examination in the Communist conspiracy trial.
An interruption in the current business boom was predicted last night by Donald B. Woodward, vice president for research, the Mutual Life Insurance Company of New York.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (UP) -- Charles Oliphant, former chief counsel of the Internal Revenue Bureau, challenged House tax scandal investigators today to make public the details of the "dairy" they subpoenaed from the Justice Department.

PRINCETON, N. J., Nov. 19 -- Champion of the Big Three for the sixth successive year, Princeton will close its football season in Palmer Stadium Saturday against a Dartmouth team that has consistently given the Tiger trouble.

Al Parsells of Tallman, N. Y., captain of the Ramapo quartet for many seasons, has been raised to nine goals, according to the 1952-53 changes in handicaps disclosed yesterday by the Indoor Polo Association of America.
CHICAGO, Nov. 19 -- The Big Ten's representative in the Rose Bowl football game New Year's Day will be announced Monday after a poll of the conference athletic directors.

EDMONTON, Alberta, Nov. 19 (AP) -- The Scandinavian Airlines' plane Arild Viking took off at 6:25 P. M., mountain time (8:25 P. M. Eastern standard time) today on the second leg of its trail-blazing flight across the Arctic cap from the United States Pacific coast to Europe.
An interruption in the current business boom was predicted last night by Donald B. Woodward, vice president for research, the Mutual Life Insurance Company of New York.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (UP) -- Charles Oliphant, former chief counsel of the Internal Revenue Bureau, challenged House tax scandal investigators today to make public the details of the "dairy" they subpoenaed from the Justice Department.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 19 (AP) -- Willie Pep, former featherweight champion, advanced along the comeback trail tonight with a unanimous decision over Fabela Chavez of Hollywood, Calif. Each weighed 129 pounds.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- President Truman will hold his first press conference since Sept. 25 at 10:30 A. M. tomorrow. He was expected to discuss his conference yesterday with Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the President-elect, but not in any detail.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, the following principal changes for the week ended Nov. 12:

Police Inspector Cornelius J. Lyons, acting commander of the Sixth Division on Manhattan's East Side, submitted his application for retirement yesterday after a morning interview at Police Headquarters with Commissioner George P. Monaghan.

HANOI, Vietnam, Indo-china, Nov. 19 -- The Vietminh contingent that hit a withdrawing French column in the Red River Valley north of Phutho Monday went into battle after a series of night marches over torturous mountain trails from the direction of the Black River front. The movements of the pro-Communist force, had been well concealed although the French had indications a Vietminh countermove was in the offing.

An American edition of "Annapurna," by Maurice Herzog, leader of the 1950 French expedition to the Himalayas, has been scheduled for publication on Jan. 9 by Dutton. Mr. Herzog was one of two to reach the top of the 26,493-foot mountain in the Nepalese Himalayas that gives the book its title.

HARTFORD, Nov. 19 -- A committee that backed Senator William Benton for re-election reported today that it had spent $142,901 in the recent election campaign in Connecticut, incurring a deficit of $13.845.

ANDOVER, Mass., Nov. 19. -- The $1,200,000 memorial gymnasium at Phillips Academy was opened for the first official inspection today with newspapermen the principal guests. Erected in honor of the 144 alumni killed in World War II, the building rounds out an athletic layout that now must be ranked with the best in America.

NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 19 (AP) -- Reports reaching here today from Kabul, capital of Afghanistan, said that country had suspended temporarily oil exploitation in the provinces adjoining its touchy neighbor, the Soviet Union.
The Federal Bureau of Investigation entered last night the search for Thomas Luchese, known also as Three Finger Brown. He is wanted by the Federal Government in a denaturalization proceeding.

LONDON, Nov. 19 -- Randolph Churchill, son of Britain's Prime Minister, in a speech at Hove tonight, denounced Lord Beaverbrook, one of this country's most powerful newspaper proprietors, as a false friend of his father.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- Benjamin Platt Thomas, author of a single-volume biography of Abraham Lincoln, today presented the original manuscript to the Library of Congress at a luncheon held in the Whitall Pavilion of the Library.
The Chicago Sanitary District announced yesterday that it will receive bids Dec. 11 on $4,000,000 of bonds dated Dec. 1, 1952, due Jan. 1, 1972, and callable from 1954 to 1971.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Nov. 19 -- Despite reports that life had returned to normal at Macassar, the capital of Celebes, following Saturday's military coup there, the Indonesian political situation continued to deteriorate rapidly today.

Lawrence Chelsi, baritone, made his recital debut at Town Hall last evening. A native of Portland, Ore., Mr. Chelsi did graduate work at the University of California at Los Angeles, and continued his studies here at Columbia University, the Juilliard School and the American Theatre Wing.
Good taste, although it seems to be almost indefinable in words, is a paying proposition, Richard Bach said yesterday at the Home Fashions League luncheon in the Roosevelt Hotel.
CHICAGO, Nov. 19 (AP) -- Will Harridge, American League president, said today he would crack down hard next season on team managers who use abusive language in squabbles with umpires.

The City Planning Commission moved yesterday to rezone about 100 acres of Manhattan, including large parts of the fur and garment centers. Most of this property is unrestricted except for a few business designations. Under the new plan most of the area would be zoned for manufacturing.

From 6:30 until 8 o'clock tonight four Fifty-seventh Street stores will endeavor to make evening shopping easy and pleasant for young women who work all day. Store windows will be decorated with a uniform scheme of red, white and black.

Coach Lou Little directed the Columbia football team through an extensive workout on both offense and defense yesterday as the Lions continued to prepare for the season's finale Saturday against Brown at Baker Field.

Mischa Elman's playing at Carnegie Hall last night showed that he is determined to keep on maturing and refining his art as a violinist and musician. When one recalls that he can make his fiddle sing with unsurpassed richness of tone and that he can project music with blazing temperament, one must be impressed by the repose and restraint his performances achieved last night.

As the weekly casualty tolls from Korea come in, and as President-elect Eisenhower prepares to make his Korean visit, surely the time has come when the American and allied people are entitled to know the full facts and implications involved in the dispute over the treaty negotiations.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 19 -- A delegation from the United Nations Association of Japan presented to the United Nations today a petition, signed by 300,000 of its countrymen, asking their nation's admission to the world organization.

Staten Island, the last frontier of the city, is waging what appears to be a losing battle with urbanization. At the head of a small and vigorous army that is trying to preserve breathing space in the city is the Staten Island Museum.

CHICAGO, Nov. 20 -- The name of Charles E. Wilson, today named by President-elect Dwight D. Eisenhower as Secretary of Defense in his cabinet, came up in the trial of the du Pont anti-trust suit in which the General Motors Corporation is a defendant.

Five pharmaceutical corporations in which the stockholders include a total of 275 doctors and nine retail druggists agreed yesterday to dissolve their businesses immediately on order of Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein, who is pressing his state-wide inquiry into questionable stock deals involving a number of drug companies.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- The steel industry urged today an end of all steel allocations for civilian goods by next April 1, three months earlier than Government officials had planned.

The Slavenska-Franklin Ballet, with Alexandra Danilova as guest artist, will play a week's engagement at the Century Theatre beginning Dec. 8. In the company of twenty-five there will be, besides the stars. Lois Ellyn, Sally Seven, Shirley Weaver, Karel Williams, Marvin Krauter, Roland Vazquez, Roland Colton and Robert Morrow.

MOSCOW, Nov. 20 -- Izvestia, official Government newspaper, published today a ringing defense of Santa Clause, who it reported was threatened with persecution at the hands of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, and Senator Pat McCarran, Democrat of Nevada, for "activity directed against the security of the United States."

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 20 -- Secretary General Trygve Lie has told the United States delegation that the Charter of the United Nations ruled out any appearance by him before a Federal grand jury that had sent him an invitation to testify.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 (AP) -- The Office of Price Stabilization lowered price ceilings on controlled canned baby foods today by about one cent on sales of three-can units.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 (AP) -- Baseball Commissioner Ford Frick said today he was convinced the Pacific Coast would have major league ball some day, but he let it be known he did not want any changes executed in a "hit-and-run" manner.

The Overseas Press Club of America started its $300,000 drive for a memorial press center in New York yesterday at a reception given at the Time-Life Building, 9 Rockefeller Plaza. It was announced that $60,000, a good part of it contributed by newspaper men, had been realized at the outset.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- John Foster Dulles was chosen as the first Republican Secretary of State since Henry L. Stimson because he is regarded here as the most competent and experienced member of his party in the field of foreign affairs and because he negotiated the support of the only men who could have prevented his appointment.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- President Truman said today that he would confer about Dec. 1 with Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois, the unsuccessful Democratic candidate for President, on plans for reorganizing the Democratic party.

Dr. James B. Conant, president of Harvard University, said yesterday that the greatest threat to American security lay in the people's "unwillingness" to face up to the gravity of the tense international situation and the struggle with Russian communism.

The appointment of 59-year-old Douglas McKay as Secretary of the Interior by Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, President-elect, brings to national prominence a name that is virtually unknown outside of his native Oregon.

TOKYO, Friday, Nov. 21 -- The United Nations artillery broke up enemy attacks last night and early today on the ridges north of Kumhwa on the central Korean front. The attacks were the heaviest the Chinese Communists had launched against the Allied defense lines since the comparative lull descended on the battleground earlier this week.

The fifty-nine-family apartment house at 312 East 206th Street, the Bronx, bought recently by Walter L. Rothschild, has been resold to a client of Bernard I. Sandford, broker. The property is assessed at $195,000 and was sold subject to mortgages of about $180,000.

Fleet Admiral Ernest J. King, retired, who was Commander in Chief of the United States Fleet and Chief of Naval Operations from 1941 to 1945, had frequent disagreements with the late James Forrestal, Secetary of the Navy, and at times felt that Mr. Forrestal was "harassing" him.

VIENNA, Nov. 20 (AP) -- The Prague radio today broadcast the proceedings of the five-man court that is presiding over the trial of fourteen former party leaders. No Western correspondents are in Prague.

DENVER, Nov. 20 -- Two American newspaper publishers foresaw today the need for a more responsible press in a period of great world change and asserted that the continuation of democratic order rested with the press.

Women headed by Mrs. Irving H. Pardee are aiding in the arrangements for the performance of "I've Got Sixpence," a new play by John van Druten, on the night of Dec. 4 at the Ethel Barrymore Theatre, which will raise funds for the Rehearsal Club.

THE German officer corps, an archaic and "exotic warrior caste" largely recruited from the Junker aristocracy, was the only force in Germany with sufficient influence to have provided a civilizing restraint on Hitler's career of infamy. It did nothing of the kind. Why it did not and the actual steps in its own degradation to "moral and political bankruptcy" is the story Telford Taylor has told in his important history, "Sword and Swastika."*
William J. Ransom, in charge of sales in the elastic products division, has been made a vice president of Liberty Fabrics, Inc.

The Long Island Rail Road announced yesterday that a new form of on-train ticket is being tried out on the Port Washington Branch. The new ticket, it was said, can be sorted more efficiently than the old.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 20 -- Following is the text of the address by Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden of Britain today to the United Nations General Assembly's Political and Security Committee on the Indian resolution for a settlement of the Korean war:

Four teachers and one teacher-clerk were suspended by Superintendent of Schools William Jansen yesterday for refusing to answer questions about alleged Communist party membership. The queries were put to them in the course of Mr. Jansen's investigation into suspected Communist influence in the school system.
Boston, Mass., borrowed $5,000,000 yesterday on an issue of notes due on Oct. 9, 1953, at an interest cost of 1.18 per cent with premium of $119. The issue was bought by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc.

ALBANY, Nov. 20 -- The Court of Appeals ruled unanimously today that Max M. Schwartz may sue as individuals Tammany leader Carmine DeSapio and three other members of the 1950 New York City Board of Elections for their refusal to approve his designating petition as Democratic candidate for Assembly in the Eighteenth Assembly District of Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 (AP) -- Tony Accardo, alleged chief of the crime syndicate founded by Al Capone, was freed today of contempt of Congress charges. So was Joseph Scalleat of Hazleton, Pa., described by the Senate Crime Investigating Committee as a racketeer.
NORMAN, Okla., Nov. 20 (AP) -- Positive action by the University of Oklahoma board of regents today eliminated the Sooners from the National football bowl picture.

THERE won't be much left of the college football season after tomorrow. There will be scattered firing throughout the country for another week and then the collegians will hand over what remains of the campaign to the professionals, who will be at it until Christmas.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 20 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower and John Foster Dulles, his Secretary of State-Designate, are very skeptical about the chances of obtaining an armistice in Korea through any of the proposals now before the General Assembly.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 (AP) -- Charles Oliphant, former general counsel of the Bureau of Internal Revenue, who resigned during a House of Representatives investigation of tax scandals, spent more than two and a half hours before a Federal grand jury today. He told reporters:
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- Not a dissident note was heard today to the chorus of approval that greeted the first three Cabinet designations by Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the President-elect.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- A substantial reduction in funds available for the Mutual Security Program next year was forecast today by officials in charge of military and economic phases of the undertaking. They said this would mean scrapping what remained of the "timetable" for European rearmament.

VIENNA, Nov. 20 -- Rudolf Slansky, former Secretary General of the Czechoslovak Communist party, pleaded guilty in a Prague courtroom today to charges of high treason, espionage, betrayal of military secrets and sabotage.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, outlined today plans for the intensified Senatorial investigation of the administrative agencies of the Government he expected to result from his chairmanship of the Committee on Governmental Operations in the new Congress.

CHICAGO, Nov. 20 -- Liquidation of longs in both grains and soybeans was the order of the day, and prices turned reactionary in all pits soon after the fairly steady tone of the early trade. Continued weakness in December oats tended to unsettle other grains, the free selling emphasizing that outside buying demand is discouragingly thin.

Events today: Philharmonic - Symphony, Dimitri Mitropoulos conducting, Friedrich Gulda, pianist, Carnegie Hall, 2:30 o'clock; Ray Lev, pianist, Carnegie Hall, 8:30 o'clock; Regino Sainz de la Maza, guitarist, Town Hall, 8:30; Grace Gimbel, pianist, Carnegie Recital Hall, 8:30; free orchestral concert, Taft High School Auditorium, Sheridan Avenue and 172d Street, the Bronx, 8:30.

Better job opportunities and housing accommodations are convincing more and more Puerto Ricans that Horace Greeley's advice to go West is still sound. As a result, a smaller percentage of islanders are coming to New York and many are leaving the city to settle elsewhere.

TOLEDO, Ohio., Nov. 19 (UP) -- Officials of the First National Bank in near-by North Baltimore today made public the salary record of a man whom a Federal judge had refused to sentence for embezzlement on the ground he had been underpaid.

" Why not repatriate all Korean prisoners and get the thing over? What if the Reds do shoot them? They fought for them in the first place, didn't they? The lives of our boys are worth more than those characters -- etc."
WARSAW, Nov. 20 (AP) -- Boleslaw Bierut stepped down today from the Presidency of Poland under this Communist-ruled country's new constitution, and became its Premier.

SALEM, Ore., Nov. 20 -- Gov. Douglas McKay, who described natural resources development as his hobby of many years' standing, said today that the first intimation that he was being considered for a Cabinet post reached him by telephone three days ago.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Nov. 20 (AP) -- Twentieth Century Vikings, winging their American-built plane across the Arctic icecap, blazed a dramatic new era of commerce in a California-Europe flight that ended here tonight.

MIAMI, Nov. 20 (AP) -- Senator Richard M. Nixon, the Vice President-elect, and his family, ending a vacation of almost two weeks at Miami Beach, were delayed an hour and 33 minutes tonight when a plane developed engine trouble as it was about to take off for Washington.

It was with some surprise that I read your Nov. 15 editorial "Trieste: The Gordian Knot," which concluded: "If we are forced to take sides, we should choose Italy. If we can exercise pressure, it should be on Yugoslavia." Such advice can hardly contribute to a just, peaceful solution.

DETROIT, Nov. 20 -- Complete abatement of Federal taxes levied on United States corporate investments in Latin America to stimulate development of the southern hemisphere was suggested before the National Industrial Conference Board meeting here.

Referee Harry C. Kane yesterday dismissed a $193,732 action brought by the late James W. Gerard, former Ambassador to Germany, against the United States Steel Corporation and others on account of an alleged secret profit derived by Richard G. Auspitzer, one of three investors who formed a corporation to develop a tin plating process.

Many members of society attended the dinner dance held last night in the St. Regis Roof for the benefit of the Big Brothers, an organization devoted to providing individual guidance and vocational direction for young boys. Alonzo Potter is honorary chairman of the beneficiary.

West Coast Pipe Line Company of Dallas, Tex., announced yesterday that it has registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission an issue of $29,000,000 of twelve-year 6 per cent debentures intended for public offering with certain common stock in units consisting of one share of common stock for one $50 debenture.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- The relative economic and social status of Negroes in this country has improved in nearly every respect since 1940, according to a study made public today by the Senate subcommittee on Labor and Labor-Management Relations.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 20 -- Paul Jarrico, a screen writer fired by R. K. O. Radio Pictures in a controversy over communism, today suffered a setback in his $350,000 counter-damage suit against the company and Howard Hughes, its former head.

The loneliest television station in the country is probably WATV in Newark. Operating locally on Channel 13 the outlet has been using a transmitting site that makes it difficult and in many cases impossible to receive its programs in the metropolitan area.

Pan American World Airways announced yesterday it would have 1,000 seats available for military personnel in Europe wishing to fly home for Christmas. Service men and women with special thirty-day Christmas furloughs are expected to take advantage of the low winter tourist fare and be home between Dec. 1 and Christmas in "Operation Way Back Home."

ALBANY, Nov. 20 -- The State Health Department said today that cases of scarlet fever and other streptococcal throat infections were running higher than in any year since 1945, although the severity of the diseases has declined in recent years.

Judge Matthew T. Abruzzo in Brooklyn Federal Court yesterday authorized the Federal Bureau of Investigation to join in the search for Thomas Luchese, also known as Three Finger Brown. Attorney General James P. McGranery directed last Monday that a proceeding to denaturalize the 53-year-old ex-convict be started in Brooklyn.

Pie belongs to Thanksgiving as eggs to Easter, plum pudding to Christmas and egg nog to New Year's. Food manufacturers constantly come forward with new, sure-success techniques in pastry-making, but in our opinion the old way is the best way, and just about as easy as the innovations.

Tom Ewell and George Axelrod might begin the day by gratefully thanking each other. For Mr. Axelrod has written the sort of giddy part that a comedian can act uproariously, and Mr. Ewell has returned the favor with a superb performance.

ROME, Nov. 20 -- Luigi Silipo, Communist Deputy, resigned his seat in the Chamber of Deputies today because he had been converted to Roman Catholicism and felt that his new convictions forbade him to continue as a member of the Communist party.

Mayor Impellitteri's proposal to create a Transit Authority to operate the municipal transit lines was denounced yesterday by the Chamber of Commerce and Industry of New York as "a subterfuge to impose new taxes" to subsidize the present 10-cent fare.

Col. John Jacob Astor, chairman of The Times of London, appealed here yesterday for help in locating the next of kin of 28,000 American service men killed in action either in Britain or in operations based on Britain in World War II.

OTTAWA, Nov. 20 -- Signs of a lessening of the danger of an outbreak of war on a global scale have resulted from the steadfast resistance of the United Nations forces in Korea and the increased strengthening of the forces of freedom in Europe, the Canadian Government said today in its declaration of policy at the opening of the new session of Parliament.

Deferment until 1954 of consideration by the State Legislature of a new bill which would repeal existing laws and enact new uniform ones to cover every phase of business dealings was urged yesterday on Governor Dewey and legislative leaders by the Commerce and Industry Association of New York, Inc.

Turkey production and receipts this year indicate that holiday gobblers will be more plentiful and lower in price than last Thanksgiving. Current retail turkey prices are averaging 4 to 6 cents a pound below the pre-Thanksgiving levels of a year ago, the City Department of Markets reported yesterday.

The Pennsylvania Railroad emphatically denied yesterday in Brooklyn Federal Court that it had forced its subsidiary, the Long Island Rail Road, into a receivership so that it could sell the passenger portions of the bankrupt railroad to a state authority for $75,000,000.

Paddy De Marco, 23-year-old performer, whose stature as a contender for the lightweight title has suffered as a result of two consecutive defeats, will endeavor to regain some prestige tonight when he faces Henry Davis, Detroit-born Hawaiian, in a ten-rounder at Madison Square Garden.

CHICAGO, Nov. 20 (UP) -- The Chicago Black Hawks scored twice in 21 seconds of the third period tonight to defeat the Boston Bruins, 3 to 1, before 6,870 fans and take a game and a half lead in the National Hockey League race.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 (AP) -- Leslie L. Biffle, Secretary of the Senate, said today that he was thinking of retiring after forty- four years on Capitol Hill.

A three-story apartment house at 343-349 Park Avenue in Nutley, N. J., has been sold by Rose Peck to Theodore Morec. J. I. Kislak, Inc., was the broker. The building contains thirty-two suites in two to four rooms. There also are thirteen private garages on the property, which occupies a plot 114 by 209 feet.

Ninety per cent of the Spanish people are anti-Franco and would and could unite to effect a peaceful transition from Franco's dictatorship to a democratic government, Felix Gordon Ordas, President of the exiled Republican Government of Spain, declared yesterday.

SOUTHAMPTON, England, Nov. 20 (Reuters) -- A new Norwegian ship today careened down the launching ways here, smashed a jetty on which 150 men had been standing a minute before and wound up stuck in the mud on the far side of the River Itchen.

Showing in schools of the film "Duck and Cover," a movie intended to help train children in immediate self-protection in case of atomic attack, is "inadvisable," members of the Committee for the Study of War Tensions in Children held this week.

New York's most spirited and enterprising stage group, the Lighthouse Players, opened its season last night by presenting Benn W. Levy's fantasy, "Mrs. Moonlight." at the Lighthouse Theatre, 111 East Fifty-ninth Street.

A freakish cross-sea that struck the Cunard liner Mauretania Tuesday midnight off Nova Scotia at the height of a hurricane smashed in windows on the ship's high promenade deck and caused injuries to fifty passengers, it was disclosed on the arrival of the vessel here yesterday.

Some interesting marketing information from two different sources was released yesterday. Both are in agreement that what is commonly known as the middle class consists of more members numerically and percentage-wise, today than ever before in the country's history.

ALBANY, Nov. 20 -- The Appellate Division, Third Department, upheld today the dismissal of the perjury indictment returned against James A. Leary, Saratoga Republican leader, by the extraordinary grand jury investigating gambling and possible official corruption in Saratoga County. The ruling was 3 to 2.

Supreme Court Justice Thomas A. Aurelio yesterday denied an application of Commissioner of Investigation James H. Shells for a warrant of commitment for Victor Clemente, sewer contractor, because of his refusal to turn over his books and records to the Commissioner.

The Port of Los Angeles, largest on the Pacific Coast and gateway to the third-largest industrial area in the nation, is nearing the end of its most prosperous year in a decade and now plans to float a bond issue of $25,000,000 to $30,000,000 for further expansion.

BAD EMS, Germany, Nov. 20 -- A policy based on a combination of the West German Government's "European" program, and demands for the recognition of West Germany's claim to independence was presnted by the Free Democratic party today on the opening of its national congress here.

SCARSDALE, N. Y., Nov. 20 -- A long-standing public confusion concerning the two industrialists named Charles E. Wilson was highlighted today when Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, President-elect, named Charles Erwin Wilson of Detroit, president of the General Motors Corporation, as Secretary of Defense.

DETROIT, Nov. 20 -- Charles E. Wilson, president of General Motors Corporation, who was named Secretary of Defense by Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, President-elect, today told a press conference that General Eisenhower was "the only man in the world" from whom he would accept such an assignment.
The Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., reaffirmed yesterday its decision to strike against eight private bus companies here on Dec. 1 to obtain a forty-hour week.

Sinclair Weeks, finance chairman of the Republican National Committee, estimated yesterday on a visit to Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's headquarters at the Commodore Hotel that between $40,000,000 and $50,000,000 was spent in the recent campaign by the two major political parties.

Plastic fabrics, which have many qualities different from those of natural fiber materials, differ also in the manner in which they are sewn. Hints on that subject were given yesterday at a demonstration on using plastics in the home at the Monsanto Chemical Company showroom, 445 Park Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- A fourth-quarter export quota for secondary tin plate almost double that for the third quarter of this year was announced today by the Office of International Trade of the United States Department of Commerce. The quota for the closing months of 1952 was fixed at 124,000 short tons.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 20 -- Philadelphia will be the scene of what promises to be the largest Methodist gathering in the world next June when members of the church from many countries will join in a celebration of the 250th anniversary of the birth of John Wesley, founder of Methodism.

A tract of forty-nine acres of unimproved farmland on Northern Boulevard and Cedar Swamp Road in Old Brookville, L. I., has been purchased for investment by a customer of Pease Elliman, Inc., broker in the transaction. The Albador Corporation, controlled by Victor Emanuel, was the seller.

FABIUS, N. Y., Nov. 20 (AP) -- The only physician in this area is scheduled to appear Tuesday for a physical examination for the draft, and residents of the village said today they would ask that he be deferred.

Registering a new high for the seventh successive week, loans to business by New York banks advanced $58,000,000 during the week ended on Wednesday. The rise, which carried the current upward movement through its eleventh week, brought total expansion since the mid-year to $804,000,000 compared with $726,000,000 in the similar period last year.

To a long list of the names of German rightists -- including Doris, Remer, von Westarp, Richter, Grohe, Dietrich -- must now be added another, Wilhelm Schepmann, former leader of Hitler's Storm Troopers. This ex-general emerged from his post-war obscurity to appear as the winner, during the recent communal elections, of a seat on the county council of the rural community of Gifjorn in Lower Saxony.

With a local goal of $440,000, the New York chapter of the Arthritis and Rheumatism Foundation opened yesterday its fourth annual appeal for funds at a luncheon attended by 400 persons at the Commodore Hotel. It also marked the beginning of the national campaign that will attempt to raise $5,000,000.

There was an upswing in October in distress conveyances of Manhattan real estate, according to the monthly survey of the Real Estate Board of New York. There were eight conveyances on total liens of $175,388, as compared to two with $158,676 liens, in the same month in 1951 and fourteen involving liens of $964,233 during October, 1950.

An ingenious and spine-tingling exhibition opened yesterday in the Print Galleries of the Metropolitan Museum. Entitled "Bresdin and Other Masters of the Weird," the show is drawn from the museum's own collection and centers around the French nineteenth -century printmaker, Rodolphe Bresdin, an eccentric and enigmatic man who was admired during his lifetime by Victor Hugo, Baudelaire, Courbet as well as by his own pupil, Odilon Redon.

District Attorney Frank S. Hogan said yesterday his office was interested in "five or six matters" that came up in the public hearings of the State Crime Commission that ended on Wednesday. He said they included alleged sale of judgeships and alleged offers of sales of judgeships; the hearing phase that dealt with activities of Thomas (Three Finger Brown) Luchese, underworld figure, and possibly perjury by hearing witnesses.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Nov. 20 -- Following three meetings between President Sukarno and Premier Wilopo during the last twenty-four hours, informed political sources said today that there were hopes of finding a compromise solution for Indonesia's present military troubles.

TRENTON, Nov. 20 -- Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll announced today he would recall the 1952 Legislature in special session in the first week of December. He will request legislative action to reapportion the sixty Assembly seats among counties in accordance with the 1950 county population.

With the completion of 120 games, contested in fifteen rounds, the women's world's chess championship challengers' tournament. which was begun in Moscow on Oct. 22, was concluded last night with a reception and dance held at the Soviet Army Officers Club, according to a report received through Soviet news sources.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- In becoming Secretary of Defense, Charles E. Wilson of General Motors not only will take control of the largest single business in the world but also bids to become in the phrase of a defense official of this Administration, "the deputy commander in chief."

In your issue of Nov. 9 an Associated Press story was published concerning the presentation of a sword to General Van Fleet, used by a Turkish officer Nov. 7, 1876, during the siege of Plevna, a Russian town held by the Turks.

Taken at its face value, the statement of Dr. Julia J. Henderson, director of the Social Welfare Division of the United Nations, that the gap between rich and poor nations has widened could be the ground for some considerable pessimism. It could even be interpreted as indicating that our efforts in the struggle for human betterment had been wasted.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Nov 20 -- Observers here noted today that almost all of the defendants in the Prague trial, as well as a high proportion of the several thousand others who have been arrested, dismissed or demoted during the prolonged purge in Czechoslovakia were Jewish.
ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 20 -- E. Robert Anderson of Rochester was elected president today of the American Bottlers of Carbonated Beverages succeeding Alvin G. Deaman of Nashville, Tenn.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 20 (AP) -- The New York Knickerbockers led all the way but had to fight off a last-minute rally by the Indianapolis Olympians to gain a 72-67 National Basketball Association victory tonight.

BERLIN, Nov. 20 -- East Germany has embarked on an intensive campaign to weed out opposition elements from its universities, according to a report issued today by United States officials here. To date more than 300 students have been jailed and many more expelled, the report added.

The Federal grand jury that has been investigating subversive activities in the New York area for the last eighteen months was discharged yesterday by Federal Judge Edward Weinfeld because its legal existence had expired. The panel indicated its work had not been completed and expressed the hope that another jury would be chosen soon.

A new regulation designed to give added protection to residents of New York State who buy insurance when they purchase an automobile, furniture or other personal property under installment or deferred payment plans was announced yesterday by Superintendent of Insurance Alfred J. Bohlinger.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 (UP) -- The Republicans, when they take over in January, will know in which direction they are going.

A $1,025,000 negligence suit was filed yesterday in Brooklyn Supreme Court against the city in the fatal shooting last March 8 of Arnold Schuster, the Brooklyn salesman who led the police to bank robber Willie Sutton.

Stamp collectors visiting the three-day National Postage Stamp show, opening today in the Seventy-first Regiment Armory, can obtain the new Red Cross stamp by donating a pint of blood for the Armed Forces.

Edwin M. Otterbourg, president of the New York County Lawyers Association, urged the organization's 8,000 members last night to work for a revision of the laws of libel to give additional protection to victims of "smear" attacks who now have no practical recourse to the courts.

The bullishness that set in in the stock market this week when General Eisenhower and President Truman met in Washington, apparently has not had any marked influence on seat prices on the New York Stock Exchange. Arrangements were made yesterday for the transfer of a seat at $42,000, or $2,000 less than was paid in the last previous sale on Nov. 10, at $44,000.

A foreign economic policy for the United States, based on "enlightened self-interest" and carried out with the fullest reliance on free enterprise, along with prompt action to encourage increased imports in the interest of expanded free world production and trade, was recommended yesterday by a major business group.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower will make his trip to Korea in complete secrecy and with a thorough news "blackout" in force. Robert A. Lovett, Secretary of Defense, announced today a rigid set of rules designed to protect the President-elect's security.

CAIRO, Nov. 20 -- Sir Ralph Stevenson, British Ambassador, conferred with Premier Mohammed Naguib for two hours today and gave him the provisional British answer to the Egyptian note of Nov. 2 containing a detailed Egyptian program for settlement of the Sudan question.

By way of demonstrating that baseball had not yet run out of surprises for the year, the Baseball Writers Association of America announced yesterday that the National League's most valuable player award for 1952 had been voted to Henry (Hank) Sauer, 33-year-old slugging outfielder of the fifth-place Cubs.

John Foster Dulles would have appeared to be flying in the face of fate if he had never achieved the role of Secretary of State. From childhood to the announcement yesterday by Gem Dwight D. Eisenhower, President-elect, his life was a steady preparation for the position of chief diplomat of his country.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- The State Department has rejected "categorically" another series of charges by Czechoslovakia that the United States is carrying on "aggressive and hostile activities" against the Prague regime.
LONDON, Nov. 20 -- This capital received the news that Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, President-elect, had chosen John Foster Dulles to be his Secretary of State with restrained enthusiasm.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 20 -- Civil defense officials from potential target cities in twenty-two states decided today to form a national association dedicated to the task of overcoming public indifference toward the problems of protecting civilian communities from air attack.

The premiere of 'Pass, Lion, Pass," a twelve-minute sound film depicting high spots in the varsity careers of Sid Luckman, Paul Governali, Gene Rossides and Mitch Price, made an attractive dessert at Columbia's final football press luncheon of the 1952 season yesterday.

Pierre La Mure and Arthur Lesser are at loggerheads. The imbroglio stems from the world premiere on Dec. 18 in Los Angeles of "Moulin Rouge," the play Mr. La Mure adapted from his amazingly successful novel of the same name.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- The question of the disposal of Government files came up today in President Truman's news conference. There had been indications recently that this would be a lively issue for many months as some Republicans were eagerly preparing to rake over two decades of Democratic rule.
Futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed barely steady yesterday, 7 to 32 points net lower than on Wednesday, led by weakness in the old December.

PARIS, Nov. 20 -- The next general conference of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization, scheduled for 1954. will be held in Montevideo, Uruguay, delegates to the conference new being held here decided today.

Three weeks ago the City Planning Commission turned out some excellent suggestions on the transit problem. The commission pointed out that if all the proposals for improving the subway system, including more and better equipment, were adopted, the cost would be $1,500,000,000. Even in these times this is not pocket money.

HANOI, Vietram, Indo-China, Nov. 20 (AP) -- Vietminh forces attacked French defenses south of the Black River on an eighteen- mile front today. The French estimated 6,000 of the Communist-fed rebels took part in the attack.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- When Charles E. Wilson, the president of General Motors Corporation, becomes the Secretary of Defense in the Cabinet of President Eisenhower he will be expected to work at least some of the miracles of production in government that his company has achieved in private industry. This plainly is the hope that led to his appointment.

More than two hundred yachtsmen from far and near attended the so-called Cruise Dinner of the New York Yacht Club, which was held last night in the clubhouse, 37 West Forty-fourth Street. It is the annual gathering at which the prizes won in the racing over the year are distributed.

The forward movement in the stock market was interrupted yesterday, but without serious consequences. In fact, more issues managed to end higher than showed losses, yet, the composite rate dipped 0.50 point as a result of a leveling down in some of the important components of THE NEW YORK TIMES index.

MOSCOW, Nov. 20 -- The official Soviet newspaper Pravda, in its first reference to the United States hydrogen bomb, today ridiculed those who think that "hydrogen blackmail will be more successful than atomic blackmail."

HARTFORD, Nov. 20 -- The Eisenhower-for-President Committee in Connecticut reported to the Secretary of State today that it spent $113,371 to help win this state's eight electoral votes for Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower in the election.

THE deer season in the central and western New York counties will open on Monday, and according to most reports these animals are plentiful almost to the point of abundance in many sections, although the buck-doe ratio is still heavily in favor of the latter.

MADRID, Nov. 20 -- The election of Spain to the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization was hailed by the Spanish press today not only as the second "major diplomatic success" of the Franco regime in a week, but as a victory over the Socialist International which at its Milan congress last month had opposed that move.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 (AP) -- Abram Flaxer, president of the United Public Workers Union, which a Senate committee called Communist-dominated, was indicted for a second time today on contempt of Congress charges.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 19 -- The Peronista press rendered unlimited praise today to a former United States Ambassador. The enconiums were heaped upon Stanton Griffis as a result of selected excerpts from his book "Lying in State," which is to go on sale tomorrow.

Olympic stars and National A. A. U. champions are slated to be among the competitors when the twenty-first annual Columbus Council, Knights of Columbus, track and field meet is staged Saturday night, Jan. 3, at the 106th Regiment Armory in Brooklyn.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 20 -- Federal District Judge J. Skelly Wright today postponed until Dec. 15 a hearing on an injunction sought by Eli Lilly Co. against Schwegmann Brothers giant super market to prevent the sale of Lilly drugs at lower than Fair Trade prices.

The current investigation of corruption in government by the New York State Crime Commision is an example of the American people's "growing moral indignation" toward dishonesty on the part of public officials, Dr. Henry M. Wriston, president of Brown University, declared here yesterday.

The position of the free world on Korea has been further consolidated as a result of two new developments. One is President-Elect Eisenhower's statement reiterating his complete accord with the principles of the United Nations and re-emphasizing his agreement that there shall be no forcible "repatriation" of prisoners of war.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 (AP) -- Dr. Vannevar Bush praised private research foundations today as leading the United States toward world supremacy in fundamental science.

Two new films will open today at first-run theatres. "Horizon West." a Universal-International Technicolor Western drama with Robert Ryan, Julia Adams and Rock Hudson, is at the Palace. Budd Boetticher directed and Albert J. Cohen produced from a story and script by Louis Stevens.

There are few who would have denied to Benedetto Croce the right to be called the greatest Italian philosopher since Giovanni Battista Vico. Many would say that he was the greatest of all philosophers of the twentieth century. Like Vico, Giordano Bruno and Campanella, he was a product of Southern Italy -- a Neapolitan.

Thirteen hundred employes of the Safeway Stores in the metropolitan area will now work a forty-hour week as a result of a settlement reached yesterday between the company and Local 474. Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Union, C. I. O.

Charles Erwin Wilson, president of General Motors Corporation, who has been named as the next Secretary of Defense by Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, President-elect, has been associated actively with defense programs since World War I when he supervised the design of radio generators for the Army and Navy.
TOKYO, Friday, Nov. 21 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,440, for the twenty-four hours ended 6 A. M., Friday, Korea time:

LONDON, Nov. 20 (AP) -- Prime Minister Churchill said today that Britain and the United States should exchange hydrogen and atom bomb information after Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the President-elect, takes office in January.

Futures on the New York commodity markets closed irregular yesterday with most items fairly inactive. Rubber, tin, cocoa, potatoes and coffee were higher and wool and sugar were mixed. Hides, lead, zinc, cottonseed oil and soybean oil ended the day lower.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 20 -- Over South Africa's protests, a majority of United Nations members voted today to set up a three-man commission to look into the race-segregation policies of the Government of Prime Minister Daniel F. Malan.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 (AP) -- Clark Griffith turned 83 today and kept his sights set on the future. His goal: another championship for his Senators.

Proper "engineering" of textiles containing the new wonder fibers is necessary to insure consumer satisfaction, Dr. P. M. Walters of E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., warned last night. The mere presence of the new fibers, he said, whether they constitute 5 per cent or 100 per cent of the fabric, does not necessarily insure a good product.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Nov. 20 -- A five-year plan to establish 300 new agricultural settlements and to double Israel's water resources was outlined today by Finance Minister Levi Eshkol in his capacity as head of the Jewish Agency's settlement department.
Herb Dickenson, 21-year-old left wing who injured his right eye two weeks ago, will be lost to the Rangers for the remainder of the season, Manager Frank Boucher announced yesterday.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Nov. 20 -- The rounding up and, if necessary, the detention of leaders of the non-white defiance of South Africa's segregation laws was called for today by a delegation of twelve representing all the municipalities in South Africa.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 (UP) -- Russia seems to have adopted the old American custom of booing the umpire, a Senate subcommittee staff reported today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- Soviet propaganda was described today as a successful combination of force and persuasion in a study for the Subcommittee on Overseas Information Programs of the United States, a unit of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee headed by Senator J. William Fulbright, Democrat of Arkansas.
CHICAGO, Nov. 20 (AP) -- Today's report on the livestock market here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

Melissa Hayden gave her first New York performance of the title role of "Firebird" last night with the New York City Ballet at the City Center, and a stunning performance it proved to be. Though the role was created by George Balanchine for Maria Tallchief who has danced it exclusively heretofore, Miss Hayden was in no sense "following" her.

General Eisenhower begins his Cabinet building early by filling the important posts of Secretary of State, Secretary of Defense and Secretary of the Interior. The country will welcome these appointments as evidence that he is fully aware of the urgency and complexity of the issues that await decision, at home and abroad.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 (AP) -- The Federal Communications Commission today authorized fourteen new television stations. They will be as follows: Galveston, Tex., two stations; Colorado Springs, Colo.; Decatur and Belleville, Ill.; Sioux City, Iowa; Jackson, Battle Creek and Flint, Mich.; Greensboro, N.C.; Lima, Ohio; Johnstown, Pa.; Sioux Falls, S.D.; and Henderson, Ky., one each.

Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the President-elect, announced yesterday his selections for three of the nine places in the Cabinet that will take office with him on Jan. 20. All three promptly announced their acceptance.
Herb Dickenson, 21-year-old left wing who injured his right eye two weeks ago, will be lost to the Rangers for the remainder of the season, Manager Frank Boucher announced yesterday.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Nov. 20 -- The rounding up and, if necessary, the detention of leaders of the non-white defiance of South Africa's segregation laws was called for today by a delegation of twelve representing all the municipalities in South Africa.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 (UP) -- Russia seems to have adopted the old American custom of booing the umpire, a Senate subcommittee staff reported today.

It can no longer come under the heading of news this morning that the Madeleine Renaud-Jean-Louis Barrault acting troupe from France is one of the finest that any student of the theatre, regardless of the condition of his French, could care to see.

The absence of a clear and positive philosophy is the great weakness of the Western world in its fight against communist ideology, according to Dr. Oliver C. Carmichael, president of the Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching.
TORONTO, Nov. 20 (AP) -- Democrat, the "old man" of the United States jumping team, tonight won the international team fault-and-out stake at the Royal Agricultural Winter Fair.

This country will take an increasing supply of raw materials from foreign nations only if prices are in line and investment conditions abroad are advantageous, Dr. Edward S. Mason, dean of Harvard University Graduate School of Public Administration, declared yesterday.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 20 -- Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden gave Britain's strong support today to the principles, purpose and most of the details of India's formula for ending the Korean war.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- President Truman expressed his gratification today over Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's acceptance of the principle that there should be no forcible repatriation of prisoners of war held by the United Nations in Korea.

Sales of the Superior Oil Company, California rose to $78,046,162 in the fiscal year ended Aug. 31 from $73,129,076 the year before, but earnings declined under heavier operating and exploration costs, W. M. Keck, president, reported yesterday.

Ten years ago a young man arrived from France early one morning and that same day found employment, despite his lack of knowledge of English, in the beauty salon of one of the large Fifth Avenue department stores. Yesterday this enterprising young man, known as Michel of Paris, showed the press his own new salon at 11 West Fifty-sixth Street, as well as his newest coiffures.

Bertrand Russell, British philosopher who won the 1950 Nobel Prize for Literature, is now working on six short stories that will comprise his first book for fiction. Tentatively titled "Satan in the Suburbs," the book is scheduled for publication next July by Simon Schuster, three months after the author's eighty-first birthday. The publisher meanwhile has scheduled for January his newest work, "The Impact of Science on Society."

A four-story and basement hotel, once known as the Bedford Hotel, at 1138-1140-1142 Pacific Street in the Bedford Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn was ordered vacated and closed last night by Fire Commissioner Jacob Grumet. The Commissioner cited "conditions perilous, to life in case of fire."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- All members of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States will be polled on endorsing a pay-as-you-go plan to provide basic Social Security for all retired aged.

It is a hopeful sign when industrial leaders express the belief that management must rely more upon its own initiative than upon the law to deal successfully with its labor problems. If the industry executives on the Business Advisory Council, which advises the Secretary of Commerce, adhere to this view as expressed at their recent meeting, we shall have less litigation of labor disputes -- and fewer disputes.

BOWIE, Md., Nov. 20 (AP) -- The footing still is squishy on Bowie's new racing strip, but the Maryland Racing Commission and the jockeys today gave their go-ahead for the track to start running again Saturday.
Anent Elmer Davis' criticism of your use of the term President-Elect with Mr. Eisenhower's name, who, pray, elected Mr. Davis to write his own definitions for THE NEW YORK TIMES?

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 20 -- A draft resolution consolidating proposals seeking to expedite study and action on means of financing economic development of underdeveloped countries was approved today by the United Nations Economic and Financial Committee.

Leo Kossove bought for investment from Alexander Hirsch the fourteen - story and penthouse apartment building on let 38 by 100 feet at 8 and 11 East Seventy-ninth Street, between Fifth and Madison Avenues, in a deal negotiated by L. V. Hoffman Co., brokers.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- The Federal Reserve Board reported today that department store sales in the week ended Nov. 15 were unchanged from the corresponding week of 1951. The following lists percentage changes from like periods of last year:

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 20 -- About sixty staff dismissals at the United Nations will take effect Jan. 31, it was learned today. Many of the Americans involved fear that the recurrent criticism of the secretariat by various investigating bodies will inevitably lead to their being dubbed Communists.

Upholstery and drapery fabric manufacturers are enjoying satisfactory sales and this situation will continue into 1953. R. C. Pohlers, vice president of the Simmons Company and general manager of its Simtex division, said yesterday. He spoke at the annual meeting of the Upholstery and Drapery Fabric Manufacturers Association in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

MEXICO CITY, Nov. 20 (AP) -- Giovanni Bracco of Italy gunned his Ferrari into the sports car division lead after three laps of the Pan-American road race today as the first-day pace-setter, France's Jean Behra, smashed up on a treacherous curve fifty miles from Puebla.
Letters and calls from readers suggesting that the freezing of nylon stockings in the refrigerator ice trays will prolong the life of the stocking has prompted a little research on the subject.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- During the week ended Nov. 19, member bank reserves increased $291,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
Ceiling price adjustments for manufacturers of metal cans were authorized yesterday by the Office of Prize Stabilization following a survey of industry earnings by the Agency.

The defense continued to hammer away at testimony given by Harry Gross, convicted bookmaker, as the departmental trial of thirty suspended policemen accused of having accepted Gross' graft resumed yesterday after a four-day postponement.

SYDNEY, Saturday, Nov. 22 (AP) -- Maureen Connolly, 18-year-old United States champion from San Diego, Calif., won the New South Wales women's tennis singles championship today by beating Julie Sampson of San Marino, Calif., 6 -- 3, 6 -- 2, in the all-American final.

DAYTON, Ohio, Nov. 21 (AP) -Two members of the United Electrical Workers Union, Independent, were jailed today shortly after they had been indicted on charges of swearing falsely they had not been Communists.

John Foster Dulles, who had been named for Secretary of State the day before, called on Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the President-elect, again yesterday and then informed reporters that he had requested J. Edgar Hoover, director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, to make a thorough check of his own record and report its findings to the President-elect.

His fiftieth anniversary as a member of the Roman Catholic Society of Jesus will be celebrated by the Rev. John M. Jacobs with a thanksgiving mass at 10 A. M. tomorrow at the Church of St. Francis Xavier, 30 West Sixteenth Street.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (AP) -- A number of additional Federal judgeships was recommended today by the Judicial Conference of the United States. The conference is made up of Chief Justice Fred M. Vinson and the chief judges of each of the eleven Federal Circuit Courts.
ASUNCION, Paraguay, Nov. 20 -- Inflation and trade difficulties have hit Paraguay even harder than most countries. Argentina's economic troubles are strongly reflected in this country.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Nov. 21 -- Half of the 300,000 Jews in Hungary and Rumania want to migrate to Israel, the Zionist General Council in Jerusalem was told today by Itzhak Raphael, head of the Jewish Agency for Palestine's Immigration Department.

PARIS, Nov. 21 -- By a small majority the general conference of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization voted today a compromise budget of $18,000,000 for the next two years.

CHICAGO, Nov. 21 (UP) -- The Krebiozen Research Foundation Inc., formerly headed by Dr. Andrew C. Ivy, released today a report on the use of krebiozen, controversial drug, in approximately 500 cancer cases. It said that the report was compiled by Dr. Ivy, who sponsored research on the drug.

ALBANY, Nov. 21 -- The Board of Regents today appointed a temporary advisory committee to cooperate with the State Education Department in developing a more widespread and intensive program for integrating the book resources of the state.

BUFFALO, Nov. 21 -- Halvard Lange, Minister for Foreign Affairs of Norway, tonight expressed doubt that a federal union of Western democracies would be attained in the near future. Mr. Lange spoke before 150 delegates to the second annual congress of the Atlantic Union Committee meeting here.
Herbert Brownell Jr. played an important role as political adviser and strategist in winning both the Republican Presidential nomination and the election for Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower.

The reputation that had preceded Regino de la Maza, the Spanish guitarist who made his local debut last night in Town Hall, did not collapse on actual test. Mr. de la Maza proved himself to be an instrumental artist in the great tradition established by Andres Segovia.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Nov. 21 -Premier Wilopo said today the Government still was continuing efforts to reach a satisfactory settlement of the armed forces issue which has split the Indonesian Army. He said prospects for a peaceful solution were good.

NEWARK, Nov. 21 -- Alone in a rowboat for the first time, 10-year-old Walter L. McCabe 3d, drifted helplessly in the storm-tossed waters of Newark Bay throughout last night and clung to the craft when it capsized until a receding tide enabled him to wade to land.
