PARIS, Nov. 21 -- Premier Antoine Pinay, after threatening to resign if he were not upheld, won temporary victory in the National Assembly today by a vote of 304 to 214. The favorable action was accomplished through the abstention of the Gaullist group whose spokesman served notice on M. Pinay the group would join the Opposition upon any major vote.
Things began looking up for the turkey dinner the other day when the Italian liner Vulcania arrived here with 800 tons of chestnuts, the largest single shipment since the end of the Second World War.

TOKYO, Saturday, Nov. 22 -Chinese Communist troops struck lightly at the ridges on the central Korean front north of Kumhwa today. But they failed to renew their powerful attacks that were beaten off yesterday after a nightlong battle by United Nations artillery and the hard fighting. Republic of Korea infantrymen.

DANBURY, Conn., Nov. 21 -- An attempt to reorganize the administration of Danbury Hospital, the scene of bitter controversy over the dismissal of two staff physicians, was started here today at the first meeting of the newly constituted board of trustees.

George Meany, 58-year-old former plumber and the present secretary-treasurer of the American Federation of Labor, is expected to succeed William Green as president of the 8,000,000-member organization.
Two more Cabinet selections were announced yesterday by Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the President-elect, along with his choice for the new Director for Mutual Security.

The Los Angeles Memorial Coliseum will be crammed to its capacity of approximately 101,500 and millions will gather around television sets today when Southern California and U. C. L. A. do battle for the Pacific Coast Conference championship and the assignment as host team in the Rose Bowl football game at Pasadena on New Year's Day.

LONDON, Nov. 21 -- Marshal Konstantin Rokossovsky, one of Russia's most famous World War II commanders, who as Defense Minister controls Poland's armed forces, today got a new high government post as one of Poland's eight Vice Premiers.

BONN, Germany, Nov. 21 -- The mysterious death of an elderly agitator for the Saar's return to Germany from either heart disease or from a beating by four unidentified men in Saarcrucken last night, has aroused deep anger in this country and the hopes of an amicable settlement of the Saar's future by France and West Germany was a heavy blow.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (UP) -- The Government decided today to drop its indictment of Ray Brennan, a reporter for The Chicago Sun-Times, and try to get another giving more details of his alleged impersonation of an employe of the Senate Crime Investigating Committee.

Despite the hopeful signs resulting from the use of the new isonicotinic acid compounds in the treatment of pulmonary tuberculosis, many newer drugs are being tested, one of the early experimenters in the new compounds declared yesterday.

When the parents of a premature baby learn that their child has lost its sight as a result of retrolental fibroplasia, a condition sometimes affecting infants born "before their time," the news is likely to come as "the final blow" in a series of difficulties that may have begun even before the child was born.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 21 -A revival by Mayor Elmer E. Robinson of plans for putting new bridges or other types of crossings over San Francisco Bay led the Bay Area Council today to declare that two new crossings were financially feasible.
M. Stuart Roesler and Richard B. Schneider have been elected vice presidents of the Empire Trust Company, according to Henry C. Brunie, president.

Futures prices were generally lower on the New York commodity exchanges, with the truce developments at the United Nations influencing the market. Hides, lead, rubber, tin, potatoes, coffee and cottonseed oil closed lower. Zinc, wool and sugar were higher and cocoa and soybean oil futures closed mixed.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., Nov. 21 -- Before Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, President-elect, announced his latest Cabinet appointments, including that of Herbert Brownell Jr. of New York as Attorney General, he had telephoned Gov. Earl Warren of California, it developed today at the Governor's regular press conference.
LONDON, Nov. 21 (AP) -- The text of a Laborite bill to set up a "watch dog" press council over British newspapers and agencies was published today.

LONDON, Nov. 21 -- Faces fell in London this week when Gen. Mohammed Naguib, the Egyptian Premier, declared that his proposals on the future of the Anglo-Egyptian Sudan were the "last word." However, as there are to be further talks with the general next week, his remark is not being taken too literally.
BALTIMORE, Nov. 21 (AP) -- Sale of Pimlico, home of the famous Preakness and one of the nation's tradition saturated race tracks, was announced today.

COLORADO SPRINGS, Nov. 21 (AP) -- Cpl. Stephen B. Flerchinger of Moscow, Idaho, a 21-year-old Camp Carson amateur boxer, collapsed and died during the second round of a scheduled three-round bout last night at the camp field house.

BOSTON, Nov. 21 -- The controversial question involving the coordination of programs by American Jewish national agencies in the field of Jewish community relations to prevent duplication came in for differences of opinion here today.

The two-week extension of the New York run of the Madeleine Renaud-Jean-Louis Barrault Company, more or less expected, is now certain. S. Hurok, sponsor of the French troupe, announced yesterday that it would remain at the Ziegfeld Theatre through Dec. 20, instead of closing on Dec. 6 as originally scheduled.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 21 -- Only one member of the Soviet bloc. Poland, spoke today in opposition to an appropriation of $300,000 for the United Nations Korean service medals and ribbons, which were originally authorized by the General Assembly in December, 1950.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 21 (AP) -- A warning of possible danger in giving aspirin to babies was issued today by three pediatric specialists at the St. Louis Children's Hospital, where three infants have died this month of salicylate (aspirin) intoxication.
Harold Silver has been appointed supervisor of the basement division in the Macy corporate buying division of R. H. Macy Co., Inc.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- A group of Protestant ministers and laymen asked President Truman today to withhold any form of aid from Spain until assurances had been received from the Government of Generalissimo Francisco France that alleged persecution of Protestants in Spain would be discontinued.

American export Lines, Inc., reported yesterday for the first nine months this year net profit of $3,062,000, equal to $2.55 a share after taxes and all charges. In the corresponding period last year the company had a net of $1,758,000, or $1.46 a share.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- The Department of State today urged owners of defaulted pre-war German bonds to report their holdings to a special committee named recently to negotiate payment.

BONN, Germany, Nov. 21 -- Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, Hitler's one-time financial "brain," was described as a "superior expert of incontestable quality" today by Dr. Wolhelm Vockel, president of the Bank Deutscher Laender.
RHINELANDER, Wis., Nov. 21 (AP) -- A $1,000,000 experimental plant designed to restore the purity of streams was unveiled today at the Rhinelander Paper Company.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Nov. 21 -- Grover Loening, New York aviation engineer, declared in a speech prepared for delivery here tonight that the Federal Government had grown to such an "enormous and unwieldy" size that the only solution was to "reallocate" many of its functions "back to the states."

With the designation yesterday of Herbert Brownell Jr. to be Attorney General, George M. Humphrey to be Secretary of the Treasury and Harold E. Stassen to direct the Mutual Security Agency the Eisenhower Administration is well along toward taking shape.

NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 21 -Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru made an impassioned appeal today for consideration of India's resolution in the United Nations on the Korean prisoners issue as offering a possible pathway to world peace.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 21 -- John Foster Dulles, in his second official action as Secretary of State-designate, paid a half-hour call today on Trygve Lie, Secretary General of the United Nations.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- President Truman said today that Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower had been "rather appalled" in their conference Tuesday at the scope of information a President needed in order to make daily decisions that might affect all the people of the United States or of the world.

William Green, who died at his home in Ohio yesterday, was the American Federation of Labor's chief ambassador to the public ever since he succeeded Samuel Gompers. In this capacity he was always sure of a respectful hearing because of his moderate and conciliatory point of view.
The length of the football Giants' workout yesterday, their final home drill before facing the Washington Redskins at Griffith Stadium tomorrow, was reduced by photographers.

Joe Black, the Dodgers' tireless relief hurler who was nosed out by Hank Sauer and Robin Roberts for the National League's most valuable player honors, came up with more than an ample consolation prize yesterday when he was named an overwhelming victor of his circuit's rookie-of-the-year award.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- George M. Humphrey, Cleveland industrialist who was chosen today by Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower to serve as Secretary of the Treasury in the incoming Cabinet, will bring an era of cooperation between the Treasury and the Federal Reserve Board, it was predicted here today by bankers, many Government officials and business men.
Northrop Aircraft, Inc., announced yesterday that John K. Northrop, president of the company since its inception in 1939, had resigned because of failing health. No successor has been named.

The Save the Children Federation which has been working in Korea since the beginning of the war, noted with satisfaction your editorial in THE TIMES of Nov. 3. It is to be hope that your large reading constituency will be inspired to do something in a practical way to help the thousands of sufferers, especially the children, in that war-devastated country.

A "group of business men began yesterday to organize what they declared to be "the most practical and business-like approach" to getting payment on some part of the present heavy Brazilian backlog of debts owed American exporters.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (AP) -A Federal grand jury at Dayton, Ohio, today indicted a former civilian employe of the Air Force on a perjury charge, based on denials that he knew atomic spy Harry Gold was a Soviet espionage agent.

Several food trade groups asserted yesterday that the recent proposal of Price Stabilizer Tighe Woods for a rollback in meat prices would create artificial shortages and lead to a revival of black markets in meat products.

ROCQUENCOURT, France, Nov. 21 -- Brigadier Sir James Gault of the Scots Guards who was President-elect Dwight D. Eisenhower's close personal assistant during World War II and came out of retirement after the war to rejoin General Eisenhower at Supreme Allied Headquarters, said farewell to Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway and his allied colleagues here today prior to retirement at his own request.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 21 (AP) -- The Villanova Wildcats, seeking a fourth straight victory over Boston University in the renewal of a brief series, have set defensive sights on Quarterback Harry Agganis as the man to stop in their clash with B. U. at Shibe Park tomorrow.

A petition filed with the Supreme Court here yesterday asked for an order that would compel the New York State Crime Commission to call Thomas (Three Finger Brown) Luchese, fugitive underworld leader, as a witness at public hearing.

Mme. Jacqueline Auriol, who on Tuesday received the Harmon International Trophy for the women's plane speed record, visited the Manhattan Eye, Ear and Throat Hospital yesterday in the role of "most grateful patient."

More than 1,200 assorted tycoons left their dignity at home last night to attend a not-too-quiet dinner in the Astor Hotel and endure a fearful ordeal -- the eleventh annual Financial Follies staged by the New York Financial Writers Association.

The newly announced consolidation of St. Luke's Hospital and the Woman's Hospital of the State of New York, scheduled to be effective by the end of this year, will provide a complete general hospital that cannot fail to be of great benefit to the New York community.

TAIPEI, Formosa, Nov. 13 -More than 500,000 acres of land now being tilled by tenant farmers in Chinese Nationalist Formosa are scheduled to change hands here early next year under a land reform program designed to convert the tenants into small landowning capitalists.

First place in the Eastern Division of the National Basketball Association will be at stake tonight in Madison Square Garden when the New York Knickerbockers tangle with the Syracuse Nationals, defending loop champions. Both clubs sport identical 5-3 records.

A thousand years of art, design and sculpture, ranging from an ivory carving dated about 950 to a Dufy watercolor of the United Nations, dated 1952, are represented in the new Christmas card collections.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower joined here tonight in old-time informal comradeship with approximately forty of his fellow cadets in the United States Military Academy Class of 1915. The President-elect was nominally "just another member" at the annual dinner held at the Army-Navy Club here.

The Communist network is employing its agents and dupes in an international campaign to discredit the United States by interpreting the atom spy case of Julius and Ethel Rosenberg as an instance of deliberate injustice.

The New York Newspaper Women's annual prize for the best column in any field written by a New York newspaper woman was awarded to Mrs. Anne O'Hare McCormick of THE NEW YORK TIMES at the club's Annual Front Page Dinner Dance at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel last night.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 21 -- Andrei Y. Vishinsky popped up in a seldom-publicized committee of the United Nations today to announce enthusiastically that the capitalist nations of the world already were at each others' economic throats and that things would get worse.

LONDON, Nov. 21 -- British doctors have been warned about the dangers and side effects of yet another chemotherapeutic agent used in the treatment of tuberculosis -- thiosemicarbazone, a drug similar in action to the sulpha group that has been widely prescribed in Germany since 1946.
LOS ANGELES, Nov. 21 (AP) -- The football teams of Southern California and U. C. L. A. went into their customary seclusion today and tensely awaited their struggle in the Memorial Coliseum tomorrow.
LONDON, Nov. 21 (AP) -- At least 3,000 Americans will be able to view the coronation procession of Queen Elizabeth II next June from official Government stands.

Dr. Oswald Aranha, Brazilian lawyer and former president of the General Assembly of the United Nations, arrived at the New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, last night from Rio de Janeiro to undergo a medical check-up.

British support is winning votes for the Indian proposal for an armistice in Korea. For the first time in this session members of the United Nations are encouraged to believe that a ceasefire may be in sight. The twenty-one nations sponsoring the resolution put forward by Secretary Acheson at the beginning of the debate met yesterday to discuss the Indian plan and the modifications suggested by Mr. Eden in his speech on Thursday.

Fordham's football team, which broke into the winning column for the first time this season last Saturday, may be in for trouble against a favored and bowl-conscious Syracuse eleven at Triborough Stadium on Randalls Island today. Syracuse, beaten only by Boiling Field and Michigan State, is the favorite.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Nov. 21 -- Israeli Government officials took full note of, but refrained from comment today on the fact that an important part of the indictment of Rudolf Slansky and his co-defendants in Czechoslovakia were directed against the Zionist movement and the State of Israel.

CHICAGO, Nov. 21 -- Lower prices were registered for all grains and for soybeans on the Board of Trade today, there having been a continuance of long liquidation, especially in the September deliveries, while Korean developments in the United Nations deliberations took the edge off demand. Routine news influences had little effect, and there was no outside buying response to the unfavorable weather news from the Southwest.
GUATEMALA, Nov. 21 -- President Jacobo Arbenz Guzman reorganized his Cabinet today, bringing in two new members and shifting another.

The four-story thirty-six-family apartment house at 118-65 Metropolitan Avenue in Richmond Hill, Queens, has been purchased by the Raze Realty Corporation, headed by Anne Yaeger, from Irving Klein. Philip Levin was the broker and the Lawyers Mortgage and Title Company insured title.

CHICAGO, Nov. 21 (UP) -- A Federal judge today dismissed a tax fraud charge against Ralph (Bottles) Capone, brother of the late Al Capone, and recommended that hereafter the tax collectors deal at "arm's length" with him.

ATLANTA, Ga., Nov. 21 -- A group of the nation's leading business and industrial leaders toured Atlanta's six Negro colleges today on the first leg of an inspection tour in connection with its goal to raise and spend $25,000,000 for thirty-one non-state-supported colleges in the South.

VIENNA, Nov. 21 (AP) -- Much of the confessions of M. Geminder, Dr. Clementis and M. Slansky has concerned alleged plotting with Jews and "Titoists." The 14,000-word list of charges against M. Slansky, once a Moscow favorite, and the other defendants called John Foster Dulles a "notorious spy" and said he plotted to help wealthy Jewish families smuggle property out of Czechoslovakia.

The railroads were the focal point of trading on the stock market again yesterday and provided the greatest help in keeping the price structure on an even keel. Quotations in other major divisions, and especially among the main industrial issues, were well scrambled.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 21 -- Harold E. Stassen said this afternoon that he was "thrilled" by his appointment as Director for Mutual Security in the Administration of President-elect Dwight D. Eisenhower.

Columbia University's 260 midshipmen in the Naval Reserve Officer Training Corps boarded the heavy cruiser Albany at Pier 26, North River, yesterday for two hours of training and indoctrination in their various specialties.

DURANGO, Mexico, Nov. 21 (AP) -- Giovanni Bracco of Italy lengthened his lead to more than seven minutes in the sports car division and Johnny Mantz of Los Angeles took over first place in the stock car division of the Pan-American road race today.

MEXICO CITY, Nov. 21 -- The magnificent physical framework of what is hoped will be a new era in Mexican education has been completed with the inauguration of the grandiose new home of Mexico's National University.

The confessions of Rudolf Slansky and his co-defendants in the current Prague treason trials represent the high point of public Communist exploitation and fostering of anti-Semitic sentiment, a leading United States Government student of Soviet bloc affairs said yesterday.
OTTAWA, Nov. 21 (AP) -- Dean Acheson, United States Secretary of State expressed confidence today that Soviet hopes for a split in Western unity would not be realized.

The Police Department survey conducted by the Institute of Public Administration for the Mayor's Committee on Management Survey was assailed yesterday as a "glib" and "smooth" operation that failed to provide an "honest evaluation" of the department's organization and administration.

In the American Memorial Chapel in St. Paul's Cathedral in London there will rest a leather-bound and handsomely illuminated volume called "American Roll of Honour." It carries the names of 28,000 Americans who gave their lives during the war in Britain or in service with British units.

MAIMI, Nov. 21 (AP) -- Gov. Fuller Warren was asked tonight to arbitrate the growing controversy over fingerprinting horsemen which threatens to delay the scheduled opening of Florida's thoroughbred racing season next Thursday.

Observers who have been comforting themselves with the thought that the question of trading hours in Wall Street would cause them no more loss of sleep should reach for the aspirin. Edward T. McCormick, president of the New York Curb Exchange, told the National Industrial Traffic League yesterday that he would not be surprised if the Street goes on an 11 A. M. to 5 P. M. schedule.

DETROIT, Nov. 21 -- Walter P. Reuther, president of the Unitedi Automobile Workers, C. I. O., said today that the drop in the price index that would cut the wages of more than 1,000,000 union members 1 cent did not indicate lower prices.
Among the "loaded" questions appearing on the agenda of the Seventh Assembly of the United Nations is the position of France in Morocco.

LORAIN, Ohio, Nov. 21 (AP) -- Don Miller, news editor of The Lorain Journal, was freed today on $200 bond for a hearing Dec. 9 on an assault and battery charge filed by a radio news broadcaster who Mr. Miller said, "pirated" Journal stories.

The average dinner table conversation probably generates millions of volts of low-amperage electricity in the sugar bowl, Paul Egli, head of the crystal branch of the Naval Research Laboratory, estimated yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (AP) -- A Senate subcommittee asked tonight that the official certification of Representative Charles E. Potter as Senator from Michigan be delayed, and state officials promptly rejected the request.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 21 -George F. Arnold, civil defense administrator of this city, was elected president of the United States Civil Defense Council at its founding session here today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (AP) -The Civil Aeronautics Board exercised for the first time today the control Congress granted it last July over air-travel ticket agents.

In Chicago last July Harold Edward Stassen, slated to become the new Director for Mutual Security, sought unsuccessfully for the third time the Republican nomination for President. As the favorite son of Minnesota, his home state, he remained more a "dark horse" than a serious contender.
CHICAGO, Nov. 21 (AP) -- The Big Ten gridiron company will end tomorrow in a photo finish for a Rose Bowl bid.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 21 -- Rain and strong winds await more than 38,000 spectators expected to attend the sixty-ninth football clash between Harvard and Yale at Harvard Stadium tomorrow.
Pierre Etchebaster retained his title as world's open court tennis champion yesterday by defeating his challenger Alastair Bradley Martin of Glen Head, L. I., four-time national amateur champion.
The unobtrusive gesture of a guard in Queens County Court yesterday gave physical effect to the words of Judge Peter T. Farrell as he said to a patient, bespectacled man seated before him:

The city's drive against firetrap tenements in Manhattan and the Bronx has resulted so far in uncovering 4,159 violations of the housing laws in the two boroughs, Frederick S. Weaver, deputy cornmissioner of housing, announced yesterday.

COSHOCTON, Ohio, Nov. 21 -- William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor since 1924, died today in the modest little home in which he had hoped to spend his final years "resting and spinning yarns." His age was 82.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 21 -- George M. Humphrey, first Clevelander to receive a Cabinet appointment since Newton D. Baker became Secretary of War in 1916, said today he would become Secretary of the Treasury "at a great personal sacrifice in salary and with the expectation of getting plenty of headaches."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- Federal officials said tonight that John Foster Dulles had no choice but to submit to a full field investigation by the Federal Bureau of Investigation unless Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, after taking office, specifically exempted him.
Mrs. Dwight D. Eisenhower is expected to give a lift to the fashion industry.

DENVER, Nov. 21 -- The Freedom of Information Committee of Sigma Delta Chi, professional journalistic fraternity, reported today that there was reason to believe that the tendencies by public officials and public agencies toward withholding information were due "in part at least, to a decline in vigilance, in enterprise, and in aggressiveness on the part of local newspapers."
BONN, Germany, Nov. 21 -- Appointment of John Foster Dulles as American Secretary of State by Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the President-elect, was welcomed officially by the Federal Government today.

Tighe E. Woods, present head of the Office of Price Stabilization, was put in that post after Congress had decided last June to terminate the wage-price controls on April 30 next. His role, as most persons saw it, was to preside over the orderly liquidation of that agency.

Two large group exhibitions and a one-man show figure among this week's art events. There are eighty-two pieces of sculpture by as many sculptors now on view at Artists Equity. Many of the artists represented here have established reputations while others are comparatively little known.

BONN, Germany, Nov. 21 -- The reconstitution of "Das Reich," the united German state, and of Prussia are among the final aims of the Free Democratic party, Dr. Thomas Dehler, Minister of Justice, announced today.

The callous disregard for the safety of pedestrians, not to say law-abiding motorists, that is practiced by bus drivers who "jump" signal lights is another blot on this city s traffic enforcement record. Apparently, as noted in our news columns recently, bus drivers enjoy immunity to arrest while less favored motor-vehicle operators feel the full force of police action.

An estimated 3,000,000 copies of the Government's final 1952 commemorative stamp, a 3-cent blue and red honoring the International Red Cross, were purchased yesterday in connection with the fourth annual National Postage Stamp Show in the Seventy-first Infantry Regiment Armory at Thirty-fourth Street and Park Avenue.
Paddy De Marco, busy puncher from the Navy Yard section of Brooklyn, defeated Henry Davis of Honolulu in the main bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden last night.

THE Mayor of Agrigento was showing Gen. George S. Patton Jr. around the Greek temple ruins of great beauty there soon after the 1943 Allied invasion of Sicily. "When we came to the temple of Hercules," General Patton wrote his wife, "which was the biggest, but in the worst state of repair, I asked him had it been destroyed by an earthquake.

Various types of pension costs that defense contractors may charge against renegotiable sales to the Government were specified yesterday in a staff bulletin made public by the Renegotiation Board in Washington.

Hearing of a petition by a group i of minority stockholders for the appointment of a temporary receiver for the $50,000,000 R. K. O. Pictures Corporation and its subsidiary, R. K. 0. Pictures, Inc., was adjourned yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Henry Clay Greenberg until Dec. 10.
A Government complaint in denaturalization proceedings against Vito Genovese, the gangster, was filed with the clerk in Federal Court in Newark yesterday by United States Attorney Grover C. Richman.
Following are tributes to William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor who died yesterday, as received by THE NEW YORK TIMES and The Associated Press and The United Press:

CORNING, N. Y., Nov. 21 -- After 104 years' living with a busy railroad running down one of their main streets, tying up traffic and loosing a pall of soot (until the recent advent of the diesel) over the business district, the residents of this upstate, glass-making city are going to get a break tomorrow.
TOKYO, Nov. 21 (AP) -- John Foster Dulles, who fashioned freedom for this island nation, was hailed today by Japan on his appointment as United States Secretary of State.

CHICAGO, Nov. 21 -- The prosecution today disclosed its intention to bring thirty-one members of the du Pont family, eighteen of them women, to Chicago for questioning on the witness stand in the Government's trial of an anti-trust suit aimed at the du Pont $5,000,000,000 alleged "industrial empire."

An "ideal choice" was the consensus yesterday among downtown financial observers who were asked for their reaction to the naming of George M. Humphrey as Secretary of the Treasury in the Eisenhower Cabinet. Bankers said the Ohio industrialist, who is president of the M. A. Hanna Company of Cleveland, was "a great financial head" and one of the country's ablest business men.

BERLIN, Nov. 21 -- On the eve of his scheduled departure for Moscow, Bishop Otto Dibelius, chairman of the Council of the German Protestant Church, was asked by the Russians today to postpone his visit.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 21 -- Secretary General Trygve Lie called in key officials in the United States anti-subversive inquiries today, said again that there was no place for "disloyal" Americans on the United Nations staff and disclosed that he intended to meet soon with the Attorney General of the United States.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was active again yesterday, and closing prices were 1 to 13 points net higher than on Thursday.

One of the most stirring dramas of the sea, the gallant battle of the freighter Flying Enterprise in a hurricane last January, has been set down on canvas by one of the men on the Navy transport General A. W. Greely that rescued passengers and crew of the doomed vessel.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's second trio of appointees to high posts in his forthcoming Administration was greeted by generally favorable reaction in the capital today, and incumbents of the posts that the three are to occupy hastened to telephone promises of their cooperation in effecting an efficient transfer of authority on Jan. 20.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- Mrs. John G. Lee, president of the League of Women Voters, announced today "an all-out" drive to arouse public opinion in this country to the importance of international trade.
The following is a round-up of new products which may be of use to the homemaker.
Members of the Student Symphony Society wondered yesterday why the Voice of America beamed their words and not their music to the Far East last week.

Herbert Brownell Jr. announced yesterday, after his designation by President-elect Dwight D. Eisenhower as Attorney General in the new Cabinet, that he would re-examine all cases, criminal and civil, pending in the Department of Justice when he takes over.

The amazing career of Thomas Luchese, a short, trimly built man of 52 years who could pass for 40, stands revealed in a study of the 583 pages of his sworn testimony given to the State Crime Commission in private examination. A condensed version of the testimony was read at the public hearings of the commission last Friday.

The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development would secure only minority participation in the proposed International Finance Corporation, Robert L. Garner, vice president of the bank, declared yesterday. He spoke before concluding sessions of the American Management Association's annual finance conference in the Roosevelt Hotel.
The ninth annual world-wide Bible reading project, which is being promoted by the American Bible Society, will begin on Thanksgiving Day and continue through Christmas.

PARIS, Nov. 21 -- France, keystone in the defense of Western Europe, now has twelve divisions, twenty-nine air squadrons and a navy of 356,000 tons earmarked for the use of the Atlantic alliance in Europe.

The Association of American Railroads at their annual meeting in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel here yesterday urged the allocation of enough steel to permit the construction of 10,000 freight cars monthly. W. T. Faricy, who was re-elected president of the association, and James K. Knudson, Defense Transport Administrator, both expressed the hope that the goal could be attained by next October.

ALBANY, Nov. 21 -- A year-long study to get a comprehensive picture and general evaluation of special purpose authorities created by the State of New York will be made by the temporary Commission on Coordination of State Activities, State Senator Walter J. Mahoney of Buffalo, commission chairman, announced today.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Nov. 21 -- Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois had planned to fly to Korea if he had been elected President, just as Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower is going to do, an aide reported today.

Nov. 21 (AP) -- The Defense Department identified today 359 additional casualties of the Korean war, including 68 dead, 243 wounded, 37 missing and 11 injured. The following were listed from New York and Connecticut (none from New Jersey):
CAMP KILMER, N. J., Nov. 21 -- Additional clerical help and record machines were being rushed here today in an attempt to clear a backlog of men waiting for pre-Christmas separations.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -Speros P. Andelenis, proprietor of the Capitol View Restaurant, 120 North Main Street, Concord, N. H., succeeded this week in patenting his "canary glass house." It is for human occupancy but looks very much like a bird cage on a high pedestal, with glass between the bars.

Two books of non-fiction are the only works published today, both by W. W. Norton. One is "Psychiatry and the Law," by Dr. Manfred S. Guttmacher and Henry Weihofen, which presents a guide to the problems of legal psychiatry from a doctor's and a lawyer's point of view.

Columbia will close its 1952 football season today with a 1:30 P. M. "Dad's Day" meeting with Brown at Baker Field. The occasion will mark the varsity farewell of twelve Columbia seniors, including Capt. Bob McCullough and the crack passing combination of Mitch Price and Al Ward.
TRENTON, Nov. 21 -- Twelve additional state troopers were assigned to traffic duly today on the New Jersey Turnpike to assist in reducing the number of accidents by rigid law enforcement.

PRINCETON, N. J., Nov. 21 -- Princeton rules a strong favorite to defeat Dartmouth for the fourth consecutive time tomorrow in Palmer Stadium when the Ivy-League foes meet in the final game of the season for both teams.

ROTTERDAM, The Netherlands, Nov. 21. -- Traffic to the world's third busiest port and gateway to the Continent, closed Nov. 7 by the sinking of a freighter in the mouth of the waterway to the North Sea, has been virtually restored to normal.

DUBLIN, Nov. 21 -- Auxiliary Bishop Fulton J. Sheen, Arturo Toscanini and Jean-Louis Barrault, French actor, were among those named here to receive this year's merit awards of the Catholic Stage Guild of Ireland.

LONDON, Nov. 21 -- The principal feature of stock markets today was the rise of Japanese bonds on renewed heavy buying, prompted by suggestions that the formal debt settlement offer giving details of the sinking fund agreements would be published over the week-end.
BOWIE, Md., Nov. 21 (AP) -- Reopening of Bowie was postponed today from tomorrow, at least until Monday, because of a northeast rainstorm that swamped the race track.

Deposits held by New York State's mutual savings banks rose $1,002,362,000 during the year ended Oct. 31, it was announced yesterday by Charles R. Diebold, president of the Savings Banks Association of the State of New York.

A new Church World Service reception center will be opened at 1 P. M. Monday at 110 East Twenty-ninth Street to facilitate the collection of gifts of clothing for destitute refugees in Korea, the Near East and Central Europe.

A rash of pre-week-end hold-ups yesterday and early this morning resulted in the fatal beating of a grocer in his store and in the killing of one of two gunmen who tried to rob a tavern where two off-duty policemen were having a glass of beer.

The sixteen-story apartment house for seventy-seven families on plot 91 by 89 feet at 760 West End Avenue, northeast corner of Ninety-seventh Street, has been sold by the Clinton Trust Company, trustee for certificate holders, to Knepper Levin, operators.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (AP) -- John W. Snyder, Secretary of the Treasury, has acknowledged to House tax investigators that he acted personally to speed up a $20,000,000 tax case, but only in the interest of more efficient administration.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- Average primary market prices declined 0.3 per cent over the week ended on Tuesday to 110.4 per cent of the 1947-49 average, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. Farm products fell 1.6 per cent, largely because of lower prices for cattle, lambs, eggs, cotton and some poultry and fresh vegetables.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif, Nov. 21 -- Moss Hart has been signed and a deal now is pending with George Zukor to team as writer and director, respectively, for the musical version of "A Star Is Born," in which Judy Garland, after a two- year absence, will return to the screen under the Warner Brothers banner.
CHICAGO, Nov. 21 (AP) -- The Packinghouse Workers, C. I. O., today announced a new two-year wage contract with Swift Co. including a 4-cent general wage increase.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 21 -- The Western members in the United Nations condemned the Soviet Union and its satellites today for obstructing the repatriation of thousands of Greek children.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Nov. 21 -- Rutgers and N. Y. U., rivals since 1890, will clash in their forty-third meeting at Rutgers Stadium this afternoon in the third annual football Hall of Fame game.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (AP) -- Mrs. Esther Caukin Brunauer, ousted State Department employe, said today she hoped the Eisenhower Administration would look "fearlessly and thoroughly" into what she called the deplorable unfairness of the Government's loyalty-security program.

Ann Cantales and Vincent Truncellito have sold the three-story factory building at 61-65 Jay Street, Brooklyn, to Bios Laboratories, Inc., of which Fred Linsker is president. Mendel Haskell was the broker and the attorneys were Sol Koenigsberg for the buyer and Harry Berger for the sellers.

The Trans-Pacific Freight Conference of Japan has rescinded its announcement of last Saturday with respect to the immediate reinstitution of a contract, non-contract rate system, regardless of the Federal Maritime Board's requirement of at least thirty days prior notice of such an action, it became known yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (AP) -Senate investigators released secret testimony today identifying First Lieut. Sheppard Carl Thierman as the Army physician recently assigned to treating Communist prisoners in Korea who refused to say whether he was a Communist.

Mankind is now living in "an age of exile" that "pales into insignificance" all of the great population moves of history, the Rev. Dr. Elfan Rees, advisor to the World Council of Churches on refugee affairs, said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- The Federal Reserve Board said today that national production has reached a point where current defense needs can be met with enough capacity left over to begin filling increased civilian requirements.

Trailing by 19 -- 6 at the end of the first quarter, the Adelphi Academy football team went on a scoring rampage to crush Horace Mann, 43 -- 19, in their concluding Ivy Prep School League game yesterday on the loser's gridiron.

Plans to buy and retire fifty of the 1,375 seats on the New York Stock Exchange were laid before the membership yesterday. They would be bought over a period of five years at prices not to exceed $45,000 each.

Most business men agree that their sales forces face a tough job during the next few years but many are unaware of the changes in selling practices necessary if consumer purchasing is to take up the expected sales slack. This is the opinion of John Fistere, director of sales development of Fortune magazine.

HANOI, Vietnam, Indo-China, Nov. 21 -- A progressive evacuation of outpost defenses along the right flank of the French front in the Black River Thai country was announced today by the French. Garrisons numbering from sixty to more than 100 men were falling back toward the southern Thai defense bastion of Sonla from small forts ranging through the mountains down to Mocchaubalay, sixty miles south of Sonla.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- President Truman has turned over to his successor, Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, a three-volume top-secret "briefing handbook" specially prepared to inform the President-elect of the Administration's policies and plans in all critical areas of the world.

Elaborate pageantry, displaying striking gowns designed especially for the occasion and jewels from famous collections, provided a colorful and sparkling decor at the third annual Fan Ball for the benefit of the Children's Memorial Cancer Fund, Inc., held last night in the main ballroom of the Plaza.

Ethel and Julius Rosenberg, convicted Soviet atom spies, are scheduled to be executed the week of Jan. 12, according to an order yesterday by Federal Judge Irving R. Kaufman. They will be the first civilians ever put to death in this nation for espionage.

Collections of blood by the Red Cross totaled 1,264 pints on Thursday, with cadets at the United States Military Academy and members of the New York Telephone Company union-management blood bank contributing 347 pints each.

Ray Lev, pianist, appeared in a recital before a capacity audience at Carnegie Hall last evening. The artist offered Tomascheck's Ecologue No. 1, Beethoven's Sonata in F sharp major, Op. 78, Bach's Organ Toccata in C major, Schumann's "Albumblaetter," the Mussorgsky "Pictures at an exhibition," a group of new pieces and works of Liszt and Chopin.

ROME, Nov. 21 -- The Vatican newspaper L' Osservatore Romano published ample details today of a new early Christian document recently discovered in the excavations under St. Peter's Basilica and attesting that the Prince of the Apostles was in actual fact buried in a grave under the main altar of the church that bears his name.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 21 -- A decided split developed tonight between the United States, on one hand, and Britain and Canada on the other, regarding proposed changes in a compromise Indian resolution on the repatriation of Korean prisoners of war.

VIENNA, Nov. 21 -- Today's proceedings in the Prague show trial of Rudolf Slansky, former Secretary General of the Czechoslovak Communist party, Dr. Vladimir Clementis, former Foreign Minister, and twelve other prominent members of the Czechoslovak Communist party, indicated this was a major effort by Moscow to give a global aspect to the alleged conspiracy by the Western world against the Soviet Union.

A NUMBER of deer hunters, and not all of them novices, had the interesting but not pleasant experience of spending an unscheduled night in the big woods recently. Those who wrote of this adventure seemed to be in a chastened mood.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- The two consumer price indexes compiled by the Bureau of Labor Statistics showed a divergence in the quarter that ended Oct. 15. The "modernized" index rose one-tenth of a point from 190.8 to 190.9.

Housewares and department stores are bulging at this time of the year with dozens of utensils designed to aid the home cook in preparing not only the holiday bird but all the other foods tradition demands for Thansgiving. A quick survey of some of the basic equipment might be apropos, especially for the young housewife who will be cooking the family turkey for the first time.

George Magoffin Humphrey of Cleveland, who was named yesterday by Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, President-elect, to be Secretary of the Treasury, is one of the most important industrialists in the United States and probably the quietest.
TOKYO, Saturday, Nov. 22 (AP) -United Nations Command communique 1,441, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Saturday, Korea time:

Events today: "Rigoletto," Metropolitan Opera, 2 P. M.; Young People's Concert, Philharmonic-Symphony, Town Hall, 3; "Madama Butterfly," Metropolitan Opera, 8; "Faust," Amato Opera Theatre, 149 Bleecker Street, 8:30; "Carmen," Salmaggi Opera, Brooklyn Academy of Music, 8:30.

IT is manifestly impossible to achieve a satisfactory survey of contemporary religion in the United States in a book of less than 250 pages. The subject is too large, too many-sided, too disputatious and refractory, and, in its most important aspects, too impalpable for compact description.

THROUGH the cooing noises he makes and through his howls of complaint the infant gains a subtle, an intangible, and yet an overpowering hold upon the affections of his parents. When he imitates the sounds of his environment (gurgling, for example, reproduces the splash of water in the sink) the infant is building a psychological bridge between himself and surrounding reality.

Many thanks to Leonard Jan Mitchell for " 'Men Are the Best Cooks' " (Nov. 16) and deepest appreciation to Jane Nickerson for her footnotes which only served to amplify and attest to the validity of Mr. Mitchell's facts.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 22 -- An inspired Southern California eleven led by Jim Sears and Elmer Willhoite, won its way into the Rose Bowl today by defeating a hard-hitting U. C. L. A. team, 14 to 12, before 96,869 fans in Memorial Coliseum.

" The Golden Medal," an opera for children by Julius Levine, with libretto by Max Levine, had its first performance yesterday afternoon at the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Young People's Concert in Town Hall, Igor Buketoff conducting.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 22 -- A charge that the United States had "sabotaged" the Inter-American Council on Commerce and Production, which just concluded a meeting in Lima, Peru, appeared today in A Noite, a Government-owned newspaper.

RECENT years have seen a soaring increase in the nation's deer population. Inventory by the United States Fish and Wildlife Service counts over eight million, even though more than a million deer are shot each hunting season. The noble buck deer, his mate and his fawn may delight the nature lover, but they are also destructive pests that slip out of the night to browse on garden plants and young fruit trees.
Q. How do the A and H-bombs compare in size, cost and destructive power?

I am sorry that some persons have found my reporting about Sartre's pro-Stalinist position unfair and biased. In answer I would like to refer Professor Peyre to the kind of "objectivity" so often expressed in Sartre's neutralist magazine Les Temps Modernes.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 22 -- Slick, strong and stubborn as the occasion required, Yale today capped its most successful football season in six years by running up one of the highest scores in the seventy-seven-year history of its series with Harvard.

TOKYO, Nov. 22 -- United Nations representatives, alarmed by bitter expressions of opposition from the Japanese press and public, appealed to the Japanese Government today to explain to its citizens the reasons for the Allied request to exercise criminal jurisdiction over the United Nations troops in Japan. The United States has such jurisdiction over its troops in Japan.
MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Nov. 22 (AP) -- State Senator Arthur H. Wicks of New York said today he did not request a good conduct certificate for Thomas (Three Fingers Brown) Luchese, underworld chieftain.

IT is characteristic of the human animal to invest certain objects out of the past with almost magical significance. Thus, a couple may make a single tune symbolize the excitements of their courtship. Nations have similar mementos. Among pictures, Americans have long cherished "The Spirit of '76" and Stuart's portraits of Washington.
Sidewalk bookmakers were taking bets on horses yesterday along Broadway and Amsterdam Avenue.

This has reference to Harold Callender's "Clues to France and French Logic" (Nov. 9).
Twin sisters, 18 years old, have organized Hunter College's first Outdoor Club.
NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 22 (UP) -- Fair Grounds officials today invited racing fans to an "open house" tomorrow for a preview of the historic southern course's eightieth and richest season of races.

LAST week-end's series of fatal accidents because of thick fog on the New Jersey Turnpike did bring two facts into the vision of motorists and highway officials. One is that the problem of controlling traffic on a high-speed modern turnpike calls for special methods that are only slowly being developed.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Nov. 22 (AP) -- Twenty of the nation's football greats -- All-America players and near All-Americans -- sat in on the New York University-Rutgers game today and swapped stories of their feats of yesteryear.

JOHANNESBURG, Nov. 22-- Afrikaners, descended from Dutch, German and French colonists in South Africa, spent 300 years withdrawing from the world. First they went inland to get away from the original Dutch settlement at the Cape of Good Hope. Then they trekked on to escape the British conquerors. In the interior they lived on isolated farms in constant dread of being overwhelmed by hordes of natives.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 (AP) -- Pentagon planners say the nation's fighting strength is being sapped because military manpower policies for the past two years have been based on the uncertain assumption that the Korean war would end soon.

CAIRO, Nov. 21 -- The Sudan may fall into general disorder that can frustrate the efforts of the new regime here and the British Government to reach a final solution of the Sudan problem as a preliminary to a possible effort to settle the general British-Egyptian problem.

BY now most Americans know the name and some of the fabulous feats of Paul Bunyan. But forty years ago he was virtually unheard of outside the lumber camps, where he was the imaginary hero of the loggers -- a superlogger whose feats were oral legends among the men of the camps.

The framers of the Constitution made no provisions for the President's Cabinet. But of necessity the institution began to develop in Washington's first term. As Congress created the executive departments -- State, Treasury, War, Justice and Post Office, to begin with -- Washington began to solicit the advice of these bureau heads, at first in writing but by 1793 in joint meeting.

The death of Benedetto Croce, reported in your newspaper on Nov. 21, has deprived the free world of one of its most vigorous spokesmen. Those of us who, in these past years, served under Croce in his capacity of honorary chairman of the international Congress for Cultural Freedom know how energetic and inspiring a part he took in the defense of civilized decency against the noxious ideologies of totalitarianism.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 22 (AP) -- A St. Louis ice cream firm president, who was slain as he attempted to rob an armored money truck here yesterday, had been "living beyond his means" and was under financial pressure, a sister said today.

SAN DIEGO, Calif. -- The first step toward the presentation of an International World Travel Congress in New York in the autumn of 1954, a congress that is expected to attract between 15,000 and 20,000 travel officials, agents and transportation leaders from all over the world, was taken here last week at the annual convention of the National Association of Travel Officials.

THERE is a small portent now visible on Britain's social horizon. It is a portent as yet no bigger than the size of a pantrymaid's hand, but growing. It is that the United States is assimilating those former adornments of the stately homes of England, the stately butlers.

FIVE years ago, just before the Labor-Management Relations Act of 1947 was born over a Presidential veto, Representative Fred A. Hartley Jr. of New Jersey's Tenth district was simply known as a good conservative Republican, a Mason, an Elk, and an Eagle.

AS usual, our Government and the Government of France are growling at each other -- politely, of course, but with some acid blended with the honey. The American G. I.'s and some of the French citizens around Bordeaux are also fretful.
NEWARK, Nov. 22 -- Ruppert Stadium, key link in the New York Yankees' farm chain until four years ago, will be sold next Tuesday to the Board of Education of this city for $275,000.
TOKYO, Sunday, Nov. 23 -- Close to 12,000 casualties have been inflicted on the Communist enemy in three weeks of ground fighting in Korea in November, Eighth Army headquarters reported today.
Columbia concluded its football season yesterday with a 14-0 triumph over Brown on the rain-soaked turf of Baker Field.

IN spite of the holiday this week a few groups of gardeners are planning to fit in special programs. Two meetings here in New York City are open to the public as well as to members of the organizations, and there is no charge for admission.

With characteristic forthrightness, however, she refuses to consider herself a film person at all.

ROBERT JOHN THORNTON (1768?-1837), a practitioner of medicine and lecturer on medical botany at Guy's Hospital in London, was imbued from his school days with the ambition to create a permanent gallery in tribute to Linnaeus, the Swedish botanist.
CORNING, N. Y., Nov. 22 -- Erie train two, Chicago-to-New York bound, burst through a paper barrier today at Corning, to mark the elimination of the Erie trains from the central of the city.

Debutantes of this season who are provisional members of the New York Junior League will be the guests of honor at the New York Junior League Ball to be held on Wednesday night in the main ballroom of the Plaza for the benefit of the organization's welfare fund.

IT'S still pretty hard for some people to be objective about William Randolph Hearst and his 88 years of life. Few men in recent times, and certainly no other newspaper publisher, have been so heartily damned and disliked.

The weather went off on a weekend spree yesterday. An inch-deep rain started a spectacular flood tying up traffic on one stretch of the Henry Hudson Parkway for nearly nine hours. Winds with gusts reaching up to sixty-five miles an hour disrupted electric power service to 50,000 homes in the metropolitan area and telephone service to 2,000.

WITH the release of each motion picture a certain normal number of letters arrives at the studio. TO Winston Churchill, Canada has appeared a "linchpin" between the United States and Britain. To Viscount Bernard Montgomery, somewhat less renowned as a phrase-maker, she is "a hinge of purest gold" between the Old World and the New.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 (UP) -- A Government order lowering retail meat ceilings was expected Monday, and it appeared certain today it would touch off new demands for dropping all price and wage controls.

UNDER the terms of a revision of the postal agreement between the United States Nations and the United Government the general public is now permitted for the first time to purchase U. N. postal paper -- regular and commemorative stamps, air lettersheet and postcard -- for philatelic purposes by paying cash at sales windows instead of being obliged to send orders by mail.

AT the end of its first week of unlimited operations since last Feb. 11, Newark Airport was handling something less than one-third of the scheduled commercial airliners it took care of before the Port of New York Authority closed it down after the third crash in Elizabeth.

The Bureau of Labor Statistics study reported in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Nov. 16 is an interesting supplement to Prof. Arthur M. Whitehill's letter published Nov. 9. He argued that a worker should not be entitled to draw benefits from an industrial pension fund if his employment is terminated before retirement, either voluntarily or involuntarily.
TOO many bridge players grieve because they stopped at game and made a small slam, or stopped at a small slam and made a big one. The best bidding known is not that precise.
THE exploration in the Eighteen Twenties of the Blue Grotto of Capri by an Englishman, a Frenchman and a Dane, is a tradition upon which is hung this enchanting tale of adventure.

Baseball, having maintained a fairly respecful silence for as long a period as can reasonably be expected, is about ready to sound off again. For coming up very shortly are the annual winter conclaves of the major and minor leagues.

Operating on an expense budget of $1,454,653,078 for the fiscal year ending June 30, 1953, the city needs about $125,000,000 of additional revenue to balance its budget for 1953-54. If the more than 200,000 city employes are to receive general pay increases and if services to the public are to be raised above present levels, a much larger sum will be required.

HAITI will celebrate 150 years of independence on Jan. 1, 1954. This island's independence was proclaimed in the town of Gonaives on Jan. 1, 1804, by Jean Jacques Dessalines. A memorial to independence is being erected in Gonaives, and a new cathedral is also to be built as part of a program to beautify the town.

Convinced that new scientific methods can throw more light on extrasensory perception and other aspects of the mind, Mrs. Eileen J. Garrett has established the Parapsychology Foundation, with headquarters at 11 East Forty-fourth Street, New York, N. Y. She has more than research in view.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- A new president of the American Federation of Labor to succeed William Green will be named by the federation's Executive Council here Tuesday.

It may be that John Tunis can't enjoy football any longer since the game began to involve more players than he is able to count on his fingers. His article "The Kick Is Out of Football" (Nov. 16) nearly had me convinced. Then last Saturday I and 60,000 other red-blooded Americans filed into that potential "archaeological ruin," the Yale Bowl.

NEW DELHI, Nov. 22 -- India's current attempts to ease the Korean truce deadlock by a compromise formula for the disposition of prisoners of war have again spotlighted the peculiar role of the New Delhi Government as liaison between Communist China and the nations of the West. India has almost a unique position as a country friendly to both power groups in the Far Eastern battleground.

ABOUT twenty-five years ago Ambroise Vollard commissioned Marc Chagall to illustrate a new edition of La Fontaine's fables. Vollard died before the project was completed and it is only this year, after many vicissitudes, that the book has finally been published. The etchings made for it are now on view at Curt Valentin's.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 22 (UP) -- Fred Bruney and John Borton combined to lead Ohio State to a 27-7 victory today over Michigan that eliminated the Wolverines from a share of the Big Ten title.

THE Old Navy had terms for such a man as he -- sun-downer, hard case, shellback. For him there were no arts of compromise; he knew nothing of the subtleties of flattery. He was, in his own words, strict but fair. He believed in keeping men and ships up to the mark: he preferred a taut ship to a happy one.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 (UP) -- The Secretary of the Treasury, John W. Snyder, today announced the formation of the last three districts to be set up under the sweeping "anti-corruption" reorganization of the Internal Revenue Service. The new regions are Ohio, Michigan, and California-Nevada-Hawaii.
THE second sentence in "Sun, Moon and Planets" goes as follows: "Many people do not know that we can see the moon by day, and get very excited about it when they do see it."
A 42-year-old truck driver was arraigned in Brooklyn Felony Court yesterday on charges of arson and homicide in the death of a 28-year-old divorcee who was burned to death in her apartment on Nov. 7.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 (UP) -- The vast fiscal outlays for the nation's defense program will be a prime target of economy-minded Republicans in the Eighty-third Congress, according to a summary of the opinions of leaders issued today.

BECAUSE summer music centers have not been fixed by any rigid academic mold, they have exfoliated in all sorts of diverse forms. One of the most interesting and experimental is the one that Albert Schweitzer helped to launch four summers ago in Aspen, Colo.

Three years ago leaders in the field of higher education became disturbed at the financial outlook confronting American colleges and universities. Although thousands of veterans were crowding the campuses, the educators recognized that the G. I. Bill had a terminal point, and that the enrollments would some day fall off.

Members of the City College chapter of Phi Beta Kappa have ended an eighty-five-year tradition by electing a woman, Marianne Greene, 1410 Hicks Street, the Bronx, to membership in the honorary society, it was announced yesterday by Prof. Arthur Dickson, president of the chapter.

TELEVISION probably never will find a wholly satisfaction answer to its most difficult and recurrent problem: the element of repetition in so much of its programming. But from an unexpected quarter has come an intriguing hint of where the difficulty may lie -- and what can be done about it -- in the case of a great number of shows that use the same dramatic characters from week to week.

The Colgate University student is being more careful with his written reports and assignments these days, for there's a good chance one of his works may be "played back" on a screen before his class. Consultants of the university's functional writing program take an opaque projector into science laboratories and other classrooms and show on a screen samples of student reports written for these courses.

SARANAC LAKE, N. Y., Nov. 22 -- Show business folk, from acrobats to television directors, have pledged themselves here at the Will Rogers Memorial Hospital to a run-of-the-show contract in the war against tuberculosis.

" THE Adventures of Ozzie and Harriet," a radio standby since Oct. 8, 1944, based on a humorous, homespun treatment of the Nelson family home life, this year has turned to television over the facilities of the American Broadcasting Company.

THE short piece has proved a problem to the manufacturers of records that play a long time. How can one assemble a lot of brief pieces on one disk and achieve any sense of unity? The difficulty has made the companies rack their minds for organizing ideas. Fortunately for Victor, one of its executives has come up with a very useful one -- an idea which covers not just one disk, but a whole series.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 22 -- So keen has been the interest of the public in the headquarters building of the United Nations that beginning Saturday, Dec. 6, the guided-tour service of the American Association for the United Nations will be offered on a seven-day-a-week basis instead of the present five-day-a-week schedule.

PARIS, Nov. 22 -- In the annual report on rearmament plans now being drafted here by the Secretariat of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, defense expenditure does not have the top priority that it had last year when the review was made by the Temporary Council Committee under the chairmanship of Averell Harriman.

DES MOINES, Nov. 22 -- Official canvass of the vote on two amendments to the Iowa Constitution regulating the succession to the Governorship will start Monday. Both amendments were adopted overwhelmingly in the Nov. 4 election.

Many boxes and seats have been purchased for the annual concert for the benefit of the Bagby Music Lovers Foundation, Inc., to be held tomorrow afternoon in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. The event has been arranged under the direction of George L. Bagby, president of the beneficiary.

A survey of pier insurance and maintenance costs being made by the Department of Marine and Aviation is expected to result in a reduction of the over-all costs of the users of city-owned piers and provide the first relief in many years for steamship companies operating under the city's expensive pier rental formula, it was learned yesterday.

A FIRST-CLASS picture book in Civil War literature has long been an outstanding need. The ten-volume "Photographic History of the Civil War" was an impressive work, but much progress has been made in reproducing pictures since its publication in 1911.

Semi-skilled workers on a production line do better in terms of take-home pay than apprentices looking ahead to becoming master machinists or tool designers. That is why there is a shortage of apprentices.

SINCE books about Christmas seem as inevitable as Christmas itself, it would be well if they were all as satisfying as Francis X. Weiser's "The Christmas Book." Seldom have so many aspects of the origin, observance and meaning of this important Christian holy season been presented in such attractive form.

ALBANY, Nov. 22 -- The new York Water Service Corporation received Public Service Commission authorization this week for provisional rate increases to customers serviced by its plants at Babylon, Glen Cove, Huntington, Rochester and Syracuse. The commission refused, however, to authorize rate changes for company plants at Sag Harbor, Haverstraw, Clyde and Woodlawn.

BERKELEY, Calif., Nov. 22 (UP) -- With the great Johnny Olszewski putting on one of his finest bulldozing exhibitions, the California Bears crushed the Stanford Indians, 26 -- 0, in the fifty-fifth "big game" today before 83,000 fans in Memorial Stadium.

Africa and South America probably were once joined by a broad land bridge which has since disappeared under the South Atlantic Ocean, says Dr. Kenneth E. Caster, professor of geology and fellow of the Graduate School of Arts and Sciences, University of Cincinnati He bases his conclusions on years of intensive study along the eastern coastal areas of South America.

THE business of making movies is so vast and complex these days -- so obviously in the orbit of mammoth industrial enterprise -- that it is a little hard to remember it was once a flimsy, fly-by-night trade, peopled by candid opportunists and not a great deal more respectable than robbing trains.

PARIS, Nov. 22 -- Dr. Jaime Torres Bodet of Mexico, director general of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization, resigned his post today in protest against a decision of the general conference yesterday to fix the organization's budget for the next two years at about 10 per cent below what he and the executive board had asked.

TUESDAY will see the second premiere of the season by the New York City Ballet at the City Center. This will be George Balanchine's setting of Paul Hindemith's "Metamorphoses," built on themes from three of Weber's piano pieces for four hands.

ELIZABETH, N. J., Nov. 22 -- The Junior Chamber of Commerce of Eastern Union County has announced the start of a "big brother" program in which members will act as counselors to Elizabeth boys involved in less serious cases of juvenile delinquency.

BAGHDAD, Iraq, Nov. 22 (AP) -- The Iraqi Cabinet resigned today after city-wide clashes between the police and demonstrators in which one man was killed and twenty civilians and thirty-eight policemen were injured.

THIS is the fourth full-length book on Korea by Robert Oliver, and it is by all odds the best of the lot. It is in some respects the most informative and the most moving of any of the analyses of the Korean conflict that have come to this reviewer's attention.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- The institution of patronage, which will be one of the most vexing problems facing Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower when he takes office as President on Jan. 20, must be credited to the founding fathers.

TOKYO, Nov. 22 -- With the election of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower as President of the United States and his approaching journey to Korea, his "Asians against Asians" remark in his campaign speech at Champaign, Ill., has now become the subject of much absorbed consideration.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- Army personnel scheduled for release from active duty between Dec. 20, 1952, and Jan. 5, 1953, with some exceptions, will be separated from the Army no later than Dec. 19, Secretary of the Army Frank Pace Jr. announced today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio casts across the incoming Congress a shadow so long that it will surely reach the White House in the new tenancy of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower as President of the United States.

NORFOLK, Va., Nov. 22 (AP) -- A Navy court of inquiry will meet Monday to consider the case of Capt. Arthur C. Jackson and his watch officers who were on duty aboard the fast Navy transport Ruchamkin when she was rammed off the Virginia Capes by the tanker Washington a week ago yesterday.

TORONTO, Nov. 22 (UP) -- Two second-period goals by Maurice (Rocket) Richard enabled the Montreal Canadiens to gain a 2-2 tie with the Toronto Maple Leafs tonight before 14,157 National Hockey League fans.

LONDON, Nov. 22 (Reuters) -- With their attack disorganized by an injury to forward Denis Wilshaw, the Wolverhampton Wanderers were turned back by Preston North End, 2 -- 0, today, but retained the first division lead in English soccer on a total of 24 points.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Nov. 22 -- Indonesia, racked with political tension, mounting lawlessness and economic crisis, is today facing her greatest test since the Dutch transferred sovereignty into Indonesian hands just three years ago next month.

The winter berries light the woods and the roadside, unusually numerous and altogether festive. They garland the woods, and black alders make a gay display of vivid red along the roadside. Holly red, for the black alder is Ilex verticillata, deciduous cousin of the familiar Christmas holly.

MADRID, Nov. 17 -- The Government censorship bureau has forbidden the publication of a book written by one of Spain's leading monarchists, who urged Generalissimo Francisco Franco to undertake a series of political reforms for the restoration of democratic liberties under a constitutional monarchy.

PHILADELPHIA -- The Photographic Society of Philadelphia, the oldest camera club in the United States, will be ninety years old on Wednesday. To mark the event, an exhibition of photographs and apparatus illustrating the activities of the society's members over the years opened here last week at the American Museum of Photography, 338 South Fifteenth Street.

Dwight D. Eisenhower may have had moments during the past week when he wished that he had quietly taken his retirement from the Army and gone fishing. A new book of regulations has been compiled by the Fire Department marking the first consolidation into one volume of various guides and orders for the uniformed personnel, Fire Commissioner Jacob Grumet announced last week. The book is being distributed.

TRENTON, Nov. 22 (AP) -- The Attorney General's office is preparing a report on the Harold Adonis case in a move to meet a rising wave of questions.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Nov. 22 (AP) -- Thin and gaunt, two young service men were taking it easy today after wandering, lost, for a month and a half in the sprawling Okefenokee swamplands of South Georgia.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- General Eisenhower is now paying off his election debts. PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 22 (AP) -- Bob Haner and Gene Filipski ignored a steady rain and a mud-caked field to run Villanova's football team to an easy 51-6 victory over Boston University today and a possible Bowl bid.

Vice Commodore Clarence E. Emery of the New York Athletic Club probably will succeed to the three-star commodoreship of the Winged Foot Yachting Department this week. He has been installed as the unanimous choice of the nominating committee, headed by Col. Edward N. Mitchell, to succeed Commodore Eugene J. Hynes.

MIDDLETOWN, N. Y., Nov. 22 -- A resolution censoring Senator Wayne Morse of Oregon for "long indicating his absence of Republican ideas and ideals," was rejected after considerable discussion today by representatives of 200 New York State Young Republican Clubs at a quarterly meeting of the group.

MIAMI, Fla., Nov. 22 (AP) -- Nat Herzfeld. president of Tropical Park, said today he had appealed to Gov. Fuller Warren to settle the finger-printing dispute which threatens to delay the Thanksgiving Day start of Florida's horse racing season.

MANY children, when they first become aware of the natural world, are fascinated by insects. In the first of these attractive and informative nature hooks for children. Mary Adrian puts the life cycle of the honeybee into simple story form.

Mrs. Richard Kaye Korn heads the benefit committee, and James M. Snowden is president of the beneficiary's board of directors.

Merchants did better last week than in the 1951 period, but still were disappointed over the results. Observers estimated the advance in sales at 7 to 8 per cent, only half the gain the stores had expected. Because Thanksgiving fell in the 1951 week the latest period had six selling days against five last year.

A program to advance American understanding of Asia has been undertaken by the American Council of Learned Societies. With a Ford Foundation grant of $250,000 for three years, the council will prepare the way for the study in American colleges and universities of twenty commonly neglected Oriental languages and civilizations.

A LITTLE man from Hollywood who operates a large and overlapping television film enterprise out of his back pocket was in town last week enmeshed in assorted deals, present and pending. He is Don W. Sharpe, who is split three ways as TV program packager, producer and talent manager.

EIGHT hundred and fifty persons, most of them from 6 to 12 years old, will attend a premiere this afternoon in an off-Broadway theatre opening its fourth season of professional adult performances of new and adapted plays for children.

W. Gatov, chairman of the Federal Maritime Board.

Critics have found the plot of the Metropolitan Opera's first revival of the season -- Verdi's "La Forza del Destino" -- complicated. So, as a service to the patrons, John Gutman, the Met's assistant general manager, supplies this guide to the story, in lucid rhymed narrative.

The bee and the horseshoe crab never lose their way. The reason is that their eyes are sensitive to polarized light. The bee receives the reflected image of the sun on the retina of its eye by means of a polarized skylight, with the result that it has a navigational reference point to guide it.
ESSEX, N. Y., Nov. 22 (AP) -- A fifty-four-foot gunboat, sunk on the Vermont side of Lake Champlain during the Revolutionary War, has been brought to the surface.

All of us have been saddened by the continuing casualty lists from Korea. Every wound is a sorrow and every death a grief. We take comfort in the fact that our men are fighting in a good cause and that they themselves put the call of duty above their own lives.

WORCESTER, Mass., Nov. 22 (AP) -- Holy Cross' swift sophomore, Lou Hettinger, scored thrice -- once on a 58-yard aerial play from Charlie Maloy -- today as the bowl-minded Crusaders whipped Temple's Owls, 28 -- 0, in mud and rain for their seventh triumph in nine starts.

DALLAS, Nov. 22 (UP) -- Baylor's Bears knocked Southern Methodist out of a chance for a share of the Southwest Conference championship today by holding Southern Methodist to a 7-to-7 tie before 30,000 rain-drenched homecoming fans.

ASUNCION, Paraguay, Nov. 21 -- The anti-Yankee efforts of President Juan D. Peron's Argentine regime are considerable here. It is doubtful that they have a serious influence, but unquestionably they have some effect.

Persons active in behalf of the Institute for the Crippled and Disabled have taken over the matinee performance of Puccini's "La Boheme" on Dec. 27 at the Metropolitan Opera House to raise funds for the organization. Bruce Barton is president of the board of trustees of the beneficiary.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Nov. 22 -- Political moves set on foot by South Africa's constitutional crisis are making strange bedfellows.
Inclement weather yesterday did not deter 30,000 philatelic enthusiasts from attending the National Postage Stamp Show.

Now that the election is over and a new Administration is about to take office, we probably have not heard the end of the topic of political morality.

THE hostess can get "good mileage" out of that dozen roses, chrysanthemums or carnations she is presented with around holiday time, provided the flowers are handled with care. Four topnotch florists, who were consulted on the subject last week, have a few suggestions to make on this score.

CHAPEL HILL, N. C., Nov 22 (AP) -- Red Smith scored three touchdowns, one on a 66-yard romp, to lead Duke to a 34-0 victory over North Carolina today. The triumph gave the Blue Devils the Southern Conference championship.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, who had expressed a desire for "plain and simple" ceremonies to mark his inauguration as President, is going to get the usual elaborate program after all.

A new and modified plan for an early reconstruction of the street system at the Manhattan end of the Brooklyn Bridge was made public yesterday by Manhattan Borough President Robert F. Wagner Jr. The scheme would cost about $5,000,000, or $2,000,000 less than an earlier proposal.

HARTFORD, Conn., Nov. 22 -- Connecticut's General Assembly meets for its biennial session the first week in January with indications that major emphasis would be placed on the growing state budget and the prospect of heavy new taxes.

The chemical industry has passed from the "coal tar" age to that of petrochemistry. As a result it has been largely dispersed from the coal-bearing Middle Atlantic States to the Gulf Coast and the Midwest. And it is expanding at a rate unmatched by any other industry since the war.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 20 -- A panel of four leading art experts has compiled a catalogue for the United Nations of the world's best prints of outstanding paintings from 1860 to the present.
