LANCASTER, Pa., Nov. 22 (AP) -- Gettysburg's manpower and the mud combined today to end the seven-game winning streak of Franklin and Marshall as the Bullets took a 20-6 decision in the annual contest between the schools.

NORMAN, Okla., Nov. 22 -- Oklahoma rolled up three first period touchdowns behind Quarterback Eddie Crowder today, then coasted to a 34-to-13 victory over Nebraska, giving the Sooners their fifth straight outright Big Seven championship.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., Nov. 22 (AP) -- Fullback Gerry Furst ignited Virginia's explosive running attack with a brilliant display in the last two quarters and the Cavaliers, trailing 7 -- 0 at the half, came from behind to whip Washington and Lee, 21 -- 14, before 14,000 here today.
Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the President-elect, expects to complete the selection of his Cabinet before leaving for Korea in the near future, according to the best information available yesterday.

CHIHUAHUA, Mexico, Nov. 22 (AP) -- Karl Kling's Mercedes Benz and a Lincoln, piloted by Chuck Stevenson of Lynwood, Calif., took over the top spots in the Pan-American road race today as the five-day marathon moved swiftly toward the finish tomorrow.
MOBILE, Ala., Nov. 22 (AP) -- A fired up Alabama team handed Maryland its second upset defeat in a row today with a strong ground attack that overwhelmed the Terps, 27 to 7, before 33,178 fans.

Proposals for changes in the state election law to lessen the opportunity for underworld links with political organizations came yesterday from two Democratic officials as a result of the recent disclosures of the State Crime Commission.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Nov. 22 -- To the United States the biggest issue in this past week's Greek elections was the question of internal security in a strategically located country where Washington has invested considerably more than $2 billion of the taxpayers' money during the last five years.

A COLLECTIVE contract lately signed by the Spanish Government with the California Range Association, which takes care of labor requirements of wool growers in twelve Western States, guarantees to immigrant Basque shepherds between $175 and $200 a month, in addition to food and the trailer-tent that is their lodging when they are out on the ranges.

TORONTO, Nov. 22 (AP) -- The French equestrian jumping team tonight won the International Challenge trophy at the Royal Agricultural Winter Fair for the second time in eighteen years. Ireland finished second, the United States third and Canada fourth.

TULSA, Nov. 22 (AP) -- Howard Waugh, a battering fullback, and Tom Miner, who specializes in place kicking, powered Tulsa's bowl-eager Hurricanes to a 44-34 triumph over Arkansas today. The Razorbacks went all out in an effort to give Otis Douglas, their coach who has resigned, a parting victory.

The Metropolitan schoolboy football program suffered an almost complete washout yesterday. The mythical City P. S. A. L. title game between Lafayette and Erasmus Hall, scheduled for Brooklyn College Field, was postponed to Thanksgiving Day.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Nov. 22 -- After a four-hour session tonight, the Indonesian Cabinet issued a formal statement accusing the armed forces of having played politics and warning that the Government no longer would tolerate such activities. The statement was issued after renewed talks earlier today among President Sukarno, Premier Wilopo and high Army officers.

TAMPA, Fla., Nov. 22 -- Jesse Walton Hunter, the state attorney who led the prosecution in the Groveland rape case trials, is himself awaiting trial here following his indictment on Tuesday by a Federal grand jury in Jacksonville on a charge of having violated the rights of a young Negro paratrooper.

In legal theory the structure of Tammany Hall -- the Democratic party organization in New York County -- is a representative democracy. The party functionaries on the lowest level, the county committeemen, are chosen by direct vote of enrolled Democrats. The committeemen elect the district leaders who form the Executive Committee that chooses the county boss. He is known, simply and officially, as The Leader.

SONLA AIRFIELD, Vietnam, Indo - China, Nov. 22 -- Small French-led garrisons in the Thai country, from posts up to fifty miles northwest and southeast of here, were fighting their, way toward this southern Thai defense bastion today.

DENVER, Nov. 22 -- Sigma Delta Chi, professional journalistic fraternity, authorized today a "comprehensive survey" of the coverage of the 1952 Presidential campaign by newspapers, magazines, radio and television.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 22 -- Although the 1952 session of the General Assembly has now been under way for six weeks, only two things can be said about it with certainty: It has accomplished virtually nothing, and it would have been much better if the Assembly had been postponed until after the inauguration of President-elect Dwight D. Eisenhower.

EASTON, Pa., Nov. 22 -- A 23-yard touchdown pass in the last 90 seconds enabled Lehigh University to defeat Lafayete, 14 -- 7, today before 12,000 who witnessed the eighty-eighth game between the rivals. The series, the longest unbroken football rivalry in the nation, started in 1884.

CHORE FOR THE WEEK: Keep foliage of house plants clean and shining by wiping with a damp cloth or spraying with water under the faucet at least once every two weeks. Brush woolly-leaved plants. This prevents insects such as red spider from getting a start. Turn plants around occasionally so that they grow evenly and not just on the one side toward the light.

BIRDS are not only useful garden visitors, but their interesting activities make them a pleasure to have around -- particularly in winter. By providing congenial surroundings for them the birds can be persuaded to live their busy lives near enough to habitation so the would-be observer can keep a watch on their domestic activities.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, Sunday, Nov. 23 -- Harold John Adonis, former executive clerk to Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll of New Jersey, was arrested here last night by the Dutch police. He is under indictment by a Bergen County, N. J., gland jury on bribery charges.

BOSTON, Nov. 22 -- For the first time since its establishment as a nation, Israel is now in a position to embark on long-range planning to achieve economic stability, two prominent American experts on the infant state asserted here today. They held that this was being made possible by a combination of outside assistance and financial reforms instituted by the Israeli Government.

Throughout the United States Roman Catholic parishes will be transformed into collection centers beginning today for the annual Thanksgiving clothing drive of the War Relief Services - National Catholic Welfare Conference.

ONE of Rudolf Bing's highly commendable objectives as director of the Metropolitan Opera Association is to infuse fresh dramatic blood into the productions. Pursuing his objective, he has on occasion engaged celebrated actors and producers of spoken drama to bring fresh and modern ideas of stage production to replace outworn routine of operatic convention and thus to renovate the interpretation of the repertoire.

LINCOLN, R. I., Nov. 22 -- Little Tony DeSpirito renewed his quest for the world's riding record today at Lincoln Downs, where the 17-year-old youngster bounced back from a sick bed to score three winners and a second with four mounts.

DUNNELLON, Fla. -- How many, many times does a Florida citizen, transplanted from the North, hear from his friends or associates, "Do you know of any place in Florida where you can wear old clothes, fish and get away from it all and where it is cheap?" Dunnellon and its surrounding countryside appear to be a reasonable answer to this appeal.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- State Department officials expressed disappointment tonight over the split between the United States and Britain over the proposed changes in India's resolution on the repatriation of Korean prisoners of war.

The killing of Gaspare Ingergiola, 63 years old, they confessed, was the culmination of a three-hour crime spree.

AFTER eleven years of research conducted in many kinds of bad weather, the National Safety Council has evolved six basic rules for safe winter driving. Tests extended over thousands of miles of snow-piled roads, icy pavements and frozen lakes, were completed last year under the direction of Prof. Ralph A. Moyer, research engineer at the University of California's institute of transportation and traffic engineering.

Having skidded into a position where another defeat would just about eliminate them as a title contender as a result of their collapse against Green Bay last Sunday, the New York Football Giants will face the Washington Redskins in Washington today.

ALTHOUGH the plays being presented at the Mark Hellinger by the Greek National Theatre Company are not in the ancient Greek of Sophocles, but the spoken language of Modern Greece -- in translation, this fact need be no deterrent to full enjoyment of them.

A reign of terror that includes murder, torture, imprisonment and exile is being conducted in Venezuela under the junta, according to Dr. Antonio M. Araujo, former Ambassador of Venezuela to the United States.

VIENNA, Nov. 22 -- Striking new facts and figures about the "Russian plan for the spoliation of Austria" will be published tomorrow by the Arbeiter Zeitung, chief organ of the Austrian Socialist party in the first of a series of articles on this subject.

MORRIS PLAINS, N. J., Nov. 22 -- The Morris County Municipal Services, Inc., which, through its police radio network, has helped to fight crime in this area for the last five years, will make it even more difficult for thieves to operate in northern New Jersey.

NATIVE partisans of Gilbert and Sullivan, and those with a particular affection for Martyn Green, whose assorted antics as erstwhile chief comedian of the D'Oyly Carte Company of London they have enjoyed all too infrequently in the past, may be pardoned if they are beginning to regard this as their jubilee year.

In some diseases of the heart the lower, large chambers (ventricles) fail to pump regularly, so that the supply of blood to the system is retarded. If the heart ceases to beat, patients may have convulsions or sink into unconsciousness; if the heart stops too long, death is the outcome; if pumping blood over a period of time can be kept up, there is a good chance that the heart will resume its normal beating.

INDORE, India, Nov. 10 -- Hundreds of villagers today demonstrated to the Maharajah of Indore and his American wife, the former Fay Watt Crane of Los Angeles, that in democratic India a prince can still reign in the hearts of his former subjects, though he is no longer their ruler.

An order halting the erection of all temporary living quarters for crews of anti-aircraft guns in the metropolitan area has been issued by headquarters of the Fifty-second Anti-Aircraft Artillery Brigade, Fort Wadsworth, S. I.

BERNARD DeVOTO writes history in the grand manner. His book rests on a solid foundation in the sources if Mr. DeVoto has not read them all, only two or three men are competent to say so -- but it is also a work of art in the sense that it is consciously designed to engage the reader's imagination as well as his desire to be informed.

Buying of spring apparel was heavy in the wholesale markets here last week, with retailers attempting to keep supplies in line with the current high level of consumer income, according to McGreevey, Werring Howell Company, resident buying office. Retailers have been concentrating on quality goods and will place about 60 per cent of their spring commitments on better merchandise.

CALCUTTA, India, Nov. 22 -- The Chinese community here intends to start a movement soon called the Anti-Communist Nationalist Salvation Movement. One of its main purposes will be to combat a Communist campaign to indoctrinate the community.

It is the misfortune of our public that it can only hear Arturo Toscanini as the interpreter of opera when he conducts passages from operas in concert form with the N. B. C. Symphony Orchestra, as he did yesterday broadcasting the second act of Gluck's "Orpheus and Eurydice" from Carnegie Hall.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Nov. 22 -- New York University's team threatened for a time today to spoil the day for the hosts of the third annual Football Hall of Fame game when they emerged from the first half with a 14 -- 7 lead over Rutgers. But the Violets' lack of man power finally caught up with them and at the end Rutgers had a 27-14 triumph.

WHEN we sit down next Thursday to the well-roasted turkey, the giblet gravy, the crimson cranberries, the creamed onions and the flaky squash pie, we shall be taking part, with good food and warm family feeling, in our only feast of American origin.

LAKEWOOD, N. J. -- Visitors to this popular near-by winter resort now have a 575-acre estate at their disposal. The Ocean County Park, one mile from town on Route 35, is the property of the 10,000 people who visit it each year. The park was once the estate of John D. Rockefeller, and passed from his hands to the ownership of five millionaires as a private resort.

THE best story in every foreign correspondent's repertoire is the one he couldn't write. In theory, at least, a collection of these off-the-record items should open more eyes than the first cup of coffee in the morning.

The retail furniture industry is out to convince railroads that they are pricing themselves out of the furniture freight market, Leo J. Heer, vice president of the National Retail Furniture Association, revealed last week. His organization represents more than 9,000 home furnishings stores throughout the country.
TANGIER, Nov. 22 -- The United States Legation has requested the extradition from Madrid of Sidney Paley, alias Nylon Sid, accused in Morocco of piracy on the high seas.

ESTORIL, Portugal -- For a place that features a casino, year-round beach life and a large colony of only slightly shelf-worn royalty, this is an amazingly inexpensive resort. Its weather and prices should attract many Americans on late fall and winter trips to Europe.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 22 -- The United States, breaking openly and sharply with Britain, turned down tonight India's formula for ending the Korean war.

There seems to be little point in bringing out an abridged German-language version of an opera which already has been recorded several times in its original French, yet this is what Urania has done with its new version of Offenbach's Tales of Hoffman (two disks).

An announcement from Formosa brings the news of one of the most sweeping "land reform" programs in Asia. Early next year more than half a million acres will pass into the hands of the tillers. More than a third of Formosa's farm population will be affected. Landlords will be compensated and the tenants will pay a fair price distributed over twenty years.

An ivory-and-bone ship model, carved in Dartmoor Prison in England about 200 years ago from the original British Admiralty plans, was sold for $500 yesterday on the second day of a two-day auction at O'Reilly's Plaza Art Galleries, Inc.

NEWARK, Nov. 22 -- It will be advantageous to the Christmas shopper with good taste, but limited purse, to visit the Newark Museum's annual exhibit of gift suggestions, which opened to the public this week. It will continue through December.

IN this formidably documented book Telford Taylor, Brigadier General and former chief counsel for the prosecution of war criminals at Nuremberg, covers two terrifying decades of German history. "Sword and Swastika" traces, in a detail that can still bring forth nightmarish memories, the period from Versailles to the German invasion of Poland.

Attention Orange Bowl committee: the number is PEnnsylvania 6-3800. The room number is 1420 and if a man answers he will be Lew Andreas, the director of athletics at Syracuse University. Immediately following Syracuse's 26-13 victory over Fordham yesterday Andreas rushed from Triborough Stadium on Randalls Island to his midtown hotel hopeful of receiving a long-distance call from Miami, Fla.

ANY ideal enthusiasm, any loyalty to duty or commandment, is incidental in man. It cannot be relied upon. You must fortify it by personal appeals, by wages in this world or the other, by some smiling prospect opened to the social conscript.
" Here's that man again" is a phrase that has had a familiar ring to the average American for the last half century.

AUBURN, Ala., Nov. 22 (AP) -- Bill Turnbeaugh, a 265-pound tackle who can barely see the ball, ran into an enemy pass today, held onto it and gave Auburn an opening for a 3-0 gridiron victory over Clemson.
TRENTON, Nov. 22 (AP) -- New Jersey today is about seven years away from acquisition of the Tacony-Palmyra and Burlington-Bristol bridges across the Delaware River.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- Final regulations for operation of the McCarran-Walter Immigration and Nationality Act, which becomes effective Dec. 24, will be published sometime during the week of Dec. 14, Attorney General James P. McGranery announced today.
IOWA CITY, Nov. 22 (AP) -- Notre Dame's football forces gave flustricken Coach Frank Leahy a potent tonic today with a smashing 27-0 victory over Iowa.

CONTRARY to many misconceptions on the subject, modern art for the most part shows contemporary artists trying to bring order out of chaos, forms and categories out of disorder and varieties. A basic impulse of these artists is not to break down a world but to bring an already broken-down world together.

IN this book, posthumously published in English translation, Nicolas Berdyaev, renowned Russian philosopher and theologian, reveals the currents of thought that entered into his theology. Of particular importance are Heraclitus, Boehme and Dostoevsky, but above them all Kant is singled out as the most suggestive. Whatever one's interpretation of Kant, Berdyaev believes his greatest achievement to have been his insistence upon the primacy of freedom.

The meeting between President Truman and General Eisenhower was presumably to discuss some of the principal problems facing the new Administration. What it may augur for the future is not known at this time, but it touched off a wave of optimism in financial circles.

Schedules for the Italian Line's passenger services from Italy to the east and west coasts of South America next year will provide an average of three sailings a month from Genoa to Rio de Janeiro and Buenos Aires as well as monthly departures to South American west coast ports.

THIS will be a book of first-rate importance to those who are in, or interested in, the business of books. It is not a volume on how to be a successful publisher, like Unwin's "Truth About Publishing," or one on the literary experience of publishing, like Burlingame's "Of Making Many Books."

Recognizing the complexities of the problem of the discharge of patients from mental hospitals, Governor Dewey recently requested the New York State Mental Hygiene Council to undertake a thorough review of New York State laws and procedures governing the release of mental patients.
HOUSTON, Nov. 22 (UP) -- Rice Institute turned two blocked punts into touchdowns today to whip Texas Christian University, 12 to 6, in a Southwest Conference game before 33,000.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., Nov. 22 -- The possible explanation of an essential part of the mechanism by which plants store sunlight was reported here tonight by Dr. Melvin Calvin. Professor of Chemistry at the University of California.

MADISON, Wis., Nov. 22 -- Minnesota's Golden Gophers held favored Wisconsin to a 21-21 tie today, but the Badgers backed into a tie for the Big Ten football title and an apparently better-than-average chance at the Western Conference Rose Bowl bid.

LAFAYETTE, Ind., Nov. 22 -- Rex Brock, 160-pound sophomore halfback, splashed through the mud for two touchdowns today and Purdue won a half share of the Big Ten football championship by defeating Indiana, 21 -- 16.

FAR HILLS, N. J., Nov. 22 -- Four hours of rain, wind, mist and fog brought the cocker spaniel open all-age stake to an end in the New Jersey Spaniel Field Trial Club's annual event on the J. C. Brady estate today. When the soggy ordeal was over, Berol Lodge Black Velvet, a 2 1/2-year-old dog from the Berol Lodge Kennels of Chappaqua, N. Y., was the winner.

SYDNEY, Nov. 22 (AP) -- Frank Sedgman of Australia and Maureen Connolly of San Diego, Calif., continued their domination of amateur tennis today as they swept to singles championships in the New South Wales championships.

METRO - GOLDWYN - MAYER appears to be setting the pace for a new trend in movie story fashions which, for want of a better designation, might be termed Hollywood's living biography phase. In the past producers have shown, with an exception here and there, a distinct preference for looking into the lives of persons long since dead.
The new man-made fibers have broadened the horizon for manufacturers of industrial textiles by providing a new series of materials to meet special conditions.

To meet the individual needs of its students, Finch College, an institution for young women in New York City, has evolved an unusual plan for the awarding of degrees. Under this program, two two-year courses of study have been created, leading to bachelor's degrees.
THE traditional parades, football and seasonal musical shows will be among the features offered by television on Thanksgiving Day.

KINGSTON, N. Y., Nov. 22 -- Over vigorous protests of the Ulster County Medical Society, the Ulster County Tumor Clinic was incorporated last night into the County Board of Health to obtain state aid.

LAST week, the Council of Actors Equity, deploring the announcement that drama activities at the City Center had to be suspended because of insufficient funds, appointed a committee to discuss with Center officials what could be done about reactivating the "valuable" project. Concern is understandable and commendable.

IN their hotly determined endeavors to lay resourceful hands on films that will have some attraction for the new movie clientele, the managers of the smaller theatres are nowadays searching far and wide -- indeed, so far and wide they sometimes wander beyond all prudent bounds.

" THE TERRIBLE MR. TWITMYER" is a gay book and a delightful one. The blurb writers have done it no service in saying that the authors have carefully controlled the vocabulary and sentence structure. Maybe they have -- but somehow the words conjure up a dreary, educational atmosphere which seems unrelated to two ladies who are able to consider children, animals and adults with so much humor and goodwill.
The author of "Bernardine" tells here how she sought first-hand information for her play about teen-age boys.

AQUATIC plants may become as much a hobby as the tropical fish for which they provide the necessary aeration. Their presence in the aquarium not only makes for healthy fish but also sets the stage for them.

STORIES, confessions and plays-for-reading are baked together in this spiced vol-au-vent. Maude Hutchins visits Mormon country in "Joseph Smith Jr.," a one-scene play that smiles wanly at the futile love-hungry insistence of Joseph's youngest wife.

PARIS, Nov. 22 -- The provisions for a draft constitution for a European political community are taking shape in the subcommittees of the Ad Hoo (Special) Assembly of the European Coal and Steel Community (Schuman plan) that have been hard at work here for the last ten days.

The market for those basic investments, obligations of the United States Government, is already reflecting tax-selling and other transient year-end influences that tend traditionally to keep it supplied with certain investments and, thereby, to hold prices in check.

An employe in the legal department of the Third Avenue Transit Corporation barricaded himself in a bedroom of his home in the Bronx last night and fired two wild shots at policemen after members of his family had called an ambulance because, they said, he had been acting strangely.
BOWIE, Md., Nov. 22 (UP) -- Larry MacPhail, president of Bowie race track, said today he would not stand in the way of shifting Bowie's racing program to Pimlico if the weather made it necessary.

WITH A U. S. DIVISION, In Korea, Nov. 18 -- The motorist rolling along the West Side Highway in New York or the Merritt Parkway just doesn't know how well off he is. He imagines his lot is a hard one on a summer week-end, when traffic thickens and he finds himself traveling bumper to bumper, with both his temper and radiator coming to a boil.

THE bomb that exploded over Hiroshima on a fine August morning seven years ago was made from a rare variant of uranium. Now, in new tests at Eniwetok in the far Pacific, another sort of atomic explosion has been set off -- the explosion of rare variants of hydrogen. Such words as "uranium" and "hydrogen" have in the past few years stepped out of the laboratory into our waking dreams.

ON Thanksgiving Day this year something over 30,000,000 turkeys will be served up. They will be a fragrant, sizzling brown, plump and full of juice and looking just the way Thanksgiving turkeys should look. But, by golly, it's surprising that they ever get that way.Because the turkey is a real gone bird, with more ways of not ending up on a platter than any other domesticated critter ever schemed out.

OUR task in the next four years is that of preserving freedom at home and extending freedom abroad; a task so great in this perilous time that any dalliance with the idea of relaxation or retrogression becomes a crime.

BOSTON, Nov. 22 (UP) -- Four convicts, two of them life-term killers, staged a two-hour rebellion at Massachusetts' old state prison today. They held two guards hostage and set two small fires before giving up.

THE Pierce family leave their comfortable small town home, journey 750 miles to start anew in a primitive prairie dugout -- and all without leaving their home state. It could only happen in Texas, and Texas is the scene of the Pierces' migration.
GAINESVILLE, Fla., Nov. 22 (AP) -- Florida defeated Miami, 43 -- 6, today and won an invitation to play in the Gator Bowl on New Year's Day.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 22 (AP) -- A midnight earthquake shook and twisted a 500-mile strip of the California coast last night and early today from San Francisco to Los Angeles.

BOSTON, Nov. 22 -- Members of the New England Council, who characteristically think twice before they speak, especially for publication, were saying privately today that the election of Laurence F. Whittemore as the organization's fourteenth president might prove to be the impetus to get the region "off dead center."

With reference to Brooks Atkinson's stimulating article, "Birds' Civilization -- and Man's" (Nov. 16), it might be noted that certain birds do not wait until migration time to emphasize their ownership of their segments of earth, air and sea. One had only to wait for twilight on a beautiful Massachusetts beach last summer to perceive the herring gulls and the sandpipers taking over.

VIVIENNE SEGAL, sleek, slim and poised apologized for being slightly late -- she had been getting her husband off on a train to California -- then settled back on the sofa of her living room high above Fifth Avenue, and said simply, "Let's talk about 'Pal Joey.'"

Korea is a gnarled land of glacial rock and ancient loam 600 miles long, 135 miles wide. It has little natural wealth. It has limited strategic military value. Yet for two and a half years the forces of eighteen nations -- sixteen on the side of the U.N., two on the side of the Communists -- have been locked in battle in Korea.

THE art of acting, to a person of Joseph Cotten's soft-spoken objectivity, also happens to signify a job. Having held down a steady one for a number of years on Broadway and in a succession of rather sombre screen roles, the actor visited town last week during a personal tour for "The Steel Trap" with some data about his next Fox vehicle, "Niagara," and his frank incentive, a good, healthy appetite.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 (UP) -- The Senate Elections Subcommittee disclosed today that it would question Senator William Benton, Democrat of Connecticut, in a closed session Monday on his charges of unfitness against Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin.
TOKYO, Sunday, Nov. 23 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,442, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Sunday, Korea time:

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 22 -- Most countries that depend on the export of raw materials and prime commodities to pay for imports of capital goods and manufactured goods are seriously concerned about recent declines in commodity prices.

STILLWATER, Okla., Nov. 22 (UP) -- Washington State shaded Oklahoma A. and M. by 9 to 7 today with an eight-yard field goal kicked by End Ed Barker from a difficult angle, but the score was misleading.

On October 5, when the first advertisement for "The Millionairess" appeared in your newspaper, I sent my check to the Shubert Theatre for two $3.60 seats to any performance. It was returned with the note: "We are sorry to inform you that due to the limited engagement, Theatre Guild subscriptions, theatre parties, and the heavy demand for tickets, we are unable to fill your order as specified."
PITMAN, N. J. Nov. 22 -- A community-supported fund is being raised here to aid a mother and her two sons, all blinded in one eye within the last eight months.

MARITIME nations last week placed in effect on a worldwide basis a new set of rules covering safety at sea in the transportation of cargo and passengers. The rules represent the most stringent and comprehensive blueprint for seagoing reliability ever promulgated.

A RUTGERS anthropologist, Ashley Montagu, recently wrote a book backing up the Unesco "statement on race," a joint manifesto aimed at dispelling racial intolerance. Now he takes a critical look at Darwin's theory of evolution.

THIS is a book for many people those anxious to understand the fundamental changes taking place in Asia, those interested in discovering a strong and attractive personality through her autobiography, or those who want a well-written love story.

Experts can learn from children clues to what constitutes happy family life, a group of experts were told yesterday at a conference on family life arranged by health, welfare and community agencies at Hunter College High School.

The "woodshed" method of treating delinquent youngsters was recommended yesterday by Magistrate Abner C. Surpless in Brooklyn Felony Court when two youths were arraigned before him for the hold-up murder of 63-year-old Gasper Ingargiola, a grocer.
BOSTON, Nov. 23 (UP) -- Boston's battling Bruins rolled up their highest score of the season tonight, but beat Toronto only by 6 -- 5 before 8,834 Boston Garden fans.

BUFFALO, Nov. 23 -- Educators must overcome their sensitivity to criticism and admit there is room for improvement in the country's public schools, 700 delegates of the New York State Teachers Association were told here tonight.

Nora Kaye and Hugh Laing made their season's first appearances with the New York City Ballet last night at the City Center, and since they are without peers as dramatic dancers in the entire field of the ballet, it was a distinguished occasion.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 (AP) -- Japan and the Philippines are making rapid progress in airway and airport-facility development, the Civil Aeronautics Administration reported today.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 23 (UP) -- The Pittsburgh Steelers used recovered fumbles to set up a field goal and a touchdown in the first period and then marched seventy-six yards for a last-quarter touchdown to defeat the Chicago Cardinals, 17 -- 14, today for their first home victory in five starts.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, Nov. 24 -- Harold J. Adonis, former executive clerk to Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll of New Jersey, was under arrest here today at the State Department's request pending extradition proceedings seeking to return him to Bergen County to face an indictment for bribery.

CHICAGO, Nov. 23 -- Uncertainty over Korean peace developments occurred during customary liquidation of December grain contracts, and with crop news more favorable as the result of recent rains there was small incentive to buy futures.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 23 (AP) -- The Los Angeles Rams, defending champions, put on another demonstration of long-range scoring today to sink the San Francisco 49ers by a 35-9 margin and throw the Western division of the National Football League into a four-way tie.
Six new films, including an importation from England, are slated to arrive in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:

With the North Atlantic Council scheduled to meet on Dec. 15 to plan the further progress of Western defense, the present officials in charge of the Mutual Security Program are beginning to voice concern over the possibility that the incoming Republican Administration will drastically reduce the funds for that program and thus scrap whatever remains of the original timetable for European rearmament.

When Irving Berlin gets enthused, thermonuclear fusion becomes outmoded. Not long ago his wife suggested that he read the newly published book by Cleveland Amory, "The Last Resorts: A Portrait of American Society at Play."

In special instances the United Hospital Fund has distributed sums to hospitals that answer a demonstrated need. The most recent of these has been given to a hospital that is conducting an investigation designed to learn the extent to which medical knowledge can prevent illness in a representative group of New York families. Scientists hope to nip budding physical illnesses or to detect advance signs of mental disturbances so as to suggest early treatment.

Employment in the United States is so high and business is so good that some business men are worried. As A. H. Raskin put it in a summary of a national survey made by this newspaper, they fear that 1953 will bring a slump because "things are just too good to continue."

Christmas is just six weeks off. Time is running short. It's a last-minute call gift-making. To be useful to you. Patterns of The Times today offers you nine suggestions for quickly made and attractive presents.

After sharp declines in the initial dealings last week, cotton prices in the domestic market shifted to a backing and filling process and closed the period irregularly lower. At the windup on Friday, prices on the New York Cotton Exchange were down 82 points to up 10 points.

BUFFALO, Nov. 23 -- A master plan for development of park and parkway facilities of the Niagara Frontier was announced here last week by the Niagara Frontier Park Commission. It would consolidate all frontier state parks from Grand Island to Lake Ontario.

The second International Art Film Festival in America will start a three-day engagement Friday at the Hunter College Auditorium. Thirty-six films have been selected from 200 subjects submitted by twenty-three countries. These will be shown in five programs, with matinees Friday, Saturday and Sunday, and evening performances Friday and Sunday at 8:30 o'clock.

Hopes for a year of labor peace on the city's daily newspapers hit a snag yesterday when members of New York Typographical Union, No. 6, A. F. L., rejected a proposed wage and welfare agreement with the New York City Newspaper Publishers Association.
ALBANY, Nov. 23 (AP) -- President Truman's personal plane, the Independence, sent the United States air defense system here into high gear for a jittery ten minutes today.

A pioneer plan by which medical societies will supply top-notch independent experts to aid the Supreme Court here in personal injury cases was announced yesterday as a new device for solving the problem of conflicting medical claims filed by plaintiffs and defendants.

DALLAS, Nov. 23 -- The United States Weather Bureau settled a wrangle today between drought - stricken Dallas and neighboring Fort Worth over which city was getting the most out of a rain-making firm Dallas had hired.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Nov. 23 -- The smaller Western Allies have received thus far only crumbs from the table of the United States offshore program of procurement of military equipment, the Netherlands feels, and better procedures are needed if these countries are to be enabled to make fuller use of their industrial capacity and finance their own defense production programs.

CAIRO, Nov. 23 -- Studies undertaken under the United States Point Four program of technical cooperation indicate that the widely dispersed project has in Egypt its first opportunity to make a major contribution to helping an Arab Government set up insurance against communism.

The 50,000,000,000-gallon Rondout Reservoir, southeastern-most basin in New York's new $420,000,000 Delaware River water supply system, has been completed and is pouring about 250,000,000 gallons a day into aqueducts and tunnels for consumption in the city.

MEXICO CITY, Nov. 23 -- An overture from the Communist-dominated Confederation of Latin American Workers to join forces in the fight against "imperialism" received cold treatment today from the federation being formed here under Argentine sponsorship.

Several thousand persons attended dedication ceremonies yesterday in which a Parks Department area on Houston Street between First Avenue and Avenue A was officially named I. L. Peretz Square in honor of a writer recognized as the father of modern Jewish literature.

Puccini's "Madama Butterfly" received its first presentation of the season Saturday night at the Metropolitan. Victoria de los Angeles reaped a personal triumph in the title role, despite the fact that in the last part of the second act she twisted her foot and was in pain during the rest of the opera.

FARMINGDALE, N. J., Nov. 23 -- The Kalmucks a band of modern pilgrims who were homeless wanderers until they settled near here last year, will be able to celebrate the American Thanksgiving in their own house of worship, which they dedicated today.

HANOI, Vietnam, Indo-China, Nov. 23 -- Recent developments in the Indo-China fighting have produced a situation rare in warfare: A fortified position, completely surrounded by enemy troops in enemy territory, is pitting, itself against enemy attacks while dependent entirely on air transportation for supplies and other support.

A cut of 7 1/2 per cent in the city's payroll costs, estimated to save $25,500,000 annually, has been suggested to the Mayor's Committee on Management Survey by its headquarters staff, it became known yesterday.

Continued high levels of employment have again caused reductions in this city's relief rolls, with October producing the greatest drop of the current year, Commissioner of Welfare Henry L. McCarthy reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 (UP) -- The Department of Agriculture said today that exports of American farm products during September showed a 29 per cent drop from a year ago.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- The continuing story of America's $82,000,000,000 effort to help other countries help themselves and us in the past eleven years is set forth chronologically and in detail in a publication released today by the Office of Business Economics of the Department of Commerce.

BAGHDAD, Iraq, Nov. 23 -- Gen. Nur Aldin Mahmoud, Army Chief of Staff, formed a new civilian Cabinet today and took over rule of Iraq under martial law after rioting mobs set fire to a United States Information Service building, attacked two police stations and stoned the British Embassy.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- A high Administration defense official urged caution tonight as many new proposals to end the stalemate in the Korean war were being advanced.

As one of the 400,000 enrolled members of the Democratic party in New York County and as one of the 6,000 members of the Democratic County Committee of New York County, in whose behalf the Hon. Carmine DeSapio issued his statement on Nov. 19, I am by no means "justly and sincerely proud" of the standing of the Democratic party in New York County.

JERUSALEM, Nov. 23 -- The Zionist movement, which has been described in the Prague trial of Rudolph Slansky and thirteen others as an instrument of Western espionage and sabotage, disputed today "with the utmost contempt the fabric of falsehoods presented by the authors of the trial proceeding in Prague."

BOSTON, Nov. 23 -- Delegates from Jewish communities of this country and Canada endorsed by a heavy majority here today the stand of those national and local Jewish groups that have called for a redivision of responsibilities in the Jewish community relations field to avoid duplication.

The reading of the changes in the temperature of the earth, as measured by the huge glacial "thermometers" in the northern latitudes, still does not reveal conclusively whether the earth is heating up or cooling down, scientists of the American Geographical Society reported here last week.

VIENNA, Nov. 23 -- Defendants in the treason trial of Rudolf Slansky, Vladimir Clementis and twelve other leading Czechoslovak Communists in Prague blamed themselves today for everything that is wrong with the Czechoslovak economy, from food rationing to the decline of foreign trade.
Montville (Monte) Peck, athletic director at Phillips Academy, Andover, Mass., was leaning against a goal post at Brothers Field the other afternoon.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 23 -- The Screen Actors Guild has set Dec. 1 as the date for its strike against producers of filmed television commercials, after the cancellation of negotiations for a collective-bargaining contract covering wages, limitation on repeated use of the same commercial and other working conditions.

The importance of community programs in which foster parents can meet to consider special problems in caring for children temporarily away from home is discussed in a report released today by the State Charities Aid Association.

Robert Frost, the poet, was the subject yesterday afternoon of the National Broadcasting Company's second televised conversation with elder leaders in different fields. It was a fascinating study of the man land his philosophy -- a close-up in more than the visual sense.

FAR HILLS, N. J., Nov. 23 -- F. T. Ch. Nimrod Tom of Fairview, a big black and white 5 1/2-year-old dog belonging to Kingsley Kunhardt of Greenwich, won the English springer spaniel open-all-age stake that brought the meeting of the New Jersey Spaniel Field Trial Club to a close today. It was the final spaniel event until the nationals next month.
SYRACUSE, N. Y., Nov. 23 (AP) -- Red Rocha's three-pointer with three seconds left gave the Syracuse Nationals a 76-73 victory over the New York Knickerbockers tonight.

The series of recent accidents on the New Jersey Turnpike has not shaken the confidence of safety engineers that the 118-mile superhighway was properly designed. While they attribute the mishaps primarily to mechanical and human failures they recognize a responsibility to improve safety standards and have acted with commendable dispatch to cut driving hazards under adverse weather conditions.

Verdi's "Don Carlo" will be performed for the first time this season on Tuesday, Dec. 2, as a highlight of the fourth week of opera at the Metropolitan. Alberto Erede will conduct the work for the first time here, Paul Schoeffler will make his first Metropolitan appearance as the Grand Inquisitor and Laura Castellano will be heard for the first time as Theobald.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 23 -- The Stanley Kramer Company, an independent producing organization affiliated with Columbia Pictures, has "drastically shaken up" its production plans, following a series of conferences between Mr. Kramer and Columbia officials in New York.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 (AP) -- Representative Clarence E. Kilburn, Republican of New York, has initiated a move to transfer the site of a $28,00,000 Air Force base from the Plattsburg, T. Y., barracks to Camp Drum, N. Y., his office said today.

Formal dedication by the Georgia Port Authority of the $15,000,000 dock and warehouse complex at Savannah marks a transport milestone in the expanding economy of the South. The port facility is on a 407-acre site along the Savannah River, eighteen miles in from the Atlantic.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 23 -- If, as some have said, there was a good chance that steel demand and output would slip off somewhat in the next seven or eight months, there was no forward sign of it visible last week. Demand was heavy, output was at new records and a general feeling of optimism was evident.

The Canadian dollar bounced back rather smartly last week from the irregularly lower trend which had marked its course the last month. In premium, the dollar climbed from 1 17/32 cent on Monday, to 2 1/4 cent, on Wednesday, with Friday's final of 2 1/16 cent, a gain of 7/16 cent over the preceding week.

CHICAGO, Nov. 23 (UP) -- The Chicago Black Hawks, fighting mad over their 10-1 defeat by the Detroit Red Wings last night, stormed back tonight to shut out the Wings, 3 -- 0. A crowd of 15,962, largest to see a National Hockey League contest this year, cheered the home club.

I ordered recently at one of the leading pork stores in the Bronx half a pound of boiled haul for sandwiches, and I was amazed to see the butcher slicing the ham on a cutting machine in such a manner that freshly cut slices of ham would drop directly upon the extended bare palm of his left hand.

The Long Lines Department of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company announced yesterday that it would transfer its eastern area headquarters from Manhattan to White Plains in Westchester County early in 1954.

The victory of Southern California over U. C. L. A. in the battle of the colossi in the Los Angeles Coliseum, the defeat of Maryland by Alabama, Tennessee's tie with Kentucky in snow-swept Knoxville and the hodge-podge finish in the Big Ten were the more momentous developments Saturday as the intercollegiate football season came to a close for all but a few teams.

The Government of Japan, through Tadaharu Mukai, Minister of Finance, today is announcing its program for the resumption of payments on fourteen issues of Japanese dollar loans involving a total of about $76,000,000.

TOKYO, Monday, Nov. 24 -- United States F-86 Sabre jets fought for a seventh straight day over North Korea yesterday with the Chinese Red Air Force's Russian-designed MIG jets and shot down one of the foe in a two-minute action.

MELVIN B. VOORHEES, a lieutenant colonel in the United States Army and former chief censor with the Eighth Army in Korea, has written a book and is in trouble because of it -- not a unique experience but still hardly the usual fate of authors, who often find their books sinking from sight without causing a ripple.
ALBANY, Nov. 23 (AP) -- There are more automobiles on the roads in New York State this year and they are burning more gasoline than ever before.
BOWIE, Md., Nov. 23 (AP) -- Bowie race track is set to resume its interrupted meeting tomorrow with $20,000 added Barbara Frietchie Handicap as the feature attraction.

One of the welcome results of visits from foreign ensembles is that they always bring some of the flavor of their own country with them. And so it was with the Boyd Neel Orchestra, which made its New York debut yesterday at the New Friends of Music's concert at Town Hall.

MADRID, Nov. 23 -- The Spanish Government released today the texts of an agreement, a protocol and by-laws to modify the present administration of Tangier, all of which were approved by representatives of eight nations, including the United States, at a meeting in that Moroccan international zone Nov. 10.

ELMENDORF AIR FORCE BASE, Alaska, Nov. 23 -- A huge C-124 Globemaster carrying fifty-two service men disappeared over Alaska's mountain-rimmed "graveyard of airplanes" early today while trying to land through heavy fog and lashing winds after a flight from Tacoma, Wash.

It should be emphasized that the various differences that have appeared among the free nations in respect to the truce resolutions in the Korean case that is before the United Nations pertain to questions of approach and method and not to questions of principle.

Events tonight: Wagner's "Lohengrin," Metropolitan Opera, 7:45 o'clock: Toshiya Eto, violinist, Carnegie Hall. 8:30: Little Orchestra Society, Thomas Scherman, conductor. Paul Tortelier, 'cellist, Town Hall, 8:30.

CHICAGO, Nov. 23 -- With a five-day week comparing with four the week before, average daily sales of grain and soybean futures were 55,000,000 bushels last week on the Board of Trade, against 50,000,000 the previous week and 47,000,000 a year ago.

The National Retail Drygoods Association has announced details of its contest for the year's best retail newspaper advertising, radio programs and displays. Howard P. Abrahams, manager of the sales promotion and visual merchandising group, said the newspaper contest will be judged solely on the basis of selling or instiutional results.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 (UP) -- Selective Service Director Lewis B. Hershey will order the drafting of 19-year-olds whenever state boards start running into manpower shortages, officials reported today.

Many Americans will feel relieved when General Eisenhower returns safety from his planned visit to Korea. There are some dangers in the trip, not only from hostile military planes but also from fanatics in South Korea and possibly also in Japan.

Venezuela, which is producing upward of $1,000,000,000 worth of crude oil annually and exporting nearly 2,000,000 barrels of the product daily, is seriously considering the construction of a tanker fleet to transport a major part of this output.

BONN, Germany, Nov. 23 -- A German bishop told Catholics in the Saar today they had no moral obligation to vote in next Sunday's elections. Thus the struggle over the Saar, the first great post-war trial of strength between Germany and France, entered a new phase.

BERLIN, Nov. 23 -- Walter Ulbricht, top Communist in East Germany, implied in a speech published today that his regime might proceed with its rearmament plans regardless of what West Germany does about pending treaties with the West.

Americans who attempt to escape from reality by an unbridled indulgence in alcohol and fantasy are toying with their own mental and physical health, the Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell warned in a sermon yesterday morning at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-fifth Street.

There is a simple way to gain a greater insight into what it means to be blind. If we should close our eyes for about fifteen minutes while our guests are seated around the dinner table, and then continue to eat and participate in the conversation, we would have a new awareness of some of the physical problems that the blind encounter.

A survey of United States Government information activities abroad, conducted this month by twenty-four foreign correspondents of THE NEW YORK TIMES, covering forty-four nations, has revealed a variable record from country to country and from activity to activity.

The recent trend toward larger, faster cargo ships, including this country's new "Mariner" class vessels, holds no interest for Irish Shipping, Ltd., Percy McGrath, a director of the concern, declared yesterday.

UNITED NATIONS, New York, Nov. 23 -- Members of the United Nations Art Club, including professional as well as amateur artists and sculptors from many lands, will open their third annual exhibit tomorrow in the south lobby of the General Assembly building, for the benefit of the United Nations International Children's Emergency Fund.

ROCQUENCOURT, France, Nov. 23 -- Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway, Supreme Allied Commander, who is Commander in Chief of all United States fighting forces in Europe, is taking a close interest in recent reports of unfriendly relations between his men and the European civilian communities in which they are stationed.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 (AP) -- A university professor, in a report written for a Senate Labor subcommittee, said today that state and local laws with "teeth" to forbid job discrimination against minorities had proved to be a "healthy thing."

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 23 -- The foreign trade of the mainland of China has undergone significant changes to the advantage of the Soviet sphere since the Communist regime of Mao Tsetung came to power there, according to the 1951 survey of the economies of the countries of Asia and the Far East, released today in Bangkok by the United Nations Commission for that region.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 (AP) -The National Education Association estimated today there would be 27,533,054 public school pupils enrolled throughout the nation this school year. That is an increase of about 821,000 over the estimated I total of 26,711,656 for 1951-52.

NAIROBI, Kenya, Nov. 23 -- The police fired on Kikuyu tribesmen today, killing fifteen and wounding twenty-seven, in the worst incident in the undeclared war between Mau Mau terrorists and whites in this British colony.
MIAMI, Fla., Nov. 23 (AP) -- Alabama was signed today to play in the Orange Bowl football game New Year's Day.

Theodore Hines, basso cantante, made an appearance in recital at Town Hall yesterday afternoon. A native of Stamford, Conn., Mr. Hines had made his debut with the Negro Opera, Company in 1940 as Ramfis in "Aida," and has been soloist with the DePaur Infantry Chorus.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, President-elect, is working out a plan for reorganizing the Executive Office to bring its various units under over-all supervision of a special assistant who would function as a Secretary General of the Office of the President.

A free and dynamic educational system is the true bulwark of democracy, Mayor Impellitteri said yesterday afternoon at the ninth annual conference of the Council of Organizations of Yeshiva University at the New Yorker Hotel.
ON THE KUMHWA FRONT, in Korea, Nov. 23 (AP) -- Allied officers on this front are sick at heart over the appalling losses in forty-one days of fighting for the Kumhwa ridges.

With the exception of church attendance and a meeting with Paul G. Hoffman, former head of the Economic Cooperation Administration, Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, President-elect, rested yesterday in preparation for a heavy schedule of appointments today.

Far too large a part of family life is given over to the bringing of utterly fantastic charges against the head of the house. This does not just seem so, this is so. In the course of a single day he may be accused of such widely diversified things as failing to put up the storm windows, taking too liberal a helping of breakfast bacon, failing to shave.

Time and space and human life are all "sacramental" because God uses them to work out His plan for the world He created, the Rev. John M. Crotty declared yesterday at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral. He is a member of the staff.

JUAREZ, Mexico, Nov. 23 (AP) -- A German engineer, Karl Kling, in a light Mercedes Benz, and Chuck Stevenson of Fresno, Calif., in a 1953 Lincoln, streaked home to win the Pan-American road race today.

A dispute has developed between the Eisenhower headquarters on one side, and the press news services and the radio and television industry on the other, over the arrangements for the Korean trip of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, President-elect.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 23 -- High-ranking United Nations officials said today that anxiety over possible trouble with labor unions in New York -- above all the fear that the electronic heart of the new headquarters buildings would be brought to a standstill -- had led the world organization to give "serious consideration" to setting up its own telecommunications system.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, Nov. 22 (AP) -- President Victor Paz Estenssoro, who won control of Bolivia in a bloody revolution last April, reshuffled his Cabinet tonight to solidify his control of the Government.
LONDON, Nov. 22 -- It may be of some interest in New Haven that there will be a yale among the Queen's beasts when she arrives at Westminster Abbey next June for her coronation.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- Final settlement of a fourteen-year fight between the Federal Government and coastal states for control of offshore lands, including rich oil deposits, is likely to be one of the first acts of the new Republican regime.

The American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations, left leaderless by the deaths of William Green and Philip Murray, will endeavor this week to pick new presidents to steer them through the economic and political trials that face both union groups.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 23 -- The twenty-one nations that have endorsed the refusal of the United Nations negotiators to agree to the repatriation of Korean prisoners of war against their will decided tonight to ask India for clarification of a revised compromise proposal that was submitted this afternoon.

NEW CITY, N. Y., Nov 23 -- Four hunters from New Jersey, captured last night after an 80-mile-an-hour chase with the carcasses of two illegally killed does in their car, became today the first defendants in lower New York to be held under a new law making poaching a felony.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Nov. 23 -- The establishment of 103 new laboratories or major research additions in the Southern states in the last year was reported today by H. McKinley Conway Jr., director of the Southern Association of Science and Industry.

The American Labor party proposed yesterday six changes in the election law in a memorandum to the State Crime Commission. The proposals were submitted in response to a suggestion by Joseph M. Proskauer, commission chairman, that the views of political parties might be useful in preparing the commission's report to the Legislature.

CLARKSVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 23 -- Monroe Street, normally a quiet residential section of this small tobacco town, was split into two feuding factions today -- those who like to hear a 28-year-old housewife practice singing and those who say her voice sounds like a police siren.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- Kyle Rote and Eddie Price scored the touchdowns, but Fred Benners, the rookie quarterback from Southern Methodist, was the guiding genius behind the attack that carried the New York Giants from nowhere to a 14-10 victory over the Redskins today at Griffith Stadium. It could be that with this performance, the tall Texan with the flat-top crew cut finally has won his spurs as a pro.

It may have come as a surprise to many to learn that the sections of mid-Manhattan given over largely to the fur and garment industries are not restricted for these uses by zoning. These areas, as far as the city's zoning maps are concerned, are "unrestricted," meaning that, at least in theory, activities not in harmony with either the garment or fur centers might gain a foothold in the region.
Three thousand persons attended the annual pre-Thanksgiving service of patriotic societies of New York yesterday afternoon at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine. Fifty-five groups participated.
Sales of residential property in the Park Slope section featured realty activity in Brooklyn reported over the week-end.
LONDON, Nov. 23 -- Britain and her Commonwealth partners meet here next Thursday to hammer out a vast world trade and banking scheme.

PARIS, Nov. 23 -- European experts are expecting the Republican Administration in the United States to launch a drive, if not immediately at least before the end of 1953, in favor of convertibility of currencies and multilateral trade agreements.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- President Truman called on the churches today to wage "ceaseless war" against social injustice and for brotherhood and the better life.

The Right Rev. Horace W. B. Donegan, Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York, said yesterday that he agreed with the Roman Catholic Bishops of the United States who, in a recent statement, deplored what they viewed as a tendency to divorce religion from education in the nation's schools.

ZURICH, Nov. 23 -- Major financial operations involving the export of Swiss investment capital in November have raised the query whether this indicates a change of policy by Switzerland and if so whether the revival of public interest in investing abroad does not indicate a willingness in Switzerland to help financially the accelerating economic recovery of West Germany.
Formation of a nation-wide organization to promote an increase of imports by this country was announced over the week-end by the National Council of American Importers.

Now and again one is reminded that it was Karl Marx who perfected the technique of vituperation to support economic views. Using prose that rolls its r's heavily, Ludwig von Mises has borrowed his polemic methods from both Marx and Senator McCarthy.

NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 23 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru said today in an interview that he hoped that at some future time a form of super-federation between India, Pakistan and Burma could be devised. He hopes such a union would insure regional cooperation between these independent countries, which once were components of British India, but at the same time would permit each to retain its identity.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Nov. 23 -- Five races in but a breath of westerly air that faded but congealed again were held today between the sailing-dinghies at the Larchmont Yacht Club. The moving air was but a flickering feather most of the time.

The local headquarters of the State Employment Service got a postcard last month from a man in Bombay, India, who had been helped by the service to get a job as foreman in a Seventh Avenue dress factory three years ago. The note said:

A divergence of opinion on the question, "How Does Soviet Policy Affect Us ?" was expressed by six high school students who took part in the weekly New York Times Youth Forum televised over Dumont Station WABD-TV.

CHICAGO, Nov. 23 (UP) -- George Blanda passed for three touchdowns, the last with nine seconds to play, and kicked three extra points and a 26-yard field goal today to lead the Chicago Bears to a 24-to-23 triumph over the Detroit Lions before 37,508 fans.
Thanksgiving week, despite the holiday, presents more than a score of exhibitions of painting and sculpture in metropolitan galleries.

The new building of the Broadway Temple Washington Heights Methodist Church, started in the early Nineteen Twenties, and halted by the crash of 1929, was dedicated yesterday by Bishop Frederick B. Newell of the New York area of the Methodist Church.

Montgomery Ward Co., Inc., second largest merchandising organization of the country, retailing through the mail and a chain of more than 610 department stores, had a sharp decline in earnings in the nine months ended with October from a year ago, according to the report issued over the week-end.

The Congress of Industrial Organizations maritime committee, which long has charged the Navy's Military Sea Transportation Service with competing with the nation's privately owned merchant fleet, continued its attack over the week-end.

LONDON, Nov. 23 -- The stock markets may be said to have taken heart to some extent last week. This, broadly speaking, is belated recognition of the recent indications of improvement in the economic situation.

In a good, rousing, thoroughly entertaining game of hockey at Madison Square Garden last night, the New York Rangers and the Montreal Canadiens played to what is known on the Belmont-Jamaica-Aqueduct circuit as a dead heat.
TOKYO, Monday, Nov. 24 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,443, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Monday, Korea time:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- Representative Frederic R. Coudert Jr., Republican of New York, declared today that he would introduce at the next session of Congress a Constitutional amendment to extend the term of members of the House of Representatives to four years, with one-half of the total membership elected every two years.

LONDON, Nov. 23 -- The Roman Catholic clergy entered today the controversy started last Sunday by the Rt. Rev. Dr. Alfred Edwin Morris, Anglican Bishop of Monmouth, in a Westminster Abbey sermon on the British coronation oath.

CAIRO, Nov. 23 -- The Egyptian Government announced today that it will buy Egypt's cotton crop this year at a set price and sell at prices obtainable on the world market. If the Government makes a profit this will be refunded to cotton producers, the Ministry of Finance statement said.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 (UP) -- The "power-hungry" leaders of the Kremlin and Soviet satellite states have a total of 491 divisions of troops stationed in Europe and Asia, the State Department reported tonight.

AMSTERDAM Nov. 23 -- A feature last week was the Netherlands Bank's exchange transaction of some $41,000,000 for gold. As a result, gold stocks rose 156,000,000 guilders to 1,397,000,000, and foreign exchange plus gold stocks 25,000,000 to 3,578,000,000.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 (UP) -- Martin Dies, Representative-elect, will return to national political life in January but there will not be a seat for him on the House committee that had originally brought him fame.

The traditional turkey is featured in the most expensive of three Thanksgiving menus at varying price levels planned by Mrs. Frances Foley Gannon of the City Department of Markets. This dinner for five is $11.15. For meal more moderate in price, baked fresh ham is suggested, and at a really low cost -- $4.78 for five, -- dinner is built around duck.

The musical Ajemian sisters, Anahid, violinist, and Maro, pianist, appeared at Town Hall last evening in the first of three recitals offering representative works of duo literature from the B Minor Sonata of Bach to contemporary pieces by Webern, Hovhaness and Cowell.

FRANKFURT, Germany, Nov. 23 (AP) -- An American engineer won release from a German jail today and immediately demanded a United States court hearing on an investigation of a big Allied defense building program.

Robert E. Sherwood, winner of three Pulitzer prizes for drama and one for biography, has signed a contract with the National Broadcasting Company to write nine original plays for television. The first will be seen in the spring.

" The Collected Works of Abraham Lincoln," a nine-volume work which contains "virtually" everything that Lincoln left us, has been scheduled for Feb. 12 publication by Rutgers University Press. The volumes, of about 550 pages each, include 6,870 items of which 3,312 had never been published in any collection, among them several speeches.
GREEN BAY, Wis., Nov. 23 (UP) -- Halfback Tony Canadeo scored two touchdowns today in the final home game of his 11-year career as the Green Bay Packers swamped the Dallas Texans, 42 to 14.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 23 (UP) -- The fired-up Philadelphia Eagles, led by their sparkling rookie backfield, scored a 28-to-20 upset over the Cleveland Browns in Municipal Stadium today and moved into a three-way tie with Cleveland and the New York Giants for first place in the American Conference of the National Football League.

IT was a rousing game that unbeaten U. S. C. and unbeaten U. C. L. A. played for television's free loaders on Saturday. The chances are that the armchair experts didn't find it quite as thrilling as the Oklahoma-Notre Dame festivities a fortnight previously because a game dominated by defense never is as spectacular as one in which the offense has free reign.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- Has anybody missed the giant squid? It appears to have dropped out of sight for the last fifty years, the Smithsonian Institution said today, possibly indicating it is nearing extinction. If so, probably no one but the giant squid itself would shed many] tears.

JERUSALEM, Nov. 23 -- Prime Minister David Ben-Gurion and leaders of four major Zionist groups in the United States formulated a program today for the strengthening of the Zionist movement by transferring certain activities from the Jewish Agency for Palestine, the executive arm of the world Zionist movement, to the American Zionist Council, which embraces all Zionist indigenous groups in the United States.

The report of the Institute of Public Administration on the Police Department was assailed yesterday by Police Commissioner George P. Monaghan as an inaccurate picture of conditions within the department.

Establishment in the new division of distribution now being set up in the Department of Commerce of a Central Index of all marketing information is advocated by Dr. Vergil D. Reed, vice president of the J. Walter Thompson Company.
Sales of plastics this year may exceed the record high reached in 1951, despite poor volume during the first six months.

THEY gathered on the steps of the temple of Lakshmi, the members of the outcast brotherhood who were victims of the Great Disease, leprosy. They slept on the steps at night and begged and ate their meals there. Here among the fellowship of the damned, human pariahs, lower even than the casteless ones, could still find friends and even, perhaps, love.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Nov. 25 -- Cold and rainsoaked infantrymen of the United Nations army pushed back sporadic Communist probing attacks along Korea's 155-mile front last night and this morning as the Korean war entered its thirtieth month.

Women interested actively in the work of the Catholic Centre for the Blind have taken over the performance of the new Cinerama on the night of Dec. 3 at the Broadway Theatre to raise funds for the organization. Assisting them in furthering the sale of tickets are members of a junior committee, among whom are Mrs. George S. Johnston Jr. and Miss Julie Kammerer.

CAIRO, Nov. 24 -- Finance Minister Abdul Ghalil Emary stated at a press conference tonight that the primary aim of the Government's decrees last night providing for governmental purchase of the remainder of this year's cotton crop and the closing of the cotton futures market was to "tempt buyers back to the Egyptian cotton market."

PARIS, Nov. 24 -- Whether the first result of the Schuman plan will be to raise prices of coal and steel within rite single tariffless market is being studied here as the High Authority of the new Coal and Steel Community prepares to raise funds to finance its activities.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 24 -- On his first tour of the headquarters of the United Nations, whose forces he plans soon to visit in Korea, Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the President-elect, hailed the world organization today as symbolizing the "free world's hopes for a peaceful and secure future."

MINNEAPOLIS, Nov. 24 (AP) -- Eight major Minneapolis milk distributors, their officials, their trade association and the A. F. L. Drivers' Union were charged with violation of the Federal antitrust act in a civil suit filed here today by the Department of Justice.

General Eisenhower paid a visit yesterday to the headquarters of the United Nations and there reaffirmed his faith in that organization. He found his visit an "inspiring experience" and declared that "this building, the people in it and their work are, in sum, the symbol of the free world's hopes for a peaceful and secure future."

TORONTO, Nov. 24 (Canadian Press) -- The Federal Government's increased aid to Canada's gold mines, announced today, was approved as "a step in the right direction" by mining company executives and mining associations here.

COSHOCTON, Ohio, Nov. 24 -- William Green, successor to Samuel Gompers as president of the American Federation of Labor, was buried this afternoon in South Lawn Cemetery, less than a mile from the humble house in which he had been born eighty-two years ago.

A number of neighborhood retail drug stores accused of defrauding the public through unethical prescription practices are under inquiry in the broadening state investigation into questionable stock deals involving pharmaceutical corporations.
NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 24 -- The troubles over Kashmir between India and Pakistan are, like many things Asian, on a grander scale than similar ills would be in the West.
PITTSBURGH, Nov. 24 -- An ambitious effort to survey the state of contemporary music, with the accent on what has been produced in the last twenty-five years, has begun here.

With Margaret Truman as mistress of ceremonies, the nineteenth annual "Night of Stars," arranged by the United Jewish Appeal of Greater New York, was held last night in Madison Square Garden with 20,000 persons in attendance.

ROCQUENCOURT, France, Nov. 24 -- The North Atlantic Treaty nations now have ninety-five major airbases built or being built in a broad arc ranging across West Europe from northern Norway to Italy. Fifty-five of these fields already are fully operational; all can accomodate jet fighter wings, or in an emergency, atomic bomb bearing aircraft.

The Port of New York Authority announced yesterday the appointment of Daniel L. Kurshan to the new post of assistant to the executive director. Mr. Kurshan, executive director of the Citizens Budget Commission, will join the bistate agency about Jan. 1.

Service on two city bus lines in Manhattan Beach, Brooklyn, was halted for three hours yesterday by forty women and children who staged a protest baby-carriage demonstration at the intersection of Oriental Boulevard and Oxford Street.

The New York State Crime Commission announced yesterday that it would begin public hearings on New York waterfront conditions on Dec. 3. The hearings will be held in the County Court House, Centre and Pearl Streets.
CHICAGO, Nov. 24 (AP) -- Wisconsin, ending its role as wallflower of Big Ten football, became the Conference's choice today to face Southern California in the Rose Bowl New Year's day.

Addresses yesterday before the second eastern regional conference of the New York Society of Security Analysts were about evenly divided between expressions of confidence in the future and arguments for better official policies and practices.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 24 (AP) -- "Immortals" of the Harvard-Yale football series are almost too numerous to mention -- but the latest will be remembered long after some of the real stars of bygone days have been forgotten.

LONDON, Nov. 24 -- Prime Minister Churchill announced a shuffle of Ministers tonight that will the British Cabinet by one member. The basic reason for the changes is the poor health of Lord Woolton, Lord President of the Council, who has been dangerously ill since October with peritonitis and pneumonia following an appendectomy.

LONDON, Nov. 24 -- Additional delegates arrived here today for the British Commonwealth Prime Ministers conference, the most important Commonwealth meeting since the Ottawa trade conference twenty years ago. The delegates will hold their first session Thursday.

FORT SLOCUM, N. Y., Nov. 24 -- William J. Peppler Jr., 11 years old, of New Rochelle, and his cousin, Donald F. Wilkens, 10, of the Bronx, did not see the world through a porthole today, but they saw the Navy -- the easy way.

The Children's Village in Dobbs Ferry, N. Y., will be the beneficiary of the Dec. 2 performance of "The Seven Year Itch" at the Fulton Theatre. Robert W. Dowling is general chairman of the benefit committee, and Mrs. William S. Kilborne is chairman of the women's committee assisting in the sale of tickets for the event.

When Governor Dewey recently closed the woods of the state, as a preventive measure against forest fires, one thing was made instantly clear. That is that there is no more fully informed class of readers of gubernatorial proclamations than the squirrels of the State of New York.

JERUSALEM, Nov. 24 -- Fear for the safety of 3,500,000 Jews behind the Iron Curtain was voiced in the Knesset (Parliament) today by Foreign Minister Moshe Sharett. He was reading a Government statement on the Prague treason trial, which has been marked by anti-Zionist charges.
SEOUL, Tuesday, Nov. 25 (AP) -- This war-battered city began an excitement-packed vigil today for the arrival of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- State Department and Defense Department experts said today that Russian-made war supplies were pouring into Indo-China over a transcontinental Communist railway system protected from Allied air attack because it cut through China.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (UP) -- Three convicts were able to escape from Lewisburg Penitentiary in Pennsylvania last September because of security weaknesses, the Federal Prison Bureau said today.

The producing firm of Feuer and Martin, sponsor of the current musical hit, "Guys and Dolls," announced yesterday that it had started a suit against Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation, seeking an "injunction and damages" based on the corporation's "unauthorized and illegal" use of the stage show's title in advertising the recently released Damon Runyon film "Bloodhounds of Broadway."
KANSAS CITY, Nov. 24 (AP) -- Roy A. Roberts, president of The Kansas City Star, said last night that the "notion of getting up a commission to investigate newspapers is tommyrot."

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 24 -- Andrei Y. Vishinsky, Soviet Foreign Minister denounced today an Indian compromise resolution on the repatriation of Korean prisoners of war. He declared that it was "designed not to put an end to the war but to perpetuate it."

VIENNA, Nov. 24 (AP) - Alexander Taub, an American described as a former representative of the General Motors Company in Prague, has been branded as a "spy" in the current trial of Rudolph Slansky and thirteen other top Czechoslovak Communists.

Fire losses throughout the United States in 1952 will run to approximately $770,000,000, an increase of 6 per cent from last year's total of $730,084,000. This was reported yesterday by the National Board of Fire Underwriters.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (UP) -- Northeastern Gas Transmission Company today accused the Algonquin Gas Transmission Company of "deliberately creating" a natural gas emergency in New England to force the Government to authorize temporary operation of the Algonquin system.

Dr. Leonard Greenburg, sworn in last week by Mayor Impellitteri as the first Commisssioner of the newly created Department of Air Pollution Control, took over his new post yesterday and immediately began a hunt for new offices to supplant the old Smoke Control Bureau quarters at 140 Nassau Street.
Francis J. Sinnott called a meeting of the Brooklyn Democratic district leaders yesterday and before the ninety-minute session was over he had almost lost his post as Kings County Democratic leader.

We sympathize with the efforts of Controller Joseph to find economies, but think he should go after bigger and more expendable game than the municipal radio station, WNYC. With a current budget of only $315,000, WNYC is performing a useful public service.

The Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., through its president, Michael J. Quill, turned on more pressure yesterday in its campaign to obtain a forty-hour week from nine private bus companies against which it threatens to call a strike at 12:01 A. M. next Monday.

The statement is sometimes made that a hospital is "like a hotel" and hence shouldn't cost a patient more than a room-and-bath. But the hospital has operating rooms with expensive equipment, skilled nurses and experi enced technicians, extensive laboraties, diet kitchens, pharmacies, blood banks, X-ray departments and auxiliary lighting plants.
