A banking syndicate headed by Salomon Brothers Hutzler will place on the market today a new isseu of $10,000,000 of first mortgage 3 1/8 per cent thirty-year bonds of Gulf States Utilities Company at a price of 100 3/4 to yield about 3.09 per cent.

NEWARK, Nov. 24 -- Joseph C. Caprio and U. Harry Perlmutter, members of the Newark Board of Adjustment, were indicted by the Essex County Grand Jury today. They are charged with bribery in connection with the issuance of two zoning permits.
TOKYO, Tuesday, Nov. 25 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,444, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Tuesday, Korean time:

SOUTHERN PINES, N. C., Nov. 24 (AP) -- Sammy Snead continued to set the pace in today's second round of the $5,000, fifty-four-hole Julius Boros open golf tournament, fashioning a 5-under-par 67 for a 135 total and a 2-stroke lead going into tomorrow's final eighteen holes.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- The Supreme Court added a fifth school segregation case today to the list scheduled for argument on Dec. 8 and 9.

The main interests in the life of Ezra Taft Benson, whom Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, President-elect, designated yesterday to be his Secretary of Agriculture, have been the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter Day Saints (the Mormon Church), farm cooperatives and youth work.

Rear Admiral Willis E. Cleaves, U. S. N. (retired), has been made general sales manager of the Bendix radio division of Bendix Aviation Corporation in Baltimore. He is a former chief of naval communications.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Nov. 25 -- The Far East Air Forces charged Sgt. Giuseppe Cascio, 34 years old, of Tucson, Ariz., today with conspiring to sell secret flight test data on the top United States jet plane in the Korean theatre.
Graham Wilson, vice president, and John DeGarmo, treasurer, have been named directors of DeGarmo, Inc.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 24 -- The $70,000,000 United Nations program for large-scale relief and reconstruction in Korea won the final approval today of a five-nation committee.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (AP) -- New corporate securities offered for cash in the third quarter of this year brought corporation financing to a new nine-month high, reflecting the year's record plant expansion program.

The current reluctance of United States exporters to sell to Brazil on a draft basis, and the continuation of tight import restrictions by that country, are reflected in the sixth successive monthly decline in new drafts drawn on Brazilian importers during October.

Events tonight: "Tosca," Metropolitan Opera, 8:30 o'clock; Robert Goldsand, pianist, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; William Harms, pianist, Town Hall, 8:30; Harpsichord Quartet, with Uta Graf, soprano, Carnegie Recital Hall, 8:30; Jan Peerce tenor, Brooklyn Academy of Music 8:30.

TORONTO, Nov. 24 (Canadian Press) -- Franz Pick of New York, publisher of Pick's World Currency Report, tonight predicted that the official gold price, under American leadership, will be increased from $35 to $52.50 an ounce.

The chances that the Congress of Industrial Organizations could head off a disruptive floor fight at its convention in Atlantic City next week dwindled last night as C. I. O. leaders remained split on the choice of a president to succeed the late Philip Murray.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 24 -- Twelve feature-length pictures will be filmed during the next fifteen months in Natural Vision, the new three dimension stereoscopic photographic and projection process, Milton L. Gunzburg, president of the Natural Vision Corporation, announced today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (AP) -- The University of Maryland's president blamed its football coaching staff today for collapse of the Terrapins in their last two games.

What should be done in the home and on the highways to reduce the number of accidents resulting from negligence or lack of knowledge was emphasized yesterday at the third annual safety institute for parents and teachers.

Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the President-elect, announced yesterday his decision to appoint Gov. Sherman Adams of New Hempshire, his principal campaign political adviser, as Assistant to the President, and Ezra Taft Benson of Salt Lake City, Utah, as Secretary of Agriculture.

Establishment of a $500,000 King George VI Memorial Fund to provide scholarships for study in this country by residents of the British Commonwealth was announced last night at the thirty-second annual dinner of the English-Speaking Union of the United States.

ROCKY MOUNT, N. C., Nov. 24 (UP) -- A Southern preacher who will publicly burn a copy of the new revised standard version of the Bible Sunday charged today that the National Council of Churches of Christ was deriving an "unmoral profit" from the book.

Since "Oedipus Tyrannus" is a more powerful tragedy than "Electra," the second bill of the Greek National Theatre is the more impressive one. Alexis Minotis and Katina Paxinou appeared in the two chief parts in a masterly performance at the Mark Hellinger Theatre last evening where the production will remain through next Sunday's matinee.

MANILA, Nov. 24 -- Senator Jose Laurel, whom President Elpidio Quirino defeated in the elections three years ago, declared in a recent radio address that Mr. Quirino was said to be planning to remove Ramon Magsaysay from his post of Secretary of Defense, "to insure victory in the 1953 elections" for the President's Liberal party.

MIAMI, Fla., Nov. 24 (AP) -- A controversy over Florida plans to fingerprint everyone working at its race tracks was compromised today, clearing the way for Thursday's opening of the state's rich winter season.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (UP) -- The Farmer's Almanac calls 1953 "atomic year 9."

Orders for the construction of four large passenger liners have been placed with British shipyards within the last two weeks. Canadian Pacific Steamships, Ltd., announced last week that it had signed-contracts for the building of two 22,500-ton craft and it was learned here yesterday that two other concerns had each placed orders for a ship of approximately 20,000 tons.
SAN JUAN, P. R., Nov. 24 (UP) -- Bishop Homer A. Tomlinson of Queens Village, L. I., believes that 700,000 Puerto Ricans should emigrate to Mexico and Central America to relieve congestion here.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- Alger Hiss lost his plea for parole today. Therefore the former State Department official convicted of perjury probably will remain in prison for at least another year as a rejected application of a prisoner usually is not reconsidered till twelve months have elapsed.
Demand for machine tools, a sensitive indicator of what is going on in production planning, disclosed yesterday a general slowing of defense orders.

In reply to Charles E. Denney's letter criticizing Senator Morse for saying that General Eisenhower and Senator Nixon "had fooled the American people and won the election," I fail, for the life of me, to see why this is "among the most shocking things ever said by a United States Senator."
Forty exhibition games during the club's Spring training campaign were announced by the Giants yesterday.

Personalities from all branches of the entertainment industry as well as other celebrities filled the Criterion Theatre last night for the special benefit showing of Samuel Goldwyn's "Hans Christian Andersen,'' the first in a contemplated annual series of film premieres to aid the Will Rogers Memorial Hospital at Saranac Lake, N. Y.

Although steel operations are scheduled to dip slightly this week, the rate will still be considerably above theoretical capacity -- the twelfth consecutive week of above-100 per cent activity. The American Iron and Steel Institute estimates the rate for the current week at 105.5 per cent and production at 2,191,000 net tons of ingots and steel for castings.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 24 -- Following are excerpts from the English translation of the address in Russian by Soviet Foreign Minister Andrei Y. Vishinsky and excerpts from the address of Secretary of State Dean Acheson, delivered today on India's Korean resolution before the United Nations General Assembly's Political and Security Committee:

PARIS, Nov. 20 -- French losses in the Indo-China war from 1946 through the first ten months of 1952 have been 28,246 killed and missing, according to comprehensive figures made available today by the Ministry of National Defense. An additional 21,250 Vietnamese soldiers have been killed during the seven years of fighting in Indo-China.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- The Supreme Court ruled today that a United States citizen by birth, who also is a national of a foreign country through parentage, does not lose his United States citizenship even if residence abroad extends beyond his twenty - first birthday.

No graver task faces America today than the elimination of discrimination against Negro citizens. At home the validity of our democratic tenets is sharply questioned by each new generation which calls attention to unresolved inequities. In the eyes of two-thirds of the world's population, who are colored, our national integrity in other matters is measured by deficiencies in this sphere of our human relations.

TOKYO, Nov. 24 -- Premier Shigeru Yoshida, making a main policy address to the new Parliament, called on Japan today to endorse a program of limited rearmament "for the sake of world peace and national security."

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 24 -- Norway has drafted a proposal to get Israel and the Arab members of the United Nations together for "direct" negotiations to settle their conflict over Palestine and will submit the plan to the United Nations General Assembly's Special Political Committee.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (UP) -- The Communist party asked the Subversive Activities Control Board ttoday to reject the ruling by a hearing panel that the party is an agent of Moscow.

ANCHORAGE, Alaska, Nov. 24 (AP) -- A Coast Guard cutter radioed tonight that yellow "wreckage" in the Gulf of Alaska, believed to be that of a missing C-124 Globemaster, had turned out to be driftwood and seaweed.

EAST LANSING, Mich., Nov. 24 (AP) -- Charlie Capozzoli, 125-pound runner from Georgetown University, whizzed around the four-mile course in a winning time of 19 minutes 36.7 seconds to set a new N. C. A. A. cross-country record today.

CHICAGO, Nov. 24 -- Charles E. Wilson, designated by President-elect Dwight D. Eisenhower as the next Secretary of Defense, personally was responsible for a 1931 contract under which General Motors Corporation agreed to buy 50 per cent of its tire supplies from the United States Rubber Company, a General Motors attorney declared today as trial of the Government antitrust suit against the du Pont interests resumed before Federal District Judge Walter J. La Buy.

A sixty-day workhouse sentence for one multiple-parking offender and a fifteen-day term for another, as well as heavy fines, were imposed yesterday in Traffic Court by Chief Magistrate John M. Murtagh.

ELIZABETH, N. J., Nov. 24 -- A motorcycle policeman, who served as an anti-aircraft officer in Europe in World War II, was assigned hero today to watch with binoculars for planes straying from the prescribed landing path at Newark Airport.
An arbitration award in the wage dispute between the International Longshoremen's Association, A. F. L., and the New York Shipping Association will be handed down today by Paul R. Hays, arbiter.
A group of abstractions by Mariska Karasz, who uses a needle and thread like brush and paints, is on view until Dec. 20 at the Bertha Schaefer Gallery, 32 East Fifty-seventh Street.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Nov. 24 -- The Indonesian Government announced today that Lieut. Col. Kretarto, commander of the Tenth Brigade, seized control Sunday of the Second Indonesian Division in south Sumatra, replacing Lieut. Col. Koasin.
TRENTON, Nov. 24 -- A new attempt to determine justice in what was once called the Trenton Six murder case and now is the case of the Trenton Two was ordered today by the State Supreme Court.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- The American Association of University Women made public today a list of eighteen women who had been recommended to Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the President-elect, for his "serious consideration" in making appointments to high Government posts.

Two statements which are inaccurate have been published in special dispatches to THE NEW YORK TIMES within the past few weeks with reference to the sovereignty status of the Kurile and Habomai Islands.

Refusing to stay the execution date of Ethel and Julius Rosenberg, convicted Soviet atom spies, Federal Judge Edward Weinfeld yesterday, ordered the Government to show cause tomorrow why the convictions should not be invalidated.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- The familiar change by a Supreme Court minority that the majority had based its decision on speculations beyond the agreed record in a case was made again today by four justices against five. But since the majority, as usual, denied the assertion, and denied it had overridden a relevant statute, as the minority said it had, lawyers and laymen once more were left to make their choice between the contentions.

According to an old American legend, the bedroom farce is what a French play ought to be. The late A. H. Woods thought so twenty-five or thirty years ago and gave us a series of which one, in February, 1920, was called "Breakfast in Bed," taken at some distance from Georges Feydeau's "Occupe -- toi d'Amelie."

Domestic air cargo will double present ton-mile volume by 1954 and quintuple it between 1958 and 1960, reaching a total well over 1,500,000,000 ton-miles annually. By then it will rival air passenger traffic in ton-miles and far exceed it in return on the airlines' investment.

John Gilligan, captain of New York University's football team, will be unable to play in Saturday's game with Fordham at Triborough Stadium, Randalls Island, Coach Hugh Devore learned yesterday. Gilligan is in French Hospital with a shoulder separation suffered in last week's 27-14 loss to Rutgers and will undergo an operation this morning.

A precise little Japanese war criminal in a red necktie testified in Federal Court yesterday that he and a Japanese lieutenant had shot an American captain to death in the dark after Sgt. John David Provoo had reported him as "uncooperative and anti-Japanese."

When Americans think of the propaganda activities of their Government abroad they are apt to think of the Voice of America and let it go at that. Powerful as the Voice may be -- and it has risen from a squeak to a trumpet blast in the last year or two -- it is by no means the only medium for presenting America's story to the world.
BONN, Nov. 24 (AP) -- The West German Government announced today that it will float its first long-term internal loan on Dec. 11.

Toshiya Eto, Japanese-born violinist who made his debut at Carnegie Hall Nov. 9, 1951, returned to that hall for a second recital last evening. A native of Tokyo, Mr. Eto studied at the conservatory there and with Efrem Zimbalist at the Curtis Institute in Philadelphia.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, Nov. 24 (AP) -- Harold J. Adonis, one-time executive clerk to Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll of New Jersey, was moved today to the Central Amsterdam detention prison from a police cell while the Dutch Government sought more evidence on a United States request for his extradition.

VIENNA, Nov. 24 -- The Czechoslovak treason trial of Rudolf Slansky, Dr. Vladimir Clementis and their twelve Communist comrades took a strong anti-Semitic trend today. Evzen Loebl and Rudolf Margolius, former Deputy Ministers of Foreign Trade, and both of Jewish origin, were brought to the stand to testify, the Prague radio said, that Israel was linked with a conspiracy in which the West had been implicated by the defendants.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Indo-China, Nov. 24 -- The first Vietminh assault against the perimeter defenses of the Nasan airfield has been repulsed. A communique released here this morning said elements of two Vietminh regiments hurled themselves against an outpost position at Nasan Sunday night, but after several charges had failed were forced to withdraw.

New life entered the stock market yesterday and broadened demand, spearheaded by the railroad issues, carried prices near the best levels of the year. The carriers enjoyed ample backing from such other important units in the list as the steels, televisions and coppers. However, lagging tendencies developed in the automotives and petroleums.

The New York City Housing Authority began yesterday to notify tenants in thirty-three of the fifty-seven projects it operates that, beginning on Jan. 1, they would have to make monthly payments for electricity ranging from 25 cents to $1.10.

CHICAGO, Nov. 24 -- Rallies in the grain futures markets were hard to hold today, and they appeared to be largely short covering operations, although on the extreme declines there was some support that was of an investment character.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 24-- A majority of United Nations members voted today to condemn the Soviet Union and its satellites for having refused to repatriate thousands of Greek children now in countries behind the Iron Curtain.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- Hermann Prey, 23-year-old German baritone, made his American debut this afternoon with the National Symphony Orchestra.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 24 -- Senator Robert A. Taft said today that he had made recommendations for all of the posts in the Cabinet of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the President-elect, and, although the appointments, so far, were not his suggestions, he "acquiesced in many of them."

Lieutenant Loeffler, 22 years old, is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Gustave Loeffler Jr. of Babylon. He had been a member of the Reserve Officers Training Corps of Princeton University and was commissioned an officer in the Army Engineers upon graduation last June.

Chicago, Ill., borrowed $9,500,000 for school building purposes yesterday on serial bonds due on each April 1, 1955 to 1972. The issue was sold at competitive bidding to Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., and associates at a bid of 97.4395 for specified interest of 2 per cent.

In the light of the recent multiple accidents on the New Jersey and other turnpikes which permit a speed of sixty miles an hour it appears necessary to adopt a new thought in traffic control, that is, that speed should be regulated to comply with driving conditions at any given time.

PARIS, Nov. 24 -- Delegates to the general conference of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization sought a way today out of the confusion created by the resignation Saturday of its director general, Dr. Jaime Torres Bodet, after the conference had voted a budget lower than he asked.

" Hans Christian Andersen," the Samuel Goldwyn Technicolor musical adaptation of some stories and incidents in the career of the Danish talespinner, which arrives at both the Criterion and Paris Theatres, is today's lone film newcomer.
ATHENS, Nov. 24 -- Premier Alexander Papagos said today that his Government had no intention of curtailing press freedom.

Many members of society attended the annual concert for the benefit of the Bagby Music Lovers' Foundation yesterday afternoon in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. The artists were Jan Smeterlin, pianist, Robert Weede, baritone, Mario del Monaco, tenor, and Irene Jordan, soprano.

A home freezer, whether used with or without a food plan, may be a convenience but it is not economical it was contended here yesterday at the meeting of the Regional Extension Conference at which extension workers from this state, New Jersey and Connecticut met to discuss frozen food plans and home freezers.
OTTAWA, Nov. 24 (Canadian Press) -- The Canadian Government has decided to tap its treasury for an additional $4,000,000 a year to boost subsidies to Canada's hard-pressed gold mines in 1953.
Coach Lou Rossini says his Columbia basketball squad has more depth and more general speed than the 1951-52 outfit.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (AP) -- The Defense Department today identified 89 battle casualties in Korea in a new list that reported 20 killed, 60 wounded, 8 missing and 1 injured. The following casualties were listed for New York and New Jersey (none for Connecticut):

The appointment of a fact-finding committee to evaluate the formula under which state aid is granted for the operation of the city's public schools was announced yesterday by Andrew G. Clauson Jr., president of the Board of Education.

The Broadway Association called upon the City Planning Commission yesterday to adopt the rezoning plan it has had under consideration for two years or at least amend the present rules to bar carnival type enterprises from the Times Square area.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange rose 7 to 25 points yesterday, with old December recovering from its recent low level.

Robert Kurka's "The Good Soldier Schweik," a suite for woodwinds, brass and percussion, suggested by Hasek's satirical antiwar novel of the same name, was the chief novelty of the Little Orchestra Society's third program of the season at Town Hall last night.

NAIROBI, Kenya, Nov. 24 (AP) -- The Kenya Government assumed powers tonight to punish whole native communities in an effort to stamp out the anti-white Mau Mau Society, which gave this British East African colony its bloodiest week-end.
BAGHDAD, Iraq, Nov. 24 -- The new Government of Premier Gen. Mahmoud Nur al-Din, which took over yesterday to end a reign of riot and bloodshed, clamped a heavy hand on Baghdad tonight.

The National Shipping Authority of the Maritime Administration announced yesterday that three more of the Mariner-class, supercargo ships have been assigned to steamship companies under general agency agreements for the transport of military cargoes for the Military Sea Transportation Service.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (UP) -- The Internal Revenue Bureau reported today that its special tax fraud squad had collected more than $13,600,000 in racket-type assessments in October.

MEXICO CITY, Nov. 24 -- The outgoing President, Miguel Aleman, formally inaugurated the schools' light systems and a half dozen new boulevards in Mexico City today as part of his farewell tour of the nation he has governed for six years.

The sophisticated American woman and girl will be wearing bathing suits and playclothes whose inspiration is taken directly from the native costumes of Africa's Gold Coast inhabitants if they select some of the fascinating togs that Carolyn Schnurer has devised as the result of a recent visit to that remote area.

Burlington Mills Corporation and its subsidiaries increased its sales in the fiscal year ended last Sept. 27, but earnings declined $5,140,000 from the previous year, the annual report disclosed yesterday.

NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 24 -- Buddhist leaders and monks from many Asian countries will meet at Sanchi in Central India next Saturday for an international Buddhist culture conference. They also will participate in sacred ceremony of reinterment of relics known as those of Sariputta and Moggallanna, two of the earliest disciples of Buddha, who lived 2,500 years ago, in a new vihara or monastery that has been specially constructed for the purpose.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (AP) -- John P. Davies Jr., career diplomat, has returned to his post in Germany after testifying at secret hearings before the Government's Loyalty Review Board.

A pleasant surprise greeted Charley Caldwell, the Princeton football coach, when he appeared at the weekly luncheon meeting of the Football Writers Association at Toots Shor's yesterday. Just before he was called upon to address the experts, Caldwell learned that he had won the Touchdown Club of New York award for meritorious service to football over a period of years.

LONDON, Nov. 24 -- Publication of Japan's formal offer of a debt settlement stimulated heavy demand for Japanese issues on the London stock market today. Elsewhere, markets were quietly firm. All of the leading Japanese bonds advanced sharply and prices withstood heavy profit-taking sales.
Gifts of clothing for destitute refugees in Korea, Europe, the Middle East and the Far East were formally dispatched yesterday by the relief organizations of the Protestant and Roman Catholic faiths.

MIAMI, Fla., Nov. 24 (UP) -- The Syracuse Orangemen, who can come appropriately dressed for the occasion, accepted a bid to play Alabama in the Orange Bowl today after Navy's midshipmen rejected an offer for the New Year's Day football classic.

THOSE who look outside at the driving rain, with the wind ripping shingles from the roof, and point out that it is a "good day for ducks," should have been with us on the Hammonasset during the Saturday blow, when even the sea gulls were walking.

President-elect Eisenhower's nomination of Governor Sherman Adams to be his Executive Office assistant follows a story published in this newspaper yesterday to the effect that plans were being made to bring the various units of the Executive Office under the "over-all supervision of a special assistant who would function as a Secretary General."

Before the turn of the century, a conscientious mother with a growing family began a journal in which for eight years she noted comments and reports on her youngsters' interests, activities and personalities, some of the things they did and said, the scrapes they got into and the measures she took to punish them for these.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- If Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower runs the White House the way he has run every other major job of his career, his newly appointed assistant, Gov. Sherman Adams of New Hampshire, may very well turn out to be more powerful than any member new Republican of the Cabinet.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (AP) -- James F. Davenport of Los Angeles, vice president of Southern California Edison Company, will become Defense Electric Power Administrator on Nov. 30, Secretary of the Interior Chapman announced today.

COSHOCTON, Ohio, Nov. 24 -- Top lieutenants of the American Federation of Labor gathered in this city for the burial of William Green, appeared to have decided tonight that George Meany, secretary treasurer of the A. F. L., should be its next president.

" The writer in America," a new work by Van Wyck Brooks, has been scheduled for February publication by Dutton. It is an explanation of why he wrote his five-volume "Makers and Finders:: A History of the Writer in America, 1800-1915."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- Tighe Woods, director of the Office of Price Stabilization, submitted his resignation to President Truman today in dissatisfaction over what he called a "weak controls law."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- Three Marine Corps heroes of the epic retreat from the Yalu River in the winter of 1950 received the Medal of Honor, the highest United States military decoration, from President Truman today.

Commodities futures on the New York exchanges closed irregularly higher yesterday with hides, lead, rubber, sugar and wool showing increases. Potatoes and cottonseed oil closed lower and tin was unchanged. Zinc, coffee, cocoa and soybean oil were mixed.
Michael J. Quill of the Transport Workers Union repeated yesterday the threat of his union to strike the major privately operated bus lines of New York City on Dec. 1.

UTICA, N. Y., Nov. 24 (AP) -- The Syracuse Broadcasting Corporation, which operates radio station WNDR, today filed a $1,088,112 suit against Samuel I. Newhouse, publisher, and the two Syracuse newspapers and radio station controlled by him.

BOWIE, Md., Nov. 24 -- They were off and running at Bowie today -- all day. The pastoral track, operated this year for the first time under the presidency of Larry MacPhail, presented a full program of eight races under weather conditions that were ideal.
Gov. Sherman Adams, who will be 54 years old in January, is finishing out his second term as the Chief Executive of New Hampshire. Tall, silvery, haired, he has a flair for wearing bow ties.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (UP) -- Henry Ford 2d told investigators of the House of Representatives today that the $502,000,000 Ford Foundation would never give "another dime" to anyone who had used the funds for un-American activities.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- The Supreme Court of the United States ruled today that a New York law, seeking to eliminate Communist influence in Russian Orthodox churches chartered in the state, fell into the realm of religious control barred by the Constitution of the United States.

LONDON, Nov. 24 (AP) -- Britain will ease her import restrictions a fraction in January in a bid to encourage intra-European trade, the Government announced today. But Chancellor of the Exchequer R. A. Butler will continue the greater part of his import cuts into 1953 despite Britain's improved trading position, the announcement said.

Frank Sampson, administrative assistant to Mayor Impellitteri, asserted yesterday that a statement issued last week by the Citizens Union had been misinterpreted and, as a result, there had been an implication that he was an intimate of Frank Costello, the gambler, and other underworld characters mentioned at recent State Crime Commission hearings.

Six American Federation of Labor printing unions signed new contracts yesterday with the Publishers Association of New York City. The contracts called for "package" increases of $5 to $6 a week in wage and welfare benefits, with the increases retroactive to Nov. 1.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (AP) -- Selective Service may begin drafting 19 years olds soon, but definitely not before the end of January. An official said today that surveys of the manpower situation were being assembled to provide an up-to-date report on how many 20-year-olds still were available for the draft.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- Mrs. Anna M. Rosenberg, Assistant Secretary of Defense, said today that commanders of forces in the Korean campaign looked forward to the visit of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower to the combat zone. They feel that the first-hand study will afford an understanding of their problems to the President-elect.

R. K. O. Pictures Corporation, which has been plagued with internal corporate difficulties since its control was purchased last Sept. 25 from Howard Hughes, is also suffering reverses in its business operations.
Philadelphia becomes the football capital of the nation this final week of the intercollegiate season.

HONG KONG, Nov. 24 -- After spending almost two years in a Chinese Communist jail, the Rev. Francis Olin Stockwell, a Methodist missionary from Oklahoma, left Hong Kong for the United States today with a Bible and a book of poetry, to which he attaches special value.

The Thirty-fourth Street-Midtown Association got just what it wanted for Christmas yesterday, when the Traffic Department began to renew white crosswalk, lines in the congested midtown area. The request for these markers was made last Tuesday, and the prompt response won the commendation of N. Peter McLean, executive secretary of the association.

BUFFALO, N. Y., Nov. 24 -- The State Board of Regents is determined to preserve freedom of inquiry and discussion while rooting out any teacher found to be subversive, Dr. John P. Myers, Chancellor of the University of the State of New York, asserted here tonight.

Further reduction of United States tariffs, even though it may hurt some domestic industry, and strong efforts by the new Administration to help other free nations achieve urgently needed convertibility of currencies were advocated yesterday in a panel discussion before members of a major business group.
The Michigan State Spartans, their football schedule completed, remained the country's No. 1 college football team yesterday in the ninth and next-to-last Associated Press poll of 1952.

NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 25 -- A Communist attempt in the Council of States (upper house of Parliament) to attack India's trade policy as discriminatory against the Soviet Union and other Communist states backfired today. The Communists' resolution suggesting that New Delhi make trade agreements with Soviet bloc countries was withdrawn by its sponsors.

With Melvyn Douglas starred, "Time Out for Ginger," an alumnus of the straw-hat circuit as well as a survivor of a trial two years ago in Houston, Tex., arrives at 8 o'clock this evening at the Lyceum. Retained from the summer junket, besides Mr. Douglas, are Polly Rowles and Roland Wood in a cast that includes Conrad Janis, Laura Pierpont, Philip Loeb, Larry Robinson and Nancy Malone.

VIENNA, Nov. 25 (AP) -- Reports received in Vienna tonight said two prominent Jews had committed suicide in Czechoslovakia in connection with the Prague treason trial. They were identified in these reports, from usually reliable sources, as Rudolph Bystricky, 44 years old, former Czechoslovak Ambassador in Britain, and Dr. Tibor Kovac, a Jewish Communist leader in Bratislava who once headed a nationalized industry.

If youth is to continue a dominant factor in keeping the Yankees and Dodgers at the top of their respective leagues, neither club should find itself greatly concerned over the future. At least not according to figures released yesterday by the American and National League champions.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 25 -- Two enterprising high school editors came here from Riverdale today to try to learn from the Russians the easiest way to distribute 10,000 copies of their weekly newspaper in and around Moscow. Copies are being printed in Russian for the first time in the history of the school, Horace Mann.

A technique that measures with accuracy the amounts of radiations received by internal cancers during treatment by X-rays, radium or other types of radioactive elements was described yesterday at the conference on electronic instrumentation and nucleonics in medicine at the New Yorker Hotel.

LONDON, Nov. 25 -- The stock markets ended a bookkeeping account today on a cheerful note with prices higher in most sections except the mining groups. Foreign bonds remained exceptionally active, British funds again improved and industrials strengthened, although one or two leaders weakened slightly in late dealings.

The Kenneth F. Sutherland faction in the Brooklyn Democratic organization joined yesterday with Francis J. Sinnott, Democratic leader, and agreed to a special meeting of the Kings County Democratic Committee on Dec. 17 to eliminate the six ex-officio votes in the organization's executive committee.
Red Cross blood centers will be closed Thanksgiving Day, tomorrow, and officials urged volunteers to make donations either today or Friday.

In the century generally labeled as the one of progress, there seems to be a decline in the ingenuity of the doll-maker, judging from an exhibit of antique and contemporary dolls to go on view Friday at Martin's in Brooklyn. The toys are in that store's fur storage building, which has taken the title of Doll House for the next four weeks.

Federal Judge Edward J. Dimock took over yesterday the questioning of Elizabeth Gurley Flynn, one of thirteen Communist party members on trial for conspiracy, in an attempt to clarify her ideas about how the party hoped to establish "the dictatorship of the proletariat."

Today's new film is "Outpost in Malaya," a British-made drama, with Claudette Colbert, Jack Hawkins and Anthony Steel, at Loew's State. Kan Annakin directed and John Staford produced the J. Arthur Rank presentation from a story and script by Peter Proud and Guy Elmes.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 (UP) -- The United States Air Force plans production of 20,000 aircraft in the next four years to meet its goal of 143 air wings completely equipped with modern planes, Under Secretary Roswell L. Gilpatric disclosed today.
BOMBAY, India, Nov. 25 (Reuters) -- The Italian delegate to a world conference on birth control here attacked the Roman Catholic church today for its stand on planned parenthood.

The election "did not represent a victory of the Republican party but of the American people," Charles H. Turtle, president of the National Republican Club, said last night at the club's victory dinner at the clubhouse, 54 West Fortieth Street.
BONN, Germany, Nov. 25 (AP) -- The Russians are spending fantastic sums to fight the radio war with the West while the United States is putting in "too little money and too frequently too late."

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 25 -- Tecumseh, painted all the colors of the rainbow, has collected many a left-handed salute; a towering stack of wood and rubble on Farragut Field awaits the torch and the echoing cheers of midshipmen marching to class in formation ring across the placid Severn.

The City Planning Commission recommended yesterday that the Board of Estimate approve tour projects, costing a total of $1,460,000, out of a list of ten projects amounting to $6,870,000. The board had asked the commission for information on the ten improvements for possible inclusion in the 1953 capital budget

SEOUL, Korea, Wednesday, Nov. 26 (UP) -- Thousands of Allied troops and police moved into this war-battered city today to insure "bullet-proof protection" for Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower on his expected visit.
An autographed baseball, sold at auction, made the current Young Women's Christian Association campaign fund thirty dollars richer yesterday.

Employed at the Empire Trust Company, 124 Broadway, for the last thirty-four years, Edward M. Tennis, 49 years old, of 104-07 223d Street, Queens Village, Queens, was arrested yesterday by Federal Bureau of Investigation. agents on a charge of embezzling $15,000 from the bank.

SYRACUSE, Nov. 25 (AP) -- Samuel I. Newhouse, publisher, said tonight that allegations in a $1,088,112 suit against him, two newspapers and a radio station he controls, were "wholly without foundation."

The second novelty of the New York City Ballet's season at the City Center was presented last night under the completely appropriate title of "Metamorphoses." It is a collaboration by George Balanchine, Paul Hindemith and Karinska, all about equally important in the final result.

While hopefully awaiting a large group of post-depression baby girls to come of age and to enter the nursing field, hospitals in the New York area are seeking and putting into practice many measures to ease the present nurse shortage, the United Hospital Fund says in a report for release today.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 25 -- Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden returned to London tonight after two weeks of trying to handle the situation created by the presence in New York of Secretary of State Dean Acheson and John Foster Dulles, who will succeed him on Jan. 20.
SCOTT AIR FORCE BASE, Ill., Nov. 25 (UP) -- Maj. James Jabara, who has six Communist MIG's to his credit, received permission today to return to Korea for more combat flying.

CHICAGO, Nov. 25 -- The weather turned favorable for the grain trade today as lower temperature with rain followed by snow was forecast for the West and Southwest, as well as the Corn Belt. This change is expected to cause a sharp rise in cattle feeding operations.

Evidently a concerted effort will be made to persuade the New York Legislature in its next session to increase state aid to education. In this city, for example, the Board of Education has set up a committee to evaluate the formula under which state aid is given, an action founded on the belief that "present funds available for public education are inadequate to provide the educational program which should be provided for New York City."
VIENNA, Nov. 21 -- Vienna, deep in the heart of the Soviet zone of Austria, is a political and psychological strongpoint of the Western world but a military liability.

R. Hoe Co., Inc., printing press manufacturers, has been called upon again to make ordnance, according to an announcement by the company. It is building a unique two-stage recoil mechanism for the Amy's atomic cannon., It was chosen, the company says, because of its long experience in extreme precision on massive equipment.

Dr Howard A. Rusk, professor and chairman of Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation at New York University College of Medicine, said yesterday that democracy was being tested by what it did for its aged people, its crippled children and its injured workmen.
To propose the elimination of the Traffic Department for reason of economy, as did Controller Lazarus Joseph is like saying that we cannot afford of and will run the car without it.
Landlords who rent cellars for human occupancy face possible prosecution in an intensive drive announced yesterday by the Kings County District Attorney's office.

CHICAGO, Nov. 25 -- The isolation of pure adrenocortiocotrophic pituitary hormone (ACTH) by a team of chemists of the Armour laboratories division of Armour and Company was reported today by F. W. Specht, president of the company.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 25 -- In response to a speech last week by Soviet Foreign Minister Andrei Y. Vishinsky, Senator Theodore F. Green of the United States delegation asked the Legal Committee of the United Nations General Assembly today to consider what had happened to a series of countries with which the Soviet Union in pre-war days had concluded treaties of nonaggression.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 (AP) -- The Revenue Bureau has instructed its field offices to make things easier for taxpayers when taxpaying time comes 'round next year.

MEXICO CITY. Nov. 25 -- Hundreds of steel-helmeted police armed with rifles were concentrated in downtown Mexico City tonight to enforce the Government's prohibition of an announced demonstration my the defeated opposition in last July's national elections.

Mobile, Ala., rejected yesterday the best bids submitted for issues of general obligation and water revenue bonds totaling $10,490,000. The most favorable purchase terms offered by bankers had been an interest cost of 3.018 per cent for $6,799,000 of general obligation and refunding bonds due from 1953 to 1970, and an interest cost of 3.246 per cent for an issue of $3,700,000 of water bonds due from 1957 to 1980.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 25 -- The establishment of a definite minimum wage rate for contract Mexican labor brought into this country under an agreement with Mexico was recommended today to the Commonwealth Club of California by its section on immigration.
Two armed robbers took an $8,022 payroll from a woman bookkeeper at a Queens bronze company yesterday and escaped in a car driven by an accomplice.

It was Arthur Ellsworth Summerfield, an automobile man from way back, who steered Gen. Eisenhower's campaign through the cross-traffic of the Republican National Convention and helped power the drive to the Presidency.
COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Nov. 25 (Reuters) -- Denmark today heard about the American premiere of "Hans Christian Andersen." And it didn't like what it heard.
The narcotics addict, whether juvenile or adult, should be hospitalized by law, James C. Ryan, district supervisor of the Federal Bureau of Narcotics, advocated last night.

BERLIN, Nov. 25 -- Three American soldiers picked up by the Russians while rabbit hunting were released today after two days in Soviet captivity. They said they had been questioned sharply about military matters but otherwise had been "very well treated."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 (AP) -- Robert S. Ramspeck, chairman of the Civil Service Commission, called today for a complete, non-political study of the work of Government information men.

Industry must exert its own initiative in the development of peacetime uses of atomic energy. Neither the Atomic Energy Commission nor any other Government agency will bring in projects "on a plutonium platter."

Police Commissioner George P. Monaghan gave personal congratulations yesterday to thirteen members of the force who took part in recent outstanding arrests and told them their deeds would "weigh heavily in your favor for future promotions."

By a vote of 46 to 5 the United Nations General Assembly's Special Political Committee has condemned the Soviet Union and its satellites for refusing to repatriate to their homeland almost 13,000 Greek children who were taken behind the Iron Curtain during the Greek civil war.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 (AP) -- The White House said today that loyalty checks by the Federal Bureau of Investigation were "routine'' on Presidential appointments to Cabinet and all other high posts.

Whether stories centering on emotional problems can help youngsters solve similar difficulties of their own concerned five specialists on work with children in a panel discussion last night arranged by the book committee of the Child Study Association of America.

The Overseas Press Club is seeking to raise $300,000 to purchase and equip a New York City press center which will be a memorial to the men and women of the newspaper profession who gave their lives in the Second World War and the Korean conflict. Soldiers are not the only ones "killed in action."
Final plans for building the $6,000,000 Gen. George W. Wingate High School in Brooklyn and for seven other schools were approved yesterday by the Board of Education.

LONDON, Nov. 25 -- Plans for a giant hydroelectric and aluminum project to exploit the bauxite deposits of the West African Gold Coast were announced today by the British Government. The total investment envisaged is 144,000,000 ($403,200,000).

CHECKING up along the south shore and as far east as Peconic Bay, we turned up no disappointed wildfowlers, and most of the old-timers encountered reported more waterfowl on Great South Bay than in many years. A surprising number of red-leg black ducks are being included in the recent bags.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 (AP) -- An indictment charging Ray Brennan, Chicago Sun-Times reporter, with posing as a Government official to get secret testimony given to Senate crime investigators, was dismissed today. The Government then asked a grand jury to return a new indictment.

Dr. Clare Baldwin, Assistant Superintendent of Schools, recommended last night to a gathering of seventy-five principals the establishment of "outpatients' departments" for high school students who are not properly adjusted to their surroundings or who cannot profit from the advice taught them in schools or at home.
ST. LOUIS, Nov. 25 (UP) -- Fred Saigh, owner of the Cardinals, said today he would ask the Giants to pay two television bills in a move to establish visiting teams' rights to TV and radio revenue.

Commonwealth Edison Company announced yesterday that its offering of 1,155,730 shares of new $25 par value $1.40 dividend convertible preferred stock has been priced for subscription by stockholders at $31 a share. The company's common stock, for which the new preferred is convertible share for share, closed yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange at 33 1/2.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 (AP) -- Attorney General James P. McGranery today ordered denaturalization proceedings started against Peter Corrado, described by the Justice Department as a Detroit racketeer.

CHICAGO, Nov. 25 (UP) -- Robert J. Lascelles, 58 years old, vice president and controller of the Pullman Company, was found shot dead today in the washroom of his offices on the fifth floor of the Merchandise Mart.
LINCOLN, R. I., Nov. 25 (UP) -- Tony DeSpirito regained his winning touch at Lincoln Downs today when he booted home four winners to increase his total for the year to 354.

RAHWAY, N. J., Nov. 25 -- Municipal Court Clerk Michael Mesaros was confronted today with a problem in international finance when he received by mail a piece of foreign paper money in payment of a parking meter violation ticket. The bill, similar to an American dollar but maroon in color, was a gulden in what is apparently Dutch West Indies currency.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- President Truman today requested Robert Ramspeck, chairman of the Civil Service Commission, to compile a roster of executives and specialists rapidly being laid off by mobilization agencies. The aim, he said, is to be able to recall them to service on short notice if their skills should again be needed in an emergency.

Mrs. Dwight D. Eisenhower, introduced at a United Service Organizations luncheon yesterday as "the next First Lady," gave in to the requests of 275 applauding women and made one of her rare speeches. It was brief.
NEWARK, Nov. 25 -- Edward Gaulkin, prosecutor of Essex County, today organized a "bribery squad" to investigate graft in this and other municipalities in the county.

The brusque Soviet rejection of India's compromise proposal on Korea seems to have dashed whatever hope there may have been for an early Korean armistice. But this rejection should have at least one positive result: it should help the free nations achieve what they are so often unable to achieve by themselves -- namely, unity in policy and action as well as in principle.

Many parties will be given at the fourth annual dinner dance of the Ballet Associates in America, Inc., to be given Friday night in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria for the benefit of the New York City Ballet Company. Mrs. Alice Pleydell-Bouverie and Mrs. Norbert McKenna are co-chairmen of the executive committee.
BAGHDAD, Iraq, Nov. 25 (AP) -- Three hundred politicians and others held responsible for last week-end's rioting were reported under arrest tonight.

Third Deputy Police Commissioner James A. Delehanty yesterday refused to dismiss charges against thirty suspended policemen accused of taking bookmaking graft from Harry Gross as the plainclothes men began their defense in the marathon departmental trial.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- George Meany, named today as president of the American Federation of Labor, is a plain-spoken 200-pounder who was born at 125th Street and Madison Avenue in Manhattan and grew up to be a union plumber.
SOUTHERN PINES, N. C., Nov. 25 (AP) -- Sam Snead regained his birdie touch today to gain a one-stroke victory in the $5,000, fifty-four-hole Julius Boros open golf tournament.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Nov. 25 -- Israelis pulled in their belts another couple of notches during the last ten days as the Government raised official prices of some things, removed ration controls from others and raised the duty on a wide variety of imported goods.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 (UP) -- Representative Harold H. Velde, Republican of Illinois, said today that the House Committee on Un-American Activities would concentrate its investigations next year on Communist infiltration of colleges and labor unions and would tone down its movie industry inquiry.

Average hourly earnings for wage earners of the iron and steel industry during September reached a record $2.206, compared with $2.139 in August, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. The estimated total payroll for the entire industry during September also set a record at $269,391,000, exclusive of retroactive payments.

A charge that an important prosecution witness in the treason trial of former Sgt. John David Frovoo had "instigated" and later "voluntarily participated" in the execution of a United States Army captain on Corregidor was read into the trial record yesterday.

Mighty Michigan State has bowled over its last opponent in an unbeaten and untied football season and now sits by for one week to await final approval of the United Press board of coaches as the mythical national college champion.

An 18-year-old Air Force corporal was in City Prison last night on a petit larceny charge after having told the police of a two-day spree of writing worthless checks while A. W. O. L. from a Tucson, Ariz., base. He was picked up in Saks Fifth Avenue after acting suspiciously in buying a $169 overcoat.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 (AP) -- The Government today increased 1952 import quotas of sugar by 100,000 tons to assure ample supplies and to keep prices steady.

William Harms, pianist, whose last New York recital took place at Carnegie Hall seven years ago, gave a program last night at Town Hall that included the first performance here of Impressions -- 1951, by Efrem Zimbalist, the violinist.

Almost 20,000 regularly employed longshoremen and an equal number of casual dock workers in the Port of New York are expected to receive a 17-cent increase in their basic hourly pay rate as the result of an arbitration award made yesterday by Prof. Paul R. Hays of Columbia University.

LONDON, Wednesday, Nov. 26 -- A Labor Member of Parliament succeeded early today in carrying off a parliamentary coup that may seriously delay the Conservatives' bill to denationalize the steel industry.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 25 (AP) -- The directors of Pimlico race track today sealed the deal by which they are selling old Hilltop to a group headed by Cary Boshamer, South Carolina textile manufacturer and horse breeder.

A plan to expedite traffic in congested areas of the city was suggested yesterday by the Broadway Association. The project, which calls for the channelization of motor vehicle movements on cross-town streets, will be presented to the Traffic Department within a few days, R. J. Wood, chairman of the association's traffic committee, said.

TOKYO, Nov. 25 -- British Commonwealth Diplomats leveled an informal attack today on Japanese press coverage of the deadlocked United Nations-Japan talks on jurisdiction in criminal cases involving Allied troops here.

CHICAGO, Nov. 25 (UP) -- A state legislative committee will investigate the action of Dr. George D. Stoddard, University of Illinois president, in banning school research on krebiozen, controversial cancer drug, the committee chairman said today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- Senator William E. Jenner, Republican of Indiana, put himself on record today as a backer of the foreign policies of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the President-elect.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board said today it was preparing "appropriate enforcement action" against a number of lawbreaking airplane ticket agents. It did not name any.

Fresh oysters from Holland, the Imperial Zeeland variety familiar to those who have lived or traveled in Europe, now have arrived in this country to be sold at retail for the first time. Priced well up in the luxury bracket, the shellfish are offered in two shops and are on the menus of one restaurant and a hotel.

NEWARK, Nov. 25 -- After an eighteen-month investigation into alleged anti-trust law violations, a Federal grand jury voted today not to return any indictments against five of the country's largest soap manufacturers and a trade organization.
PUSAN, Korea, Nov. 25 -- Tension and uncertainty hang over this humanity-swollen temporary capitol like heavy clouds before a thunderstorm.

Reporting on operations of Hiram Walker-Gooderham Worts, Ltd., and its subsidiaries for the fiscal year ended last Aug. 31, Howard R. Walton, president, revealed yesterday that, while sales and earnings were less than the previous year, the company fared better than others in the distilling industry.
Robert Goldsand, the admirably equipped pianist, and a musician as modest as he is wise in the ways of his art, gave a recital last night in Carnegie Hall.

Shopping tips that will save time and make Christmas buying a pleasure rather than a dreaded chore were disclosed in an interview yesterday by Arthur L. Manchee, vice president in charge of operations at Macy's.

If there was anybody left who needed a reminder of how disturbed the Middle East is these days and how strongly the current of xenophobic nationalism is running, Iraq has provided the clincher. On Saturday and Sunday rioting mobs set fire to the United States Information Service building, stoned the British Embassy, attacked police stations and overthrew the Government.

George Meany, who was chosen yesterday to succeed William Green as president of the American Federation of Labor, has had a long and honorable career in the labor movement. Beginning as a journeyman plumber in New York City, he became business agent of his union and then president of the New York State Federation of Labor, in which post he served with distinction.
AMSTERDAM, The Netherlands, Nov. 25 -- The police said today that two Indonesians arrested yesterday would be deported for having engaged in "undesirable political activity."

The eventual prevention of premature births should be the objective of the present program of providing medical care in five city centers for infants in this category, Dr. Leona Baumgartner, assistant health commissioner in charge of this service in the city, declared yesterday.
JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Nov. 25 (UP) -- Tulsa accepted an invitation today to play Florida in the Gator Bow1 here Jan. 1.

A ROMAN phrase-maker might offer the warning, "De gustibus non est disputandum." That's merely another way of saying, "Concerning tastes there can be no dispute." However, that still can't explain or, excuse the selection of Hank Sauer of the Cubs as the Most Valuable Player in the National League by twenty-four committeemen of the Baseball Writers Association from eight cities.

The New York County Council of Veterans of Foreign Wars presented yesterday to General Sessions Judge Saul S. Streit its Americanism award for encouraging "Americanism amongst the youth of America which is in keeping with the ideals and principles embodied in the Constitution."

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 25 -- The United Nations Trusteeship Council adopted today a resolution introduced by the United States that in effect gave scant hope to the 1,500,000 inhabitants of Togoland in West Africa for their independence ambitions in the near future.

Futures closed higher yesterday on the New York commodity exchanges except for domestic sugar. Tin quotations were unchanged with no sales recorded. Hides, lead, rubber, zinc, cocoa, potatoes, wool, coffee and vegetable oils closed higher.

LONDON, Nov. 25 -- Oliver Lyttelton, Colonial Secretary, told the House of Commons tonight that he feared that the situation in Kenya, where Britain is faced with a mysterious ritualistic rebellion, was going from bad to worse. He implied that Britain, in trying to curb the depredations of the Mau Mau terrorists against white settlers, might be risking the disaffection of the whole Kikuyu tribe.

HONG KONG, Nov. 25 -- Mao Tse-tung, leader of the Chinese Communist regime, was quoted by the Peiping radio tonight as having stated that Tibet, the Himalayan borderland on Communist China's southwest frontier, was "too thinly populated" and that it required "development."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- This country's three most famous documents, the Declaration of Independence, the Constitution and the Bill of Rights, will be elevated into their showcases each morning, and descend into their safe each night, in an unusual arrangement now nearing, completion at the National Archives.

CHICAGO, Nov. 25 (UP) -- Governor Stevenson and his top aides mapped reorganization of the Democratic party today in the first part of a two-day session designated to rebuild party strength throughout the nation.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 (AP) -- The Air Force disclosed that it had canceled 35 per cent of its contracts for the Lockheed F-94C Starfire.

PARIS, Nov. 25 -- The critical examination, now completed, of the 1953 defense plans of the North Atlantic Treaty countries indicates that their aggregate effort in the coming year will be above that of 1952 in terms of expenditure and effectives but below that which had been tentatively foreseen for 1953.

West Germany could solve its present dollar deficit problem if there was a further reduction in United States tariffs on her products, it was declared at a news conference yesterday held by members of the German - American Capital Commission.

Directors of the Erie Railroad at a meeting yesterday in Cleveland declared a dividend of $1 a share on the common stock, payable Dec. 15. The company paid 75 cents a share on the common in June, making total payments for the year $1.75 a share. In 1951, Erie paid 50 cents a share in June and $1.25 in December for a similar total of $1.75 a share.

If Foreign Minister Vishinsky ever has the misfortune to fall under the displeasure of his Government it might be for giving the first sharp jolt to the Indian policy of neutrality and healing a threatened rift between Great Britain and the United States. Two clear objectives of Soviet strategy are to keep the greatest non-Communist country in Asia from swinging toward the West and to break the unity of the Western Powers.

Sales by furniture manufacturers now stand only 2 per cent behind the 1951 level and the manufacturers believe they will close the year with a volume somewhat ahead of last year. This was reported yesterday in Chicago by officials of the American Furniture Mart, which houses most of the country's important furniture manufacturers.

ATHENS, Nov. 25 -- The United Nations Political Committee's resolution dissolving the standing committee on the repatriation of Greek children abducted dining the war against the Communist-inspired guerrillas has provoked a reaction here.

Methodist Bishop G. Bromley Oxnam, in reply to the recent annual statement of the Catholic Bishops of the United States, has commented: "Private and parochial schools make their contribution to American life. But they cease to be private if publicly supported."

MONTREAL, Nov. 25 (Canadian Press) -- Considering its wealth of resources and "timely capital-expansion program," Canada may hope to "benefit richly over the short and middle term from the colossal appetite for materials of our neighbors to the south," the Bank of Montreal comments in its current Business Review.

A new aerial navigation system based on precision gyroscopics will make it possible in the near future to send to any spot on earth with unerring accuracy supersonic missiles with the most modern warheads or commercial air transports loaded with passengers.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois, defeated Democratic candidate for President, has been invited by the President and Mrs. Truman to their most important farewell social function, a dinner for the members of the Cabinet on Dec. 4.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Nov. 25 -- The Indonesian Government announced today the reappointment of the former commander of the Second Division, Col. Bambang Utoyo as the South Sumatran commander in the first of a series of steps to resolve the crisis that has split the Indonesian Army.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 25 -- Winners of an international contest for United Nations postage stamp designs were announced today by the United Nations Postal Administration after a day-long meeting of a five-man jury at United Nations headquarters.

E. B. Weiss, director of merchandising at the Grey Advertising Agency, has been vigorously nudging department stores to "wake up" to the changing retailing picture. Yesterday at the luncheon of the Sales Executives Club in the Roosevelt Hotel he defended them for not expending more time and effort in training sales people who, he said, are in reality only "housekeepers."

A proposal that Roman Catholic and Protestant leaders meet in Colombia, South America, some time during January to discuss allegations of Protestant persecution in that country was made yesterday in that current (Nov. 29) issue of Presbyterian Life, official church periodical published in Philadelphia.

BOSTON, Nov. 25 -- The New England Governors were warned today that, much as the region welcomed and needed new industries, it was imperative that the real bread-and-butter producer, textiles, should not be abandoned.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- A group of prominent citizens, many with military experience or backgrounds, opened today a full-scale inquiry into the military services' use of manpower.

Election of Philip S. Harris as president of the Grayson-Robinson Stores, Inc., which operates a chain of apparel stores from coast to coast, was announced yesterday by Walter Kirschner, chairman. He succeeds Hyman P. Kuchai who resigned to give greater attention to his personal interests.

HACKENSACK, N. J., Nov. 25 -- John Winberry, former deputy attorney general in charge of gambling investigations in Middlesex County, told the Bergen County grand jury here today that he believed gamblers had enjoyed effective protection in several New Jersey areas and particularly in Bergen County.
CHICAGO, Nov. 25 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:...

The Swiss Army could mobilize 800,000 well-trained soldiers in two days and successfully defend that strategically placed republic against an aggressor, Richard C. Patterson Jr., United States Ambassador to Switzerland, told 300 guests at an American-Swiss friendship dinner last night.

Mrs. Ivy Baker Priest, designated yesterday by Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the President-elect, to be Treasurer of the United States, got her start in politics at the age of 10, she told reporters yesterday at Eisenhower headquarters in the Commodore Hotel.

Public officials are being forced to undergo "too many investigations by people interested only in sensationalism or in promoting themselves," Park Commissioner Robert Moses declared yesterday. Included in his criticism were some newspapers that he felt were putting sensationalism into news.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- The American Federation of Labor named George Meany as its president today and made a dramatic new bid to the strife-torn Congress of Industrial Organizations for a merger.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 25 -- The United States and twenty of its allies agreed today to give priority to India's new formula for ending the Korean war, but Washington remained determined to insist on the changes it believed were necessary to make the plan workable.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 25 -- The gem of the two opening concerts of the first Pittsburgh International Contemporary Music Festival was Anton von Webern's Five Movements for String Quartet, Op. 5. Here is music of concentration and deep conviction.

One of the country's largest open-end, or mutual fund, investing companies was a substantial purchaser of common stocks during the recent market reaction. As a result of these purchases, the $238,000,000 Wellington Fund of Philadelphia reported yesterday, the percentage of common stock holdings, which had been reduced substantially during the market rise last year, presently accounts for 63.34 per cent of all resources.
Allow me to correct some -- probably unintentional -- inaccuracies in the list of former Presidents of the Polish Republic, printed on Page 7 of your issue of Nov. 21.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 25 -- A five-member negotiating committee appointed by the United Nations reported today that it had not been able to come to an agreement with the Union of South Africa on the future of the former mandated territory of South-West Africa.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 (AP) -- Representative E. E. Cox, Democrat of Georgia, asserted today that Owen Lattimore, Johns Hopkins University professor, had obtained large sums of money from the Rockefeller Foundation and that the money had been used "for subversive purposes."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- The National Labor Relations Board asserted today that it had imposed its first punishment for the filing of a false non-Communist affidavit by a union officer since it began receiving the affidavits in 1948 under prove, ions of the Taft-Hartley Act.

AT "SNIPER RIDGE," on the Korean Front, Nov. 20 -- Many of the leaders and advisers of the South Korean Army, which has fought well in this rock-strewn crucible of the war, believe that there are deficiencies in this Army that must be corrected before it can become a top-notch fighting force.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 25 -- Ambassador Abba S. Eban of Israel called today for a fresh start in the United Nations' long-standing efforts to mend Arab-Israeli relations and proposed a "blueprint for peace in the Middle East."

Passports of Henry Willcox, a New York engineer, and his wife, Mrs. Anita Parkhurst Willcox, said to be the first Americans to return here from a so-called Asian and Pacific Peace Conference in Communist China, were seized yesterday by immigration authorities at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Nov. 26 (AP) -- Painstaking work by United State Air Force investigators prevented Staff Sgt. Giuseppe E. Cascio, a photo laboratory technician accused of having conspired "to give intelligence to the enemy," from selling secret data on improved F-86 Sabre jets, the Air Force said here Tuesday.
MEXICO CITY, Nov. 25 -- General Eisenhower aroused hopes here today that he would pay an official visit to Mexico in the near future, possibly before his inauguration.

A portrait of Dr. George Francis Cahill, done by the English portrait painter Frank O. Salisbury for the Presbyterian Hospital, will be unveiled this afternoon by Dr. Cahill's 12-year-old granddaughter, Peggy Ann McGrath, at a reception at the Metropolitan Club.

Gerald M. Loeb, partner in E. F. Hutton Co., members of the New York Stock Exchange, in a recent address before the Wharton School of Finance of the University of Pennsylvania declared that Wall Street must become a "growth industry."
TOKYO, Wednesday, Nov. 26 (AP) -- United Nations Headquarters communique 1,445, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M. Wednesday, Korean time:
PARIS, Nov. 25 -- For the second time within a week, Premier Antoine Pinay won a vote in the National Assembly today by threatening to resign.
LONDON, Nov. 25 -- A design of the head of Queen Elizabeth II by a 71-year-old woman artist has been adopted for the coins that are to be struck next year for the new reign.

Like most civilized persons, Charles Best is concerned with the alarming growth of delinquency among our youth. It is this subject into which he has searched in his play, "Gordon Reilly," which opened last night at the Originals Only Playhouse in Greenwich Village.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- Arthur E. Summerfield said today he would submit his resignation as chairman of the Republican National Committee at a meeting of that organization which he will call around inauguration day, next Jan. 20. He will presumably take the oath of office as Postmaster General on Jan. 21, provided the Senate confirms his and other Cabinet nominations immediately, as is the custom.
Clifford F. Hood, a former Illinois farm boy, will become president of the world's largest steel company, the United States Steel Corporation, on Jan. 1.
Lack of facilities to train all the students in this country who want to study medicine was deplored yesterday by Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt.

In nominating Ezra Taft Benson of Utah to be Secretary of Agriculture President-elect Eisenhower has selected a man who by all accounts is a "middle-of-the-roader." This is strikingly indicated by Mr. Benson's apparent acceptability to both right and left wings of organized farming.

Direct passenger service between Israel and the United States will be established by M. Dizengoff Co. (Shipping), Ltd., after the merger of the concern with Zim Israel Navigation Company, a company spokesman said here yesterday.

Police Commissioner George P. Monaghan said yesterday that he was thinking of buying eight-pound bulletproof vests and eighteen-pound shields for members of the force. He made it clear, though, that he did not intend to weigh down the cop on the beat like the motion picture extras in "Quo Vadis."

J. J. Haggerty and J. Foster each scored three-game victories yesterday as the New York Athletic Club turned back the Yale Club, 5 -- 0, on the loser's courts and moved into first place in the Class A interclub competition of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association.

" Mary Todd: Biography of a Marriage," by Ruth Painter Randall, a presentation of the personality and "intimate life of Abraham Lincoln and a biography of his wife, has been scheduled for February publication by Little, Brown.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- Everybody wants to know what President Truman plans to do when he retires. Today he said somewhat facetiously that he would be raising yellow-legged chickens down on the family farm in Missouri.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- A program for building stand-by equipment capable of producing armaments on short notice in event of all-out war was outlined today by Henry H. Fowler, director of the Office of Defense Mobilization.

Much has been made of the point -- and rightly so -- of television developing its own writers. One of those who has shown a marked development is Horton Foote, who last Sunday evening over the Television Playhouse (9 P. M. on N. B. C.) contributed a penetrating study of a father-and-son relationship under the title of "The Old Beginning."

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Nov. 25 -- "Selective selling," making items of less tonnage that require more labor and greater selling effort, was prescribed today by Herman W. Steinkraus, president of the Bridgeport Brass Company, as the answer to metal shortages.

The happiness note surrounds Howard Cann, who is working on his thirtieth season as basketball coach at New York University. He's happy for more than one reason, and when he says "I think we're going to have a good ball team," you have to agree with him.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Indo-China, Nov. 25 -- French aircraft made damaging attacks on Vietminh troops today around the perimeter of the Nasan airfield, the isolated French defense position in the Thai Mountains 110 miles northwest of Hanoi.

MOSCOW, Nov. 25 -- Eugene Varga, noted Soviet economist, charged in the newspaper Pravda today that the ban imposed by the United States upon free British trade with the Soviet Union, China and Eastern Europe was driving British economy deeper and deeper into a crisis.

ATLANTA, Nov. 25 (AP) -- Senator Richard B. Russell, Democrat of Georgia, said today that Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois was the titular head of the Democratic party but that Democratic policymaking would be set in Congress during the next four years.

JERUSALEM, Nov. 25 -- The Israeli Parliament voted a resolution tonight expressing its feeling of "outrage" at the Czechoslovak treason trial. The trial was described in the debates as an affront to the Israeli nation and was said to have besmirched the good name of the state of Israel.

Enthusiasm was dampened a bit yesterday on the stock market as the pace of dealings slackened and what is generally termed a consolidation process ensued. It was a session that offered some contradictions, since gains still outnumbered losses and while the composite rate touched a new high since 1930, the closing figure showed a net decline on the day of 0.19 point.

Despite the fine winning performance of the Giants in Washington last Sunday with Fred Benners quarterbacking the team from the T, Charley Conerly probably will be the starting field general against the Steelers in Pittsburgh next Sunday.

LONDON, Nov. 25 -- With an eye to the conference of British Commonwealth prime ministers here this week and the new administration taking office in Washington next year, the directors of the American Chamber of Commerce in London published a program today for a long-term solution of the persistent imbalance of payments between the sterling and dollar areas.

Counsel for two major private bus lines formally asked yesterday that Theodore W. Kheel, impartial chairman of the private transit industry, use his full power -- including an injunction -- to stop a strike threatened for next Monday.

Paul Caravella, 42 years old, of 411 East 116th Street, who was found dead in a Bronx lot on Oct. 25, a bullet in his head, a leather belt around his neck, and six cents in his pocket, left an estate of more than $60,000, according to papers on file in Surrogate's Court yesterday.
BALTIMORE, Nov. 25 (AP) -- Maryland hopes to keep Jim Tatum as its football coach after his present contract expires next June, the university president, H. C. Byrd, said today.

FALL RIVER, Mass., Nov. 25 (AP) -- A grand jury today indicted Mayor Edward C. Peirce of New Bedford and seven other persons on charges of conspiracy in connection with gambling in the old whaling city.
Settlement of a long impasse between East Coast deck officers and their employers was achieved yesterday with an increase of about 15 per cent in base pay and other benefits.
Lamps and decorative accessories make up the wares of a new shop at the Sachs Quality Store, Thirty-fifth Street and Eighth Avenue.

A new issue of $35,000,000 of twenty-seven-year debentures of the Pacific Telephone and Telegraph Company will be placed on the market today by underwriters headed by White, Weld Co. at a yield to investors of 3.13 per cent.

Billy (Curly) Vessels, University of Oklahoma left halfback, has been chosen the winner of the Downtown Athletic Club's 1952 Heisman Memorial Trophy, emblematic of the country's outstanding college football player.

Three more selections for key places in the new Republican national administration were announced yesterday by Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the President-elect, at his headquarters in the Commodore Hotel.

The New York Rangers, virtually at full strength-for the first time this season, will meet the rookie-studded Toronto Maple Leafs at Madison Square Garden tonight. The game will be the first Of seven for the Blues in the next twelve nights.

Disabled Korean veterans, who normally experience difficulty in procuring work, are obtaining more gainful and enjoyable employment through the New York City Veterans Service Center at 500 Park Avenue.

Any substantial change that may occur in pricing of cotton textiles in the months ahead is likely to be upward, according to Robert C. Jackson, executive vice president of the American Cotton Manufacturers Institute. There should be little hesitancy on the part of wholesalers and retailers to come into the market, he said, to take advantage of current low prices.

BUFFALO, N. Y., Nov. 25 -- For the first time in a generation, the New York State Teachers Association revised its code of ethics here today to include a specific declaration of loyalty to the state and nation.
Both the Pennsylvania Railroad and Long Island Transit Authority plans for reorganization of the Long Island Rail Road were opposed yesterday by the city.
Revocation of the National Labor Relations Board's certification of four independent unions with a total membership of 500,000 was urged yesterday by a Federal grand jury.

Producers of men's wear fabrics should work with retailers to find what the public wants and then produce the types of cloth that will meet with consumer acceptance, Ralph Schneider, president of Broadstreet's, said yesterday at a meeting of the National Association of Wool Manufacturers at the Gramercy Park Hotel.

After deliberating for almost eight hours, a General Sessions Court jury last night found James J. Fox, suspended detective, and a 28-year-old woman co-defendant guilty on a three-count indictment in connection with a $20,000 shakedown plot.

FRANKFURT, Germany, Nov. 25 (AP) -- A United States Occupation District Court was told today a new American engineering company headed by a former Army engineer had collected more than $1,000,000 in fees on United States Army defense projects in West Germany in the last fourteen months.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- Price ceilings on most women's, misses' and junior misses' apparel, apparel furnishings and accessories were ordered suspended today by the Office of Price Stabilization, effective tomorrow.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Nov. 26 -- The Chinese Communists last night and early today raided United Nations positions at "Jackson Heights" on the approaches to the South Korean capital of Seoul but failed to hold the ground after a five-hour engagement.
