HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Nov. 25 -- Hofstra College closed its greatest football season with a 55-to-7 triumph over Wagner today. It was the eighth victory in nine starts for the Flying Dutchmen and the fifth setback in eight for the Seahawks.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 25 -- A majority of the delegations in the General Assembly's Economic and Financial Committee announced at the close of debate today support of an Argentine proposal aimed at establishing a parity between world prices for raw materials and agricultural commodities and those for manufactured goods.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 25 -- The Screen Writers Guild did not vote last night on ratification of the contract terms negotiated with the Alliance of Television Film Producers because the complete agreement has not yet been put into writing.
Futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were moderately active yesterday and closing prices were somewhat irregular, 48 points higher to 10 points lower than on Monday.
MONTREAL, Nov. 25 (AP) -- Gordie Howe, trying for a record-breaking third straight National Hockey League scoring championship, is the undisputed leader today in a tightly-bunched race.

Bonds listed on the New York Stock Exchange in October recovered most of their September losses. The average price on Oct. 31 was $98.05, a gain of 59 cents from the Sept. 30 level of $97.46. It compared with the Aug. 31 price of $98.14.

CHICAGO, Nov. 25 -- The Government announced late today that it would ask for a continuance of the trial of its anti-trust suit against 117 members of the du Pont family and six corporations until Jan. 5 because of the illness of Willis L. Hotchkiss, chief prosecutor and mainspring of the Federal case.

Coach Ed Danowski intends to start a new Fordham backfield against New York University in the traditional game of the Bronx rivalry that will be played Saturday at Triborough Stadium, Randalls Island.

BOWIE, Md., Nov. 25 (AP) -- Olympic View, claimed for $10,000 at Monmouth Park last July, gained his second straight victory over allowance company by winning the Governor's Mansion Purse today at odds of 14-1.

VIENNA, Nov. 25 -- Karel Svab, former Czechoslovak Deputy Minister of Defense, and Bedrich Reicin, Deputy Minister for Security, pleaded guilty to high treason in Prague today and with their testimony evidence in the trial of fourteen Czechoslovak Communist leaders ended.

Sister Elizabeth Kenny, seriously ill at her home in Toowoomba, Australia, after suffering a stroke on Friday, began a new treatment last night based on instructions received from New York by long-distance telephone.

Two three - story apartment houses at 61-25 and 61-27 Flushing Avenue in Maspeth, Queens, have been sold by Joan Kabriski to Carmelo and Carmela Iuvara. The Title Guarantee and Trust Company insured title for the buyers, who were represented by Mathew M. Balmuth, attorney.

A trial-and-error program to dislodge "permanent" parkers from congested main thoroughfares by barring all vehicles from standing, loading or unloading during rush periods will go into test operation on First and Second Avenues within thirty days.

Incensed over the service of subpoenas by the New York State Crime Commission on top pier labor officials and "large numbers" of the union membership, several hundred dock workers employed on the major North River passenger ship piers made plans last night to stage a protest strike at 8 A. M. today.

In an article recently THE NEW YORK TIMES described what in essence was called the generally deplorable housing situation of our Municipal Courts on Reade Street. As a recent juror, I wish to correct erroneous impressions. I believe that the building presents a variety of thoughtfully adjusted ideas which could well be applied elsewhere.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 26 -- Deputy Premier Blagoje Neskovic has been removed from office for pro-Russian tendencies, it was announced today.

Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, President-elect, yesterday named Arthur H. Vandenberg Jr., 45 years old, of Grand Rapids, Mich., to be Secretary to the President, and William P. Rogers, 39, a war veteran of Bethesda, Md., to be Deputy Attorney General.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- The Gulf Power Company of Pensacola, Fla., asked the Securities and Exchange Commission today for authority to sell up to $4,000,000 of short- term bank loan notes by next June 1. The notes are to be marketed to a group of fifteen banks.

Orders booked in October by furniture manufacturers were 5 per cent below the preceding month but exceeded bookings in the like month last year by 16 per cent, according to the monthly report yesterday by Seidman Seidman, accountants for many leading producers.

PARIS, Nov. 26 -- Delegates to a general conference of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization accepted today the resignation of Jaime Torres Bodet of Mexico as Director General. The delegates then agreed to proceed to an examination of a program for the next two years and to leave the budget for the moment at the ceiling they approved last Friday.

LONDON, Nov. 26 -- Tomorrow the British Commonwealth Prime Ministers' conference opens in London and on its agenda is the most challenging economic problem in the Commonwealth's history, a problem that can be solved by nothing less than a revolution in the free world's system of trade and payments.

As the rest of the city bustled with last-minute preparations for Thanksgiving, 300 disabled persons and their relatives gathered yesterday at the Institute for the Crippled and Disabled, Twenty-third Street and First Avenue, for an early celebration of the holiday.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 26 -- Pennsylvania's football team will be a 13-point favorite to win Coach George Munger's tenth Ivy League championship in fifteen years tomorrow when the Quakers take on Cornell in Franklin Field at 1:30 P. M.

PARIS, Nov. 26 -- The terms of the French proposals for the revision of conditions in the French-Saar conventions establishing the economic attachment of the Saar to France were approved officially today by the French Cabinet.

NEW DELHI, Nov. 26 -- Faced with a serious slump in the tea industry, more than twenty tea gardens in Assam and West Bengal have been closed down and many more were expected to go out of business, T. T. Krishnamachari, Minister of Commerce and Industry, told the House of the People today.
TORONTO, Nov. 26 (Canadian Press) -- A halt to higher living costs in Canada is seen by I. K. Johnston, president of the Imperial Bank of Canada. Addressing the bank's annual meeting today, he said:

Guards and tackles seldom get their hands on the ball during a football game, but Elmer Willhoite, Southern California guard, intercepted a pass in the third quarter of last Saturday's game with U. C. L. A. and raced down the sidelines 72 yards to the U. C. L. A. 8-yard line.

SYDNEY, Nov. 26 (AP) -- The managing director of one of Australia's biggest wool brokerage firms, on his return from the United States this week, warned that the Australian wool trade was in danger from substitute fibers.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture set 1953 production goals today calling for an increase of 3 per cent in the white potato crop and 39 per cent in sweet potatoes.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 26 --The contention of R. K. O. Radio Pictures that Paul Jarrico, the screen writer, had become an "object of public disgrace" and thereby had violated the "morals clause of his personal employment contract by his refusal to tell a Congressional committee if he was or had been a member of the Communist party was upheld today in Superior Court in Los Angeles.

Life is getting too pleasant to keep on like this indefinitely. Another highly enjoyable comedy has come to town. "Time Out For Ginger" is what Ronald Alexander, the author, calls it. Melvyn Douglas and a winning cast gave it a lively performance at the Lyceum last evening.

LONDON, Nov. 26 -- Prices advanced in most sections of the London stock markets today on modest investment demand. Domestic industrials sometimes closed below the day's best but the firm undertone was maintained and small gains were recorded among most of the leaders.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 26 (AP) -- Fred Saigh, Cardinal owner, said today he believed a blackout of telecasts of major league baseball for one year would be good "to see if TV really is as harmful as we think."

Two years ago Vladimir Clementis was here in New York, sitting in the General Assembly as head of the Czechoslovak delegation to the United Nations. He was then Foreign Minister, and the big boss in the regime he faithfully served was Rudolf Slansky, secretary-general of the Communist party.
OTTAWA, Nov. 26 (Canadian Press) -- Canada's grin men have opened full throttle on the biggest grain-moving rush of the season.
Heavy travel in and out of the city and pre-Thanksgiving dinners, parties and religious services set the pattern here yesterday for the annual observance of the holiday today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, the following principal changes for the week ended Nov. 19:

LOS ANGELES, Calif., Nov. 26 -- "Grandma" asked a taxi cab driver to wait while she robbed her third bank here today and fled with $257. She is the gray-haired little lady about 50 years old who since Oct. 17 has stolen $4.069 and started the most unusual dragnet in years.

Thanksgiving in these harried times is not a mockery. On the contrary, giving thanks is virtually a necessity to which we are impelled by the facts of modern life. In spite of the warfare, real or incipient, that threatens millions and the dire want that shadows too many tens of millions all over the world, there is abundant cause for deep-felt gratitude.
Win, lose or tie with Fordham on Saturday. New York University's football squad already has won high praise from Coach Hugh Devore.

SEOUL, Korea, Thursday, Nov. 27 (UP) -- South Korean sources indicated today that President Syngman Rhee would back down on his demand for the unification of Korea by force when he conferred with Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, United States President-elect.
BOWIE, Md., Nov. 26 (AP) -- In a bid from last place, Eugene Constantin Jr.'s Prop got up to win the $5,000 Southern Maryland Purse today by a length over Harborvale Stable's Alladier.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Nov. 26 -- While the cadet corps took over the Plain to rehearse its marching order for the pre-game parade into Municipal Stadium, Army's football squad today went through a final scrimmage in Michie Stadium in preparation for Saturday's clash with Navy at Philadelphia.

A showdown fight between the "liberal" and "conservative" wings of the Democratic state organization appeared in the offing yesterday as rival factions lined up behind their favorite candi dates for the post of state chairman being vacated by Paul E. Fitzpatrick.
The performance of "Don Giovanni" last night by the Metropolitan Opera Association was one of many distinctions, including the most interesting cast of the season thus far.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Nov. 26 -- The Indonesian Cabinet held a four-hour meeting tonight on the eve of the return of the Indonesian Parliament after a recess since some army officers staged the Oct. 17 demonstrations demanding its dissolution.

Many of the more than 2,000,000 American boys and girls of school age, now working full or part-time in industry and agriculture, are employed illegally, the National Child Labor Committee reported yesterday.

The Kimberly-Clark Corporation, pulp and paper producer, increased its sales in the six months ended with October to $80,255,422 from $78,728,580 in the similar period last year, but earnings declined, according to the report issued yesterday.
John J. McDonough retired yesterday after thirty-nine years in the Police Department and scores of young detectives expressed their regret.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- Plans for reorganization of the Veterans Administration designed to effect a saving of about $10,000,000 annually were announced today by Carl R. Gray Jr., Administrator.

Henry Willcox, whose passport was seized for traveling to Communist China, said yesterday that he went there "to stand up and be counted for peace." The New York engineer said his observations indicated Chinese Communist claims to be improving living standards of 500,000,000 Chinese by 15 per cent a year seemed "plausible."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- A decided upsurge in the number of new students entering college this fall was reported today by Earl J. McGrath, Commissioner of Education.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 26 (UP) -- The chairman of the Ohio Newspaper Association's Committee on Freedom of Information said today that a proposed rule to prohibit the taking of pictures in courtrooms while courts were in recess would be a "serious threat" to freedom of information.

MATTAMUSKEET, the concentration point for Canada geese and hopeful wildfowlers, seems to be providing more geese and a higher percentage of contented hunters than at any time in the history of this regulated shooting ground.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 26 -- An anti-trust action seeking treble damages of $242,166 was filed against the Canners League of California and six California canneries today by Zuckerman-Mandeville, asparagus grower in the San Joaquin Delta area near Stockton.

A new civic reform group, whose objectives include reducing the city budget by $100,000,000 and mobilizing "forceful action" by citizens against "the apparent disregard of moral ethics by certain city officials," announced yesterday its organization under the chairmanship of the Right Rev. Charles K. Gilbert, retired Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- The Communist purge in Prague, with its ugly anti-Semitic overtones, is regarded here as just one more effort by the Kremlin to isolate the captive countries.

The Madeleine Renaud-Jean-Louis Barrault French company puts on its fifth bill at the Ziegfeld Theatre this evening at 8 o'clock under the auspices of S. Hurok. It is the Jean Anouilh play, "La Repetition ou L'Amour Puni" ("The Rehearsal or Love Punished").

Gen. Jonathan M. Wainwright, commanding officer on Corregidor after the departure of General of the Army Douglas MacArthur, has consented to be a defense witness at the treason trial of former Sgt. John David Provoo, defense counsel announced yesterday.
TORONTO, Nov. 26 (AP) -- A block of 90,000 shares of Loblaw, Inc., American self-service food chain, is reported to have been bought by Garfield Weston, Canadian industrialist.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- Senator Wayne Morse of Oregon, who resigned in a huff from the Republican party during the recent campaign, said after a visit with President Truman today that he was going home to dig the new postholes required in his new position as an independent.
The Government-owned liner Washington, which arrived here yesterday on her final run this year as a carrier of military dependents, is being prepared for temporary lay-up at Pier 16, Staten Island.

CHICAGO, Nov. 26 (AP) -- Ezzard Charles, former heavyweight champion, scored a first-round knockdown, but then plodded to a unanimous ten - round decision over Jimmy Bivins in a dull bout at the Chicago Stadium tonight.

A large group of pottery pieces. hand turned in quaint traditional forms, will go on display tomorrow at the Pottery of All Nations, 108 Seventh Avenue, South. These pieces were made by C. C. Coles of the Coles family of North Carolina, whose craft is said to date back to pre-Revolutionary days.

Prices of futures were generally higher on the New York commodity exchanges. Trading was light, except in cocoa and coffee, as the holiday lull set in. Lead, tin, zinc, cocoa, sugar and coffee closed higher. Hides, rubber and cottonseed oil futures were lower and potatoes, wool and soybean oil ended mixed.
A radioactive cobalt "bomb" for the treatment of deep-seated cancers was delivered to Montefiore Hospital in the Bronx yesterday from the Canadian atomic energy plant at Chalk River, Ont.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- The Most Rev. Angel Herrera, the Bishop of Malaga, Spain, and one of that country's most outspoken advocates of land and labor reforms, said today that Spain and the United States were the two logical countries to lead in the fight against communism.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 26 (UP) -- Jordan Olivar, a hasty fill-in whose first job was to get acquainted with his players, today signed a new three-year contract as Yale's head football coach for having led the Elias to their best season since 1946.

Theodore W. Kheel, impartial chairman of the private transit industry, notified union leaders yesterday that he would issue an injunction to stop a bus strike threatened for next Monday if he found he had legal authority to do so.

DANBURY, Conn., Nov. 26 -- Dr. John D. Booth and Dr. Nathaniel B. Selleck, whose suspensions from the medical staff of Danbury Hospital on Oct. 1 touched off a bitter controversy, were reappointed to the staff today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- Mrs. Harry S. Truman, outgoing first lady, will show Mrs. Dwight D. Eisenhower, incoming first lady, through the White House Monday morning.

Business will come to a halt today, as the nation observes Thanksgiving Day, and all financial and commodity markets will be closed. Many units in the industrial world will extend the holiday over the week-end, suspending operations until Monday.

MEXICO CITY, Nov. 26 -- Ambassador William O'Dwyer, whose resignation was announced by the White House today, said he would take a holiday when he left office Dec. 6 and would not announce his plans for private life until the end of December.

New York University's basketball team came from behind in the fourth quarter last night to defeat the surprisingly strong St. Peter's College of Jersey City, 75 -- 71, at the Alumni Gymnasium on the University Heights campus.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 (AP) -- The Federal Reserve Board reported today that department store sales in October topped sales in September and also those for October a year ago.

ITHACA, N. Y., Nov. 26 -- Since religious training, to be most meaningful, must be closely related to everyday life, parents themselves play an important part in this training, Edward V. Pope of the New York State College of Home Economics, Cornell University, declared today.

Joseph Bonavita, the generous Brooklyn tavern-keeper who has attracted the attention of the police and hospital authorities by handing out thousands of dollars to unfortunates along the Bowery in Manhattan, may have to forego his annual visit there this year.

Plans for a World Fair in Sao Paulo, Brazil, scheduled for February, 1954, are already arousing the interest of prospective exhibitors from the United States, it was reported yesterday by Joao Costa Doria, representative of the organizing committee.

" IN the name of Allah, woman! Enow is enow!" the exasperated Persian gentleman in Cobean's cartoon is saying. He is addressing a somewhat beautiful lady whose interminable singing, apparently, is distracting him from the book of verses and the jug of nutritious wine underneath the bough in the wilderness.

BINGHAMTON, N. Y., Nov. 26 -- American chemical research, much of it for defense, is being delayed and retarded by a "marked shortage of technically trained men," Louis W. Munchmyer, president of the Armed Forces Chemical Association, said here today.

Festoons of smilax, oleander trees and masses of white chrysanthemums provided the traditional green and white decor for the New York Junior League Ball, held last night in the main ballroom of Plaza. Debutantes of this season, provisional members of the group were honored at the fete.

Things continue to look brighter for the New York Rangers. The local skating heroes managed to record a victory over the Toronto Maple Leafs in a National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night.

TORONTO, Nov. 26 (Canadian Press) -- United States cigarettes -- priced at 20 for 33 cents -- now are being sold in stores of two grocery chains in Ontario and one in Quebec, officials of the stores said today. The cigarettes were first advertised here at this price last week.
With seven standout lettermen returning, Ken Norton, in his seventh season as head coach, believes he will have "a good representative Manhattan College team this season."

Traditional clashes mark the annual Turkey Day schoolboy football program today, but principal interest will be focused on the games that will have mythical. City P.S.A.L. and City C.H.S.A.A. championships at stake. Lafayette, the only undefeated and untied public high eleven in the city, will meet once-beaten Erasmus Hall at Brooklyn College Field at 10 A. M.

The Federal Maritime Board has informally notified steamship company members of the North Atlantic Continental Freight Conference that its inquiry into the conference's dual rate system would be reopened next week, according to reports from Washington last night.

HARTFORD, Nov. 26 -- The State Board of Election Canvassers officially certified today the results of the state and national election on Nov. 4. The official figures showed Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower defeated Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson in Connecticut by a margin of 129,363.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 26 (UP) -- President Truman, most of the Cabinet, and Chief Justice Fred N. Vinson will be among the dignitaries in the stands at Philadelphia Saturday for the Army-Navy game.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Indo-China, Nov. 26 -- The Communist-led Vietminh regime is expected to try to build up the political movement against the French and against Bao Dai, the Vietnam Chief of State, in the northwest Tonkin mountain country into which their forces have driven during the last month. A Thai chieftain named Bac Cam Quy, who joined the Vietminh years ago, may figure prominently in the political maneuvers.

Truly the most important part of Thanksgiving Day is the morning, and the spending of it deserves the closest study. The morning of Thanksgiving Day is not to be treated as that of another day, another Thursday, or even just another holiday away from work.

The American Gas and Electric Company, one of the largest operating utility systems in the country, reported yesterday a net income of $26,307,500 for the year to Oct. 31, compared with $24,364,525 in the preceding twelve months.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- The Roman Catholic hierarchy in the United States joined today in paying tribute to the thousands of clergy and laity of that church who had suffered persecution and death for their faith in countries conquered by the "hosts of atheistic materialism."

HOUSTON, Tex., Nov. 26 -- Giuseppe Cascio, Air Force staff sergeant accused in Tokyo of conspiring to sell jet fighter information to Korean Communists, was called a mental case today by his former wife and a medical officer at the Houston Veterans Administration Hospital.

CHICAGO, Nov. 26 -- Grain futures were weak most of the session today, reversing the late trend of yesterday when little follow-up buying appeared. Uncertainty over the Korean situation, expectation of liberal deliveries on December contracts and the more favorable weather conditions for winter wheat were unsettling influences.

TOKYO, Thursday, Nov. 27 -- Communist forces renewed attacks today on the central front in Korea, striking during the early morning darkness at "Pinpoint Hill" and "Rocky Point" on sharply contested "Sniper Ridge."
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed barely steady yesterday, with active months 18 to 38 points net lower than on Tuesday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- A Congressional investigating subcommittee laid before the public today what it called the "incredible saga" of the United States vs. Norman E. Miller.

VIENNA, Nov. 26 -- The trial of Rudolf Slansky, Vladimir Clementis and twelve other former Czechoslovak Communists ended in Prague today after financial, economic and military experts had estimated the alleged damage done to Czechoslovakia by their so-called treason and the prosecutor had demanded the death sentence for all fourteen.

Directors of Bausch Lomb Optical Company declared an extra dividend of 20 cents a share on the common stock and a quarterly dividend of 15 cents a share, payable on Dec. 1 and Jan. 15, respectively, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- The careers in private life of citizens whom General Eisenhower has chosen as most important members of his Cabinet explain the pithy comment here that "the seat of domestic government is to be transferred to the industrial Middle West."

Followers of the stock market will have good reason to give thanks on this traditional holiday, for prices shot ahead yesterday to peak levels for twenty-two years. In a continuation of the post-election advance which has carried quotations well past the highs for the year, the share list scored further additions of 1 to 3 points with the composite rate of THE NEW YORK TIMES advancing 1.57 points.

MEXICO CITY, Nov. 26 -- In one of his last official acts, outgoing President Miguel Aleman today publicly embraced the Mexican primate, Archbishop Luis Maria Martinez, under the nave of the Basilica of Guadalupe, Mexico's national shrine.

Today has special significance for Gustave Kopeczel, 42 years old. Yesterday in Kings County Court. Judge Louis Goldstein vacated a 1944 five-to-twenty-year sentence as a second felony offender and re-sentenced him to two and one-half to five years.

IT was just a dozen years ago that the mighty Chicago Bears turned loose the awesome striking power of their T-formation on the Washington Redskins in the championship playoff to stun the nation by their 73-0 victory. A few weeks later, Stanford bedazzled Nebraska in the Rose Bowl, also with the T, and an irresistible trend in sports began. The entire country went hog-wild over the terrible T.

Factory shipments of most large electrical household appliances for the first nine months of 1952 were behind the volume in the comparable period last year, the National Electrical Manufacturers Association reported yesterday.

Handing out the stiffest jail sentences thus far in his drive against multiple-parking violators, Chief Magistrate John M. Murtagh yesterday sent three offenders to the workhouse for thirty to ninety days and fined the three a total of $1,562.

CHICAGO, Nov. 26 -- A planned delay until Jan. 5 in the trial of the Government's anti-trust suit against the du Ponts will add heavily to expenses of the defendants and force a reshuffling of operations of Federal District Court, fifteen major law firms in Chicago and other cities, and the Anti-Trust Division of the Justice Department in Washington, court observers said today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- Sir Oliver Franks, British Ambassador to the United States, declared today that United States-British friendship was the foundation for the hopes of freedom, and that despite differences and disagreements, should it come "to the pinch and to the clinch," the two friends "are one."

There are now in the United States about 22,000,000 boys and girls between the ages of 10 and 19, with an annual addition of 2,500,000 replacing a somewhat similar number becoming adults yearly. This is the estimate of the Gilbert Youth Research Organization, which points out that about 7,000 new prospects come into the market daily.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 26 -- Other programs of the first Pittsburgh International Contemporary Music Festival may deal with weightier musical matters, but last night's concert at Carnegie Music Hall had a charm all its own.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- Following are the letter of resignation of William O'Dwyer. Ambassador to Mexico and former Mayor of New York, and President Truman's acceptance:
Amid the many disappointments of the post-war world there is reason for some satisfaction over the latest developments in the two principal former enemy countries -- Germany and Japan.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 26 -- The United States accepted tonight, with one minor condition, the second revision of a compromise Indian proposal on the repatriation of Korean prisoners of war. The new Indian draft was submitted in the afternoon by V. K. Krishna Menon in response to pleas by Britain and Canada, the spokesmen of the Western powers.
CHICAGO, Nov. 26 (AP) -- An early winter assault on the Midwest slackened tonight after at least fifteen persons had died and traffic had been tied up from Colorado east to Minnesota.

An increase last week of 572,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline supplies was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end, total stocks were 123,885,000 barrels, compared with 123,313,000 a week earlier and 122,105,000 a year ago.

The whole concept of Thanksgiving Day is deeply woven into the fabric of our lives. It follows familar patterns of behavior. It has its own symbols. To each of us it has its own group of remembrances, its own direction that probably stems from childhood. It is, indeed, so much a part of us that we may risk taking much of it for granted.

The Commonwealth Prime Ministers conference which begins today in London was recently described by Foreign Secretary Eden as the most important in twenty years. Like all the rest of us the Commonwealth has reached the end of a chapter and has to begin a new one.

The New York Newspaper Printing Pressmen's Union, Local 2, A. F. L., last night joined the Typographical Union in rejecting a proposed wage and welfare agreement with the New York City Newspaper Publishers Association.

Stuart Gorrell and William Huckel have been named second vice presidents of the Chase National Bank, it was announced yesterday by Percy J. Ebbott, president. Both are on the bank's public relations and advertising staff.

The National Collegiate Athletic Association's television committee gave approval yesterday for Notre Dame to televise part of its game with Southern California Saturday after completion of the Army-Navy game.

For an outstanding essay on the subject "What Can We Do to Make America Better?" James William Conroy, 26-year-old paraplegic who is a patient at the Kingsbridge Veterans Hospital, the Bronx, received a $100 prize and a certificate at a dinner last night in the Henry Hudson Hotel, 353 West Fifty-seventh Street.

CAMDEN, Nov. 26 -- The Delaware River Port Authority expects to place on the financial market in January a $90,000,000 bond issue to finance construction of a second bridge across the Delaware River between Philadelphia and Gloucester, N. J.

HONG KONG, Nov. 26 -- Amid intensified preparations now being made in Peiping for the introduction of Communist China's first Five-Year Plan early next year, Kao Kang, chairman of the Northeast People's Government, is emerging as a man of increasing stature in the top layers of Chinese Red hierarchy.

DANBURY, Conn., Nov. 26 (AP) -- Transfer of the controlling interest of Flight Refueling, Inc. of Danbury to a group of new owners, including Laurance S. Rockefeller has been arranged, the Danbury concern announced today.

BONN, Germany, Nov. 26 -- The Foreign Affairs Committee of the Bundestag completed today its report on Allied-German treaties and, with only Socialist members dissenting, recommended ratification of the treaties by the Lower House.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 26 -- Thanksgiving, turkey and trimmings found an unexpectedly eloquent champion at the United Nations today in the person of Uruguay's Dr. Enriques Fabregat.

Presbyterian Hospital was described as the finest demonstration of the "altruistic purpose of a great people under free enterprise" at a reception held yesterday at the Metropolitan Club, Fifth Avnue and Sixtieth Street. The speaker, Joseph E. Davies, former Ambassador to the Soviet Union, said there was no hospital in the world to compare with it, and with the urological clinic headed by Dr. George Francis Cahill.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 (UP) -- The Defense Department announced today that American battle casualties in Korea now total 126,997, an increase of 271 over last week's report.

NEWARK, Nov. 26 -- An ordinance providing for a $325,000 bond issue for the purchase by the Board of Education of Ruppert Stadium from the New York Yankee Baseball Club was passed on first reading by the City Commission today.

The old and the new, as is often the case in the world of realism, are blended this year in the world of toys. Despite the inroads of science, in the form of space suits and ray guns, little girls who dream of princesses and small boys who want a fishing set just like daddy's can have their wishes gratified.
The offering by Magma Copper Company of 266,227 new shares of capital stock to its stockholders at a subscription price of $24.50 a share is now effective, the company said yesterday.

LONDON, Nov. 26 -- Egg rationing in Britain will be abandoned in the spring because a widespread black market has completely broken down the legal egg distribution system, the House of Commons was told today.

ROCQUENCOURT, France, Nov. 26 -- There are some dark looks and grumblings at Supreme Allied Headquarters these days because Field Marshal Viscount Montgomery, Deputy Supreme Commander and a well known "fresh air fiend" has decided that most of the 385 North Atlantic Treaty Organization officers on duty are getting soft and sedentary.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 26 (AP) -- Clifford F. Hood, who will become president of the United States Steel Corporation on Jan. 1, fired the explosive charge which tapped the billionth ton of steel his company has made.
The Federal Bar Association of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut observed its twenty-fifth anniversary yesterday with a luncheon attended by 500 members and guests at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
DETROIT, Nov. 26 (AP) -- One of the leadership jams in the National Football League is expected to be broken partially here tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- William P. Rogers, who has been designated to be Deputy Attorney General in the Administration of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the President-elect, already has made his imprint on the nation's capital. A former chief counsel for two Senate investigating committees, Mr. Rogers has impressed both Republicans and Democrats in Congress as one of the best investigators to climb Capitol Hill in recent years.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- The Administration appeared tonight to be fighting a desperate rearguard action to preserve the framework of wage and price controls until the party had left office in January. Labor, business groups, Southern Democrats and Republicans were banded together in an effort to force the Administration's hand.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- The resignation of William O'Dwyer, the controversial former Mayor of New York, as Ambassador to Mexico was announced today in an exchange of expressions of mutual high esteem with President Truman.

REHOVOT, Israel, Nov. 26 -- The creation of an institute of Zionist studies, the expansion of the Weizmann Institute of Science and the establishment of seventy - eight post - doctorate fellowships are among the features of plans for a "livng memorial" to the late President Chaim Weizmann.

Manufacturers of women's popular priced dresses are anticipating a substantial pick-up of business for spring. Volume producers are getting the first reaction to styles which have been shown to store buyers, and orders for January delivery are beginning to come in, it was learned yesterday.
TOKYO, Thursday, Nov. 27 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,446, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Thursday, Korea time:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- Charles E. Wilson, president of General Motors who has been designated as the next Secretary of Defense, spent four hours today in the Pentagon getting a first look at his expected duties and a briefing on the world situation.

As one of the taxpayers for whom City Controller Lazarus Joseph has offered to "save money" by eliminating the municipal radio station, WNYC, I should like to register the strongest negative votes against Mr. Joseph's bizarre concept of economy. As one of the city station's devoted listeners, I can think of no more rewarding expenditure of my tax dollar.

Jack Gross, younger brother of Harry Gross, convicted bookmaker, was arraigned yesterday before Judge Samuel S. Leibowitz in Kings County Court on an indictment charging him with one count of perjury in the first degree and two counts of second-degree perjury.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 26 (UP) -- Detectives said Raul Rodriguez Vargas, 32 years old, had admitted today that he had stolen a $6,000 ring from Black, Starr Gorham, Inc., a Fifth Avenue jewelry store in New York and asserted that he then lost it.

William A. Tierney, the 26-year-old suspended patrolman who received a suspended sentence on a charge of third-degree assault last Tuesday, after agreeing to leave the department, submitted his resignation that same day, it was announced yesterday at Police Headquarters.
LONDON, Nov. 26 -- A controversy has arisen over the plastic relief design of the head of Queen Elizabeth II for the new coins to be minted next year.

The green of the shamrock will join the blues, the oranges and the golds of other international airlines over the North Atlantic next April 1 when Aerlinte Eireann (Irish Air Lines) begins scheduled air tourist service between Ireland and the United States.

Top leaders of the Congress of Industrial Organizations expressed certainty yesterday that the C. I. O. convention in Atlantic City next week would accept an American Federation of Labor proposal for resumption of unity negotiations.
PARIS, Nov. 21 -- Expressly for real jewelry, Gilbert Orcel designs calots and diadems, beautifully sculptured and as precious in their way as the gems they display.

MIAMI, Fla., Nov. 26 (AP) -- Tropical Park's $10,000-added Inaugural Handicap, opening-day feature of a Florida racing season that promises to be the richest yet, was split into two $10,000 divisions today to accommodate the twenty-one entries.

This is in reply to the letter of William R. Mathews, editor and publisher of The Arizona Daily Star, published Nov. 20. Mr. Mathews advocates that we capitulate to the Communist demands for return of all Chinese and Korean prisoners, including those who have indicated that they are violently opposed to being returned.

The strike of more than 1,000 dock workers on North River piers yesterday was a strike not against employers but against the public, a mutiny against lawful official inquiry. It reflects an apparent opinion among some longshore union members that they and their hiring bosses are beyond the reach of the law, as indeed they long have been.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 26 -- Representative John J. Allen Jr. of the Seventh California Congressional District disclosed to the Propeller Club here today a sixpoint merchant marine program that he said had been worked out by him and other Republican advisers for the guidance of the President-elect, Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 26 -- The United Nations got assurance today from a leading Arab spokesman that Jordan would agree to the internationalization of Jerusalem if Israel would agree to carry out the re-admission of Arab refugees and the settlement of territorial claims on the basis of past United Nations decisions.
Making her New York debut last night in Town Hall, Martha Holmes, soprano, sang a difficult program of music by Schubert, Schumann, Debussy and Wolf. Paul Ulanowsky accompanied.

Dr. Albert Schatz, co-discoverer of streptomycin, and Dr. Sarah Riedman, physiologist, have cooperated to write a book about the microbial world for children. In "The Story of Microbes," the two doctors tell how the organisms were discovered, how we have been able to use them on farms, in industries and in our kitchens, as well as in the war against disease.

A new marketing of toll revenue bonds of the Maine Turnpike Commission is being planned, with a view to retiring by call the commission's present outstanding debt and financing extension of the expressway from Portland north to Augusta.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 (AP) -- An oil lease buyer has told the Security and Exchange Commission that within a seven-month period he made almost a million dollars on a thousand dollar investment -- and that he has prospects of making plenty more.
HUNTINGTON, W. Va., Nov. 26 -- Fourteen women and children perished tonight in a blaze that swept a three-story building at the Huntington State Hospital, a mental institution.

CLEVELAND, Nov 26 -- Techniques to allow jet aircraft engines to run hotter, and therefore faster, are one of the major challenges facing the metals industry, the American Society for Metals reported last night as a two-day conference of engineers and scientists adjourned.

EL PASO, Tex., Nov. 26 (AP) -- A formal protest was made to Mexico's Pan-American road race officials today that the Lincoln stock car entries that had taken the first three places were illegally "souped up."

PARIS, Nov. 26 -- Premier Antoine Pinay today maintained his hold on a majority in the National Assembly in a number of skirmishes with the Opposition. The agenda that the Premier insisted upon was accepted by a vote of 315 to 290.

MINEOLA, L. I., Nov. 26 -- The will of Allan S. Lehman of Picket Farm, Westbury, a partner in the banking firm of Lehman Brothers and a nephew of Senator Herbert H. Lehman, was filed today for probate in Nassau County Surrogate's Court.

Official action on the proposed $40,000,000 improvement of Columbus Circle, including the new 130-foot-high coliseum, was initiated yesterday by the City Planning Commission when it set Dec. 10 for a public hearing on the improvement.

A majority of the delegations in the Economic and Financial Committee of the United Nations went on record on Tuesday as supporting a proposal by Argentina which would establish "a parity" between world raw material prices and the world prices of manufactured goods.

Today's new film is "The Thief of Venice," a period costume drama filmed on location and at the Scalera Studios in Italy, with the late Maria Montez, Paul Christian, Massimo Serrato and Faye Marlowe, at the Mayfair. The Twentieth Century-Fox release was produced by Robert Haggiag and directed by John Brahm from a script by Jesse L. Lasky Jr. and a story by Michael Pertwee.

More than 1,000 longshoremen employed on Hudson River piers between Forty-fourth and Fifty-seventh Streets staged a one-day strike yesterday to protest the serving of subpoenas on four union leaders by the New York State Crime Commission.

Three fifth-grade pupils and their teacher received cuts and bruises yesterday when plaster from a ceiling beam fell on them in their fourth-floor classroom at Public School 11 at 320 West Twenty-first Street. All returned to the school after examination and treatment at St. Vincent's Hospital.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 26 -- Asian and Arab members of the United Nations are working on a resolution calling on the world organization to use its influence toward a resumption of French-Tunisian negotiations leading to the sovereignty of France's North African protectorate.
CLEVELAND, Nov. 27 (UP) -- Western Reserve University crushed Case Institute, 48 to 7, today in the fifty-seventh game of their football rivalry.
In giving thanks yesterday the people who live or work in New York City may have recalled that they have the protection of the finest hospital system in the world.

Thirty-six pedestrians, ranging in age from 67-year-old Harry Lohman of the Bronx to 18-year-old Ed Gulczynski of Philadelphia, started in the forty-second annual walk from City Hall to Coney Island yesterday. Only one failed to finish and at the surfside end of the ten-and-a-half-mile heel-and-toe test the winner was Arthur Fruauff, an unattached man from the Middle Village section of Queens.
BOONTON, N. J., Nov. 27 (AP) -- Two men drew jail terms totaling 270 days and fines of $612 on charges of illegally hunting deer last night. A companion paid a $220 fine and avoided jail.

DENVER, Nov. 27 (UP) -- Wyoming's defensive team came through in the clutches to fight off Denver's desperate passing attack in the final period here today for a 21 -- 14 victory before 7,152 fans who braved the 19-degree weather.

Keeping pace with the population growth on Long Island, the Long Island Lighting Company has just placed in operation a 100,000 kilowatt unit at its Glenwood Landing power station on the North Shore. This initial step in a $50,000,000 expansion program that will almost double the utility's generating facilities by 1954 provides for the system one of the most modern power plants in the country.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 27 -- Roy Harris, executive director of the first Pittsburgh Contemporary Music Festival, did not neglect the music of Roy Harris, composer. His Fifth Symphony was on last night's Pittsburgh symphony program, and his symphony for band was on tonight's program of the United States Military Academy band.

As the executives of the Yankees, Dodgers and Giants boarded a train at 6 o'clock last night for Phoenix, Ariz., site of the major-minor meetings which open there next Monday, there were differences of opinion on matters that will come up for decision.

It comes as a distinct shock to learn that many of the more than 2,000,000 boys and girls of school age working full or part time in industry and agriculture are employed illegally. This is the finding of the National Child Labor Committee.

One of the most revolutionary transportation trends in recent years has gone virtually unnoticed by the American public, according to the November issue of Planes, publication of the Aircraft Industries Association.
VIENNA, Nov. 27 -- Rudolf Slansky, Dr. Vladimir Clementis and nine other prominent Czechoslovak Communists tried for treason were sentenced today in Prague to death by hanging.

The letter you published in THE NEW YORK TIMES on Nov. 20, in which the writer mentioned the apathy of the people with regard to the hearings of the State Crime Commission, did not place sufficient emphasis on the attitude of the general public.

BERWICK, Pa., Nov. 27 -- Browning Ross set his third course record in a row as he won the forty-third renewal of the Berwick nine-and-one-third mile marathon race today. His time was 46 minutes 40 seconds -- one second better han his 1951 mark.

LONDON, Nov. 27 -- The Government's bill to denationalize the steel industry passed its second reading in the House of Commons today by a vote of 305 Go 269, giving Prime Minister Churchill's party a majority of thirty-six of the 574 members who voted out of a House of 625.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 (AP) -President Truman and his family went to church today and joined other worshipers in hymns of thanksgiving and prayers for world peace.

United States merchandise exports, which slackened in the third quarter from the 1951 annual rate of $15,000,000,000 to slightly more than $11,000,000,000, should show an upturn in 1953, according to an analysis of world trade problems made by John F. McKiernan, director of the New York Regional Office of the United States Department of Commerce.

LONDON, Nov. 27 -- For the first time since 1932 the Prime Ministers of the British Commonwealth countries got together here today to talk about their mutual economic problems. During the next two weeks or more they will survey every aspect of international trade and payments that affects the sterling area.

His expressed desire to be "a big shot" brought about the arraignment yesterday in Felony Court of Paul Knudsen, 16 years old, of 21 Helene Avenue, Larchmont, N. Y., on a charge of violating the Sullivan Law.
August fur promotions at retail are "essential and should be continued."

PARIS, Nov. 23 -- The highest United States economic officials in Europe are convinced that the solution of the "dollar problem" is not only in sight but within the grasp of intelligent administrators.

Dr. Jaime Torres Rodet's resignation as Director General of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization, which took effect in Paris on Wednesday, dramatized the startling contrast between what the agency is supposed to do and the means it has to do it with.

CHICAGO, Nov. 27 -- Snow continued to fall in flurries, driven by winds up to twenty miles an hour, across parts of Wisconsin, Minnesota, Michigan and Northern Illinois today. The hardest hit states of Iowa and Nebraska were hit again, this time by near-zero temperatures.

Many young women were introduced to society at the annual Gotham Debutante Ball held last night in the main ballroom of the Plaza for the benefit of the New York Foundling Hospital. Before the fete, the debutantes were honor guests at a dinner and reception, at which they were presented to Cardinal Spellman, chairman of the board of the hospital.

Two new films will arrive at fuetium theatres this morning. "Kansas City Confidential," a melodrama featuring John Payne. Caisen Caay and Preston Foster, is at the Globe. Phil Karisen directed the Edward Small production from a script by George Bruce and Harry Essex and a story by Harold R. Greene and Rowland Brown. United Artists is releasing the offering.

Consolidated net income of the Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation and all subsidiaries, including Wesco Theatres Corporation and Roxy Theatre, Inc., amounted to $3,845,946, for the thirty-nine weeks to last Sept. 27, the report to be issued today discloses.
SAN JOSE, Calif., Nov. 27 (AP) -- A combination of a hard-charging Santa Clara line and San Jose State fumbles gave the Bronco football team a 15-to-7 victory today before 12,924 fans.

The foreign exchange difficulties in Brazil are of a temporary nature, reflecting the continuous pressure for imports of a country in the process of rapid development, unassisted by any largescale imports of capital, and declining exports reflecting postKorean price and demand readjustments.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Nov. 27 (UP) -- Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois tonight thanked supporters who were raising funds to keep him in the political limelight but said he still had not decided about his future.

Formation of a citizen's committee to promote educational television, of which Dr. Milton S. Eisenhower, brother of the President-elect and head of Pennsylvania State College, is to be one of the active leaders, comes at a most opportune time. If educational TV is to be a reality, it is going to need far broader support and understanding than it has received thus far.

Members of the armed forces and their families made more than 77,000,000 visits in the last two years to United Service Organizations (U. S. O.) operations in the United States and overseas, A. E. Roberts, president of the United Defense Fund, reported yesterday on the second anniversary of the establishment of the fund.

THE midshipmen issued the first challenge. They exuberantly romped ashore from the ships of a practice squadron that anchored in the Hudson River at the foot of West Point. The middies challenged the cadets to either a baseball game or a boat race. The soldier boys cautiously confessed to a total unfamiliarity with either sport but brightly suggested a brisk marble-shooting match because they had some deadly marble-shooters on the Plains.

ROME, Nov. 2 -- The United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization today urged all member governments to consider immediately what assistance they could give to Yugoslavia, which is threatened with famine, and instructed its Director General to continue to give upon request of the Yugoslav Government all appropriate assistance, technical or other, that lies within his authority and competence.
OTTAWA, Nov. 27 (Canadian Press) -- Lionel Chevrier, Transport Minister, said today in Commons that he was confident the St. Lawrence River Seaway project would start in the "not-too-distant future."

We welcome the creation of the City Affairs Committee by a group of 150 citizens who are angry over misgovernment of New York City. The chairman is the Right Rev. Charles K. Gilbert, retired Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York. It is necessary to mention the names of some of the founders to suggest the substance, the character, the strength for intelligent, sustained and enthusiastic action promised.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 27 -- Overwhelming support developed this afternoon for an Indian compromise resolution on the repatriation of Korean prisoners of war. However, the Political and Security Committee of the General Assembly adjourned until tomorrow without taking a vote because V. K. Krishna Menon, the Indian representative, was not ready to announce his Government's position on amendments to the much revised proposal.

MANY will stretch the holiday through the week-end in order to get in the two-day "deer of either sex" season which will run today and tomorrow in twenty-eight of the Catskill, central and western counties.

BAGHDAD, Iraq, Nov. 27 -- Communism, using its peace partisans neutralist tactic, has made long strides here in consolidating its strange but effective alliance with extreme nationalism, it is indicated in evidence gathered on the details of the sanguinary riots of the last week-end and the events leading up to them.

LONDON, Nov. 27 -- The will of the late Viscount Astor, published here today, gave evidence of the American-born peer's anxiety to protect his Sunday newspaper, The Observer, and the trust he had established for it in 1945 against enfeeblement through taxation.

MEXICO CITY, Nov. 27 -- A new Latin-American trades union federation calling itself A. T. L. A. S. and setting itself an anti-communist and anti-United States policy closely paralleling that of Argentina, came into existence today.
CHICAGO, Nov. 27 (UP) -- The Chicago Black Hawks and the Toronto Maple Leafs played to a 3 -- 3 draw here tonight. Sid Smith's goal with 68 seconds left to play gave the Leafs the deadlock.
Production has begun at a sulphur "mine" deep beneath Bay Ste. Elaine in the remote Louisiana marshland.

Nurturing the road with a cushion of guaranteed as well as contented audiences is not a sinecure. No matter how sincere or intensive the exploitation, the results are inextricably woven into the quality quotient of the entertainments sent out.

A melancholy diversion, in late November, is a walk through the New York Botanical's rose garden, that small hollow some yards to the east of the hot-houses in Bronx Park. Seen from the surrounding rises, it is a strange place now.

HONOLULU, Nov. 27 -- Six freighters of the Matson Navigation Company remained idle at piers today as some 500 longshoremen refused to work cargo for Castle and Cooke Terminals, Ltd., for the seventh day despite the issue of a temporary restraining order in Circuit Court.

DETROIT, Nov. 27 (UP) -- Cloyce Box and Leon Hart, Detroit's giant ends, hauled down five touchdown passes today as the Lions defeated the Green Bay Packers, 48 to 24, to move into sole possession of first place in the National Conference of the National Football League.

BAYVILLE, L. I., Nov. 27 -- Military and itinerant aircraft traffic was light over Long Island Sound today but a group of vigilant Nassau County Civil Defense volunteers each gave two hours of holiday time to man Air Force Ground Observer Corps post "12-Alpha" to spot and report all planes coming within visual range.
EAST ORANGE, N. J.. Nov. 27 -- A sustained drive of 88 yards in the second period produced the touchdown as Barringer beat East Orange, 7 -- 0, at Martens Stadium today before 7,500.

SEOUL, Korea, Friday, Nov. 28 (AP) -- The police ransacked Seoul's ruins today for subversive persons, and 400 Koreans already were jailed in "Operation Safeguard" for President-elect Dwight D. Eisenhower's forthcoming visit.

JERUSALEM, Nov. 27 -- The Zionist General Council ended its annual meeting here today by approving the largest budget in its history -- 83,750,000 (Israeli) -- one-half of which will be devoted to agricultural settlement.
LONDON, Nov. 27 -- Aneurin Bevan, leader of the left wing of the British Labor party, won a seat on the Opposition's front bench in the House of Commons today.

ROANOKE, Va., Nov. 27 (AP) -- Virginia Tech broke up Bill Brehany's vaunted pass offense and paraded four different backs across the goal line on power plays today to defeat Virginia Military Institute, 26 -- 7, in their forty-eighth football clash.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Nov. 27 -- White Plains High School's football team closed its campaign by drubbing Rome (N. Y.) Free Academy, 44 to 0, before upward of 10,000 fans at the high school stadium this morning.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 27 (UP) -- Happy Go Lucky, H. G. Bockman's 3-year-old colt, took the lead in the stretch and won the $7,500 Thanksgiving Handicap before a record crowd of 20,000 today as the Fair Grounds opened its eightieth season.

TOKYO, Friday, Nov. 28 -- United Nations troops yesterday threw back light enemy attacks on the the central Korean front north of Kumhwa or scattered them with gunfire. The more powerful assaults that some believed the Communists might have scheduled for the American Thanksgiving Day holiday failed to develop.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 (AP) -- The head of a non-scheduled airline asked the Supreme Court yesterday to halt the Civil Aeronautics Board's "discriminatory practice" of issuing certificates only to scheduled airlines, and limiting others to "letters of registration."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 (AP) -- Howard University of Washington scored three touchdowns in eleven minutes of the last quarter today to tie Lincoln University of Pennsylvania, 19 to 19, before 6,371 fans.

The day after the feast is the time when, as a sort of reaction against epicurean excess, one starts to count calories and pennies. So much is being said about the former that the focus here will be on the latter, with the welcome news that city shoppers can today find meats at less than 20 cents a serving and fresh vegetables for less than 3.

The shipping industry leaders will face close questioning and probably criticism by members of the New York State Crime Commission after the state body opens its public hearings on Wednesday, it became known yesterday.

The market here will be flooded with Christmas tree ornaments produced in countries under Soviet control, according to H. L. Dillingham, secretary-treasurer of the Glassware Institute of America. About 50 per cent of the 150,000,000 ornaments that will be sold this year will come from Poland, Czechoslovakia and East Germany, he said.

Five hundred delegates, attending the opening of the twenty-ninth annual convention of Junior Hadassah, the Young Women's Zionist Organization of America, called yesterday for repeal of the McCarran-Walter immigration law, denouncing it for "inequities, injustices and anti-democratic discriminations."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 27 -James Ramsay Ullman's novel. "River of the Sun." has been purchased by Columbia Pictures and assigned to William Fadiman for production in the spring. The studio plans to film the entire action in the jungle country of Brazil, the actual locale of the adventure story, which deals with a search, led by his wife, for a missing scientist.

DALLAS, Nov. 27 -- The United States will never win the ideological war against communism by putting its leaders in "mental strait-jackets," delegates to the thirty-second annual meeting of the National Council for the Social Studies asserted today.
SALT LAKE CITY, Nov. 27 (UP) -- Utah won its second straight Skyline Conference championship by defeating Utah State, 20 -- 0, today before 13,090 fans. The temperature was 15 degrees.

For those who are already anticipating events of the new year, the days of 1953 may be found in calendar form in a variety of shapes and styles. These range from the usual wall and desk types to new engagement books as well as small baskets and caddies for a desk.
WEST POINT, N. Y., Nov. 27 (AP) -- Army is high, Navy is worried and both are scheming to slip over a quick opening punch in their football game Saturday at Philadelphia.

SAARBRUECKEN, the Saar, Nov. 27 -- In a radio appeal to Saar voters tonight Premier Johannes Hoffmann interpreted the proposals made yesterday by Robert Schuman, French Foreign Minister, as a concession by the French Government of equal rights to the Saar in a partnership that would replace dominance by France in this territory.

NICE, France, Nov. 27 (AP) -- Major airlines have agreed to air coach rates that will allow travelers to circle the globe at new low prices in 1954, the International Air Transport Association announced today.

The Renaud-Barrault company rose magnificently to a severe test last night, which was to give reality and tenderness to a play that is essentially unreal and decidedly bitter to the taste. Perhaps we can never get to like Jean Anouilh in this country, even when he is played so superbly.

BOSTON, Nov. 27 (UP) -- Boston's hard - checking Bruins tonight notched their first National Hockey League victory over the New York Rangers this season, delighting a crowd of 8.849 with a goal-a-period 3-1 triumph.

The emphasis was on passing as New York University worked out at Ohio Field yesterday in preparation for tomorrow's football game with Fordham at Triborough Stadium, Randalls Island. Quarterbacks Ray Cadieux, Frank Sauchelli and Bill Morgan did the throwing.

HANOI, Vietnam, Indo-China, Nov. 27 (AP) -- French fighter and bomber planes carried the war to the Communist-led Vietminh today on two fronts -- around menaced Nasan, in the northwest, and within the French-held Red River delta.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Nov. 22 -- Nearly 2,000,000 Venezuelans will cast their votes Sunday for a national Congress whose function will be to return this country to a constitutional form of government. The Congress, consisting of 103 delegates, will be the first to meet since the dissolution of the Government of Romulo Gallegos by the military coup of Nov. 24, 1948.

BOWIE, Md., Nov. 27 (AP) -- Making his thirty-second start of the season, Hampton Stable's Alerted, the "iron man" of the handicap division, scored a victory in the $25,000-added Fort McHenry Handicap at the new Bowie race course today.

Indo-China is becoming an even more critical battleground in the struggle of the free world against predatory Communist imperialism, and what is happening there can have its impact on the whole of East Asia. During this week two significant dispatches have come from the area.

A new radio dramatic series based on the history of western man will make its debut over the A. B. C. network on Dec. 11, from 8:30 to 9 P. M. The dramatizations will cover the fields of science, literature, exploration, invention and religion from the beginning of the Middle Ages to modern times.

BOMBAY, India, Nov. 27 -- Delegates from fourteen countries attending the Third International Conference on Planned Parenthood here this week have heard the explosion of another among many doubtful assumptions held about India. It has been widely thought that Indians through religion, ignorance or prejudice would not take to birth control in sufficient numbers to affect the severe problem of population pressure in this country.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 27 -- Pennsylvania went 80 and 85 yards for two touchdowns and a 14-0 lead, yielded one to Cornell's drive of 79 yards and stopped the Ithacans on the 1 and 9-yard marks today in a 14-7 triumph at Franklin Field.

THE TIMES in an editorial "Tin and Non-Intervention," published on Nov. 3, stated some facts with regard to Bolivia's nationalization of certain mining properties with which all sensible persons should agree.

Johnny Gonsalves of Oakland, Calif., and Orlando Zulueta of Havana will meet in the feature ten-round bout at Madison Square Garden tonight. It will be Gonsalves' New York debut and the 22-year-old second-ranking lightweight moves in with a five-fight winning streak.

A crowd of 15,000, one of the largest to watch a schoolboy game in the city, saw Cardinal Hayes and Mount St. Michael football teams battle to a 6-6 tie at Tri-borough Stadium, Randalls Island, yesterday.
TORONTO, Nov. 27 (AP) -- Abitibi Power and Paper Company, Ltd., is advising its Canadian customers that the price of their newsprint will be increased $10 a ton on Jan. 1.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- Republican Congressional leaders are looking to Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the President-elect, for guidance on what to do about $5,400,000,000 of tax reductions that will take effect automatically next year unless Congress acts.

PARIS, Nov. 27 -- The records of some of the Czechoslovaks convicted in the Prague trial reveal a series of acts hostile to Jewish and Zionist interests rather than the pro-Semitic conduct with which they were charged, an official of a United States Jewish organization asserted here today.

The traditional exploitation of the Mexican "wetbacks" on the great farms of the Southwest, will have to come to an end sooner or later, and the sooner the better. Everyone knows that the employment of these illegal migratory border-crossers at substandard pay is wrong.

The perfect advertising medium -- obviously a dream -- would tell the American people about 16,000 products made by 13,000 advertisers. To sell them all, the perfect medium would have to reach 30,000 people among the makers of and the agencies for advertised products.

When families sit down together, as millions did yesterday, to a time-honored feast served in a time-honored way, they are doing more than just enjoying a good meal and a few happy hours together, according to Dr. Lester A. Kirkendall, Professor of Family Life at Oregon State College, Corvallis, Ore.
SWEET BRIAR, Va., Nov. 27 (AP) -- Philadelphia teams dominated play in the first day of the U. S. Field Hockey Association's national tournament at Sweet Briar College here today.

MANILA, Nov. 27 -- The Philippine House of Representatives, controlled by the Liberal party of President Elpidio Quirino, has ordered an investigation of reports that local politics is interfering with the progress of the United States assistance program here.

LONDON, Nov. 27 -- Prices continued to rise in all stock markets today except in foreign bonds, and business expanded. Gold mining shares in particular were stronger following the reported suggestion in Toronto by the publisher of The World Currency Report that the price for gold would be raised next year.
TOKYO, Friday, Nov. 28 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,447, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Friday, Korea time:
The imposing of the death sentence on the two Rosenbergs is, to say the least, a troublesome matter for the conscience of thoughtful people.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 (AP) -- It will cost $300 -- including tax -for a box from which to view the Inaugural Ball, one of the festivities of the Jan. 20 inauguration, the subcommittee in charge said today. A box will hold eight guests.

James C. Hagerty, Governor Dewey's secretary, who is on leave of absence serving as press secretary to Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, was named yesterday by the President-elect to be press secretary to the President in the new Administration.

Allan S. Haywood, executive vice president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations and a leading candidate to replace the late Philip Murray as head of the C. I. O., moved last night into the dispute between the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., and nine local private bus lines.

JERUSALEM, Nov. 27 -- The statement by Ahmed Shukairi, Syrian delegate in the United Nations, to the effect that Jordan was willing to accept the internationalization of Jerusalem under United Nations supervision, caused surprise here.

LONDON, Nov. 27 -- Reporting to the House of Commons today upon his return from the United Nations, Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden expressed confidence that the differences among the member nations on phases of India's resolution to break the Korean truce talks deadlock would soon be overcome.

ON THE KOREAN FRONT, Nov. 27 -- The armed forces of the United Nations observed today a day of Thanksgiving. If the day was somber and cheerless and if there was a bleak prospect of another cruel winter of war, the soldier did have some things for which he was grateful.

ONE of the good books which was crowded out of this space during the autumn freshet of new titles certainly does not deserve to be overlooked. It is "We Chose the Islands: A Six-Year Adventure in the Gilberts," by Sir Arthur Grimble. The Gilbert Islands lies a part the Equator thousand miles or so northern the Fijis and northeast of the Solomons.
The greatest single fire hazard confronting city hospitals is unauthorized smoking by hospital patients and personnel, the Citizens Budget Commission has advised the Hospitals and Fire Departments.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Nov. 27 (AP) -- A record crowd of 17,862 fans launched the 124-day Florida horse racing season at Tropical Park today and watched Jet Fleet take the first division of the Inaugural Handicap and Starecase the second.
For the twenty-sixth year, Macy's had its Thanksgiving Day parade yesterday -- ablaze with color, bands, clowns, floats and, above all, the huge, eye-catching, helium-filled balloons.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., Nov. 27 -- Colgate and Brown engaged in a highly entertaining football game this morning and, as was expected, the well-primed Red Raiders from the Chenango came out on top. It was not an easy victory, however, as the Bruins dug in after spotting their rivals 13 points in the first quarter and gave some bad moments to the opposition before succumbing, 33 -- 27.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 (AP) -The Government today tagged shoes, leather, hides and skins as likely candidates, for recontrol if hides prices continue to rise.

The only thing to fear in Anglo-American relations is an "unreasoning passion of a purely nationalistic approach," Sir Oliver Franks, retiring British ambassador to the United States, said last night in a farewell message to the American people.

HUNTINGTON, W. Va., Nov. 27 (UP) -- Firemen searched through the charred interior of a building at the Huntington State Hospital, a mental institution, today for the cause of a Thanksgiving Eve blaze that killed fourteen women and girls.

CHARLESTON, W. Va., Nov. 27 -- Charleston faced the loss of airline service tonight while various governmental agencies debated over who was responsible for controlling deerlife surrounding Kanawha Airport.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 27 -- Although there are Hondurans and Greeks at the United Nations, there is not even a single lempira or drachma in the neat little envelopes that Malcolm Shea, foreign exchange teller, keeps behind the counter at the Chemical Bank and Trust Company branch here.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- Prospects for an overseas economic agency, twice recommended by Presidential study groups, brightened somewhat today with the announcement of a third investigation of the nation's foreign economic policy and methods of its application.

Goodhue Livingston Jr., a member of the City Planning Commission, urged yesterday that the Department of Marine and Aviation be abolished and that the function of managing the city-owned piers and the waterfront development be turned over to the Port of New York Authority.

An American edition of Giovanni Papini's newest work, "Michelangelo: His Life and His Era," will be published on Dec. 8 by Dutton. Mr. Papini, who devoted twenty years to research for the book, goes deeply into various parts of the great Renaissance sculptor's life that have been "disregarded by other biographers."

BONN, Germany, Nov. 27 -Chancellor Konrad Adenauer and his policy of integrating a rearmed West Germany in Europe won a decisive victory today when the Bundestag voted to hold the final debate on the Bonn peace contract with the Western Allies and the European Defense Community Treaty next week.

The recent revelations regarding the action of postal authorities in failing to deliver, or delivering after long delays, magazines and other publications received here from the Soviet bloc nations must give Americans a sense of unease. So too must the news that these authorities have taken it upon themselves to decide what universities or scholars in this country may or may not receive these publications.

Soup, although a particularly satisfying cold-weather dish, seldom today is made at home by Americans. But the principal argument against soup -- that it requires too much time to prepare -- need not apply if housewives take advantage of such modern conveniences as the pressure cooker and the electric blender.

KHARTUM, the Sudan, Nov. 27 (AP) -- The General Assembly of the newly formed Sudan Nationalist Unionist party decided today to accept Egyptian proposals on the Sudan as the party's minimum demands. The new party embraces all groups favoring unity with Egypt.

The cherished American tradition of Thanksgiving, older than the Republic itself, was celebrated yesterday by a nation in transition at home and by its sons and citizens on the hot and cold war fronts abroad.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Nov. 27 -- Long-standing threats from the groups demanding dissolution of the Indonesian Parliament and the calling of general elections failed to materialize today as the House reconvened after a recess following the disorderly demonstrations of Oct. 17.
When a holiday comes on a Thursday, as yesterday's observance of Thanksgiving did, it seems like a good idea to take today off, too, as well as tomorrow and Sunday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- Existing laws governing election expenditures are too antiquated to cope with the new cost features introduced into campaigning by radio and television, Representative Hale Boggs, Democrat of Louisiana, said today.

AUSTIN, Tex., Nov. 27 (AP) -- Texas ground out one touchdown per quarter and added a safety and field goal toay to whip its bitterest rival, Texas A. and M., 32 -- 12, for a sweep in Southwest Conference play.

LONDON, Nov. 27 -- On Prime Minister Churchill's intervention Sir William Lawther, president of the National Union of Mineworkers, has had a refund of 43 ($120.40) in duty for a gold watch presented to him by the United Mineworkers of America.
The United Fruit Company, after a two-month delay, will open today its $1,000,000 terminal in Weehawken, N. J., designed for the handling of bananas.
An eleven representing the National Soccer League played to a 2-2 tie with stars of the American Soccer League at Sterling Oval in the Bronx yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- Men on horseback were not the only heroes in the Civil War. The foot-slogger was a hero, too, but his heroism has not been preserved in the monuments and the books as has been that of the generals.

AKRON, Ohio, Nov. 27 (AP) -- The homeless Dallas Texans, who hadn't won a game all season, bounced back in the last 34 seconds today to defeat the favored Chicago Baers, 27 -- 23, before 3,000 in Akron's Rubber Bowl.

Hugh Laing gave his first performance of the title role in George Balanchine's "Tyl Ulenspiegel" with the New York City Ballet at the City Center last night. Although the role was built specifically for Jerome Robbins. Mr. Laing plays it beautifully, retaining every detail of the pantomine and choreography, but giving it a distinctive tone of his own.

PARIS, Nov. 27 -- Experts from sixteen member countries of the Organization for European Economic Cooperation seeking ways for Europe to earn more of the dollars it needs were counseled today to concentrate efforts on increasing productivity and lowering prices to strengthen the arguments for lower United States tariffs.

This week the workers of the United States Steel Corporation poured the billionth ton of steel manufactured by that enterprise and thereby set a mark of which all of us can be proud. Produced during a period of little more than half a century, this billion tons of steel has made an incalculable contribution to our national welfare in peace and war.
DETROIT, Nov. 27 (UP) -- Reg Sinclair and Gordie Howe scored third-period goals tonight as the Detroit Red Wings fought back to tie the Montreal Canadiens, 2 -- 2.
CARVILLE, La., Nov. 27 -- (UP) -- A Philippine war heroine, who is being treated for leprosy at the United States Public Health Service Hospital, faces a deportation hearing Dec. 5.

OLYMPIA, Wash., Nov. 27 -Preliminary plans for a floating bridge across Puget Sound, to link Seattle with the Bremerton area by way of Vashon Island [cross on upper map], have been approved by the State Toll Bridge Authority.

Moral responsibility for the welfare of others was emphasized yesterday in Thanksgiving sermons here. Gifts of money and food for the needy were received at many services. In several meetings Jews and Protestants worshiped together.
VIENNA, Nov. 27 (AP) -- Western diplomats who studied the Prague radio reports of the Czechoslovak Communists' trial said today it apparently had seveal aims. In their views:

Sir Oliver Franks, British Ambassador to Washington for the last four and half years, writes "Finis" today to a notable term. Those who heard his beautiful and moving farewell to the American people on the radio yesterday had a fresh reminder that a good friend and an exceptionally keen mind are being lost -- temporarily one hopes -- to Anglo-American relations.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 27 (AP) -- The University of Cincinnati's Bearcats collected touchdowns on every one of their major scoring opportunities today to smash to a surprisingly one-sided 34-9 victory over Miami University of Ohio.

LONDON, Nov. 27 -- Half a dozen outstanding radio engineers and theoreticians here are working on a superficially simple device for the simultaneous transmission of telecommunication waves and electrical power on the same wire line. Some experts feel it may prove to have more ramifications than the invention of radar.
LINCOLN, R. I., Nov. 27 (UP) -- Tiny Tony DeSpirito booted home a pair of winners at Lincoln Downs today to boost his total triumphs to 358 -- just thirty short of the all-time record.

CHICAGO, Nov. 27 (UP) -- Dr. Andrew C. Ivy, world famed physiologist and central figure in the controversy over the so-called cancer drug, krebiozen, said tonight he intended to continue his work with the substance.

The New York metropolitan area, now the nation's largest manufacturing center, is still expanding dynamically, it is declared in a survey in the current issue of Commerce Review, monthly economic digest issued by the state's Department of Commerce.

Lafayette High, probably the highest scoring football team in Public Schools Athletic League football history, captured the mythical city schoolboy championship by trouncing Erasmus Hall, 35 -- 7, before an overflow crowd of 7,500 at Brooklyn College Field yesterday. The Frenchies recorded their seventh straight victory and Erasmus suffered its second setback in eight games.

CLEARWATER, Fla., Nov. 27 (AP) -- The defending champion, Clemente Inclan, won the fourth race of the Western Hemisphere Snipe Class sailing championships today to move into second place in point score.
DETROIT, Nov. 28 (AP) -- The direction of new car prices during the year ahead currently is arousing considerable discussion in automotive circles.

MONTREAL, Nov. 27 (Canadian Press). The recession in the Canadian textile industry last year was accentuated because foreign countries "unloaded their surplus textiles here." J. Irving Roy of Montreal said last night.
