PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 28 -- The Army-Navy football game at Philadelphia's municipal stadium tomorrow will be followed with interest by the greatest undergraduate and alumni bodies in the world.
LONDON, Nov. 28 -- A bill that Sir Lionel Heald, Attorney General, declared threatened the freedom of the British press was defeated on a technicality in the House of Commons today without a vote.

Mr. Tighe Woods, who succeeded Ellis G. Arnall as director of the Office of Price Stabilization early in September, has now resigned, and he has resigned in the same general spirit that marked his three months of administration of the office. It was discouraging, it seems, just "doing nothing but sign orders increasing prices"; besides, he didn't have a good law to work with.

An assertion that the well-being of Israel depends on an increase in domestic production for export was made yesterday by Dr. Heinz Gruenbaum, senior vice president of the Palestine Economic Corporation in charge of operations in Israel.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- The Food and Drug Administration issued a warning today to parents of small children to discontinue using Swift's canned dried egg yolk and to grocers to discontinue selling it.

The suggestion by Goodhue Livingston Jr. that the city would do well to abolish its Department of Marine and Aviation was condemned yesterday by Commissioner Edward F. Cavanagh Jr., who heads that department. He is a long-time foe of the City Planning Commission member, and he said the proposal was not unexpected, although he characterized it as unfortunate for the Port of New York.
SEOUL, Korea, Nov. 28 (UP) -- President Syngman Rhee will propose to President-elect Dwight D. Eisenhower that South Korean forces be strengthened but that United States troops stay on in Korea.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 (UP) -- Ezra T. Benson, slated to be the new Secretary of Agriculture, will face a strong move to break Federal control of the Soil Conservation Service.

MEXICO CITY, Nov. 28 -- Charles Brannan, Secretary of Agriculture, arrived tonight on a special air force plane bringing members of the United States delegation to the inauguration of Adolfo Ruiz Cortinez as President of Mexico Monday.
High school students are feeling the high cost of living in proportion to their elders, the Institute of Life Insurance reports on the basis of a survey made by the University of Wisconsin.

Net profit of Solar Aircraft Company for the six months ended on Oct. 31 was $1,739,700, equal to $2.93 a share on 587,898 common shares, it was announced yesterday. Results for the period include a non-recurring income of $975,600, or $1.66 a share, from the sale of property.

Buffeted by strong winds, a 34-year-old rigger climbed to the top of a 262-foot smoke stack at a Consolidated Edison Company plant in the Bronx yesterday and in thirty dramatic minutes saved the life of a masonry worker who had been overcome by coke fumes.

An Army ferryboat plying between Manhattan and Governors Island was the setting yesterday for the birth of Rudolph John Arnold Powell Jr., whose father is stationed in Germany. The child arrived with the aid of Sgt. 1/C Ivy M. Poplett of the Women's Army Corps, an obstetrical surgical technician on leave from Fort Meade, Md.
Brother Bonaventure Thomas, president of Manhattan College, announced yesterday the election of Frederick H. Zurmuhlen, Commissioner of Public Works, as a trustee.

Walter T. Margetts Jr., state treasurer of New Jersey, announced yesterday that the sale of $25,000,000 of the state's institutional bonds will not take place on Dec. 9, as scheduled. The $25,000,000 issue will be offered later, probably in conjunction with an issue of $15,000,000 of bonds for the state teachers' college, Mr. Margetts said.

OTTAWA, Nov, 28 (UP) -- The nation's railways today agreed to a conciliation board's recommendation for wage increases for some 144,000 employes, and immediately applied for a 9 per cent freight rate boost to offset it.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- The Department of the Treasury announced today that investors had subscribed to $873,123,000 of the $1,062,634,000 of additional certificates of indebtedness bearing 2 per cent interest offered in exchange for similar securities bearing 1 7/8 per cent interest and maturing on Dec. 1.
A program to increase trade and investment between the United States and West Germany was announced yesterday by the German-American Capital Commission.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- The Duralum Products Company, Inc., of New York City, has been found guilty of violating conservation orders of the National Production Authority in using aluminum for unauthorized production. A suspension order issued by the agency prevents the company from obtaining more than 10,000 pounds of aluminum a quarter until a total of 80,000 pounds of the metal has been repaid.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 (AP) -- Farm product prices declined 2 per cent between mid-October and mid-November, the Department of Agriculture reported today. This marked the third consecutive month that these prices declined.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 28 (AP) -- Sanford Astor of St. Louis scored a 6-1, 6-2 upset today over third-seeded Maxwell Brown of Louisville in the third round of the boys' division in the National junior indoor tennis tournament here.

TACOMA, Wash., Nov. 28 -- Thirty-six persons, including seven women and eight children, were killed in the crash of a military transport plane here today near the destination of a Thankgiving Day flight from Alaska. It was the ninth military air crash in three weeks in the Pacific Northwest, Alaska and Korea Theatre.
Thomas Luchese (Three Finger Brown), New York underworld figure, voluntarily submitted yesterday to service of papers in Government deportation proceedings against him.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Nov. 28 (UP) -- The biggest cities in the International League and the American Association eventually will be merged to form a fourth major league along with the Pacific Coast, American and National, a top baseball executive said today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 (AP) -- The U. S. Court of Appeals today upheld a Federal Trade Commission ruling against a concern that makes a business of finding delinquent debtors.

The three-month rise in New York bank loans to business which has brought the total of such credit outstanding to a record $8,479,000,000 was slowed last week to a gain of $5,000,000, against $58,000,000 in the previous week.

BOWIE, Md., Nov. 28 (AP) -- Larry S. MacPhail starts dealing out the big money at his new Bowie race course tomorrow in the first running of the $50,000 Maryland Gold Cup. Twelve juveniles are entered.
CLEARWATER, Fla., Nov. 28 (AP) -- Ted Wells won the Western Hemisphere Snipe Class sailing championship for the United States today, turning back Cuba's Clemente Inclan in the fifth and final race.
YOKOHAMA, Japan, Nov. 28 (AP) -- Japanese customs officials today ignored the demand of seven Russians for diplomatic exemption and searched their baggage before letting them sail for home.

The Iron Curtain countries are going to be upset when they hear about preparations being made by the Australians to house athletes and officials at the 1956 Olympic Games in Melbourne. They may even boycott the event.

SOMEWHERE IN KOREA, Nov. 28 -- Most of the churches in Korea have been ravaged by war. Shells have smashed and burned their roofs and when the war itself passed, the weather has taken over to complete the course of destruction.
Mrs. B. P., a young woman from Germany, came to the United States in September, 1952, being invited, all expenses paid, by the United States Department of Labor.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 (AP) -- The Tariff Commision by a three-to-two vote has refused to recommend higher duties on imported tuna canned in brine or on any type of canned bonito.
Fordham and New York University close their football seasons today in their traditional game at Triborough Stadium, Randall's Island. The kick-off is set for 1:30 P. M.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- The State Department ventured the prediction today that the Albanian people would win their freedom from the "current Soviet puppet regime" just as they have won their freedom and independence in the past.

The first step in the transformation of a rather dreary basement gymnasium at Public School 30 in Manhattan into a colorful, cheerful setting for a teen canteen was taken last week by an enthusiastic group. Armed with brushes and buckets of bright aqua and yellow paint, twenty-five boys and girls, who participate in a recreation program at the school, attacked one long and dingy wall with firm and hearty strokes.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 28 -- Warner Brothers is going to dust off the mellow musical called "Wonder Bar" and bring it out again next year in color with Danny Thomas taking over the starring role played by the late Al Jolson in the 1934 edition.

DALLAS, Nov. 28 -- The nation's schools and colleges must prepare students for the responsibilities they will face as citizens and inform them about the world in which they live, the thirty-second annual meeting of the National Council for the Social Studies was told today.

CHICAGO, Nov. 28 (AP) -- Bitter cold gripped a large portion of the country between the Appalachians and the Pacific Coast today, in the wake of storms that left thirty-eight dead in the Midwest and Southwest.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 28 (AP) -- A funeral procession of 400 mourners wound through this resort today to a pet cemetery, where they buried Nightlife, a little brown mongrel dog who was killed by a car Wednesday night.

Michael J. Quill's periodic alarums and excursions have again gone full circle. The contract-breaking private-line bus strike that he and his Transport Workers Union had threatened for Dec. 1 has been called off.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 (AP) -- A long series of proposed amendments to the Taft-Hartley Law is being drafted by Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio. He was one of the authors of the labor measure.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended last Saturday totaled 810,922 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.

Maggie Cline was one of the stars at Tony Pastor's. B. Altman Co. was selling mink capes for $19. Boxes for the flower show at Madison Square Garden cost $4. At Huber's Palace on Fourteenth Street there was "a dollar show for 10 cents" featuring performing bears, trick cattle, champion club-swingers "and other wonders."

OTTAWA, Nov. 28 -- Defense Minister Brooke Claxton explained to the House of Commons this afternoon, the situation that now exists at Goose Bay, Labrador, and in general, with regard to the rights and activities of the United States Air Force in Canada.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 --Roger L. Putnam, head of the Economic Stabilization Agency, today upheld the decision of price officials to reimpose ceilings on radio and television components.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 28 -- The Arab States have dropped their demand for the establishment of a new United Nations body on Palestine to tackle longstanding Arab-Israeli disputes.

SAARBRUECKEN, the Saar, Nov. 28 -- Johannes Hoffmann, Minister-President of the Saar, said today that his wife had received a letter threatening death to his family unless he resigned. He added that several other officials of the Saar Government had received similar letters.

For the seventh successive year an effort will be made to persuade the Legislature to take the necessary steps in 1953 toward enabling off-track betting as a means of helping New York City out of its financial difficulties.

WACO, Tex., Nov. 28 (AP) -- Baylor University today abandoned use of the helmet block for protection on passes and punts, Coach George Sauer said. Sauer explained that the decision was made for the protection of all players against injury.

DETROIT, Nov. 28 -- The Michigan Board of Canvassers, acting for the second time in two years on a Republican challenge to the re-election of Gov. G. Mennen Williams, Democrat, ordered today a recount of ballots cast Nov. 4 in 1,571 of the state's 4,478 precincts.

While the General Assembly of the United Nations tries to find a formula for ending Communist aggression in Korea the Assembly's Legal Committee is concentrating on two ambitious projects in a closely connected field. One of these projects aims at an international agreement on a precise definition of just what specific acts constitute "aggression," and at making such a definition part of the developing international criminal law.

WESTBROOK, Conn., Nov. 28 -- Despite the bluebird weather and a shifting wind, the breakwater shooters did fairly well on broadbill and scoters, but the black ducks moved out to the open sound early in the morning and waited until sunset to return.

It is now reported that close associates of Argentina's President Peron have at last formed a new Latin-American trades union federation. For several years Dictator Peron's labor attaches and their followers in Latin America have beaten the drums in preparation for this step.

LINCOLN, R. I., Nov. 28 (UP) -- Tony DeSpirito made up more ground in his bid for a new national riding record when he rode five winners at Lincoln Downs today to increase his total for the year to 363.

Considerable proof that the Advertising Council's twenty-page booklet, "The Miracle of America," is accomplishing its purpose is provided by the results of a survey recently conducted by the council among industrial workers and high school students. Results revealed conclusively that readers of the booklet were far better acquainted with the reasons for America's greatness than nonreaders.

Kings County Judge Samuel S. Leibowitz offered yesterday to set nominal bail for Jack Gross, brother of Harry Gross, the convicted bookmaker, if Assistant Corporation Counsel Victor J. Herwitz would "assume the responsibility" of assuring young Gross' appearance for his trial on perjury charges.

PARIS, Nov. 28 -- Experts of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization have abandoned the attempt to set firm goals for the 1953 arming program, it was announced today officially at the alliance's headquarters here.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- Users of an invention patented this week by Adolph M. Brown of Chicago are promised the advantages of a face-lift without surgery. The effect is only temporary, but ought to last through cocktails and dinner.

Events today: "La Forza del Destino," Metropolitan Opera, 2 P. M.; Free Orchestral Concert presented by Local 802, Walton High School, 2:30; "Carmen," Metropolitan Opera, 8; "Faust," Amato Opera Theatre, 159 Bleecker Street, 8:30; Philharmonic - Symphony, Carnegie Hall, 8:45; Nathan Milstein, violinist, Hunter College, 8:30; Bennington Composers Conference Concert, Lexington Avenue Y. M. H. A., 8:40; Pierre Fournier, cellist, Washington Irving High School, 8:30.

ANCHORAGE, Alaska, Nov. 28 (AP) -- The Alaska Command reported today the wreckage of a C-124 Globemaster missing since Saturday with fifty-two passengers aboard had been found by a pilot who radioed there was no sign of life.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- The Great Lakes-St. Lawrence Association, reversing its stand on the point, urged the Federal Power Commission today to approve New York State's application for authority to participate in the construction and operation of hydroelectric power facilities on the St. Lawrence River.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- Dr. Rosa Goldstein, Israel's leading woman scientist, told a press conference here today that the whole future of the experiment of swift modernization of that country depended on its ability to develop more engineers and technicians in the near future.
SOUTH BEND, Ind., Nov. 28 (AP) -- The luck of the Irish may never be needed more by Notre Dame than tomorrow when Coach Frank Leahy's lads meet unbeaten Southern California.

Labor unions and other organizations representing city employes have begun an intensive campaign to obtain pay increases for their members in the 1953-54 budget. Programs now being drafted will include not only demands for increases in salaries and wages, but also insistence that the forty-hour week promised to the 55,000 city workers not yet enjoying that schedule be put into effect not later than next July 1.
MIAMI, Nov. 28 (AP) -- North Carolina cracked Miami's defenses open with a four-touchdown second-period spree, then rambled on to a 34-7 victory tonight.

BERLIN, Nov. 28 -- A Soviet soldier who later told the police he was on his way to see Maj. Gen. Lemuel Mathewson, United States Commandant in West Berlin, staggered up Argentinische Allee this evening firing his machine pistol at various targets, including street lamps.

Operating assets of the Attapulgus Clay Company, in liquidation, have been acquired for an undisclosed sum by Minerals Separation North American Corporation, according to announcement yesterday by David E. Lilienthal, president of Minerals Separation and L. R. Streander, president of Attapulgus.

The Commodity Exchange, Inc., has added a new rubber futures contract which broadens the base of trading and eliminates the danger of a "squeeze." It will become effective on Monday, and the first futures to be traded under it will be those for delivery in March 1953.
Albert Einstein left the quiet of his Princeton office yesterday to testify for two hours as an expert witness in a patent infringement suit involving a highly technical medical camera.
The following is a round-up of new products that may be of interest to the homemaker:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 (UP) -- The Department of Agriculture forecast today that lagging domestic and export demand will keep the rate of increase in American farm output well below maximum levels during the next five years.

The upper Hudson River piers from Forty-fourth to Fiftieth Street roared with activity yesterday as steamship operators sought to make up some of the time lost in the one-day strike of longshoremen. The dockmen, members of Local 824 of the International Longshoremen's Association, A. F. L., refused to work Wednesday in protest against the serving of subpoenas on several of their leaders.
LONDON, Nov. 28 -- General agreement on two fundamental propositions was evident among the delegates to the British Commonwealth Prime Ministers' conference which started its work in London today.

Today's program in the second International Art Film Festival at Hunter College Auditorium to be presented at 2:30 P. M. will include the following art motion pictures: "Les Gisants," "St. Louis," "Mirror of Holland," "Open Win dow," "Masques et Visages de James Ensor" and "Animated Genesis."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 (UP) -- The District Appeals Court refused today to reconsider a decision upholding the perjury conviction of Harold R. Christoffel, a former union leader, but urged him to carry his case to the Supreme Court.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed barely steady yesterday 1 to 10 points net lower than on Wednesday.

HONOLULU, Nov. 28 -- Ichiro Izuka, a former Communist, testified today that Jack Kimoto, charged with having violated the Smith Act, had assisted him and others in digging up Communist literature buried on a Hawaii farm in the spring of 1943. He said they had been caught in the act and arrested by two Federal officers.

In New York City's present financial predicament it is not surprising to find the administration looking wistfully at the $3,000,000 in real estate taxes being lost through the bankruptcy of the Long Island Rail Road and the back taxes owed of $13,000,000. Dennis M. Hurley, Corporation Counsel, has recommended to Mayor Impellitteri that the city oppose two proposed plans for reorganization of the road before the Interstate Commerce Commission, and the Mayor has concurred.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- Air Force headquarters here, concerned at a series of fatal flying accidents this month in and near Alaska, the Pacific Northwest and Korea, announced tonight creation of a special survey team to look into possible causes of the unusual sequence of military tragedies, of which the crash at Tacoma today was the latest.

There is a story about a New Yorker who was showing a visitor the city and who was becoming exasperated by his guest's refusal to be impressed by anything. When the visitor came to a thousand-family housing development and asked what it was, the New Yorker said casually:

The Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service intervened yesterday in an effort to avert a strike called by the Newspaper Guild of New York, C. I. O., against The Brooklyn Eagle for 3 o'clock this afternoon.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 (UP) -- The Petroleum Administration for Defense has recommended a price increase on crude oil and refined petroleum products to ease an oil shortage on the West Coast, it was disclosed today.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 28 -- Officials of the United States Council of the International Chamber of Commerce are sounding out labor, farm, professional and other groups in the United States on a proposal that a general nongovernmental economic conference for the non-Communist world be held in Europe late next spring.

CARACAS, Nov. 28 -- Venez uela's political parties closed today their campalgns for Sunday's congressional elections--the first since 1948--with mass meetings in Caracas and other sections of the country. One hundred and three members are to be elected.

The stock market showed no evidence yesterday of halting its advance as prices improved further. All components of THE NEW YORK TIMES index touched new peaks since 1930, and with a further aggregate rise of 1.02 points.

TORONTO, Nov. 28 (Canadian Press) -- V. C. Wansbrough, managing director of the Canadian Metal Mining Association, said yesterday the Canadian Government's increased assistance to Canadian gold mines will probably save at least five mines from suspending operations.

LONDON, Nov. 28 -- Gold mining shares and industrials made the best showing in generally cheerful stock markets today. There also were price rises and an improved turnover in British Government securities, the volume of business here being the best of the week.

In the next few weeks our thoughts will turn to the Christmas season and the pleasure of giving joy to little children in the warmth, security and relative peacefulness of our American homes. The American Friends of Russian Freedom, Inc., hopes some Americans will turn a little of their attention to the less happy picture of our friends, the Russian post-war escapees from communism living in dreadful conditions in camps and hospitals in Western Europe.

NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 28 -- Himalayan travel experts here have a favorite indoor sport these days -- trying to figure out whether the Swiss mountain climbing expedition has succeeded in conquering Mount Everest.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 28 -- Still deadlocked in their search for a new president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, top union leaders decided tonight to give themselves more time to hammer out an agreement and thus avoid an open fight that might tear the organization apart.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 28 -- Mayor Joseph S. Clark Jr. today urged officials of the Philadelphia Transportation Company and the Transport Workers Union to resume negotiations on a new contract to avert a threatened transit strike on Dec. 15.

Your editorial of Nov. 21 "Progress on Korea" points with evident satisfaction to what you describe as General Eisenhower's statement "re-emphasizing his agreement that there shall be no forcible 'repatriation' of prisoners of war." May I suggest that your editorial is something less than candid.

SPOKANE, Nov. 28 (AP) --Don Heinrich, a young Army recruit on a three-day pass, will end a brilliant college football career for Washington tomorrow in the traditional game with oft-beaten Washington State.

Trading was light yesterday on the New York commodity exchanges. Only rubber and sugar were active. Futures closed irregularly with rubber, hides and vegetable oils higher. Cocoa, potatoes, zinc and tin were lower and sugar, coffee, wool and lead were mixed.
Heralding the large number of group shows of paintings and sculpture that are perennial Christmas features of the art season, there is an attractive selection at the Midtown Galleries.
CHICAGO, Nov. 28 (AP) -- Department of Agriculture reports of livestock trading here today:

The letter of Sir Gerald Clauson on the Kikuyu problem did not throw any light on the matter except to inform us that he had spent thirty years or more in the Colonial Office in London (not in Kenya). May I say that this fact alone does not make Sir Gerald an authority either.

A dividend of 40 cents a share on the common stock, payable on Jan. 2, has been authorized by directors of the Brillo Manufacturing Company, it was announced yesterday. The company previously distributed 35 cents a share at quarterly intervals.

SEOUL, Korea, Saturday, Nov. 29 (AP) -- Thirty-four United States B-29 Superforts dumped hundreds of tons of bombs last night on Communist airfields and other targets south of the Yalu River within sight of the big Red fighter base at Antung, Manchuria.

ATLANTA, Nov. 28 (U P) -- Georgia Tech was rated a 20-point favorite today to hit the gridiron jackpot tomorrow. The Engineers appear certain to beat Georgia, take the Southeastern Conference championship and post their first perfect record since 1928.
An assortment of four cream cheese varieties, each in an ounce-and-a-quarter foil-wrapped square, is a convenient packaging innovation of Meyer Zausner, Inc., of New Holland, Pa.

Most home furnishing are opposed strongly to additional night openings and many doubt whether continuation of night openings now in effect is desirable, the National Retail Furniture Association reported yesterday. The contentions were based on a survey of more than 800 stores in 403 cities.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- Resignations from the outgoing Truman Administration continued today. But it was not all on the debit side, for the President gave out a job. He appointed Walter J. Cummings Jr., 36-year-old Chicagoan, Solicitor General. W. John Kenney, Deputy Director for Mutual Security, and Robert T. Creasey, Assistant Secretary of Labor, were the two wh osubmitted their resignations.
TOKYO, Saturday Nov. 29 (AP) -- United Nations Command Headquarters communique 1,448, for the twenty-four hours ended at 6 A. M., Saturday, Korea time:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- Raymond M. Foley, Federal Housing Administrator, informed Congress today that there was insufficient legal authority to enforce a request that occupants of all Federally aided housing projects swear they were not members of a subversive organization.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 28 -- The outlook for the approval of a compromise Indian resolution on Korea was suddenly clouded over today by another request by V. K. Krishna Menon, its author, for more time in which to prepare the statement he is to make before the Political and Security Committee of the General Assembly takes a vote.

Orlando Zulueta, flashy little Cuban lightweight, won a fight last night in Madison Square Garden. But he didn't win the decision, and that's what counts. All he did was to jar to some extent the world lightweight championship aspirations of Johnny Gonsalves, Oakland, Calif., pretender to Jimmy Carter's honors, who left the ring the victor on an unpopular decision in his local debut.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 28 -- Harvard University announces the receipt of $2,805,139 during the three months ending Sept. 30. The biggest gift was a series of grants from the Ford Foundation, a total of $473,463. The grants were made for research in juvenile delinquency, a cooperative tax project and other studies in economics, law and business administration.

The New York Knickerbockers, on the eve of today's game with the Indianapolis Olympians, last night sold Ray Lumpp, a guard, to Baltimore for an undisclosed sum of cash and the Bullets' second choice in the draft next year. The Knicks are now down to the required ten-man squad of the National Basketball Association.
Michael J. Quill's Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., canceled yesterday a strike set for 12:01 A. M. Monday against nine private bus companies here.

A heavy volume of selling is expected at the Popular Price Shoe Show of America which opens tomorrow and continues through Thursday at the New Yorker and McAlpin Hotels. Last year there was little buying at the show, but this season spring orders started to arrive before the exhibit opened, according to Edward Atkins and Maxwell Field, co-managers.
LONDON, Nov. 28 -- Nineteen Mexican boys, here to sing at concerts, were left on their own last night when illness removed the only two adults in their group.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- The Air Force is developing a new jet engine that will be more powerful than any now in use and may give the huge B-52 intercontinental bomber supersonic speeds.

HANOI, Vietnam, Indo-China, Nov. 28 (AP) -- French fighter bombers today continued to attack the Communist-led Vietminh troops besieging French Union forces in the strongly fortified base at Nasan, 117 miles west of Hanoi.

Santa Claus, who has been practically everywhere and isn't due in these parts for another twenty-six days, made his first visit -- it was by request -- to Bronx Magistrates Court yesterday. He listened to a dissertation on New York apartment living, was stanchly defended by an 8-year-old boy and several others who had to be restrained from rushing to his aid, and then went back to his activities in a department store.
Addressed to students home for Thanksgiving vacation, the Lord Taylor showing of holiday and resort fashions yesterday was gay with suggestions to freshen up campus wardrobes.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 28 (AP) -- The Tennessee and Vanderbilt football squads settled down tonight in suburban quiet away from the noise and confusion which usually precede their annual clash.

TOKYO, Nov. 28 -- In formally endorsing the proposal before the United Nations General Assembly by Soviet Foreign Minister Andrei Y. Vishinsky, Premier Chou again attacked the United States for "sabotage" of the Korean truce conferences at Panmunjom.

TOKYO, Saturday, Nov. 29 -- Premier Shigeru Yoshida removed Hayato Ikeda, Minister for International Trade and Industry, from the Government today as the result of an unexpected vote of non-confidence in the House of Representatives yesterday in the Premier's top economic consultant.

Six parent bodies of Lutheran groups in Canada have ratified a proposed constitution for a Canadian Lutheran Council, which will be set up formally in Winnipeg on Thursday, the National Lutheran Council reported recently.

This office is fully aware of the financial hardship imposed on some pensioners by the unavoidable delay before payment of the initial installment of retirement allowance is made. It welcomes the opportunity to explain the delay to "Mrs. Citizen" and to correct the erroneous impression created by her recent letter to THE NEW YORK TIMES that applicants are not advised until after retirement of their allowances.
BAGHDAD, Iraq, Nov. 28 -- The Communist leadership in Iraq may have made a strategic blunder in the rioting last week-end by showing its hand too openly according to expert opinion.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Nov. 28 (UP) -- Authorities seeking Winnie Ruth Judd, insane slayer, tried today to link her sixth escape with the disappearance of two other women formerly employed at Arizona State Hospital for the Insane.

MOSCOW, Nov. 28 -- The government newspaper Izvestia said in a page-one editorial today that direct losses to the state from the production of bad and substandard goods in industries subordinate to the central Soviet Government last year reached a total of 3,000,000,000 rubles ($750,000,000) at exchange rate of four rubles to $1).
Students from twenty-seven colleges in New York City, Westchester County and Long Island met yesterday to form an intercollegiate group for bettering human relations on school and community levels.

The Philippine House of Representatives has ordered an investigation of reasons why American aid has not been more effective. There have been charges that local politics had played a part in delaying needed projects. Accusations that part of the assistance program had been channeled into the "pork barrel" have been quickly denied in Manila.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 28 -- After a thorough briefing by United Nations experts on the intricate business of running an international meeting, Dr. Manuel Arocha of Venezuela has returned to Caracas, where he heads the secretariat for the Tenth Inter-American Conference scheduled to be held there late in 1953.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- Department store sales in the week ended Nov. 22 were 9 per cent above sales in the corresponding week of last year. The following lists percentage changes from like periods of 1951:

In the interest of judicial expediency and because two defendants face death, Federal Judge Irving R. Kaufman yesterday requested to be relieved of hearing applications to invalidate the convictions of three Soviet atom spies.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 28 -- Army and Navy meet on the football field of battle for the fifty-third time tomorrow and President Truman will be back in the sell-out crowd in the Municipal Stadium.

From Chapel Hill, seat of a notable institution of learning, comes a letter reminding us in well-tempered terms that in our columns good English words sometimes stray from the appointed path of usage.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- November employment reached a new high for the month, exceeding by about 900,000 the totals for the corresponding month in 1951, the Census Bureau of the United States Department of Commerce reported today. Total civilian employment during the week ended Nov. 8, the Bureau added, was 62,228,000.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Nov. 28 -- Israel is debating this week-end the question of what the government of this state should do about the extraordinary offensive against the State of Israel, Zionism and Jews in general involved in the Prague trial.

John Bright, a professor at Union Theological Seminary in Virginia, has been chosen winner of the $7,500 Abingdon-Cokesbury Award for 1952 for his manuscript, tentatively titled "The Kingdom of God." His book is described as a "history of the biblical concept of 'the people of God.'" The award is given for an unpublished manuscript that will "accomplish the greatest good for the Christian faith and Christian living among all people."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 (AP) -- The St. Lawrence power project as approved by the International Joint Commission last month could result in users of the power paying more than their share of the cost of Canada's St. Lawrence Seaway project, an American member of the commission argued today.

CHICAGO, Nov. 28 -- Grain futures were under pressure at times today but met active buying on setbacks and the general tone was strong at the close, wheat being especially strong in the last few minutes of trading. Soybean futures showed more strength than grains, statistics being regarded as more favorable in regard to oil consumption.

PARIS, Nov. 28 -- The North Atlantic Council has agreed to vacate the temporary Paris quarters it has occupied since last spring near the Palais de Chaillot and move to a new twenty-one-acre site offered by the French Government five miles west of the capital and north of Versailles as soon as the new building can be erected.

ARCHIBALD MacLEISH is the Renaissance Man of the Lost Generation. He has had more careers than you can shake a Who's Who at. In his undergraduate days at Yale he was quarterback of the football team and captain of water polo, a bracing form of approximate murder afloat, as well as editor of The Lit, America's oldest magazine devoted to beautiful letters.

JERSEY CITY, Nov. 28 -- Three teen-agers were killed and a fourth was injured critically here tonight when the car in which they were riding rammed into a load of overhanging steel girders on a trailer truck on Route 1. The accident occurred near Roosevelt Stadium.
SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Nov. 28 (AP) -- The Yale and Springfield basketball teams shared top honors with two victories each tonight in a round-robin competition with Holy Cross and Amherst.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- During the week ended Nov. 26, member bank reserves increased $179,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board announced today.

Because grocery retailers work on small margin -- in some cases no larger than 1 per cent -- the big operators have been casting about for some time for additional items to build volume and sweeten the profit mixture. They have hit on books, magazines, hosiery, hardware, housewares, and the like, and in many stores the results have been profitable.

HONG KONG, Nov. 28 -- Communist China formally rejected India's compromise formula on the exchange of war prisoners tonight as Premier and Foreign Minister Chou En-lai placed the Peiping Government solidly behind the Soviet proposal for an immediate cease fire in Korea and the establishment of an eleven-nation commission to work out a general settlement of the "Korean question."
INDIANAPOLIS, Nov. 28 (AP) -- The Indiana University Medical Center announced today it had succeeded in patching a hole the size of a half dollar in a boy's heart.

Money in circulation throughout the nation passed the $30,000,000,000 mark last week for the first time in history. According to data issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, the public's pocket money requirements during the week ended on Wednesday lifted volume $310,000,000 to a new record level of $30,152,000,000.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Nov. 28 (UP) -- Alrick Man, manager of the U. S. Davis Cup team, today received a cablegram advising him that Tony Trabert of Cincinnati, would arrive at Sydney on Dec. 7 to join the squad.

Although "Two's Company," starring Bette Davis, will adhere to its scheduled plan of opening in New York on Thursday night, Dec. 4, the producers of the revue, Michael Ellis and James Russo, have asked the local drama appraisers not to show up at the Alvin Theatre until the evening of Dec. 15.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 28 -- With five events today and tomorrow, the first Pittsburgh International Contemporary Music Festival is winding up with a spate of performances that should gladden the hearts of the defenders of modern music and perhaps test the endurance of their ears and minds.

Four broadcasting companies and the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists, A. F. L., facing an expiration of contracts covering TV performers, agreed yesterday to extend the deadline until Tuesday in the hope of reaching an agreement on new pacts.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 (UP) -- A Democratic tax expert demanded today that President-elect Dwight D. Eisenhower and his incoming Republican Administration live up to their campaign "pledge" to cut individual income and excise taxes.
Former Mayor James J. Walker's net estate totaled $34,668 at his death Nov. 18, 1946, it was shown in an estate tax appraisal yesterday at the State Tax Commission office, 80 Centre Street.

BONN, Germany, Nov. 28 -- The resignation of Dr. Hans Ilau from the Free Democratic party because of its trend toward the "perniciousness" of reactionary nationalism has drawn attention to the gradual development of that party into a force on the extreme Right Wing of West German politics.

BOSTON, Nov. 28 (UP) -- Quarterback Charlie Maloy will lead his favored Holy Cross mates in their traditional battle with Boston College tomorrow to ring down the curtain on New England football. Maloy has a chance to break several national passing records, in the game expected to attract a sellout crowd of 40,000 to Braves Field.

TOKYO, Saturday, Nov. 29 -- The Chinese Communists, in light force but backed by powerful artillery fire, struck again today at "Sniper Ridge," main battle ground on the central Korean front for the last six weeks. They failed to penetrate the United Nations lines.
Judge Mortimer W. Byers denied in Brooklyn Federal Court yesterday an application to make surveys of the bankrupt Long Island Rail Road to speed up operation and cut down expenses.

Occurrences in the last two days suggest that the outlook for Western Europe is not quite so gloomy as it appeared when President Truman reported to President-elect Eisenhower on the state of the world after the campaign dust had settled. A week ago it seemed to many informed observers that the foundations of the Atlantic alliance were visibly cracking.

About a month ago Felix Belair Jr. of our Washington staff reported a project which was enough to send cold chills running up and down one's spine. In conferences on next year's Mutual Security Program, wrote Mr. Belair, one ambitious approach under consideration called for the establishment of "a multi-billion dollar currency stabilization fund, to be called the Atlantic Reserve System."

Delegations from the Congress of Industrial Organizations, which opposed the election of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, and from the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, which was nonpartisan in the campaign but issued an "evaluation" unfavorable to him, called on the President-elect yesterday and later expressed themselves as highly pleased with their reception.
The American Red Cross Blood Donor Program reported yesterday that on Wednesday 931 pints of blood were contributed in this area. No collections were made Thanksgiving Day.

The newest palace of ex-King Ahmed Zog I of Albania was spared from a tax sale in Nassau County yesterday. But his lawyer made it plain that the King would continue to seek on Long Island the "sovereign immunity against the imposition of local taxes" that is the kingly right in Europe.

American Silk Mills has purchased specialty yarn twisting machinery from Malina Textile Corporation which will substantially increase American's capacity for boucle yarns, it was learned yesterday. The new equipment, it was indicated, will give American Silk Mills a capacity greater than that of all other boucle twisters combined.

The controversy over whether college Greek-letter societies have the right to select their own members, free from any "interference or restriction" by college or university authorities, neared a showdown stage yesterday at the forty-fifth annual sessions of the National Interfraternity Conference in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 (AP) -- Following is the list of those aboard the Army plane that crashed at Tacoma, Wash., today. The address following that of victim is that of next of kin:

LONDON, Nov. 29 -- Walter S. Gifford, United States Ambassador in London, has informed Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the President-elect, that in January he will tender his resignation, asking that it become effective as soon as convenient and when circumstances permit.

Numerous readers, youthful and otherwise, have responded by letter to Clellon Holmes' article, "This Is the Beat Generation" (Nov. 16). Here is a sampling of opinions on whether his thesis -- that the generation in question, despite misbehaving, is desperately seeking constructive faith -- is right or not.

The wave of optimism which has prevailed in financial circles since the election kept building up during the last week. As the month drew to a close there was a turning point in sentiment -- from uncertainty to a more hopeful outlook on national affairs.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- Of the British Commonwealth conference that began in London this week the least that can be said from this reluctant capital of the free world is that rarely have so many official persons wished so devoutly for the success of an all-British undertaking.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the President-elect, accustomed to handling vast operations in World War II, is now planning the management of the biggest and toughest job on earth.

Both American exports and imports should rise somewhat next year if present indications hold true, the head of the New York office of the Department of Commerce has reported. The declining tempo of exports recently should be reversed in 1953, while there should be a moderate increase in imports, though during the first nine months of this year our imports were about $600,000,000 below the same period of 1951.

TUNIS, Tunisia, Nov. 29 (UP) -- France told the Bey of Tunis to face up to his responsibilities today in a stiff note that demanded a "clear" answer to the French proposal for granting more home rule to Tunisia.

Oldtimers have been telling us that winters are not as cold as they used to be and that summers are warmer. Two years ago the Danish Royal Geographical Society issued a report in which it accepted a warmer climate for the earth as a whole but suggested that fluctuations in solar radiation may account for some observations that have been recorded by the distinguished Swedish climatologist Dr. Hans W. Ahlmann.

BAGHDAD, Iraq, Nov. 29 -- Gen. Nuriddin Mahmoud has begun to make public some details of his program, which appears to look a bit beyond the merely transitional function of preparing for National elections.

FROM 194 sketches submitted by sixty-seven artists representing thirty-two United Nations member countries, an international jury of five philatelists appointed by Secretary General Trygve Lie selected last week sixteen designs for use on future stamps of the world organization.

HERE is a regional book which is so contemporary and so moving that it should be translated into a wide variety of foreign languages. The setting is South Dakota and the narrative centers on a summer's work on the gigantic statue of the Sioux chief, Crazy Horse, which the sculptor Korczak Ziolkowski is blasting out of the face of Thunderhead Mountain.

Senator Paul H. Douglas, in his fine appraisal of the city of Washington, "Washington Is Not the United States" (Nov. 16) points to the undemocratic "dual school system" in the nation's capital. He should have said "dual public school system."

ENCOURAGED by a sizable number of requests for information about events of interest to tourists in the islands, the Hawaii Visitors Bureau has increased the size of its "What to Do" daily events guide, and prepared a year-round calendar of traditional events.

Business during November maintained the high rate of the preceding two months, and indications are that it will continue at that level through the first quarter of next year, the business survey committee of the National Association of Purchasing Agents reports in its monthly survey, issued for publication today.

SPORTS have become an Integral part of the American scene and the growth of the country is reflected in the growth of athletics. Timely, indeed, is this massive and fascinating book, which has been jointly produced by John Durant and Otto L. Bettmann.

FORT MYERS, Fla. -- After three weeks of worry on the part of west coast hotel men and everyone else hereabouts who depends on the tourist dollar, Florida's "red tide" scare of 1952 washed out to sea and disintegrated last week.
TOKYO, Sunday, Nov. 30 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,449, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Sunday, Korea time:
DETROIT, Nov. 29 (AP) -- A steadily increasing number of 1953 model automobiles are moving from factory to dealer right now By the year-end few 1952 models will be moving from the factories.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 29 -- President Truman attended his seventh and final Army-Navy football game as Commander in Chief today. He saw the Navy win, 7 -- 0.

At first glance, it may not be apparent -- or, at least, it may not spring to mind -- that there is a remarkable kinship between the "Plymouth Adventure" of M-G-M and the "Hans Christian Andersen" of Samuel Goldwyn, even though they may look such different films, the first being a pseudo-history drama and the second a music-ballet film.

MOSCOW, Nov. 29 -- Pravda gave editorial support today to charges published in detail from Korea that the Americans were inflicting atrocities on prisoners of war. These charges, attributed to the central telegraph agency of Korea, contended that in May, 1951, 1,400 prisoners of war were secretly sent to the United States "for atomic weapons to be tried out on them."

AS a member of the faculty of the University of Zulia in Maracaibo, Venezuela, I feel compelled to denounce the very clever and sorrowful maneuver on the part of Salvador Madariaga to belittle and distort the historical figure and thinking of Simon Bolivar in his book "Bolivar" that was recently reviewed.

Noel Haviland Field arrived in Washington in September, 1926, a gangling young man of pleasant appearance and polished manners, eager for a career in diplomacy. A member of a Quaker family from New York, he had been born in London and brought up in Switzerland, where his father was the founder and head of an international bibliographical service in biology.

f.r. and Mrs. Hooker Talcott of 136' East Seventy-ninth Street and Hook's Farm, Atlantic Highlands, N. J., gave a tea dance yesterday afternoon at the Cosmopolitan Club to introduce their daughter, lE[iss Gertrude Geer Talcott. The debutante, who received with her mother, wore a bouffant gown of white gold chiffon.

TEL AVIV, Nov. 29 -- The Israeli delegate to the United Nations Assembly Ambassador Abba S. Eban, has been instructed to accept the recent proposal by the six Arab nations that Israel and the Arab states engage in direct negotiations.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 29 (AP) -- The Pacific Coast's first Roman Catholic prince-elect humbly prayed for world peace today upon receiving word that he had been elevated to the Sacred College of Cardinals.

TACOMA, Wash., Nov. 29 (UP) -- One of three survivors of the crash of a C-54 transport here yesterday died today, raising the death toll to 37. Injuries proved fatal to Airman Third Class Bobby Wilson, a crew member of the plane that crashed in a fog.

SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Nov. 29 -- Walter Dukes and Richie Regan led Seton Hall University to a 84-61 victory over Arnold College in its basketball opener before 2,500 at the Seton Hall gymnasium tonight. Dukes, who fouled out at the end of the third quarter, scored 20 points.
PRINCETON, N. J., Nov. 29 -- Princeton University will receive a bequest of about $750,000 under the will of William Shubael Conant of Washington, it was announced today by President Harold W. Doods.

INQUIRIES into the personal lives of creative artists can hinder our understanding of their masterpieces, for they are usually inquiries into that art in which geniuses are as inept as the rest of humanity. The concluding paragraph of this latest volume on the matchless master of keyboard music by a celebrated pianist unwittingly describes this reviewer's reaction.
Mayor Impellitteri laid the foundation yesterday for a re-election campaign in 1953 with preservation of the ten-cent fare on public and private transit lines as a major plank in his platform.

A MAN dies when his jet-propelled speedboat cracks up doing 200 miles an hour and the next day a woman announces she is going to try to go faster than that, in another jet boat. Year after year at Indianapolis automobile drivers compete to break racing records, and between whiles they use Bonneville Flats or the sands of Daytona Beach trying to set straightaway marks in giant special jobs.
ROME, Nov. 29 -- Twenty-four new Cardinals -- eleven of them Italians -- were named today by Pope Pius XII and will be installed in a secret consistory to be held on Jan. 12.
CORAL GABLES, Fla., Nov. 29 (AP) -- Ogden Phipps' Torch of War, ridden by Jimmy Stout, won the $7,500 DeSoto Handicap at Tropical Park today in a field of fourteen 2-year-olds.

THE growth of the modern art movement has brought with it sharply revised estimates of earlier artists, among them El Greco, Poussin and the great Italian etcher, draftsman and architect Piranesi. The imaginative and fantastic elements in Piranesi's powerful work have struck responsive chords in the work of expressionist and surrealist artists of our own day across the span of two centuries.

HAVING opened his third Metropolitan Opera season with "La Forza del Destino," Rudolf Bing is holding back his other trumps. Naturally there is curiosity about when they will be led. By an unexpected twist, some of the dates have been revealed.

IN Montgomery, Ala., four Negroes were walking slowly back and forth in front of a half-built office building on which work had stopped. They carried aloft placards proclaiming their complaints about the construction company, against which they were on strike.
While rapid strides have been made in industrial health, little has been done to reduce noise in industry.

In a drive to comply with the warning issued on Friday by the Food and Drug Administration against the use of Swift's canned dried egg yolk, seventy-seven Department of Health inspectors placed an embargo yesterday on 4.485 cans of the product found in 182 stores of 1,615 that were searched.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 29 -- American oil companies have been virtually shut out of Argentine trade, according to crude oil import quotas for the coming year, announced last night. About $70,000,000 worth of crude oil imports will come from the sterling area.

Older workers do as good a job on precision tasks as their younger associates. This is indicated by tests conducted last week by the Waltham Watch Company of older and younger workers handling similar lathe, drilling, assembling and other precision work.

ANNOUNCEMENT of the Ten Best Films for 1952 was made last week by the Amateur Cinema League, international association of amateur filmers. The Hiram Percy Maxim Memorial Award was won by Timothy M. Lawler Jr., of Kenosha, Wis., for his 750-foot 16mm color sound-on-film movie, "Duck Soup," which is described as "a well planned and crisply executed family film."

Seldom does it fall to the lot of one man to preside over the liquidation of a large corporation while attending the rejuvenation of another. Especially when the corporations have no common meeting ground.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 29 -- Senator Alexander Wiley, ranking Republican member of the Senate Foreign Relations committee, declared today that the appointment of Senator Henry Cabot Lodge Jr. was the answer to the "fearists" who had said that the Eisenhower administration would not be 100 per cent behind the world-organization and cooperation with the west.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 29 -- The Soviet bloc of delegates in the Economic and Financial Committee of the General Assembly of the United Nations failed today in an attempt to gag Dr. Isador Lubin of the United States when he replied to denunciations by G. P. Arkadyev of the Soviet Union of the "machinations" of "American monopolies."

A man of rugged faith and keen administrative ability, Archbishop J. Francis A. McIntyre of Los Angeles is the first Roman Catholic prelate on the West Coast to be named a member of the Sacred College of Cardinals.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 29 -"Well, it was a good show, and I'm glad I saw it," a man said, "but at times this afternoon I wished I'd stayed home and curled up with a warm television set."

RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 29 -- A dual exchange bill passed its first reading by the Chamber of Deputies late last night in an extraordinary night session. An amendment that would have given the Superintendent of Currency and Credit the power to suspend dual exchange transactions for sixty days was voted down.

The word "hallmark" stems from the official stamp of the Goldsmith's Company, London, on gold and silver articles to attest their purity. Figuratively, it has come to mean a distinctive mark or token of genuineness, good breeding or excellence.

The oldest college president in the United States, Dr. Maurice J. Lewi of the Long Island University College of Podiatry, who will be 95 years old tomorrow, lighted his sixth cigar of the day at 3 P. M. on Friday as he waited for the press to begin its annual interview.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Nov. 29 -- The concensus among impartial observers today was that the results of the Congressional elections are completely unpredictable. They agree that the Government, which is in the hands of a junta, has many resources on its side but they are of the opinion that the balloting will indicate the will of the people.

Senator Henry Cabot Lodge Jr., Republican of Massachusetts, comes from a family of statesmen appointed to head the United States mission to the United Nations, and politicians. His forebears include six United States Senators, a Secretary of State, a Secretary of the Navy, a Governor of Massachusetts and a candidate for Vice President of the United States.

NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 29 (AP) -- The brusque Soviet rejection of India's Korean resolution, now before the United Nations, apparently has shaken many Indians' faith in Russia as a firm proponent of world peace.

We have so much submerged ourselves in the policies, dictates and frustrations of others that we tend to lose sight of the possibly calamitous occurrences which could engulf our generation and probably the future world.

OBSERVERS of American letters have often expressed their surprise at the apparent inability of the American writer to remain young while growing old. French authors seem to possess the perilous secret of persistent maturing, or of recurrent youth, beyond the Biblical age of three score years and ten.

Whatever the economic aspects may be, the recent trend in the direction of producing more and more pictures in their authentic locales is one that benefits the filmgoer considerably. From the Hollywood dispatch appearing in Sunday's TIMES I note that twenty-four such photoplays have recently been or are currently on exhibition, while an additional seventeen can be expected in the not-too-distant future.

Plagued by mounting costs and falling sales volume, the fur industry appears to be suffering from a bad case of the jitters. So acute is its sense of insecurity, it was pointed out last week, that certain segments of the trade are strongly opposed to a meeting for discussing a program for lowering the 20 per cent excise tax on furs lest the ensuing publicity have an adverse effect on sales before the Christmas holidays.

Two teen-agers preached at Temple Israel, 210 West Ninety-first Street, yesterday morning, bringing to a close the congregation's part in the month-long national project knows as "Religion in American Life."

IN the face of a trend toward expanded tourist-class service by both domestic and international scheduled airlines of this country, United Air Lines last week announced it was cutting back its low-cost service. W. A. Patterson, president of United, stated that the line was limiting its DC-4 tourist-class service to fifty-four rather than sixty-six passengers.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 29 (UP) -- Louisiana State University threw up a strong air defense, then struck swiftly for two touchdowns and a field goal for a 16-0 victory today over arch-rival Tulane in the annual Bayou grudge game.

GENEVA, Nov. 29 -- One result of the privately voiced charges of poor cooperation in economic matters leveled at the United States by its North Atlantic Allies has been that serious attention is being given by the United States financial technicians to the possibility of developing a two-year budget for United States military aid and United States military expenditures abroad.

Last year the city's radio station WNYC provided for the public a total of 12,947 hours of broadcasting service at a cost of approximately $22 an hour, Seymour N. Siegel, director of the station, told Mayor Impellitteri yesterday.

An appeal for pints of blood as holiday gifts to wounded service men in Korea was made yesterday by T. Morgan Williams, chairman of the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program, as a feature of the solicitation for this month.

WASHINGTON. PRESIDENT TRUMAN has said that life in the White House is like a prison. He's right. When those big problems come up, like dropping an atomic bomb or aggression in Korea, your advisers bring plans and recommendations. Then they walk out, and in your loneliness you make up your mind.
LUBBOCK, Tex., Nov. 29 (UP) -- Tulsa withstood two last-period Texas Tech thrusts to defeat Tech, 26 to 20, today.

DURING the Nazi occupation of France the children of a little mountain school sheltered ten young Jewish refugees, shared their scanty food with them and cared for them. When the Nazis came in search of the refugees, the children hid their guests in a cave and, fearful of betraying them, kept absolute silence for two days in the face of Nazi questioning.

AN inexpensive Brownie Movie Projector for projection of 8mm home movies has been placed on the market by Eastman Kodak. The $62.50 projector, which may also be purchased complete with thirty-inch-wide Brownie Projection Screen for $67, has a quickly removable cover and is designed for easy operation.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 29 -- For the time being, at least, India's complicated resolution on the repatriation of Korean prisoners of war -- which is even more complicated than most compromise proposals -- will merely fill out a page on the books of the United Nations General Assembly.
DALLAS, Nov. 29 (AP) -- Ronald Clinkscale, a sophomore, starred against Southern Methodist today to pace Texas Christian to a 14-7 victory in the season's finale.

SPLENDID is the best word I can think of to describe book on Williamson County, Ill., and its long and turbulent history of violence. The author, a well-known Lincoln historian and director of the Chicago Historical Society, has not only drafted a factual and fair account of the county's bloody history but a readable and gripping one as well.

LONG range development of transportation facilities in this area by the Port of New York Authority calls for an expenditure of more than $500,000,000 over the next ten years. The magnitude of the task ahead is emphasized by a recent survey indicating that highway development during the last quarter of a century here has cost about $1,100,000,000.

NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 29 -- It will come as a surprise to most Americans and it certainly astonished Chester Bowles, our able Ambassador here, to discover that the United States has not yet evolved any basic long-range policy toward India.
Proposals to extend Federal Social Security on a voluntary basis to all Protestant clergymen have stirred wide debate over the issue of the separation of church and state, it has been learned.

Roger Baudrin, Mayor of the French city of Angouleme, attended the rededication yesterday of the Battery Park statue of Giovanni da Verrazzano, Italian-born navigator who is generally credited with having discovered the New York Bay region.

The annual Christmas sale of St. Bartholomew's Protestant Episcopal Church will be held Tuesday afternoon in the Community House of the church at 109 East Fiftieth Street. Mrs. James M. Price heads the committee for the event, and serving with her as co-chairmen are Mrs. John Tate and Miss Karen Collier.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- The Administration still was without a solution tonight to the perplexing problem as to what to do about the rise in pay for coal miners.

Jacques Fath, one of France's most prominent designers of women's clothes, found himself enmeshed yesterday in the technicalities of American immigration law. and spent several hours on Ellis Island before being freed on a permit allowing him to stay here ten days on business.

It takes a long time for hot jewelry to cool off -- longer, at any rate, than Henry Schwartz, a 50-year-old Bronx taxi driver, thought it would. Schwartz, who lives at 1270 Gerard Avenue, was arrested in a Bowery, jewelers' exchange yesterday as he tried to sell $15,000 worth out of about $17,000 in gems stolen in 1944 from the widow of Joe Penner, the radio and movie comedian. Mrs. Penner died in 1946.

THE apostate to whom this strenuous little book is addressed is Karl Stern, a teacher of psychiatry at McGill University, who published last year an account of his conversion from Judaism to the Roman Catholic faith, under the title, "The Pillar of Fire."

Despite the gains of medical science, the great improvements in the health of the public in the last century have resulted largely from general economic and social advances, a health economist declared yesterday. However, he said, such gains may not be duplicated in the future.

EXPANSION of Christmas trade now takes the center of the business stage. Retailers are prepared for a record volume, and the vigor of consumer response will have a bearing not only on immediate business but will afford some clues on the trend of buying during the early months of next year.

SYDNEY, Australia, Sunday, Nov. 30 -- Sister Elizabeth Kenny, Australian nurse famed for her methods of polio treatment, died peacefully in her sleep today at her home in Toowoomba, Queensland. She was 66 years old.

Even though no one but the cowhand Shorty wanted him at first, it didn't take Smoky long to make a special place for himself on Horsetrack Ranch.
The New York Knickerbockers walloped the Indianapolis Olympians, 94 -- 72, in a National Basketball Association game that a crowd of 14,831 yawned through in Madison Square Garden last night.
MADRID, Nov. 29 -- Spain's Minister of Commerce, Manuel Arburua, said today he expeted an agreement on economic collaboration to be concluded between Washington and Madrid.

The school board in Croom, Md., has deeded its no longer used one-room schoolhouse to the teacher who presided there for twenty-one years. Mrs. Burroughs, the teacher, had said that she could never forget the little schoolroom. We venture the assertion that most of the pupils who had the advantage of her teaching will also never forget.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- It's too early to be sure what General Eisenhower's official family is, but at least we now know fairly well what it isn't.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 29 (UP) -- Tennessee routed Vanderbilt, 46 -- 0, today before a crowd of 28,000 huddled in driving sleet and snow.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 29 -- The aftermath of the steel strike and coal mine stoppage has nearly disappeared as an impediment to expansion of industrial activity. Factory output, employment and total payrolls this month showed gains over October and in some lines surpassed November, 1951.

Water-color techniques for beginners and the correct tools for use in the medium will be described and demonstrated by a specialist in the art, James A. Ernst, at a free art lecture at 6:15 P. M. Tuesday at the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and Forty - second Street.

SANCHI, India, Nov. 29 -- Inaugurating the international Buddhist cultural conference here, Prince Minister Jawaharlal Nehru declared today that this gathering of thousands of religious leaders and high officials from several Asian nations might mark the "turning point" in strengthening the forces of peace in the world.

By this time wild ducks have migrated south from the Northern states. At the Pennsylvania State College there are more than 130 exceptions -- mallards, wood ducks and blue-wing teals. Their habitat is the roof of one of the college buildings.
Guido Cantelli, the young Italian conductor who in 1949 made his American debut with the N. B. C. Symphony, returned to lead that orchestra yesterday afternoon in a concert at Carnegie Hall.

MEXICO CITY, Nov. 29 -- The formal ceremonies of President Miguel Aleman's retirement and inauguration of the new President, Adolfo Ruiz Cortines, began today with the presentation of credentials by special delegations from fifty-four countries.

Into his Commodore Hotel headquarters in New York came a steady stream of callers and delegations -- national committeemen, Congressmen, foreign dignitaries and diplomats, leaders of labor and industry, representatives of racial organizations.

Business, industry and agriculture are on an even keel and employment is high, but some other ingredient apparently is lacking.

THIS morning, if you happen to be interested in such matters, marks the completion of the first six months of the current Broadway season -- the season, as every literate theatregoer knows, having begun on June 1 with the inception of the new Actors Equity contracts.

VIENNA, Nov. 29 -- The trial and condemnation in Prague this week of Rudolf Slansky, former Secretary Genera' of the Czechoslovak Communist party, Dr. Vladimir Clementis, former Foreign Minister, and twelve other leading Czechoslovak Communists crowned the most drastic purge that has yet taken place in any Soviet satellite.

MacDonald of the Royal Air Force to Supreme Allied Headquarters this week marks an important step in the development of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization's Air Examining Squadron, which Marshal MacDonald formed two years ago and has led since.

THIS is a time of year when there is interest in culinary equipment. One thinks of it in terms of Christmas gifts and as a way of easing one's own holiday entertaining. THERE is a popular belief that after Cain killed Abel he was marked or branded in order to stigmatize him with murder. This belief, however, is quite erroneous. According to the written record, the mark was intended only to protect Cain from punishment in the course of his wanderings, or as the Bible puts it, "lest may finding him should kill him."

A 17-year-old Brooklyn youth survived being struck by a motorist yesterday and run over almost immediately by a following taxi driver. The police said the drivers of both vehicles contended that they did not know they had hit anyone.

WHAT is by anybody's reckoning a major event is Jose Limon's series of six performance at the Juilliard Concert Hall, 130 Claremont Avenue, which gets under way on Friday for two week-ends. Spingarn, one of the Government agency's commissioners, that indicates there is little love lost between the two groups.

A new method employing a coaxial cable or television "pipe," making it possible to transmit a complete television network program from city-to-city along with hundreds of telephone calls, will be ready for operation next year between New York and Philadelphia, the Bell Telephone Laboratories announced yesterday.

A FEATURE length semi-documentary film dealing with the struggle of three young Koreans against the destruction of war is being shot in and around this city. The forty-first annual appeal for The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund will be opened next Sunday. The campaign, which will follow its traditional pattern, had yielded $9,285,026 up to the close of last year's drive on March 1, 1952.

The American Merchant Marine Library Association has just issued its annual Christmas letter, an appeal for funds and books to maintain its "public library of the high seas." PARIS, Nov. 29 -- Experts of the European countries who met this week at the headquarters here of the Organization for European Economic Cooperation completed today an exchange of views on how to combat Europe's dollar gap. They expressed satisfaction with the discussions and asked the organization's Council to consider calling another conference on the question.

STILLWATER, Okla., Nov. 29 (AP) -- The Oklahoma Aggies' Bill Bredde returned the opening kickoff 98 yards for a touchdown, but that made the Oklahoma Sooners mad -- and they pounded their cross-state rivals through the rest of the fifty-nine minutes for a 54-to-7 decision.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 29 -- An Israeli spokesman said today that the Tel Aviv Government was willing to negotiate directly on any subject with each of the Arab states with which it had signed armistice agreements, but without any prior commitments.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 29 -President Truman was on the side of a winning Eisenhauer today as Navy defeated Army at football for the third successive year.

Work on the revolutionary new pier that was started more than two years ago at West Fifteenth Street is progressing at such a rate that the project is expected to assume the appearance of a pier soon after the end of the year.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 (AP) -- An investigating Senate subcommittee reported today's constant and close check was needed on operation of President Truman's order on security of information.

Deadlocked with Cleveland and Philadelphia for American Conference leadership as the National Football League race heads into the homestretch, the New York Giants today will oppose the Pittsburgh Steelers in their final road test.

ORIGINALLY an address delivered in Hamburg on the two-hundredth anniversary of Bach's death, this slim book is a tribute by one of the leading German composers of today to a great predecessor. It is also an attempt to substitute a credible picture of Bach, both as a man and as a musician, for the mythical and shadowy portrait which prevailed for so long after the rediscovery of Bach more than a century ago.

IN an article which I wrote recently for Brassey's Annual -- the armed forces year book -- I expressed the opinion that there are indications that the atomic bomb or any other form of atomic missile may not be used in a future war. This can be no more than an opinion but I propose in this article to give my reasons for this belief.

Sixty-one years ago Congress initiated a policy of setting aside public forest lands to assure the permanent protection of their water supply, recreation and wildlife. Later legislation provided for the reservation and administration of public grasslands also.

ALTHOUGH the theatre-going audience is constantly encouraged to be noble and intellectual, it stubbornly insists upon enjoying itself. Nothing originating on Broadway this year has elevated anyone's soul. But two of the new plays -- "The Seven Year Itch" and "Dial M for Murder" -- have succeeded admirably in entertaining the customers.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 29 -- John Gurski, Navy's football captain, shouldered his way through the interviewers clustered around Eddie Erdelatz, the beaming coach of the mishipmen, in their crowded dressing room following Navy's 7-0 victory over Army today.

TALENTED teen-age youngsters from high schools in the New York-Connecticut-New Jersey area will participate in a new series of Monday, Wednesday and Friday television variety shows to be introduced over WOR-TV tomorrow evening from 7 to 7:30 o'clock.

WACO, Tex., Nov. 29 (AP) -- Rice Institute used two intercepted passes and a magnificent 61-yard punt return by Horton Nesrsta today to beat Baylor, 20 -- 14. Thus what had been a woebegone football team became runner-up in the Southwest Conference.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Nov. 29 -- The South is now a "creditor region" in the field of undergraduate schooling, and accounts for 27.5 per cent of the total national expenditures by publicly controlled colleges and universities, according to a report by the Southern Regional Education Board.
SAARBRUECKEN, the Saar, Nov. 29 -- About half a million Saarlanders will vote tomorrow in an election that both sides now regard as a kind of referendum on European unity.

SEVERAL of the more popular piano concertos in the repertoire have found their way onto recent LP disks. Perhaps the most welcome is Wilhelm Backhaus' account of the Brahms Concerto No. 2 in B flat, with the Vienna Philharmonic under Carl Schuricht (London).

Well-known women, including Mrs. Lytle Hull and Mrs. Harry C. Mills, are serving with the Duchess of Windsor on the committee for the entertainment to be known as the Duchess of Windsor's Ball, to be held on the night of Jan. 5 in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel for the benefit of the Hospitalized Veterans Music Service.

ANCHORAGE, Alaska, Nov. 29 (UP) -- Officers and men in this month's subarctic maneuvers have shown themselves to be mentally and physically ready to meet an attack if it should come, according to the official observers.

Young matrons are aiding in the plans for the 1952 "Adopt Me" doll exhibition and sale for the benefit of the Spence-Chapin Adoption Service that will open tomorrow at the East River Savings Bank, Rockefeller Plaza and Fiftieth Street, and will continue through Dec. 12.

THE reader of Westerns is, or should be by now, quite well adjusted to villains of assorted degrees of perfidy, but Jim O'Mara's RUSTLER OF THE OWLHORNS, (Dutton, $2.50), introduces a skunk who takes all medals and silver casters for slick-as-grease skunkiness.

The Marquis Childs article, reprinted from The Washington Post by the International Latex Corporation, questions the advisability of General Eisenhower's inspection trip to Korea, chiefly because of the danger involved.
