WE saw an educational film for children a few weeks ago with a title both commonplace and remarkable -- "Rules and Laws." We say "commonplace" because surely nothing could be more ordinary than a title composed of three old-fashioned, one-syllable words; yet in the parent education field these words are in a sense remarkable for they are heard rarely indeed nowadays.

Plans have been advanced rapidly for the fourteenth annual White Elephant Party, a buffet dinner dance, for the benefit of the Child Placing and Adoption Committee, which will be held on the night of Jan. 16 in the main ballroom of the Pierre.
SANTA FE, N. M., Nov. 29 (AP) -- United States Senator Dennis Chavez, Democrat, was declared winner today of the Nov. 4 election by a 5,071-vote margin over Patrick J. Hurley, Republican.

THE mild, dry fall has made the need of adequate winter protection more imperative than usual. Shrubs and trees transplanted within the last year, or even the last two years, have been checked by the drought. Next spring the plants are apt to show reduced vigor and may even be completely lost, unless proper care is taken before winter sets in.

WE feel that the attack made on Hemingway's Spanish by Pepe Mostaza (Book Review, Nov. 2) is unjustified. Mr. Mostaza assumes that Hemingway is using Peninsular Spanish. This is a gross error. Hemingway is here employing Spanish as it is actually spoken in Cuba.
For the first time in six years the Dodgers will play a spring exhibition game at New Orleans as one of the thirty-five games in which they will participate during the 1953 training period.

Coffee prices appear to be stabilized for some time to come. Brazil has been attempting to place a floor on the export price of coffee through various methods and traders believe that this will be accomplished through an edict issued by the Brazilian Government.
SOUTH BEND, Ind., Nov. 29 -They cannot and will not claim the national championship this year, but the Fighting Irish of Notre Dame are the undisputed upset kings of the 1952 college football season.

OXFORD, Miss., Nov. 29 -- Sugar Bowl-bound Mississippi kept its unbeaten record intact by beating Mississippi State, 20 -- 14, today as Pete Mangum, fullback, stopped a desperate last-period State drive with a pass interception.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 29 -- The Political Action Committee of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, which sought unsuccessfully to defeat Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower in the Nov. 4 election, expressed confidence today that 70 to 75 per cent of C. I. O. members had followed the recommendations of their union leadership in the Presidential balloting.

In your article "Art Macabre" (Nov. 23) the name of the artist who made the engraving "First Dream: Crime and Expiation" did not appear in the caption. He was the extraordinary Frenchman who signed himself J.-J. Grandville, his real name being Isidore-Adolph Gerard, and whose dates were 1803-43.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- All doubt of the Republicans' ability to take control of the new Senate on Jan. 3 was removed today when Senator Wayne Morse of Oregon announced that he would vote with his former party colleagues in the opening-day organizational proceedings.

The Boston Symphony Orchestra will play a special concert in New York next Sunday for the benefit of its Pension Fund. Since this fund is the oldest of its kind in this country -- its inception goes back to 1903 -- its structure and importance are worth examination.

In Prague last week the first major purge trial since the Communists took over Czechoslovakia in 1948, and the largest in any country since the Moscow trials of 1937, came to a close. On Thursday eleven of the fourteen defendants, including Rudolph Slansky, former secretary general of the Czech C. P., and Vladimir Clementis, former Czech Foreign Minister, were sentenced to hang.

NEW HAVEN, Nov. 29 -- The Rev. Dr. Luther A. Weigle, dean emeritus of the Yale Divinity School, said here today that the new Revised Standard Version of the King James Bible had set new publishing records. A total of 1,600,000 copies of the perennial best-seller has been sold in the eight weeks since its publication date of Sept. 30, he declared.

SYSTOLE and diastole, the heart of Charles Dickens beat steadily in the cause of humanity. In this magnificent edition of new letters, selected by Edgar Johnson from the Burdett-Coutts Collection now owned by the Pierpont Morgan Library, it is possible to follow, as never before, the nearly absolute devotion with which Dickens conceived and developed an extensive program of private charities.

KINGS POINT, L. I., Nov. 29 -- The third annual North Shore Thanksgiving Ball, to aid the North Shore Hospital at Manhasset, took place this evening in O'Hara Hall of the United States Merchant Marine Academy.

A learned professor of Oriental and Greek languages was honored once again, yesterday, for a bit of "doggerel" he dashed off to amuse his children. The professor was Dr. Clement Clarke Moore, the doggerel "A Visit From St. Nicholas," memorized and loved by generations of children ever since its composition 130 years ago.

MEXICO CITY -- The "travel light" maxim for touring is generally scrapped on the trip home from Mexico, since one of the main items in the plans of almost every visitor here is shopping. A good many of Mexico's most attractive products are regularly exported to the United States, and the advantage of buying these on the spot lies chiefly in getting a bargain.
SCARSDALE, N. Y., Nov. 29 -The Boulder Brook Club's twenty-eighth annual fall horse show opened a two-day stand today with familiar names taking a majority of the blue ribbons.

TOKYO, Sunday, Nov. 30 -- The Chinese Communists poured heavy artillery and mortar fire on "Sniper Ridge" in the hills north of Kumhwa on the central Korean front. The foe followed up the fire with only minor attacks, all of which were repulsed.

MOSCOW, Nov. 29 -- The Soviet athletic authorities today launched their preparation for the next Olympic Games with the publication of new athletic norms and standards of training rules, aimed at capturing the principal world records.

FOR his first Christmas as director of music at St. Thomas' in Leipzig, Bach composed a cantata, Christians, Engrave Ye This Day. Eleven years later, when the holiday came round again, he composed another work to celebrate it. The Christmas Oratorio.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 29 -- Cleveland played an important part in the steel news this week with announcement that a 1,350-ton blast furnace, third to rise from the Cuyahoga Valley in the last two years, is planned. The new $10,000,0000 furnace is to be constructed by American Steel and Wire Company, a division of United States Steel Corporation.

Stanford University in California has a "proton bombarder," a modification of atom-smashing machines. It identifies and measures minute amounts of elements by bouncing a stream of protons (hydrogen nuclei) off surfaces. The apparatus comprises a two-million-volt generator, a twenty-foot vacuum tube and two large electromagnets.

HOLLYWOOD BEACH, Fla., Nov. 29 -- The forty-first annual convention of the Investment Bankers Association of America, which is scheduled to get under way here tomorrow, will be the largest in the association's history, according to advance registrations at the Hollywood Beach Hotel, where main convention sessions will be held.

MELBOURNE, Nov. 29 (UP) -- Two United States Davis Cup players and two California girls scored straight-set, first-round victories in singles and doubles play at the Victoria tennis championships today, while Australia's powerful cup squad took six places in the men's quarter-finals.

IN 1937, in London, at the age of 78, there died in disgrace a man whose bibliographical studies in nineteenth-century English literature had won him an outstanding place in the field of book collecting. Three years before, this man, Thomas J. Wise, had been exposed as one of the master forgers of all time -- an unscrupulous manufacturer of "first edition" pamphlets purportedly by such eminent Victorians as the Brownings, Ruskin, Kipling, Swinburne and others.

BOSTON, Nov. 29 -- D. B. Snyder, publisher of The Atlantic Monthly, said today that The Journal of the American Medical Association had refused to accept an advertisement from his publication calling attention to an article on national health insurance. The item was by Dr. James Howard i Means and appeared in the December issue of The Atlantic.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 29 -- After conferences with Foreign Minister Jeronimo Remorino and Raul Apold, chief of the subsecretariat of information, Eric Johnston, president of the Motion Picture Association of America, said today he believed the financial problems between the Argentine Government and the American film industry had been resolved.

Powered by a 205-horsepower V-8 engine, the 1953 Lincoln line of cars was announced yesterday by the Lincoln-Mercury division, Ford Motor Company. The engine is the most powerful ever installed in cars produced by the division; last year's Lincoln had a 160-horsepower engine.

Opportunities for collectors in varying fields an for householders after attractive buys for the home will present themselves at the auction houses this week when a quantity of furniture will be up for sale, also numerous decorative objects, rare books, arms and armor and modern paintings.

The American Jewish Committee and the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith, veteran Jewish agencies, announced yesterday that they have placed into operation a joint program "to provide a stronger impact on the American mind concerning the evils of anti-Semitism" and other forms of racial and religious bigotry and discrimination.
City College's basketball team rolled to an easy 77-52 victory over Hunter College last night in the annual Stein Fund basketball game at the Beavers' gymnasium.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- The eight fatal accidents to military aircraft this month have revived discussion of the relative safety of the airplanes used by the armed services and those employed by the civil airlines.

BONN, Germany, Nov. 29 -- The charge that the Saar is being transformed into a French protectorate like Morocco and Tunisia is leveled at France in a final German appeal to the people of the territory to abstain from voting in tomorrow's Landtag elections.

Richard Rogers Bowker is best remembered for his contributions to the book business and his activities in the movement for independent political action.

WILLIAMSBURG, Va., Nov. 29 (AP) -- Quarterback Charlie Harding threw two touchdown passes today as Virginia's Cavaliers won the Virginia state college championship by whipping William and Mary's Indians, 20 -- 13.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 29 -- Walter P. Reuther, president of the United Automobile Workers, took long strides forward tonight in the contest for the presidency of the Congress of Industrial Organizations.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- The amount of the national product going into national defense is steadily rising -- it will come to about 20 per cent by next June -but the economic controls, voted to cushion the effect of this great effort on the economy, are being reduced even more rapidly.
DALLAS, Nov. 29 -- School textbooks that deal with controversial subjects were defended today against indiscriminate charges that they were subversive.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 29 -- A novel experiment to take symphonic music played by a live orchestra under an eminent conductor to the workers in the steel towns in this area will be started on Tuesday. It is the product of cooperative arrangement among the Pittsburgh Symphony Orchestra, the United Steelworkers of America, C. I. O., and service and civic organizations in each town.

BERLIN, Nov. 22 -- Claims from former Berliners who suffered losses at the hands of the Nazis have so exceeded expectations that it will take at least ten years to settle them, according to Ulrich Eichholtz, director of the Berlin Restitution Office.

IN his first one-man exhibition of paintings at Paul Rosenberg's, Raymond Mintz introduces himself as a realist, not only in the superficial sense that he paints what he sees but also in the profounder sense that he feels strongly about his subject matter, figures and still-life.

BOSTON, Nov. 29 -- Holy Cross took advantage of two last-period mistakes by the Boston College football squad and converted them into quick touchdowns to defeat its rival, 21 -- 7, before a chilled crowd of 37,889 at Braves Field today.

DALLAS, Nov. 29 -- Christmas shopping got off to a slow start over Texas as a result of rainy weather, but has been picking up steadily for the last week. Merchants reported moderately good business. The Eleventh Federal Reserve Bank in its monthly summary of district business conditions for release tomorrow reported department store sales in October 9 per cent over the previous month and 12 per cent over October a year ago.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- An investigation to determine whether bribery figured in the parole of three Chicago gangsters in 1947 was ordered today by Attorney General James P. McGranery.

IN this pleasant land where the greatest tension ever felt by most people in the past was the pull of a fish on a baited line all the countryside is now taut with the strains of the Atomic Age. It is here -- in the Atomic Energy Commission's $1,250,000,000 Savannah River plant -- that the materials for the latest nuclear weapon, the hydrogen bomb, are to be mass-produced.

THE borough of Brooklyn has a great variety of things to its credit -- in addition to a well-known baseball team -- and not the least of them is a young and enterprising musical organization which calls itself the Chamber Music Associates.
TOKYO, Nov. 29 (AP) -- Japanese police tonight handed to British Commonwealth authorities a British and an Australian soldier accused of robbing a Tokyo taxi driver of about $7.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 29 -- The battle ended with Navy precisely five and seven-eighths inches away from a second touchdown. It was typical. The fray came to a close on just another note of frustration. This was a very frustrating afternoon. The midshipmen had the superior team and yet they had to settle for a 7-0 victory. They even were denied the luxury of that extra touchdown, not that it was necessary.

SHORTLY after 16-year-old Amy Burton moved to Coast City, Calif., she began running with "the wrong people." Her family didn't worry until Amy and her 21-year-old husband were arrested. Then they had to face the fact that their daughter was a narcotics addict.

MOSCOW, Nov. 29 -- The editorial board responsible for publishing the bimonthly journal Communist, organ of the Central Committee of the Communist party of the Soviet Union, has undergone considerable change and enlargement, the latest issue of the journal disclosed today.

The National Education Association, in its annual report on public elementary and secondary schools last week, set out this balance sheet of favorable and unfavorable factors for the 1952-53 academic year:

ALBANY, Nov. 30 -- The State Mental Health Commission made public today its directory of psychiatric facilities. There are twenty-nine agencies in the state list and the commission noted that it was distributing $220,000 to them this year.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., Nov. 30 -- In their first real wintry touch of this cold-weather sailing season, twenty dinghies were out today off the Larchmont Yacht Club. There was less snow here than in Manhattan, so the pier and floats were bare and the ground only white speckled.

CHICAGO, Nov. 30 -- Wheat futures showed a generally easier trend last week, while coarse grains and soybeans worked moderately higher. In all grains long liquidation was in evidence, especially in the December deliveries, but on the whole the absorption of futures on small recessions has been active enough to hold the market in a narrow range.

Joshua Logan doesn't believe in suppressing any news, especially a coup of great import. From Ocho Rios, Jamaica, B. W. I., he sent the following cable on Saturday: "Evidently Mary Martin's friends were right [and how!] as she signed a contract with me today to star next season with Charles Boyer in Norman Krasna's comedy, 'Kind Sir.'

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 30 -- The dismissal from the United Nations staff of all active members of the United States Communist party or other organizations officially declared subversive was recommended today by a special three-man legal panel set up by Secretary General Trygve Lie.

The creation of a "superblock" in Columbus Circle, on which would be constructed a huge convention and exposition hall and two twelve-story apartment houses, was recommended yesterday to Mayor Impellitteri and the Board of Estimate by the Committee on Slum Clearance.

A dwelling on plot 75 by 100 feet at 60 Dow Avenue, Mineola, was sold by Anthony R. Marsicovetere to a buyer who insured title with the Title Guarantee and Trust Company and obtained a mortage loan of $11,000 from the Serial Federal Savings and Loan Association.

A six-point traffic safety program, including compulsory fingerprinting of applicants for operator's licenses and at least once-a-year inspection of motor vehicles, has been submitted to the Legislature, Chief Magistrate John M. Murtagh announced yesterday.

The Right Hon. James Miller, Lord Provost of Edinburgh, who arrived here Saturday to speak at the St. Andrew's Day dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel tonight, will make a courtesy call on Mayor Impellitteri at City Hall at 10 A. M. today.

It was almost French night yesterday at the opening concert of the League of Composers' thirtieth season. Presented at the Museum of Modern Art, the program contained two fairly lengthy song cycles by Louise Talma and Jacques de Menasce, in addition to songs in French by Albert Roussel and Jacques Ibert.
BOSTON, Nov. 30 -- Work will be resumed in 1954 on the Shrine of the Immaculate Conception in Washington, the Most Rev. Richard J. Cushing, Roman Catholic Archbishop of Boston, said today.

BOSTON, Nov. 30 (UP) -- Boston's onrushing Bruins, threatening to overtake the leaders in the bitter National Hockey League race, notched their first victory this season over Montreal tonight, beating the Canadiens, 3 -- 1.

James J. Lyons Jr. has been named national secretary-treasurer of the Propeller Club of the United States, Hugh Gallagher, president of the maritime industry organization, announced here yesterday. Mr. Lyons, whose father is Borough President of the Bronx, succeeds the late Harold J. Harding.

VIENNA, Nov. 30 -- Harsh words that seemed to presage a shake-up in the Hungarian Government were addressed to the Hungarian Communist leaders by Deputy Premier Erno Geroe at a meeting of the party's Central Committee in Budapest Thursday.

A month ago, a number of trial balloons were sent aloft over Washington dealing with a gigantic new plan designed, one gathered, to solve the foreign aid problem, the problem of the dollar shortage, and a miscellany of other problems, such as the annoying tendency of world commodity prices to fluctuate, instead of standing still, as they should do, and would do, of course, in any well-organized world.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 30 (AP) -- The 1952-53 burley tobacco sales season opening Monday will pour something like $300,000,000 into growers' pockets.

This city has 200,000 to 300,000 chronic alcoholics to whom drinking is a compulsive illness, progressively impairing health and efficiency. The probable annual private and public cost to the victims and community is $200,000,000. The toll includes $50,000,000 in lost wages, and perhaps $13,000,000 in home relief, nearly a tenth of the city's relief bill.

BONN, Germany, Nov. 30 -- The newly formed All-German People's party issued a manifesto today calling for the creation of a united Germany as the basis for a European "third force" that would be neutral in the struggle between the Soviet Union and the Western powers.

A forty-eight state survey by correspondents of THE NEW YORK TIMES to determine expenditures in the 1952 political campaign indicated that at least $32,155,251 had been spent by political organizations, independent groups and candidates.

Today we have little girls' dresses for you. They are very special, for they have been designed by one whose life's work and thought has been devoted to the making of children's fashions. Hers is a fascinating story. Since her own childhood days she has devoted herself to the career, which has today given her a well-known name in her field.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 30 (UP) -- The Los Angeles Rams, defending champions of the professional football world, stayed in the race for 1952 honors today by defeating the San Francisco Forty-Niners, 34 -- 21, before 51,000 fans in Kezar Stadium.

The following table was compiled from reports submitted by correspondents of THE NEW YORK TIMES on campaign expenditures in 1952. The total figure for the states does not purport to be the total actually spent, but wherever possible it represents the total according to official reports or the statements of competent party officials.

Mayor Impellitteri's proposal for control, construction and operation of municipal transit lines by a transit authority that would be made "self-sustaining" with the help of a heavy tax on business concerns has little or no chance of approval by Governor Dewey and the Republican leaders of the predominantly Republican Legislature.

New financing in November was featured by an increase in bond offerings and a decline in equity financing. New issues of bonds publicly offered were the largest in volume since June and the biggest for a November in over twenty-five years, principally as a result of large offerings of notes by Home Loan Banks.

An inch of snow that brought a dance-floor slickness to highways in the city and suburbs early yesterday caused scores of traffic accidents and resulted in temporary closing of part of the Henry Hudson Parkway and an enforced slowdown along the New Jersey Turnpike.
BONN, Germany, Nov. 30 -- Germans must never forget the crimes committed by their compatriots during the Nazi regime, West German President Theodor Heuss said today at Belsen, in Lower Saxony.

A formal demand that the Export-Import Bank provide relief for smaller export concerns having large amounts of money tied up in Brazil's heavy backlog of unliquidated dollar exchange credits due for United States goods will be presented tomorrow at a meeting of exporters.
With an unusually large number of exhibitions of all sorts, the art world will present this week the widest range of attractions so far this season.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (UP) -- Seven former Collectors of Internal Revenue, who got their jobs through political appointment, have landed top Civil Service posts in the reorganized tax system, the Revenue Bureau said today.

A sharply divided State Democratic Committee will meet here Dec. 10 in an effort to select a successor to Paul E. Fitzpatrick, its present state chairman. Letters announcing the meeting, which will be held at 11 A. M. at the Biltmore Hotel, were mailed to the 300 committee members yesterday.
The redemption of bonds in November before maturity was the smallest for any month since April and the lowest for any November since 1933.

Three members of the Budapest String Quartet and Eunice Norton, pianist, were the artists for yesterday afternoon's concert of the New Friends of Music at Town Hall. The program was devoted entirely to Mozart, chief of the classical composers being featured in the series this season.

LONDON, Nov. 30 -- There is no doubt that the projected appointment of Winthrop W. Aldrich as the next United States Ambassador to Britain will be welcomed here. Mr. Aldrich's record of friendship for Britain assures that.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif, Nov. 30 -An unseasonal production slump at Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer has resulted in temporary unemployment for approximately 200 casual workers. Reports that the total was between 400 and 500 were denied officially by Edgar J. Mannix, general manager of the studio.

Bernice B. Ashdown's Samoyed, Ch. Silver Spray of Wychwood, a striking member of a breed that doesn't gain best-in-show championships often, was the winner at the fifth annual event of the Brooklyn Kennel Club last night.

SAIGON, Indo-China, Nov. 30 -- Developments so far in this winter's renewal of major hostilities in the vital Tonkin theatre of the Indo-China war emphasize the difficult prospect facing the French-Vietnamese forces. On the basis of events so far this season the defeat of the Vietminh rebels in a decisive way appears to be as remote and uncertain a possibility as ever.

SEOUL, Korea, Nov. 29 -- The Republic of Korea Government favors the earliest possible release of all Korean anti-Communist prisoners of war and is willing to grant them full citizenship, with no strings attached.

George Byron Gordon (apparently not the George Gordon, Lord Byron who hated dumpy women) has written a book that should be of great value to anybody who is planning to die in the near future -- and of even greater value to the heirs. It is called, "You, Your Heirs and Your Estate."*

As a freshly graduated nurse of 23 Sister Elizabeth Kenny saw her first case of poliomyelitis in a cottage in her native Australia. In her ignorance of the disease she telegraphed for advice to her medical mentor, only to receive the reply: "Infantile paralysis. Do the best you can." At the bedside of that 2-year-old girl she found that only wrappings steeped in boiling water did any good.
Nathan Milstein violinist, played a recital at Hunter College Saturday evening as the third event of the college's Jubilee Subscription Series.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Nov. 30 -- The Chilean Minister of National Defense, Col. Abdon Parra, has announced the cancellation of a contract under which a British-controlled corporation has had the exclusive right to the commercial exploitation of Easter Island, a little Chilean possession in the Pacific, 2,350 miles off the coast of Chile.

Your editorial of Nov. 23 "Gains by the Negroes" represents another example of the unbiased, free and constructive editorial policy of THE TIMES, and therefore deserves the expressed appreciation of all who desire to see our country continuing to move steadily and peacefully toward the realization of those ideals reflected in our Constitution.
Engineers are in short supply, and many are being used in jobs that non-engineers could do as well.

Not only man's environment but man himself has been radically changed through medicine's impact on society, it was noted yesterday at the final session of the symposium on "Medicine and Society" at Mount Sinai Hospital, marking the end of a year-long observance of the 100th anniversary of the founding of the hospital.

If the strong nationalist undercurrent in the recent German local elections caused some alarm in Western Europe, it sent cold shivers down the spine of all those who today can speak freely for Germany's Eastern neighbors.

A responsive audience brings out the best in a performer, as everyone knows. This goes in the restaurant field as well as in that of the theatre arts -- a discriminating diner puts a chef on his mettle.
A panel of six high school students at THE NEW YORK TIMES Youth Forum, telecast over the DuMont Network from 6 to 7 P.M. yesterday, debated the question: "Who is the problem -- parent or child?"

In an attack on the McCarran-Walter Immigration Act, Secretary of Labor Maurice J. Tobin declared yesterday that the United States could absorb several hundred thousand immigrants each year without any detrimental effect on the nation's economy.
CHICAGO, Nov. 30 (UP) -- The New York Rangers, entrenched in the National Hockey League cellar, battled the first-place Chicago Hawks to a 1-1 tie tonight before 13,894 fans in the Chicago Stadium.

Last-minute efforts by Joseph P. Ryan, president of the International Longshoremen's Association, A. F. L., to form a united front of union leaders before the opening of the New York State Crime Commission public hearings into waterfront crime blew up over the weekend as dissension and distrust spread within the union.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- Corporations complaining that the Federal excess profits tax has worked unintended hardships against them would get an avenue for relief under terms of a bill to be introduced in the new Congress.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 30 -- The bitter-end fight for the presidency of the Congress of Industrial Organizations got hotter tonight as 700 union delegates poured into this seaside resort for the opening of their fourteenth annual convention tomorrow.

Harry Fuchs, a talented and serious young pianist, gave his first New York recital last night at Town Hall. His ambitious program included Beethoven's "Hammerklavier" Sonata, Chopin's E major Scherzo and four new piano pieces by Marion Bauer.

IT just didn't seem to make sense or add up properly. Navy dominated the game and yet Army contrived somehow to hold the midshipmen to a 7-0 victory. The muscular mariners made seventen first-downs to four and gained 323 yards to a mere 106. They set up a practically permanent advance post deep in cadet territory and the West Pointers never seriously threatened.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 30 -- Steel output last week was estimated at 106.5 per cent, down one-half point from the week before. Enough evidence has piled up to indicate that November production will have made a new record for that month. A preliminary check on the trend of steel output makes it almost a foregone conclusion that a new high record will be established for the month of December.

Tomorrow afternoon, at 4:25 Eastern standard time, will mark the end of the first decade of the atomic age and the beginning of the second. The event will be commemorated at the "birthplace" on the squash court underneath the west stands of Stagg Field, on the University of Chicago campus, where, amid the greatest wartime secrecy, the first atomic fire on earth was lighted on the afternoon of Dec. 2, 1942.

MEXICO CITY, Nov. 30 -- Vice President-elect Richard M. Nixon arrived tonight, bringing a personal invitation from Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower for a meeting with the new Mexican President, Adolfo Ruiz Cortines.
TOKYO, Monday, Dec. 1 -- Rain and low lying clouds slowed fighting in Korea yesterday and grounded all except a few United Nations planes.

E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., confirmed over the week-end that 12 denier monofilament nylon yarn may be available for the hoseiry trade early next year. If such yarn is released for production purposes, women's hosiery will be somewhat sheerer than those made out of 15 denier yarn, which is in wide use throughout the industry.

KRASIC, Yugoslavia, Nov. 30 (UP) -- Archbishop Aloysius Stepinac said today he would not go to Rome to receive his red hat as a newly appointed Cardinal because he would ask no favors of the Yugoslav Communist regime.
SANCHI, India, Nov. 30 -- More than 100,000 persons witnessed today the reinstallation of ancient relics venerated as those of Buddha's two disciples in a new monastery on a hilltop in this village.
Jackie Robinson, the Dodgers' Negro second baseman, yesterday charged the New York Yankees organization with being prejudiced against members of his race.

ALBANY, Nov. 30 -- The cancer mortality rate for women declined 13 per cent in the last twenty years, but increased 18 per cent among men, according to an upstate survey. Dr. Herman E. Hilleboe, State Health Commissioner reporting this today, said the figures showed that the cancer death rate among women past their fifteenth years was 7 to 24 per cent lower in 1948-50 than in 1931-33.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (UP) -- Cleveland's powerful Browns spotted the Washington Redskins two touchdowns in the first five minutes today and then stormed back on Otto Graham's passes for a 48-24 victory and undisputed first place in the American Conference of the National Football League.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 30 -- Following are excerpts from the opinion, made public tonight, of the three jurists recently asked by Secretary General Trygve Lie of the United Nations to advise him on certain questions with regard to staff members of United States nationality:

Martha Lipton, the Metropolitan mezzo-soprano, was heard in a recital yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. In a carefuly planned program featuring such seldom presented offerings as the solo cantata, "Cleopatre" of Berlioz, and excerpts from Alban Berg's "Seven Early Songs," the comely artist impressed by the seriousness, musicality and sensitivity of her work.

British sterling and the Canadian dollar vied with one another last week as new highs for this movement were marked up in each. Markets were extremely active and notwithstanding what might be termed lack of leadership on the part of this center last Thursday when we were closed down for the Thanksgiving Day holiday, firm markets were maintained in London and the cities of the Dominion.

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public, which will mature within twelve months, amount to $56,427,860,434. They consist of Treasury bonds, certificates of indebtedness, bills and notes as follows:

The glittering baubles and tinsel that, in the form of tree and house decorations, contribute to the gaiety of Christmas are now on view in many stores, some of which have special shops devoted to such wares.

FONTAINEBLEAU, France, Nov. 30 (UP) -- A framework has been set up and tested for backing tactical fighter units in Europe with the striking power of the United States Strategic Air Command, Lieut. Gen. Lauris A. Norstad said today.

MIAMI, Fla., Nov. 30 -- The winter session of the twenty-sixth annual National Contract Bridge Championships opened today here at the Sea Isle Hotel against a background of brilliant sunshine and warm tropical breezes.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Nov. 30 -- As baseball men from all sectors of the nation converged upon this bustling desert metropolis for their annual major and minor league conclaves today, it remained for the Giants and Yankees to move into the spotlight.

In opening the Commonwealth Conference, now in session in London, Winston Churchill declared that the main difference between this and previous gatherings was that the assembled Prime Ministers were about to start on a planning discussion, not a crisis meeting. The distinction is arresting and important.
The Commonwealth Fund in the fiscal year ended June 30, 1952, appropriated $2,719,737, of which nearly $2,000,000 went for medical education, experimental health services and medical research.

It was the day after Thanksgiving. Bill Wild, head baker at the Mount Hermon School, was being followed by a group of students. He wasn't surprised. He was pushing a cart through West Hall, and on it were forty-four pies.
TOKYO, Monday, Dec. 1 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,450, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Monday, Korea time:

CARACAS, Venezuela, Monday, Dec. 1 -- Unofficial returns with about 8 per cent of the vote tabulated gave the leftist Opposition party, U. R. D., or Nationalist Democratic Union for a Republic, a lead in yesterday's national election in Venezuela.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (UP) -Most state directors of the Selective Service System agreed today that they probably would have to start drafting 19-year-old youths by March or soon afterward to meet military manpower quotas.
BUFFALO, Nov. 30 -- Fred Wilt, former F. B. I. man running for the New York Athletic Club, regained the National senior A. A. U. 10,000-meter cross-country championship today.

LONDON, Nov. 30 -- Increased confidence recently displayed in the stock markets was fully maintained last week and was accompanied by an expansion in business. Anything approaching real activity has been confined, however, to foreign bonds, where a large turnover in Japanese bonds has been followed by the formal announcement of the terms of the debt settlement.

Thanks to THE TIMES for its valuable report and subsequent editorial on the activities of United States Information Service and on the effectiveness of our overseas information program. Most Americans know vaguely of the existence of the Voice of America but are sadly uninformed on the other aspects of the program.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- The American Red Cross and its 3,727 chapters spent $103,605,782 in the fiscal year that ended June 30, this year, E. Roland Harriman, the national president, reported today.

The pairings for the first annual holiday basketball carnival at Madison Square Garden on Dec. 27, 29 and 30 were released yesterday by Asa S. Bushnell, chairman of the Metropolitan Intercollegiate Basketball Committee.
Five of the new Mariner class of high speed, national defense cargo vessels have received their "greetings" and are to be drafted for military service.

If history is proof that "man finds in tragic situations his profoundest insights into the Divine," Christians need not fear the prospect of finding God in a wilderness, the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick declared in a sermon yesterday morning at Riverside Church.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 25 -- The army of Communist but anti-Stalinist Yugoslavia is something of a paradox in the military equation of Europe.

MOSCOW, Nov. 30 -- The newspaper Izvestia today declared that THE NEW YORK TIMES survey of the Voice of America programs in various countries had revealed that the State Department's propaganda effort was an "unprofitable enterprise."

There is no need to dwell upon the technical capacities of the violinist Tossy Spivakovsky, who gave a recital last night in Carnegie Hall. Mr. Spivakovsky's capacity to execute the most complicated passages can be taken for granted, whether or not one agrees with his particular bowing and phrasing, which are unorthodox and for which he is famous.

The Metropolitan Opera's fifth week of the season will feature the first "Die Meistersinger" of 1952-53 and the performance of "Carmen" that will be telecast on a closed circuit to theatre screens from coast to coast.

SCARSDALE, N. Y., Nov. 30 -- One ring star, Peg's Pride, and a newcomer, a 4-year-old hunter named Mr. O'Malley, shared the championship spotlight as the Boulder Brook Club's twenty-eighth annual fall horse show ended tonight.

HOLLYWOOD BEACH, Fla., Nov. 30 -- The year now ending has been a record-breaking period so far as the issuance of state and municipal bonds is concerned and such public borrowing will probably be even heavier in 1953, the convention of the Investment Bankers Association of America was told here today.

A program of chamber works new to New York was played Saturday evening at the Lexington Avenue Y. M. H. A., the first of four concerts sponsored jointly by the "Y" and the Bennington Composers Conference. It was an outgrowth of the seventh annual summer session held a few months ago at Bennington College.
DETROIT, Nov. 30 (UP) -- Gordie Howe scored two goals tonight as the Detroit Red Wings defeated the Toronto Maple Leafs, 4 -- 1, to gain sole possession of second place in the National Hockey League.

The former Sunset Theatre, an old motion picture house at 4705-09 Fifth Avenue, Brooklyn, has been sold by Catherine R. Caragol of Caldwell, N, J., to the J. S. Gould Son's Company, which plans to convert it into a supermarket for occupancy under long lease by Dilbert Bros., Inc., a food chain.

LONDON, Nov. 30 -- The presence in London of seven of the British Commonwealth Prime Ministers, attending one of their occasional conferences, has led to a revival of proposals for some permanent organization for Commonwealth consultation.

Greenwich Village still has many of the neighborly aspects of a small town, and the activities of the Village Art Center are a good example of this friendliness. Many artists who owe their start to this non-profit organization will join in sending good wishes on the occasion of the center's tenth birthday.

The city is beginning to collect some liquid dividends, after all these years, from the millions of dollars it has been investing in the new "Delaware project" reservoirs it has been building since 1931 in the Catskill Mountains. The new 50,000,000,000-gallon Rondout Reservoir is virtually finished and is filling.

To aid distressed persons of all races, creeds and national origins the Brooklyn Bureau of Social Service and Children's Aid Society, one of the nation's oldest community services, must raise from its friends and well-wishers $245,000 to complete the coverage of its anticipated expenditures of $1,032,319.

ROCKY MOUNT, N. C., Nov. 30 (AP) -- A Baptist minister ripped a page out of the Revised Standard Version of the King James Bible tonight and burned it as his congregation looked on outside the church.

Cotton prices held rather firm in early dealings last week, but turned easier in subsequent sessions to close the period with irregular net changes. At the close of trading on Friday on the New York Cotton Exchange active futures were 27 points higher to 19 lower than in the week previous.

The popular conception of death is not realistic and is therefore not in accord with the Christian tradition, the Rev. Dr. James A. Pike, Dean of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, declared yesterday at Trinity Protestant Episcopal Church, Broadway at Wall Street.
Trading on the New York Stock Exchange in November expanded to the largest volume of any month since last January, and exceeded the total for the corresponding month last year by 4,562,401 shares.

Darifresh, Inc., sold the warehouse at 5 Worth Street through Philip J. Miller, broker, to the Cadish Realty Corporation, which insured title with the Title Guarantee and Trust Company. The buyer is an investor.

CHICAGO, Nov. 30 (UP) -- Ollie Matson returned a kick-off 79 yards for one touchdown and crashed 13 yards around end for another today as the Chicago Cardinals broke a five-game losing streak with a 28-to-22 triumph over the Philadelphia Eagles before 13,577 fans.

The Long Island State Park Commission will take over today the former country estate of the late W. Bayard Cutting at Great River, L. I., and begin its development as a public "oasis of beauty and quiet." The property, which consists of 643 acres, a manor house built in 1887 and several minor buildings, is on an inlet in the Great South Bay, near Heckscher State Park, about fifty miles from New York City.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (AP) -- Lewis K. Gough, American Legion national commander said tonight that he believed the United Nations should fix a deadline on the Korean truce talks and then prepare to launch an offensive that would achieve "victory and peace with honor and punishment for the aggressor" if the Allies' minimum terms were not accepted by the Communist foe.

" Romulo: Voice of Freedom," a new work by Cornelia Spencer, has been scheduled for Jan. 16 publication by John Day. It is an informal biography of Gen. Carlos P. Romulo which follows the Filipino statesman's life from his early days as a student in America to his election as President of the United Nations General Assembly.

A week-end switch presented a new program line-up for the New York Philharmonic-Symphony in Carnegie Hall. Louis Krasner was soloist yesterday afternoon and Saturday night in the late Arnold Schoenberg's Violin Concerto, while Dimitri Mitropoulos conducted the orchestra in Wagner's "Tannhaeuser" Overture, Boccherini's delicious little Symphony in A and the popular "Galanta" Dances by Kodaly.

The Renegotiation Act of 1951 was denounced as a peacetime measure yesterday by the National Industrial Conference Board. A statement called it a "guessing game" in which the executives of 176 companies surveyed say they do not yet know how they stand, profit-wise, on their government contracts and orders for 1951.
Four new films, including an Italian importation, are slated to arrive in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:

A New York artist-war correspondent whose pint of blood was used on a badly wounded Brooklyn infantryman in Korea two years ago is trying to arrange a reunion, with the help of the New York Chapter of the Red Cross, with the boy whose life his blood helped to save.

Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the President-elect, designated Winthrop W. Aldrich yesterday to be the new Ambassador to Great Britain, and established a special committee headed by Nelson A. Rockefeller to survey the possibilities of streamlining the Executive Branch of the Federal Government.

Your editorial entitled "Soviet Corruption" was very much to the point, but there is something one must bear in mind. In Soviet Russia -- and to a lesser extent in the Iron Curtain countries -- crime is endemic. The Soviet man must use his wits if he wants to stay alive.

In naming Winthrop W. Aldrich to succeed Walter Gifford as Ambassador to Great Britain President-elect Eisenhower has selected a solid citizen who has been successful as a lawyer and banker and has given a great part of his time to unpaid services in good causes. The son of the late Senator Nelson W. Aldrich of Rhode Island, Republican leader and spokesman for the high tariff, the new Ambassador-designate had a fortunate start in life.

Behold now the shopper with his list, going from store to store, from counter to counter in search of gifts to match the names on the bit of paper held tight in his hand. Now, today, this bit of paper will be neat and unwrinkled, bearing no hastily scratched second thoughts.
The Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, at Fifty-fifth Street, commemorated its 100th year on the avenue yesterday. The Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell, the pastor, conducted the service.

Despite the high prestige of the teaching profession, parents seldom encourage their sons to enter teaching, probably because of the low pay, according to a study of teachers' salaries in Brookline, Mass., made public yesterday by the Institute of Field Studies of Teachers College, Columbia University.
A theory that the construction industry's ups and downs indicate what the entire economy will do is scored in a study released for publication today by the Committee for Economic Development.

GENEVA, Nov. 30 -- Economic activity in Western Europe continued into the second quarter of 1952 the decline that began in the first quarter, the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe reported toady.

With the inauguration of Adolfo Ruiz Cortines as President of Mexico, in ceremonies which start today, Mexico is going to have her third civilian chief executive. In fact, the first -- Emilio Portes Gil -- only served for six months, and one can really say that the six-year term of Miguel Aleman, which has just ended, was the first time in Mexico's stormy history that civilian rule was consolidated.

SAARBRUECKEN, the Saar, Monday, Dec. 1 -- The Saar territory in an election yesterday gave what was regarded as a decisive vote in favor of retaining its present status and against rejoining Germany by becoming a part of the Bonn republic.
WESTPORT, Conn., Nov. 30 -- Victor W. von Hagen, explorer and author, and his wife, Silvia, will leave New York Friday on a two-year exploration of the ancient Inca highway system in South America.
Paul Williams, who reported Saturday's football game between Notre Dame and the University of Southern California, obviously faces prompt expulsion from the Sports Broadcasters Association.

In fact, the first -- Emilio Portes Gil -- only served for six months, and one can really say that the six-year term of Miguel Aleman, which has just ended, was the first time in Mexico's stormy history that civilian rule was consolidated.

" Star of Bethlehem," the Christmas show at the Hayden Planetarium, Eighty-first Street and Central Park West, begins today. In the opening feature, a giant lollipop tree fills the seventy-five foot dome with a burst of color. Then Santa Claus brings to life the toys at the base of the tree and they dance around it.

Mrs. Laurance S. Rockefeller will be general chairman of American observance of the world-wide celebration of the centennial of the Young Women's Christian Association in 1955, it was announced today.

A project started in mid-October at Temple University, Philadelphia, under the direction of the university's head, Dr. Robert L. Johnson, may have a significant impact on the Eisenhower Administration. What Dr. Johnson did was to assemble "specialists in various major fields of government" to prepare research reports on which improvements in the Federal Executive Branch might be based.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 30 -- It was a great play. Tom Landry fired a pass to Bill Stribling, who flipped a lateral to Joe Scott, who returned the ball to Stribling, who went over for a touchdown. It covered seventy yards, and Ray Poole place-kicked the extra point.

The ancient ceremonial splendor of Christian Byzantium was reflected yesterday in St. Mary's Greek Catholic Church, 225 East Thirteenth Street, where the Most Rev. Daniel Ivancho, Exarchate of Pittsburgh, pontificated at the rededication of the forty-year-old building after its renovation.

A recent announcement by the Federal Bureau of Investigation states that automobiles valued at more than $190,000,000 were stolen last year in the United States. The magnitude of this type of crime poses a major problem for federal and local law enforcement agencies. The success of their efforts will depend, in large measure, upon the degree of cooperation these agencies receive from the public.

Five hundred persons attended yesterday a luncheon in the Plaza Hotel for Dr. Maurice J. Lewi, president of the Long Island University College of Podiatry, who will celebrate today his ninety-fifth birthday. Dr. Lewi is the oldest college president in the United States.

LONDON, Nov. 30 -- Prime Minister Winston Churchill celebrated his seventy-eighth birthday today with his family at 10 Downing Street. A constant stream of telegraphed and written congratulations arrived at the Prime Minister's official residence.

The week-end brought the announcement of one of the most important mergers recently made in the advertising agency field. Effective on Jan. 1, J. D. Tarcher Co., Inc., will merge with Cecil Presbrey, Inc. Jack D. Tarcher, president of the former, will not only bring to Cecil Presbrey the bulk of his creative staff but a group of accounts that will put Cecil Presbrey's annual billing in the $20,000,000 category.
PARIS, Nov. 30 -- Trade between France and the dollar zone has declined compared with 1951, according to indications given here today by the the Ministry of Economic Affairs.

The United States Navigation Company, Inc., at 17 Battery Place, is agent for half a dozen foreign-flag lines in addition to its own American-flag steamship service. The resultant linguistic mixture causes little or no difficulty for the company's personnel, however.

Most New York commodity markets reported light activity yesterday with futures generally higher. Cocoa, wool, hides, lead and vegetable oils closed higher, while coffee and rubber futures were lower. Sugar, potatoes and zinc closed mixed and tin was unchanged with no sales.

CHICAGO, Dec. 1 -- A suggestion that Herbert Brownell Jr., Attorney General-designate, might call off the Government's du Pont anti-trust action was made before Federal District Judge Walter J. La Buy today as trial of the suit was continued to Jan. 5.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 1 -- Bristol-Myers Company filed suit in Federal District Court here on Saturday against Schwegmann Brothers, giant super market, asking that an injunction be issued restraining the market from selling Bristol Myer products at lower than fair-trade prices.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 1 -- Following is the text of India's revised resolution on Korea, with the separate vote on each paragraph, as approved today by the United Nations General Assembly's Political and Security Committee:

Two medical schools in this city have expressed "real interest" in starting state-aided clinics on alcoholism, which might require $30,000 each in annual state appropriations, a report submitted to the committee on alcoholism of the Welfare and Health Council of New York City said yesterday.

Powder-actuated fastening tools were authorized for the first time on all electrical jobs in this area under a voluntary decision announced yesterday by the Joint Industry Board of the Electrical Industry, comprised of union leaders and contractors.

The role of atomic power in furthering the expansion of this country's economy will be discussed this week at the fifty-seventh annual Congress of American Industry. The congress, under the sponsorship of the National Association of Manufacturers, will open tomorrow at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel and will continue through Friday.

A number of important advances in engineering were put on display in the twentieth biennial National Exposition of Power and Mechanical Engineering, which began a six-day run yesterday at Grand Central Palace.

HOLLYWOOD BEACH, Fla., Dec. 1 -- The nation's investment specialists were told in convention session here today that "there are signs that our country is on the threshold of a new diplomacy, a more realistic policy, a new approach to the problems of the free world."

Food Fair Stores, Inc., which operates a chain of 156 units extending from New York to Florida, achieved the highest sales and operating profits in its history during the twenty-eight weeks ended last Nov. 8, according to the report issued yesterday by George Friedland, president.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- Department store sales by Federal Reserve Districts, as reported by the Federal Reserve Board, and percentage comparisons with a year ago, for the latest week, are given today. The figures, usually printed on Sunday, were delayed because of the Thanksgiving holiday.

ORANGE, N. J., Dec. 1 -- New York University's quintet cagers outscored an undermanned Newark-Rutgers team by 18 points in the second quarter and then went on to tally an easy 81-49 victory over the Bombers at the Orange Armory tonight.

Election of Gordon R. Ball as president of the Bank of Montreal and appointment of Arthur C. Jensen to succeed him as general manager were announced yesterday following the bank's 135th annual meeting in Montreal by B. C. Gardner, president since 1948. Mr. Gardner was elected chairman of the board and of the executive committee.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- John Foster Dulles, who will succeed Dean Acheson as Secretary of State, will make a serious effort to restore the bipartisan American foreign policy.

The Fellowship Committee of the Reid Foundation announced yesterday that $5,000 fellowship grants have been won by each of four newspaper men and two newspaper women. The committee said the selections were made on the basis of the winners' newspaper ability and their choice of study projects.
Twenty-three women took the law into their own hands yesterday when Police Commissioner George P. Monaghan appointed them members of the Police Department.

Virtually unknown to the public but described as an excellent administrator, Martin P. Durkin, designated yesterday by Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower to be Secretary of Labor, is a registered Democrat who not only voted for Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson but urged the members of his union to support the Democratic candidate.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Dec. 1 -- Major league baseball's annual player draft which today officially launched the week-long winter meetings, opened with a flourish and with Commissioner Ford C. Frick presiding. In exactly 22 minutes it took its place in history as another dud.

Hard on the heels of the revelations about the sorry state of Czechoslovakia's economy given at the Slansky trial comes similar news from Hungary. According to Hungarian Deputy Premier Ernoe Geroe, the coal, iron, steel and building industries are so far below their planned targets that the country's five-year plan is endangered.

Television has not cut into the reading of magazines as drastically as many believe, nor are all publications affected to the same extent. This is contended by Ray Robinson, research director for the Crowell-Collier Publishing Company, who offered the results of a special survey to prove his contention yesterday.

Al (Dusty) De Stefano, St. John's University coach, doesn't anticipate a miracle from his basketball team this season. Mindful of the fact that there are nine lettermen available from the 1951-52 outfit that had a 25-5 slate, Dusty feels the Redmen will have to prove themselves against the rugged competition booked for the Brooklynites.

OTTAWA, Dec. 1 -- Reports published in a Canadian morning newspaper today that United States Air Force jet planes were ignoring the Canadian border and "investigating" planes flying over Canadian territory brought an explanation in Parliament by Brooke Claxton, Defense Minister, of how the Mutual Defense Agreement works.

Measured by Old World standards Columbia University is just getting the ivy well started. It will, nevertheless, be celebrating its 200th anniversary in 1954, and has won an honored place in the roll of institutions of learning that have fought for and defended "Man's right to knowledge and the free use thereof" -- theme of the bicentennial celebration set by President Eisenhower in May, 1950.

Twenty private bus companies that have been transporting school children at a ten-cent fare without city or state authority for the last twenty years were enjoined yesterday from further operation by Supreme Court Justice Maximilian Moss in Brooklyn.

The Secretary of Defense, Robert A. Lovett, whose urbane sardonicism and practice of cocking a suspicious eye at just about everything are legend in the fabulous Pentagon, has assembled a few notes on "Initialese."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- The special House committee to investigate campaign expenditures is now engaged in trying to find the formula for another legal experiment, "noble in purpose," as was said of the national prohibition law, and probably as impossible to draft or enforce without further downward revision of the constitutional rights of American citizens.

NEWARK, Dec. 1 -- A dinner tonight in the court of the Newark Museum, 49 Washington Street, marked the formal dedication of the Spitz Planetarium presented to the institution by Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Dreyfuss of Caldwell, N. J. Mr. Dreyfuss, who is State Civilian Defense Director, is president of the United Advertising Corporation of this city.

Two new assistant managing editors of THE NEW YORK TIMES were named yesterday by Turner Catledge, managing editor. Other executive changes on the news staff were announced at the same time, all to take effect today.
TRENTON, Dec. 1 -- A new Delaware River toll bridge between Trenton and Morrisville, Pa., designed to relieve traffic congestion in this growing industrial area, was opened at 2:25 P. M. today.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Dec. 1 -- Drivers for a trucking company who walked out to protest assignment of a tall driver to a small-cab truck returned to work today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (UP) -- Two Government officials said today that the Republicans would find all the records they needed to investigate the outgoing Administration when they took over the Government Jan. 20.

HACKENSACK, N. J., Dec. 1 -- Frank Erickson, former Eastern overlord of bookmaking and policy rackets, who recently completed a sixteen-month term in the Rikers Island Penitentiary in New York, began today a twelve-to-fourteen-month sentence growing out of his violation of the gambling statutes of New Jersey.

Production of shoes has been higher than consumption since August and, while business for the first quarter of 1953 is expected to be good, manufacturers face a slowdown in production during the spring, officials of the Popular Price Shoe Show of America said yesterday at the New Yorker Hotel.

The long-planned meeting between Military Sea Transportation Service officers and tramp ship operators, at which the latter will present their grievances against the Navy agency's chartering policy, will finally take place Monday in Washington.

GENEVA, Nov. 28 -- Europe is still letting immense quantities of energy run off into the sea -- too much for the good of its own economic future, the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe believes.

LONDON, Dec. 1 -- Weakness of Japanese bonds was the feature of an otherwise cheerful stock market here today. A wide range of domestic industrials improved a few pence and British Government securities were slightly higher.
SANTIAGO, Chile, Dec. 1 -- President Carlos Ibanez, faces his first real contest of wills with Congress in the near future over his request for power to legislate by decree in economic matters.

Sinclair Weeks, who has been named as the new Secretary of Commerce by Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, thePresident-elect, is chairman of the National Republican Finance Committee and has been a national committeeman since 1940.

CHICAGO, Dec. 1 -- New York City was fourth among the nation's five major urban centers in motor traffic fatalities in the first ten months of this year, according to an announcement here today by the National Safety Council.

Steel operations this week are scheduled at 105.5 per cent of the industry's theoretical capacity, a rate which would yield 2,191,000 net tons of raw steel, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. The same estimate had been given for last week, but last week's actual rate was 106.1 per cent and production was 2,203,000 tons.

The Rev. John Paul Jones in his letter to THE TIMES accuses Federal Judge Irving Kaufman, who presided at the trial of the Rosenbergs, of having made improper remarks in the court. He cites Judge Kaufman's remark "that the Rosenbergs bore a direct responsibility for Communist aggression in Korea."

NEW HAVEN, Dec. 1 -- A two-year survey to determine the extent of racial and religious prejudice in Protestant church literature has been started here by the Yale Divinity School, Dean Liston Pope announced here today. The project will be financed by a grant from the American Jewish Committee.

JERUSALEM, Dec. 1 (AP) -- Henry Morgenthau Jr. and three other Americans have offered to resign from a group handling Israeli bonds in the United States because of "lack of cooperation" by Israel, it was disclosed today. Prime Minister David Ben-Gurion refused to accept the resignations.

Animal experiments and tests on patients in advanced stages of cancer were described last night by leaders in medicine as lending "strong support" to a new concept of malignant disease that may lead to a radically new approach to its ultimate control.
ATLANTIC CITY, Dec. 1 -- The Congress of Industrial Organizations called upon the Truman Administration today to suspend all wage controls.

MEXICO CITY, Dec. 1 -- In his inaugural address, Mexico's new President, Adolfo Ruiz Cortines, promised today vigorous campaigns against corruption in government and profiteering in business as the keystones of his Administration.

LUXEMBOURG, Dec. 1 -- Differences over a French request to change the proposed membership of the Consultative Committee of the Schuman plan came to a boil at a meeting today of the Council of Ministers.

Rights will be offered today to stockholders of the Davison Chemical Corporation to subscribe for 106,666 additional shares of its $1 par value common stock at $34.50 a share, on the basis of one new share for each four held. The offering is being underwritten by an investment banking group headed by Alex.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 1 -- The first shipments of Argentina's long-awaited "big crop" have begun to pour into the nation's ports, and farmers and railmen are girding for the task of harvesting and transporting an expected 7,000,000 tons of wheat.

In the first ten months of this year five great new blast furnaces were blown in, two more were scheduled to start operations before the year-end and eleven more were under construction for completion in the first half of 1953, the American Iron and Steel Institute said yesterday.

LONDON, Dec. 1 -- Changes in the pattern of British life since the days before World War II are reflected in the latest issue of the official Annual Abstract of Statistics to be published here tomorrow.

Kate Cameron, motion picture critic of The Daily News, yesterday was elected vice chairman of the New York Film Critics at a meeting of the group held at the New York Newspaper Guild Clubhouse, 133 West Forty-fourth Street.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., Dec. 1 (AP) -- Tommy Harrison, 178, Los Angeles, moved up another step on the heavyweight boxing ladder tonight by taking a split decision over Wes Bascom, 176 1/2, St. Louis, in a ten-rounder at the Auditorium.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 1 -- Secretary General Trygve Lie announced today that he had dismissed fifty-nine United Nations employes upon recommendation of the Walters Selection Committee, which reviewed 400 cases in the professional category in its most recent study of staff positions.

Ray Robinson, world middleweight champion, has until Friday to advise the State Athletic Commission of his future ring plans, if any. At that time the Commission will make known its attitude toward the Harlemite, who is facing the prospect of having his title declared vacated unless he consents to a defense.

The merger of Spear Co. and Ludwig Baumann Co. was announced jointly yesterday by Albert M. Kahn, president of Spear's and Walter S. Baumann, head of Ludwig Baumann. The merger was effected through purchase of a majority interest in Ludwig Baumann by Spears from individual stockholders.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- Republicans in Congress reported today that they had far more patronage requests than they had patronage.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- The House of Representatives "watchdog" subcommittee announced today it would open hearings on Wednesday to determine if the Military Establishment was heeding orders to eliminate waste and duplication in its purchasing and supply systems.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 1 -- With the Soviet bloc standing alone, the Political and Security Committee of the United Nations General Assembly approved tonight a compromise Indian resolution on the repatriation of Korean prisoners of war. The vote was 53 to 5, with Nationalist China abstaining and Lebanon absent.

In a parliamentary election the people of the Saar have endorsed the present autonomous regime of that hotly contested region by a vote which under normal circumstances would be regarded as decisive. With an electoral turnout of 93 per cent they have cast 68 per cent of their votes for the Government parties which stand for the permanent detachment of the Saar from Germany and its economic union with France.

The United States comes close to being Public Enemy No. 1 in the Near East, but there is still time to regain the position it once held, Dr. Stephen B. L. Penrose Jr., president of the American University of Beirut in Lebanon, said yesterday. He spoke at the Park Lane Hotel at a reception opening a $10,000,000 campaign for the university.
Trading on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday was light, but prices were steady and closing quotations on active months were 12 to 25 points higher than on last Friday.

ALBANY, Dec. 1 -- Only about half of the state's 2,952 school boards have reported to the State Education Department on the loyalty of their employes, out all of those reporting have denied having any teachers charged with subversive activities or membership.
Gov. Theodore R. McKeldin of Maryland will be a speaker at the eleventh annual dinner of the Thoroughbred Racing Associations at the Plaza Hotel Thursday night, it was announced yesterday.
MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Dec. 1 -- National and international contract bridge experts gathered here today at the Sea Isle Hotel for the twenty-sixth annual National Contract Bridge Championships.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- Representative Clarence J. Brown of Ohio, prominent both in the Republican party and in Congress, recommended today the scrapping of all limitations on spending in a national political campaign and the substituting of a system of full disclosure of all expenditures.
POINT PLEASANT, N. J., Dec. 1 (AP) -- A Navy helicopter today staged a dramatic rescue of a man who had fallen inside a 160-foot high water tank and broken his neck.

Edward F. jkddis has been elected a vice president of A. D. Juillard Co., Inc., effective Jan. 1. Pie was formerly chairman of Susqueharma Mills, Inc. Kenneth B. Cook, president of the Rhode Island Textile Association, will become executive vice president, manufacturing and sales, for Susquehanna.

The International Confederation of Free Trade Unions, meeting yesterday at Freedom House, 20 West Fortieth Street, condemned the trials of ousted Communist leaders in Prague. The procedure was called "a clumsy maneuver to stir the passions of the reactionary elements in t he Arab world so as to rally them to the camp of Stalin."

THE football folks have been profoundly critical of the shift that Notre Dame uses in the vicinity of the enemy goal-line, a cute device which usually is worth five yards every time it is tried. Frank Leahy's Irish swing from their T-formation alignment to the old Rockne formation, the once famous Notre Dame box. They move before the ball is snapped and the overeager opposition promptly bulls through for an offside.
The National Collegiate Athletic Association television committee yesterday pinned a "worked satisfactorily" tag on its 1952 program of restricted college football television.

OMAHA, Neb., Dec. 1 -- Governors and other representatives of the ten Missouri River Valley states approved today a basin compact under which the states and the Federal Government would be equal partners in the land and water development projects in the 529,000-square-mile area.
LONDON, Dec. 1 (AP) -- Britain accused Russia tonight of nearly doubling the size and firepower of East Germany's armed forces within the last six months.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- The possibility that Dean Acheson, Secretary of State, and his designated successor, John Foster Dulles, might discuss next Wednesday the inclusion of Mr. Dulles in the United States delegation to the forthcoming meeting of the North Atlantic Council in Paris was raised at the State Department today.

The first city-wide "clean-up fix-up" drive arranged by municipal agencies in conjunction with local business men and civic organizations will be conducted here in the first two weeks of May. Should this campaign prove successful, it will become an annual event.
" It's a good thing that I am such a great defensive coach. Otherwise the score would have been 100 -- 7."

HARRIMAN, N. Y., Dec. 1 -- The answer to growing demands for medical care caused by an aging population and a corresponding increase in chronic diseases will not be found in the building of more institutions to provide such care, Miss Ruth W. Hubbard, general director of the Visiting Nurse Society of Philadelphia, said today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (AP) -- E. H. Eacker, president of Boston Consolidated Gas Company, told the Federal Power Commission today that without a supply of natural gas his concern and Old Colony Gas Company, with which it proposes to merge, would be unable to serve their customers.

Sam Silbey, manager of a temporary rental office of the Cunningham Heights Apartments in Hollis, Queens, was speaking on the telephone to his main office at 4:22 P. M. yesterday when two armed men walked into the three-room frame building at the corner of Hillside Avenue and Whitehall Terrace.
ATLANTIC CITY, Dec. 1 -- Walter P. Reuther, president of the United Automobile Workers, was assured tonight of election as president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 1 -- Before a special session of Congress today, President Juan Peron presented social measures to be adopted during Argentina's Second Five-Year Plan. After a quick reading of the proposals members of the Socialist, Radical and Conservative parties declared they assessed the plan as further evidence that the President was attempting to introduce more of Mussolini's policies into Argentina.

If Aetna Life Insurance Company stockholders approve at their meeting on Feb. 10 the concern will celebrate its hundredth anniversary with a 50 per cent stock dividend, the directors announced yesterday. The dividend would be payable March 2 to holders of record of Feb. 17.

MINEOLA, L. I., Dec. 1 -- A plan for the distribution to charity and other institutions of more than $2,680,000 of a trust fund was filed today with the Nassau County Surrogate's Court by trustees of the fund provided for under the will of Marguerite S. Davis, who died March 18, 1948.

Plans have been formulated by a large group of debutantes of recent seasons, including Miss Barbara Gile Lord and Mrs. Ludlow Fowler Jr., for the Post Debutante Tiara Ball, to be held on the night of Dec. 29 in the main ballroom of the Plaza for the benefit of the Spence-Chapin Adoption Service. Mrs. David A. Gimbel and Miss Jean Tanburn are co-chairmen of the executive committee.

Saturday night boxing bouts from various arenas around the country will be televised by the American Broadcasting Company network, beginning Jan. 24, at 9 P. M. TV rights will be bought from Famous Sports Enterprises, Inc., headed by Ray Arcel.
As the first 1950 draftees return from overseas, all of them, as veterans, enjoy the benefits of the new G. I. Bill of Rights.

Industrialist cooperation on the Schuman Plan, officially limited to a consultative basis, will take in "a close watch" of the effects of the coal-steel pooling on other branches of the associated nations' economies, it was said yesterday by Quinto Quintieri, new president of the Union of Industrial Federations of the Member Countries of the European Coal and Steel Community.

The variety of effects and uses to which things of the past lend themselves is pointed up in an exhibition of six rooms, each designed by a different decorator, that opened yesterday at Stair Co., 59 East Fifty-seventh Street. The exhibition, which runs through Saturday at $1 admission, is for the benefit of the Lighthouse, the New York Association for the Blind.
A strike of flight engineers employed by Eastern Air Lines, Inc., forced the line yesterday to ground its fleet of Constellations and Super-Constellations.

The fourth unit of the Mariner class of thirty-five large and speedy dry cargo ships, the Tar Heel Mariner, entered service when she began loading military supplies at the Brooklyn Army Base yesterday, it was announced here by the Maritime Administration.

Confidence continued fairly strong yesterday on the stock market although there were periods of hesitation which left final quotations in a highly mixed state. There was no reason for the list to crawl into such a scrambled position, except that switching operations in the wake of tax transactions prevented the charting of a set course.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 1 -- France, which has sought to avoid discussing the situation of the Arabs in Tunisia and Morocco in the Political Committee of the United Nations, took the occasion today to defend the French administration of the North African areas in connection with agrarian reform.
In a boutique fantasque, Lilly Dache has gathered together the razzle-dazzle that spells the spirit of luxurious Christmas giving. It opened yesterday morning in her East Fifty-sixth Street shop.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 1 -- Israeli Ambassador Abba S. Eban urged the United Nations today to call for direct and unfettered Arab-Israeli negotiations to end the Palestine dispute, and he offered as a basis a six-point "blueprint for peace."

CLEVELAND, Dec. 1 (AP) -- The executive news editor of a radio-television station said today that radio was doing a better job of news reporting than was television. That was because radio had newsmen with more experience in the critical spots, Paul W. White of KFMB AM-TV, San Diego, Calif., told the National Association of Radio News Directors at its convention here.

LAKE HARMONY, Pa., Dec. 1 -- A census unquestionably would reveal that there are more deer and more deer hunters per square mile in Pennsylvania than any other state in the union, and although no one can testify as to the number of deer in this area, the hunters certainly turned out for the opening day.

The skirl of bagpipes resounded last night through the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel as 1,200 members and guests of the St. Andrew's Society of the State of New York celebrated its 196th anniversary with the traditional piping of the haggis to mark St. Andrew's Day, which was Sunday.
The Newspaper Guild of New York announced last night that it had set a "strike deadline" for Friday at 8 A. M. in its stalemated contract negotiations with The Daily News.

Roland La Starza, Bronx heavyweight who is ranked fourth among contenders for the title, came back from a second round knockdown at the Eastern Parkway Arena in Brooklyn last night to outpoint Rocky Jones of Chester, Pa., in ten rounds.
TOKYO, Tuesday, Dec. 2 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,451, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Tuesday, Korean time:

BONN, Germany, Dec. 1 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer refused today to recognize as legitimate the results of yesterday's elections in the Saar because they were not a "free expression" of the will of the Saarlanders.
John van Druten's latest play, "I've Got Sixpence," co-starring Edmond O'Brien and Viveca Lindfors, opens tonight at the Barrymore Theatre. The curtain will rise at 8 o'clock.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Tuesday, Dec. 2 (AP) -- Vic Seixas, American Davis Cup captain, slammed his way into the semi-finals of the Victorian tennis championships today but his team-mate -- Ham Richardson -- was sent to the sidelines.

The Philharmonic-Symphony Society of New York has set aside a sum "up to $8,000" to present four concerts this season in New York high schools. Each will be in a different borough. The first will be given on Wednesday, Dec. 10, in the 1,500-seat auditorium of the Prospect Heights High School in Brooklyn.

LOS ANGELES, Dec 1 (UP) -- Numerous football coaches, headed by a visiting coach, Jordan Olivar of Yale, agreed today that Notre Dame's controversial shift violated the ethics of coaching if not the rules of the game.

BAGHDAD, Iraq, Dec. 1 -- The extent to which Iranian Communists are reaching over the frontier to further the world Communist movement's effort to break up the West's development of Middle Eastern oil resources has become a vital problem here.
JERSEY CITY, Dec. 1 -- Revisions in Jersey City's proposed business license ordinance, which comes before the City Commission for action tomorrow, were announced today by Mayor John V. Kenny.

While the police of the Tenth Division were rounding up nine persons suspected of policy operations at the rear of a candy store at 44 St. Nicholas Avenue yesterday, an armed man walked into the front of the shop and announced a hold-up. Within minutes he became the tenth prisoner.

" The Murder of Sir Thomas Overbury," a biographical analysis by William McElwee, will be issued by Oxford University Press on Thursday. Mr. McElwee follows the fortunes of four highly placed persons in the reign of King James I -- James, himself, Robert Carr, Sir Thomas and the Countess of Essex.
