High-level stability is expected to mark general business conditions through most of next year, with the possibility of a "quite mild setback" in the second half of the year.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 1 (AP) -- Baltimore will be in the National Football League again in 1953, it was learned here today.

I approve heartily what you say about the Mayor's Transit Plan in your issue of Nov. 21. You have exposed the fallacies behind this plan and apparently believe it will receive little consideration. I think it will take constant vigilance and exposure to keep this iniquitous plan in its proper place.

The International Press Institute has completed the preliminary steps of a comprehensive survey of the flow of foreign news, Lester Markel, chairman of the institute's executive board, announced yesterday. The survey will run through January and be completed next summer.

The New York City Mission Society will be the beneficiary of an exhibition "Treasures from Imperial Russia," comprising art masterpieces from the collection of Joseph E. Davies, former United States Ambassador to Russia, and Mrs. Davies of New York and Washington, which will open this evening at the Hammer Galleries, 51 East Fifty-seventh Street, and continue through Saturday.

THANKSGIVING morning, with the kitchen in a bustle and the extra leaves already in the dining room table, is no time to write a piece for this space. There are too many distractions. Will the young man of the family wake in time to drive to the village and get the newspaper without which not even a holiday is worth facing?

BOWIE, Md., Dec. 1 (AP) -- Tony DeSpirito had eight chances today to gain on the world mark for the greatest number of winners in a single season, but the 17-year-old New Englander brought home only one winner.

PARIS, Dec. 1 -- One of the most important items on the agenda for the North Atlantic Council's conference opening here Dec. 15 will be the determining of the fourth phase of its "infrastructure" program and the setting of its estimated cost.

Michigan State. the No. 1 college football team in the nation, will lose nineteen key players, including thirteen from the first two platoons, through graduation, Biggie Munn told the Football Writers Association yesterday at its luncheon-meeting at Toots Shor's.
BOSTON, Dec. 1 -- Sinclair Weeks said tonight that he hoped to create a "business climate" in the nation's economy as Secretary of Commerce.
The United Press board of coaches named unbeaten and untied Michigan State the 1952 mythical national college football champion yesterday by near-unanimous acclaim.
The new Cabinet that will take office with Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower on Jan. 20 stands as follows:

W. Walter Williams; Seattle banker and real estate dealer who headed the Citizens for Eisenhower organization in the recent campaign, once said he believed business men must be willing to challenge their own methods if they wanted a sound economy and political freedom.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- Michael V. DiSalle, first head of the Office of Price Stabilization, began a survey of the nation's economic controls today in his new temporary post as a special adviser to Roger L. Putnam, chief of the Economic Stabilization Agency.
HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Dec. 1 -- Hofstra College routed Roanoke's basketball team, 79 -- 57, tonight at Calkins gymnasium. The game was the season's first for both schools.
The American Jewish Congress filed a complaint yesterday with the New York State Commission Against Discrimination against two upstate resorts, accusing them of illegal discriminatory advertising.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- Representative Daniel A. Reed, Republican of New York, the prospective chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee in the next Congress, asserted today that he would introduce a bill on the opening day of the new session to reduce individual income taxes by 5 per cent in 1953 and a further 5 per cent in 1954.

A $30,000,000 issue of 1 7/8 per cent five-year second series bonds (Series A) was sold at par yesterday by the New Jersey Turnpike Authority to a group of institutional investors, banks and trust companies, according to Paul L. Troast, chairman of the authority. The issue, which is due on Jan. 1, 1958, may be called at any time on and after July 1, 1953. Smith, Barney Co. negotiated the transaction.
Christmas day will be a sparkling one for those who take their lead from the glitter and the gold currently displayed in stores.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- Mrs. Harry S. Truman welcomed Mrs. Dwight D. Eisenhower at the White House front door today with one of her heartiest handshakes, and both made pleasant comment while photographers took their picture.

Federated Department Stores Inc., had record sales in the fifty-two weeks ended last Nov. 1 and increased sales and earnings for the thirteen weeks ended on that date, according to the report released today.

PRINCETON, N. J., Dec. 1 -- The election of Homer A. Smith, 21-year-old junior from Omaha, Neb., as captain of Princeton University's 1953 football team was disclosed tonight at the twenty-third annual Princeton football dinner.

VAN NUYS, Calif., Dec. 1 (UP) -- Mrs. Mary Ann Huff, who carries on her daily duties although she is almost completely paralyzed, said today that the thing she wanted most was a portable chest respirator, "so I can go to the beach with the boys."

Success, if bestowed too early, can sometimes be fate's most unkind gift. Ruth Slenczynski, California pianist who was heard last night at Carnegie Hall, provides a demonstration. She scored so signally when she was 8 years old that her career has been clouded ever since.

LONDON, Dec. 1 -- The attention of the British Commonwealth Prime Ministers Conference was focused today on the fact that the sterling area countries spend hundreds of millions of dollars each year for essential commodities that they should be producing in greater quantities for themselves.

Filtrol Company of California plans to merge into the Filtrol Corporation, a Delaware organization, it was announced yesterday. The Delaware concern, which is engaged in the production of clay cracking catalysts and of absorbents and decolorizing agents, is 50 per cent owned by the Filtrol Company of California, 25 per cent by Atlantic Refining Company and 12 1/2 per cent each by F. Eberstadt Co., Inc., and Lazard Freres Co.

LONDON, Dec. 1 -- Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden told the House of Commons today that after his recent talks with the United States President-elect he felt sure Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's Administration would desire "to work closely" with the British Government.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Dec. 2 -- The Communists charged yesterday that United Nations planes had bombed a camp in North Korea where United Nations prisoners of the Korean war were interned, wounding three, two of them seriously.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Indo-China, Dec. 1 (AP) -- French officials said today the Communist-led Vietminh rebels had launched a violent political campaign agianst the 500,000 Roman Catholics living in territories held by Vietminh troops in northern Indo-China.

BOSTON, Dec. 1-- The council of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences called today for "drastic modification" of the McCarran-Walter Immigration and Naturalization Act of 1952 and the McCarran Internal Security Act of 1950.

Hamlet as a Frenchman still has enormous vitality. That was proved again last night when the wonderful Renaud-Barrault company gave us the tragedy in Andre Gide's translation. It was Shakespeare the dramatist, shorn of his "verbal music," of the poetry that gives him his especially exalted rank.

November sales of department stores in this city showed a decline of 9 per cent, according to a survey made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES. The figure covers the volume of twelve stores against the same number a year ago and does not include on a comparative basis the sales of Frederick Loeser Co., which closed early this year.

CHICAGO, Dec. 1 -- Grain and soybean futures showed a decidedly strong tone today, following heavy initial selling which was due principally to the big deliveries on December contracts. In wheat, buying was stimulated by export sales of nearly 5,000,000 bushels of hard winter wheat to Italy for January shipment, and in corn buying was active because of the strength in the cash market.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- Average primary market prices declined 0.2 per cent over the week ended on Nov. 25, to 110.1 per cent of the 1947-49 average, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

CIDADE DE GOA, Portuguese India, Dec. 1 -- Festivities for the last exposition of the body of St. Francis Xavier, the "Apostle of the Indies," who died 400 years ago tomorrow, began this afternoon in a pageant of ecclesiastical and temporal glory with the arrival in this tiny Portuguese settlement of Emanuel Cardinal Gonsalves Cerejeira. He is Patriarch of Lisbon and papal legate representing Pope Pius at the historic ceremony.
Your recent editorial on the so-called "reparations" agreement between West Germany and Israel raises three questions in my mind:
The only central coordinating committee for activities on behalf of the children and youth of this country has decided to go out of business because of lack of funds.

The quiet, honest way of serving music rather than high-pressure self-promotion has its virtues, as the short history of the Musicians' Guild will show. Starting its seventh season at Town Hall last night, this group of musicians, functioning like a cooperative, seems to have established a substantial audience of its own.

WASHINGTON, Dec 1. (AP) -- Government investigators have turned up evidence indicating a Canadian company agreed to pay Paul G. Griffith, former Assistant Secretary of Defense, and an associate more than $800,000 to promote a contract with the United States Government, Jess Larson, head of the General Services Administration, asserted today. His agency conducted the investigation.

The 500 children of Public School 69, at 125 West Fifty-fourth Street, marched out of the building like West Pointers yesterday morning when the fire alarm clanged. They experienced unexpected pleasures offered by the fire drill that their teacher in charge had devised.

The New York correspondent of one of London's most prominent dailies has reported that your American newspapers have been giving a great deal of space to reports of friction between American servicemen and civilians in England.

A Senate internal security subcommittee called yesterday for the summary dismissal of Frank Coe as secretary of the International Monetary Fund after he had refused to tell whether he ever had been or was at present engaged in espionage against the United States.

SAARBRUECKEN, the Saar, Dec. 1 -- Commenting today on yesterday's Saar election in which 68 per cent of those voting approved the present autonomous status, Gilbert Grandval, French Ambassador here, said the French and Saar Governments must now go to work to apply the French proposals for greater autonomy and "to try to find a solution in accord with Germany."

When President Truman and President-elect Eisenhower met recently some constraint was evident. Mrs. Eisenhower's visit to Mrs. Truman at the White House yesterday was a pleasanter occasion. Each of these two estimable ladies perhaps had a certain sympathy for the other, for each understood the ordeal of being married to a man very much in the public eye.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 1 -- Eleven young women from metropolitan New York were among sixty presented tonight at the Bachelors Cotillon or first Monday German in the Lyric Theatre. The annual event, first held in 1796, rivals the St. Cecilia's Ball of Charleston, S. C., as the country's oldest debutante party.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (AP) -- The Federal Reserve Board estimated today that industrial production rose to a post-war high in October and climbed higher in November.

NYERI, Kenya, Dec. 1 -- The authorities here have returned to their owners about half the cattle, sheep and goats that were seized from the Thigonge location in Kenya Nov. 10 partly as a punishment for the murder of Chief Nderi, partly in the hope of attracting information.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- The Pennsylvania Railroad told the Interstate Commerce Commission today that its stake in the bankrupt Long Island Rail Road now was $112,000,000 and insisted that the line could be operated as a self-supporting private enterprise with increased fares and tax relief.

A charge that New York lost $500,000 because of "loose, wasteful and fraudulent practices" in coal contracts negotiated by the Board of Transportation during Mayor William O'Dwyer's administration was made yesterday by a New York County grand jury.

Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the President-elect, completed his nine-member Cabinet yesterday by designating Sinclair Weeks of Boston to serve as Secretary of Commerce and Martin P. Durkin of Chicago to be the new Secretary of Labor.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- A special House Committee looking into complaints that there are too many cheap-edition stories of sex and crime on newsstands heard a publisher today cite the classics of literature as a precedent.

Confusion and uneasiness haunted the Port of New York's 700-odd miles of waterfront yesterday as the New York State Crime Commission completed preparations for the opening tomorrow of its public hearings into shoreside crime.
Censorship, beginning yesterday morning, curtailed official news of the first election held in Venezuela in four years.

Air Cargo Day was celebrated yesterday at the Statler Hotel at the opening of the five-day annual meeting of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers. Hundreds of civilian and military technicians from many parts of the United States and several foreign countries discussed air transportation of freight, generally predicting a steady increase in volume.

PUSAN, Korea, Nov. 24 -- Since the beginning of the Korean war the United Nations Command has been plagued by guerrillas. At times the raiders have become such a problem that mere mention of "guerrillas" in press dispatches has been deleted by censors.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- Approval of a wage increase of $1.90 a day for coal miners is expected from the White House tomorrow, or Wednesday at the latest.

Ten years ago today a momentous event occurred in the stands of Stagg Field on the campus of the University of Chicago. In the presence of forty-odd associates Dr. Enrico Fermi withdrew a cadmium-plated control rod from an experimental "pile" constructed of uranium and graphite.

HONOLULU, Dec. 1 -- Five hundred members of the International Longshoremen and Warehousemen's Union still refused to return to work at the Castle Cooke terminals on the waterfront here today despite a Circuit Court order restraining them from continuing their work stoppage.

Circuit Court Judge Harold R. Medina yesterday heard proposals aimed at eliminating the need for the defendants in the trial of seventeen investment banking firms to defend themselves against the Government charges.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Dec. 1 -- Experts from Pakistan, India and the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development opened talks here today in an effort to settle the long-drawn-out dispute between the two countries on water rights. With the issues of Kashmir and of refugees, this is a main obstacle in relations between the two countries.

Representative Harold H. Velde, Republican of Illinois, who is slated to become chairman of the House Committee on Un-American Activities, has asked Federal Judge Irving R. Kaufman, who presided at the trial of Julius and Ethel Rosenberg, to stay the execution of the convicted atom bomb spies.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 1 -- The Screen Actors Guild, A. F. L., began a general strike today against the producers of filmed television advertising matter by honoring a request from two major Hollywood producing sources, the Alliance of Television Film Producers and the Hal Roach group, to open contract negotiations.

Representative Harold H. Velde, Republican of Illinois, who is slated to become chairman of the House Committee on Un-American Activities, has asked Federal Judge Irving R. Kaufman, who presided at the trial of Julius and Ethel Rosenberg, to stay the execution of the convicted atom bomb spies.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 1 -- The Screen Actors Guild, A. F. L., began a general strike today against the producers of filmed television advertising matter by honoring a request from two major Hollywood producing sources, the Alliance of Television Film Producers and the Hal Roach group, to open contract negotiations.

Kings County Judge Samuel S. Leibowitz called yesterday for a "reappraisal" of the methods of dealing with juvenile delinquents as he sentenced two teen-agers to long prison terms in a Brooklyn murder.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 2 -- The Bell Telephone Company of Pennsylvania was granted today an annual intrastate rate increase of $21,227,000 by the Pennsylvania Public Utility Commission.

CHICAGO, Dec. 2 -- David L. Behncke, founder and former president of the Air Line Pilots Association, A. F. L., and the union's present leadership compromised today differences that had been before Federal and county courts.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- James P. McGranery, Attorney General, said today that he had directed a Federal grand jury investigation be started Thursday into charges that Prof. Owen Lattimore of Johns Hopkins University committed perjury before a Senate subcommittee.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- The cease-fire negotiated between Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower and Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio at Columbia University on Morningside Heights last Sept. 12 ended today when the Senator blasted the General for inviting Martin P. Durkin, a Democratic labor union official, to be his Secretary of Labor.
R. H. Macy Co., Inc., improved its sales and earnings for the quarter ended on Nov. 1, according to the consolidated report issued yesterday by Jack I. Straus, president.

Three officers of the Colin Pharmacal Company, Inc., of 36-31 Thirty-third Street, Long Island City, Queens, announced yesterday that they would cooperate with the state's efforts to obtain a court dissolution of the corporation.

T. Morgan Williams, chairman of the New York Regional Blood Program, reported yesterday that on Monday blood donations here fell to 382 pints, the lowest for a day since September. He said that at the Manhattan donor center only ninety-one pints were collected, against the usual 125 to 160 pints.

NEW BEDFORD, Mass., Dec. 2 (AP) -- Basil Brewer, New Bedford publisher who managed Senator Taft's unsuccessful Presidential nomination campaign in Massachusetts, said tonight that the Senator's condemnation of the appointment of Mr. Durkin expressed the case "plainly but mildly."

CINCINNATI, Dec. 2 -- Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican of Ohio and co-author of the Taft-Hartley labor act, today called Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's designation of Martin P. Durkin of Chicago as Secretary of Labor "an incredible appointment."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- President Truman accepted today the resignation of Dr. Philip C. Jessup as Ambassador at Large, an assignment, said Mr. Truman, that had contributed to "the security of our country and the peace of the world."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 (AP) -- Senator Alexander Wiley, Republican of Wisconsin, said today that Iron Curtain countries in one of their "most diabolic conspiracies" were flooding the United States with Christmas tree ornaments.
CHARLOTTE AMALIE, Virgin Islands, Dec. 2 (AP) -- Blackbeard's Castle, one of the Virgin Islands' most ancient landmarks, was destroyed by fire early today.

OMAHA, Neb., Dec. 2 -- One of the basic conflicts in man's effort to harness the Missouri River, big dams versus small dams, cropped out again today as the Missouri Basin Inter-Agency Committee reviewed "seven years of progress" on developing the vast river valley.

Public telephones at Madison Square Garden and Pennsylvania Station were tapped in efforts to detect bookmaking operations, Capt. James W. Flynn, one of the defendants in the departmental trial of thirty policemen on charges of conspiracy, testified yesterday.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Dec. 2 (AP) -- The higher classification minor leagues drafted fifty-five players for a total of $183,500 today at their annual selection meeting. The Class B and C leagues will draft tomorrow to conclude the selections.

CHICAGO, Dec. 2 -- In recognition of their efforts to reduce religious, racial and nationality prejudices, Dr. Henry Townley Heald, Chancellor of New York University, and Leonard S. Florsheim, chairman of the Board of the Independent Pneumatic Tool Company, were cited tonight by the National Conference of Christians and Jews at the organization's American Brotherhood Silver Jubilee Dinner.

KANSAS CITY, Dec. 2 (AP) -- A Kansas City manufacturer denied today that he had promised a former civilian buyer at Wright Patterson Air Force Base a commission on contracts obtained with the Government.

The Henry Rosenfeld collection, presented yesterday afternoon at Russeks Fifth Avenue, defied the season's first snowfall. It was the expression of spring and the sunny South. Full skirts rounded over stiffened underskirts. Cottons brought their freshness to the scene and nylons were as airy as thistledown.
George Meany, newly elected president of the American Federation of Labor, said here last night that the existence of racial and religious bias in Washington was a "national disgrace."

Steve Owen, coach of the Giants, won't have the grandstand quarterbacks telling him this week who should handle the passing duties for his club against the Washington Redskins on Sunday. Tom Landry, who took over after Chuck Conerly and Fred Benners were hurt in the Pittsburgh debacle last Sunday, will get first call.

The Newport News Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company of Newport News, Va., confirmed yesterday the signing of a contract for construction of four 38,000-dead-weight-ton super tankers for Grand Bassa Tankers, Ltd., of Monrovia, Liberia.

The board of trustees of the Rockefeller Foundation, meeting yesterday in Williamsburg, Va., elected John D. Rockefeller 3d as its chairman. His grandfather, the late John D. Rockefeller, oil producer and philanthropist, established the foundation in 1913 to "promote the well-being of mankind throughout the world."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- In the United States Court of Claims today the following proceedings were had:
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 2 -- Many provisions of the Federal highway aid program date to the horse and buggy days, Glenn C. Richards, Detroit Superintendent of Public Works, charged today.

The longevity of the modern roasted turkey is appalling. The precedent of the turkey entree on Thanksgiving began when American families were considerably larger than they are today. But despite the fact that the size of the average family has shriveled to a mere four or five, the housewife insists on investing in the traditional ten-to-fifteen-pound birds.

The Saar vote was magnified out of its local importance because it was worked up and played up as a contest between Germany and France. The excitement in Saarbrucken last Sunday did not reflect concern over the status of the little territory itself. It reflected the interest of the Western World in the issue on which the future of Europe turns.

Howard W. Fitzpatrick of Malden, Sheriff of Middlesex County, Massachusetts, received last night the 1952 St. Vincent de Paul Medal from St. John's University at a ceremony honoring St. Vincent, patron of the Vincentian Fathers under whose jurisdiction St. John's is administered.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 2 -- Lazarus Joseph, Controller of New York City, said here today that New York could economize by consolidating municipal department, as has been done in Philadelphia under a "model charter" adopted in April, 1951.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 (AP) -- The Army said today that it had charged First Lieut. Sheppard Carl Thierman with violation of the military code's section dealing with fraudulent enlistment, appointment, or separation."

The Coast Guard Merchant Marine Council, headed by Rear Admiral Halert C. Shepheard, conducted a hearing in Washington yesterday at which owners of water taxis, junk boats, sludge barges and other small craft gave their views on new control regulations that the council proposes to enforce.

Premier Joseph Stalin is the subject of two books scheduled for publication a week apart next month. On Jan. 23, Farrar, Straus Young will issue "Stalin: A Self-Portrait," a collection of photographs hitherto unpublished in this country that traces his life from early childhood to the present.
MAYS LANDING, N. J., Dec. 2 -- The special May grand jury went out of existence today with the admission that it had failed to find any proof of official corruption in Atlantic County.

All of New York's 175 hospitals will have full - scale participation in the city-wide atom bomb drill on Saturday, Dec. 13, the Office of Civil Defense announced yesterday. The public participation air raid test was ordered by the state Civil Defense organization.

I have just read with deep distress that Elizabeth Gurley Flynn has been sentenced to jail because she refuses to accuse her friends and associates of being Communists. In other words, she refuses to buy her own freedom at the expense of disaster to others, for she knows what it means to be accused of Communist affiliation.

SAN BERNARDINO, Calif., Dec. 2 (UP) -- Search pilots today spotted high on the San Bernardino Mountains wreckage that might be the remains of an Air Force C-47 feared to have rammed a peak with thirteen persons aboard during the stormy night.
Furniture of the nineteenth century -- Biedermeier. Regency and Empire -- has been used to achieve a feeling of quiet elegance in a four-room model apartment now on view at 200 East End Avenue.

The weeks since the election have been heartening to business, with a strengthening of confidence evident not only in rising stock prices but a leveling out of the earlier commodity price decline, the National City Bank of New York comments in its bank letter for December.

ELIZABETH, N. J., Dec. 2 -- Carol Ann Casarelli, 9 years old, a periodic patient at the Elizabeth General Hospital since she was 11 months old for treatment of Mediterranean anemia, a rare blood disease, died last night at the hospital.
TORONTO, Dec. 2 (Canadian Press ) -- Both the Ontario Securities Commission and the Toronto Stock Exchange expressed concern today at sharp fluctuations in the prices of certain stocks.
Ground was broken yesterday for a new Domestic Relations Court building in Brooklyn as a part of the borough's growing Civic Center in the downtown area.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- A Roman Catholic priest and a city police censor told Congressional investigators today that the Federal Government, publishers with a mind to "clean up" and an "aroused" public must work together to clear indecent literature off the book and magazine stands.
CHAPEL HILL, N. C., Dec. 2 -- Carl Snavely today resigned as head football coach at the University of North Carolina.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Dec. 2 -- President Carlos Ibanez opened an international press congress tonight in the ceremonial hall of the Senate building here with a pledge of continued press freedom in Chile. He charged that the press itself was responsible for many of the world's current misunderstandings among peoples.

John van Druten has written a little play on a big subject, "I've Got Sixpence," acted at the Ethel Barrymore last evening. Since he is an able writer and director, and since he has cast Viveca Lindfors in the chief part, there are many things to enjoy in the production.

MEXICO CITY, Dec. 2 -- Richard N. Nixon, the United States vice president-elect met privately today with Mexico's new President, Adolfo Ruiz Cortines, to deliver General Dwight D. Eisenhower's invitation to an official meeting between the two chiefs of state after the latter's inauguration in Washington next month.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 (UP) -- Investigators of the House of Representatives were told today that the Carnegie Corporation had made grants to the Johns Hopkins University for work by Owen Lattimore and to the Institute of Pacific Relations before the charges of communism in Congress.
Wages of 10,000 elevator operators and doormen in 1,100 Manhattan apartment buildings were raised yesterday $2.30 a week under an agreement between labor and management groups.

Keeping wine bottles on their sides so their contents wet the corks, preventing them from drying out and thus letting in the air, is not always easy to do when one lives in a two-by-four with hardly room to lay down one's hat, let alone a few good bottles.

BERLIN, Dec. 2 -- A decree issued last Friday by the Government of East Berlin forbidding outsiders to shop there has hit hard at the living standard of low income West Berliners and threatens to wipe out the chief magnet drawing Soviet zone residents to view the "show window of the West."

CARACAS, Venezuela, Dec. 2 -- The Venezulan Army announced tonight that Col. Marcos Perez Jimenez, a member of the ruling junta, was the Provisional President of the country. The junta, of which Dr. German Suarez Flamerich and Col. Luis Felipe Llovera Paez were the other members, had resigned.

The Walter W. Naumburg Musical Foundation, which can always be counted on to discover unusual talent, presented yesterday afternoon at Town Hall an extraordinarily gifted soprano in the person of Lois Marshall, third and last of the season's Naumburg winners.

HONOLULU, Dec. 2 -- The International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union in Hawaii announced today that 500 union longshoremen engaged in a work stoppage against Castle and Cooke Terminals, Ltd., were returning to work "involuntarily" because of a temporary restraining order issued by Judge Allen R. Hawkins of the Second Circuit Court.

Business and industrial failures dropped to 127 in the week ended Thursday, compared with 167 in the preceding week and 148 in the like week a year ago, according to Dun Bradstreet. The drop was attributed in part to the Thanksgiving Day holiday.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Dec. 2 -- The lower house of Parliament approved today, 86 to 7, constitutional amendments making the Netherlands the first country to enact specific provisions for yielding authority to supranational organizations.

In recently published reports on various phases of alcoholism the "revolving door" is aptly used as a figure of speech to show the futility of police, jail, hospital, welfare and other institutional treatment that merely returns the patient to an unsatisfactory status quo, where he came in before. "

HUNTINGTON, W. Va., Dec. 2 (UP) -- A state investigator said today a 220-pound woman doomed herself and eleven others when she hysterically blocked a door on the ward for feeble-minded women during last week's fire at the state mental hospital here.

Coach Bud Wilkinson of Oklahoma, here to attend the presentation of the Haisman award to his star halfback, Billy Vessels, yesterday said that the two-platoon system "was ruining football on a broad scale."

George M. Humphrey and Sinclair Weeks, Secretaries-designate of the Treasury and of Commerce, respectively, in the Cabinet of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the President-elect, voiced a hope yesterday that the incoming Administration could make an early reduction in Federal taxes.

The automatic factory machine can replace many workers in industrial plants but it will in no sense make employes "obsolete" unless it is greatly mishandled, Dr. Norbert Wiener suggested yesterday at the annual meeting of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers at the Statler Hotel.

Giant presses for forgings and extrusions running up to 50,000-ton capacity are already showing huge savings in weight, complexity and dollars in the aircraft program. This, with some startling details of actual operation, was the theme of an all-day session yesterday in the Statler Hotel of groups of engineers under the sponsorship of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers.

DENVER, Dec. 2 (AP) -- The birth of a baby made history tonight on a nationwide television network. It was a boy -- Gordon Campbell Kerr -- third child of John R. and Lillian Kerr of Denver. The child weighed five pounds, seven ounces. Gordon was born by caesarian section, an operation that takes the baby from the mother.

The Thoroughbred Racing Association will conduct its annual membership meeting today and tomorrow at the Plaza Hotel. Representatives from thirty-seven race tracks which are members of the T. R. A. will attend the eleventh annual conference.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Dec. 2 -- A record field of 196 contract bridge pairs last night played the first qualifying session of the 1952 Master Mixed Pair Championship, first major event in the winter session of the twenty-sixth annual National Contract Bridge Championships conducted here by the American Contract Bridge League.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- Representative Clarence J. Brown, Republican of Ohio, announced today that he intended to propose a new reorganization study by a commission that he believed could bring about a $10,000,000,000 to $15,000,000,000 reduction in Federal Government costs.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Dec. 2 -- As baseball's winter meetings moved into their second phase today, with the minor leagues taking over with their annual draft, the Dodgers decided this to be as good a time as any to step in and win the headlines.

SEOUL, Korea, Dec. 2 -- President Syngman Rhee said today that the South Koreans would unify the Korean peninsula or die in the attempt. In restating a stand he had made public repeatedly since the war began, he said he believed the United Nations troops now holding the present line of battle could drive the Chinese Communists back into Manchuria.

John Feltman, for two years assistant manufacturing manager of the receiver division of Albert B. Du Mont Laboratories, Inc., has been named assistant manufacturing manager of the company's cathode ray tube division.

Dr. Grayson Kirk, acting head of Columbia University, left here yesterday by plane for a tour of six European capitals to discuss with university officials methods by which they could help to mark at their institutions the Columbia bicentennial celebration in 1954.

BONN, Germany, Dec. 2 -- Victory for Chancellor Konrad Adenauer's Government coalition appeared almost certain tonight as the Bavarian party pledged its twelve Bundestag votes to the support of the Allied-German treaties.

Joseph D. Nunan Jr., Commissioner of Internal Revenue from 1944 to 1947, was indicted yesterday by a Brooklyn Federal grand jury on a charge of cheating the Government out of $91,086 in income taxes for the years 1946 to 1950, inclusive.

The Socony-Vacuum Oil Company, Inc., will have made capital expenditures in the United States of nearly $2,000,000,000 since the start of 1934 through this year, B. Brewster Jennings, president, told the New York Society of Security Analysts at a luncheon meeting here yesterday.

An offering of $22,600,000 of Chicago 3 3/4 per cent parking facility revenue bonds, maturing July 1, 1982, will be made today by a banking group headed jointly by Blyth Co., Inc.; Smith, Barney Co.; Harriman Ripley Co., Inc.; Glore, Forgan Co., and John W. Clarke, Inc. The bonds are priced at par and accrued interest.

TRENTON, Dec. 2 -- The State Board of Canvassers officially certified today the New Jersey vote in the general election, showing that Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the President-elect, received 1,373,613 votes and Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson, his Democratic opponent, 1,015,902.

The thirty-second annual bazaar, known as "Ye Olde English Faire," under the auspices of the Daughters of the British Empire in the State of New York, will be held this afternoon and evening, tomorrow and Friday in the main ballroom of the Biltmore Hotel.

ALBANY, Dec. 2 -- The President of the State University, Dr. William S. Carlson, said today that the university would ask the Attorney General next week to institute condemnation proceedings for land essential to the development of a permanent site for Harpur College at Vestal in Broome County.

There have been many disappointments over lack of civic progress in freeing the legitimate theatres in New York City from restrictions that prevent new building and deprive playgoers of comforts and conveniences that would add to the pleasure of a night out.

More than 40 per cent of the heat and power generating plants in this country operate equipment more than twenty years old, and this must be replaced to improve efficiency and reduce smoke and smog, it was asserted yesterday by G. E. De Siena, vice president of Superior Combustion Industries, Inc., New York and Pennsylvania boiler and combustion equipment manufacturer.

Church-related colleges are engaged today in a desperate struggle for survival, Dr. Harry Thomas Stock of Boston said last night at a dinner given in honor of his thirty years of service in religious education, by the Board of Home Missions of the Congregational Christian Churches.

ONE of the characteristic aspects of the current publishing scene is the increase in the number of picture books and the increase in the skill with which pictures are used. And one of the most interesting and popular uses of pictures in books is to illustrate and document history. Today's batch of five picture books are all concerned with history in one way or another and all are good books of their kind.

The settlement of contract negotiations covering 20,000 East and Gulf Coast seamen on a basis of base pay increases of 5 to 15 per cent, higher overtime rates and other benefits was announced yesterday by Paul Hall, secretary-treasurer of the Atlantic and Gulf district of the Seafarers International Union, A. F. L.
TOKYO Wednesday Dec. 3 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,452, for the twenty-four hours ended at 6 A. M. Wednesday, Korean time:

Corporation Counsel Denis M. Hurley has been instructed to take "all legal steps necessary" to recover money improperly paid for coal contracts negotiated by the Board of Transportation, Mayor Impellitteri announced last night at City Hall.

PARIS, Dec. 2 -- Commenting on the Saar election, Robert Schuman, French Foreign Minister, said today his Government "still desires to hasten through direct negotiation" an agreement with the Bonn regime for a final settlement of the Saar question on a basis of "Europeanization."

Verdi's "Don Carlo" was given last night for the first time this season by the Metropolitan, and again the opera thrilled the audience by the sweep power and beauty of its music. Mr. Bing's restoration of this magnificent work to the Metropolitan repertory, in a setting of especial splendor, is one of his deeds that have made our public his debtor.

A former Japanese infantry lieutenant testified yesterday at the treason trial of former Sgt. John David Provoo that on Corregidor Provoo had sought to curry favor with him by giving him unsolicited gifts. These gifts usually consisted of food and clothing, but on one occasion, when Provoo wanted to have another American non-commissioned officer share his quarters, he gave the Japanese lieutenant an American camera, the witness told the court yesterday.

On the eve of the opening by the New York State Crime Commission of its long-awaited public hearings on waterfront corruption, the Jarka Corporation, one of the largest stevedoring concerns in the East, last night obtained a court order directing the commission to show cause why it should not be enjoined from making public the testimony corporation officials had given in private.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 2 -- Mark Robson, who recently returned from the Fiji Islands, where he directed his own production of "Return to Paradise," is going traveling again. This time his destination is England, and his scheduled date of departure is Dec. 29.

A dogged Federal grand jury brushed aside attempted restraints by the Department of Justice to return yesterday a presentment castigating the State Department for clearing "disloyal Americans" for key jobs at the United Nations.

The Christmas bazaar of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Holy Trinity will be held tomorrow and Friday at St. Christopher's House, 316 East Eighty-eighth Street. Mrs. Livingston Cromwell heads the bazaar committee, Mrs. Sinclair Hatch and Mrs. George Dwight are vice chairmen and Mrs. Robert N. West is treasurer.

The Manhattan Savings Bank will open its new main office tomorrow at 385 Madison Avenue, simultaneously discontinuing its two midtown branches at 7 Rockefeller Plaza and 570 Lexington Avenue. The bank's other branches will be continued at 154 East Eighty-sixth Street Bowery at Canal Street and Broadway at Eighth Street.
Cotton futures trading on the New York Cotton Exchange was again moderately active yesterday and prices turned easier in the late trading, closing 12 to 33 points lower than on Monday.

BOWIE, Md., Dec. 2 (AP) -- The weather closed Bowie race track again today and the nation's leading rider, Tony DeSpirito, promptly took off for Florida where he can keep going after the world record for the most winners in a season.

Prizes of $500 each, a total of $9,000, were awarded yesterday to eighteen artists who had entered a nation-wide competition of watercolors, drawings and prints, the third in a cycle covering the field of art to be sponsored by the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

LONDON, Dec. 2 -- An 18-year-old British soldier was convicted at a court-martial at Bovington, Dorset, today of plotting to hand over military secrets to a foreign power through the Young Communist League, of which he was a member.
As part of a campaign to overcome flagging box-office interest in fistic attractions, the International Boxing Club yesterday revealed plans to revive an old favorite of ring followers.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 2 -- Secretary General Trygve Lie is expected to give United Nations employes who had refused to answer questions about alleged Communist activities a chance to change their minds and testify.

The National Board of Fire Underwriters has reported that thirty of New York City's firehouses "could safely be discontinued," Fire Commissioner Jacob Grumet disclosed yesterday at a press interview at fire headquarters in the Municipal Building.

BONN, Germany, Dec. 2 -- A West German official said today that Federal Germany was willing to reopen negotiations with France on the future of the Saar, but the economic convention linking the economy of the territory to France must be completely abolished.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- Gen. Hoyt S. Vandenberg, Air Force Chief of Staff, declared today that United Nations air power had destroyed "all actually good air targets in North Korea with the exception of lines of communication."

Trading continued slow on the New York commodity exchanges yesterday with futures closing higher or irregular except for cottonseed oil, which was lower. Cocoa, lead, tin and coffee closed higher and hides, rubber, zinc, potatoes, sugar, wool tops and soybean oil were mixed.

LONDON, Dec. 2 -- While the British Commonwealth Prime Ministers' Conference was continuing its discussions on closing the sterling area's "dollar gap," it was announced here today the sterling countries had earned a gold and dollar surplus of $128,000,000 in November.

Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois arrived here yesterday for a brief visit with his sister-in-law, Mrs. Ralph Hines of 231 East Sixty-ninth Street. He is scheduled to address the Congress of Industrial Organizations convention in Atlantic City later today and then go to Washington, where he will confer with President Truman and attend a Cabinet dinner in his honor tomorrow night.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Dec. 2 -- Twenty non-white leaders of the defiance campaign against South Africa's racial segregation laws received suspended prison terms of nine months today. All were charged with offenses under the Suppression of Communism Act.

Martin P. Durkin, nominated by General Eisenhower as Secretary of Labor, has the distinction of having served as Director of Labor of Illinois to the satisfaction of both Republican and Democratic Governors. An efficient administrator of his own union, the Plumbers and Steamfitters, Mr. Durkin has the reputation of seeing things in perspective and, as a realist, in noting trends and appraising them sensibly.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- The United States Court of Claims today ruled against a university professor, who died here two weeks ago, in his multi-million dollar suit, charging the Government with infringement of a patent, left unsettled.

A new star in the person of Arthur Kennedy will be discerned in the Broadway galaxy tonight. At 8 o'clock the prerogatives and the purple of that select circle will be conferred upon him at the Cort, where "See the Jaguar" will have its premiere.

ARLIE LATHAM was a nice little guy with twinkling eyes and mischievous grin. Until recent years he had served as press box attendant at both the Polo Grounds and Yankee Stadium, a delightful sinecure for an old-time ball player. His duties were not much more onerous than watching the games. But Arlie is gone now, dead at the age of 92.

Ranging in age and interest from that of a retired businessman to that of a 6-year-old, the craftsmen of the Greenwich House pottery have produced a large and varied collection of ceramic objects for the annual Christmas sale at the pottery, 16 Jones Street.

The stock market moved into fairly even balance yesterday with a slightly higher emphasis. Slackening in the recent activity tempered a fresh rise to a net increase of 0.33 point in the composite rate.

TORONTO, Dec. 2 (AP) -- H. G. Miller, recently elected president of Silver Miller Mines, Ltd., said today that he had ordered killed a contract with the United States Government for the sae of cobalt, and he made it clear that the company had no such contract now.
Adoption and promulgation of a new quality standard for vinyl plastic film is expected early in 1953.

More than 150 striking flight engineers of Eastern Air Lines were notified by telegram last night that if they did not report for work by 2 P. M. today, the line would consider that they had "resigned."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 (UP) -- When Government agents go "grocery shopping" to support farm prices they carry a long shopping list.

A Florida Power Corporation offering of $15,000,000 of first mortgage bonds, 3 3/8 per cent series due Nov. 1, 1982, will be marked today by a banking group headed by Kidder, Peabody Co. and Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Beane. The bonds are priced at 101.804 and accrued interest from Nov. 1, 1952, to yield 3.28 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 (AP) -- Mr. Hoffman, who will head the House Government Operations Committee in the Republican Eighty-third Congress, acknowledged that his proposal for a limit on newspaper space might involve complications -- an obvious anticipation of objections that the proposal would interfere with freedom of the press.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 2 -- Carlos de Lacerda, publisher of the newspaper Tribuna da Imprensa, was jailed last night for contempt of court in what he said was a result of a Fascist law that curtails freedom of speech.

LUXEMBOURG, Dec. 2 -- The six-nation European Coal and Steel Community, which has its temporary headquarters in this city, constituted today its Consultative Committee consisting of three 17-member groups representing labor, management and consumers respectively.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- Virginius Francis Coe, who has been secretary of the International Monetary Fund since its organization in June, 1946, could not have been appointed to the Bretton Woods agency according to established practice without the concurrence of Fred L. Vinson, now Chief Justice of the United States.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 (UP) -- House investigators began work today on their final report on tax scandals and prepared recommendations for the outgoing Eighty-second Congress.

Lieut. Gen. Willis D. Crittenberger, First Army commander, who is scheduled for retirement at the end of the year, announced yesterday that personnel under his command eligible for discharge between Dec. 20 and Jan. 4 would be separated from the service no later than Dec. 19.

LAKE HARMONY, Pa., Dec. 2 -- The snow, which began before daybreak and continued throughout the day, discouraged many of the local venison enthusiasts and sent most of the deer into the deep thickets where hunting was not only difficult but also unproductive.

Four confidential investigators of the State Temporary Rent Commission were indicted yesterday on charges of having extorted $9,100 from rooming house operators by threats of reducing rent levels and reporting violations.

The Beverly Hotel and adjoining Randolph Apartments, properties at the northeast corner of Lexington Avenue and Fiftieth Street with a combined assessed valuation of more than $2,000,000, have passed to Irving Maidman, a realty investor, who reported yesterday that a contract for their purchase had received court approval.

In THE NEW YORK TIMES on Nov. 21 Dorothy Barclay reported on the concern of a group of experts who reviewed the Civil Defense Administration film, "Duck and Cover," and urged the schools to devote themselves to the counteracting of the tensions that arise from our current everyday life.

LONDON, Dec. 2 -- Peers attending but not participating in Queen Elizabeth's coronation ceremonies at Westminster Abbey in June will be allowed to dispense with the costly robes of state, it was announced today.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 2 (UP) -- Louis B. Seltzer, editor of The Cleveland Press, a Scripps-Howard newspaper, today proposed that radio, television and newspapers set up a "board of objective inquiry" to examine threats to freedom of information.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- The Democratic party has emerged from the Presidential election as a revitalized political organization and its candidate, Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois, has gained stature in his defeat, Stephen A. Mitchell, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, said today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 (AP) -- Consumer credit -- what the buying public owes for goods, services and repairs -- shot up $650,000,000 in October to an all-time high of $22,311,000,000.

KINGS POINT, L. I., Dec. 2 -- Brooklyn College's unbeaten quintet marked up its third success in crushing the United States Merchant Marine Academy, 81 -- 55, tonight in the opener for the Mariners. The visitors moved into a 19-9 lead at the first quarter and held a 37-25 margin at the intermission.

The elections which were held in Venezuela on Sunday provided one of the most astonishing and significant results in Latin-American history. The Government junta, controlled with an iron hand by an army clique headed by Col. Perez Jimenez, was so certain of victory that it permitted a regular, secret ballot. However, as we and they know now, popular feeling and the growth of political and social consciousness had been miscalculated.

PARIS, Dec. 2 -- Premier Antoine Pinay asked the National Assembly today for a vote of confidence approving his insistence on immediate discussion of the appropriation bill and budget for 1953. The vote will be taken Thursday and the Premier announced that on Friday he would ask for another vote of confidence to insure that the Assembly would take up the Government's proposal on the measure, which has been badly mutilated in committee.

LOS ANGELES, Calif., Dec. 2 -- Immigration authorities in Washington have denied the appeal of Dr. Tsien Hsue-shen, California Institute of Technology rocket expert, against a deportation order, it was disclosed today by German R. Landon, District Director of Immigration.

Events tonight: "Rigoletto," Metropolitan Opera, 8:30 P. M.; Boston Symphony Orchestra, Pierre Monteux conducting, Corinne Lacomble, pianist, Carnegie Hall, 8:45; Richard Ellsasser, organist-composer, Town Hall, 8:30; Charles L. Riley, tenor, Lexington Avenue Y. M. and Y. W. H. A., 8:40; Music festival presented by New York Association for the Blind, Lighthouse Auditorium, 111 East Fifty-ninth Street, 8:15; Apollo Club of Brooklyn, Alfred Boyes conducting, Frances Yeend, soprano, Brooklyn Academy of Music, 8:30.

The Chicago Black Hawks, leaders of the National Hockey League, will oppose the New York Rangers at Madison Square Garden tonight. The game will be the second half of a home-and-home series, the teams having played to a 1-to-1 tie in Chicago on Sunday night.

ENFIELD, Conn., Dec. 2 -- A prison superintendent today praised inmates at the State Penitentiary Farm for a "nearly professional" performance of Verdi's opera, "La Forza del Destino" ("The Power of Destiny").
CHICAGO, Dec. 2 (AP) -- Today's livestock prices reported by the Department of Agriculture follow:

McKesson Robbins, Inc., has named Ellington Co., Inc., as agency for its trade and professional advertising. This includes the industrial, chemical and drug merchandising departments previously handled by the Bisberne Advertising Company of Chicago.

HOLLYWOOD BEACH, Fla., Dec. 2 -- The last wave of post-Korea inflation is now breaking up and the managers of the public credit and public debt should look to the devices of the free market place to prevent the formation of another wave, William McChesney Martin Jr., chairman of the board of governors of the Federal Reserve System, declared here today before the Investment Bankers Association of America.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 2 -- Mexico made an appeal today to Arab members of the United Nations and Israel to cease exchanging complaints on the Palestine issue, to use "self-control" and to seek a new constructive approach toward ending the five-year-old dispute.

The New York Athletic Club retained first place in the Class A team competition of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association by defeating the Racquet and Tennis Club, 3 to 2, on the Winged Foot courts yesterday.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Indo-China, Dec. 2 -- All-out Vietminh attempt to overwhelm the isolated French position of Nasan in Northwest Tonkin has been repulsed, a communique issued here tonight announced. A preliminary Vietminh attack night before last was followed last night by a massive assault against the Nasan perimeter which failed after seven hours of intensive fighting, the communique said.

Ed Molloy of Yale and Mitch Price, Columbia star, finished in a tie for the 1952 passing title in the Ivy Group, revised official figures disclosed yesterday. Each wound up with ninety-two completions, breaking the mark of 90, established by Cornell's Alan Dekdebrun in 1945.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 2 -- The British action of a year ago in evicting 3,000 Wameru tribesmen from their tribal lands in Tanganyika and the United Nations Trusteeship Council's subsequent failure to condemn the action, were both denounced in strong language by eight small powers today.
Controller Joseph is reported in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Nov. 19 as having proposed for economy reasons the discontinuance of the city's Commerce Department.
MOSCOW, Dec. 2 -- A special military court in Kiev has sentenced to be shot as "enemies of the people" three men convicted of "counter - revolutionary wrecking" for engaging in a trade conspiracy.
EDGEMONT, S. D., Dec. 2 (UP) -- Business was "pretty good" today for the opening of the Edgemont uranium ore-buying station even though there was only one lot sold.

City College's rugged basketball squad possesses height and enough necessary speed and has "the makings of a representative team," according to Coach Dave Polansky's view of the Beavers' 1952-53 court picture.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- Secretary of Defense Robert A. Lovett said today that he favored the greatest possible flexibility in the use of various weapons by different armed services and discounted reports indicating that an inter-service fight was brewing within the Pentagon.

ROME, Dec. 2 -- Pope Pius, seeking to simplify the dress that Roman Catholic Cardinals have worn for centuries and to reduce its excessive cost, introduced some changes today in the traditional and elaborate vestments.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- The Pennsylvania Railroad asserted today that it was showing "favoritism" to the Long Island Rail Road by charging it only 15 per cent of the cost of operating Pennsylvania Station in Manhattan and the East River tunnels, whereas the Long Island used 30 per cent by value of the facilities.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 2 (AP) -- A 6-point spree in the opening minutes of an overtime period enabled the New York Knickerbockers to defeat the Philadelphia Warriors, 89 -- 82, in a National Basketball Association game at Convention Hall tonight.

Low prices for Japanese cotton textiles, offered for first quarter 1953 delivery to American buyers, cannot be maintained indefinitely, importers pointed out yesterday. Components costs, aside from labor, they said, preclude continuing quotations which have brought Japanese textiles below prices for comparable American constructions for the first time since World War II.

VIENNA, Dec. 2 -- Dr. Antonin Gregor, Czechoslovak Minister for Foreign Trade, has been relieved of his post, according to a Prague radio broadcast today. His successor is Richard Dvorak, former Deputy Minister.

Central reserve city banks in New York City and Chicago, required to maintain larger reserves against their deposits than banks in other cities, are suffering "discrimination" under the regulations, J. Stewart Baker, chairman of The Bank of the Manhattan Company, told stockholders yesterday at their annual meeting.
New York had its third snow of the season yesterday, nearly one and one-half inches falling from 7:20 A. M. until 3:15 P. M.

HONG KONG, Dec. 2 -- Swarthy, 52-year-old Michael Patrick O'Brien, a human shuttlecock who says he is an American named Stephen Stanley Ragan from Tacoma -- "only the State Department figures different, thank you very much" -- began today his seventy-sixth consecutive day as an involuntary commuter between Hong Kong and Macao.

LONDON, Dec. 2 -- The stock markets lost some of their recent buoyancy today and prices became irregular. British funds were one of the exceptions, remaining quietly firm in expectation of the gold and dollar reserve statement which was made after the market closed. recovery on the denial of the report that the World Bank had refused to grant load facilities to Japan.

The work of the National Midcentury Committee for Children and Youth, a follow-up group on the White House Conference on Children and Youth held in 1950, will not die when the organization ceases to exist in the near future.

A United Nations official, ordered by the international organization to return here from his post in Switzerland for questioning by Federal investigators, testified yesterday that he was not a member of the Communist party, but refused to say whether he had been one as recently as the day before.

The feminine quality of intriguing allure, known in grandfather's day as "it," is in danger. Some of the girls on television are trying so awkwardly to project a spicy charm that it begins to look as if they didn't know the difference between ooo-la-la and oh.

Ezio Pinza has withdrawn from the cast of a new musical radio series to be presented by the National Broadcasting Company network beginning Monday from 10 to 10:30 P. M. Robert Merrill, engaged as a replacement, will be featured with Marguerite Piazza and Meredith Willson's orchestra.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 (AP) -- Attorney General James P. McGranery filed a breach-of-contract suit today against Schering Corporation, which the Government sold only a few months ago to a group of private investors.

With a display of free world solidarity unequaled since the first days of the Korean war, the General Assembly of the United Nations, acting as a committee, has adopted an amended Indian resolution calling on the Communists to end that war on the basis of a compromise solution of the prisoner-of-war issue.

Your editorial of Nov. 18 "Terror in Iran" was read with a great deal of surprise. A large newspaper such as yours, which has capable correspondents all over the world, is expected to present to the American people a true picture of what is taking place. This editorial is considered misleading and as misrepresenting the real facts.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 2 (AP) -- Notre Dame's two-platoon halfback, John Lattner, today was named the outstanding college football player of 1952 by the Maxwell Memorial Football Club.

BERLIN, Dec. 2 -- East Germany announced tonight that another United States soldier had sought asylum within its territory. In all five British or United States soldiers have been reported in the last week as seeking refuge in the Soviet zone.

ATLANTIC CITY, Dec. 2 -- Assured of the convention votes needed to make him president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, Walter P. Reuther took steps today to prevent the union group from tearing itself apart in the process of his election.

JERSEY CITY, Dec. 2 -- Action on the proposed municipal business license tax ordinance will be taken at a special meeting next Friday, it was announced at today's regular meeting of the City Commission.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Dec. 2 (UP) -- Buzzy Bavasi, vice president of the Dodgers, today expressed anger at the Yankees for their suggestion that Jackie Robinson had "popped off" when he accused the front office of the Bombers of anti-Negro sentiment.
PITTSBURGH, Dec. 2 (UP) -- Bob Baker of Pittsburgh moved another step toward the heavyweight challenger class tonight by pounding out a ten-round split decision over Billy Gilliam at the Gardens.

CHICAGO, Dec. 2 -- The adoption of the Indian armistice proposal by the United Nations, while not conclusive, cooled buying enthusiasm on grain and soybean futures on the Board of Trade today. The market also had to absorb considerable long profit-taking, so that with a slower demand, prices showed a reactionary trend much, of the day.

If the Chilean Government had nationalized a mainland sheep ranch this event might not have made news outside Chile. It is news, however, when the Government takes over the concession of a British-controlled corporation which is raising Merino wool on Easter Island.

Zino Francescatti's playing is a light glowing in an elegant and perfectly balanced lantern. Last night, at the violinist's annual Carnegie Hall recital, a large audience basked in the rays of that warm, steady light, obviously enjoying the experience. One could tell this from the extraordinary silence with which it listened, and the waves of appreciative applause that greeted the violinist before and after each work.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- The State Department, apparently replying to the charge by a Federal grand jury that it had cleared "obvious cases of disloyalty," said tonight that the decision to hire or discharge United Nations employes was made by the Secretary General and not the Department of State.

The possibility of a general price rise for shoes at retail in the spring all but disappeared yesterday at the semi-annual gathering at the New Yorker and McAlpin Hotels of retailers representing stores throughout the country.

ATLANTIC CITY, Dec. 2 -- The Congress of Industrial Organizations sent its congratulations today to Mr. Durkin on his appointment as Secretary of Labor. The C. I. O. convention unanimously approved a telegram to the American Federation of Labor leader, assuring him of the C. I. O.'s "complete and whole-hearted cooperation and support."

James Wolfe, pianist, played his debut recital in Town Hall last evening. A native of Omaha, Mr. Wolfe studied with the late Artur Schnabel and in addition to concert performances has composed and conducted music for the film, "Father Damien."

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 2 -- Millions of acres of land in various parts of the world have been and are being distributed to the landless since the United Nations, called to action here by Secretary of State Dean Acheson two years ago, began its work in the field of land reform, Dr. Isador Lubin declared today.

ALBANY, Dec. 2 -- The Public Service Commission today accused the State Supreme Court of having usurped the commission's regulatory powers by granting to New York City an order restraining the Staten Island Rapid Transit Company from seeking permission to abandon passenger service.

Increasing support was given yesterday to the movement by a group of smaller export concerns to seek help from the Export-Import Bank on the serious financial burden involved for them in long-delayed dollar remittances on goods shipped to Brazil.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- Arthur E. Summerfield, soon to step down as Republican National Chairman to become Postmaster General, urged Congress today to retain some limit on political spending "so there is some point beyond which you cannot go."

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 2 -- The Soviet Union's demand for an immediate cease-fire in Korea -- with prisoner-of-war talks to come later -- was turned down today by a heavy majority of the members of the United Nations.

A reduction in the frequency of accidents among employes in the industrial plants that participated in the annual contest of the Greater New York Safety Council, just completed, was reported yesterday at the annual meeting in the New Yorker Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- President Truman approved and made public today the details of a plan that not only would permit but would encourage the nation's standard broadcasting stations to remain on the air during an enemy attack, whether by airplane or by guided missile.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- An orderly transfer of foreign aid programs to Republican management after Jan. 20 was canvassed today by Averell Harriman, Director for Mutual Security, and Harold E. Stassen, who has been designated as his successor by Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, President-elect.

CHICAGO, Dec. 2 -- Uranium, the atomic energy element with a potential energy content 3,000,000 times that of coal, has been found as a result of intensive explorations to be as abundant in recoverable amounts as is recoverable coal, it was reported here today by Dr. William Davidson, director of the Office of Industrial Development of the Atomic Energy Commission.

The progress made in the arthritis field during the past few years has brought research tantalizingly close to the goal of complete relief for arthritis sufferers. But still that goal has not been reached. Scientists believe that a cure cannot be far off, and their unremitting efforts are underscored by the hopes and prayers of more than 8,000,000 victims of arthritis in this country.

Whereas, the undersigned constitute all the present members of the June, 1951, Federal Grand Jury of the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York -- a jury impaneled to investigate violations of laws of the United States including those directed against subversive activities and espionage; and
ALBANY, Dec. 2 (AP) -- The per-capita income of Westchester County residents -- $2,679 -- was the highest of any county in the state in 1951, the State Commerce Department reported today.

Asked what he thought of Senator Taft's criticism of the selection of Mr. Durkin, George M. Humphrey, who will be General Eisenhower's Treasury Secretary, said in New York yesterday that his only information on the subject had been derived from a quick glance at newspaper headlines "and I hope they aren't true."
DENVER, Dec. 2 -- Dr. John Maston Travis of Jacksonville, Tex., was voted "general practitioner of the year" by the American Medical Association today at its annual clinical meeting here.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Dec. 3 -- Fifteen Superforts of the Far East Air Forces' Bomber Command struck heavily last night at the North Korean Communist capital of Pyongyang and at railroad yards and a military staff school north and south of the city.

Activity on the New York commodity exchanges increased slightly yesterday. Futures closed irregularly with cottonseed oil, cocoa and rubber higher and hides, lead, zinc, potatoes and wool lower. Sugar and coffee ended mixed and tin was unchanged on no sales.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- John Foster Dulles made his first official call on the State Department today in his role as next Secretary of State and he promptly assured "loyal servants of the Government" that they had "nothing to fear."

MELBOURNE, Thursday, Dec. 4 (AP) -- Maureen Connolly, American and Wimbledon champion from San Diego, Calif, entered the final of the Victorian tennis championship today with a 6 -- 4, 6 -- 1 victory over Mrs. Mary Hawton of Australia.

A plea for the cooperative ownership of housing facilities was made by Robert W. Dowling, president of the City Investing Company, at a luncheon meeting yesterday of the Lions Club of the Bronx at the Concourse Plaza Hotel, the Bronx.

A Gladstone bag containing $200,096 in cash was found last night in a Queens furnished room a few minutes after the tenant, a shabby, eccentric old man with holes in his trouser knees, was discovered sitting dead in an armchair by his landlady.
The nation's 1,600 college football coaches, will be asked for an opinion on Notre Dame's controversial shift, Columbia's coach, Lou Little, said yesterday through The Associated Press.

There is no formula for the solution of the difficulties in which we find ourselves today. But there is a will which can prevent these difficulties from developing into a Third World War, and save our nation from a depression that would be an invitation to Communist imperialism to launch a Third World War.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- President Truman, discarding the counsel of his economic stabilization officials, approved tonight the wage contract under which coal miners will receive a full $1.90 a day increase in wages.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 3 -- Henry W. Drath, a vice president

Leaders of the National Association of Manufacturers counseled American business yesterday not to misinterpret the election results to mean free enterprise had received a green light to exploit labor, consumers or foreign countries.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- Attorney General James P. McGranery said today that he had ordered a Federal grand jury investigation into the surplus oil tanker transactions. Former Representative Joseph E. Casey, Democrat of Massachusetts, and Newbold Morris, who was dismissed as investigator of Government corruption, were among those involved in the deals.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson received a warm welcome tonight at the residence where, as he said on arrival, he would not live for the next four years.
Striking Eastern Air Lines flight engineers rejected yesterday an ultimatum to return to work by 2 P. M. or lose their jobs, and the line announced the employes were off the payroll as of that time.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange turned easier again yesterday and declined 2 to 27 points with weakness most pronounced in the near months.

R. Hoe Co., Inc., manufacturer of printing presses, accessories and equipment, is inviting tenders for sale to it of its class A stock. Joseph L. Auer, president, announced yesterday that the sum of $103,483 will be appropriated out of earnings for the fiscal year ended Sept. 30, 1952, as a sinking fund for retirement of the stock.

The Ford Foundation has announced plans for another significant public service. Fellowships will be granted to properly qualified persons for special study and residence in East Asia and the Near and Middle East. The purpose of this grant is to broaden the scope of Americans who may be called upon to deal with Asian problems.

Because of the "intolerable" cost of supporting the defense in the eight-month Communist conspiracy trial, thirteen secondary party leaders rested their case yesterday, contending they had effectively refuted the charge of seeking to overthrow the Government by force and violence.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 (AP) -- The Department of Justice today announced an anti-trust consent judgment against United Engineering and Foundry Company of Pittsburgh "terminating international cartel agreements in the manufacture and sale of rolling mill machinery and equipment."

The concert of the Boston Symphony Orchestra, Pierre Monteux conducting, last night in Carnegie Hall, began with a performance of Brahms "Academic" Overture, which is Brahms in the least pedantic vein of his whole creative career. It is a wonderfully joyous, waggish piece, filled with the spirit of youth and the campus.
CHICAGO, Dec. 3 -- Demand for wheat and soybeans was not broad enough to absorb selling on the early hard spots, with rather concentrated commission buying in the early trade.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 (UP) -- The Department of Agriculture has denied cotton price support loans to California, Texas. Arizona and New Mexico producers who store their crop in the open, a spokesman said today.
The establishment of a special court in the city devoted exclusively to handling cases of alcoholism was announced yesterday by John M. Murtagh, Chief City Magistrate.

MEXICO CITY, Dec. 3 -- Vice-President-elect Richard N. Nixon took the opportunity of a guest appearance before the Mexican Congress today to reassure Latin America that Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's Administration would reinforce the bonds of Western Hemisphere relations.

BONN, Germany, Dec. 3 -- Dr. Konrad Adenauer said today in the opening of the most momentous debate in the short history of the West German Federal Republic that his countrymen faced a choice between freedom and equality in alliance with the West or subjugation by the Soviet Union.

HOLLYWOOD BEACH, Fla., Dec. 4 -- William A. Patterson, president of United Air Lines, Inc., said here today that this nation was still eight years or more away from the commercial use of a high-speed jet plane such as that just developed in Great Britain through Government subsidy.

Gov. John Davis Lodge of Connecticut visited the headquarters of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the President-elect, at the Commodore Hotel yesterday afternoon and thereby gave fresh currency to reports that he might become this country's Ambassador to Italy.
CHICAGO, Dec. 3 -- One of the last Victorian mansions on Chicago's Lake Shore Drive will soon be razed to make way for a modern office and apartment project.

William H. Morgan of Cortland County formally announced his candidacy for the chairmanship of the Democratic State Committee yesterday and touched off a new series of reactions in the fight to choose a successor to Paul E. Fitzpatrick, the retiring chairman.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Thursday, Dec. 4 (AP) -- Detroit traded Outfielder Johnny Groth, Pitcher Virgil (No-Hit) Trucks and Pitcher Hal White to the St. Louis Browns for Outfielder Bob Nieman, Second Baseman Owen Friend and Catcher J. W.

Averell Harriman, Director for Mutual Security, emphasized last night the necessity for the United States to "maintain a dynamic expanding economy, not only for our sake, or for Israel, but for the sake of the whole free world."

An era in which preventive medicine will preclude the need for surgery in the treatment of disease was predicted yesterday by Dr. John H. Mulholland, chairman of the Department of Surgery at New York University's College of Medicine.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 3 -- Secretary General Trygve Lie has notified several leading delegates to the General Assembly that he is willing to stay in office until the expiration of his term on Feb. 1, 1954, if the United Nations is not able to reach an agreement upon his successor before then.

Herbert Brown, 48-year-old owner of a Brooklyn trucking concern, was released yesterday in $500 bail after pleading not guilty to charges of making false statements in a registration application to the State Motor Vehicle Bureau. The criminal information also accused Brown of operating his fleet of six trucks while under a blanket suspension by the bureau.

LOS ANGELES, Calif., Dec. 3 -- Mayors and other municipal officials from all parts of the country closed their three-day meeting here today by adopting a resolution favoring state ownership of offshore oil lands after a spirited floor battle.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 3 -- Secretary General Trygve Lie has instructed United Nations employes who have refused to answer questions about alleged subversive activities to testify or face loss of their jobs.

What happened in Venezuela these last few days comes as a shock to all who cherish the growth of democracy in Latin America. The shock is no less great because the leader of the military junta, Col. Perez Jimenez, appears to have done just what everybody expected.

ATLANTIC CITY, Dec. 3 -- Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois, unsuccessful Democratic candidate for President, told the Congress of Industrial Organizations today that the Republican election victory should not be considered "a disaster or, necessarily, even a misfortune for labor."

After six months of futile negotiation with the American Weigh-masters Association, three small but important locals of the International Longshoremen's Association, A. F. L., made plans last night to issue a strike notice today to their employers.

In the interest of mathematical accuracy some comment is necessary in regard to the open letter, sent to the President by a distinguished group of Protestant clergymen, protesting economic aid to Spain.

Christmas and year-end bonuses of more than $40 need not be approved by the Wage Stabilization Board, if they conform to the requirements of its General Wage Regulation 14, which was issued in 1951, Arthur J. White, chairman, Region 2, comprising New York State and northern and central New Jersey, said yesterday.

LONDON, Dec. 3 -- Two devices for combating wide fluctuations in commodity prices, which have been responsible for much economic uncertainty and distress in the sterling area, were decided upon today in the British Commonwealth Prime Ministers' Conference.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 (AP) -- The New Jersey Natural Gas Company today urged the Federal Power Commission to grant an operating permit to Algonquin Gas Transmission Company, its only source of natural gas for northern New Jersey.

ATHENS, Greece, Dec. 3 (AP) -- Spyros Skouras, noted figure in the American movie industry, and the Greek Government have been holding discussions the last few days on the projected establishment of sugar and oil refining industries in Greece, a Government source disclosed today.

Layers and layers of toys lined the four walls of a large room yesterday in the basement of the New York Telephone Company at 140 West Street. Among the 7,000 items were 1,500 dolls dressed by employes of the organization, who will help to distribute the collection on Saturday to children in ninety-eight hospitals and orphanages in the metropolitan area.

As a British West Indian resident in the United States, and as a regular reader of THE NEW YORK TIMES, I join my compatriot, Wendell Malliet, in expressing appreciation of your recent articles on Caribbean federation.

FARMINGDALE, L. I., Dec. 3 -- A new jet fighter, sweptwinged and powered with an engine that develops 7,200 pounds of thrust, was displayed at the Republic Aviation Corporation's big plant here today before military and civilian officials.
Precautions to take in buying and caring for Christmas trees were listed yesterday by the Greater New York Safety Council and the Welfare and Health Council of New York City as follows:
