LONDON, Dec. 3 (AP) -- Emil Zatopek, Czechoslovakia's triple Olympic champion, was selected ahead of America's Bob Mathias as the world's No. 1 sportsman today in a poll sponsored by World Sport, official magazine of the British Olympic Association.

BERLIN, Dec. 3 -- Without advance warning, Soviet sector authorities brought motor traffic between East and West Berlin to a virtual standstill early today. The West Berlin police estimated 300 cars from the West had been seized when they crossed the line into the Soviet sector.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 (AP) -- The Federal Power Commission was asked today to approve a plan for using natural gas from the Gulf coastal bend area of Texas to supplement gas supplies moved to the East through the "Little Big Inch" pipe line.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- The International Monetary Fund announced today the dismissal of its secretary, Frank Coe, who refused last Monday to tell Senate investigators in New York whether he was now or had ever been a Communist or subversive agent taking orders from Communists.

Attendance continued heavy at the Popular Price Shoe Show of America despite unfavorable weather yesterday and orders were placed in quantity, it was announced by show officials. Buyers continued to avoid lines that have increased in price.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 3 -- Secretary General Trygve Lie announced today the appointment of Constantin Stavropoulos as the principal director of the United Nations legal department, effective Dec. 1.
Your editorial emphasis of Nov. 25 on the great utility of the exchange-of- persons program in the Campaign of Truth is very welcome.

BOSTON, Dec. 3 (AP) -- Vince Boryla tossed in 21 points and Connie Simmons 16, to pace the New York Knickerbockers to a 100-75 victory over the Philadelphia Warriors in a National Basketball Association game tonight at the Boston Garden.

TORONTO, Dec. 3 (Canadian Press) -- Noranda Mines, Ltd., big northern Quebec mining corporation, has completed arrangements for $30,000,000 of financing for new projects now under way. This was announced today by James Y. Murdoch, president.

Bendix Home Appliances division of Avco Manufacturing Corporation introduced yesterday the first home laundry appliance that dries as well as washes in one continuous operation. The new appliance, known as the Duomatic, was demonstrated to distributors of the division at Bendix headquarters in South Bend, Ind.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 (AP) -- Following is the text of President Truman's directive granting the full $1.90 a day wage increase for the Bituminous Coal Operators' Association and the United Mine Workers of America, as announced today by Roger L. Putnam, Economic Stabilization Administrator:

Wholesale food prices declined slightly in the week ended on Tuesday, according to the Dun Bradstreet index. It stood at $6.22 at the end of the week, against $6.23 in the previous week and $6.68 for the comparable week a year ago.

PARIS, Dec. 3 -- The result of the Saar election last Sunday when an unexpected majority vote was given for the French proposals for European unity, was a striking illustration of the singular character of the progress made toward this unity.
VIENNA, Dec. 3 (AP) -- The eleven men executed in Prague today had been judged "Zionist, Trotskyite" enemies of Stalinism.

With Brown joining Columbia, Cornell, Dartmouth, Pennsylvania, Harvard, Yale and Princeton, the Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League will operate as an eight-team circuit in 1953-54. The admission of the Bruins was made official at the league's annual meeting yesterday and they were allocated a full quota of dates in next season's double round-robin.

FLINT, Mich., Dec. 3 -- In event of a sudden cutback in defense orders, the automotive industry is preparing a program to absorb the released labor forces, and Buick's part was outlined today by Ivan L. Wiles, general manager of the Buick Division of the General Motors Corporation.

Following a successful high-speed press test of newsprint made from bagasse, the Dominican Republic has decided to build a $2,500,000 plant to produce this type of paper for printing and other uses, it was announced yesterday by the country's New York Information Center.

N. Richard Nash, who wrote a simple play called "The Young and Fair" in 1948, has now written one that is waist-deep in symbolism. "See the Jaguar," he calls it, with a metaphorical accent. With Arthur Kennedy in the leading part, it opened at the Cort last evening.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- The Department of Defense prepared today to put into effect on Jan. 1 the new law covering military reserves. Officials estimated that about 2,500,000 persons would be affected.

The idea that the New York City government could learn anything from the way other cities do things is usually regarded as preposterous. Nevertheless Controller Lazarus Joseph, chairman of the Mayor's Committee on Management Survey, has made a precedent-breaking trip to distant Philadelphia to see how things are being done there under a new charter.
CHICAGO, Dec. 3 -- Martin P. Durkin said today that he intended to keep politics out of the Labor Department if he was confirmed for the office of Secretary of Labor.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- Congressional investigators learned today that considerably more than $1,200,000 was spent in advance of the Republican National Convention to help win the Presidential nomination for Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Dec. 3 -- Although the major league meetings are still forty-eight hours away -- the minors alone occupied the spotlight today with the formal opening of their annual convention -- battle lines already are forming on the right.

BOWIE, Md., Dec. 3 (UP) -- The Bowie meeting, which was halted yesterday by a heavy snowfall, resumed today and Nick Shuk rode three winners on the muddy track, including Larry Ellis in the $10,085 Old Dominion Handicap.

TRENTON. Dec. 3 -- The New Jersey Legislature ended its special session tonight without reapportioning Assembly representation to conform with the 1950 census. The bill failed to pass the Assembly by one vote, the final tally, being 30 to 24.

The Colin Pharmacal Company of Long Island City, one of five pharmaceutical concerns that Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein is seeking to dissolve because of alleged questionable sale of securities and monopolistic practices, indicated in Supreme Court yesterday that it would not fight the appointment of a receiver.

Excerpts from testimony given at yesterday's public hearing of the State Crime Commission and from private testimony read into the record follow. The questioning was conducted by members of the commission's legal staff.

ATLANTIC CITY, Dec. 3 -- Past presidents of the New Jersey Association of Real Estate Boards held their annual dinner tonight to open the thirty-sixth annual convention of that organization. The chief speaker was Dr. Ivor Griffith, president of the Philadelphia College of Pharmacy and Science.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 3 -- Levi Harner, who specializes in broken bones and winning harness races, was first in both departments this year.

Just when it looked as if the New York Rangers had worked out matters to their own satisfaction, the Chicago Black Hawks struck at them with three goals in the third period. This late harvest proved more than enough for the league-leading Hawks, and they skated off the winners by the score of 5 to 3, at Madison Square Garden last night.
MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 3 (AP) -- Reubin Clein, publisher of the weekly Miami Life, entered Dade County jail just before midnight last night to begin serving thirty days for contempt of court.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 (AP) -- The Federal Power Commission's engineering staff has approved New York State's plan to help Canada build a huge hydroelectric power system along the St. Lawrence River.
BALTIMORE, Dec. 3 (AP) -- The National Football League hung a steep price on a franchise for Baltimore today.

Brown Brothers Harriman Co. announced yesterday that effective Jan. 1, David G. Ackerman and L. Parks Shipley will become general partners. Mr. Ackerman joined the private banking firm in 1930 and has been a manager and in charge of its investment advisory business in recent years.

MADRID, Dec. 3 -- Edwin V. Huggins, United States Assistant Secretary for Air, arrived here today for a two-day visit during which, it is understood, he will discuss the administrative and technical aspects of a program for the construction of Spanish air bases to be financed by the United States Government.

The Hochschild mining interests, which between 1948 and 1950 produced 22 per cent of the Bolivian tin concentrate, rejected yesterday a request by the Bolivian Government that it appoint representatives to diiscuss payment for its expropriated mines.
CINCINNATI, Dec. 3 (AP) -- The Cincinnati Stock Exchange said today it had been notified that a special meeting of stockholders of Crosley Motors, Inc. has been set for Dec. 12.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 (UP) -- The Petroleum Administration for Defense announced today it has allocated 222,896 tons of line pipe for the first quarter of 1953 for six large crude oil pipelines and eight big petroleum-products pipelines.

VIENNA, Dec. 3 -- Rudolf Slansky, Dr. Vladimir Clementis and nine other prominent Czechoslovak Communists, sentenced to death last week for high treason and sabotage, were hanged this morning in Pankrac prison in Prague, the Prague radio reported.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 3 -- Thirteen Asian and Arab countries called on the United Nations today to set up a three-member commission to arrange for direct negotiations between France and the Tunisian nationalists.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 3 -- Carlos Lacerda, publisher of the newspaper Tribuna da Imprensa, was released from prison today by the Supreme Court as the Brazilian Press Association called on Congress to repeal the National Security Law under which he was jailed.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- The Women's Bureau of the Department of Labor today released its 1952 handbook of facts on women workers, showing approximately 19,000,000 women in the labor force. This was nearly half a million more than in 1951.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 (UP) -- The National Planning Association, seeking the causes for industrial peace, said today that a "strong, responsible, Democratic" union was one of the "significant" factors leading to good profits for a company and high wages for its workers.

DOBBS FERRY, N. Y., Dec. 3 -- The village board sent to Governor Dewey today a request that he investigate assertedly criminal activities by fugitives from Dobbs Ferry Children's Village, a school for maladjusted boys 10 to 18 years old.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- The presentment of the Federal Grand Jury in New York City is only the latest arraignment of the State Department for its failure to obstruct subversive American citizens from infiltrating its own personnel, and that of the United Nations.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- Mrs. Margaret Culkin Banning, the author, urged publishers today to exercise self-censorship to purge the newsstands of "girlie" magazines, which she said had "no purpose except pictorial prostitution."

CLEVELAND, Dec. 3 (AP) -- Television station WTVJ of Miami and radio station WHO of Des Moines, Iowa, won gold trophies for outstanding news operation tonight at a meeting of the National Association of Radio News Directors.
MOSCOW, Dec. 3 (AP) -- The English language periodical The News dwelt at great length today on Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's Korean trip.

LONDON, Dec. 3 -- The stock markets were dull today despite yesterday's statement of the November rise in the sterling area's gold and dollar reserves. Business dwindled and prices after a firm opening drifted lower.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 3 -- Delegates to the United Nations lend a respectful ear to a privileged group of ordinary men and women here, known casually as N. G. O.'s (non-governmental organizations). The scope of these observers, most of them representing powerful international associations, is world-wide and their status is protected under the United Nations Charter.

GOA VELHO, Portuguese India, Dec. 3 -- The body of St. Francis Xavier, from which life departed 400 years and a day ago, was uncovered this morning in the awed presence of Roman Catholic pilgrims from many countries, including Emanuel Cardinal Goncalves Cerejeira, Patriarch of Lisbon and papal legate representing Pope Pius.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 3 -- A group of small countries crushed a move in the General Assembly's Trusteeship Committee today to form a new alignment of nations favoring a policy of moderation in the handling of colonial affairs.

Despite the inclement weather, Bonwit Teller's showing of Hannah Troy resort and spring designs brought out a capacity audience yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. The linen suits with pretty scoop-neck silk blouses and chic print ensembles for southern wear were typical of the simple good taste and charming femininity characteristic of these designs, as were the crisp wool frocks and suits that could slip under furs immediately.

Today's new film is "Million Dollar Mermaid," Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer's biography of Annette Kellerman with Esther Williams portraying the noted swimmer, at the Radio City Music Hall. Mervyn LeRoy directed and Arthur Hornblow Jr. produced from a screen play by Everett Freeman. Victor Mature, Walter Pidgeon, David Brian, Donna Corcoran, Jesse White and Maria Tallchief are among the principals.

TOKYO, Thursday, Dec. 4 -- Hard-fighting Republic of Korea infantry yesterday lost and then rewon the northern slope of Pinpoint Hill," dominating "Sniper Ridge" on the central Korean front north of Kumhwa.
PHOENIX, Ariz., Dec. 3 (UP) -- Manager Casey Stengel of the Yankees had bitter criticism for the Indians, Dodgers, Senators and Athletics.

Many tickets have been purchased for the performance of Cinerama on Tuesday night at the Broadway Theatre, which has been taken over for the benefit of the Catholic Centre for the Blind. Proceeds will further the work of the beneficiary, situated at 22 East Seventy-first Street, which provides a home for blind girls as well as giving them employment and remuneration.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 (UP) -- The Army announced reassignment today for Maj. Gen. Orlando C. Mood whose name figured in the recent Presidential campaign controversy over the training of South Korean troops.

Emphasis is placed on the light, rather than on the lamp, in a new collection of illuminating devices designed by Jason Harvey. The group, which includes table and wall lamps, may be ordered through Mr. Harvey's showroom at 438 East Eighty-eighth Street.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Dec. 3 (AP) -- Navy's basketball team opened its season today with a record-smashing 126-44 victory over Western Maryland.

Continuance of the unsatisfactory dollar credit situaion in Brazil, involving a high backlog of unliquidated drafts due United States exporters, is increasing the necessity of a dollar loan to that Latin-American country. This view was expressed yesterday at a meeting of the Foreign Credit Interchange Bureau in the Statler Hotel.

HAVANA, Dec. 3 (AP) -- Jack Shields of Glen Ellyn, Ill., a newcomer to United States professional golf, led thirty of his colleagues today in the first round of the seventy - two - hole invitation open tournament with a six-under-par 66.

LONDON, Dec. 3 -- A Vatican radio broadcast has indicated that the Roman Catholic Church does not expect the pre-war church status in Hungary to be restored in all respects when that country eventually is "liberated."
PUSAN, Korea, Nov. 24 -- With winter here, the guerrilla bands operating behind the Allied lines in Korea are concentrating on raiding small villages for food, fuel, clothing, money and weapons.

MIAMI, Dec. 3 -- The contract bridge team of John R. Crawford of Philadelphia and B. Jay Becker, Peter Leventritt and George Rapee, all of New York, with a score of twenty matches, took an early lead today over a field of forty-one teams in the Men's Team-of-Four Championship, second major event in the week-long winter session of the twenty-sixth annual National Contract Bridge Championships conducted by the American Contract Bridge League.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 30 -- Despite the fact that there has been no active fighting between the Arab states and Israel, beyond minor frontier incidents, during the last three years, it would appear to be the conclusion of many diplomats stationed in the Middle East that peace in Palestine is as far from realization as ever.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- The President's Commission on the Health Needs of the Nation will report on Dec. 18 that comprehensive health services can be delivered to all the people in the United States on an insurable basis without continuing Federal subsidies.

Guaranty Trust Company of New York plans a five-for-one stock split, it was announced yesterday. The action would reduce the par value of the bank's stock from $100 to $20 a share and increase the number of authorized shares from 1,000,000 to 5,000,000. After the announcement was made, the market price of the stock rose 8 points to close at $353 bid, $362 asked.
CHICAGO, Dec. 3 (AP) -- Today's livestock prices reported today by the Department of Agriculture follow:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- Robert A. Lovett, Secretary of Defense, has proposed to President Truman changes in the structure of the Joint Chiefs of Staff and "clarification" of their relationships with civilian superiors.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 3 -- When Ann Blyth says goodbye to Universal-International upon the expiration of her contract on Dec. 20, she will be free to put her signature on an agreement being drawn up at Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer.

Twenty-five "substitute" daddies, including a taxi-cab driver, a Federal Bureau of Investigation employe, a television actor and an ex-newspaperman, all of whom find the time each week to play with hospitalized youngsters at Bellevue, will be honored today, along with 170 "substitute" mothers, at these "hospital parents."
HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Dec. 3 -- Hofstra's Flying Dutchmen won their second basketball game of the season against no losses tonight by defeating Hillyer College 84 -- 50, in the Hofstra gymnasium.

A 33-year-old ex-convict, who pleaded guilty yesterday in Traffic Court to twenty-nine unanswered summonses, was sent to Bellevue Hospital for ten days' psychiatric observation to determine if he is sane. Chief Magistrate John M. Murtagh made the unusual move in the case of William W. Holt of 33-33 Eighty-second Street, Jackson Heights, Queens.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Dec. 3 (AP) -- Venezuela accepted calmly today the armed forces appointment of Col. Marcos Perez Jimenez, as Provisional President and an official announcement that the pro-Government party was leading in returns from Sunday's election.
OTTAWA, Dec. 3 (Canadian Press ) -- Canada's exports during the first ten months of 1952 climbed to a new high of $3,558,500,000, the Bureau of Statistics reported today.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 3 -- The United Nations General Assembly adopted by an overwhelming majority today an Indian compromise resolution recognizing the right of Korean prisoners of war to be repatriated but rejecting the use of force to compel the return of those unwilling to be.

LAKE HARMONY, Pa., Dec. 3 -- There is some question as to what constitutes successful hunting, for we considered today one of the most successful huntings days in our memory, yet we did not so much as fumble for the trigger.

Trade show exhibits are a necessary part of advertising and selling but they have not kept pace with the improvement in other media, it was asserted yesterday by speakers at the fourth annual trade show clinic and exposition of display techniques sponsored by the Exhibitors Advisory Council.

An attractive National Basketball Association double-header will be played at Madison Square Garden tonight. The feature test will bring together the New York Knickerbockers and the Minneapolis Lakers. In the opener, scheduled for 7:30 o'clock, the Boston Celtics face the Milwaukee Hawks.

Two days of intermittent snow and a mixture of snow and rain ended here at 12:10 P. M. yesterday, leaving city streets covered with slush and suburban areas plagued with snowdrifts and a thin undercoating of ice. Thousands of commuters were late for work.

Some newspaper men have a cynical turn of mind. When it was announced at Richard Elsasser's organ recital, last night in Town Hall, that he would conclude the evening with an improvisation on a theme by Ernst Krenek -- said theme reposing in a sealed envelope, not to be opened until the Moment -- there were some lifted eyebrows in the back section of the hall.

An increase last week of 2,948,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end, total supplies were 126,833,000 barrels, compared with 123,885,000 a week earlier and 122,893,000 a year ago.
Foster L. Bryan, formerly with William Wittman, has joined Collins Aikman as men's wear stylist.

Another chapter was added yesterday to the checkered career of "Two's Company," the revue that is to bring Bette Davis, motion picture star, back to the Broadway stage. Scheduled to give its first performance this evening at the Alvin Theatre, the attraction will not be unveiled locally until Miss Davis has completely recovered from a throat ailment described as laryngitis.

The multi-million dollar shipping industry was startled yesterday by disclosures before the State Crime Commission of huge inter-company payments made to oil the cogs of waterfront business, and by regular goodwill payments to officials of the International Longshoremen's Union, A. F. L.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- The Long Island Rail Road is trying to get reductions of nearly 65 per cent in real estate taxes payable to New York City and Nassau and Suffolk County communities, the parent Pennsylvania Railroad told an Interstate Commerce Commission hearing today.
A Hadi paid 30 cents a case for 3,602 cases of Virgin Islands dry gin yesterday. He will have to leave the country if he wants to drink it at that price, or pay $100,000 in taxes and duties.
NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Dec. 3 -- Jim McDermott's Iona College basketball squad is the biggest in the history of the school.

An expansion of mail service, including an increase in carrier deliveries and collections and an extension of the lobby hours of terminals and stations, was announced yesterday by Acting Postmaster George M. Bragalini as the Post Office prepared to cope with the annual avalanche of Christmas mail.

The State of Washington sold $25,000,000 of motor vehicle fuel tax revenue bonds, due from Sept. 1, 1953 to 1976 at public bidding yesterday at a net interest cost of 2.51 per cent for a combination of 6's, 2 1/4s and 2 1/2s.

The dismissal of four men and three women teachers who refused to answer school officials' questions about Communist party membership was recommended yesterday by a special trial examiner of the Board of Education.

When Fordham University's end, Ed Brown, set five pass-receiving records against New York University last Saturday, he completed the most powerful statistical assault ever recorded in the Eastern Intercollegiate Association, final official figures revealed yesterday.

THE principal casualty of battle in "The Red Badge of Courage" was its author, Stephen Crane. He wrote that immortal Civil War story in 1894, when he was 22 and had never seen combat. But it made him a military expert then and there. And living up to the reputation did as much as anything to kill him, long before his time.

IT is to be doubted that any coach ever received a more frightening assignment than was dumped unexpectedly into the lap of Jordan Olivar at Yale this year. Yale isn't just another college with a football team attached. It's -- well, it's Yale, the school that Knute Rockne once described solemnly, respectfully and sincerely as "the fountainhead of all football."
In a game played at speedy a pace all the way, Seton Hall's basketball squad defeated St. Francis College, 77 -- 61, before 2,000 persons at the II Corps Armory in Brooklyn last night.

Moderating influences were at work yesterday in the stock market. The list earlier in the week had lapsed into a period of calm after expressing its enthusiasm price-wise over the post-election developments.
There certainly is magic in the article in THE TIMES of Nov. 29 entitled "Replacing a Slum Seems Like Magic."

Scheduled helicopter service that will link suburban sections and near-by towns and cities with the New York metropolitan area will fly more than 6,000,000 passengers, 40,500,000 pounds of mail and 6,500,000 pounds of cargo into and out of Manhattan annually by 1975, it was forecast yesterday.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Indo-China, Dec. 3 -- Vietminh troops around the isolated French strong point of Nasan did not renew their all-out assault on the Thai country bastion last night and today there were only scattered exchanges of fire around the Nasan perimeter as the Communist-led forces pulled back and measured their losses after having been repulsed in two savage attempts Sunday and Monday nights.

The lining industry must keep pace with the apparel field and is now faced with the problem of constructing light - weight and washable linings to match the clothing trend. To meet this demand N. Erlanger, Blumgart Co., Inc., has been experimenting with the new "miracle synthetics," it was announced yesterday by David F. Seiferheld, president.

Reflecting the record sales volume, exceeding $8,250,000 for the quarter ended last Nov. 30, directors of the General Instrument Corporation yesterday resumed the payment of dividends with the declaration of 25 cents a share for payments on Dec. 22. The last one was 20 cents paid May 15, 1951.

The recent change in the personal foul rule may draw out collegiate basketball games from seven to ten minutes, according to Dave Walsh, secretary of the National Association of Approved Basketball Officials.

Twelve Long Island and Westchester central offices will be equipped in the coming year with direct dialing facilities for many station-to-station telephone toll calls by 50,000 individual and two-party line customers, the New York Telephone Company announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- Henry H. Fowler, head of the Office of Defense Mobilization, asserted today that he opposed the abandoning of controls over wages, prices or materials allocations before the Truman Administration left office.

The Netherlands Government has put itself at the head of a procession leading not only toward the unification of Europe but toward a transformation in the idea of national sovereignty. The Parliament in The Hague is the first in the world to amend its Constitution to permit a cession of national power to a supranational authority.

The blood-drenched Communist juggernaut, which has crushed millions under its wheels in many lands, rolled again through Prague yesterday and took to the gallows eleven of the Communist conspirators who betrayed Czechoslovakia into Stalin's hands and now were hanged on the charge of betraying Stalin.

Investors bought from Jerome A. Lawrence the one-story taxpayer containing five stores and a post office on plot 78 by 158 feet at 450-58 Hempstead Turnpike, northeast corner of Plainfield Avenue, Elmont, L. I. The property faces the entrance to Belmont Race Track and was sold for cash over two mortgages amounting to about $113,000.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 (AP) -- The Defense Department abolished today its practice of referring to men killed, wounded or missing in Korea as "casualties."

The top wine-producing district of Germany is the Rheingau; it lies on the north bank of the Rhine where that great river shifts its course and runs for twenty miles, from Mainz to Bingen, from east to west. Best known of the Rheingau's wines is perhaps the Schloss Johannisberger.

The rise of competing retail outlets, the trend toward suburban living and qualitative population changes here have been mainly responsible for relatively unfavorable showing of department stores in this Federal Reserve district, and particularly in New York City.

LONDON, Dec. 3 -- An exasperated and tired House of Commons that had been up half the night went into a series of verbal explosions today after Prime Minister Churchill had impugned the patriotism of Emanuel Shinwell, a former Labor Defense Minister, in terms that unintentionally smacked of East European totalitarian phraseology.
TOKYO, Thursday, Dec. 4 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,453, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Thursday Korea time:
Defying the snow, the New York Football Giants practiced outdoors for more than one hour yesterday in preparation for Sunday's contest with the Washington Redskins at the Polo Grounds.

An English fair for the benefit of the Victoria Home for the Aged opened yesterday at the Biltmore Hotel. Booths were arranged by thirty chapters of the Daughters of the British Empire in New York State which since 1915 has maintained a home in Ossining for men and women of British birth or ancestry.
Fordham opened its basketball season last night by crushing Adelphi, 80 -- 57, at the Fordham gymnasium.

The recent reduction of 3 cents a pound in the price of rayon staple has stimulated sales of spun rayon fabrics at the wholesale and mill levels, it was learned yesterday. Concessions made by the manufacturers of the fabric to compensate for lower material costs have brought in a sizable volume of business from wholesale buyers requiring fabrics for apparel production early next year.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 (AP) -- A meeting of the International Wheat Council here to consider renewal of a world wheat export program has been postponed until after the Eisenhower Administration takes office. Originally set for Jan. 12, it now will be held on Jan. 30.

A girl collector was arrested yesterday when she interrupted police raiding a policy ring headquarters in East Harlem, apologized for being late and handed a policeman three envelopes containing 780 numbers.
ALBANY, Dec. 3 -- The State Federation of Labor announced tonight a legislative program for the 1953 session that included recommendations for "eliminating the chaos" on Capitol Hill.
ATLANTIC CITY, Dec. 3 -- Startled newsmen got an advance announcement today of the outcome of tomorrow's election of a new president by the strife-rent Congress of Industrial Organizations.
DETROIT, Dec. 3 (AP) -- Coley Wallace, the New York heavyweight who looks like Joe Louis, knocked out Bob Dunlap at 46 seconds of the sixth round tonight with a smashing right.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 3 -- The solution for the long range inflationary trend that is visible in the American economy and also in foreign countries is improved machines and better organization. H. Thomas Hallowell Jr., president of the Standard Pressed Steel Company, Jenkintown, Pa., told manufacturing executives today.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 3 -- Rising unemployment in two major maritime unions was reported yesterday despite much shipping activity.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 3 -- The execution of eleven Czechoslovak leaders, eight of them Jews, was raised in the United Nations' Palestine debate today by Ecuador in an appeal to Arab delegates to settle their bitter quarrels with Israel.
BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Dec. 3 -- The half - million - dollar inheritance that a Stratford dishwasher thought he would get in Pennsauken, N. J., has turned out to be a balloon full of rumor.

The city's civil defense organization will call upon 21,000 auxiliary police now on its rolls to aid in a city-wide public participation in an A-bomb test on Saturday, Dec. 13, William M. Kent, chief of the auxiliary police corps announced last night.

An imaginary market basket was filled yesterday by the National Industrial Conference Board with thirty-one standard items of food, clothing and household use and the store owner's bill read: "309 hours of work."

DETROIT, Dec. 3 -- Fifty improvements are listed in the 1953 B-4 series of Dodge "Job-Rated" trucks announced today by L. J. Purdy, vice president and general manager for trucks of the Dodge division of the Chrysler Corporation.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 3 -- Dr. John W. Nason, president of Swarthmore College since Oct. 26, 1940, has resigned to become president of the Foreign Policy Association, Inc., of 22 East Thirty-eighth Street, New York.

PARIS, Dec. 3 -- France will not be represented, it was learned from official sources today, when the United Nations General Assembly tomorrow takes up consideration of the Tunisian and Moroccan issues raised by the Arab-Asian nations.

The Allied Stores Corporation and its subsidiaries, including 97 per cent-owned Stern Brothers in New York and Gertz in Jamaica and Flushing, Queens, increased sales volume in the three, nine and twelve months ended last Oct. 31, according to the report issued yesterday.

Emanuel Celler, Representative in Congress from Brooklyn, who has been re-elected for the sixteenth consecutive time, has written his autobiography that John Day will issue under the title "You Never Leave Brooklyn."

WASHINGTON, Dec 3 (AP) -- President Truman today revoked the Taft-Hartley labor act, a law he has often condemned, in an effort to end a strike of 1,500 United Steelworkers, C. I. O., who make nickel pipe essential to the atomic energy program.

A necessity for chain stores to maintain "fire department associations" to meet possible destructive attacks was set forth at the annual meeting yesterday of the Institute of Distribution, Inc., at the New York Athletic Club by Ted Braun, president of Braun Co.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, the following principal changes for the week ended Nov. 26:

Representatives of major stevedoring corporations reluctantly admitted before the New York State Crime Commission at a public hearing yesterday that they bought "goodwill" along the New York waterfront at $10,000 to a few dollars a year.

A mathematical analysis of writing presented here yesterday at the annual meeting of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers suggests that the number of different 4,000-word essays it it possible to write is limited to the figure ten followed by 8,000 zeros.

The immediate integration of the personnel and equipment of the Civil Air Patrol into local Civil Defense organizations throughout the state was recommended yesterday by Lieut. Gen. C. R. Huebner, director of the State Civil Defense Commission.

" This has been racing's most prosperous year all around," Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt, president of the Thoroughbred Racing Associations, said in his report yesterday as the T. R. A. eleventh anual membership meeting opened at the Hotel Plaza.

PARIS, Dec. 3 -- France will not be represented, it was learned from official sources today, when the United Nations General Assembly tomorrow takes up consideration of the Tunisian and Moroccan issues raised by the Arab-Asian nations.

The Allied Stores Corporation and its subsidiaries, including 97 per cent-owned Stern Brothers in New York and Gertz in Jamaica and Flushing, Queens, increased sales volume in the three, nine and twelve months ended last Oct. 31, according to the report issued yesterday.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 4 (AP) -- At the request of the Atomic Energy Commission the oil industry is developing a plan to search for scarce and vital uranium at the same time it looks for oil.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 4 (AP) --The Post-Dispatch reported today that Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio still felt he might be able to work with the Administration of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the President-elect.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Dec. 4 -An Indonesian Government spokesman refused tonight to confirm or deny reports that the Defense Minister, the Sultan of Jogjakarta, had tendered his resignation and that the Cabinet was verging on a crisis as the result of splits within the Army over the Defense Ministry and Army leadership.
BOWIE, Md., Dec. 4 (AP) -- The Campbell Stable's Ann's Love ran off with the $7,500 added Bowie Breeders' Stakes today, registering by three lengths over Mrs. Rebecca Collins' Becky's Shirt.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Dec. 4 -- After a medical examiner adjudged that Myron Husak, a 30-year-old displaced person from the Ukraine, was "sane but lazy," the man was sentenced today to fifteen to eighteen months in State Prison for neglecting his three minor children.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 4 -- Nine employes of the United Nations -- all United States nationals and all holders of permanent contracts -- will be dismissed for refusing to tell Senate investigators whether they had taken part in Communist or subversive activities.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 (UP) -- A Federal grand jury began today study of charges that Owen Lattimore had committed perjury in testimony before a Senate Internal Security subcommittee. The Johns Hopkins University professor, a Far Eastern expert, was questioned in the subcommittee's investigation of United States "China policy."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- President Truman and Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois, the defeated Democratic candidate for President, spoke out today against a Democratic role of opposition for opposition's sake under the new Republican Administration.
A center where students of international management techniques may study a "record of the past to serve the future" was dedicated yesterday at New York University.

To Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt, who was retiring as president of the Thoroughbred Racing Associations, was handed the top trophy in the award-presenting ceremony that marked the annual dinner of the T. R. A. membership at the Hotel Plaza last night.

TORONTO, Dec. 4 -- The public-owned Canadian Broadcasting Corporation next week will officially decline to telecast the highly rated program of Roman Catholic Bishop Fulton J. Sheen, originating in New York.

The Playwrights Company is about to spring into action. Understandably enough, the organization isn't content with having only "The Fourposter" here and on the road, where the two-character marvel has been attracting phenomenal trade with Jessica Tandy and Hume Cronyn.
A feeling of light-heartedness pervades the new group of additions to the Picasso and Philippe Lambercy ceramic collections, now on view at Living Today, Inc., 1398 Lexington Avenue.

Modern business promotion methods attracted more than 30,000 persons to the new main office of the 102-year-old Manhattan Savings Bank, Madison Avenue and Forty-seventh Street, at the opening of the two-story structure yesterday. More than fifty patrolmen were needed to handle the crowds.

PARIS, Dec. 4 -- The general concept of European unification has been accepted as doctrine by most Frenchmen but they are divided on the means to achieve it, ill-informed on steps being taken toward federation and easily swayed by strong emotions and nationalistic currents working against it.

MONTREAL, Dec. 4 (UP) -- The undermanned Toronto Maple Leafs limped and scrambled past the Montreal Canadiens tonight, scoring two second-period goals and holding on for a 2-1 victory that moved them into third place in the National Hockey League.

The National Collegiate Athletic Association program of controlled football television produced another blast yesterday. This time from the National Opinion Research Center of the University of Chicago, which has been surveying the situation for three seasons.

PARIS, Dec. 4 -- Premier Antoine Piney obtained a vote of confidence of 314 to 207 today on the procedural question of priority for the discussion of the bill providing ways and means to finance next year's budget.

NAPLES, Italy, Dec. 4 -- Intensive political and military efforts in recent weeks to integrate Yugoslavia's armed forces into the North Atlantic Treaty Organization's defense structure have so far yielded no definite results.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange declined 15 to 47 points yesterday led by the weakness in old December.
A strike of 160 Eastern Air Lines flight engineers -- now in its fifth day -- continued yesterday, and the company announced that the stoppage was costing it $150,000 every twenty-four hours.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Dec. 4 -- Alabama's law protecting newspaper reporters from disclosing confidential news sources was in effect, upheld today by Federal District Judge Seybourn H. Lynne, examination of Mr. Sparrow.

Calling for a "showdown with Russia within the framework of the United Nations," Gov. Theodore R. McKeldin of Maryland demanded last night that the world organization halt shipments of all supplies that might help North Korean or Chinese Communist armies.
NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Dec. 4 -- The Iona College basketball team defeated Roanoke (Va.) College, 75 -- 49, to gain its second straight victory of the season in O'Connell Gymnasium tonight.
I agree with M. D.'s letter (printed Nov. 24) about the unsanitary handling of cold cuts that seems to be prevalent in meat and delicatessen stores in the area.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- Whatever might be their suspicions about the manner or the outcome of the current Venezuelan elections, authorities here do not believe that United States recognition of the new Government will be withheld or that relations with Caracas will be changed.

The six-story apartment house at 97-25 Sixty-fourth Road in Rego Park, Queens, has been sold by Harry and Samuel J. Lefrak and Harold Menowitz to a client of William Weintraub, attorney. The Title Guarantee and Trust Company insured title to the property, which is assessed at $800,000.

Imaginative designs for cruise and resort were previewed for the press yesterday at Orhbach's. Coordinated groups of separates, dresses and beachwear available in the store's third-floor Cruise Shop were presented in unusual fabric combinations appropriate for early vacations.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 (AP) --The Federal Communications Commission authorized new television stations today in Yakima, Wash.; Beaumont, Tex.; Lima, Ohio; Monroe, La., and New Brunswick, N. J.

Fordham will play nine football games in 1953, John F. Coffey, graduate manager of athletics, announced yesterday. Five of these games will be played on the road. Four are listed for Triborough Stadium on Randalls Island.

E. G. Grace, chairman of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, declared yesterday that the nation emerged from last month's election with a "new-found unity" and is "launched on an era of constructive progress."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- President Truman in a jovial and relaxed mood, indicated at his news conference today that he intended to spend several months resting after he left the Presidency Jan. 20. He gave no clue to any other plans he might have formulated for the future.

COLUMBIA, S. C., Dec. 4 -- Gov. James F. Byrnes of South Carolina said tonight that Southern Democrats who voted for Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower in last month's Presidential election should spurn the invitation of some Democratic leaders to forget their differences and work to reform the national party organization.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 4 -- The death of the 77-year-old Milan Grol yesterday occasioned some contemplation here among foreigners of how times have changed and political tensions eased in this Communist country since the end of World War II and particularly since Yugoslavia was ousted from the Cominform four years ago.

Surgical advances that promise to reduce the recurrence of some forms of cancer; more powerful X-ray equipment, and chemicals for the temporary arrest of cancer beyond the reach of surgery are among advances described in the report of the Memorial Center for Cancer and Allied Diseases, made public yesterday by Laurance S. Rockefeller, president of the board of managers.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Dec. 4 -- Gordon R. Clapp, chairman of the Tennessee Valley Authority, urged the Eisenhower Administration today to match the "faith and foresight" of the Democrats in regional resource development by supporting a $1,000,000,000 five-year program for expansion of the authority's electric power supply.
The three qualified bidders that have offered to install 13,000 parking meters in New York streets at costs ranging from $742,075 to $755,974 were instructed last night to submit new bids.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 (AP) -- Following is the text of the letters exchanged today between Archibald Cox, chairman of the Wage Stabilization Board, and President Truman:

BONN, Dec. 4 (AP) -- Donald C. Cook, chairman of the United States Securities and Exchange Commission, said here today that he hopes trading in German securities in the United States can be resumed soon.

LONDON, Dec. 4 (AP) -- Gen. Sir Gerald Templer, British High Commissioner for Malaya, said today Britain had decided to set up a full-scale new army in Malaya as a major step toward giving self-rule to the troubled Federation.
The six reports on alcoholism in the city that were made public early this week were unanimously endorsed yesterday by the board of directors of the Welfare and Health Council of New York City.

Detroit plans to place on the market a $6,000,000 bond issue in the early part of February, it was announced yesterday. Proceeds of the offering will be used to finance extension of the city's water tunnel system.

The letter of Erika Strauss in THE TIMES of Nov. 29 points out a basic problem in selecting foreign visitors to the United States to study our way of life. The Department of Labor is not the only one which brings guests whose ignorance of English makes their stay futile.

Fordham's basketball squad is being touted by some as one to watch this season, but Coach Johnny Bach insists on lifting a cautioning finger. He would prefer that "the experts" await this month's developments before tabbing the Ram as a head-on, fire-snorting instrument of destruction.

The contest for the chairmanship of the Democratic State Committee appeared to have crystalized yesterday into a contest between William H. Morgan, former chairman of the Cortland County Democratic Committee, and Richard H. Balch of Utica, who was the party's candidate for Lieutenant Governor in 1950.

The Bureau of Education on Fair Trade refused yesterday to act as a friend of the court in the current Federal Trade Commission action against Eastman Kodak Company. The refusal was contained in a letter to Stephen J. Spingarn, one of the Government agency's commissioners, from Maurice Mermey, bureau director.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 4 -- With France's seat vacant, the Political and Security Committee of the United Nations General Assembly began today its discussion of complaints by thirteen Asian and Arab states against the French administration of Tunisia.
SOUTHAMPTON, England, Dec. 4 (AP) -- The liner Queen Elizabeth arrived today with a dent in her side caused by a collision with a tug in New York harbor.
CHICAGO, Dec. 4 (AP) -- The Big Ten football coaches and athletic directors today called for more intensive spring football practice.

A NEW YORK TIMES editorial of Nov. 29, devoted to the efforts of the United Nations Assembly's Legal Committee to develop international criminal law and to establish a permanent criminal court, stresses the cynical approach of the Soviet delegation to the question of defining aggression.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- The bankrupt Long Island Rail Road's prospects are "more hopeful than ever before" because of an increase in passengers and a more level year-round operation instead of seasonal peaks, an Interstate Commerce Commission hearing on reorganizing the line was told today.

Clarification of the Tariff Act to eliminate over - technical and confusing import duty classifications will be advocated by foreign-trade groups as part of an import development program, members of the National Council of American Importers were told yesterday at the Astor Hotel.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Dec. 4 -- Students from fifty-one Eastern colleges and universities began round-table discussions tonight on the problem of formulating a United States policy for combating Soviet communism.

Washington Irving's Sleepy Hollow country echoed with Dutch hymns and tile hoofbeats of a white horse ridden by a red-robed, bearded St. Nicholas yesterday, as neighboring school children and townsfolk joined with a delegation from this city to honor St. Nicholas, the patron saint of Dutch Christmas giving.

BERLIN, Dec. 4 -- Maj. Gen. Lemuel Mathewson, United States commandant in Berlin, denied today Soviet charges that United States authorities had coerced a Soviet soldier into seeking asylum in the West. The United States commander offered to allow Soviet representatives to interview the man in question.

" We need only compare the books that youngsters were reading a century ago with the hundreds of wonderful ones published for them now to see how fortunate children are today and to see the great improvement made in this field," Miss Dorothy Leland, head of the Brooklyn Public Library's central children's room, said this week.

MEXICO CITY, Dec. 4 -- Remarkable parallels with the burial customs of ancient Egypt have been found in a newly discovered Mayan tomb at Palenque, a ruined city in the heart of Mexico's southern jungle, which archaeologists say has been deserted for at least a thousand years.

A picture of multimillion dollar steamship and stevedore corporations meekly accepting union-designated ex-convict pistol-toters as their pier bosses rather than risk work stoppage came out of yesterday's State Crime Commission hearing in the County Court Building.

The Chinatown Golden Age Center, the city's 'first venture in a recreation center for the elderly men of Chinatown, opened its doors to the public yesterday for an exhibition and sale of handicraft articles made ,by its members.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- Roswell L. Gilpatric, Under Secretary, reported today that the Air Force had achieved $2,000,000,000 of savings in its budget for the coming fiscal year as the result of an analysis of materiel requirements.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 (AP) -- The chairman of the Democratic National Committee told election law investigators today that the key to their problem was "a fair presentation of the opposite sides to the people."

Some items useful to the housekeeper of a century or more ago are displayed in the redecorated model rooms of Altman's Country Shop. The rooms, bedecked with Christmas presents and ornaments, are furnished with casual, provincial antique pieces from this country and Europe.

Many dinners were given last night in the Carnaval Room of the Sherry-Netherland before the performance of "An Evening With Beatrice Lillie" at the Booth Theatre that was taken over for the benefit of the Samaritan Home for the Aged.
A two-to-one election victory covering employes aboard the tugs and ferryboats of the Jersey Central Railroad was claimed yesterday by two American Federation of Labor maritime affiliates.

A great shoot was reported the other day in the French Presidential domain of Rambouillet. The bang-bang, or, as the French say, the pan-pan, was inordinate. One of the foremost expressions of conspicuous waste must, indeed, be that of the official shoot in Europe.

A three-member subcommittee of the State Board of Regents opened a hearing here yesterday to determine whether membership in the Communist party should disqualify person from holding any position in the state public school system.

An estimated $13,000,000 worth of free space and time is being contributed annually by virtually all types of media to promote the work of the Brand Names Foundation, it was said yesterday by John W. Hubbell, chairman of the board of the foundation.

Two unauthorized pier employes took letterheads of the United States Lines on two occasions and wrote letters pledging jobs for convicts on their later release from prison, the State Crime Commission was informed yesterday.

Recalling the shortage of blood that developed after the attack on Pearl Harbor on Dec. 7, 1941, when 960 men were reported seriously wounded, the Red Cross urged donors yesterday to help meet the monthly quota of 300,000 pints set by the Department of Defense.
HAVANA, Dec. 4 (AP) -- E. J. (Dutch) Harrison of Ardmore, Okla., fired a 7-under-par 65 today to take the halfway lead in the Havana invitation golf tournament with a 36-hole score of 133.

As a result of letters threatening workhouse sentences to 150 motorists who had run up five or more tickets for traffic violations, ninety - seven drivers appeared yesterday in Traffic Court and paid $10,074 in fines to avoid going to jail.

Prices of commodity futures were generally lower yesterday in dull trading on the New York exchanges. Cottonseed oil, soybean oil, hides, rubber, tin, zinc and wool closed lower. Cocoa and lead were higher and potatoes, sugar and coffee ended mixed.

A two-year agreement between the Paper Association of New York and Local 447, International Printing Pressmen's Union, A. F. L., ending a four-day strike, was announced yesterday by Irving R. Shapiro of the State Mediation Board.

Four teachers and a school clerk who refused to answer questions about alleged membership in the Communist party were served yesterday with charges and specifications relating to their suspension for insubordination and unbecoming conduct.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 4 -- A check for $423.90 was handed here today to a young widow who became the 5,000,000th person to receive a payment since the Social Security program went into effect in January, 1937, and first monthly benefits became payable in 1940.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 4 -- Arab-Israeli agreement to a new compromise formula for settling the Palestine dispute was sought today in a move that some quarters felt might be the first small break in the four-year-old impasse.
DENVER, Dec. 4 (AP) -- Hormones are being badly abused in treating some sex and mental problems, a psychiatrist declared today.
TRENTON, Dec. 4 -- Frank Erickson, metropolitan gambler charged with big time bookmaking in Bergen County, entered State Prison today to serve a 12-to-14-month sentence.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 4 -- Faculty members and students at Lincoln University were raising a $3,000 defense fund today for Rauel Mugo Gatheru, a student from Kenya, East Africa, who has been ordered to leave the country tomorrow or face deportation.

The renewed importance of the role of the lamp as a decorative element in a room, as well as a source of light, was apparent in a new collection of lamps designed by Kurt Versen and introduced here at Fabry Associates, 6 East Fifty-third Street, where they are available through decorators.

The stock market was headed for some sort of a corrective phase and it occurred yesterday, but in a milder form than expected. There was bound to he some simmering down in the post-election enthusiasm without any definite evidence from business and industrial circles that the pattern would be quickly altered.
Johnny Bratton of Chicago will be back in the main bout at Madison Square Garden tonight. The fast-punching battler will oppose Ralph (Tiger) Jones of Yonkers in a clash listed for ten rounds.
Shower curtains, draperies and similar products made of plastic materials have been running into store trouble in recent months.

LONDON, Dec. 4 -- The Soviet Union produced probably twice as many aircraft in 1951 as the United States will in 1952, according to estimates in the 1952-53 edition of Jane's All the World's Aircraft published today.

HARRIMAN, N. Y., Dec. 4 -- Many physicians are ignorant of the assistance the Public Health Nurse can give them in the care of their patients at home, Miss Ruth Fisher, director of the Department of Public Health Nursing of the National league for Nursing, said today.

The first man-carrying rocket into space, which, according to most estimates, will leave the earth before the end of the century, will be very poorly equipped to save crewmen in case of an accident, it was suggested here yesterday at the annual meeting of the American Rocket Society.

The Defense Department's inability to find a broader word than "casualty" to cover battle injuries has led it to eliminate total injuries from its weekly reports and to list, instead, the specific categories of dead, wounded and missing. Some persons had assumed that the term "casualty" meant death.

The American theatre is a theatre of motion while the foreign theatre is one of words. Abroad, the theatre competes with books; in America it competes with the movies. For this reason the American theatre "has to move faster than the movies while abroad it has to be more interesting than books."

One of the best of all the orchestral transcriptions of Bach that we know, Leo Wiener's instrumentation of the C major organ Toccata and Fugue, opened the Philharmonic-Symphony concert, directed by Mr. Mitropoulos, last night in Carnegie Hall. This arrangement is scored by a rarely competent, informed, and self-respecting musician, in a way that does not disguise or upholster the grand creation, but reveals and illuminates its essence.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 4 -- Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer has changed its mind about Ava Gardner's next picture. "The Ember Days," slated to be filmed this winter in Paris and Rome, now is somewhere off in the distant future and Miss Gardner's next assignment will be as Guinevere in "King Arthur and the Round Table."

A threat to call a strike yesterday, made by a small but important segment of the International Longshoremen's Association, A. F. L., after six months of futile negotiation for a new contract, brought quick action from city and Federal authorities.

The thirty-nine-family apartment house at 1205 Nelson Avenue, the Bronx, has been bought by Geisinger Rau, operators, from Isidore Sokolow. The property is assessed at $105,000. Mintz, Brown Parker, Inc., were the brokers in the sale.
DETROIT, Dec. 4 (UP) -- Marty Pavelich scored two goals tonight as the Detroit Red Wings beat the last-place New York Rangers, 5 -- 3, before 9,841 fans at Olympia.

Eggs were marked down from 4 to 8 cents a dozen yesterday, bringing them to the lowest level since last July and also the lowest for this time of the year since 1949. The only other price decreases were on two loin cuts of pork and one of veal. Fish prices rose from a nickel to 30 cents a pound on some half dozen species.

Governor Dewey, returning to New York last night from a Florida vacation, expressed confidence last night that Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the President-elect, would have harmonious relations with the Republican majorities in the Senate and House of Representatives.

DETROIT, Dec. 4 (AP) -- From a hospital bed, pitcher Virgil Trucks said today that because of his physical condition he might not report to the Browns, to whom he was traded by the Tigers in a six-player deal.

BERLIN, Dec. 4 -- The three Allied commandants in West Berlin protested today to Sergel A. Dengin, their Soviet opposite number, against yesterday's action by the East Berlin police, who virtually halted all motor traffic between the Eastern and Western parts of the city, as well as impounding a number of cars that entered the Soviet sector.

ALBANY, Dec. 4 -- The Temporary State Commission on Highway Financing held its first meeting today and was told that the state should spend $2,884,500,000 in the next ten years for "essential" rehabilitation of its highway system.

Industrial leaders were advised yesterday to impress upon the Eisenhower Administration the need for maximum production at the lowest possible cost to insure retention and expansion of the nation's social and economic gains.

A resolution welcoming Mayor Impellitteri's recent establishment of an interdepartmental Health Council and calling upon that body to work vigorously for economy and efficiency was adopted yesterday by the New York Chamber of Commerce at its December meeting at 65 Liberty Street.

A strike against The New York Daily News, scheduled to start at 2 A. M. today, was called off at 10 o'clock last night by the Newspaper Guild of New York after the newspaper and the union had reached an agreement on the terms for a new two-year contract. A negotiation session had begun at the Federal Mediation and Conciliation offices at 4 P. M.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 (AP) -- The Veterans Administration today gave a hint on what kind of Christmas presents not to give to its hospital patients.

Sites for two apartment houses in Brooklyn have been purchased by the Lefrak Organization of Forest Hills. A plot of 20,000 square feet at Ocean Parkway and Avenue L was acquired from the Nathans Realty Corporation through Abraham Randell, broker.

HOLLYWOOD BEACH, Fla., Dec. 4 -- The head of one of the world's largest insurance companies warned the nation's investment bankers here today that the proposed reshaping of the free world on the basis of "trade, not aid" will run into the "violent" opposition of business and labor groups -- "opposition of peculiar difficulty to the Republican party."
Brooklyn College, the team champion, and City College placed four men each on the 1952 all-star team selected yesterday by the Metropolitan Intercollegiate Soccer Coaches Association.

" Studio One," the prize drama program of the Columbia Broadcasting System, has been having its difficulties this season. Since the departure of Worthington Miner from the producing helm, the weekly Monday presentation has tended to flounder in rather trite seas.
The new C. I. O. president will have need of all his constructive qualities to heal the rift which divided his organization in its search for a successor to Philip Murray.

Some years ago when Walter P. Reuther was a vice president of the United Automobile Workers, C. I. O., one of his associates in a critical mood, said the red-haired labor leader had only three ambitions in life.

ALBANY, Dec. 4 -- The Court of Appeals upheld unanimously today the constitutionality of a New York City law requiring members of the police force to give thirty days notice before retiring on pensions. There was no opinion.

Manufacturers of "liquid hair net" preparations for women were warned yesterday by Fire Commissioner Jacob Grumet that these products must be withdrawn from sale here and re-labeled to show fire hazard or stocks of the commodity will be seized by the Fire Department "immediately."

Every third person one meets on the street has benefited in some way from the services of one or more participating agencies of the Greater New York Fund, 11 West Forty-second Street, New York 36. Each citizen of the community benefits indirectly whenever a family problem is solved, whenever a boy or girl is restored to society and whenever anyone is given a longed-for chance to become self-supporting.
TOKYO, Friday, Dec. 5 (AP) -United Nations Command communique 1,454, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M. Friday, Korea time:

CHICAGO, Dec. 4 (AP) -- Owners of nearly sixty night clubs in the Chicago metropolitan area barred entertainers last night in protest against a strike called by the American Guild of Variety Artists against four carbarets.

LONDON, Dec. 4 -- British Government securities fell today and in turn dragged down other stock markets. The weakness in gilt-edge securities was induced chiefly by suggestions that the mounting budgetary deficit precluded hopes of tax relief.

The International Confederation of Free Trade Unions announced yesterday that it wanted nothing to do with Democratie Combattante, an organization founded by Leon Jouhaux, winner of the Nobel peace prize last year.

BONN, Germany, Dec. 4 -- One of Germany's war heroes returned last night to harangue a group of more than 100 former Wehrmacht and Elite Guard officers about the "dangers" of the Allied-German treaty system and the "treason" of those officers who had plotted against Hitler.

ROME, Dec. 4 -- The repeatedly proclaimed Communist intention of shrinking from nothing to prevent approval by Parliament of the electoral reform proposed by the Government produced tonight one of the bitterest hand-to-hand fights on the floor of the Chamber in Italian parliamentary history.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- During the week ended Dec. 3, member bank reserves increased $22,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

LONDON, Dec. 4 -- R. A. Butler, Chancellor of the Exchequer, reported today that the British Commonwealth Prime Ministers' Conference, now about half-way through its two weeks of work, had "made good progress" in planning the economic future of the sterling area.

The American courts and lawyers should "not confuse sincere liberalism with communism" and should train themselves to distinguish between the two, Peter Campbell Brown, chairman of the Federal Subversive Activities Control Board, told members of the Brooklyn Bar Association last night.

HANOVER, N. H., Dec. 4 -- The Dartmouth undergraduate daily newspaper, started today a "Give Vermont Back to the Indians" campaign based on the claim of two members of the Iroquois tribe that they had a legal right to 2,225,000 acres of land embracing five counties on the western border of that state.

Seasonal influences increased New York bank loans to business additional $90,000,000 last week, pushing the total outstanding to $8,569,000,000, another new high. Major factors in the latest rise, according to data issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, were tobacco manufacturers, wholesale and retail trades, commodity dealers and sales finance companies.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- In the interval, happily shortened by the Twentieth Amendment, between the quadrennial November election and the beginning, a new Administration in this country the indications and rumors of change in executive policy and personnel fly thick and fast.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 4 (AP) -- Tony Despirito, the nation's No. 1 jockey, arrived at Tropical Park at 12:40 P. M. today to continue his campaign for an American record for winners in a single season.
MELBOURNE, Dec. 4 (AP) -- Vic Seixas and Frank Sedgman, the top tennis players of the United States and Australia, will meet in the final of the Victorian championships on Saturday.

WHEN Charles Dillon Stengel was managing Toledo in 1929, his diamond heroes were so busy plunging in the stock market -- this was just before The Crash -- that baseball was merely an incidental distraction to them. Instead of talking baseball, they discussed the market, to the monumental disgust of the Ol' Perfessor, a single-minded gent who always has been passionately devoted to the game.

As a rule, nobody is quite so much out of the news as a defeated Presidential candidate. Gov. Adlai Stevenson is an exception. Although a sizable majority of the American electorate decided they preferred another man for President, many do seem to have found in him a philosopher to whom they were and are willing to listen.

For some weeks it has been generally expected that John L. Lewis would get the full $1.90 increase he has been demanding for his miners' union. Such speculation as there has been on the issue has centered almost completely on how Mr. Truman would attempt to rationalize a course of action which would violate so flagrantly the Government's own wage-stabilization policies.

Buying was satisfactory at the Popular Price Shoe Show of America which closed its five-day run at the New Yorker and McAlpin Hotels yesterday. Many exhibitors, especially of women's shoes, reported production booked solid for delivery through the spring season.

Only one Knick seemed to have the knack of playing basketball, but Harry Gallatin alone could not carry the burden against the champion Minneapolis Lakers and the New York Knickerbockers dropped an 81-71 decision at Madison Square Garden last night. It was the first home defeat suffered by Joe Lapchick's squad this season and the first regular-season setback here since Nov. 29, 1951.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- Republican foes of wage and price controls have "changed their position" since the recent election, Michael V. DiSalle, first head of the Office of Price Stabilization, said today. Mr. DiSalle, who was called back last week from Toledo to counsel the Administration on its controls program, stated this view after a visit with President Truman at the White House.

The problem of agreeing on who is a commentator and who isn't is delaying the signing of new contracts between the major broadcasting chains and the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists, A. F. L.

Abraham Dor, chief engineer of the Israel Mining Industries, which is owned by the Israel Government, asserted yesterday that within five years his nation would be able to derive a gross income of $24,000,000 from the export of potash and phosphate throughout the world.

SPOKANE, Wash., Dec. 4 (AP) -- The Amateur Athletic Union's executive committee decided today to ask the sports-minded American public for half a million dollars to refill the A. A. U.'s shrunken purse and revitalize its program.

CHICAGO, Dec. 4 -- Decidedly mixed trends were noted in the Board of Trade operations in grain and soybean futures today. Corn, which has been the bull leader recently, was reactionary on the heavy profit-taking by longs, while wheat for a time showed marked strength, but only to sell off late in the session.

A report on the polygamous practices of a tribe of Cameroon natives will be published Dec. 29 by Doubleday under the title "The Fon and His Hundred Wives." The author is Rebecca Reyher, who made a trip from Lagos, on the Nigerian coast, into the heart of the English Cameroons where she spent several months with the Fon of Laakom, absolute ruler of the tribe. Mrs. Reyher is the author of "Zulu Woman."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- The increasing circulation of obscene writings and photography in the United States, House of Representatives investigators were told today, had encouraged an increase in importations of such material from European countries that tried to keep pace with, if not "go farther" than the American product.

BONN, Germany, Dec. 4 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer and the coalition parties decided today to postpone until next year ratification of the Bonn peace contract with the Western Allies and the European Defense Community Treaty.

Emphasizing his interest in junior golf, William B. Kuntz of the Branie Briar Country Club, Larchmont, assumed the post as president of the Westchester County Golf Association at the organization's annual meeting yesterday at the Hotel Roosevelt.
FORT WORTH, Tex., Dec. 4 -- L. R. (Dutch) Meyer, who believed passing was the ideal way to pay dirt, today stepped down as coach at Texas Christian University after nineteen years.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 4 -- A national income higher than the present rate of $288,200,000,000 and a gross national product higher than the present "unheard-of figure of $344,000,000,000" were forecast for 1953 by Ellsworth C. Alvord, Washington, D. C., a tax authority, in an address today at the annual meeting of the California State Chamber of Commerce.

TOKYO, Friday, Dec. 5 -- Communist China's Air Force sent its Russian-designed MIG's south of the Manchurian border in some force yesterday and lost one to United States F-86 Sabre jets patrolling Northwest Korea.

Public offering of 100,000 shares of Circle Wire and Cable Corporation's common stock at $22 a share will be made today by an under writing group headed by Van Alstyne, Noel Co. and Hornblower Weeks. The stock being offered is issued and outstanding. It represents no new financing by the company but is being sold on behalf of certain stockholders.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Dec. 4 -- The contract bridge team of Oswald Jacoby of Dallas, Tex., Samuel Stayman, New York, Charles H. Goren, Charles Solomon, and Sidney Silodor, all of Philadelphia, this afternoon won the men's Team of four championship, the second event in the winter session of the twenty-sixth annual National Contract Bridge Championships.
LONDON, Dec. 4 -- A good time was had by all in the House of Commons tonight. The members enjoyed a jolly evening at the favorite sport of party politicians, berating one another.

Marisa Regules, who last night gave her first local piano recital in five seasons, played with considerably more maturity than she has ever before shown. Even at her debut in 1941 there never was any doubt about her natural aptitude for the keyboard. But her musical conceptions left something to be desired, whereas last night they suggested that Miss Regules is well on her way toward a realization of her potentialities.

BOSTON, Dec. 4 (UP) -- With Ed Sandford setting the score-a-period pace, the Boston Bruins ended the league-leading Chicago Black Hawks' unbeaten streak at five games tonight when they turned in a 5-1 victory at the Boston Garden.

City College students and faculty members will hold the first all-college conference in the institution's 105-year history this month to make recommendations for future school policies, Dr. Buell G. Gallagher, the president, announced yesterday.

Prominent women are active in the plans for the performance of "La Boheme" in English on the afternoon of Dec. 27 at the Metropolitan Opera House to raise funds for the Institute for the Crippled and Disabled.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Dec. 4 -- Dr. Laureano Vallenilla Lanza, new Minister of the Interior, in a radio speech today said the Government "will respect the principles of the Republic," that the election results must be accepted or, "in the contrary case, "the only way to object is as indicated by the law."

Following are excerpts from testimony at yesterday's public hearing of the State Crime Commission. Witnesses included steamship, stevedore and trucking executives and union officials. The questioning was by members of the commission's legal staff.

ALTHOUGH it is rather difficult for an archer to claim he "didn't know it was loaded," one of these modern refugees from Sherwood Forest has a five-point buck that would be browsing the New Jersey woods right now if a bowstring hadn't slipped.

Syracuse University yesterday was named the 1952 winner of the August V. Lambert Memorial Trophy, presented each year to the college football team voted the strongest in the East by a panel of sports writers and broadcasters.

Rodger P. Stewart, 70-year-old eccentric who was found dead Wednesday night in a $25-a-month Queens furnished room that held $250,000 in cash and stock, was pictured last night as a man who carried around a $10,000 bill as a "conversation piece" and, at the same time, pleaded he was too poor to pay the costs of a law suit.

CHICAGO, Dec. 4 -- Elimination of the excess profits tax and a "severe revision" of the capital gains law in 1953 was predicted tonight by J. K. Lasser, chairman of New York University's Institute of Federal Taxation and a New York City certified public accountant.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 (AP) -- The Defense Department today idetified 145 service men killed, wounded, injured or missing in the Korean war. The new list included 25 killed, 114 wounded, 4 injured in accidents, and 2 missing. The following were listed from New York and New Jersey (none from Connecticut):
PHOENIX, Ariz., Dec. 4 (UP) -- George Trautman, president of the minor leagues, made a strong appeal to the majors today to "give us a little help before you destroy us."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- President Truman accepted tonight the resignation of Archibald Cox as chairman of the Wage Stabilization Board and named Charles C. Killingsworth, vice chairman, to succeed him.
LONDON, Dec. 4 -- A plan to release idle dock workers for other jobs was announced today by the National Dock Labor Board.
WATERTOWN, N. Y., Dec. 4 -- Navigation on the St. Lawrence River will be closed at midnight tomorrow to Atlantic-bound ships seeking to enter the Canadian canal system at Cardinal, Ont.

SAIGON, Indo-China, Dec. 4 (AP) -- The French high command disclosed today that mortar fire from Communist-led Vietminh rebel troops had damaged the airstrip in the besieged northwest Indo-China keypoint of Nasan but said French union troops later drove the guerrillas back.
TOKYO, Friday, Dec. 5 -- Okinawa-based B-29's braved 100-mile-an-hour winds early today and blasted Communist targets on Manchuria's doorstep for the second day in a row.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- President Truman, who has scolded the newspapers of the country on numerous occasions, had a good word today for the typically American institution of the press conference.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 (AP) -- The Defense Department today idetified 145 service men killed, wounded, injured or missing in the Korean war. The new list included 25 killed, 114 wounded, 4 injured in accidents, and 2 missing. The following were listed from New York and New Jersey (none from Connecticut):
PHOENIX, Ariz., Dec. 4 (UP) -- George Trautman, president of the minor leagues, made a strong appeal to the majors today to "give us a little help before you destroy us."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- President Truman accepted tonight the resignation of Archibald Cox as chairman of the Wage Stabilization Board and named Charles C. Killingsworth, vice chairman, to succeed him.
LONDON, Dec. 4 -- A plan to release idle dock workers for other jobs was announced today by the National Dock Labor Board.

The New Orleans Terminal Company sold an $8,000,000 issue of 3 3/4 per cent first mortgage bonds, due on Nov. 1, 1977, to Kidder, Peabody Co. and White, Weld Co. and associates yesterday at a net interest cost of 3.8124 per cent.
Cardinal Spellman announced yesterday he would leave for Korea on Dec. 17 to spend his second successive Christmas season with the fighting forces in that country.

New York City will not have the largest convention hall in the world when the new Coliseum in the Columbus Circle area is completed, but Commissioner Moses' tentative plans suggest that, wher. all the advantages are combined, the city will be in an excellent competitive position.

ATLANTIC CITY, Dec. 4 -- Glenn E. Knaub, of the P. J. Ritter Company, Bridgeton, N. J., was elected president of the Tri-State Packers Association here today to succeed Samuel E. W. Friel of Queenstown, Md., who was named director-at-large.

LONDON, Dec. 4 -- Prime Minister Churchill told the House of Commons today that the Government had decided that to keep the defense production program within Britain's means in the face of rising costs "some curtailment involving the cancellation or modification of contracts already placed" would be necessary.

" Scores" of common stock issues listed on the New York Stock Exchange are now selling for "less than the per share equivalent of the company's working capital, well below the post-war high and only moderately above the post-war low," according to an article in the current issue of The Exchange, magazine published by the trading institution.

In the heyday of the Austrian Empire, we learn in a cook book published today, there were as many strains of cooking as there were languages. That was a good many indeed, for, under Francis Joseph I. Emperor from 1848 to 1916, sixteen languages were spoken.

LONDON, Dec. 4 -- Dr. Grayson Kirk. Vice President and Provost of Columbia University, spent today conferring with British leaders in the field of education and culture, seeking their participation in the university's bicentennial in 1954.

ENGLEWOOD, N. J., Dec. 4 -- A crate of four dozen snowballs, packed in dry ice, was prepared by Mayor M.
