Leslie Denning of this city today for shipment by plane from LaGuardia Airport at 9 o'clock tomorrow morning to Mayor George C. England of Inglewood, Calif., in payment for losing a get-out-the-vote contest between the two cities.

THE idea of a dual personality is an ancient one. German literature and German national thought are full of it. The idea appears frequently in English and American fiction also -- in Poe's "William Wilson," in Stevenson's "Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde" and in Wilde's "The Picture of Dorian Gray." But such supernatural fantasies are designed to dramatize a symbolical concept about extremes of good and evil.

SEATTLE, Dec. 4 (AP) -- British concerns have underbid American competitors twice this week for large electrical equipment, transformers and generators, for the big Chief Joseph Dam on the Columbia River in central Washington.
PHOENIX, Ariz., Dec. 4 -- The tempo of the baseball meetings suddenly roared to a whirlwind pace today as both major and minor leaguers plunged into the spotlight.
George Hunter, who went hunting on Hunters Island off Orchard Beach in tile Bronx, where hunting is not allowed, was accorded justice that was literally poetic yesterday.

Importing artists' materials would seem like a peaceful, if not a big money-making, business. Not in the present state of the world. There's trouble about those small hairs on the end of artists' paint brushes, and it's being had by a New York importer.

Dr. David B. Steinman, engineer and bridge builder, was inducted last night as president of the New York Academy of Sciences at the 135th annual meeting of the organization, held in its headquarters, 2 East Sixty-third Street. Dr. Steinman, who has served as designing and consulting engineer in the construction of bridges on five continents, received this year the highest award of the National Society of Professional Engineers for professional achievements.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 4 -- The Chinese delegation to the United Nations will ask the General Assembly in plenary session tomorrow to revise in the Chinese language text of the genocide convention, the meaning of the word "genocide."

The Associated Dry Goods Corporation, which operates a chain of eight department stores, among which are Lord Taylor and James McCreery here, showed improved sales for the quarter and twelve months ended last Nov. 1, but little change in earnings from the corresponding periods a year ago.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended last Saturday totaled 670,167 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 140,755 cars, or 17.4 per cent fewer than for the preceding week; 151,609 cars, or 18.4 per cent fewer than for the corresponding week last year, and 69,998 cars, or 9.5 per cent fewer than during the corresponding week two years ago.

The new spirit of American capitalism, a far cry from "the-public-be-damned" attitude of some business leaders of the past, was expressed clearly this week at the National Association of Manufacturers Congress of American Industry. There speaker after speaker warned business against attempting to turn back the clock or interpreting the Republican election victory as a green light to exploit labor, consumers or foreign countries.

The scene for the allegedly treasonable acts of John David Provoo shifted yesterday from the Philippines to the island of Formosa, as a witness accused the former Army sergeant of friendliness with his Japanese captors and of bragging that he was now "in the driver's seat."

The Board of Estimate unanimously adopted yesterday a 1953 capital budget of $432,279,993 and sent it to the City Council for consideration at a meeting next Tuesday. The City Council has no power to increase the amount but may reduce it by deleting items.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 (AP) -- Eastern Air Lines said today that it had withdrawn its resignation from the Air Transport Association. There was no comment, but the action apparently ended a dispute involving Robert Ramspeck, chairman of the Federal Civil Service Commission.

Longshoremen in their work-shirts and dungarees who attended yesterday's hearing of the State Crime Commission blinked in amazement as a stevedore executive told how he had donated $11,000 last year to Michael Clemente, East Side dock union boss, to pay for the wedding of the labor leader's daughter at the Biltmore Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- A Judiciary subcommittee of the House of Representatives called today for "drastic measures" to end "fee-splitting, bribe-taking and double-dealing" by lawyers in the Department of Justice.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 4 -- Argentina's atomic energy project has exploded with the force of a bursting soap bubble, it appeared today. According to engineers who had been engaged on the top secret project, all the 300 workers in Argentina's atomic energy pilot plant on Huemel Island at San Carlos de Bariloche have been dismissed.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 4 -- The Russians have made known their first choice for Secretary General of the United Nations: Stanislaw Skrzeszewski, the Foreign Minister of Poland.
Johnny Bratton would be well advised to confine his activities to the welterweight ranks and discard his announced plan of bidding for the world middleweight title.

Mr. and Mrs. James Todd of Bedford Village, N. Y., and Faraway, Edgartown, Mass., and Mr. and Mrs. Edward Leffingwell Smith of 17 East Ninety-sixth Street and Red Knoll, West Redding, Conn., jointly will give a dinner dance on Dec. 23 in the Colony Club to introduce to society their respective daughters, Miss Louise Livingston Todd and Miss Charlotte Allison Smith.

Five manufacturers of "liquid hair net" preparations for women informed Fire Commisisoner Jacob Grumet yesterday that they would comply with his order that labels on containers of the compound give prominent display to warnings of fire hazards in their use.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- Frank M. Kaneski, a Duluth (Minn.) inventor, contends that "the only useful purpose known for a cow's tail is to keep flies off of her, and there are no flies during the winter months." In addition to getting in the way during milking, the appendage is, in his opinion, in-sanitary.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- Gov. Sherman Adams of New Hampshire, who will be Assistant to the President in the Eisenhower Administration, paid today what he called a housekeeping reconnaissance visit to the White House. He was accompanied by Arthur H. Vandenberg Jr., who will be the President's secretary after Jan 20.
BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 5 (AP) -- The Director of Argentina's National Atomic Energy Commission denied today that Dr. Ronald Richter, supervisor of this country's atomic pilot plant, had been arrested.

William E. Buchanan, president and treasurer of the Appleton Wire Works, Inc. of Wisconsin, has been elected a director of the Allis-Chalmers Manufacturing Company, it was announced yesterday by W. A. Roberts, president. Mr. Buchanan succeeds Edmund Fitzgerald of Milwaukee, president of the Northwestern Mutual Life Insurance Company, who has resigned from the board.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Dec. 5 -- The release today of official attendance figures for both leagues in 1952 did not serve to put the baseball club owners in extra fine humor, as they opened their meetings. For these revealed that both circuits had suffered losses of approximately 11 per cent from their 1951 levels.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- Stephen J. Spingarn, Federal Trade Commissions, rebuked the Bureau of Education for Fair Trade today for what he described as an "attempt to substitute political pressure for decisions of a quasi-judicial Federal agency."

SPOKANE, Wash., Dec. 5 (AP) -Ford Konno of Hawaii and Ohio State University was named five times on the All-America men's swimming team announced today by the swimming committee of the Amateur Athletic Union.

PARIS, Dec. 5 -- The mutilated body of Farhat Hached, Tunisian labor leader and chief strategist of the Tunisian nationalists in their effort to wrest home rule concessions from the French protectors of Tunisia, was found today beside a road near Tunis. He was the victim of unidentified assassins.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 (AP) -- The estimated net income of the nation's Class I railroads was lower in October than in the same month last year, but figures for the first ten months showed improvement over the like period of 1951.

COLLEGE PARK, Md., Dec. 5 (AP) -- An editorial in the Diamond-back, University of Maryland student newspaper, today criticized its president, Dr. H. C. Byrd, for his remarks about Coach Jim Tatum after the football team lost its last two games.

WITH U. S. THIRD DIVISION, in Korea, Dec. 4 (AP) -- President-elect Dwight D. Eisenhower side-stepped the generals today and ate Army chow with three awed United States soldiers seated in the icy open. He cleaned up a meal of grilled pork chop, sauerkraut and pie with evident relish.

Chlorophyll compounds sold to be taken by mouth for deodorizing cannot be as effective as some advertisers claim and there is a serious possibility that they may be harmful if taken in large quantities, it was suggested last night.

The Nash-Kelvinator Corporation and its subsidiaries, producers of the Nash passenger automobile and a line of electric household and commercial appliances, reported yesterday reduced sales and earnings for the fiscal year ended last September.

IT must be nearly twenty years since Francis Yeats-Brown, the "Lives of a Bengal Lancer" man, brought out his bulky treasury of celebrated escapes, hospitably including Daniel among the lions of Darius and Casanova's Venetian escapade. When that book, "Escape," appeared, antiquarians tell me, the critical scuffle over "escape literature" still seemed comparatively fresh and new.

QUEBEC, Dec. 5 -- Discovery of a multi-million ton iron ore deposit in Ungava -- possibly bigger than the vast deposit now being operated by Iron Ore Company of Canada -- is reported by Cyrus S. Eaton, Canadian-born United States Financier.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 (AP) -- Paul A. Walker, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, proposed today that the Government license radio and television networks as protection for individual stations. He also urged a ban on radio and television advertising of "hard liquor," but said he had no suggestions to make about the advertising of beer.
Frank J. Sinnott, Democratic leader of Kings County, announced last night he was recommending the election of Richard H. Balch of Utica as the new chairman of the Democratic State Committee.

Two eminences, the one titanic, the other puckish, will be bowing to one another across the terrace of the American Academy of Arts and Letters beginning today in a gracious harmony based on the circumstance that both have been honorably associated with this institution.

I. Robert Bassin, Assistant to the Borough President of Queens, appeared briefly yesterday morning in Queens County Court before County Judge William B. Broad and seventeen members of the holdover June, 1952, Grand Jury, which is investigating the Laurelton sewer scandal.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- Dan A. Kimball, the Secretary of the Navy, struck back tonight at a series of official and semi-official Air Force statements that had criticized naval aviation and the role of aircraft carriers in defense strategy.

The superliner United States, flagship of the United States Lines' fleet, has passed her inspection under the builder's six-month guarantee without the need for one more major alteration or replacement, it was announced yesterday by the Newport News Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company.
CAMDEN, N. J., Dec. 5 -- The 13,319-ton transport Upshur of the United States Maritime Service returned here today after having successfully completed official machinery trials off Lewes, Del.

It was recently reported in THE TIMES that New York City employe organizations are counting on the "probability" of state employes receiving a wage increase to buttress their demands for a similar raise from the city administration.

The Board of Higher Education and the Board of Education received in a State Supreme Court decision yesterday, approval of an additional weapon in their drive to rid the city's educational system of subversive elements.

President-elect Eisenhower has now taken a hard personal look at the ugly face of the frozen war in Korea and has come away with a firmer grasp of the situation in the Far East and a better picture of its political, military and economic possibilities. He went as close to the front lines as considerations of security would permit.

BONN, Saturday, Dec. 6 -- The Allied German treaties restoring a rearmed and sovereign West Germany to the European community were endorsed by the Federal Bundestag early this morning in a vote that brought final ratification a step nearer.
A pair of deadly passers, one of the nation's leading ground gainers and a triple threat star make up the attacking unit on the 1952 All-America football team named yesterday by The Associated Press.
One airline strike was ended yesterday while another started.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 (AP) -- The Defense Department ruled today that its Public Information Office would be the only releasing agency in the department for information on the military applications of atomic energy, guided missiles and new weapons.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 5 -- A comprehensive program for advancing land reform in the world at a faster rate was adopted unanimously today by the United Nations General Assembly's Economic and Financial Committee.

Major producers of rayon viscose yarn will conduct a combined promotion campaign for the fiber, it was learned yesterday. Plans for the campaign are still in the discussion stage, but there is agreement among the manufacturers that the product needs a promotional lift to better its competitive position in the textile industry.
HAVANA, Dec. 5 (AP) -- Dutch Harrison of Little Rock, Ark., took a commanding lead today in the Havana invitation open golf tournament by firing a third-round 68 for fifty-four-hole total of 201.

Roomier bodies mounted on longer wheelbase chassis are offered in 1953 line of cars presented yesterday by Pontiac division, General Motors Corporation. Other improvements include increased steering and riding ease and more power in the six-cylinder engine.

The Columbia Broadcasting System's television network is becoming increasingly concerned as to how to combat the commercial program competition of two other networks in the Tuesday evening time period from 8 to 9 o'clock.

MANHASSET, L. I., Dec. 5 -Clerks at the newest and largest Arnold Constable branch store, ready for Christmas shoppers in the center of a residential area of 500,000 population, have handled 3,000 customers daily since the official opening ceremonies last Monday morning.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- A book and magazine distributor told the House of Representatives investigators today that publishers were demanding in their contracts that lurid literature be accepted for sale along with their most highly reputable products.
The Voice of America broadcast yesterday as part of its Far East English Service a program in celebration of the largest postwar deal involving American capital investment in Japanese industry.

SEOUL, Korea, Saturday, Dec. 6 (AP) -- Dozens of United Nations planes smashed at Chinese Communist positions on the "Sniper Ridge" sector of the Korean central front yesterday for the third Straight day.

In a move designed to add blocking and defensive strength for their game with the Washington Redskins at the Polo Grounds tomorrow, the New York Football Giants yesterday returned Pat Knight to active status.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 5 -- Secretary General Trygve Lie, as part of a new policy to oust active American Communists and all "subversives" from his staff, has quietly asked the United States to give him the names and testimony of all United Nations employes denounced as disloyal by a Federal grand jury.

The American Chemical Society, which includes nearly all the chemists of the country, has created the Charles Lathrop Parsons award for "outstanding public service." There are good reasons why chemists should recognize public service and why Dr. Charles Lathrop Parsons should be the first to receive tonight the award named for him.

The Tennessee Valley Authority is one of the most successful of the Rooseveltian experiments. It is hard to find anybody in the Valley, including business men, who will say anything against T. V. A. Most Valley citizens will probably agree with the statement of T. V. A. Chairman Gordon R. Clapp, in a speech at Knoxville, that this federally owned power system ought to be expanded.
ATLANTIC CITY, Dec. 5 -- Walter P. Reuther decided today to make abolition of Government wage controls his first goal as president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations.

Figures for production and sales of sports shirts have been exaggerated because of poor definitions and manufacturers have been misled in planning production, according to M. J. Lovell, director-counsel of the National Association of Shirt, Pajama and Sportswear Manufacturers.

Walter P. Chrysler Jr., major backer of the successful revue "New Faces of 1952," has joined forces with Sam Lambert for the production of "Say It With Flowers." This is the Robert Moore adaptation of the Jean Guitton French comedy, "Je L'Amais Trop," which scored in the French and German capitals.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 5 -- South Africa failed in a last-minute maneuver today to forestall United Nations approval of measures aimed at the race-segregation policy of the Malan Government.

A witness at the treason trial of John David Provoo was prevented yesterday by a Federal judge from repeating the strong pro-Nazi sympathies the defendant allegedly expressed to her, but Assistant United States Attorney Moses L. Kove had them introduced into the trial record in the absence of the jury.

Lumber production for the week ended Nov. 29 was 9.2 per cent below the like week last year according to reports received yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES from regional associations. Shipments were down 10.6 per cent and orders were up 6 per cent. Following are the weekly statistics in thousands of board feet:

The annual Christmas tea at the Studio Club of the Young Women's Christian Association, 210 East Seventy-seventh Street, will be held on Wednesday afternoon. Mrs. G. Allen Hopkins is chairman of the committee for the tea.

The ten-story building at 101 West Eightieth Street and 420 Columbus Avenue, containing four stores and fifty-nine apartments, has been sold by Gus R. and Esther N. Roberts to the Friedsel Realty Corporation, represented by Lawrence I. Gerber, attorney.

The National City Bank of New York yesterday announced a profit-sharing plan for all eligible personnel of its organization and subsidiaries. More than 13,000 persons are employed by the institution. The plan, which will be submitted for stockholder approval at the bank's annual meeting on Jan. 13 next year, is designed to supplement the bank's retirement, group insuranceand hospitalization plans.

BIRMINGHAM, Eng., Dec. 5 (AP) -- The Austin Motor Company announced today it has signed a seven-year agreement with the Nissan Motor Company of Japan under which 2,000 Austin cars will be assembled every year in Nissan's Yokohama factory for the Japanese market.

SEOUL, Korea, Dec. 5 -- The elaborate security precautions for President-elect Dwight D. Eisenhower's Korean tour prevented most Koreans and the vast majority of the United Nations fighting men as well as most of the world from the certain knowledge "Ike" was on the war-racked peninsula.
BERLIN, Dec. 5 -- At two separate meetings, East Germany's leading Communists have called for the stepping up of revolutionary activity in both parts of the country.

This morning children in the Netherlands were out of bed early to see the gifts St. Nicholas left in the wooden shoes they set by the fireplace last night. Most certainly the youngsters found plenty of speculaas, crisp cookies spiced with cloves, cinnamon and nutmeg and containing citron and almonds.

It was a relief to read your editorial on the appointment of Martin P. Durkin of Chicago as Secretary of Labor. The reaction of Senator Taft, while deplorable in the seeming loss of the sweetness and light that has up to now prevailed in Republican ranks, nevertheless has left this writer a trifle cold.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 (AP) -- The Public Power and Water Corporation of Trenton applied to the Federal Power Commission today for a license for a hydroelectric project in the International Rapids section of the St. Lawrence River near Massena, N. Y.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 5 -- A 2-year-old fawn dog. Ch. Mazelaines Keynote, owned by Robert and Florence Corregan of Newton, Mass., and handled by Jane Kemp, was the winner tonight of the Eastern Boxer Club specialty, which drew 102 dogs to Town Hall.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- Completing a fifteen-months' investigation into operations of the Securities and Exchange Commission, a House sub-committee today found the agency had done "a pretty good job" in protecting the public and investors but criticized the Commission's actions in five major cases.
Mrs. Dwight D. Eisenhower go her first news of the President elect's safe arrival at and departure from Korea in a 7 o'clock radio news broadcast yesterday morning.
CAMP KILMER, N. J., Dec. 5 -- Kentucky holly will deck the halls of this sprawling Army post, and, in exchange, a poor Kentucky family will have a well supplied Christmas party.

WITH GEN. EISENHOWER, Aboard U. S. S. Helena off Guam, Saturday, Dec. 6 (AP) -- President-electDwight D. Eisenhower completed a three-day close-hand inspection of the Korean war situation last night, flew to Guam today and boarded the heavy cruiser Helena. On the leisurely trip home, he will study the information he gathered.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 (UP) -Retail food prices declined slightly between Nov. 15 and Nov. 24 with meats, fresh fruits, vegetables and eggs setting the pace, the Department of Labor reported today.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 5 -- Neutral powers, pushing a compromise plan for settling the Arab-Israeli Palestine dispute, reported tonight that only one point still remained a stumbling-block.

SEOUL, Saturday, Dec. 6 (AP) -President-elect Dwight D. Eisenhower, in a letter to President Syngman Rhee of South Korea, praised him and his countrymen for "their march toward the great goal of freedom." The South Korean Government made public the letter today.

ATLANTIC CITY, Dec. 5 -- The Nation's cigar industry is enjoying its best year in a decade with total retail sales for 1952 expected to reach a volume of $560,000,000 as the result of the production and sale of more than 6,000,000,000 cigars.

Mrs. David Willock Wallace, the former Madge Gates, who died yesterday at the home of her daughter, Mrs. Harry Truman, in Washington, never cared for personal publicity. At the age of 90 she seems to have had great interest in life but no vanity and no pretentiousness.

John A. Burke, conciliator assigned by the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service to the contract dispute between the American Weighmasters Association and three locals of the International Longshoremen's Association, said yesterday that separate meetings with employers and the union would be held next week.
The following is a round-up of new products that may be of interest to the homemaker.

The Arab peoples, deserving of friendship and aid from all Americans, are scarcely befriended or helped by the kind of letter which appeared in the Dec. 2 issue over the signature of T. Robert Bassett. His statement, regrettably, evidences a lamentable lack of factual accuracy and Christian charity, attributes we might reasonably expect of an American educator in a Middle East school.

HACKENSACK, N. J., Dec. 5 -- Superior Court Judge J. Wallace Leyden today sentenced Police Chief Henry Witte of Lodi to six months in jail and imposed a fine of $2,000 for having failed to suppress gambling in his community. But, the judge added, he is not happy over the sentence.

CHICAGO, Dec. 5 (UP) -- Commissioner Kenneth L. (Tug) Wilson revealed to the Big Ten winter meeting today that "penalties" have been invoked on member institutions during the past year for violation of the conference rules on recruiting and aid to athletes.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 5 -- A spokesman for the French delegation to the General Assembly, speaking in the name of the French Government, said tonight that it was shocked by the "bloody, foul, criminal murder of M. Hached." He gave a formal denial that the French Government had given protection, or attempted to give protection to the murderer.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was barely steady yesterday and closed 8 to 17 points net lower than on Thursday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- Average primary market prices increased 0.2 per cent over the week ended last Tuesday to 110.2 per cent of the 1947-49 average, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. Farm products increased 0.9 per cent largely because of higher prices for livestock, grains and some fresh fruits and vegetables.
Getting enough extra employes to handle the Christmas rush this year has been a tough problem forretailers in the metropolitan area.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 (AP) -- The railroads have hauled more iron ore since the end of the steel strike last summer than in any similar period, the Association of American Railroads reported today.

What happens on New York's waterfront is everybody's business because, in this city of the sea, commerce affects directly or indirectly the welfare of millions of people. The testimony developed by the New York State Crime Commission which has been spread on the record in daily installments so voluminously this week is, therefore, of great concern.
CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 5 (UP) -- Tony DeSpirito mantained his average of a winner a day when he piloted Prize Ring to victory today in the featured Flavonius Purse at Tropical Park.

Paced by Dick Duckett and Frank Giancontieri who tallied 18 and 14 points respectively, St. John's University opened its 1952-53 basketball campaign last night by conquering Roanoke College of Salem, Va., 72 -- 55, in the De Gray Gymnasium in Brooklyn.
WITH GENERAL EISENHOWER, in Korea, Dec. 4 (UP) -- The President-elect moved soberly past rows of cots in the hospital, his head bared, his hat in his hand, and looked at the faces of the hurt men.

TOKYO, Dec. 5 -- Japanese Government circles made little effort today to conceal their obvious disappointment at the failure of United States President-elect Dwight D. Eisenhower to stop even briefly in Japan during his visit to the Far East.

HARRIMAN, N. Y., Dec. 5 -- Regardless of the change in the National Administration, recurring inflation and its long-term effects will be a problem of the American people "for some time to come," Dr. Philip Young, Dean of the Graduate School of Business at Columbia University, declared tonight.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 (AP) -- Relations between the Truman and Eisenhower Administrations in the field of foreign policy for the next six weeks have now been clarified in talks between John Foster Dulles and top State Department officials.

The metropolitan college basketball season hits full stride tonight as the initial twin bill of the season is staged at Madison Square Garden and more than a dozen other quintets see action in near-by gymnasiums. Local quintets taking part in the curtain raiser at the Garden are Iona and New York University which face Siena and Boston College, respectively, to launch the nineteenth consecutive campaign at the big arena.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- Secretary of State Dean Acheson has summoned Edwin A. Locke Jr., special coordinator on economic and technical assistance in the Near East with the rank of Ambassador, for consultation on "obvious differences of viewpoint" on United States aid to that area.

SEOUL, Korea, Dec. 5 (UP) -Recommendations looking to all-out war in Korea if there is no peace by spring were laid before President-elect Dwight D. Eisenhower by United States military authorities and Korean officials during his visit.

LONDON, Dec. 5 -- British shipyards have enough work on hand, including the 3,900,000 tons for British owners, to keep them busy for the next four years, J. A. Boyd-Carpenter told the House of Commons today.

ALBANY, Dec. 5 -- The State Court of Appeals upheld today the authority of a Russian commission in Moscow to arbitrate a contract dispute between a Philadelphia company and the Soviet Government's trade agency in this country.

Soccer, the national game of the Soviet Union has fallen upon evil days in that country and only a major change of players and tactics can save the day, the Young Communist League newspaper, Komsomolskaya Pravda, has declared in a sharply worded indictment.

Jose Limon and his company, with Doris Humphrey as artistic director, last night gave the first of a series of six performances at the Juilliard Concert Hall, divided between this week-end and next, and made the journey up to Claremont Avenue even on a rainy night seem a small price indeed to pay.

HOLLYWOOD BEACH, Fla., Dec. 5 -- Ewing T. Boles, president of the Ohio Company of Columbus, was installed as president of the Investment Bankers Association of America here today at the final convention meeting of the association at the Hollywood Beach Hotel.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 5 -- Lester B. Pearson, president of the General Assembly, sent tonight by cable to Communist China and North Korea the proposals contained in India's compromise resolution on a Korean armistice, adopted by the Assembly Wednesday.
SEOUL, Korea, Dec. 5 (UP) -Following is the text of President-elect Dwight D. Eisenhower's remarks to the press here today:

PHOENIX, Ariz., Dec. 5 -- Fred Saigh, owner of the Cardinals who seems to have a penchant for gaining his objectives, was seen to have achieved another signal victory today when the Cubs aceeded to the St. Louis club demands for a share of radio and television receipts when the Redbirds play in Chicago.
SOMEWHERE IN KOREA, Dec. 4 (AP) -- Dwight D. Eisenhower today met the South Korean army. They liked each other.

SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Dec. 5 -- Walter Dukes, 6-11 center, scored 27 points last night to raise his three-year varsity total to 1,009 as he led Seton Hall to a 79-67 victory over Loyola College of Baltimore at the Seton Hall gymnasium.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 (UP) -- Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois ended a two-day White House visit today after conferring with Secretary of the Interior Oscar L. Chapman and top officials of Americans for Democratic Action.

CHICAGO, Dec. 5 -- Dr. George Stoddard, president of the University of Illinois, was named today chairman of the board of directors of a new non-profit corporation formed to develop and circulate programs for educational television stations throughout the nation. The organization, with headquarters in Chicago, is the Educational TV and Radio Center.

A new patented process for dyeing wool was offered yesterday to the textile industry without royalty. The Victor Chemical Works of Chicago, in making the gift known at a meeting of the American Association of Textile Chemists and Colorists in Lowell, Mass., last night, said it would improve efficiency, cut production costs and make for a better product.
SEOUL, Korea, Dec. 5 (AP) -- Following is the text of the United Nations command communique on President-elect Dwight D. Eisenhower's trip:

MIAMI BEACH, Dec. 5 -- As the third and final session of the open team of four championship gets under way tonight here, the contract bridge team of Mrs. Henry Kemp, Tobias Stone, both of New York, Alvin Roth of Washington and Harry Harkavy of Miami Beach continue to lead a fifty-one-team field.

To help meet requests for tickets to "This Is Cinerama" during the holiday season, a series of seven additional performances has been scheduled at the Broadway Theatre between Christmas and New Year's Day. The extra show ings will be at 5:30 P. M. on Dec. 25, 26, 29, 30 and Jan. 1, and at 10:40 A. M. and 11:40 P. M. on Dec. 31.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 (AP) -- A special House investigation of election laws ended today with Republican and Democratic campaign directors agreeing on one point -- that the national committees should be allowed to spend more money.
Two members of the notorious Anastasia family of Brooklyn yesterday put stumbling blocks to the State Crime Commission's investigation into waterfront conditions in the Port of New York.

ALBANY, Dec. 5 -- The Court of Appeals cleared the way today for resumption of Public Service Commission proceedings on proposed discontinuance of passenger service by the Staten Island Rapid Transit Railway Company. Hearings are to resume Tuesday at 2 P. M., with the city due to take up its presentation of testimony.
General of the Army Douglas McArthur expressed confidence last night that "there is a clear and definite solution to the Korean conflict."

The atomic power plant for the submarine is now "well along toward completion," it was revealed yesterday at the Congress of American Industry of the National Association of Manufacturers in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 (UP) -Secretary of Agriculture Charles F. Brannan set a 1953 sugar quota of 7,800,000 tons today but promised to increase it later if consumer prices threaten to get out of hand.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- Private industry payrolls spurred personal income in October to the record high annual rate of $275,800,000,000, the Department of Commerce reported today. This was the third consecutive month that personal income at annual rates has hit a new peak.

The Keystone Merchandising Company has leased the one-story building at 59 Ingraham Street, Brooklyn, from George Keller and will use it for the warehousing and distribution of corrugated products. The lease was negotiated through the Kalmon Dolgin Company as broker.

The State Athletic Commission's action in summarily declaring Ray Robinson's world middleweight title vacated at 12:01 yesterday morning shrouded the 160-pound championship in a veil of confusion and contradiction.
New York Harbor, a network of seven bays, four rivers and four estuaries, is to American commerce what Texas is to American geography.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- The policies of the Wage Stabilization Board, which were overridden by President Truman in ordering a $1.90 daily wage rise for the nation's coal miners, will remain in force in all other industries, Charles C. Killingsworth, new chairman of the wage board, said today.

HANOI, Vietnam, Indo-China, Dec. 5 -- Pushing through the Thai Mountains of northwest Tonkin, a Vietminh contingent has reached Dienbienphu, twelve miles from the border of Laos, a French military spokesman said today. Dienbienphu is sixty miles due west of the isolated French defense position of Nasan and about the same distance south of the Thai capital of Laichau.

WITH GEN. EISENHOWER, in Korea, Dec. 5 -- It was 5:30 A. M., Saturday, Nov. 29, when two men stepped quickly through the doorway of the residence at No. 60 Morningside Drive in New York into the cold star-lit night.
Suiting their occupation to the inclement weather of yesterday afternoon, 250 members of the New York Historical Society settled down indoors to hear a "mystery" story.

Rudolf Serkin had the piano singing from the beginning to the end of his Carnegie Hall recital last night. It is no secret that he is one of the commanding pianists of our day, and there was no place in last night's program where he was not in sovereign control of the instrument.

A common-law married couple convicted of the kidnapping of a child from a Harlem movie theatre and then posing as his parents to obtain home relief, were sentenced yesterday in General Sessions to mandatory jail terms of twenty years to life.

A joint delegation from the Realty Advisory Board on Lebor Relations and Local 32-B, Building Service Employes International Union, A. F. L., called on State Rent Administrator Joseph D. McGoldrick yesterday to direct his attention to the effect of present rent controls on collective bargaining in the apartment field.
SEOUL, Korea, Dec. 3 -- Aides of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower revealed here today how they planned for the secrecy that surrounded his trip to the active battlefront in Korea.
Two new leaders of the American labor movement pledged themselves last night to work whole-heartedly for the uniting of the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations.
TOKYO, Saturday, Dec. 6 (AP) -United Nations Command communique 1,455, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M. Saturday, Korea time:

Emil Lengyel, author of many books, including "The Danube" and "Turkey," has completed a volume for the general reader on the Middle East. Titled "World Without End," it deals with the countries that comprise the Middle East, their peoples and their problems.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- The heads of two New York philanthropic foundations acknowledged today that the foundations had given financial aid to some organizations later criticized or cited by Congressional committees or listed as subversive by the Attorney General.

The American Academy of Arts and Letters opened yesterday two strikingly contrasted exhibitions. In the gallery of the Academy is a memorial display of paintings, drawings and caricatures by Boardman Robinson, while across the court in the Academy museum is an exhibition of caricatures, books and manuscripts by the incomparable Max Beerbohm, who has entered his eighty-first year.
Clergymen of the Roman Catholic, Jewish and Protestant faiths will take part this week-end in calling for gifts to aid blind persons through The Lighthouse of the New York Association for the Blind.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 (AP) -- Ray Brennan, Chicago Sun-Times reporter, pleaded innocent today in Federal court to a charge of posing as office manager of the Senate Crime Investigating Committee to get secret testimony. His trial was set for Jan. 12 and he was released on $2,500 bond.

Another link in the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway, which eventually will provide a six-lane, intersection-free highway between the Brooklyn plaza of the Battery Tunnel and Grand Central Parkway, near the Triborough Bridge, will be opened to traffic today.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 5 -- American industry can save $7,000,000,000 annually on material handling costs by utilizing more modern methods and machinery. Allen K. Strong, head of the material handling section of the American Cyanamid Company of New York, told the American Management Association's manufacturing conference today.

LONDON, Dec. 5 -- Dr. Grayson Kirk, acting head of Columbia University, said at a press conference today that he had found "a gratifying response" among British educational and cultural leaders to his invitation to join with Columbia in its bicentennial year in emphasizing the theme of "man's right to knowledge and the free use thereof."

New laws are needed to help eliminate abuses uncovered by the state's six-month-old investigation into "illegal and unethical" prescription tie-ups among pharmaceutical corporations, doctors and retail druggists, Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein advised Governor Dewey yesterday.
The following book, of interest to parents, was published recently:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 (UP) -- Senator Lester C. Hunt, Democrat of Wyoming, announced tonight that he intended to support the legislative proposals of the Eisenhower Administration except for any that might be "against my conscience."

Events today: Boston Symphony Orchestra, Pierre Monteux, conducting, Carnegie Hall, 2:30 P.M.; Vivien Harvey, pianist, Town Hall, 5:30; Balalaika Symphony Orchestra, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; Aurora Ragaini, pianist, Town Hall, 8:30; Frederick Marantz, pianist, Carnegie Recital Hall, 8:30; Hamilton College Choir and Hunter College Glee Club, Hunter College, 8:30, and Composers Forum, McMillin Theatre, Columbia University, 8:30.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Dec. 5 -- If you live near Wildwood Circle here and saw the Perutzes' Irish setter out for a walk today you could be almost certain that the Manns' Doberman was locked indoors -- and vice versa. For the court has so decreed.

Civil Defense authorities, preparing for "Red Alert" exercises to be held throughout this city and Westchester County next Saturday morning, gave advice yesterday to persons planning to board trains or airplanes at that time. Although trains and planes will operate on normal schedules, Herbert R. O'Brien, City Director of Civil Defense, explained:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- George C. McGhee, United States Ambassador to Turkey, today described a recent decision of the Turkish Government to "denationalize" its oil resources as an important step toward stabilizing the petroleum industry of the Near East.

The New York University Glee Club, Alfred M. Greenfield, director, sang its twenty-third annual Town Hall concert last evening in a joint appearance with the Smith College Glee Club, directed by Iva Dee Hiatt.
BOWIE, Md., Dec. 5 (AP) -- The Bobanet Stable's Brazen Brat, 4 to 5, won the $10,000 Annapolis Plate Handicap by a nose in the rain and mud at Bowie today before 6,116 fans.

CHICAGO, Dec. 5 -- Lower prices were registered yesterday for both grains and soybean futures, but buying resistance seemed to stiffen a little on the setbacks, and there was enough commission absorption partly to cushion liquidating sales. The grain markets did not seem to have recovered from the impact of heavy deliveries on December contracts, and the big imports of oats and rye from Canada the past week.

CALGARY, Sask., Dec. 5 (Canadian Press) -- Liberal Petroleums, Ltd., has announced discovery of a large potash deposit and the acquisition of potash permits from the Saskatchewan Government and the Canadian Pacific Railway covering 100,000 acres in the Palo area of west-central Saskatchewan.

Calendars that "double in brass" as cook books, parent's guides to child care or as round-ups of useful household hints have grown so much in popularity that one out of three of the 1953 productions will serve such purposes.

JERSEY CITY, Dec. 5 -- A modified form of this city's controversial business license tax ordinance was passed on first reading by the City Commission today at a spirited meeting during which three of the Commissioners were sharply criticized by Public Works Commissioner Charles Witkoski for failure to effect economies.

LONDON, Dec. 5 -- During this week-end Prime Minister Churchill will have his first opportunity for a private talk with the Australian and New Zealand Prime Ministers about a matter that has pinked his imperial pride and that of the British public -- Britain's exclusion from the Australian, New Zealand and United States defense pact.

Recently you ran an excellent article on traffic conditions in New York City in which your reporter stressed the fact that although bus drivers were among the worst offenders they rarely received a ticket for a traffic violation.

LONDON, Dec. 5 -- The Stock Exchange ended the week today on a dull note with almost all prices falling. However, losses were generally small except in armament shares, which were depressed by Prime Minister Churchill's reference to curtailing defense contracts.
Tomorrow's lawyers faced seasoned jurists in a moot court yesterday and argued the validity of a state law that prohibits aliens ineligible to become citizens from owning land within the state.
WITH U. S. FIRST MARINE DIVISION, IN KOREA, Dec. 3 -- President-elect Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower was greeted by an unrehearsed thunder of rocket fire when he arrived at this front line position today.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 5 (AP) -- A first-half aerial barrage by Georgia's big quarterback, Zeke Bratkowski, overwhelmed Miami's Hurricanes tonight, 35 -- 13, and set a new yardage record for Southeastern Conference passers.
WITH U. S. FIRST MARINE DIVISION, IN KOREA, Dec. 3 -- President-elect Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower was greeted by an unrehearsed thunder of rocket fire when he arrived at this front line position today.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 5 (AP) -- A first-half aerial barrage by Georgia's big quarterback, Zeke Bratkowski, overwhelmed Miami's Hurricanes tonight, 35 -- 13, and set a new yardage record for Southeastern Conference passers.

PARIS, Dec. 5 -- The fear of a reviving, ambitious Germany dominates in the complex of factors that cause many Frenchmen to react emotionally against the unification of Europe, even though most of them are intellectually convinced of its necessity.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 5 -- At least two Hollywood producers of television advertising films and three other companies in Chicago and New York have signed interim contract agreements with the Screen Actors Guild, it was confirmed today.
John J. McCloy, former United States High Commissioner for Germany, is slated to become chairman of the Chase National Bank, succeeding Winthrop W. Aldrich.

A New York County grand jury finds that "loose, wasteful and fraudulent practices" in purchase of coal to generate power for subways run by the Board of Transportation have brought a loss of $500,000 to the city. The period covers parts of 1948, 1949 and 1950.

Five hold-ups, four of them within a period of forty-five minutes, in scattered areas of Brooklyn, resulted yesterday in thieves escaping with a total of $7,397 in cash and jewelry. The police said all the robberies were carried out by different gangs.

TOKYO, Saturday, Dec. 6 -- President-elect Dwight D. Eisenhower completed last night his visit to Korea and took off by air for the United States with "no panaceas, no trick solutions," to end the fighting but confident that "much can be done, and will be done," to back the United Nations effort on the war-torn peninsula.

George H. White, ace Federal Narcotics Bureau agent and undercover man, was jailed for ninety minutes for contempt yesterday for refusing to name his informants to a special rackets grand jury investigating Thomas (Three Finger Brown) Luchese, underworld overlord, unless representatives of United States Attorney Myles J. Lane left the room.

Many loyal friends of France regret that the French delegation to the United Nations has decided to absent itself from the sessions of the Political and Security Committee during the discussion of the charges against French administration in Morocco and Tunisia. Refusal to participate in any way in the hearings on this issue was forecast a month ago in the address of Foreign Minister Robert Schuman to the General Assembly. "

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 (UP) -- The Senate elections subcommittee sent a second and blunter request tonight to Michigan elections officials for their "cooperation" in recounting ballots in the state's disputed Senatorial election.
LA JOLLA, Calif., Dec. 5 (AP) -- Undersea studies of the remains of one-cell organisms may disclose what South Pacific weather was like millions of years ago.
SCHENECTADY, N. Y., Dec. 5 (AP) -- Two Canadians have bought the Troy-Schenectady Bus Lines, Inc., and Taconic Valley Bus Lines, Inc., subject to approval by the Public Service Commission.

The city's drive on violations of municipal housing laws in tenement houses in Manhattan and the Bronx has uncovered 6,269 such offenses to date, according to figures made public yesterday at the Department of Housing and Buildings.

PARIS, Dec. 5 -- After a day of political surprises, Premier Antoine Pinay announced tonight in the National Assembly that he would defer the speech on his financial program that he was to have made tonight. He said it would be delivered Tuesday.

A method to cut down the sharp fluctuations in the market for lead and zinc was suggested yesterday by Felix E. Wormser, vice president of St. Joseph Lead Company, in an address before the Northwest Mining Association in Spokane.

HOBOKEN, N. J., Dec. 5 -- Three men were killed and two others were made critically ill here today by fumes in a cofferdam tank in the stern of the Norwegian freighter, Golden West. The accident occurred at 9 A. M. while the ship was undergoing an overhaul at the Bethlehem Steel Company's shipyard, Fourteenth and Hudson Streets.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Dec. 5 -- The newspaper men of eleven Latin-American countries attending a press congress here voted today to organize a Latin-American Confederation of Journalists. Action was taken in a special meeting outside the regular procedure of the World Congress of Journalists meeting here.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 5 -- Stockholders of American President Lines, at their first meeting since the Federal Government sold its 92 per cent control of the company to private interests, elected today a nine-member board of directors.

Retail furniture salesmen are doing something unusual this month. They are selling furniture. For many years there has been a saying in the trade that "December is a month for sitting around and playing pinochle." But the usual seasonal slump in retail furniture sales is absent this year.

With public hearings scheduled for early next week by the New York State Crime Commission on the New Jersey aspect of waterfront racketeering, the Hudson County (N. J.) holdover grand jury indicted a staff investigator of the New York City Anti-Crime Committee yesterday for allegedly conspiring to "defame" Mayor John V. Kenny of Jersey City.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 5 -- The United States told India and Pakistan today that it believed allowing their quarrel over Kashmir to "drift" would present danger "to us all."

Scientists today are more confident that they can place and man an impregnable fortress in space 1,000 miles from the earth than they were confident ten years ago that atomic fission might be militarily useful, a top rocket expert said here yesterday.
