O'Donnell, d/b/a Pres-To-Line Sales of Manhattan, in 79 Madison Ave.; Magazine of Industry, Inc., in 232 Madison Ave.; Kastor, Farrell, Chesley Clifford, Inc., advertising, in 400 Madison Ave.; Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States, in 50 E. 42d St.; Jacob Lesson, Emma Locker, and Nat Silver, women's apparel, in 257 W. 38th St. -- Cross Brown Co., broker.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 5 -- Hope was expressed today by Sherrill C. Corwin, board chairman and operating head of R. K. O. Radio Pictures, that the company's tangled managerial state would be straightened out over the week-end.

In a brief ceremony at City Hall yesterday Mayor Impellitteri and Dominick F. Paduano, Commissioner of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity, presented several thousand Christmas toys collected by the department's Catholic Guild to the Rev. Bernard A. Cullen, rector of the Marquette League for Catholic Indian Children.

Trading in commodity futures continued dull yesterday on the New York exchanges with closing generally mixed. Rubber, lead and wool closed higher and zinc and cottonseed oil were lower. Cocoa, sugar, coffee, soybean oil, potatoes and hides closed mixed.

Considerable progress has been achieved in setting up standards for vinyl film producers as a means of improving quality of the industry's products, it was reported yesterday by William T. Cruse, executive vice president of the Society of the Plastics Industry, Inc.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Dec. 5 -- The Indonesian Cabinet announced tonight the dismissal of the Army Chief of Staff, Colonel Nasution, and other high-ranking officers in a sequel to demonstrations against Parliament in which Army officers were involved.

The railroad issues were the mainstay yesterday of a stock market that showed some wavering tendencies. The market action was not very definite even though the composite rate of THE NEW YORK TIMES showed a gain of 0.19 point, with little difference, numerically, beween the gains and losses.

AS any hunter or fisherman can testify, it is difficult to exchange neckties, socks and handkerchiefs for items that would have some utility in the field. But a few books are available for the Christmas stocking that would bring joy to the sportsman's heart.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- Oscar R. Ewing, the Federal Security Administrator, now in India to give addresses to three social welfare conferences and scheduled to visit other countries, has been asked for a complete accounting of travel expenses by Controller General Lindsay C. Warren.

BECAUSE there are about 7,325 people to the square mile, and more than 9,000,000 people living within a twenty-mile radius of St. Paul's Cathedral London is the largest aggregation of human beings that ever lived in a single community
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 6 (AP) -- Harness racing's Grand Circuit today re-elected Octave Blake of South Plainfield, N. J., to his seventh term as president.

PEARL HARBOR, Honolulu, Dec. 6 -- Ground-breaking ceremonies for a shrine honoring an unknown sailor will be held here tomorrow at 7:55 A. M., the exact hour and minute that Japanese bombers struck Pearl Harbor and the adjacent Oahu military reservations eleven years ago to touch off World War II in the Pacific.
ROCQUENCOURT, France, Dec. 5 -- The military chiefs of the North Atlantic Treaty alliance were reported today to be nearing agreement on a compromise plan on the Allied command in the Mediterranean.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 6 (AP) -- North Catholic High School captured its second city football championship in the 15-year-old inter-league series today by routing Abraham Lincoln High, 25 -- 0.

LUXEMBOURG, Dec. 5 -- The job of creating the first great work of European economic integration, the common market for coal and steel and the materials that go into the making of steel, now has entered its practical phase.
ON THE KOREAN FRONT, Nov. 26 -- As naturally as an eagle soars or a hen lays eggs, an army is sure to adopt a rich and flavorsome language of its own.

WITH a typical turn-of-the century Teutonic mixture of idealism and sentimentality, Mahler named his Third Symphony the Joyful Science" and subtitled it "A Summer Morning Dream." He originally gave each of the six movements a title: "What the Flowers in the Meadow Tell Me"; "What the Beasts in the Forest Tell Me"; "What Love Tells Me," and so on.

MOSCOW, Dec. 6 (AP) -- The Communist party organ Pravda today reported that since 1948 trade within the Communist bloc had trebled, and Russia -- key nation of the group -- had increased by ten-fold her exports of machinery and equipment to her neighbors.
Dolls are big business today, for they are the kind that youngsters go for.

" COOKERY is become an art, a noble science; cooks are gentlemen." So wrote a learned gentleman of the late sixteenth century who, had he lived in 1952, might well have added that cooks are gentlemen and ladies -- and also authors.

I must emphatically disagree with your critic's "theory" that repertory is not possible in this country. No matter how many reasons are quoted to support this fallacy, it remains a fallacy. There are just as many reasons to quote in support of repertory.
SAN BRUNO, Calif., Dec. 6 (AP) -- Tee Dee Gee, coming on again after giving up the lead in the stretch run, won the $15,000-added San Bruno Handicap at Tanforan today by a head.
LOS ANGELES -- Automobile travel across the continent this winter is swifter, safer and more comfortable than ever before. Roads and motels are generally satisfactory and often superb.

LONDON, Dec. 6 -- A Foreign Office spokesman described as "helpful" the official warning by the United States today that American companies attempting to trade in Iranian oil would do so at their own risk.

AT a point near the long and still unquiet frontier which separates Israel from Jordan, a section of Israeli infantrymen recently dropped off a truck near the edge of a citrus orchard. They were counted quickly by their sergeant. "Follow me." he said quietly.

Japanese business leaders are commencing to put together their old pre-war trading company combinations, crushed and fragmented by six years of the Allied occupation, according to Robert Hall of Bache Co., members of the New York Stock Exchange.

An editorial in THE NEW YORK TIMES on Dec. 4 states that the "Parliament in The Hague is the first in the world to amend its Constitution to permit a cession of national power to a supranational authority." In this connection it is pertinent to point out that the Constitutions of France, Italy and the Federal Republic of Western Germany contain clauses indicating a willingness to surrender national sovereignty in the interests of international peace.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- President Truman said today that he was "gratified" by the progress made in Western Germany so far toward approval of the European Defense Community and the "peace contracts" but he warned at the same time of serious consequences "if ratification is long delayed or not accomplished."

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 5 -- With remarkably little fanfare even for a country where the results are not in doubt, the Yugolavs have begun voting for new Parliaments from the municipal to the national level.

BRITISH artistic institutions have a queer habit of spending their whole lives in dying. The theatre, for instance, has been dying for nearly four centuries. Every time a fresh toy was invented to amuse the public, theatre managers shook their heads dolefully and said it would kill the theatre.

The volume of new urban and rural housing built in the Soviet Union this year will be approximately one-third less than the comparable housing finished last year, data appearing in the Soviet press indicate.
Justice Justine Wise Polier of the Domestic Relations Court of New York asserted yesterday that she had never belonged to any organization that to her knowledge was subversive.

English, Prof. Mario Pei has told us in our Book Review, is spoken by more of the world's inhabitants than any other language except Chinese, which has a long lead over all the rest -- in spite of what has been done behind the Iron Curtain to reduce the number of customers.

MIAMI BEACH, Dec. 6 -- The open pair championship, final event in the twenty-sixth annual contract bridge championships held here at the Sea Isle Hotel under the auspices of the American Contract Bridge League, got under way this afternoon with a field of 160 pairs playing the first of four scheduled sessions.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Dec. 6 -- In a last-minute switch, the American League today voted to concur with the National League in adopting the much discussed "two-league waiver rule," which aims to curb interleague trading after the June 15 deadline.

Waukegan, Ill., and Skowkegan, Me., have more in common than names that rhyme. They both have produced men of considerable wit and versatility - namely, Jack Benny and Joseph Mendell Russakoff, respectively.

A DOZEN demi-gods in sweat shirts and gym pants are walking the earth, or rather the floors of two New York armories, these days, flanked by a host of mortal worshipers. The instruments in their Olympian hands are baseballs, bats and gloves, whose mysteries they are revealing to their neophytes. These latter are teen-age scholarship holders -- all free -- in the American Baseball Academy.

SINGAPORE, Dec. 6 -- Thousands of Malayans voted today in what were widely described as the country's "guinea pig" elections for municipal and town councils in Singapore and six towns in the Malayan Federation. It is the first time that so many local elections have been held simultaneously in Malaya and the official view is that these polls represent the first step on the long road to general elections in the country.

MEDFORD, Mass., Dec. 6 -- Dr. Nils Y. Wessell, vice president of Tufts College, was named acting president of the institution today to fill the position soon to be vacated by Dr. Leonard Carmichael, the college president, who resigned recently to become head of the Smithsonian Institution in Washington.
A new drug synthesized in the chemistry laboratories of Columbia University may prove a boon to vast areas of southeast Asia and India that are ravaged by malaria.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Dec. 6 (UP) -- Detroit's Red Wings blanked the Chicago Black Hawks, 2 to 0, before 10,259 fans tonight for their fourth consecutive victory to shave the Hawks' hold on first place in the National Hockey League to half a game.

A 100-mile Western Union submarine cable is being used to measure the flow of the Gulf Stream, it was announced last week by the telegraph company. The cable lies between Florida and Cuba. Scientists have determined that the movement of water over the earth's magnetic field produces electrical energy and that this energy can be measured and recorded on an automatic voltage indicator by placing an electrode on the end of the cable.

It is a truism to state that twentieth-century artists are not bound by any conventions of technique. Ever since Picasso made a picture centering round Gertrude Stein's visiting card, painters have felt free to abandon the brush ford more out-of-the-way means of filling the picture space.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 (AP) -- Following is the text of the letter of resignation sent to President Truman today by the industry members of the Wage Stabilization Board:

ABOARD THE U.S.S. HELENA, en route to Hawaii, Sunday, Dec. 7 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, President-elect, will meet with five members of his prospective Cabinet and other staff members aboard this heavy cruiser for a series of historic conferences, beginning tomorrow, dealing with the Korean war and Far East policy.

Caesar Cirigliano of the New York Athletic Club and Henry Bellingham of the Ohrbach A. A. won the men's events in the Amateur Athletic Union open handicap meet at the Ninety-second Street Y. M. H. A. last night.

The Near East College Association, comprising seven American institutions in the Near East, will be aided by the proceeds from the performance of "The Millionairess," with Katharine Hepburn in the leading role on Thursday night at the Shubert Theatre.

THE Stereo-Realist Silvrscreen, an elastic screen that can be stretched to assure the needed flat surface, is announced by David H. White Company. Powdered aluminum is firmly bonded to the surface to permit rolling up the screen, which is fastened by quick-snap buttons to a lightweight aluminum frame that packs away in a tubular carrying case with a handle.

A DETAILED plan which will systematically extend low-cost scheduled air tourist service until it girdles the earth by April 1, 1954, has been worked out by the International Air Transport Association. Sixty-seven airlines from fifty countries, all members of I. A. T. A., agreed unanimously on the step-by-step plan at a series of traffic conferences that ended recently in Cannes, France.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 (AP) -- A whole generation of mice has become dizzy riding miniature merry-go-rounds trying to help scientists solve this problem: To find an insecticide that will kill tough flies and mosquitoes. A lot of these insects have become immune to DDT and other bug killers.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- Staff reductions by United States missions abroad were demanded today by Senators Alexander Wiley of Wisconsin and Tom Connally of Texas, the chief Republican and Democratic foreign policy spokesmen in Congress.

Consumer buying for Christmas had an active start last week, but unseasonable warmth and rain held down the volume of the expansion. Trade observers estimated the week's volume was about even with that of the 1951 period. Confidence was expressed and merchants generally forecast that the season would show an advance over 1951.

With a remarkable display of foul-shooting accuracy, Fordham upset Columbia, 71 -- 65, in the first intracity clash of the young basketball season in the University Hall Gymnasium of the Lions last night.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 6 -- Crystal Boot, who was racing in claiming events in New York less than two months ago, stole the show from Tony DeSpirito today by galloping to a surprise victory in the $7,500 Ponce De Leon handicap at Tropical Park.
WESTFIELD, N. J., Dec. 6 -- Reminiscent of a quaint Dutch tradition, a Christmas program was staged here today with John Birch, in the role of St. Nicholas riding into town astride a white horse.

Educational institutions do not violate academic freedom by inquiring whether teachers belong to the Communist party, Patrick Murphy Malin, director of the American Civil Liberties Union, declared yesterday at New York University's eighth annual Higher Education Conference.

TOKYO, Sunday, Dec. 7 -- Communist aircraft may have tried to break through the protective screen of United Nations planes and guns shielding President-elect Dwight D. Eisenhower before he left Korea Friday night, it was revealed yesterday.
The vast and perplexing problems bound up in the single word Korea are in triple stalemate.

NUMEROUS large and decidedly miscellaneous exhibitions compete for public attention this week. Seven of the exhibiting painters holding one-man shows are landscapists, and each, in his own way, would seem to put us in touch with the visible world. Yet the fact that their pictures are so radically different is proof again that the visual facts one artist considers significant are totally rejected by the next.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Dec. 6 -- Col. Marcos Perez Jimenez, by his seizure of power in Venezuela, put an abrupt end this week to a series of peaceful constitutional transfers of power that had been heartening observers to hope that Latin America was taking to government by democratic processes rather than by the strong arm.

LAST Friday the Milwaukee Road placed on public display in Chicago, Milwaukee, the Twin Cities and Seattle the first all-dome railroad cars to be built in this country. On Jan. 1 one of these Super-Dome cars will go into daily service on each of the six units of the Olympian Hiawatha between Chicago, Seattle and Tacoma and on each of the two morning and afternoon Hiawathas, daytime streamliners between Chicago, St. Paul and Minneapolis.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 6 -- The United Nations made public tonight an urgent and direct appeal to the Chinese Communists and the North Koreans to end the "suffering and destruction" in Korea on the basis of a truce formula accepted by fifty-four of the organization's sixty members.

SIR ALEXANDER KORDA, who has been fascinated by the Indian scene before, again is immersed in film plans which include extensive use of that exotic locale. Last week it was learned that the British producer quietly has started the production wheels turning on a picture tentatively titled, "Tiger, Tiger," a label borrowed, of course, from William Blake's noted poetic lines: "Tiger, tiger, burning bright." etc.
In an effort to intensify the sale of Israel bonds to help consolidate Israel's economic structure, the State of Israel Bond Organization has scheduled a series of events throughout this country.

AT the end of this exemplary biography of a relatively little-known American statesman and philanthropist, the author explains in one word why Elias Boudinot has not attracted earlier biographers. Unlike James Boswell and Aaron Burr, Boudinot was "predictable."

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N. Y., Dec 6 -- Thousands of winter sports enthusiasts visited here today and inspected the new winter recreational facilities recently completed by the Palisades Interstate Park Commission in Bear Mountain-Harriman State Park.
TORONTO, Dec. 6 -- Goals by Edgar Laprade and Hy Buller, enabled the New York Rangers to tie the Toronto Maple Leafs, 2 to 2, tonight before 12,500 National Hockey League fans.

The auction galleries, with the holidays approaching, are presenting this week an attractive aspect for the many collectors and other buyers with a Christmas list in mind. This is the time of year when the auction shopper finds the galleries aglitter with precious jewels, gold objects and bibelots, and when decorative objects of every description make their appearance in volume.

IN his exposition of his "Ten Operatic Masterpieces," Olin Downes has followed a novel plan. In place of the customary few bars here and there of musical quotation to elucidate this or that detail of action, he gives us a number of extracts more or less complete in themselves -- the Toreador's song from "Carmen," the Barcarolle from "The Tales of Hoffmann," Cherubino's canzone in "Figaro," and so on.

STRATEGIST, historian, resonant leader and fine seaman, Admiral Sir Herbert Richmond was a most remarkable man. In the neat, affectionate biographical essay which introduces this collection of his private papers, Arthur Marder, Professor of History at the University of Hawaii, refers to him as "perhaps the ablest naval officer of his generation."

I WAS an early riser when I was a boy, not from choice but from those persuasions parents know (or used to know). I was up with the sun in spring and summer because the garden must be spaded, the corn planted, the roses picked, and lawn mowed and all these before school or fishing in Oak Orchard Creek or swimming in Lake Ontario, or baseball on the diamond at the Fairgrounds.
HONOLULU, Dec. 6 (UP) -- Tom McCormick scored three touchdowns to lead College of Pacific to a 49-to-13 victory over the University of Hawaii in Honolulu Stadium last night.

GRANVILLE HICKS in his review of Madison Cooper's "Sironia, Texas." cites, as similar in spirit, the work of Edgar Lee Masters, Sherwood Ander son and Ross Lockridge. I should like to add to these the name of Edgar Watson Howe.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 6 -- A six-man delegation, headed by the Yugoslav charge d'affaires in Moscow, left last night for Galati in Rumania to participate in the seventh session of the Danube Commission in what is expected to be a fruitless attempt to break the Cominform's control of shipping on this longest and most historic of Europe's rivers.

FOR THIS WEEK: Mound soil in an eight-inch cone around canes of rose bushes. Mulch hardy climbing roses.... When buds show on Christmas cactus, fertilize once and water daily.... Water occasionally outdoor window boxes which hold ivy or evergreen plants.... Keep a rake or broom handy to dislodge heavy snow from evergreens....

MINNEAPOLIS, Dec. 6 (AP) -- The Minneapolis Lakers won their eleventh game in their last twelve starts tonight but had to go overtime to rack up an 85-78 victory over New York in a National Basketball Association game.

Charles Castleman, 10-year-old violinist who gave a successful Town Hall recital last year, showed yesterday that he is capable also of appearing impressively with a major orchestra. He was soloist at Carnegie Hall with the New York Philharmonic-Symphony in its Young People's Concert.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- The State Department said today that United States interests could try to buy Iranian oil if they wanted to, but only at the grave risk of legal action by the British-owned Anglo-Iranian Oil Company.

TODAY'S column takes off from the quotation which heads the Treasure Chest. Macneile Dixon's "The Human Situation" was published about fifteen years ago. Reviewing it in these pages, Waldo H. Dunn said he considered it "perhaps the most important book of its kind which the twentieth century has yet produced."
The Brooklyn College basketball team made Yeshiva its fourth straight victim by a score of 74 -- 53 at the Flatbush gymnasium last night. The defeat was the second in three games for Yeshiva.

A MAN doesn't seem to rate these days unless he can mournfully but bravely identify himself with some regrettable Generation. If he isn't Lost, or Forgotten, or Defeated, or Mislaid or Tragic, or (right now) Beat, he finds it hard to get into a conversation, write a book or run up a tab in a saloon.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- Presidentelect Eisenhower must now place his estimate of the Korean situation against the estimate of the world situation gathered here this week by the next Secretary of State, John Foster Dulles. For this purpose Mr. Dulles will probably fly to the Pacific to report to the General.

FOR three centuries Englishmen have burned Guy Fawkes in effigy on the fifth of November, and thanked God for the deliverance of their nation from the danger of "gunpowder, treason and plot." If the most recent historian of the Gunpowder Plot is to be credited, that danger was not really grave, and indeed may never have existed at all.

IF, one of these days, you should approach a Broadway box office, you may notice that the man behind the wicket is considerably more cheerful than usual. His joviality may be attributed to the coming of the Yuletide season, but it is different from the Christmas spirit that prevails among many other citizens as the holidays near.

THE present visit to Broadway of the Barrault-Renaud company from Paris, and of the Greek National Theatre from Athens, reminds us, as no library of books could do, of the wide range and alternance of styles in dramatic literature, and, even more pointedly, in the art of acting.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 6 (AP) -- United States delegates won an initial victory today in a fight to soften an international regulation authorizing countries to stop cable and radio messages they consider dangerous to internal security.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- The industry members of the Wage Stabilization Board resigned in a body today rather than be a party to a wage program that they described as "nothing but a sham and a mockery."
The article "Europe's Aching Trouble Spot -- The Saar" (Nov. 23) inspired the following reflections:
HOLLYWOOD. MY personal theory about Ethel Merman is that she is nothing less than a natural phenomenon, like a halo around the moon, or Times Square at midnight.

NICOSIA, Cyprus, Dec. 6 -- Twenty-two centuries ago an Indian political philosopher named Kautilya defined as an enemy "that state which is situated on the border of one's own state." As they look northward to their Soviet and Chinese neighbors, this opinion is still held by the great arc of Asian countries stretching from the Mediterranean to the South China Sea.

HARTFORD, Conn., Dec. 6 -- A Shakespeare sampler stitched by a company of noted actors had its premiere at the new Parsons Theatre here last night on behalf of the projected American Shakespeare Festival and Academy. "An Evening With Will Shakespeare" is what they are calling it.
LONDON, Dec. 6 (Reuters) -- All five London matches and the Cambridge - Oxford game were postponed today as fog and frost hit the English soccer program.

WITH the subtitle. "Tobacco Through the Centuries." Jerome Brooks tells the story of a commodity and does it with urbanity and wit, as well as learning. In this he is helped by his subject, for tobacco has had a career even more startling than that of coffee.

Ervin Laszlo, yesterday afternoon in Town Hall, played what was undoubtedly his finest New York recital, even taking into consideration his spectacular debut in 1948. There were greater breadth and musicianship to his conceptions; and the technical inaccuracies that sometimes have marred his previous work were missing.

Adelphi College's basketball team handed City College its initial loss of the campaign, 69 to 64, last night at the Beaver's home gymnasium. The game was in doubt until the final seventeen seconds when Adelphi forged ahead by five points.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Dec. 6--Stalled in their efforts to entice the southpaw ace, Warren Spahn, from the Braves, the Dodgers turned their blandishments upon the Reds today in a last-minute effort to swing a deal before the assembled executives disperse for their homes tomorrow night.

The Board of Transportation has asked Mayor Impellitteri to seek legislation at Albany next year to prevent the Municipal Civil Service Commission from weakening its disciplinary powers over the 42,000 transit employes responsible for the safety of the riding public.

CHICAGO, Dec. 6 -- The Big Ten Conference today took its first stand on live television of football games by voting for regional control as opposed to the National Collegiate Athletic Association's controversial nationally restricted program. The Conference, however, made it clear that the regional plan merely was a preference and that it had no desire for an all-out fight with the N. C. A. A. over TV policy.

BUFFALO, Dec. 6 (UP) -- La Salle's basketball team, featuring most of the tall players who carried it to the National Invitation Tournament title a year ago, swept aside Niagara, 87 -- 76, tonight before a capacity crowd at Buffalo's Memorial Auditorium.

AN exchange of hospitality marks the Christmas season ahead. In its connection the epicure may think of champagne, eggnog, hot buttered rum. Tom and Jerry and, simplest of them all to serve, the so-called fortified wines -- sherry, port and what has become an almost unknown quantity, madeira.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 6 -- Six children burned to death at midnight in the ruins of their three-story frame house after it had been leveled by a gas explosion that blasted their parents and a third-floor tenant to safety. The gas seeped from a utility main that had been damaged in an automobile crash nearly an hour earlier.

BONN, Germany, Dec. 6 -- The endorsement given in the Bundestag to rearmament and the entry of West Germany into the affairs of Europe has not blinded Germans to the importance to the Federal Republic of a number of pressing questions about its future position in the Western world.

FOUR stamps which will commemorate "important events in the early history of our country" were announced by Postmaster General Jesse M. Donaldson last week for release in 1953. He said that "the remainder of the program for the calendar year would be left for decision" by his successor, Arthur Summerfield.
The power-hungry Pacific Northwest is winning its race against time. An important landmark has just been passed in meeting the insatiable demands for electric power throughout the region.

WASHINGTON -- The Civil Aeronautics Board is moving against what it calls "unscrupulous" ticket agents representing the irregular or non-scheduled air carriers, and these carriers are looking on with approval.

The eightieth anniversary of the founding of the Reform branch of Judaism in America wil be observed with a series of events beginning on Jan. 7. On that date there will be an anniversary dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel that will be attended by descendants of Rabbi Isaac Mayer Wise, founder of Reform Judaism, who died in 1900.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 6 -- A new 500-bed Veteran's Administration hospital, dedicated to the service of some 250,000 Veterans of al wars in this area, will be dedicated tomorrow, the anniversary of the attack upon Pearl Harbor.

Frank Turner of Seton Hall and Jimmy Gathers, Olympian from Mitchel Air Force Base, captured the feature Amateur Athletic Union events in the interscholastic track meet sponsored by the Queens Masonic Association last night at the 102d Engineers Armory. Proceeds from the affair went to aid cerebral palsy patients in city hospitals.

The Meadow Brook Club's debut in indoor polo was a successful one last night as the Westbury, L. I., trio defeated Al Parsells' Ramapo Polo Club, 10 to 7, in the feature match of the weekly double-header at the Squadron A Armory.

FEW of the sleepy nighttime travelers passing through Rome's new, vast, modernistic, glass-marble-aluminum railroad terminal, have noticed, in recent weeks, the arc lights, the web of cables, the strangely garbed people: the obvious signs of a movie in the making.
ATLANTIC CITY, Dec. 6 -- The nation's leading cigar manufacturers were told today that the development of a well-rounded distribution program was the key to expansion of sales on their industry.

Six guiding principles for effective school board action are listed in a survey of 800 school board members in twelve Midwestern states. The study, conducted by Prof. Maurice E. Stapley of Indiana University, uncovered significant areas of ability needed by school board members.
LONDON, Dec. 5 -- A proposal was presented to Queen Elizabeth II tonight for a change in style and title that many of the Commonwealth governments want made for her coronation on June 2.

HONG KONG, Nov. 24 -- Beyond the range of the Formosa-Pescadores "neutralization" zone, where the presence of the United States Seventh Fleet has frozen Communist and Nationalist combat operations, lie two little-publicized chains of Nationalist islands that extend almost 500 miles along the Southeast China coast.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 6 -- Britain told the United Nations today that it had no right to look into the dispute between France and the nationalists of Tunisia.

EVANSVILLE, Ind., Dec. 6 (UP) -- It will be the ground attack of the defending champion, Arkansas State, against the passing of Western Kentucky in the fifth annual Evansville Refrigerator Bowl football game tomorrow.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 6 (AP) -- Penn's basketball team opened its fifty-third basketball campaign tonight by downing Maryland, 70 -- 53, despite a 26-point effort by Forward Gene Shue for the Terrapins at the Palestra.

MONTREAL, Dec. 6 (UP) -- The bustling Boston Bruins, unperturbed by the loss of two key men, stretched their victory string to five games tonight by downing the Montreal Canadiens, 2 -- 1, on a third period goal by Johnny McIntrye.

DETROIT, Dec. 6 -- The Detroit Symphony Orchestra, revived and reconstituted last year after a two-year lapse, has announced plans for a five-week concert tour beginning in January, 1954, under its permanent conductor, Paul Paray.

LONDON, Dec. 6 -- The worst fog in two years smothered London today, blacking out the metropolis by 2 p. m. The gray blanket began to settle down yesterday and the city only partly awoke this morning for a few hours of half-hearted twilight after a night of crawling and groping.
HAMILTON, Bermuda, Dec. 6 (UP) -- The crash of the Cuban airliner off Bermuda today occurred in shark-infested seas. None of the plane's passengers were believed to be from the United States.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- Wage controls will continue in force in the American economy, at least until the present Administration leaves office.
TOKYO, Sunday, Dec. 7 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,456, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Sunday, Korea time:

CHICAGO, Dec. 6 -- Despite precautions, preachments and predictions, the human race, during 1952, succeeded in producing a quota of bizarre accidents and mishaps, according to a survey by the National Safety Council.

Long efforts to get nations to reduce and simplify the large numbers of documents and excessive formalities required from exporters, importers, freight carriers and forwarders, bankers and brokers engaged in world trade are nearing realization.

The New York Rangers will oppose the Canadiens of Montreal in the National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden tonight. Deep in last place in the loop race, the Broadway Blues nevertheless are hopeful of hitting the victory column at the expense of the Habitants.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Dec. 6 -- To keep the thousands of soldiers in its midst from being too lonely as Christmas approaches, this city has undertaken a concerted effort to make them feel at home.
NIAGARA FALLS, Ont., Dec. 6 (AP) -- Visitors to Niagara Falls are due for some surprises in the next few years.
Shelton College, formerly the National Bible Institute, has purchased Skylands, a 1,187-acre estate in Ringwood Borough, northern New Jersey, it was announced yesterday by Previews Incorporated.

HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Dec. 6 -- With the conclusion of the forty-first annual convention of the Investment Bankers Association of America here yesterday, the nation's investment securities specialists were placed on record as urging the Treasury, in borrowing new money, to sell securities outside the banking system, preferably in the form of longer-term, fully marketable bonds.

AN opinion generally accepted in British and American circles, and often endorsed also by Italian spokesmen abroad, ascribes the spread of communism in Italy to the wretchedness of the poor, the selfishness of the rich and the lack of Government intervention. I have read this interpretation in scores of American and British newspapers; I have heard it from highly qualified British and American observers.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Dec. 6 -- Forty-eight hours before the scheduled election of a President to succeed Dr. Chaim Weizmann, a deadlock between supporters of the Mapai candidate, Itzhak Ben Zvi, and the religious bloc's nominee, Rabbi Mordecai Nurock, remained unresolved.

RIEGELSVILLE, Pa. -- Modern Americans, used to skating as a form of sport, are likely to forget that it first came to this country as a form of locomotion. A skilled skater can cover five miles in little more than fifteen minutes; less practiced ones can maintain a steady pace in excess of ten miles an hour.
A memorial tribute to Chaim Weizmann, late President of Israel, was paid by the congregation of Temple B'nai Jeshurun, 257 West Eighty-eighth Street, yesterday morning.

ABOARD U. S. S. HELENA, En Route to Hawaii, Dec. 6 -- President-elect Dwight D. Eisenhower, journeying back home from his visit to the Korean battlefront, is proving himself a good sailor and -- stripped down to shirt-sleeves -- has been at work most of the day in the admiral's cabin despite the rocking of the ship.

If a pleasure boat owner wants to spend his winter visiting one boat show after another -- and many of them will do just this -- he can keep busy from early January until late April in what is patently the biggest season of boat shows on record.

AMERICA'S $800,000,000 a year toy business, with eyes on 45,000,000 children, is ready for the holiday season -- entertainingly, educationally, and what's more, psychologically. As pictures on these pages show, shelves are stocked with toys from foreign countries and our 1,200 year-round manufacturers.

FOR about four months of the year the political and social center of the United Nations is a block-long room that the guided tours do not take in. It is a room stuffed with delegates, sofas and rumors, and known to the irreverent as the chicken-yard -the place where kernels of diplomatic information are strewn and pecked up.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 6 (AP) -- Gale-whipped snows tonight halted train travel between California and Oregon, stranded 800 passengers on three trains, blocked highways and marooned scores of motorists.
SEOUL, Korea, Sunday, Dec. 7 (AP) -- President Syngman Rhee said today he urged President-elect Dwight D. Eisenhower to find a solution to Korea because "our people have become impatient."

HACKENSACK, N. J., Dec. 6 -- Hackensack High's football powerhouse rolled to a 40-0 triumph over Rutherford today and clinched its fourth successive Northern New Jersey Interscholastic League championship. The game was the fiftieth in a series that dates back to 1902.

MRS. MALLET is the newest and most gifted recruit to the Proustian school of French novelists. It is impossible not to admire the qualities of imagination which this 20-year-old author brings to bear on the evocation of a private world.

HENRY ADAMS as a boy was taken to the White House to meet President Zachary Taylor. Outside, in a paddock in front, "Old Whitey," the President's charger, was grazing as they entered, Adams remembered later, and inside the President was receiving callers as simply as if they were in the paddock, too.

When a physician listens to heart sounds with a stethoscope he is engaged in what he calls by the high-sounding term "auscultation." The procedure is as old as medicine. It tells a good diagnostician much, yet not enough because the ear is not a perfect instrument and because some murmurs and other suspicious sounds are not heard at all.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- President Truman again called on all Americans today to volunteer as air raid spotters in "Operation Sky-watch," so that "our cities and our industries will be less vulnerable to devasting attack."

But, Sunday traffic on the lines to Richmond is still a picture of congestion and of long lines of passengers and cars pressing ahead to get on the boats.

PARIS, Dec. 6 -- Poland informed the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization today that she was withdrawing as a member after "fruitless efforts to prevent the organization's conversion into a tool of the United States policy of aggression."
The Federal Maritime Board's hearing on two applications by American President Lines centering on its New York-Indonesia service has been scheduled for Jan. 12 before Board Examiner C. W. Robinson.

LONDON, Dec. 6 -- No one knows why good Scotch whisky owes its character to the water from the burns (i. e., streams) of the Scottish Highlands, but it does. Now it is reported that Scandinavian distilleries are importing water from the Scottish Highlands to give the authentic "Scotch" flavor to their own whiskies.

THE production of Verdi's "Don Carlo," given its first performance of the present season last Tuesday night at the Metropolitan, must rank as one of Mr. Bing's proudest accomplishments. This was the opera with which he opened his first season as general manager of the Metropolitan, Nov. 6, 1950.

ATLANTA, Dec. 6 (UP) -- The South will fight to maintain segregation in its public schools even if the United States Supreme Court rules separation of the races in classrooms unconstitutional, a survey showed today.

ALBANY, Dec. 6 -- Twenty-two proposals to amend the State Constitution, including several that would have important effects on New York City's courts and financial situation, will be up for possible final passage before the 1953 Legislature when it convenes here Jan. 7.

American colleges and universities will spend a record total of more than $350,000,000 for research projects during this academic year. Most of this money -- about $300,000,000 -- has been granted by the Federal Government. Business foundations and individual donors are providing the rest.

Vivien Harvey, pianist, gave her first Town Hall recital yesterday afternoon. A graduate in piano of the Cincinnati Conservatory of Music, Miss Harvey is also a composer and her orchestral suite "A Box of Toys," has been played by the Rochester Philharmonic and Cleveland Symphony Orchestra.
THIS is definitely a week of premieres, with no less than five pieces new to New York on the collective schedule of the various companies.

Although financial markets continued last week to reflect the highly favorable condition of the nation's economy, several adverse developments occurred as the final month of the year began. Business and political circles were jarred by the decision on the soft coal miners' wage increase and opposition to the Secretary of Labor designate.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- A new cry for volunteers for Eisenhower was heard in the capital this week and showed every sign of winning as enthusiastic a response as its pre-election counterpart. The new call is for all kinds of assistance fair the Eisenhower-Nixon Inaugural Committee 1958.

PARIS. The dove in Europe, as is well known, is no longer a simple feathered creature of the family Columbidae, but a political symbol meaning Communist "peace."

TOKYO, Sunday, Dec. 7 -- November's fighting in Korea cost the Communists almost 15,000 in killed, wounded and prisoners, Eighth Army Headquarters announced yesterday as combat dwindled along most of the front in temperatures just above zero.

IT'S fun to grow your own Christmas decorations, but American holly trees have much more to offer than just holiday cheer. The handsome shape, the evergreen foliage and bright berries enhance the winter landscape around almost any home. Since the trees can be kept relatively small, they are in scale with even small homes.

YONKERS, Dec. 6 -- Three holdup men entered the home of Edward Mishkin at 53 Algonquin Road shortly before midnight last night as Mrs. Mishkin was watching a crime story on television, and promptly put her into the lead role in a real-life drama.
DETROIT, Dec. 6 -- Walter Reuther's barking watchdog got an eviction notice today even though he barks in a soundproofed courtyard.

EVEN when he is not in top form, as in the case of "I've Got Sixpence," John van Druten is an attractive playwright. In the past twenty-seven years he has brought a lot of pleasure into the theatre. He began in 1925 with "Young Woodley," which was a notable event at a time when notable theatre events were a good deal more common than they are today.

With governments now fixing the prices of their principal commodities, mostly agricultural products entering the international markets, a difficult surplus problem is being created which may have serious repercussions on the economy of the countries involved as well as world trade.

Pressures of the "cold war" -- including inflated costs of higher education and the draft -- confront Columbia College with the need to reconsider major aspects of its liberal arts education, Dean Lawrence H. Chamberlain and Dean of Students Nicholas M. McKnight declared yesterday in their annual report.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 6 -- It used to be, in the days when the United Nations was fresh and new, that the staff workers of the organization were conscious of a sense of privilege and that the atmosphere of dedication, goal and hope was so strong that it could almost be touched.

Convinced that the career and salary plan for city employes to be prepared by the Municipal Civil Service Commission will not be ready in time to affect the 1953-54 budget, labor unions and other organizations representing city workers have intensified their campaign for a cost-of-living pay rise in the fiscal year beginning July 1.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 6 -- Discussion in Congress of the United States-Brazilian military defense pact came to near-violence last night when a Communist member demanded that the treaty be sent back to committee.

IT all began, said Lady Milbanke, at a dinner party in London last summer, when her friend, the Maharajah of Cooch Behar, mused with faint melancholy, "How am I going to keep my elephants?" Out of that poignant question grew a travel project which, its sponsors believe, is unprecedented.

In Topics of The Times in the issue of Nov. 23 the topic "The Greeks and Democracy" is discussed in an interesting and instructive manner. The writer, however, perpetuates a time-honored but unfortunate error, which deserves correction. He states: "The alien, the artisan, the shopkeeper could have no voice in public affairs."

GLENWOOD LANDING, L. I., Dec. 6 -- A blackout of all the seaward lights at the Long Island Lighting Company's huge generating plant here has succeeded in breaking a mysterious, week-long siege by millions of silvery round herring.

NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 6 (AP) -- Mount Everest's numbing winds and below zero cold have defeated a courageous Swiss mountain climbing expedition reported last month to have reached a point only 150 feet from its unconquered peak.

AFTER three months of television programming in Canada, the publicly-owned Canadian Broadcasting Corporation has not yet weaned Canadian viewers from looking at United States television stations. But Canadian TV programs, as exemplified by those shown on CBLT, Toronto, are improving and gaining a larger share of the audience in the most concentrated TV receiving set area in Canada.

Since Controller Lazarus Joseph suggested a few weeks ago that the city abolish its radio station, WNYC, to save the station's annual operating cost of $315,000 out of a total city budget of $1,454,653,078, both the Controller's office and that of WNYC have been deluged with mail from residents pleading that the station be retained.

IN January a Swedish bridge team, the champions of Europe, will come to New York to play the American champions. To many observers it seems strange that eight men will travel so far with no other purpose than to get their names engraved on a silver cup -- if they win.

CAIRO, Dec. 6 -- The world has been treated to a spectacle of embittered riots in the streets of the capital of Iraq against the statesman who has just provided his impoverished fellow citizens with an excellent chance to become prosperous.

THE New York City Ballet provides an instance of a left hand showing what a right hand is doing. In the program notes for one of the ballet company's new works, Hindemith's "Metamorphoses," it is stated flatly that next fall the New York City Opera Company will present Hindemith's "Cardillac."

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 6 -- Neutral powers knit together today a "compromise" Palestine proposal that, they hoped, would not be blocked by Arab opposition from mustering the two-thirds majority vote needed for adoption by the United Nations sixty-member General Assembly.

From leaf-fall to first snow we think of the outdoor world, in these latitudes, as a drab and colorless scene, for our eyes are still remembering October and our hearts remember June. But late fall has its own spectrum, of browns and grays and conifer greens. We begin to recognize that narrower spectrum when the snow comes with its sharp accents.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Dec. 6 -- Chile's First World Congress of Journalists closed today with a formal session in Valparaiso after four days of meetings here in which both Communist and peronista elements failed conspicuously in efforts to get support for their ideas.
DENVER, Dec. 6 (AP) -- A multi-denominational religious team will go to work tomorrow on the problems and plans of the nation's biggest cooperative church enterprise.

In New York last Monday, Eisenhower headquarters at the Commodore Hotel put out this statement: "President-elect Dwight D. Eisenhower announced today the [designation of] Martin P. Durkin of Chicago, Ill., for Secretary of Labor."

An almost audible sigh of relief went over the nation when news came on Friday that President-elect Eisenhower had completed his visit to Korea and was safely on his way home. As far as possible the timing of the trip had been kept secret, but many people must have noticed that fresh photographs of the General ceased to appear in the newspapers and that there was a slight ambiguity in the communiques from Morningside Heights.
VERDUN, France, Dec. 4 -- Young Americans setting foot in France for the first time expect to find themselves among another American people -- but speaking French!

WE have run into the slack water which comes each year before the Christmas flood. During these weeks nobody is thought to go to the theatre and, though no particular change is to be seen in the box-office returns of the smash hits, managements are shy of putting on new plays.

THE American Theatre Wing Community plays, whose earlier productions for parent groups, "Temperate Zone" and ". . . You Never Know" have had and are still enjoying great success as discussion starters at meetings of mothers and dads, have just introduced a new play to their list -- "The Case of the Missing Handshake." by Nora Stirling, its topic "the serious subject of manners."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- A plan to provide the President with three deputies to ease the administrative burdens of the office was made public today by H. Christian Sonne, chairman of the board of trustees of the National Planning Association, a private, nonprofit organization with headquarters here.
Fat is a good index to the general physical condition of deer in the winter. A thin wintering deer is close to starvation, Science Service points out.
TRENTON, Dec. 6 -- The recently formed narcotics squad of the state police reported today that "no serious juvenile problem" had been uncovered in its year of investigations and prosecutions.

No physicist took at its face value the announcement of President Juan D. Peron, made early in 1951, that with Argentina's technical and financial support Dr. Ronald Richter, an obscure Austrian refugee, had carried out "thermonuclear experiments * * * under conditions of control on a technical scale." No bombs were to be made.

THERE are, as an old saying goes, more ways to kill a cat than by hitting it in the head. One of the cats in the dance field that has been most in need of killing for a long time is the abominable practice of putting small children "on toe" in dancing schools, but how to get rid of the pestiferous animal has been a difficult problem to solve.
ANKARA, Turkey, Dec. 4 -- In the words of Fuad Koprulu, Turkey's Foreign Minister, "war and peace are today total conceptions."

Medical problems to the average citizen are highly personalized. His primary questions are: How do I go about selecting a physician? How can I be sure he is competent? Where can I find a good general practitioner?

PITTSBURGH has cause for satisfaction with its first International Contemporary Music Festival, which took place during the week of the Thanksgiving holiday. There undoubtedly were shortcomings, irritations and miscalculations, but when you consider that this was an initial undertaking in a difficult field, you realize that it accomplished a great deal.

The concert given by the Boston Symphony Orchestra, under Pierre Monteux, yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Hall reached its peak in a noteworthy performance of Richard Strauss' tone poem, "Ein Heldenleben." This was, indeed, a masterly reading of a masterly work.

THE low-priced Japanese twin-lens reflex camera, the Ricohflex, is now available in the new model VI at $50.45, including a new leather ever-ready case with snap-off front and swivel straps. Features of the new model include an extra-bright ground - glass, self - erecting and closing hood, and single-lever cocking and release tripper.

Young women headed by Miss Joan Myers are serving on the junior committee for the third annual Animal Kingdom Ball, which will be held on Jan. 29 in the main ballroom of the Pierre for the benefit of the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 (UP) -- Attorney General James P. McGranery will leave to the Eisenhower Administration a wide range of investigations and prosecutions to be carried through, a check showed today. His gift to his successor, Herbert Brownell Jr., is the product of work begun in May when he stepped down from the Federal bench in Philadelphia to take over the scandal-ridden Justice Department.

In a desperate effort to save the life of Sister Elizabeth Kenny, paralyzed on her right side by a blood clot in her brain, Dr. John Ogden of Sydney, Australia, her physician, telephoned to Dr. Irving Innerfield of New York for some trypsin. At the time there were just eight vials of trypsin in all Australia -- enough for only four days' treatment.

The decision of the Turkish Government to open up its nationally owned oil fields for development by foreign private capital is, in a sense, revolutionary. It runs so directly counter to the destructive economic hypernationalism prevalent in many underdeveloped countries of the world, of which Iran is the most obvious example, that it merits particular attention.

OVER the equatorial landscape of Kenya, the British Crown Colony in East Africa, lies the frightening shadow of Mau Manu, a secret tribal society whose campaign of murder has forced the imposition of emergency law. The British Government and the Colonial Government of Kenya, trying to crush the movement, are not sure what they are fighting, not even what the name means.

NORWALK, Conn., Dec. 6 -- The City Zoning Commission will hold a public hearing Thursday on the application of the Connecticut Light and Power Company to build a $15,000.000 steam-generating plant on Manresa Island. It is strongly opposed by shorefront residents.

THE impact that the continuing rapid expansion of television is having on radio broadcasting is perhaps most vividly apparent at the year-end when options are picked up -- or allowed to lapse. Recent defections on the part of sponsors mean that some long-standing radio shows will vanish with the old year.

HANOI, Vietnam, Indo-China, Dec. 6 -- Communist-led Vietminh forces have withdrawn from the immediate vicinity of the French perimeter at Nasan. Reconnaissance patrols pushing out today from the isolated French bastion in the Thai country mountains encountered no Vietminh troops within two miles of the Nasan defense area.

PRINCETON, N. J., Dec. 6 -- A gift of $200,000 under the will of John W. Garrett of Baltimore has made possible the establishment of a chair of foreign affairs in the program of Near Eastern studies at Princeton University, Dr. Harold W. Dodds, president of the university, announced today.

NEWARK, Dec. 6 -- The Public Service Coordinated Transport began this week the study of a plan proposed by City Commissioner Leo Carlin to relieve the downtown area of Newark of traffic congestion. Under the plan, about 1,250 daily bus passengers would be transferred to a high-speed trolley car shuttle service in the city's subway, which is an underground trolley line.

A new type of glass fabric has been developed which will broaden the field of laminated materials in the aviation, automotive and industrial fields, it was learned last week. Hess, Goldsmith Co., largest weaver of glass fiber, has gone into production of a glass fabric which stretches while the yarn remains stable.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, Dec. 6 -- A Cuban Airlines plane crashed early today two or three miles northeast of the Kindley Air Force base, taking the lives of probably thirty-seven persons. The plane, a DC-4 en route from Europe by way of the Azores to Cuba, went down shortly after taking off here with eight crew members and thirty-three passengers.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Dec. 6 (AP) -- Australian tennis writers, backed by tradition, virtually handed the twice-postponed Victorian tennis championship to Frank Sedgman today but the small American camp still held out hopes for Vic Seixas against the Aussie ace on Monday.

IT is enough to begin with that a gift book be reasonably expensive, that it be handsomely packaged, and provided with its own box. Exactly these qualities grace a number of old friends reprinted this month that are taking their places among the Christmas items now filling the bookstores.

In your editions of Dec. 1 you quoted excerpts from the "Report of the Jurists" to Secretary General Trygve Lie on ousting subversives from the United Nations staff. It was, on the whole, a notable and valuable contribution to the task of ridding the staff of members guilty of disloyalty or subversive activities.

ONCE again a growing number of collectors of contemporary art are turning their attention to photography. Framed photographs by masters of the camera can be seen on the walls of their homes, along with paintings, drawings, and etchings.
BOSTON, Dec. 6 -- The possibility of a solution to the $1,219,000 Brink's robbery before Jan. 17, 1953, the third anniversary of the crime, was being widely discussed this week in Boston.

Delos (Dutch) Schoch of Princeton was re-elected president of the Rowing Coaches Association of America yesterday at the annual meeting at the Hotel Lexington. Jim Rathschmidt of Yale will serve again as secretary-treasurer.
SPOKANE, Wash., Dec. 6 (AP) -The Amateur Athletic Union certified 182 new national records today, including one in track that was allowed despite protests it was "impossible."

THE schoolmaster Domingo Faustino Sarmiento (1811-1888), whose presidency was the most progressive Argentina has ever known, whose book "Facundo" has been called the "Don Quixote" of Spanish American literature, and who during the dictatorship of Rosas defended the principles of liberty and democracy at the peril of his life, is still the symbol of a century-old struggle.

VIENNA, Dec. 6 -- In line with the anti-Semitic and anti-Zionist attitude it displayed in the recent treason trial of fourteen former Communist officials, the Czechoslovak Government proclaimed the Israeli Minister in Prague persona non grata today and demanded his instant recall. The announcement was broadcast from Prague.
MEXICO CITY, Dec. 6 -- The new Mexican Administration today dismissed 300 municipal inspectors in Mexico City as the first earnest of its pledge to war on graft.

THERE are so many possible uses to which motion pictures may be put above and beyond the most frequent and familiar one of telling a tale that it is almost as hard to define them and establish standards for each as it is to define and establish rigid standards for the uses of words.

CRANBERRIES are raised in quantity in only five states, although small areas of wild berries are found from Maine to North Carolina, westward to Washington and Oregon. Why, then, are they not a usual feature of the home garden? In the first place their moisture requirement is high, and north of Virginia they usually have to be flooded during December, January and February to prevent winterkill.

BELIEVING that in every writer's heart lies concealed a gobbet of professional envy. The Book Review asked twelve authors of some of this year's most popular books to make public confession of what book published this year, other than their own, they wished they had written.

" Designing a Car" subject will be the subject of a free art lecture on Tuesday at 6:15 P. M. in a weekly series at the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street. The speaker will be Jacques Martial, a consultant designer for several automobile makers, who will illustrate his talk with diagrams.

RICHMOND, Va. -- A large store of pictures of the Civil War period made by George Smith Cook, a Connecticut Yankee who became the official photographer for the Confederate Army and who died fifty years ago, were recently discovered in the attic of a house near here and are now on exhibition at the Virginia Museum of Fine Arts here.

Difficulties in remitting earnings to its American headquarters and in importing raw materials soon may halt or force revision of expansion in the vast foreign manufacturing activities of the General Electric Company. Last week William R. Herod, president of International General Electric Company, hinted strongly that his organization is far from satisfied with treatment by foreign governments.

The second annual Mardi Gras of the Junior League of New York will be held on Feb. 17 in the grand ballroom of the Astor for the benefit of the league's Welfare Fund. Mrs. Thomas D. Luckenbill has been named chairman of the committee for the second consecutive year

PINEHURST, N. C., Dec. 6 (AP) -- Judd Brumley of Greeneville, Tenn., North and South Seniors champion, and Dr. S. T. Lewis of New Bern posted identical 73's today to share the lead at the halfway mark of the fifty-fourth annual Southern Seniors Golf Association title event.

THE first of the year's Christ-has shows are scheduled for this week. Programs range from exhibits of holly and mistletoe to corsages and gift packages and New Year's buffet table settings. On Wednesday, for example, a special show staged by the Hunterdon Hills Garden Club in the Methodist Church Social Room in High Bridge, N. J., may be seen from 2 to 5 P. M. and from 7 to 9 P. M.
BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 6 -- With a daring and an influence usually attributed to United States investors an Argentine syndicate has cornered a healthy section of Bolivia's planned industrialization.

THE theme of "The Zone of Indifference," a thoughtful but not always too clear or overly optimistic book, is signified by a citation from the twenty-first chapter of St. Luke following the title page: "And upon the earth distress of nations, with perplexity."

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Dec. 6 -- Failure to meet adequately the public housing needs in southern cities has resulted in "incalculable harm" to human relations in the region, the Southern Regional Council has reported.

FOUR Brazilian cities, each excitingly different from the others and completely unlike any place listed in the United States Postal Guide, can be visited by North Americans who see South America from a cruise ship.
HARRISON, N. J., Dec. 6 -- The Worthington Corporation, manufacturers of machinery and equipment, has formed the Worthington Foundation for charitable, scientific and educational purposes.

DACCA, Pakistan, Dec. 4 (Reuters) -- The rivers of east Pakistan, which form the delta of the great Brahmaputra and Ganges Rivers and have been a severe handicap in building communications, are now being turned to advantage.
GAINESVILLE, Fla., Dec. 6 -- Rick Casares threw a 39-yard pass to Papa Hall the first time Florida got the ball today and Gators went on to a 27-0 victory over Kentucky.

HARRIMAN, N. Y., Dec. 6 -- Members of the American Assembly regarded inflation as less of an immediate threat today than they thought it was six months ago when they spent five days studying the problem. They expressed the view, however, that underlying inflationary pressures were still present and might flare up again as they did in 1950 at the outbreak of the Korean war.

The major portion of the collection of American paintings formed by the Encyclopedia Britannica, a collection which; in whole or in part, has been seen by millions in museums, universities and colleges throughout the country, will be auctioned beginning this week.

HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Dec. 6 -Hofstra College gained its third success in as many starts, by defeating Scranton University of Pennsylvania, 61 -- 12, tonight. The Flying Dutchmen had trouble with the visitors during the first half, leading by only 24 -- 19 at the intermission.

How pensions for its members are being safeguarded under a three-pronged arrangement of benefits was described last week by William C. Greenough, vice president of the Teachers Insurance and Annuity Association, in an address to the thirty-eighth annual Church Pension Conference at the Park Sheraton Hotel.

The initial public hearings into waterfront crime and corruption by the New York State Crime Commission last week have again centered the public's attention on what probably is the largest industry in the metropolitan area -- the Port of New York.

Probably the greatest of all experimental chemists was the late Emil Fischer, Nobel Prize winner of the University of Berlin. He spent years in tearing proteins apart and trying to put the parts together again. Though he did not succeed in synthesizing proteins, which mean beefsteak, milk, egg-white, all living tissue, he did show that they are built up from amino acids of which twenty-five are now known.

THE myth of Talos, the man of brass appointed by Minos to guard Crete, has more than one version. Talos either had molten brass in his veins, or he had the habit of heating himself red-hot and crushing foreigners in his arms. He seems to have been a mythological isolalationist.

For the first time in American higher education, college students are going to have a chance to study Shakespeare and other Renaissance classics direct from the original pages of first editions, Haverford College has announced. This has been made possible through a $2,000,000 bequest left to the college by William P. Philips, New York lawyer and business man.

The annual Yuletide Ball arranged by the Yuletide committee of the Brooklyn Kindergarten Society will be held on Dec. 26 in the Main Ballroom of the St. George Hotel Proceeds will be used for the settlement houses of the beneficiary.

Plans have been formulated for the forty-fourth annual Blue Ridge Ball, a dinner dance, which will be held Jan. 30 in the main ballroom of the Pierre for the benefit of the Blue Ridge School at Bristol, Va. Funds realized from the fete will be donated to the school, which provides educational opportunities for many underprivileged children from remote rural districts of Virginia.

CREATIVE artists working in the motion picture industry under terms of personal employment contracts as well as collective bargaining agreements between studios and the respective talent guilds, or unions, last week were wondering which contract carried the most legal weight.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 6 -- A duel between the colonial powers and an increasing number of small countries that wish to curb their control over backward territories continued today in the General Assembly's Trusteeship Committee, with the voting about evenly divided in this latest exchange.
Detectives of the city narcotics squad believed they had broken up the largest narcotics ring yet uncovered in Brooklyn with the arraignment yesterday of eight men in Brooklyn Felony Court.

PITMAN, N. J., Dec. 6 -- Trustees of the Kircher Eye Fund said today that this community had raised $2,500 to aid two of three members of a family who were blinded in one eye within the last eight months.

FOR the Hundred Neediest Cases of New York, THE NEW YORK TIMES today makes its forty-first appeal. Here on these pages you will find the stories of the Neediest -- stories of heartbreak, loneliness and despair which will end as sadly as they have begun unless those of us who are more fortunate give with a generous hand.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 6 -- The Ohio Supreme Court is expected to postpone until after Jan. 1 action on a recommendation that it approve for Ohio court procedure a canon of judicial ethics prohibiting the taking of news photographs in courtrooms "during sessions of the court or recesses between sessions."

CAIRO, Dec. 6 -- Ali Maher, head of a committee drafting revision of the Egyptian Constitution, is believed to favor a form of government resembling the corporate state idea that was partially developed in Italy before World War II.

AS one whose bent was supremely rational, Shaw should have been as much the master in his prose pamphlets as in his plays. He wasn't. The dazzling shower of intellectual sparks thrown off by the dialogue in his plays has no counterpart in these pages.
The money that one trade association gets from its member companies to further their interests is 2,000 times the amount -- to $1,000 of sales -- that another such group obtains.

ITHACA, N. Y., Dec. 6 -- More than half of Cornell University's 9,500 students will take part in discussion sessions during the university's fourttenth Campus Conference on Religion opening tomorrow and continuing through Tuesday.
I HAVE just finished reading the chapter, "A Long Ash Wednesday," in Sean O'Casey's latest volume of his autobiography, "Rose and Crown," and I am angry.

M. Maldwin Fertig, counsel to Franklin D. Roosevelt and Herbert H. Lehman when they were Governors, announced last week the formation of the Bronx Public Affairs Committee, "to be a permanent watchdog organization interested in civic affairs in the Bronx."

BRIGANTINE ISLAND, N. J., Dec. 6 -- Three bodies were found here today washed ashore on this island two miles north of Atlantic City.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Dec. 6 -fourteen members of a twenty-eight-man panel of college students studying the political aspects of the Soviet threat to the United States today recommended aggressive action, including war if necessary, to hilt communism.

YESTERDAY was St. Nicholas' Day, and the good saint's presence is very much felt in any household where there are children. Already there is a great scurry, but in spite of all the things that must be done, these days before Christmas seem very long to children.

BUCKFAST, England, Dec. 6 (Reuters) -- A Benedictine monk from St. Mary's Abbey here is back from a seven-month tour of Africa and the Middle East -- seven months spent searching for a better kind of bee.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 6 -- The threat of a strike against nine private bus companies in New York City on Dec. 31 will be one of the problems to come before the convention of the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., opening here Tuesday.

6 -- Dr. Lewis W. Jones, president of Rutgers University, has announced that contributions for Rutgers scholarships, research fellowships and physical expansion totaling $1,963,000 were made in the fiscal year ended last June 30.

THE Seventeenth Rochester International Salon of Photography will be held March 6-29 at the Memorial Art Gallery in Rochester. Exhibitors are invited to submit entries in pictorial, nature and documentary sections.

LONDON, Dec. 6 -- Having just escaped the imposition, by statute, of a press council with one-fifth of its members unconnected with the newspaper profession, the British press is preparing to establish a voluntary council drawn entirely from the profession to carry out the functions recommended by a royal commission more than three years ago.

THE succulents are the neat, tailored miniatures among house plants. Although the group includes the cactus family, they are not all cacti, and a great diversity of form may be represented in the smallest amount of space. Even in a single bowl of succulents something is always happening: a new leaf starts to appear, an old one changes color or form or an unexpected and exotic blossom opens.

MOSCOW, Dec. 6 -- The Kiev newspaper, Pravda of the Ukraine, reporting on the plenary session of the city party committee, has described the consequences of the improper selection of personnel. One party worker cited conditions in the Tsepi Gallya factory where he said the chief of the cadre section fixed up his relations with positions in many responsible posts.

The total funds and resources of pension boards of twenty-five religious organizations represented at the thirty-eighth annual church pensions conference at the Park Sheraton Hotel last week were reported as $426,290,548, compared with $392,834,312 a year ago.

IT is natural that there should be a steady stream of books about Mahatma Gandhi. He was so unmistakably great that we know his name will go into history with the chosen few that are never forgotten. Each generation and each age will reinterpret the qualities that make for Gandhi's greatness.

THE decision of television to put many of its programs on film has turned out to be the colossal boner of the year. On every count -- technically and qualitatively -- the films cannot compare with "live" shows and they are only hurting video, not helping it.

Less than half the 11,014 fans who turned out for the start of the nineteenth college basketball season at Madison Square Garden last night were still in the arena at the finish when New York University staggered to an 80-71 victory over Boston College.

Fighting to stay alive in the race for the National Football League's American Conference title, the New York Giants will oppose the Washington Redskins at the Polo Grounds today. A defeat almost certainly would put the Giants out of contention.

IN England one of the weekly duties, and pleasures, is to listen on the radio to Alistair Cooke's Letter from America. It never disappoints and sometimes, as with the discussion of national stereotypes just a few weeks ago, it is superb. For Alistair Cooke is a phenomenon: he is almost an institution, an international institution.

DEBUSSY could be very witty about what he disliked. And one of the developments of the musical life of his time that irked him was what was then the fairly recent practice of collecting folk-songs. "The fashion for popular airs," he wrote, "has spread quickly throughout the musical world.

SPOKANE, Wash., Dec. 6 -- The Amateur Athletic Union, nearing the close of its sixty-fourth annual convention, leveled its guns today on its financial problem and nominated nine men and one woman for the coveted James E. Sullivan Award, which is given each year to the amateur athlete who has done most to advance the cause of sportsmanship.

NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 6 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru, addressing a large public meeting in Bombay tonight, said the Soviet attack on India's truce plan for Korea was "somewhat unkind to us." The Soviet delegate, Mr. Nehru added, "forcefully" rejected the resolution and Communist China immediately followed suit.

NOT even the long winter can dull the enthusiasm of rose lovers. Rose gardens down through the ages come alive as they read about this favorite flower by the fireside. And, too, experiences of fellow growers are shared in the latest American Rose annuals while the snow lies deep on the garden.

HEMPSTEAD, L. I. Dec. 6 -- The Town of Hempstead's new $2,500,000 incinerator, designed to accommodate needs of the increasing population until 1980, will be opened for public inspection at 2:30 P. M. Thursday.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 6 -- Three harness horses, led by W. H. Cane's Good Time, broke the single season money-winning record in 1952.

SUNMOUNT, N. Y., Dec. 6 -- A radical step toward speeding the cure of tuberculosis, featuring early ambulation for patients effectively treated with streptomycin and PAS (para-amino salicylic acid), has been instituted here at the 534-bed Veterans Administration Hospital, just north of Tupper Lake.

MITCHEL AIR FORCE BASE, L. I., Dec. 6 -- Paul Michener, 7-year-old son of Air Force Sgt. Albert Michener, is receiving between 800 and 1,000 letters a day from people wishing him success in his battle against a fatal glandular disease.

SANTA MONICA, Calif., Dec. 6 (UP) -- Dr. Charles Ainsworth Marrin, wealthy eye specialist and son of a late New York City municipal court justice, killed himself early today because he was going blind, authorities reported.

TWO years ago the Eastern German "Democratic Republic" could still claim, with some appearance of reason, to be "progressive" or at least "liberal" in literature and the arts. Though avowedly Communists, its leading literary quarterly, Sinn und Form, was more experimental and less stuffy than anything of the same sort that was published in Western Germany, with the possible exception of West-Berlin's Das Lot.

IN reviewing my book "Crime Without Punishment" (Nov. 9), John H. Lichtblau makes fourteen misstatements of fact. To refute them all requires more space than you could accord me. Thus I must limit myself to a few major points.

France and West Germany are to the concept of west European unity what two pillars are to an arch. Between them the two countries control 85 per cent of west Europe's land area, four-fifths of its population, 75 per cent of its coal and 85 per cent of its steel.

Debutantes who will be presented at the seventh annual Yuletide Assembly to be held on Jan. 2 in the main ballroom of the Plaza will participate in an elaborate and colorful pageant entitled "The Court of Yuletide," a feature of the event.
With the unkind game and big-game seasons soon to close the pressure will soon rest on one of the game animals that can take it and still remain in the cottontail.

READERS of the general press, newspapers and magazines can hardly be blamed for thinking that the mystery novel in 1952 has gone over entirely to the tough private eye school, typified at its worst by Mickey Spillane.
The Salvation Army's soldiers are out in force, as is customary at this season, but their appeal is accompanied here and there by a concealed, slow-speed automatic record player.

THE distance from Tucson, Ariz., to New York City is exactly the same as the distance from New York to Tucson. This simple fact seems to be overlooked by those who ask how one can be happy "so far away" without specifying how far from which or even how far from what.

PARIS, Dec. 6 -- Premier Antoine Pinay asked the National Assembly today for another vote of confidence. The balloting will take place Tuesday since the French Constitution provides for a waiting period. The outcome seemed to be in doubt.

BOSTON, Dec. 6 (AP) -- The Most Rev. Richard J. Cushing, Archbishop of Bsoton, said today "no man in the American chapter of that [trade union] movement's history has given it more dignity, prestige and potential for good than has Phil Murray."

A young ex-soldier, arrested yesterday in connection with a delicatessen store hold-up, was identified later by the police as the red-haired man who had tried unsuccessfully to rob the Park Avenue branch of the Irving Trust Company last Thursday.

NEWARK, Dec. 6 -- William J. Dearden, Motor Vehicle Director of New Jersey, asserted today that the campaign promulgated this week by the Joint Council of Teamsters, A. F. L., to revise or abolish the point system of driving in New Jersey was "an apparent bid for immunity by the teamsters from compliance with traffic laws and regulations."

THE energetic efforts of a small group of conservationists to preserve from the bulldozer Sunken Forest on Fire Island have already had partial success. Sparked by Oakleigh Thorne 2d, a student in the Yale Conservation program, the conservationists' group has bought for $25,000 about one-third of the desired property.

ON Thursday night, directly from the stage, the Metropolitan Opera's production of "Carmen" will be telecast on a closed circuit to various theatres throughout the country. Although it would be premature to venture any guesses as to what this will mean to the musical organization, or what it could mean to the Broadway theatre, it is safe to say that the event is going to be watched by groups interested in the welfare of both.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Dec. 4 (Reuters) -- Alarmed at recent increases in crimes of violence, Turkish Members of Parliament, like some of their British counterparts, are urging the revival of flogging as a punishment.

The Ford Foundation is offering fellowships to young Americans who wish to devote from one to three years to intensive study pertaining to Asia and the Near and Middle East.
