This is the second fellowship offered under the Foreign Study and Research Fellowship Program initiated by the foundation earlier this year.

WHEN John Groth's "Studio: Europe" appeared in 1945 it was greeted by an avalanche of superlatives. Book critics liked the warmth, the humor and the poignancy of his writing; art critics enthused over his uncanny ability to capture the vital moment of excitement in his drawings.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 6 (AP) Braeval Biscuit, 3 1/2 - year - old cream-colored imported miniature poodle from the Seafren Kennels of Mr. and Mrs. Saunders L. Meade of Malvern, Pa., became best in show tonight in the fifty-eighth event of the Kennel Club of Philadelphia.

Igor Bogolepov, a career officer in the foreign service of the Soviet Union until he deserted to the Germans in 1942, said in an address here yesterday that, contrary to an opinion prevalent in the Western world, the Russians were a freedom-loving people whose "war" against the Communist regime had never ceased.

THE HAGUE -- The Netherlands has played host to more tourists this year than ever before and, for the first time in history, Americans were the most numerous. Time was when this placid land of lakes and windmills was off the well-worn track for vacationists.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- A high Democratic official who sat through most of the conferences this week between President Truman and the party's defeated Presidential candidate, Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson, had this to say in private conversation:

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 6 -- Senator Angel Maria Cusano of Uruguay introduced today before the United Nations General Assembly's Economic and Financial Committee a draft proposal to reaffirm the right of each country to nationalize and exploit freely its natural wealth.

Because of successful compliance with an air raid test a year ago, railroads and airlines will be permitted to maintain their regular operating schedules during the city-wide atom bomb drill next Saturday.
In-ancient Phoenicia, it was argued that men were made to live on land, and their physical and mental beings could not survive on the ocean.

THE Civil War, like all conflicts, was as much political as intersectional. There were communities in Alabama and Mississippi which united to denounce secession, refused to join the Confederacy, and from Bull Run to Appomattox stood as lonely islands of Unionism.

An accomplished Japanese artist, Munakata, whose woodblock prints are at once traditional and highly personal, is introduced at the Willard Gallery. The woodblocks are wonderfully mounted on kakemonos and screens, among the former being a very impressive series of disciples of Buddha and bodhisattvas, big solid figures in strikingly differentiated oriental expressionism.
Northeast Airlines, strike-bound since Thursday, continued yesterday to curtail service between New York, Montreal and thirty-four New England cities.

THE Broadway theatrical season, which has just passed its midpoint, has been singularly devoid of musical shows, the total to date being three. Even this figure gives a slightly inflated impression of the real situation for one of these musicals closed almost as soon as it opened while the music for another was borrowed from the Metropolitan Opera repertoire.

THE enterprising nutritionist, who, over a period of some thirty years, has found that suggesting self-help and diets can make friends, influence many people and be handsomely rewarding, again is purveying the plausibility of that ancient maxim, mens sana in corpore sano.

Pleading "immunity from being coerced by the laws and orders of the National Government into participation" in military affairs, a 23-year-old Nebraska farmer has taken action to have the Supreme Court of the United States declare our Korean campaign unconstitutional.

BOSTON, Dec. 6 -- A plan for the reorganization of the district court system of Massachusetts by the gradual replacement of all part-time judges with full-time jurists was embodied in a bill filed this week in the Legislature.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Dec. 6 (Reuters) -- An archaeological team, headed by Prof. Pinhas Delougaz, curator of the museum of the Oriental Institute of the University of Chicago, is digging at Beth-Yerah, "The House of the Moon God," in the Jordan Valley at the site of Israel's largest archaeological mound to find new information on the story of the Holy Land.
CHICAGO, Dec. 6 (AP) -- A steady increase in losses suffered by banks through embezzlements has prompted formation of a banking association to combat such thefts.
MEMPHIS, Tenn. (UP) -- John Rust, who so disliked cotton picking as a boy that he later helped to invent a mechanical cotton picker, was honored here when his bust was unveiled.
Some of the recent discussions on the question of repatriation of prisoners of war seem to me to be based on certain false notions about international law which should be corrected.

THE theme of this book is America's accomplishment and the right to pride that it gives Americans. The volume presents a panorama of our history from the discovery of the New World by Columbus in 1492 -- and even back to Leif Ericson, 500 years earlier -- in a running summary of events distributed in eight periods and coming right down to 1951.

The selection of Martin P. Durkin as Secretary of Labor is President-elect Eisenhower's most controversial and most unconventional appointment to date. Mr. Durkin is a Democrat and voted for Governor Stevenson; he is an A. F. L. man and a critic of the Taft-Hartley law.

THIS little book finds Paul Horgan in the full maturity of his powers, exploiting his carefully garnered competence in narrative and the master etcher's art of spare, economical character portrayal. Not only his selection of subjects in recent years suggests the manner of Willa Cather, he resembles her too in the brilliant management of the suggestive or uncluttered novel.

J. Stewart Baker, chairman of the Bank of the Manhattan Company, struck a familiar chord last week when he told the bank's annual stockholders' meeting that New York and Chicago banks are suffering "discrimination" under the present system of geographic reserve requirements.

THE first daily non-stop service between New York and Havana, Cuba, is announced by National Airlines starting Jan. 1. This is in addition to the company's two daily flights which at present stop at Miami or Washington and Tampa en route between the two countries.

WASHINGTON -- Dec. 6 (AP) -- Most income taxpayers are now getting a booklet designed to simplify filing 1952 Federal returns. The new booklet, the Internal Revenue Bureau said today, contains the instructions, tax schedules and forms that in other years were stuffed separately into an envelope.

AT various periods of his life, Archibald MacLeish has been, if not a jack of all trades, at least a worker at a good many. He has been, simultaneously or singly, poet, football player, editor, lawyer, Assistant Secretary of State, the Librarian of Congress, many more.

ATLANTIC CITY, Dec. 6 -- Renewed confidence in the business world, inspired by the election of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower as President, will be reflected in expanded activity in many lines, including realty and building, Joseph W. Lund of Boston, president of the National Association of Real Estate Boards, predicted here today.

HEADQUARTERS EIGHTH ARMY IN KOREA, Dec. 6 -- There is no question but that General Eisenhower was impressed -- very much impressed -- by what he saw here of the Korean Army. In fact, the most spectacular thing he saw during his entire visit was a simulated company attack by Korean troops on a typical Korean hill.

NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 6 -- Two agricultural development projects being carried out in India with United States financial and technical assistance already are showing concrete results in terms of increased food production and are providing employment to a large number of landless peasants, according to information given today to the House of People (the lower house) by the Food Ministry.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 6 -- Following is the text of a message sent last night by Lester B. Pearson, president of the United Nations General Assembly, to Chou En-lai, Foreign Minister of the Chinese Communist Government, transmitting the text of India's resolution on Korea, which was adopted Wednesday by the General Assembly. (The text of the resolution and a similar message were sent to the North Korean authorities.)

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- Dr. Martha M. Eliot, chief of the Federal Children's Bureau, has urged a four-point attack on juvenile delinquency. Her plea is in the current issue of the Bureau's periodical, The Child.

STARING once more at books upon a shelf, "Keep a stiff upper chin," I tell myself. "This is no time to quake," I say. And, quaking Before the folly of my undertaking, I look, with mind bedazzled and askew, To find, my love, a Christmas book for you -- It being Christmas, when of all the days I would discover the felicitous ways Of pleasing you.

SALT LAKE CITY, Dec. 6 (AP) -- The first "Man of the Year" award ever presented by the National American Legion Auxiliary will go to Dr. Howard A. Rusk of New York, Mrs. Harold Burdett, national chairman of the auxiliary's Rehabilitation Committee, said today.

Mrs. Lytle Hull will be the guest of honor at a dinner to be given on Wednesday in the grand ballroom of the Plaza by the board of directors and the auxiliary board of the Philharmonic-Symphony Society of New York. The event will celebrate Mrs. Hull's twenty-five years as a director of the society and thirty years as chairman of the women's auxiliary board.

HOUSTON, Tex., Dec. 6 (UP) -- Houston recovered from a spell of fumbling long enough to score two quick third-period touchdowns today and closed its most successful season with a 20-to-0 victory over Wyoming before 23,000.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Dec. 6 -- Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson, the defeated Democratic candidate for President, returning by plane from Washington today, said that as yet he had no personal plans for the future.

NIGHT-TIME shopping is taking hold. According to a survey made earlier this year by the National Retail Dry Goods Association leading downtown department and specialty stores were staying open at least one night weekly in eighty-three out of 100 United States cities.

HAVANA, Dec. 6 (AP) -- E. J. (Dutch) Harrison of Ardmore Okla., shot a blazing 69 today to win the Havana invitation golf tournament with a 72-hole score of 270 -- six strokes better than his closest competitors.

TUNIS, Tunisia, Dec. 6 -- Six labor and nationalist leaders were thrown into an internment camp today as an aftermath of the assassination of Farhat Hached, secretary general of the Tunisian labor federation. French authorities said the group had been picked up to forestall a general outbreak of violence.
CEDARHURST, L. I., Dec. 6 -- A stellar field of top-ranked players opened another squash racquets season as the twenty-first annual Gold Racquet competition began at the Rockaway Hunting Club today.

T. Morgan Williams, chairman of the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program, announced yesterday that the blood donor center at 70 West Fortieth Street would remain open evenings in December to accommodate midtown Christmas shoppers.

LONDON, Dec. 6 -- Abandoning a campaign by British Roman Catholics to block Premier Marshal Tito's scheduled visit to London, Bernard Cardinal Griffin, Archbishop of Westminster and Roman Catholic Primate of England, publicly urged today that Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden use the opportunity to protest against anticlerical measures in Yugoslavia.

The United Jewish Appeal will hold its fifteenth annual conference in New York next Friday, Saturday and Sunday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. The meeting will be devoted to the adoption of a quota and the formulation of plans to meet the needs of Jews throughout the world, particularly in Israel.

AFTER more than twenty-four years of issuing passports by the hundreds of thousands to Americans desiring to travel abroad, I made a European trip this fall on a regular $10 green passport, determined to see just what are the hazards and also the rewards of purely private travel as an everyday, unofficial American.

BORODIN'S Prince Igor, which from the standpoint of public performance usually means the Overture and the Polytsian Dances, now is available in a full-length recording made in the U. S. S. R. under the direction of A. Malik-Pashayev and released in this country by arrangement with Leeds Music Co. (Period, three disks).

BOWIE, Md., Dec. 6 -- Jockey Dave Gorman, who has been doing a bit of vacationing (and a bit more eating than usual), was five pounds over his normal riding weight for the running of the $59,700 President's Plate Handicap at the Bowie track today, but he had no worries about that fact.

Thousands of embryo inventors scattered from coast to coast want to convert their ideas into money. "I have an idea," they write to the United States Patent Office, "but I do not know how to patent or sell it. What do I do?"

A flood of 285,700,000 proof gallons above normal consumption of American whisky is facing the distilling industry in the next eight years. Furthermore, the distillers would have to pay in Federal taxes at the current rate nearly $3,000,000,000 on a product which, as one distiller expressed it, "we might have to pour down the drain."

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 6 (AP) -- Harold E. Stassen, picked by Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, President-elect, to administer the foreign-aid program of the United States, said today his prime objective was "peace and good living conditions for all the world's peoples."
The new Adriatica Navigation Company passenger liner Messapia will start her maiden voyage from Italy to Greece, Cyprus and Israel next Thursday.
Better quality merchandise at lower prices is in prospect for crews of ships sailing out of Atlantic Coast ports as a result of a new "stop chest" plan of the Seafarers International Union, A. F. L.

TUNIS, Tunisia, Dec. 7 -- Tunisia was outwardly calm today under heavy French security and strictly enforced curfew regulations, but the two-day-old unsolved murder of Ferhat Hached, leader of the Tunisian labor movement and militant nationalist, worked like a slow poison in the atmosphere of this French protectorate capital.

Mario Jazzetti, Italian pianist who made his New York debut last season at Town Hall, gave his second local recital yesterday afternoon in the same auditorium. His exacting program comprised Beethoven's "Appassionata" Sonata, the four Ballades of Chopin, Debussy's suite, "Pour le piano," a Nocturne and a Tarantella by Martucci and Liszt's "Mazeppa."
Only four films, including an importation from France, comprise the pre-holiday film fare this week in first-run theatres. The programs follow:
RAPID CITY, S. D., Dec. 7 (UP) -- Fire swept through a wooden Air Force barracks where officers were sleeping early today and killed five and injured six of them.

Reports come from New Delhi that the Swiss Mount Everest Expedition has been compelled to turn back in one of the most determined attempts to scale the highest mountain in the world. Great interest has attended the group's progress up the icy slopes of Mount Everest.

Cotton prices on the New York Cotton Exchange dropped last week with the greatest losses being recorded in near deliveries. Despite a firm beginning, Friday's closing prices were 27 to 76 points below the levels of the previous week. The market of the preceding week had been up 27 to down 19 points.

They were tempting fashions that Bergdorf Goodman gathered together for a resort showing on the store's third floor last Friday morning. All were cast in a five-scene pageant under the headings: "Going places", "Lazy days", "Around and about", "Eye catchers'', and "Night life".

The recent forecast that two decades hence helicopters would be flying more than 6,000,000 passengers annually into and out of the New York metropolitan area may have sounded fantastic to many people. If it did, it is largely because the helicopter is still the greatest novelty in the family of man-made birds.
PHOENIX, Ariz., Dec. 7 -- Governors of a dozen western states and three territories assembled here today for the annual Western Governors' Conference, a two-day meeting on regional problems.

Recent tenement fires have taken a heavy toll of the lives of children, men and women. One aspect which is implicit in the entire tragic business has almost been ignored. It is no accident that most of those who died have been Puerto Ricans and Negroes.

PARIS, Dec. 7 -- Andre Marty, veteran leader of the Communists of France, was deprived today of all his functions in the party and the charges made against him were turned over to his party cell. He probably will be expelled from the party.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 7 -- Twelve of the sixteen leading dairy countries of the world have witnessed a swing from butter to margarine similar to that taking place in large parts of the United States, according to an interim report of the Committee on Commodity Problems of the Food and Agriculture Organization.

In eighteen months the Federal Reserve authorities have achieved success with their flexible credit policy, according to a joint article by G. Rowland Collins and Marcus Nadler in the current bulletin of the Institute of International Finance of New York University.

The present policy of the Board of Education is to dismiss teachers who refuse to answer questions as to their political affiliation. This policy has been met with cries from teacher groups of "witch hunt," "oppression" and "fascism." On the other hand, this policy enjoys the support of those who demand the dismissal of teachers who are Communists.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- On the basis of two factors -- a public awareness of the importance of the industry to New England's economy and the possibility of pressure in Washington to narrow the labor gap between the North and South -- New England textile industry leaders are taking a brighter outlook on the future.

The four men's clothing stores of Witty Brothers will enter the haberdashery business tomorrow. The outlets will carry hats, shirts, sport shirts, ties, socks, jewelry, belts and underwear for the first time.

NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 7 -- An informed source reported today that a high powered consultative committee consisting of top Communist leaders and strategists from all Asian countries would soon be established in Peiping.

From one point of view President Lester B. Pearson of the United Nations General Assembly spent money uselessly when he transmitted the Korean resolution on Saturday to the Governments of North Korea and Communist China. He already knew what the answer would be.

HEIDELBERG, Germany, Dec. 7 (AP) -- United States soldiers stationed in West Germany, Britain and France committed 1,399 crimes in the six-month period ended Oct. 31, the Army's European headquarters here said today. Included were three murders, 74 rapes, 461 assaults, 57 robberies and 307 thefts.

ROME, Dec. 7 -- Confusion reigned for three hours this afternoon in the Chamber of Deputies, which held an extraordinary Sunday session to hasten approval of a highly controversial electoral reform bill before general elections scheduled for next spring.

INDEPENDENCE, Mo., Dec. 7 --Without the usual fanfare at attending a Presidential visit, President Truman returned today to his home here. He made the visit to attend funeral services for his mother-in-law, Mrs. David W. Wallace, and at his own request there was a minimum of advance public notice on the trip, which began early yesterday evening on a special train over the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad.

The second program by Jose Limon and his admirable company of dancers at the Juilliard Concert Hall on Saturday evening added two more new works to the season. Both of them had their world premieres in the American Dance Festival in New London last summer.

Those who attend the Composers Forum concerts at the McMillin Theatre of Columbia University are so accustomed to modern, dissonant music that, at the second forum of the season on Saturday night, considerable stir was caused by a work that was freely and unabashedly melodious.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., Dec. 7 -- Jack Sutphen, already certain of the fall series title in the Larchmont Yacht Club's dinghy program, scored his fifth triumph of the frostbite season by taking today's regatta with Rum Dum.
BERLIN, Dec. 7 (AP) -- The secret police have started arrests in the Soviet zone that may presage East Germany's version of the recent Prague purge trial.

Appointment of four assistant vice presidents to vice presidents by the Bankers Trust Company was announced over the week-end by S. Sloan Colt, president. They were Talbot Babcock, Graham H. Brewer, W. Neal Fulkerson Jr. and Robert B. Lee.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Dec. 7 -- Club owners of baseball's two major leagues, in concluding one of their most harmonious sessions, announced today through Commissioner Ford C. Frick, legislation that they confidently expect will have a beneficial and far-reaching influence not only upon their own affairs but extending on down through the minors.
The colorfully dressed young woman in the embroidered Lebanese skirt and blouse at the convention of Junior Vegetable Growers this week is really as American as a girl from Colorado can be.

Michael Potter, chairman of the City Fusion party, announced yesterday that the leaders of 400 civic organizations had been invited to attend a meeting Feb. 10 at the Advertising Club to explore the possibility of presenting next year a fusion candidate for Mayor behind whom all forces for good government could unite.

Herbst Brothers, seed merchants, who recently relocated at 678 Broadway, have sold the five-story store and loft building at 162 Chambers Street, near Greenwich Street, to the Merrin Electric Company, marine electrical contractors, who will vacate their present quarters at 120 Beekman Street after alterations to the Chambers Street property. The latter was sold for cash through Raymond E. Ryan, Inc., broker. The expansion move will triple the space now used by the electrical contractors.

The end of the road seems at last to be in sight for the St. Lawrence Seaway and the connected hydroelectric development of the International Rapids section of the river. Tomorrow the Federal Power Commission in Washington will begin hearings on the hydroelectric part of the plan.

The ninetieth military review of the Reserve Officers Training Corps Regiment of Xavier High School was held yesterday in the Seventh Regiment Armory at Park Avenue and Sixty-sixth Street in honor of Cardinal Spellman.
An offer to arbitrate personal injury cases arising from automobile accidents was made yesterday by the American Fore Insurance Group in the interest of relieving court congestion."
DENVER, Dec. 7 (AP) -- Protestants today were reported tackling the "greatest home missions task in the history of American churches."

MIAMI BEACH, Dec. 7 -- The open pair championship, final event in the nine-day winter session of the twenty-sixth annual national contract bridge championships, tonight went into the fourth and final session here at the Sea Isle Hotel.

A good many things happened at yesterday afternoon's New Friends of Music concert at Town Hall. Paul Hindemith was present, conducting his own music and appealing on a New York podium for the first time since 1948. There was a crowded house, which seemed to include every musician in town.

DETROIT, Dec. 7 (AP) -- A major engineering advance in 1953 automobiles will be an optional item -- refrigerated air conditioning. At around $600 extra it will be in the class of a luxury item. Nevertheless it will be offered in several Chrysler and General Motors models for next year.

RIVERSIDE, Calif., Dec. 7 (AP) -- Heavy clouds and biting winds near the crest of 11,485-foot Mount San Gorgonio today forced back four skiers who had attempted to reach wreckage believed to be that of a C-47 plane missing since Monday with thirteen men aboard.

Nora Kaye made her second Sunday night appearance with the New York City Ballet at the City Center last night, this time in the Jerome Robbins-Igor Stravinsky work, "The Cage." Nicholas Magallanes, Yvonne Mounsey and Michael Maule had the other roles.

A proposal to set up a nonprofit Long Island Commuters Cooperative to own and operate the bankrupt Long Island Rail Road was made public here yesterday by Lincoln Epworth and Sherman S. Lawrence, New York attorneys. They had filed the proposal with the Interstate Commerce Commission in Washington with a petition to intervene in present reorganization hearings.
TOKYO, Monday, Dec. 8 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,457, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Monday, Korea time:
Today, Patterns of The Times brings you several suggestions that will enable you quickly to enlarge your holiday wardrobe.

In wholesale fashion, temporary replacements will be made in John Golden's successful revival of "The Male Animal" for the purpose of giving its retinue of stars a rest. Effective Dec. 21, Buddy Ebsen will assume Elliott Nugent's part for one or two weeks.
A major steamship company executive is scheduled to be the prime witness today when the State Crime Commission resumes its open hearings into the New York waterfront situation.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 7 -- Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer will make a new version in Technicolor of its silent film classic, "Ben Hur," which was a tremendous box-office success in 1927. When production will get under way and who will step into the role of the Roman soldier, portrayed originally by Ramon Novarro, are matters that remain to be determined.

BONN, Germany, Dec. 7 -- The primary military problem facing the meeting of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization in Paris next week is the almost certain prospect that the West German divisions regarded as indispensable to a successful defense of Europe will not be ready next year or, as matters stand now, in 1954.
BURBANK, Calif., Dec. 7 (AP) -- Lockheed announced today a new airliner that the company called the fastest, longest-ranged and most elegant ever built in the United States.

In an effort to broaden man's knowledge of insects, spiders, reptiles and other amphibia four men will start out next week for the Bahama Islands aboard the forty-three-foot auxiliary schooner White Wing on a six-month expedition supported by the American Museum of Natural History.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 (UP) -- A Federal grand jury this week opens an inquiry into $80,000,000 in loans granted to the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.
MELBOURNE, Australia, Monday, Dec. 8 (AP) -- Vic Seixas of Philadelphia whipped Australia's mighty Frank Sedgman today, 8 -- 6, 3 -- 6, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 4, to win the Victorian tennis championship.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 7 (AP) -- The Los Angeles Rams racked up their seventh straight victory today, a resounding 45-to-27 triumph over the Green Bay Packers to remain tied with Detroit for the division lead in the National Football League. A crowd of 49,872 watched.

ROME, Dec. 7 (UP) -- The Italian Federal police swooped down on "little Stalingrad" and other points near Milan and Naples and seized hundreds of tons of weapons and ammunition, it was announced today.

LONDON, Dec. 7 -- London was blacked out again tonight by a dense fog that had lasted more than forty-eight hours and showed no sign of lifting. Reminiscent of the record thick weather that lasted from Nov. 23 to Dec. 2 in 1948, the fog has halted or disrupted all traffic in the city except the subways.

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public, which will mature within twelve months, amount to $63,482,173,231. They consist of Treasury bonds, certificates of indebtedness, bills and notes as follows:

WASHINGTON, Dec. (UP) -- Joseph C. McGarraghy, chairman of the 1953 Inaugural Committee, said today he expected Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's inauguration ceremonies to be the largest and best attended in the Capital's history.

The hydrogen bomb, with its potential "to cause universal sterility or, worse, the reproduction of a generation of abnormal mutations, or monsters, is morally hideous," the Rev. Donald Harrington said yesterday morning in his address at the Community Church, 40 East Thirty-fifth Street.

CEDARHURST, L. I., Dec. 7 -- Diehl Mateer Jr. of Merion, the country's second ranking player, captured Gold Racquet laurels today as the Rockaway Hunting Club's twenty-first annual squash racquets competition came to a close.

British sterling moved irregularly last week. It hardened at the outset on the improved gold and dollar surplus in November of $128,000,000, which lifted the pound to $2.80 11/16, highest since mid-May. Later, on the Churchill plan that Britain had decided to limit its defense program because of financial difficulties the pound turned to the offering side and drifted slowly to a close on Friday of $2.80 1/4.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 7 -- Bill Haughton, who was currying horses for a dollar a day eleven years ago, picked up the biggest bundle of cash of all harness horse drivers this year.

Last Monday's piece here dealt with stories out of Washington indicating that plans were under consideration for a new super Atlantic Stabilization Fund -- a sort of Financial Collossus, with one foot planted in the United States and the other in Western Europe.

MEXICO CITY, Dec. 7 -- An intricate, long-range plan to swing Mexico into the column of Argentine-led "third force" countries in the event of world war, and sooner if possible, has come to light in a strange document.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 (AP) -- State Department officials said today that they were looking into reports that a veteran foreign service officer had been carrying secret papers when he and his wife were arrested on intoxication charges early yesterday morning.

DETROIT, Dec. 7 (AP) -- End Cloyce Box helped the Detroit Lions continue their drive toward the National Conference championship of the National Football League by grabbing two over-the-shoulder touchdown passes within six minutes of the first period today. The Lions went on to trounce the Chicago Bears, 45 to 21, before 50,410 fans. In all, Box caught three touchdown passes from Quarterback Bobby Layne, who had one of his greatest days.

A municipal income tax to help the city balance its 1953-54 budget and buttress a long-range financial program for succeeding years is being considered by Mayor Impellitteri and his fiscal advisers. Imposition of such a tax is viewed by them, however, as definitely a "last resort" step, to be taken only if the city's financial predicament leaves no alternative.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 7 -- The California Medical Association, through its policy-making House of Delegates, approved "in principle" today a revolutionary proposal to standardize medical fees.

NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 7 (Reuters) -- Swiss mountain climbers will make a new attempt on unconquered Mount Everest unless rival expeditions with improved oxygen equipment succeed in scaling the peak first.
FORT WAYNE, Ind., Dec. 7 (AP) -- The New York Knickerbockers rallied in the fourth quarter, but couldn't knock Fort Wayne off its winning stride tonight, and the Pistons won, 102 -- 91.

Italy, on which we depend almost entirely for chestnuts, is supplying us abundantly this year. As a result of the large shipments that have been arriving recently -- and they will continue through February -- the price of the thin-shelled, sweet nuts is down to 19 cents a pound, a dime less than at this time last year.
A familiar landmark in the Bronx was dedicated to a new use yesterday -- to serve as the home of the Westchester-Bronx branch of the Young Men's Christian Association.

A panel of six high school students last night, at The New York Times Youth Forum, televised over Station WABD from the DuMont Adelphia Theatre, Fifty - fourth Street and Seventh Avenue, unanimously portrayed the United Nations as a valuable force in the search for peace.
A new device that makes it possible to replace severely broken teeth was described yesterday at the Tri-State Conference on Dentistry for Children held in the Governor Clinton Hotel.
Four major studies to evaluate the voluntary health insurance plans that have mushroomed in the last decade were announced yesterday by the Health Information Foundation.

DETROIT, Dec. 7 (UP) -- Red Kelly's goal late in the third period enabled the Detroit Red Wings to gain a 1-to-1 tie with the Boston Bruins in a National Hockey League game before 10,982 fans at Olympia tonight.

ALBANY, Dec. 7 -- Governor Dewey announced today the appointment of R. Burdell Bixby, his executive assistant for nearly three years, as secretary to the Governor, and of Harry J, O'Donnell, a former newspaper man, as executive assistant. The designations are effective tomorrow.

TAIPEI, Formosa, Monday, Dec. 8 (AP) -- Maj. Gen. William C. Chase, who spent three days with President-elect Eisenhower in Korea, said today the entire strategic situation in the Far East was reviewed and discussed during the Eisenhower visit.
A tour of famous New York kitchens will be held tomorrow afternoon for the benefit of the Parents League of New York and the Yorkville Youth Council.

SOMMERVILLE, N. J., Dec. 7 -- While 100 state troopers and police carried on an intensive search for a convict who escaped at 9:30 A. M. today from the county Jail here, their quarry broke into a home tonight and stole a suit of clothes.

Sixty-four voluntary hospitals reported yesterday that they had sustained a loss of $6,315,360 in operating their out-patient departments for the year ended last June 30. They appealed to the Board of Estimate for a city appropriation of $3,000,000 to meet in part the loss entailed in caring for those out-patients who otherwise might be city charges.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 (UP) -- Representative Clarence J. Brown said today that he saw no conflict between his proposal for a "new Hoover Commission" and Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's plans for streamlining the Federal Government.

New working conditions for performers in radio and television here were tentatively agreed upon over the week-end by the major broadcasting chains and the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists, A. F. L. The proposed contracts would run for two years.

HANOI, Vietnam, Indo-China, Dec. 7 -- While quiet reigned today around the isolated French mountain bastion of Nasan, developments 150 miles southeast in the Tonkin south delta sector pointed to intensification of the struggle between the French and Vietminh forces in this thickly populated zone of battle.
ST. LOUIS, Dec. 7 (AP) -- Billy Morrow Jackson, 23 years old, who lost the use of his hands following a world War II injury, opened his first one-man art show here today.
CHICAGO, Dec. 7 (UP) -- The Toronto Maple Leafs notched two third-period goals tonight as Harry Lumley shut out the Chicago Black Hawks, 2 -- 0, and dropped the Hawks into a first-place tie.

Russia's "very definite anti-Semitic policy" is a long-range program designed to gain control of the Middle East oil fields by "making love to the Moslems and getting them on the side of the Soviets," Rear Admiral Harold B. Miller, U. S. N., retired, declared yesterday.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 7 -- After years of undisputed sway as the magnet for sightseers in New York, the Statue of Liberty is being nudged uncomfortably by a newcomer. The recently completed United Nations headquarters has reached a point in public interest where the loose statistics of tourist attractions demand its recognition among the top half dozen "musts" in the visitor's itinerary.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 7 (UP) -- The resurgent Pittsburgh Steelers, quarterbacked by Jim Finks, former Tulsa star, pulled their second upset in two weeks today as they downed the failing Forty-Niners, 24 -- 7.

A broad hint that the city Administration would welcome a new offer by the Port of New York Authority to take over for operation and development the municipal piers and allied waterfront facilities was made yesterday by Controller Lazarus Joseph.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Dec. 7 -- The Israeli Foreign Ministry announced today that it would send a note to the Czechoslovak Foreign Ministry in the next few days asserting Israel's views on the "anti-Semitic nature of the Prague trial and calumnies which it directed against the State of Israel and its leading personalities."

CAMDEN, N. J., Dec. 7 -- Mr. and Mrs. Len Carey's Doberman pinscher, Ch. Rancho Dobe's Storm, from Cos Cob, Conn., denied the top award in the larger Philadelphia show the night before, came through in the Camden County Kennel Club fixture tonight.

SINGAPORE, Dec. 7 -- As expected, the election alliance of the Malayan Chinese Association and the United Malays National Organization made a clean sweep of five out of the seven towns contested yesterday in Malaya's first nation-wide elections.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 (AP) -- Veterans organizations observed the eleventh anniversary of Pearl Harbor Day today with brief ceremonies at Arlington National Cemetery.

Retail activity was heavy after Thanksgiving and the cold weather spurred orders for winter coat promotions. Many buyers in the wholesale markets here last week planned post-Christmas sales, according to McGreevey, Werring Howell Company, resident buying officer. The popular-priced dress departments stressed spring items with few fill-in orders for holiday merchandise. Pastel failles and jerseys were most active in junior holiday dress lines.

Cardinal Spellman, surrounded by a sword-bearing guard of honor of the Knights of Columbus, his staff and members of the Staten Island Catholic clergy, yesterday dedicated the new church edifice of the Roman Catholic parish of the Blessed Sacrament at Forest Avenue and Manor Road, West New Brighton, S. I.

A number of novel aluminum products have been developed in Europe "that may literally change the face of Europe and the British Isles," it was reported here yesterday by Frank R. Nichols, president of the Nichols Wire and Aluminum Company. Davenport, Iowa.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- The prospect that Michael V. DiSalle, who was the first Administrator of the Office of Price Stabilization, might lead the Government's over-all economic stabilization program in the final weeks of the Truman Administration gained currency today as Mr. DiSalle was winding up a mission as special adviser to stabilization authorities.

THE big league trail has ended for George Robert Tebbetts. But it will be only a temporary absence. He'll be back again. He can't miss. The Cleveland Indians wisely appointed the shrill-voiced Birdie as the manager of their top-ranking farm team, Indianapolis, and some major league club is a cinch to grab him once he's completed his apprenticeship.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- A. Congressional housing subcommittee urged today that better home planning and quality, together with greater protection for buyers, be afforded in future building under Government-aided housing programs.

Like a drowning person reviewing his entire life within a few seconds, the New York Giants yesterday at the Polo Grounds saw the whole season flash back in front of their eyes. Even as Hugh Taylor was catching his third touchdown pass. the one that wrapped up a 27 -- 17 victory for the Washington Redskins, something within the Giants died.

PEARL HARBOR, Dec. 7 -- A shrine "at which all Americans will recall the price of freedom and will forever remember those who have paid the price" was dedicated here today just eleven years to the minute after the Japanese attack began on Pearl Harbor.

Ponchielli's "La Gioconda" will return to the Metropolitan Opera during the week starting Dec. 15. It will be the first performance of the work since 1948 and several singers will appear in it for the first time, including Fedora Barbieri as Laura, Cesare Siepi as Alvise, Mario Del Monaco as Enzo and Jean Madeira as La Cieca. Fausto Cleva will conduct the Tuesday evening performance.

Plans for a three-story candy factory in the Bronx have been announced in connection with the purchase of a vacant plot of land fronting 280 feet on Antin Place, with an "L" through to Bronxdale Avenue, by the Delicia Chocolate and Candy Manufacturing Company, which owns the adjoining building.

AUBURN, N. Y., Dec. 7 (AP) -- Representative John Taber, Republican, of New York, said tonight that Army engineers were about $50,000,000 short in their estimates of the cost of building Air Force bomber base at Plattsburg.

CHICAGO, Dec. 7 (AP) -- The Cleveland Browns today clinched at least a divisional title tie in the waning National Football League race by scoring in the first sixty-three seconds and adding a third-period field goal for a 10-0 victory over the Chicago Cardinals.

BANGOR, Me., Dec. 7 -- Development of a "clear image" lens, said to be powerful enough to give vision to about half the estimated 150,000 partially blind persons in the United States, was announced here today by Dr. William Feinbloom at the annual meeting of
The forty-first annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund opened yesterday with donations of $78,740.25 from 249 contributors in hand.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 7 (AP) -- Big Harry (Bud) Grant caught eleven passes for 203 yards and two touchdowns to lead the Philadelphia Eagles to a 38-21 victory today over the Dallas Texans. The Eagles' seventh victory against four defeats carried them into second place and kept alive their title hopes in the American Conference of the National Football League.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 7 -- Steel demand was rolling along last week at a high level with little in sight to indicate a marked change in the tempo for the near future. The distribution of demand was general and had a more nearly normal pattern. That condition was believed to have been due to a general pick-up in all types of manufacture using steel.

Twenty-three vessels, with a total capacity of 230,840 gross tons, were added during October to the list of ships building here and abroad under the requirements of the American Bureau of Shipping, bringing to a post-war high of 3,420,575 gross tons the volume of ship construction supervised by that group.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., Dec. 7 (AP) -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt condemned today the "guilt by association" technique she ascribed to Congressional committees in hunting Communists and urged a strengthening of the Federal Bureau of Investigation as a better way to protect the country from subversion.

CHICAGO, Dec. 7 -- A moderate improvement in the pit trade in grain and soybean futures was registered last week, with total purchases averaging about 51,000,000 bushels daily. This compared with approximately 47,000,000 bushels for the corresponding week last year.

A long solo goal by Hy Buller in the third period enabled the Rangers to draw even with the Canadiens of Montreal in their National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night and although they waged a blistering attack on the Habitants' cage in the subsequent minutes, the New Yorkers were unable to break the 2-all tie, which stood to the end of the contest.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- George Meany declared tonight that he was prepared to step down from the presidency of the American Federation of Labor, a post to which he had been elected less than two weeks ago, if it would make possible organic unity with the Congress of Industrial Organizations.

The great number and variety of exhibitions listed for this week make it one of the busiest in the art season so far. Christmas is the theme of the 100 prize-winning water colors in the second International Hallmark Award, which will be on view at Wildenstein's starting Thursday.

HONG KONG, Nov. 24 -- On the night of Oct. 8, Nationalist commandos holding island bases along the Chekiang coast in the East China Sea staged a fairly typical raid. It was directed against the Communist-held island of Chikwanshan, which lies two miles off the lower tip of a mainland peninsula that separates Lotsing Bay from Taichow Bay to the north.

Tunisian events are conforming to the unhappy pattern of the vicious circle. The struggle for complete independence sets up its French reaction. The consequent tension leads to bloodshed. The bloodshed leads to repressions which, in turn, increase the tension and the certainty of new bloodshed. The bloodshed leads to repressions which, in turn, increase the ten!sion and the certainty of new bloodi shed.

Officers of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace joined yesterday in laying the cornerstone for a new international center for nongovernmental organizations across the street from the United Nations headquarters.

" The Little Madeleine: The Autobiography of a Young French Girl," by Mrs. Robert Henrey, has been scheduled for Jan. 12 publication by Dutton. It is a description of the author's girlhood in Montmartre, where she was born in a one-room flat above a cafe on the same street where Picasso and Utrillo had their studios.

Edwin J. Locke Jr., special coordinator on economic and technical assistance in the Near East, arrived here yesterday by air from Beirut, Lebanon, and said that, as far as he knew, he had had no differences with the State Department over the application of the Point Four program in the Near East.

KLAMATH FALLS, Ore., Dec. 7 (AP) -- Snow-laden fifty-mile-an-hour winds knocked out all electrical power lines to this southern Oregon town of 15,000 today. Suffering from the sub-freezing temperatures was widespread during the three and a half hours that the city was without electricity.

Winning seven of his eight bouts in the final round-robin, George Worth of Salle Santelli took top honors in the open saber competition for the Nicholas Muray medals at the New York Athletic Club yesterday.

The green light is on for the importation of cut-rate Iranian oil to this country, a New York oil broker declared yesterday in commenting on a State Department announcement that United States interests were free to purchase Iranian oil if they dared risk the consequences of legal action by the Anglo-Iranian Oil Company.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Dec. 7 -- In the next four years private electric utility concerns in the South will add 6,452,000 kilowatts to their generating capacity as part of a $4,149,000,000 ten-year expansion program, the Southern Association of Science and Industry reported today.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 7 -- Northern California's worst storm of the season moved on tonight after having taken five lives. Heavy snows temporarily halted seven trains, blocked highways and disrupted communications. Pounding rains flooded river valleys.

Arrangements for voluntary retirement of the bonds of the Atchison, Topeka Santa Fe Railway Company were announced yesterday in a letter to shareholders by F. G. Gurley, president. Aim of the plan is retirement of "almost all of the debt," according to Mr. Gurley, in the next forty-three years.

It wasn't long ago that a Columbia professor from New York set out armed with a Guggenheim grant to run down the origin of place names in Europe. Another college professor at the University of Missouri -- which happens to be in a town called Columbia -- has been rounding up American place names with particular attention to those found on the map of many or most of the states of the Union.

CHICAGO, Dec. 7 -- Chemical companies manufacturing the so-called "miracle" fibers are practicing deception on a "vast scale" in their claims for the products, according to J. B. Wilson, president of the American Wool Council, Inc.

KEARNY, N. J., Dc. 7 -- Three persons died and at least ten others suffered injuries here tonight when a truck containing ten student farmers returning from a weekend in New York City was in collision with two passenger cars in the old Lincoln Highway.

In your editorial of Nov. 27 headed "F. S. A." you listed the impressive titles of bureaus that fall within the jurisdiction of that agency. These concern the health, education, social and economic welfare of our people. You pointed out that they will be the grave responsibilities of Mrs. Oveta Culp Hobby after January.
The American Medical Association, which traditionally has frowned on sensational publicity for the medical profession, apparently has decided to throw in its lot with Dr. Kildare.

Down at the Public Theatre on Second Avenue and Fourth Street, Herman Yablokoff is offering a new English adaptation of "Uncle Sam in Israel," the musical play that has been running there as a Yiddish attraction for almost two months.

With the approach of Christmas, Fire Commissioner Jacob Grumet yesterday warned New Yorkers of the "grave danger to life and property" in the use of candles, cotton batting and other highly flammable materials in Yuletide decorations.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- William Pierce Rogers, at 39 years of age, is one of the youngest men on the team of President-elect Dwight D. Eisenhower and will be one of the youngest ever to assume the responsible position of Deputy United States Attorney General.
SANTA FE, N. M., Dec. 7 -- Eight or nine prisoners seized two guards at the New Mexico State Penitentiary late today and refused to release them after hours of bargaining with prison officials.

Bill Pudvah Jr., now in his fourth season as Choate School's hockey coach, is happy because his luck is changing. Since he took charge of the varsity team there has been virtually no ice at the Wallingford (Conn.) school -- but things are going to be different.

The Rev. Dr. John Howard Melish, who was removed in March, 1949, as rector of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Holy Trinity, Clinton and Montague Streets, Brooklyn, for supporting alleged radical activities of his son, the Rev. William Howard Melish, was the recipient yesterday of many tributes expressing confidence in him.

As spiritual preparation for the advent of Christmas, people should strive anew to acquire the basic Christian virtues of faith, love and hope, the Rev. Rolf Lyshoei declared in a guest sermon yesterday morning at the St. Ignatius Protestant Episcopal Church, Eighty-seventh Street and West End Avenue.

RICHMOND, Va., Dec. 7 (UP) -- Reynolds Metals Company announced today the purchase of Berbice Company, Limited, a British Guiana subsidiary of American Cyanamid Company with a productive capacity of about 20,000 tons of bauxite a month.

CAIRO, Dec. 7 -- Gen. Mohammed Naguib, Egyptian Premier, stated today that he would meet, on a date to be announced, with all Egyptian political leaders to strive to unite the nation for the sake of the supreme interests of Egypt.

Accused of breaking shop windows and stealing costume jewelry and women's shoes, which the police said he offered for sale as Christmas gifts, Thomas Atkins, 47 years old, mechanic and ex-convict of 255 Martense Street, Brooklyn, was held without bail in Brooklyn Felony Court yesterday by Magistrate Matthew F. Fagan.
GENEVA, Dec. 7 -- Europe is somewhat hesitantly conceding that a general economic recovery may be under way.

HARRIMAN, N. Y., Dec. 7 -- The American Assembly, closing three days of restudy of the problem of inflation, reversed the field today with a recommendation that the new National Administration set up promptly a program to combat a business recession if it should occur.

ABOARD THE U.S.S. HELENA, off Wake Island, Monday, Dec. 8 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the President-elect, arrived off Wake Island aboard this cruiser today and was joined by John Foster Dulles and two other Cabinet designates to begin a series of talks on United States foreign policy in the Orient.

The American Civil Liberties Union announced yesterday that it believed no question of civil liberties was involved in the issue of commuting the death sentences of Julius and Ethel Rosenberg, convicted atom spies.

PARIS, Dec. 7 (AP) -- Before the Central Committee of the French Communist party acted against Andre Marty and Charles Tillon, Leon Mauvais, acting as committee prosecutor, gave the bill of particulars on the "fractional" activity of the two. Both erred, he said, on these points:

Advertising men who have sold their customers -- clients, if you insist -- on "institutional" and "goodwill" schedules should keep the late G. Lynn Sumner's book away from the men who pay the bills. "How I Learned the Secrets of Success in Advertising"* is determinedly down to earth. It considers no results that cannot be measured and it shows how to get measurable results.

After seven hours of sharp debate, the executive committee of the Zionist Organization of America late yesterday afternoon endorsed in principle a plan calling for the extension of activities by the American Zionist Council. In essence, the Council would be empowered to coordinate several areas of Zionist activities that are now being carried on by separate groups here.

LONDON, Dec. 7 -- As a stimulant to the stock markets the excellent gold reserves statement issued by the Treasury last week rather badly missed the mark. Absence of any favorable response, however, in no way implies dissatisfaction with the progress shown.

ITHACA, N. Y., Dec. 7 -- Cornell University's fourteenth annual Campus Conference on Religion opened tonight with a supper and the first of three panel discussions on the theme of "Personal Security."

Sir Gerald Templer, British High Commissioner for Malaya, announces that Britain has decided to set up a full-scale new army in Malaya as a major step toward giving self-rule to the Federation. Other steps, looking in the same direction, are receiving attention.

Accommodations for 21,400 pupils will be provided in the twenty-three new schools and additions authorized by the Board of Estimate for construction in the 1953 capital budget, the Board of Education reported yesterday.

VIENNA, Dec. 7 -- A detailed examination by economic experts here of the evidence given during the recent treason and sabotage trial in Prague has convinced them that they have been too credulous in assessing Communist claims of rapid mechanization by the Soviet bloc.

AMSTERDAM, Dec. 7 -- The spectacular improvement in Holland's foreign exchange reserves is shown by figures published by the Netherlands Bank this week. On Sept. 30 there were 1,090,000,000 guilders in convertible currencies against 341,000,000 at the end of 1951.

ROME, Dec. 7 -- Italy, struggling to rise from the ashes of defeat and troubled by a strong Communist minority, overpopulation and major economic problems, nevertheless has created sizable and growing armed forces.

MADRID, Dec. 6 -- Labor circles said today that about 6,500,000 Spaniards, including industrial workers and private office employes, would receive by the end of this year an extraordinary bonus to offset temporarily the steady rise in the cost of living and ease the economic plight of the people.
Residents of the Bay Ridge area and students at two Brooklyn colleges are expected to add to mass blood donations this week in response to the Brooklyn Red Cross appeal for pre-holiday blood donors.
PARIS, Dec. 7 -- The trend in trade between France and Italy has in the past year been reversed. The deficit for France continued from 1947 to 1951.

Straddled, bracketed and zeroed in by the heaviest guns in Christmas advertising history -- and nobly responding, according to retailers' reports -- the consumer is already being plotted for the barrage of Valentine's Day. The coordinates are being laid down by Joseph Broslaw, executive vice president of the National Valentine's Day Council.

The Philharmonic Chamber Ensemble played the first concert of its second season Saturday evening at the Theresa L. Kaufmann Auditorium of the Lexington Avenue Y. M. and Y. W. H. A. Dimitri Mitropoulos, conductor of the New York Philharmonic - Symphony, whose interest and sympathy were at least partly responsible for the successful opening of this venture by the men of his orchestra, conducted.

Observers from several foreign countries will be at the atom bomb training exercises in the Bronx next Saturday, it was announced yesterday by Lieut. Gen. C. R. Huebner, director of the New York State Civil Defense Commission.

Money is much affected by tile law of diminishing returns. Personally, there are few thimgs a man can do with his second million he can't do just as well with his first. To a progressively lesser degree, the same can be said of the second and first one hundred thousand, the second and first ten thousand, the second and first thousand.

TOKYO, Monday, Dec. 8 -- Fifth Air Force F-86 Sabre jet pilots patrolling Northwest Korea yesterday shot down seven of the Chinese Communists' Russian-designed MIG fighters. It was the Allies' largest bag of the enemy aircraft in a day since mid-September.

Two staff appointments in connection with the new 30,000-ton Italian luxury liner Andrea Doria were announced yesterday by W. H. McConnell, vice president in charge of passenger traffic of the American Export Lines, general agent here for the Italian Line. He said both were veteran employes of the Italian concern.

The Board of Transportation announced yesterday that it had filed with the Public Service Commission, with Mayor Impellitteri's approval, a complaint against the rate now charged by the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., for electric power for the IND subway division of the municipal transit system.

CHICAGO, Dec. 7 -- Trading in grain futures last week raised many conflicting cross-currents of speculation, reflecting in part the sluggish export trade in wheat, uncertainty over crop developments in the Southwest, heavy deliveries on December contracts of all grains and the influx of Canadian oats and rye into the Chicago market.

WIGGENHALL ST. MARY, England, Dec. 7 -- Although nobody seems to know for sure who holds the world's record for wheat-growing, there is reason to believe that three brothers, John, George and William Turrell, smashed it this year on their farm here in Norfolk, ninety miles north of London.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 7 -- The difficulties that the countries in Asia and the Far East have been meeting in obtaining capital goods and materials from suppliers, mostly European, are reviewed in a report by the secretariat of the United Nations Commission for the region to its Committee on Industry and Trade, just released in Bangkok.

A plot about 190 by 100 feet on the north side of East Sixty-ninth Street, between Second and Third Avenues, has been assembled for a syndicate of operators for possible improvement with a twelve-story apartment house.

Allan Savitt, president of Allan Savitt Associates, a New York publicity firm, filed a suit in Federal Court yesterday seeking $250,000 each from Mickey Mantle, star outfielder of the New York Yankees; the New York Yankees, Inc., and Murray Kaufman according to the Associated Press.
SYRACUSE, N. Y., Dec. 8 (AP) -- Virgil Day requested today withdrawal of his nomination to the Wage Stabilization Board as an industry member.

TOKYO, Dec. 8 -- Japan's Diet heard charges today that United States authorities in Japan had kidnapped and detained a Japanese Leftist writer for more than a year in an effort to make him an American spy.

To accomplish acquisition by Atlas Corporation of controlling interest in Italian Superpower Corporation from Institute per la Ricostruzione Industriale (I. R. I.), Floyd B. Odlum, Atlas president, announced yesterday several changes.
HARTFORD, Conn., Dec. 8 -- Gov. John Lodge today called on state agency heads of Connecticut's government to help him cut the budget so that the need for tax increases next year could be minimized.

Mia Slavenska and Frederic Franklin and their little ballet company, with Alexandra Danilova as guest artist, came into town last night for a week at the Century Theatre and succeeded in surprising us all. The troupe was assembled and the repertoire put together for the primary purpose of touring, and with absolutely nothing pretentious about it.

The American Federation of Labor indicated yesterday that it would take a "hands off" attitude toward disclosures of pier union racketeering, even though its top leaders made no secret of their hostility toward Joseph P. Ryan, president of the International Longshoremen's Association, and the way his union was run.

A model of the gilded coach in which Queen Elizabeth II will ride to her coronation ceremonies in June went on display yesterday at a hobby fair in the quarters of the Hobby Advisory Council, 3 East Fourteenth Street. The exhibition will run through Jan. 10.

DETROIT, Dec. 8 -- The Michigan Board of Canvassers today rejected the Senate Elections subcommittee's second request for a recount of ballots in the disputed contest between Blair Moody, Democrat, and Charles E. Potter, Republican, for Senator.

One of the most hectic places in the world these days is the floor of the Italian Chamber of Deputies. Members are knocking each other over the head with chairs, tossing inkpots about, exchanging fisticuffs, shouting, screaming and generally providing a lively, if somewhat disgraceful, picture of the workings of Italian politics.

BOSTON, Dec. 8 (AP) -- Tommy Collins, Boston featherweight, bounced back from two first-round knockdowns tonight to gain a unanimous ten-round decision over Lauro alas of Monterrey, Mexico, the former lightweight champion, before a Boston Garden crowd of 13,909. Salas weighed 131, Collins 128.

TORONTO, Dec. 8 (AP) --Japan's Ambassador to Canada appealed today for Western investment in his country and a chance for Japanese goods in Western markets. Contrary to general belief, he said, high-cost production now rules much of Japan's industry.

The fourth annual Pillsbury Grand National Bake-off took place yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel's grand ballroom. One hundred finalists, chosen from hundreds of thousands of entries, participated. The contestants, eighty of whom are in the senior section and twenty in the junior section, represented thirty-six states.

Immigration officials at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, yesterday picked up the passports of Edwin H. Cerney and his wife, Isobel, of Menlo Park, Calif., when the couple arrived from London at 4:25 P. M.

TRENTON, Dec. 8 -- Sanford Bates, State Commissioner of Institutions, said today a very large part of the $50,000,000 New Jersey is investing in welfare construction is being devoted to mental hospitals and training and protection of mentally retarded children.
Reference is made to an article under Topics of The Times which appeared in THE NEW YORK TIMES on Nov. 22 and which had to do with chestnuts for the turkey.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- Roger L. Putnam, Director of Economic Stabilization, declared tonight that the prospects of reconstituting the Wage Stabilization Board were "very excellent." He asserted a determination jointly with Henry H. Fowler, Mobilization Director, to keep the whole stabilization program in operation.

CINCINNATI, Dec. 8 -- "Radiology is one of the youngest of the medical specialties, yet it wields an influence in organized medicine far in excess of its comparative size," Dr. Joseph C. Bell of Louisville said here today in his presidential address at the opening of the six-day annual convention of the Radiological Society of North America.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 8 -- Israel accepted today the compromise Palestine proposal worked out by neutral members of the United Nations calling for direct Arab-Israeli peace talks end their four-year-old dispute.

ABOARD THE U.S.S. HELENA, En Route to Hawaii, Tuesday, Dec. 9 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the President-elect, and key members he has designated for his Cabinet continued secret conferences on Korean war policy today as this cruiser plowed through rolling seas.
CASABLANCA, French Morocco, Dec. 8 -- Morocco's Nationalist-led riots have brought death to more than fifty persons and verged on open rebellion tonight.

A spirited defense of hair preparations which have been accused in recent weeks of a measure of responsibility for starting fires was offered yesterday by John D. Conner, general counsel of the Chemical Specialties Manufacturers Association.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 8 (AP) -- Directors of the United States Trotting Association today voted forty-two rule book changes for the harness racing sport in 1953.
Gross income of the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation for the first nine months this year exceeded the 1951 total by over $48,000,000, Robert E. Gross, president, reported to shareholders yesterday.

Seton Hall, highly rated among Eastern collegiate basketball teams, is "not a one-man club," John (Honey) Russell, the coach of the New Jersey Pirates, told the Metropolitan Basketball Writers Association yesterday at its weekly luncheon-meeting at Leone's Restaurant. Russell chided the scribes for overpublicizing 6-foot 11-inch Wally Dukes, who looms as a unanimous All-America choice.

LONDON, Dec. 8 -- Commenting on the State Department's declaration that if United States citizens attempt to trade in Iranian oil they must do so at their own legal risk, Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden reaffirmed today that such a risk does exist.

The round-table conferences held from time to time at Arden House, the Harriman campus of Columbia University, are almost unique in one respect. The delegates include representatives from such disparate groups as business leaders, professional men and women, trade union officials and housewives, thus comprising a typical cross section of intelligent Americans.

A group of eight wallpapers newly added to the Herman Miller collection makes it possible for an amateur decorator to achieve an effect of consistency. For the papers, designed by Alexander Girard, are planned in both color and style to go with the textiles introduced by this architect earlier the year.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 8 (AP) -- Ellis Ryan said tonight he "definitely" wanted to remain president of the Indians and that he expected the front-office squabble within the club to be settled "in a satisfactory manner" sometime this week.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- George Murphy, film actor, today was named director of entertainment for the three-day party that begins before and ends after the inauguration of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower as President.

The results of the Venezuelan election on Nov. 30 were about what one might expect. The Union Republicana Democratica, a mildly leftist group, led the poll before the Government decided to stop counting ballots.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (UP) -- Senator Richard M. Nixon said today that Senator Robert A. Taft's recent outburst against the selection of Martin P. Durkin as the new Secretary of Labor did not mean "a major break" in Republican ranks.

All Presidents-elect must give some thought between Election Day and Inauguration Day to the work that lies ahead of them. They must select their chief associates and discuss policies and plans. Mr. Hoover spent part of this period on a journey to several Latin-American countries, where he tried to lay the foundations for a more neighborly relationship among the nations of this hemisphere.

HARTFORD, Conn., Dec. 8 -- The abolition of Connecticut's town and city court system was suggested today by the State Judicial Council. The recommendation was sent to Gov. John Davis Lodge and will be referred to the Legislature when it convenes on Jan. 7.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 8 -- The Peron government was charged today with having "definitely assumed the character of a totalitarian government based on force only." The charge was made by Union Civica Radical, Argentina's largest opposition political party, as it ended a three-day national convention.

The testimony of a bullet-crippled former convict who pleaded that felons be restrained for their own good from working on the docks gave a dramatic touch yesterday to the State Crime Commission hearing into waterfront conditions.

The manpower shortage in defense production is complex but not critical, according to a consensus of military and educational authorities and representatives of large Government contractors who attended the first of the Armed Forces Regional Council meetings in New York yesterday.
Fluoridation of this city's water supply to reduce tooth decay was advocated here last night by the president of the American Dental Association, Dr. O. W. Brandhorst of St. Louis.
BETHESDA, Md., Dec. 8 (AP) -- Marines recently wounded in Korea thanked today the inventor of an armored vest that helped save their lives.

Events today: Philadelphia Orchestra, Eugene Ormandy, conductor, Efrem Zimbalist, violinist, Carnegie Hall, 8:30 P M.; Mieczyslaw Borszowski, pianist, Town Hall, 8:30; Amy-Ann Andrews, soprano, Carnegie Recital Hall, 8:30; Marcia Hannah, organist, St. Paul's Chapel, Columbia University, 5:05; Erica Morini, violinist, Brooklyn Academy of Music, 8:30.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (UP) -- A 41-year-old Detroit mother tearfully told a special House committee today that her son, then 16 years old, had become an accused murderer after having read crime comics and "girlie" magazines.

CAIRO, Dec. 8---The Egyptian Government has decided that Egypt needs a new constitution. A national committee will be formed to study the creation of a new charter and will be free to consider whether Egypt should remain a kingdom or become a republic. This was announced today by a Government spokesman.

ONLY duck hunters and the manufacturers of snow removal equipment are interested in having the wintry winds begin blowing without delay, and as the open seasons on waterfowl are drawing to a close in many areas, the former are growing impatient.
Considerable vigor was shown yesterday by the stock market. Best gains in two weeks brought out an increase in trading and a centering of interest in the better type investment issues.
Food supplies are adequate and prices for 1953 should remain "pretty much at present levels." Paul S. Willis, president of the Grocery Manufacturers of America, asserted yesterday.
It is difficult to believe that President Truman has as little knowledge of the consequences of his acts as his latest decree overriding the Wage Stabilization Board would seem to indicate.

The right of the State Crime Commission to hold public hearings was upheld yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Felix C. Benvenga, who at the same time denied motions by five dock bosses to vacate subpoenas calling for their appearance as witnesses.

TUNIS, Tunisia, Dec. 8 -- A French firing squad executed at dawn today three Tunisians convicted by a military tribunal of the murder of a French gendarme near Tunis. The murder occured at the outbreak of the clashes between Arab nationalists and the security forces in this French protectorate in January.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Dec. 9 -- American Sabre jets flew a protective screen over Northwest Korea yesterday for bridge-busting fighter-bombers of the Fifth Air Force and shot down one of the Communists' Russian-designed MIG fighters -- their eighth in two days.
JERUSALEM, Dec. 8 (UP) -- Mr. Ben-Zvi lives in a three-room apartment and his furniture is on the dilapidated side. His desk is the same small, rickety table he has used for more than two decades.

PARIS, Dec. 8 -- Dr. Grayson L. Kirk, acting head of Columbia University, met the rectors of French universities here today to explain the plans for the observance of the bicentennial of Columbia in 1954. Dr. Kirk came from London, where he had discussed the plans with educational and other leaders of Britain.

Charles Sawyer, Secretary of Commerce, said yesterday on his return from Europe that he would ask Sinclair Weeks, who will succeed him, and W. Walter Williams, Under Secretary of Commerce-designate, to a conference in Washington.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (AP) -- The Government reported today that world production of natural and synthetic rubber in the first ten months of this year totaled at least 2,185,500 tons.

MILLEVILLE, N. J., Dec. 8 -- Four men were arrested and four new sedans, allegedly stolen recently in New York City, were confiscated by state and local police here today after one vehicle valued at $3,250 was offered for sale for $1,000.
Plans to purchase the John A. Roebling's Sons Company and its two New Jersey plants were announced yesterday by the Colorado Fuel and Iron Corporation.

A 700-car garage was opened yesterday on the site of the old Hippodrome, Avenue of the Americas from West Forty-third to Forty-fourth Streets. The off-street facility will occupy the basement level and the second and third floors of a five-story building. Construction started July 16, 1951.

BOWIE, Md., Dec. 8 (AP) -- Gaining his second straight victory of the meeting, Phantom Farm's Press scored a length-and-a-quarter decision today in the $5,000 St. Michaels Purse. The 3-year-old son of First Fiddle was obliged to withstand a claim of foul.

Despite the presence of forty or fifty customers, a pistol-pointing hold-up man got $500 in cash from a teller, in the Peoples Industrial Bank at noon yesterday and fled without attracting the attention of either the customers or the other bank employes.

The storm which hit the Pacific Coast over the week-end was to some extent an example of misplaced energy. There was too much wind, too much rain, too much snow. Rivers got out of bounds, railroads and highways were blocked, thousands of persons lost time that was -- or seemed -- precious.
Several hundred members of the National Association of Insurance Commissioners moved into the Commodore Hotel yesterday for their annual mid-winter meeting. The parley will continue five days.

NEWARK, Dec. 8 -- Known to have nearly $17,000 on deposit in Newark banks, Mrs. Mildred Shafer, 41 years old, of 161 Plane Street, was sentenced to thirty days in the Essex County Penitentiary today for begging. She was arrested Friday by Patrolman James Donahue, who said she was annoying pedestrians and asking for money on downtown Newark streets.
ALBANY, Dec. 8 (AP) -- The State Board of Canvassers today released this breakdown, by counties, of the official New York vote in the Nov. 4 general election:

Donn Moomaw, the U. C. L. A. player with double letters in his name, was the outstanding lineman in college football during the 1952 season, in the opinion of the nation's sports writers and broadcasters.

NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 8 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru presented to both Houses of Parliament today a report on India's first five-year plan. The report puts its emphasis on adopting the "democratic approach" in the execution of the plan.

Goldman, Sachs Co. and Piper, Jaffray Hopwood, head a group of forty underwriters today offering an issue of $17,00,000 3 1/8 per cent sinking fund debentures due on Dec. 1, 1972 of Pillsbury Mills, Inc. at 100 1/4 per cent and accrued interest.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- W. H. Sebrell Jr., director of the National Institutes of Health, told the National Food and Nutrition Institute today that obesity had replaced the vitamin-deficiency diseases as the "No. 1 nutrition problem in the United States."

Mario Pei, associate professor of Romance Philology at Columbia University and author of "The Story of English" and "The Story of Language," will have his first novel published in March by John Day. Mr. Pei, an authority on the Middle Ages, has based his story on the Song of Roland.
Global output of newsprint reached a record high of about 10,250,000 tons in 1951, according to a compilation announced yesterday by the Newsprint Service Bureau.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 8 -- After thirteen delegations had voiced objections to a Uruguayan proposal for reaffirming the right of each state to nationalize and exploit freely its national resources, the Uruguayan delegation won an adjournment today.

Discussing the effects of television upon children, Dr. Peter Neubauer, an authority on child psychology, said last night in a lecture that the fears to which youngsters are subjected in their home lives are related closely to those produced by certain television programs. He addressed 300 persons at a parents' meeting in the Downtown Community School, 325 East Eleventh Street.
The first "Meistersinger" of the season was given last night by the Metropolitan Opera Association in Broadway's famous theatre of song.

The resignation of John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State-designee, as chairman of the board of trustees of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace was accepted "with regret" yesterday by the board at its semiannual meeting.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (AP) -- Sammy Baugh, rated among the greatest passers in football history, announced today he would retire as a Washington Redskins player after one more game.

A merger of two prominent maritime unions, one affiliated with the American Federation of Labor and the other with the Congress of Industrial Organizations, is expected to be effected soon after the first of the year, it was learned yesterday.

MONTREAL, Dec. 8 (Canadian Press) -- Frank Selke, general manager of the Montreal Canadiens of the National Hockey League, tonight announced the purchase of Gaye Stewart, left winger of the New York Rangers, for the waiver price of $7,500.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (AP) -- Lawyers for the State of Kansas, acting on the eve of a historic Supreme Court test, defended today a Kansas law permitting segregation of white and Negro children in some grade schools.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- Vice Admiral William M. Callaghan, commander of the Military Sea Transportation Service, told five representatives of tramp ship operators today that the Navy agency was not in a position to grant their "radical relief measures."

The Consolidated Edison Company said yesterday that it actually had made a concession to the city on the concern's 37 per cent increase in charges for subway power. Except for this concession, the utility declared the new rates had followed a pattern of increases ordered into effect by the state's Public Service Commission last Aug. 4 for other large commercial consumers.

Because of higher Federal excise taxes, liquor advertising expenditures declined this year for the first time since Repeal in 1933, said W. W. Wachtel, president of the Calvert Distillers Corporation, at the weekly meeting of Advertising Men's Post 209 of the American Legion, yesterday in the Lexington Hotel.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 8 -- The Transport Workers Union of America, an affiliate of the Congress of Industrial Organizations with a membership of some 112,000 workers, announced tonight that it would seek a forty-hour work week with no reduction in the forty-eight hour pay scale for all transit workers from coast to coast.

Mayor Impellitteri last night expressed his personal opposition to a city income tax, but left the door open to the possibility that such a tax might have to be enacted to help the city out of its financial muddle.

To become president of the new Biscayne Television Corporation, Niles Trammell resigned yesterday as board chairman of the National Broadcasting Company and a director of the Radio Corporation of America. Mr. Trammell has joined James M. Cox Jr. and John S. Knight and their associates in formation of the new company which filed an application with the Federal Communications Commission yesteray for a television station on Channel 7 at Miami, Fla.
