The program board of the Columbia Broadcasting System will consider today the possibility of resuming the Ken Murray television show on Tuesday evenings from 8 to 9 o'clock. Other major program changes also are up for consideration.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (AP) -- The Government today set its 1955 target of cobalt supply at 27,000,000 pounds, more than two and one-half times the supply in 1950 before the rearmament program gained headway. The revised goal set by the Defense Production Administration is an increase of 6,000,000 pounds over the expansion total set last May.
Mayor Impellitteri inspected fifteen bright new civil defense fire engines yesterday noon in the plaza of City Hall, and read a proclamation declaring this New York City Civil Defense Week.
PHOENIX, Ariz., Dec. 8 -- The annual Western Governors Conference explored the possibility today of limiting Federal control by sharply restricting the Government's taxing powers within the states.

A program under which many thousands of children in stricken areas in the country are to receive protection against paralytic poliomyelitis was announced yesterday by E. Roland Harriman, president of the American Red Cross. Mr. Harriman emphasized the importance of public support of the plan, which depends on increased contributions to the National Blood Program, as well as on additional financial support for the Red Cross.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 8 (UP) -- Tony DeSpirito maintained his Tropical Park average of a winner a day by piloting Jack Carroll to victory in the first race today. The nation's leading jockey failed with six other mounts.

James Lees Sons Company will spend $5,500,000 on capital improvements in the next eighteen months, Joseph L. Eastwick, president, announced yesterday. The company, fourth largest carpet manufacturer in the country, has spent $1,700,000 in similar expenditures this year and a total of $15,000,000 since World War II for plant improvement and expansion.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Dec. 8 (AP) -- Vic Seixas, the American Davis Cup captain, handed Frank Sedgman and the confidence of Australian tennis fans a severe jolt today by defeating the Australian star, 8 -- 6, 3 -- 6, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 4, to win the Victorian singles championship.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 8 -- Yugoslav sources asserted today that Italian and Roman Catholic church "irredentist" elements had been defeated in the elections held yesterday in Yugoslav-occupied Zone B of the Free Territory of Trieste.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 8 -- Dana Andrews and Randolph Scott will do plenty of hard riding and fast shooting in their next pictures. Andrews, operating under the Universal-International standard, will star in "Outlaw Haven" as a Confederate officer who encounters difficulties on a mission along the Texas-Mexican border, near Brownsville, to buy ammunition to help further the Civil War.

DETROIT, Dec. 8 (AP) -- Walter P. Reuther said today he would be willing to give up the presidency of the C. I. O. for lesser office if it could help toward "effective" A. F. L.-C. I. O. unity. His statement was made in a national television interview on his return from the Atlantic City convention at which he wsa elected president of the C. I. O.

PARIS, Dec. 8 -- French Cabinet leaders met with Premier Antoine Pinay and President Vincent Auriol at the Elysee Palace tonight for a special conference concerning the outbreak of violence in Morocco, coupled with the disorders in Tunisia and the situation of the French territories in North Africa in general.

NEW DELHI, Dec. 8 (AP) -- India's five-year plan sets out as its central objective "to raise the standard of living of India's people and open to them opportunities for a richer and more varied life." It covers almost every phase of the nation's industrial, commercial and agricultural life, as well as recommendations for expansion of the communications, health and education programs.

Capt. Herman Schwartzberg, one of thirty suspended policemen on departmental trial under charges of taking bribes from Harry Gross, convicted bookmaker, testified yesterday that the jailed bookmaker's younger brother, Jack, tried to extort $1,000 from him to keep him out of the graft proceedings.

ALBANY, Dec. 8 (AP) -- New York State, casting its largest vote in history, gave Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, President-elect, an official plurality of 848,214 votes over Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson in the Nov. 4 election.
San Francisco awarded four issues of various purpose bonds totaling $15,000,000 yesterday to a syndicate headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc. Maturity dates range from 1953 to 1967.

There are various schools of belief, all firmly held, about what constitutes the best meal of the day. One stresses breakfast, pointing out with authority that a proper breakfast will make a proper day, whereas a poor one will make a day that will be blue throughout.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- The National Guard Bureau announced today that organization of the 5,400 planned Army units of the Guard in the states, territories and District of Columbia had been 96 per cent completed.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 8 -- Dr. Henry Augustus Pilsbry, internationally known zoologist, observed his ninetieth birthday today by working as usual in his office at the Academy of Natural Sciences of Philadelphia.
ALBANY, Dec. 8 (AP) -- William J. Waters, managing editor of The Ithaca Journal, today was elected president of the New York State Associated Press Association.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed steady yesterday, 2 to 26 points net higher than on last Friday.

NORTH TARRYTOWN, N. Y., Dec. 8 -- A 50-year-old railroad employe was arrested here early today as the "pants burglar" who had been entering darkened homes in the Sleepy Hollow countryside of Westchester County since 1948.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 8 -- For the second time the nation's writers have voted Good Time, son of Hal Dale-On Time, the harness racing horse of the year. He also was chosen in 1950.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- The Vice President-elect, Senator Richard M. Nixon, returned from Mexico City today and told reporters that it was essential that the Eisenhower Administration should not make the same "mistake" as the Democrats in "loading" the Cabinet with members of one party.

Members of the pharmaceutical industry were warned yesterday that there is a "steady pressure" to broaden special Federal controls over the drug field, such as regulations requiring that new products meet standards of effectiveness as well as safety.

There is no place like home for hearing all about the troubles that beset the other families on the street and how financial problems are mounting as a result. The physical or mental ills may vary, but the economic difficulties are ever present. Over the dinner table you learn that Mr. B., down a few doors, has developed a heart condition and will be unable to work.
CHICAGO, Dec. 8 (AP) -- Notre Dame and Army athletic directors plan to meet next month to discuss resumption of the famed football rivalry, a Notre Dame official said yesterday.

Gifts from widely scattered areas of the country added $9,266 yesterday to the forty-first annual appeal of the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, bringing the total for the first two days to $88,036.25.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Dec. 8 (AP) -- The president of the National Farmers Union said today a farm program that included firm supports and prices at 100 per cent of parity was essential if this nation was to avoid a depression similar to that of the Nineteen Twenties.

ALBANY, Dec. 8 -- Governor Dewey urged the Board of Regents today to take immediate steps to "develop safeguards" against the possibility of unethical relationships between physicians and pharmacists and between phycians and drug wholesaling companies.

Despite commercial bankers' opposition, New York savings banks plan to press for broader branch office powers and "have strong hopes" that suitable enabling legislation will be enacted at next month's session of the Legislature. The plans, including a decision to seek limited borrowing powers for the savings banks, were disclosed yesterday at the mid-year meeting of the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks at the Commodore Hotel.

LONDON, Dec. 8 -- Over the week-end, which brought the news that Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower had said after his visit to Korea that he had "no panaceas, no trick ways of settling any problems," the British relaxed.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 8 -- Dr. Howard A. Rusk, Director of the Institute for Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation of the New York University-Bellevue Medical Center, said tonight that rehabilitation must be met dynamically with programs that were integrated into medical care.

CHARLESTON, S. C., Dec. 8 (AP) -- Five Negro physicians have been admitted to membership in the Charleston County Medical Association. This was said to be the first time in the history of South Carolina medical groups that white and Negro doctors have belonged to the same local organization.

Pierre Langlois, French middleweight, last night celebrated his return to American boxing with a ten-round victory over Harold Green, rugged Brooklynite, in a slashing battle before about 3,000 fans at the Eastern Parkway Arena, Brooklyn.

The announcement of the State Department that American concerns are at liberty to purchase Iranian oil if they wish to do so does not change the legal situation. Ever since the Iranian Government nationalized -- perhaps the better word now is expropriated -- the properties of the Anglo-Iranian Oil Company in Iran Americans have been free to buy the oil if they were willing to run the legal risks involved.

NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 8 -- Maulana Abul Kalam Azad, Minister of Education, emphatically denied today Communist allegations in the House of the People (the lower house of Parliament) that American teachers in a local college were practicing racial discrimination against Indians.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Dec. 8 (AP) -- Mrs. Bill Meyer, wife of the recently released manager of the Pittsburgh Pirates, is en route here by plane from Knoxville, Tenn., to be with her husband, now recovering from an attack of pneumonia.

A record sales volume for Christmas toys will be established this year because of the increased use by stores of lay-away plans and the earlier start of Christmas promotions, Norman G. Wintermantel, president of the Toy Manufacturers of the U. S. A., said yesterday at the association's annual meeting at the Park Sheraton Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- A letter that Secretary of State Dean Acheson wrote on Oct. 12 was thrown back at him today as evidence that he lacked "an awareness of the present danger posed by the great number of subversives who have been allowed to occupy 'key' positions" in the United Nations.
Following are excerpts from testimony by some of the witnesses at yesterday's open hearing of the State Crime Commission. The questioning was by members of the commission staff.

" DEMOCRACY is a frontier institution as far as the modern world is concerned." This bold statement and many similarly provocative ideas may be found in "The Great Frontier"* by Walter Prescott Webb, a learned, well-written, original and challenging contribution to the growing library of books that seek to find a pattern in history.

Kuhn, Loeb Co., New York investment bankers, and S. G. Warburg Co., Ltd., London bankers, have formed a new company in Toronto, Ontario, called L. N. T. North American Holdings, Ltd., which will invest in industrial and financial enterprises in the United States and Canada.
Assistant District Attorney Julius Helfand charged yesterday that a bookmaking enterprise in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn had been operating with police protection.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Dec. 8 -- The Israel Philharmonic Orchestra last night canceled its scheduled, performance of Richard Strauss' "Till Eulenspiegel."
TOKYO, Tuesday, Dec. 9 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,458, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M. Tuesday, Korean time:
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (UP) -- The vote in the Nov. 4 election passed the 60,000,000 mark today -- by far the largest number of ballots, ever cast in any United States Presidential election.

LONDON, Dec. 8 -- After a week end of fog paralysis, London revived temporarily as the weather cleared around midday today. The respite was a short one. The fog settled down again at sunset and reduced visibility to a few yards.

BASEBALL men have no sense of humor in their official actions. They are more inclined to be pontifical and a bit on the stuffed shirt side. But the threats they are tossing in the direction of Bill Veeck are real funnybone-ticklers. It's almost as if they used as their theme song the Gilbert and Sullivan ditty, "Let the punishment fit the crime."

LONDON, Dec. 8 -- Tempers cooled sufficiently in the House of Commons tonight for the Labor party to withdraw its motion of censure against the Deputy Speaker, Sir Charles Macandrew, whom it had accused of partiality, incompetence and impropriety.

CHICAGO, Dec. 8 -- An initial bulge in December wheat of as much as 3/7 cents from the closing price of Friday was a big surprise to shorts, and this example of latent strength in the market started active buying not only of other wheat deliveries but of other grains as well.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- The State Department said today that Foy David Kohler, one of its top policy planners, had two secret documents with him at the time of an automobile accident that led to his arrest on charges of public intoxication early last Saturday.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (AP) -- Attorney General James P. McGranery today announced the arrest for deportation of Jack Ignatius Dragna, described by the Department of Justice as a Los Angeles racketeer.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 8 -- India rejected today the joint United States-United Kingdom resolution calling for immediate negotiations between India and Pakistan with a view to settling the five-year-old Kashmir dispute. The negotiations were to have been directly concerned with the issue of the number of troops to remain on each side of the cease-fire line at the end of a period of demilitarization.
SCARSDALE, N. Y., Dec. 8 -- Mr. and Mrs. Reuben T. Carlson will give a supper dance on the night of Dec. 20 at The Birches, their home here, to introduce their daughter, Miss Catherin Boykin Carlson.

During its recent session in this city the executive board of the International Confederation of Free Trade Unions, representing labor organizations in seventy countries, visited the United Nations as guests of Trygve Lie. It was a significant gesture, for these two agencies are working side by side to achieve the same goals -- world peace and the advancement of living standards.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- The Soviet Embassy issued a visa today to permit the Rev. Georges Bissonette to enter the Soviet Union to take over the duties of the Rev. Arthur Brassard, the only Roman Catholic priest in Moscow.

MIAMI BEACH, Dec. 8 -- Official results in the open pair championship, final event in the twenty-sixth annual national contract bridge championships, conducted during the last nine days, were announced early today.

George H. White, ace Federal narcotics agent, was cleared yesterday of contempt charges when he agreed to give the name of his informant to a special Federal rackets grand jury investigating Thomas (Three-Finger Brown) Luchese, underworld overlord.

SOMERVILLE, N. J., Dec. 8 -- Russell Ford, 30-year-old convict, was recaptured today after a twenty-four-hour manhunt following his escape from the Somerset County jail. He will be taken into court in irons tomorrow and receive sentence as a multiple offender. He faces a mandatory life prison sentence.

A British spokesman appealed here last night for a cut in American tariffs to promote "trade, not aid," and immediately ran into an exporter's counter-appeal against British exchange controls as a barrier to markets when the United States defense economy tapers off.

The eleven graduating seniors on Columbia's 1952 football team were honored by their predecessors last night at the annual dinner of the football division of the Varsity "C" Club at the Men's Faculty Club.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (UP) -- The Selective Service received orders today to induct 537 physicians and 286 dentists during February.

Last night at the Essex House, 165 gourmets, all men, tucked ample white napkins under their chins and sat down to savor the autumn dinner of Les Amis d'Escoffier, the society whose purpose it is to perpetuate the memory of the great chef, August Escoffier, and to encourage the art of good living.

In response to your editorial entitled "The Revolving Door" it may be in order to observe that society's freedom must be commensurate with its responsibility. If as a parent I am responsible for the welfare of my children, and I am, then it is my prerogative and responsibility to exercise whatever control I can over everything that jeopardizes that welfare.

Two babies, one 2 years old and one 7 months, were burned to death yesterday at 2 P. M. in a flash fire in a two-story frame house at 10501 Seaview Avenue, Canarsie, Brooklyn. The older boy, Joseph Hanson, was the son of Mrs. Louise Hanson. The younger child, Raymond Milnes, was her grandson.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Dec. 8 -- Premier Wilopo flew to Bali today for a conference with President Sukarno on the steps taken by the Cabinet over the week-end to resolve the month-old crisis in the Army over its leadership. On Friday, the Cabinet announced the removal of Colonel Nasution as the Army Chief of Staff and on Saturday the Defense Ministry announced a structural reorganization of the Armed Forces High Command.
Holiday shopping here is beginning to set a faster pace after a slow start.

Thomas Scherman and the Little Orchestra Society continued their policy of playing seldom performed works in their fourth concert of the season last night at Town Hall. They demonstrated once again what a wealth of interesting material lies in that peripheral area outside the bounds of those works that have "held" their place in the standard repertoire.

LONDON, Dec. 8 -- Britain's television audience has won a victory over the Government and the coronation authorities representing the palace. As a result of public pressure most of the ceremonial of the coronation of Queen Elizabeth II will be televised from Westminster Abbey June 2, 1953.

Of the many Broadway overtures being made to the much sought-after Jose Ferrer, the one likely to prove acceptable to him is the directorial assignment for "Angels Cooking," the Sam and Bella Spewack adaptation of Albert Husson's Parisian hit, "Cuisine des Anges."
LONDON, Dec. 8 -- The stock markets here threw off much of their initial weakness today and some sections finished with modest price advances.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Dec. 8 -- Amos H. Carnegie, 67-year-old Negro president of the National Hospital Foundation, Inc., Washington, reported here tonight that he had been assaulted by two passengers on a bus while en route from Atlanta, Ga., to this city earlier this evening.

SANTA FE, N. M., Dec. 8 (AP) -- Fourteen convicts at the state prison here dropped a revolt today and released unharmed eight guards they had held as hostages for twenty hours. They capitulated abruptly under a promise of lighter-than-normal punishment, isolation instead of confinement in the prison's underground dungeon.

Pepsi - Cola Company, second largest soft drink maker in the world, and Schweppes, Ltd., giant British producer of soda water, tonic and mixers, have agreed to bottle each other's products in their own home markets. W. B. Forsythe, Pepsi-Cola first vice president, declared yesterday that this is the first important international franchise exchange ever made in the beverage industry.

Milwaukee, Detroit, St. Louis and Cincinnati could "give New York cards, spades and little casino and still have better police departments than yours," Bruce Smith, internationally known authority on police affairs, told the Mayor's Committee on Management Survey at a City Hall public hearing yesterday.

SEATTLE, Dec. 8 -- The American Farm Bureau Federation opened its annual convention today in an atmosphere of optimism over the change in Presidential administration. The federation's leadership foresaw the change as promoting a sounder and healthier economic approach to agricultural problems.

SEA ISLAND, Ga., Dec. 8 -- The effect on United States participation in the United Nations of a proposed constitutional amendment limiting the United States treaty-making power was parried today at a meeting of the National Association of Attorneys General.

A rarely invoked section of the Penal Law relating to gifts and gratuities given "with intent to influence" business transactions was brought up yesterday as a possible weapon that District Attorney Frank S. Hogan might use against racketeers on the waterfront and in the garment district.

Nat Holman, suspended Basketball coach at City College, arrived home from Europe yesterday aboard the French liner Liberte and announced he would fight the "wholly unjustified" charges made against him by the Board of Higher Education.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (AP) -- The Defense Department today identified 124 more service men killed, wounded, injured or missing in the Korean war. The new list included 16 dead, 100 wounded, 8 injured in battle-zone accidents. The following were listed from New York (none from New Jersey or Connecticut):
A large water main burst at West Tremont Avenue and West 177th Street, the Bronx, at 11 o'clock last night, sending a torrent racing down near-by Snake Hill and into neighborhood basements.

A 23,000-ton passenger liner under construction in Scotland for the Greek Line is the first of four similar vessels the company plans to build, it was disclosed yesterday by John Goulandris, director of Goulandris Brothers of London, agent for the Greek Line.

Steel operations this week are scheduled at 105.5 per cent of the industry's theoretical capacity, and production is expected to be 2,191,000 net tons, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute. This marks the third successive week that operations have been scheduled at that level.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 8 (Reuters) -- Five former Czechoslovak ministers have been arrested in a renewed Communist purge in Czechoslovakia, the official Yugoslav news agency Tanjug reported today. Many other persons were also reported to have been caught up in the wave of arrests.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (AP) -- The final cotton report of the year of the Department of Agriculture put the 1952 crop at 15,038,000 bales of 500 pounds gross weight, an increase of 133,000 bales over the November estimate and more than 1,000,000 above indicated market needs.
Coach Danny Lynch's St. Francis College Terriers, smarting from the defeat at the hands of Seton Hall last week, have the "makings of a strong team."

Three upper West Side pier thugs, all hiring bosses on the rolls of the International Longshoremen's Association, A. F. L., defied the New York State Crime Commission yesterday at the public hearing on local waterfront conditions.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Dec. 8 A beauty queen swept the kings off their traditional place on Swedish paper money today.

Eddie Price, whose left hip bone was severely bruised in the losing game against the Redskins, was released from St. Elizabeth's Hospital yesterday, but he will be unable to play with the Giants against the Cleveland Browns at the Polo Grounds next Sunday.

The New York Knickerbockers will strive to snap a three-game losing streak tonight, when they oppose the Rochester Royals in the feature game of a professional basketball double-header at Madison Square Garden. The National Basketball Association twin bill will start at 7:30, with the Boston Celtics facing the Philadelphia Warriors.

White has come into its own as the most fashionable of evening furs, and for those who are looking for a de luxe Christmas gift, it is the little fur that has swept to the top in style prominence. At the opening of the opera and other recent leading functions, it was the small white fur that was outstanding, making the full-length coat, despite its obvious luxury, look heavy, as did other mutations and colors.

HANOI, Vietnam, Indo-China, Dec. 8 -- A strong French reconnaissance force pushed eight miles into the countryside east of Nasan [1 on map] today without encountering any Vietminh troops. The patrol further confirmed a general Vietminh withdrawal from the immediate vicinity of the Nasan perimeter.

DENVER, Dec. 8 -- Critics of the United Nations were taken sharply to task here today by the Rev. Dr. Walter W. Van Kirk, executive director of the Department of International Justice and Good Will of the National Council of the Churches of Christ in the U. S. A.
Two new 1953 auto lines, the Hudson and the Mercury, were presented here yesterday.
ALBANY, Dec. 8 -- Governor Dewey announced today the establishment of a program of state aid to special experimental centers for the care and treatment of emotionally disturbed children.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Dec. 8 -- The campaign against South Africa's race segregation laws took a significant turn today when whites participated in organized defiance of the laws. Patrick Duncan, son of Sir Patrick Duncan, former Governor General of the Union of South Africa, and Manilal Gandhi, son of Mohandas K. Gandhi, were arrested with thirty-seven others, six of them whites, this afternoon.

ABERDEEN, Wash., Dec. 8 (UP) -- The 7,000-ton freighter Yorkmar was driven aground by heavy seas off Gray's Harbor today and appeared at the mercy of a hammering surf as the Coast Guard fought to rescue her thirty-seven-man crew.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- The Supreme Court ruled, 8 to 1, today that food manufacturers could refuse to permit inspection of their premises by the Federal Food and Drug Administration without incurring penalties under the Food, Drug and Cosmetics Act.

Philatelists all over the country have mailed an estimated 200,000 addressed covers to the United Nations Postal Administration with requests that two special United Nations stamps being released tomorrow be placed on the envelopes.

Accompanied by Commissioner Ford Frick and Fresco Thompson, Dodger vice president, Walter O'Malley, president of the Brooklyn baseball club, returned yesterday from the winter meetings at Phoenix, Ariz. O'Malley emphasized his stand against trading Jackie Robinson or Gil Hodges, regardless of the inducement.
Nation-wide offering will be made today of two bond issues of the twelve Federal Land Banks totaling $231,500,000 by Macdonald G. Newcomb, their fiscal agent, and associates.

LONDON, Dec. 8 -- The British Commonwealth Prime Ministers' conference has been discussing what can be done to assist and expedite the ambitious economic development programs of the member countries of the Commonwealth, programs designed to increase their earning power.

JERUSALEM, Dec. 8 -- Itzhak Ben-Zvi, a scholar, statesman and soldier, was chosen as the second President of Israel by the Knesset (Parliament) tonight in succession to Dr. Chaim Weizmann, who died Nov. 7.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 8 -- The United States gave its support today to a Latin-American compromise resolution on the Tunisian question asking that negotiations be continued "on an urgent basis with a view to bringing about self-government for Tunisians in the light of the relevant provisions of the Charter of the United Nations."

With the Democratic State Committee slated to meet at 11 A. M. tomorrow at the Biltmore Hotel to elect a new chairman, backers of neither of the leading contenders, Richard H. Balch of Utica and William H. Morgan of Cortland, could claim enough votes among the 300-member committee to make victory certain.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- Philanthropic, educational and charitable foundations that finance research and experimentation to improve the public welfare cannot depend much longer on large family fortunes to provide their funds, a special House of Representatives investigating committee was told today.

Futures prices closed generally higher yesterday in the New York commodity markets with volume light except for potatoes and cocoa. Cottonseed and soybean oils, cocoa, hides and zinc closed higher. Potatoes and lead closed lower but there were no sales of lead.

The property at the southeast corner of Fifth Avenue and Forty-sixth Street has been purchased by Charles and Milton A. Kimmelman, in association with Samuel Seaver, from the Oceanic Investing Corporation. A ninety-nine-year lease on the site was taken last August by the Kimmelmans from the Oceanic Investing Corporation and plans were filed in October for a nineteen-story office structure to replace the present buildings on the site.
Junk accumulations rivaling those of the recluse Collyer brothers' home in 1947 were revealed yesterday by housing authorities in four separate apartments in one tenement house on the East Side.

Olin Downes, music critic of THE NEW YORK TIMES, will be guest of honor at the forty-sixth annual dinner of The Bohemians Club, to be held in the grand ballroom of the Hotel Plaza Sunday evening, Dec. 21. Mr. Downes will be the first music critic to be so honored by the organization.
The shipping companies resisted an effort by the city to end the pier loading racket three years ago, Chief Magistrate John M. Murtagh asserted yesterday.

Any stick is good enough these days for a few whacks at Uncle Sam. The latest case in point is the contradictory reaction of London and Teheran to the State Department's announcement that American citizens attempting to trade in Iranian oil do so at their own risk.

The proposed merger of the National Organization of Masters, Mates and Pilots, A. F. L., and the Marine Engineers Beneficial Association, C. I. O., which was reported on Monday to be all but concluded may be delayed as the result of two important questions yet unresolved.

Public opinion will strongly condemn the A. F. L. if, as reported, it adopts a "hands-off" attitude toward current disclosures of pier racketeering involving the International Longshoremen's Association.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 9 -- Elections for a new-style Federal Parliament have been scheduled for next May or June, it was announced today through Tanjug, the Yugoslav press agency.
The following book, of interest to parents, was published recently:

Trustees of the Bank of New York yesterday declared an extra dividend of $2, payable on Dec. 22 and the regular quarterly dividend of $3.50 for payment Jan. 2. A similar extra was distributed a year ago.

George (Muscles) Futterman, an ex-convict and suspended union business agent, went on trial yesterday in General Sessions on charges that he had paid $100 to a key prosecution witness to perjure himself at a murder trial last year.
G. Keith Funston, president of the New York Stock Exchange, has asked Gov. Thomas E. Dewey to withhold a "uniform commercial code" from proposed legislation.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (AP) -Martin P. Durkin, designated as Secretary of Labor in the forthcoming Republican Administration, is planning a series of talks with leaders of organized labor, industry and Congress to chart possibly changes in the Taft-Hartley Act.

Bolstered by the return of the rookie left wing, Dean Prentice, who was on the sidelines last Sunday because of a wrenched right knee, the New York Rangers will face the Boston Bruins in a National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden tonight.

American business was criticized yesterday by Arthur H. (Red) Motley, president of Parade Publications, for aiming its sales guns only at people on this or that side of the "tracks"; fo not talking a language that the masses can understand; and for neglecting to sell the fact that what the service industry provides is an essential part of the thing that makes the country tick.

CHICAGO, Dec. 9 -- The grain markets failed to consolidate the gains registered yesterday, the trend today being reactionary by absence of any important follow-up buying. Recessions wiped out much of Monday's gains. Buyers were extremely cautious, lacking the inspiration of any big wheat export business, while other gains were affected by the mild weather easing the feed situation.

Justice Cortland A. Johnson reserved decision in Queens Supreme Court yesterday on a petition to declare illegal an election of directors of an 1,800-family cooperative apartment development in Whitestone, Queens.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Dec. 9 (AP) -- A triumph by Frank Sedgman and Ken McGregor in the doubles final of the Victorian tennis championships today brightened Australia's badly tarnished Davis Cup hopes. The top Australian duo routed the younger team of Ken Rosewall and Lewis Hoad, 6 -- 4, 10 -- 8, 3 -- 6, 6 -- 3, in this final tournament before the cup matches.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- The prairie chicken, once flushed in huge flocks by the tide of covered-wagon pioneers, is threatened with extinction and the National Wildlife Federation announced today a program to try to save it.

Price reductions ranging from $95 to $193 in this city were announced with the presentation of the 1953 Aero Willys passenger car line yesterday by Willys-Overland Motors, Inc. The cars are scheduled to go on display Monday.

Reporting on operations of the Taylor Oil and Gas Company for the fiscal year ended last June, G. L. Rowsey, president, informed shareholders yesterday that a 5 per cent common stock dividend will be recommended to directors if a proposed boost in the authorized stock of the company is approved at a special shareholders' meeting today.
FREEHOLD, N. J., Dec. 9 (AP) -- Vito Genovese, already facing Government deportation proceedings as a racketeer, is being sued by his wife, Anna, for seperate maintenance.

Making cities less vulnerable to attack is one of two "important" measures that will permit civil defense to remain under civilian control, according to conclusions to be embodied in a forthcoming report of "Project East River," a study of civil defense in the nation.

It is never too early to start taking precautions against Yuletide fire hazards. There is one logical starting point -- no acceptable method has yet been found for flame-proofing an evergreen tree at home. Thus, says the Greater New York Safety Council, a small fresh green tree is the safest.

A plan by Warner Brothers to divest itself of motion-picture theatre holdings, as required by the government consent decree calling for the separation of theatres from production and distribution, was made known by the company yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (AP) -The Democrats are starting a newspaper advertising campaign on a national scale to drum up contributions to the party's operating fund.

The City Club of New York yesterday asked the Association of the Bar of the City of New York to determine whether charges of unfitness should be filed with the Appellate Division against former Supreme Court Justice Aaron J. Levy, now an official referee of the Supreme Court, and Municipal Court Justice Cornelius D. McNamara.

LONDON, Dec. 9 -- Some time next spring a senior delegation from the United Kingdom, speaking for the British Commonwealth as a whole and perhaps for Western Europe as well, is expected to approach the new United States Administration with proposals for steps to attain a limited convertibility for the pound sterling.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Dec. 9 -- The Governors of nine western states and the Territories of Alaska, Hawaii and Guam urged today that the Federal Government virtually get out of the highway business by surrendering to the respective states the receipts of all Federal gasoline taxes.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 9 (AP) -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt told the Communists today to stop shedding crocodile tears over injustice and insecurity in the United States.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 9 (UP) -- After failing on four previous mounts, Tony DeSpirito scored his 369th victory of the year today when he won aboard Colonel Zeder in the ninth race to maintain his one-winner-a-day pace at Tropical Park.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (UP) -The United States faces a shortage of 6,000 to 10,000 barrels of aviation gasoline a day during the next eighteen months, a Government oil expert warned today.

Capt. Herman Schwartzberg, one of thirty suspended policemen on departmental trial on charges of having taken bribes from Harry Gross, convicted bookmaker, accused Gross from the witness stand yesterday of "shaking down" policemen who might face graft charges.

Distribution of 70,000 shares of Copperweld Steel Company's cumulative preferred stock, 6 per cent series, $50 par value, is being made today by an underwriting group headed by Riter Co. The stock is priced at $50 a share plus accrued dividends from Dec. 10, 1952.

Edward R. Murrow, narrator for the "See It Now" television program, will leave for Korea Monday to make a one-hour film report on how front-line soldiers spend Christmas Day. The film will be televised over the Columbia Broadcasting System network Sunday, Dec. 28, at 6 P. M.
TOKYO, Dec. 9 (AP) -- The deepening mystery of what actually happened to Wataru Kaji, Japanese Leftist writer, loomed ominously tonight on the horizon of American-Japanese relations.

Retail sales of home sewing machines next year may reach a record $270,000,000, Leon Jolson, president of the Necchi Sewing Machine Sales Corporation, said yesterday. He spoke at a company meeting in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

In a move to eliminate nuisance taxes introduced early this year to help the City balance its 1952-53 budget, three City Councilmen yesterday introduced into the Council a bill to repeal the $5 and $10 automobile use tax, effective next June 1.

Eric Johnston, president of the Motion Picture Association of America, yesterday called for an international economic general staff. On it, he suggested at a luncheon for the National Association of Insurance Commissioners in the Commodore Hotel, should serve representatives of American agriculture, labor and industry along with Government officials.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 9 -- Independence for Tunisia was urged today by Mme. Vijaya Lakshmi Pandit of India, who declared that if the French were correct in their contention that their administration had greatly benefited the protectorate, this was all the more reason why Tunisia should have complete independence.
RALEIGH, N. C., Dec. 9 (AP) -- A six-man North Carolina State swimming squad broke three American records for breast-stroke distances in an exhibition today.

IT'S an extraordinary thing about authors of sports books. If they are active in the sphere of athletics, they immediately stir up an otherwise quiescent whammy. It doesn't matter whether they are managers, coaches, players or what-not. As soon as they write a book, there is a cackle of ghoulish laughter and all the witches, goblins and hobgoblins immediately begin to torment them.

A bitter fight for control of the Democratic state organization was being waged yesterday as members of the state committee prepared to meet this morning at the Biltmore Hotel to elect a successor to Paul E. Fitzpatrick of Buffalo, the retiring chairman.

SINGAPORE, Dec. 9 -- In a survey today of a five-day top secret conference of Britain Southeast Asia officials and Briton representatives which ended yesterday, Malcolm MacDonald, British Commissioner General for Southeast Asia, said that although the overall situation in this area had improved since last year, the potential situation was as dangerous as it ever was and might even more dangerous.
Amy-Ann Andrews, soprano, appeared last evening in a program of songs at Carnegie Recital Hall. She was presented by Mme. Ethel Szantho, who also was the accompanist.

Another strong advance was made by the stock market yesterday as investor confidence became further evident. Embracing most of the major groups of the list, the fresh advance carried prices to new highs for the current movement.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- The $321,000,000 Rockefeller Foundation came under Congressional scrutiny today in connection with its extension of financial aid to some organizations and individuals criticized by Senate and House committees investigating subversive activities.
By acclamation, Rocky Marciano, the world champion, yesterday became the first heavyweight with an unblemished ring record ever chosen to receive the Edward J. Neil Memorial Plaque.

Under the auspices of Gold Star Wives of America, Inc., a Christmas supper dance will be held on the night of Dec. 19 on the St. Regis Roof to raise funds for a Christmas party for Gold Star children, whose fathers lost their lives in World War II and in Korea.

Following what amounted to a rebuff from Vice Admiral William M. Callaghan, commander of the Military Sea Transportation Service, representatives of American-flag tramp ship operators took their problems direct to the White House, it was learned yesterday.

The preview of 100 prize-winning water-colors selected by a jury in the second international Hallmark Art Award Competition, sponsored by the United States National Commission for the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization will be held this evening at the Wildenstein Galleries. Prizes totaling $12,500 will be officially announced.

BOMBAY, India, Dec. 9 -- Problems affecting mentally retarded and orthopedically handicapped children formed the main topic of the fourth day's session of the International Study Conference on Child Welfare here today.
" The Librarian," presented last Sunday afternoon over the N. B. C. television network, was a play that easily might go unnoticed. It shouldn't.

Two American composers, who were present, figured in the program given by the Philadelphia Orchestra under Eugene Ormandy's direction last night in Carnegie Hall. David Diamond's suite "Music for Shakespeare's Romeo and Juliet" was played on the Philadelphia programs for the first time in this city.
BERLIN, Dec. 9 -- The East German Government suspended its supply minister and his deputy today and instituted an emergency program to relieve the growing food crisis in the Soviet zone of Germany.
Mayor Impellitteri announced yesterday at City Hall that he would leave tomorrow for a vacation of ten or twelve days in Florida. He said he had not yet decided just where in Florida he would go.
TOKYO, Wednesday Dec. 10 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,459, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M. Wednesday, Korean time:
Letters generally hold little fascination for mailmen, but this is the time of year when even foot-sore postmen can smile at the extra burden of "Dear Santa" letters they are carrying.
A new master, Gastone Giolli, was on the bridge of the Home Lines 10,000-ton passenger ship Homeland when she sailed last night with 430 passengers for Mediterranean ports.
BOWIE, Md., Dec. 9 (UP) -- Willie Lester enjoyed a banner day at Bowie today as he booted home four winners, including Mrs. E. D. Jacobs' Dashing By in the feature race, before a crowd of 6,845.

CAIRO, Wednesday, Dec. 10 -Maj. Gen. Mohammed Naguib, Premier of Egypt, announced over the radio shortly after midnight cancellation of the Egyptian Constitution and the passing of authority to "a transitional government." He said that a committee would be formed to draw up a new Constitution.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 9 -- Fred (Dixie) Walker today joined the Cardinals as a coach. The former Dodger outfielder filled the post vacated by Terry Moore, onetime Cardinal star who disagreed with Manager Eddie Stanky. Moore joined the Phillies as a scout.

The letter of Isabel M. Keleher, secretary, New York City Employes Retirement System, Board of Estimate, published Nov. 29, commenting on a previous letter from "Mrs. Citizen" on the subject of delayed pensions for eligible New York City employes, would seem to indicate a lack of knowledge as to the extent of delays.

SEOUL, Korea, Dec. 9 -- A small but valiant unit from the only country in South America to send troops to Korea -- the Colombian battalion -- was decorated yesterday for bravery and heroism, by the United States.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Dec. 10 -United Nations warplanes, flying from ground bases and from United States Navy carriers in the Japan Sea, smashed at Communist military and industrial installations on the Manchurian border yesterday along a line from near Supung (Suiho) on the Yalu River in the west to the northeastern tip of Korea close to the Soviet frontier.

If the Secretary of the Treasury were to announce tonight that the Federal Government was about to pump a billion dollars into retail trade channels his statement no doubt would appear on the front pages of tomorrow morning's newspapers from coast to coast.

TORONTO, Dec. 9 -- James Stewart, president of the Canadian Bank of Commerce, told shareholders at their annual meeting here today that "we are entering a period of increasing risk in business," but said there is no need for pessimism, "provided the utmost efficiency is exercised in the conduct of our affairs."
Mayor Impellitteri will preside at noon today in City Hall Plaza at the graduation of 791 probationary patrolmen who have just completed the three-month course at the Police Academy.

In a world torn with doubt of the future it is easy to bypass the needs of individuals whose own particular lives have for reasons beyond their control fallen into a morass of suffering. Each year at Christmas time the Neediest Cases in the city, those afflicted and who cannot rescue themselves, are given aid by their neighbors.

Two new films will arrive at first-run theatres this morning. "Stop, You're Killing Me," Warner Brothers' remake of the Damon Runyon-Howard Lindsay play, "A Slight Case of Murder," starring Broderick Crawford and Claire Trevor, is at the Paramount.

The relationship between the creation of an abstract sculpture and the designing of a functional contemporary chair becomes each day more apparent. The idea, fostered by the open, uncluttered spaces of modern architecture, seems to have finally reached its apex in an exhibition opening today at Knoll Associates, Inc., and devoted to the art of Harry Bertoia.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- Bert Bell, commissioner of the National Football League, today praised Sam Baugh for the courage, sportsmanship and skill he has shown during his sixteen years as a professional player.

Events tonight: "La Forza del Destino," Metropolitan Opera, 8 P. M.; Bach Aria Group, Town Hall, 8:30; Maurice Eisenberg, 'cellist, Lexington Avenue Y. M. and Y. W. H. A., 8:30; Brooklyn Doctors' Symphony Orchestra, Brooklyn High School for Homemaking, 910 Classon Avenue, Brooklyn, 8:30.

The American Kennel Club, which has been studying veterinary examination of dogs at shows for almost a year, will pursue its studies on a more formal basis, William E. Buckley, president, told the A. K. C. delegates at their quarterly meeting at the Hotel Commodore yesterday.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 9 -- The list of United Nations employes dismissed in the "loyalty" controversy is expected to grow, and reliable sources here said that the names of non-Americans might be added soon.

Five city and business executives received Downtown Manhattan Association medals of award yesterday for "accomplishments during 1952 toward the improvement and preservation of Downtown Old New York City on Lower Manhattan Island."

Prominent women, headed by Mrs. Thomas S. Lamont and including Mrs. Duncan S. Ellsworth, are furthering the success of the performance of "The Millionairess," starring Katharine Hepburn, next Monday night at the Shubert Theatre for the benefit of the English-Speaking Union.

Halsey, Stuart , Inc., and associates will offer an issue today day of $4,440,000 Chicago, Rock Island and Pacific Railroad equipment trust certificates, due semi-annually on July 1, 1953, to Jan. 1, 1965, at prices scaled to yield from 2.15 per cent to 2.9 per cent.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- Lieut. Col. Irene O. Galloway, commander of the Women's Training Center at Fort Lee, Va., was appointed director of the Women's Army Corps today.

DENVER, Dec. 9 -- The election on Friday of Methodist Bishop William C. Martin of Dallas, Tex., as president of the National Council of the Churches of Christ in the U. S. A. appeared a certainty here today as the council formally opened its second general assembly.

Deferred from Dec. 4 because of Bette Davis' illness, "Two's Company" will have its premiere next Monday night at the Alvin. "Positively!" says the management, with a sigh of relief. Miss Davis, who has been sick with an acutely infected larynx, will report today for rehearsals.

Dr. Nahum Goldmann, chairman of the Conference on Jewish Material Claims Against Germany, said yesterday that the agreements between the West German Government, Israel and world Jewish organizations, involving approximately $882,000,000, would be ratified by the German Bundestag (Parliament) "within the next four to six weeks at the latest."

A dramatic comeback by the New York Knickerbockers went to waste at Madison Square Garden last night when Arnie Risen's hook shot fifteen seconds before the final buzzer broke the deadlock and gave the Rochester Royals a 77-75 victory over the home side.

Voters of four states and 338 municipalities approved new issues totaling $1,285,864,630 in November compared with $1,307,869,300 in November, 1951, according to The Daily Bond Buyer. The general elections accounted for $1,239,263,530 of last month's total.
Futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were barely steady yesterday and active months closed 20 to 34 points net lower than on Monday.

DETROIT, Dec. 9 -- Richard W. Reading, former Mayor of Detroit, who served three years of a four-to five-year prison term for having accepted graft from gamblers, died today in Mallus Hospital in Brighton, Mich. He was 70 years old.

MIAMI, FLA., Dec. 9 -- Indictments were returned against four persons today by a Federal grand jury investigating the bombings of Carver Village, Negro-occupied apartment units adjoining a white project in northwest Miami. The identity of those indicted was withheld pending their arrest, which is expected tomorrow.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 9 (AP) -- Storm warnings were hoisted along the West Coast again today as another of a series of storms born in the Alaskan Gulf blustered across three states.
An integrated program of treatment, rehabilitation and assistance available to persons who have tuberculosis was described yesterday to 400 newly appointed investigators of the Department of Welfare.

Two hundred thirty-six more ships are on the ways of the world or on order than there were a year ago, the Shipbuilders Council of America reported yesterday, but the 1,791 vessels now under construction are thirty-eight fewer than were reported at the middle of this year.
Ten Christmas trees, each one decorated according to the individual ideas of a well known fashion designer, offered a novel and amusing Yuletide display at De Pinna's yesterday.

BERLIN, Dec. 9 -- There is a growing fear in official United States circles here that a United States Army officer and possibly two enlisted men are being held by Soviet authorities as hostages against the return of Alexander Alexandrovich Kulikov, a Soviet soldiers who recently deserted to the West.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 9 -- United Nations delegates heard today a plea for emergency relief and long-range planning for the refugees of World War II who still have not found homes.
The Staten Island ferry commuter's version of the "pierhead jump" has been ruled out of order by the Department of Marine and Aviation, it was made known yesterday.
An insurgent movement in the ranks of Local 802, American Federation of Musicians, has swept out of office a union administration in power for eighteen years.

The New York Zoological Society decided yesterday to try to "arouse the people" to contribute $5,000,000 toward at great new aquarium at Coney Island, a project that has been on the drawing boards for many years.
Capitalizing on its height advantage by dominating the backboards, Columbia's basketball team routed Trinity, 75 -- 55, last night at the Lions' University Hall gymnasium.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 9 -- Uruguay and Bolivia submitted today to the General Assembly's Economic and Financial Committee a revised draft proposal, reaffirming the right of nationalization of natural resources. They said the new draft had the support of eight other delegations.

SEA ISLAND, Ga., Dec. 9 -- Senator Richard B. Russell, Democrat of Georgia, called upon Canada, Australia and New Zealand to send additional troops to reinforce United Nations forces in Korea and urged immediate naval blockade of the China coast.

Persistence paid off yesterday for Mrs. Peter S. Harlib of Chicago. In her fourth try in the Pillsbury annual baking contest the wife of a Windy City homicide squad policeman took the top prize of $25,000 for what the flour manufacturer called her "snappy turtle cookies."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- Arguments began in the Supreme Court today on the question whether segregation of white and Negro students in separate schools violated the Federal Constitution.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 9 -- Paramount, which has a backlog of twenty completed pictures, will not attempt to follow a set schedule of new productions next year, Don Hartman, studio production head, announced today. He recently returned from an inspection trip to London, Paris and Rome.

Immediate collection of blood by the Red Cross here for processing into gamma globulin to protect children in polio epidemic areas next summer was announced yesterday by Dr. William A. Markel, administrator of the program.

Paul S. Willis, president of the Grocery Manufacturers of America, Inc., declared yesterday that the group's entire membership, including the largest food processors in the country, would favor clearing up ambiguities in the Food and Drug Act.

The second natural gas pipeline into the city across Staten Island and the Narrows was dedicated formally after completion at 1 o'clock yesterday afternoon. Brief ceremonies were held at the metering station of the Transcontinental Gas Pipeline Corporation at the foot of Clifton Avenue, Clifton, S. I.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- The Colorado Fuel and Iron Corporation of Denver, applied to the Securities and Exchange Commission today for authority to market 340,000 shares of common stock (no par), which will be offered for public sale through an underwriting group headed by Allen Co.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 9 -- Michael J. Quill, president of the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., whose strike threats have kept New York's straphangers in a constant state of jitters for years, assumed the role of Santa Claus today and promised to let 3,500,000 Gotham bus riders travel free in the Christmas shopping rush.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (AP) -- The Defense Department said today United States casualties in Korea would continue to be described as such in the mimeographed lists mailed each week-day despite the elimination of the term "casualty" for the weekly summaries issued each Wednesday.
Two men die, a third was badly hurt and a fourth escaped with minor injuries yesterday when a small private plane crashed into a wooded area near the Staten Island Airport at 1:29 P. M.

PURCHASE, N. Y., Dec. 9 -- A test run of the first helicopter airmail service for New York suburbs and near-by areas was made this afternoon in preparation for the opening of the service tomorrow morning. Airmail will be delivered to communities in Westchester County and southern Connecticut, with similar service to come later for communities on Long Island and in New Jersey.

A new substance designed to provide plants and crops with trace elements regarded as necessary to full growth and to restore vital minerals to deficient soil was announced here yesterday by the Ferro Corporation of Cleveland.
Ronald Hutchins, 14-year-old Ground Observer Aircraft Spotter from Newcomb, N. Y., was the guest of the Air Force yesterday.

The letter of Associate Professor Adolph M. Dettloff which you published on Dec. 4 with respect to the cost of the state-aided Carver Houses project which is to replace the slum homes from East Ninety-ninth to East 106th Street, Park to Madison Avenue, indicates that he has not been provided with full information concerning the necessity for and breadth of the state's slum clearance, low-income housing and neighborhood redevelopment program.

A discussion by a panel of four New York University professors on the decade of their youth will mark the opening today of a symposium designed to give university students new insights into "Your Parents' Generation: The American 'Twenties."

SALEM, Ore., Dec. 9 -- The State Supreme Court was told today that State Senator Paul Patterson held two separate offices under Oregon's constitution, one in the Legislative Branch as president of the Senate and the other in the Executive Branch as first successor to the Governor.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Dec. 9 -- Police arrested today four young white persons who showed their sympathy for the non-white cause by ostentatiously writing a telegram protesting racial laws to Prime Minister Daniel F. Malan in the non-white section of the General Post Office in Capetown.

Mieczyslaw Horszowski devoted himself to four Beethoven Piano Sonatas in his annual Town Hall recital last night. The event drew an audience of 1,000 persons, who listened intently and who applauded so long, at the end, that the pianist had to return to the stage five times.

The message that scout Jack Lavelle brought to the New York Football Giants yesterday contained 5 few words of cheer. Speaking at the weekly luncheon at the Polo Grounds press headquarters, Lavelle described the Cleveland Browns, who meet the Giants on Sunday, as "the best conditioned team," he had seen this year.

Despite charges by Henry Epstein, attorney, that contract specifications were "rigged" in favor of a bidder, the Board of Estimate accepted yesterday the offer of the Magee-Hale Park-o-Meter Company for 13,000 parking meters at a cost of $455,000.

If any introspective subway riders have been wondering what they look like to an oncoming motorman as he pilots his train alongside the platform where they stand, they may have this answer from a veteran motorman:
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- Republican leaders of Congress in the economic field have agreed not to act on any proposal to end controls until hearings have been held.
Small lessons in high finance were put into practice yesterday by 400 underprivileged children, who received $5 each as a Christmas present from the Young Men's Board of Trade.
Andrei Y. Vishinsky made his annual holiday season dockside speech yesterday: A verbal scowl in the direction of the United Nations and a "happy Christmas" for the American people.
BOCA RATON, Fla., Dec. 9 (AP) -- Production of coffee to meet increasing demands of United States consumers can be accomplished by two means, a prominent Brazilian declared today.
Japanese wartime propaganda broadcast recordings in which John David Provoo participated were played yesterday for Federal Judge Gregory F. Noonan and a jury of seven women and five men.
SHERMAN, Tex., Dec. 9 (AP) -Ray Morrison has resigned as head coach and athletic director at Austin College to accept a non-coaching job at Southern Methodist University, it was announced today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (AP) -- James P. McGranery, Attorney General, asserted today he believed that many persons regretted the "nasty things" they once said about the Justice Department.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 9 -- Thanks to a Los Angeles spinster who died in 1948, the United Nations Children's Emergency Fund was enriched today by $3,797.02 and twenty-seven properties of doubtful value scattered over New Mexico, Arizona and her native California.

Commodity futures on the New York exchanges closed irregular yesterday with most items dull. Sugar and potatoes were active. Rubber, the only commodity to close higher in all positions, showed sizable gains. Cottonseed oil, cocoa and lead were lower.
Decorating accessories for Christmas are on display in the Candelier Shop, 22 Greenwich Avenue, along with candles and holders, the principal merchandise offered by the store.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- The Department of Defense, in a new "stretch-out" of defense goals, has ordered cutbacks in the production of tanks and trucks that will result in the closing down of several large arms plants.

BONN, Germany, Dec. 9 -- West Germany was confronted today by a constitutional crisis that complicated and delayed still further ratification of the Bonn peace contract with the Western Allies and the European Defense Community Treaty.

CINCINNATI, Dec. 9 -- Arthritis is "number one crippler of the American people," Dr. A. A. Delorimier of St. Francis Hospital in San Francisco, said today at a session of the thirty-eighth annual meeting of the Radiological Society of North America.
Brooklyn College's basketball team may not be so big as the 1951-52 outfit, but Coach Morris (Tubby) Raskin's Kingsmen have gained added over-all strength, particularly off the boards.

The Public Service Commission stressed yetserday the increased use of private automobiles and traffic congestion as factors in the reduced earning power of bus lines in the larger municipalities of the state.

Fritz Reiner said yesterday that he was leaving the Metropolitan Opera at the end of the season to become the musical director of the Chicago Symphony. He will succeed Rafael Kubelik, who has been the Chicago leader since 1950, the governing body of the symphony announced yesterday in Chicago.

Extortion payments to dock union officials by importers of furs from Russia and other shakedowns were related yesterday as the New York State Crime Commission closed the first phase of its inquiry into local waterfront conditions. The commission will take up a second phase next Monday.

Shoppers with limited money and limited time are invited to view a display in the Interior Design Gallery at Pratt Institute in Brooklyn. The exhibit, assembled and installed by second-year students, is called "A Penny to a Dollar" because that's what the items in it cost.

BONN, Germany, Dec. 9 -- The Federation of German Industry, to secure the direct participation of long-term American capital in the further economic expansion of West Germany, has brought to light the fact that the Bonn republic's capital investment rate already averages between 22 and 23 per cent of the national income.

Three high-ranking State Department officials were called yesterday before an executive session of the Senate Internal Security Subcommittee investigating possible subversive activities among American employes of the United Nations, and were scheduled to return for another closed-door session at the Federal Courthouse in Foley Square at 10 A. M. today.

LONDON, Dec. 9 -- Winding up a State Department-sponsored tour of seven European countries, Representative Emanuel Celler, Democrat of New York and chairman of the House Judiciary Committee, today vigorously contradicted Senator Alexander Wiley's recent charges of overstaffing and inefficiency in United States' missions abroad.

A proposal that its 1953 championship sprint regattas be switched to the Potomac River in Washington was considered yesterday by the Eastern Association of Rowing Colleges. The association, conducting its annual meeting in conjunction with the sixteenth schedule-making convention of the Eastern College Athletic Association, recessed before a decision was reached.

Arthur Williams has been appointed vice president of the Pacific Airmotive Corporation, it was announced yesterday. Mr. Willams was also named general manager of sales, overhaul and maintenance activities in the East.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- Public school leaders from the states heard high Federal officials ask the schools today to help provide able personnel to carry the nation's security and technical aid programs to peoples abroad.
I read with interest your editorial view under the head of "Mr. Lovett to His Critics" in THE TIMES of Nov. 16.

A quarter of a century ago Stalin lifted Andrei Y. Vishinsky out of relatively decent obscurity -- until then he was known merely as an ex-Menshevik lawyer who had turned Bolshevik just in time -- to prosecute the "purge" trials by which Stalin consolidated his control over the party and the Soviet Union.

When the computing machines of Republic Aviation Corporation at Farmingdale showed the hundred millionth dollar for payroll in 1952, Charles F. Bartow, a Port Jefferson riveter, became the man of the hour. He got the dollar in silver.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- Texas-born Mary Martin, former star of "South Pacific," was raised to the rank of an honorary admiral in the Texas Navy today at a National Women's Press Club luncheon, where she sang the story of her life in six cantos.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (UP) -- The National Geographic Society reported new evidence today to support Dr. Albert Einstein's theory that gravity can bend light rays.
New Hampshire sold $10,000,000 of highway bonds at public bidding yesterday to a group managed jointly by the First National Bank of Chicago and Kuhn, Loeb Co.

Motor carrier freight rate increases scheduled to go into effect today in this state have been suspended by the Public Service Commission. In a ruling yesterday, the commission announced that no action would be taken pending a public hearing in Albany on Jan. 16.

SEATTLE, Dec. 9 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower called on farmers of the United States today to analyze their problems thoroughly and be prepared to express possible solutions when the present farm price support law expires in two years.

LYNN, Mass., Dec. 9 -- Yale's hockey team lost its second game in two starts this season, 6 -- 4, to Boston College at the Lynn Sports Arena tonight. The Elis went down, 3 -- 0, in the first period and spent the rest of the night trying to break Boston's goalie, Joe Carroll.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- C. W. Crawford, Commissioner of the Food and Drug Administration, appealed to food experts at the National Food and Nutrition Conference today to help expose "widespread nutrition quackery" that he said was immune to present laws.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 9 (AP) -- Andy Gaspar, a husky Pittsburgh pro with little confidence in his ability to win big-money golf tournaments, today shot a 5-under-par 65 to lead the qualifiers in the $10,000 Miami Open.

PARIS, Dec. 9 -- By the narrow margin of nine votes Premier Antoine Pinay obtained a vote of confidence from the National Assembly today. The victory assured priority to his proposals for financing the 1953 budget. The count was 300 to 291. In a test vote last week, also on the budget, M. Pinay also scored a victory, 314 to 207.

Purchase of new life insurance by Americans will run close to $33,000,000,000 this year. This new record in personal protection for both families and individuals is a gain of 12 per cent over 1951. Meanwhile, benefits paid by life insurance companies this year to policyholders and beneficiaries will set a new record of more than $5,000,000,000.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 9 -- The United States led a successful move for moderation today during a discussion of colonial affairs in the United Nations General Assembly's Trusteeship Committee. It was the first setback this committee's current session had handed to an expanding, strongly anti-colonial bloc of fifteen or twenty small countries in Latin America, the Middle East and Asia.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 9 -- Iraq and Egypt, confronted by certain Arab defeat on a bitterly opposed Palestine proposal, offered today to let the United Nations drop the whole Palestine issue, at least at this seventh session of the General Assembly.
The United States Public Health Service last night received from the American Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Association that group's fourteenth annual scientific award.

MOSCOW, Dec. 9 -- The card-index love system of Peter Petrovich Kokushky, which brought him at least nineteen romances, a divorced wife in Moscow, a current wife in Leningrad and countless "fiancees," finally has broken down, the newspaper Literary Gazette made plain today.

Although large numbers of New York high school students are seriously retarded in reading, the city's level of achievement in this regard is about the same as that for high school students throughout the country, according to a report made public yesterday by the Board of Education.

CASABLANCA, French Morocco, Dec. 9 -- Two Moroccans were killed and eight were wounded today when troops clashed with 1,000 demonstrators in Beni Mellal, 100 miles southeast of Casablanca. At the same time forty demonstrators in Casablanca were rounded up by police as a crowd massed in front of a jail demanding the release of about 300 persons arrested in yesterday's rioting when fifty-nine persons were reported killed and more than 200 wounded.

Last March, after the state administration nursed a stop-gap financial solution for New York City through the Legislature, it put the city on notice that it would have to put its house in order. The city has not put its house in order. Mayor Impellitteri has shown complete irresponsibility on the transit fare.

ROCQUENCOURT, France, Dec. 9 -- Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway, Supreme Allied commander, and his chief of staff, Gen. Alfred M. Gruenther, urged today that the North Atlantic Treaty nations spend at least $400,000,000 for further military construction in Europe to support the Allied forces earmarked for late in 1954.
Two actions to forestall the appearances of witnesses subpoenaed by the State Crime Commission for public hearings in its waterfront inquiry were on Supreme Court calendars yesterday.

Earnings between $4.80 and $5 a common share are expected to be made this year by the American Smelting and Refining Company, Roger W. Straus, chairman, told shareholders at a special meeting yesterday in Jersey City. In 1951 the company earned $6.89 a common share.
Strong differences of opinion exist among public health administrators here on whether the city should fluoridate the water supply as a method of reducing tooth decay among children.

Joseph P. Ryan, lifetime president of the International Longshoremen's Association, A. F. L., may retire from his post at the close of the present State Crime Commission hearings into waterfront corruption, pier spokesmen declared yesterday.

A resolution asking Governor Dewey to appoint a commission to make a complete investigation of the courts of the First Judicial District, comprising Manhattan and the Bronx, was adopted unanimously last night by the Association of the Bar of the City of New York, at its headquarters at 42 West Forty-fourth Street.

LONDON, Dec. 9 -- The last complete bookkeeping account of the year ended today with business shrinking still further and with prices irregularly rising and falling slightly. Only among British Government securities, which continued to improve, was there any consistency.
The Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation has offered to pay brokerage costs and transfer taxes for any owner of less than ten shares of its common stock who wishes to sell.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Dec. 9 (AP) -- Further hospitalization was recommended today for a Negro preacher who was beaten up on a bus during an alleged segregation incident, but he insisted on flying back to his home in Washington.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Dec. 9 -Premier Wilpo arrived in Surabaya today to attend the sixth congress of the Indonesian Nationalist party. He told the local press that the Indonesian crisis over the armed forces remained serious but was not alarming.

A NUMBER of hunters have written recently to comment on the "past grouse season," apparently unaware that this season will not close in a number of Catskill and Adirondack counties until Dec. 19, and will not end in central and western counties until 5 P. M. today.

A NUMBER of hunters have written recently to comment on the "past grouse season," apparently unaware that this season will not close in a number of Catskill and Adirondack counties until Dec. 19, and will not end in central and western counties until 5 P. M. today.

LONDON, Wednesday, Dec. 10 (Reuters) -- A long-term solution to racial troubles in Britain's East African colony of Kenya can be found only in the full development of the territory's economic resources, an official Government report said today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- John E. Burton, chairman of the New York Power Authority, told the Federal Power Commission today that users of electricity in his state would save $95,000,000 a year through his agency's operation of a hydroelectric plant in the International Rapids of the St. Lawrence River, near Massena, and another in the Niagara River.

Assistant Corporation Counsel James P. Thornton warned yesterday that officials of the Staten Island Rapid Transit Railway Company would face contempt of court actions if they attempted to halt passenger service on their three Staten Island lines on Dec. 19.

DETROIT, Dec. 9 -- Nine roofing concerns, eighteen individuals and a trade association were indicted here today by a Federal Grand Jury on charges of conspiracy in restraint of trade under the Sherman Anti Trust Act.

The four United States individual champions each received the No. 1 spot in his specialty in the annual national rankings of the Amateur Fencers League of America, released yesterday. The ratings were based on last season's major competitions.

Many dinner parties will be given in advance of the fifth annual Bachelors' Ball Saturday night in the Terrace Room of the Plaza. The event has been arranged under the direction of Mrs. W. Montgomery Wilcox for the debutantes of recent seasons and bachelors between the ages of 22 and 35.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Dec. 9 -- Justice Elbert T. Gallagher of the State Supreme Court vacated today an order he had issued on July 10 to permit the Algonquin Gas Transmission Company to build a large pipeline across private properties in northern Westchester County for carrying Texas natural gas to New England.

A mothproofing product that will protect woolens quickly and easily was announced by Department of Agriculture entomologists at the closing sessions of the convention of the Chemical Specialties Manufacturers Association at the New Yorker Hotel yesterday.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 9 (AP) -- Branch Rickey, general manager of the Pirates, said tonight Fred Haney, manager of the Hollywood Stars of the Pacific Coast League, is coming here on Thursday to discuss the possibility of managing the Pirates.

In apparent disdain of the State Crime Commission's current waterfront theft investigation, three longshoremen were caught redhanded early yesterday morning in an attempt to steal 500 pounds of Air Force-consigned meat from Pier 32, North River, at Canal Street.

The noise nuisance of low-flying aircraft will be reduced in the near future when new airways navigational equipment, now used on only a part of the nation's airplane network, is put into general service, Charles F. Horne, Administrator of Civil Aeronautics, declared last night.

The University Club blanked the Racquet and Tennis Club, 5 -- 0, on the victors' courts yesterday and took first place with a record of fifteen triumphs and five losses in the Class A Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association team championships.

The $20,000,000 offering of New England Telephone and Telegraph Company's twenty-five-year 3 1/4 per cent debentures by Kuhn, Loeb Co. and Union Securities Corp. was oversubscribed yesterday and the books closed. The debentures due Dec. 15, 1977, were offered at 101.721 to yield 3.15 per cent.

ABOARD THE U.S.S. HELENA, en Route to Hawaii, Dec. 9 -- An exchange of messages cleared the way today for Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the President-elect, to meet face to face with Gen. Douglas MacArthur and receive the former Far Eastern commander's plan for ending the Korean war.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Dec. 9 (AP) -- The Netherlands Government announced today that it had refused to submit the documents of oil companies established in the Netherlands for use in United States legal action against alleged international oil cartels.
MUROC, Calif., Dec. 9 (AP) -- The first faster-than-sound flight by an American fighter plane completely equipped for combat was made here recently, it was announced officially today.
The police have opened a whirlwind drive against bus drivers "jumping" traffic signal lights and last week issued thirty-four summonses to violators.

ALBANY, Dec. 9 -- The State Conference Board of Farm Organizations urged Governor Dewey today to order a "reappraisal of the state's entire walfare system, with an eye to giving localities greater administrative responsibility in reducing local welfare costs."

PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 9 (UP) -- Pacific Coast Conference football coaches will recommend to conference athletic directors and faculty representatives that the traveling limit on squads for conference games be raised from thirty-seven to forty men, Kip Taylor, Oregon State mentor and secretary of the coaches group, said tonight.

A sordid picture of unscrupulous union men appropriating for their own ends the multi-million-dollar waterfront industry of the country's greatest port was drawn for the State Crime Commission yesterday by a file of shipping men who marched to the witness stand in the Federal Court House.

The Federal Government began deportation proceedings yesterday against Albert Anastasia, Brooklyn waterfront racketeer and chief executioner of Murder, Inc., by filing suit in Newark, N. J., to denaturalize him.

The following excerpts are from testimony given at yesterday's hearing by the State Crime Commission. They deal with extortion, the employment of thugs as hiring bosses and other abuses on the waterfront.
CHICAGO, Dec. 9 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock market here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

Having made something of a splash with its dramatic and experimental "Streetcar Named Desire," the Slavenska-Franklin Ballet at the Century Theatre last night offered another novelty which serves ifs purpose equally well at the opposite end of the repertoire.

TUNIS, Tunisia, Dec. 9 -- After three days of relative calm throughout Tunisia, French protectorate officials today announced the lifting of the special security measures imposed last Friday to forestall possible violent public reaction after the murder of Farhat Hached, the Tunisian Nationalist labor leader.

Police Commissioner George P. Monaghan said yesterday his office would use for "study and administrative help" evidence uncovered by the Kings County District Attorney's office in its investigation of an alleged police-protected bookmaking ring in the Brownsville area of Brooklyn.
SYRACUSE, N. Y., Dec. 9 (AP) -Minimum salary schedules for school principals were urged today by the State Association of Elementary School Principals.

The Federal Government began deportation proceedings yesterday against Albert Anastasia, Brooklyn waterfront racketeer and chief executioner of Murder, Inc., by filing suit in Newark, N. J., to denaturalize him.

The following excerpts are from testimony given at yesterday's hearing by the State Crime Commission. They deal with extortion, the employment of thugs as hiring bosses and other abuses on the waterfront.
