A sordid picture of unscrupulous union men appropriating for their own ends the multi-million-dollar waterfront industry of the country's greatest port was drawn for the State Crime Commission yesterday by a file of shipping men who marched to the witness stand in the Federal Court House.

The Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company employes throughout the country will share more than $2,000,000 in pre-holiday compensation this year, according to Ralph W. Burger, president of the food chain. Those with six months' service will receive a part of the annual fund voted by the company's board of directors, for distribution tomorrow.

BONN, Germany, Dec. 10 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer won a political victory for his European policy today when President Theodor Heuss withdrew his request to the Federal Constitutional Court for an opinion on the constitutionality of the Bonn treaty system. The President made his decision after two long conferences with the Chancellor.

LONDON, Dec. 10 (AP) -- Actor Sam Byrd of Charleston, S. C., revealed today that he had been married for a year and a half to the British girl who was hurled at his feet in story-book circumstances by an explosion on the invasion beaches of southern England in 1944.
BALTIMORE, Dec. 10 (AP) -- George N. Reeves, an elderly, well dressed man, might have been seen any evening during the last fourteen years quietly eating dinner alone in a Baltimore restaurant.

Millions of Americans every year are exposed to a special problem in what is known as adjustment. It is a compulsive process which often begins just about this season, but which generally reaches its agonizing peak in mid-February and is completed some time in June.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (AP) -- The Secretary of Labor, Maurice J. Tobin, proposed today a new minimum wage of $1.00 an hour for nearly all work done under Government contract by the cotton, silk and synthetic textile industry.

Formation of the Association of Medical Advertising Agencies, to preserve and advance high professional standards in pharmaceutical advertising, was announced yesterday following a meeting of leading agencies in this field in the Barclay Hotel.

SEA CLIFF, L. I., Dec. 10 -- A "what-is-it" was shot here today by a greenskeeper at the North Shore Country Club. Golfers had caught glimpses of the strange animal frequently for a year, but no one had come close enough to capture it alive -- or dared to, either, if the truth must be told.

A counterfeit of The Bulletin, the Barnard College newspaper, appeared yesterday morning on the campus of the women's college, which lies just beyond the Broadway border of the men's ("boys," say the Barnard women) stronghold at Columbia College.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- The heads of Federal regulatory commissions that operate as business and industry courts found today that public confidence in the machinery of government was being slowly undermined by propaganda attacks of special interest lobbies and decided to do something about it.

BOSTON, Dec. 10 -- The Massachusetts Commission against Discrimination said today that a Cape Cod motor court operator had paid fixed damages of $50 to a New York Negro social worker for denying him accommodations last July.

The drama of General Eisenhower's visit to the Korean battlefront heights is as he lands today at Pearl Harbor. On the trip from Guam to Hawaii the President-elect has been in almost constant consultations with four of the men he has chosen to be members of his Cabinet, and now they will be joined by the Secretary of Defense, who flew ahead for a preparatory conference with General Bradley and other military officers.

From the time of the invasion of South Korea in June, 1950, through the first half of 1951, the rise in living costs kept even with, or ahead of, changes in non-farm wages. Since that time, however, with prices and wages "managed" under the stabilization program, the reverse has been true.

ALBANY, Dec. 10 -- State Conservation Commissioner Perry R. Duryea announced today that the duck hunting season would be extended beyond the official Dec. 18 closing date to make up for the time lost to hunters when the woods were closed because of fire hazards.

Commodity futures in New York markets generally lost ground yesterday. Trading was light except for potatoes, which approached record levels. Potatoes and sugar closed mixed and coffee, tin and lead were higher, with no sales in the two metals.

The city's police force is still the "finest" in the country despite expert opinion that it ranks only sixth, Mayor Impellitteri declared yesterday at City Hall exercises marking the induction of 791 graduates of the Police Academy into the ranks as probationary patrolmen.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (UP) -- The Department of Agriculture said today rains and melting snow have improved the condition of the nation's drought-threatened winter wheat crop.
LONDON, Dec. 10 -- Opening of a new bookkeeping account today found business still shrinking and price movements undecided. The main exception was the copper mining market, which rose.

A new way of glaceing canned pineapple for the holidays has been developed by a commercial kitchen. It cuts processing time from twenty to seven days. The shorter method does no violence to flavor or texture, we decided after taste-tests.

MIAMI, Dec. 10 -- Three men and a woman, residents of the Miami area, surrendered today to Federal authorities on indictments charging them with lying in connection with last winter's terrorism against religious and racial groups.

Renewed amazement at the infinite variety of the human race came over me as I read in THE TIMES of Dec. 3 Dr. Alice Hamilton's letter in praise of the "essential nobility" of a Communist who refuses to "accuse" her fellow-Communists of being Communists.

CASABLANCA, French Morocco, Dec. 10 -- French police began rounding up Nationalists and Communists blamed for the recent bloody Casablanca riots tonight shortly after the Sultan of Morocco had thrown his support to the French in the current crisis.

John Heinrich, vice president of The Lincoln Savings Bank, was elected president of the Bankers Club of Brooklyn last night at the annual dinner meeting at the Towers Hotel. He succeeds Carl J. Mehldau, vice president of Kings County Trust Company.

IT was indeed startling when Eddie Stanky exercised his managerial prerogative and failed to retain Terry Moore as one of his coaches on the St. Louis Cardinals Perhaps it's even more surprising that he should reach all the way down to Birmingham to fill the vacancy with his old Dodger team-mate, Dixie Walker.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14 a group of motion pictures to be shown, tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified.

On a day when the face of nature seems as amiable as that of a Russian diplomat the amateur ornithologist turns to the solace of the bird kingdom whose inhabitants seem stoically indifferent to snow, sleet, or biting wind.

BERLIN, Dec. 10 -- Walter J. Donnelly, United States High Commissioner, sent a Christmas food package today to Soviet headquarters in East Berlin for delivery to Dr. Walter Linse, kidnapped West Berlin anti-Communist. The retiring high commissioner sent the package on the eve of his departure for the United States.

A traveler who finds the inspiration for her fashions in distant parts of the globe is Lotte of Drewyn, whose collection of resort designs was shown yesterday by Saks Fifth Avenue at the Pierre Hotel. For this presentation, the designer journeyed to Trinidad and Tobago which, famous as a pirate refuge years ago, proved ideal spots with their wealth of color and lore.

HARTFORD, Dec. 10 -- Gov. John Lodge has offered a compromise to officials of Northeastern and Algonquin to assure Connecticut natural gas service in case of emergency. The principal provision of the compromise is that in event of an emergency brought on by a prolonged cold weather period, Algonquin would permit Northeastern to send gas through the Algonquin lines.

Members of a special Police Commissioner's squad headed by Supervising Assistant Chief Inspector James R. Kennedy raided last night an apartment at 56 West Sixty-fifth Street, between Columbus Avenue and Central Park West, in which they found, Inspector Kennedy said, one of the largest policy banks in the city.
ADEN, Dec. 10 (UP) -- A test case brought by Britain to block sales of Iranian oil opened here today before the Supreme Court of this tiny British protectorate.

PARIS, Dec. 10 -- The military leaders of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, meeting in a closed session today, agreed unanimously on a compromise solution of the Allied Mediterranean Command issue. This question has been in dispute, notably between the United States and Britain, for the last eighteen months.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (AP) -A Negro minister said today he planned to sue Southeastern Greyhound Lines for injuries suffered when he was attacked Monday by two white men because he would not move to a rear seat on a bus in Georgia.

NEWARK, Dec. 10 -- Harold J. Adonis, former executive clerk on the staff of Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll, and recently linked with Bergen County gambling operations, was indicted by a Federal Grand Jury today on charges of "willful evasion of a large part of his income taxes for the year 1948."

Fifteen acres of land at the northwest corner of East Shore Road and Hicks Lane, Great Neck, L. I., have been sold by the Tilyou Realty Corporation of Coney Island to Kings Point Properties, Inc., representing Sidney Berg and Robert Bernhard, builders, of Wantagh, L. I.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- Several hundred Marines in the combat line in Korea are now testing armored shorts that are worn along with their armored vests. Meanwhile, the Army has announced that a new protective "lower torso item," or shorts, had been developed and that it would start to deliver test garments to Korea next February.

The stock market took a rest yesterday. But the interlude was expected and surprised nobody. After prices slackened during themorning, the list managed largely to recoup the losses and the close was mixed.
Brooklyn College's unbeaten basketball team overpowered Hunter College, 75 -- 47, for its fifth straight victory at the Flat-bush gymnasium last night. The defeat was Hunter's third in five games.

PALO ALTO, Calif., Dec. 10 -- A 200-foot "rifle," designed to fire electron "bullets" at approximately the speed of light and to develop energies up to 1,000,000,000 volts, was unveiled today by Stanford University as the newest tool for probing the nucleus of the atom.
Softly tailored dresses and suits by David Crystal and trim separates by Haymaker were presented yesterday by Best Co. in a resort and spring fashion show at the Waldorf Astoria Hotel.

LONDON, Dec. 10 -- A spokesman of the Cunard Line expressed his company's approval tonight of the arrangements being made by United States immigration officials to minimize the inconvenience and complication expected by liners entering United States ports, particularly New York, after Dec. 24.

WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., Dc. 10 (AP) -- Mrs. Kinta Desmare Merrill, 50 years old, will receive many thousands a year from Charles Edward Merrili, according to a stipulation filed in Circuit Court today in their divorce proceedings.
SEA ISLAND, Ga., Dec. 10 -- Attorneys general of the various states today joined a move for a constitutional amendment that would subordinate the Federal treaty making power to the Bill of Rights.

Pierre Monteux, who retired last year as the head of the San Francisco Symphony, and George Szell, musical director of the Cleveland Orchestra, have been engaged for next season as conductors in the French and German wings, respectively, of the Metropolitan Opera, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- Secretary of State Dean Acheson predicted today that there would be repetitions of the recent Czechoslovak Communist purge trials wherever it was necessary in the Soviet sphere to teach "unquestioning dependence on the Kremlin and unswerving and successful compliance with its purposes."

PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 10 (AP) -- Football coaches of the Pacific Coast Conference, heeding protests that arose from the Stanford-Southern California game, decided tonight to try to curb over-zealous playing. In another formal action, the recruiting rule for athletes was relaxed on one issue.
JERUSALEM, Dec. 10 -- Dr. Itzhak Ben-Zvi was inaugurated today as President of Israel in succession to Dr. Chaim Weizmann at a ceremony in the Knesset (Parliament).

The nation's steel furnaces produced 9,446,000 net tons of raw steel during November, a record output for that month and the second largest for any month, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.
Harold R. Johnson has been elected a director of the American Gas and Electric Service Corporation.

An analysis of China's present position in world politics and her outlook for the future has been scheduled for January publication by Bookman Associates under the title "The Third Force in China." The author is Carsun Chang, author of the "Constitution of the Nationalist Government of China" and a leader of the democratic government there.

Remarks allegedly made by Chief Magistrate John M. Murtagh that Eugene E. McManus, Tammany district leader, tried to "fix" traffic tickets his wife had received was the subject of an action in Supreme Court yesterday.

New experimental toys appeared in the eleventh Children's Holiday Carnival, which opened yesterday at the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street. All of the toys, which are by leading artists and designers, are planned to encourage the active participation by children and to stimulate creative insight by exploring texture, color, light and motion.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- Officials of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace told a Congressional inquiry today that Alger Hiss, as president of the organization, had administered its affairs in 1947 and 1948 without any sign of bias in favor of the Soviet Government.

Victor van der Linde, board chairman of the Dolcin Corporation, charged yesterday that the Federal Trade Commission had ignored evidence favorable to the producer's product. In addition to filing an appeal with the commission, he said, one also will be made to the United States Circuit Court of Appeals for reversal of the commission's order.

Indications of an approaching business recession should give no cause for expecting a serious or prolonged slump, and certainly do not justify a "depression psychology" already evident among some business men, it was asserted yesterday by Raymond Rodgers, Professor of Banking at the New York University Graduate School of Business Administration.

The removal of Special Deputy State Attorney General William B. Herlands, who is conducting a special grand jury investigation of organized gambling and corruption on Staten Island, was demanded yesterday by Irving Rivkin, a former assistant district attorney of Richmond County.

Michael J. Quill's latest device, to order the members of the Transport Workers Union to give away free rides to passengers on privately owned bus lines in New York City starting next Sunday midnight, is nothing more or less than incitement to crime.

The Presbyterian Home for Aged Women will benefit from the performance of the Christmas show and the motion picture, "Million Dollar Mermaid," with Esther Williams, Walter Pidgeon and Victor Mature, at the Radio City Music Hall on the night of Dec. 19.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (AP) -Northeastern Gas Transmission Company was blocked today in an effort to present at a Federal Power Commission hearing evidence it has suficient natural gas resources to serve its proposed expansion in the New England market.

Reflecting record sales of $66,503,941 for the fiscal year ended on last Sept. 30. net income of Canada Dry Ginger Ale, Inc., rose to $2,301,691 from $2,157,547 in the previous fiscal year, according to the annual report issued yesterday.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., Dec. 10 -- The United States premiere of George Bernard Shaw's historical play, "In Good King Charles' Golden Days," was presented tonight in the Students Building on the Smith College campus by the Smith College Department of Theatre.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 10 (AP) -- The International Telecommunications Union, which represents eighty-two countries and colonies, today overwhelmingly approved a resolution endorsing the principle of "unrestricted" flow of news throughout the world.

The Du Mont Television Network will open its new $4,000,000 Tele-Centre at 205 East Sixty-seventh Street this week-end. Programming, engineering and film departments will be moved first to the new facilities from 515 Madison Avenue, which is still the network's main headquarters.

A fugitive desperado who carried two revolvers and fifty bullets engaged in a spectacular pre-dawn gun battle with the police yesterday along Eighth Avenue in the Times Square vicinity. When the duel ended, the captured thug, three policemen and three civilians had been wounded.

BERNARD SHAW'S love letter's sometimes sound alarmingly like platform lectures on economics. His formal writings about economics and less dismal arts, on the other hand, are often rather passionately lyrical. It is particularly interesting, then, to have in the same season two such complementary books as the new Shavian volumes we shall review today and Saturday.

The 24-year-old master of a small freighter left his ship somewhere off St. John, N. B., yesterday in obedience to his father's orders after wild radio messages had been sent from the ship, including a threat to sink the vessel unless the father were made a Cabinet Minister in the Israeli Government.

I dislike very much taking exception to the editorial which appeared in THE NEW YORK TIMES on Dec. 8 in relation to the St. Lawrence Project. The article was well written and must have given many of your readers the impression that, if all opponents of the project had not already passed away, any further opposition by those having the temerity to speak would be useless and a waste of good newspaper space.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 10 (AP) -- Ellis Ryan, president of the Indians, said today he intended to keep his job and has the backing of more than 50 per cent of the baseball club's stock. Ryan said he expected to win his fight to "restore unity to the ball club."

There are still fourteen Americans on the Secretariat of the United Nations on whom the State Department has filed "adverse comments" seeking their ouster, a Senate internal security subcommittee was told here yesterday. Carlisle H. Humelsine, Deputy Under Secretary of State, testified that twelve were considered "security" risks to the United States and two were "morals" cases.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (UP) -- Harry Darby, Republican National Committeeman for Kansas, said today Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, President-elect, should recognize his "home state" by backing Wesley Roberts for chairman of the Republican National Committee.
AT THE KOREAN FRONT, Dec. 10 -- The United States Eighth Army is settling down to what is expected to be another hard but rather unspectacular winter of war.

High-ranking United Nations delegates, Israel diplomats and Zionist leaders paid solemn tribute last night to Dr. Chaim Weizmann, Israel's first president, at a memorial meeting at Carnegie Hall under the auspices of the American Zionist Council, the public-relations arm of all Zionist organizations in this country.

Land Properties, Inc., representing Leo Silver and Stanley Katz, sold the six-story loft building on plot 50 by 100 feet at 322-24 West Forty-eighth Street to Lithos Properties, Inc., in a deal negotiated by L. J. Phillips Co. Assessed at $210,000, the property was sold for cash over a new mortgage of $150,000 placed on the premises by the John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 10 -- More than 1,000 collective farms in Yugoslavia have been dissolved in the Government's drive to rectify the errors of indiscriminate collectivization that marked the early years of the Communist regime.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Dec. 10 -- Foreshadowing what may become South African policy if Dr. Daniel F. Malan wins the spring elections, the Prime Minister struck a blow today at the education of non-whites at South Africa's two biggest and best universities, those at Capetown and Johannesburg.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (AP) -- The Department of Commerce estimated today that retail sales were 6 per cent higher in October this year than in October a year ago.

Something has been lacking in New York City since 1941, when the old Aquarium at the foot of Manhattan was closed. Now, after being submerged for a decade, the plan for a fine new Aquarium at Coney Island, to cost $10,000,000 and be a cooperative venture of the New York Zoological Society and the city's Park Department, has been put before the public for action.

A treatment for fractured teeth that greatly accelerates the building up of new dentine tissue was demonstrated at yesterday's session of the Greater New York Dental Meeting. The demonstration was presented at a clinic set up in the Statler Hotel.
The New York State Crime Commission will inquire deeply at public hearings in the County Court House here next week into the affairs of the International Longshoremen's Association, A. F. L.

LAWRENCE, Kan., Dec. 10 (AP) -- The 1952 collegiate All-America track and field team was announced today by M. E. (Bill) Easton, Secretary-treasurer of the National Collegiate Track Coaches Association.

Clarence (Biggie) Munn, the former University of Minnesota lineman, who piloted Michigan State's football powerhouse to its second straight unbeaten and untied season during the recent campaign to continue a winning streak through twenty-four games, yesterday was named "coach of the year" by members of the American Football Coaches Association.

Plans for a broad slum-clearance project covering 11.28 acres near the Manhattan Bridge in downtown Brooklyn were announced yesterday by Robert Moses, chairman of the Mayor's Committee on Slum Clearance. The development will include two housing projects, each consisting of three fourteen-story buildings.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- Here goes science again, converting illusions into delusions, if such a distinction can be made about those flying saucers. The scientists at the Civil Aeronautics Administration would have you believe that the saucy saucers are just a matter of reflections, and they are quite convincing about it.
AMSTERDAM, The Netherlands, Dec. 10 -- Harold J. Adonis was reported tonight to be negotiating for a voluntary return to the United States to face a Bergen County (N. J.) bribery indictment.

The appointment of Mrs. Dorothy D. Waddington as executive director of the Fashion Group, an organization of women employed in the fashion industry, was announced yesterday at a luncheon held at the Biltmore Hotel under the auspices of the group's cosmetic division.
CHICAGO, Dec. 10 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

LONDON, Dec. 10 -- British authorities were aware that the State Department had been consulting United States oil company representatives about a solution of the oil dispute between Britain and Iran, a Foreign Office spokesman said today. However, Britain has not been participating in the discussions.

Tonight's televised performance of "Carmen" from the Metropolitan Opera House will be seen by an audience estimated at 70,000 in twenty-seven cities from New York to San Francisco, officials of the opera house announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- Questions from the bench to counsel in the current arguments before the Supreme Court over the legality of racial segregation in the public schools tend to strengthen the expectation that on this issue the justices will be sharply divided.
Once more have the problems of France in North Africa been thrust to the forefront of world attention by the murder of Farhat Hached in Tunis.
Three men were killed and two were injured, one of them fatally, when a tank exploded yesterday aboard a Navy landing craft in a Brooklyn drydock.

An increase last week of 2,647,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end they amounted to 129,470,000 barrels compared with 126,833,000 a week earlier and 124,063,000 a year ago.
Contemporary designs and textures predominate in the collection of decorating fabrics on view at Scalamandre Silks, Inc., 598 Madison Avenue. The materials may be ordered through decorators.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., Dec. 10 (UP) -- Representative Joseph W. Martin Jr. of Massachusetts, House Republican leader, said tonight that "we must arm the Chinese Nationalists and start a threat to the Reds on the Chinese mainland" to spur a Korean peace.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 10 -- The fourth anniversary of the Universal Declaration on Human Rights was marked at a plenary session of the United Nations General Assembly this morning. Lester B. Pearson of Canada, the Assembly president, declared that on the day that had been widely designated as Human Rights Day, such rights still were being openly disregarded in many parts of the world.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 10 -- Four Western European members of the United Nations staff were reported today to have been dismissed as part of the drive to oust all employes believed to be subversive or dangerous security risks.

A government view of the handling of racial relations in the Union of South Africa was presented yesterday by Gerhardus P. Jooste, South African United Nations delegate and Ambassador to the United States. He spoke at the Columbia Law School Forum, held at the McMillin Theatre, 116th Street an dBroadway.

It is a human failing or virtue -- call it what you will -- to spend more for Christmas gifts than one had intended. Junior's electric train puffs real smoke and has a two-tone whistle. Sister's bottle of perfume is a size larger than budgeted for. Even Aunt Edna's tin of English biscuits somehow turns into a wicker basket of delicacies.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 10 -- On the eve of its sixth anniversary, the United Nations International Children's emergency fund gave out today its first extensive account of the way in which limited, "stop-gap" help to seventy-two needy nations had been pyramided into welfare programs of lasting benefit.

The New York Academy of Medicine accused the Board of Education yesterday of nullifying standards for the position of chief school medical inspector and indirectly endangering the health of the city's public school children.

ABOARD THE PRESIDENTIAL SPECIAL, Dec. 10 -- President Truman, Commander in Chief of the armed services, today called upon General of the Army Douglas MacArthur, or anyone else having a "reasonable plan" to end the Korean war, to submit the plan to him "at once."

The application to set aside the convictions of three Soviet atom spies was dismissed yesterday by Federal Judge Sylvester Ryan, who, at the same time, refused to stay the execution of Julius and Ethel Rosenberg, scheduled to die in the electric chair the week of Jan. 12.

ABOARD THE U. S. S. HELENA, en route to Hawaii, Dec. 10 (AP) Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower and Gen. Douglas MacArthur will meet in New York shortly after the President-elect's return to discuss General MacArthur's plan for shortening the Korean war, a reliable source said today.
STOCKTON, Calif., Dec. 10 -- A 9,500-ton cargo of bulk barley was being loaded today at Stockton aboard the Korea, flagship of the Korean Republic's first independent merchant marine.

E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., will receive a tax refund of $29,000,000, or about 6 per cent of its total tax liability, in accordance with its claim allowed by the United States Government under Section 722 of the excess profits tax law.

DAVIS DAM, Ariz., Dec. 10 -- The dedication today of this $119,000,000 installation, which backs up the waters of the Colorado in a sixty-seven-mile reservoir for irrigation and power generation in two nations, marked the formal completion of a historic program for harnessing the lower reaches of the river that had been under way for more than two decades.

Coach John (Honey) Russell's Seton Hall University quintet has ample power to "give anyone trouble." That's how Russell described his team yesterday as he put the Pirates through their paces for the battle tonight with West Texas State at Madison Square Garden.

As expected, the great educational and philanthropic foundations that have brought honor to the name of America throughout the world have been giving a good account of themselves before the special House committee now investigating them. The inquiry, headed by Representative E. E. Cox of Georgia, is supposed to determine whether the tax-exempt foundations "are using their resources for un-American and subversive activities."

New York City will open its three-day, state-ordered civil defense exercise this afternoon with the presentation and solution of a "paper" problem involving an atom bomb attack on the Bronx. It will end Saturday with a mamnoth physical drill in which 5,000 volunteers and the public will take part.

Public hearings on the petition of the Staten Island Rapid Transit Railway to discontinue passenger service Dec. 19 ended yesterday before the Public Service Commission after testimony by Sidney Bingham, chairman of the city's Board of Transportation, that buses could not adequately substitute for rapid transit service.
Mayor Impellitteri named yesterday a three-man committee to "inquire broadly" into the gathering crisis on eight local private bus lines.

Directors of the National City Bank of Cleveland, second largest bank in Ohio, plan to increase the capital stock to 875,000 from 750,000 shares by the sale of 125,000 shares at $36 a share, subject to approval of stockholders at the annual meeting on Jan. 13.

TOKYO, Dec. 10 -- The United States Central Intelligence Agency was identified by reliable sources as the group that held the Japanese writer Wataru Kaji in custody for seven months after Japan had regained her independence. These sources said the essentials of this information had been made known to the highest Japanese authorities.

Struggles for control of the Security Banknote Company came into the open yesterday, when S. W. Muldowney, president, called a special meeting of shareholders in Wilmington, Del., on Jan. 23. The meeting would consider a proposal to increase the number of directors and to elect new directors to fill the posts thus created.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- The segregation of pupils in the public schools on the basis of color is not a question of constitutional rights but of legislative policy, John W. Davis told the Supreme Court today. For that reason, he asserted, the court should not set aside as unconstitutional the segregation statutes enacted by the states.

The Rocket Paper Company, manufacturer of corrugated paper, has leased the one-story building at 997 Grand Street in the Greenpoint section of Brooklyn from L. Dressner through the Kalmon Dolgin Company, broker. The structure contains about 7,000 square feet of space.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- The State Department today threatened legal action against the Soviet Union and Hungary unless they both give a satisfactory explanation for the detention of four United States airmen in Hungary a year ago, and return the plane and its cargo, still held by Soviet authorities.

With Jim Henry contributing another one of his sensational performances in the nets, the Boston Bruins subdued the New York Rangers in a National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night.

DENVER, Dec. 10 -- Senator Henry Cabot Lodge Jr. of Massachusetts, United States Ambassador-designate to the United Nations, declared here tonight that the Soviet Union, despite its "overwhelming" military power, had refrained from "open-armed aggression'' largely because the General Assembly of the United Nations constituted a "very real deterrent."

BERLIN, Dec. 10 -- Several key officials in one of East Germany's important coal mining districts have been arrested for sabotaging the country's coal production an article in Neues Deutschland, official Communist newspaper, disclosed today.
PRINCETON, N. J., Dec. 10 -- A last-quarter rally enabled Temple's basketball team to defeat Princeton, 62 -- 57, in Dillon Gymnasium tonight.

Milton R. Rackmil, president of Decca Records, Inc., said the consent decree "eliminates the vestiges of certain agreements made by American Decca in 1934." The decree, he emphasized, affects foreign markets for all concerned but makes valuable foreign recordings available to American Decca. Existing property rights are specifically reserved for the American organization under the decree, Mr. Rackmil added.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 10 (AP) -- Tough luck rode with Tony DeSpirito, the nation's leading jockey, at Tropical Park today as his battle to set a new record faced the threat of sudden termination by the track stewards.
TOKYO, Thursday, Dec. 11 (AP) -United Nations Command communique 1,460, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Thursday, Korea time:
Bishop Loughlin High of Brooklyn dominated the third annual Catholic High Schools A. A. relay carnival at the Twenty-second Engineers Armory last night as it captured five of the twelve relay events.

SEOUL, Korea, Thursday, Dec. 11 -- Chinese Communist troops struck early today in their biggest attacks in a month on the western front. South Korean soldiers fought doggedly in subfreezing weather to hold "Nori Hill" and another outpost against the Communist onslaught.
The Ford Motor Company, world's second largest automotive producer, realized a net profit in 1951 of $87,000,000 on the $2,952,000,000 sales transacted during that year, it was learned yesterday.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 11 (UP) -- Chuck Davey of Lansing, Mich., cleared the last barrier to his welterweight title match with Kid Gavilan in February by scoring a technical knockout tonight over outclassed Fitzie Pruden in the third round.
ALBANY, Dec. 10 (AP) -- Bigger budgets and higher taxes generally are predicted for New York State Cities and counties next year.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was weak again yesterday and active months declined 17 to 72 points to new lows for the season.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture forecast production of citrus fruits for the 1952-53 season at 177,890,000 boxes. This compares with 175,890,000 last season and with 170,443,000 for the ten - year (1941-50) average.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- The New York State Power Authority told the Federal Power Commission today that its operation of the St. Lawrence River hydroelectric power project, for which it is seeking a license, would save state residents $60,206,000 a year on their electric bills, once it was in full integrated operation.

An elimination tournament among the four leading aspirants to the title was proposed yesterday by the International Boxing Club to determine a successor to Ray Robinson as world middleweight champion, if and when the Harlem fighter officially announces his retirement.

Richard H. Balch, Utica fishing tackle manufacturer, was elected Chairman of the Democratic State Committee yesterday, defeating William H. Morgan, former Cortland County Chairman, by a vote of 181 to 104. He succeeds Paul E. Fitzpatrick, Buffalo contractor and builder, who resigned following the Presidential election after eight years in the post.
From the very young and from persons of wider experience came interested comment yesterday on the progress of the forty-first annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

Color television was used for the first time yesterday to present a commercial product at a sales meeting of a business concern. In Lancaster, Pa., approximately 500 company wholesalers and invited guests received a closed circuit preview in color of 1953 linoleum patterns introduced by the floor division of the Armstrong Cork Company.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- Secretary of State Dean Acheson said today that the State Department was meeting regularly with United States oil companies in an effort to find a solution to the Iranian oil problem.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (AP) -Partial reopening of the Government's synthetic rubber plant at Louisville, Ky., was ordered today.

Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, charged yesterday that "Communist thinkers" already were trying to infiltrate the incoming administration of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the President-elect. The Senator defined Communist thinkers as those who thought like Communists as well as those who actually belonged to the party.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 10 -- The Political and Security Committee of the United Nations General Assembly rejected today a Pakistan proposal to invite the Bey of Tunis to appoint a representative to take part in its debate on the Tunisian question.

The Giants and Dodgers will clash four times under the lights at Ebbets Field during the 1953 campaign, according to the home night game schedule announced yesterday by the Brooklyn Club. This will include the opening night game of the season on Friday, April 24.

CHICAGO, Dec. 10 -- A fresh wave of long liquidation hit the grain futures market today, resulting in sharp declines. The drop in grains helped unsettle soybean futures, which also suffered a slump. The grain weakness was in the face of liberal export sales of wheat and corn, while there was also some business predicted in beans, as Formosa has been granted $2,000,000 for such purchase.
HARRISBURG, Pa., Dec. 10 (AP) -- Gov. John S. Fine opened the way today for Negroes to serve in the state police and approved an end to segregation in the Pennsylvania National Guard.

DETROIT, Dec. 10 -- The automobile industry, its hopes buoyed by Government assurances that it would be allowed to build 1,500,000 passenger cars in the April-June quarter of 1953, received calmly today the Defense Department's decision to cut back production of medium tanks and two-and-one-half-ton military trucks.

JERSEY CITY, Dec. 10 -- Robert W. Greene, 25-year-old investigator for the New York City Anti-Crime Committee, entered a plea of not guilty before Hudson County Judge Paul J. Duffy today to an indictment charging him with conspiracy to defame Mayor John V. Kenny of this city.

TUNIS, Tunisia, Dec. 10 -- The French Resident General, Jean de Hauteclocque, today had a twenty-five minute interview with the Bey of Tunis, the first since delivery of a French Government note requesting the Tunisian ruler to renew direct negotiations on the home rule reform program proposed by France and rejected by the Bey's Nationalist advisers.

Mechanical improvements that make for a smoother ride and control sidesway on turns are offered in the 1953 line presented yesterday by the Ford division of the Ford Motor Company. Each of the cars has a balanced and synchronized suspension system that adds to maneuverability and safety in driving.

SEATTLE, Dec. 10 -- A comprehensive review of existing Federal farm legislation appeared likely today as a result of the drive of some leaders of the American Farm Bureau Federation to knock out high, rigid price support mechanisms for agricultural commodities.

At the annual meeting of the Dominion Bank in Toronto yesterday Robert Rae, president, told stockholders the principal reason for the Canadian dollar selling at a premium is the improvement in Canada's merchandise trade position.

BOWIE, Md., Dec. 10 (UP) -- Willie Lester, the new "fair-haired" boy of Bowie who booted home four winners yesterday, continued his spectacular riding today by gaining three more victories and finishing in the money with three other mounts.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Dec. 10 -- This year's six Nobel prizes winners in the fields of sciences and literature today received from Sweden's King Gustaf Adolf their diplomas and checks totalling $132,000 dollars. The traditional solemn ceremony took place at Stockholm's modernistic Symphony Hall on the anniversary of the death, 56 years ago, of Swedish donor Alfred Nobel, inventor of dynamite.

ATLANTIC CITY, Dec. 10 -- Next year will be a record year for automotive servicing with Americans spending $2,000,000,000 for automotive replacement parts, it was predicted here today by Don H. Teetor of Hagerstown, Ind., chairman of the Automotive Service Industries Show.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Dec. 3, the Federal Reserve Board reported today: ...

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 10 -- The major colonial powers persuaded the United Nations General Assembly today to kill a widely supported measure for continuing indefinitely the life of an information committee handling non-self-governing territories.

Fordham's basketball squad defeated its third metropolitan rival last night as the Maroon swept to a 69-51 victory over St. Francis of Brooklyn before 1,000 persons on the Rams' court in the Bronx. The victory was the third in three starts for the Maroon, which previously had beaten Adelphi and Columbia.

The investing public in this country is continually increasing its ownership in the nation's industries through the purchase of shares of mutual investment companies. This trend, Waldo Coleman, president of the Commonwealth Investment Company, said yesterday at a press luncheon at the Bankers Club, "is evidenced by the fact that approximately one out of every ten stockholders in the United States owns mutual fund shares."

Josephine Hull, who has not been seen here in two years, will star in a new comedy by Robert Finch called "Whistler's Grandmother," opening tonight at the President Theatre under the sponsorship of Anthony Parella. The curtain will rise at 8 P. M.

Josephine Hull, who has not been seen here in two years, will star in a new comedy by Robert Finch called "Whistler's Grandmother," opening tonight at the President Theatre under the sponsorship of Anthony Parella. The curtain will rise at 8 P. M.

The Bach Aria Group, which gave the first of its three concerts this season at Town Hall last night, proclaims its allegiance to one composer in its name. And it proves its devotion to him by the care and spirit with which it brings to life that immense section of his creative output that it has made its province.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 10 -- The United States, Canada, and a group of Latin American countries have drafted a resolution under which the General Assembly, starting next spring, would open its annual sessions in mid-April instead of mid-September.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- The conclusion that calcium leads the list of nutrients low both in supply and in intake in the American diet was reached today at the closing session of the National Food and Nutrition Institute.
LONDON, Dec. 10 -- George Wigg, a Laborite Member of Parliament, accused the British Army tonight of favoring the "cultured English gentleman" accent of southern England over the brogue of the north.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 10 -- A type of automobile public liability and property damage insurance designed to reward careful drivers and penalize careless ones was announced today for a tryout in California by the Liberty Mutual Insurance Company.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Dec. 10 -- Navy rolled to an easy 69-47 victory over American University today as John Clune, 6-foot 3-inch middle forward, bucketed twelve of twenty-four field goal attempts and added two free throws for 26 points.

Dates for the 1953 horse racing season in this state were approved by the State Racing Commission yesterday. The turf campaign will begin on Wednesday, April 1, and continue through Saturday, Nov. 14, making for 196 days of the sport.

Michael J. Obermeier, former president of Local 6, Hotel and Club Employes Union, A. F. L., was deported yesterday because he is a former Communist. Obermeier sailed for his native Germany at 10 A. M. aboard the Swedish American liner Stockholm.
GARDEN CITY, L. I., Dec. 10 -- Robert B. Baxter, South Bay Golf Club, Bay Shore, L. I., was elected president of the Long Island Golf Association at the annual meeting and dinner tonight.

An anti-trust consent judgment was entered yesterday by Judge Sidney Sugarman in Federal Court against Decca Records, Inc., of New York and the Decca Record Company, Ltd., London, terminating restraints in the manufacture and sale of commercial phonograph records. The announcement was made by C. Worth Rowley, assistant chief of the New York office of the anti-trust division of the Department of Justice.

ROTTERDAM, the Netherlands, Dec. 10 -- Outbound for New York with 600 passengers, the newest steamship of the Holland America Line, the 15,000-ton Maasdam, today rammed and sank a German oil tanker in Rotterdam's waterway. Six of the eleven German crew members are presumed dead.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Dec. 10 -- Ground was broken here today for a $7,000,000 eastern headquarters for the Long Lines department of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company. The new building will include a switching center, described as a "gateway for New York and New England long distance telephone calls."

TOKYO, Thursday, Dec. 11 -United States B-29's from Okinawa last night plastered three strategic targets near the North Korean Communist capital at Pyongyang, following up the Navy's heavy bombing raid Tuesday on enemy communications centers in the far northeast.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- The National Association of Manufacturers refused today to recommend members to represent industry on the Wage Stabilization Board. In a statement issued by Charles R. Sligh Jr., president of the organization, the N. A. M. lined up with the Chamber of Commerce of the United States.

NASHUA, N. H., Dec. 10 -- The five-month strike of the Nashua Newspaper Guild, Local 217, American Newspaper Guild, C. I. O., against the Nashua Telegraph Publishing Company ended today when the local conceded defeat and withdrew picket lines that had been maintained since July 10.
The election of Karl A. Borntrager, Arthur E. Baylis and Ernest C. Nickerson as vice presidents of the New York Central System, with headquarters here, was announced yesterday.

Diana Adams made her first appearance of the season last night with the New York City Ballet at the City Center in Antony Tudor's "Lilac Garden," which also was making its season's bow. Since she is one of the loveliest of dancers, and it is one of the finest of ballets, it was good to have them back.
TORONTO, Dec. 10 (UP) -- The Montreal Canadiens won their first game in ten starts tonight, defeating the Toronto Maple Leafs, 2 to 1, to knock them out of a tie for third place.

Prominent women are aiding in furthering the success of a concert, to be held on Jan. 18 at Town Hall, under the auspices of the Music Education League and the Little Orchestra Society. Mrs. Henry P. Davison is honorary chairman of the committee headed by Mrs. Alexander H. McLanahan in charge of plans for the events.

Mayor Impellitteri announced yesterday that he would ask the Board of Estimate to appropriate next Thursday $190,000 to set up a reclassification bureau in the Municipal Civil Service Commission. The purpose would be establishment of a career and salary plan for the city's 200,000 civil service employes.

CAIRO, Dec. 10 -- Maj. Gen. Mohammed Naguib, Premier of Egypt, declared tonight that Egypt desired to join in an over-all alliance for the purpose of defending the Middle East but only after her national aspirations had been satisfied.

MINNEAPOLIS, Dec. 10 (AP) -The controversial long and short haul provision of the Interstate Commerce Act was injected today into a regional transportation conference sponsored by the United States Chamber of Commerce.

ACCORDING to one of our more persistent correspondents there are two forms of outdoor activity that require a higher type of insanity -- ice fishing and coon hunting -- and, although special weather conditions are required for the former, all that is needed for the latter is a good coon population, which we now have.

A research program dealing with the relations of business and agriculture will be started today by the Harvard Graduate School of Business Administration at a meeting in Cambridge, Mass., of a committee of eighteen leaders in agriculture, business, government and education.

PARIS, Dec. 10 -- The European Marshall Plan Council, which will meet here Friday, is expected to take the first steps toward an economic conference between Western Europe and the United States early next year on trade and monetary questions.

Top management of the nation's life insurance companies should develop a closer understanding with its agency forces, David B. Fluegelman, president of the National Association of Life Underwriters, said yesterday at the second session of the forty-sixth annual meeting of the Life Insurance Association of America at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

SYDNEY, Australia, Dec. 10 (UP) -- The United States Davis Cup team, which is favored to defeat the Italy-India inter-zone winner and then meet Australia in the challenge round, began an intensive training program today calling for workouts twice daily.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- Dr. H. van Zile Hyde, director of the Health and Sanitation Staff, Technical Cooperation Administration, reported today visible progress in the sanitation and health of the Middle East as a result of international cooperation.

PARIS, Dec. 10 -- Foreign Minister Robert Schuman made a full report to the French Cabinet today on the disturbed conditions in Tunisia and Morocco for which the French Government considers the United Nations to be in a large degree responsible

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 10 -- Michael J. Quill's Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., took steps today to safeguard its own union treasury against the possibility of damage suits resulting from its decision to play Santa Claus with the buses of eight privately owned transit companies in New York.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- The National Production Authority today eased curbs on apartment house and other types of construction, effective Jan. 1, and authorized increased production of automobiles for the second quarter of 1953.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 10 -- A taxpayer's suit that sought to force the trustees of the Barnes Foundation to open to the public its multimillion dollar art collection in suburban Merion, was dismissed today by the Montgomery County Court in Norristown.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 10 -- Syria offered another proposal today in the United Nations debate on Palestine -- this time a suggestion that the International Court of Justice be asked to determine whether the fate of 850.000 Arab refugees could be properly decided by proposed Arab-Israeli negotiations.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Dec. 10 -- Dr. Grayson Kirk, acting head and provost of Columbia University, who is on a tour of Western Europe to seek cooperation in emphasizing the university's bicentennial theme of the "right of mankind to knowledge and to the free use thereof," spoke at a dinner in the United States Embassy here tonight.

The sixteenth annual schedule-making convention of the Eastern College Athletic Conference continued yesterday at the Hotel Biltmore with meetings of five affiliated organizations and closed sessions by committees working on reports and proposals to be presented at tomorrow's' annual meeting of the ninety-one college conference.

The City Athletic Club's first team triumphed over the Williams Club, 3 -- 2, on the C. A. C. courts yesterday to maintain its lead with seventeen victories and three losses in Division I of the Class C Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association.

BONN, Germany, Dec. 11 -- The West German delegation to the conference of the Organization for European Economic Cooperation, which will open in Paris tomorrow, will urge the restoration of free trading practices among the eighteen member states.

Excerpts from affidavit presented by Assistant District Attorney Anthony J. Scotti to General Sessions Court asking contempt of court action against Jerry Finkelstein, campaign manager in 1949 for former Mayor O'Dwyer, follow:

DENVER, Dec. 11 -- John Foster Dulles, who will be Secretary of State in the Eisenhower Cabinet, said today that "openness, simplicity and morality" would serve as the hallmarks of America's foreign policy.

The Frye Trophy, an award that will be presented annually to the commercial airline of this country that maintains the fastest regularly scheduled service, was given yesterday to Panagra (Pan American-Grace Airways) for its regular flight from Miami to Buenos Aires. It was the first presentation.

In preparation for his role as Secretary of Agriculture in the Eisenhower Administration, Ezra Taft Benson is now on a country-wide tour to renew acquaintances with leaders in various phases of the agricultural industry and to get suggestions for possible staff appointments.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 11 -- Britain announced today that she "cannot possibly accept" any proposal to amend existing agreements with a view to creating a united Togoland in West Africa and thereby encourage members of the Ewe peoples to hope for independence.

The Metropolitan Golf Association will revive a qualifying procedure, adopted during the war days but subsequently discarded, by establishing sectional trials for the 1953 metropolitan amateur championship.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Dec. 6, 1952, totaled 719,159 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 48,992 cars, or 7.3 per cent more than for the preceding week, 54,371 cars, or 7 per cent fewer than for the corresponding week of last year and 47,736 cars, or 6.2 per cent fewer than during the corresponding week of 1950.

CASABLANCA, French Morocco, Dec. 11 -- Three clashes today between Moroccan demonstrators and French security forces resulted in the death of three natives, one at Rabat, the administrative capital of Morocco, and two elsewhere, raising the casualty toll in the current outbreak of nationalist rioting to sixty-four dead, according to official French sources.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (UP) -- The State Department said today that the Soviet Union had refused to pay damages for an unarmed American B-29 Superfort bomber shot down by Soviet fighter planes off the northern tip of Japan Oct. 7.
ELIZABETH, N. J., Dec. 11 (AP) -- Union County Judge Edward A. McGrath approved today a final executor's accounting of a $478,461 estate, the bulk of which will go to a small Canadian resort town.

Five hundred and eighty-five specially constructed apartments for the aged will be ready, or under way, in public housing developments in New York State in 1953, Herman T. Stichman. State Commissioner of Housing, announced yesterday.

A Senate internal security subcommittee has received information that an ousted American woman employe of the United Nations has been talking over the idea of "organizing" present United Nations employes, Robert Morris, committee counsel, said yesterday. The woman, Miss Alfreda Abell, called as a witness, refused to say whether she had been "retained by any Communist" for such an effort.

BONN, Germany, Dec. 11 -- Erich Ollenhauer, leader of the Social Democratic party, accused Chancellor Konrad Adenauer today of leading West Germany down a ruinous road by tampering with the Federal Constitutional Court and warned his countrymen that freedom "stands or falls with the constitution."

Dimitri Mitropoulos has been re-engaged as musical director of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony by unanimous vote of the orchestra's directors. The decision was reached at a meeting of the board Wedensday afternoon.

Against a background of multi-branch candelabra festooned with snowy fir boughs and wide tables spread with gold metallic cloth, Elizabeth Arden opened her "Christmas Wonderland of Gifts" yesterday on the second floor of her Fifth Avenue salon.

Operations of the Anglo-Lautaro Nitrate Corporation in the twelve months ended on last June 30, resulted in a profit of $5,702,621, equal to $1.29 a share on the class A stock, Harry F. Guggenheim, chairman of the board, reported yesterday. In the previous year the corporation made $7,034,287 or $1.58 a class A share.

TORONTO, Dec. 11 (Canadian Press) -- The Telegram, in a financial page story today, says that Steep Rock Mines, Ltd., west of Port Arthur, is the center of repeated "million dollar street rumors regarding a new deal developing between the company and Inland Steel Company, Chicago."

BERLIN, Dec. 11 -- The Christmas present that Walter J. Donnelly, the United States High Commissioner, sent yesterday to Dr. Walter Linse, kidnaped West Berliner, in care of the Soviet Headquarters in East Berlin, came back today by special messenger marked "missing."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- The stalemate in Korea, with its bloody harvest, and the repudiation of the Administration's record that was implicit in the overwhelming choice by the voters of General Eisenhower over Governor Stevenson for President, are closely linked in the mind of President Truman.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- Earl J. McGrath, Federal Commissioner of Education, announced today the formation of an advisory committee to review and re-evaluate the country's vocational education program.

The future of the helicopter seemed to be looking up yesterday when the Port of New York Authority announced it had purchased two new models at a cost of $70,000. The agency will sell its first helicopter, in service for eighteen months, to the highest bidder.

Theodore W. Kheel, impartial chairman of the private transit industry, ordered the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., yesterday to abandon its plan to collect no fares on eight private bus lines beginning Sunday midnight, but the union promptly rejected the directive.

Josephine Hull Phi Beta Kappa (Radcliffe), and a sweetheart, is playing the part of a benign fraud in Robert Finch's "Whistler's Grandmother," which was put on at the President last evening. By being motherly and protective, she persuades some crumb-bums that she is a fine old lady in a fine old family, and they love the home she has created. Eventually they learn Ithat she i. common clay.

FORT LEE, N. J., Dec. 11 -- The Lee Theatre, a few blocks south of the George Washington Bridge, was one of the few movie houses in the metropolitan area that carried the televised "Carmen" last night. Despite the rainy, blustering weather, more than 1,100 people attended.

MORRISVILLE, Pa., Dec. 11 -- Less than two years after rich farm land was turned up for the start of construction, the United States Steel Corporation's giant $450,000,000 integrated mill, the Fairless Works, was put into operation two miles south of here today.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 11 -- The State Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that the California Toll Bridge Authority has no legal power to issue $50,000,000 in bonds for construction of new approaches to the San Francisco-Oakland Bay Bridge.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 11 -- One aspect of the confused state of management affairs at R. K. O. Radio Pictures was clarified late today when Ned E. Depinet revealed that he had decided against accepting "at this time," an offer from Howard Hughes "to return to the board of directors and to again become the president."

A twenty-year period in French history is delineated in the designs on some of the antique fabrics and reproductions of materials in an exhibit at the Scalamandre Museum of Textiles, 20 West Fifty-fifth Street.

More than an inch of rain fell on the city yesterday in intermittent downpours that began at 2:25 A. M. and continued into the late evening. During the morning hours, the rains were driven by winds that attained velocities of forty-five miles an hour.

CINCINNATI, Dec. 11 -- The United States Circuit Court of Appeals denounced investigating procedures of the Senate Kefauver Committee as a violation of the Fifth Amendment to the Constitution, and in a unanimous opinion today, the court reversed the conviction of Joseph Aiuppa of Cicero, Ill.

Failure of Brazil to liquidate debts owed to United States exporters is having an adverse effect on trade with that nation and on the capacity of many affected exporters to maintain normal operations with other countries, it was declared yesterday by the Commerce and Industry Association of New York.

LOS ANGELES, Calif., Dec. 11 -- Combining of two large wholesale grocery concerns was disclosed today with the announcement that Smart Final Company has purchased Haas, Baruch Co., pioneer Los Angeles company.

Vice Admiral Richard Lansing Conolly, president of the Naval War College at Newport, R. I., said last night there was a need for a continuing and "objective military policy which will provide the means for implementing our national policy, support our diplomacy and execute, in case of war, a planned, winning strategy."

Vivid in color and with the spirit of the islands of the Caribbean, the Calypso-inspired fashions by Cabana Beachwear, shown yesterday by Bonwit Teller at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, were like a brief glimpse of a Southern holiday.

The agenda for the next convention of the National Theatre Assembly, to be held Jan. 1-3 in Cincinnati, will be formulated here next week. Prof. Sawyer Falk of Syracuse University, who heads the committee, will consult with Roger Stevens, chairman of the American National Theatre and Academy's group, and his colleagues.

After sixteen years, Manhattan College finally won its opening game at Madison Square Garden when Ken Norton's Jaspers struggled to a 65-63 victory over an aggressive University of Louisville quintet last night at the Eighth Avenue arena.

Syracuse University's 1952 football team received the Lambert Trophy as the East's outstanding eleven, and Charlie Caldwell, Princeton University coach, was honored for his long and distinguished service to football at the Touchdown Club of New York's sixteenth annual dinner in the Astor Hotel last night.

A new method of bonding foam rubber to carpeting has been developed by Collins Aikman Corporation, it was announced yesterday by Albert R. Jude, president. Foam-backed carpeting made by the company will be utilized in several of the new 1953 automobile models, he said, and when production facilities are increased the product will be made available for the home rug field.

The Italian Line's new flagship Andrea Doria has "easily exceeded" her builder's contract speed of 25.3 knots in final trials in the Gulf of Genoa, W. H. McConnell, vice president of American Export Lines, agents for the Italian Line, announced yesterday.
Akram Solh, a 31-year-old Lebanese student, was held in $10,000 bail for action of the grand jury yesterday for the illegal importation of seventy ounces of heroin.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- Some "mistakes" in granting fellowships to individuals since cited for Communistic activities were acknowledged today on behalf of the $30,000,000 John Simon Guggenheim Memorial Foundation of New York City.

If the three distinguished educators whose letter is published in your issue of Dec. 6 are regular readers of THE TIMES they should be aware of facts which contradict many of their statements. Their recognition of the fact that the Arabs are "deserving of friendship and aid from all Americans" is welcome: aid is futile, however, and friendship is mockery if simple justice is denied.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission choked off a threatened competition in bus fares between Boston and New York City today when it suspended for seven months the tariffs of Trailways of New England, Inc., and of the New England Greyhound Lines.

Persons who termed themselves "more fortunate" took the opportunity yesterday to make Christmas a happier time for those described in the forty-first annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

WESTPORT, Conn., Dec. 11 -- The Fairfield County Chapter, National Council of Arts, Sciences and Professions, has been refused rental of a room in the Young Men's Christian Association building here for a meeting tomorrow night. Officials of the Y. M. C. A. canceled the reservation for the room, which was engaged for the purpose of hearing a talk by I. F. Stone, former columnist of the now defunct New York Compass.

A $5,000,000 issue of 5 per cent convertible subordinated debentures and 250,000 shares of common stock of Standard Coil Products, Inc., is being offered today by F. Eberstadt Co., Inc., and associates. The company manufactures electronic devices.

Asserting that the city was rapidly heading toward financial disaster, Walter Hoving, president of Bonwit Teller, said yesterday that this situation was due to corruption and inefficiency in the administration of former Mayor William O'Dwyer and to the "complete incapacity" of Mayor Impellitteri.

Rain swept throughout the East yesterday washing away hopes skiers entertained of getting in early running on slopes and trails this week-end. Since mid-November and until the torrential downpour and mild weather had arrived, a fair amount of skiing had been available.

The ninety-one members of the Eastern College Athletic Conference today will weigh recommendations banning out-of-season practice and defining the length of seasons, number of contests and sizes of squads in all sports.

MONTREAL, Dec. 11 (AP) -- Capt. Adan Graetz, master of the Israeli freighter Abraham Graetz, said tonight reports that he threatened to scuttle his ship unless his father was appointed Israeli Communications Minister were "a complete fabrication and unfounded rumors." But he said he would not look into their origin.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- The Canadian Government officially urged the Federal Power Commission today to permit an early start on developing the hydrolectric power generating potential of the International Rapids section of the St. Lawrence River.

THERE are those who insist that consistent success draws most of the challenge and zest from a sport, but few wildfowlers run any risk of losing interest in their activity as a result of this factor, as we can testify after Wednesday's sortie on Long Island Sound.

New York's second city-wide civil defense exercise will begin tomorrow morning when sirens sound the "red alert" about 8:30 A. M. The rising and falling three-minute signal will also be broadcast by radio and television.

Children are taught many useful things in school, but one thing they are not taught is the art of waiting. Knowing that the child will need to read and write as he makes his way through the world, the school teaches him reading and writing.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (AP) -- Attorney General James P. McGranery notified President Truman today that steps would be taken to recover about $10,000,000 from the United States Lines Company in proceedings growing out of the superliner United States.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- Marion B. Folsom of Rochester, N. Y., chairman of the Committee for Economic Development, will be Under Secretary of the Treasury in the Eisenhower Administration, according to reliable information obtained here today.

The Columbia Broadcasting System has decided not to resume the Ken Murray television show on Tuesdays from 8 to 9 P. M., although another program must be found to fill the time period, beginning Dec. 30.

Trading on the New York Cotton Exchange was active again yesterday, and after opening 17 lower to 1 point higher rose and closed virtually at or near the best levels of the day 13 to 55 points net higher.

A joint survey of forest resources by Canada and the United States to improve conservation and use on a continental rather than national basis was urged yesterday by R. M. Fowler, president of the Canadian Pulp and Paper Association.

HARRISON, N. Y., Dec. 11 -- A petition by twelve leading citizens asking that the State Commissioner of Education order the Harrison Board of Education to rescind its loyalty oath regulation was served tonight on Joseph A. Vassallo, board president.

Dr. William Jansen, Superintendent of Schools, said yesterday that he intended to nominate Miss Florence S. Beaumont, an assistant superintendent, to be associate superintendent in charge of the elementary school division.

CINCINNATI, Dec. 11 -- Dr. Ira H. Lockwood of Kansas City entered upon his duties as new president of the Radiological Society of North America at a dinner at the annual convention here tonight. He succeeds Dr. Joseph C. Bell of Louisville, Ky., who is a past president also of the Kentucky State Radiological Society.
TRENTON, Dec. 11 -- A proposed 2 per cent sales tax to finance state aid to schools was strongly opposed today by Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll.

Senator Estes Kefauver called last night for a reorganization of the Democratic party to bring in young people and women, hold frequent caucuses, give it more strength as the nation's liberal party and make it more effective in its new minority role.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (UP) -- The Department of Commerce said today there are several "elements of inconsistency and inequality" in newsprint transportation costs.

CINCINNATI, Dec. 11 -- Described as one of the most exhaustive "on-the-spot" social agency surveys ever conducted in this country, a 269-page report entitled. "The Cincinnati Report -- 1952," was made public here today by the Council of Social Agencies of Cincinnati and Hamilton County.

Kidder, Peabody Co. and White, Weld Co. and associates offered a new issue yesterday, subject to Interstate Commerce Commission's approval, of $15,000,000 Southern Railway Company -- New Orleans and Northeastern Railroad Company joint 3 3/4 per cent bonds, due Nov. 1, 1977.

ABOARD THE U.S.S. HELENA, Dec. 11 (AP) -- An authoritative source disclosed today that Attorney General-designate Herbert Brownell had completed plans for a great housecleaning in the Department of Justice.

LONDON, Friday, Dec. 12 -- Viscount Kemsley's newspaper chain, the largest in Britain, announced today that it had sold its London morning tabloid, The Daily Graphic, to Associated Newspapers. Associated, the chain headed by Viscount Rothermere that publishes The Daily Mail here.

George Szell gave his first concert as guest conductor with the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra last night in Carnegie Hall with a program exclusively of Beethoven. The evening was an unmitigated triumph for all concerned -- for the conductor, for the orchestra and for Rudolf Firkusny, who as soloist of the occasion gave a masterly performance of the Third piano concerto. Finally it was another and sovereign triumph for Beethoven.

Neither President Truman nor General MacArthur gains stature because of their contributions during the past week to the question of Korea. General MacArthur chose a meeting of the National Association of Manufacturers to express the belief that "there is a clear and definite solution to the Korean problem."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (AP) -- The Armed Services announced today a uniform system of censorship regulations to take effect in Korea shortly and apply whenever or wherever United States forces become involved in a declared or undeclared war.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 11 -- The federation of autonomous Eritrea with Ethiopia, an accomplished fact since Sept. 15, was hailed in the United Nations Special Political Committee today by the delegates of Ethiopia, the United Kingdom and the United States and by Italy's permanent observer, Ambassador Gastone Guidotti.

SAMUEL ADRIAN BAUGH, the cattle rancher from Texas, will throw his last forward pass for the Redskins in Washington on Sunday. It will be a new National Football League record because Slingin' Sammy automatically sets a new mark every time he slings the ball. The wiry Texan with the whiplash arm was the best passer of them all. This isn't merely an opinion. The record book proves it.
City civil defense officials showed state and foreign experts yesterday how they could effectively cope "on paper" with the aftermath of an atomic bomb attack.

In a continuing drive to counteract vandalism in the city's parks, the Park Association of New York City, Inc., the sponsor of a measure that would levy fines of $25 on parents of children who willfully destroy such property, renewed its efforts yesterday for early passage of the bill.

PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 11 (AP) -- The Pacific Coast Conference today voted to invite the Big Ten Conference to renew their Rose Bowl football pact for three years when the present contract expires on Jan. 1, 1954.

W. Randolph Burgess, chairman of the executive committee of The National City Bank of New York, will leave that post shortly to become a special assistant to the Secretary of the Treasury in the new Administration. The 63-year-old executive of the country's second largest bank, it is understood, will serve in a consultative capacity on Federal debt management problems.

TOKYO, Dec. 11 (AP) -- The United States Embassy said today that if it was proved that Wataru Kaji, Japanese leftist writer, had been mistreated by American personnel "no effort will be spared to mete out justice to the responsible persons."

A total of 1,058 pints of blood was collected by the Red Cross Wednesday at its three centers and through four mobile units. The day's best collection was made at Brooklyn College, Bedford Avenue and Avenue H, Brooklyn, where students and faculty members contributed 315 pints.

The first New York resort collection of Pierre Balmain was presented yesterday by De Pinna in the Terrace Room of the Plaza Hotel. It was highlighted by the designer's current signature, the Brittany stole, which was shown over ensembles for day, afternoon and evening.

ATLANTA, Dec. 11 -- Paul A. Walker, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, told a southern regional conference on educational television today that only by building their own stations could educators expect to control educational television in their communities.

CHICAGO, Dec. 11 (UP) --Al Weill, manager of heavyweight champion Rocky Marciano, conferred with Jim Norris, president, and Truman Gibson, secretary of the International Boxing Club, today about the site and date of the title re-match with Jersey Joe Walcott.

" Holding the Stirrup, The Memoirs of Baroness Elisabeth von Guttenberg," as told to Sheridan Spearman, will be issued Jan. 8 by Duell, Sloan Pearce-Little, Brown. The author, a Bavarian noblewoman, describes a way of life that was changed by World War I and destroyed by Hitler. Her story tells the nobility's part in the abortive plot to assassinate Hitler in which her cousin, Claus Stauffenberg, and many friends lost their lives.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- The names of "seven or eight" replacements for industry members who walked off the Administration's Wage Stabilization Board were turned over to the White House today by Roger L. Putnam, head of the Economic Stabilization Agency.

Mayor Impellitteri will certify to the 1953 Legislature with the approval of the Board of Estimate the city's need for at least $125,000,000 to $130,000,000 more revenue in 1953-54 than the $1,469,265,101 appropriated in the record budget for the current fiscal year.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 11 (AP) -- Unaffected by gusty winds that raked the Miami Springs Municipal Golf Course, Doug Ford, 30-year-old Harrison, N. Y., professional, fired a three-under-par 67 today to gain the first-round lead in the $10,000 Miami open tournament.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 11 (UP) -- Two Australian Davis Cup team members, Frank Sedgman and Ken McGregor, will receive proposals to join an American professional tennis troupe if they come out on top in the matches later this month.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- Anthony Eden, British Foreign Secretary, has sent a note to the State Department refusing to concede the sole right of the United States Government to subpoena certain documents sought from the Anglo-Iranian Oil Company in a grand jury investigation, which will be resumed here tomorrow.

The article carried in your issue of Nov. 27 of the reports made at the National Child Labor Committee conference and your editorial on illegal child labor contained in the Nov. 28 issue are greatly appreciated by those of us who are engaged in the serious effort of eliminating or at least reducing illegal child labor in this country to a very minimum.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 11 -- With only one more speaker to be heard, the Asian-Arab bloc succeeded tonight in adjourning the day's meeting of the Political and Security Committee of the General Assembly. As a result the committee postponed until tomorrow a vote on the bloc's proposal that the Assembly set up a three-nation good offices committee to "expedite" negotiations between France and "the true representatives of the Tunisian people."

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Dec. 11 (AP) -- Dr. Selman Waksman, 1952 Nobel Prize winner in medicine, got five red carnations from a little girl -- one flower for each year she had lived -- as a result of his codiscovery of streptomycin.

Regulation of the railroads by Federal and state commissions was sharply criticized last night in messages from the heads of four companies read to the New York Railroad Club at its eightieth anniversary dinner at the Commodore Hotel.

CHICAGO, Dec. 11 (UP) -- The Montreal Canadiens knocked the Chicago Black Hawks out of a first-place tie in the National Hockey League, winning a 3-to-2 decision before 7,640 in the Chicago Stadium on three first-period goals.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (AP) -- President Truman today accepted, "effective immediately" the resignation of James G. Mackey as United States Attorney for the Territory of Guam. It was submitted by Mr. Mackey to be effective Jan. 20.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (AP) -- The Congress of Industrial Organizations tonight seized on a labor union dispute involving the American Locomotive Company as the means of trying for a quick Supreme Court test of the Taft-Hartley Act's entire national emergency provisions.

Carmine G. DeSapio, leader of Tammany Hall, announced yesterday that New York County Democrats, at the legislative session opening in Albany in January, would press for a series of electoral reforms and fight any attempt to raise fares on the city transit system.
The defense contention that widespread condemnation of communism made it impossible for an accused Communist to receive a fair trial here was rejected yesterday by Federal Judge Edward J. Dimock.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- A study of the effects of cuts by Congress in the amounts of funds asked by the Veterans Administration for administration, medical, hospital and domiciliary services will figure in the economy drive that is scheduled to set off Republican control of the incoming Congress.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Dec. 11 -- A symposium conducted today at the University of Notre Dame by scholars of Russian affairs from Harvard, Yale, Fordham and Notre Dame universities presented a searching analysis of Russian behavior in world affairs.
BOWIE, Md., Dec. 11 (UP) -- Willie Lester boosted his victory total to nine in three days when he won two races at Bowie today, including the $5,000 Leonardtown Purse.
