KANSAS CITY, Kan., Dec. 11 -- The most Rev. Edward J. Hunkeler, a son of Swiss immigrants, today became the first Roman Catholic Archbishop of Kansas.

The problems of European defense are due for a new survey at two important meetings in Paris. One, beginning today, is a meeting of the European Marshall Plan Council, which is to pass on economic plans designed to cope with Europe's continued "dollar shortage" and to provide the economic basis for further rearmament.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 11 (AP) -- The industry members of the Third Regional Wage Stabilization Board today voted unanimously to remain on their jobs here.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- During the week ended Dec. 10, member bank reserves decreased $71,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
A large credit extended to petroleum interests accounted for approximately two-thirds of the expansion in New York bank loans to business last week.

CIDADE DE GOA, Portuguese India, Dec. 11 -- Whatever movement exists here to merge this 442-year-old Portuguese colony with the Indian Republic seems to lack the vitality that freed India from British rule.

J. L. Van Volkenburg, president of the Columbia Broadcasting System Television Network, urged advertisers yesterday not to finance television at the expense of other media. American business, he said, can support television as well as other media by taking a closer look at the country's investment in advertising as a whole and at the peculiar and unique nature of television itself.

An article appeared in THE NEW YORK TIMES Nov. 30 on the subject of Social Security for clergymen. It anticipated and called attention to the annual convention of church pension boards. The arguments against participation by clergymen were indicated. But there was no clear reference to the broad and growing sentiment of ministers in favor of inclusion, nor to the strong arguments in support of this position.

A regular subscription performance of "Carmen" at the Metropolitan Opera House last night had a paying audience of about 70,000. In addition to the more than 3,000 persons in the Opera House, there were audiences in thirty-one movie houses in twenty-seven cities across the land watching the show, which was being televised on large theatre screens via a closed circuit.

Arch Ward, sports editor of The Chicago Tribune, said last night that in spite of televising the Golden Gloves bouts and the All-Star football game in Chicago "we have had the largest gate receipts in our history," The Associated Press reported.

LONDON, Dec 11 -- Persistent reports that Anglo-Iranian Oil Company soon would offer a large debenture issue diverted funds from British Government securities on the stock markets today. Subsequently gilt-edged issues drifted lower.

William Thon, whose oils and water-colors are at the Midtown Gallery, is a landscapist. Roughly, he has one principal subject, the Maine countryside, and in this he chooses as his favorite theme an abandoned quarry. On it he performs a number of variations, more and less abstract, which are characterized by paint texture of enormous refinement.

Sufficient buying developed on the stock market yesterday to offset tax selling, enabling prices to remain on an even keel. The market was obviously still operating on a cautious basis, traders preferring to take the line of least resistance until investors' intentions become more pronounced.

NEWARK, Dec. 11 -- The three leading soap producers in the nation and a trade association which they allegedly control were named defendants in a civil anti-trust suit filed today in Federal Court here by the Government charging restraining and monopolizing the manufacture and sale of soap and synthetic detergents for household use.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 11 -- Senator Alexander Wiley, a leading Republican foreign affairs spokesman, warned today that the new Congress would block United States funds for the United Nations unless there were security guarantees against "espionage and subversion" in the world organization.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, Dec. 11 -- International traders familiar ith the devious channels through which Communists procure needed goods from the West report strenuous efforts are being made to buy at least 1,000,000 vials of penicillin, preferably American, for Communist China.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- A resolution urging immediate establishment of a central authority to allocate the limited supply of gamma globulin, the blood fraction newly coming into use as a poliomyelitis preventive, was adopted today at the annual meeting of State and Territorial Health Officers.
HONOLULU, Dec. 11 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the President-elect, looking fit and slightly sunburned, stepped ashore here today from the cruiser Helena to receive the plaudits of ...

The fourth new work on the schedule of the Slavenska-Franklin Ballet at the Century Theatre had its local premiere last night. It is "Portrait of a Ballerina," choreographed by Mia Slavenska to the Dohnanyi "Nursery Rhyme Variations," and the only piece in the repertoire that boasts the presence of all three of the company's stars -- Miss Slavenska, Alexandra Danilova and Frederic Franklin -- in its cast.

LONDON, Dec. 11 (AP) -- Jack Solomons, British promoter, kept the middleweight controversy going today by declaring that Sugar Ray Robinson had "definitely agreed" to defend his world middleweight crown against Randy Turpin on June 9 in either London or Dublin.

Jerry Finkelstein, political confidant of former Mayor William O'Dwyer, was an eyewitness at the Gracie Mansion meeting in October, 1949, when John P. Crane, then president of the Uniformed Firemen's Association, turned over to Mr. O'Dwyer an envelope containing $10,000, it was alleged yesterday in an affidavit filed in General Sessions.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- President Truman asserted today that if Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower and Gen. Douglas MacArthur had an immediately practicable plan to hasten the end of the Korean war, they should bring it forward now. But he disparaged the sincerity of their motives.
TOKYO, Friday, Dec. 12 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,461, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Friday, Korea time:

LONDON, Dec. 11 -- The long debated relationship between smoking and cancer of the lung has been thoroughly investigated again by Dr. Richard Doll and Prof. A. Bradford Hill, who have concluded that "the association is real." The arguments of the researchers fill fifteen pages of the current issue of the British Medical Journal.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- Following is an unofficial transcript of President Truman's press conference comments on the Korean war. The President's replies to questions have been paraphrased in accordance with a White House rule that the President may not be quoted directly without his express permission:

PARIS, Dec. 11 -- The United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization ended its seventh general conference today by adopting a program of activities for the next two years within the limit of the $18,000,000 budget that the delegates had previously approved.

Chuck beef steak and leg of lamb as well as several other popular cuts of meat are cheaper this week-end. The retail price of leg of lamb is the lowest it has been in two years. Liberal supplies of beef and extra large receipts of lamb and pork raised the total arrivals of meat for the week to about 36,000,000 pounds.

Bud Abbott and Lou Costello never have had serious rivals as two of the unfunnier gentlemen in the entertainment world. Their title is more secure than ever after the opening of their new film series at 10:30 P. M. on Fridays over C. B. S. television.

ATLANTIC CITY, Dec. 11 -- New and improved products designed for the safety and convenience of American motorists highlight the displays at the 1952 Automobile Service Industries Show now under way here at Convention Hall.

Trading in commodity futures continued dull yesterday with prices generally down on the New York exchanges. Cocoa, sugar, coffee, potatoes, rubber, soybean and cottonseed oil closed lower. Lead and zinc were higher and hides and wool closed mixed.

A statement that decreased use of natural rubber is likely in this country as a result of recent price increases of 20 to 25 per cent was made yesterday by John L. Collyer, president of the B. F. Goodrich Company.

We commend the current drive of the Police Department to bring to book bus drivers who "run the lights" at intersections. It did not require the fatal accident in Times Square last winter to prove how perilous a practice this is. Bus drivers are by no means the sole culprits in this respect.
ALBANY, Dec. 11 (AP) -- A total of 1,468 persons died as a result of motor vehicle accidents in New York State during the first nine months of this year.

Today's new film is "The Raiders," a frontier drama of early California, filmed in Technicolor by Universal-International and starring Richard Conte and Viveca Lindfors, at the Palace. Lesley Selander directed and William Alland produced from a screen play by Polly James and Lillie Hayward and a story by Lyn Crost Kennedy.

In the ultimate welfare state where complete care -- not to mention complete supervision -- is provided for each citizen from the cradle to the grave, there would be no need for anything like The Hundred Neediest Cases. In this super-state the individual in need of special aid would be dropped into the hopper of the state machinery.

TULSA, Okla., Dec. 11 (AP) -- Ruling that a newspaper has the right to refuse to publish any item, District Judge Elmer Adams yesterday dismissed an Oklahoma county judge's $10,000 suit against The Tulsa Daily World because it did not print his letter to the editor.

LONDON, Dec. 11 -- A comprehensive long-term plan for the progressive removal of import restrictions in the sterling area and the progressive restoration of free exchange between the pound and other currencies was agreed upon at the British Commonwealth Prime Ministers' conference, which concluded its work in London today.
BOSTON, Dec. 11 (UP) -- Detroit routed road-weary Boston tonight. 10 -- 1, in a National Hockey League game played before 8,147 Boston Garden fans.

HANOI, Vietnam, Indo-China, Dec. 11 (AP) -- The French High Command said tonight there was "steadily increasing pressure" from Communist-led Vietminh forces in the Red River delta, already riddled by infiltration and hit-and-run attacks.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- An investigating subcommittee of the House of Representative reported today on how a civilian renter of Navy facilities that were needed by other Federal agencies was enabled to lease back to the Government less than one-half of his acquired space at a profit estimated at nearly $10.00 a year.

Lieut. Gen. Willis D. Crittenberger, Commanding General of the First Army, will be the guest of the senior officers of the National Guard and the Organized Reserve of the First Army at a dinner tonight at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. The First Army area includes New England, New York and New Jersey.

MADRID, Dec. 11 -- Rear Admiral Edward William Clexton, Director of the Office of Budgets and Reports of the United States Navy, arrived in Madrid today by plane for what was understood to be a thorough briefing by the United States special military mission here of what it will cost the United States Navy to equip Spanish naval bases for use by the Navy under terms of the military agreements with the Spanish Government.

NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 11 -- A comprehensive social reform bill seeking radically to alter the 2,500-year-old marriage, divorce and inheritance laws of 280,000,000 Hindus and giving women equal rights to property was introduced today in the Council of the States or upper house of Parliament by Law Minister C. Biswas.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (UP) -- George Meany, president of the American Federation of Labor, said today he considered a merger of the Federation and the Congress of Industrial Organizations a "necessity" but that the "odds are not in favor" of such action.

The city's new court for alcoholics on Pakers Island opened yesterday afternoon with Chief Magistrate John M. Murtagh meting out to denizens of the streets -- some of whom were appearing in court for close to their hundredth time -- sentences that caused them to gasp "Wow!"

Cecil Johnson, 25-year-old ex-convict and gunman, was arraigned yesterday in Felony Court before Magistrate John R. Starkey and held without bail for hearing next Wednesday on charges of felonious assault and violation of the Sullivan Law.
The nation's life insurance industry has made "tremendous direct contributions" toward improving the economic and physical health of the American public.

Mayor John V. Kenny of Jersey City turned down yesterday a written invitation from the New York State Crime Commission to testify next Wednesday at a public hearing on local waterfront conditions. The invitation was presented to the Mayor in his office by two Crime Commission investigators. His answer was immediate and blunt:
LONDON, Dec. 11 -- Paul H. Nitze, director of the State Department's Policy Planning Staff, arrived in London today for talks with Foreign Office officials.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 11 (AP) -- Tropical Park's racing stewards blasted Tony DeSpirito's hopes for a new American winning record today by suspending the nation's leading jockey for ten days, and will decide tomorrow whether to extend the suspension for another faulty ride in today's sixth race.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 11 -- Over Arab protests, a majority of United Nations members approved today a Palestine proposal asking for direct Arab-Israeli negotiations to settle their lingering quarrels over Arab refugees, compensation claims and boundary adjustments.
WINNIPEG, Dec. 11 (Canadian Press) -- William Johnston Keswick has been appointed governor of the Hudson's Bay Company, succeeding Sir Patrick Ashley Cooper, it was announced here and in London.

BOMBAY, India, Dec. 11 (AP) -- Oscar R. Ewing, United States Federal Security Administrator, said today that "a common concern for children can become a compelling force for world understanding and peace."

Charles G. Johnson, California state treasurer, has announced that $100,000,000 of California veterans' farm and home bonds will be marketed on Feb. 3. The issue is part of the $150,000,000 of bonds authorized in the November election.

SYRACUSE, Dec. 11 -- Attorneys for property owners along the south shore of Lake Ontario with claims for high-water damage are preparing to file a default judgment against the Dominion of Canada in the Northern District of the Federal Court in the test case brought by Arthur and Dorothy Oster of Rochester.
Johnny Saxton, unbeaten welterweight from Brooklyn, will appear in the main bout in Madison Square Garden tonight. His opponent will be Raul Perez of Matanzas, Cuba.

The Jewish Feast of Lights or Hanukkah, will begin at sundown today. It will continue eight days, with a candle being lit daily in an eight-branched candlestick in homes, synagogues and other Jewish institutions, in memory of the eight days required to rededicate the Temple of Jerusalem after its desecration in the second century B. C., by idolatrous worship under the Syrian-Greek King Antiochus.

YONKERS, Dec. 11 -- Dagsworthy Lola, the homeless mare of Yonkers Raceway, was back in Delaware today, munching oats in her owner's barn after an experience that shouldn't happen to a dog, let alone a pacing horse.

SEATTLE, Dec. 11 -- The American Farm Bureau Federation reaffirmed today its opposition to high, rigid farm price supports and called for a flexible price system that it had been unable to attain under Democratic Administrations.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 11 -- The Norwegian motorship Fernstream, outbound for Manila, Hong Kong and Yokohama, was in collision with the freighter Hawaiian Rancher of the Matson Line in a heavy fog today and sank in about a half hour in 240 feet of water in san Francisco Bay.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Dec. 11 (UP) -- The National Collegiate Athletic Association announced today that a ten-point program to strengthen the enforcement machinery of the N. C. A. A. and its member conferences had been sent to 406 member colleges.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- Federal Trade Commissioner Stephen J. Spingarn told the Bureau of Education in Fair Trade today that its efforts to stimulate Congressional pressure on the agency showed "a contempt for democratic government and processes which, carried far enough, could end only in their destruction."

CHICAGO, Dec. 11 (AP) -- The Journal of the American Medical Association today called for an all-out effort -- including a redesigned boxing glove -- to cut "the high incidence of deaths and injuries" in the ring. It urged research and renewed action all along the line to protect professional fighters in their careers.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 11 -- The General Assembly's Economic and Financial Committee approved today a proposal pushed by Bolivia and Iran intended to promote the nationalization of resource industries in less developed countries. The majority prevented the United States and other defenders of the rights of private investors from expressing their views, and rejected any reference to such rights.

DENVER, Dec. 11 (AP) -- Following are excerpts from the text of a speech recorded by John Foster Dulles, incoming Secretary of State, presented at the General Assembly of the National Council of Churches of Christ in the U. S. A.:

While the process of refueling aircraft in flight was termed safe enough for commercial operation, an airline official said yesterday that the scheduled air carriers could not use the system on an economical basis today.

PARIS, Dec. 11 -- The basic military blueprint of the fourteen-nation North Atlantic Treaty Organization, which is known as the Strategic Guidance Directive and has been recently revised, presupposes that in any future war German military forces will be fighting beside those of Atlantic pact nations, it was officially disclosed here today.

MOUNT VERNON, N. Y., Dec. 11 -- A Bronze plaque has been received by historic St. Paul's Protestant Episcopal Church, Eastchester, Mount Vernon, national shrine of the Bill of Rights and the freedom of the press, from the Department of the Interior.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 11 -- Michael J. Quill's Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., defied today an impartial chairman's order to scrap its plan to give free rides to 3,500,000 New York bus passengers during the Christmas shopping rush.

BRISBANE, Australia, Dec. 11 (AP) -- The surprising Indian Davis Cup tennis team gained a chance of upsetting Italy and qualifying to meet the United States in the interzone final after dividing the opening two singles matches.
DETROIT, Dec. 11 -- Henry Ford 2d, president of the Ford Motor Company, issued the following statement this evening:

James A. Farley, former Democratic national and state chairman, made public without comment yesterday a telegram he had received from Stephen A. Mitchell, the present Democratic national chairman, congratulating him on his loyalty to the Democratic party, apparently as an answer to a charge that he had failed to support a Democratic candidate for state office in the last ten years.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- The Supreme Court heard final arguments today on the constitutionality of racial segregation in the public schools and took five cases involving the issue under advisement.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 11 (AP) -- Fred Haney, who won two Pacific Coast League pennants in four years as skipper of the Hollywood Stars, took on the biggest managerial headache of his baseball career today, that of pulling the luckless Pirates out of the National League cellar.

What is said to be the world's slimmest hearing aid, slightly larger than a box of safety matches, about as thin as a package of chewing gum, using vacuum tubes no thicker than a lead pencil and weighing about the same as a pack of cigarettes and a lighter, has been developed by the Sonotone Corporation.

The Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., the world's largest operating electric and gas utility, put its best foot forward yesterday for some 150 public utility analysts. Harland C. Forbes, executive vice president of the utility system, discussing the recent order of the New York State Public Service Commission, said that while some rates went down others were increased.

" Nominate able, conscientious and competent people for public office." That was the reply of Richard H. Balch, newly elected chairman of the Democratic State Committee, when he was asked if he had any formula for insuring Democratic success in New York State in the future.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- The State Department announced today that six of the important European shipping countries had protested or sought information about the imminent immigration restrictions of crews of foreign vessels.

In his first speech written since he was designated as the next Secretary of State John Foster Dulles outlined last evening some of the basic principles that will guide his conduct of foreign policy. Since the speech was written for a special audience and before Mr. Dulles has assumed office, the statement was necessarily general in its approach; nevertheless, it is significant both in its tenor and in its substance.

TOKYO, Friday, Dec. 12 -- South Korean troops this morning launched furious counter-attacks at "Little Nori" hill on the Western Korean front, seized yesterday by Chinese Communists in the heaviest fighting for a month.

FRANKFURT, Germany, Dec. 11 (AP) -- The highest United States judge in Germany issued "an open and emphatic protest against the continued confinement" of an American citizen today and demanded his immediate release on bail.

A thousand wild goats of Nigeria, an estimated $1,250,000 in money and a decade in time contributed to the production of a British book that is to be exhibited here today for the first time publicly in America. Titled "The Royal Philatelic Collection," it lists the 250,000 stamps that Britain's King George V began assembling when he was a midshipman in Indian waters.

In an eloquent statement written for the House committee investigating whether tax-exempt foundations are supporting "subversive" activities, Henry Alien Moe of the Guggenheim Foundation set down a few things that we hope the committee will read and take to heart.

Raymond A. Norden, president of Seaboard and Western Airlines, Inc., told the New York Society of Security Analysts at luncheon yesterday that, despite the negative attitude of the Civil Aeronautics Board and the failure of the certificated passenger airlines to develop the business, air freight across the Atlantic would amount to 160,000,000 tons in 1955.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- Ambassador Edwin A. Locke Jr. resigned today as overseer of all United States economic and technical assistance to the Near East.

Mayor John V. Kenny of Jersey City, who has refused to testify at public waterfront hearings before the New York State Crime Commission next week, was served yesterday with a subpoena from the New Jersey Law Enforcement Council.

As the number of violations served on Harlem landlords since Oct. 20 soared to 4,566 yesterday in the drive of housing inspectors against firetrap tenements, Frederick S. Weaver, Deputy Commissioner of Housing, announced that he was seeking authority to take on forty-five more inspectors to "keep up the pace" of the campaign.
The 579 air raid sirens in the city will sound a "red alert" about 8:30 A. M. today to begin the biggest civil defense training exercise in the city's history.

Federal Trade Commissioner Stephen J Spingarn challenged the oil industry yesterday to present specific complaints against the commission to the incoming Republican Administration. At a press meeting in the United States Court House, Foley Square, he asked that the present staff of the commission be permitted to defend themselves if this is done.

PARIS, Dec. 12 -- "To establish a common front in Europe against ill health" was the phrase the French Foreign Minister, Robert Schuman, used to describe the purpose of the "white pool" conference which he opened today in the salons of the French Foreign Ministry.
When we talk about price controls we should be clear in our minds whether we are talking about the facts of the situation or about political policymaking.

MINNEAPOLIS, Dec. 12 (AP) -- The transportation and communication committee of the United States Chamber of Commerce was told today that a major portion of the nation "cannot be calm about fighting for its economic life."

November sales of leading mail order and chain store companies showed an increase of 2.4 per cent over the volume for the same month of last year, according to a compilation of forty-two companies made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

The Rex. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman, minister of Christ Church (Methodist), Park Avenue and Sixtieth Street, will leave by Swissair tomorrow afternoon for Lucknow, India, where he will attend a meeting of the Central Committee of the World Council of Churches.

The first attempt at presenting a stage production by television to paying audiences in movie houses across the country, when "Carmen" was sent out Thursday night from the Metropolitan Opera to twenty-seven cities on a closed circuit, was pronounced yesterday successful enough to justify planning for the transmission of further performances.

The city's plans for the proposed $40,000,000 development at Columbus Circle, including housing and an 18,000-seat coliseum, and for slum clearance projects in the Fort Greene section of Brooklyn and the Morningside-Manhattanville area of Manhattan were approved yesterday by the City Planning Commission.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- Hope of some day alleviating the world's critical food shortage through use of Chlorella, a microscopic alga of the sea, was held out today in the annual report of the Carnegie Institution of Washington.

HONG KONG, Dec. 12 -- Preparations in Peiping for the advent of Communist China's first five-year plan are being accompanied by a flood of posters, books, pamphlets and newspaper dispatches designed to make the process of industrialization come alive for the average Chinese.

NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 12 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru told the House of the People (lower house of Parliament) today, that numerous Hindu extremist organizations in India had joined hands with their counterparts in Kashmir and had made Jammu Province a "base of operations" for carrying on a "subversive movement" against Sheikh Mohammed Abdullah's administration.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- A coat hanger designed to foil shoplifters and restaurant coat thieves is among the 854 inventions patented this week. It sounds a loud alarm in protest against the removal of a garment. The inventor, Juby E. Towler of Danville, Va., expects it to be especially useful in guarding expensive fur coats.

Two men who were graduated from the Police Academy on Wednesday didn't have to wait long to find out what the life of a policeman is like. They got a good example in the first hour of their first tour of duty in the Bronx early yesterday morning.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- Wanted: 67 boys, aged 14 through 17, able to get up early in the morning and having a liking for politicians -- Republicans Politicians.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- Seatrain Lines, Inc., put to the Interstate Commerce Commission today a question about I. C. C. power to deal with a claim of damages against some railroads. The Federal District Court at Trenton, N. J., has told Seatrain that the claim should be adjudicated by the I. C. C.

In the hurly-burly attendant on the State Crime Commission's disclosures of racketeering on the waterfront no mention has appeared of a simple, direct and effective method of dealing with financial exactions by union representatives and payment by employers. Under the Taft-Hartley Act the Department of Justice can proceed against any representative of employes who accepts illegal payments from employers and against the employers who make them.

ROME, Dec. 12 -- The civilian heads of four countries, acting on behalf of Pope Pius XII, will place the red biretta on the heads of six Cardinal-designates, including four Papal Nuncios, in January, the Vatican announced today.

TAIPEI, Formosa, Dec. 11 -- President Syngman Rhee of South Korea recommended to Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, during the President-elect's recent visit, the unleashing of Nationalist Chinese forces to open a second front on the Chinese mainland as the "only solution" to the Korean war, it was revealed by the South Korean Ambassador to Nationalist China today.

Dr. William Jansen's announcement at a meeting of the Public Education Association that he intended to nominate Miss Florence S. Beaumont as associate superintendent of schools is highly welcome. The elementary division of the public school system, responsible for the education of more than half a million of our city's children, has been without an officially designated head since Sept. 1, when Miss Regina Burke retired.

Carnegie Recital Hall last night was the scene of a concert given by a chamber orchestra under the direction of Roland Fiore. An interesting program was played, including the first local performances of a Rameau aria Sammatini's Symphony in C (in a Torrefranca transcription) and Tibor Serly's Three Songs from Joyce's "Chamber Music."

The State Crime Commission, which will resume public hearings Monday on waterfront evils, is seeking additional funds to complete its investigation and write a report that will include recommendations for action by the New York and New Jersey Legislatures and by municipal administrations in this port area, it became known yesterday.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec 12 -- Senator Robert Avajon, a native of Togoland speaking for France in the General Assembly's Trusteeship Committee, criticized today the United Nations Secretariat for assigning a man to a visiting mission to his country last summer who, he said, had failed "to adopt the absolutely neutral attitude" required under the circumstances.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (AP) -- Fears that rural electric cooperatives might not receive full benefits if New York State joined with Canada in developing the St. Lawrence River power project were expressed today at a Federal Power Commission hearing.

BONN, Germany, Dec. 12 -- The political crisis on the ratification of the Bonn treaty system entered a new phase today when the Social Democratic party announced it would move a vote of censure against Chancellor Konrad Adenauer and his Government in the Bundestag.

A group of individuals and organizations seeking to improve safety conditions in the home and on the highway met the other day, with the headline going to a member of this city's Fire Department. The kitchen is the most dangerous room in the house, he said clearly, mentioning the prevalence there of gas stoves and gas refrigerators with constant flame.

NORMAN, Okla., Dec. 12 (UP) -- Walter Kraft, the University of Oklahoma's faculty representative in the Big Seven conference, confirmed tonight that Oklahoma was investigating possible membership in the Southwest Conference.

VIENNA, Dec. 12 -- The Communist-organized, though ostensibly non-partisan Congress of the Peoples for Peace opened here today with an assortment of well-known names but not with the 5,000 delegates promised in advance notices.

The three constituent bodies of the United Jewish Appeal outlined yesterday budgetary requirements totaling. $144,354,250 for 1953 to meet Jewish needs over the world, with special emphasis on Israel. The appeal opened its fifteenth annual conference at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel before 1,200 delegates, representing every Jewish community in the country.

BUFFALO, N. Y., Dec. 12 (AP) -A jury acquitted two present and two former City Councilmen and a restaurant proprietor today of all charges in Buffalo's third pinball-graft trial. The first acquittal in the series of trials was returned to Justice George H. Rowe of the State Supreme Court after the jury of eleven men and one woman deliberated just and hour and a half.

Officials of the New York Stock Exchange moved yesterday to prepare for the resumption of interest on twelve Japanese bond issues, which will be eligible for payments of 1942 and earlier coupons on Dec. 22. Hitherto all these bonds have been traded "flat."

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Dec. 12 -- Lieut. Col. Sutoko, the Indonesian Army Deputy Chief of Staff, disclosed today that a group of high ranking staff officers, after a meeting Wednesday night, sent a letter to the Government "requesting to know upon what ground" Premier Wilopo's Cabinet removed the Army Chief of Staff, Colonel Nasution and several other high officers from their posts Dec. 5.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 12 -- Paul C. Smith, editor and general manager of The San Francisco Chronicle since 1937, announced his resignation late today by posting a notice on the editorial room's bulletin board addressed "to all hands, all departments."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (UP) -- Counsel for Edward A. Rumely of New York told the Supreme Court today that House investigators had no right to demand the names of persons who purchased books from his client's Committee for Constitutional Government.
The following is a round-up of household hints that may be of interest to homemakers.

ELIZABETH, N. J., Dec. 12 -- Lifetime rights to the income from $99,000 of a $100,000 estate of Walter L. Schnaring and his wife, Helen M. Schnaring, were granted today to Jose Crespo, whom the Schnarings had reared at their home in Summit but who never was legally adopted.

Reflecting larger sales, net income of the ABC Vending Corporation for the forty-three weeks to last Oct. 26 increased to $1,147,552 from $869,650 earned in the corresponding period of the previous year.

One of the heartening results of the Hundred Neediest Cases appeal year after year is the salutary participation by children in helping the less fortunate. While their contributions are often no more than pennies and dimes, it is a good and welcome development.

ATLANTA, Dec. 12 -- Dr. Arthur S. Adams, president of the American Council on Education, said today that educational television was probably the "ideal vehicle" for countering "the planned attacks of those anti-intellectual forces that are looking to the destruction of the educative process as we have known it in this country."

For those who may still have some luxury gifts left on Christmas shopping lists, a beautiful object for the home may be a happy solution and one that is sure in please the heart of a homemaker. Many especially lovely objects from other lands have recently arrived in the shops: Linens from France, glass from Holland, silver from Denmark, china from England.

CLEMSON, S. C., Dec. 12 (AP) -- The Southern Conference grappled with the controversial grants-in- aid question at length today at its annual winter meeting, then referred the matter to a nine-man committee for exhaustive study and a report to the conference at its meeting next spring.

BUFFALO, Dec. 12 (AP) -- A judge today ordered striking members of the C. I. O. Steelworkers union to return immediately to the job of producing atomic energy supplies at the American Locomotive Company's plant in Dunkirk.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- Average primary market prices declined 0.4 per cent in the week ended Dec. 9 to 109.6 per cent of the 1947-49 average, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (AP) -- A record 61,547,861 total vote was cast for President on Nov. 4 when Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower won election by a plurality of 6,616,233.

Dr. Arthur A. Schuck, chief executive of the Boy Scouts of America, received a citation and the George Washington Medal yesterday from the Freedoms Foundation for his work on the "Get Out the Vote" campaign jointly supported this year by the two organizations.
The St. John's basketball team will open its nineteenth season of Madison Square Garden play with its third test of the campaign when the Redmen meet Rhode Island State tonight.

WITH the upland game and waterfowl seasons drawing to a close, except for cottontails which will be legal game for another two months in many areas, the shooting preserves are receiving more attention, and many of these set-ups report more activity than at any time in the past.

A frequent visitor to New York and one familiar with conditions in other major cities can echo the authority on police affairs, Bruce Smith, in the discovery that the "finest" are not that. Based on the slovenly policing of the Times Square area, Commissioner Monaghan's outfit is pressing close for the booby prize.

MEXICO CITY, Dec. 9 -- An angry memorial asking the new Mexican Administration to look into favoritism in the distribution of newly opened farm lands is likely to bring on the long-awaited reevaluation of the entire Mexican land reform program.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- The White House tonight reportedly was selecting nominees for four of the six regular places held by industry members of the Wage Stabilization Board from a list of names supplied by Roger L. Putnam, retiring Economic Stabilizer, and by present members of the board.
A schism among dentists over the question of hypnodontics -- the use of hypnosis as an adjunct in the treatment of frightened patients -- became apparent yesterday.

J. C. Penney Company, nationwide department store organization, announced yesterday that directors authorized a special year-end payment for more than 50,000 workers in its 1,629 stores, offices and warehouses. The payment will be equal to two weeks' pay for all full-time employes with the company for the full year of 1952, and proportionate amounts for extra and part-time workers and those employed less than a year.

PARIS, Dec. 12 -- The Marshall Plan Council, meeting at the ministerial level, adopted today a report urging freer trade between Europe and the United States and the investment of American capital abroad to reduce Europe's dollar shortage.

The football Giants yesterday restored Bob Wilkinson, formerly of U. C. L. A., to the active list and placed Pat Knight, rookie full-back from Southern Methodist, on the reserve roster. The New Yorkers will close their season tomorrow by meeting the Cleveland Browns at the Polo Grounds.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- Whether Senator Styles Bridges of New Hampshire or another -- possibly Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio who lost the Presidential nomination to Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower -- would become the majority floor leader in the Republican-controlled Senate that convenes Jan. 3 remained unsettled today, but it looked as though Mr. Bridges would get the job.

The British Commonwealth conference, which had wrestled for two weeks with the economic and financial problems of the largest trading area in the world, has ended its work with a program designed to restore a better balanced world economy. This program is stated only in the most general terms.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 12 (AP) -- Doug Ford, standing off a great first-place bid by Jack Burke, maintained a one-stroke lead in the $10,000 Miami open golf tournament today with a 36-hole six-under-par score of 131.
Governor Dewey made his first official visit to Governors Island yesterday to bid farewell to Lieut. Gen. Willis D. Crittenberger, First Army commander, who is retiring at the end of this month.

ATHENS, Dec. 12 -- Greece, her ancient glories part of a proud tradition of independence and national pride, is maintaining ten small divisions and modernizing nine air squadrons as her contribution to Europe's defense against communism.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- The Air Force said today that despite temporary setbacks in plane production a 143-wing Air Force would be in operation on schedule by mid-1955 though not all the wings would be fully equipped with the latest aircraft.
HUCKSVILLE, L. I., Dec. 12 -- Charles (Chuckie) Regenie, who would have been 4 years old Dec. 22, drowned today in a drainage ditch in a realty development at Tip Top and Picture Lanes.
TOKYO, Saturday, Dec. 13 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,462, for Friday's operations:
Anna Russell, concert comedienne, returned to Town Hall last evening to give an all-request program of her somewhat sardonic impressions of the musical scene.

With one of the quickest and most emphatic knockouts of his career, Johnny Sexton, Brooklyn's unbeaten contender for the world welterweight title, last night made Raul Perez, frightened Cuban fighter, his thirty-fourth professional ring victim.

A motion for the acquittal of thirteen secondary Communist leaders was filed with Federal Judge Edward J. Dimock yesterday on the ground that, rather than conspiring to teach and advocate the overthrow of the Government by force and violence as charged, they have done no more than exercise their Constitutional rights.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- Judge James R. Kirkland announced in Federal District Court here today that "sensitive" documents bearing on the relationship of foreign countries to an alleged international oil cartel that is being investigated by a grand jury would not be made public unless they were cleared through diplomatic channels.

Today's housewives may not spend as much time in the kitchen as their mothers did but often they are better cooks. The home economist who expressed this opinion was Miss Joan Rock. Her public relations work for the seasoning called monosodium glutamate has enabled her to talk to and exchange recipes with women in all parts of the country.

The Consolidated Vultee Aircraft Corporation declared a special dividend yesterday of one-tenth of a share of San Diego Corporation, a new and wholly-owned subsidiary, for each share of outstanding Convair common stock,payable on Feb. 2.
The news from Stowe, Vt., one of the most comprehensive and diversified ski arcas in North America was good on two counts yesterday.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 12 -- The Asian-Arab group lost its fight today for a United Nations General Assembly resolution that would have called on France to resume negotiations with the "true representatives of the Tunisian people" regarding the independence of the protectorate of Tunisia.

Events today: "Tosca," Metropolitan Opera, 2 P. M. Witold Malcuzynski, pianist, Carnegie Hall, 3; Brooklyn Community Symphony Orchestra, young people's concert, Brooklyn Academy, 3; "Don Carlo," Metropolitan Opera, 8; Philharmonic-Symphony, George Szell conducting, Erica Morini, violinist, Carnegie Hall, 8:45; Brooklyn String Orchestra, Carnegie Recital Hall, 8:30.

Old friends of the Yorkville Branch of the New York Public Library went yesterday to the handsome limestone building at 222 East Seventy-ninth Street not to browse or borrow books, as some have been doing regularly for nearly half a century, but to talk over memories of the early days and eat a piece of birthday cake.

VIENNA, Dec. 12 (AP) -- Prompted by the Kremlin, the "Congress of the Peoples for Peace" is supposed to find ways to end the shooting in Korea, Malaya and Indo-China, terminate the "cold war" and insure the security of nations.
Futures on the New York Cotton Exchange became somewhat irregular yesterday and active months closed 5 points higher to 9 points lower than on Thursday.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 12 -- Four grandmothers and a former inmate of a Japanese concentration camp in Borneo help to make the United Nations telephone and information service what it is: A constant recourse for people who want to know the where, when, why and how, not only of world affairs but of extremely localized matters.

Samuel Blumenthal, a key witness at the first degree murder trial of Benedict Macri, who had been acquitted of the slaying of William Lurye, union organizer, admitted yesterday at the General Sessions trial of George (Muscles) Futterman that he demanded a $5,000 bribe to commit perjury at the Macri trial.

CHICAGO, Dec. 12 -- Long liquidation was again the order of the day in the grain markets but there were indications of support from commission houses on resting orders, which cushioned the selling to some extent. There also was considerable profit-taking by shorts.

Tax selling posed no serous problems on the stock market yesterday and, as a result, prices forged ahead with considerable vigor. A comeback in the railroad issues paved the way for the new advance, as the list shook off the lethargy which marked the three previous sessions.

The New York Stock Exchange has ruled that in order to facilitate settlement of contracts in the closing days of the year, deals on Dec. 26, 29 and 30 may be effected on a "next day" basis, except in United States Government obligations. This will permit 1952 settlements of deals that ordinarily would not be closed within the calendar year.

John L. Connolly of St. Paul, Minn., was reported yesterday to be in line for appointment as Commissioner of Internal Revenue in the new Republican Administration to be headed by Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower.

Thousands of spectators stood in delightful amazement in the streets and buildings surrounding the sunken plaza at Rockefeller Center as the eighty-five-foot Christmas tree was lighted at dusk last evening for the first time.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- Allah-Yar Saleh, the Ambassador of Iran, appealed today for purchases of Iranian oil by American firms, discounting the "legal risks" that might be encountered.

Gen. Jonathan M. Wainwright, the hero of Corregidor, testified yesterday, as a defense witness at the treason trial in Federal Court of John David Provoo, that he had not seen or heard officially of any act of disloyalty by any American prisoner of war while he and Provoo were in the same Japanese prison camp. But he said there were rumors of such acts.

ALBANY, Dec. 12 -- Condemnation of the survey of the New York City Police Department made by the Institute of Public Administration was voted today by the executive committee of the Police Conference of New York State.
Edward D. Rohrbach has been made director of industrial relations for Botany Mills, Inc., of Passaic, N. J., succeeding Maj. Gen. Irving J. Phillipson, who recently resigned.

Lumber production for the week ended Dec. 6 was 8.8 per cent above the comparable week last year according to wires received yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES from regional associations. Shipments were up 19.1 per cent and orders 15.6 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (AP) -- The Government has about $12,000,000 of United States Lines funds it could take over if the courts decide the shipping firm got the Government-built super-liner United States too cheaply, it was disclosed today.

PARIS, Dec. 12 -- The Council of the Republic, advisory upper house of the French Parliament, condemned today what it termed the return of nazism and pan-Germanism in Germany. It asked the Government to do what it could to halt "an evolution disastrous for the future not only of French-German relations but also of the entire free world."

At the annual meeting of the American Public Health Association the dramatic announcement was made that experiments conducted over the past two years in Utah, Texas, Iowa and Nebraska had demonstrated the effectiveness of gamma globulin as a preventive measure for paralytic poliomyelitis.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (AP) -- Following is the 1952 official vote for President as tabulated by The Associated Press from state canvassing board reports. It shows the total vote, Republican, Democratic and "other" vote and percentages of each, by states:

There are only two books issued today. Devin-Adair has at $5 "Grasses and Grassland Farming," by Hi W. Staten, professor of Agronomy at Oklahoma A. M. College. It is a discussion of the role grass plays in feeding livestock. Exposition Press is publishing at $2 "Ski Town: a Children's Story of Life in the Black Hills," by Pauline Stewart Pearson.

Roman Catholic and Protestant church choirs will be heard in Christmas carols during dinner hours next Tuesday through Friday and on Monday and Tuesday, Dec. 22 and 23, at the Savoy-Plaza Hotel, it was announced yesterday.
DETROIT, Dec. 12 (AP) -- Doak Walker, who missed most of the Detroit Lions' campaign will be in the starting backfield for tomorrow's big game with the Dallas Texans.

Another Communist-sponsored "peace congress" opened yesterday in Vienna. Beginning in Wroclaw, Poland, in 1948, previous meetings have been held in New York, Paris, Stockholm, Berlin, Warsaw and Sheffield, England. All are under the auspices of the World Peace Council, which has its headquarters in Prague and claims a membership of 600,000,000 in seventy-two countries -- "the Partisans of Peace."

HONOLULU, Dec. 12 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower spent today resting and holding informal conferences as he prepared to take off by plane at noon tomorrow (5 P. M. Eastern standard time) for California.

BOWIE, Md., Dec. 12 (UP) -- Baby-faced Willie Lester extended his current victory streak at Bowie today when he rode four straight winners, including Mrs. Ethel D. Jacobs' Sweet Naomi in the featured Easton Purse.
City College's basketball team set a Lavender scoring record last night defeating Massachusetts Institute of Technology, 96 to 56, at the Beavers' gymnasium.

LONDON, Dec. 12 -- Queen Elizabeth II received seven new titles tonight, one for each country of the Commonwealth. Each country of the Commonwealth except India redefined its constitutional relationship with the crown in an announcement of their respective styles for their Queen.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Dec. 12 -- The board of trustees of Rutgers University ordered the dismissal today of two faculty members, effective on Dec. 31, unless prior to that date they make themselves available to the United States Senate Internal Security Committee to answer questions regarding alleged Communist affiliations.

The "Seal of Good Practice," displayed on the air by television stations subscribing to the program code of the National Association of Radio and Television Broadcasters, will be modified shortly so that viewers will know how to contact the association.

Among the newly opened art exhibitions is one of paintings by Milton Avery. Selections from his work from 1929 to the present, are included in the show of his work at the Borgenicht Gallery. Avery's development seems to be away from a thick, dark, romantic style, not unrelated to Soutine, toward one that is simple, decorative, flat and rather airless.
The State of Oregon will receive bids for $10,000,000 of highway bonds on Jan. 6. They will be dated March 1, 1953, and will mature from March 1, 1954 to 1973.

CHICAGO, Dec. 12 (AP) -- "Vigorous action" against several unidentified violators of its stern athletic de-emphasis program today was promised soon by the North Central Association of Colleges and Secondary Schools.

Presumably it is not by land or sea but through the air that an aggressor nation in this modern world will launch its initial attack. Yet the vast expanse of the sky above us cannot be adequately patrolled without a broad base of public support and participation. Our country's airpower would be hopelessly and ineffectively spread out if it attempted to guard every inch of the vast area encompassed by our frontiers.

NEWARK, Dec. 12 -- A plan to consolidate the National Newark and Essex Banking Company of this city and the Savings Investment and Trust Company of East Orange was approved today at meetings of the stockholders of both institutions.

HONOLULU, Dec. 12 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the President-elect, is shocked and puzzled by President Truman's criticism of his trip to Korea, but is determined not to become involved in any public wrangle with the President.

The girl who sells popcorn at the Lee Theatre, Fort Lee, N. J., complained that the audience which came on Thursday evening to see a televised version of Carmen bought only two bags of popcorn. This evidence of gentility or self-restraint or whatever it was might have eased the spirits of those magnificent individuals who created the Metropolitan Opera, from whose House the broadcast came.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (UP) -- The Government has resumed the buying of butter and cheddar cheese to aid dipping dairy prices.

JERSEY CITY, Dec. 12 -- One of the longest City Commission meetings on record ended at 5:45 o'clock this evening with Mayor John V. Kenny and three commissioners voting for the controversial municipal business license tax.

The Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., and eight private bus companies agreed yesterday at City Hall to begin active collective bargaining for a new contract to replace the agreement expiring on Dec. 31.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 12 -- Testimony that the Matson freighter Hawaiian Rancher, in collision yesterday with the Norwegian motorship Fernstream in San Francisco Bay, was actually "going astern" at the moment of the impact was given today before a Coast Guard board of inquiry.

PARIS, Dec. 12 -- The principal defense problem for next year that will face the North Atlantic Council when its meeting begins here Monday will be whether to give priority to full equipment of the existing forces, with minor additions, or to seek primarily to expand the reserves more nearly in accordance with the program tentatively adopted at the Lisbon, Portugal meeting of the Council in February.
CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 12 (AP) -- Tony DeSpirito, suspended until Christmas Eve for faulty riding, today escaped further punishment for another foul.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- Sinclair Weeks, who will become Secretary of Commerce Jan. 20 on the inauguration of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, conferred today with Charles Sawyer, outgoing Secretary of Commerce.

Irvington House Thrift Shop is holding a drive for rummage this month and through Jan. 15 to replenish its stock. From the bundles collected during this period, the bundle judged the ideal one for the thrift shop's purposes will be selected.

LONDON, Dec. 12 -- The stock markets remained lifeless today with prices sensitive to slight selling. British Government securities continued to slip and some leading industrials also weakened although some of them appeared to be recovering toward the close.

Prices closed irregularly higher yesterday on the New York commodity exchanges with most markets continuing dull and featureless. Cocoa, cottonseed oil, soybean oil, wool and hides closed higher and coffee, rubber and lead were off. Zinc, potatoes and sugar were mixed and tin closed unchanged.
DENVER, Dec. 12 -- Following is the text of a formal message from the General Assembly of the National Council of the Churches of Christ in the U. S. A., adopted today:
A plan under which the Doehler-Jarvis Corporation would be acquired by the National Lead Company through an exchange of stock was approved yesterday by directors of Doehler-Jarvis.

HOLLYWOOD, Saturday, Dec. 13 -- The appointment of a new board of directors for R. K. O. Radio Pictures Corporation that includes Howard Hughes, former controlling stockholder of the company, was announced early this morning.
CASABLANCA, French Morocco, Dec. 12 -- A Moroccan court today sentenced 167 Arabs to one-year prison terms for demonstrating yesterday against the French Government in this tense and uneasy city.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 12 -- A Philadelphia judge issued a sweeping anti-strike injunction against the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., today and warned Michael J. Quill, the union's bombastic president, that he would "feel the full effect of the court" if 10,800 Philadelphia transit employes walked out in defiance of the order.

AUSTIN, Tex., Dec. 12 (UP) -- Charles E. Wilson, designated to be Secretary of Defense, and others who will be high in Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's Administration paid a "social visit" of an hour on Gov. Allan Shivers today while en route home from conferences with the President-elect in the Pacific.

November saw a gain of $1.32 in the average price of stocks listed on the New York Stock Exchange, the trading body reported yesterday. The average on Nov. 30 was $42.26, against $40.44 a month earlier. This was the figure level since the $42.46 of July 31 last.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 12 -- Michael J. Quill's Transport Workers Union. C. I. O., abandoned today its plan to let 3,500,000 New York bus passengers ride free during the Christmas shopping rush.
Sal (The Barber) Maglie and Vic Raschi boast the best lifetime marks among pitchers still active in the major leagues.
With a backlog of 90,000 orders, Cadillac faces capacity production next year. The 1953 models will be announced early in January.

ATLANTA, Dec. 12 (AP) -- The Southeastern Conference presidents voted today for a share-the Bowl-wealth plan, but tabled all efforts to repeal the thirty-freshmen rule and revise the total number of athletic scholarships a school may grant.
Directors of the Whelan Drug Company have elected Frank Kohn as president of the Whelan Drug Company, Inc., of California, a subsidiary, effective Jan. 1, it was announced yesterday.
Representatives of the Cheese Importers Association of America will seek a further relaxation of cheese import curbs in a conference next Thursday with Department of Agriculture officials.
This is in reply to Ambassador Andrade's letter to THE NEW YORK TIMES outlining certain facts concerning the seizure of the tin mines in Bolivia.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (AP) -- Thomas C. Buchanan, Federal Power Commission chairman, explained today why he joined in a commission finding of Nov. 26 denying Algonquin Gas Transmission Company a temporary permit to supply natural gas to New England communities.

The greatest threat to consumer confidence in advertising, says the National Better Business Bureau, is the "unbridled use of unprovable superlative claims by a minority of national advertisers." The statement is based on a study of national copy by forty local Better Business Bureaus, made at the request of the N.B.B.B.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- Members of Congress demanded today an inquiry into General of the Army Douglas MacArthur's recent assertion that "there is a clear and definite solution to the Korean conflict," but it appeared unlikely that the study would be made.

A resolution urging Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, President-elect, to redeem "as soon as possible" his campaign pledge to revise the controversial McCarran Immigration Act was adopted unanimously yesterday by delegates to the annual conference of the Italian-American Labor Council at 218 West Fortieth Street.

TOKYO, Saturday, Dec. 12 -- South Korean infantry in a counter-attack before noon today recaptured "Little Nori" hill on the Western Korean front, in the third day of the heaviest local fighting on the Peninsula since the battles for the central ridges in October.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 12 -- State Department specialists have been assigned to try to work out a formula under which the United States could give more information to the United Nations about employes it considers disloyal or subversive.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 12 -- The United Nations Peace Observation Commission voted today, over Soviet objections, to continue a "watchdog" team of observers in the Balkans.

William C. Booth, who began his career in the Municipal Court two years before the Spanish-American War, is still active as a shorthand reporter in the New York County Courthouse at 60 Centre Street. Next month, he will have completed fifty-seven years as a court stenographer.

HACKENSACK, N. J., Dec. 12 (AP) -- Henry Witte, former Police Chief of Lodi who was to have begun a six-month jail term today on a conviction of ignoring gambling and bookmaking operations, obtained a certificate of reasonable doubt and was freed in bail.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (AP) -- The Pacific Northwest's public versus private power fight today brought a request for a Department of Justice investigation of activities of private utilities in the sale of Puget Sound Power and Light Company to six public utility districts.

BRISBANE, Australia, Saturday, Dec. 13 (AP) -- Fausto Gardini sent Italy into the interzone Davis Cup final against the United States by defeating Sumant Misra of India, 8 -- 6, 8 -- 6, 1 -- 6, 6 -- 4, in the deciding singles match today. The final will be played at Sydney on Dec. 18-20.

Last winter the presidents of the eight Ivy League colleges agreed on a new and strict de-emphasis program which banned, among other things, spring football practice. A few other colleges and groups in other sections also eliminated spring drills, while most of them limited them to the twenty-sessions-in-thirty-days program recommended by the National Collegiate A. A.

Continuing efforts to soothe the ruffled feelings of executives of American Actors' Equity and British Actors' Equity over the controversy involving employment of each organization's nationals appear to be producing satisfactory results.

PARIS, Dec. 12 -- Premier Antoine Pinay, once more at odds with the National Assembly over the means of giving France a balanced budget, tonight was obliged to move a vote of confidence to prevent changes in the text of his finance bill.

Shipments of machine tools have been going up steadily, and the total for the full year is expected to approximate $1,200,000,000. Tell Berna, general manager of the National Machine Tool Builders Association in Cleveland, said yesterday in a telephone conversation that this figure was being achieved by means of longer hours, more shifts and subcontracting.

MANCHESTER, England, Dec. 12 -- The Manchester Guardian, famed British morning newspaper, informed its staff in a confidential circular today that it plans to print a London edition by a publishing method utilizing photographic transmission.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (AP) -- A recently discovered moon of the giant planet Jupiter is traveling the wrong way, the Carnegie Institution of Washington announced today in its annual report.

Narcotics addiction among teenagers is a symptom of their inability to cope with life, a chemical escape from reality, just as alcoholism is, fifty representatives of twenty national organizations dealing with young people were told yesterday.

New studies at the Federal Narcotics Addiction Hospital at Lexington, Ky., indicate the complex nerve activity of physical pain and mental agitation, recognized as addiction withdrawal symptoms, are not just "in the mind" but are experienced by all conscious and unconscious branches of the nervous system.

SAVANNAH, Ga., Dec. 12 (AP) -- The Savannah Naval Stores Exchange today issued no figures on receipts or shipments while its attorneys conferred over the effects of the latest legal move in the Government's anti-monopoly action against the market.

DENVER, Dec. 12 -- The National Council of the Churches of Christ in the U. S. A. warned here today that unless religion was restored to its "rightful place" in the social and educational areas of American life the United States eventually would become a secular state capable of committing "satanic crimes."
A dancing teacher's contribution of $10,000 to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund almost matches the total of 446 other gifts that are acknowledged today by this newspaper.

Sales taxes, like the Old Man of the Sea, are hard to get rid of once they are imposed. In fact, twenty-four States now depend upon a sales tax for their great single source of revenue, according to a report by Commerce Clearing House. This is three States more than in 1951.

A new organization called The Fund for the Republic has been established by the Ford Foundation to work for "elimination of restrictions on freedom of thought, inquiry and expression in the United States," it was announced yesterday by Paul G. Hoffman, president of the foundation.
MILWAUKEE, Dec. 12 -- Hundreds of examples of the finest in the architect's and decorator's arts have taken over this city's three-story Art Institute.
BOMBAY, India, Dec. 12 -- Outside employment for mothers of young children was condemned in a report adopted by the International Study Conference on Child Welfare at its concluding session today.

LONDON, Dec. 12 -- An abnormal increase of lung and bronchial illnesses following the heavy three-day fog this week has excited some alarm in London. The Central Bed Service, which coordinates admissions to hospitals, received requests for 500 beds on Tuesday, the day the fog lifted, compared with a normal demand for about 135 beds a day.

A 31-year-old stenographer so confused a pair of hold-up men yesterday that they fled with only $34 when $750 more was within their grasp. They outran the stenographer, who chased them down three flights of stairs.

The Eastern College Athletic Conference yesterday went overwhelmingly on record in favor of continued national control of football television and enjoined its members from making 1953 television commitments in advance of National Collegiate Athletic Association action next month.
The Turkish Government's $50,000,000 program to expand and modernize its merchant fleet and related shore and harbor installations is now virtually completed.

IN the course of the long literary tennis game they called their love letters, Mrs. Patrick Campbell once wrote Bernard Shaw: "I have hunted through your beautiful wedding gift and it's not there!" The wedding gift comprised the seventeen volumes of his works that Shaw had presented to her in a characteristic gesture in 1914 when she was married to George CornwallisWest.

OBJECTS from the Orient, particularly from Japan, have been frequently suggested during the past year as a potentially important source for home furnishings designs. Such a possibility is appropriate, it has been argued, because of the similarities between the houses of Japan and contemporary examples in our own country.

Discoveries in medical science have a way of promoting, suddenly, little-known chemical compounds or other natural complexes from obscurity in the dusty archives of organic chemistry to international fame as disease killers.

TOKYO, Sunday, Dec. 14 -- United Nations guns today smashed a new Chinese Communist attack on "Little Nori" hill overlooking the Imjin River northwest of Yonchon on the Korean western front and killed or scattered 300 Red troops.

MANHASSET, L. I., Dec. 13 -- The board of trustees of the North Shore Hospital reported today that "a policy controversy" with a group of seventeen recalcitrant doctors "seemed settled" in favor of the board.

VANCOUVER, B. C. -- Skiers who have been going to the Canadian Rockies for the winter sport season in past years will find this winter that facilities have been improved. New slopes have been added and existing runs improved.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- In the state capitals of the country there will assemble on Monday the Presidential electors -- those men for whom you voted last Nov. 4, believing that you were voting for Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower or Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois for President.
T0EL AVIV, Israel, Dec. 13 -- After more than three years of an uncertain Israeli-Arab armistice, there is much talk and a glimmer of hope for peace in the Middle East.

RED BANK, N. J., Dec. 13 -- Mrs. Geraldine L. Thompson of Brookdale Farm, Lincroft, who founded the Monmouth County Organization for Social Service forty years ago and has served continuously as its president, retired yesterday.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 13 -- From a venture that began with a single desk in a crowded office and a "stock" of three items for sale, the United Nations Bookshop has expanded over the last six years into a full-scale enterprise with its own spacious quarters and a business volume of several thousands of dollars weekly.

IN the music of Respighi's "The Fountains of Rome" the technical impression is given of water bubbling up from four of the famous fountains of the Eternal City. The glittering shafts of diamond-threaded spray rise higher and higher until they reach a musical apex against the lush Italian background.

MANILA, Dec. 13 -- An American sergeant who went A.W.O.L. twice to join the Philippine expeditionary force in Korea received the Philippine Legion of Honor Medal from Defense Secretary Ramon Magsaysay today.

PASSAIC, N. J., Dec. 13 -- A move to make a national shrine of the site of Acquackanonk Landing, where the old Revolutionary Bridge crossed the Passaic River, may yet make a reality of the dream of Passaic residents.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., Dec. 13 (AP) -- Under a proposal that gained support today pupils moving into the state would not be eligible to compete in inter-school sports if they were ineligible in the schools they attended before moving.

In his article "Trieste Vital to West." in THE TIMES of Dec. 2, Hanson Baldwin writes from Trieste: "This disputed area * * * is assuming new importance on the strategic map of Europe. * * * Trieste lies along the coastal approach to the North Italian plain and the Ljubljana Gap in Yugoslavia, leading toward Trieste and Gorizia, is the historical gateway to Northern Italy.

JOHN WILLIAMS never had a direct contact with a detective in his life. A thorough Londoner, he has never even visited Scotland Yard to see what it looked like. He is faintly repelled by even such two-dimensional mysteries as crossword puzzles and he simply will not read a Whodunit.

SAN BRUNO, Calif., Dec. 13 (AP) -- Simonsez, setting most of the pace, won the $25,000 added Tanforan Handicap today to highlight the closing-day program. The time for the mile and an eighth was 1:53 2/5.

ALBANY, Dec. 13 -- New fuel was added to a smoldering controversy between truckers and the State Tax Commission this week, when the State Conference Board of Farm Organizations, representing 100,000 farmers, joined in protesting against the new regulations for truck registration fees.

REPORTING last week on his recent tour of Europe in search of photographers to supply pictures for his international "Family of Man" project for the Museum of Modern Art, Edward Steichen was optimistic about the plan's chance of succeeding.

IN the year 1699 an English clergyman named Thomas Bray visited the Province of Maryland as the Bishop of London's representative to the "Foreign Plantations." His stay was brief, but it was to have far-reaching results for colonial America and, in time, for many parts of the world.
The most comprehensive system of safeguards for boxers performing in this state now is in operation under the State Athletic Commission, it was claimed yesterday by Chairman Robert K. Christenberry.

NEXT to the child's parents, his teachers play the greatest role in his life. If we think of the teacher as a composite person of all who have ministered to the child's educational needs from kindergarten to college days, it is safe to say that the child spends almost as much time in the presence of his teacher as of his parents -- or at least of his father.
MOTORISTS who visit winter sports areas during the next few months or the warmer regions of Florida and the Southwest will meet more recreation seekers on the road than ever before.

BERLIN, Dec. 13 -- Dr. Grayson Kirk, Provost and acting head of Columbia University, told a group of leading German educators here today that the free flow of ideas was threatened by a number of forces in the West as well as in the Communist world.

VIENNA, Dec. 13 -- Mme. Sun Yat-sen, widow of China's first President, appealed to the American people today to hold Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower to "his promise to end the Korean war on the strength of which he was elected President." Simultaneously she scolded him for "his vicious proposal to let Asians fight Asians."

On and after tomorrow there need be no more argument as to whether General Eisenhower should be called President-elect or President-designate. He will on that day actually be elected by an electoral vote of 442 to 89.

BOWIE, Md., Dec. 13 -- Rated expertly by Jockey Joe LiCausi, Mrs. James McGee's Occupancy won the Capitol Hill Handicap at the Bowie track today. Getting off fourth in the field of seven. Occupancy improved her position gradually in the seven - furlong test to take the victory by a neck for her third successive triumph.

The United States Supreme Court was asked last week to end school segregation now in effect in seventeen Southern and border states and the District of Columbia. This is generally conceded to be one of the most important issues in the field of education that has come before the highest tribunal in many years.

ALBANY, Dec. 13 -- New York's forty-five electoral college members will convene in the State Senate chamber at noon Monday to cast their ballots for Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower and Senator Richard M. Nixon as President and Vice President of the United States.

SETTLING back comfortably on a divan, Shirley Booth indulged in her favorite pastime, next to acting. She smiled. "I don't think enough has been said about picture acting," mused the amiable lady who happens to be one of the best and best-liked proponents of her craft.

BACK in the early days of the New York Football Giants one of the stockholders was Dr. Harry March, a pro football enthusiast who had been most responsible for persuading Tim Mara to buy the original franchise. The doctor was so stanch a supporter that he insisted on watching all games from the players' bench.

THE tendency to use beguiling though meaninglessly applied terms to describe types of photographic activity has lured the Metropolitan Camera Club Council to repeat last year's so-called "creative" contests.

THINGS being what they are, with everyone looking for new worlds to conquer, it was only a normal extension of our times that led the editors of this section to include among the reports on travel and vacation possibilities for the coming winter season, an article on travel out into space -- to Venus, Mars and the moon.

CONTROLLER LAZARUS JOSEPH, the short - sighted gentleman who proposed the abolition of Station WNYC to save a mere pittance out of the total city budget, may have inadvertently done the cause of good broadcasting a tremendous turn.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 13 -- A circular map of London in 1802 about two inches in diameter has been acquired for the map and chart collection of Yale University. This miniature city chart, known as a "watchpaper map," is printed on silk and is of a type used by London's gay blades of the era to find their way about their town.

Fifty of the nation's leading medical specialists in the puzzling disease knoavn as multiple sclerosis met here Thursday--for the annual medical session of the National Multiple Sclerosis Society--to discuss advances in their science. The meeting ended with the agreement that multiple sclerosis is just about as mystelous as ever.

Control of tuberculosis in New York has been achieved through a series of health and medical measures that form milestones in the first fifty years of this century. The story is told in a recent study, "A Half Century's Progress Against Tuberculosis in New York City, 1900-1950."

JACKSONVILLE, Fla. -- "Let's face it," said a Miami newspaper recently. "Florida is not perfect." Even the most perfect thing about Florida, its climate, is not quite perfect. He who comes to Florida this winter for the first time should heed the warning of United States Weather Bureau records: Florida at times can get downright chilly, as many visitors found last winter, when temperatures ran below normal.

CHRISTMAS shopping is moving into its peak period Using department store sales as a criterion plus signs are evident in figures on retail trade. Volume in several areas is lagging behind last year's, but, on balance, indications are that country-wide dollar sales this month will top those of 1951.

The editorial in this month's issue of the bulletin of the National Tuberculosis Association summarizes the current status in tuberculosis with its title, "1952 -- A Good Year in Tuberculosis Control."

ST. KITTS, B. W. I. -- St. Kitts residents are more interested in their sugar cane crop than they are in acquiring visitors. Ambiguous as it may sound, this is one of the island's biggest selling points to those who are looking for a spot in the West Indies which hasn't been overridden by tourists.
Frida Beckman, a high school senior at George Washington Evening School, 192d Street and Audubon Avenue, is never absent, never late, always has her homework done and is her teachers' pet.
The Illinois Manufacturers Association is urging its 4,000 members to ship their wares under the American flag when possible.

The Brothers Anastasia, a band of obscure Italian sailors who jumped ship to fade into the shadows of the waterfront here twenty-five years ago, are now becoming one of the prominent families of New York.

Tight engineering secrecy on the part of air conditioning manufacturers is going out of the window almost as quickly as air expelled by their products. Last week, Paul B. Moore of the York Corporation said some engineering information and techniques now are being exchanged freely "in the best interests of the industry."

THE American public's attitude toward science is a complex mixture of awe and resentment (two feelings which often go together). Recent technical advances are publicized so widely and well that we cannot help being impressed.

PARIS, Dec. 13 -- Preliminary discussions on the French proposal for a European health community ended today with a motion that all interested nations should appoint experts to examine the question and determine how such an organization could be formed.

WHEN Byzantium was the golden city of Rome's Eastern Empire, a beautiful Grecian pagan became its empress. She was Athenais, bride of Theodosius II, the young Caesar who, bored with the details of ruling, left the problems of state to his maiden sister, Pulcheria.

DALLAS, Dec. 13 (UP) -- The Southwest Conference today formally adopted the contract plan used by the Southeastern Conference for enrolling of athletes, but took no action on Oklahoma's implied readiness to move from the Big Seven to rejoin the Southwest group.

DENVER, Colo. -- Winter came late to the Rockies this season but now there is good snow. Aspen, Arapahoe and Berthoud Pass and most of the other big resorts will be open this week-end all along the Big Divide for 1,000 miles from the big mountain layout at Whitefish, Mont., south to La Madera near Albuquerque, N. M.

IN a recent review of the SPA recording of Mahler's Third Symphony, a typographical error changed the Vienna Philharmonia Orchestra into the Vienna Philharmonic. A tired, resigned, patient letter from the London Gramophone Corporation immediately followed.

Gardnar Mulloy, the 38-year-old campaigner from Miami, Fla., who, on his eighteenth attempt, gained the final of the national singles tennis championship last September for the first time, tentatively has been ranked first in the ratings of the United States Lawn Tennis Association for 1952.

In the columned chamber of the U. S. Supreme Court last week another round in the battle over segregation began. To the justices' left sat an imposing battery of Negro lawyers: to the court's right were the legal forces defending segregation. At issue was the question of whether the separation of Negro and white children in different schools could be reconciled with the U. S. Constitution and past decisions of the Supreme Court.
