THE author of this scholarly piece of work, a Professor of Law and Political Science at Dartmouth, makes the point that "when Congressional inquisitors have seemed overly vigorous or thorough in their methods they have been accused of conducting a 'witch hunt'": whereas "when they have gone about their work in calm and unspectacular fashion their efforts have been belittled as amounting to a 'whitewash.'"

I noted in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Dec. 8 that Walter P. Chrysler Jr. "demurred when asked if he would like to become an investor in 'Two's Company' with the explanation that he would be competing against his own show."

ANSONVILLE N. C. -- Tourists interested in one of the most unusual wild-goose refuges in North America will do well to detour on southern vacations and go via U. S. 52 to Ansonville in south-central North Carolina. Here at the Lockhart Gaddy Wild Goose Refuge just south of town is an amazing wintering place of the Canada goose.

WILD fowlers will find pleasant entertainment and valuable information in this latest book by the Wood, Field and Stream columnist of THE NEW YORK TIMES. Raymond Camp has spent many years gunning for and studying the habits and characteristics of wild ducks and geese and has earned for himself the reputation of an authority in this field.

CHICAGO, Dec. 13 (AP) -- Finger-wagging at "paid gladiators" and proposals for streamlining the Olympic Games highlighted the first directive by the new president, Avery Brundage, to his International Olympic committee.

PARIS, Dec. 13 -- Anthony Eden, British Foreign Secretary, proposed today to the Marshall Plan Council that the British Commonwealth with European nations and the United States should seek to adopt common policies by which to solve the problem of the dollar shortage and restore the balance of world trade.

ALBANY -- New York State winter resorts feel this season will be even better than last year's, when a revenue of more than $10,000,000 was realized. The fact that the first good period of snows in four years produced such a volume of business is an indication that winter vacations are an important part of the state's year-round travel industry.

EL PASO, Tex., Dec. 13 (AP) -- Faculty representatives at the winter meeting of the Border Con ference relaxed today after an announcement by Texas Tech that its ban on Negro athletes had been lifted.
In the middle of East Harlem, one of the most thickly settled communities in the nation, is the Benjamin Franklin High School -- a school where the melting pot boils.

THERE have been many changes in the musical scene since I lived here about six years ago. I can remember when there existed only a summer season of concerts conducted by Carlos Chavez, sporadic operas, some concerts of the National University Symphony Orchestra and a few good recitals.

EVERY two or three seasons American theatregoers have to wrestle with the disturbing problem of Terence Rattigan. London audiences like his plays enormously. On the current evidence of "The Deep Blue Sea," which is still on view over there, many Londoners now regard Mr. Rattigan as England's best dramatist.

New Yorkers took their biggest civil defense training exercise since World War II in stride yesterday, and showed state and foreign observers with surprising unanimity that they would know what to do if a bomb should be dropped.

BOSTON -- Although the Old Farmer's Almanac predicts there will be "more bare than snow-covered lawns" in New England on Christmas Day, ski resort operators have gone ahead with extensive improvement programs for the winter vacation season.
SEATTLE, Dec. 13 (AP) -- Pickets left the Seattle waterfront today in advance of an expected injunction, ending a thirty-two-day shipping tie-up.

In the parade of witnesses who have given evidence over the past two years of bribery and corruption during the administration of New York City Mayor William O'Dwyer, only one person is known to have directly implicated Mr. O'Dwyer himself. That was John P. Crane, former president of the Uniformed Firemen's Association.

Churchmen are agreed that the Christian Church in Germany, during the early period of the rise of Hitler, failed generally by not taking his words seriously or condemning his outright professions of bigotry. Consequently, the anti-Semitism which Hitler perfected as an instrument to secure power was permitted to grow until the entire continent of Europe capitulated in hatred and violence.

FAYID, Suez Canal Zone, Dec. 13 -- From a world point of view, the negotiations taking place between Egypt and Britain have one ultimate purpose. They would first harmonize relationships between a shrinking empire and an ebullient people emerging from a chrysalis.
The two-year effort of New York savings bankers to obtain broader branch office powers, while avoiding an open break with their commercial bank competitors, is fast coming to a head.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 (AP) -- The Defense Department identified ninety-one victims of the Korean war today. The new list includes twenty-two killed in action, sixty-one wounded, seven injured in accidents and one missing. The following are from New York and New Jersey (none from Connecticut) :

St. John's bowed into Madison Square Garden last night and bowed out the loser, 74 -- 72, to a Rhode Island University quintet that only forty-eight hours previously had yielded 105 points to North Carolina State at Raleigh. It was a sorry seasonal Garden debut for the Brooklyn Redmen and their new coach, Al (Dusty) DeStefano.

In connection with the letter of Myrtle M. Westbrook in The Times Magazine, Nov. 30, objecting to Leonard Jan Mitchel's reference to marinating in "wine and olive oil on a budget," I would like to point out that today olive oil is not expensive and fits into any budget.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla. -- Eighty-two per cent of out-of-state visitors come to Florida by automobile, 8.8 per cent by train, 5.2 per cent by airplane, 3.7 per cent by bus and a fraction of one per cent by boat, according to a survey made by the State Advertising Commission.

THROUGHOUT the years there has been a certain amount of agitation for "reprint records." The argument ran that book publishers could bring out, after an initial sale and after a given book had lain fallow for some time, a cheaper reprint that would attract a new public without detriment to the original work.

DESPITE the increased hunting pressure placed on many states as a result of the ban on the importation of big game from Canada this fall, preliminary surveys indicate that little if any damage has been done to the herds, and some states report that an additional kill would have been beneficial in certain areas.

" GREAT is the power of words," says Homer. "words will make this way and that way." Like other conventions, language takes root in the organism, develops there a life of its own, and by its inner tensions or accidental entanglements distorts the facts it professes to report or sways the feelings which facts would naturally arouse, so as to create artificial and heady passions.

HONOLULU, Dec. 13 (AP) -- General Eisenhower left for home today, confident that his fifteen-day survey of the Korean war and other Far Eastern problems had paid dividends, despite criticism by President Truman. other Far Eastern problems had paid dividends, despite criticism by President Truman.

THERE aren't many streets like Bean Street any more, and there aren't many doctors like Doc Saunders -- a fact for which the world is poorer. With a loving hand, a kindly eye, and a wry chuckle, the author has set down in his first novel this delightful account of what happened in Bean Street, a small part of London's Soho, over a period of several months.

ALBANY, Dec. 13 -- The state director of the National Education Association declared today that the 1953 Legislature must authorize an increase of $100,000,000 in state aid for education or face the prospect of "a widespread breakdown of educational services."
ANNAPOLIS, Md. -- Florida-bound motorists will find a new route south open to them this winter because of the completion during the past summer of new toll bridges in Maryland and Virginia.

" FORBIDDEN GAMES," the French film now at the Little Carnegie, has been winning prizes all over Europe in the face of official obstacles at nearly every starting post. The French selection committee passed it by as an entry for the Cannes Film Festival last April.

Warm and rainy weather hampered department store volume in the week, and trade observers estimated that sales here would show a decline of as much as 10 per cent from 1951. It was pointed out that a factor in the drop was that the 1951 week was closer to Christmas in terms of shopping days.

JOHN REESE, whose last book was a realistic tale about a lost dog ("Big Mutt"), has now written a rambling fable which is consistently delightful if not always pointed. His thrusts at mankind's foibles are too good-natured to wound.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 13 -- Since the Philadelphia wage tax went into effect thirteen years ago, it has produced more than $362,000,000, an amount in excess of one-quarter of the city's total revenue.

EDWARDS AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., Dec. 13 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower arrived here shortly before midnight (Pacific Coast time) en route from Honolulu to New York after his historic visit to the battlefront in Korea.

AN amateur color printing section, perhaps the first to be formed in a camera club, has been organized and is now in operation at the Camera Club, 121 West Sixty-eighth Street, the oldest in the city. The section is part of a long-range program designed to regain the club's one-time leadership in local photographic activities and to provide for its members new opportunities for improving and extending their abilities. The club was started in 1885.
Selling to the Government is a type of business that involves some risks, a bit of guesswork and a measure of finger-crossing, just as in private business.

BECAUSE the pony, when she was foaled, had been far below standard in looks, the owner of the stables jokingly said she was only a penny's worth of horse. But Penny grew into a first-rate mount for youngsters taking riding lessons.

THE perennial outbursts about the difficulties of trying to buy theatre tickets in New York embolden me to offer a solution. I hardly claim originality for the idea. But its desirability has occurred to me again and again, as I have trudged my weary way from box office to box office.

The short days are upon us. It will be another week before the winter solstice, but the day's change now is slight. Daylight, sunrise to sunset, will shorten only another two minutes or so before it begins to lengthen. The evening change, in fact, has already begun, the year's earliest sunset already past; but sunrise will continue to lag on through the year's end.

Devotion to one's family is an admirable trait, but it also can involve one in embarrassing and frequently unprofitable situations such as are depicted in the comic strip "Li'l Abner." In the case of Al Capp, creator of the strip, however, the trait has paid off handsomely not only for him but for his two brothers and sister and, to a degree, for his father, a retired traveling salesman.

The Political and Security Committee of the United Nations General Assembly has acted wisely in giving its support to the Latin-American resolution on Tunisia rather than to the more harshly worded draft offered by the Asian-Arab bloc. There is good reason, in the interest of the United Nations, to reaffirm confidence in France's essential good faith, which is what the chosen resolution does.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 13 -- California, eyed as a lush field for the operations of crime syndicates only a few years ago, now is free of organized crime, according to a biennial report of Edmund G. (Pat) Brown, State Attorney General, issued this week.

PARIS, Dec. 13 -- France will not talk to the United Nations about Tunisia and Morocco but she will talk with great insistence about Indo-China to the Council of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization next week.

Unless considerably higher maximum and minimum prices are agreed to by importing countries at a meeting to be held in Washington on Jan. 30, the International Wheat Agreement, which was put into effect in the middle of 1948 after some fifteen years of discussions and negotiations, may be permitted to automatically lapse next July 31, its expiration date.

MODERN political leaders, even on our side of the Iron Curtain, feel strongly and express themselves eloquently against modern art. President Truman calls it "merely the vaporings of half-baked lazy people" and believes "the ability to make things look as they are is the first requisite of an artist."

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 13 -- Michael J. Quill, president of the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., undismayed by the overnight recall of his promise to give free bus rides to 3,500,000 New Yorkers during the Christmas shopping rush, bounced back today with a plan for putting $22,500,000 of New York City's funds into the pockets of 45,000 union members of the city-owned subway, elevated and bus lines.
Considerable progress has been made in solving the problem of static electricity in the new synthetic textile fibers, but development of a permanent anti-static finish is months if not years away.

HAMILTON, Bermuda -- Announcement last month that the wholly owned subsidiary of Pan American World Airways, Intercontinental Hotels Corporation, had taken over management of the Princess Hotel reinforced Bermuda's steadily gaining bid for year-round tourist trade.

The Korean war must be fought through to a successful conclusion if 700,000,000 "neutral" Asians are to be won over to the side of the free nations, Ambassador Ben C. Limb, permanent Korean representative to the United Nations, declared yesterday.

MANHASSET, L. I., Dec. 13 -- National champion Alastair Bradley Martin and John Hay (Jock) Whitney led Long Island to a 2-1 victory over New York in court tennis today as the annual Payne Whitney Memorial doubles tournament started at Greentree. In the other match. Philadelphia defeated Boston by the same score, 2 -- 1. The finals will be played tomorrow, starting at 11 A. M.

ACCORDING to the latest estimate, there will be 815,000 homes-on-wheels in this country by 1953. Of these, 80 to 90 per cent will be used as year-round residences. It would follow, then, that many will be attractively planted with gardens, scaled to trailer size.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N. Y., Dec. 13 -- Mezzy Barber, 33-year-old Brattleboro, Vt., flyer and holder of the national open title, tonight captured the Metropolitan Invitation Ski Jump. It was the opening event of the season over the wellpacked Bear Mountain 50-meter hill.

NORMAN, Okla., Dec. 13 (UP) -- Oklahoma's Big Seven Conference representative said today the North Central Association of Colleges and Secondary Schools' ban on athletic scholarships was a "critical point" in discussions concerning the Sooners' possible withdrawal from the conference.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- The Truman - MacArthur, Truman - Eisenhower controversies over Korea this week illustrate at least one difference between the President and his successor. This is that Mr. Truman is a combative, abrasive man while General Eisenhower is not.

Thomas K. Finletter, Secretary of the Air Force, said last night that air power would either destroy the world or have a large part in saving it. He spoke at the golden jubilee dinner of the Bronx County Bar Association in the Biltmore Hotel.

RABAT, French Morocco, Dec. 13 -- With the Nationalist movement decapitated by arrests and with 45,000 French troops and policemen deployed throughout the country, French Morocco was outwardly at peace today after nearly a week of the worst Moroccan outbreaks of violence since the war.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 13 -- Back from a tour of South Korea as a representative of the American Friends Service Committee, Dr. Jonathan Rhoads of Philadelphia observed here this week:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- General of the Army Omar N. Bradley, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, delivered a report to President Truman today on the controversial trip to Korea by Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower.

SEOUL, Korea, Dec. 13 (AP) -- The United Nations Command announced today that a North Korean prisoner of war was shot and killed by a United States Army guard at midnight Wednesday on Koje Island. It said the prisoner refused to halt after being challenged twice.

WORK by two American representatives at the 1952 Venice Biennale, Stuart Davis and Yasuo Kuniyoshi, has finally been returned to this country and is being shown at the Downtown Gallery. The exhibition is also something in the nature of a miniature retrospective since it includes selections of paintings by Davis from 1916 to 1951 and of Kuniyoshi's work from 1923 to last year.

THE discovery of a new young photographer of considerable talent was a rewarding feature of a recent contest at Fort Dix in connection with the Fourth Interservice Photographic Contest. The photographer was Pfc. Harold J. Riedel of 22 Jefferson Avenue, Emerson, N. J., whose entries in the contest, considered as a group, revealed a body of work of rare quality and versatility.

HOPES that 1953 will be a better year for British films have been raised by the announcement that the Rank Organization is returning to the policy of financing its own production. This may not seem a very remarkable step, but here it is of considerable significance.

For the first time since the downward trend began in 1949, college enrollments have gone up this year. At the same time, however, the financial plight of America's 1,900 institutions of higher learning has grown worse.
Believe it or not, but Westinghouse Electric Corporation, second only to General Electric in the field of home appliances, found itself a few years ago with no general objective.

THIS selection of the uncollected essays and reviews of the late Harvard professor, Jamesian scholar and author of "American Renaissance," bears witness once more to F. O. Matthiessen's unique position in contemporary criticism, and our loss.

The United Nations can benefit by constructive criticism, but is in danger of being "seriously poisoned by venomous attacks" that must not be left unchallenged, Mrs. Edith Sampson, United States alternate representative to the United Nations General Assembly, asserted yesterday.

THERE have been so few worthwhile pictures from France and Italy this year -- so few that would bear comparison to the best from those countries in years gone by -- that perhaps the extraordinary impact of the new one from France, "Forbidden Games" ("Jeux Interdits"), seems more forceful and shattering than it might in a less barren year.
The forthcoming session of electors to name General Eisenhower President of the United States recalls the fact that some of his predecessors gained office by the narrow margin of one vote.

KEY WEST, Fla. -- There will be no shortage of accommodations for winter vacationists this year at the tourist centers that dot the "Broadway of the Wilderness," the Overseas Highway between here and Miami. This southermost city in the United States, 165 miles south of Miami, has taken steps to ease the housing shortage of other winters.

THAT account of the Nazis and the German generals, "Sword and Swastika," came about due to the combination of a number of things. Its author, Telford Taylor, was, of course, associate counsel and then Chief Counsel at the Nuremberg War Crimes Trials, and so was in a position to know of what he spoke.
DETROIT, Dec. 13 -- Marguerite Ann Norris, who never has seen the Detroit Red Wings play in Olympia Stadium here, today became president of both the Red Wings and the Stadium.

Is cigarette smoking the reason why there are more cases of cancer of the lung than ever? In three papers presented at the International Cancer Congress held in Paris in 1950, strong evidence was presented that it was. But clinicians are not agreed that cigarette smoking is the reason.

ANTHONY POWELL'S "Afternoon Men" appeared in England in 1931, and since that time he has published seven novels. Five of these are smooth, foible-tweaking social comedies written by a worldly man who understands vanity so well that he can be humorously magnanimous about it.

On Sunday, Dec. 9, 1951, THE NEW YORK TIMES printed 100 stories of the Neediest drawn from the files of the city's major private philanthropic organizations. The response to one of these, Case 7, attested by the Catholic Charities of the Diocese of Brooklyn, was so great that donors to the annual appeal have asked what has happened to the "disfigured girl, 18" described in these columns.

NEW BRUNSWICK. N. J., Dec. 13 -- Two Rutgers professors today pondered what they would do about the university's ultimatum that they offer to answer questions of the Senate Subcommittee on Internal Security about alleged Communist affiliations or lose their jobs.

Last iVfonday morning twelve United States Navy men began an intensive training program for a new type of sea duty--operating an atomic-powered submarine. The two officers and ten enlisted men are expected to form the nucleus of an atomic submarine crew. They will instruct other future atomic submariners as the use of atomic power in the Navy increases.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Dec. 13 (AP) -- The Indonesian Government, striving to steer a neutral course in world politics, announced today it had reached an agreement in principle with the United States on a new plan for future American economic aid.

More realistic studies of pension costs, based on new developments which have affected retirement programs in recent years, have been suggested by insurance officials. The trend toward more adequate pensions, changes in retirement ages and indicated lower mortality rates among older persons, give impetus to the need for such studies, they contend.

TRAVEL by train to winter resorts this season will be unusually heavy, passenger traffic officials reported last week after a look at mounting reservation requests. Recent snowy skies and icy roads in the East caused many vacationists to hasten their plans for vacations in more balmy areas.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 13 -- Air Pine, a Florida-bred son of Ariel Game surprised the crowd of 10,484 at Tropical Park today by beating Shipper Bill in a stretch drive to win the $7,500 added Coral Gables Handicap for 2-year-olds.

IN this age of jets and turbines it was no surprise to discover that a 20,000-mile, three-continent trip from New York, incorporating a round-Africa voyage, was possible in a twelve-week vacation. But it was a pleasant discovery to find that the entire round-trip fare was just $675, tourist class, of course.
TORONTO, Dec. 13 (UP) -- The Detroit Red Wings took a 4-point lead at the top of the National Hockey League tonight by defeating the Toronto Maple Leafs, 3 -- 1, before 12,841 fans.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 13 -- The United States has made a charge of "attempted espionage" against a Soviet citizen on the United Nations secretariat -- the personal assistant to the highest-ranking Soviet national on the staff -- and has barred his re-entry into this country.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 13 (UP) -- The National Board of Americans for Democratic Action today urged the appointment of a Presidential commission to recommend legislative measures to curb the rising cost of political campaigns.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 (AP) -- Minor party candidates didn't do so well in the Nov. 4 Presidential election. Along with the scattered write-ins, they polled an official aggregate of only 308,996 votes, or 0.5 per cent of the total. In 1948 they received 2,613,424 votes, or 5.4 per cent of the total.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- An increasingly bright economic aspect, culminating in 1960 with great rises in productivity and living standards, was suggested as a distinct possibility today in a report by the National Planning Association.

SHRUBS and flowering trees that bear their fruits in autumn and also perform well at other times with fine flowers and handsome foliage are valuable plants for even the smallest property. A large collection of such material was displayed recently by the Pennsylvania Horticultural Society.
ROCKLAND, Me., Dec. 13 -- Dazed and bewildered residents of this community of 9,000 persons began fighting their way back to normalcy today following the worst fire in its history.

A FREIGHTER trip along the South American coast had been a dream of mine since school geographies widened my horizons, and the travel advertisements attracted me as a cleverly tied fly attracts a lively trout. Recently, I had occasion to take such a trip under conditions surprisingly different from my original dream.

LONDON, Dec. 13 -- Ever since the beginning of Britain's oil dispute with Iran some segments of British opinion have tended to be suspicious, critical or resentful of United States intervention in the affair. This week, despite reassurances from officials on both sides of the Atlantic, they found cause again for suspicion.

FOR THIS WEEK: Clean the foliage of house plants before the holidays. Wipe large leaves with a damp cloth, and stand small plants under a faucet or shower for spraying. Dust woolly leaves. . . . Bring bulbs started in pebbles and water three to four weeks ago to the light so top growth can catch up to root growth. . . .
Newspaper editors in nineteen cities over the country have expressed optimism about the status of civil liberties and the outlook for their preservation in the United States.

BEAR MOUNTAIN -- As the closest thing to a municipal winter sports area, this Palisades Interstate Park skiland is a sort of off-season Coney Island. It attracts vast crowds of city people every week-end, both to ski and enjoy other winter activities and to watch the ski jumping competitions on the fifty-meter hill.
College All-America lacrosse stars were named yesterday and honored at the seventieth annual dinner of the United States Intercollegiate Lacrosse Association at the Hotel Statler.

TO Eric Jorgenson the little Good Hope had always been he most beautiful ship on the Great Lakes. As soon as he got out of school he bought her and set about paying for her by fishing. He had courage and needed it. The catches were small, often ruined by lamprey eels. Someone was stealing the expensive nets of the fishing fleet.

IT is good news that the Slavenska-Franklin Ballet has extended its season at the Century Theatre through Jan. 3. What turned the trick was the success of two new works -- Valerie Bettis' "Streetcar Named Desire" and Zachary Solov's "Mile.

HICKSVILLE, L. I., Dec. 13 -- A full investigation of the sump at Jade Homes, Inc., the open drainage ditch that claimed its second child victim here yesterday, was being conducted today by the homicide squad of the Nassau County police and by the Nassau District Attorney's office.
ISTANBUL, Dec. 13 -- The North Atlantic Treaty Organization is now entering upon the winter of its discontent,

HARRISBURG, Pa. -- The best in winter sports and vacations in many years will be provided by Pennsylvania resorts, a survey by the State Department of Commerce discloses. Many thousands of dollars have been spent to improve facilities and accommodations. Reservations are far ahead of last year.
LONDON, Dec. 23 (Reuters) Results of soccer and rugby games In Britain today:

IT has always been a baffling question to the cat-admirer why in so many instances he finds himself a cat-defender. To the true devotee, cats are the wisest, most sensitive, and, with their variety of moods and impulses, the most interesting of pets.

AIRPLANES are disappointing as sight-seeing vehicles; they spend too much time over clouds or water. When they do glimpse the surface, it is generally Kansas. Or they fly so high that the reliefless map below them might as well be Kansas.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- One of the big issues of the day as the Republicans prepare to take over in the White House and in Congress is whether direct economic controls over prices, wages and rents, which many of them fought so bitterly in the past, are to be continued.

It occurs to me that the solution to the moral uneasiness of our times offered by Professor Mills in "A Diagnosis of Our Moral Uneasiness" (Nov. 23) is inadequate. It would appear that the good professor expects "Representative Men" to be born of awakened industrialists and dethroned movie stars, with a government bureaucrat as midwife.

There was no abatement of enthusiasm last week regarding the outlook for business under the incoming administration. And more hopeful predictions for 1953 based on current trade statistics bolstered sentiment. The stock market reflected the outlook by moving to new high levels in heavy trading.

At the end of the last century and the beginning of the present Madrid had an operetta tradition almost as lively, though not so internationally famous, as that of Vienna. In Spain, however, the light operas were called zarzuelas.

AMONG the prime periods of concentrated achievement, none was greater than the Italian Renaissance, nor any in which the human protagonist played a more predominant part. It was indeed the Age of Individuals, and its supreme accomplishments were muscled into being by men -- and sometimes women -- whose personalities were always as interesting, and often as important as their work.

HAVANA -- The noble and loyal city of Habana, as it was called by conquering Spaniards in the days when they ruled the Caribbean, is undergoing plastic surgery for the tourist season. In fact, the Cuban capital is having its face lifted and all the wrinkles removed in order to look its best for the thousands of visitors who are expected here soon.

IN the first two chapters of this book Mr. Galt observes: "The apes Invented war" and "we already know how to stop wars." He then traces the history of strife from primitive man to the Korean conflict. This history, however, is but a framework into which he has woven accounts of the earliest leagues, unions and peace movements, of the gradual acknowledgment of human rights and the various methods of diplomacy.
THE ways of broadcasting are ofttimes remarkably wondrous to behold -- and unpredictable.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, I Dec. 13 --Arrangements for the voluntary return of Harold J. [Adonis to face New Jersey and Federal indictments fell through today and his case threatened to become the subject of an international legal tangle.

GENEVA, Dec. 13 (UP) -- The Red Cross Societies adopted today an Indian resolution asking both sides in the Korean war to repatriate all sick and wounded prisoners. The vote was 15 to 2, with the Soviet and Chinese Communist Societies voting against.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 13 -- Navy, fast and aggressive, continued in the unbeaten ranks tonight by defeating Yale, 88 -- 73, for its fourth triumph.

The scholarship fund of the Institute of Music of the Aspen (Colo.) Institute for Humanistic Studies will be the beneficiary of a concert to be held on Tuesday in Town Hall. Mrs. Robert C. Johnson is chairman of the committee for the event, tickets for which may be obtained from the Burden Littell Bureau, 114 East Sixty-second Street. A varied progrem of piano music, songs and chamber music will be presented.

ERNEST BLOCH'S first String Quartet made a deep impression when it was introduced here by the Flonzaley Quartet in 1916, and it still seemed a fine work when it was played here by the Griller Quartet in 1940. His second String Quartet was so clearly the finest new chamber work of the 1946-47 season that it romped away with the New York Music Critic's Circle chamber award for 1947.
Studies in productivity and economic progress made by Frederick C. Mills for the National Bureau of Economic Research have produced some startling figures and conclusions:

ATLANTA, Dec. 13 -- Long-term personal savings in six Southeastern states reached a new high in 1952, according to the Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta. Personal savers put about $594,000,000 more into their long-term savings during the first half of this year than they had at the end of 1951, the report showed.

BONN, Germany, Dec. 13 -- The Federal Government of West Germany is appealing to the United States for early dispatch to Bonn of a strong and active Ambassador who, by invigorating European unity, would help win approval of the Allied-German treaties.

CLEARWATER, Fla. -- There are even more fish in Florida's waters than there are tourists on the land. Some are difficult to lure and to catch, very choosy and suspicious; others, when hooked, put up a terrific battle for freedom, but the great majority are easy-going and cooperative and quite easily boated by the most inexperienced visiting anglers.

THIS Christmas season offers a varied selection of unusually fine books on gardening and related subjects. The topics of recently published ones range from biblical plants to general gardening. Some of these books fill a long-existing need.
The end of the holiday rush in foreign mails is in sight at the two local post office installations handling the bulk of this country's contribution to overseas Christmas stockings.

Among the thousands of indefatigable shoppers bending over the counters to select appropriate Christmas cards for relatives, friends and business acquaintances probably only a handful know that the first Christmas card was printed in London 110 years ago by a 16-year-old engraver's apprentice named William Egley.

IT sometimes surprises me to find that I am a devotee of bus travel. The reasons for this devotion, I think, are its intimacy and economy. There is a bond of shared affliction between people wide awake on a bumpy bus at 4 o'clock in the morning and a gratifying bond of triumph between those traveling, as I did recently, 1,197 miles for $26.05, tax included.

Summer employment of Barnard College students reached a new high this year when 500 undergraduates, or nearly half the student body. obtained jobs, Mrs. Ethel C. Burgess, assistant director of the placement office at Barnard, reported yesterday.

WHILE Mexico provides a greater variety of sightseeing spectacles than any other land in the Americas, each of the seven small Central American countries offers a rich elaboration upon some phase of the Mexican scene.

GREAT bridge players, like generals and prime ministers, always write books sooner or later. They do it for about the same reasons, too: some to explain or justify their methods; some in the hope of making money.

BRISBANE, Australia, Dec. 13 (AP) -- Italy's Davis Cup squad, playing unimpressive tennis, squeaked through to victory over a sub-par India team today and will face the United States next week-end in the interzone final at Sydney.
BOSTON, Dec. 13 (UP) -- Fresh snows fell on New England today, swelling drifts that had isolated twenty Vermont communities and killed at least twelve persons.

Women of society headed by Mrs. Walter Hoving and including Mrs. Frances H. McAdoo, are helping to further the success of a luncheon Tuesday at the Waldorf-Astoria, which is being held under the auspices of the Salvation Army Association of New York.

TOKYO, Dec. 13 -- Fighting died down in Korea this week except for some heavy blows along the Manchurian border by land and carrier-based United Nations bombers, and both sides speculated what move might result from the three-day visit of President-elect Eisenhower.

Communique No. 1,461 from the U. N. Command in Korea spoke last Friday of enemy attacks "up to two companies in size," of "probing patrols," of relative "quiet" on much of the front. That was the Korean war, two and a half years old come Christmas Day, now in its third winter in the rugged Korean hills.

Many world-wide industries, faced these days with the necessity of meeting expanding communications requirements, have discovered a relatively new and magic tool with which to solve the problem -- microwave radio.

In the face of rising costs of labor and materials, the city's school construction program is proceeding at lower average costs than in 1951, according to a report submitted to Mayor Impellitteri by John P. Riley, Coordinator of School Construction for the Board of Education.

The twenty-eighth annual concert of the Mount Holyoke College Glee Club will be given on Friday in Town Hall for the benefit of the scholarship fund of the Mount Holyoke Club of New York. Tickets may be obtained at the club, 111 East Forty-eighth Street, or at the box office.

Because important advances have been made in educational practices during the past decade, many parents are slightly confused by the "new" or "modern" methods used to teach their children how to read, write, spell or figure. Sometimes the schools are charged with being lax in teaching the fundamentals, or in neglecting the important factors that go to make a child well educated and sufficiently disciplined to take his place in a democratic society.

In spite of the psychologists and psychiatrists whom C. B. Palmer quotes in his article "Why They Want to Go Faster" (Nov. 30) it seems to me that the desire to go faster is basically physical. Man, being a gravity-burdened animal, easily exhausted, likes the feel of being pulled or pushed by the powerful engines that he has created.
The distillers are using a new approach to the problem of high taxation and its consequent bootlegging -- and they believe, as the result of preliminary experience, that it will be successful.

WITH the air of a man used to making big decisions or, if you prefer, with the bravery of a Daniel about to face the lions, Morton Baum, chairman of the executive committee of the New York City Center of Drama and Music, has instructed this department to come right out in print and say that if it is at all humanly possible, there will be a winter theatre season on Fifty-fifth Stree.

In one of the highest scoring matches in the twenty-seven-year history of indoor polo at the Squadron A Armory, the Ramapo Polo Club topped the New York Athletic Club, 15 to 14, in the feature match of the weekly doubleheader at the Madison Avenue arena last night.

CHICAGO, Dec. 13 -- Business activity in the Chicago area in November continued at a fast pace, although there were indications that the tempo had slackened slightly, the monthly survey of the Purchasing Agents Association of Chicago showed.

THE Norwood Flashrite Exposure Meter, a new calculating device introduced by the Director Products Corporation, makers of the Norwood Director Exposure Meter, uses the principle of the rangefinder to determine exposure in flash photography.
Plans are being formulated for the third annual ball of the St. Nicholas Society of New York to be held on the night of Jan. 30 in the main ballroom of the Plaza.

ONCE again airline officials .are predicting that the winter travel season will usher in the biggest travel year in the history of aviation That has been a standard forecast for at least the last three years and so far every one of the predictions has stood up.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 (UP) -- The American Veterans of World War II protested to President-elect Gem Dwight D. Eisenhower and to President Truman today against any reshuffle of the Veterans Administration before the Republican Administration takes over.

THE sparkling vision of new towns in America, graceful and spacious cities with attractive homes and progressive civic planning, has danced on the drafting boards of idealistic young architects for years immemorial A few tentative experiments in greenbelt living actually advanced beyond the blueprint stage prior to World War II.

YOUNG, vigorous and determined, Pasquale (Patsy) Esposito came to the Land of Golden Opportunity from Italy, firmly resolved to realize his dream -- to make enough money to return to his native Sorrento and buy a four-acre olive farm on which to live happily ever after.
TOKYO, Sunday, Dec. 14 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,463, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Sunday, Korea time:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- With musical skits of original lyrics and borrowed music, members of the Gridiron Club marked tonight the ascent of the Republican party to power as the awakening of "Rip Van G. O. P." and the defeat of the Democratic party as "Mutiny Against the Bounty."

OTTAWA, Dec. 13 -- A tiny radioactive leak in the atomic pile of the nuclear research and development center at Chalk River, 100 miles from here, combined with heavy clouds and high humidity, was responsible yesterday afternoon for the forced evacuation of all workers in the plant, according to Dr. C. J. Mackenzie, president of the Government-owned company.

DETROIT, Dec. 13 -- End Cloyce Box scored on 77, 41 and 40-yard pass plays today and ushered the Detroit Lions -- title starved for seventeen years -- to at least a tie for the National Conference honors in the National Football League.

Detroit officials countered a starling invasion in the Sherwood Forest section by installing loudspeakers emitting 11,000-cycle whistlings. These sounds frightened off the birds, but were inaudible to humans.

I have read with great interest your letter of Nov. 10 from Somerset R. Waters Jr. I entirely agree with its opinion that increased tourism by Americans in Europe is a highly effective way to bridge the dollar gap.

BOMBAY, Dec. 13 -- Important political as well as social implications are seen here in the emergence of India as this year's magnet for international conferences of organizations interested in promoting a better life in a free world.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- The dozen United States Senators who -- either by their own will or that of their constituents -- will not be members of the Eighty-third Congress when it meets on Jan. 3 are having more than their share of headaches these days.

PESHAWAR, North-West Frontier, Pakistan, Dec. 13 (AP) -- Outlaws under command of Mohammad Wali Khan and Afridi tribesmen of Pakistan fought a pitched battle Tuesday at Mamani, near the Kohat Pass, it was reported here today.

LOS ANGELES -- The "Sun Belt" of the Southwest, with its inviting hotels, its luxurious guest ranchos, its desert attractions, is entering what its resort owners and promoters hope will be one of the most successful winter seasons on record.

IN his review of "Luchow's German Cookbook" Maxwell Kriendler complained at the omission of the well known dessert Kaiserschmarrn. The omission can be explained by the fact that Kaiserschmarrn is not a German but an Austrian dish, dating back to the era of the Austrian monarchy.
With the release yesterday of official figures, Ferris Fain of the Athletics was confirmed as the American League batting champion of 1952.

PHIADELPHIA, Dec. 13 -- With operations beginning at the new $400,000,000 Fairless plant of United States Steel this week, about 1,800,000 tons of steel will be added to annual production in this Federal Reserve district and six thousand more steel workers will have employment.

HOW, and why, does the writer find the subject? -- his subject, which germinates into play or story, poem or novel? Is this a matter of chance, or of expert calculation? The question, natural enough, is not easy to answer in natural terms -- hence, the growth around literary art of a myth or mystery.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- Military pomp usually reserved for the highest state occasions attended the transfer here today of two of the nation's most precious documents, the Declaration of Independence and the United States Constitution, from the Library of Congress to their permanent home in the National Archives Building.

NEVER has it been so difficult as in 1952 to trace the main trends in French literature. In almost every other period French writers have grouped themselves in schools. At the beginning of the century the classic writers opposed the romantic: then came the naturalists and the symbolists, and between the two wars we came to know the populists and the surrealists.

Six of the seven industry members of the regional Wage Stabilization Board, covering New York and northern New Jersey, announced yesterday that despite their disagreement with President Truman's decision in granting a $1.90 daily increase to coal miners, they would not resign.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- State Department officials said today that they could not be sure of the exact terms for United States aid on which the Indonesian Government had announced "agreement in principle."

ON persimmon trees from the Midsouth to the Gulf Coast the brown fruits hang mellow and sweet until the snows, sometimes until spring. Small boys and cattle well know where this fruit grows largest and sweetest. Yet the delicious American persimmon (Diospyros virginiana) is almost unknown to markets.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- Attorney General James Patrick McGranery is acting these days, in the opinion of some observers, more like a man who has a permanent job than one who knows almost to the minute when he will be out of work.

EARLY this month the National Midcentury Committee for Children and Youth released to the press findings of a survey it had conducted throughout the country on what teenagers consider the biggest problems facing them today.
Brooklyn College's basketball team dropped its first game of the season tonight, bowing to St. Peter's of Jersey City, 71 -- 63.

NEWARK, Dec. 13 -- One hundred and fifty practicing pharmacists in this area and about 100 Rutgers University undergraduate students in pharmacy completed today the first phase of a three-part course in the treatment of injuries resulting from atomic, chemical and bacteriological warfare.

CHICAGO, Dec. 13 (UP) -- Housewives rejoiced in falling meat prices today and bought pork roasts for as little as 29 cents a pound. The price of middle grade beef also fell in many retail stores on the heels of sharp wholesale price cuts.

BERLIN, Dec. 13 -- Predictions of a purge in the Soviet zone of Germany flew thick and fast this week. In the wake of the call by the East German Communists for a weeding out of "American agents" in their midst, Supply Minister Karl Hamann and his deputy were suspended for allowing "criminal" elements to operate within their ministry.

THIS is described as a "book of unconventional sermons" for people who are "doubtful that religion can do anything to help them but who very much wish that it could." The author is minister of All Souls' Unitarian Church in Washington, D. C., and author of a number of other books.
An Army officer was killed and three youths were injured yesterday as a result of a two-car crash at the intersection of Drumgoole and Jefferson Boulevards in Annadale, S. I.

My mother has sent me the Oct. 26 issue of THE TIMES Magazine in which I was very surprised and happy to see my picture on the cover. I am sure your picture display "Story of a Soldier," helped people to understand what a soldier has to go through before he gets to Korea.

WHEN the young son of the house mows the lawn he is very likely unaware that he is helping to preserve one of the most necessary forms of plant life. If, however, he dips into "Grass: Our Greatest Crop" he will soon learn what a vital part grass plays in supplying him with food and clothing.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., Dec. 13-- Members of the Herreshoff "S" Class of Long Island Sound held their annual dinner and awards presentation at the Larchmont Yacht Club tonight to mark the successful completion of the fourteenth season since the L. I. S. fleet was re-activated.
The Citizens Traffic Safety Board is ready to open an aggressive campaign to relieve traffic "chaos," Percy C. Magnus, president, asserted yesterday.

Despite a perennial challenge from the forces of violence to the supporters of spiritual ideals "we must have faith in God and faith in the potential goodness of every human being," Rabbi Louis C. Gerstein said in a sermon yesterday morning at the Spanish and Portuguese Synagogue. Central Park West and Seventieth Street.

IT would be difficult for the Woodrow Wilson Foundation to find a more appropriate subject for study or a more competent group of professionals to carry through such a think-piece as this one on the adequacy of our eighteenth-century Constitution and our structure of government to the demands of global crisis.
Theodore W. Kheel is not likely to accept redesignation as impartial chairman of the private transit industry when his contract expires on Dec. 31.

The East Side House Settlement at 540 East Seventy-sixth Street will be aided by the premiere performance of the Hollywood Ice Revue on Jan. 15 at Madison Square Garden. The funds realized will further the work of the beneficiary and its affiliates, the Winifred Wheeler Day Nursery and the Stepney Camp at Botsford, Conn., which have aided needy and underprivileged families in the Yorkville district of the city for many years.

Mrs. Margaret Sanger, who has become accustomed to opposition in her life-long struggle to establish birth control methods throughout the world, returned yesterday from conferences in India and Japan mildly surprised at one fact: No one had asked her to leave.

The 1953 campaign for $2,265,000 to support the Union of American Hebrew Congregations and the Hebrew Union College-Jewish Institute of Religion will be led by Louis Broido, executive vice president of Gimbel Brothers, Inc. In connection with the campaign, a dinner will be held Jan. 7 in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel to mark the eightieth anniversary of American Reform Judaism.

A LAYMAN venturing into the world of patented inventions is likely to become lost at first in the mazes of transistors, slurries, esters and mercaptans that only engineers and patent lawyers really understand. But if he persists he is sure to find certain definite rewards, such as the alarm that rings when the bath water gets too high and the rocking chair that operates a music box.
NEW ORLEANS, La. -- A year-long series of festivals will be launched here on Jan. 1 to celebrate the 150th anniversary of the Louisiana Purchase.
The National Football League will reach the end of its seventy-two game regular schedule today without advance assurance that either of its divisional races will be settled.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 13 -- Doug Ford, the Harrison, N. Y. pro with a record for golf tournament consistency, picked up a stroke today in his duel with Jack Burke, Houston, Tex., for the first prize in the $10,000 Miami open.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 13 -- The Asian-Arab bloc opened discussion of the Moroccan question in the United Nations General Assembly's Political and Security Committee today.

Guido Cantelli showed his versatility late yesterday afternoon in his third program of the season with the N. B. C. Symphony at Carnegie Hall, for he led the orchestra with equal grasp through two entirely different works. One was Bartok's Music for Strings, Percussion and Celeste, the other was Mozart's Symphony No. 29 in A major.

County Court Judge Samuel S. Leibowitz suspended the perjury sentence of a Brooklyn dock union official yesterday and ordered a police guard assigned to him after he had agreed to come before the Kings County rackets grand jury tomorrow and to testify fully about waterfront conditions.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 (UP) -- The Presidential electors will cast ballots in all forty-eight states Monday, ratifying what the more than 60,000,000 voters decreed in the general election Nov. 4 -- that General Eisenhower and Senator Nixon were their popular choices.

The usual pre-Christmas rush for fast-selling goods was noted in the wholesale markets here last week, according to Kirby, Block Co., Inc., resident buying office. Many buyers were completing purchases for January sales and placing orders for spring dresses and coats.

CLOCKWORK efficiency and precision achieved on the basis of experience enabled the United Nations Postal Administration to solve last week a problem posed by American and foreign collectors of stamps and "first-day of issue" covers.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- President Truman had a Wage Stabilization Board ready to function tonight but it lacked any representatives of industry in its make-up.

PRINCETON, N. J., Dec. 13 -- Fordham's young basketball team, looking more impressive with each start, registered its fourth straight victory tonight. The victim, by a 76-61 score, was Princeton, last year's Eastern Intercollegiate League champion.

HARRY BAKER, who once relieved a United States Secret Service chief of his watch, has some expert advice to offer women shoppers during the Christmas rush. Mr. Baker's interest in picking pockets, while professional, is legal.

CHARLES ERWIN WILSON welcomed the confusion a few weeks ago when some newspaper readers -- and not a few editors -- got the impression that the C. E. Wilson about to be tapped for Secretary of Defense by President-elect Eisenhower was Charles Edward Wilson, former Director of Defense Mobilization. "He has been quite a protection to me," said Charles Erwin, speaking of Charles Edward.
A call to the shipping industry to free itself of criminal influence was made yesterday by a young maritime executive prominent in civic and merchant marine affairs.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 13 -- A father and son were held for questioning today in the slaying Oct. 10 of a grocer and three small children at Chester, a lumber town in the Feather River country.

LONDON, Dec. 13 -- What the Americans are supposed here to call grid football was played for several hours this afternoon at Wembley Stadium in gathering darkness. The match was a contest between two large groups of helmeted, padded sportsmen attached to the United States Air Forces in Europe.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., Dec. 13 -- Since the British Navy gave Michael Lewis Hatcher a "genuwine cutlass and spyglass" last September, the 9-year-old Cub Scout does not know what will be added to his collection of historic relics by Christmas.

Many boxes and seats have been purchased for the performance of "Rigoletto," with Lily Pons, Giacinto Prandelli, and Leonard Warren in the leading roles, on Thursday night at the Metropolitan Opera House for the benefit of the Free Milk Fund for Babies, Inc., of which Mrs. William Randolph Hearst is founder and president.

THE conquest of China is one of the great case histories of international communism. It is hard to exaggerate the importance of anything that helps us to understand it, if only because the same strategy and techniques, and, indirectly, some of the same men, are being used to achieve the same ends in the rest of Asia.

Any reader who has looked at even a dozen cases from the Hundred Neediest can't help but see running through them all, holding each separate pattern from tearing into meaningless patches, the white thread of hope and the red thread of the urge to live. Not all the threads touch.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- Herbert Brownell Jr., who will be Attorney General in the Eisenhower Administration, said this evening that he would confer on Monday with Chief Justice Fred M. Vinson and other members of the United States Supreme Court on the selection of a Solicitor General and other matters pertaining to the relationships between the Justice Department and the high tribunal.

IT'S true what they say in the travel folders re Virgin Islands. For me, no veteran tourist, it is a highly satisfactory visit. I got the change of scenery the doctor ordered, forgot the election excitement, the creeping bronchitis, etc.

Distribution of a product is becoming more and more of a factor in locating a plant or warehouse, it was asserted last week by Leonard C. Yaseen, senior partner in Fantus Factory Locating Service, plant locating counselor of New York and Chicago.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 13 -- Appropriations totaling $1,246,200 for three major United Nations organs during 1953 were approved today by the General Assembly's Administrative and Budgetary Committee.

CHICAGO, Dec. 13 -- There is growing indication the Big Ten will renew its Rose Bowl football pact with the Pacific Coast Conference, a confidential Associated Press poll of high conference officials disclosed today.

The twenty-first annual dance under the auspices of Groton and St. Mark's Schools for the benefit of their summer camps will be held on Friday in the Jade Suite of the Waldorf-Astoria. John B. Morrell of St. Mark's and Franklin B. Conlan of Groton are undergraduate chairmen of the benefit committee.

THIS is an unusually generous omnibus: one short story, one novel of the short length common in detective and science-fiction stories, and one novel, full length by any standards, none of them published before in book form, and all of high quality.

OMAHA, Neb., Dec. 13 -- Dr. Howard A. Rusk, Director of the Institute of Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation, New York University-Bellevue Medical Center, was named today the 1952 winner of the Dr. C. C. Criss Award of $10,000 and a gold medal, in recognition of his work in rehabilitating the physically handicapped.

Preventive maintenance for cars, trucks and buses will be stressed at the third annual National Transport Vehicle Show and Fleet Maintenance Exposition scheduled For Feb. 25 to 28 at the 212th Regiment Armory, it was announced last week by H. Franklin Turner, chairman of the Automotive Transport Trades Council sponsoring the event.
SAN FRANCISCO -- More than $1,000,000 has been invested in new facilities and accommodations at California winter resorts, in preparation for the official opening of a new season this week.
Central America, an area often neglected by United States exporters, is showing signs of new and stable economic progress offering prospects for increased trade and investment.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla. -- U. S. 1 between Jacksonville and Miami carries by a considerable margin the heaviest flow of motor traffic of any highway in Florida. Twelve miles below Jacksonville the winter peak is 6,301 cars a day, of which 51.1 per cent are from out-of-state.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 (UP) -- The Agriculture Department warned consumers today not to expect general cuts in retail food prices next year despite a forecast of record production.

IN the Arctic, more than anywhere else in the world, meat is a necessity for survival. Today the North American Eskimos and Indians who inhabit the Barren Lands of Canada's western Arctic are apprehensive.

Two items in yesterday's news were disturbing to many of us because they seemed to indicate that something was wrong with the universe. In the first place, an astronomer named Dr. Seth B. Nicholson, operating at the Mount Wilson and Palomar Observatories, has found a new moon of Jupiter, the twelfth.

Dr. Harry J. Carman, whose failure to be reappointed to the Board of Higher Education by Mayor Impellitteri touched off a storm of protests, urged yesterday that future appointments be given to men of ability, "not just to persons who like to tell their friends they are members of the board."

The article entitled "Will the A-Bomb Be Used in Another War?" (Nov. 30) by C. N. Barclay is typical of the thinking of the day. The author is quite sure that it will not be used, but that if it is the Western Powers will not be the aggressors.

ALONE in an open cockpit, his senses reeling from gasoline fumes, his goggles smeared with oil, the pilot searched frantically for the pylon. That was air trophy racing forty years ago -- and here is its history right up to the screaming jets of 1951. Aviation owes much to the air races, for they served as a continual stimulant to progress.

THE play which turned a nice quiet young woman named Lillian Hellman into one of the best-known modern playwrights -- "The Children's Hour" -- again comes to life in all its tragic fascination Thursday night at the Coronet.

UNHESITATINGLY the Hill children welcomed Bucky Moran to their Virginia plantation house, although the lame boy arrived during their parents' absence. That the children were right, Mother and Father agreed. Later the whole hospitable family was puzzled. Bucky's dodging of their natural questions, his avoidance of visitors perplexed the children.

LAST week's criminous Best-of-1952 list covered only the novel. This week we'll survey the adjacent fields-in which the year's highpoints are as high as the most captious critic could possibly demand.

A MONTH'S tour of the lower Caribbean shows that below the Virgin Islands the Antillean crescent is still little known to American tourists. That half-moon of Dutch, British and French islands, well-serviced by plane, is at the beginning of a tourist boom.

IT IS the season, of course, for decking the halls with holly. But it is also the season for exhibitions of religious art. There are several such shows and taken together they are at once provocative and bewildering.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- The Evening Star of Washington next Tuesday will become the first newspaper in the capital to celebrate a centennial.

MANY film producers have dived headlong into television, but Richard de Rochemont is tiptoeing with caution. An old newsreel man and former producer of the "March of Time" series, he wants to make films of a serious nature in his own special way. He isn't sure he'll be successful.

NOT so long ago an elderly woman, a guest at my hotel, stopped at the desk early one morning and apologetically asked the desk clerk, "Will it be all right if I don't make my bed till I get back? I overslept and have to hurry to a meeting."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 (UP) -- When Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower and his wife take over as the nation's first family on Jan. 20 they will inherit a fleet of automobiles of the kind most Americans only dream about.
ATLANTA, Dec. 13 -- Southeastern Conference officials voted today to permit freshmen to engage in varsity athletics for another year.

Records of French Christmas carols, cantatas and pastorales made from tape recordings of performances in France only a week ago will be played at the monthly recorded concert at 8:15 P. M. on Wednesday at the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street.

IN France, the Catholic novelist and Nobel Prize winner Francois Mauriac, who is known for his acid pen, was asked if he had read Jean-Paul Sartre's latest Existentialist novel. "I had great pleasure in reading it." he replied, then paused and added: "and in finding that it was extremely bad."

Harry Schwartz in "Stalin's 'New Asia'" (Nov. 30) mentions the cold and undeveloped land of Siberia. He blunders in thinking that climate and under-development will deter the Russian people from turning that vast land-mass into useful, habitably living space.

AN Egyptian writer, Albert Cossery explores in his short second novel a rich, essentially comic level of Egyptian life; this is a preposterous yet spell-binding tale of a house that went to sleep and took its inhabitants with it. Mr. Cossery creates an exotic and subtle society immersed in ancient wisdoms and matter-of-fact satisfactions.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 13 -- France disclosed today that she would call next week for an investigation of the men and the methods used by the United Nations Trusteeship Department in missions to overseas territories. Leon Pignon, French representative on the Trusteeship Council, said objections had been raised by France, Britain and Belgium to "undesirable" United Nations personnel.

ATLANTA, Dec. 13 -- The Southern Regional Conference on Educational Television today approved recommendations designed to foster regional cooperation in the establishment and operation of educational television stations in fourteen Southern States.

SEATTLE, Dec. 13 -- A major farm meeting this week indicated that the Republican Administration of Gem Dwight D. Eisenhower, the President-elect, might have as much of a fight over farm policy as the Truman Administration had.

Two Jewish leaders underscored last night the precarious position of 2,500,000 Jews in Soviet Russia and in satellite nations and declared that American Jews must play the dominant role in effecting "the release of as many Jews as possible at whatever the cost in money and effort and whatever the risk involved."

French North Africa is a massive colonial block running 1,000 miles across the top of Africa from the Atlantic to the Libyan desert. In the center is Algeria, the coastal belt of which is part of metropolitan France. Flanking Algeria are two protectorates: Morocco on the west; Tunisia on the east.

TOMORROW, to no gasps of surprise whatever, Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower and Senator Richard M. Nixon will be elected President and Vice President of the United States by a vote of 442 to 89. This, of course, will be the post-factum doings of the Electoral College going through its Constitutional paces for the forty-second time in 164 years -- and serving to remind the voter that he balloted for a slate of middlemen.

THE close link between French and American Impressionists appears most strongly in the robust and charming art of Childe Hassam, a selection of whose water-colors is at the Milch Galleries. Monet's investigations of light meant much to Hassam but the American's response to the visible world was far less detached and scientific.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 13 -- Michael J. Quill, president of the Transport Workers Union. C. I. O., bowed tonight to a court order forbidding 10,800 unionized employes of the Philadelphia Transporartation Company from going on strike at midnight tomorrow.

Mayor Vincent R. Impellitteri's search for new sources of revenue to balance New York City's mounting municipal expenditures and the dissatisfaction of Western Governors with the amounts of Federal highway giants have focused attention again on the rivalry among Federal, state and local governments in the field of taxation.

THIS model of assiduous research and unerring editorial judgment is quite likely the best anthology of science-fantasy stories to be published this year. Why? Primarily, because Miss Merril is one of those few editors with a planned program of operations -- a species, by the way, that is rapidly becoming extinct.

RUNNING through the stories of the Neediest is a single theme, repeated over and over again: It is terrible loneliness. When trouble besets those of us who are in more fortunate circumstances, there are relatives we can turn to or friends on whom we can count. But the Neediest are utterly alone -- in a city of 8,000,000.

MIDWAY, Utah -- For more years than the oldest Mormon settlers of this tiny community, sixty miles from Salt Lake City, can remember, white men and redmen have been coming to "Schneitter's Hot-Pots" to gape at bubbling pools of 98-degree water, and to dunk in the naturally heated tubs or "pots" of aqua pura.

TWO recordings of Donizetti's Don Pasquale have arrived almost simultaneously. One was made for Westminster in Vienna, under the direction of Argeo Quadri, the other is a release by Urania made in Milan, under the baton of Armando La Rosa Parodi (both on two disks).

The best season of winter sports in more than a decade and a half is anticipated for 1952-53. Glowing accounts of improvements and additions on a major scale from the Atlantic to the Pacific Coast, with new chair and Alpine lifts, trails and slopes and ski schools, are whipping up the enthusiasm of an estimated 3,000,000 skiers in the United States.

The Port of New York Authority expects to increase the volume of cargo handled at its Port Newark terminal from about 500,000 tons, to more than 1,000,000 tons a year after construction of three new terminal buildings and a new wharf on the southeast side of Port Newark channel.

Final quarter profits are expected to be the best for any three-month period this year for the nation's manufacturers, but it is indicated that the twenty-one-month downtrend in earnings is likely to be checked only temporarily. However, no outright slump is anticipated in corporate income so long as production, employment, national income and gross national product continue at top levels.

THE author of "The Great Frontier," Walter P. Webb. Professor of American History at the University of Texas, is not one of those compilers of antiquarian minutiae that are the bane of every intelligent reader.
WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Dec. 13 -- The Williams' College student body will vote on a proposed student goverment constitution Wednesday in a move to provide better representation on the campus.
AMERICAN television just now is acting as a powerful stimulant on the unsponsored B. B. C. brand. The most vigorous infusion has been hard-hitting controversy and frank discussion of social problems.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 (UP) -- The vast magnifying power of the world's largest telescope has pulled the moon so close to Earth, the National Geographic Society disclosed today, that lunar features no larger than the Pentagon are clearly visible.

CHRISTMAS is coming and the movie people are hoping that the box office will be getting fat. For several weeks producers and distributors have been watching with mounting concern a decline in business over what now are being recalled fondly as the lush days of June, July and August.
SUMMIT, N. J., Dec. 13 (AP) -- A new wrinkle in wrinkle testing has been developed at the laboratories of the Celanese Corporation of America.

BELGRADE Yugoslavia, Dec. 11 -- Yugoslavia unlocked another drawer of Cominform secrets today as a consequence of the current struggle against Soviet domination of Danube River navigation, which is base on a convention drawn up in 1948 with Yugoslav support.

MIAMI BEACH -- It sounds like an echo to say it again, but Miami and Miami Beach are all set for another big winter. Reservations are pouring in. Space is filling up. In fact it is already hard to get a room in any of the more obvious hotels in town for the early part of the season.
The most enthusiastic matinee audience in New York yesterday wore pink flannelette nightgowns, striped terry cloth bath robes, bandages, casts and other hospital regalia.

A BOOK about a Scoutmaster, eh? -- how sweet is revenge long delayed. Little did the editor reck that his reviewer thirty-five years ago tried for the Tenderfoot badge and failed, and all because a tyrant of a Scoutmaster refused to let him start a fire out in the woods and take the cooking test. Woods were too dry, said the Scoutmaster.

PARIS, Dec. 13 -- The probable conclusions of the North Atlantic Council, at the end of its meeting here next week, were foreshadowed in a draft resolution framed today by the leading permanent members of the Council, notably those representing the United States, Britain and France.

THE Bohemians, musicians' club of this city, will have a music critic as its guest of honor at its forty-sixth annual dinner at the Plaza next Sunday evening. Since the man chosen for this tribute is Olin Downes, who is completing his twenty-ninth year as music critic of this newspaper, it might be best, in the interests of modesty, to record the fact and to pass on to other matters.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 13 -- The United States accepted today a five-power Central American proposal for handling the question of admitting new members to the United Nations through study of the problem between sessions of the General Assembly.

TRADITIONALLY, the Bill of Rights denotes the first nine Amendments to the Constitution which protect the individual against Government encroachment on basic personal liberties. They became law on Dec. 15, 1791, 161 years ago tomorrow.

White shirts will be difficult to obtain before the year is over, manufacturers said last week. While the situation will not be as critical as immediately after World War II, Christmas buying Will consume retail inventories. Retail customers may have to shop around to obtain a desired brand or collar style when the Christmas buying "peak" arrives.

THESE three handsome volumes, the work of a Professor of History in Boston University, fill a curiously neglected place. We have had entertaining compilations of travel accounts by British visitors, and equally amusing and instructive compilations of the observations of Continental sojourners; but never until now have we had a really systematic book devoted exclusively to the writings of American travelers.

IT is as though Max Shulman's Dobie Gillis had graduated, read "How to Succeed in Business Without Really Trying," given his neurosis a tweak, and launched into the advertising game. The advertising game, which is getting a terrible kicking around lately, suffers anew.

LONDON, Dec. 13 (AP) -- Rain, snow and thunderstorms with winds up to 110 miles an hour gave Western Europe today a week-end foretaste of what to expect from one of the deepest atmospheric depressions recorded over the Continent in years.

YEATS was given to saying that political defeat, in the early Eighteen Nineties, turned Ireland inward, away from its then frustrated present into the escape of its large legendary past. Political success, in the Nineteen Twenties, on the other hand, turned Eire outward, away from the dreams of its past to the problems of its present freedom.

More than one hundred young women will be introduced formally at the Debutante Cotillion and Christmas Ball to be held on the night of Dec. 22 in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria for the benefit of the New York Infirmary.

ITHACA, N. Y., Dec. 13 -- Cornell's basketball team, outscored in field goals, defeated Colgate, 74 -- 71, in an overtime game tonight as Lee Morton made good four straight free throws in the last half minute before 5,000.

I ACCEPT only the first objection as correct. The statement in his preface that the records of the United States Senate Subcommittee on Internal Security had been available to him plus the fact that the dust-jacket describes him as consultant to several Congressional investigating committees, led me to believe he had worked for this committee.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 13 -- The Economic Council made known today a series of decrees that only one grade of flour be milled for bread and that prices be increased for flour, bread, milk and butter. Further such measures were officially forecast. Last month rents were doubled.
C. B. Palmer in his fascinating article "Why They Want to Go Faster" (Nov. 30) fails to mention that the dream and idea of speed is much older than the machine.

STE. AGATHE, Que. -- Building of a new $75,000 ski area at this town in the Laurentian Mountains, as well as extensive developments at Piedmont, to the south, highlight current preparations for what promises to be a banner season for winter tourism in the Province of Quebec's vast ski country.

BONN, Germany, Dec. 13 -- The West German economy has almost arrived at maximum employment of its effective labor force, according to the latest statistics. This explains in part the Germans' reluctance to migrate to the Western and other hemispheres and the unfavorable attitude of West German industry and Government toward the question of migration.

MANILA -- The Republic of the Philippines is deep in preparations for its first big world promotion effort, an International Fair which is to open in Manila on Feb. 1, 1953. It is scheduled to last three months, closing on April 30.

TILBURG, the Netherlands, Dec. 13 -- Robert Schuman, French Foreign Minister, declared here today that peace for the West could be safeguarded only by a union of former enemy nations stripped of individual military potential.
CHRISTMAS is a repetition of customs -- culinary customs in particular. We enjoy the foods our forefathers did, and the deeper their tradition the more flavor we seem to extract from them.

CAIRO. EGYPT'S five thousand years of history are divided for the little man in the streets of Cairo into before Mohammed Naguib and after. The Premier cannot move in public without attracting a jostling, joyous crowd crying "Mohammed Naguib, Mohammed Naguib!" Walk in the streets and his name is all around you in the conversation of passers-by.

There is little danger that the Nazis will take over Germany again, since 90 per cent of the people support democratic, representative government, John J. McCloy, former United States High Commissioner for Germany, said last night.

No enemy airplane dropped a bomb in the Bronx yesterday. Two hundred and three thousand New Yorkers were not killed. Two hundred and seventy-seven thousand others were not injured. The fifteen minutes of yesterday morning when we were herded off the streets in every respect as we would be if an enemy did attack saw the playing of a gigantic game.

WASHINGTON Dec. 13 -- The Atomic Energy Commission is finding business men highly cautious in approaching the development of nuclear energy for industrial purposes, according to a report issued today by the Congressional Joint Committee on Atomic Energy.

THREE dramatic scores will be given in concert form in Carnegie Hall by the Little Orchestra Society this season. The first of these, Berlioz' "L'Enfance du Christ," really more an oratorio than an opera, will be heard tomorrow night.

ALISTAIR CONRAD, a New Yorker of the twenty-first century, is hypnotized by beautiful Val von Rachin, an official of Unesco, into searching for the world's only telepath, Rene de Lamiter. Object: assassination. Thereupon follow sundry neckings, both of the amatory and homicidal variety, culminating, after thirteen murders, in the discovery of the disguised telepath in what was supposed to be a surprise ending.

Brantwood Camp in Peterborough, N. H., will be the beneficiary of the performance of "The Millionairess," with Katherine Hepburn in the leading role, Wednesday night at the Shubert Theatre. Mrs. James Russell Lowell is chairman of the committee of sponsors.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- The key question confronting the Special Committee of the House of Representatives, working on a revision of the election law, is whether spending done to win a nomination, as well as expenditures in the regular campaign, shall be regulated.

ST. PETERSBURG -- The incoming tide of winter tourists has started earlier this year than ever before along Florida's West Coast and bids fair to exceed any previous high-water mark. From every resort community, whether it be Tarpon Springs in the northern section or Naples or Everglades in the southern, come the same enthusiastic and hopeful reports by chambers of commerce, city officials and business people whose livelihood depends upon this seasonal trade.

OF all the historic mansions studding the highways leading south, none is more interesting, handsome and inspiring in its reminders of American history than Stratford Hall, the birthplace of Gen. Robert E. Lee. It is one of the two or three really fine houses of its period still standing in America.

GOVERNMENT CAMP, Ore. -- Complete renovation of the Pacific Northwest's most popular ski resort is the big vacation news here as leaden, snowy skies over the mountains promise a cheery season for winter sports enthusiasts.

JAPANESE film makers are set to produce dramatizations of the careers of its World War II heroes, General Tomoyuki Yamashita and Admiral Isoroku Yamamoto, it was revealed last week. According to Ray Falk, a Tokyo contributor to these pages and an experienced observer of the Nipponese film scene, the move is being made "in an effort to reawaken Japanese patriotism."
