Undergraduates of Yale, Harvard and Princeton have arranged the Guards Costume Ball, to be held on the night of Dec. 27 at the Astor Hotel. The fete will be attended by debutantes of this and recent seasons, as well as by undergraduates and alumni of various colleges throughout the country.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Dec. 13 -- Congress has completed the election of thirty-two members of the forthcoming Constitutional Congress, all of whom are Conservatives and supporters of the present Government. The Liberal party has taken a definite stand against participation in the Congress, which, they assert, is intended to amend the Constitution to strengthen the present hold of the Conservative party on the Government.
LONDON, Dec. 13 -- Americans who are planning to come to Britain for the coronation may like to know how costs over here compare with United States prices.

TWO distinguished American theatrical experts, Paul Green and Joshua Logan, have extolled the Kabuki theatre of Japan in these columns. They have said that artistically Kabuki is the first theatre in the world today.

GREEN TURTLE CAY, the Bahamas -- If an adventurous Palm Beach Crow were to set out some day and fly almost due east for about I50 miles, it would find itself over one of the most interesting island groups of the outer Bahamas.

THIS is an expansion of a radio play -- "The Odyssey of Runyon Jones" -- written by Mr. Corwin several years ago, about the time of his own odyssey, made as a recipient of the Wendell Willkie One World Flight Award.

PROBABLY the best solution to the photographic gift problem is to come right out with it and ask the photographer what he wants. Unless the donor is also a photographer and already knows the prospective recipient's desires, the surprise tactic is no match for the candid approach.

Carnegie Institute of Technology has received a grant of $30,000 from the Ford Foundation to finance an inventory of knowledge in the field of human behavior in business and other organizations. The study will investigate what is now known about the way people behave as parts of going organizations, and will attempt to point out gaps in knowledge that need to be filled for more effective planning and operations in such organizations.

H EHE we are, back again with the mystery of woras, about which I have often g-ritten. Two quotations used on this page, one prose, one poetry, turned my thoughts in that direction. Recently I spoke of skepticism as a two-edged sword; so too. of course, is language.
ITHACA, N. Y., Dec. 13 -- The college fraternity without a public service program is missing a chance to build a better community, according to the Interfraternity Council at Cornell University.
Yale had just scored a touchdown to take a 40-to-14 lead in the closing minutes of "the game."

MEXICO CITY -- More comfort and convenience for the traveler, whether airborne, train-borne or motorized, is the keynote of touring developments in Mexico this winter. In part the new facilities reflect Mexico's growing interest in becoming a highly frequented sunshine vacation land for the United States, and in part they are the result of the country's general progress.

BERLIN, Dec. 13 -- Michael R. Rothkrug, 44 years old, of Westport, Conn., has been arrested here in connection with the disappearance of confidential documents from a United States military intelligence office in West Berlin.

The head of the $35,000,000 American Palestine Trading Corporation bears little resemblance to a penniless seventeen-year-old youth who swung a pick and shovel building roads in Palestine thirty-two years ago.

THEODOR REIK has recently become increasingly intent on one specific aspect of psychoanalysis -- intuition. He holds that technical knowledge is insufficient; the analyst's unconscious must cooperate: "I still consider those insights most valuable that come as a surprise to me."

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 13 -- Michael J. Quill, author of a thousand New York transit crises, was re-elected president of the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., tonight under circumstances that disclosed a sizable revolt against his leadership inside the union.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- The key question confronting the Special Committee of the House of Representatives, working on a revision of the election law, is whether spending done to win a nomination, as well as expenditures in the regular campaign, shall be regulated.

ST. PETERSBURG -- The incoming tide of winter tourists has started earlier this year than ever before along Florida's West Coast and bids fair to exceed any previous high-water mark. From every resort community, whether it be Tarpon Springs in the northern section or Naples or Everglades in the southern, come the same enthusiastic and hopeful reports by chambers of commerce, city officials and business people whose livelihood depends upon this seasonal trade.

OF all the historic mansions studding the highways leading south, none is more interesting, handsome and inspiring in its reminders of American history than Stratford Hall, the birthplace of Gen. Robert E. Lee. It is one of the two or three really fine houses of its period still standing in America.

GOVERNMENT CAMP, Ore. -- Complete renovation of the Pacific Northwest's most popular ski resort is the big vacation news here as leaden, snowy skies over the mountains promise a cheery season for winter sports enthusiasts.

JAPANESE film makers are set to produce dramatizations of the careers of its World War II heroes, General Tomoyuki Yamashita and Admiral Isoroku Yamamoto, it was revealed last week. According to Ray Falk, a Tokyo contributor to these pages and an experienced observer of the Nipponese film scene, the move is being made "in an effort to reawaken Japanese patriotism."

MILWAUKEE, Dec. 14 (AP) -- The New York Knickerbockers pulled themselves together in the final five minutes to defeat the Milwaukee Hawks, 74 -- 69, today in their National Basketball Association game before 3,806 fans.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Dec. 14 -- The Belgian Post Office has stopped printing its new King Baudouin issue of stamps following complaints about the artistic license taken with the young ruler's features, it was made known today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (UP) -- Government officials said today that sweeping changes in the Labor Department's cost-of-living price index early next year would forge renegotiation of wage contracts for some 3,500,000 workers.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 14 -- On the eve of the Paris talks of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, the press here stressed this week-end the power of the combined Turkish, Greek and Yugoslav military forces.

BOSTON, Dec. 14 (UP) -- Boston's battling Bruins, fighting to move in with the league leaders, came from behind tonight to deadlock second-place Chicago, 2 -- 2, in a National Hockey League game before 8,578 fans at the Garden.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- The chairman of the Eisenhower-Nixon Inaugural Committee announced today that Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower would be inaugurated as the thirty-fourth President of the United States.

It was Darius Milhaud's turn last evening at the New Friends of Music concert in Town Hall. The eminent French composer, who is one of the contemporaries for whom the New Friends is playing host this season, appeared as conductor in three of his own works; the rest of the program also was devoted to his music.
MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 14 (AP) -- Jack Burke calmly sank a 10-foot putt to defeat Dick Mayer in a "sudden death" play-off for the top prize in the $10,000 Miami Open golf tournament today.

A generally optimistic view of progress in civil rights in the United States was expressed yesterday by the American Jewish Committee and the American Civil Liberties Union. These organizations made public the results of inquiries that they had made in conjunction with the celebration today of the 161st anniversary of Bill of Rights Day.

The 106th Bombardment Wing of the New York Air National Guard, which completed twenty-one months of Federal service, celebrated its return to state status yesterday with a parade and review at Floyd Bennett Naval Air Station, Brooklyn.

CHICAGO, Dec. 14 (AP) -- Quarterback George Blanda's 20-yard field goal and his 7-yard touchdown pass today enabled the Chicago Bears to snap a four-game losing streak and beat the Chicago Cardinals, 10 -- 7, in a National Football League finale.

Today, the 161st anniversary of its ratification, finds the Bill of Rights, along with the Constitution and Declaration of Independence, newly transferred from their shrine in the Library of Congress to the National Archives Building, displayed in a sealed, helium filled, filtered glass case which will protect them permanently from deterioration.

LONDON, Dec. 14 -- The Prime Ministers of Britain, Australia and New Zealand have reached agreement on "certain fundamental propositions" relating to the defense of the Pacific and Southeast Asia that will be discussed with the Republican Administration in Washington next year.

With the deadline for a threatened strike on the city's private bus lines only seventeen days away, company representatives and officials of the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., were scheduled to open their first formal bargaining sessions today.

CHARLEY JOHNSTON hasn't so loud, so persistent or so nagging a voice as had his brother, Jimmy Johnston, the unforgettable Boy Bandit. But the impudent and brassy Jimmy gave Charlie a liberal education in slick managerial maneuvering. The Boy Bandit, who changed his nickname to Venerable Vandal on his seventieth birthday, probably would have yelled more stridently and accomplished the job faster.

As time passes the free world is getting more and more reason to be thankful that Maj. Gen. Mohammed Naguib became Premier of Egypt. The presence of this one man in such a key position of power has made a dramatic difference to Middle Eastern affairs.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Dec. 14 -- Pakistan's air force bombed areas near the Khyber and Kohat Passes last week in an action against hostile tribesmen who, it is alleged, had tried to interfere with communications.

A strong drive for Federal economy and conservative financing measures was further indicated for the incoming Administration yesterday, when Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower announced three appointments to fill out the general staff of his Treasury Department.

The Very Rev. Hughell E. W. Fosbroke, dean emeritus of the General Theological Seminary of New York, attacked in a sermon at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine yesterday the credulous acceptance by great numbers of people of the "far-fetched charges of disloyalty which have been bandied to and fro."

Asserting that the number of policemen assigned to the city's vast park system was "far below any reasonable standard" for the public's protection, Commissioner Robert Moses asked yesterday for an over-all increase of more than 50 per cent in park police assignments and a 75-per-cent increase in foot-patrol coverage.
MANHASSET, L. I., Dec. 14 -- The Payne Whitney Memorial Cup was won today by the Philadelphia court tennis team.

Some of the best radio programming on this side of the Atlantic has been produced in the studios of the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation. The point was proved afresh at 1 o'clock yesterday afternoon with the debut over WNYC of a new series called "The Ways of Mankind," which could very easily take the seasons honors in sound broadcasting.

" Proud Kate," a new work by Ishbel Ross, has been scheduled for Jan. 7 publication by Harper. Subtitled "Portrait of an Ambitious Woman," the book presents a biography of Kate Chase, daughter of Salmon P. Chase, Lincoln's Secretary of the Treasury.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- Representative Frederic R. Coudert Jr., Republican of New York, said today that he would ask the incoming Congress to decide whether more than 100 business enterprises of the Federal Government should be returned to private ownership.

Dr. Milton S. Eisenhower, president of Pennsylvania State College and a brother of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the President-elect, has accepted the chairmanship of the newly formed American-Korean Foundation, Inc., it was announced yesterday.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Dec. 14 -- The State Council for a Fair Employment Practices Commission has named Robert J. O'Donnell, of New York, executive director. The council is a coordinating agency of fifty-one sate civic, religious, labor, veterans and human relations groups working cooperatively for enactment of a compuslory F. E. P. C. law in Pennsylvania.

This year the nation's Christmas Clubs are setting records. More people than ever before have set aside more faithfully than ever before, so that the joy of Christmas giving might not be diluted by the lack of wherewithal to pay for it. Average distributions, for instance, by mutual savings bank clubs were $86.11 per account, compared with $85.74 last year.

American-flag tramp ship operators, having exhausted all avenues of appeal for Government assistance, are pinning the survival hopes of their industry upon the incoming administration of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the President-elect.

Whoever first said that time and tide wait for no man might have added that problems do wait. Nobody knows that better than the statesmen assembled today in Paris for the meeting of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. The North Atlantic Council always has to deal with the unfinished military business of the preceding conference, and in an ever-moving political context.

The Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra under George Szell, with Erica Morini, the eminent violinist, as soloist, gave a Brahms program Saturday night at Carnegie Hall. This was, indeed, an evening of distinguished music-making, in the course of which Miss Morini won new laurels by her magnificent performance of the formidable violin concerto.

MOUNT VERNON, N. Y., Dec. 14 -- A bronze plaque was unveiled at the front door of historic St. Paul's Protestant Episcopal Church on the Eastchester village green here this afternoon to dedicate it formally as a national shrine of the Bill of Rights and the freedom of the press. The event, under sponsorship of the Mount Vernon Citizens Committee for Preservation of the National Historic Site, was attended by 150 persons.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N. Y., Dec. 14 -- Hitting the take-off vigorously on his flights of 161 and 158 feet, the longest of the program, Merrill (Mezzy) Barber, 34-year-old national open champion, today scored one of his most convincing victories over Art Devlin in winning for the third straight year the annual Torger Tokle memorial ski jump.

LONDON, Dec. 14 -- Members of Parliament are developing a rebellious mood. They have fears, not only for their own healths, sanity and solvency, but also for the reputation of Parliament and the principles of good Government.

The students and faculty members who were on the Manlius School campus in upstate New York on Wednesday, May 16, 1951, long will remember that date. It was then that the 37-year-old Dodge Gymnasium was left a mass of twisted metal and charred concrete as a result of a fire caused by defective wiring.

CHICAGO, Dec. 14 -- Long liquidation in grain and soybean futures became general late in the week, resulting in sharp declines. The renewed selling pressure was largely because bullish news developments failed to cause any important market response.

A special committee of the Twentieth Century Fund, consisting of university, business and labor economists, yesterday issued a report urging the adoption of a "flexible" program for "whittling down" the Federal debt and managing it to promote the nation's financial stability and economic progress.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Dec. 7 -- Prime Minister David Ben-Gurion asserted in an interview today that Israel wished to make peace with the Arab world and thus terminate their state of war. He said also that as soon as a settlement could be arranged his Government would be prepared to "start talks" with neighboring states on regional cooperation, including mutual defense arrangements.

VIENNA, Dec. 14 -- The Congress of the Peoples for Peace aims at bringing about understanding between the Soviet Union and the United States. Ilya Ehrenburg, Russian writer, said today. But by the end of the session, the third, all pretenses of such an aim seemed to have been dropped.
LONDON, Monday, Dec. 15 (Reuters) -- The Times of London said today President Truman had led the greatest peacetime revolution in policy in United States history.

It costs 13 cents more for New Yorkers to send a package to a service man in Japan or Korea than to a civilian in the same countries. There is also a 13-cent difference in the cost of mailing packages from the West Coast to service men or civilians in Germany, France or England.

Weskits are high fashion today. Recently reported in THE NEW YORK TIMES was the news that the well-known designer, Digby Morton, had fashioned a "coronation weskit" in needle point for Queen Elizabeth.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 14 -- As 1952 nears its close most steel interests look for a profitable operation in 1953. Some sources predict a falling off in total steel orders by June, 1953. In recent weeks considerable revision has been made in estimates covering an expected decline.

WORCESTER, Mass., Dec. 14 -- A white toy poodle from Long Island, Wilber White Swan, belonging to Bertha Smith of Bethpage, became best in show tonight in the annual event of the Worcester County Kennel Club.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- The State Department has looked in on the Jim Johnson family to show how they and their fellow-Americans would suffer without trade with other countries.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 14 -- National leaders of the Americans for Democratic Action pledged today to support Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower as President if he stands by his "liberal" campaign statements.

With the holiday period in the offing, exhibitions in museums and galleries continue to open in considerable numbers. The Museum of Modern Art will begin on Wednesday an exhibition illustrating the work of the group of Dutch artists, designers and architects known as de Stijl in the period 1917-27, together with examples by artists and designers of the present, indicating the continuing influence of the earlier group.

PARIS, Dec. 14 -- The United States Government has already set aside in its military warehouses and air depots enough equipment to supply the entire West German force proposed as a contribution to the North Atlantic Treaty defenses. This was revealed today on the eve of the meeting here of the North Atlantic Council.

Having ended all doubt that she is the top woman player in the world with her victories at Wimbledon and the nationals at Forest Hills, Maureen Connolly of San Diego, Calif., yesterday was named as the No. 1 performer in the 1952 rankings of the United States Lawn Tennis Association.

As you rightly stress in your well-balanced editorial of Dec. 8, "The Battle of Tunisia," the opinion that the United Nations has no right to meddle in the dispute between France and Tunisia is arguable. There seems to be much confusion surrounding the legal problem involved.

A Hoboken assistant hiring boss, who is slated to be an important witness today when the New York State Crime Commission resumes its public hearings into waterfront conditions, received a last-minute police guard yesterday as a result of threats against his life.

BERLIN, Dec. 14 -- Lieut. Gen. Manton S. Eddy, Commander in Chief, United States Army in Europe, demanded in a note to the Soviet authorities here yesterday that they release Second Lieut. Horace J. Sincore of the United States Army, who is believed to have been detained in the Soviet zone of Germany since Nov. 24.

The youngsters and faculty of a private school at Mountain Lakes, N. J., and a native of Vienna now living here who sent a donation in memory of his mother, a Nazi concentration camp victim, were among the 203 contributors who added $6,781 yesterday to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (UP) -- The Washington Redskins, rising to the heights for retiring Sammy Baugh, stormed from behind three times to beat the Philadelphia Eagles, 27 -- 21, and keep them from tying the Cleveland Browns for the division title.

A six-story apartment house for fifty families on plot 150 by 200 feet at 760 Hunts Point Avenue, the Bronx, has been purchased by Walter Berger and Leo A. Bercow, operators, from a client of Bernard Friedman in a deal negotiated by Mrs. Anne Inselstein, broker. Charles H. Kelman was the attorney for the buyers.

A panel of six youths discussed for an hour yesterday on The New York Times Youth Forum the question: "Is economic nationalism a challenge to peace?" Together with George A. Sloan, chairman of the United States Council of the International Chamber of Commerce, they agreed that it was.

The four-story building at 383-89 Lafayette Street and adjoining parcel at 24-26 East Fourth Street have been sold by the Hubbs Corporation, owner and occupant for thirty-five years, to a client of Stone Feller for occupancy. The main building is 80 by 120 feet.

A two-goal lead with only eight minutes to go didn't matter to the New York Rangers in their National Hockey League game with the Toronto Maple Leafs at Madison Square Garden last night. The Blues managed to avoid winning the game, just the same.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- Action on a backlog of 12,000 pay-increase cases was apparently assured today as the Economic Stabilization Agency prepared to put interim wage-control machinery into operation tomorrow.
In a recent edition of THE TIMES Arthur Krock speaks of the patent shift by General Eisenhower to the business world and the effects this will have on America.

Eugenia Snow, young pianist from Georgia, was heard in her second local recital yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. As yet her playing has not reached the level required of artists in this city's concert auditoriums. But though her work was exceedingly uneven, there were some difficult offerings at the close of the program in which she gave her most commendable performances.

The seventh week of the Metropolitan Opera, which begins on Monday evening, Dec. 22, will be marked by the premiere on Saturday afternoon of the Puccini "La Boheme" in an English translation by Howard Dietz. The production has been directed by Joseph Mankiewicz; sets and costumes have been designed by Rolf Gerard.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 14 -- A commercial forestry expert said today there would be plenty of Christmas trees this year -- because the fishing is good off the Atlantic Coast of northern Canada.

British sterling was on the firm side all of last week. Moving steadily upward from $2.80 1/4, on Tuesday, it closed Friday at $2.80 9/16, a gain of 5/16 cent over the previous week. Forwards hardened approximately 3/8 cent, with 90 days' at $2.80, and six months' at $2.79 3/8. Banks and commercials were credited for the strong undertone, which was ascribed to adjustment of year-end accounts.

LONDON, Dec. 14 (AP) -- Coronation planners sent another wave of military men through the streets of London today to determine what obstructions will have to be removed for the big parade next June 2.
WASHINGTON, Dec 14 (UP) -- More than half of this country's imports now come from neighboring nations in North and South America, Department of Commerce figures showed today.

The men's clothing industry operated at 69 per cent of capacity during the first ten months of the year, a decline from the 73 per cent of the like period last year and the 85 per cent of the corresponding 1950 period, according to the Clothing Manufacturers Association of the U. S. A.

Christmas motifs are utilized in some of the patterns for Yule gifts, which the home needlewoman might make for herself as well as others. Designed by the National Needlecraft Bureau, Inc., the patterns may be obtained free of charge by writing to Department W. D., THE NEW YORK TIMES, 229 West Forty-third Street, New York 36.

PARIS, Dec. 14 -- The Union of French Petroleum Associations in its report for 1952 gives an account of the present status of the industry. The report shows that the capacity for refining has increased substantially, that the French fleet of oil tankers is considerably larger and that a pipeline 250 kilometers long soon will link Paris with the port of Le Havre.
Herbert Seidman, former New York State champion and M. Boysan won their second-round matches and took the lead yesterday in the annual tournament for the championship of the Manhattan Chess Club.

An explosion on an oil barge in the Kill Van Kull shattered windows on Richmond Terrace and rocked buildings there and elsewhere on northern Staten Island early today. Two men were reported to have been burned.

TOKYO, Monday, Dec. 15 -- An estimated 300 Chinese backed by heavy artillery, failed yesterday to dislodge troops of the South Korean First Division from "Little Nori," savagely contested height on the west central front.
TOKYO, Monday, Dec. 15 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,464, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Monday, Korea time:

BONN, Germany, Dec. 14 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer has summoned the principal leaders of his Christian Democratic Union party to a meeting tomorrow in Bonn to examine the serious political situation that has arisen over the delay in the ratification of the Bonn convention and the European Defense Treaty.

Shareholders of the National Can Corporation have been called to a special meeting on Dec. 30 to consider the absorption of Cans, Inc., a can manufacturing and lithographing company with plants in Chicago and Warren, Ohio. The deal would involve issuing 130,000 shares of National Can authorized but unissued stock in exchange for all the capital stock of Cans, Inc.

OLEAN, N. Y., Dec. 14 (UP) -- Bill Kenville racked up 29 points today to lead unbeaten St. Bonaventure to its 43rd consecutive victory on its home basketball court, beating the Quantico Marines, 86 to 83.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- The Public Housing Administration moved today to remove an obstacle to the temporary financing of the $500,000,000-a-year low-rent housing program. It abandoned its insistence on the sale of notes of the participating local housing authorities at an interest cost of not more than 1.2 per cent.
Following are the formal statement issued by Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower on his arrival at La Guardia Airport today and his extemporaneous remarks, as transmitted by The Associated Press:

LARCHMONT, N. Y., Dec. 14 -- Corny Shields, steering Dainty to victory in the last of nine races on today's dinghy racing program at the Larchmont Yacht Club, captured the final regatta of the fall frostbite series by one point, with a total of 246.
LONDON, Dec. 14 (AP) -- British private enterprise is pouring $1,680,000,000 of new capital into this nation's nationalized steel industry to boost output from 12,750,000 to 20,000,000 tons a year.
WARSAW, Dec. 14 (AP) -- Polish newspapers published today a letter instructing all Roman Catholics in Poland not to take part in "underground activities and economic diversions."

We are happy that General Eisenhower is with us again here. In spite of all efforts to minimize danger the feeling of anxiety could not be avoided. We are glad, also, that he can speak to us with the sense of a mission accomplished. Making the trip was the right thing to do.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 14--Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer will have more than a casual interest in the Broadway fortunes of the forth-coming play, "The Tea House of the August Moon," starring Maurice Evans. The company has purchased screen rights to both the book written by Vern Sneider and the play adaptation by John Patrick, it was announced today by Dore Schary, studio chief of operations.

PRINCETON, N. J., Dec. 14 -- The names of the thirty-two men who have been selected to receive Rhodes scholarships as a result of this year's competition were announced here today by Dr. Frank Aydelotte, American secretary to the Rhodes trustees.

CHICAGO, Dec. 14 (AP) -- Marion Ladewig, averaging 204 pins per game, piled up 154.29 Petersen points to breeze to her fourth straight women's championship tonight in the wind-up of the nine-day national all-star bowling tournament.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 14 (UP) -- Little Frankie Albert, the fellow who put the "T" in the current football formations, bade farewell to the game today as he piloted the San Francisco 49'ers to a 24-14 victory over the Green Bay Packers.

Events tonight: "Carmen," Metropolitan Opera, 8 o'clock; Little Orchestra Society, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; Walter Hautzig, pianist, Town Hall, 8:30; Pauline Schlecta, pianist, Carnegie Recital Hall, 8:30; People's Chorus of New York, Plaza Hotel, 8:30; Frank Casseus, guitarist, Circle-in-the-Square, 5 Sheridan Square, 8:30; Collegiate Chorale, Hunter College Auditorium, 8:30.

LONDON, Dec. 13 -- The leaders of the British Communist party are striving desperately to halt the loss of members and funds since the recent Prague trial and executions. The anti-Semitic features of the treason trial have struck a more damaging blow at the British Communist party than any of the earlier purge trials in Eastern Europe.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Dec. 14 -- Argentina's decision to drop, at least for the present, measures taken against Uruguay for supposedly having recognized British sovereignty over the Falkland Islands has produced general satisfaction here. Uruguayans have always denied there was any ground for the Argentine action.

In days when punishment before trial and guilt by association threaten to supplant the legal philosophy on which our nation was founded, a Professor of Legal Philosophy at City College cannot calmly ignore the summary suspension of Prof. Nat Holman in absentia by the Board of Higher Education, before hearing, on charges which Professor Holman did not even see before they were delivered to the public press.

It didn't figure. It wasn't in the cards that the Giants, humiliated by Pittsburgh and upset by Washington in their last two games, could, in their crippled and undermanned condition, accomplish what they did against the Cleveland Browns yesterday at the Polo Grounds. Still, 41,610 fans, on hand for the season's finale, saw the Giants' greatest performance of the campaign, a magnificent 37-34 victory over Paul Brown's divisional champions.
CHICAGO, Dec. 14 (AP) -- Swift Co. today, reported net income of $21,698,147, equal to $3.66 a share, in the fiscal year ended Nov. 1, 1952.

ABERNATHY, Tex., Dec. 14 (AP) -- In accordance with the Scriptures, a group of farmers here brought their tithes into the house of the Lord today. What they brought filled two washtubs with $14,132.65 in cash and checks -- money from the harvest on the land they had dedicated to God last spring.
Three new films, including an importation from Italy, are scheduled to arrive in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:

LONDON, Dec. 14 -- While it is the opinion in the City that the Commonwealth Conference has been a success, it has accomplished nothing that calls for immediate reflection, either in the markets or in financial circles generally.

The Rev. William R. Woofenden issued a rebuke yesterday to twentieth century rationalists who reject the doctrine of the Virgin Birth as "unscientific." He preached at the New (Swedenborgian) Church, East Thirty-fifth Street between Park and Lexington Avenues, to which he came as assistant pastor in September.

CAIRO, Dec. 14 -- Col. Adib Shishekly, Army Chief of Staff and Syria's strong man, said today united Arabs could impose their will in their own region and in the troubled international field. "The map of the Middle East cannot be changel without the consent of the Arabs," he added.

An exercise boy at a race track who took money from friends in the paddock, placed the bets at the pari-mutuel windows and received a gratuity if the bet was cashed will be held to be guilty of bookmaking in a decision to be handed down today by Magistrate J. Irwin Shapiro in Queens Felony Court.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Dec. 14 -- The Indonesian Cabinet announced yesterday that it had taken several "important steps" toward resolving the rifts within the Army over its future leadership. Meanwhile, demands continued that the Defense Minister, the Sultan of Jogjakarta, resign.

Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower returned to New York yesterday from his 22,000-mile visit to war-ravaged Korea and voiced confidence that a satisfactory solution of the struggle there could be speeded by taking measures that would "induce" Communist aggressors to want peace also.

Christmas parties in offices, which in many cases "are nothing more than old Roman Saturnalias," represent only one aspect of secularism rampant in our nation to day, declared the Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell yesterday at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, at Fifty-fifth Street.
The National Executive Committee of the Socialist party has voted seven to three to run no more candidates for national office, it was learned last night.

As a local shopkeeper remarked recently, people everywhere -- from Texas to Brooklyn -- are making fruit cakes for sale this Christmas. Many of these products are available to New Yorkers; so many, in fact, that it is difficult to estimate the total.

Cotton prices in the domestic market moved over a fairly wide trading range last week, especially the nearer future deliveries. Daily net changes were irregular but declines more than offset advances and the market closed the week somewhat lower.

Jose Limon and his dance company presented the third and final program in their series of performances at the Juilliard Concert Hall Saturday evening. The program was repeated last night to close the season.

TOKYO, Monday, Dec. 15 -- Communist China has rejected formally the India-designed plan adopted by the United Nations in an effort to break the Korean truce stalemate and has demanded the United Nations urge the United States to resume the Panmunjom peace talks, the Peiping radio said today.

There is less activity on the two-piano frontier than there used to be. The old ensembles do not turn up with much frequency these days, and not many new ones are being organized. Vitya Vronsky and Victor Babin, who gave a recital on Saturday evening in Hunter College, comprise one of the veteran ensembles, and their playing demonstrated that they remain one of the best.

As Christmas shopping for children's toys goes into its last hectic days, sources as diverse as a university professor, toy shops and the local safety council offer suggestions to those who have delayed their buying.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 14 (AP) -- Gordon Soltau of the San Francisco 49'ers picked up six points by way of a field goal and three conversions today to capture the 1952 National Football League scoring crown.

A warning that 925,000 Jewish men, women and children over the world "may suffer a tragic worsening of their difficulties" unless American Jews give large-scale financial assistance in 1953 through the United Jewish Appeal was sounded yesterday in a resolution unanimously adopted by 1,200 delegates representing every Jewish community in the United States.

Standard Factor's Corporation, with heavy accounts in the financing of television manufacture and sales, radio, movies and in other fields, including book publishing, phonograph records and musical instruments, declared yesterday that television would not undermine the other fields.

Ross H. Smith of Cornell, Charles W. Havens of Western Maryland and Ivan J. Geiger of Massachusetts Institute of Technology were elected members of the executive board as the seventieth annual meeting of the United States Intercollegiate Lacrosse Association ended yesterday at the Hotel Statler.

The "proud who overestimate their own value, attribute everything they have to their own efforts and use their fellow men as stepping stones to further their own goals" were rebuked yesterday by the Rev. Vincent P. McFadden, Roman Catholic missionary priest who preached the second in a series of Advent sermons at St. Patrick's Cathedral.

HICKSVILLE, L. I., Dec. 14 -- Angry men and women and teen-agers pushed sand and topsoil back into the sump at Jade Homes, Inc., today, determined to fill it up before other Levittown children lost their lives playing near it.

Two persons were killed and fourteen others, including five firemen, were injured last night when a flash fire swept through a five-story brick apartment building containing twenty families at 31 Brooklyn Avenue, between Atlantic Avenue and Herkimer Street, in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn.

Princeton University and television station WNBT, owned and operated by the National Broadcasting Company, have created a joint project "designed to explore the problems and potentials of educational television."

ZURICH, Dec. 14 -- Brown Boveri und Cie, Motor Columbus AG and Elektrowatt, three Swiss electro-technical concerns, have taken part in discussions of a plan, conceived by Electricite de France and Verbundgesellschaft of Austria to exploit the vast latent hydro-electric power resources of the Austrian Tyrol and Vorarlberg, under which France would obtain yearly up to 2,000,000,000 kilowatt-hours of energy at a price lower than it now costs to generate power in France.

LONDON, Dec. 14 -- Discussions between Britain and Egypt on the constitutional future of the Anglo-Egyptian Sudan, which have been proceeding slowly and quietly in Cairo, have now reached the crucial point: the question of safeguards for the rights and interests of the south Sudanese.
In a dispatch from Bonn by Drew Middleton, dated Nov. 28, he refers to Ernst (Putzi) Hanfstaengl as a "well-known figure whose name awakens echoes of the early days of the Nazi regime."

TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 14 (AP) -- A high Iranian Government official, in a bristling parliamentary address today, laid most of Iran's woes to a policy "imposed" by United States Secretary of State Dean Acheson. He said American sympathy for Iran in the bitter oil dispute with the British had been nullified by Mr. Acheson's actions.

Experimental changes in medical education looking toward a more productive doctor-patient relationship and a better balance between specialized and general medicine are emphasized in the financial aid dispensed by the Commonwealth Fund. The annual report, just issued, shows that in the latest fiscal year the Fund appropriated $2,719,737.

Times Square belongs to everybody. It is one of the major showplaces of the city. Our millions of visitors from all over the world do not feel that they have seen New York until they see the Square. New Yorkers should be able to take pride in it.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 14 (AP) -- Propelled by the brilliant three-touchdown passing of Norman Van Brocklin, the Los Angeles Rams defeated the Pittsburgh Steelers, 28 to 14, today and climbed into a tie with Detroit for the National Conference title in the National Football League.

Plans for the reorganization of the RKO Pictures Corporation were released yesterday by Milton M. Gettinger, an attorney with important connections among banking circles interested in the motion picture industry.

Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, President-elect and outgoing president of Columbia University, got an impromptu serenade last night from twenty-two Barnard College girls who gathered after dinner around the front door of his official university residence, 60 Morningside Drive, and sang Christmas carols and college songs.

ELIZABETH MACKINTOSH, who died last February, was a Scotswoman who achieved a successful literary career under two pseudonyms. As Josephine Tey she wrote superior detective stories. As Gordon Daviot she wrote poetry, plays (including John Gielgud's great success "Richard of Bordeaux") and novels. Her last novel is about the greatest of all buccaneers, Sir Henry Morgan, and is called "The Privateer."*

The idea of the late J. M. Keynes for an international clearing union received partial recognition in the so-called Keynes-White Plan of 1944, which was a blue-print for the present International Monetary Fund. It is a somewhat ironic fact, however, that this particular version of Keynesian pump-priming was accepted to the extent it was, at a time when world conditions bore little or no resemblance to those it had been devised to combat.

The State of Israel $500,000,000 bond issue staged a special one-day campaign throughout the United States yesterday to focus attention on the sale of Israel bonds to enable that country to consolidate its economic structure.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- Some Government career men who have risen through the ranks to top policy-making posts, perhaps as many as 100 altogether, stand to lose their jobs when the Republicans take control of the administration Jan. 20.
William Ashworth of the London School of Economics and Political Science has written a book that keeps surprising you with: How much you knew, and how little you realized what it meant.

DELFT, the Netherlands, Dec. 14 -- With the endorsement of the national Government and the enthusiastic cooperation of municipal authorities, test referendums will be held Wednesday in this quaint pottery-making city and in the Frisian market town of Bolsward to determine the extent of Dutch support for a European federation.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (UP) -- Mrs. Anna M. Rosenberg, Assistant Defense Secretary, said tonight she believed Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower had learned "a great deal" by his visit to Korea.

MADRID, Dec. 14 -- An episcopal "warning" has been issued against what Spanish prelates regard as a danger threatening the Roman Catholic religion in Spain: the increasing popularity of Santa Claus and of "profane" Christmas cards.
After having been beset by problems soon after it went into rehearsal several months ago, "Two's Company," the revue starring Bette Davis, is scheduled to open at the Alvin Theatre tonight at 8 P. M.

AMSTERDAM, Dec. 14 -- The Netherlands Bank converted another 76,000,000 guilders worth of dollars into gold last week making total conversion during the last four weeks 328,000,000 guilders. Bank authorities are being praised by the financial press for this operation because gold is considered the safest asset today.
A two-month survey on drifting oil slicks off the southwest coast of England has just been completed by a yacht operated by three large oil concerns.

CHICAGO, Dec. 14 (AP) -- The Big Ten conference has authorized an expenditure of nearly $11,000 to give its university presidents a free trip to Pasadena, Calif., to help in their decision on renewing the Rose Bowl football pact with the Pacific Coast Conference.

A!ichigan Gas and E!ectrm Compa_ny has received permission from' the Public Service Comn!ission to pay a 3 per cent stock dividend, Payable m: Dec. 26 to holders of record on Dec. 11. Shares repre/senting fractions fi!! be issued to the Illinois Stock Transfer Company, which will sell them and distribute the proceeds to shareholders entitled to them.

The yellow and white lights of thirty tall Christmas trees were turned on after dark yesterday in the center plots of Park Avenue from Ninety-sixth Street to Thirty-fourth Street. At an interdenominational service on the avenue outside the Brick Presbyterian Church at Ninety-first Street, the trees were dedicated "as a prayer for the men and women of all faiths who died in World War II and in Korea."

" The religion that makes sense in this world of the atomic bomb is the religion that goes forward with common sense in one hand and the Bible in the other," the Rev. Dr. Fred C. Leining, superintendent of Universalist Churches in New York State, declared in his sermon yesterday morning at the Universalist Church of the Divine Paternity, Seventy-sixth Street and Central Park West.
DETROIT, Dec. 14 (UP) -- Detroit and Montreal battled to a scoreless tie tonight as the Red Wings retained their four-point hold on first place in the National Hockey League standings.

Production of plastics of the type used to make radio and television cabinets, small refrigerators, air-conditioners and the like is expected to be increased at least 50 per cent in 1953. Such an increase is possible with existing facilities.
It was quite some time before the head of the house was able to discover why getting ready for Christmas, 1952, seemed to be just a little different from the approach to Christmas, 1951.

In the face of the old myth about Santa Claus traveling by reindeer, 425 children of the city are ready to testify that he rides on a large red fire engine and that it gets him places well before Christmas.

PARIS, Dec. 14 -- Discussing the meeting of the North Atlantic Treaty Council at the Foreign-Minister level, which will begin here tomorrow, spokesmen for the permanent organization of the North Atlantic Treaty said today that the contribution of the fourteen member countries in 1953 would show a net increase in terms of expenditure and in terms of new military units formed.

The Port of New York's premier position as a major gateway for foreign commerce "may stand or fall" on the outcome of the waterfront investigation of the New York State Crime Commission, in the opinion of Edward F. Cavanagh Jr., Commissioner of Marine and Aviation.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- Republican leaders who came here for the Gridiron Dinner last night expect an announcement this week of the three civilian service secretaries to serve under the Secretary of Defense in the Eisenhower Administration.

The Ukrainian Congress Committee of America, the central organization of Americans of Ukrainian ancestry, has decided to recommend to Ukrainian exile groups in Europe that they cooperate fully with the Coordinating Center of Anti-Bolshevik Struggle in a common effort against the present Soviet regime.

Forty-nine groups whose blood donations in the last four years have amounted to 150,000 pints will receive special citations, T. Morgan Williams, chairman of the New York regional blood program of the American Red Cross, announced yesterday.

BELGRADE, Yugoslovia, Dec. 14 -- In a front page article in Borba, the Yugoslav Communist party organ, Milovan Djilas, one of the four principal party leaders, offered an analysis of anti-semitic motiviations in the Soviet Union and attributed an anti-semitic attitude directly to Premier Stalin.

The revolt of the Washington agencies, spearheaded by Commissioner Spingarn of the Federal Trade Commission and reported in THE TIMES of Dec. 11 and 12, centers on two things that should be distinguished: pressures exerted by interested groups on regulatory commissions via members of Congress and the undermining of public confidence in the regulatory agencies by open criticism.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Dec. 16 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower promised that "no effort will be spared" by his Administration to provide the United States fighting forces in the Far East with "everything you need."

DETROIT, Dec. 15 (AP) -- Quarterback Bobby Layne's fitness for starting duty in next Sunday's tie-breaking pro football game means the Detroit Lions will field their first-string backfield for the first time in eleven weeks.

MINEOLA, L. I., Dec. 15 -- Nassau County officials, spurred into action by the deaths last week of two small boys in a Hicksville housing development's storm-water sump, today started machinery grinding out severe building ordinance amendments designed to prevent possible recurrence of the incidents.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- The Supreme Court held unconstitutional today Oklahoma's law requiring state employes to take a loyalty oath on the ground that the statute did not provide adequate safeguards for innocent persons.
Fordham went on a second half scoring drive last night to overwhelm Wagner, 81-51, before 1,000 fans at the Fordham gymnasium. The victory was the fifth straight for the unbeaten Rams.

Endeavoring to offset as much as possible the production lost during the long mid-year strike, the domestic steel industry has maintained better-than-capacity production the last three months. The present gait is only a shade slower than October's all-time record pace.

There were no distress property transfers in Manhattan during November, according to the Real Estate Board of New York. In its monthly survey of forced sales, the board reported that this is the first time that there has been an absence of such transactions since it started compiling statistics on distress property conveyances in 1935.

ALMOST any fly fisherman, especially one who makes early-season fishing a tradition, could name plenty of waters that are "not" inhabited by trout. He therefore should have no trouble finding an adequate body of water for ice fishing, but to be on the safe side it might be a good plan to obtain a list of open waters from the state.

The proposed New York Coliseum at Columbus Circle was endorsed strongly yesterday by the New York Convention and Visitors Bureau. Recalling the bureau's long support of such a building, Bernard F. Gimbel, president of the bureau, said:

TRENTON, Dec. 15 -- The sixteen electors chosen by New Jersey voters at the general election, cast their ballots unanimously today for Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower for President and Richard M. Nixon for Vice President.

The 1953 summer field training program for the 26,000 Army reservists in the eight-state First Army area was the subject yesterday of a day-long conference of officers at First Army headquarters on Governors Island.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 15 -- A suit to recover more than $1,000,000 in corporate losses allegedly suffered by R. K. O. Radio Pictures due to the "reckless abandon" with which financing assertedly was advanced to independent producers was filed today in the United States District Court in Los Angeles.

PARIS, Dec. 15 -- Jean de Hauteclocque, Resident General in the French protectorate of Tunisia, is expected here tomorrow to confer with officials following his latest failure to persuade the Bey of Tunis, the country's nominal ruler, to accept all or part of the French plan of administrative reforms.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 15 -- Nikolai Skvortsov, the Soviet citizen whose dismissal by the United Nations was revealed last Saturday, was accused before then by the United States of trying to recruit assistance in attempts to ferret out some of this country's secrets.
The following excerpts are from testimony given at yesterday's public hearing by the State Crime Commission. They deal with political influences and gangster control on the docks of Hoboken, N. J.

Three new issues of securities having a subscription value of about $9,600,000 will be offered to investors today. The transactions represent new equity financing for a western natural gas company, a California manufacturer of scientific instruments, and for a rubber manufacturing business.
The Little Orchestra Society, Thomas Scherman conductor, last night gave the first of three performances of oratorios and operas it will give this season in Carnegie Hall.
TOKYO, Dec. 15 (AP) -- A $10,000 check from John L. Lewis arrived today in support of the sixty-day-old nation-wide strike of Japan's Federation of Coal Miners Unions.

Federal Judge Edward J. Dimock rejected yesterday a motion by counsel for thirteen secondary Communist leaders and refused to submit to the jury the question of whether the acts of the defendants constituted a "clear and present danger" to the Government.

Formation of a board for development, comprising sixteen New York business leaders, was announced yesterday by Chancellor Henry T. Heald of New York University. The board will help to run the university's ten-year program to raise $102,105,000 for buildings and endowment. Chairman is Charles R. Cox, president of the Kennecott Copper Corporation and member of the N. Y. U. governing council.
Long strides forward in the development of electrical typesetting devices were announced yesterday by Bernard Kilgore, president of Dow Jones Co., publisher of The Wall Street Journal.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, Dec. 15 -- Harold J. Adonis, former executive clerk to Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll of New Jersey, today began a legal battle against being extradited to New Jersey, where he is wanted on bribery charges.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Dec. 16 -- Sabre jets of the Fifth Air Force, patrolling over North Korea yesterday, clashed in ten brief fights with China's Russian - designed MIG fighters, and damaged two of the enemy aircraft.

Departmental trials were held yesterday in the Municipal Building for seven members of the Fire Department -- four officers and three firemen -- on charges of conduct unbecoming members of the department. Deputy Fire Commissioner Nathan C. Horowitz, who presided, reserved decision in all cases.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (AP) -- The Supreme Court probably will be asked to rule on whether the Federal Power Commission has jurisdiction over rates of natural gas producers such as the Phillips Petroleum Company.
TOKYO, Tuesday, Dec. 16 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,465, for the twenty-four hours ended at 6 A. M., Tuesday, Korean time:

TOBACCO ROAD was not peculiar to Georgia in the depression years. It runs across the world wherever the poor and ignorant live in squalor, misery and despair. In the twenty years since Erskine Caldwell's novel added a new phrase to the American language many other novels have been written about other equivalents of his celebrated rural slum.

We have read your editorial in THE TIMES of Dec. 8 concerning the St. Lawrence Project. In the past our association has taken no position with respect to the hydroelectric phase of the St. Lawrence Project. However, we have been deeply interested in the Seaway aspects for many years and have consistently been opposed to this feature of the project, which is of course the transportation facility feature as distinguished from the power feature.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (AP) -- Following is the text of the State Department's announcement today in the loyalty cases involving John Paton Davies Jr. and John Carter Vincent:

BOSTON, Dec. 15 -- The Government of Belgium today presented 1,000,000 francs to the Harvard School of Public Health in memory of Dr. Richard Pearson Strong, who led scientific expeditions to the Belgian Congo to combat tropical diseases.

A new organization for furthering our aid to Korea, the American-Korean Foundation, has made a strong choice in naming Dr. Milton S. Eisenhower as its chairman. Out of his long and wide experience he can bring to this work the contribution of sound judgment and good leadership.

Berkeley Bell of New York, the former University of Texas star who turned professional in 1936 but who was reinstated as an amateur this past summer, has been designated as the No. 1 veteran in the 1952 rankings announced yesterday by the selection committee of the United States Lawn Tennis Association.

SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Dec. 15 -- Led by Walter Dukes, who scored 30 points and set a school record for the third straight game, Seton Hall University downed Louisville, 77-66, tonight for its sixth straight victory before 3,300 at the Seton Hall Gymnasium. Dukes scored sixteen free throws for a new mark.
WEST ORANGE, N. J., Dec. 15 -- Authorities here are investigating a "flying saucer" type of disk that was discovered today atop a rocky cliff of the Orange Quarry Company at 318 Eagle Rock Avenue.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Dec. 15 -- The new presentation of Stephen Vincent Benet's "John Brown's Body," arranged for the stage and directed by Charles Laughton as a sequel to last season's "Don Juan in Hell," received its premiere in the New York area here tonight at the R. K. O. Keith Theatre.

After encountering more trouble than should be visited on any human being, Bette Davis has turned up in "Two's Company," which opened at the Alvin Theatre last evening. She is in good spirits and she gives a willing performance as the star of a Broadway revue.
The appointment of Dr. Robert S. Wilkinson, a graduate of Dartmouth College and the Harvard Medical School, as a police surgeon was announced yesterday by Police Commissioner George P. Monaghan.

UPTON, L. I., Dec. 15 -- Formal dedication ceremonies were held here this afternoon for one of the world's great scientific instruments -- the 2,200-ton cosmotron of the Brookhaven National Laboratory, a machine so powerful it can literally pick up the pieces after an atomic bomb explosion and start to put them back together again.
MOLINE, Ill., Dec. 15 (AP) -- A. F. L. printers struck today at four Quad-Cities newspapers, but the dailies pooled their resources and published abbreviated afternoon editions.

Commodity futures on the New York exchanges closed irregularly yesterday with coffee the only item showing improvement in volume over last week. Rubber, hides, potatoes and coffee closed lower. Sugar was mixed. Cocoa, lead, zinc, wool, cottonseed and soybean oils closed higher.

PARIS, Dec. 15 -- British policy is moving toward that of France in opposing the admission of a German national army to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization should plans for the European Defense Community founder.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 15 -- A suit in which Eli Lilly Co. is seeking an injunction restraining Schwegmann Brothers supermarkets from selling Lilly products at lower than fair trade prices was taken under advisement today by Federal District Judge J. Skelly Wright after hearing testimony and arguments.

Capt. E. V. (Eddie) Rickenbacker, president and general manager of Eastern Air Lines, announced yesterday that 84,000 of the company's shares had been taken by the employes under its 1950 plan for purchase at 15 per cent below market value and on a salary deduction basis.

A fair share of the Christmas shopping is unwise, of course, and it will be regretted deeply by noontime of Christmas Day. Take, for example, that small drum. In the window of the store or on the page of the catalogue the little drum seems the ideal gift for any young boy, one that he long will treasure.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (AP) -- The Michigan Consolidated Gas Company shared in a steel pipe deal in 1947 that cost an extra $1,819,000, but saved its customers $18,500,000, a Federal Power Commission accountant testified today.

CAIRO, Dec. 15 -- All Arab League governments delivered at noon today a simultaneous protest to British diplomatic missions in their respective capitals against British support of a resolution in the United Nations Special Political Committee calling for direct peace talks between the Arab states and Israel.

The State Bank of Albany, N. Y., which will observe its 150th year of uninterrupted dividends with a raise from $1 to $1.20 annually in its payment on Jan. 2, plans to increase its capital fund by approximately $2,500,000, it has been announced by Frederick McDonald, president.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 15 (AP) -- The sponsors of the annual pro bowl football game, featuring picked stars of the two conferences in the National Football League, today announced the selection of Cleveland's Otto Graham as the quarterback for the American Conference team for the game here on Jan. 10.

Results of a survey showing adverse effects of Brazil's heavy backlog of unliquidated commercial debts due United States exporters have been presented by the Commerce and Industry Association of New York to Brazilian and United States governmental officials, the association's world trade department announced yesterday.
A man who has been called the "crown prince of caviar" has turned his attention from that luxurious tidbit to a homely hot drink that is almost as inexpensive as caviar is costly.

The net profit of Distillers Corporation-Seagrams, Ltd., and subsidiaries for the quarter ended on Oct. 31 was $11,942,136, according to the report released yesterday. This was more than the $10,158,520 cleared in the 1951 quarter.

ALBANY, Dec. 15 -- More than 10,000 stock corporations which have failed to file an annual franchise tax report for three consecutive years were dissolved today by Secretary of State Thomas J. Curran.

PARIS, Dec. 15 (AP) -- British Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden and United States Secretary of State Dean Acheson discussed today a new move by President Truman's Administration to break the British-Iranian oil deadlock.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (AP) -- The American Public Power Association, describing itself as having a "friendly interest" in New York State's application to join with Canada in construction of a St. Lawrence River power project, urged today its "earliest possible development."
VIENNA, Austria, Dec. -- 15 (Reuters) -- Eight officials of a nationalized banking concern were brought to trial today charged with illegal currency deals in the amount of nearly $300,000.

Gifts in memory of the soldier dead, Christmas contributions from organizations and a year's savings from a little girl to help The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, were among the gifts received yesterday from 338 donors who sent $7,198.45 to bring the total of the forty-first annual appeal to $180,466.56.

Foreign aid programs and the unity of Western Europe were the principal topics discussed yesterday by Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower on his first full day of activity here since his return Sunday from a sixteen-day trip to Korea.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 15 -- The Soviet Union and Britain -- two of the Big Five nations, all of which possess the right to veto -- today opposed new efforts by the Latin-American countries to circumvent the veto on applications for United Nations membership.

BONN, Germany, Dec. 15 -- Samuel Reber, Acting United States High Commissioner, conferred tonight with Chancellor Konrad Adenauer. He then departed for Paris where he will report to Dean Acheson, United States Secretary of State, on the serious situation that has arisen over the ratification of Bonn peace contract with the Western Allies and the European Defense Community Treaties.

The Bahrein Petroleum Company, Ltd., a member of the Caltex Group of Companies, has formally notified authorities in Bahrein that it will submit to the decree levying a 50 per cent income tax, according to an announcement made here yesterday by the California Texas Oil Company, Ltd.

PARIS, Dec. 15 -- The importance of Britain's establishing organic links with the European coal and steel community was stressed in a statement issued after a conference here today between officials of the coal-steel pool and those of the Council of Europe, the consultative body of the Western European countries.

The stock market was forced to battle cross currents yesterday but still emerged on the higher side in an extension of the forward movement. The new upturn stemmed primarily from strength in the railroads, with considerable assistance from a selected list of chemicals, motors and metals.

CHICAGO, Dec. 15 -- Grain futures on the Board of Trade reacted after small rallies in the early trade. Buying was stimulated by the reported allocation of nearly $5,000,000 to Jugoslavia for purchase of bread grains.

Eisenhower headquarters in the Commodore Hotel delivered a gentle prod yesterday to the consciences of some staff members who had borrowed portable radios during the campaign and had so far failed to return them. James M. Lambie Jr., business manager of the Eisenhower staff, posted a notice which read:

Details of its "The New in Shoes" seasonal opening promotional program, begun about eight months ago by the National Shoe Institute, have been completed and the organization is urging all segments of the industry to cooperate.

The first concrete step toward a forty-hour work week on the city's principal privately owned bus lines was taken yesterday with an agreement by Michael J. Quill's Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., and two large companies to work out detailed operating schedules for use when and if contracts embodying the shorter work week are signed.
LONDON, Dec. 15 -- Quiet prevailed in nearly all sections of the London stock market today and prices drifted, although losses were generally small.

Hoboken's mile of waterfront was described yesterday to the New York State Crime Commission as a devil's playground of extortion, murder, labor racketeering and other crimes made possible by political-gangster relations consummated in the office of Mayor Fred M. DeSapio.

Back from a successful road trip, which saw them defeat the Royals at Rochester and the Hawks at Milwaukee, the New York Knickerbockers will be at home at Madison Square Garden tonight for a game against the Syracuse Nationals.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Dec. 15 (UP) -- State lawmakers stepped into the embroiled University of Arkansas athletic situation today with the idea of abolishing the office of athletic director at the Fayetteville school to help obtain Coach Paul (Bear) Bryant from Kentucky.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 14 -- The return of Miguel Miranda, former economic czar of Argentina, from voluntary exile in Uruguay has lifted the Argentine stock market out of the doldrums and has encouraged a flurry of reports that President Juan D. Peron soon may announce many changes in his Government.
LONDON, Dec. 15 -- A contract under which Britain will build 500 Centurion tanks for North Atlantic Treaty countries at a cost of $90,000,000, to be paid by the United States, was signed today.

Events today: Ponchielli's "La Gioconda," Metropoltian Opera, 8 P. M.; Leonardo Pennario, pianist, Carnegie Hall, 8:30, Concert by faculty members of Aspen Institute. Town Hall, 8:30, Harpsichord Quartet, Hugues Cuenod, tenor, Carnegie Recital Hall, 8:30; Judith Rasking, soprano, Alfred Medinets and Clifford Snyder, baritones.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- The State Department announced tonight the suspension of John Carter Vincent, veteran Foreign Service officer now assigned as diplomatic agent and Minister at Tangier, after President Truman's Loyalty Review Board had found that "there is reasonable doubt as to his loyalty to the Government of the United States."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- A House of Representatives subcommittee assigned last May to investigate offensive scenes, dialogue and advertising in radio and television programs reported today that there was too much emphasis on crime.

Proposals for reducing or eliminating United States tariff duties on numerous commodities not produced in this country are gaining support among foreign traders, and are expected to be advocated strongly in connection with renewal of the Reciprocal Trade Agreements Act expiring in June, according to trade sources here yesterday.
PARIS, Dec. 15 -- The North Atlantic Council formally opened today a session that brought together the foreign finance and defense ministers of its fourteen member nations.

GENEVA, Dec. 15 -- International migration experts here have reluctantly come to the conclusion that no serious dent can be made in Central Europe's overpopulation problem without the expenditure of a great deal more money than has heretofore been contemplated.

Working fast, Robert White-head accomplished three tasks over the week-end for his second production of the season, "The Emperor's Clothes," the new play by George Tabori. He engaged Harold Clurman as director, signed Maureen Stapleton for the feminine role and acquired the Playwrights Company as associate producer.

The Board of Higher Education last night granted budget requests from the four municipal colleges for next year totaling $22,778,118. That sum, greater by $1,955,190 than the allotment in the present fiscal year, is subject to approval by the Budget Director and the Board of Estimate.

Federal Judge David N. Edelstein refused yesterday to entertain an application by two independent unions for an order seeking to expunge a grand jury presentment filed Nov. 25 suggesting that the National Labor Relations Board revoke certification of the unions.

The so-called parity formula employed by arbitrator Paul R. Hays in granting a 17-cent hourly wage increase to East Coast longshoremen is "one of the most dangerous precedents ever imposed on the shipping industry," John V. Lyon, chairman of the New York Shipping Association, declared yesterday.

Fifth Avenue's fabled shops are again playing their major role in the pageant that is New York at Christmas time, with brilliantly decorated windows that delight the young and the old, the native and the tourist.

Andy Carey, rookie infielder who has spent most of his time at third base in the Yankee organization, will undergo an experiment in conversion this spring. The Yankees are looking to the day when Phil Rizzuto loses that extra step that has heralded the end of playing days of so many great shortstops before him.

When students of child development and behavior at the Institute for Child Observation in Paderborn. Germany, want to know more about a specific youngster's relationship with his mother, they may call at his home or invite the parent for an interview at the center.

President-elect Eisenhower has announced appointments to three top posts in the Treasury Department under its Secretary-designate, George M. Humphrey. They are Marion B. Folsom, treasurer of Eastman Kodak, but better known to the public as chairman of the Committee for Economic Development; W. Randolph Burgess, banker and economist, and H. Chapman Rose, a Cleveland attorney.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (UP) -- American business spent a record $26,900,000,000 to build and expand factories and buy new equipment this year and will spend even faster in the next three months, the Government reported today.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 15 -- A resolution on Morocco similar to that rejected last week by a close vote on Tunisia was proposed today by the thirteen Asian-Arab nations in the United Nations General Assembly's Political and Security Committee.
An overflow audience of 19,000 bought $2,575,000 of Israel Bonds to witness the Hanukkah Festival of Light in Madison Square Garden last night.

I have been following with interest the recent series of columns and letters concerning the fate of New York City's station WNYC. It is to be deplored if this station, performing as it does such a useful public service, is allowed to be written off the books as a luxury.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N. Y., Dec. 15 -- Top Hill Cottage, the "dream house" designed by the late President Roosevelt, was purchased today by Philip S. Potter of this city. Mr. Potter, who is an executive of the California Oil Company, said that he and his wife and son, Robert, would occupy the house as soon as it could be redecorated. The purchase price was not disclosed.

" Jefferson Reader: A Treasury of Writings About Thomas Jefferson," edited with an introduction by Francis Coleman Rosenberger, will be issued by Dutton on Jan. 30. The volume contains comments about the "many-faceted" Jefferson by famous contemporaries, little-known friends and acquaintances and by notables of later days.

Mrs. Hilda G. Schwartz, first woman magistrate appointed to the Brooklyn Adolescents Court, sat with the court for the first time yesterday and heard the details of a case coming before it on Dec. 29.
PARIS, Dec. 15 -- A 15,250-ton liner, destined for the Far East service, will be launched at La Ciotat, shipping center near Marseille, on Sunday, the Messageries Maritimes announced today.

OTTAWA, Dec. 15 (AP) -- Prime Minister Louis St. Laurent, in pre senting the Currie report to the House of Commons, said today that he hoped its "severe and sweeping statements" would not be taken out of context and used to smear the Army or its engineering works services as a whole.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (AP) -- Representative Joseph W. Martin Jr., Republican of Massachusetts, slated to be the next Speaker of the House of Representatives, said today that he thought the Eighty-third Congress should put the emphasis on legislation rather than investigation.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- The American governing system and the Constitution that established it are, of course, the noblest and wisest devisements of mortal man resolved to be born, live and die free, and away to the stocks and the village ducking-stool with him who disputes it.

The sisters and the cousins and the aunts who shop for clothes for children around Christmas time will find a fashion standard equal to their own. Fashion design does not begin with teen and junior styles but, by popular request, has invaded the toddlers' and first graders' field.
TRENTON, Dec. 15 -- The newly enacted business tax in Jersey City was attacked today in a Superior Court suit by four retail business enterprises.

Milton M. Gettinger of the New York law firm of Gettinger Gettinger said yesterday that he had prepared the reorganization plan for R. K. O. Pictures Corporation, published in these columns yesterday, at the instance of substantial groups interested in buying into the concern.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture said today it had purchased 1,586,837 pounds of butter since it entered the market about two weeks ago to support butter prices.

Attorney General James P. McGranery directed United States Attorney Frank J. Parker in Brooklyn yesterday to start denaturalization proceedings against James J. Matles for allegedly getting his American citizenship papers through fraud.

The shortage of acrylic fibers should be alleviated by early spring when production of Chemstrand Corporation's Acrilan fiber attains the planned rate of 30,000,000 pounds a year, according to Robert E. Smith, sales manager for Chemstrand.

The Brooklyn phase of the waterfront investigation gained impetus yesterday as Frank Nawrocki, 39-year-old business agent of Local 808, International Longshoremen's Union, A. F. L., appeared as a witness before the borough's rackets grand jury.
Directors of Emerson Radio and Phonograph Corporation and Webster-Chicago Corporation have approved plans for merging Webster-Chicago into Emerson Radio, it was announced yesterday.

An alcoholics clinic has been created in Home Term Court at 300 Mulberry Street to provide medical and psychiatric treatment for any person whose problem drinking threatens to break up family relations, Chief Magistrate John M. Murtagh announced yesterday.

A last-minute spurt in Christmas buying during the eight remaining shopping days may push volume of local department stores "close" to last year's record volume, store executives here said yesterday. Crowds in the stores were large yesterday, and reports were that there was an improvement in spending as compared with "looking."

BOSTON, Dec. 15 (AP) -- Ezzard Charles of Cincinnati, former world heavyweight champion, scored a technical knockout over young Frankie Buford of Oakland, Calif., in 2:13 of the seventh round of their scheduled 10-rounder in Boston Garden tonight.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Dec. 14 -- The Asker, or Turkish soldier, a hardy son of the Anatolian hills, who can live on a daily ration of a handful of olives, a loaf of bread and a piece of cheese, guards the North Atlantic Treaty Organization's eastern flank, the Dardanelles and the rugged ramparts of the Caucasus.

Plans were announced yesterday by the International Business Machines Corporation for a research center in Poughkeepsie. Construction will start early in the spring, with completion planned before the end of 1954. The purpose is to provide centralized facilities for the company's widespread electronics research program.

IT was a couple of hours after the Giants had achieved their spectacular upset of the Cleveland Browns at the Polo Grounds on Sunday. The players, coaches and members of the official family were relaxing, still aglow from their tremendous victory and savoring every piquant flavor. They had forgotten, perhaps deliberately, their own missed opportunities during the season.
The Graybar Electric Company announced over the week-end the election as directors of A. D. Hammond and J. W. Frazier, district managers.

Margaret Hillis, a slim young woman in black, conducted the massed choral forces of the Collegiate Chorale and an orchestra in an exacting program at the Hunter College Auditorium last night. There have been women conductors in New York before, but they are still rare enough to warrant special attention for any newcomer in the field.

BOWIE, Md., Dec. 15 (AP) -- Maryland wound up its racing season here today with Phil Godfrey's Elias G., a 10-1 shot, taking first money in the $4,000 Westover Purse. It also marked the end of racing for 1952 at the major eastern tracks.
E. W. Bliss Company announced a 20 per cent stock dividend and a quarterly dividend of 25 cents a share on the common stock, both payable on Feb. 2, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- The conviction of a pawnbroker who had conspired with thieves to rob the homes of wealthy persons was upheld by the Supreme Court today on the ground that evidence obtained by state officers by wire tapping was admissable in state courts.

MOSCOW, Dec. 15 (AP) -- Pravda warned Soviet citizens today that they ought to keep a close watch on the spending habits of their close relatives and tell the Government if any start living beyond their means.
ENCINAL, Tex., Dec. 15 (UP) -- A Brooklyn soldier and three fellow service men were killed today when their car struck a bridge abutment five miles north of here.

" Congress Dances," the German-made musical drama featuring Lillian Harvey, Conrad Veidt, Lil Dagover and Henry Garat, will be re-released early next year, it was announced by Noel Meadow, who acquired distribution rights to the import from the United States Alien Property Custodian.
CHICAGO, Dec. 15 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

ALBANY, Dec. 15 -- The forty-five New York members of the Electoral College gathered in the ornate State Senate Chamber today and spent an hour and forty-four minutes in the process of formally casting the state's vote for General Eisenhower and Senator Nixon.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 (UP) -- The Export-Import Bank announced today that President Truman had accepted the resignation of Herbert E. Gaston as chairman of its board of directors, effective Jan. 19.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- Judge James R. Kirkland ruled in Federal District Court today that the Anglo-Iranian Oil Company must be excluded from the Government's investigation of an alleged international oil cartel.

The State Department, trying to impress upon the public the simple facts about foreign trade, has dreamed up a character named Jim Johnson who, with his family, is living in a United States "completely isolated from the rest of the world." In such a case, the Department reminds us in its entertaining pamphlet entitled "Together We Are Strong," Jim and his family would be in a fix.

With the completion of strengthening work on its two trailerships, the American and Overseas Chartering Corporation is prepared to continue its Hudson River service to Albany throughout the winter, Hans J. Hvide, president, announced yesterday.

Ben Carnevale, the head basketball coach at Annapolis, served notice on Penn State, Pennsylvania, Maryland and Duke that the midshipmen were "gunning" for them. Speaking at the weekly luncheon-meeting of the Metropolitan Basketball Writers Association at Leone's yesterday, Carnevale said that Navy's undefeated twelve-man squad was potentially the best in his seven years at the United States Naval Academy.
