Republic Aviation Corporation is distributing a Christmas bonus equal to one week's straight-time earnings, according to Mundy I. Peale, president. The bonus will total $1,775,000 and will be paid to more than 22,000 employes who have been on the company's payroll since Nov. 21.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Dec. 16 -- Eighty-two prisoners were killed and 120 were injured Sunday in a new outbreak of rioting among Communist captives of the Korean war interned in United Nations stockades, the Prisoner of War Command announced last night.

ROME, Tuesday, Dec. 16 -- Thirty-seven American seamen were huddled in the stern of the freighter Grommet Reefer this morning awaiting to be taken off in breeches buoy. Nineteen hours earlier their ship had broken in half on Queens Rock, 150 yards off shore just outside the port of Leghorn, in one of the worst storms experienced in this part of Italy.

In his first speech since his designation as Secretary of Labor in the Eisenhower Cabinet, Martin P. Durkin, president of the United Association of Plumbers and Pipefitters, A. F. L., called upon union members last night to make the promotion of cooperative labor-management relations their prime concern.

" Carmen" had two Don Joses last night at the Metropolitan Opera House, for Brian Sullivan, American tenor, stepped into the part after the first act when it became obvious that Kurt Baum's cold had made it impossible for him to continue.
OGDENSBURG, N. Y., Dec. 15 -The controversial Gut Dam is virtually nothing more than a memory today as a Canadian dredging firm put the finishing touches on its demolition.

Planning for the future relocation of its banking facilities, the Manhattan Savings and Loan Association has purchased the six-story building at 1640-42 Second Avenue, northeast corner of Eighty-fifth Street, from Samuel Koskovitz. Hardy, Brauneis Naumann, Inc., was the broker and the attorneys were Burack Burack for the seller and Joseph M. Creamer for the buyer.

ROME, Dec. 15 -- A pulp industry based on tropical and subtropical woods and agricultural discards is a readily available answer to increasing world demand for, and rising prices of, paper and newsprint, according to a group of international pulp and paper experts who have been meeting the last two weeks at the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization headquarters in Rome.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (AP) -- A House of Representatives investigating group recommended today that a bitter and prolonged intra-governmental battle be ended by turning over to the Army's Corps of Engineers primary responsibility for the nation's flood-control program.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 15 -- Following are the texts of a message from Chou En-lai, Foreign, Minister of the Central People's Government of China, to Lester B. Pearson, President of the United Nations, in reply to the latter's message transmitting the text of the Assembly's resolution on Korea, and of a statement by the United States on the Chinese Communist's reply:

PARIS, Dec. 15 -- After a consultation with President Vincent Auriol, who is eager to avoid a Cabinet crisis, and after a conference with Cabinet members, Premier Antoine Pinay decided today to ask the National Assembly to defer the major votes of confidence he had called for Tuesday.

On his return from Korea General Eisenhower put special emphasis on one point -- namely, that we are in the midst of a world-wide struggle against Communist aggression and that the Korean war is, to us and at this moment, only the most dramatic and most painful phase of this global conflict.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio sounded out fellow Republican Senators today about the party's Senate floor leaders, and some of them believed he was anxious to get the post himself.

DETROIT, Dec. 15 -- The Republican Administration of President elect Dwight D. Eisenhower will act "with speed and courage" to advance the reorganization of the Executive Branch of the Government, the national chairman of the Citizens Committee for the Hoover Report predicted today.
Christmas parties scheduled by schools, hospitals, clubs and other organizations in the city will be largely for the benefit of hospitalized or underprivileged children.

ALBANY, Dec. 15 -- The State Thruway Authority revealed today it would be forced to substitute another design for the proposed Tarrytown-Nyack bridge superstructure because of the failure of any companies to submit bids on the original project.
The right of a corporation to donate money to institutions of higher education is being challenged in a stockholders' suit that has been brought against a New Jersey manufacturing concern.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- The Government's wage control program was turned over to a new wage stabilization committee today, and a few hours later its chairman announced that the one-week "log jam" in operations had been broken.

Wrecking operations are scheduled to get under way at once to clear the site for the two office buildings which Ivor B. Clark proposes to erect at 579 and 589 Fifth Avenue. Contracts have been awarded by the builder, the Diesel Construction Company, and work is to be started on 3 East Forty-seventh Street.

The fight to preserve the civil liberties guaranteed in the Bill of Rights and elsewhere in the Constitution of the United States is a never-ending one. Particularly during the past few years it has seemed as if the internal assaults against our traditional democratic liberties have been mounting under the external pressures of Communist Russian imperialism.

Your continued attitude of unfairness to President Truman -- evidenced during the campaign and more recently in connection with the Korean problem -- is saddening to one who has long been an ardent admirer of your great newspaper.
Colonie, N. Y., announced yesterday that it will receive bids on Dec. 23 on $1,851,000 of water bonds dated July 15, 1952, and due Jan. 1, 1953 to 1991.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower moved today a step closer to the Presidency a post that 34,000,000 Americans fondly believed they had guaranteed to him six weeks ago, as 531 Presidential electors met in their state capitals and cast their ballots.

OTTAWA, Dec. 15 -- A sharp indictment of the National Defense Department was containued in a report submitted to the House of Commons today on large-scale thefts by Army personnel at the Petawawa military camp.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Dec. 15 (AP) -- Representative Bill Shibley of Bristow, author of Oklahoma's loyalty oath struck down by the Supreme Court, said today that he would introduce a new loyalty bill in the Legislature next year.

NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 15 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru said today it was only after having obtained Communist China's approval to the basic principles embodied in the Indian resolution on Korea that New Delhi had instructed its delegation at the United Nations to proceed with the actual framing of the resolution.

A whole palette of shades, rather than merely the conventional reds and greens, has been utilized to color many of the new Christmas wrapping papers, some of which display contemporary designs based on traditional themes.

Mrs. Richard J. Reynolds, wife of the tobacco heir, retrieved yesterday from the Police Department a $7,500 diamond bracelet belonging to her mother, Mrs. Eleanor Littlewood Marston of Toronto, which was lost more than a year ago.

Charges of collusion between union and management in the longshore industry, which have been made repeatedly by dissident factions within the International Longshoremen's Association over the last few years, were renewed yesterday as the State Crime Commission released a chart detailing payments of $182,214 to union officials by stevedoring and shipping concerns.

As three specters appeared in Charles Dickens' "Christmas Carol," so too do three phantoms haunt the hearts and minds of today's needy. The infirm, aged, homeless and hungry are haunted by the specter of the past. This ghost of reminiscence recalls the better days when vitality and opportunity were in flower and when age and trouble had not taken their toll.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Tuesday, Dec. 16 -- An agreement to bring the General Zionist party, which favors private enterprise, into Prime Minister David Ben-Gurion's Government was approved early today by the Central Committee of the Mapai, the Prime Minister's party. The General Zionists' Executive Council was expected to approve the accord shortly.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (AP) -- Following are excerpts from the Supreme Court's opinion, written by Justice Tom C. Clark, invalidating Oklahoma's Loyalty Oath Law today:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- President Truman, in the presence of Chief Justice Fred M. Vinson and other Government dignitaries, today unveiled the Constitution, the Declaration of Independence and the Bill of Rights in their new shrine under the dome of the National Archives Building.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (AP) -- Three Baltimore philanthropists urged Congress today not to impose more limitations on small personal and corporate phihlanthropic foundations.

Looking younger as it grows older in the service of the lower East Side, the Educational Alliance at 197 East Broadway opened new glass doors yesterday on premises bright with fresh paint and plaster.

Willard E. Henges, president of the Graybar Electric Company, Inc., has been appointed to the advisory committeee of the Grand Central Branch of the Chase National Bank, and Clyde B. Morgan, president of Rayonier, Inc., has been named to the advisory committee of the Forty-second Street branch.

The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was less active yesterday, and closing prices were unchanged to 15 points higher than on last Friday. The market opened with gains of 2 to 14 points on some trade covering, and some speculative buying on belief that the Far Eastern situation looked worse.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 15 -- The United States Government formally announced tonight a policy of no-compromise in its opposition to the repatriation of prisoners of war against their will and reaffirmed "its determination to continue to fulfill its responsibilities in Korea."

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 15 (AP) -- Long shots dominated the program at Tropical Park today and one of the major upsets resulted when T. Owen Campbell's Mackville captured the seventh and best race of the program paying 52.70, $22.90 and $7.80.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (AP) -- Following is the prepared text of President Truman's address today at the dedication of a new shrine for the Constitution, the Declaration of Independence and the Bill of Rights:

Young matrons and debutantes of recent seasons, headed by Mrs. George H. P. Dwight and including Mrs. William Arnold Wood, are aiding in arrangements for a jazz concert to be held for the benefit of The Lighthouse, the New York Association for the Blind, on the night of Dec. 27 at Carnegie Hall.

In his Seventh Town Hall recital last night, Viennese-born Walter Hautzig confined himself to four major works of the piano literature. Bach's Prelude and Fugue in C sharp minor. Beethoven's "Waldstein" Sonata, Schumann's "Davidsbuendertaenze" and Chopin's Sonata in B minor.

TRENTON, Dec. 15 -- New Jersey is ready to put up 2,500 new signs and gasoline companies have ordered new road maps to help motorists find their way through New Jersey's renumbered highways after Jan. 1.

NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 15 (AP) -- The Afghanistan Ambassador to India, Sirdar Magibullah Khan, said today that severe fighting was taking place at Peshawar, the capital of Pakistan's Northwest Province, between Pakistani soldiers and independence - seeking tribesmen.

New community price ceiling charts for market basket foods were posted in grocery stores and delicatessens in this area yesterday. The charts show that the items on which ceilings have been reduced outnumber by more than two to one those items on which ceilings have been increased, according to the regional Office of Price Stabilization for New York and northern New Jersey.

The Queens Central Chapter of the American Red Cross celebrated its thirtieth anniversary yesterday with an open house fete at which Christmas shoppers either donated or watched 125 donors make gifts of blood.

When in 1949 the people of Jersey City elected John V. Kenny, a short, affable man, as Mayor they had reason to believe they were sweeping away the last vestiges of the iron rule imposed for thirty years by Frank Hague.
More than 2,200 Hunter College students and faculty members will attend the traditional Christmas assembly today at 12:40 P. M. in the college auditorium, Sixty-eighth Street and Park Avenue.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- The Supreme Court began consideration today of the question whether the 1951 Federal law requiring gamblers to register and buy a $50 tax stamp is constitutional.

The continuing influence on architecture and design of the home by the group of artists known as de Stijl (Dutch for "the Style") is demonstrated in an exhibition opening at the Museum of Modern Art today. It is the first historical survey in this country of a movement that started in Holland in 1917.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 16 (AP) -- At the ripe old age of 36, Archie Moore finally will get his long-sought crack at the light-heavyweight title tomorrow night when he clashes with Champion Joey Maxim in a fifteen-rounder at the Arena.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 16 -- Warner Brothers has contracted to distribute "The Diamond Queen," a historical adventure story to be co-produced independently by Frank Melford and Edward L. Alperson.

Leonard Pennario, pianist, chose as the major work for his recital at Carnegie Hall last evening the Beethoven Sonata in E Major, Op. 109. One can only suppose that the selection of this work by a performer of Mr. Pennario's tastes and temperament was meant to prove that he can play anything in piano repertoire.

ALBANY, Dec. 16 -- The State Athletic Commission has served notice on boxing promoters that it intends to suspend or revoke their licenses if they fail to enforce regulations barring all betting in sports arenas.

OTTAWA, Dec. 16 (Canadian Press) -- The Board of Transport Commissioners intends to give the Canadian railways a freight rate increase to cover the cost of their 16-cents-an-hour wage boost to non-operating employes, Justice John D. Kearney, chief commissioner, said today.

Attorney General James P. McGranery ordered yesterday that denaturalization proceedings be instituted here against Constantine Radzie, Polish-born member of the Communist party's central committee in New York City.

Plans for improving the southeast corner of Lexington, Avenue and Fifty-sixth Street with a fifteen-story store and apartment building were announced yesterday in connection with the resale of the property by Frederick Brown to a client of Goodman Mabel, attorneys.

LONDON, Dec. 16 -- Prime Minister Churchill, whose stubborn pride in the Royal Navy and concern for the security in Britain's Empire lifeline caused a long delay in the appointment of an Allied naval commander for the Mediterranean, professed himself satisfied today with the command arrangement finally made by the North Atlantic Treaty Organization in Paris.

The New York City Ballet opened the seventh week of its engagement at the City Center last night, and added a bit of a novelty to the repertoire. This was "Harlequinade," choreographed by George Balanchine for Maria Tallchief and Andre Eglevsky, and costumed by Karinska.

The State of Michigan borrowed $20,000,000 yesterday on an issue of limited access highway tax bonds. The securities were sold at public bidding to a banking syndicate headed by Smith, Barney Co., Drexel Co. and Harriman Ripley Co., Inc., at an interest cost of 2.032 per cent.

In the first public sale of local government housing notes backed by the Public Housing Administration since the November election, thirty-nine local housing authorities yesterday borrowed $208,514,000 on notes maturing in from about three months to about eleven months at interest costs ranging from 1.195 per cent to 1.42 per cent.

PARIS, Dec. 16 -- The National Assembly, showing signs of rebellion, refused today to put off debate indefinitely on the North African protectorates of Tunisia and Morocco, although Foreign Minister Robert Schuman had told it that such discussion was premature.

LONDON, Dec. 16 -- The House of Commons voted down a Labor motion tonight expressing "grave concern" over the Churchill Government's efforts to suppress Mau Mau terrorism in Kenya. The Conservative majority in the division was twenty-three.

The recent action of the United Nations in passing a Uruguayan-Bolivian proposal approving any country's right to nationalize private property without mentioning any obligation to compensate the owners drew sharp criticism yesterday from the National Association of Manufacturers and the New York Stock Exchange.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- President Truman said today that he would complete more than seven years in the White House proud of the United States for having faced hard realities, for having borne financial burdens and for having refused to cut corners in the interest of lower taxes and greater comfort in daily living -- all in the nation's leadership against Communist aggression.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- A special committee of the House of Representatives refused today to conduct recounts sought in the Tenth District of Virginia and the First District of Idaho.

The art of channel-jumping and staying away from the big shows often can lead to some intriguing television viewing. Such was the case Monday evening, which all in all turned out to be quite a worthwhile night.

Modern astronomy is sure that there are no birds on the moon, or any other form of life, for that matter. Yet this newspaper published a photograph yesterday which might fairly be termed a birdseye view of our celestial satellite, a breath-taking view of the jagged craters, high mountains and vast plains that make up the lunar landscape.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Dec. 17 -- The air war over Korea increased in intensity yesterday when United States Sabre jets of the Fifth Air Force fought thirteen separate engagements with Communist China's Soviet-designed MIG fighters. The Communists, holding the balance of numbers in the dogfights, lost four planes shot down over Korea near the Manchurian border.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 16 (AP) -- The National Conference will lead off with a backfield made up of Norman Van Brocklin, Dan Towler, Bob Hoernschemeyer ad Joe Perry when they play the American Conference in the annual pro bowl football game here Jan. 10.

The internal political stress on the Pinay Government in Paris due to the Tunisian and Moroccan disputes must not be minimized. There was a reminder of this yesterday when a plea by Foreign Minister Schuman to delay a National Assembly debate on the North African issue was defeated 310 to 303.

In a report made public yesterday, the National Civil Service League called on Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the President-elect to reorganize the Federal civil service system completely. James R. Watson, the league's executive director, estimated that at least $1,000,000,000 a year could be saved from the $10,000,000,000 payroll of the Government's 2,500,000 employes.

The New York City branch of the American Association of University Women has accused Mayor Impellitteri of "failing to serve the public interest" in his recent appointments to the Board of Education and Board of Higher Education.

SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Dec. 16 -- Walter Dukes scored 36 points tonight as Seton Hall University routed John Carroll University of Cleveland, Ohio, 89 -- 77, for its seventh straight victory at the Seton Hall gymnasium. Dukes sank eighteen foul shots to set a new school record.

The National Music Advisory Committee, a new consultative organization made up of musical artists, national and local concert managers, held its first meeting yesterday afternoon at the St. Moritz Hotel as part of the fifth annual convention of the National Association of Concert Managers.

HONOLULU, Dec. 16 -- Harriet Bouslog Sawyer, one of four defense attorneys in the trial of seven Hawaii residents as subversives, was ordered today to appear before Federal Judge Jon Wiig, who is presiding at the trial, to explain a speech she made Sunday at a union meeting at Honokaa.

Ben Hecht, Pulitzer Prize-winning playwright, author and dramatist, will write two half-hour television plays a month as part of a new weekly program. He also will be supervising editor and co-producer of the entire series to be televised by the Columbia Broadcasting System network.

One problem that received some attention at the New York legislative session of 1952 was the motorist who carries no liability insurance. Statistics are lacking on how numerous he is. Governor Dewey in his annual message on Jan. 9 said that consideration was being given "to the insertion of a question on automobile registration blanks requesting information on insurance to procure an accurate survey of the number of uninsured motorists."

HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Dec. 16 -- "Hell Week," during which pledges to Hofstra College's eleven fraternities are hazed, was outlawed today by the school's Interfraternity Council. It was announced that less violent forms of initiation rites were being sought.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- President Truman today named Michael DiSalle as Economic Stabilizer, completing a new team to lead the Administration's fight to retain direct economic controls until the Jan. 20 inauguration of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the President-elect.

PARIS, Dec. 16 -- The Duke of Windsor announced today that he and his Baltimore-born Duchess would not attend the coronation of his niece, Queen Elizabeth II, though he probably will be in London at the time.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (AP) -- Senator Estes Kefauver, Democrat of Tennessee, unsuccessful candidate for the Democratic Presidential nomination, said today he recognized Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois as the party's nominal head -- but with no authority "to dictate or determine party policy."

THE Long Island wildfowlers can give their heavy duck guns a final cleaning and oiling tomorrow night, for when the sun is an hour above the western rim the waterfowl season in this area will be over for the year. Gunners are hoping for a good wind for the final day.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 16 -- The United Nations General Assembly voted today to ask Governments to sign a United Nations pact that would oblige them to help correct "false or distorted" news reports for which other foreign governments demanded redress.
Considerable hard-hitting advertising will be needed to sell those fancy vests which some manufacturers are trying to market, it was agreed yesterday by men's wear retailers.

Plymouth Lamps, Inc., in an expansion move, has leased the factory building at 341-345 Essex Street, Hackensack, N. J., from Helen Harand and Evelyn C. Mercer in a transaction negotiated by J. I. Kislak, Inc., broker. The building formerly was occupied by the Goldberg Slipper Manufacturing Company.

JERSEY CITY, Dec. 16 -- Mayor John V. Kenny charged in a statement tonight that the New York State Crime Commission was being imposed upon by irresponsible witnesses, including his political enemies, to the extent that a completely unrealistic picture of conditions on the Jersey City waterfront was being formed at the New York hearings.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (AP) -- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation said today the Follansbee Steel Corporation of Pittsburgh has applied for a $29,500,000 loan.

Hugues Cuenod, tenor, was the guest soloist with the Harpsichord Quartet last night when it gave the third of its four programs this season at Carnegie Recital Hall. He sang with the ensemble in Bach's Cantata No. 189, "Meine Seele," and delivered a group of English songs with Sylvia Marlowe at the harpsichord.

ELIZABETH, N. J., Dec. 16 -- Although the din from aircraft that blaze routes over parts of Elizabeth and vicinity has dwindled, fear of death from the sky still grips this area, a survey revealed today -- the first anniversary of three plane crashes here that resulted in a total of 119 fatalities.

PARIS, Dec. 16 -- The North Atlantic Council unanimously approved today a compromise arrangement on the Allied command for the Mediterranean. It will place the powerful British Mediterranean fleet for the first time under the orders of Gem Matthew B. Ridgway, Supreme Allied Commander in Europe.

The first merger among New York City banks since 1951 is scheduled for completion next month. Under the terms of the plan, jointly announced yesterday by the directors, Bankers Trust Company will take over the Bayside National Bank of New York with its four offices in Queens County.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Dec. 16 -- The Uruguayan National Congress concluded its 1952 session at midnight last night without acting to ratify the Military Assistance Agreement with the United States that was signed here last June 30. Rumors that a special session will be called to vote on that treaty have not been confirmed.
Dr. C. Canby Balderston, dean of the Wharton School of Finance and Commerce, has been elected a director of the American Institute of Management.

A $3,927,068 contract for the construction of the superstructure of the city's revolutionary new pier at West Fifteenth Street has been awarded to the Corbetta Construction Company, Inc., Edward F. Cavanagh Jr., Commissioner of Marine and Aviation, announced yesterday.

Operations of the Ohio Edison Company and subsidiary for the twelve months ended on Nov. 30 resulted in a net income of $15,820,326, equal to $2.91 a share on an average of 4,798,460 shares outstanding in the period, it was announced yesterday.
Two leading maritime associations announced plans yesterday to cooperate fuly in efforts to wrest control of the waterfront from criminal influence.

In a season highlighted by brilliant individual performances as well as improved team accomplishments, the pitching staff that carried Casey Stengel's Yankees to their fourth straight pennant and world series triumph carried off major honors. This is revealed in the official pitching averages of the American League released for publication today.

The keel of the 60,000-ton carrier Saratoga, most powerful vessel ever constructed, was laid yesterday at the New York Naval Shipyard, Brooklyn, for future service as "another great weapon for the arsenal of. democracy."
The United States Lines will resist any effort of the Federal Government to extract an additional payment of $10,000,000 for the new superliner United States.

Federal Judge Gregory F. Noonan refused yesterday to dismiss treason charges against John David Provoo, former Army sergeant, then adjourned the trial until Jan. 5 because the defense said it would be unable to produce any witnesses before then.

Ken Norton's Manhattan College basketball team won its third straight game last night by halting Hofstra College, 74 to 52, on the Jaspers' court. The defeat snapped a thirteen-game winning streak begun by Hofstra last season.
The State Congress of Industrial Organizations, representing 1,000,000 workers, called on Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois yesterday to continue as leader of the Democratic party.

BONN, Germany, Dec. 16 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer obtained today unanimous approval by the National Executive Committee of his Christian Democratic Union for an all-out fight to obtain the Bundestag's ratification of the Bonn peace contract with the Western Allies and the European Defense Community Treaty.
CHICAGO, Dec. 16 (AP) -- Plans to speed up presentation of the Government's civil anti-trust suit against the du Pont family and six corporations were made today at a pre-trial conference.
Lieut. Gen. Willis D. Crittenberger, First Army commander who is retiring at the end of the year, will be honored by the city at noon tomorrow with a farewell parade up Broadway.

The nation's $55,000,000 Christmas tree industry opened its 1952 doors yesterday as thousands of evergreens from Canada, from Maine, and from New York and Pennsylvania began to appear in pungent-smelling bundles outside local nursery stores and floral shops.

The football situation, a losing proposition at Fordham over the past seven years, is under survey by the office of the Director of University Development, the Rev. Vincent Hart said yesterday. However, Father Hart declared that "it is not true at this time that Fordham will drop football."

United Nations, N. Y., Dec. 16 -- The Arab States in the United Nations paved the way today for another full-scale airing of their complaints against Israel and of their opposition to a majority-backed proposal on the Palestine question.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- Oscar L. Chapman, the Secretary of the Interior, conferred with seven of his public advisers today on the possibilities of economically converting salt and brackish water into fresh water and then reported that all had agreed that Federal research on the problem would require more money.

As darkness fell yesterday, the sound of Christmas carols rose from City Hall Plaza and a huge decorated switch was thrown, turning on the brilliant lights of the sixty-foot Canadian spruce Christmas tree in City Hall Park. New York City's Yuletide season was officially opened.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 16 -- David Owen, executive director of the Technical Assistant Board of the United Nations, reported today to the plenary session of the Economic and Social Council that the program had reached a critical stage. Of a total of $18,824,642 pledged by sixty-five governments for the current year's development projects, $7,136,401 remained unpaid, he said.

As one of many thousands of residents dependent on the Flushing, Main Street and Roosevelt Ave. I. R. T. subway station and the connecting buses, I am writing this letter hoping some faint cry of protest may be heard.
TOKYO, Wednesday, Dec. 17 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,467, for the twenty-four hours ended at 6 A. M. Wednesday, Korean time:

Two men, arrested in connection with a "subway ride hold-up" on Monday afternoon, in which an official of a liquor distributing concern was robbed of a manila envelope containing $115,000 in checks and $4,000 in cash, were held for grand jury action in Felony Court yesterday.

The New York Knickerbockers defeated the Syracuse Nationals, 98 -- 93, last night at Madison Square Garden and ordinarily that would be rated a "good" victory. However, there was nothing ordinary about this National Basketball Association encounter, which was decided in overtime after the Nats had fought to an 85-85 standstill in regulation playing time.

Negotiations have been opened between the Export-Import Bank and Brazil on the South American country's financial difficulties, particularly the heavy backlog of unliquidated dollar credits due on goods shipped from this country, it was learned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (UP) -- House of Representatives investigators will urge the new Congress to force all key tax officials to file regular financial statements to prevent a recurrence of scandals in the Internal Revenue Bureau.

JERSEY CITY, Dec. 16 -- Charging that New York men were getting preference in a "shape-up," members of Local 1247, International Longshoremen's Association, refused today to unload a cargo of steel pipe from the freighter Siddons at the Claremont Terminal here.

The stock market ran into sufficient year-end tax selling yesterday, without the beneift of quick reinvestment demand, to stall the upward movement. No serious damage was done but prices were well scrambled at the close. Some slight progress was registered until the midday period, after which sales exceeded buying orders, more stocks declining than advanced.
The board of directors of Isthmian Steamship Company, a subsidiary of United States Steel, announced last night that Walter M. Wells had resigned as president of Isthmian.
Edgar Laprade will play his farewell game for the Rangers tonight when the New York hockey team meets the Boston Bruins at Madison Square Garden.

Because he lacked a passport, John Price Booth, 2-year-old son of Lieut. Col. Maynard Booth, who is stationed in Frankfurt, was unable yesterday to leave the New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, for a Christmas reunion with his father.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (AP) -- Testimony on cost accounting and the technicalities of railroad operations marked the opening today of a new hearing on grain freight rates from Buffalo to Atlantic ports.
SEATTLE, Dec. 16 (AP) -- Coach Howie Odell, who tutored two All-America backs during his five years at Washington, is on the way out as head coach of the Huskies' football team.

Cardinal Spellman, in his last public appearance before his departure tomorrow for Korea to spend Christmas with the United Nations forces, played host yesterday at his annual party for the children of the New York Foundling Hospital.

Many phases of the use of chlorophyll for drug or cosmetic purposes require further controlled investigation according to a statement released yesterday by John Hopkins University. It was prepared by Dr. Alsoph H. Corwin, Professor of Chemistry.

LONDON, Dec. 16 -- There was a slight change for the better on the stock markets here today. Although business generally continued restrained, a little more interest was taken in British Government securities and oil shares developed a decidedly better trend.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Dec. 17 (AP) -- The Foreign Office disclosed yesterday that the police were working on a bizarre international spy case that, the Japanese press said involved an unidentified official of the Soviet mission here.

A defense lawyer challenged yesterday the ability of the jury that since last April 23 has been hearing evidence in the trial of sixteen secondary Communist leaders on charges of conspiracy to teach and advocate the overthrow of the Government by force and violence. Addressing Federal Judge Edward J. Dimock in a plea for acquittal of the defendants, John T. McClernan demanded:

WEST ORANGE, N. J., Dec. 16 -- The "flying saucer" found yesterday atop a cliff in a local quarry here was part of the ceiling decorations at a dance held on Nov. 22 in the near-by Crystal Lake Casino.

Elias Hellow, 45 years old, a Brooklyn truck fleet owner, was indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury in Brooklyn on a charge of cheating the Government out of income taxes totaling $21,250 for 1946 and 1947.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Dec. 16 (AP) -- A 45-year-old Army Reserve major pleaded "no contention" today to a charge of falsely stating he never had been a Communist when he applied for a job at the naval ordinance depot here.

Richard H. Balch, new Democratic state chairman, said yesterday that one of his first measures to unify and revitalize the party would be to develop a legislative program that all groups could support. A meeting of all Democratic members of the new Legislature will be called for some date before the end of the year for this purpose.

SYDNEY, Australia, Wednesday, Dec. 17 (AP) -- Sir Norman Brookes, president of the Lawn Tennis Association of Australia, said today the L. T. A. A. would not review Frank Sedgman's amateur status unless asked to do so by Alrick Man, American Davis Cup manager.

In your editorial of Dec. 9 on the Iranian oil dispute you assert that the legal risks involved in purchases of such oil by private American firms "are considerable." You also state that it is proper to discourage such purchases in order not to "influence the course of British-Iranian negotiations over the disputed property." May I express my doubts as to the validity of your position?

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- Prof. Owen Lattimore of Johns Hopkins University was indicted by a Federal grand jury here today on seven counts of perjury, including a charge that he had lied when he told the Senate Internal Security subcommittee he had not promoted communism or communistic causes.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 16 (AP) -- Dr. Detlev Bronk, president of Johns Hopkins University here, said tonight that he had sent a letter to Professor Lattimore giving him a leave of absence, with salary, from his university duties.
BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 16 (AP) -- The price of foreign gold coins has risen more than 25 per cent in a week in the Buenos Aires open market.

With a demand that "racketeer domination" of the city's waterfront be eliminated, City Council President Rudolph Halley threw into the Council hopper yesterday two proposed local laws and two resolutions to effect reforms that he predicted would end the pier crime evil.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 16 -- Communist China's rejection of the United Nations General Assembly's compromise proposals on the repatriation of Korean prisoners of war will be officially reported to the Assembly later this week, whether or not North Korea's reply has been received by that time.

For those who have not been able to get out to Aspen, Colo., where the Aspen Institute of Music has been adding its bit to the culture of the nation, Aspen came to New York last night. If this Town Hall program was a fair sampling of what Aspen offers during July and August, it should be off to the Colorado hills for a lot of us next summer.
BERLIN, Dec. 16 -- Attempts to recruit paramilitary forces in East Germany are meeting strong passive resistance, according to an analysis today by United States headquarters in Berlin.

The Minute Maid Corporation yesterday mailed bonus checks for $623,000 to Florida citrus growers as final payment for the 1951-52 season under its growers participation plan. These payments were in addition to the 40 cents per box for pick and haul and the 11 cents a pound of orange solids paid on delivery of the oranges which amounted to $3,445,000 during the harvest.

TRENTON, Dec. 16 -- Paul Jones, information director of the National Safety Council, told the second annual New Jersey Safety Conference today that the accident toll on highways was "a disgrace to any civilized nation." He said a "me first" driving technique actuated too many motorists, converting the pleasure of driving into a mad scramble to be first at the finish line.

The following excerpts are from testimony given at yesterday's hearing of the New York State Crime Commission. They relate to waterfront and gambling activities in Jersey City, with particular reference to Mayor John V. Kenny.

Many of the readers of our forty-first annual Neediest Cases appeal, particularly if they grew up in small towns, will recall the custom of distributing Christmas baskets to unfortunate families. These baskets contained food, perhaps a few articles of mended but still serviceable winter clothing, possibly a small toy or two tucked in by a good woman who could imagine her own children finding their Christmas stockings empty.

Evidence of large payments by stevedoring and shipping companies to nearly a hundred officials of the International Longshoremen's Association comes with a new sense of shock even to a public inured to sensational developments in the State Crime Commission's investigation of the waterfront. And the evidence continues to pile up showing the culpability of the employers and the tie-in of politicians, racketeers and criminals in the whole nasty mess.
TOKYO, Dec. 16 -- Premier Shigeru Yoshida appeared today to have weathered a political storm that threatened to topple his seven-week-old administration.
General Electric Company's total sales for 1952 will approximate $2,600,000,000, Ralph Cordiner, president, estimated yesterday. This will represent a 12 per cent gain over 1951, he said.

PARIS, Dec. 16 -- Members of the French labor union committee from the liner Liberte met in Le Havre today and ordered members not to submit in the future to the screening examinations by the United States immigration enforcers of the McCarran Law.
ALBANY, Dec. 16 (UP) -- The State Commerce Department reported the following winter sports conditions at New York resorts:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- The United States sternly repeated today its demand to the Soviet Union for "appropriate compensation" for the loss of a B-29 bomber and the lives of eight crew members shot down by Soviet planes on Oct. 7.

Terms that are common in the patois of the waterfront are receiving more general circulation as a result of the hearings of the New York State Crime Commission. A number of them, however, are confusing, particularly since their practical connotations do not always agree with standard dictionaries. Some follow:

The city's chief fiscal officer attempted last night to pass off to the state government responsibility for financing a forty-hour work-week on New York's principal privately operated bus lines and thus heading off a strike scheduled for Jan. 1.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 16 -Senator Wayne Morse of Oregon, who resigned from the Republican party in the recent Presidential campaign, said today that he expected that Republican leaders would attempt to "discipline" him when Congress convened.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (AP) -- The Congress of Industrial Organizations told the National Labor Relations Board today that the board would open "an insane Pandora's box" if it penalizes a union on charges a union official made a false non-Communist oath three years ago.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- The altitude record for single-stage rockets -- 135 miles -- was equalled today by the Navy's Viking 9 rocket at the Army White Sands Proving Grounds, Las Cruces, N. M.

PONGAM ISLAND, Korea, Dec. 16 -- The desperate fanaticism of the Korean Communist civilian internees, which inspired them to continue to sing their Communist songs as fusillade after fusillade was fired into their ranks, was blamed today for Sunday's riot on this island in which eighty-four prisoners were killed and 118 others were wounded.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (AP) -- American business will plow back more of its earnings than ever before into expansion and improvement during the last quarter of this year and the first quarter of 1953, two Government agencies estimated today.

MIAMI, Dec. 16 (AP) -- Mrs. C. A. Cope's Bob F., unplaced in five previous 1952 starts, found his best stride at Tropical Park today when he surged from last place in a belated response and captured the featured Viscaya Purse before a chilled crowd of 6,840, the smallest of the current meeting.
NAIROBI, Kenya, Dec. 16 (Reuters) -- British officials in the terror-ridden colony of Kenya got sweeping new emergency powers today in the battle against the anti-white Mau Mau cult.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 16 -- Secretary General Trygve Lie told diplomatically critical delegates today that his campaign against alleged subversives on the United Nations staff had been carried out under the laws of the world organization.
METZ, France, Dec. 16 (AP) -- A German doctor admitted before a French military court today that he had used concentration camp prisoners ah human guinea pigs to test the effects of poison gas.

Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio was backed yesterday for the post of majority leader of the Senate by Senators H. Alexander Smith of New Jersey and Frank Carlson of Kansas, both close to Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the President-elect.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (UP) -- The outgoing Reclamation Commissioner, Michael W. Straus, said today he had offered to Douglas McKay, incoming Secretary of the Interior, "every aid and assistance" to prevent interruption of the Government's reclamation program.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 16 -- New York University rallied from an early second quarter 8-point deficit to remain in the unbeaten ranks by defeating Yale, 87 -- 72, on the Payne Whitney court tonight.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., Dec. 16 -- An amendment to the State Education Law requiring local school authorities to adopt salary schedules for principals and to file copies with the State Commissioner of Education before July 1 was advocated today in a resolution adopted by the secondary school principals of the state at their annual meeting.

A new German rayon textile will be used in 100 American apparel lines next year. The fabric, known as Ridia, has been introduced here by Morris Shoenthal, Inc., importers, and is manufactured by Augsburger Buntweberie Riedinger, largest producer of yarn dyed rayon cloth in Western Germany.

CAMBRIDGE, England, Dec. 16 -- Prof. Alexander R. Todd, Scottish biochemist, and a group of researchers at the University Chemical Laboratories here have synthesized three of about six complex substances that may be regarded as the biochemical sparkplugs in the engine of the life cell.

ROME, Dec. 16 -- The crew of the United States Refrigerator ship, Grommet Reefer, which broke in two early yesterday morning on Queens Rock, just outside the port of Leghorn, imprisoning forty officers and men in the stern portion, was on land today after two days of rescue efforts.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- Another dividend will be paid next year to about 5,000,000 veterans holding National Service Life Insurance policies, the Veterans Administration said today.

Two New York State parole officials described to the State Crime Commission yesterday how 200 or more criminals, many of them while they were still in prison, were assured of or placed in jobs by a company headed by William J. McCormack, millionaire industrialist.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 16 -- The Second Five-Year Plan of President Juan Peron was subjected today to severe criticism by the Radical party, which has rejected its adoption because of the unlimited powers it would give the general.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 16 -- A new draft resolution that would bypass the Asian-Arab suggestion for direct negotiations between the Frenck and the Sultan of Morocco was submitted this morning to the Political and Security Committee of the United Nations General Assembly by eleven Latin-American nations.

A molded, fluid look characterizes a new group of furniture which, together with a new group of fabrics, is now on view at Kagan-Dreyfuss, 123 East Fifty-seventh Street. The furniture and materials are available through decorators.
Net income of the Sheraton Corporation of America for the six months ended on Oct. 31 amounted to $3,281,418, equal to $2.05 a share on 1,599,464 common shares, it was announced yesterday.

MOLINE, Ill., Dec. 16 (AP) -- Four Quad-Cities newspapers continued, publication today during a strike of printers and the union introduced the first edition of what it said would be a regular tabloid daily.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange turned weak yesterday and closed virtually at the lowest levels of the day, 23 to 61 points net lower on the active months than on Monday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (AP) -- The Defense Department today identified 96 Korean war casualties in a new list that reported 19 dead, 70 wounded 3 missing and 4 injured. The following were listed from New York and Connecticut (non from New Jersey):

Mayor John V. Kenny of Jersey City was named yesterday by witnesses before the State Crime Commission as the associate and protector of criminals and racketeers both before and after his election in 1949 on a reform ticket.

A slightly built, middle-aged couple and their small, middle-aged beagle hound drove off a husky hoodlum last night from their delicatessen in the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn after a knockdown fight in which the wife clouted the thug with a soft-drink bottle and the beagle bit him severely.

MADRAS, India, Dec. 16 -- For millions of South Indians one of their countrymen was raised to sainthood here tonight with the cremation according to Hindu rites of Potti Sriramulu, 51-year-old Gandhian nationalist.

MIAMI, Dec. 16 (UP) -- A cold wave reaching into semi-tropical Florida has killed about 80 per cent of the snap beans and corn in the rich Lake Okeechobee truck garden district but has spared the state's citrus crop, it was reported tonight.

The "hostile atmosphere" created by newspaper accounts of the State Crime Commission's hearings resulted yesterday in the transfer to Washington of the perjury trial of Edward J. Florio, organizer for the International Longshoremen's Association, A. F. L., in New Jersey and boss of the Hoboken waterfront.

Few important decisions will come out of the current NATO conference. The meeting of the top Ministers of the West is extremely interesting, nevertheless, as a revelation of what happens to the play when Hamlet is not performing. For some time a growing number of our European friends have been restive under American leadership.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (AP) -New York completed its case today before the Federal Power Commission for a license to join with Canada in constructing a $50,000,000 St. Lawrence River power project.

India has a fifty-fifty chance of going communistic at her next election, Dr. Frank C. Laubach, educator and missionary, told the annual luncheon of the Salvation Array Association of New York yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

Supreme Court Justice Felix C. Benvenga denied yesterday a motion by Anniello Ercole, manager of prizefighters and reputed power on the Brooklyn waterfront, for an order vacating a subpoena issued by the New York State Crime Commission requiring him to appear as a witness at a public hearing.

The Walker Manufacturing Company of Racine, Wis., manufacturer of automobile hydraulic equipment and mufflers, has leased the one-story warehouse at 47-30 Twenty-ninth Street in Long Island City, Queens, which it will use for its eastern office and as a distribution center.

Trading continued show yesterday on the New York commodity exchanges, potatoes showing the most activity. Most markets were dull and featureless with only slight price fluctuations. Prices closed irregularly with hides, zinc, and vegetable oil futures higher. Rubber, potatoes, lead and cocoa were lower and sugar, coffee and wool were mixed.

The local office of the New York State Extension Service in Marketing already has planned and computed the cost of the Christmas dinner. Its figuring was based on the perishable food prices reported last week by the New York City Department of Markets.
PARIS, Dec. 16 -- Some influential Yugoslav officials recently have shown an active interest in joint operational planning with the West in defense of the key Ljubljana Gap-Trieste-Austria area.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- United States aid of $100,000,000 to Iran was reported today to be under consideration as a possible key to solving the long and bitter British-Iranian oil dispute.

LONDON, Dec. 16 -- The new planning by Britain and the United States, seeking a settlement of the oil dispute between Iran and Britain, is apparently based on the idea that some group other than the British-owned Anglo-Iranian Oil Company should market Iranian oil in the future.

President Truman has directed the State and Justice Departments and the Federal Civil Service Commission to collaborate on a plan to guarantee a maximum of security in the selection of United States personnel for employment at the United Nations, Attorney General James P. McGranery, announced here yesterday.

A demonstration of proposed new lighting for the Avenue of the Americas, from Canal to Fifty-ninth Streets, was given yesterday on the stage of the Radio City Music Hill. The showing was witnessed by several hundred merchants and members of the Avenue of the Americas Association, sponsor of the demonstration.
Simplicity of line and lack of ornamentation are notable in a small collection of accessories on view at New Design, 33 East Seventy-fifth Street.

CHICAGO, Dec. 16 -- Fluctuations within a moderate price range featured the trade in grain and soybean futures today. From the firm initial range there was a reaction, but a commission absorption broadened a little in all pits on the declines, resulting in at least partial recoveries.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 16 -- Pakistan announced tonight that she was willing to accept India's demand that 28,000 Indian troops remain in Kashmir during the plebiscite to determine the political future of the state.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- President Truman congratulated The Evening Star of Washington on its centennial anniversary today. In a special message, he described The Star as "one of this country's great newspapers," even though "I sometimes disagree with Star editorials."

The Trans-Lux Seventy-second Street Theatre will reopen on Christmas Day with a revival showing of the British-made version of Charles Dickens' "A Christmas Carol." featuring Alastair Sim, Kathleen Harrison, Jack Warner and Mervyn Johns.

Merger of Gross-Krasne Productions, Inc., and Studio Films, Inc., with United Television Programs, Inc., was announced yesterday. The affiliation, United Television Programs, Inc., will form the first major all-purpose organization in the television industry with well-developed distribution, production and financial facilities.

As they did yesterday and will again tomorrow, pop-eyed young ones by the thousands will form long lines in department stores today and wait their turn to climb aboard Santa's lap, from which vantage they will do their best to entangle a lollipop in the jolly gentleman's whiskers.

Three hold-up men, who pretended they were assistants to the owner of a jewelry store, urged two women to "stop back later when the boss isn't tied up," and escaped yesterday after taking $20,00O worth of jewelry and $125 in cash from the store at 2372 Broadway, near Eighty-sixth Street.
JOHNSON CITY, N. Y., Dec. 16 (AP) -- A young mother completely paralyzed by polio has given birth to a three-pound-twelve-ounce girl and both are doing well, physicians said today.
CLEVELAND, Dec. 16 -- Two- day-old girls who were Siamese twins for the first three hours of their lives were "doing fine" today in separate incubators.

MOSCOW, Dec. 16 -- Interest in Soviet-Chinese economic relations was enhanced today by the emphasis given in the Soviet press to a declaration by Mao Tse-tung, Chinese Communist leader, that China shortly would be launching large-scale economic expansion.
ST. LOUIS, Dec. 16 (AP) -- Osteopaths were held today by a state court of appeals to be physicians and surgeons under the laws of Missouri and entitled to practice in county hospitals of the state.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (AP) -- Following is the text of President Truman's address before the Alumni Association of the Industrial College for the Armed Forces today:
The anonymous "Lady Bountiful" who has brought in person to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund $1,000 in cash every year for at least twenty-five years did it again yesterday.

Miles Leslie, 43 years old, a self-styled artist, was sentenced yesterday by General Sessions Judge Jonah J. Goldstein to three to four years in state prison on his guilty plea to an indictment charging compulsory prostitution and living off the earnings of a prostitute.

Opening at 8 o'clock this evening at the Martin Beck, "The Grey-Eyed People" will introduce two newcomers, John D. Hess, playwright, and Albert Selden, producer. Mr. Hess is better known as a TV writer, while Mr. Selden collaborated on the music for the revue, "Small Wonder" (1948), and composed the tunes for "A Month of Sundays," a musical comedy that never reached its Broadway destination.

Chilean import licenses due to expire on Dec. 31, 1952, have been extended to March 31, 1953, it was reported yesterday by the Commerce and Industry Association of New York. The organization's world trade department said it had been advised of the extention by Alfonso Grez, retiring Consul General of Chile in New York.
The New York Dress Institute's list of best dressed women of the world was announced yesterday and it numbered twelve -- not the usual ten -- to include two new political figures.

Detailed plans for a "glamour" campaign designed to attract more young men to its ranks, were made public yesterday at a meeting of members of the National Tool and Die Manufacturers Association at the Biltmore Hotel.

The New York Chapter of the Arthritis and Rheumatism Foundation will be the beneficiary of a performance of "Two's Company," with Bette Davis in the leading role, on the night of Jan. 15 at the Alvin Theatre. Among the women serving with Gordon K. Greenfield on the benefit committee are Mrs. Seward Brisbane and Mrs. William H. Woolverton Jr.
BERLIN, Dec. 16 -- Only five roads crossing the border between West Berlin and the Soviet zone are open to motor traffic, according to a survey issued by United States Headquarters today.

PARIS, Dec. 16 -- With the reports of the juridical and liaison subcommittees in, the drafters on the European steel and coal community, committee had before them today the complete proposal that would form a constitutional poliical authority around the Schuman plan to merge Western Europe's steel and coal.

A first novel by Mikhail Soloviev, a former Soviet journalist, will be published Jan. 2 by David McKay under the title "When the Gods Are Silent." Translated by Harry C. Stevens, the story covers thirty years of life in Russia, from the Revolution of 1917 through World War II, and the disillusionment of the hero in the Soviet regime.
" La Gioconda" was the opera last night at the Metropolitan, with an all-star cast.
Five United States war correspondents agreed in a recorded radio broadcast from Tokyo last night that there were no prospects for a truce in Korea in the near future.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- Lieut. Gen. Lewis A. Pick, retiring Chief of Army Engineers, and two of his colonels have been "admonished" by Frank Pace Jr., Secretary of the Army, in the wake of a Senate investigation into alleged waste and confusion in the building of five strategic air bases in French Morocco.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 16 -- In the course of a heavy attack on the Vatican and the Italian Government, Premier Marshal Tito suggested today that if the Western powers did not take Yugoslavia as an ally Yugoslavia had "another outcome."

CAIRO, Dec. 16 -- The rector of Al Azhar University, influential Moslem institution, together with learned ulemas, or religious leaders, sitting in formal session today, issued a summons to the Moslem world to boycott France commercially, industrially, politically and culturally.

DETROIT, Dec. 16 (AP) -- A quick sellout is predicted for Sunday's Detroit Lions-Los Angeles Rams play-off game -despite a forecast of snow and sub-freezing chill. Of Briggs Stadium's 56,000 seats, 30,000 had been sold in the first fourteen hours.

Millicent C. McIntosh, president of Barnard College, declared yesterday that "young people today know what is good, but are so caught up in the swirl of everyday things that they cannot effect their values."

THOSE freebooting buccaneers, who boisterously roamed the Spanish Main a couple of centuries ago, observed one particular custom whenever they planned an unpleasant fate for one of their company. They slipped him the black spot. Branch Rickey is too respectable and God-fearing a man ever to be another Captain Kidd. But the Mahatma is the skipper of the Pirates and he has just slipped the black spot to Fred Haney by appointing him his manager.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- The Civil Service Commission conceded today that it takes a man to detect a cheat, and a machine cannot do it.

Three prominent clergymen heading the League of West Side Organizations urged District Attorney Frank S. Hogan yesterday to impanel a grand jury to investigate landlords who were converting "the heart of the great residential areas of New York into festering slums."

The magic that attaches to the famous of the theatre world seemed to lose its potency yesterday. "There's no sentiment left," someone remarked sadly at an auction sale of mementoes of theatre folk that had been donated for the benefit of the American National Theatre and Academy.

The Genocide Convention is in great danger because of the Chinese proposal to revise the convention in such a manner that this revision would necessitate formally new ratifications by forty Parliaments. We fear, however, that the convention will ultimately be put on ice and superseded by the proposed United Nations Draft Code of Offenses Against Peace and Security of Mankind, which, being a declaration, will not be enforceable as binding international law.

Mrs. Joseph George Gage gave a buffet dinner last night in her home at 300 Park Avenue for Mrs. Beatrice B. Cartwright of 820 Fifth Avenue and Casa Estella, Cap d'Antibes, France, who will leave in the middle of next month to spend the season in Palm Beach, Fla.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Dec. 16 -- The Israeli Army is making a list of United States citizens either in the armed forces or subject to duty, and the United States Consulate here is issuing letters to resident Americans here endorsing their applications for exemption from military service.
DETROIT, Dec. 16 (UP) -- Fred M. Alger Jr., who demanded a recount in Michigan's Nov. 4 gubernatorial election, tonight conceded he was beaten by G. Mennen Williams, Democratic incumbent.

VIENNA, Dec. 16 -- Klement Gottwald, president of Czechoslovakia, denied at the opening session of a two-day conference of the Czechoslovak Communist party in Prague today that the recent execution of eight Jewish Communist party leaders convicted on charges of treason and sabotage was an Anti-Semitic act, the Prague radio reported.

From now until Christmas several thousand specially designed self-help toys for use by cerebral palsied or similarly handicapped youngsters will be distributed to hospitals, clinics and schools working with these children in forty cities throughout the country.

SEATTLE, Wash., Dec. 16 -- With estimates showing $275,000,000 worth of annual construction needed in the next six to ten years to meet the power shortage in the Pacific Northwest, the Bonneville Regional Advisory Council received a report today recommending revenue bonds for future financing of Federal power generating facilities.

Jackie Robinson said yesterday that he had talked with Commissioner Ford Frick concerning a television interview in which the Brooklyn infielder had accused the Yankees of discriminating against Negro players.

The National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis made grants totaling $204,491 to Mount Sinai Hospital yesterday for investigation of poliomyelitis. The sum was divided into a three-year grant of $94,500, an additional $90,958 to expedite the first year's work and a one-year grant of $19,023.

Mayor Kenny of Jersey City has been pictured by witnesses before the State Crime Commission as the associate and protector of criminals and racketeers. He has refused an invitation to clear himself. Instead, he has issued a statement seeking to discredit the witnesses and indicating that the Commission is being hoodwinked by his political enemies.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 17 -- After a short but fiery debate, the United Nations General Assembly adopted tonight a resolution on Tunisia expressing "the hope that the parties will continue negotiations on an urgent basis with a view to bringing about self-government for Tunisians in the light of the relevant provisions of the Charter of the United Nations."

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Dec. 17 -- The Targum, a student newspaper at Rutgers University, today criticized the university's board of trustees for its decision to dismiss two faculty members by Dec. 31 unless they reappear before the Senate Internal Security subcommittee to answer to questions about alleged Communist affiliations.

The Forrestal Memorial Committee voted yesterday to dissolve itself after an existence of a year and a half, in which it raised $1,251,507 to establish the James Forrestal Research Center at Princeton University. The action to end its existence was taken at a committee luncheon at the Century Club, 7 West Forty-third Street.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (AP) -- Alton L. Blakeslee, a science reporter for The Associated Press, and Morton M. Hunt, a freelance writer, today won $1,000 awards for science writing.

The theory of child development still set forth by some parent educators -- that whatever a youngster is or will be depends on his parents' treatmentof him -- "overburdens parents with guilt and apprehension" and also can undermine a child's opinion of himself, according to Dr. Hilde Bruch, psychoanalyst and pediatrician.
HANOI, Vietnam, Indo-China, Dec. 17 -- The French Army announced today a "reshuffle of' defense arrangements" in Indo-China, involving the pulling back of some French units.

ROME, Dec. 17 -- The Vatican Secretariat of State had received late tonight no confirmation from its nunciature in Belgrade of Marshal Tito's decision to cut diplomatic relations. No official comment or reaction was therefore forthcoming.

James P. McAllister, president of McAllister Brothers, Inc., and also of the New York Towboat Exchange, has been renamed chairman of the Marine Towing and Transportation Employers Association. Lloyd H. Dalzell, president of Dalzell Towing Company, Inc., was again chosen as vice chairman of the association.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- The Agriculture Department estimated today that the country's farmers would wind up the year with about the same net income they got last year -- in the vicinity of $14,300,000,000.

DELFT, the Netherlands, Dec. 17 -- Despite a storm and slush huge majorities in this pottery-making city and the Frisian market town of Bolsward trooped voluntarily to the polls today in an unofficial test referendum to register their support of a European federation.

The Institute of Public Administration's report on the Police Department was attacked yesterday as "biased" and as "written by people who obviously were out to do a job on the Police Department." The critics were representatives of police line organizations who spoke at a final City Hall public hearing on the document.
With advance appointments by prospective blood donors next week only 30 per cent of normal, the Red Cross renewed its appeal to New Yorkers yesterday to give "the gift of life" for Christmas.

Princeton University's freshman hockey team broke a 1-all tie in a ten-minute overtime period to defeat St. Paul's School of Concord, N. H., 2 -- 1, in their annual Christmas Holiday game at Madison Square Garden before a crowd of 3,000 yesterday.

Flota Mercante Grancolombiana, one of the largest and most successful of South American shipping companies, will be dissolved soon after Jan. 1 to the extent that Venezuela, the primary financial partner, will drop out of the concern, it was learned last night.

Aluminum has been chosen for the exterior in a modified plan of the twenty-six-story office building to be erected at 99 Park Avenue by the Tishman Realty Construction Company. The customary masonry construction originally had been planned for the skyscraper which is to occupy the east blockfront on Park Avenue between Thirty-ninth and Fortieth Streets.

Effective Wednesday from 7 to 7:30 P. M., the "March of Time" documentary series filmed for television will be presented over WNBT instead of WJZ-TV. The program will have its last showing over the latter channel tonight at o'clock tonight.

MADRAS, India, Dec. 17 -- East is meeting West at the Sixth International Conference of Social Work here this week in the sense that discussions have revealed a high degree of understanding that Asian problems cannot be attacked on the same basis that might work in the United States or Europe.

OAK RIDGE, Tenn., Dec. 17 (UP) -- The Protestant Episcopal Church issued holy orders to an atomic scientist today and exhorted him to wield its power of wisdom with goodwill lest it "blow to bits everything that mankind holds dear."
TOKYO, Thursday, Dec. 18 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,467, for Wednesday's activities:

Those in search of a negligee for Christmas giving will find a decidedly new feeling dominating these fashions. Undoubtedly influenced by the popularity of separates designs, they've been shorn of boudoir atmosphere. There's a much more "dressed" look about them, with, as one designer humorously put it, mink taking the place of marabou.

With a strike on the city's principal privately owned bus lines only two weeks off, the state passed back to the city yesterday responsibility for providing any financial help the bus operators might need to meet union demands for a forty-hour work-week.

Chief Magistrate John M. Murtagh was requested yesterday to reduce court congestion by simplifying procedure on allocating trial dates for traffic violation cases. Delegation of power to traffic court clerks to accept pleas of not guilty was suggested by William J. Gottlieb, president of the Automobile Club of New York.

PANAMA, Dec. 17 -- Pianist Jose Iturbi moaned today that in thirty-six years of performing for the public he had never been so mishandled as he was here last night. During the intermission in his recital, he said, a Government tax collector arrived asking for $40 he contended the pianist owed on the night's earnings.
A two-point program to give the Board of Education fiscal and political independence was offered yesterday in a statement issued by the Public Education Association.

TRENTON, Dec. 17 -- The second state industrial safety conference adjourned here today after adopting committee recommendations for a state institute fo rstudy of industrial diseases and for a broad safety education program in plants and schools next year.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Dec. 17 -- Vice Premier Prawoto, acting for Premier Wilopo who entered a hospital this morning for a minor operation, announced today the appointment of Col. Bambang Sugeng as the new Indonesian Army Chief of Staff. He replaces Colonel Nasution, who was dismissed Dec. 5 following a split within the Army over its leadership.

TOKYO, Thursday, Dec. 18 -- United States F-86 Sabre jets fought with the Chinese Reds' Soviet-designed MIG fighters over North Korea again yesterday and for a third successive day inflicted losses. One MIG went down in flames over the Yalu River into Manchuria and four others of the foe were damaged.
The following are excerpts from testimony given by witnesses yesterday or previously, all of which went into the record at yesterday's hearing by the New York State Crime Commission.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- That living anachronism, the "Electoral College," embodied this year by 531 American citizens, met Monday in groups scattered over its forty-eight state "campuses" and cast 442 votes for General Eisenhower and 89 votes for Governor Stevenson in settlement of their contest for the Presidency in 1952.

John D. Rockefeller Jr. has purchased for investment the eighteen-story building at 740 Park Avenue, northwest corner of Seventy-first Street, where he occupies an apartment, it was announced yesterday by Webb Knapp, Inc., the seller. The property is assessed at $2,800,000, of which $800,000 is land value, and fronts 102 feet on the avenue and 270 feet on the street.
The preposterous and intolerable traffic conditions now strangling New York and costing it millions yearly in lost trade and time are caused to no small degree by illegal parking.

Lillian Hellman's drama, "The Children's Hour," will be revived tonight at the Coronet Theatre at 8 o'clock by Kermit Bloomgarden. Patricia Neal and Kim Hunter have been recruited for the roles of the anguished teachers, and Iris Mann will portray the envenomed youngster who destroys them.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- Termination of all but military aid to Western Europe and abolition of the existing Federal agencies that administer "give-away" programs were recommended today in a report to President Truman by a government-industry group headed by Charles Sawyer, the Secretary of Commerce.
The Kings County Democratic Committee adopted last night a series of rules changes that may lead to the ousting of Francis J. Sinnott, Brooklyn Democratic leader.

BURBANK, Calif., Dec. 17 (UP) -- The University of Wisconsin football team -- forty-four players strong -- arrived by air today to drill for its Rose Bowl encounter with Southern California on New Year's Day.
PRINCETON, N. J., Dec. 17 -- Princeton's basketball team led all the way to defeat Lafayette, 79 -- 47, tonight.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (UP) -- Ralph R. Roberts, clerk of the House of Representatives, has done his best to set members of the new Eighty-third Congress straight on the devious ins-and-outs of official Washington life.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- Campaign promises that helped put Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower on the job as President worked to put two highly paid Washington lobbyists out of a job.

The New York City Housing Authority and the Housing Authority of Newark, N. J., have moved to comply with a new Federal law requiring the exclusion of members of "subversive" organizations from Federally aided, low-cost housing, it became known yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- The election of Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio as Republican leader of the new Senate is now regarded as foregone even among some colleagues who would have preferred another to fill the post.

ALBANY, Dec. 17 -- One hundred and forty-nine of the State Department of Taxation and Finance's 1,000 tax examiners have engaged in outside business activities -- two-thirds of them without obtaining the required written permission, a department survey disclosed today.
A flood of mail yesterday from 598 contributors, who sent $16,979 to the forty-first annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, raised the fund to $211,330.

LAWRENCE, Mass., Dec. 17 (AP) -- Superior Court Judge Daniel D. O'Brien today discontinued prosecution of all indictments against a New York lawyer and a deceased Massachusetts doctor and his widow charged with operating an adoption racket.

It was a difficult program that Charles Rosen selected for his Town Hall piano recital last night, a program that demanded the utmost in technical and musical requirements, with scarcely a break anywhere throughout the evening.
Columbia University's swimming team yesterday handed to City College its first defeat of the season, 54 to 30, at the loser's pool.

Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the President-elect, and John Foster Dulles, who will be his Secretary of State, conferred for two and a quarter hours yesterday with Gen. Douglas MacArthur on possible plans for ending the Korean war and the relationship of such plans to the world-wide struggle between Communist and free governments.

MOSCOW, Dec. 17 -- The chief editorship of Pravda, the leading newspaper of the Soviet Union, has been placed in the hands of Dmitri Trofimovitch Shepilov, who for many years has been one of the Communist party's top specialists in the field of agitation and propaganda.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (AP) -- Representative Hubert R. Scudder, Republican of California, proposed today that Congressional action be required before import duties could be lowered below a point where American industry would be injured.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- Stephen J. Spingarn, a Federal Trade Commissioner, said today that he was endeavoring to enlist the support of President Truman, Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the President-elect, and the chairmen of the Democratic and Republican National Committees in his campaign against unethical pressures on quasi-judicial Government bodies.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- The name of John Carter Vincent was on President Truman's desk by the day Mr. Truman took over the White House, and it now appears that this same name will be on top of the pile again when Mr. Truman departs.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 17 (AP) -- The United States swept today's opening matches of the Davis Cup interzone singles finals with Italy, at Sydney, Radio Australia reported.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 17 -- The Soviet Union and its satellites were condemned tonight by the United Nations General Assembly, for having refused to repatriate thousands of Greek children now in Iron Curtain countries.

DETROIT, Dec. 17 (AP) -- Bobby Layne, the Detroit Lion quarterback who confuses foes because he sometimes runs with the ball instead of passing, will test his injured leg with full-scale sprints tomorrow morning for the first time in four days.

The passport division of the State Department at 630 Fifth Avenue and the German Embassy played Santa Claus yesterday to wrap up a Christmas present for 2-year-old John Price Booth that probably will become his most important gift this holiday season --a Yuletide reunion with his father in Frankfurt, Germany.

Lieut. Gen. Willis D. Crittenberger, commanding general, First Army, who is retiring from the service on Dec. 31, reviewed his last retreat parade at Governors Island yesterday afternoon. Led by the First Army Band, 750 men, women and officers passed in review before the general in a brief ceremony on the Fort Jay parade ground.

Fullback Eddie Price and Tackle Arnie Weinmeister of the New York Giants, Halfback Hugh McElhenny of the San Francisco Forty-Niners and Tackle Lou Groza of the Cleveland Browns were the outstanding choices on the 1952 United Press All-National Football League team announced yesterday.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Dec. 17 -- It is apparent to a visitor in the turbulent Middle East these days that both the Arab states and Israel would benefit enormously by a settlement of the Palestine war, but it also is apparent that peace still is a long way off.

Elmer Schuer, sole survivor of three men who engaged in a fatal pistol battle last Sept. 21 in a Harlem apartment, where a detective was killed and another wounded, avoided a possible death sentence yesterday when a grand jury found that the detective died of a bullet from another policeman's revolver.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 17 -- Yugoslavia broke diplomatic relations with the Vatican today, charging the Holy See with refusing to settle the church-state conflict in this country.

A phantom voice provided comic relief to yesterday's hearing into waterfront conditions by the New York State Crime Commission. It orated ten minutes from a record made of a tapped conversation at a conference.
Futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were moderately active yesterday and closing prices were irregular 7 points lower to 5 higher than on Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- Tobias E. Diamond, who recently resigned as United States Attorney for northern Iowa, today faced and fought charges against his conduct in office that the Department of Justice had called "intolerable" and "a source of embarrassment" to it.

The New York commodity markets continued idle yesterday with many of the items registering less volume than in the previous day's slow trading. Prices were irregular with cottonseed oil, potatoes and hides closing higher. Rubber, zinc and coffee were lower and cocoa, sugar, soybean oil and wool closed mixed.
The State of South Carolina yesterday designated Jan. 7 for the sale of an issue of $10,000,000 of highway bonds. Dated Dec. 1, 1952, the bonds will come due on Dee. 1, from 1954 to 1967.

In "The Grey-Eyed People," which opened at the Martin Beck last evening, John D. Hess has set the cause of civil liberties back twenty-five years. He has written a wise-cracking comedy about a community that boycotts a puppeteer who was a member of the Communist party from 1937-39.

William L. Pfeiffer has been elected a director of the United Cigar-Whelan Stores Corporation, it was announced yesterday. Mr. Pfeiffer, who is chairman of the New York Republican State Committee, is president of the W. L.
