Pfeiffer Company, Rochester mortgage organization, and a director of the Kalamazoo Stove and Furnace Company.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Dec. 17 (UP) -- Archie Moore, 36-year-old restaurateur of San Diego, Calif., gave Joey Maxim a thorough battering tonight and wrested the world light-heavyweight championship from him on a unanimous fifteen-round decision before 12,610 in the Arena.

Anthony (Tony Bender) Strollo, reputed successor to the jailed Joe Adonis as boss of many rackets on both sides of the Hudson River, balked yesterday at telling the State Crime Commission's public hearing what happened at a midnight meeting he had with Mayor John V. Kenny of Jersey City in a hotel suite here last March 14.

The Graham-Paige Corporation, a specialized type of closed-end investment company, disclosed yesterday that, in conjunction with a group of associates, it had concluded negotiations for the acquisition of $11,000,000 of real estate in Los Angeles, Calif.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- The Post Office Department announced today that a partial mail service would be provided on Friday, Dec. 26, which President Truman has designated as an additional Christmas holiday for Government workers.

The three-story building containing three stores and seven apartments at 6602-6604 Seventeenth Avenue, Brooklyn, has been sold by Gladys Maria Lombardi to Samuel Ioppolo. The property, on a plot 40 by 80 feet, is assessed at $34,000. Thomas Politano was the broker and title was insured by the Lawyers Mortgage and Title Company.
As a member of a "Women's Affairs" group of visitors from Germany to this country in September I was interested to read a letter from Erika Strauss which you published.

The Amazon is the subject of two books scheduled for publication in the next two months. On Jan. 12, Holt will issue "Amazon Head-Hunters," a new work by Lewis N. Cotlow. It is an account of his three trips to the Amazon head-hunter country in South America. Dutton will publish on Feb. 14 "Two Against the Amazon" by John Brown.

The World Jewish Congress reported yesterday that 360,000 Jews living in the French North African protectorates of Tunisia and Morocco were confronted "with the most precarious political, social and economic conditions" because of the current demands for independence in those areas.
PENN YAN, N. Y., Dec. 17 -- Sheep farmers of Yates County today sought wolf-like animals like the one captured and killed this week on a farm near the village of Italy.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 17 -- Columbia Pictures will make a personalized history of West Point and its famous graduates over the last fifty years from "Bringing Up the Brass," the autobiography of Sgt. Marty Maher, U. S. A., retired, who served at the military academy as soldier and civilian physical education instructor for half a century.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 17 -- Austria appealed directly to the United Nations today to call for the speedy conclusion of a treaty with the Western powers and the Soviet Union that would end the eight-year occupation of the country and restore its full sovereignty.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Dec. 17 -- In its first nine months of operation, "Government by Committee" has proved more efficient in Uruguay than a "Presidential Regime" like that in the United States, Dr. Andres Martinez Trueba, President of the Governing Council and a former President of Uruguay, said today.

Faced with continuance of a low sugar import quota by the United States, the Dominican Republic is negotiating a proposed new trade agreement designed to switch a large part of its annual $60,000,000 purchases here to Great Britain, it was asserted yesterday by Dr. Felix W. Bernardino, Dominican consul general. The conference was held at the consulate, 30 Rockefeller Plaza.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Dec. 17 -- Navy's fast-breaking basketball team, sparked by Center Don Lange's 31 tallies and a 25-point effort by Forward John Clune, turned back Rutgers, 95 -- 73, today for its fifth straight victory.

LONDON, Dec. 17 -- The stock markets maintained their slightly improved tone today although business remained sparse in most sections. British Government securities were extremely quiet while awaiting details of the Anglo Iranian Oil Company's stock issue.

Twenty million dollars has been expended by Hadassah, the Women's Zionist Organization of America, on its Youth Aliyah (youth immigration) activities in Israel in the last eighteen and a half years, it was reported yesterday by Moshe Kol, co-treasurer of the Jewish Agency for Palestine, and chairman of the Youth Aliyah management committee in Israel.

The finding of the Loyalty Review Board that "there is no reasonable doubt" of the loyalty of John P. Davies Jr. to the United States does not, unfortunately, repair the damage that has been done to Mr. Davies. This career official was subjected to charges that led to his suspension from the State Department a year and a half ago.

Two metropolitan quintets will be protecting unbeaten records tonight as Temple and Western Kentucky invade Madison Square Garden. The Owls face New York University in the twenty-fifth meeting between the schools while Western Kentucky, also undefeated, tackles Seton Hall.

With the aid of plenty of safety pins and Scotch tape the Administration has finally succeeded in putting together a new stabilization team of sorts. This new team -- the fourth to take the field in the space of less than two years since wage-price controls were introduced -- is built around the only "old pro" its roster boasts -- Michael DiSalle of Toledo.

PARIS, Dec. l7 -- Military sources in a position to know and judge the facts maintain that there is no margin for error in the European military situation and that the tendency of the North Atlantic Council to slow down or stretch out defense efforts courts disaster.

PARIS, Dec. 17 -- The North Atlantic Council formally concurred today in the French thesis that the war in Indo-China was a common security interest and that the French effort there deserved "continuing support" from France's Atlantic allies.

Plans for the publication of a Bible for Roman Catholics that would combine the new translation of the first eight books of the Old Testament with the Douai version were disclosed yesterday with the filing in Federal Court of a voluntary bankruptcy petition by William H. Wise Co., Inc., publisher of a number of popular books.

I note that Carmine G. DeSapio, on behalf of the New York County Democrats, will press for the direct election of district leaders as one of the electoral reforms to be presented to the Legislature in January.
Home owners in the United States have 10,000,000 water heaters that are eight or more years old. Of these about 1,000,000 annually "die" of corrosion or other causes.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 17 -- The United States accused the Soviet Union today of having used its veto in an apparent attempt to wreck the United Nations, and attacked a number of Soviet-sponsored candidates as unfit for admission to the world organization.

Sales of Westinghouse Electric Corporation this year will total more than $1,400,000,000, Gwilym A. Price, president, predicted yesterday in a year-end statement. He said this will constitute a record for the company.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (AP) -- The Bureau of the Census reported today cotton consumption for the period of Nov. 2-29 averaged 38,961 bales for each working day.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities, the Federal Reserve Board reported today, shows the following principal changes for the week ended Dec. 10:
The Appellate Division reversed yesterday a lower court ruling that directed the arbitration of charges that the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel had withheld $3,000,000 in tips from "banquet waiters."

This is a season when we examine some of the verities. The physicists tell us that nothing is ever destroyed. It merely changes form. The kindness you do is returned in warmth of gratitude. The gift made to the needy enriches another's life, but by some miracle does not impoverish the donor. The sympathy bestowed on an unfortunate neighbor produces a mutual alchemy of benefit.

A record number of city parents -- answering the invitation of teachers and administrators -- visited the public schools last month in "Open School Week," Dr. William Jansen, Superintendent of Schools, reported yesterday. A total of 881,349 visitors was recorded this year, an increase of 157,389 over the previous record, which was established in 1951.

TANGIER, Dec. 17 -- Only two men -- the Sultan of Morocco and the Bey of Tunis -- still block achievement of French political objectives in North Africa after the tragic events of the past twelve days in this troubled area.
TRENTON, Dec. 17 -- Present methods of dealing with chronic illness were outlined today by experts in various fields to assist the State Division of Chronic Illness in planning a broadened program.

After searching for fifteen minutes for a fire in the vicinity of Broadway and Forty-third Street, firemen in four engines and two trucks were redirected and converged yesterday at 1:22 P. M. on 1571 Broadway, the old Strand Theatre Building at Forty-seventh Street The Warner Theatre, in that building, has been closed for several months.

Ground-breaking ceremonies were held yesterday on the site of the large apartment group which will replace old landmarks in the block bounded by Broadway, University Place. Eighth and Ninth Streets, near Wanamaker's.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- The United States made a second effort today to deliver a note asking the Soviet Union to return or compensate for an Air Force C-47 cargo plane forced down by Soviet planes in Hungary more than a year ago.
Creation of a permanent citizen's commission to advise the Government on practical international economic policies was proposed yesterday by Warren Lee Pierson, chairman of Trans World Airlines.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Dec. 17 (AP) -- Skip Alexander, St. Petersburg, Fla., and Jim Ferrier, San Francisco, fired 7-under-par 65's today to pace the field in a pro-amateur curtain-raised to the $13,000 international four-ball golf tournament.

TARRYTOWN, N. Y., Dec. 17 -- Early construction of the projected $4,200,000 Phelps Memorial Hospital in Mount Pleasant Township, midway between Tarrytown and Ossining, became a virtual certainty today when the fund committee qualified for an $800,000 gift from the Rockefeller family and $500,000 and a site from the James Foundation.

The precarious nature of any cooperation with any Communist regime is illustrated again by the provocative manner in which Marshal Tito is beginning to throw his weight around. He has just broken off diplomatic relations with the Vatican in retaliation for the elevation to Cardinal of Archbishop Stepinac, recently released from a Tito prison in which other clergymen are still languishing.

Fordham's undefeated basketball squad maintained its reputation of being a great second-half team last night when it swept to a 73-53 victory over City College, after being held on even terms for practically all of the first two quarters. The victory was the Rams' sixth, five of the decisions having been scored over metropolitan rivals.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (AP) -- American farmers produced a record volume of agricultural products this year despite handicaps of drought, reduced acreages and mostly lower farm prices. Furthermore, most of the crops were of generally excellent quality.

Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower announced yesterday that he had arranged a series of meetings with Republican leaders in Congress to develop an Administration legislative program for dealing with Government reorganization, inflation control and other vital issues.

TANGIER, Dec. 17 -- The trial of an American citizen -- a former Jersey City resident -- on a charge of armed robbery on the high seas opened today before a United States consular court in a quiet, pleasant room of the ancient Moorish palace that serves as the United States Legation here.

SYDNEY, Australia, Dec. 17 (UP) -- The "Affair Sedgman" was dropped today for all practical purposes when Alrick H. Man, manager of the United States Davis Cup team, said he would not protest the Aussie tennis star's amateur status.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Dec. 17 -- Senator Pat McCarran, Democat of Nevada and chairman of the Senate Internal Security subcommittee, said today the indictment yesterday of Prof. Owen Lattimore was "inevitable" and the Department of Justice was "to be commended for a fair presentation of evidence before the grand jury."

CHICAGO, Dec. 17 -- Grain and soybean futures were all under pressure of long liquidation today, and, in the case of wheat, prices dropped to new crop lows for all deliveries except May. On the setbacks the lower prices attracted moderate investment buying and considerable profit - taking by shorts, but rallies were still not very convincing.

Those engaged in many phases of agriculture who join brand name manufacturers in long-range planning will emerge as the leaders in their fields in the next five years, it is predicted by Ambrose E. Stevens, vice president of the Minute Maid Corporation.

A strong hint that the sailing ahead might not be so smooth for ships with National Maritime Union crews unless steamship operators bargained in good faith was given yesterday by Joseph Curran, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations affiliate.

Thirty prominent store executives from all sections of the country will serve on the committee of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, whose purpose will be to chart retailing's role in the post-defense economy.

SEATTLE, Dec. 17 -- A possibility that the new Congress may be asked to take the Federal Government entirely out of the power business in the Pacific Northwest and make Columbia River development a regional responsibility was foreseen today by delegates attending a meeting of the Bonneville Regional Advisory Council.

SYRACUSE, Dec. 17 -- A fifty-four-count indictment charging Cargill, Inc., grain dealer, and two of its employes in charge of the corporation's elevators in Albany with converting 80,000 bushels of U. S. Commodity Credit Corporation corn to use of the Cargill company and to use of an unnamed person, or persons, was returned by a Federal grand jury here this afternoon.

Operations of Ralston Purina Company and domestic subsidiaries for the year ended on Sept. 30 resulted in a net profit of $8,512,781, it was announced yesterday. This compares with a net profit of $8,784,341 for the year ended on Sept. 30, 1951.

TOKYO, Dec. 17 -- Communist North Korea today joined Russia and Communist China in denouncing the United Nations resolution based on India's proposal for ending the stalemate in Korean truce negotiations.

The announcement that Canada is granting to the United States leases and other facilities for American planes and Air Force personnel is one of those many items of Canadian-American news which Americans will take in their stride, as if it were in no sense unusual. In reality, the relations between our two countries are unique in the world.

A Canadian-American merger was announced yesterday to provide seafood from the whole Atlantic seaboard for the American market. The SeaPak Corporation of St. Simon's Island, Ga., has joined with the newly organized Fortune Bay Products, Ltd., of St. John's, Nfld.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 17 -- Howard Hughes was elected chairman of the board of directors of R. K. O. Radio Pictures Corporation this afternoon shortly after A. D. Simpson, vice chairman of the National Bank of Commerce of Houston, Tex., was named as the fifth and final member of the board.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State-designate, was reported by a New York publicist today to have said he had recommended Alger Hiss for president of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace despite reports that Hiss was "a sort of fellow traveler."
LONDON, Dec. 17 -- A howling gale drove the 53,000-ton liner United States broadside against the quay as she tried to sail from Southampton today.

VIENNA, Dec. 17 -- President Klement Gottwald's statement in Prague yesterday that it would be difficult to fulfill the Czechoslovakian Five-Year Plan as a result of sabotage by Rudolf Slansky and his fellow-conspirators was followed by a pessimistic speech today by Premier Antonin Zapotocky.

The Andrea Radio Corporation, Long Island City manufacturer of television sets, will again distribute its annual Christmas bonus to all employes ,Frank A. D. Andrea, president announced yesterday. It will be 3 to 5 per cent of the total amount earned by each employe during the current year and is based on length of service with the company.
The crisscross pattern of the stock market was again in evidence yesterday as the absence of reinvestment demand failed to outweigh selling for income tax accounts.

Experimentation with the pedestrian control system will enter a new phase tomorrow when "Walk" and "Don't Walk" signs employing a variation of signal colors other than red and green will be tried out at Broadway and Thirty-fourth Street, Traffic Commissioner T. T. Wiley announced yesterday.
NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Dec. 17 -- A housewife will discover when she opens her mail tomorrow that City Judge Christopher J. Murphy of New Rochelle is lacking neither in chivalry nor Christmas spirit.

PARIS, Dec. 17 -- In face of a strong warning by Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway, Supreme Allied Commander in Europe, and his staff of experts against reducing the Allied military construction program in Europe, the civilian leaders of the North Atlantic treaty powers were reported tonight to be preparing to slash the proposed program by about 45 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (AP) -- The Air Force today said it would need 4,864 acres for a proposed $28,500,000 air base at Plattsburg, N. Y. The figures were made public by Representative Clarence E. Kilburn, Republican of New York, who has proposed that Camp Drum, N. Y., be selected as an alternate site for the base.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 17 -- The Social, Humanitarian and Cultural Committee, by a vote of 37 to 0, approved today the proposed convention on political rights for women and sent it to the United Nations General Assembly.

Africa's economic "growing pains," including the hurried adjustment of "virtually neolithic tribesmen" to industrial society, were described yesterday by two Columbia University professors who returned Saturday from a fourteen-week journey through the central and southern parts of the continent.

Because taxation has placed the "so-called patron in a class as extinct as the dinosaur," the American Museum of Natural History is seeking to broaden its base of gifts from private individuals, Alexander M. White, president of the museum, declared yesterday in the institution's eighty-third annual report.

IT isn't often that George Halas makes a mistake. But the Papa Bear was guilty of an atrocious fumble in the case of Bobby Layne. The blond Texan was the No. 1 draft pick in 1948 and Halas added him to his collection although he already was hip-deep in star passers. He had Sid Luckman and he had Johnny Lujack. It was like Rockefeller finding another oil well.

The proposal to build a New York Coliseum at Columbus Circle was endorsed yesterday by the local branches of two national convention-holding organizations and attacked as a dramatic example of bad planning by a third organization, the Citizens Housing and Planning Council of New York Inc.

Harvard Equities, Inc., operators, have resold the five-story apartment house at 2833-5 Decatur Avenue, the Bronx, to a client of Sara Horn, lawyer. William L. Rosen, lawyer, represented the seller, and Nehring Brothers, Inc., were the brokers.

CHICAGO, Dec. 17 -- James G. Cross, 40-year-old secretary-treasurer of the Bakery and Confectionary Workers International Union, A. F. L., was named today to succeed William F. Schnitzler as the union's president with a salary of $17,500 a year.
Distributors of upholstery fabrics to the popular and medium-priced furniture trade have built up a backlog of orders that will extend through the first quarter of 1953, it was learned yesterday.
BOSTON, Dec. 17 (UP) -- Four more balky witnesses were cited for contempt today for "obstructing justice" in the Federal grand jury investigation of the $1,219,000 Brink's hold-up.

LONDON, Dec. 17 -- The British Government announced today that it had asked the United States for a full report on the Pongam prisoner riot in Korea Sunday in which eighty-four Communist prisoners were killed.

With the broad canvas it has to cover, and some limit on time and powers, the New York State Crime Commission must necessarily leave parts of the landscape only lightly sketched in -- as to the courts, for instance. Here the Association of the Bar of the City of New York steps in.

Joseph F. Breslin, 33-year-old mounted city patrolman, was arraigned yesterday in Brooklyn Felony Court on a charge of burglary. Magistrate Eugene R. Canudo freed him in $500 bail for a hearing in the same court Tuesday.

ITHACA, N. Y., Dec. 17 -- Cornell's basketball team defeated Harvard, 64 -- 56, in an overtime game before 2,500 in Barton Hall tonight as Lee Morton set a scoring record for the court with 31 points. The game was an Eastern Intercollegiate League opener.

The letter addressed to you by the leaders of the Hungarian, Lithuanian, Czechoslovak, Ukrainian and Albanian organizations in the United States on the question of the revision of the Chinese text of the Genocide Convention is based, I believe, entirely on unfounded suspicions.
ACCORDING to reports received of the first few days of the New Jersey deer season, the hunting is excellent, but the shooting is only fair, which constitutes a normal situation.

The nation's gasoline stocks last week increased 92,000 barrels, according to the weekly figures of the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end, they amounted to 129,562,000 barrels compared with 129,470,000 a week earlier and 125,375,000 a year ago.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Dec. 17 -- State police patroling the New Jersey Turnpike are using radar to catch speeders, it was revealed today by Lieut. George L. Probert, commanding officer of the turnpike police detachment.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Dec. 17 -- Official fraternity control of the Williams College student government was ended tonight when the students approved a new constitution by a vote of 499 to 240, six votes more than the necessary two-thirds majority.
HAVANA, Dec. 17 (AP) -- The Cuban Government's National Economy Board has recommended construction of a mill in Cuba to make newsprint from bagasse -- the waste of sugar cane.

PARIS, Dec. 17 -- After an informal but very secret meeting tonight the French Cabinet was scheduled to make a final decision tomorrow on the course to follow in the French protectorate of Tunisia, particularly regarding the nominal and extremely recalcitrant ruler of that country, Sidi Mohammed el Amin Pasha, the Bey of Tunis.

Israel needs to create a "reservoir of scientific knowledge and talents" to replace the "great repository of Jewish scholarship and science" that has in large part been destroyed in Eastern Europe, David Sarnoff, chairman of the board of the Radio Corporation of America, declared last night.

Prime Minister Robert G. Menzies of Australia intimated after his arrival by air yesterday from Amsterdam that he would see Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower while in New York. Mr. Menzies, who had been attending the British Commonwealth Ministers Conference in London, is scheduled to leave for home from La Guardia Airport at noon Sunday.

Mark up another one for the New York Rangers. Coach Bill Cook's skaters swashbuckled their way through the Boston Bruins in a National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night and set down the Massachusetts outfit, 5 to 0. The Rangers now have four victories to their credit, and are still resting comfortably in last place.

In expressing our appreciation of your very timely editorial "Times Square" we would like also to express the hope that its message will be taken to heart by every city official, elective and appointive (including the vacationing Mayor), to whom present conditions in the Times Square area may be ascribed.

Music far removed from conventional fare -- a German Requiem and a setting of the story of the Nativity by Heinrich Schuetz -- was offered last night by the Cantata Singers under the leadership of their scholarly conductor, Arthur Mendel, at the Church of Heavenly Rest.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- President Truman tonight urged the stepped-up development of new weapons and fighting techniques to stay the Communists from "plunging the world into war."
CHICAGO, Dec. 17 -- A team of surgeons today separated the 15-month-old Brodie Siamese twins, joined at the head at birth, in a day-long operation, but doctors said the "ultimate outcome is unknown."

CHICAGO, Dec. 17 (AP) -- Julius Boros, golf's Cinderella man, today officially was crowned 1952 money-winning champion and sharp-shooting Jack Burke Jr. was certified as Vardon Trophy winner for the best scoring average.

PANAMA, Dec. 17 (AP) -- An exiled leader of Venezuela's opposition Democratic Union for a Republic party (U. R. D.) charged today that his nation's military-backed Government had falsified the count to gain victory for its supporters in Venezuela's recent election.

Stories that children all over the world undoubtedly heard last night at bedtime recently came to these shores in their original manuscript form. The ageless "Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs" is among them; also the romantic "Sleeping Beauty," "Hansel and Gretel," "Rumpelstiltskin" and others familiar to young and old, in a collection of forty-seven fairy tales that the brothers Grimm published in 1812.
In the vast array of Christmas candies now being offered, chocolates from Europe are perhaps most novel.

Since Christmas is almost at hand, every honorable and right-thinking father now is considering the matter of buying a bicycle for his son. This is a traditional present, and worthy, and the world is a far better place because of father's consideration.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- Steel allocations for the second quarter of the coming year will be at the highest levels since the outbreak of the Korean war, the Defense Production Administration announced tonight.

Leif Gilstad has been promoted from vice president in the Chicago office of the Transportation Association of America to first vice president in the New York offices in charge of all activities in the Eastern region.

Major waterfront racketeers considered Claremont Terminal in Jersey City such a rich plum after the Army's Corps of Engineers moved in that they fought a bitter battle to control the establishment, witnesses told the State Crime Commission yesterday.

The situation in French Morocco, according to the secretary general of the Istiqlal, or independence party, who has been here since October, is that the millions of Moroccans are being deprived of the most elementary civil and political rights, and reduced to the grade of second-class citizens, in their own country.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Dec. 17 -- The Mapai and General Zionist parties agreed today to postpone for one day the signing of their agreement to enter into a coalition while an attempt is made to broaden the grouping by the inclusion of the Hapoel Hamizrahi, the religious labor party, and the Progressive party.

Mayor Impellitteri's proposal to turn the municipal transit lines over to an independent transit authority was stymied yesterday by a politically minded Board of Estimate that also withheld approval of the Mayor's proposals for new sources of revenue to help balance the city's budget for the fiscal year starting next July 1.

The New York Post and its editor, James A. Wechsler, filed libel suits yesterday against Walter Winchell, newspaper, radio and television commentator, asking damages of $1,525,000 for what they alleged were false charges of pro-communism.
The New York Central Railroad borrowed $11,625,000 in the public market yesterday on equipment trust certificates maturing from 1954 to 1968 at an interest cost of 3.227 per cent.

In the closing days of the eight-month-long Communist conspiracy trial, a woman juror was excused yesterday by Federal Judge Edward J. Dimock for having discussed the case and expressed opinions about it.

Construction of the handsome new East Harlem General Hospital that eventually is to replace the gloomy, century-old Metropolitan Hospital is 45 per cent completed, Frederick H. Zurmuhlen, Commissioner of Public Works, disclosed yesterday.

New York's 235 savings and loan associations reported that their net savings rose $10,317,000 last month, an increase of 56 per cent over the corresponding month last year. The Savings Association League of New York State reported yesterday that savings held in these thrift institutions were $1,617,346,000 at the end of the month.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 17 (AP) -- Hal Price Headley's Libba, only filly in the race, came from last place to overhaul the leaders in the $7,500-added Hurricane Handicap at Tropical Park today and score by three-quarters of a length over D. J. Gleeson's Chombro.

The delivery of Christmas gifts to patients at Goldwater Memorial Hospital on Welfare Island began yesterday with a helicopter visit from Santa Claus. The air trip was arranged according to Mrs. Beatrice H. Hill, chairman of recreation at the hospital, because construction activities precluded the delivery of gifts by trucks as in the past.

Fine checks were highlighted among the crisp sheer wools designed to impact fresh chic beneath furs and winter coats and shown yesterday in Bonwit Teller's presentation of Larry Aldrich designs at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
LYNN, Mass., Dec. 17 (AP) -- The Rev. Edward B. Wilcox, crusading anti-Communist Unitarian minister, announced today he was resigning from the ministry because of what he termed "smear attacks."

Manufacturers of shells, tanks, guns and similar military goods, together with shipbuilders and exporters, were the only ones of twenty classifications of steel consumers which received more finished steel during the first nine months of 1952 than in the similar part of last year.

Lieut. Gen. Henry Larsen of Denver, Colo., president of the National Association of State Civil Defense Directors, charged yesterday after a conference with Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the President-elect, that the civilian defense program had not received the positive and effective support it needed from President Truman's Administration.

Industrial relations are a relatively unexplored dimension in advertising, according to Harold Kathman, staff member of Fisher, Rudge Neblett, management, labor and community problems consultants. He defines such relations as "all those things that affect the attitude of employes toward each other, toward management and their jobs."

Activity improved yesterday in most of the New York commodity markets although volume still was not heavy. Both cocoa and potatoes reached the price limits for the day but potato futures fell off before the close. Prices closed irregularly with wool, hides, lead and zinc lower.
CAMDEN, N. J., Dec. 18 -- At noon tomorrow the first commercial ultra-high frequency television transmitters will be shipped by the Radio Corporation of America from its plant here.
The railroad issues gave new life to the stock market yesterday, ending the indecision of the three preceding sessions.

MANILA, Dec. 18 -- A report on the land tenure situation in the Philippines drawn up by the United States Mutual Security Agency has been rejected by President Elpidio Quirino. At the President's request, the United States Embassy has canceled plans for public circulation of the report.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Dec. 18 -- A three-pronged personnel management program, designed to keep municipal salaries in step with changing conditions and to divorce routine public jobs from politics, was put into effect here today.

When Winston Churchill picked Gen. Sir Gerald Robert Templer, K. C. B., K. B. E., C. M. G., D. S. O., as High Commissioner for Malaya he sent out a distinguished soldier who has earned a reputation for defeating the Communists in that battle-scarred area.

CHICAGO, Dec. 18 (UP) -- Player Coach Sid Abel beat Goalie Jim Henry for a score with less than six minutes to play tonight to give the Chicago Black Hawks a 3-3 tie with the Boston Bruins in a National Hockey League battle before 6,614 fans.

PARIS, Dec. 9 -- The coming coronation of Queen Elizabeth of Britain influences magnificent gifts now being shown by Paris jewelers. At Carrier's Christmas exposition, the rose, the national flower of England, is exquisite as a clip, a three-dimensional half-blown rose of paved jonquil diamonds and a leaf of emeralds.

Young persons interested in fashion design would have found much to attract their attention at the eighth annual fashion review presented last night by the Fashion Institute of Technology, 225 West Twenty-fourth Street. Here, through an arrangement of picture slides, the audience received an over-all view of the school's educational program.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended last Saturday totaled 721,252 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 2,093 cars, or 0.3 per cent more than for the preceding week last year, and 51,879 cars, or fewer than for the corresponding weeklast year, and 51,897 cars, or 6.7 per cent fewer than during the corresponding week two years ago.

The identification of an original Twelfth century manuscript of poses Maimonides, the medieval philosopher, codifier and physician, the rare book room of the Jewish Theological Seminary of America's library, was announced yesterday by Dr. Louis Finkelstein, chancellor of the seminary.

BOSTON, Dec. 18 -- The Federal Bureau of Investigation has named Joseph J. (Specs) O'Keefe, 44 years old, of Boston as one of the masked men who robbed Brink's, Inc., of $1,219,000 on the night of Jan. 17, 1950.

David I. Mackie, vice president and general counsel of the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad, yesterday was named chairman of the Eastern Railroad Presidents Conference. The conference is concerned with all matters affecting railroads in the East.

VIENNA, Dec. 18 (Reuters) -- Seven of eight leading officials of Austria's nationalized Creditanstalt Bank were jailed today for terms of three weeks to six months and heavily fined for alleged illegal currency dealings. An eighth official was found not guilty.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- Following is a summary of the findings and recommendations of The President's Commission on the Health Needs of the Nation in its report, entitled "Building America's Health," transmitted to Mr. Truman today:

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Dec. 18 (AP) -- The oldest golfer in the international four-ball tournament -- Miami Beach's 51-year-old Willie Klein -- teamed with a New Yorker, Al Brosch, today to spring a first-round surprise by ousting Sam Snead and Jim Ferrier, 3 and 2.

TANGLER, Dec. 18 -- Sidney Paley -- "Nylon Sid" as he was sometimes known in Tangier's raffish business circle -- the 34- year-old Jersey City man accused of complicity in an armed robbery on the high seas, today sputtered an indignant denial of the charges from the witness stand of the United States Consular Court here.
The police reported the finding of the body of an 85-year-old woman yesterday in a junk-cluttered, fourth-floor room in a condemned tenement at 631 East Ninth Street.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Dec. 18 -- The Israeli Government rejected today, "with utmost vigor," a note in which the Czechoslovak Government twelve days ago charged Israel's Minister in Prague, Dr. Ariyeh Leon Kubovy, with interfering in Czechoslovakia's internal affairs and demanded his recall. Israel protested against the note.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 18 (AP) -- Ellis W. Ryan resigned as president of the Indians late today and his supporters in the club's front-office dispute agreed to sell nearly all their stock holdings. Myron H. Wilson was elected to succeed Ryan.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- The Republican advisers of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower were said authoritatively today to be preparing with his assent one of the most generous patronage policies in history to repay the President-elect's Democratic backers in the South.

HACKENSACK, N. J., Dec. 18 -- A radar-operated camera that makes, unattended, a record of automobiles exceeding the speed limit on busy highways was demonstrated here today to state law enforcement, highway and turnpike authorities.
CLEVELAND, Dec. 18 -- Officials of near-by Beachwood village today were ordered to issue a permit to the Euclid Avenue Temple for the construction of a $2,000,000 synagogue in the suburb.
PARIS, Dec. 18 -- France sent an ultimatum today to the Bey of Tunis in a message approved at a Cabinet meeting.

Dr. Juliusz Katz-Suchy, demoted last year from head of the Polish delegation at the United Nations to an alternate delegate and booked to fly home tonight, was critically injured early yesterday morning when he drove an automobile into a pillar at the Manhattan end of the Triborough Bridge.
TOKYO, Friday, Dec. 19 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,468, covering Thursday's operations:

BONN, Germany, Dec. 18 -- A government-sponsored committee to activate trade with the Soviet Union and Soviet bloc countries was organized yesterday in Cologne. The committee is composed of representatives of West German associations of bankers, industrialists, export and import concerns, insurance companies and transportation organizations.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- "High-pressure" athletic competition for grade and junior high school boys and girls was opposed in a report on a three-year study issued today through the National Education Association.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 18 -- A musical with a Metropolitan Opera setting is on the planning board at Twentieth Century-Fox bearing the identification label "The Girl With Black Glasses." Walter Reisch, the author, has been engaged to prepare the screen play, which will have as its central character a young soprano who is called on to substitute for the prima donna on opening night and becomes a great success.

Governors of the New York Stock Exchange held a policy meeting yesterday and voted to remain open on both Friday, Dec. 26, and Friday, Jan. 2. The Chicago Board of Trade came to the same decision but voted to close at 1 P. M. Eastern standard time on both Wednesday, Dec. 24, and Wednesday, Dec. 31.

PARIS, Dec. 18 -- The North Atlantic Council adjourned today after agreeing that $229,600,000 should be spent on bases and communications work to be begun in 1953, a portion of the approximately $473,000,000 that the military authorities had requested for 1953 and 1954.

Acting almost at the same moment that union-management negotiations to prevent a New Year's Eve bus strike collapsed, Mayor Impellitteri made public last night his long-awaited plan to provide the financial aid needed to finance a forty-hour work-week for 8,000 members of the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., on eight privately owned bus lines.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (AP) -- The Public Power and Water Corporation of Trenton, N. J., urged the Federal Power Commission today to license it to join with Canada in building a big St. Lawrence River power project.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 18 -- The Inter-American Regional Labor Organization voted 46 to 29 at 4 o'clock this morning, after an all-night debate, to shift its headquarters from Havana to Mexico City. The 10-hour discussion ended in what was described here as a partial victory for the United States, which favored Puerto Rico rather than Mexico, but wanted headquarters moved from Cuba.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 18 (AP) -- Secretary General Trygve Lie today asked the United Nations General Assembly for advice on what to do with employes charged by the United States with subversion. Russia immediately labeled the move "rather bizarre."

PARIS, Dec. 18 -- Robert Schuman, French Foreign Minister, said today that a German contribution to the West's defense could be obtained only with United States' support. He was referring to the ratification of the European Army treaty -- long deferred -- which the North Atlantic Council yesterday urged as soon as possible.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- Roger Tubby, acting White House press secretary, today was promoted to press secretary by President Truman. Joseph G. Feeney, legislative assistant to the President, was raised to administrative assistant.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- Department store sales in the week ended Dec. 13 were 4 per cent above sales in the corresponding week last year.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 18 -- The $800,000 libel suit of Martin Gang, attorney against Howard Hughes was dismissed today "without prejudice" by Federal Judge William M. Byrne on the ground that the complaint for general damages failed to specify sufficient facts.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- President Truman said today he had nothing to add or to take away from his criticisms of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower and Gen. Douglas MacArthur, but that he had received a full and fair report on the Korean situation from General of the Army Omar N. Bradley, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff.

NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 18 (AP) -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru said today that India regarded Premier Stalin's mid-October speech offering Russia's support to Communist parties abroad, including India, as a "clear case of interference in internal affairs."

Reluctantly -- because my stake in convention-and-exposition facilities in the country is considerable -- I voice doubts about the soundness of the proposed Coliseum in Columbus Circle. I believe that I can speak with authority on the subject, since my company is engaged professionally in the management of industrial expositions.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- During the week ended Dec. 17, member bank reserves increased $330,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

As the forty-first annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Causes Fund advanced into the last week before Christmas, the tempo of giving increased. In New York, where anonymity is probably greater than in other cities, citizens warmed to the spirit of consideration for fellow beings.

The New York City Ballet last night augmented the repertoire of of its City Center season by the first performance of a new work by Ruthanna Boris, called "Kaleidoscope." It is a slight piece for five dancers, set to a suite by Kabalevsky, written originally as incidental music for a play, and costumed by Alvin Colt.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Dec. 18 -- Faculty members and students sought to help today the two Rutgers University professors who will be dismissed unless they answer Senate subcommittee questions about Communist affiliations before Dec. 31. But the support failed to change the status of the two teachers.

With fresh meat output larger than in some years, roasts share the spotlight with poultry during the holiday season. A handsome roast (if that adjective is permitted in this instance) is the old-fashioned crown of lamb or pork, which, in view of lower prices on both meats, might well be revived this Christmas.
Major college football in 1952 produced four individual single-game marks. The National Collegiate A. A. Service Bureau said yesterday it was not an unusually large number of record feats.

As the United Nations struggles through the last stages of its debates on Tunisia and Morocco one is struck with the fact that nothing has been, can be or will be changed by all the arguing. France boycotted the discussions; the Arab-Asian bloc failed to get through any strong resolutions, and what is being done will merely result in France continuing her direct efforts to reach an agreement with the Tunisian and Moroccan nationalists.

New evidence in the unsolved thirteen-year-old murder of Peter Panto, an insurgent Brooklyn longshoreman, was made public for the first time yesterday by the State Crime Commission as it focused its spotlight on that borough's waterfront.

The State Crime Commission concentrated its attention yesterday on the notorious Camarda family and their underworld associates who have ruled the six so-called Italian locals of the International Longshoremen's Association with an iron hand for the last forty years.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- Senate investigators into the loyalty of American employes of the United Nations were advised today by Dean Acheson, Secretary of State, that President Truman had upheld his department's refusal to identify the officials who manage the security screening of those functionaries.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- The Department of Justice is up a tree in its search for certain proofs that United States petroleum companies are parties with foreign petroleum companies to illegal cartels, and that is where the new Attorney General, Herbert Brownell, will find it when he takes over from James P. McGranery.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- The Federal Government today added 550,000 tons of steel, mostly carbon sheet and strip, to the allocation available to automobile manufacturers and the producers of consumer durable goods for the first quarter of 1953. Improved production rates at the steel mills, strikebound last summer, have made the concession possible.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- The three Congressional leaders who met today with Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the President-elect, will take over their new posts in the House of Representatives Jan. 3 without a contest as the result of a quietly arranged understanding.

JERSEY CITY, Dec. 18 -- Mayor John V. Kenny, Hudson County Democratic leader, whose administration and waterfront associates have been spotlighted by witnesses at the New York State Crime Commission hearings during the past few days, today called an emergency meeting of his political lieutenants.

BERNARDSVILLE, N. J., Dec. 18 -- A big black bear was tracked down today in near-by Harding Township. And that, area residents believe, is the end of the famed Somerset Hills Bear, a honey-loving legend of the hills whose very existence, all these last five years, has been a subject of cracker-barrel debate and commuter train talk.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (AP) -- The United States bought more from other nations in October than in September and also sold more of its wares abroad, the Bureau of the Census said today.

LONDON, Dec. 18 (AP) -- Gales and blizzards relaxed their grip on Western Europe tonight. Although snow blanketed much of the area from Scandinavia to Italy, ships, trains and motor vehicles generally resumed normal operations.

It is welcome news that the two leading maritime associations have pledged themselves to cooperate in efforts to wrest control of the waterfront from criminals. Without the cooperation of the employers, forced or voluntary, conditions on our piers could not have deteriorated to the extent shown by the shocking disclosures of the State Crime Commission.
DETROIT, Dec. 18 -- A University of Detroit professor announced today he had perfected a new system of operating an airplane, so simple that a beginner could learn its rudiments in two hours.

The Government-owned liner Washington, idle in reduced operational status at Pier 16, Staten Island, since Nov. 28 with a skeleton crew of eighty aboard, will be laid up soon permanently in the James River, Va., reserve fleet, it was announced yesterday by the Maritime Administration.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 18 (UP) -- Truman Gibson, secretary of the International Boxing Club, said today that Archie Moore's next fight probably would be a non-title bout with either Jake La Motta or Danny Nardico at the St. Louis Arena on Feb. 18.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (AP) -- House investigators charged today that Army ordnance officers had spent several hundred thousand dollars in a "face-saving" effort to correct the mistakes of an "inexperienced" company assigned to modernize scarce bazooka launchers.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 18 -- The United States told the United Nations today that it would continue to work for restoration of Austria's sovereignty, but would not leave the country "enslaved or beholden to any foreign power."

Holiday gobblers for the Christmas feast will probably cost a little more than they did at Thanksgiving. Small turkeys have advanced 4 cents a pound since last week-end and though the large birds are unchanged in price, a slight increase is expected.

Rudolf Bing, who succeeded Edward Johnson as general manager of the Metropolitan Opera in 1950, has been engaged for another, three years, it was announced yesterday by George A. Sloan, chairman of the board of directors.

The Board of Education announced yesterday the completion of a $167,400 building restoration of the Erasmus Hall Academy, which today marks its 165th anniversary as the forerunner of Erasmus Hall High School, Brooklyn, and the first chartered secondary school in the state.

BUFFALO, Dec. 18 -- The recently interrupted strike of 1,500 workers at the American Locomotive Company's plant at Dunkirk, N. Y., became the focal point today of the nation's first constitutional test of the eighty-day Taft-Hartley Act labor injunction.

The Board of Estimate approved yesterday the retirement application of Julius Wolff, chief accountant in the office of Controller Lazarus Joseph. Mr. Wolff, who is 68 years old, has been in the city's service forty-six years. His retirement becomes effective Jan. 1.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 18 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower is expected to appoint Mrs. Oswald B. Lord of New York, who was co-chairman of the Citizens for Eisenhower-Nixon during the Presidential campaign, to succeed Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt as United States representative on the United Nations Human Rights Commission.

The educational value to parents of participation in a cooperative nursery school is a subject of discussion -- and some argument -- among parent educators. Such activity can have valuable results both for the parents and children involved, according to Josephine S. Gottsdanker, director of the Hoff Community Nursery School, Santa Barbara, Calif.

The concert given by George Szell and the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra last night in Carnegie Hall was devoted partly to classic symphonic literature, in the instances of Mozart's "Magic Flute" overture and "Jupiter Symphony," and partly to opera, as exemplified by the finale of Richard Strauss' "Salome," with Astrid Varnay as the Salome, Blanche Thebom as Herodias, and Set Svanholm as Herod.

Extension to Jan. 31 of the four-week drive of the Community Service Society, begun on Nov. 16, to enlist support in the prevention of juvenile delinquency was announced yesterday by Keith S. McHugh, general chairman of the drive and president of the society and the New York Telephone Company.

PARIS, Dec. 18 -- The North Atlantic Treaty Council's decision here today to raise $229,600,000 for the military construction program of the Western alliance means that the "hard core" of airbases and other facilities needed by the Allied forces can go forward without delay.

MADRID, Dec. 18 -- Gen. J. Lawton Collins, the Chief of Staff of the United States Army, flew to Lisbon today after a series of meetings with some of Spain's highest military leaders, including Gen. Augustin Munoz Grande, the Minister of Defense, and Lieut. Gen. Juan Vigon, Chief of the General Staff.

MADRAS, India, Dec. 18 Community development projects launched throughout India last October with United States financial aid were described by a prominent Indian social scientist today as this country's "greatest experiment" in mass education as a contribution to higher living standards.

Christmas carols with an international flavor echoed through the marble halls of the New York Public Library yesterday as the United Nations Choir, in its first public appearance, sang the songs associated with the Nativity as a prelude to the opening of the library's Yuletide exhibition depicting the Christmas story in several languages.
VIENNA, Dec. 18 (Reuters) -- Delegates from the West today broke through the curtain of pro-Communist speeches at the so-called peace conference here and criticized Soviet policies.

BERLIN, Dec. 18 -- East Germany's Communist politburo decided last Monday night not to let Bishop Otto Dibelius, head of the German Evangelical Church, set foot again in the Soviet Zone of Germany, according to a report accepted as factual by church circles here.

SYDNEY, Australia, Friday. Dec. 19 (AP) -- Vic Seixas of Philadelphia and Tony Trabert of Cincinnati scored an easy victory today in the doubles against Italy, and put the United States into the challenge round for the Davis Cup tennis trophy against Australia in Adelaide later this month.

More than 800 eligible field and office workers of the Davey Tree Expert Company in the United States and Canada will share $101,000 of company profits for Christmas, it was announced yesterday by Martin L. Davey Jr., president.

ALBANY, Dec. 18 -- The State Educational Conference Board today called on the Legislature to increase state aid to education by $90,000,000 a year to help local school boards regain the purchasing power they had lost through inflation.

At a special meeting yesterday the Board of Education awarded contracts totaling $13,175,050 for the construction of six new schools, including the city's first high school building in more than ten years.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- Who rides down Pennsylvania Avenue with whom on Inauguration Day? Does President Truman ride with his successor, Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, or vice versa?

ALBANY Dec. 18 -- The Public Service Commission today approved the merger of the Rockland Gas Company of Spring Valley and the Rockland Light and Power Company of Nyack, effective at the end of this month. The merger is expected to reduce natural gas rates for some customers of the new company.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 18 (UP) -- President Juan D. Peron of Argentina today sent a cable to Archie Moore, thanking him for having dedicated his victory over Joey Maxim to him and for the offer to send to him the gloves he wore to win the title.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 18 -- An abrupt switch by Soviet-bloc and Latin American states defeated tonight a neutral-power Palestine proposal that had asked for direct Arab-Israeli negotiations to end the four-year-old dispute.

A grand jury investigation into a purported $10,000 payment in 1949 to former Mayor William O'Dwyer is being conducted to determine whether he "committed the crime of perjury" or violated the Penal Law, it was revealed yesterday at a General Sessions hearing of a contempt charge against Jerry Finkelstein.

The Sinclair Oil Corporation filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday, covering an offering of $101,758,900 convertible subordinated debentures to its common stockholders. The debentures are to be dated Jan. 15 and will mature on that date in 1983.

The National Foreign Trade Council offered specific recommendations yesterday for further United States opposition to a General Assembly Economic Committee's resolution approving the right of any country to nationalize private property.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 18 -- In a scathing attack on the Vatican and on Archbishop Aloysius Stepinac, whom the Pope has designated to be a Cardinal, Foreign Minister Edvard Kardelj explained today why Yugoslavia had severed diplomatic relations with the Holy See.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 18 -- More than 150 persons attended an organizational meeting tonight in the Trusteeship Council chamber for a United Nations International Housing Cooperative, for which 430 persons already have signed up at a fee of $3 each. Ernest Weissman of the Social Welfare Division presided as temporary chairman.

THE most peculiar novel I have read this year is "Limbo"* by Bernard Wolfe, an incredible mish-mash of science fiction, psychological theory and political parable. Mr. Wolfe is a former editor of popular science magazines, an avid student of psychiatry and psychology, an intensely earnest viewer with alarm of the trends of modern civilization and an exasperatingly awkward and clumsy writer.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- The President's Advisory Committee on Management recommended today that permanent power be granted to the President to reorganize the branches of the Federal Government under his jurisdiction. This authority will expire by limitation on March 31, 1953.

OTTAWA, Dec. 18 -- The Canadian Parliament adjourned last night until Jan. 13. The holiday adjournment came in the midst of a storm of criticism for Prime Minister Louis S. St. Laurent's Liberal government over irregularities in operations of the Petawawa army camp.

Milton O. Loysen, director of the Division of Employment of the State Labor Department, reported yesterday that unemployment insurance executives from seven northeastern states would meet here early next year to consider their joint action to insure the solvency of all unemployment insurance funds.
Items for the holiday table, including decorations as well as such practical objects as flatware or dishes, are on view in the new Alice H. Marks shop, 18 East Fifty-third Street.
DETROIT, Dec. 18 (AP) -- Bobby Layne and Doak Walker -- who played on the same high school football team nine years ago -- were question-marks on the Detroit Lions pro team today.

The two three-story apartment houses accommodating thirty-four families on a plot 100 by 173 feet at 357 and 363 West End Avenue in Elizabeth, N. J., have been purchased for investment by the Ruthie Corporation. Florence and Herman Siegel and Sally and Benjamin Colton were the sellers. J. I. Kislak, Inc., was the broker.

The durability of Arthur Godfrey's personality has baffled more than one showman. It was Fred Allen who once observed that no one could remember anything Mr. Godfrey said five minutes after he said it. Quite true, to be sure, but therein may lie Mr. G.'s key to success. He's the most professional non-professional of them all.

Skiing enthusiasm is running high in this part of the country as reports from many areas tell of fair to good sport, thus giving the army of snowbirds an unusually early start. While the bulk of ski-lands usually marks time until the Christmas and New Year's Holidays, many yesterday told of lifts and tows operating. The "Welcome" sign is out in big, bold snow-letters.

Your editorial of Dec. 12 concerning the Police Department drive on red light "runners" neglects to mention the traffic conditions which make it well-nigh impossible for a driver to apply his brakes the instant a traffic light turns red.

A new bid by thirteen Communist party secondary leaders to have a mistrial declared failed yesterday after a defense attorney asserted that a woman juror discharged on Wednesday had telephoned yesterday morning to say that many members of the jury had expressed opinions on the case.

MOSCOW, Dec. 18 -- The newspaper Izvestia charged today that more than 30,000,000 rubles in thefts and embezzlements had occurred in the regional fisheries consumers' cooperatives system of the Khabarovsk territory in the Far East, of which about 5,000,000 rubles had been stolen in the last half year.

TOKYO, Friday, Dec. 19 -- The opposing armies lay almost quiet across the snow-covered Korean war front today after the Communist radio threatened yesterday a Red offensive to take the South Korean capital of Seoul by Christmas.
Predictions that holiday travel this year would be the heaviest since the war were made yesterday by representatives of railroads and airlines serving this city.
DETROIT, Dec. 18 (UP) -- Metro Prystai's third-period goal lifted the Detroit Red Wings to a 1-1 tie with the Toronto Maple Leafs tonight before 11,381 fans at the Olympia.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (AP) -- International allocation of tungsten will end on Jan. 1 because of a 50 per cent increase in western production during the past eighteen months.

With contract awards in thirty-seven Eastern States totaling $15,307,552,000 for the first eleven months of this year, a new record in building construction seems assured for 1952, according to the F. W. Dodge Corporation. The 1951 total was $15,751,131,000.

Four athletes who represented the United States in the recent Olympics at Helsinki competed in the all-handicap track meet that opened the metropolitan A. A. U. season at the 102d Engineers Armory last night but only one was able to emerge with a victory.

ALBANY, Dec. 18 -- The president of the State Tax Commission advised the Temporary State Commission on Highway Financing today to go slow in attempting to unearth new sources of state revenue to rehabilitate the highway system.

HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Dec. 18 -- Yale's basketball team won its second game in five starts, defeating Hofstra, 79 -- 59, with a last-period surge of 33 points on the Hofstra court tonight. It was the second defeat for the Flying Dutchmen in seven games.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 18 -- Photographs of the winning designs of an international competition for United Nations postal stamps were released today by the United Nations Postal Administration.

A vacant plot of about 32,000 square feet on Forty-first Avenue, between Seventy-second and Seventy-third Streets, in Jackson Heights, Queens, has been purchased by the Horace Realty Corporation from Brown Zaubler, builders. The Advance Realty Company was the broker in the sale of the property, which is zoned for apartment house construction.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 18 (UP) -- Motion picture industry heads and high-ranking military representatives today saluted sixty-five top movie, radio and stage enterttainers who leave ttomorrow to brighten the Christmas of United States personnel stationed overseas and at territorial outposts.

IT seems a pity that Joey Maxim should be so bountifully equipped to be a fighter in every respect except one. He boxes beautifully and counters smartly. He is dead game. He has a cast-iron jaw. He knows all the moves and is smart enough to direct them. But he is a feather-duster puncher. Too bad.

Events today: Philharmonic-Symphony, George Szell conducting, Astrid Varnay, soprano, Blanche Thebom, mezzo-soprano, Set Svanholm, tenor, Carnegie Hall, 2:30 P. M.; National Association for American Composers and Conductors, Town Hall, 5:30; "The Messiah," Oratorio Society of New York, Carnegie Hall, 8:30, Mount Holyoke College Glee Club, Town Hall, 8:45.

CHICAGO, Dec. 18 -- Shorts were buyers in a fairly big way on the Board of Trade today, cashing in oil profits, and there was also some buying from commission firms. Recent declines were believed to have discounted bearish developments to a great extent, especially as prices for both wheat and corn are now well below the support levels, which indicates heavy impoundings of these grains, with consequently lessened pressure on the cash markets.

CHICAGO, Dec. 18 -- Ford Motor Company announced today that its aircraft engine division has received an allocation of an additional $20,000,000 to prepare for production of J-57 Pratt Whitney turbojet engines for the Air Forces.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 18 -- North Korea's contemptuous rejection of a compromise proposal by the United Nations General Assembly on the repatriation of Korean prisoners of war was received today by Lester B. Pearson of Canada, president of the Assembly.
Ken Murray and Alan Young will alternate appearances as stars of a new Sunday evening television series beginning Feb. 8 from 9:30 to 10 o'clock over the Columbia Broadcasting System network.

Twenty-five marines stationed at the New York Naval Shipyard, Brooklyn, will contribute a pint of blood apiece today at the Brooklyn Red Cross chapter, 57 Willoughby Street, for the critically ill mother of a Korean-bound marine sergeant.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- The Office of Price Stabilization today issued an order permitting restaurants to increase their charges, if they could prove that food and labor costs had increased since last February when controls began.

Unbeaten Seton Hall came from far behind to down previously undefeated Western Kentucky, 77 -- 74, for its eighth straight basketball victory last night, Then, to the disappointment of the local adherents among 7,122 spectators at Madison Square Garden, New York University, which also went into action with an unblemished slate, was upset by Temple, 77 -- 68.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- The new Wage Stabilization Committee, composed of the four public members of what used to be the tripartite Wage Stabilization Board until industry members walked out of the agency, today approved wage increases of about 5 per cent for 200,000 General Electric Company workers.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- The fifteen-member President's Commission on the Health Needs of the Nation today urged complete health services available to all as a "basic human right" achievable through prepayment plans plus Federal grants to the states.
Following are excerpts from testimony put into the record yesterday at a hearing of the New York State Crime Commission in its investigation of waterfront rackets:

Sugar Ray Robinson retired yesterday as the middleweight champion of the world. Pointedly ignoring the New York State Athletic Commission in his action, the 160-pound king made public the news of his abdication in a formal statement to Abe Greene of Paterson, N. J., a commissioner of the National Boxing Association.

MONTPELIER, Vermont, Dec. 18 -- With typical Yankee shrewdness, the rugged little state of Vermont has driven a sharp bargain with the Federal Government, after eighteen months of typical Yankee stubbornness.

BERLIN, Dec. 18 -- Two United States military policemen who, American officials suspected, were being held by the Russians as hostages for the return of a Soviet soldier who defected to the West, were alleged by the Communists tonight to have asked asylum in East Germany.

Trans World Airlines is prepared to extend its international air route from Bombay to Tokyo as soon as the Civil Aeronautics Board gives its approval, Warren Lee Pierson, chairman of the board, announced here yesterday.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Dec. 18 -- The Taconic State Park Commission and the State Council of Parks filed a formal request today with the Westchester Board of Supervisors for permission to convert the county's Mohansic Park at Yorktown into a major state park.

The electric home and farm freezer was the only large appliance with a long marketing history to show a gain in factory shipments for the first ten months of this year as against the corresponding period last year. The National Electrical Manufacturers Association reported yesterday that freezer factory shipments in the first ten months totaled 696,168 units.

Directors of the Aluminum Company of America voted yesterday to split the common stock two for one and to increase the number of authorized shares. Both proposals will be submitted to stockholders for approval at the next annual meeting on April 16.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- Edward J. Florio, Hoboken waterfront boss and longshore union organizer, admitted at his trial on perjury charges today that he testified falsely before a New York Federal rackets grand jury last October concerning a $2,000 payment he had exacted from a stevedoring corporation in New Jersey.

Moving speedily to beat the change in Federal administrations in Washington, with its anticipated turnover of top personnel in the Housing and Home Finance Agency, the Board of Estimate unanimously approved yesterday plans for the $40,000,000 improvement of Columbus Circle.

MONTREAL, Dec. 18 (UP) -- Big, relaxed and confident, Jean Marc Beliveau crashed into the National Hockey League with a spectacular three-goal performance tonight to lead the Montreal Canadiens to a 6-2 victory over the New York Rangers before 14,641 at the Forum.

PARIS, Dec. 15 -- Warning that failure to establish a European army would lead to "disintegration" of the movement for European unity, Secretary of State Dean Acheson appealed vigorously today for ratification of the treaty that establishes a continental defense force, including twelve German divisions.

Prime Minister Robert Gordon Menzies of Australia said yesterday following a conference with Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the President-elect, that the British Commonwealth Prime Ministers had agreed to submit to the United States certain proposals dealing with the convertibility of the pound sterling and with inclusion of Britain into the Australia-New Zealand-United States defense agreement covering the South Pacific.
CHICAGO. Dec. 18 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

MINEOLA, L. I., Dec. 18 -- Nassau County officials, in a move designed to allay anxious parents' fears of storm-water sumps, ruled today that in the future all sumps to be constructed must be surrounded by concrete curbs and six-foot chain-link fences topped by three strands of barbed wire before excavation work began.
LONDON, Dec. 18 -- Business continued to dwindle on the stock markets today except in the foreign bond and South African gold mining sections but the undertone remained steady.

PETERBOROUGH, Ont., Dec. 18 (Canadian Press) -- Argus Corporation, Ltd., a specialized investment company, has reported net income of $1,379,243 for the year ended on Nov. 30, compared with net income of $1,578,749 the previous year.

The land underlying the Rialto Theatre Building at 1481 Broadway, northwest corner of Forty-second Street, in Times Square, has been sold by the Gerry Estate to an inveostr. The "fee" is assessed for tax purposes at $2,300,000, and the theatre building, transaction, is valued at $1,000,000 and occupies the site on a land leasehold.
George Eliot Leighton, assistant vice president of the Fiduciary Trust Company, has been elected a vice president.

LONDON, Dec. 18 -- The ruins of Roman Britain have yielded a secret that will prevent rust and permit iron and steel to hold up indefinitely, a report of the Scientific and Industrial Research Department said today.

LONDON, Dec. 18 -- As a result of the recent Paris talks between Secretary of State Dean Acheson and British Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden, it is expected here that Loy W. Henderson, the United States Ambassador to Iran, will soon make a preliminary approach to the Iranian Government for a settlement of its oil dispute with Britain.

When playwright Maxwell Anderson was in North Africa back in 1943 interviewing the troops to collect notes for his war play, "Storm Operation," he listened to two captains who were discussing the matter of morale. What they told him then is worth repeating because it is just as true today -- in Korea.
LONDON, Dec. 18 (AP) -- Britons are now on their biggest Christmas spending spree in history, Bank of England figures showed today.

The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was somewhat quieter yesterday than during previous sessions this week and active months closed 8 points lower to 1 point higher than on Wednesday.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 18 (AP) -- Professional women golfers will shoot for $24,500 in a seven-tournament schedule next spring.

Merit pay rises totaling $50,000 were voted yesterday by the Board of Estimate to 150 city employes, including eighteen attached to Mayor Impellitteri's office and seven in the office of City Council President Rudolph Halley.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- The State Departent disclosed tonight that it had sent a note to Czechoslovakia demanding the "prompt release" of Noel and Hermann Field, United States citizens who vanished separately in Communist-held Europe three years ago.
The management improvement program in the Department of Sanitation "has been well advanced and is being vigorously prosecuted," Mayor Impellitteri was told yesterday.

The ruling of the North Atlantic Council that the French defense effort in Indo-China is a matter of common security interest and therefore deserving of "continuing support" from France's Western allies is a further attempt to get the clash of the free world with Communist imperialism into a global focus.

The White Sox, who wound up in third place in the standings, had the slickest defense in the American League last season. Official fielding averages, released yesterday, show Paul Richards' Pale Hose with a mark of .980, one percentage point ahead of the world champion Yankees.

SCARSDALE, N. Y., Dec. 18 -- A fifty-eight-year tradition will be broken on Sunday when the two surviving members of the James K. Hand Walking Association fail to set forth on a pre-Christmas hike initiated by the group in 1894.

Plans have been advanced at luncheon and tea meetings at the Plaza for the dinner dance on behalf of the Yorkville Community Association to be held on the night of Jan. 16 in the main ballroom of the hotel. Miss Joan Pressprich and Miss Barbara Gile Lord, co- chairmen of the junior committee for the benefit, entertained at tea in the Palm Court of the hotel recently for their aides.

Two new films will open at first-run theatres this morning. "Pony Soldier," a Twentieth Century-Fox period adventure in Technicolor about the Royal Canadian Mounted Police, stating Tyrone Power, is at the Globe. Joseph M. Newman directed and Samuel G. Engel produced from a script by John C. Higgins and a story by Garnett Weston.
New York said good-by yesterday to Lieut. Gen. Willis D. Crittenberger, retiring commandling general of the First Army.

LONDON, Dec. 18 -- A new production of "Swan Lake," longer and more elaborate than the old one, was presented tonight by the Sadler's Wells Ballet at the Royal Opera House, Covent Garden. Queen Elizabeth II, the Queen Mother and Princess Margaret attended the premiere, which was a gala performance, the proceeds of which went to the Sadler's Wells Ballet Benevolent Fund.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- The report issued today by the President's Commission on the Health Needs of the Nation is Volume I in a series of five volumes. It covers the commission's principles, major findings and recommendations.

SCHENECTADY, N. Y., Dec. 18 -- A state-wide conservation organization tonight charged that failure to close the flood gates of two state dams has contributed to severe flood conditions in a twenty-nine-mile stretch of the Black River Valley between Carthage and Lyons.

Kenneth F. Sutherland said yesterday that he had the pledged support of twenty-nine of the forty-eight members of the Kings County Democratic executive committee, a sufficient number to insure his election as Brooklyn Democratic leader in place of Francis J. Sinnott. He added that a meeting of the executive committee would be held on Dec. 29.

The faculty of New York University's Washington Square College of Arts and Science has named a "Special Committee on Faculty Responsbilities to Investigative Governmental Agencies," which is currently working to evolve a statement of policy on the controversial subject.

This is the season for which the store window clearly was invented. Across the country it shines and glitters, offering its wares for inspection. At any other season these wares are called merchandise, a word carrying such prosaic connotations as invoices, factors, bills of lading.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 18 (AP) -- The Boncrist Farm's Better Goods, an 8-to-1 shot, celebrating his first start of the winter, came from far off the pace to win the Gislebert Purse, the best race of the card at Tropical Park today.

The General Motors Corporation reported yesterday that the number of holders of its common and preferred stock increased by 1.001 during the fourth quarter of this year to 486.985, a new high. In the fourth quarter of 1951, the corporation had 477,206 owners.

" The Confidential Clerk" is the title of T. S. Eliot's newest play, opening next August at the Edinburgh Festival under the auspices of Henry Sherek. New York is slated to witness it two months later. Presumably this is the same script the Nobel prize-winning poet described here last May as one with a modern London setting.
The management improvement program in the Department of Sanitation "has been well advanced and is being vigorously prosecuted," Mayor Impellitteri was told yesterday.

Billy Graham, clever welterweight boxer from the East Side, will meet Joe Giardello of Philadelphia in the feature bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden tonight. Graham has a large following locally and the chance exists that the turnout will be somewhat larger than those that have been appearing at the Eighth Avenue arena in recent weeks.

The Material Handling Institute, organization of manufacturers of handling equipment, elected Howard M. Palmer as president for 1953 at the group's annual meeting yesterday at the Statler Hotel. Mr. Palmer, who is general sales manager of Lewis-Shepard Products, Inc., Watertown, Mass., replaces L. West Shea of the Union Metal Manufacturing Company, Canton, Ohio, who becomes a director.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 18 (AP) -- The resumption of the Yale-Army football Series on Nov. 6, 1954, in the Yale Bowl was announced today by Bob Hall, Eli athletic director.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- Harry A. McDonald, Reconstruction Finance Corporation Administrator, said today he would be willing to remain in his position under the new administration, but that, to date, he had not been asked to stay.

Yesterday's developments made it plain, if anyone doubted it earlier, that the Transport Workers Union is deadly serious in its demands for the forty-hour work week on privately owned bus lines. We believe a strike is a certainty, and with most serious consequences, on Jan. 1, when contracts will have expired, unless the union's demand in respect to working hours is met.

THE Long Island waterfowl season ended with a rolling salute at 3:30 P. M. yesterday. Apparently the wildfowlers had synchronized their watches, for thereafter only whispering wings and the lap of water on the flush deck of a duck boat came to the ears of listening wardens.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- Vice Admiral William M. Callaghan, outgoing chief of the Military Sea Transport Service, said today that, should the international situation get worse, rationing of civilian petroleum products might become necessary because of the country's fuel tanker shortage.

Representative Joseph W. Martin Jr. of Massachusetts, prospective Speaker of the next House of Representatives, forecast yesterday, following a conference with Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the President-elect, that Government finance would be the main concern of the new Congress.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- Society as a whole can minimize medical evils by expressing greater interest in the organization of health services, the President's Commission on Health Needs of the Nation indicated in its report today.

ROME, Dec. 18 -- The Vatican newspaper L'Osservatore Romano, which was expected to give an official reaction to the unilateral rupture of relations between Yugoslavia and the Vatican, announced in Belgrade yesterday, surprised everyone today by not mentioning the subject even indirectly.

Newsprint consumption in November by daily newspapers reporting to the American Newspaper Publishers Association amounted to 416,974 tons, the organization reported yesterday. This was an increase of 3.5 per cent over the month last year, and 2.2 per cent over the month in 1950.
