LOUISVILLE, Ky., Dec. 18 (AP) -- A drop in prices at Kentucky burley tobacco markets was indicated by early reports on today's sales.

Aggregate short interest on the New York Stock Exchange dropped on Dec. 15 to 1,570,986 shares, the lowest figure since mid-April, 1949, when it was 1,498,493 shares. The figure on Nov. 15 was 1,791,203 shares. Neither total includes the short positions carried in the odd-lot accounts of odd-lot dealers. These declined from 71,597 to 52,150 shares in the month.

Following are the officers of six Brooklyn locals of the International Longshoremen's Association before and after the 1940 investigation by the Kings County District Attorney's office. The Kings prosecutor at that time was William O'Dwyer.

CHICAGO, Dec. 18 -- One of the Siamese twin boys, who were severed in Research and Educational Hospitals of the University of Illinois by a surgical team in a twelve-hour and forty-minute operation yesterday, was clinging to life tonight. The second was given little chance of survival.

Advancing for the fifteenth successive week, business loans from New York banks rose $13,000,000 last week to reach a new high total of $8,689,000,000 and bring total expansion since the mid-year to $1,019,000,000, against $1,029,000,000 in the similar period of 1951.

The appointment of Lee Thompson Smith as chairman of the committee for celebration of the 300th anniversary of New York as an incorporated city is a happy one. Member of an old New York family, Mr. Smith is deeply interested in the history of the city, and has been active in various patriotic and other societies that cherish the past.

Strong reactions greeted the report made yesterday by the President's Commission on the Health Needs of the Nation, with President Truman in Washington upholding the report as "impressive" and "a fresh and constructive approach," while Dr. Louis H. Bauer, president of the American Medical Association, attacked one recommendation as "national compulsory health insurance."

Charitable New Yorkers gave $6,000,000 this year to the Greater New York Fund. While that was the largest amount raised in the fifteen-year history of the volunteer collection organization, it was insufficient to the growing needs of the 423 voluntary health and welfare agencies that will receive their proportional shares in checks mailed to them yesterday from the fund's headquarters at 11 West Forty-second Street.
Dallas County, Tex., borrowed $10,000,000 yesterday on issues of road and permanent improvement bonds due from 1954 to 1983, at an interest cost of 2.462 per cent.

Having recently returned from Egypt, a country in which I resided and the fortunes of which I closely followed for over thirty years, may I add the following comments to the accurate and very interesting description of conditions in Egypt in your editorial of Dec. 15.

Since Lillian Hellman's "The Children's Hour" was a sound play originally, it is still powerful and lacerating in the production put on at the Coronet last evening. It may, in fact, have grown a bit in stature. In 1934 it was a self-contained story about two school teachers whose lives were destroyed by a false accusation of abnormal sexual relations; and that was sufficiently shocking at the time.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- The United States and Canada joined forces today to eradicate a parasitic, thoroughly unpleasant water creature in the Great Lakes.

There are only two books published today. New Directions is selling for $3 Kenneth Rexroth's philosophical poem "The Dragon and the Unicorn" William-Frederick is issuing in two editions "The Metaphysical Organs of Man: A Theoretical Interpretation of the General Body of Psychic Phenomena," by James Baker Jr. The cloth edition sells for $2 and the paper edition for $1.50.

BERLIN, Dec. 18 -- A United States High Commission Court today set bail at $20,000 for a former employe of the United States Army's Intelligence Office here who is charged with unauthorized possession of several hundred documents, some of them classified "top secret."

SEATTLE, Wash., Dec. 18 -- An amendment to the Bonneville Act may be sought from the next Congress to enable the Bonneville Power Administration, marketing agent for hydroelectric power from Federal dams of the Pacific Northwest, to help privately owned utilities meet extra power costs of many millions of dollars resulting from the use of steam plants during this low water year.

Magistrate J. Irwin Shapiro issued a verbal blast about the state pari-mutuel laws yesterday in giving out a suspended sentence to an exercise boy convicted of bookmaking for taking money from friends in the paddock and placing bets at the pari-mutuel window at the race track.

SEATTLE, Wash., Dec. 18 -- An amendment to the Bonneville Act may be sought from the next Congress to enable the Bonneville Power Administration, marketing agent for hydroelectric power from Federal dams of the Pacific Northwest, to help privately owned utilities meet extra power costs of many millions of dollars resulting from the use of steam plants during this low water year.

Magistrate J. Irwin Shapiro issued a verbal blast about the state pari-mutuel laws yesterday in giving out a suspended sentence to an exercise boy convicted of bookmaking for taking money from friends in the paddock and placing bets at the pari-mutuel window at the race track.

Food Fair Stores, Inc., has sold its warehouse at Route 25 and Stiles Street in Linden, N. J., to the John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company of Boston, Mass., and has leased back the property. Richard Abeles was the broker. The property, which contains 313,000 square feet of space including a general office and cafeteria, is used to service stores in northern New Jersey and Long Island.
MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Dec. 19 (AP) -Some more of golf's proudest reputations suffered in today's second round of the $13,000 international four-ball tournament.

VIENNA, Dec. 19 -- Eleven new candidates have been appointed to the Central Committee of the Czechoslovak Communist party, the Prague radio announced today, to fill the places left vacant by the and his alleged fellow conspirators, the Prague radio announced today.

MEXICO CITY, Dec. 19 -- William O'Dwyer, former Mayor of New York, asked today "why don't they prosecute" Albert Anastasia, Brooklyn waterfront figure, "if they have a case against him" in connection with the 1939 slaying of a longshoreman reformer.
The stock market was encouraged to make a further moderate advance yesterday by the railroads and the oils.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- The Government today dropped its eight - year - old anti - trust suit against forty-seven Western railroads and others charged with conspiring to restrain and monopolize transportation in the region.
TOKYO, Saturday, Dec. 20 -- United Nations fighter-bombers swarmed yesterday over a big Communist military concentration area behind the western Korean front and left the target a mass of flames.

LONDON, Dec. 19 -- Despite further dwindling in business before the Christmas holiday the stock markets remained steady today. The only exceptions were in British funds, which had some minor falls, and foreign bonds, which became dull on profit-taking.

JERUSALEM, Dec. 19 -- Premier David Ben-Gurion submitted his Government's resignation to President Izhak Ben-Zvi this morning a few minutes after a Cabinet meeting had taken official note of the fact that the existing Government does not have a majority in Parliament.

BOSTON, Dec. 19 -- The contempt case against Joseph (Specs) O'Keefe of Boston, named in affidavits by the Federal Bureau of Investigation as one of the robbers in the $1,219,000 Brink's, Inc., holdup in 1950, was taken under advisement today in Federal district court.

LONDON, Dee. 19 -- The members of the House of Commons shut up shop for the holidays this evening, having heard a lot of evidence during the day that there is no Santa Claus and that the spirit of Scrooge is still around.

A mother sent a $10 gift to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund yesterday to mark her daughter's first Christmas and the accompanying letter expressed the hope that the child upon growing older would continue the family tradition of contributing each year.

ARCADIA, Calif., Dec. 19 (UP) -- Calumet Farm's two great 3-year-olds, Marke-Ye-Well and Hill Gail, today drew top weight of 130 pounds each for the sixteenth running of the $100,000 Santa Anita Handicap.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- A loan of $31,500,000 to India for expansion of her iron and steel production was announced today by the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development. To run for fifteen years, the loan was made to the Indian Iron and Steel Company, Ltd., and guaranteed by the Government of India.

BONN, Germany, Dec. 19 -- United States Ambassador William H. Draper Jr., head of the Mutual Security Agency in Europe, is scheduled to arrive tomorrow from Paris to confer with Chancellor Konrad Adenauer on urgent problems facing the West German Republic.

MADRAS, India, Dec. 19 -- Reports read today at the concluding session of the sixth International Conference of Social Work implied that advanced western countries trying to assist underdeveloped nations, particularly in Asia, were in danger of mistakenly over- emphasizing quick economic returns at the expense of projects for permanent improvement of basic social conditions.
LONDON, Dec. 19 (AP) -- Britain's Boxing Board of Control lined up solidly behind Randy Turpin today as the logical No. 1 contender for the world middleweight crown vacated by Sugar Ray Robinson.

EAST LANSING, Mich., Dec. 19 (AP) -- Kansas State, making good use of its great neight and sharp shooting, raced into an early lead and held the advantage throughout to whip Notre Dame, 80 -- 64, and set a scoring record for the annual Spartan Basketball Classic tonight.

The first major criminal indictment resulting from the State Crime Commission hearings was reported yesterday when a New Jersey longshore union official was arrested on charges that he and a second man, now dead, extorted $45,000 from importers of Russian furs during a fake dock strike two years ago.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- Wesley Roberts, former Kansas publisher, was reported by Republican leaders here today to have received the approval of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the President-elect, to succeed Arthur E. Summerfield as Republican National Chairman.

The Swedish American Line announced yesterday that Capt. John O. Pettersson, head of the New York office of the Brostrom Lines Agency became last Monday the first Swede in the United States to receive the Emmery Medal, presented once every five years to an outstanding Swedish seafarer.

Your editorial of Dec. 10 "A Limit on City Taxes" raises an issue which undoubtedly is of unusual importance. I am not writing you in reference to the problem itself, because I do not understand the intricate angles or the involved situation. I have learned, however, from my long medical experience, both research and clinical, never to come to a conclusion without knowing all the facts.
Marked variation in the quantity of Vitamic C, or ascorbic acid, in frozen orange juice concentrate was found in recent tests of twenty brands at the University of Massachusetts.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 19 (UP) -- General Manager Hank Greenberg said today he would waste no time effecting reforms in the Indians' baseball operation now that he had received free rein by the new president, Myron H. (Mac) Wilson Jr.
You can walk for miles around Manhattan, these days, without seeing anything unusually spiritual or nostalgic. Then you turn a corner, and suddenly it's Christmas.

A jury in General Sessions Court last night convicted George (Muscles) Futterman, 34-year-old suspended union representative, of subornation of perjury and of bribing a witness in the Benedicto Macri murder trial last year.

Dan River Mills will expand the distribution of its X-2 chemical for finishing rayon and rayon blends and will not exclude competitors in the textile industry, it was learned yesterday. Dan River has sold Burlington Mills the X-2 finish, and the latter company is currently showing samples of rayon goods processed with it.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (AP) -- The nation's 1953 wheat crop may be a short one of less than 900,000,000 bushels because of poor weather, the Department of Agriculture reported today.

Despite the close tie between the two, no careful or extended study has ever been made to determine the immediate or long-range effect of the sales of phonographs on those of records. This is the word from the Record Industry ssociation of America, Inc., which is planning to undertake such a survey as its second promotional effort.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J. Dec- 19 -Eighty-four manslaughter indictments against the Pennsylvania Railroad, returned by a grand jury after eighty-four persons had been killed in the derailment of a commuter train that had plunged off a temporary trestle in Woodbridge on Feb. 6, 1951, were dismissed today by Judge Charles M. Morris in County Court here.

ALBANY, Dec. 19 -- An appraisal of thirty-six historic portraits in the executive chamber at the State Capitol was begun today. Sigmund Rothschild, New York City specialist handling the appraisal, said he expected the total value to run to $500,000.

The Bond Building, a seven-story office structure at the southwest corner of Fourteenth Street and New York Avenue in Washington, D. C., has been purchased by Charles D. Benenson, New York investor, from the Irvin Realty Corporation.

NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 19 (AP) -- Parliament overrode Communist-led Left-Wing opposition today and completed approval of Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru's five-year plan for raising India's standard of living.

Elaborate programs of choral and instrumental music, pageants of the Nativity and processions to mangers for ceremonies of blessing will begin tomorrow the principal celebrations of Christmas. Many others will be held Christmas Eve and on Christmas Day.

A crackdown on dilatory ring champions was planned by Robert K. Christenberry, chairman of the State Athletic Commission, at a meeting yesterday with Dr. Clilan B. Powell and Leon F. Swears, his colleagues on the board.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 19 -- Forty-eight of the sixty United Nations delegations approved today a four-power resolution urging the West and the Soviet Union to come to terms quickly on a treaty restoring full sovereignty to Austria.

ALBANY, Dec. 19 -- Governor Dewey announced today that he would meet with the members of the State Crime Commission and their chief legal advisers in the Capitol tomorrow to review the results of their investigations into political graft and waterfront scandals in New York City.

HACKENSACK, N. J., Dec. 19 -- A statement indicating that in 1941, when he was District Attorney of Kings County, former Mayor William O'Dwyer believed that Peter Panto had been murdered in Brooklyn and his body dumped in Lyndhurst, N. J., was issued today.

BERLIN, Dec. 19 -- Michael Rothkrug of Westport, Conn., who is being held in the United States Army stockade for trial on a charge of illegal possession of secret Government documents, said today that the $20,000 bail set yesterday by the High Commissioner's court was "prohibitive."

ROCQUENCOURT, France, Dec. 19 -- It was obvious today at Supreme Allied Headquarters that the fruits of the tenth North Atlantic Council Session just ended had been a disappointment to the Allied military planners charged with the responsibility of defending Western Europe.

PEORIA, Ill., Dec. 19 (UP) -The president of Bradley University, David Blair Owen, who was criticized by a New York judge for his attitude toward athletics during the basketball scandals of 1951, resigned today for reasons of health. He received an indefinite leave of absence Nov. 21 and is believed to be in a Philadelphia hospital.
Following are excerpts from testimony put into the record yesterday at a hearing of the State Crime Commission in its investigation of waterfront rackets:

The strike of 220 maintenance employes against the Northeast Airlines resulted yesterday in a decision to furlough 142 reservation and clerical workers on the system, which links New York with Montreal and thirty-four New England cities.

NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 19 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru announced in the House of the People (the lower house of Parliament) today the Government's decision to create a new state, Andhra, composed of the twelve Telugu-speaking areas of Madras State.

William Shakespeare will make a delayed contribution to daytime television beginning Jan. 5 when his "Hamlet" will be presented in the framework of a soap opera program over WABD, local outlet for the Du Mont network.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., Dee. 19 -- Facilities for legal aid for indigent persons in this state have increased considerably in the last year, the New York State Bar Association's committee on legal aid reported today. The report was released by Herbert T. Slade of Syracuse, committee chairman.

In its first change of ownership in more than 100 years, the three-story business building at 931-33 Broadway, near Twenty-first Street, has been sold by Frank H. Bayles, Sr., and Frank H. Bayles, Jr., to Jack Gordon, owner of the adjoining building at 929 Broadway.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 19 -- Twenty United States citizens dismissed by the United Nations during the current loyalty investigations are filing formal appeals and may ask that the world organization's tribunal hear their cases outside this country.
In an action unique in boxing here, the State Athletic Commission last night reversed a decision immediately following a bout, because of dissatisfaction with the award.
The cotton futures market continued barely steady on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday, and closing prices were up 8 to 17 points.

STANFORD, Calif., Dec. 19 (UP) -- A load of "hot atoms," encased in a two-ton layer of protective materials and equivalent to $80,000,000 worth of radium, rested safely in ten feet of water at Stanford Research Institute today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- William McChesney Martin, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, will continue in that post under the Administration of President-elect Dwight D. Eisenhower. It was learned today that the former Assistant Secretary of the Treasury has been assured that the President-elect wants him to stay on the job.

Tintagel, a waterfront estate of seven and one-half acres at Kings Point in Great Neck, L. I., has been sold by Edward J. Churchill to Joseph Weinstein of Brooklyn, builder. Arthur F. Rausch was the broker.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 19 -- Lester B. Pearson of Canada, President of the General Assembly, scheduled today a meeting for Sunday at 3 P. M. in the hope that the Assembly may be able to start its Christmas recess late Sunday night. The Assembly will hold morning and afternoon meetings tomorrow.
Roger M. Kyes, a vice president of the General Motors Corporation, named to the post of Deputy Secretary of Defense, has been a manufacturing executive most of his adult life.

HONG KONG, Dec. 19 -- The Panamanian-flag freighter Nidar, of 2,760 tons, which was en route from Hong Kong to Kobe, Japan, with a cargo of scrap iron, was reported today to have been seized by her Chinese crew and diverted to the Chinese Nationalist island of Quemoy, off the coast of Fukien.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- A device that notes and records each opening of a door is among the 917 inventions patented this week. Installed on a closet door, for instance, it would report to father and mother how many peeks the small fry of a household had taken at the Christmas presents.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- Prof. Owen Lattimore was arraigned in Federal District Court here today and pleaded innocent to an indictment charging that he committed perjury when he told the Senate Internal Security subcommittee last Spring that he had not promoted Communist interests or supported Communist causes.

PETERSBURG, Va., Dec. 19 -- John F. Maragon, a former bootblack whose connections with the White House became the subject of corruption headlines, was released from the Federal reformatory near here today. He was convicted of having lied to a Senate subcommittee investigating five percenters.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -Fifteen minutes after a Federal court jury here began deliberating his perjury case, Edward J. Florio, Hoboken waterfront boss, pleaded guilty to lying to a New York grand jury investigating racketeering. Judge Irving R. Kaufman immediately sentenced Florio to eighteen months in prison and placed him on probation for five years.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 19 -- The United Nations General Assembly's Legal Committee adopted today by 24 to 16 a much amended and revised draft of a resolution submitted by China to change the Chinese language text of the genocide convention.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (UP) -- The Justice Department ordered action today to strip Myer Lansky, described as a "close associate of leading gamblers and racketeers," of his American citizenship.

The 165-year-old Erasmus Hall Academy in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn, which, by a few hours, holds the distinction of being the first chartered secondary school in the state, was the scene yesterday of the regular monthly meeting of the State Board of Regents and a colorful rededication program that harked back to the school's early days.

An arrangement whereby six mystery novels by Mickey Spillane will be filmed by Victor Saville, producer and director, was announced yesterday. The exclusive five-year contract calls for two films annually, the first six stories to be selected from the eight Spillane best-sellers published thus far.

Mr. Stevens said yesterday that he was "very much surprised" when General Eisenhower had asked him to be Secretary of the Army. Mr. Stevens told a press conference that he had accepted the designation Thursday after a fifteen-minute conference at which he had met the President-elect for the first time.

The State Crime Commission produced evidence yesterday that some more local officers of the International Longshoremen's Union, A. F. L., had long been unning their locals like "padrones," or private labor contractors.
The National Association for American Composers and Conductors presented a concert at Town Hall yesterday afternoon to commemorate the birthday of the late Henry Hadley.

Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower picked four leading industrialists yesterday to fill key posts in the Department of Defense after a series of conferences with Charles E. Wilson, whom he had already designated for Secretary of Defense.

The exact number is a military secret but enough presents to supply every Korean veteran in the six Government hospitals in this area were wrapped yesterday by a group of women directed by Mrs. Nadine Blakeslee.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- Average primary market prices declined 0.3 per cent over the week ended Tuesday to 109.3 per cent of the 1947-49 average, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. Farm products receded 0.5 per cent as a result of lower prices for many fresh fruits and vegetables, nearly all grains and livestock, live poultry and raw cotton.
TOKYO, Saturday, Dec. 20 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,469, for Friday:

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 19 -- A Turkish military delegation arrived tonight to repay an earlier visit to Turkey by a Yugoslav mission, and so far as this Government is concerned the Turks could not have come at a more opportune time.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (AP) -- The Senate Elections subcommittee has directed Michigan election officials to preserve the ballots of the Moody-Potter Senatorial contest.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 19 (AP) -- The Misssouri Pacific Railroad, in the process of reorganization under the Federal Bankruptcy Act, is enjoying its best year financially since the end of World War II, Paul J. Neff, chief executive officer, reported today.

Peter Cookson, whose Broadway credits to date include appearances in three straight plays and sponsorship of two others, will mark a new phase in his theatrical career this season. He will have the leading male role in the forthcoming musical, "Can-Can," the Cole Porter-Abe Burrows show that the team of Feuer and Martin is producing.

BERLIN. Dec. 19 -- Master Sergeant William T. Rice of Farmville, Va., who was arrested by the Soviet zone police Tuesday while in charge of a detail erecting sign posts along the city border, said today that during his two-day detention he had been invited three times by the Russians to settle in East Germany.

PARIS, Dec. 19 -- The Constitutional Committee of the European Coal and Steel Community, which has been engaged all week in drafting recommendations for a supranational European political authority, reached agreement today on the power of its proposed parliament in overruling executive decisions.

The aging man or woman, though taken into the home of relatives, often knows acute loneliness as memories turn back to earlier days with longing for a departed loved one and the home of happy years together. Such loneliness of the spirit is quite apart from the tender ministrations afforded by son or daughter.

The Public Housing Administration has under consideration a plan to reduce in amount the periodic offerings of bonds of local housing authorities, so that the market will be better able to absorb the weight of offerings, particularly of the longer-term bonds.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 19 -- In three of the four food-deficit areas of the world the rate of increase in cereal production will have to be increased 50 to 100 per cent in the next seven years to meet minimum nutrition targets. This conclusion is set forth in a Food and Agriculture Organization study made public here.

Some statistics are in order. Last night's "Messiah" was the 129th performance by the Oratorio Society in the group's first concert of its eightieth season. Alfred Greenfield conducted, as he has for some seasons past.

You recently had a news item about some bus drivers who were in the habit of light jumping. The spokesman for the bus drivers registered a legitimate complaint against certain motorists who park in regularly designated bus stops.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 Senator Taft is the top-ranking Republican on the Senate Labor Committee, but whether he will take the committee chairmanship in addition to serving as floor leader is uncertain.
DETROIT, Dec. 19 (UP) -Forecasts of snow flurries and subfreezing temperature threatened today to turn Sunday's playoff battle between the Detroit Lions and the Los Angeles Rams into a ground game.

You're a small business man. You make widgets. The Government needs widgets. They are important in making larger widgets work. So, after some trouble and time you obtain a Government contract to supply widgets.

Net sales of J. P. Stevens Co., Inc., for the fiscal year ended Oct. 31 rose to $387,147,793 from the $349,470,532 volume transacted in the previous year. but earnings declined sharply, according to the annual report issued yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- A rise of one-tenth of 1 per cent in the living costs of moderate-income urban families between Oct. 15 and Nov. 15 was reported today by the Department of Labor's Bureau of Labor Statistics in making public its Consumers Price Index.

ALBANY, Dec. 19 -- The Public Service Commission today authorized the Staten Island Rapid Transit Railway Company to discontinue passenger service on its short east shore and north shore branches after March 31, 1953.

MONTREAL, Dec. 19 (Canadian Press) -- Shareholders of Canadian Industries, Ltd., were advised today that it may be divided into two separate companies as a result of an anti-trust action by the United States Department of Justice against two firms which jointly control the concern.

BETHPAGE, L. I., Dec. 19 -- The United States Navy's newest weapon against submarines, a twin-engine warplane capable of operating off carrier decks as well as land bases, successfully made its first flight here last Dec. 4, the Navy announced today.
The ill mother of a Marine Corps sergeant who will leave on Dec. 28 for duty in Korea was the recipient of his comrades' blood yesterday.
IF I were making out a list of the year's books that would make fine Christmas presents for all kinds of persons for all sorts of different reasons, I would not want to overlook these:
TAMPA, Fla., Dec. 19 (AP) -- Columbia University's quintet completely outclassed the University of Tampa tonight with its nifty passing and effective shooting to win, 89 -- 51.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio will be the Republican Floor Leader of the new Senate, at the head of a party hierarchy in the upper chamber in which no early Eisenhower backer is likely to have a significant place.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 19 -- The United Nations General Assembly completed its action on the North African question today by adopting a compromise resolution expressing the hope that negotiations would be continued on an urgent basis toward developing "free political institutions" for French Morocco.

The United Nations General Assembly's rejection of a proposal for direct negotiation between the Arab states and Israel leaves this thorniest of all Middle Eastern problems as far from settlement as ever. In all honesty it must be added that even if the resolution had been approved it would not necessarily have had any concrete results.

Thirty-three records were broken or tied in the American League last season, according to official figures released yesterday. The same number of junior circuit marks were shattered or dead-locked in 1951, although the 1952 season saw American Leaguers account for five majorleague records broken and fifteen tied.

Cheney Bros., maker of silk, nylon and other textile products, announced a plan yesterday to split its stock seven for one, subject to stockholder approval at a special meeting on Jan. 21. If approved, the split will increase outstanding shares to 238,728 from 44,566 at the end of last year.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Dec. 19 -- The Rutgers basketball team put on a spectacular last-quarter rally to defeat Princeton, 83 -- 68, before a crowd of 1,500 persons.

ROME, Dec. 19 -- Under the inconspicuous headline "Diplomatic Relations Between Holy See and Yugoslavia." and in only six lines of print, the Vatican newspaper L'Osservatore Romano today told of the Yugoslav Government's decision to break off relations with the Vatican.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 19 -- Israel, in the wake of yesterday's defeat of a neutral-power Palestine proposal supported by Tel-Aviv, withdrew today her counter-complaint against the Arab members of the United Nations.

A flood of holiday travelers started moving through the city's air, rail and bus terminals yesterday as schools and colleges began closing for Christmas recess and military bases began the holiday furlough period.

Jerry Finkelstein agreed yesterday to appear before the January, 1951, grand jury, which is investigating a purported $10,000 "campaign contribution" in 1949 to William O'Dwyer, then Mayor, and repeat a denial made Thursday in open court that he had any knowledge of such a payment.

BOSTON, Dec. 19 (AP) -- Mariano S. Bishop, cotton-rayon director of the C. I. O. Textile Workers Union, asserted today that "the New England textile industry is suffering from competition of its own making.

SANTA FE, N. M., Dec. 19 -- Maj. Gen. Lewis B. Hershey, the Selective Service director, said today that draft board would call some 19-year-olds in January, February or March and that he would be "very much surprised if we aren't taking those under 19 within the next nine to twelve months."
The variety in this week's art exhibitions is such that gallery visitors of completely opposite tastes should find among them a number of shows to please them.
New ways to deck the holiday house, many of them using traditional evergreen, have been suggested by various sources.
Only absence from the city prevented my commenting promptly on your editorial of Dec. 15 on Times Square.

The forty-three-family apartment house at 3418 Gates Place, the Bronx, has been sold by Eli Ross to a client of Leonard Fastenberg, lawyer, for cash over a first mortgage of $140,000. King King, Inc., were the brokers in the sale.

The Home Lines announced yesterday that the 22,000-ton luxury liner Atlantic had proved so popular on North Atlantic service between Canadian ports and Western Europe that the vessel had been assigned permanently to the run.

Mayor Impellitteri's transit fact-finding committee moved yesterday to keep the breakdown in negotiations between the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., and eight private bus companies from hardening into a deadlock and a certain strike on Jan. 1.

ELIZABETH, N. J., Dec. 19 -- After thirty-three years and eleven accountings in court, the distribution of the million-dollar estate of William H. Rankin, Elizabeth tarpaper manufacturer, was authorized today by Union County Judge Edward A. McGrath.

The City Club of New York, which has made competent investigations of port problems over the years, urges the setting up of city-operated hiring halls and the licensing of waterfront personnel as a solution to crime on the waterfront. Its plan would do away with the present practice of hiring longshore labor daily at the "shape-up."

Autumn, which at this point seems far back among the yesterdays, officially bows out tomorrow afternoon. The almanac says that winter will arrive at 4:44 P. M. That is an appropriate time for the debut of winter, 1952 -- or indeed for any winter -- being, at this season, a dismal hour of the day.

MAMARONECK, N. Y., Dec. 19 -- A large cache of munitions, said to have been gathered for a revolution in Cuba, was seized today by Westchester County authorities in a former gasoline station on West Boston Post Road. Three men were arrested.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (AP) -- Following is the prepared text of President Truman's address today to the National War College:

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 19 -- Four military transport planes carrying sixty-five motion picture and radio entertainers on a Christ-mass show mission to troops overseas took off this morning from the Lockheed Air Terminal in near-by Burbank.

SCRANTON, Pa., Dec. 19 -- Counsel for stockholders and former stockholders of the Williamsport Wire Rope Company today accepted, subject to court approval, a $6,000,000 offer from Bethlehem Steel Company to settle the equity suit brought by the shareholders in 1946 in which is was charged that the 1937 sale of the rope company to the steel corporation was accomplished by fraud.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- President Truman declared today this country had demonstrated to Soviet leaders that their world imperialism could be checked and that they could gain "nothing from war but catastrophe."

The Christmas shopping picture here brightened considerably this week as shoppers crowded stores in a wave of late buying. Estimates indicated that this week's department store sales stand a good chance of breaking even with last year's record volume.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Dec. 19 -- The Yonkers Board of Education was accused in Supreme Court here today of unfair discrimination in failing to permit the Yonkers Committee for Peace to conduct an evening public forum on world peace in one of the school buildings.

Holy Cross, rated one of the East's top basketball powers, will appear at Madison Square Garden tonight. The Crusaders, victorious in their three starts to date, will oppose once-beaten St. John's in the non-televised 7:45 P. M. opener of the season's fifth college doubleheader here.

After receiving a report of widespread crime and hoodlumism on the West Side of Manhattan between Fifty-ninth and 125th Streets, Police Commissioner George P. Monaghan assured a committee of clergymen yesterday that he had assigned additional policemen to the area. He said more would be sent there as they became available.
ROME, Dec. 19 -- Pope Pius' Christmas message to the world will be broadcast in twenty-four languages -- including those spoken in most of the countries behind the Iron Curtain.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 19 (AP) -- Belair Stud's Golden Gloves, a stakes' winner in New York during the past season, went down to a stunning defeat in the featured Diomed Purse at Tropical Park today, bowing to W. Hull's selling plater, Saddle Bags by a nose before a crowd of 7,231.

A United Nations Economic Committee's resolution approving the right of any country to seize private property, without mentioning obligations to provide compensation, was assailed yesterday as abridging the rights of governments whose nationals' investments would be affected.

President Truman was speaking for the record, with an eye on the judgment of history, when he reviewed his foreign policy in an address yesterday before the National War College. His resume covered only the seven years of his own Administration and it was definitely the testament of a man finishing his course and summing up his case for the annals.

The New York Regional Blood Program of the American Red Cross collected 100 per cent more blood during the 1951-52 fiscal year than in the preceding twelve months and topped its quota by more than 38,000 pints, according to the forty-sixth annual report of the New York Chapter, made public yesterday.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 19 (AP) -- The United States Davis Cup team won its final two singles matches against Italy, scoring a 5 -- 0 sweep of the interzone series at Sydney, Radio Australia reported tonight. The United States already had clinched the right to challenge Australia's powerful team for the cup on Dec. 29-31 at Adelaide.

The oft-referred-to modern horse racing track for this city, to be operated by the three associations that conduct the sport here, may become a reality if plans of Jim Butler, president of the Empire City Racing Association, are permitted to materialize.
PARIS, Dec. 19 -- Jean de Hautecloque, the French Resident General in Tunisia, left Paris tonight for Tunis, the bearer of a peremptory note to the Bey of Tunis.

Governors of the New York Stock Exchange will consider on Dec. 23 the transfer of the memberships of John M. Schiff to Robert F. Brown, that of John M. Hynes to Malcolm E. McAlpin, that of the late Stuart Logan to Harry B. Spring and that of Robert V. Nehrbas to Gilbert J. McLellan.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 19 -- The Bank of Brazil began today to try to work its way out of a situation in which it has purchased the entire cotton crop at an estimated cost of $130,000,000 and cannot meet competitive world prices to sell it.
The following is a round-up of items that may be useful to the hostess for decorating the home and the holiday table:

WEST POINT, N. Y., Dec. 19 -- Scoring its highest point total since 1948, Army defeated Middlebury, 86 -- 76, today for its second straight basketball triumph. Army racked up 88 against Lehigh in '48.

Station WCBS-TV will add an hour to its weekday morning schedule by coming on the air at 7:50 o'clock beginning Monday, Dec. 29. The only other local station presently seen at that hour is WNBT, which signs on at 6:55 A. M.

The Maritime Administration has collected $33,238,219 in interest since 1946 on 446 of the surplus Government-owned merchant vessels that were sold to foreign governments and non-citizens, it was disclosed in the agency's quarterly report to Congress.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 19 -Two Russian speakers trained their heaviest fire on Senator Alexander Wiley today and in a reply, lasting an hour and a half, the United States delegate defended this country against the "perverted" Soviet charges and hammered at "enslavement" of the workers under Communist domination.

McDonnell Aircraft Corporation has announced the election of one director and four vice presidents. Kendall Perkins, vice president engineering, was elected a director and a member of the executive committee. Garret C. Covington, William A. Roth, William R. Oethwein Jr. and John F. Aldreige have been elected vice presidents.

Your editorial of Dec. 15 entitled "Bill of Rights" makes statements and has omissions to which, as a citizen of North Carolina, I must make protest. The statement, the accuracy of which it would be impossible to establish, is:

Mr. and Mrs. John H. Lalor of 290 Park Avenue and Utica, N. Y., gave a dinner dance last night in the Georgian Suite at 1A East Seventy-seventh street to introduce to society their daughter, Miss Anne Lalor, who received with her mother and sister, Miss Joan Lalor.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- The Wage Stabilization Committee announced approval today of fringe adjustments contained in contracts negotiated by three major meat packing companies and various unions covering 72,000 employes.

APPARENTLY the muzzle-loader hunters are increasing with a rapidity equaled only by the long-bow enthusiasts, and the reports received on the activities of the old rifle addicts indicate that they were more successful this season.

Four new-type pedestrian signal lights similar to those used in Times Square since March were tried out at 10 A. M. yesterday at Thirty-fourth Street and the Avenue of the Americas. The signals worked well but the pedestrians didn't.

SELMA, Ala., Dec. 19 -- The last class of Air Force cadets to be graduated in propeller-driven fighter planes left Craig Air Force Base today, and from now on the nation's fliers will train in jet planes.

MANILA, Dec. 19 -- Conferences between the Philippine and Japanese Governments on the delicate subject of reparations for damage and loss of life caused by Japan during the three wartime years of occupation were resumed today after the arrival of Eiji Wajima, director of the Asian Affairs Bureau of the Tokyo Foreign Ministry.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- President Truman, welcoming home Secretary of State Dean Acheson, today, described the North Atlantic Council meeting just concluded in Paris as "one more step" in the progress toward world peace.

CHICAGO, Dec. 19 -- The general tone of the grain market was stronger today, but there was still considerable selling opposition, with free selling of wheat on the upturns, and a lot of evening up in the December contracts which expired at the close of the session today.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Dec. 19 (AP) -- Paul Bryant, the coach who elevated Kentucky's downtrodden football stock to a big-time level, said today he would retain his coaching job here. He has a contract that runs through the 1962 season.

The more the Federal Government spends the more important it becomes to spend wisely and, by and large, the more difficult it is to do so. When we have to calculate in terms of more than $80 billion, economy isn't merely good ethics or good management; it is almost the difference between national economic health and national economic sickness.

ROME, Dec. 19 -- Dr. Grayson L. Kirk, acting head of Columbia University, who will conclude here on Sunday a three-week tour of Europe to stimulate participation of institutions of learning in the celebration in 1954 of Columbia's two-hundredth anniversary, was guest tonight at a dinner given in his honor at the United States Embassy.

REGINA, Dec. 19 (Canadian Press) -- Terms of the largest land deal ever completed between two companies in Saskatchewan were announced today in a joint statement by the Sohio Petroleum Company group and Socony-Vacuum Exploration Company.
FRANCONIA, N. H., Dec. 19 -- Midwinter conditions provide a superb setting for the cross-country and giant slalom races this week-end at Cannon Mountain.
For the third straight day in the Federal Court trial of thirteen secondary Communist party leaders, the defense failed yesterday to win the granting of a mistrial motion.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower was said today by Army officers to he dissatisfied with the amount of ammunition available to United Nations forces in Korea. One general said the present ammunition supply would be inadequate to support an offensive should the decision be made to "get the line moving again."

PARIS, Dec. 19 -- The action yesterday by the North Atlantic Treaty Organization Council to give "continuing support" in the Indo-China war has raised the hope here that United States aid for the conduct of that struggle would be increased by at least $100,000,000, Jean Letourneau, Minister for the Indo-China States, told the National Assembly tonight.

PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 19 (AP) -Southern California's Trojans believe in heavy duty workouts while Wisconsin is following a program of lighter drills as they prepare for their Rose Bowl clash New Year's Day.

The liner United States, flagship of the United States Lines, was racing through North Atlantic seas toward New York last night at a pace that may result in her fastest crossing since she won the ocean speed laurels last July.

CHICAGO, Dec. 19 -- Surgeons at Research and Educational Hospitals of the University of Illinois were confronted by a new peril today in their efforts to save the lives of the now-separated Brodie Siamese twins.

Commodity futures on the New York exchanges closed generally higher yesterday. No markets were lower than Thursday, and only potatoes, sugar and wool closed mixed. Activity improved on sugar and cocoa.

SCARBOROUGH-ON-HUDSON, N. Y., Dec. 19 -- Many dinner parties will be given in advance of the annual Assembly Ball tomorrow night in the Sleepy Hollow Country Club. Mrs. John H. Tinker Jr. is chairman of the committee in charge of the plans for the event, at which a large group of young women will make their formal debuts.
The annual candlelight carol service at Riverside Church, 122d Street and Riverside Drive, will be held at 5 P. M. tomorrow.

Last-minute shoppers in search of a gift for a man may find, in the selection still available, wares to suit a variety of temperaments. Some are tempting imports from Europe and others, of domestic origin, are designed to please the hobbyist.

ATLANTA, Ga., Dec. 19 -- Frank Costello, New York gambler, was denied a habeas corpus petition by U. S. District Judge Frank Hooper today after the court had learned that he would be transferred from the Atlanta Federal Penitentiary to a Federal correctional institution in Milan, Mich., on Monday.

Edward Phelan, in a recent letter to THE NEW YORK TIMES, argued persuasively for a fresh examination of alternative methods of financing the United Nations, presently achieved by annual contributions of the member nations.

BOSTON, Dec. 19 (AP) -- A protest by a Protestant minister against celebration of a Roman Catholic Mass on Boston Common Wednesday as part of a pre-Christmas program was rejected today by Mayor John B. Hynes.

The Paris meeting of the North Atlantic Council has ended with meager results. In the face of urgent warnings from its military staff that Soviet military preparations permit no slowdown, and in disregard of its own acknowledgment that any relaxation must increase our danger, the Council decided to relax.

The man generally considered the most feared figure in the underworld was the principal witness at yesterday's hearing into waterfront conditions by the State Crime Commission. He was Albert Anastasia, and his defiant appearance on the stand was the most dramatic incident of the hearings to date.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- The Washington Post Company said today it had reached agreement with the Florida Broadcasting Company to buy the radio stations WMBR and WMBR-FM, and television station WMBR-TV, at Jacksonville, Fla.
ELIZABETH, N. J., Dec. 20 -- Thousands of employes in Union County industries will have a four-day week-end starting Christmas Day.

Despite a "precarious" financial position at the end of the fiscal year last June 30, the Brooklyn chapter of the American Red Cross increased its total services to the community, according to the chapter's annual report issued yesterday.

Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the President-elect, moved against communism yesterday by scheduling a luncheon meeting tomorrow at his Commodore Hotel headquarters at which four key members of the new Administration will join members of the Committee on the Present Danger.

ROBERT JOSEPH, producer of Charles Friedman's "My Darlin' Aida," at the Winter Garden, and before that a co-sponsor of Strindberg's "The Father" and "King Lear," is headed in the direction of another ambitious project, this one aimed for next season.

ROME, Dec. 20 (UP) -- Twenty-seven Americans, including a 69-year-old former Iowa business man who is the father of fourteen children, were ordained as Roman Catholic priests today in churches and basilicas of Rome.

ONE of the first paradoxical truisms confronting the layman who enters the 16-millimeter film world, either as spectator or creative participant, is its complete lack of distributional simplicity. Ironically, even without a central clearing

Educators generally are opposed to loyalty oaths for school or college teachers. They object to being singled out as a profession, holding that by being required to declare their loyalty to this country they are placed in an inferior position. At the same time, the educational leaders of the country are opposed to the employment of any teacher who is in any way subversive or is a member of the Communist party.

FIVE picture books in which photographs are reproduced partly for their own sake, partly to illustrate the text, but in all cases dominating the work as a whole, were recently published. Probably the most impressive of these is A. Aubrey Bodine's "My Maryland" (Baltimore: Camera Magazine, $7.50), a 9x12-inch volume of about 170 pictures by this well-known photographer of The Baltimore Sunpapers and winner of many exhibition honors.

A STIFF breeze kicked up by wind machine swelled the main course of the Great Harry, flagship of King Henry VIII's navy, as it "sailed" down the English Channel toward open sea in a corner of the big tank on Stage 30 at Metro-Goldwyn -Mayer for the filming of an important sequence in "Young Bess."

GRAHAM GREENE'S early novel "The Shipwrecked" (originally, "England Made Me") will sail on schedule from the Viking Press Jan. 9, but without Mr. Greene, who had planned to come to the United States in time for publication. He refused the offer of the State Department to give him a limited visa. . .

WHILE the Army hasn't yet found a way to bring armchair television to troops in the field here, they can still listen to good old-fashioned American radio programs -- minus the commercials -- just about twenty-four hours a day.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- President Truman led the nation's defense officials today in sending Christmas and New Year's greetings to the Armed Forces.

New York State is in the midst of a record-breaking school-building program. A total of 650 new elementary and secondary schools, to cost $575,000,000, is under construction or in some stage of preparation.

The last aria sung in public by Enrico Caruso, "Rachel, quand du Seigneur" from Halevy's "La Juive," will be played in the noon-to-2 P.M. recorded concert on Wednesday at the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street.

There are more reasons than one that bring thousands from many parts of the hinterland to New York City every January for the National Motor Boat Show. The main appeal, of course, is the display of the newest creations of pleasure craft, engines, gear and paraphernalia.
PRINCETON, N. J., Dec. 20 -- Princeton's varsity hockey team came through with a pair of goals in every period today to roll over previously undefeated Northeastern,6 -- 1, at Baker Rink.

Harold Clurman's views on theatrical trends ("Actors in Style -- and Style in Actors," Dec. 7) made provocative reading, particularly his jibe at the "industrialized theatre" which hires "types." How true! Instead of actors and actresses we have enactresses and reactors. In the Hollywood mind's eye, which calls for rigid idealization of identity, the tyranny of type-casting hangs heavy.

THE heartiness of the local welcome to the little Slavenska-Franklin Ballet at the Century Theatre bears striking testimony to the eagerness of the dance public for new choreographers with theatrical ideas. With all due respect, the company would never have got to first base on the strength of its "Nutcracker," its "Don Quijote" and the two competent but conventional little pieces by Mia Slavenska.

THE outdoor picture for 1952 has many details that are somewhat out of perspective, as viewed by the individual angler, hunter and shooter, but a few strokes of a brush in 1953 will clarify or obliterate these details.

It appears to us that C. B. Palmer, in his entertaining antidote to the pathos of the Beat Generation, must be mistaken when he disclaims any title for his own generation. Is he not the parent of the youngster who calls himself "beat." If so, his flippancy is incredible.

Lee Thompson Smith, chairman of the committee for celebration of the 300th anniversary of the incorporation of New York as a city, announced yesterday that he would confer with Mayor Impellitteri on the selection of other committee members.

DETROIT, Dec. 20 -- It rained all day today and snow was predicted for tonight, but tomorrow's playoff between the Los Angeles Rams and the Detroit Lions for the National Conference (Western Division) championship of the National Football League will be in clear and cold weather.

The recent elections in the Saar have by no means decided the fate of this area. The French want the Saar, as do the Germans. The Saarlanders manage to survive under each regime. Apparently all they want is peace and prosperity. Should it be really so difficult to grant just that?

DETROIT, Dec. 20 -- A seven-man professional committee was named today by Sigma Delta Chi, national journalistic fraternity, to weigh a proposed study to find if newspapers, magazines and radio and television outlets in the United States were based in covering the recent Presidential campaign.

STILL in her early thirties, Jennifer Blake seems to have everything. She has been married for thirteen years to a devoted, prosperous husband and she has three attractive children. Her husband's dominating, ultra-conservative parents regard her as an ideal wife for their son.

WILLIAM ELINE is a travel agent in Marseille, France. His firm sends hundreds of immigrants to the United States, dreams up side trips for American tourists in the south of France and handles one-day sightseeing for United States Sixth Fleet sailors by the dozens.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (UP) -- The United Textile Workers, A. F. L., blasted today the rival Textile Workers Union, C. I. O., as a "crumbling organization." It made the first public attack on new attempts at labor unity.

A four-point program, specifically designed "for advancing the cause of full equality for all Americans," was proposed to Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the President-elect, by the American Jewish Congress last night. One recommendation called for the establishment of a Civil Rights Division in the Department of Justice.

Benjamin R. Epstein, national director of the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith, announced yesterday that the league has submitted an appeal to the New York State Commission Against Discrimination for the banning of such phrases as "churches near by" in resort advertisements.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 20 -- The United Nations General Assembly gave its approval today to a resolution calling on the Western powers and the Soviet Union to agree on the terms of a treaty ending the occupation of Austria and restoring the country to full sovereignty.

THIS is the time of the year when I find myself yearning for a visit to the jockey room at Hialeah Park. Instead, I wander about with a hangdog look, shrinking in shame at my midget height. What am I? Man or mouse? Let's face it. I'm mouse, the smallest, most insignificant one you ever saw.

IN this book Lily Abegg sets herself the task of analyzing the East Asian mind. She brings to this task not only the equipment of a person trained in modern psychology but, what is more important, the intuition of a woman.

THERE is no doubt that "Eric Sloane's Weather Book" is not a professor's idea of a text book. And it seems clear that a textbook is exactly what Mr. Sloane did not want it to be. It is written for him who reads as he runs -- but who, nevertheless, has time for wondering at it all between steps.

THE female of the species is as desperate as the male. On this proposition James D. Horan, author of "Desperate Men," has built a second fascinating book. "Their appetite for life, action, and excitement," he writes of America's desperate women, "was insatiable.

There were only an average number of flying saucer reports from New Jersey last week, but, at long last, the Air Force was able to lay hands on one. The six-foot cone-shaped object, silver-plated, with red lights on its rim, was identified by a technical sergeant as a part of the ceiling decorations at a dance held on Nov. 22 in the Crystal Lake Casino near West Orange, N. J.

One must at once admire the selflessness and question the wisdom of the resignation of Trygve Lie. Of the selflessness there can be no question; and in this his decision is characteristic of the sense of service and of dedication which has marked his term of office as Secretary General.

Manhattan had Cappy Lane to thank for its fourth straight basketball victory last night. Madison Square Garden's official timekeeper, to whom the decision was referred, ruled that what would have been a game-winning goal for Furman had been tallied after the final buzzer.
A loan exhibition of contemporary Spanish paintings will be opened by the Barnard College Spanish Department on Jan. 19, at the Schaeffer Galleries, 52 East Fifty-eighth Street.

This period between the election and the inauguration is often referred to as an interregnum. The Constitution provides for a President and Vice President of fixed terms but says nothing about an interrex or interregnum.

Sales of television receivers in Canada will reach record proportions in the next few years, Ernest A. Marx, director of the international division, Allen B. DuMont Laboratories, Inc., predicted last week. He said, however, that the Dominion will never be more than a negligible export market for American manufacturers.

WHEN the country decided it was "time for a change," organized labor did not suspect it was in for the biggest and quickest change of all. Within a month after the voters canceled the Democratic lease on the White House and ended an era in which unions had made their most spectacular gains, the deaths of William Green and Philip Murray compelled both major branches of American labor to pick new leaders.

Bankers Trust Company resumed its expansion program of "banking for the masses" last week with the public announcement that it plans to merge the Bayside National Bank and operate its four offices in Queens. When ratified by shareholders on Jan. 28, the proposal will mark the first successful merger transaction since May, 1951, when Commercial National Bank and Trust Company was also absorbed by Bankers Trust.

Christmas is a festival that has a way of reshaping itself in different countries and through different generations. And late yesterday afternoon at Town Hall, for the thirteenth consecutive year, the Trapp Family Singers gave New Yorkers a glimpse of how the holiday is traditionally celebrated in the Austrian villages in the mountains around Salzburg.

HOLLYWOOD. COLUMBIA Pictures is the first of the big studios to admit it has more than a curiosity interest in Cinerama. There are reports that Warner Brothers also has serious intentions about the new process in photography and projection that now is exciting New York audiences, but studio sources are not ready to acknowledge anything as yet.

While shipping magnates could do more to stop pilfering and murders along New York's docks it is up to the citizens to take over control of the city government from racketeers, Rabbi Nathan A. Perilman declared yesterday.

CAMDEN, N. J., Dec. 20 -- The Upshur, a 17,600-ton vessel originally built as a luxury liner for the American President Lines and then converted to a transport for the Navy's Military Sea Transportation Service, was officially turned over to the Navy in a ceremony today at the New York Shipbuilding Corporation yard here.

BONN, Germany, Dec. 20 -- United States Ambassador William H. Draper Jr., head of the Mutual Security Agency in Europe, met briefly today with Chancellor Konrad Adenauer to discuss the economic and political problems of the Federal Government.
BONN, Dec. 20 -- Industrial production in West Germany increased 21 per cent between August and December, according to statistics released today by the Ministry of Economics.

NOW that the State Crime Commission is making public the horrors of New York dockside operations, it is timely to point out that none other than Budd Schulberg and Elia Kazan are ready to put a dramatization of such goings-on on film. Last
COLD is the Northern world, All green under the snow, Battle-flags are unfurled, Ready for more woe. But the cottage-windows glow.

ELIZABETH, N. J., Dec. 20 -- Mrs. Madlynn Kirby Dempsey, 46 years old, widow of Roy S. Dempsey, executive vice president of the United States Trucking Corporation which he had founded with the late Gov. Alfred E. Smith of New York, was burned to death shortly before daybreak today in a fire that swept her fourth-floor apartment in the Elmora Towers here.

I wrote, and you published, a letter on Clellon Holmes' article on the "Beat Generation." Now you publish C. B. Palmer's satirical "Lament for the Normal Generation" (Dec. 7) -- hurrah for C. B.! All such labeling of generations is really just a convenient way to express the "signs of the times."

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 20 (AP) -- The man elected to run the world's largest steel company on Jan. 1 gets a lot of personal satisfaction from thinking his G. I. son in Korea may be using some of the defense goods his company makes.

BOSTON, Dec. 20 -- Predictions that department stores would have their best Christmas season sales apparently are being substantiated. Last week a number of stores in Boston sold more goods than in any previous week. Retail business has been generally excellent for the last fortnight.

THE 1953 National High School Photographic Awards, offering $4,000 in cash prizes to students from the ninth to the twelfth grades in American public, private or parochial schools, has been announced by the National School Press Association.

AMERICAN foreign relations during the Civil War is the theme of these two books. One, by the English novelist Evan John, tells an old story from a new angle. The other, by Albert Woldman, American lawyer and Lincoln student, recounts a story that is, if not entirely new, not known to many Americans.

BEGINNING next month the famous Black Hills, S. D., Passion Play will be enacted in an amphitheatre set among orange groves outside Lake Wales, Fla. The dramatic presentation of Christ's passion will star Joseph Meier, and remain in Florida until March of each year.

Although few buyers were in the wholesale market here last week, many rush orders were received as retailers prepared for the two extra days before Christmas which is expected to push sales volume well over last year's figures, according to Kirby, Block Co., Inc., resident buying office.

" EXTREMS meet," as the French say. "We've all heard of the yokels who believe that the actor who plays the villain is a bad man and the comedian who cracks jokes makes it up himself on the spur of the moment.

MOSES LAKE, Wash., Dec. 20 -- A giant Air Force transport plane crashed here a few seconds after having taken off early today with a load of 115 service men going home on Christmas leave, killing eighty-four persons in the world's worst aviation disaster. The plane was headed for San Antonio, Tex.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 20 -- G. P. Arkadyev of the Soviet Union replied today to yesterday's rebuttal by Senator Alexander Wiley of the United States of Soviet bloc attacks on United States foreign policy with personal vilification of the Senator from Wisconsin and a lapse into blasphemy.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- Three events of this week have brought once again into sharp focus a question which rapidly is causing one of the most virulent schisms in American life of this century. The question is this: How should a democratic government guard itself against the menace of subversive political doctrines and yet preserve the basic freedoms of the citizens who serve it?
John Cobb, Walter O. Briggs, Wilbur Francis (Fats) Henry, Bo McMillin, Hugo Bezdek, Floyd (Arky) Vaughan and James Norris Sr., were among the many sports notables who died in 1952.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- Washington's society matrons are looking forward to the change in administrations next month with interest, considerable approval and no little trepidation.

PARIS, Dec. 20 -- The process of rearming Germany, already two and a half years old, seems to be entering the doldrums. For although the need for German divisions is probably greater than it was a year ago from the purely military point of view, political and public opposition and apathy are gaining in Europe.
DETROIT, Dec. 20 (AP) -- Easy credit terms and the possibility that 1953 will bring a competitive market are giving auto finance companies concern.

SPRINGFIELD, Mo., Dec. 20 -- Robert Henry Best, World War II traitor, died Tuesday at the United States Medical Center for Federal Prisoners here, its officials announced today. His body was claimed by his Viennese-born wife, Erma, and was shipped to Spartanburg, S. C., yesterday. He was 56 years old.

Claremont Terminal, a typical example of the rich waterfront plums for control of which racketeers and hoodlums engage in mortal combat in this port, came under the surveillance last week of the State Crime Commission. Despite the revelations of many witnesses, the real importance of installations of this type to the underworld remained only partially answered.

RODIE STAMM, the unheroic hero of "Heaven Pays No Dividends," grew up in an old house overlooking the Rhine. His father, a former German Foreign Service man, read The London Times regularly, wrote articles on science and taught his son to abhor loud-mouthed, vulgar people.

TOKYO, Sunday, Dec. 21 -- Allied bombers raided North Korea as far north as Pyongyang and patrols traded blows along the Korean fighting front yesterday, but low-flying clouds, snow flurries and zero temperatures hampered most activities.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 20 -- Cigarette consumption is high compared with pre-war levels in all but a few of the tobacco-consuming countries, and it is largely because more women are smoking and smoking more than ever.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (UP) -- Senator Herbert H. Lehman, Democrat of New York, said today that he would ask the next Congress to vote the principal recommendations of the President's Health Commission. He appealed for bi-partisan support of the proposed bill.

ONCE every year all over the world there is a return to sentiment -- everyone wants a Christmas tree. What is Christmas, wherever it may be celebrated, without this traditional and universal symbol? Christmas is for children -- and all grown-ups become children, too, at this time of year.

The second annual Frederik Lunning prize to advance Scandinavian art, handcraft and applied arts will be awarded today in Stockholm, Sweden, to Carl-Axel Acking and Grete Prytz Korsmo. The two winners of the $5,000 award by Just Lunning, president of Georg Jensen, Inc., will share the money to further their studies in the United States.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- Senator H. Alexander Smith, Republican of New Jersey, who calls himself a "middle-of-the-roader" on labor-management issues, emerged today as the probable chairman of the Senate Committee on Labor and Public Welfare.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- Defense sources disclosed today that the United States could use atomic rockets and guided missiles in combat whenever they were needed.

The auction of the dredge U. S. Talcott and her equipment last week by the Corps of Engineers may set a new pattern for the disposal of surplus equipment, local dealers in marine equipment said yesterday.
Your editorial of Dec. 14 on the Imperfect Universe was a delightful and welcome note in the midst of comment on the grim and discordant events taking place on our unhappy planet, Earth.

PARIS, Dec. 20 -- The estimates of defense expenditure for the coming fiscal year given to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization by member governments indicate that Italy and Portugal propose to reduce their financial efforts next year while other member countries propose to increase them in varying degrees.

NICOSIA, Cyprus, Dec. 20 (Reuters) -- A Syrian C-47 transport with fourteen aboard was missing today after being asked to search for a Netherlands Navy Catalina flying boat, which had crashed in Lebanon.

The ninth meeting of the NATO Council was held eight months ago in Lisbon. It was the seat of historic decisions: to build a defense force of ninety-six divisions and 9,000 aircraft by 1955; to place under NATO a European army including a rearmed West Germany. French Foreign Minister Robert Schuman said: "One rarely attends a conference which accomplishes as much as this one did."

THE American Theatre Wing's Professional Training Program, which in the past six years has provided some 6,000 members of the entertainment world with a chance to refurbish, reshuffle or replenish their skills for stage, opera, concert

During the next twelve months the country will observe in many ways the immense contribution of the Wright brothers. The fiftieth anniversary of the achievement at Kitty Hawk falls on Dec. 17, 1953. Meantime this year's anniversary has been suitably celebrated in Washington at a ceremony in which three important trophies for the advancement of aviation were presented by the President to their respective winners.
The holidays will be a "Champagne waltz," according to reports last week of growing sales by both importers and retailers. Most of them report the largest sales since repeal.

WITH three shopping days to go, Christmas trade is in the home stretch. The pace of buying last week in most sections of the country was fast, if not hectic, and it seems probable that a new record will be set when all the sales figures are in.
LONDON, Dec. 20 (Reuters) -- Cardiff City, newcomer this season to Division One of the English Soccer League, today held the league-leading Wolverhampton Wanderers to a scoreless draw.

Formal dedication ceremonies were held at Upton, L. I., last week for one of the world's great scientific instruments -- the 2,200-ton cosmotron of the Brookhaven National Laboratory, a machine so powerful it can literally pick up the pieces after an atomic bomb explosion and start to put them back together again.

It's Christmas time in the animal world, too, and yesterday 600 dogs and fifty cats, together with 900 assorted owners and custodians, converged on the headquarters of the Humane Society of New York at 313 East Fifty-eighth Street for their share in the annual good cheer.

CHICAGO, Dec. 20 (AP) -- Rodney Dee Brodie, the Siamese twin to whom surgeons concede the better chance to survive, perked up a little today in response to his nurses. His brother, Roger Lee, still was unconscious and in a precarious condition.

IT is only since the war that Italian painting has rejoined the mainstream of European art, and the work of its younger artists, those who have only recently swung into recognition, is distinguished by a romantic, often truculent, appeal.

SEOUL, Korea, Dec. 20 -- Though there will be few of the gay trimmings of the Christmas season here, no round of merry cocktail parties and a scarcity of Christmas trees with colored lights in this beleaguered capital city, there already is evident a generosity of spirit that is heart-warming.

When William Maw Egley, a sixteen-year-old apprentice engraver in London, designed a quaint Christmas greeting card for his friends back in 1842 he created the backbone of an in dustry which this year, in America alone, will realize about $110,000,000 at the retail level.

NO figure in modern literature has been more personal in his writing than Miguel de Unamuno, and yet there is no personality more difficult to define and assess. He himself disliked easy classifications: he was a philosopher and poet, a novelist and teacher, an essayist and political prophet, but above all he was the incarnation of his country, one whose consciousness was "a Spanish consciousness, made in Spain."

TELEVISION is rapidly developing a new kind of magician -- the special effects man. He is not new, of course, in the world of show business, but TV is forcing him to enlarge his bag of tricks, some of them wholly electronic. His job is to make the viewer "believe" in something which, in reality, is far different from what it seems.

The public revenue bond, whose evolution in a multiplicity of new forms has been an arresting post-war development, may be introduced into a field of public enterprise previously underwritten by the budget of the Federal Government.

Red poinsettias, red gladiolus blossoms, silver foliage and southern smilax provided a Christmas decor for the second and last Junior Assembly for this season last night in the main ballroom of the Plaza. The ceiling of the ballroom was arched with masses of red balloons and clusters of red balloons festooned the columns, the bases of which were banked with red poinsettias, gladiolus blossoms and frosted branches.

The domestic steel industry increased its productive capacity to a record level this year, and its output has been the third highest on record, despite the prolonged work stoppage in June and July, George S. Rose, secretary of the Iron and Steel Institute, declared in a year-end statement.
BERLIN, Dec. 20 -- Television has arrived in the divided city of Berlin and promises to open up a new field of battle in the "cold war."

Reports indicating that Christmas sales of department stores here are running behind last year's in contrast to gains elsewhere in the country do not mean that holiday sales in the metropolitan area are on the toboggan.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 20 -- The United Nations hopes for private aid in financing a new library, costing $3,000,000 to $3,500,000, the need for which is regarded as urgent in view of the physical inability of the present library, a converted office building, to hold any more books.

With President-elect Eisenhower's four designations last Friday his Department of Defense is taking final shape. Cooperation between Defense Secretary Charles E. Wilson and his deputy is assured by the fact that Roger M. Kyes has already served General Motors as a subordinate official to Mr. Wilson.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 20 -- Yugoslav military authorities declared sharply today that Western military assistance to their country was insufficient in volume and too slow in delivery.

LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., Dec. 20 -- John P. Humes and H. C. Schwab of the home club led the way into the semi-final round of the annual invitation doubles squash racquets tournament at the Piping Rock Club today by defeating Seymour Knox Jr. and Allston Flagg Jr., Piping Rock, 15 -- 6, 15 -- 12, 15 -- 13.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- The "simple and dignified" inaugural celebration approved by Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the President-elect, has blossomed into a three-day affair that will attract a half million visitors to Washington and cost nearly $1,000,000.

TANGIER, Dec. 20 -- Sidney H. Paley, the Jersey City "pirate by proxy," was found guilty today of complicity in armed robbery on the high seas and conspiracy, and was sentenced to a three-year term in a Federal penitentiary.
THERE is an atmosphere of glad tidings in the room at The Cloisters in which a special Christmas exhibition, "Shepherds in the Fields," has been arranged.
LONDON, Dec. 20 -- Britain, still fighting an economic battle for survival, has decided to extend and increase her "calculated risk" and to cut back and spread out her military program.
LONDON, Dec. 20 (Reuters) -- Poland has accused the Israeli Legation in Warsaw of activities of an espionage character and called for them to be stopped, the Warsaw radio reported tonight.

ILLUSTRATIONS of six postage stamp designs which won three $1,000 and three $500 cash awards in a United Nations world-wide contest among artists were made available last week by Reidar Tvedt, Chief of the United Nations Postal Administration.

Bishop Loughlin Memorial High School's track team, indoor and outdoor Catholic High School Athletic Association titleholder, registered 17 points to capture team honors at the forty-sixth annual Stuyvesant High School A. A. track meet at the 102d Engineers Armory last night.

PONGAM ISLAND, Korea, Dec. 20 -- The fierce riot that resulted in the death of eighty-five North Korean war prisoners on this grim island was not an isolated, local flare up. It was, rather, the result of careful planning and careful indoctrination by Communists in a new kind of battle.
Direct cargo service between New York and the interior of Peru will begin at the end of next month, Stockard Co., agents for the Corporacion Peruano de Vapores, announced here yesterday.

Not the least of the wonders we commemorate this week was the simplicity surrounding the Birth itself. A carpenter named Joseph went with his young wife up from Nazareth to Bethlehem, the town of his fathers, to enroll for taxation as the governing Romans had ordered. Bethlehem was a simple hill town of no particular consequence at the time.

One of the first photographs of Jupiter obtained with the 200-inch Hale telescope at the Palomar Observatory in California was released yesterday by the California Institute of Technology, Pasadena, which operates the observatory jointly with the Carnegie Institution of Washington.
I enjoy skimming through the Sunday edition of THE TIMES. This Sunday, thus, I made myself comfortable in an armchair and began the reading of The Times Magazine while drinking a cup of coffee.

LAST week I was talking about words in general; today I am concerned with only two. They are words constantly used in estimating the quality of a writer's work. We speak of talent and genius and try to draw a distinction between them.

A message from the Far North within range of the North Pole that Santa himself might have chosen for an operating base, was delivered yesterday to the forty-first annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

THE stringent provisions of the controversial McCarran-Walter Immigration and Nationality Act are likely to have a delaying effect, at least in the immediate future, on general tourist travel movement to this country -- a movement already overburdened with red tape.

SENTIMENTAL Dickensians, always too many and too vocal, will not like this book. Those canonizers and eulogists whose version of a great creative genius has been that of a jejune, saintly figure, compounded of a nauseous mixture of the Brothers Cheeryble, Tiny Tim, Little Nell and Pickwick at his worst, benevolent and saccharine off-moments, will rage at the emergence of the real Dickens from behind their officious camouflage.
