LONDON, Dec. 20 -- "Dear Charles," Alan Melville's artfully concocted play from the French "Les Enfants d'Edouard," by Marc Gilbert Sauvajon and Frederick Jackson, was hailed by all the aisle-sitters after its opening at the New Theatre Thursday night.

Company and union officials announced at 9 o'clock last night that 220 mechanics, inspectors and cleaners of Northeast Airlines, Inc., would return to work at 12:01 A. M. today, ending a strike that had begun Dec. 5.

The last full week of trading in stocks for 1952 found the market more subdued than in many preceding weeks approach of the Christmas holidays had a diversionary effects on stock transactions, with prices moving irregularly in quiet trading.

LONG recognized as the dean of living English historians of the literary school, George Macaulay Trevelyan, grew up in a historical environment and under the influence of a historical tradition. His father, Sir George Otto Trevelyan, was a historian of considerable distinction and the author of a life of Thomas Babington Macaulay, his uncle, which has taken its place as a classic biography.

THE story which Herman Petersen tells is of the Chenango Valley in south central New York State. The time includes the years just before and just after the Civil War. Hannah Barty is the daughter of a poor French-Canadian farmer, Mish Barty, once Michel Bartet.
City College's basketball team defeated Lafayette, its first major out - of - town opponent, 83 -- 59, in C. C. N. Y.'s main gymnasium last night.

TO abuse further Mark Twain's observation on the weather: everyone talks about India's foreign policy, but no one does anything about it. Werner Levi, Professor of Political Science at the University of Minnesota, has provided a handy guidebook to the labyrinth of Indian approaches to other nations of Asia and the rest of the world.

THE well-known English line of Ensign folding cameras is again available in this country. Three models are announced, all with built-in flash synchronization and finished in leatherette and satin chrome.

ARE-CREATED Lawrence's Daguerreian Gallery, one of seventy-one such establishments operating locally 100 years ago, is one of the features of "New York Street Scenes, 1852," currently on view at the Museum of the City of New York, where it will continue for an indefinite period through the spring.

ALBANY, Dec. 20 -- Governor Dewey, after a four-hour conference with members of the State Crime Commission in the executive chambers at the Capitol today, said he would recommend an appropriation of $100,000 by the Legislature to carry the agency through this fiscal year, which ends next March 31.

McCHORD AIR FORCE BASE, Wash., Dec. 20 -- More radio aids for aerial navigation over Alaska are expected to be recommended in the wake of a costly series of military airplane crashes last month, it was indicated today at this base near Tacoma.

A GROWING appreciation of the potential glamour inherent in pursuing the culinary arts is evidenced in the pictures on these pages. All the rooms and objects shown here are connected with cooking. But with happy consideration for the holiday hostess who must also serve as cook, all are distinguished by a charm that erases the staid, workaday, functional look.

Manufacturers of men's clothing have established a three seasonal operation. Added to the old standby of fall suits and spring suits are light-weight summer lines. Producers, now in the middle of spring operations, are using lighter colors and weights than the fall lines but the clothing is still too heavy to meet the consumers' requirement for summer wear.
THOSE who have operatic records on their Christmas shopping lists will find wide variety among the newest releases.

Leo Seidman's letter in your section on December 14 seems to me to offer a supremely fallacious argument in asserting that the American National Theatre and Academy would "justify its existence only by production of plays written by American authors."

THE last Sunday before Christmas is an appropriate time to commend three new disks which underline the religious significance of the approaching holiday. Each in its different way brings into the home music that stirs the feelings which seem to getmore crowded out as Christmas grows more hectic.

This morning's cup of coffee, multiplied by the hundreds of thousands up and down the country, means big business. A battle is being fought behind the scenes over who is to get the major share of the dollars that this business represents.

JERUSALEM, Dec. 20 -- A little bit of Christmas spirit appears to have entered the relations between Israel and Jordan. Liaison officers of the two countries meeting in the No Man's Land at the Mandelbaum Gate here have agreed on two small concessions to make it easier for Christians to carry out the pilgrimage to Bethlehem and other Holy Places during Christmas week.
PARIS, Dec. 20 -- The Bey of Tunis yielded quickly today to French threats and approved two decrees on administrative reforms that he had rejected earlier in the week.

" ONLY in an atmosphere of ceremony, courtesy and chivalry can the dance maintain itself in perfection" wrote a contributor to the Encyclopedia Britannica forty-odd years ago. That Edwardian would be astonished at the brilliance of the ballet in these unceremonious times and especially at its enormous popularity with our something-lessthan-courtly blue - jeans set.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- James P. McGranery, Attorney General, welcomed Herbert Brownell Jr. to the Department of Justice today as "my very worthy successor."

NEXT Friday night the Gulf Playhouse is finishing its run on N. B. C. television and the following week will be replaced by a Hollywood film version of William Bendix in his old radio show, "The Life of Riley."

The preservation of democracy depends as much upon an understanding of the issues in the present conflict as upon military preparedness and technological efficiency, according to Dr. Earl J. McGrath, United States Commissioner of Education. Writing in the current issue of the University of Chicago School Review, Dr. McGrath says that college graduates, though competent in their chosen field, are baffled by their inability to understand and to deal intelligently with problems of contemporary life.

SKIING'S booming development in this country might well be attributed to (1) the 1932 Winter Olympics at Lake Placid, (2) the introduction of low-rate snow trains, (3) the establishment of tows and lifts, (4) inauguration of good ski schools and (5) the present trend of learn-to-ski weeks.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 20 -- Foreign Minister Joao Neves da Fontoura, returning last night from a visit to the United States, gave a message of optimism to the nation. He forecast increased aid and declared that Brazil would soon be "startled to see how many dollars come in."
OTTAWA, Dec. 20 -- Defense Minister Brooke Claxton told news men today on his arrival from Paris that it wars for Prime Minister Louis St. Laurent to decide whether or not he should resign.

COMMON fruits bought at the local supermarket are a source of seed for unusual house plants. They may even produce candidates, unpredictable but interesting, for the home orchard. Seedlings started now will be sizable plants by next spring.

The third list of dates for important archaeological and anthropological discoveries was published last week in Science by Dr. W. F. Libby of the Institute for Nuclear Studies of the University of Chicago. The dates are those determined by precise measurement of the amount of radioactive carbon in a sample of a material that was living (and so storing carbon) centuries ago.

TWENTY years ago, when Georges Simenon was an incredibly prolific hack, living in a barge on the Seine and grinding out at least a novel a month, he made some of the most distinguished contributions to the serious literature of murder in the French, or indeed in any language.

PARIS, Dec. 20 -- The Constitutional Committee of the European Coal and Steel Community closed its preparatory program today by issuing a series of documents defining the foundations for what is hoped will ultimately become the constitution for the United States of Europe.

Dwight Eisenhower has thirty days to go before he takes the oath that changes him from Citizen Eisenhower to President Eisenhower. Last week, as the nation and the world waited out the interregnum in U. S. executive power, events emphasized the global scope of the problems that will be his when he moves from the Commodore to the White House.

WASHINGTON -- Recent announcement that two sister organizations had merged into the National Trust for Historic Preservation gave the impression in some quarters that the United States, like Britain, now had an institution with vast holdings in ancient estates and historic places.

A milestone has been reached in the long efforts to unify exiles from the Soviet Union for a common struggle against Stalinist oppression. A conference of Ukrainian exile organizations is meeting in Munich, Germany, to consider the recommendation of the Ukrainian Congress Committee of America that Ukrainian exiles work with the Coordinating Center of Anti-Bolshevik Struggle, a group formed earlier this fall by nine exile units, some Russian and some non-Russian in membership.

On your editorial page of Dec. 14 Francis Kilcoyne asserts that Jefferson was elected President in 1800 by one vote, which he credits to Representative Matthew Lyon of Vermont. This assertion seems to distort the record as we have it in standard histories.

Traditionally Christmas has been an occasion for joyful family reunions and, in many instances, a time for a cordial greeting among friends long separated. Those whose work has taken them away from childhood firesides make a special effort to return home. The family get-togethers have been as much a part of Christmas as holly, mistletoe and evergreen trees.

FOR THIS WEEK: Until the cut Christmas tree is brought indoors to be trimmed, keep it in a cool place. A support holding water is safest indoors. . . . Protect the bark of young fruit trees from the nibbling of mice and rabbits by putting up ready-made guards or cylinders of fine mesh wire eighteen inches high. . . . Ventilate and water the coldframe according to weather. . . .

THERE is no escaping the Bible. Ignorance and atheism are equally futile as defenses. The Bible has so persistently infiltrated the blood stream of Western civilization that the illiterate ditch-digger unknowingly quotes and paraphrases its lines, and the professor expounding logical positivism uses a diction and turn of phrase that echo the book farthest removed from his convictions.
MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Dec. 20 -- The accent on age in the $13,000 international four-ball golf tournament was erased today when Willie Klein and Al Brosch lost after reaching the next-to-the-last round.
It's a brother team that today runs the biggest safe-making company in the world, and they are the fourth generation of the family to head up the Mosler Safe Company.

WHEN Bette Davis agreed last summer to appear in a musical show, it all looked like a lark for her and the rest of us. She has been an illustrious screen actress for more than twenty years. In her case the word "actress" is used advisedly.

A 210-HORSEPOWER engine with an 8.5 to 1 compression ratio, rated the mightiest ever utilized in an American stock car, will be one of the outstanding exhibits at the General Motors "Motorama of 1953," at the Waldorf-Astoria from Jan. 17 to 23.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., Dec. 10 (UP) -- Frank Gannett, head of the Gannett Newspapers, urged Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower today to establish a Department of Peace in his Administration with "a Cabinet officer at its head."

Through the entire sessions of the just concluded Sixth International Conference of Social Work, Robert Trumbull reports from Madras, India, there has run a thread of emphasis on the need to adapt aid programs of all sorts to local culture patterns. It is not enough, the conference was agreed, to think merely in terms of spending a given amount of money to get a quick economic result.

Airlines, railroads and bus companies were prepared yesterday to handle travel in the holiday season that is expected to be as great or greater than last year. The seasonal increase began to be noticeable here on Friday.

Under arrest in the $2,040 payroll hold-up of a messenger he had been hired to protect, a private detective has admitted committing nine liquor store robberies in the last six weeks, it was said in Bronx Magistrates Court yesterday.
New York trade unionists undertook yesterday a new program to integrate hundreds of thousands of Puerto Rican and other Spanish-speaking workers into the organized labor movement.

HOWARD HUGHES is back in the driver's seat at R. K. O. Radio Pictures, this time as chairman of the board. Last September Mr. Hughes, majority stock owner and studio managing director of production, sold his interests to a five-man
Mayor Impellitteri proposed yesterday that all city surface transit operations be taken over by a new Omnibus Redevelopment Corporation under private operation.

MOLINE, Ill., Dec. 20 (AP) -- A combined edition was published for three newspapers of this area today after mass picketing by printers had disrupted operations at the plants of The Moline Dispatch and The Rock Island Argus.

FIASCHERINO, Italy -- With their flair for the colorful phrase, the Ligurian Italians refer to the U-shaped Gulf of La Spezia as the Bay of the Poets. Seventy-five miles to the east of Genoa, this sparkling sun strip is backgrounded by mountains, punctuated by headlands, slashed by beaches. Over the centuries it has attracted such writers as Petrarch, Dante, Byron, Shelley, Leigh Hunt, Dickens, Twain and D. H. Lawrence.

Payments of social security benefits have increased sharply since the new formula for computing old age and survivors' insurance benefits was adopted, according to the November edition of The Social Security Bulletin, official publication of the Federal Security Agency.

The New York A. C. defeated the Meadow Brook Club, 11 to 7, and Farmington triumphed over Fairfield, 16 -- 8, in the opening twin bill of the Metropolitan Indoor Polo League at the Squadron A armory last night.

A marked change from the formula followed by the Truman Administration during the last seven years to check the steady rise in prices and living costs appears to be due when the new Republican regime that Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower will head takes office next month.

BABYLON, L. I., Dec. 20 -- A 10-cent toll on the Southern State Parkway, one of the most heavily traveled roads in the metropolitan area, was proposed today to finance a $40,000,000 program of highway improvement in Nassau County.

IF YOU haven't read a word of fiction since the days, a quarter of a century ago, when Anderson and Hemingway were introducing a Chekhovian immediacy and a Maupassantish abruptness (plus the American language) into the U. S. short story, you're still capable of guessing the tone -- not to say the limitations -- of editor Martha Foley's "best" for 1952.

We are in the week of Christmas. It is a season of rejoicing, of generosity, of the exchange of tokens of affection and esteem, of worship and of warmth of heart. In all its aspects one phrase recurs most conspicuously, "Peace on earth, goodwill toward men." It is long since the established leitmotif of our Christmas celebration. Those words are on countless cards, in hundreds of carols and anthems, in millions upon millions of homes.
SEOUL, Korea, Sunday, Dec. 21 (AP) -- Chinese Reds attacked near "Old Baldy" on the west-central Korean front in a pre-dawn snowstorm today and temporarily seized two Allied outposts.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Dec. 18 -- Haile Selassie, the Emperor of Ethiopia, declared today that his country not only wished to join a Middle East defense organization but was eager to have an American military aid mission established here to modernize the army and help establish a navy.

The Police Department's newest launch, the Harold K. Randolph, named in the memory of a Negro patrolman who was slain in the line of duty, was commissioned yesterday by Commissioner George P. Monaghan at a ceremony attended by high ranking officers.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 20 -- Two of the best-known members of the United States first-string team at the United Nations -- Warren R. Austin and Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt -- said their good-bye to the United Nations today, quietly and without much diplomatic fuss.

THE relation of geometric abstract painting to modern architecture and industrial design is clearly illustrated in an illuminating exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art. The Dutch group known as De Stijl, which flourished in the decade between 1917 and 1929, is the subject of the show.

TORONTO, Dec. 20 (UP) -- The Toronto Maple Leafs scored three third-period goals tonight to defeat the Chicago Black Hawsk, 4 -- 1, in their National Hockey League game before 12,543 fans at the Gardens.
NUREMBERG, Germany, Dec. 20 (AP) -- Santa Claus brought a big Christmas present this year to the men who help fill his gift pack -- the German toy makers.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 20 -- Industrial employment in this district is slightly higher than a month ago. Average factory wage level is 8 per cent higher than a year ago. In considerable part this is due to the steel and the metal working boom now under way.

A flood of commendatory telegrams poured into the office of Robert K. Christenberry, chairman of the State Athletic Commission yesterday, in the wake of his reversal of a boxing decision by which Billy Graham, East Side welterweight, was made the winner over Joe Giardello, Philadelphia middleweight, at the end of their ten-round bout in Madison Square Garden Friday night.

THE seventh annual report of the Arts Council of Great Britain has some words to say on the subject of the Government support of the fine arts in the program of a modern state. These apply with singular appropriateness to problems which now confront America's great musical organizations, symphonic and operatic, and the question of Government subsidy of their activities.

HERE again is the great story of the ship, from prehistoric log to modern liner, told this time in distinctive fashion by a British marine artist and naval architect. Striking color plates and numerous line drawings point up a readable text.

DETROIT, Dec. 20 -- Hy Buller's goal with less than thee minutes to play enabled the New York Rangers to gain a 1-1 tie with the Detroit Red Wings in a National Hockey League game tonight before 10,171 fans at Olympia.

Many advertising executives have unusual hobbies but that of Willard A. Pleuthner, a vice president of Batten, Barton, Durstine Osborn, Inc., seems especially worthy of mention at this time of the year. His principal avocation is helping churches of all denominations to build up their congregations by utilizing modern advertising and selling methods.

IF the magazine writings of Peter De Vries have not already laughed the public into the conviction that he is a humorist then this collection of twenty-nine cheerful pieces should establish his position.
TOKYO, Dec. 20 -- British Commonwealth soldiers at three bases in Japan were called out today to replace 13,000 Japanese workers striking for higher pay and a year-end bonus.

A 16-year-old delivery boy for a Bronx dry cleaning store, who resisted a gunman on the roof of a six-story apartment house at 940 Grand Concourse, the Bronx, was robbed of $7 and beaten about the face and head yesterday at 12:20 P. M., he told the police.

i Allow a vote of dissent from James H. Sheppard's position g/yen in THE TIMES of NOV. 16. Out here we can't gei much of .the. "repellent" music of American contemporaries he discusses. But through records and occasional visitors we hear a little.
The multi-billion dollar natural gas industry is playing a role in industry far more significant than indicated in figures on the growth in consumption by consumers in recent years.

A brave little nation of 4,000,000 hardy persons, a phenomenal runner of almost superhuman endurance and the United States shared the honors in the games of the Fifteenth Olympiad, in which American athletes again maintained the tradition of their supremacy in the face of the strong challenge from the athletes of Soviet Russia, competing for the first time.

" THE WHITE PLAGUE." that fascinating and recently published study of tuberculosis, came into being mainly because one of its family of authors prefers to utilize and control his hobbies, rather than let them control him. A bacteriologist at present concerned with problems of tuberculosis, Dr. Rene Dubos just declined to departmentalize his life into laboratory work, 9 o'clock each day, to 5, and fly-tying or poodle raising, 6 o'clock to midnight.

The city's finances are in a mess. They haven't been so scrambled since 1934, when the community's leading bankers were compelled to save the city from financial chaos by taking its elected officials by the scruff of the neck and shaking them into a regime of retrenchment and economy.

SYDNEY, Australia, Dec. 20 (AP) -- Elated over their 5-0 shutout of Italy in the interzone final, the United States Davis Cup players will go to Adelaide tomorrow and immediately begin practice for the challenge round, starting a week from Monday.
Should a historian of the future thumb through the pages of sport a half-century hence it is not likely that when he scans 1952 he will pause to exclaim, "Boy, that must have been a year!"

The crash of the giant Air Force transport near Moses Lake, Wash., yesterday was the ninth major accident in United States military aviation since Nov. 7 and the tenth in the North. Some 300 lives have been lost in the crashes.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 20 -- A new $1,000,000 wharf to expedite the handling of bananas from ships to rail and truck facilities will be formally opened here on Monday by the United Fruit Company with the arrival of the steamship Chiriqui.

FRANCONIA, N. H., Dec. 20 -- Flashing mid-season technique and stamina, Claude Richer, St. Lawrence University's Canadian Olympic ace, today skied off with the honors in the invitation cross-country meet held on the deep snows of this picturesque White Mountain national forest.

Institutions of higher education in the United States that lack facilities for evaluating the educational credentials of foreign students applying for admission may now call upon the Office of University admissions at Columbia University for assistance. This cooperative service is being rendered by Columbia because of the growing number of foreign students now enrolled at American colleges and universities.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., Dec 20 -- An obsolete Air Force light bomber and a single-engine private plane collided in the air over Deer Park, Suffolk County, yesterday morning but all three pilots involved were "able to walk away from it."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- A campaign to raise $1,500,000 for a public library to house President Truman's papers got a fresh and fully authorized start today with the naming of about three score eminent trustees and an advisory panel of five historians and scholars.

An unidentified armed hold-up man was killed last night by a traffic policeman who shot from behind a stack of liquor cartons as the thug tried to herd four persons to the rear of a Queens liquor store.
CLEVELAND, Dec. 20 -- Two Great Lakes shipping records were set last month, according to statistics compiled by the Lake Carriers Association.

IN the last two weeks the air has been full of news about conductors. Important changes were involved, but they were not such as to precipitate the game of musical chairs that starts when a conductor moves from one orchestra to another, requiring a further shift for the filling of his old post.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Dec. 20 -- Navy coasted to its sixth straight basketball success of the season here today by routing Harvard, 85 -- 62, in Dahlgren Hall.

MAMARONECK, N. Y., Dec. 20 -- A fourth suspect was arrested today in the discovery here yesterday of a cache of munitions believed to have been gathered for a revolution in Cuba, possibly at Christmas time. Police and Federal authorities were seeking a fifth man, who is reportedly heading for Miami, Fla.
The National League batting averages for 1952, released for publication today, can be termed a resume of another brilliant season in the career of Stan (The Man) Musial.

THERE are two stories in "No Time For Flowers." One is the screenplay by Laslo Vadnay and Hans Wilhelm, which we filmed. The other concerns our experiences in filming it in Vienna and behind the Iron Curtain. Perhaps I shall bring the latter to the screen one of these days as another project.

LONGEST-LIVED of all bridge books are those written for true beginners, persons who have never played bridge before. When contract bridge replaced auction bridge, the best-selling books of the great auction-bridge expert, Milton Work, quickly became non-sellers -- with one exception.

IT would seem almost that Roy Campbell was born to write this explosive little book. He himself has so many of the romantic qualities that he finds, or imagines that he finds, in Federico Garcia Lorca -- the dash, the gallantry, the Andalusian mixture of raw living and mysticism, and above all, the poetry -- that one could scarcely imagine a happier coincidence of author and subject. Much of this expectation is fulffiled.

NEWARK, Dec. 20 -- Superior Court Judge Frederick R. Colie today began the study of 1,000 pages of testimony and summaries presented in a ten-day trial, in which the litigants are seeking a judicial definition of the term "patent and proprietary medicines" as used in the New Jersey Pharmacy Act of 1901. The trial ended yesterday.

BEFORE he began rehearsals for the new English version of "La Boheme," which the Metropolitan will unveil next Saturday afternoon, Joseph Mankiewicz assembled the singers for what would be called in football a skull drill.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- President Truman and his top defense and diplomatic advisers conferred at the White House today amid reports that they would decide finally how much to ask for in new military appropriations.

A non-woven fabric that can be used in outerwear is definitely within sight of current textile research, it was learned last week. Fulfillment of the technician's dream of manufacturing a non-thermal plastic bonded material will be accomplished with natural fibers, according to David Morgenstern, president of the Pellon Corporation.
Two hundred handicapped children from city hospitals and homes were guests yesterday at the Mayor's annual Christmas party at City Hall.

MOSES LAKE, Wash., Dec. 20 (AP) -- Brig. Gen. W. H. Bowman, commanding officer of the Larson Air Force Base, today released the following list of survivors of the crash of the Globemaster. General Bowman said the list was not complete and revisions would be made as rapidly as possible.

ATLANTA, Dec. 20 -- Christmas buying continued brisk in the Southeast this week and some merchants reported they sought but could not obtain enough extra clerks to handle the volume of business. Several stores reported the holiday trade had set new records.

ELABORATE in every way is the new Decca release, on five disks, of all ten Beethoven Violin Sonatas played by Joseph Fuchs and Artur Balsam. The records are housed in a sturdy album, there are comprehensive program notes and photographs, and the actual printed music to all of the sonatas is reproduced in a booklet.

LAST year Ellery Queen published "Queen's Quorum," a collectors' check list of the 106 high points in the history of the detective short story in book form . . . and already it's outdated: two of 1952's volumes imperatively demand inclusion.

TRENTON, Dec. 20 -- Replacing the "ancient, inadequate" State Prison with a modern penal institution outside Trenton was recommended today by a special committee in a report on the causes of riots here and at the Rahway Prison Farm last spring.

News has just reached us west of the Hudson that "The Seven Year Itch," like other recent productions, having been acclaimed a solid hit, has had its Friday and Saturday night top raised from $4.80 to $6.00. Does this mean that success is the latest contributor to higher operating costs?

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- An immigration and naturalization act that sets a new pattern for the admission of aliens into the United States will go into effect next Wednesday. Regulations implementing the law were promulgated yesterday in the Federal Register.
BALTIMORE, Dec. 20 (AP) -- The New York Knickerbockers, with a tremendous spurt in the final quarter which overcame a 13-point deficit, defeated the Baltimore Bullets, in overtime tonight, 102 -- 99.

AS I turned to Page 14 of The Times Magazine of Nov. 23, I suddenly felt ten years younger. There, facing me as part of George Barrett's story on the Korean campaign, "That's the Way the Ball Bounces," was a photograph showing marines landing at Inchon from the landing boats of the Attack Cargo Ship No. KA-13.

THE Italian is pleasant but without sinews, as too stilly fleeting water; the French delicate but over nice, as a woman scarce daring to open her lips for fear of marring her countenance; the Spanish majestical, but fulsome, running too much on the o, and terrible, like the devil in a play; the Dutch manlike, but withal very harsh, as one ready at every word to pick a quarrel.

ONE of the most curious phenomena of the modern record collector's world is the appearance in force of anonymous or vaguely titled performing organizations whose lack of precise identity constantly harasses the conscientious listener.

WHAT is the Christmas wish of the Neediest? It is the same wish we would all put first if it had not already been granted to us. It is the sense that we -- ourselves and our families -- are wanted, remembered, loved. Without that feeling there can be no Christmas.
NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 20 -- India will reject Pakistan's conditional offer to concede New Delhi's troop demands in the disputed state of Jammu and Kashmir.

CAIRO, Dec. 20 -- The Egyptian Government, according to sources here, has asked the United States Technical Cooperation Administration to make an aerial survey and other studies for a high-level dam in upper Egypt about ten miles above the present big Aswan dam's reservoir.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (UP) -- Backers of a move to place a constitutional ceiling of 25 per cent on Federal taxes predicted today that they would obtain enough state support in 1953 to force Congressional action.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- The Serge Koussevitzky Music Foundation in the Library of Congress today announced seven commissions for major score to be added to the foundation's library of contemporary music. Three of the composers to receive the commissions, which include varying cash awards, are Americans.

ONE of the many cakes with which the peoples of the world celebrate Christmas is strufoli. Sicilians -- and Americans of Sicilian background -- make it of squares of dough, cut small, fried, glazed with honey and piled together in a variety of shapes -- like clusters of grapes or pyramids or long loaves. The cake is sprinkled with pine nuts and colored candies, and remains in a convenient spot throughout the holiday season.

PHOENIX, Ariz. -- Arizona and New Mexico are the source of some of America's most artistic handcraft products. Yet, like the contrasting land itself, these states are also headquarters for a trashy hodge-podge of tawdry knickknacks and spurious goods aimed at a quick tourist dollar.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 20 -- The American Friends Service Committee reported today that the 9,000,000 refugees in West Germany and the 300,000 in Austria are a world problem and a threat to world peace.
TOKYO, Sunday, Dec. 21 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,470, covering Saturday:
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- Martin Patrick Durkin, Secretary of Labor - designate in President - elect Dwight D. Eisenhower's Cabinet, is an Irishman who is long on temper and short on talk.

Efforts by Israel to increase exports as a means of strengthening her economy have recently been aided by the signing of bilateral trade agreements with other countries. While these agreements have been a help, Israel now looks upon ratification of a commercial treaty with this country as a major step in balancing her present unfavorable trade position.

THE innocent reader, trapped between lunatics and lovers in this idyl of English snakepits, has the ready sympathy of at least one reviewer. For John Cowper Powys has still a nice turn for the slightly addled, a sly and vastly entertaining trick of making commonsense and commonplace incredibly crazy.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 20 (AP) -- Duntreath Farms' Starecase, a 15-1 shot, streaked home a length and a quarter in front of Jet Fleet to win the $10,000-added Dade County Handicap at Tropical Park today.

ATHENS, Dec. 10 -- Against 331 vessels of all types, totaling 1,359,365 gross tons at present under Greek registration, 904 Greek-owned vessels, totaling 6,727,833 gross tons are under foreign flags, not only the Panamanian and Honduran, but also American, British and Canadian.
THIS has been an eminently satisfactory year in sports, one packed with drama and historic moments. But let's skim through the calendar and take a quick look for ourselves.

FOR centuries the Orient has fascinated the western world. In the United States this attraction reached a furious intensity about a hundred years ago. It developed, in part, out of the belief that we were an empire-in-the-making ripe to batten on the East, as Byzantium, Portugal, Spain and Britain before us had.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., Dec. 20 (AP) -- The Boiling Air Force Base Generals, led by Al Dorow, former Michigan State quarterback, defeated the San Diego Naval Training Center, 35 -- 14, today in the first Poinsettia Bowl football game. With the victory went the national service football championship.

THE Christmas season will be celebrated by television and radio with many specially prepared programs including, as usual, a number of Christmas Eve and Christmas Day church services. Practically all of the regularly scheduled shows will reflect the spirit of the season and some will abandon their regular formats for a seasonal presentation. Herewith is a list of the major Yuletide programs:
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 20 -- Dr. George Blakeman Lovell, now 74 years old, will retire in June after thirty-six years as rector of Hopkins Grammar School here.

THE picture of a giant passenger plane throttling back at 18,000 or 20,000 feet to latch onto the hose trailing from a tanker plane flying slightly above and ahead of it and taking on a full load of fuel is in no way fantastic from a technical standpoint. Thousands of in-flight refueling operations have been completed without a single accident by the United States Air Force's fast jet fighter planes in the past two years.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- The signing in London this week of a $90 million contract under which the United States purchased 500 British Centurion tanks for NATO forces on the continent turned attention to the development of this country's offshore procurement program.

MONTREAL, Dec. 20 (UP) -- The Boston Bruins shattered the Montreal Canadiens' unbeaten streak tonight by scoring four goals in the second period and routing the Habitants, 6 -- 3, before 14,714 National Hockey League fans at the Forum.

IN his editorship of the post-war issues of Universal Photo Almanac, Ralph Samuels has attempted from the first to raise the quality of this popular annual, both in its content and appearance. Although progress has been slow, the changes often inconsistent and the choice of material sometimes ill-balanced, marked improvements have appeared with each issue.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 20 -- The United Nations General Assembly rejected today troublesome clauses in a resolution on the Ewe and Togoland unification problem and adopted one believed to be full of compromise and promise.

VIENNA, Dec. 20 -- One of the most instructive demonstrations yet given of the Soviet tactic of confusing world issues and appropriating the very ideals whose realization Russia has done most to defeat has been the "Congress of Peoples for Peace" which has been running its marathon course here since Dec. 12.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 20 -- Reports on volume of electric current consumed indicate that industrial activity in this area is holding at a high level. Comparative figures show a 5 per cent increase in current used this year over the same 1951 week.

LOS ANGELES -- It was quite a shock to the New York and New England visitors at Yosemite Valley the other day when a ranger of the National Park Service remarked earnestly that the East has the nation's historical monuments and the West has the scenery.

Early next Wednesday evening, just before the excitement of Christmas Eve at home with their own children and grandchildren, a New York couple will come out of their apartment on the upper East Side, hail a taxi and head for Bellevue Hospital.

ONCE upon a time there lived in Paris, in a yellow-gray mansion overlooking the gardens of the Tuileries, a shrewd and slippery old gentleman who made his upstairs parlor the spider's home in the spider's web of European diplomacy. His name was the Duke of Talleyrand and his home was called, of course, the Hotel Talleyrand.

TOKYO, Sunday, Dec. 21 -- The United Nations Commander, Gen. Mark W. Clark, served notice today that the Allies would not tolerate terrorism or rioting in the compounds where the Communist war prisoners are interned in Korea, but would demand that captives as well as camp authorities observe the obligations of the Geneva Convention.

A stabilizing influence on the nation's economy when defense spending and foreign aid tapers off may be a highway construction and modernization program for which an estimated $2,000,000,000 in state and Federal funds has been earmarked.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Dec. 20 -- Neither Karl Marx nor Friedrich Engels, two of the most distinguished deities in the Soviet Valhalla, had any sympathy with the national aspirations of colonial races.

" A gardening gift that doesn't hint at more work for me and one I can start using right now is what I want for Christmas," confided the most avid gardener in the neighborhood. That's a twist that most gardeners would sympathize with as they sit idle waiting for spring's outdoor days, and one that gardeners' Santas might well note.

EARLY this month a California psychiatrist, speaking before a group of 1,000 elementary school teachers assembled in Los Angeles, made the somewhat obvious statement that, judging by commonly accepted standards, "Everybody cannot be a success."

A grant of $420,000 by the Lavanburg Corner House, 40 East Sixty-sixth Street, to New York University for a new graduate program in social-service education, was announced yesterday by Henry T. Heald, university chancellor, and Miss Ethel H. Wise, president of Lavanburg Corner House.

In Washington last week there was action in three cases involving three men whose names have figured prominently in the Government's effort to deal with the delicate and increasingly complex problems of loyalty in a time of mounting world tension. The three cases were:

MOSCOW, Dec. 21, (UP) -- An International Stalin Peace Prize award to Paul Robeson today hailed the American singer as "the standard-bearer of the oppressed Negro people and all honest Americans struggling against imperialist reactionaries preparing a disastrous war for the Americans."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- George Meany, president of the American Federation of Labor, said today that his organization was now ready to settle for less than repeal of the Taft-Hartley Act. He expressed confidence that organized labor could "get the kind of law we want" through amendment of the act.

TOKYO, Monday, Dec. 22 -- The Peiping radio reported this morning that Chou En-lai, the Chinese Communist Foreign Minister, had sent a "grave protest" to the United Nations yesterday against the Dec. 14 "mass murder" of Communist internees on Pongam.
Strong markets continued in British sterling and the Canadian dollar last week, and each closed at good gains over the preceding week. Turnover ran to moderately heavy volume.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 21 -- Yugoslavia's complaint that she was getting two little Western armament and receiving it too slowly was reinforced over the week-end by individual appeals for heavy equipment from three ranking Yugoslav military leaders.
AMSTERDAM, Dec., 21 -- Last week The Netherlands Bank converted a further 227,000,000 guilders worth of dollars into gold, making total gold stocks of 1,796,000,000 guilders.

By defeating A. Kaminsky in the third round of the annual tournament for the Manhattan Chess Club title, Abe Turner yesterday took the lead. He now has won three games in a row. Herbert Seidman, with 2 -- 0, adjourned his game with Alexander Kevitz. M. Boysan, also 2 -- 0, had the bye.
The Port of New York's position as the premier gateway for the nation's foreign commerce is easily matched by its ranking as the most iniquitous of all waterfronts.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Dec. 21 (AP) -- Ted Kroll and Lew Worsham rode Kroll's magic putter to a 3-and-1 victory over Cary Middlecoff and Skip Alexander in a tense battle today for the top prize in the international four-ball golf tournament.
Arnold Rosenthal has achieved an honor rare among teenagers -- a one-man show of his paintings at the House of Duveen.

The season's fifth "Tosca" was presented on Saturday evening at the Metropolitan Opera House, with Licia Albanese singing the title role for the first time here, Jan Peerce in his first Cavaradossi of the season and Robert Weede, a replacement for the indisposed Paul Schoeffler, making his first Metropolitan appearance since the 1948-49 season as Scarpia.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Dec. 21 -- The Greek Orthodox Church has launched a campaign against communism among its Arab members in Israel by developing educational and welfare services and improving the conditions of the Greek Orthodox clergy.
The board of trustees of the Public Education Association urged suport yesterday of the plan of the New York State Board of Regents to establish a state network of educational television stations.
The New York regional Red Cross blood program needs more blood from individual donors over the holiday period to meet its December quota of 17,500 pints, headquarters here reported yesterday.

A number of prominent economists taking part in a forum session under the auspices of the National Industrial Conference Board expect sustained high-level business activity in 1953. This was disclose in a report issued by the board over the week-end.

ANCHORAGE, Alaska, Dec. 21 -- A plane loaded with thirty-six Hollywood personages landed yesterday at Kodiak, Alaska, instead of Honolulu. the spot to which the passengers thought they were headed en route to Korea to entertain the troops.

Anahid Ajemian, violinist, and her sister, Maro Ajemian, pianist, last night at Town Hall completed their cycle of three concerts devoted to "Distinguished Duos of Three Centuries." Because the scheme of the cycle was chronological, the final program was devoted to contemporary music.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 21 -- As the seventh session of the United Nations General Assembly neared its pre-holiday adjournment, the highly controversial question of admission of new member states was advanced tonight for decision at the eighth session, coming in 1953.

TOKYO, Monday, Dec. 22 -- United States Marine, Fifth Air Force and South Korean fighter-bombers worked over enemy positions and supply depots along the front in Korea yesterday, concentrating over eastern sectors. The Allied pilots reported they had destroyed four Communist artillery positions and two supply shelters. Last night, B-29 bombers smashed at two new enemy supply depots in Northwest Korea.

LONDON, Dec. 21 -- The British Treasury lays claim to having checked inflation. If the definition of inflation is too much money chasing too few commodities then the Treasury appears to be right, for at the end of this year there seems to be plenty of both money and goods.

The long holiday recess of the General Assembly will indicate in a general way something of the halfway mark in this session. Action on several measures was planned and discussed in the light of what could be accomplished before Christmas. In addition there were many persons who felt that either delay or a long hiatus was desirable because of the forthcoming change in the Administration in this country.
A panel of six junior high school students agreed unanimously last night that international, spiritual and material cooperation could result in world peace.

" Hamlet" will be presented in the framework of a soap opera program over television Station WABD, beginning Jan. 5. The tragedy will be divided into fifteen-minute segments to be televised each weekday at 11:45 A. M. for two weeks. -- THE NEW YORK TIMES, Dec. 20.
This is the season of the holly, of gay ribbons, bright wrapping paper, rosy faces, good cheer -- and of bells. In the bustling days before Christmas even the church bells that sound

Agreement has been reached between city and state authorities for the construction of an interchange between the Major Deegan and the Cross-Bronx Expressways, the key north-south and east-west arteries now under construction in Bronx.

THE power of the press is sometimes frightening. A fellow never knows his own strength. It was just about a month or-so ago that cautious mention was made in this space of the fact that a wrestling show was soon to be held in Madison Square Garden. Then the parishioners were warned that modern wrestling is an outrageous burlesque of a once noble sport and they were urged to stay away.
BALTIMORE, Dec. 21 -- The ill wind of New York's waterfront rackets blows favorably on the Port of Baltimore, second only to New York in foreign trade tonnage in the first half of this year.

Orders setting higher minimum hourly wage for 400,000 workers in New York State have been signed by Industrial Commissioner-Edward Corsi, the State Department of Labor announced yesterday. The orders, which will become effective Feb. 15, cover employes in the restaurant, hotel, laundry, cleaning and dyeing, and beauty service industries.

ZURICH, Dec. 21 -- Quite unforeseen consequences resulting from the skill developed in operating the European Payments Union became conspicuous last week when the two Netherlands chambers of commerce, hitherto with headquarters here, merged to form "The Netherlands Chamber of Commerce for Switzerland."

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public, which will mature within twelve months, amount to $63,478,786,231. They consist of Treasury bonds, certificates of indebtedness, bills and notes as follows:

GENEVA, Dec. 21 -- The United Nations World Health Organization published today its latest death statistics, showing, among other data, that far more men commit suicide than women, particularly in the United States.
TOKYO, Monday, Dec. 22 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,471, for Sunday:

WILMINGTON, Del., Dec. 21 (AP) -- The president of E. I. Du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., called attention today to the fact that the Department of Justice has withdrawn a criminal anti-trust charge filed in 1948 against du Pont in the Federal district court in Pittsburgh. Crawford H. Greenewalt declared:

Pre-Christmas activity in the metropolitan art galleries has slackened this week, there being only a comparatively small number of exhibitions on view. The largest of these is at the Riverside Museum, where members of the New York Chapter of Artists Equity are showing work in diverse mediums.

The late Judge George Z. Medalie once said that the State Constitution contained an "absolutely false" pretense. "It pretends," he said, "that the people select the judges. That is the greatest farce that has ever been enacted in the history of democracy. * * * The selection of judges is made not by the people but by the leaders of the predominant parties. * * *"

PARIS, Dec. 21 -- Two events over the week-end -- the capitulation of the Bey of Tunis to the French Government's demand and the overwhelming victory of the Government candidate in today's elections in a Paris district -- have greatly improved Premier Antoine Pinay's chances in two confidence votes to be taken tomorrow in the National Assembly.

Citing the action of the Kings County Democratic Committee in abolishing the "synthetic" votes in its executive committee on election of a county leader, Bert Stand called yesterday on Carmine G. DeSapio, leader of Tammany, to abolish the five "synthetic" votes in the Tammany executive committee.

Bipartisan legislation in the forthcoming Congress to limit the "merger movement among banks" is urged by Representative Emanuel Celler, Democrat of New York, chairman of the House Judiciary Committee. Citing the plans of the Bankers Trust Company of New York to absorb the Bayside National Bank in Queens, Mr. Celler advocated specific measures to subject all future mergers to special Federal scrutiny.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- The Department of Commerce's Business Advisory Council recommended today the creation of a conference section in the Department of Justice where business men could discover current antirust policies in advance of embarking on ventures which might later lead them to expensive litigation and possible heavy damages.

DETROIT, Dec. 21 -- Winter and a championship came to the Motor City today when Buddy Parker's Detroit Lions conquered the Los Angeles Rams, 31-21, in the play-off for the National Conference crown in the National Football League.

City officials, seeking to ward off a New Year's Eve strike on eight privately owned bus lines, are considering a plea to the companies and the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., to sign short-term contracts that would keep the buses running while Mayor Impellitteri's tax-relief plan is under consideration in Albany and at City Hall.

Igor Stravinsky, who made an appearance at yesterday's New Friends of Music concert, was the fourth distinguished composer so honored by the organization this season. Like his predecessors -- Aaron Copland, Paul Hendemith and Darius Milhaud -- Mr. Stravinsky not only appeared on the program in an executive capacity but also presented some recently composed music for the first time in this city.

Roman Catholics who maintain a "half-ashamed outward adherence to the church" are Catholics "in name only" because they lack the knowledge, humility and gratitude necessary for loyalty to the church and Christ, the Rev. Vincent P. McFadden declared yesterday at St. Patrick's Cathedral.

John Haynes Holmes, minister emeritus, and Donald Harrington, minister of the Community Church of New York, 40 East Thirty-fifth Street, joined yesterday in their eighth annual Christmas-Hanukkah sermon-conversation.
Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower met yesterday for the first time with the three-man committee he named on Nov. 30 to report on methods of reorganizing the Executive Branch of the Federal Government.

Wind and rain escorted winter into town at 4:44 P. M. yesterday while pre-holiday travelers straggled through railroad, airline and bus terminals that are preparing for a record number of passengers in the four-day holiday that will begin on Wednesday.

After celebrating the removal of a cast from his right leg, which was injured several months ago when he fell four stories down an elevator shaft, Louis Sudano, 20 years old, of 1126 Metcalfe Avenue, the Bronx, was killed in a collision of two automobiles at Metcalfe Avenue and East 172d Street, the Bronx, yesterday at 1:30 A. M. Three other persons were injured.
It is encouraging to read of Commissioner Monaghan's strong disapproval of handouts to the police in the form of assessments by the policeman on the beat during the pre-Christmas season.

Your editorial of Dec. 8 has led the public to expect that at last the Federal Power Commission, with the support both of President Truman and President-elect Eisenhower, would ratify the treaty agreement with Canada to harness the St. Lawrence River.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, Dec. 21 (AP) -- An All-Star soccer team from Ivy League colleges began a holiday tour of Bermuda today with a 3-1 upset victory over the Bermuda Athletic Association, former Bermuda amateur champion.

Plans for an apartment building with parking garage on the lower level were announced in connection with the purchase by Abraham Yarmark of three buildings on plot 65 by 100 feet at 314-16-18 East Twenty-seventh Street. The property is between First and Second Avenues, in the vicinity of Bellevue Hospital, and was bought from the trustees of the estate of Margaret Kenny.

MOSES LAKE, Wash., Dec. 21 (AP) -- An Air Force captain with considerable heavy-plane flying experience who survived the crash said today that he believed the plane "had not developed enough power to complete the take-off."
LARSON AIR FORCE BASE, Wash., Dec. 21 (UP) -- A New Yorker who served as a crew member of the Globemaster said today that he had no idea how he had escaped from the wreckage.

Archbishop Thomas E. Molloy of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn yesterday blessed and consecrated an edifice for the new Byzantine-Melkite rite Church of the Virgin Mary at Eighth Avenue and Second Street, Brooklyn. The building formerly housed the Park Slope Congregational Church.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (AP) -- Dr. Harold E. Edgerton, Professor of Electrical Engineering at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, inventor of the stroboscopic speed light for photography, and Dr. George van Biesbroeck, who produced tangible evidence to support Dr. Albert Einstein's relativity theory, were named tonight by the National Geographic Society as winners of the Franklin L. Burr Awards.

Mr. Gromyko does not believe in Christmas. The midnight message to Lester B. Pearson, president of the General Assembly, demanding that the United Nations discuss before adjournment the killing of the North Korean prisoners in the Pongam camp, was relayed posthaste from Moscow and received with groans by the weary members of the Steering Committee.

Mention of Russian cooking brings to most American minds a picture of shashlik, the flaming meat impaled on a sword borne aloft by a red-jacketed waiter. But this dramatic dish was merely everyday fare in the cuisine that flourished in the Russia of the Czars.

WILLIAMSBURG, Va., Dec. 21 -- The coronation robe and coronet worn by Britain's Princess Margaret when her father, the late George VI, was crowned in 1937, will be exhibited in this one-time Colonial capital at the Fifth Annual Williamsburg Antiques Forum in January.

Santa Claus is pretty busy these days but it is only fair to let him know that prep schools should not be overlooked. He could make any number of coaches happy with a 9.9 sprinter, some hipper-dipper backs or a 6-6 basketball player. A new gymnasium or an artificial hockey rink would be accepted and appreciated in many cases.

The ideas of Bernard Baruch, which have earned him the title "Adviser to Presidents," have been brought together by Morris Victor Rosenbloom under the title "Peace Through Strength: Bernard Baruch and a Blueprint of Security." It is scheduled for Jan. 19 publication by Farrar, Straus Young. It will have a foreword by Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt and an afterword by Charles Edward Wilson, former director of the Office of Defense Mobilization.

SEOUL, Korea, Dec. 21 (AP) -- Gen. James A. Van Fleet gave a farewell review today to the "collection of heroes" from his Eighth Army who will march in the Eisenhower inaugural parade in Washington Jan. 20. He wished "Godspeed -- and a good trip" to the seventy combat veterans.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 21 -- Since the waterfront strike that developed into the general strike of 1934, San Francisco's busy waterfront has been comparatively free of the evils now under investigation in New York.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Dec. 18 -- Africa, being largely illiterate, is a center for rumors, and one of the most fantastic of these is that the Soviet Union has established in this Ethiopian capital a massive center for propaganda and agitation throughout the vast continent.

LONDON, Dec. 21 -- With the Christmas vacation so near and with the public very largely preoccupied by preparations for the holiday, it is scarcely surprising that the business turnover in the stock markets has fallen to the lowest level of the year.

The famous old sailing ship Cutty Sark, the last of Great Britain's famous clippers that served in the tea and wool trades in the nineteenth century, will be reconstructed in England and preserved as a national shrine, according to information from abroad.

I wish to reply to a letter by Walter F. Smith advocating the use of the A and H bombs by the United States when such use is necessary "to enforce justice and decency in the world." No nation has a better right to do this than the United States, he states.

Guiomar Novaes was heard as soloist with the Philharmonic Symphony Orchestra, under George Szell, Saturday night at Carnegie Hall. The Brazilian pianist gave a scintillating performance of Beethoven's Fourth Concerto, the only offering on the list the conductor had not led before during his engagement this season with the organization.
DOVER, N. J., Dec. 21 -- Two little boys from near-by Mount Freedom spent last night alone in a wonderful land of toys and goodies and came away this morning untempted and unsullied.

Earnings have little to do with stock prices. In fact, for the past eleven years, they have persistently moved in opposite directions, according to Harry Comer, economist of Paine, Webber, Jackson Curtis, in his current market letter.

BOSTON, Dec. 21 (UP) -- Jean Beliveau, an "amateur" playing his last "trial" National Hockey League game, scored two goals tonight to pace the Montreal Canadiens to a 4-3 victory over the Boston Bruins before 12,984 fans at the Garden, the largest crowd of the season here.

HONOLULU, Dec. 21 -- The American freighter Quartette, bound for Korea, ran aground on a coral reef ninety miles east of Midway Island today and bobbed in heavy seas with her hull ripped open. A Navy patrol boat raced to rescue the forty-four crewmen aboard.

MOSES LAKE, Wash., Dec. 21 -- Four Air Force generals personally sifted the charred wreckage of a Douglas C-124 Globemaster at near-by Larson Air Force Base today trying to determine why the giant transport plane crashed and burned during a take-off yesterday leaving the worst death toll in aviation history, eighty-six at the latest count.
William B. Cott has been appointed manager of air conditioning application engineering for the Sturtevant division of Westinghouse Electric Corporation.

GENEVA, Dec. 17. -- European economists believe that the next phase in reshaping Western Europe's economy to make it less dependent upon United States assistance in various forms must include a coordinated attack on fuel problems, particularly the supply of oil.

CAIRO, Dec. 21 -- The Government of General Mohammed Naguib decreed tonight a general purge of public life in Egypt. The decree provided that persons convicted of corruption or abuse of power would be barred from political activity and public office. The decree was retroactive to 1939.
Twelve new films, including English and Polish importations, are slated to arrive as holiday attractions this week in first-run houses. The programs follow:
CHICAGO, Dec. 21 (AP) -- The Brodie Siamese twins failed to gain today in their fight for life.

HONG KONG, Dec. 21 -- Communist China gives top priority to its mobilization movements whose slogans are "Resist America -- Aid Korea," "Basic Construction" and "Increase Production -- Practice Economy," but in addition a number of auxiliary mass campaigns have cropped up.
DETROIT, Dec. 21 (AP) -- What made the Detroit Lions of championship caliber today?

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 21 -- Longshoremen in the Philadelphia port area, which extends from Trenton, N. J., to Wilmington, Del., are hired by a modified shape-up system, which reportedly is working "fine." The men report at various locations along the Delaware riverfront, where representatives of stevedoring companies hire the labor they require.

PARIS, Dec. 21 -- It is announced officially that steel production of the Franco-Saar Economic Union has how reached 14,500,000 tons, compared with 12,400,000 in 1951 and 10,500,000 in 1950. This increase derives largely from the sensational jump in output by French industry in November and notably October, when the peak of 1,000,000 tons in one month was attained by French steel factories.

FRANCONIA, N. H., Dec. 21 -- Dartmouth's Norwegian freshman, Egil Stigum, led the Big Green to a clean sweep of the first five positions in the slalom race that attracted 102 entries to the snowy slopes of Cannon Mountain today.

The High School Teachers Association announced yesterday that a sampling among 10,000 city high school teachers indicated that 69 per cent believed it was necessary to hold extra jobs and that 65 per cent felt it was necessary for other members of the family to work "to keep the family on an even financial keel."

SYDNEY, Australia, -- Dec. 21 (AP) -- The animosity which existed between Australian and American tennis officials just a year ago has been virtually erased, largely through the efforts of Fred Small, an American industrialist.

Hitting for 35 points in the fourth quarter, Joe Lapchick's New York Knickerbockers won their fifth straight Eastern Division battle in the National Basketball Association by walloping the Baltimore Bullets, 102 to 77, in the feature of a league twin-bill at Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon.

Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the President-elect, in a statement yesterday denounced the recent Prague trials as "a political act designed to unloose a campaign of rabid anti-Semitism through Soviet Russia and the satellite nations of Eastern Europe."

United Nations children paid the greatest possible tribute to their hosts at the United Auto Workers Union's annual Christmas party for children yesterday at the St. Nicholas Arena. After they had clicked through the turnstiles at the gate, the United Nations youngsters were so much at home that the union's party officials could not pick them out from the 6,000 other young persons there.

The Board of Education of the City of New York has debated proposals to open public school classes with prayer for such a long time that "one wonders if God isn't a bit amused," the Rev. Dr. Norman Vincent Peale said yesterday in his sermon at the Marble Collegiate Church, Fifth Avenue and Twenty-ninth Street.

The trustees of the Institute of International Education, an agency in the field of international exchange of students and specialists, have elected new officers and oppointed three additional trustees, it was announced yesterday by George N. Shuster, outgoing chairman of the board.

Both the Liberal party and the Citizens Union advocated establishment of a system of permanent personal registration in their proposals to the Legislature for election law reform, made public yesterday.

LONDON, Dec. 21 -- Philip J. Noel-Baker, a leading Labor party member, replied to British ecclesiastical criticism of Yugoslavia and her Premier, Marshal Tito, tonight by calling the new Yugoslav Constitution "an exciting adventure" and saying he was "glad" Marshal Tito would visit Britain.
CINCINNATI, Dec. 21 -- The Cincinnati Reds, ,who now boast the farthest flung right field in the National League, said today they are going to shorten the distance to 342 feet for the 1953 season.
Employment figures for this country's principal private shipbuilding and repair yards indicate a definite upward trend in vessel construction work, while repair employment remains almost stationary.
The Duke of Windsor reiterated here yesterday his intention of remaining absent from the coronation next June 2 of his niece, Queen Elizabeth II.

An off-duty fireman, once a judo instructor in the Air Force, disarmed, injured and turned over to the police early yesterday a pistol-carrying man from Shrewsbury, Mass., whom the fireman accused of attempting to rob him. The hold-up attempt was so similar to the circumstances of a killing in Yonkers last month that the suspect's bail was set at $25,000.
MOSES LAKE, Wash., Dec. 21 (AP) -- Larson Field officials tonight released the following partial list of the eighty-six persons killed in the crash of the Globemaster here yesterday:

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 21 -- New Orleans' 2,200 longshoremen are hired by the shape - up system. They congregate daily at the foot of Canal Street, where foremen and "straw bosses" dispatched by the steamship companies pick their work gangs.
Soon it will be "the night before Christmas," one of the most important in the lives of little children.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (UP) -- The Government is $8,267,000,000 deeper in debt now than it was when President Truman took office in 1945, a survey showed today.

TRENTON, Dec. 21 (AP) -- The New Jersey Turnpike Authority had a net revenue of $14,777,279 in its first year of operation, the Authority said today in a report to bondholders. The figure for the twelve months ending Nov. 30, 1952, is before interest payments on turnpike bonds, which amount to $8,000,000 a year.
MONTREAL, Dec. 20 (UP) -- World newsprint supply and demand have come into approximate balance for the first time since World War II, the Newsprint Association of Canada said today.
Pleas for a more mature approach to the Christmas season were voiced in many pulpits yesterday as churchgoers throughout the city and nation prepared for the holy day.

The Dodgers will conduct a baseball clinic for Little League and amateur coaches at Vero Beach, Fla., next spring. The clinic, which will be under the supervision of Vice President Fresco Thompson, is slated for March 9 to 20.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 21 -- Warner Brothers announced today that it would begin production next month on a film to be photographed in Natural Vision, the newly developed stereoscopic three-dimension process, which requires the use of polarized glasses by the audience to complete the pictorial illusion of depth and roundness.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (UP) -- Agriculture Department experts predicted today that family food costs would drop next year, with farmers, rather than processors or marketing men, absorbing the decrease.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (UP) -- The National Boxing Association, alarmed over the fate of small fight clubs, disclosed today it would open a drive next month to ban the televising of boxing in areas where bouts are being staged.

Michael Clemente, labor boss over all of Manhattan's East River piers, was arrested yesterday on charges of having extorted $2,500 from a stevedoring concern on a North River pier that he also controls.

What started out as a tough battle for the Detroit Red Wings developed into an easy touch at Madison Square Garden last night. The New York Rangers scored two goals in twenty seconds of the first period of the National Hockey League game, and the crowd of 11,383 fans sat back in gleeful anticipation of a rare Ranger victory.

ATLANTA, Dec. 21 (UP) -- Frank Costello will board a heavily guarded Federal prison bus tomorrow for a trip to a "common jail" in Michigan to serve the remainder of his eighteen-month term for contempt of Congress.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- A Congressional subcommittee charged today that the military services were wasting the taxpayers' money in their giant building program and said they might be giving "misinformation" to the lawmakers to get more.

The American Jewish Congress adopted a resolution yesterday criticizing recent statements by the Roman Catholic Bishops of America and the Protestant National Council of Churches as favoring more direct religious instruction in public education.

The thoroughbred horse racing season for 1952 in this state was a good one for the sport, according to the annual report of the New York State Racing Commission. Wagering and attendance showed gains over the previous campaign, and the quality of the competition adhered to the high standard that has become synonymous with racing here.

As joval as ever, but not as frisky as he would like to be, Arthur Hammerstein, a colorful theatrical producer of a vanished era, celebrated his eightieth birthday yesterday. The event took place at his home in Lantana, Fla., five miles from Palm Beach, where he resides for seven months each year. Among those present was his famous nephew, Oscar Hammerstein 2d.

For the third successive year Johann Strauss' "Fledermaus" will be given at the Metropolitan Opera House on New Year's Eve. The holiday presentation will be its first appearance in the repertoire this season.

The ratification of the Convention on Political Rights for Women by the General Assembly of the United Nations marks another milestone in the uphill fight for women's rights. Much must still be done by individual nations before the effect of the convention will be felt, but it represents, none the less, a heartening symbol of women's progress.

CINCINNATI, Dec. 21 -- Expected heavy decreases in enrollments this fall in American colleges and universities did not materialize largely because of an unforeseen upsurge of freshmen of both sexes and the "academic persistence in the three upper years of college women," Dr. Raymond Walters, president of the University of Cincinnati, reported here tonight.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Monday, Dec. 22 -- Taking account of the misgivings of investors in various parts of the world, the United Nations General Assembly amended last night a controversial resolution on nationalization of resources before adopting it by a vote of 36 to 4.

Still another clear indication of how the twisted minds of Communists operate -- something not all of us have yet learned in the United States -- is the statement by Klement Gottwald, president of Czechoslovakia, as reported in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Dec. 17, that the recent purge trials in Prague were not anti-Semitic.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Monday, Dec. 22 -- The Soviet Union launched a bitter attack this morning on the "American hangmen," whom it accused of the "mass murder" of eighty-two North Korean and Chinese Communist prisoners of war on the island of Pongam.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 21 -- Following is the text of a letter addressed yesterday by Andrei A. Gromyko, deputy head of the Soviet delegation, to Lester B. Pearson, president of the United Nations General Assembly, requesting that the issue of "mass murder" of prisoners of war in Korea be placed on the Assembly's agenda. Also appended are the texts of the draft of a Soviet resolution and an explanatory note:

RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 21 -- The Brazilian Government is intensifying its efforts to increase the immigration of suitable persons to speed the development of its great underpopulated territory. Japanese residents are cooperating in a plan to move 4,000 families here from Japan, it was reported today.

A syndicate of investors represented by Daniel D. Cantor, Brooklyn investment and mortgage counselor, has purchased Jeffrey Garden Apartments, Inc., and Jeffrey Garden Apartments Section 2, Inc., a group of three-story garden apartment buildings housing 279 families at 216th Street and Forty-seventh Avenue, Bayside, Queens.

Gifts to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund took on an international flavor yesterday as donations arrived from a resident of Tangier and persons associated with the Brazilian delegation to the United Nations and the New York office of the Central News Agency of China.

There are veterans who will tell you the jeep -- and the C-47 -- won the war. Now the creator of the busy little vehicle is going to give it a look at Queen Elizabeth's State Coach when she rides to be crowned on June 2. "Even a cat can look at a King," as Dick Whittacker said.

DEAL, N. J., Dec. 21 -- The most unseen member of television's unseen audience threw this town into a fever of anxiety last night as 300 policemen, volunteer firemen, searchlight crews and first-aid squads converged here from three communities to look for him.

MOSCOW, Dec. 21 -- No public note was taken of Premier Stalin's birthday today beyond the annual announcement of winners of the International Stalin Peace Prizes, which were established in 1949 at his seventieth birthday celebration.

An attempt by the membership of a local of the International Longshoremen's Association, A. F. L., to hold its first election of officers since 1922 was almost foiled Saturday night, according to waterfront spokesmen.

A continued reduction in the number of person receiving public assistance may no longer be possible unless emphasis is placed on a comprehensive program of rehabilitation and placement, "especially of handicapped persons," Welfare Commissioner Henry L. McCarthy declared yesterday in his monthly report to Mayor Impellitteri.

This phrase, vaguely understood by the ordinary American citizen, is increasingly stressed by our European allies as a vital part of the evolving program of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. During the past year, indeed, it has become almost symbolic, a touchstone of the new economic relationship the nations of Western Europe hope to establish with the United States.

NYACK, N. Y., Dec. 21 -- Rockland County suffered a financial shock today when it learned that the State Board of Equalization and Assessment had ruled that the twenty-mile-long strip of property being taken for the New York Thruway would be exempt from taxation.

ALBANY, Dec. 21 -- Governor Dewey will meet Tuesday noon with officials of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York to discuss a proposed investigation of the courts and political influences in the selection of judges.

Of the millions of gifts to be distributed in the city this Christmas, few will serve a more lasting purpose than the gifts to the Neediest Cases Fund. For the Fund does more than relieve present distress. It also insures against future trouble -- while there is still time.

CHICAGO, Dec. 21 (UP) -- Bill Gadsby scored his first goal of the year on a third period shot from the blue line tonight to lead the Chicago Black Hawks to a 4-2 triumph over the Toronto Maple Leafs for third place in the National Hockey League race.

An atomic scientist, Dr. Felix Bloch of Stanford University, who received the Nobel Prize for physics at Stockholm on Dec. 10, arrived yesterday by plane from Zurich at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens. He was accompanied by Mrs. Bloch.

NEW DELHI, India, Monday, Dec. 22 -- For the last several days all India has been following with grave anxiety the condition of Acharya Vinoba Bhave, anti-Communist Hindu ascetic known to millions of poor peasants as "the god who gives away land."

President-elect Eisenhower has good reason to appreciate the work of the Committee on the Present Danger, whose members he is meeting at luncheon today. When General Eisenhower was Commander of the NATO forces in Europe he had no more stanch supporter than this non-partisan group of business and professional men who created their organization about two years ago.
BOSTON, Dec. 21 -- Union leaders, delegates, stevedores and the police give Boston's waterfront a clean bill of health.

A hold-up man who was killed Saturday night by a policeman in a Queens liquor store was tentatively identified last night as a parolee from the Massachusetts State Prison who was being sought for recent robberies in Boston and Somerville, Mass.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation has paid the Treasury $12,293,880 as a dividend for the 1952 fiscal year on the corporation's capital stock of $100,000,000 held by the Secretary of Treasury, Harry A. McDonald, administrator of the R. F. C., announced today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (UP) -- Local housing authorities in forty-five cities, towns and rural communities will seek funds for low-rent public housing projects next month through sale of $130,000,000 in tax-exempt bonds backed by the Federal Government, the Public Housing Administrator announced today.

SEATTLE, Wash., Dec. 21 -- Approximately 1,500 longshoremen here are carried on the rolls of the International Longshoremen and Warehousemen's Union, independent, as "regulars." In addition, there are about 500 "permit" men -- a pool of longshoremen who do not belong to the union, but who are permitted to work on the piers during rush periods.
The wood itself forms the design interest of some new groups of furniture available through decorators at Fabry Associates, Inc., 6 East Fifty-third Street.

BOSTON, Dec. 21 -- The Rev. Harold J. Ockenga, pastor of the Park Street Congregational Church, today carried to the pulpit his protest against the proposed celebration of a Roman Catholic mass on Boston Common.

MIDDLE ISLAND, L. I., Dec. 21 -- One person was killed and eight were injured in a head-on automobile collision on Route 25 near here this afternoon. The driver of one of the cars, Mrs. Virginia Hunter, 49 years old, of Amityville, L. I., told the police that she was a diabetic and blacked out just before the accident.

BOSTON, Dec. 21 -- The Rev. Harold J. Ockenga, pastor of the Park Street Congregational Church, today carried to the pulpit his protest against the proposed celebration of a Roman Catholic mass on Boston Common.

MIDDLE ISLAND, L. I., Dec. 21 -- One person was killed and eight were injured in a head-on automobile collision on Route 25 near here this afternoon. The driver of one of the cars, Mrs. Virginia Hunter, 49 years old, of Amityville, L. I., told the police that she was a diabetic and blacked out just before the accident.

ALTHOUGH it has never been so popular a theme as man against other men or man against himself, man against nature is one of the oldest and one of the grandest subjects of imaginative literature. Fine and stirring books have been written about men struggling with tropical jungles, Arctic seas and Himalayan peaks. Roger Frison-Roche's new novel, "The Lost Trail of the Sahara,"* is a gripping tale of men against the desert.

Bishop D. Ward Nichols of the First Episcopal District of the African Methodist Episcopal Church expressed his conviction yesterday that a decision from the United States Supreme Court against racial segregation in public schools would not cause "violent social upheaval anywhere in the United States."

BERLIN, Dec. 21 -- East Germany's first television station built its inaugural program tonight around a Soviet film that told of Germany's disastrous defeat at Stalingrad. The program was in honor of Premier Stalin's seventy-third birthday.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 21 -- There was every indication last week that steel output would top 93,000,000 tons this year despite a loss of 20,000,000 because of the strike. Operations last week were at 106 per cent, unchanged from the week before.

With the exception of a sharp decline on Tuesday, cotton prices in the domestic market last week tended to back and fill within a relatively narrow trading range.
