At the close of trading on Friday, active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange were down 10 to 58 points from the levels of the previous week.

SCHENECTADY, N. Y., Dec. 21 -- Receding flood waters in the Black River Valley have left in their wake a renewed controversy over the proposed construction of Panther Mountain Dam, on the south branch of the Moose River.

OSSINING, N. Y., Dec. 21 -- Informed in advance that none of their number would be permitted inside Sing Sing prison, 716 persons came here nevertheless today on a special train and staged an organized demonstration at the railroad depot for Julius and Ethel Rosenberg. The Rosenbergs have been condemned to death for conspiring with a former Soviet vice consul and others to transmit secret atomic information to the Soviet Union.

ALBANY, Dec. 21 -- Perry B. Duryea, State Conservation Commissioner announced today the starting of comprehensive study aimed at reducing "by legislation or any other appropriate means" the number of hunting injuries and deaths in the state.

BONN, Dec. 21 -- Reports that the Russians are carrying out methodical and extensive construction to improve the potential of Eastern Europe from the Arctic Ocean to the Carpathian Mountains as a springboard for full-scale military operations against the Western powers: continue to reach authoritative sources here.

HOUSTON, Tex., Dec. 21 -- Union officials report there are about 5,000 members of International Longshoremen's Association locals here, with 12,500 in the West Gulf Coast District extending from Lake Charles, La., to Brownsville, Tex. Port operations officials estimate that 3,500 longshoremen are active at the Port of Houston.

NORFOLK, Va., Dec. 21 -- Approximately 2,500 longshoremen work in Hampton Roads, about 2,100 in Norfolk, and the remainder in Newport News. They are hired by shape-ups held at thirteen International Longshoremen's Association halls forty-five minutes before the shifts go on at 8 A. M., and 1 and 7 P. M.

With a city election scheduled for next November, there are now four and possibly five aspirants for the Democratic nomination for Mayor, with a strong possibility that there may be a primary fight for the nomination.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 21 -- Charles A. Sprague, who has represented the United States at discussions on freedom on information at the current session of the United Nations General Assembly, urged today that the United States be prepared at the next session to redraft the convention on which action was postponed by a tie vote in committee several weeks ago.

The free world's output of nickel this year will approximate 315,000,000 pounds, an increase of 20,000,000 over the 295,000,000 in 1951, according to John F. Thompson, chairman of the International Nickel Company of Canada, Ltd., in a year-end review. He estimated Canadian production at 280,000,000 pounds or about 90 per cent of the total.

Production of military electronics equipment for the armed forces next year will exceed the estimated rate for 1952 of $4,000,000,000, Dr. W. R. G. Baker predicted in a year-end statement. He is a vice president of the General Electric Company and general manager of its electronics department.

Olin Downes, music critic of THE NEW YORK TIMES, was guest of honor last night at the forty-sixth annual dinner concert of The Bohemians, New York musicians' club, in the grand ballrom of the Plaza Hotel.

CHICAGO, Dec. 21. -- Grain futures showed a substantial recovery late in the week, after persistent selling pressure had forced prices sharply lower. Most deliveries of wheat and corn registered new lows for the season.
Even the youngest participant in a "trim the tree" party might join in making some novel ornaments out of such materials as eggs, soap or bluing.

The divinity of human life is proclaimed in the Christmas theme, the Rev. John Walter Houck declared in a sermon yesterday morning at the Pilgrim Congregational Church of New York, 1800 Grand Concourse, the Bronx.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 21 (AP) -- A Yale pathologist suggested today that a guppy was better that the birds, bees and flowers when it came to explaining the facts of life.

On Dec. 1 the Chicago Daily Tribune published an editorial titled "Another Devaluation to Aid Britain?" which dealt with proposals, which have been recurring recently, that the United States raise the dollar price of gold.

The Right Rev. Horace W. B. Donegan, Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York, ordained seven deacons to the priesthood yesterday in a solemn service at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

The Columbia College Council has elected Thomas W. Chrystie of the law firm of Webster, Sheffield Chrystie as its chairman for 1953. He succeeds Dr. Frank D. Fackenthal, former acting president of Columbia University.
GARRISON, N. Y., Dec. 21 -- There was little room at St. Christopher's Inn at Graymoor Monastery here tonight, just as there was little room at another inn some 1900 years ago.
SYRACUSE, Dec. 21 -- Syracuse University will put Orange Bowl profits into a fund to build a field house.

LONDON, Dec. 20 -- Inheritance taxes, known here as death duties, are checking the growth of family-owned businesses and are encouraging concentration of wealth in big corporations, according to a survey issued today by the Intelligence Unit of The Economist, authoritative London weekly journal.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- Leroy A. Lincoln, national chairman of the 1953 Red Cross Fund Campaign, named a nineteen-member committee today to help raise some $95,000,000 in the drive that begins next March.

The appointment of a commission to "get all the facts" on segregation practices against minority groups in the United States was pledged yesterday by Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower to a group of Negro clergymen who called on him at his Commodore Hotel headquarters.

MOSES LAKE, Wash., Dec. 22 (AP) -- A thirty-five-man investigating board spent most of today at the barren scene of Saturday's disastrous crash of the giant C-124 Globemaster transport in which eighty-six service men died. Several of the thirty survivors remained in critical condition

" Come Back, Little Sheba," which arrives at the Victoria, is today's lone film newcomer. Shirley Booth, who makes her motion picture debut in the role she created in the William Inge play, and Burt Lancaster are starred in the drama, with Terry Moore and Richard Jaeckel among the featured players.
The flow of blood donations has declined to such a trickle that individual donors will be welcomed this week without advance appointments, the Red Cross announced yesterday.

HARRISON, N. Y., Dec. 22 -- The theft of $559 from Manhattanville College of the Sacred Heart here was solved, the suspect arrested and the money recovered this afternoon, just one hour after the crime was committed. The swift, cooperation of a nun and the police was credited with the solution.

MINEOLA, L. I., Dec. 22 -- The appointment of F. Howard Covey of Centre Island and Hicksville as campaign chairman of the 1953 Nassau County Red Cross fund drive was announced today. Mr. Covey, a retired Nassau County Boy Scout executive, was vice chairman of the campaign this year.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., Dec. 22 -- Gov. Earl Warren ended California's post-election political guessing game today by appointing Thomas H. Kuchel, the State Controller, to the United States Senate seat to be vacated by Richard M. Nixon, the Vice President-elect.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- Mrs. Ivy Baker Priest, who will be the Treasurer of the United States in the new Administration, has a deep regard for money. It is the type of respect one acquires when money is difficult to come by in the early years.

It should not come as a surprise to learn, as Cyrus L. Sulzberger tells us in a dispatch from Addis Ababa, that there are few Russians and little communism in Ethiopia. This is, in fact, generally true of the whole of Africa, even of Tunisia and Morocco, where there is so much agitation and revolutionary fervor.

President-elect Eisenhower has been losing little time in getting the wheels in motion for his Administration, which will take office in less than a month. The businesslike way in which he has been tackling his manifold problems has been impressive; and it is particularly encouraging to note that he is evidently giving a high priority to the need for more efficiently organizing the executive branch of the Federal Government.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (AP) -- Jess Larsen, Defense Materials Procurement Administrator, said today the Government is working on an expanded program to step up the supply of nickel. He said there is an urgent need for the material.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (UP) -- Frank Pace Jr., Secretary of the Army, announced today that, effective Jan. 1, inducted personnel who saw service in Korea would be returned to civilian life after only twenty months service instead of the present twenty-one.

Capturing seven of the eight first places, Coach Bill Connell's Brooklyn Technical High School squad won the city P. S. A. L. dual meet swimming championship yesterday by halting Bayside High, Queens ruler, 48 to 19, in the final-round swim-off at Textile High School.

A hold-up, believed to have been the first ever staged at La Guardia Airport, netted two robbers $3,623 at 1:50 P. M. yesterday and left the police and everyone else wondering how the intruders entered and escaped from the well-guarded hangar-offices of American Airlines.

BOUND BROOK, N. J., Dec. 22 -- A flash explosion followed by fire ripped through a four-story building of the Bakelite Company plant in near-by Piscataway Township today, killing one man and injuring twenty-seven others, seven critically.

CAMDEN, N. J., Dec. 22 -- J. Earl Blades Jr., 39 years old, credit manager for General Motors Acceptance Corporation here, spent his lunch hour today shopping for presents for his wife, Dorothy, 38, and his 63-year-old father, who shared his home in suburban Delaware Township.
ITTA BENA, Miss., Dec. 22 -- White teen-age vandals wrecked a Nativity scene at Mississippi's new Negro college here but white citizens, by the hundreds, helped restore it.

Dr. Grayson Kirk, vice president and acting head of Columbia University, returned here yesterday from a three-week tour of Western Europe in which he invited 232 academic institutions to participate in Columbia's bicentennial celebration in 1954.
Christmas trade reached its peak here last week and produced this month's first sales increase over last year's figures for local department stores.

The Federal Government, it is pointed out in a United Press story from Washington, is $8,267 millions deeper in debt at the present time than it was when Mr. Truman took office. It is estimated, however, that between now and June 30 next this figure may be reduced to the point where the net change will be about $5,500 millions. How good, or how bad, is this record ?

TRENTON, Dec. 22 -- Waterfront crime in the New York harbor area is so shocking that it will have to be dealt with in New Jersey by new legislation, Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll declared here this evening. He said he intended to submit proposals on the subject to the next session of the Legislature.

A threat by building unions to halt all contract construction on Army battery sites if troops manning anti-aircraft defenses in the metropolitan area are permitted to erect prefabricated winter huts has forced a drastic change by the Army in its sheltering program.

A former city detective and four members of a burglary gang, for which he was the "mastermind" in an attempted $20,000 shakedown through a framed marijuana arrest, were sentenced yesterday in General Sessions Court to terms ranging up to five years.

Anger is usually a had counselor. Worse than that is misrepresentation of facts. Your editorial "Tito's Tantrums" of Dec. 18 is a mixture of both. All those who have any knowledge of the facts concerning Archbishop Stepinac's activities during the Nazi and Ustashi regime in Croatia could not but be highly surprised at his elevation by the Vatican.

The 400 members of the New York Mercantile Exchange celebrated the eightieth anniversary of that organization yesterday in their building at Harrison and Hudson Streets. While deals in Maine potatoes, butter, eggs and onions were being made by shouting traders in part of the trading room, the rest of the room was left to the anniversary observance and to the return visit of Frank G. Henry.

Thirty-five nursery school children took unsentimental leave of historic but shabby Hamilton House, lower East Side community center, yesterday morning. The youngsters, carrying toys and pushing doll carriages, then hiked to their new quarters in the Alfred E. Smith Houses.

White Christmas trees, silver stars and bells and silvered smilax formed a glittering holiday decor for the Debutante Cotillion and Christmas Ball held last night in the Grand Ballroom and adjoining suites of the Waldorf-Astoris. More than 100 young women, most of them making their formal debuts, had subscribed to the ball.

MEXICO CITY, Dec. 22 -- A huge billboard twenty feet off the main road proclaimed: "Save Our Forests!" An old woman emerged for the darkness behind the billboard, glanced furtively along the street and approached the car. After a hasty whispered conversation she called a young boy, who got into the back seat and told the driver where to go.

Attempts to prevent crippling conditions from affecting untold numbers of children yet unborn are under way in research centers about the country, financed by grants from the Association for the Aid of Crippled Children, according to the association's annual report, to be issued today.

A bid of 100.33 for 2s was the bot qubmittad yesterday for $4,566,000 of refunding bonds of Seattle, Wash., due from 1955 to 1968. This offer was made by a banking syndicate headed by Union Securities Corporation. On Iraoffering subject to award, the bonds were priced to yield from 11.25 per cent to 2.3 per cent.

Many products and services are designed, manufactured and sold with no consultation whatever with those who are to consume, use or enjoy them. Examples of two notable exceptions, however, were disclosed yesterday.

Sixteen railway officials from eight Far Eastern nations wound up a month's inspection tour of rail systems in various parts of the United States with a session yesterday in the New York City Transit System's Bureau of Line Equipment School under the Fourteenth Street station of the IND subway at Eighth Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- Local 80-A of the Packinghouse Workers Union, C. I. O., was stripped today of authority to bargain for the employes of four big companies at Camden, N. J., because one of its officers filed a false non-Communist affidavit.
BUFFALO, Dec. 22 -- A decision on the nation's first constitutional test of the eighty-day Taft-Hartley Act labor injunction was delayed here today.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Dec. 22 -- A gross budget of $33,889,510 for next year was adopted this afternoon by the Westchester County Board of Supervisors. Deleted from earlier proposals was a subsidy for the continuance of concerts here at the County Center after the current season.

Directors of Namm Loeser's, ' Inc. yesterday elected to the board I2ernard Pineu, vice presiden in charge of ready-wear, accessory, children's divisions and branch stores. Edwin Cavanagh, sales promotion manager and Allan Steinhardt, store manager were named vice presidents. Benjamin H. Namm, president and board chairman, announced that all appointments are effectiye immediately.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Dec. 22 -- Prime Minister Khwaja Nazimuddin presented to the Pakistan Constituent Assembly today the report of a committee that was assigned in 1949 to the task of recommending principles for Pakistan's future Constitution.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 22 -- Abdel Khalek Hassouna, Secretary General of the Arab League, expressed today his "general satisfaction'' with decisions at the Seventh General Assembly session on Palestine, Tunisia and Morocco.

ADELAIDE, Australia, Dec. 22 (AP) -- America's Davis Cup forces buckled down to hard practice on Adelaide's Memorial Drive courts today, confident they have a good chance of recapturing the international tennis trophy from the Australians next week.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (UP) -- Members from rural Midwest areas will wield in the new Congress the preponderance of legislative power that has been held by members from the South and big Northern cities. Midwest Republicans will head thirteen of the nineteen standing committees of the House of Representatives and nine of the fifteen standing committees of the Senate.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture reported today that official returns on a burley tobacco marketing quota referendum held on Nov. 22 show that 98.3 per cent of the growers voting favored such controls.
C. Howard Paul, secretary and treasurer of Mackintosh-Hemphill Company, has been elected a vice president, it was announced yesterday.

The arrest yesterday in Brooklyn of twenty employes of a stevedore corporation broke a strange story of live "ghosts" carried on the payroll merely to give them the run of the piers where they allegedly fattened on gambling and loan shark profits.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- The finding of the President's Loyalty Review Board that "there is reasonable doubt as to his [John Carter Vincent's] loyalty to the Government of the United States" has revived a controversy over the bases of judgment to which the board is limited by the President and the requirement that it must withhold from the public detailed reports of its proceedings.

Before departing for Hollywood yesterday, Jos Ferrer signed contracts to stage "Angels Cooking," the Sam and Bella Spewack adaptation of Albert Husson's Parisian hit, "Cuisine des Anges." Thus, the energetic actor-director has put an end to various speculations as to what would be his next Broadway project.

For the first time in fifty years New York appears to be on the way toward cleaning up the alliance of racketeers, crooked union officials and politicians whose operations have, as Governor Dewey says, made this port "a stench in the nostrils of the community and a barrier to the lifeblood of New York -- its international trade."

BONN, Germany, Dec. 22 -- The importance of West German rearmament to the defense of Europe has been underlined by the relaxation of arms efforts in the nations of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. However, it is doubtful that a speed -- up in German efforts to achieve rearmament has resulted.

An order extending minimum wage protection for the first time to 150,000 janitors and other building service workers in New York State has been approved by Industrial Commissioner Edward Corsi, the State Department of Labor announced yesterday.

In its final action before adjourning until February the General Assembly of the United Nations did one last good deed by turning a contemptuous thumbs-down on a Soviet attempt to indict the United States on charges of "mass murder" of war prisoners in Korea.

LONDON, Dec. 22 (UP) -- Freak weather brought wintry gales to some parts of Europe and warm winds to others. Strawberries ripened and roses bloomed in several towns in the flood-swept south of France.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 22 -- While Paramount Pictures is about to plunge into television film production, Universal - International has decided to cut back its operations in the new field of entertainment. The company, through its wholly owned subsidiary, United World Films, has made thirteen half-hour-length movies for "The Fighting Man" series.

After a four-year absence, Zadel Skolovsky, Canadian-American pianist, returned to Town Hall last night to give his fifth New York recital. He devoted most of his program to three modern masters, Hindemith, Bartok and Milhaud.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (AP) -- The Bureau of the Census reported today that 13,987,832 running bales of cotton from the 1952 crop were ginned prior to Dec. 13. This number compared with 13,592,012 ginned to the same date last year and 9,178,376 to the same date two years ago.
ATLANTA, Dec. 22 -- Frank Costello, the New York gambler, was put aboard a Bureau of Prisons bus at the Federal penitentiary here early today, bound for the Federal "common jail" in Milan, Mich.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 22 -- As his final official act early this morning before suspending the session of the United Nations General Assembly until February, Lester B. Pearson of Canada, Assembly president, named Dr. Ralph J. Bunche, Dr. Herman Santa Cruz of Chile and Dr. Jaime Torres Bodet of Mexico as members of a commission to study the question of race conflict in the Union of South Africa.

In a respite from the developments following the State Athletic Commission's action last Friday night in reversing the decision in the Billy Graham-Joe Giardello middleweight bout in Madison Square Garden, Chairman Robert K. Christenberry yesterday approved plans for a world light-heavyweight championship battle between the new titleholder, Archie Moore and Randy Turpin, England's former world middleweight champion.

New momentum was generate yesterday by the stock mark.e t, again under the sponsorship of ,the railroads, with somehelp from'he petroleums. AH components Usdd in THE NEW YORK .TIMES index were at new highs for the year-end upswing,, vlith gains in many of the most heavily traded issues ranging beyond a' pint.

MINEOLA, L. I., Dec. 22 -- Leone D. Howell, retiring after thirty-six years as Nassau County Surrogate, presented his law library of 1,000 volumes to Nassau County this morning and administered the oath of office this afternoon to a Supreme Court justice, a county court judge and a new county executive.

An excellent article in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Dec. 7 discusses the concern expressed by many educators and scientists over the disproportionately large share of financial support devoted to applied research as compared to fundamental research in American universities.

LONDON, Dec. 22 -- Great Britain plans renewed representations to the United States about the difficulties that may be put in the way of British seamen through stringent enforcement of provisions of the McCarran-Walter Immigration Act. The new law is effective on Wednesday.

TRENTON, Dec. 22 -- The State Supreme Court ruled today that a man who murdered his wife could not claim their property as the surviving joint owner. It held he was entitled only to the income from half of it.

The nomination of Arthur Eckstein, president and treasurer of Arthur Eckstein, Inc., real estate concern, and of Charles Schnurmacher, president of the Manhattan Pontiac Corporation, for three-year terms as directors of the Broadway Association was announced yesterday.
When the State Legislature convenes next month it will be asked by the New York State Pharmaceutical Association to exempt all drugs from local sales taxes.

PARIS, Dec. 22 -- Several days of reflection have caused observers here to contend that the resolution on Indo-China adopted last week by the North Atlantic Council ties France's hands as much as, if not more than, those of the other Western powers.
LONDON, Dec. 22 -- The United States armed forces in Britain are providing Christmas cheer for more than 10,000 British youngsters.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- The Government was warned by the Supreme Court today, in an 8-to-1 decision, not to seek excessive penalties in cases involving violations of the Fair Labor Standards Act.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- Carl D. Shoemaker, who in 1936 helped organize the National Wildlife Federation, will retire as its conservation director Dec. 31. He was formerly secretary and Washington representative of the federation, a private organization.

Walter Sullivan, welfare director of the International Longshoremen's Association, A. F. L., and one of four union officials accused of having seized a ballot box after an election of officers on Saturday in Local 1171, denied yesterday that any force had been involved.
The biggest small man in college basketball, Johnny O'Brien, will lead the Chieftains of Seattle University against N. Y. U. in the curtain-raiser of a double-header at Madison Square Garden tonight.

The seventy-one-family apartment house at 309 East 164th Street, the Bronx, has been sold by Emil Litwin to Leo Lubarsky. The property is assessed at $190,000 and was sold subject to mortgages of $147,400. Rubin Nason were the brokers.
The supposed impersonality of the biggest city in the world was dispelled yesterday in the laughter of children and veterans who shared the hospitality of New Yorkers in a pre-holiday mood.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 --A new Gov. ernment census, he first of its ldnd 'since the end of World War II, revealed today that private American direct investments abroad totaled $11,804,100,000 at the end of 1950.
PARIS, Tuesday, Dec. 23 -- Threatened with defeat in three votes of confidence, Premier Antoine Pinay announced his resignation last night before a vote was taken in the National Assembly.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange turned slightly steadier yesterday and closed 11 to 24 points net higher than on Friday.
There will be generally higher business volume in all lines in 1953, and employment will rise, although there will be a number of complications.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 22 -- The 12,500-ton French liner Champollion was breaking up three miles south of Beirut harbor tonight with about 800 passengers and crew aboard. Rescue operations, thus far largely fruitless, were continuing.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 22 -- Premier Marshal Tito's major statement for today's celebration of Yugoslav Army Day emphasized the role of youths, not only as potential fighters but as revolutionaries for whom preliminary training was vital ideological and political activity.

LONDON, Dec. 22 -- The "beefeaters" -- scarlet-clad yeomen guards who have kept watch over the Tower of London for 500 years -- today became first-class civil servants with the right to pensions when they retire.

Persons prominent in society and the theatre joined last evening with Clifton Webb and the United States Marine Band in celebrating the reopening of the Roxy Theatre, which has been provided with a $250,000 ice stage as a permanent and exclusive facility for live entertainment.

Now the gleam of winter steals gently out of the night and over the land. Across glen and glade the gathering light of a waxing moon gives a luminous sheen to snowy pasture, field and pond lying amid upland hills. It rests peacefully on roof of house, shed and barn.
As Christmas approaches our hearts turn toward Korea. We thank God for the men holding the frontiers of freedom against the hordes that fight because they are deceived by communism.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 22 -- A plenipotentiary meeting of the International Telecommunications Union Conference ended tonight when delegates signed the Buenos Aires Convention, which supersedes the Atlantic City Convention. The organization, affiliated with the United Nations, allots international radio frequencies.

Dollar draft indebtedness of Brazil rose $2,300,000 last month to a new high of $200,700,000, according to the monthly report on Latin-American export credit issued yesterday by the Federal Resrv'Bank of New York. The report is compiled from data submitted by fifteen participating banks

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (AP) -- The Petroleum Administration for Defense reported today that if the nation's natural gas utilities are to carry out planned expansion to care for potential demand by the winter of 1955-56 they must lay almost 10,000,000 tons of pipe in the next three years.
TOKYO, Tuesday, Dec. 23 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,472 for the twenty-four hours ended at 6 A. M. Tuesday, Korean time:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- !George J. 'Burger, vice president of the National Federation of Independent Business, said today the federation would "vigorously oppose'' the creation of a conference section in the Department of Jus-I rice where business men could be informed of current anti-trust policies.
MONTREAL, Dec. 22 (AP) -- Jean Beliveau is running Santa Claus a close race as the most talked of man in Montreal today.

Pichler, Inc., in a purchase for investment, has acquired the three-story business and apartment building at 7701 Eighteenth Avenue in the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn from Dr. John R. Santeramo. The building, on a plot about 20 by 105 feet at the northwest corner of Seventy-seventh Street, has five stores and four apartments.

In this season so propitious for the development of coughs, wheezes and sniffles it seems appropriate to pay tribute to Glycyrrhiza glabra. Were it not for the properties of Glycyrrhiza, many of the medicines and other preparations available for use in the treatment of colds and bronchial disturbances would be less palatable than many of them are.

Used through the ages to cast a soft light on the Christmas scene, the candle, according to the Columbia Encyclopedia, signifies joy, reverence and sacrifice (it consumes itself). This year it comes in several handsome new designs, some of which might make pretty Christmas gifts.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- The Government released today documents showing that the International Committee of the Red Cross had warned the United Nations Command in Korea of a "dangerous situation" that existed on Koje Island before the major prisoner of war uprising last May.

IT surprised no one at all when Sugar Ray Robinson last Thursday formally announced his retirement from the ring. The immensely talented middleweight champion had his nose made handsome not long ago, an operation designed to further his new career as a night-club dancer. It was a cinch that he wouldn't permit an unlicensed surgeon such as Randy Turpin to operate on it again with crude fists.
An Alaskan husky, a small, blackish gray mongrel and four little girls, all of Greenwich Village, will have sad Christmases this year unless they find one another in the next couple of days.

Pierre Langlois, French middleweight making his fifth appearance in a local ring, last night battled Walter Cartier of Greenwich Village to a draw in a bruising ten-round bout at the Eastern Parkway Arena, Erooklyn, and retained his position as a contender for the vacated world middleweight title.
CHICAGO, Dec. 22 (UP) -- The Brodie Siamese twins, whose heads were separated in a day-long operation five days ago, clung to life today despite the pessimism of physicians.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (UP) -- The Farm Home Administration of the Department of Agriculture approved $212,242,141 in loans to 96,500 farm families in 1952, Director Dillard B. Lasseter reported today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture predicted today it will lose $100,u !000 or less on more than $2,100,i000,000 it has advanced in price support loans to farmers during the last seven years.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- Michael V. DiSalle was sworn in today as Economic Stabilization Administrator and moved at once to reconstitute the Wage Stabilization Board on a tripartite basis by asking the National Association of Manufacturers and the Chamber of Commerce of the United States to nominate industry members.
TOKYO, Dec. 22 -- Christmas will be bleak and giftless for at least 4,000 United Nations soldiers in Communist prisoner of war camps in North Korea.

In our society the family is the first and fundamental unit of organization. There the child first learns love, discipline, self-restraint, respect for others and respect for property. There he can usually find sympathetic understandings of his problems but not necessarily approval for any course of action he might plan.

Commodity futures trading on the New York exchanges was slow yesterday, as the holiday period approached. Prices closed generally higher with potatoes, rubber, lead, zinc, coffee and hides showing increases. Cocoa and cottonseed oil closed lower and sugar, wool and soybean oil were mixed.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (UP) -- American Reds have found charitable foundations a "very lucrative" source of funds to finance subversive work, two former Communists told a Congressional committee today.

ALBANY, Dec. 22 -- Governor Dewey granted Christmas commutations today to six convicts and reduced by two years the sentence of a seventh. Most of the six were expected to be freed in time for Christmas.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 22 (UP) -- The Ohio State and Pittsburgh basketball teams would just as soon forget the experiment they made in fouls last Saturday night, the coaches indicated today.
The 700 men and women over 60 years old who belong to the Sirovich Day Center, celebrated the center's third anniversary yesterday by staging a fair.

PARIS, Dec. 22 (AP) -- Eight Frenchmen, accused of engineering the torture and death of hundreds of persons just before the liberation of Paris, were doomed tonight to die. A military court's sentence went beyond the prosecution's demands.

The Kerbs Memorial Hall was dedicated yesterday as a new teaching and staff building of Memorial Center for Cancer and Allied Diseases in memory of Edward A. and Alice H. Kerbs, and a gift of their daughter, Mrs. Jeanne E. Kerbs.

TRENTON, Dec. 22 -- The theft during last night of approximately $33,000 in railroad ticket receipts from a safe, opened and relocked by someone who knew the combination, posed a mystery today for Pennsylvania Railroad and Trenton police.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 22 (AP) -- Gil Turner scored a technical knockout over New York's Joe Miceli tonight in 58 seconds of the sixth round. Turner weighed 149 1/2 and Miceli 146 1/2 for the scheduled 10-round welterweight scrap at the Arena.

Fifty-four families were evacuated late last night from a six-story apartment house in the Bronx when flames, accompanied by heavy smoke, swept through a series of adpoining two-story buildings on the east side of Jerome Avenue, between 170th Street and Elliot Place.
LONDON, Dec. 22 -- Idle conditions prevailed in most sections of the stock market here today and price movements, sensitive to small transactions, were generally without significance.
CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 22 (AP) -- Clear Path, a son of Contradiction, raced to his third straight triumph at Tropical Park today in the Donnithorne Purse.
When Congress convenes on Jan. 3 I hope it will consider the advisability of enacting legislation looking toward three important reforms in connection with future Presidential elections:

BONN, Germany, Dec. 22 -- Measured in terms of retail sales, the economic system of West Germany has completed its most successful year since the end of World War II and, in a relative sense, surpassed the level of the pre-war period.

Gravy for the Christmas roast, whether it be turkey, chicken or perhaps ribs of beef or a crown of pork or lamb, is likely to present difficulties for those who are not practiced cooks. Some last-minute tips on preparing this essential sauce for the holiday meat might be apropos.

American business men still will have good markets in Europe after the Schuman plan begins operating, but they will have to meet new requirements in quality and currency, Ryk Pieter Schoonheim, Rotterdam coal importer and ship-owner, said today on his arrival at Idlewild Airport.
Sales and earnings records were set by Dresser Industries, Inc. in the fiscal year ended on Oct. 31, according to the preliminary annual report issued yesterday by H. N. Mallon, president.

A tract of 232 acres on the north side of Montauk Highway in Hampton Bays, Southampton, L. I., has been sold by Alfred Grant Walton as administrator of the estate of Louisa D. Pratt to the M. T. M. Realty Corporation. Arthur Miles, broker in the transaction, will act as agent for the new owner in the subdivision and resale of the land.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Dec. 22 -- In a brief and impressive military ceremony before President Sukarno's palace, 37-year-old Col. Bambang Sugeng took the oath today as Acting Chief of Staff of the Indonesian Army.

Queen Nazli of Egypt, mother of ex-King Farouk, has signed a contract with Putnam for the publication of her autobiography. Queen Nazli, who is now living in California, is writing the book in collaboration With Kate Holliday, author of "Troopship" and numerous magazine articles.

ROME, Dec. 22 -- The recently appointed Archbishop of Cracow, Msgr. Eugene Baziak, was arrested last Monday by the Communist Government of Poland, according to information received today by the Vatican.

Premiums written during 1952 by the 197 mutual casualty insurance companies of the United States will approximate $1,220,000,000, according to a survey released yesterday by L. A. Fitzgerald, director of information of the American Mutual Alliance. This represents an increase of about 14 per cent over the $1,070,638,733 written by mutual companies in 1951 and will mark the fourteenth consecutive year in which mutual casualty insurance premium volume established a new high record.

The cast of "South Pacific" was added yesterday to the list of donors to the New York Times Neediest Cases fund. Through Juanita Hall, one of its stars, a contribution of $180 was received to help the unfortunate New Yorkers aided by the campaign.

BUFFALO, Dec. 22 (AP) -- Sweetwater Clifton and Carl Braun led the New York Knickerbockers to an 80-75 victory over the Milwaukee Hawks before a crowd of 9,000 tonight. It put New York into a first-place tie with the Boston Celtics in the Eastern Division of the National Basketball Association.

LONDON, Dec. 22 -- Loy W. Henderson, United States Ambassador to Iran, who is soon returning to Teheran to make a new effort to resolve the oil dispute between Britain and Iran, will be acting on very limited instructions.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (AP) -- In the third quarter of this year foreign countries sold substantially more to the United States than they bought here, continuing the trend of the second quarter.

Net profits of department stores are turning upward. This was reported yesterday by the Controllers' Congress of the National Retail Dry Goods Associaion, covering department and specialty stores throughout the country.

HANOI, Vietnam, Indo-China, Dec. 22 -- It now is clear that the French have won the battle for Nasan for the time being. Heavily damaged in their attempts to take the isolated Nasan mountain bastion 100 miles northwest of Hanoi in early December, the Communist-led Vietminh forces have thinned out in the vicinity of Nasan to the extent that they no longer present a serious threat to the garrison there.
Members of the police force received holiday messages yesterday from Mayor Impellitteri and Police Commissioner George P. Monaghan.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- President Truman was urged in a report of the National Security Resources Board today to seek amendment of the Atomic Energy Act whereby "private interests could operate commercially to benefit from their atomic power research, development and production."
CLEVELAND, Dec. 22 (AP) -- Milk shakes and touch-tackle last week. Today, loafing.
HONOLULU, Dec. 22 -- Judge Jon Wiig denied a defense motion for a mistrial in Hawaii's Communist conspiracy case today after listening to arguments of opposing attorneys for two hours.

Mayor Impellitteri's transit survey committee called on representatives of the private bus companies yesterday to resume collective bargaining with the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., in an effort to prevent a strike on Jan. 1 on lines that normally carry 3,500,000 riders a day in Manhattan, the Bronx, Queens and lower Westchester.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (AP) -- The Defense Department identified today 104 Korean war casualties, including thirty-six dead, sixty-one wounded, two missing and five injured. The following casualties were listed for New York and New Jersey (none from Connecticut):

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- A Congressional investigation of allegations of Communist atrocities in Korea and an international prosecution of the Soviet Union for the Katyn Forest massacre of 1940 were recommended today by a committee of the House of Representatives.

AT THE KOREAN FRONT, Dec. 22 -- A wanderer who has the fortitude and stamina to climb a steep hill on the forward perimeter of the United States defense line here may roam into a squat, uncomfortable-looking bunker within which a studious bespectacled Army captain sits cross-legged on the floor and writes in a ponderous notebook by candlelight.

HAVERSTRAW, N. Y., Dec. 22 -- In a pre-Christmas tragedy that saddened this Hudson Valley town, two small children were burned to death this morning as their mother tried in vain to penetrate a wall of flame that separated her from them.

HUNTERS and fishermen are universally afflicted with itching feet. Distant waters and covers always assume a brighter aspect, but many sportsmen have been restricted in their travels by the high non-resident license fees initiated by some states.

Bobby Sherwood, former bandleader, will conduct an early morning radio program over WJZ on Mondays through Fridays from 6:30 to 8 o'clock, beginning Monday. The show will be interrupted for news broadcasts at 7 and 7:30.

MANILA, Dec. 22 (UP) -- Eugenio Perez, Speaker of the House, today criticized "officious" United States experts in the Mutual Security Agency who would "change the Philippines overnight into an ideal nation."

JERSEY CITY, Dec. 22 -- Assemblyman William V. Musto of Hudson County was elected today as 1953 minority leader of the New Jersey State Assembly. He was chosen by seventeen Democratic members of the Assembly at a luncheon meeting here.

JERUSALEM, Dec. 22 -- Prime Minister David Ben-Gurion announced today to the Knesset (Parliament) that he had succeeded in forming a coalition government composed of the Mapai, General Ziohist and Progressive parties. At the same time he issued an urgent call to the country for unity in the face of threatening political and economic difficulties.

The American Ice Company, formerly the Knickerbocker Ice Company, has sold the five-story building at 348-354 Broome Street to a client of Nathan Nathan, attorneys. The property occupies an irregular plot about 163 by 101 feet at the northeast corner of Elizabeth Street. Occupied as an ice plant, the building was erected in 1917 by the Knickerbocker concern.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- The Inaugural Committee announced today that 2,000 paratroopers of the Army's Eighty-second Airborne Division would march in the parade celebrating the swearing-in as President of their onetime commander, Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower.

A year-end dividend of 30 cents on the common stock of the Cannon Shoe Company will be paid on Jan. 2, in addition to a stock dividend of one share of new Class A non-voting common for each share of present common held, payable on Jan. 15.

MOSCOW, Dec. 22 -- An authoritative Communist party source has defined Zionism as "a reactionary nationalist trend of the Jewish bourgeoisie" that acts as "a faithful agency of American imperialism" and engages in "carrying out espionage and subversive activities for the benefit of United States imperialists."
Thirteen persons were wounded by an exploding hand grenade tossed into the Royal Flush Bar and Grill at 100 West 103d Street at 1:15 A. M. today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- Two written opinions interpreting the laws regarding infringement of trade-marks and copyrights were handed down by the Supreme Court today.

Police Department ballistics men announced yesterday that an automatic pistol allegedly owned by a hold-up man disarmed by a city fireman who is a judo expert was the weapon used a month ago in two murders, one in Queens, one in Yonkers.

ROTTERDAM, the Netherlands, Dec. 22 -- Four European shipping lines have served notice of withdrawal from the North Atlantic Westbound Freight Conference, effective Jan. 1, creating the threat of a rate war on cargoes from the Continent to American ports.

VIENNA, Dec. 22 -- An avalanche roaring down Austria's Arlberg pass smashed a busload of Christmas holiday skiers into an Alpine stream tonight and killed twenty-three of the thirty-one passengers. The police said thirteen of the dead were women.

FRANCONIA, N. H., Dec. 22 -- A program to groom outstanding young skiers for international competition will get under way at Mount Mansfield in Stowe, Vt., on Jan. 9. The youngsters will be trained for the world title meet (Federation Internationale de Ski) in Sweden in 1954 and the Winter Olympics in Italy two years later.

In general I find your editorial comment on the German situation fair-minded and enlightened. But regretfully I find that I must object strongly to the tenor of your editorial of Dec. 10, dealing with the constitutional crisis which has developed in Germany in connection with the European Defense Community treaty.

MODERN travelers who fret when their train is late or fume when their plane is grounded take speed and comfort for granted. But most travelers through most recorded history have enjoyed little speed and less comfort. Prairie schooners were not equipped with foam rubber or automatic heating. The Mayflower did not serve chicken broth and crackers at 11 each morning.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (AP) -- A speed-up in the construction of new multiple-purpose reservoir projects to develop additional power supplies was recommended today by the National Security Resources Board.

As Christmas travel grows heavier, in and out of the city, extra accommodations are being provided on trains, planes and buses, and all facilities will be taxed to capacity, the transportation lines reported yesterday.

Chief Magistrate Joseph M. Murtagh yesterday directed a second multiple traffic law violator to go to Bellevue Hospital for psychiatric observation after the offender had pleaded guilty to ignoring thirty-six tickets.

Although the cost of living has mounted rapidly in the last five years, the contributions of many Americans to their churches have risen even faster, according to a report yesterday by the National Council of Churches of Christ in the U. S. A.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Dec. 18 -- Ethiopia has the longest tradition of independence among African states. Except for five years of Italian occupation (1936-41) it has been a sovereign country for centuries.

With the help of the substantial amount of new productive capacity brought into operation during the last twelve months, the steel industry is closing the year in high gear. It is apparent that this month will see the highest December output on record, with production of more than 9,600,000 tons of raw steel.

WASHINGTON, DeC. 22 --Thel Supreme CoUrt ruled today, 6 to 3,I that .the Interstate. C0mlnerceI railroads. A commission order directing Florida railroads to establish intrastate rates that would "reflect the same increases" the commission had authorized for comparable interstate traffic was sustained,

Dimitri Mitropoulos, physically exhausted after more than a year of continuous activity both in this country and abroad, has canceled six weeks of scheduled concerts with the Philharmonic-Symphony in January and February, the Philharmonic announced yesterday.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Dec. 23 -- United States Sabre jets patrolling North Korea's Manchurian frontier on the Yalu River shot down three of the Communists' MIG fighters yesterday in two high-altitude engagements.

HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Dec. 22 -- The Hofstra College basketball team had to fight off a determined Tufts second-half rally before gaining a 60-to-53 victory at Calkins Gymnasium tonight. Hofstra moved ahead 14 -- 4 in the first six minutes but Tufts fought back steadily and within ninety seconds of the game's end wa sonly four points behind.

A 26-year-old orphan returned to the Mission of the Immaculate Virgin on Staten Island yesterday laden with $700 of gifts for boys and girls whom he promised to remember when he left there five years ago. It was the fifth consecutive Christmas period in which he kept that promise.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture today forecast a continuing decline in pork supplies next year.

ALBANY, Dec. 22 -- The State Catholic Welfare Committee charged today that an attempt to have the phrase "near churches" barred from hotel and resort advertising as discriminatory "is based on vain fears and erroneous judgments."

TAIPEI, Formosa, Dec. 22 -- President Chiang Kai-shek pledged today that Nationalist preparations for a counter-offensive against the Communist-held mainland would be completed within the next year, strongly indicating a possible Nationalist landing in China in 1954.

Southern Company and subsidiaries earned a net income of $20,263,204, equal to $1.18 a share on 17,076,669 capital shares for the twelve months ended on Nov. 30, it was announced yesterday. This compares with a net income of $16,231,553, or 99 cents each on 16,306,494 shares in the preceding twelve months.

Farrell Lines has authorized Gibbs Cox, naval architects of New York, to develop preliminary designs, plans and specifications for two seventeen-knot combination passenger and cargo ships for the company's South African service.
Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower asserted yesterday that Marshal Georgi K. Zhukov's friendship for him led to the Soviet military hero's "disgrace" in 1946.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 22 -- Lester B. Pearson of Canada, President of the General Assembly, said in an au revoir statement today that, despite the Assembly's recent failure to obtain an armistice, the United Nations would yet succeed both in stopping the fighting and in bringing about the reconstruction of Korea.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Dec. 23 -- Ten tennis players from Cuba will compete in the Orange Bowl junior tennis championships, Dec. 26-31. A record 161 players enrolled for the tournament, Eddie Herr, chairman, reported today.

Portents for a brighter Christmas filled the mall yesterday, as 844 contributors -- a record number for the forty-first annual appeal -- sent gifts totaling $33,239.13 to the New York Times Neediest Cases fund.
AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, Dec. 20 -- Aided by the opening last May 21 of the Amsterdam-Rhine Canal, this port is winding up a banner post-war year.

The measure designed to reduce vandalism in city parks by assessing fines up to $25 against parents for damage done by their children passed the City Council yesterday 16 to 8. The bill has the support of Park Commissioner Robert Moses and the Park Association of New York City, Inc.

THE bullfighting season in Spain does not get well under way until late May, a fact that may make MacKinley Helm's "Spring in Spain" unusual among travel books about Spain. It does not contain a single description of a bullfight. This is purely accidental, says Mr. Helm, who has lived in Mexico for many years and learned to like bullfights there.
Dr. Pauling replied yesterday in Pasadena, Calif.: "This statement is a lie. I have never been a member of the Communist party, and I have sworn to this fact."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 (AP) -- A proposal by which the Federal Government would step out of the Pacific Northwest power picture in favor of an interstate agency was described today by Senator Guy Cordon, Republican of Oregon, as a step toward more orderly development of the region's power resources.
Impish and sentimental sides of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's nature came to light yesterday at his Commodore Hotel headquarters.

LONDON, Dec. 23 -- Prices tended to rise on the stock markets here today despite further contraction of business before the Christmas holiday. Selected industrial shares made further moderate gains. Japanese bonds recovered part of yesterday's losses.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 23 -- When a certain clergyman in Chappaqua bows his head to say grace over his Christmas dinner, two Haitian women and a French girl will be waiting, with his family, to see him carve the turkey.

BOSTON, Dec. 23 -- Approximately 25,000 Massachusetts motorists who had been notified that their compulsory personal injury liability policies would not be renewed in 1953, because they were considered "bad risks," have received a reprieve.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 (AP) -- The nation's new immigration act, known as the McCarran-Walter Act, has ploughed a rough sea since its launching three years ago and faces fresh storms in the new Congress.

ATLANTA, Dec. 23 -- Gov. James F. Byrnes of South Carolina was appointed today a chairman of the Southern Foundation, an organization established by the Southern Governors' Conference "to present the Southern viewpoint to the nation."

CLEVELAND, Dec. 23 (AP) -- They joke about themselves as "the nine old men," these seven-season players of the Cleveland Browns. But any one of them still is good enough to be a key man at Municipal Stadium Sunday in the game against the Detroit Lions for the National Football League championship.
MAMARONECK, N. Y., Dec. 23 -- Four men accused of storing munitions here for a revolution in Cuba denied the charges today at a hearing in Village Court.

Deploring any use of chlorophyll not supported by sound research, a group of leading processors have formed the Chlorophyll Industry Committee. The purpose of the organization is to codify standards in processing and application, encourage research and disseminate information about the newly identified element of nature.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 23 -- The United Steelworkers, C. I. O., announced today that David J. McDonald, who left high school to go to work when he was 15 years old, had been nominated without opposition to succeed the late Philip Murray as president of the 1,100,000-member union.

The case of "the reversed decision" that arose after last Friday night's bout between Billy Graham and Joe Giardello in Madison Square Garden took an unexpected turn yesterday when J. Norman Lewis, of the law firm of Lewis Mound, revealed that he had been retained to seek reinstatement of the original determination of the two judges and the referee.

Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower and former President Herbert Hoover had an hour-and-a-half luncheon conference yesterday dealing with governmental problems and organization. They met at the home of John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State-designate, 72 East Ninety-second Street.

The tempo of holiday travel continued to increase here yesterday, pointing to a peak late this afternoon. Predictions of possible rain today, with temperatures around 45 degrees, are not expected to dampen the ardor of Christmas Eve travelers, except those who have yearned for a white holiday.
ALBANY, Dec. 23 -- Governor and Mrs. Dewey played Santa Claus today to fifty-six girls of St. Vincent's Home at the traditional Governor's Christmas party for orphans.

MONTREAL, Dec. 23 (AP) -Canada's capital expansion program in 1952 took up almost 23 per cent of the country's total available production, and a rising volume of new construction under way points to a further increase next year, the Bank of Montreal said today in..a year-end business review.

It was disturbing to learn in a dispatch from Australia the other day that an inoffensive individual had been hospitalized as the result of an encounter in a zoo with a cassowary -- or rather two cassowaries.

WHEN hunters gather during the coming holiday, there will be long and perhaps heated arguments on big game records, so those who have left their Christmas shopping until the last minute can make some sportsman happy by providing the new "Records of North American Big Game."

Messages of hope, reassurance and comfort will emanate from an eight-by-ten-foot room in a Brooklyn office building today and tomorrow to help ease the anxiety of families and service men in distress at Christmas.

LUXEMBOURG, Dec. 23 -- The first tax on the European coal and steel community's production was virtually agreed upon here tonight by the community's High Authority. It is a levy on the value of coal and steel that the six nations of the community -- France, West Germany, Italy, the Netherlands, Belgium and the Grand Duchy of Luxembourg -- produce.

After a year's investigation, during which it heard 103 witnesses, a bipartisan Congressional committee has voted unanimously to indict Soviet Russia on charges of having perpetrated the Katyn massacre of some 15,000 Polish officers and has called on President Truman to take steps through the United Nations to bring the Soviet Government to trial on this charge before the International Court of Justice.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- The two largest organizations representing business nationally declined today to cooperate in any effort to reconstitute the Wage Stabilization Board on a tripartite basis.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 23 (AP) -Ralph Kiner, player representative of the National League, said today a protest may be handed to Commissioner Ford Frick because of the Pirates' spring exhibitior schedule which calls for twenty-' six night games.

A one-story house with a basement and two porches is the kind of home preferred by more than half of the farm families in the Western, North Central and Southern sections of the United States. In the South two-thirds of the families also want a fireplace.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- Officials of the Defense Minerals Procurement Agency disclosed today that the Agency was negotiating with several mining companies for production of enough manganese ore from Mexico to justify the construction of a processing plant at El Paso, Tex.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- One clear attribute of booming business conditions in the closing months of the year was the continued upswing that drove retail sales above the record peak reached in January 1951, during the second wave of post-Korean scare buying.

Santa Claus came through yesterday with a big present for New York's 912,000 public school children -- a vacation that will last through Jan. 4. Gifts ware bestowed also upon the sick and the needy at Christmas parties given by private organizations throughout the city.
WENHAM, Mass., Dec 23 -- Kissing bunches, the British forerunner of Christmas trees during the first Elizabethan era, are being revived in this Essex County village on Boston's North Shore.

There's a tempting array of resort beachwear this season. Stores report that many customers, though not anticipating southern sojourns, have been unable to resist the fresh lively charm and are buying for next summer. Swim-suits alone have a multifold story to tell.

Ray Bolger, the dancer and pantomimist, made his first full-dress television appearance over the N. B. C. network on Sunday, and there's no point in beating about the bush: his was one of the most thoroughly delightful and charming hours seen all year on the screen.

Ernie Kovacs, whose comedy antics on television have been limited to daylight hours, will make his nighttime debut over the Columbia Broadcasting System video network on Tuesday from 8 to 9 o'clock. The time period previously was divided between the Red Buttons show, now presented on Saturday evenings, and Eddie Albert's "Leave It to Larry," which has been discontinued:

Surrogate William T. Collins upheld yesterday the right of a committee of three, including Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, President-elect, to designate City College as a $250,000 beneficiary of the estate of Jacob R. Schiff, banker and lawyer, who died here in 1949.

Three new offerings arrive at first run theatres today. At the Paramount is a Technicolor musical comedy, "April in Paris," starring Doris Day, Ray Bolger and Claude Dauphin in a screen play by Jack Rose and Melville Shavelson.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 (UP) -- The International Materials Conference last night announced its allotments of crude sulphur for the first three months of 1953, with the United States getting 1,190,800 long tons -- by far the largest share.
LONDON, Dec. 23 -- The Treasury announced today that Great Britain would meet in full her obligations to the United States and Canada when they fall due at the end of this year.

VIENNA, Dec. 23 -- While the Russian Deputy High Commissioner, Gen. V. M. Kraskevitch, was denouncing United States aid in the Allied Council here today as the cause of rising unemployment in Austria, the American Economic Cooperation mission announced the release of half billion schillings ($19,230,000) in counterpart funds to counteract it.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 (AP) -- The Defense Production Administration today authorized Federal tax benefits to assist a $43,400,000 electric power expansion project of Southern California Edison Company, Los Angeles.

Wes Westrum, in town to do some last-minute shopping, dropped in on the Christmas party of the Giants at their West Forty-second Street offices yesterday and, in the course of the festive proceedings, achieved a meeting of minds with President Horace C. Stoneham on the terms of his 1953 contract.

AUBURN, N. Y., Dec. 23 (AP) -- Representative John Taber, who will be the chairman of the House Appropriations Committee, said today that "millions of dollars are lying idle" in Government departments and agencies and "could not possibly be spent" in three years or more.

More trouble for the gangsters, crooked labor leaders and politicians, and conniving shipping men who have made the port of New York a hellhole of racketeering was spelled out yesterday in Washington, where Attorney General James P. McGranery ordered the Federal Bureau of Investigation to set the stage for Federal prosecutions.

An expected pick-up in defense orders has been slow to materialize, and new orders for machine tools dropped sharply as a result in November, it was reported yesterday by the National Machine Tool Builders Association.

Plans for two new midtown garages to house a total of 472 cars have been submitted to the City Planning Commission, it was learned yesterday, when the agency fixed Jan. 21 as the date for a hearing on the applications.

ALBANY, Dec. 23 -- Governor Dewey asserted today that he would urge, in his annual message to the Legislature, the enactment of a Constitutional amendment to improve the method of selecting Supreme Court justices who, he said, were known "to be chosen today by one or more members of the dominant political party."

BONN, Germany, Dec. 23 -- The Mutual Security Agency announced today the release of $22,000,000 in aid to the West German Federal Government, with the proviso that a counterpart equivalent in Deutsche marks be employed exclusively to improve the economic situation in western sectors of Berlin.

PARIS, Dec. 23 -- The resignation of the French Cabinet had a bullish effect on gold and dollar prices on the Paris market today, reflecting the belief that the end of the Pinay experiment would mean the resumption of inflation, largely checked by Premier Antoine Pinay.

There were squeals of joy last night in the Greenwich Village home of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Hellmuth. Sitka, the Alaskan husky who had wandered away from their four little daughters last Sunday, was reunited with his chums.
TOKYO, Wednesday, Dec. 24 -- Enemy troops early today launched a strong attack on the western front in Korea but were thrown back by United Nations defenders after sharp fighting.
HEADQUARTERS, Eighth Army in Korea, Dec. 23 -- Francis Cardinal Spellman of New York arrived in Korea tonight as United Nations soldiers finished preparations for their celebration of Christmas.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 (AP) -- The Air Force identified the following additional Air Force men today as victims of the crash:

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 23 (AP) -- The Third United States Circuit Court of Appeals today upheld a ban on the manufacture by the Atlas Powder Company and Glyco Products Company of a chemical used by bakers to keep bread softer longer.

JERUSALEM, Dec. 23 -- Prime Minister David Ben-Gurion's new Mapai-General Zionist-Progressive coalition, his fifth Government since the establishment of the State of Israel in 1948, received a 63-to-24 vote of confidence in the Knesset (Parliament) tonight.
THE NEW YORK TIMES of Dec. 16 carried a letter from Dr. John M. Clark, Professor of Economics at Columbia University and one of the nation's most eminent economists.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- The top-level Defense Department team of the new Administration, headed by Charles E. Wilson of General Motors Corporation, visited the Pentagon today for what was described as "an indoctrination in the larger-sized headaches."

The single vote of Borough President James J. Lyons of the Bronx put an end in the Board of Estimate yesterday to the elaborate plans of the Bulova Watch Company to erect a $10,000,000 shopping center in a Forest Hills, Queens, "superblock."

WASHINGTON, Wednesday, Dec. 24 -- Under the new immigration law, which went into effect at midnight last night, 269 members of the crew of the French liner Liberte will forfeit shore leave when the ship arrives in New York this morning, the Department of Justice said yesterday.
The largest manufacturer of women's apparel in Holland will supply the American market with more than 7,000 coats and suits for the spring season.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission today announced approval of a reorganization plan under which Eastern Utilities Associates, a Boston holding company, will reclassify its stock into a single class of common shares.

GRAND JUNCTION, Colo., Dec. 23 -- The Atomic Energy Commission and the American Cyanamid Company in a joint announcement disclosed today construction was under way here on a pilot plant to demonstrate new and cheaper methods of extracting uranium from ore.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 (AP) -- Dominick Vita, chief alcohol and tobacco tax inspector at Newark, N. J., was back at his job today after winning a fourteen-month fight against dismissal.

ADELAIDE, Australia, Dec. 23 (AP) -- America's tennis hopefuls finally have reached the end of their long trip into nowhere and have settled down for their last hard practices before facing the Australians in the challenge round for the Davis cup starting next Monday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 23 -- Although "The Robe" will not go before the cameras until late next month, Twentieth Century-Fox already is plotting a sequel to the Lloyd C. Douglas novel dealing with the birth of Christianity.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Dec. 23 -- The growing interest and concern of child development specialists in education and recreation programs for children and youth confined to hospitals is indicated by a nationwide project undertaken recently to determine the extent of existing programs and to stimulate the development of others.

The plight of ten thousand European refugees in Communist China calls for prompt attention. About half this number were maintained by I. R. O., which turned over to the High Commissioner for Refugees of the United Nations enough money to continue their maintenance temporarily.

ROME, Dec. 23 -- Italian sources said today the twenty-six Italian fishing vessels seized by the Yugoslavs were well outside Yugoslav territorial waters. An alarm was sent by wireless by the seized vessels to hundreds of others to repair hastily to Italian ports.

TRENTON, Dec. 23 -- Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll said today he was "disgusted" by the testimony of former Gov. Harold G. Hoffman before the New York State Crime Commission last week and that he had asked State Labor Commissioner Percy A. Miller Jr. to get a transcript and confer with him about it.
The Atlantic and Gulf District of the Seafarers International Union, A. F. L., has filed unfair labor practice charges against the Atlantic Refining Company, it was disclosed yesterday.
Andrei A. Gromyko, Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister, about twenty-four other Russians and four or five television picture-tubes sailed aboard the Cunard liner Queen Mary yesterday.

John Powell Co. John Bonuses being paid, by Powell Co., Inc., aggregate $30,-I !000 and range from 4 to 8 per cent [of annual earnings for one to fiveI years' service, respectively. Eraployes who have been with the insecticide and soap concern for as [little as one day share in the distribution, which is being made for! the twenty-second consecutive i ;year.

Plans for remodeling the three-story brownstone house at 222 East Sixty-eighth Street into apartments have been announced in connection with the sale of the property to an investor in a deal negotiated by the Durand Taylor Company, broker.

BONN, Germany, Dec. 23 -- The Social Democratic party appeared to have crushed all hopes of achieving bipartisanship in West German foreign policy for 1953 -- or even a Christmas political truce -- by a violent attack today on Chancellor Konrad Adenauer, his policies and the pending Allied-West German treaty system.
TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 23 (AP) -- Premier Mohammed Mossadegh issued a decree today that would limit the members of all foreign diplomatic and other official missions to one term in Iran.
Two sets of triplets were born within three hours of each other in this city early yesterday, one in Brooklyn and the other in the Bronx.

The proposed 10-cent toll on the Southern State Parkway was protested yesterday by the Automobile Club of New York. The levy was suggested by Robert Moses, president of the Long Island State Park Commission, to help finance a $40,000,000 parkway improvement program in Nassau County.

Michael V. DiSalle, who has just been sworn in as Economic Stabilization Administrator, has asked that the National Association of Manufacturers and the Chamber of Commerce of the United States cooperate in reconstituting the Wage Stabilization Board as a tripartite body by nominating representatives from industry.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 23 -- The United Nations Security Council voted today to ask India and Pakistan to re-open negotiations at once on their dispute over Kashmir in the hope of settling the one basic issue still obstructing agreement.

CORAL GABLES, Fla. Dec. 23 (AP) -- Charlie Burr, a lanky 18-year-old from Arkansas City. Kansas, was the riding star of the card at Tropical Park today as the meeting's top booter completed a triple astride Emerald Hill Stable's Blue Square in the featured Toxophilite Purse before 7,654 fans.
GENEVA, Dec. 23 -- The French Government has proposed a new method under which free nations might, to their mutual advantage, negotiate all-round tariff reductions.

LONDON, Dec. 23 -- An extremely high proportion of Scottish sheepdogs are being slowed down in their tracks by a form of pellagra akin to the disease that has struck portions of the Southern United States, an inquiry here has shown.

KANSAS CITY, Dec. 23 (AP) -- A strong majority of college athletic directors, coaches, athletes and non-athletic students approve of "properly controlled and administered" post-season athletic events. College presidents share that view, with one exception. A majority of the presidents oppose football bowl games.

ALBANY, Dec. 23 -- James R. Macduff, State Commissioner of Motor Vehicles, notified New York City authorities today that permission to place the city auto use tax stamps on car windshields would not be renewed after the May 31 expiration date.

Richard S. Reynolds Jr., president of the Reynolds Metals Company, predicted in a year-end statement yesterday that there will be plenty of aluminum for all who want it before the middle of 1953, unless there is an extension of hostilities.

New York's biggest college basketball crowd of the season last night was treated to the highest scoring duel in nineteen seasons of varsity play at Madison Square Garden and, in the absence of evidence to the contrary, the first college double-century count ever returned on any court in this city.

EAST LANSING, Mich., Dec. 23 -- Michigan State College threw open its campus today for 125 foreign students from forty-five countries, here to participate in a "Christmas adventure in world understanding."

MIAMI, Dec. 23 (AP) -- Both North and South squads completed heavy work today for the Shrine's college All-Star game on Christmas night in the Orange Bowl and the coaches named their starting line-up.

RICHMOND, Va., Dec 23 (AP) -- Silas Rogers, a Miami, Fla., shoeshine boy hoboing his way north, trapped by circumstance in a murder conviction and sentenced to death nine years ago, walked out of the State Penitentiary here today a free man.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 (AP) -The Federal Reserve Board said today 1952 has been a year of swellig credit, with debt growing in every sector of the expanding economy but with savings LucreasLug at the same time.

In the medium that proved highly effective because of its simplicity with "Don Juan in Hell," Tyrone Power, Judith Anderson and Raymond Massey will be starred in "John Brown's Body," arriving Feb. 14 at the Century under the auspices of Paul Gregory, sponsor of "Don Juan."

John J. McCloy, former United States High Commissioner for Germany, was officially named chairman and director of the Chase National Bank yesterday, succeeding Winthrop W. Aldrich, in both posts. Mr. McCloy's election by the bank's board of directors will become effective on Jan. 19, the date of Mr. Aldrich's resignation to become Ambassador to Great Britain.

ANTWERP, Belgium. Dec. 23 (AP) -- The North Atlantic Westbound freight Conference, an association of seven shipping companies handling cargoes from the Continent to North America, met here secretly today to deal with a threatened rate war.

Although it was the Phillies' Robin Roberts and the Dodgers' Joe Black who received most of the pitching accolades when the curtain rang down on the National League's 1952 season, it remained for Hoyt Wilhelm, rookie relief ace of the Giants, to bag the two major mound awards of the year for his circuit.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 (UP) -- Senator Alexander Wiley predicted today that Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower would outline his Korean war plans in a special message to Congress soon after his inauguration on Jan. 20.

The Misses Kathleen and Marcia Connor of 47 East Sixth-fourth Street gave a luncheon yesterday at the Carlton House for their debutante niece, Miss Phoebe Ann Connor, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Hayden Connor of Over-hill, Dairen, Conn.

CHICAGO, Dec. 28 -- All grains were fractionally lower in the early trade today, but declines did not go far, and there was a substantial amount of short profit-taking and general commission buying on the small setbacks. Commission buying in corn was broader.
BERLIN, Dec. 23 -- That Santa Claus speaks all tongues has been borne out in West Berlin by an organization of college students known as Tusma.

A measure calling for a payroll tax of one-half of 1 per cent on city employers, estimated to raise $70,000,000 a year for the city's coffers, was introduced into the City Council yesterday by three Manhattan Democrats, John J. Merli, Robert Weisberger and Earl Brown.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- John Foster Dulles, who will be the next Secretary of State, will receive an opportunity to explain to a special House committee his part in the selection of Alger Hiss as president of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace.

BOSTON, Dec. 23 -- The discussion of "any aspect" of cases being heard in closed sessions of the Federal District Court at Boston was forbidden today by Judge William T. McCarthy in a warning to attorneys and other persons involved

VANCOUVER, Dec. 23 (Canadian Press) -- Canadian officials of a large American brewery said yesterday they have rejected a $25,000,000 offer to sell its three California and Washington plants to Schlitz of Milwaukee, world's biggest brewery concern.

In your editorial of Dec. 18 on the report of the Loyalty Review Board in respect of John Carter Vincent you refer to the board's reference to Vincent's "studied praise of Chinese Communists and equally studied criticism of the Chiang Kai-shek Government throughout a period when it was the declared and established policy of the Government of the United States to support Chiang Kai-shek's Government."

PARIS, Dec. 23 -- President Vincent Auriol announced today that he had accepted the resignation of Premier Antoine Pinay, who chose to retire rather than give way on some aspects of his financial program and go on fighting for the stability of the franc without a sure majority in the National Assembly.

One week from today the contracts between major privately owned bus lines and the Transport Workers Union expire and bus drivers will be free to strike on New Year's Day. Persons close to the situation described it variously yesterday as "very black," "serious," "hopelessly deadlocked."

SEOUL, Korea, Dec. 23 (UP) -- A hospital plane flown by the Greek Air Force and loaded with United States battle casualties collided on the ground last night with a jet plane, killing fourteen persons, the Fifth Air Force disclosed today.

John Giragosian, 27 years old, of Shrewsbury, Mass., who was captured in the Bronx early Sunday morning when he allegedly tried to hold up an off-duty fireman, was indicted by a Bronx grand jury yesterday on charges of attempted robbery, attempted grand larceny, assault and violation of the Sullivan Law.

Chances of averting a New Year's Day bus strike were set back yesterday when Federal Judge Irving R. Kaufman warned that he would order liquidation of the bankrupt Third Avenue Transit Corporation rather than allow it to grant a forty-hour work-week without a higher fare.

The position of the Mizrachi, or general religious party, in the face of the Israeli coalition government, in which it will not take part, was outlined last night by Rabbi Max Kirshblum, president of the Mizrachi Organization of America.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 (UP) -- Senator A. S. Mike Monroney, Democrat of Oklahoma, challenged the new Republican-controlled Congress today to renew the Reciprocal Trade Act or risk throwing the European economy "into a tailspin."

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Dec. 18 -- The task of modernizing backward Ethiopia devolves primarily on Emperor Haile Selassie. He still is an absolute monarch, temporal and spiritual, with powers of life and death.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Dec. 23 -- A cornucopia of books published in the United States is pouring into Israel this winter. If one goes into any of the scores of bookstores in Tel Aviv, Jerusalem or Haifa one will find a happy throng buying up stacks of brightly bound American books of every description, from inexpensive pocket editions to weighty encyclopedias.

PISCATAWAY TOWNSHIP, N. J., Wednesday, Dec. 24 -- The death toll rose to four today in the explosion and flash fire Tuesday at the Bakelite plant of the Union Carbide and Carbon Corporation in River Road.

An undeveloped tract of about 250 acres on New Mill Road in Smithtown, L. I., has been sold by Carlyle F. and Harriet S. Hodgkinson of Smithtown Branch to an investment group represented by Friedman, Glick Wachtel, attorneys.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 23 -- The high command of the Eisenhower Administration has worked out a new strategic plan for the conduct of the Korean war that, it believes, will exert so much pressure on the Communist forces that the Soviet Union will agree to an armistice.

A "new approach" should be taken to the long-pending Customs Simplification Bill under the new Administration, with greater emphasis given elimination of red tape hampering import trade, it was urged yesterday by Harry S. Radcliffe, executive vice president of the National Council of American Importers.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 23 -- The Yugoslav Coast Guard has seized twenty-six Italian fishing vessels in the Adriatic Sea, Borba, official Communist party newspaper, reported today.
