WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- The Truman and Wallace families already have started gathering for their first White House Christmas since 1947.

The stock market ran into a flurry of late selling yesterday that caused a moderate unsettlement in the price structure. The railroads provided the early support for the share list but when this group encountered some difficulty late in the afternoon session, quotations sagged all along the line.

MADRID, Dec. 23 -- The Vatican was understood today to have instructed Enrique Cardinal Pla y Deniel, Spanish primate, to accept proposed amendments to a bill to reform high school education in Spain.

Reichhold Chemicals, Inc., has gone into large-scale production of formaldehyde and is turning out the vital chemical at the rate of 50,000,000 pounds a year. Herbert W. Mason, vice president in charge of purchasing, disclosed yesterday.
TAMPA, Fla., Dec. 23 -- Columbia's lanky Lions riddled Georgia's zone defense for three periods and then held on against a late Bulldog rally to post a 61-to-51 basketball victory tonight.

Commodity futures trading continued slow on the New York exchanges yesterday, with most activity shown in soybean and cottonseed oils. Prices closed generally higher with increases in coffee, wool, cottonseed and soybean oils, tin and zinc. Hides and cocoa were lower and rubber, potatoes and sugar ended mixed. Lead was unchanged.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture predicted today that exports of American cotton may decline more than 25 per cent this marketing year, largely because of sharper competition in world markets.

Alphonse A. (Blackie) Amato, 31 years old, of 78 Windfield Avenue, Grassmere, S. I., was found guilty of contempt of court yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Felix C. Benvenga for refusing to testify before the special grand jury investigating organized crime and official corruption on Staten Island.

For its latest novelty, the New York City Ballet at the City Center last night gave us its own version of Jerome Robbins' "Interplay," set to the music of Morton Gould's "American Concertette," and danced for the last seven years by Ballet Theatre. Not only danced by Ballet Theatre, as a matter of fact, but generally quite admirably danced.

The uptrend in savings deposits held by the nation's 529 mutual savings banks was continued during November, with regular deposits advancing $155,000,000 during the month, against $126,000,000 a year before. According to data issued yesterday by the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks the advance was the largest recorded for any November since compilation of the association's figures began in 1947.

The wanton bombing early yesterday of a crowded bar on the upper West Side was attributed to group intolerance in a statement issued last night by the chairmen of the League of West Side Organizations.

WILKES-BARRE, Pa., Dec. 23 -- Charging that a Nanticoke banker, now deceased, used inside information to make a profit, Fletcher C. Booker, investment broker, filed a suit in equity at the Luzerne County Courthouse today to have the sale of 144 shares of Nanticoke National Bank stock voided and ownership restored to him.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 23 -- The Perricone quadruplets arrived today from Korea, headed for Texas and the happy change from tank riding to home on the plains.

The Woodmore Realty Corporation, of which Isidore Batwin is president, has sold the six - story forty - one - family apartment house at 101 Woodruff Avenue, Brooklyn, to the Managed Realty Corporation, headed by Murray Faeber. The Lawyers Mortgage and Title Company insured title to the property, which occupies a plot about 87 by 100 feet and is assessed at $155,000.

The fall of Antoine Pinay's Government in France had become almost inevitable. This is hindsight, but it is nevertheless true that the centrifugal tendencies of French politics have been working for weeks, and a crisis could only have been postponed. It is an unhappy but inescapable fact that in the present stage of French history political crises are unavoidable.

Hundreds of donors to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund accompanied their contributions with illuminating letters. Gifts were received from residents of many states, including Florida, Texas and California, while one came from the Province of Quebec, Canada.

As a result of an error in transmission, the Democratic campaign expenses in Mississippi were incorrectly reported as $200,000 in a country-wide survey of campaign costs published in THE NEW YORK TIMES on Dec. 1. Actually, the figure, which was attributed to Gov. Hugh White, should have been $20,000, according to THE TIMES' correspondent at Jackson, Miss.

LONDON, Dec. 23 -- Reports from Warsaw today said that five Roman Catholic church officials had been arrested with the Archbishop of Cracow, Eugenisz Baziak. The reports added that gold and foreign currency, including $35,700 in United States notes had been found in the palace of the Archbishop, who is charged with espionage and subversive activities.

MOSES LAKE, Wash., Dec. 23 (AP) -- As the toll in Saturday's C-124 crash here rose to eighty-seven today, the Air Force announced that a preliminary inquiry had failed to disclose the cause of the disaster, the worst in aviation history.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 23 (UP) -- Jim Psaltis, star defensive halfback of the University of Southern California, today was ruled ineligible to compete in intercollegiate football by conference vote, H. C. Willett, U. S. C. faculty athletic representative, disclosed.
Four hold-ups were staged in various sections of Brooklyn yesterday and the thieves escaped with a total of $5,033 in cash and jewelry. One of the robbery jobs was done by two women.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 23 -Nearly one-half cent a pound, which will be passed on to foreign consumers, has been added to the production cost of coffee by the creation of a new "Brazilian Coffee Institute," approval of which by President Vargas was announced today.

Alexis Lichine, wine authority, is back from one of his many trips to France with news of the 1952 vintage. The only American to own a vineyard in Bungundy and among the few to have holdings in Bordeaux, he is a competent reporter on what is happening to the grape in the most wine-minded nation in the world.
Eighty-six Sanitation Department employes were promoted yesterday by Commissioner Andrew W. Mulrain.

When the Cunard liner Queen Mary departed yesterday for Europe, she carried what was said to be the largest load of fuel oil ever pumped aboard a passenger liner in New York Harbor in peace time. Four barges of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) began loading almost 8,500 tons of oil into the giant vessel's tanks right after she docked on Sunday.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- Motor carriers operating in the Middle Atlantic states today proposed increased rates which they said would not be opposed by shippers.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 (AP) -- Secretary of Agriculture Charles F. Brannan today announced the Government's farm production goals for 1953 -- a program calling for an output of crops at least equal to this year's record volume.

CHICAGO, Dec. 23 -- The American Federation of Radio Artists and the Television Authority, talent unions, called strikes today at WGN, WGN-TV and WLS. Executives and supervisory personnel stepped in as announcers and talent, enabling all stations to remain on the air with regular or substitute programs.

LONDON, Dec. 23 -- Spokesmen for airline crews and marine officers expressed concern today over the new United States immigration laws. D. Follows, secretary of the British Air Line Pilots Association, said the members of his group felt that air crews' visas should be sufficient for entry, especially considering "what they [United States immigration officers] put our chaps through" to get them.

Today's news is no better than yesterday's. The General Assembly of the United Nations adjourned a frustrating session on a note of angry recrimination. The fall of the Pinay Cabinet ended nearly a year of unusual stability and portends another political crisis in France. Signs of nervous tension are reported in nearly every foreign capital, from Bonn to New Delhi, from Rome to Teheran.

HEADQUARTERS, Eighth Army in Korea, Dec. 23 -- Venereal disease, which has plagued fighting armies for centuries, has almost been beaten in the Eighth Army. In the three-month period ended in October, only one soldier in the command was hospitalized because of venereal infection.

NEWARK, Dec. 23 -- Mayor Ralph A. Villani at a meeting of the City Commission today closed a sharp criticism of the Board of Education with a request for the resignations of the nine men and women constituting the board.

COLUMBIA, S. C., Dec. 23 -- An interracial conference of representatives from throughout the South on "youth and racial unity through educational opportunity" will be held on the campus of Allen University here on Dec. 29, 30 and 31, the Southern Conference Educational Fund, Inc., has announced.

Most of us have known at one time or another the painful emotion of fear. It strikes in diverse forms, varying in degree. As children perhaps we were afraid of the dark, or feared punishment when we misbehaved. Collectively, as a nation, we fear danger or, worse, anticipate danger.

An offer to buy 100,000 shares of the Security Banknote Company's common stock at $4.50 a share was made yesterday by a new stockholders' protective committee, according to Arthur N. Pierson Jr., chairman of the group, who said it owns and represents "more than 140,000 shares."

Returning yesterday from an inspection tour of American installations in Europe, North Africa and the Near East, Senator Olin D. Johnston, Democrat of South Carolina, urged a 50 per cent cut in the next twelve months among the 250,000 Americans and foreigners employed by the United States Government abroad.
TOKYO, Wednesday, Dec. 24 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,473, for the twenty-four hours ended at 6 A. M. Tuesday, Korean time:
Futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed steady yesterday and 15 points higher to 5 points lower than on Monday.

An unusually large amount of railroad financing is scheduled for early in 1953. The New York, Chicago and St. Louis (Nickel Plate) Railroad has made plans to sell $10,000,000 of its refunding mortgage bonds at competitive bidding early in the year. Part of the proceeds will be used to retire, in advance of maturity, a collaterally secured note of $2,250,000 and the remainder will be added to working capital.

Schenley Industries, Inc. reported yesterday for the three months ended on Nov. 30, first quarter of its 1953 fiscal year, net earnings of $3,997,300, equal to 91 cents a share on 4,363,726 common shares outstanding.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 23 -- By 6:30 P. M. today the last survivors were being taken off the wreck of the Champollion, the 12,500-ton French cruising vessel that had broken in two on a sand bar three miles south of Beirut. Fifteen persons had died in the effort to reach shore.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 (UP) -- Farmers and foresters find that the Christmas tree not only is a fine holiday custom but a $20,000,000-a-year business.

It is a jarring reflection in the Christmas season that thanks to the building trades unions the soldiers manning anti-aircraft defense batteries in this area are being deprived of maximum protection from wintry blasts. Instead of living in comparatively comfortable metal and plywood prefabricated huts, these men are living either in canvas squad tents, such as those used in Korea, or in arctic-type canvas Jamesway huts, a grade better but not up to the prefabs.
MIAMI, Dec. 24 (AP) -- Two squads of senior college football stars will match speed, brawn and brains in the Orange Bowl tomorrow night in the Shrine's annual North-South gridiron contest.

MANILA, Dec. 24 -- Terminating a round of conferences on Japanese reparations with special diplomatic representatives from Tokyo, the Philippine Government indicated today that progress had been made toward some sort of agreement that could lead eventually to ratification of the Japanese peace treaty by the Philippine Senate.

BETHLEHEM, Dec. 24 -- The silver bells of the Church of the Nativity here in Bethlehem, proclaiming another anniversary of the birth of Christ, have been heeded for a little while in both Moslem Jordan and Jewish Israel. For five days, ending Saturday, Christians are being allowed to travel back and forth across the border almost as though peace had been restored.

The Board of National Missions of the Presbyterian Church in the U. S. A., 156 Fifth Avenue, announced yesterday that the Rev. Dr. Louis Hadley Evans, pastor of the First Presbyterian Church, Hollywood, Calif., had resigned to become minister at large of the board, a newly created post. He will assume his duties March 1.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- During the period ended Dec. 23, member bank reserves decreased $148,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
A surge of generosity near Christmas Eve from donors who wished a happier future for the less fortunate set a new record for a Christmas Day total in the annual New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.
HONG KONG, Dec. 24 -- Christmas Eve brought a faint hope to passportless Michael Patrick O'Brien that his endless shuttling on the Hong Kong-Macao ferryboat might yet be terminated.
LONDON, Dec. 24 -- Details of the cuts made by the North Atlantic Council last week in Gen. Matthey B. Ridgway's two-year military building program were made known today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- The Senator was busily directing the removal of his official and personal gear from his large suite in the Senate Office Building to a small two-room pair when this department called to wish him a Merry Christmas. His reign as a mighty chairman was over -- for two years at least -- and the occasion was a fit one for melancholy.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- The United States used a newspaper editorial to indicate to India its annoyance with the conduct here of V. K. Krishna Menon, an Indian delegate to the United Nations who recently sponsored a plan for a truce in Korea.

An increase last week of 1,435,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end they amounted to 131,017,000 barrels, compared with 129,582,000 a week earlier and 128,145,000 a year ago.

A constructive move in the direction of lowering production costs is being made in connection with the forthcoming Tennessee Williams play, "Camino Real," due on Broadway in March. Both the author and Elia Kazan, who will stage the offering, have agreed to minimum royalties.

HONG KONG, Dec. 24 -- The Chinese Communists have invited three Japanese organizations to send a five-member delegation to Peiping to discuss, the repatriation from China of stranded Japanese "residents'" who "voluntarily wish to go back to their homeland."
The heavily burdened mailman had an extra bag full of children's letters and donations to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund yesterday on the Eve of Christmas.
Holiday travel to and from the city reached its peak yesterday and last night with a reported heavy but smooth flow on all major transportation facilities, and without major mishaps.

PARIS, Dec. 24 -- Guy Mollet, secretary general of the French Socialist party, declined today to accept President Vincent Auriol's proposal that he try to form a Cabinet to replace the Right-Center government of Antoine Pinay.

CHICAGO, Dec. 24 -- Sears, Roebuck Co., mail order and retail concern of Chicago, announced today that its 1953 midwinter sale catalogue, in which prices of all merchandise lines are cut an average of 9 per cent, is being distributed to its customers throughout the country this week. Price cuts range to as much as 50 per cent.

Three hold-up men, temporarily more familiar with payroll details than the plant superintendent, escaped with $12,000 at 10 A. M. yesterday from the Concord Supplies and Equipment .Corporation at 617 Brooklyn Avenue Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- Dr. Charles Greeley Abbot of the Smithsonian Institution, who has been batting a thousand on weather predictions for Presidential inaugurations, said today indications were for "rain or snow" when Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower takes the oath Jan. 20.
CHICAGO, Dec 21 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- The resignation of John Forney Rudy as director of public relations of the National Federation of American Shipping was announced here today, effective Jan. 15.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 (AP) -The Senate Elections subcommittee was reported today to have reached virtual agreement on a report sharply critical of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, and much less critical of his political opponent, Senator William Benton, Democrat of Connecticut.

First place in the eastern division of the National Basketball Association gull be at stake tonight when the Knickerbockers clash with the Boston Celtics at Madison Square Garden. The teams are deadlocked for the leadership with seventeen victories and eight defeats apiece.

We use the phrase "Merry Christmas" as an automatic greeting today and probably do not think of the word as having any especial meaning. Indeed, the usual modern connotation of "merry" may be far from what we are thinking and feeling. The word comes into our usage from an older period in English when it conveyed a larger sense of well-being, of repose, of good temper and of warmth of heart.

A Brooklyn mail carrier who had been hired for the Christmas rush was arrested yesterday for destroying or throwing away letters he was assigned to deliver. He said his bag was too heavy and that he was confused at the amount of mail he was directed to deliver on his temporary route in the Bushwick section.

ROME, Dec. 24 -- In a Christmas message to the world, in which he sharply criticized both capitalism, as exemplified by the United States, and communism, as exemplified by the Soviet Union, Pope Pius appealed today for greater solidarity and a more human conception of relations between man and man and between nation and nation.
Carols, pageantry and instrumental mental music were on the Christmas program of churches yesterday afternoon and evening, opening celebrations of the anniversary of the birth of Christ.

The stern facade of New York presents a gay appearance to passers-by this morning, its residences vying with the store and municipal holiday displays. The houses and apartments, although not so glitteringly decorated as the stores, have a simplicity and charm that recalls the small towns from which many New Yorkers have come.

CHICAGO, Dec. 24 (AP) -- Tension eased this Christmas Eve in the hospital children's ward where the 15-month-old Brodie twins rounded out their first week as separate individuals. Officially, their condition was listed as still unchanged -- Rodney Dee, critical, and Roger Lee, very precarious.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today gave notice of its intention to hold hearings on the reorganization of the Missouri Pacific Railroad to determine if changed conditions since it approved a plan in 1949 make necessary alterations in that plan.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 (UP) -The Wage Stabilization Committee cut 10 cents from a 30-cent hourly pay rise for 2,800 truck drivers in the St. Louis, Mo., area today but put off an action on a wage increase for 21,600 shipbuilding employes in East Coast shipyards.

THE first gun "of his very own" is a memorable event in the life of every boy, and this morning will find thousands of these events entering the initial stage, for that long package under the tree can provide one of two things -- countless hours of pleasure, or stark tragedy.

BONN, Germany, Dec. 24 -- The offices of the United States, British and French High Commissioners are discussing the advisability of removing or further relaxing more basic industrial controls on the ground that their continued existence prevents West Germany from making an effective contribution to the Western defense effort.

Fireworks that may rock New Jersey's political structure were foreshadowed yesterday by an announcement from Mayor John V. Kenny of Jersey City that he would appear Monday before the state's Law Enforcement Council with a battery of lawyers and would "be prepared."

SEOUL, Korea, Dec. 24 (AP) -Francis Cardinal Spellman, spending his second successive Christmas in the place "where I am happiest at Christmas time," celebrated mass and visited hospitals and troops at the front today.

Jewelers, policemen and persons of numerous other callings stepped out of their everyday roles yesterday to help brighten Christmas Eve for thousands of children and grown-ups. The story of the success of the various volunteer Santas could be read in the smiling faces of boys and girls, of service men and women, of hospital patients, and of passers-by.

For the past week your newspaper columns have been full of the cheerfulness and the colorful pageantry of Christmas. I should like to call your attention to another aspect of the holiday: "Christmas in the dark."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- President Truman, in a Christmas message to the nation today, called on the people to pray for the troops in Korea, and to pray also that the spirit of God shall enter the lives of this country's enemies and "prevail in their lands."

It is not alone in this country that people are celebrating the feast of the Nativity with special fervor and festivity. Reports from Rome and Paris, London and Madrid, note that in less opulent lands this is the best Christmas since the war. The shops are full of goods, the hurrying crowds are gay and friendly, the windows of millions of homes are as bright as ours with holly wreaths and shining candles.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Dec. 24 -- The Foreign Ministry announced today the arrest on espionage charges of Lev Constantinovitch Pissarev, Russian correspondent in the Netherlands of Tass, Soviet official news agency.

Again we celebrate the season of hope for peace on earth. "Everywhere," as John Foster Dulles recently observed to the National Council of Churches, "there is revulsion against the death, the misery, the starvation of body and soul which recurrent war and economic disorder now wreak upon men."

The Dodgers not only were the best fielding team in the National League last summer, but also tied one record and broke another, according to the official 1952 fielding averages released for publication today. On top of that the champions stalked off with two individual titles.

" The Right Playmate," a novel by James Broughton, has been scheduled for February publication by Farrar, Straus Young. Illustrated with drawings by Gerard Hoffnung, the story deals with a little boy's search for the right playmate at his mother's insistence, the search proving to be harder than it seemed.
The family of Benjamin De Stefano received a visit yesterday from Santa Claus, who brought gifts for the triplets born last Tuesday, and for the unemployed longshoreman's seven other children.

Christmas as Reported a Century Ago Whatever its other claims to completeness, and they were well justified, the new-born NEW YORK TIMES of a century ago certainly gave scant news of the celebration of Christmas, in the world or in New York City. The reason was, perhaps, that the editor felt that the modern observance was so poor a thing.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, DEC. 24 -- This is a gloomy Christmas for Swedes. Inflation, high taxes, credit restrictions and a record low stock market have drastically reduced purchasing power. The result has been a Christmas shopping turnover estimated to be only half of last year's.

SAN JUAN, Dec. 24 -- Representative Adam C. Powell Jr., Democrat of New York, gave reporters here a suggested solution to the islan's sugar problem today. The plan was reached after eight days of study of the situation undertaken at the request of the House Labor Committee, in the course of which he conferred with Governor Munoz Marin, heads of three local banks, managers of important sugar companies and C. I. O. organizers.

The Spanish-American War would probably not have been fought if two United States Senators had not dawdled over approval of an ultimatum that Spain was ready to accept, according to a passage in the autobiography of the late George B. McClellan, former Mayor of New York.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- Robert Virgil Fletcher, 83 years old, special counsel of the Association of American Railroads who said he was "too busy" to retire at the age of 70, finally will get around to it next Wednesday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 24 -"The Mountains Have No Shadows," a novel by Owen Cameron, has been purchased for filming by Alex Gottlieb, the independent producer, and will be the third of the five pictures he recently contracted to release through Warner Brothers.

A new radio program featuring young musicians will be presented by the National Broadcasting Company network in cooperation with the National Federation of Music Clubs beginning Sunday, Jan. 4, from 3:15 to 3:30 P. M. Entitled "Youth Brings You Music," the program will present both instrumentalists and vocalists, all non-professionals.

Police Commissioner George P. Monaghan yesterday ordered the biggest shake-up he has made since taking office a year and a half ago. He transferred nineteen high officers "for the good of the service" and promoted ninety-nine others of all ranks, with warm praise for the department as a whole.

A "plowing back" of earnings of American business into plant expansion and improvement, along with other favorable factors, indicates good business in 1953, in the view of James P. Fordyce, president of the New York Board of Trade, Inc.
Recent archaeological digging has shed new light on the site in Athens where some of the forms of political democracy were first tested five centuries before the start of the Christian era.

A new project has been initiated by the Advertising Research Foundation. Known as the "Buying Habits Study," it will be under the direction of a special committee headed by Robert M. Gray, advertising and sales promotion manager of the Esso Standard Oil Company.

Benjamin G. Browdy, former president of the Zionist Organization of America, called upon the organization yesterday to rescind "its resolution of identification" with the General Zionist party in Israel.
TOKYO, Thursday, Dec. 25 (AP) -United Nations Command communique 1,474, for the twenty-four hours ended at 6 A. M. Wednesday, Korean time:

On Christmas morning, by pleasant custom, we make an interim report on our stewardship of gifts to THE TIMES Neediest Cases Fund. In this forty-first annual appeal the response has been most gratifying: $316,285.80 has been contributed and the number of gifts is 8,469.
LONDON, Dec. 24 (Reuters) -The 2,041-ton Panamanian freighter Virginia today joined the ranks of distressed ships hammered by the pre-Christmas storms around the British coasts.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 (UP) -Senator John J. Sparkman of Alabama urged his fellow Democrats today to recognize Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois as head of the party even though the Democratic record for the next four years "will be made in Congress."

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 24 -- Mr. Menon handled India's part in the public debate and private negotiations on Korea during the first half of the Seventh Session of the General Assembly. For weeks, he was the most-discussed delegate at the United Nations and held conferences with the major diplomats of the West and of the Soviet bloc.
VIENNA, Dec. 24 -- Christmas has been almost completely Russianized this year in the People's Democracies of Eastern Europe.
HANOI, Vietnam, Indo-China, Dec. 24 -- French forces launched a major clean-up attack today against a strong Vietnam redoubt in the south delta area below the Roman Catholic center of Buichu.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- The Office of Price Stabilization, rejecting a contention by Safeway Stores, Inc., refused today to decontrol a long list of food items, including baby foods containing meat, jams and jellies, soups, wine and hard cider.

NEWARK, Dec. 24 -- Six of the nine members of the Board of Education who were asked yesterday to resign by Mayor Ralph A. Villani issued a statement today defying the executive and proclaiming their intention of "remaining free from political control."

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 24 -- United Nations circles expressed special interest tonight in the portion of Premier Stalin's statement in which he said he favored diplomatic conversations leading to a settlement of the Korean war.

ADELAIDE, Dec. 24 (AP) -- This was the day before Christmas, but it meant another day of toil under the burning sun for members of the American and Australian Davis Cup teams preparing for the challenge round starting Monday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Dec. 27, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 (UP) -The House Armed Services Committee will open hearings Jan. 8 on the world military situation with special emphasis on the deadlocked Korean war, Representative Dewey Short announced today.

A proposed campaign to encourage increased imports will place emphasis on finished manufactured commodities, specialized foodstuffs including luxuries and beverages, according to trade reports here yesterday.
ROME, Dec. 24 (AP) -- Excerpts from the Vatican's English translation of the Pope's Christmas message to the world follow:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- The State Department announced today that the British Government had delivered a second note protesting new regulations for the screening of foreign seamen as required by the McCarran-Walter Immigration and Nationality Act.

If Father Knickerbocker -- the composite New Yorker -- can be imagined as passing out Christmas greetings today, we would not want him to forget a certain number of men and women who came from all over the world to make this past year happier for us.

LONDON, Dec. 24 -- The United States will soon place a large order for military aircraft among its European allies, an even larger order than the recent $90,000,000 contract for British Centurion tanks.

The new plans announced by Robert Moses' Committee on Slum Clearance for a comprehensive redevelopment of a large blighted area adjacent to Fort Greene Park in Brooklyn, almost in the shadow of the Manhattan Bridge, may well be expected to revolutionize the appearance of an important and busy section of the borough's downtown area.
Six new films are the Christmas day offerings at first run theatres.
BOSTON, Dec. 24 (AP) -- The Weather Bureau today issued the following forecasts and lists of winter sports conditions:

J. L. Green has leased the one-story building at 431 Broadway, Brooklyn, from H. Goody Sons and will use it for the warehousing and distribution of steel. The Kalmon Dolgin Company, broker in this transaction, also reported the leasing of the ground flour comprising 6,500 square feet at 32 Lexington Avenue for the Tafenclark Realty Company to the Holbrook Hardware Corporation for the manufacture of hardware.
LONDON, Dec. 18 -- The approaching coronation of Queen Elizabeth has caused many regulations to be issued concerning the robes and headdresses which will be worn by those attending the ceremonies.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- Robert A. Lovett, Secretary of Defense, denied today that there had been any "dragging of feet" in the failure of North Atlantic Treaty Organization nations to produce their annual year-end report at the North Atlantic Council meeting in Paris earlier this month.

ALBANY, Dec. 24 -- The State Banking Department announced today that the Capital Finance Corporation, 96 Springfield Boulevard, Queens Village, Queens, had received approval to move its place of business from 113 Broadway, Hicksville, L. I., to 7 West Marie Street, Hicksville.

LONDON, Dec. 24 -- United States service men away from home will eat splendidly in military messes on Christmas Day, but the average mess sergeant is not a substitute for a family. Some hundreds of the American soldiers here, more curious and perhaps bolder than the rest, will avail themselves of generous British hospitality to learn something about Christmas in a foreign land.

A GOOD volume to have at hand these days is "Fireside Book of Favorite American Songs"* -- particularly if the singing around you has been a shade ragged so far and you hope to bring the level of harmony up by New Year's.
Robert Delson in THE TIMES of Dec. 17 chides you for saying in your editorial on Iranian oil that the purchaser of the oil runs considerable legal risk.
The rise in retail sales of women's apparel for Christmas has been reflected in an upswing of production in New York's wholesale markets, it was pointed out yesterday.

The Vanadium-Alloys Steel Company of Latrobe, Pa., has purchased Murray Steels, Ltd., of Toronto, Canada, and will be reorganized under the name of Vanadium - Alloys Steel Canada, Ltd., Roy C. McKenna, board chairman of Vanadium, announced yesterday.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 24 -While housewives were complaining bitterly of holiday profiteering and record high prices, merchants reported today that this Christmas season was proving the busiest Brazil had ever seen.

Corliss Lamont, lecturer in philosophy at Columbia University, denied yesterday that he had ever been a member of the Communist party as Louis F. Budenz, a former Communist, testified on Tuesday before a special House investigating committee.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 24 -- A 52-year-old woman was arrested today while trying to rob a bank in suburban Arcadia with a toy gun. The police said she was the "Grandma" bandit, the elderly, sweet-faced, beshawled woman who held up several banks recently.

MEXICO CITY, Dec. 24 -- Although the new Administration of President Adolfo Ruiz Cortines has made no official announcement, the United States has received semi-official assurances that Mexico will uphold the migratory farm worker [Bracero] agreement entered into by the previous admiinstration of Miguel Aleman.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 (UP) -The Army established a uniform system today governing the promotion of reserve officers who are not on active duty.

AND how did Santa Claus treat you? Very well, it is to be hoped. Perhaps you may be wondering what "the jolly, old elf" brought the folks in sports. Nothing that follows is guaranteed but it may give you an approximation of gifts which tumbled out of his sack.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 24 (AP) -- The French Embassy said tonight the death toll in the Champollion disaster was sixteen. The French liner was carrying pilgrims to the Holy Land. The Lebanese Security Department earlier had reported a higher toll of twenty-seven.

The Board of Estimate was called yesterday to an emergency meeting tomorrow to grapple with the threat of a New Year's Day strike on bus lines that carry 3,500,000 riders a day in Manhattan, the Bronx, Queens and lower Westchester.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- Gen. James A. Van Fleet, commander of the Eighth Army in Korea, will be continued in active service beyond Jan. 31, the date on which he would be nominally due for retirement. He will remain in his present assignment, Frank Pace, Secretary of the Army, announced today.

Your recent editorial entitled "Paradise Postponed" states that this "is the apt label for the Soviet Union suggested by Admiral Alan G. Kirk, director of the Psychological Strategy Board * * *." It further states, "the task of Admiral Kirk's group, and of other related agencies in the Government, is to provide the most effective answers to, and exposures of, Communist propaganda * * *.

TANGIER, Dec. 21 -- France has brought impressive social and economic progress to her North African protectorates -- the French, the Arabs and neutrals are in accord on this -- but there is almost total disagreement on the question of whether the benefits have been equitably distributed and on the future course for the area.
Trading on the New York Cotton Exchange was quiet yesterday, and closing prices for active months were 4 to 13 points net higher than on Tuesday.
One of the smaller independent, privately owned utility enterprises in the United States will mark its one-hundredth anniversary of gas service to the community of Nyack, N. Y., tomorrow.

WOODBURY, N. J., Dec. 24 -- A pretty brown-eyed girl has been lying at Underwood Hospital since last June unable to remember a single event of her life prior to the auto accident in which her skull was fractured.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 24 -President Juan Peron denied today that he was planning any important changes in his Government. He declared that reports that Argentina's former economic czar, Miguel Miranda, would return to administer the country's second five-year plan were untrue.

OAKLAND, Calif., Dec. 24 -Fifteen Japanese airmen are being trained at the Taloa Academy of Aeronautics at Oakland Airport here to man the airliners in Japan's projected entry of the international air transportation field, Herbert A. Webb, director of the academy, said today.

ALBANY, Dec. 24 (AP) -- There will be special religious observances, Christmas trees, movies and turkey tomorrow for most of the 17,850 inmates within New York State's prisons and allied institutions.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 (AP) -The Federal Security Agency announced today that state-Federal public assistance payments cost $2,168,000,000 during the year ended last June 30.
DENVER, Dec. 24 -- A taciturn young New Yorker, who had not even ridden a horse five years ago, today was named world champion cowboy of 1952.
NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 24 (AP) -Louisiana's Civil Air Patrol will begin an air search tomorrow from Texas to Mississippi for two New York men reported missing in a single-engine private plane.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 24 (AP) -- Jockey Tony DeSpirito, the nation's leading rider, celebrated his eighteenth birthday today by returning to the saddle and bringing in three winners in five races at Tropical Park to run his score to 373 for the year.

All stock and commodity exchanges in North and South America, Europe and many other places around the world will be closed today. Tomorrow British markets will be closed for Boxing Day as well but trading centers elsewhere -- save for those in sugar futures -- will be open.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 24 -Citizenship applications have been received from more than 500 local alien Japanese under the new McCarran Immigration and Nationality Act, which went into effect today, it was reported by Herman R. Landon, district director of immigration.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 (AP) Senator William Langer, Republican of North Dakota, predicted today that an attempt might be made to keep him out of the Senate, but, he asserted, "it will fail."
AT THE KOREAN FRONT, Dec. 24 -- Christmas Eve is being observed here tonight in bunkers and on forward ridge lines in an atmosphere of melancholy that is almost heartbreaking.

MANILA, Dec. 24 -- Fear is growing among Filipinos that the 1953 national elections will be accompanied by fraud and violence that could wreck Philippine democracy, disrupt national unity and undermine suppression of the Communist-led Hukbalahap rebellion.

CHICAGO, Dec. 24 -- Many new faces and voices are being seen and heard by the public since radio and television artists' unions called a strike against WGN, Inc., and its stations WGN, WGN-TV and WGNB, and WLS, Executive and supervisory personnel and other employes of the stations have taken the places of union members since the walkout was called yesterday at 6 A. M.

TOKYO, Thursday, Dec. 25 -Red China's air force sent its Russian-designed MIG's south of the Manchurian border in force yesterday and two of them were probably destroyed and nine others were damaged by United States Sabrejets patrolling over northwest Korea.
Three German and three Turkish runners and hurdlers will invade the United States this winter, the Amateur Athletic Union announced yesterday.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 24 (AP) -- College football stars who will clash Saturday in the twentyeighth annual East-West game for the crippled children's hospital raced through strenuous workouts today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- The Air Force reported today that the crash of a C-124 transport last Saturday at Moses Lake, Wash., with 86 dead, had resulted from failure to unlock control mechanisms before the take-off.
WALLA WALLA, Wash., Dec. 24 (AP) -- Four of seven escaped Washington State Prison inmates were reported seized without resistance in two pick-ups within twelve hours today.

That Christmas -- with small children in the house -- is not always a day of unremitting laughter and joy is a fact well known to parents but all too frequently forgotten from one year to the next. Recommendations for getting full pleasure from the occasion have come this week from a university professor, a safety organization and the head of one of the country's largest educational toy concerns.

The National Labor Relations Board called on warring American Federation of Labor unions yesterday to end a jurisdictional dispute that has impeded work on an atomic submarine project in a General Electric plant near Schenectady.
An appeal for volunteer blood donors to fill an emergency request for a shipment of whole blood to Korea was issued yesterday by the New York Regional Blood Program.
LONDON, Dec. 24 -- The general tone of the stock markets was firm today despite the Christmas Eve contraction in business. The Stock Exchange will reopen on Monday.
BOSTON, Dec. 24 -- The Most Rev. Richard J. Cushing, Roman Catholic Archbishop of Boston, celebrated mass on Boston Common this noon before a pre-Christmas throng estimated by the police at 10,000.

French seamen sailing in and out of New York for as many as twenty-five years were among 271 members of the crew of the French liner Liberte to whom shore leave was forbidden on arrival here yesterday as the controversial McCarran-Walter Immigration and Nationality Law went into effect.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 (AP) -The National Boxing Association today assured the British Boxing Board of Control that Randy Turpin is the N. B. A.'s No. 1 contender for the middleweight crown vacated by Sugar Ray Robinson.

The Christmas holiday had a dominating effect yesterday on the stock market. Interest lagged in the railroads, which accounted for a recession of 0.21 point in the composite rate despite the fact that more stocks advanced than declined.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 24 (UP) -Coach Paul Brown, getting gloomier by the minute, fanned his feud today with Coach Buddy Parker, by declaring that the battered Cleveland Browns should be "at least 15-point underdogs" in Sunday's game with the Detroit Lions for the professional football championship.

BERLIN, Dec. 24 -- As Berlin's residents in both the Soviet and Western sectors headed home tonight, many of them with Christmas trees over their shoulders, the "cold war' 'that divides their city was almost -- but not quite -- forgotten.

CHICAGO, Dec. 24 -- Grain futures were steady in the first hour of trading, but the demand slackened and further long liquidation was in evidence later in the short session. The prospect for rain or snow in the Southwest checked the buying demand for wheat, and support was feeble in corn and other grains after the early buying, which was easily supplied.

Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower put aside temporarily last night his responsibilities as President-elect of the United States to become just another American grandfather concentrating on making Christmas a joyous occasion for his family and particularly for his three grandchildren, the oldest of whom is only 4 years old.
Children of nursery school age who are at home during the holidays and may be missing some of their school-day routine can attend class, instead, by television.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 (UP) -The Army said today it had finally perfected the turret mechanism on its new Walker Bulldog light tanks and had begun shipping them out to troops.

I am calling upon the wide publicity of THE NEW YORK TIMES to express our warm Christmas greetings and our deepest feelings of gratitude to the American people, who so generously received us, exiled Hungarians, giving us not only asylum but also a home and security.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- Harry N. Rosenfield, executive director of the President's Commission on Immigration and Naturalization, tonight denied all charges made by Senator Pat McCarran, Democrat of Nevada, and declared that the Senator was "either deliberately lying or doesn't know the facts."

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 24 -- True Delbert Morse, agricultural specialist named Under Secretary of Agriculture in the Eisenhower Administration, is chairman of the board of directors of Doane Agricultural Service, Inc., said to be the nation's largest farm management, appraisal and farm research organization. He has been editor of the Doane Agricultural Digest since 1938.

National Theatres, Inc., acquired all capital stock of the Wesco Theatres Corporation and all the common stock of Roxy Theatre, Inc., last Sept. 27, it was reported yesterday by Charles P. Skouras, president.

RENSSELAER, N. Y., Dec. 24 (AP) -- An A. F. L. local today began a drive for Federal legislation to permit the return of the Government-operated General Aniline and Film Corporation to private ownership.

Wherever happy families gather around the Christmas tree today to celebrate the event that brought to a troubled world the message of "peace on earth, goodwill toward men," thoughts must inevitably turn at times to those valiant men who are spending the day in the fox holes, the hospitals, the tents, huts and prison camps of Korea.

MOSCOW, Dec. 24 -- The Communist party's leading theoretical organ, the magazine Communist, today attacked George F. Kennan as the American successor to "Hitler, Goebbels and Rosenberg," and called him the leader of the crusade against cooperation between the Soviet Union and the United States who favors heightened tension between the two countries.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 (AP) -The Defense Production Administration today approved construction of a 54,000-ton aluminum reduction plant at The Dalles, Ore.

MOSCOW, Dec. 24 -- Secretary Mikhail A. Suslov of the Communist party's Central Committee sharply criticized P. Fedoseyev, former editor in chief of the magazine Bolshevik, today for failure to mention in two recent articles his mistakes in economic and political ideology that led to his removal from the top Communist party organ in 1949.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- In reply to four questions submitted by this correspondent, Premier J. V. Stalin of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics said in a message received tonight that he would favorably regard diplomatic conversations with representatives of the new Eisenhower Administration with the objective of holding a meeting between the President-elect and himself on easing world tensions.

There was little activity in the New York commodity markets yesterday, all exchanges closing by 1 P. M. for the holiday. Most futures were dull and featureless, with prices closing generally higher. Cottonseed oil, soybean oil, cocoa, lead, rubber and zinc were higher. Hides, potatoes and wool closed lower and sugar and coffee were mixed.

Trade practices governing anticipatory-type discounts in the buying of merchandise by retail stores are "chaotic" and constitute "an open invitation to some Government agency to step in and supervise their regulation."

Julius and Ethel Rosenberg, scheduled to die in the electric chair the week of Jan. 12 for transmitting atomic bomb secrets to the Soviet Union, will apply Tuesday to Federal Judge Irving R. Kaufman for judicial clemency.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 24 -- The Government's draft social plan for 1953, which will be discussed in six regular sessions of the Yugoslav Parliament beginning tomorrow, foresees cutbacks in capital investments, concentration on only a few new major projects and no increase in the standard of living by the end of next year.

Financial aid, clothing, toys and other gifts have been obtained in larger amounts and have been distributed by New York newspapers to more persons this year than last year. This assistance was made possible by the direct solicitation of readers by the papers.

BERLIN, Dec. 24 -- Maj. Gen. Lemuel Mathewson, the senior United States representative in Berlin in both the military and diplomatic spheres, is to be relieved probably next month, official sources said today.
MOSCOW, Dec. 24 -- Grigori Novak, one of Russia's crack weightlifters and the holder of several world records, lifts other things, too.

TEANECK, N. J., Dec. 25 -- Mrs. Ruth A. Peffall did not buy presents this Christmas for her two young sons who disappeared without trace four and one-half years ago. She worked all through the day at her real estate office here instead of waiting at home as in the past in the vain hope that the magic of Christmastide might bring them back.

PARIS, Dec. 25 -- Jacques Soustelle, secretary general of the anti-parliamentary Gaullist movement (Reunion of the French People), announced tonight his willingness to try to form "a national and social Cabinet" of the type desired by his leader, Gen. Charles de Gaulle.
HANOI, Vietnam, Indo-China, Dec. 25 -- French Union forces continued today their drive to wipe out an important pocket of Vietminh power in the southern end of the Tonkin delta, below Buichu.

The charming woman who began selling America on the joy of cooking back in the Thirties gave us the other day some ideas on New Year's Eve suppers. She was, of course, Mrs. Irma S. Rombauer, whose best-selling cookbook reached its latest edition in 1951, this time under the title "The New Joy of Cooking."

Union hotel workers of this city received a total of $7,289,037 in welfare benefits over the last seven years through the New York Hotel Trades Council and Hotel Association Insurance Fund, according to the fund's seventh annual financial report made public yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 -- Scheduled airlines operated within the country during the last twelve months with the best safety record in commercial aviation history, the Civil Aeronautics Board announced today. United States international air carriers, however, had their worst year for passenger fatalities since 1946.

To provide more telephone service in Flushing, Queens, telephone conduits will be installed in Main Street, from Northern Boulevard to Forty-first-Avenue, Borough President James A. Lundy of Queens announced yesterday. Telephone construction workers will begin digging up the street about Jan. 5.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 -- The House Ways and Means subcommittee that investigated tax scandals, ending a two-year assignment, put higher pay, a larger staff and machinery for merit promotions at the top of its list of recommendations for the Bureau of Internal Revenue.

The monthly payroll of the entire iron and steel industry reached a higher level in October than ever before with an estimated $282,896,000. This was $13,500,000 larger than in September and $33,000,000 or 13 per cent greater than a year ago.
EATON RAPIDS, Mich., Dec. 25 -- Three Air Force sergeants played Santa today to 144 war veterans' orphans as efficiently as old Kris Kringle himself could have done.

In England, it is the wassail bowl, in Sweden glogg and for Americans the hot drink for the Christmas holidays is either buttered rum or Tom and Jerry, the frothy blend of eggs, sugar, spices and Jamaica rum. Other lands where December is likely to be chilly also have the tradition of a warming beverage at this time.

Tugboat workers have asked for wage increases ranging from 30 to more than 50 per cent, double time for overtime work, additional holidays and other benefits for their new contract, it became known yesterday.

EAST WILLISTON, L. I., Dec. 25 -- Robert Bacon Whitney, an assistant vice president of J. P. Morgan Co., Inc., and son of George Whitney Sr., chairman of the board of the banking house, was killed just after 10 o'clock last night when he was hit by a car while walking along a dark road near here.

HONG KONG, Dec. 25 -- The Peiping People's Daily, the leading Chinese Communist organ, told its readers in effect today that the Korean war would go on and that Red China would have to step up its mobilization efforts. The party newspaper contended that China's economic development would not suffer in the process.

ARCADIA, Calif., Dec. 25 (AP) -- Santa Anita Park, basking in sunshine and affluence, opens the gates for its sixteenth winter racing season tomorrow and features the $20,000 Las Flores Handicap as the main attraction of the day.
OTTAWA, Dec. 25 -- Premier Stalin's reply to the questions asked him by James Reston roused the greatest interest in the Canadian capital today.

" No. 1 Yuletide Square," an original fantasy created by Leon Leonidoff, who produces the shows at the Radio City Music Hall, had its debut over the N. B. C. television network yesterday afternoon. It was an ambitious spectacle, containing a number of pleasing moments, but many viewers must have wished that color TV were already here.
Christendom went through another Yule Day yesterday in despairing supplication for world peace.

AT THE KOREAN FRONT, Dec. 25 -- Christmas Day passed in Korea under a clear and cloudless steely blue sky. Except for the soldiers who manned the front lines there was some relief from the tedium of war in the sumptuous meals served and in the parties and presents for Korean children.

NAIROBI, Kenya, Dec. 25 -- The sturdy British farmers who pioneered the famous Kenya uplands carved their Christmas geese and turkeys today with a gun beside them on the table. Dusty volunteer policemen came home at dawn from patrols of isolated districts and grazing herds of livestock.

The music and dramatization of Christmas begun at churches and cathedrals on Christmas Eve was carried over into the early morning hours yesterday as Roman Catholics and Protestants gathered for midnight devotions. Many other services were held yesterday forenoon.

DENVER, Dec. 25 (UP) -- Mrs. Leona Brookman, who died Sunday, left a large share of her $1,233,000 fortune to Bible institutes and missionary societies. Under the terms of her will, which was filed yesterday in Denver County Court, thirteen Bible institutes will receive grants of from $5,000 to $100,000.

Miss Victoria Evans Pearson was the guest of honor at a dinner dance given for he rlast night by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Theodore Pearson of 215 East Seventy-second Street, and her grandmother, Mrs. Henry Gansevoort Sanford of 55 East Seventy-second Street, in the Georgian Suite, 1A East Seventy-seventh Street.
Fifty - six players, representing fourteen colleges, are expected to line up today for the biennial tournament of the National Inter-collegiate Chess League at Columbia.

Some 12,000,000 Americans will be paid a return visit from Santa Claus next week. That is how many persons are due to share in the year-end dividend distribution by the nation's savings associations and cooperative banks.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 25 -- Officials of the French Embassy and of the French steamship company concerned maintained their refusal today to shed any light on the mystery of the wrecked liner Champollion.
LONDON, Dec. 25 -- Three researchers at the Liverpool School of Tropical Medicine have discovered that rats, fed on a diet of milk and vitamins, resist malaria.

In the annual report of the Association for the Aid of Crippled Children, Leonard W. Mayo, its director, calls attention to the fact that there are at present more than 1,500 private and as many corporation foundations now making research grants.
MANILA, Friday, Dec. 26 (AP) -- President Elpidio Quirino has called the United States Mutual Security Agency report on Philippines land problems unfortunate and exaggerated.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 25 -- The Government presented its social plan for 1953 to Parliament today. It called for expenditures for national defense of slightly more than 20 per cent of estimated national income, probably the biggest proportionate outlay of this nature of any country in Western Europe.

TOKYO, Friday, Dec. 26 -- Communist China sent its Russian-designed MIG jet fighters far south over Korea yesterday in a strong Christmas Day raid, which failed, however, to penetrate to the United Nations fighting lines.

LONDON, Dec. 25 --- The British Foreign Office evinced less interest today in Premier Stalin's replies to James Reston's questions than in the motivation behind answering them at all. They pointed out that journalists from all over the world are constantly submitting questions to the Soviet Premier in the hope of getting answers.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 (AP) -- Representative Dewey Short, Republican of Missouri, who will head the House Armed Services Committee, predicted today that the conferences between Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower the President-elect and General of the Army Douglas MacArthur and others would be "very fruitful."

MOSCOW, Dec. 25 -- Diplomatic observers here believed today that the chief value of Premier Stalin's answers to four questions submitted by James Reston was the prospect that they might lead to new and more fruitful negotiations toward a Korean settlement.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Dec. 25 -- Members of the fourth class -- freshmen -- at the United States Military Academy entertained their parents and friends at one of the nation's largest family Christmas dinner parties today.

There has been no hint in recent Soviet newspapers or domestic propaganda broadcasts of an improved Soviet attitude toward the United States that might support any peace hopes arising from Premier Stalin's Christmas Eve statement that he would be willing to meet President-elect Eisenhower.

BERLIN, Friday, Dec. 26 -- Second Lieut. Horace J. Sincore of the United States Army garrison in Berlin was released early today after having been held in Soviet custody for more than a month. An Army spokesman said he had been generally well treated.
CLEVELAND, Dec. 25 (AP) -- The Cleveland Browns forsook Christmas trees and happy families today to face a raw wind and cleat mud in preparation for Sunday's game with the Detroit Lions.
A small collection of fresh-looking accessories, designed by an American, Peter Mitchell, and executed in Italy, may be found at Studio M, 116 East Fifty-seventh Street.

UTICA, Dec. 25--State appraisers yesterday began a survey of Utica State Hospital farm lands in West Utica and New Hartford under a plan by which the land would be used by a college, two hospitals and the city for industrial and public housing.

MIAMI, Dec. 25 (AP) -- The most interesting contest in the five-year history of the Shrine's North-South college All-Star football game ended in a 21-21 deadlock tonight after a tense aerial duel starring Maryland's All-America Jack Scarbath and Purdue's Dale Samuels.

A Christmas program was offered by Bruno Walter, guest conductor of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra last night in Carnegie Hall. Mr. Walter played the exquisite Sinfonia from the second part of Bach's Christmas Oratorio; then the G-minor Concerto Grosso of the Corelli with the final number, the Pastorale, intended by the composer to be played with the other movement of the concerto, or as a separate piece.

Peter McKenzie was a cotton and linen salesman -- and apparently a good one. In twenty-five years in the textile field he had become an executive of the company he represented. Yet, ironically, his heart was not in this work and his interest in it had diminished with the years.

Spending a quiet Christmas at home yesterday, Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower got up early, exchanged gifts at a family gathering around the Christmas tree, went to church, heard a sermon on world peace, returned home, played with his grandchildren, and ate a turkey dinner in the late afternoon.

ROME, Dec. 25 -- Crisp cold weather and cloudless skies over the greater part of Italy contributed to the success of today's Christmas celebration. In the north a thick carpet of snow lay over the ground, providing the traditional Yuletide aspect for the scene.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 -- Diplomats and students of Soviet foreign policy agreed today that Premier Stalin's overtures for diplomatic talks with Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower merited study, but they warned against accepting at face value the Soviet leader's stated willingness to negotiate an end to the Korean war and other "world tensions."

Vince Martinez, the fast-punching middleweight boxer from Paterson, will be in the main bout at Madison Square Garden tonight. He will oppose Don Williams of Worcester in a clash slated for ten rounds.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 (UP) -- Draft boards have assigned 385 conscientious objectors to special civilian work instead of military service in the last six months, Selective Service officials said today.
SEOUL, Korea, Dec. 25 (UP) -- Gen. and Mrs. James A. Van Fleet played Santa Claus to 100 Seoul orphans today at a Christmas party held at Eighth Army headquarters.

BONN, Germany, Dec. 25 -- Premier Stalin's amicable phrases in reply to questions submitted by James Reston generated a current of anxiety today in the Government of Federal Germany, the most exposed of all the Western Powers to the Soviet armies.
HAMBURG, Germany, Dec. 25 (AP) -- Daily televiseion broadcasts -- with no commercials -- began in Western Germany tonight, with a Christmas play as the first offering.

Eli E. Albert, manufacturer of juvenile wear, has purchased the Jefferson Building, a ten-story structure on plot 50 by 200 feet at 119-21 West Twenty-third Street through to 112-14 West Twenty-fourth Street, about a block west of Madison Square, from the Robrill Realty Corporation, represented by Bing Bing.

Deductions are being made in London that Robert Morley is becoming a bit weary from appearing in "The Little Hut" there since Aug. 23, 1950. What brought it to the surface is the star's enthusiasm for "Howe Hummel," Howard Teichmann's dramatization of Richard Rovere's book, expanded from a series of New Yorker articles dealing with a pair of slick New York lawyers.
CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 25 (AP) -- Reginald L. Webster's Crystal Boot took the lead at the start and held it all the way to win the $10,000 added Christmas Handicap at Tropical Park today.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Dec. 21 -- The rains of the last few days in Galilee have begun to accumulate behind a new dam called Beit Natufa in a glistening pool that will eventually grow to a lake three times the size of Lake Huleh and more than one-third the size of the Sea of Galilee.
ST. PAUL, Minn., Dec. 25 -- Desecration of an outdoor nativity scene at a suburban St. Paul Roman Catholic Church stunned the community today.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 25-- Convention visitors to this city this year spent $5,000,000 less than in 1951, according to a report submitted by W. Lansing Rothschild, president of the San Francisco Convention and Visitors Bureau, to a board of directors meeting this week.

On Dec. 18 you published a letter from Arthur R. Silsdorf. He contends that by a simple amendment to the rules of the county committee of the Democratic party of New York County direct election of district leaders may be accomplished. Recognized election law experts maintain to the contrary.

An "acute" situation has resulted from failure of volunteer blood donors to heed a Christmas Eve appeal to fill an emergency whole blood shipment for Korea, Dr. William Markel, administrator for the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program, said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 (AP) -- William T. Faricy, president of the Association of American Railroads, reported today that last summer's steel strike cut deeply into railroad freight traffic and seriously set back the carriers' program for increasing freight car supply.

The mild exception taken by the State Department against V. K. Krishna Menon, Indian delegate to the United Nations, points up an interesting and baffling difference between Eastern and Western thinking. Mr. Menon originally offered a compromise proposal on the return of prisoners in the hope of achieving a Korean armistice.
The statement from Premier Stalin published in THE NEW YORK TIMES yesterday was obtained by merely writing a letter.
Sam and Sophie Gorowitz bought for investment from Hyman Fleischman the four-story apartment house at 1807 Phelan Place, the Bronx, in a deal negotiated by J. Edgar Leaycraft Co., brokers.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Dec. 25 (UP) -- Tennessee's football team lost the services of its coach, Gen. Robert Neyland, today and it is doubtful whether he will be able to direct the team against Texas on New Year's Day in the Cotton Bowl.
Boston, Dec. 25 (AP) -- The Daily Record says the Federal Bureau of Investigation knows of a Boston lawyer who has been custodian of the $1,219,000 stolen in the Brink's robbery of Jan. 17, 1950.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 -- President-elect Dwight D. Eisenhower is expected to announce soon, possibly next week, creation of an interim committee to help, guide the new Administration's farm programs, an informed source reported today.

REIDSVILLE, Ga., Dec. 25 (AP) -- Ten women came here to console Rosa Lee Ingram, controversial Negro life-termer, on Christmas day, but officers with a court order stopped them well short of the prison limits.

Lockheed Aircraft Service, Inc., reported yesterday a record $38,000,000 backlog of commercial and military aircraft overhaul and modification work. Involved are over 700 tactical, training and transport aircraft.

Economic prospects of the United States in 1953 are favorable for continued prosperity, in the opinion of a group of prominent economists gathered together by the National Industrial Conference Board concluded recently. Their forecast is that present high levels of production and employment should not be disturbed very substantially next year, though there may well be some price declines which, together with continued wage increases, will put further pressure on profit margins.

SCHENECTADY, Dec. 25 -- State Housing Commissioner Herman T. Stichman said last week that this city had been chosen as a "guinea pig,, to show that public funds and the help of private enterprise can haalt the movement of mercantile business from the cities to the suburbs.
TOKYO, Friday, Dec. 26 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,475, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Friday, Korea time:
LONDON, Dec. 25 -- Queen Elizabeth II evoked today the spirit of adventure that characterized the reign of Elizabeth I and asked all her subjects to band together to keep that spirit alive.

The New Jersey Law Enforcement Council, which on Monday is to question Mayor John V. Kenny of Jersey City about his asserted connections with waterfront racketeers, was accused yesterday of having refused to avail itself of important evidence offered by a special prosecutor.
Eugene Holman, president of Standard Oil Company (New Jersey), said yesterday 1952 was a satisfactory year from the standpoint of balancing oil supply with demand.
LONDON, Dec. 25 (AP) -- Arsenal moved into second place in the first division of the English Football League today with a 6-4 victory over the Bolton Wanderers.

BOSTON, Dec. 25 (UP) -- Center Paul Ronty came back to haunt his former mates in Boston tonight, breaking a deadlock and giving the New York Rangers a 2-1 victory before 8,007 fans at the Boston Garden.

A young A. W. O. L. soldier who said he enjoyed holding up people and watching them tremble when he pointed his pistol at them, admitted yesterday that he had robbed twenty-four Brooklyn places, most of them liquor stores, since he disappeared from Fort Dix on Nox. 18.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Dec. 25 -- Dr. Mahmud Hussain, Minister for Kashmir Affairs, addressing a public meeting held today to celebrate the birthday anniversary of the late Mohammed Ali Jinnah, founder of Pakistan, declared that Pakistan was determined to make Kashmir independent.
Carloadings for the first quarter of 1953 will be 3.9 per cent greater than during the initial three months of 1952, according to an announcement yesterday by Atlantic States Shippers Advisory Board.

Because Hawker Siddeley Group, Ltd., will need to borrow substantially to finance its expansion program, holders of ordinary and preference shares will meet on Jan. 7 to vote on a proposal to amend the Group's borrowing powers.

The decision to retain Generals Van Fleet and Eddy on active duty for at least two months after their scheduled retirement on Jan. 31 is a wise one. Army Department spokesmen said that this move was made for the convenience of the incoming Eisenhower Administration."

Brig. Gen. Frank L. Howley, retired, first American Military Governor of Berlin and author of "Berlin Command," has a new book on Holt's list for Jan. 24 publication. In "Your War for Peace" the author discusses the world situation and America's foreign policy.

It has been some weeks now since a young lady bearing pad and pencil stopped in, on her round from office to office, to check on the size and style of the desk calendar. Any day she will return, carrying a refill to be clamped into the metal stand that at present holds the old calendar.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 25 (AP) -- Thanks to foresight and the State of Texas, Californians should have warm feet on cold nights this winter and for many a winter to come.

Limited skiing, not exactly unexpected at this time of winter, will provide the holiday menu for enthusiasts this week-end unless snow flurries that are forecast turn into a heavy fall. Then the entire Northland will be over-run with enthusiasts who haven't had the feel of snow under their boards since last spring.

It is disturbing to all American friends of the Philippines to hear that there is grave apprehension in the archipelago over the character of the next election. The fears of fraud and force may be groundless, but their very expression indicates an uneasiness at a critical time.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 (AP) -- Although great progress has been made in providing pensions for the aged in the last fifteen years, a Congressional study group reported today, the average payments being made are still considerably below the subsistence level.
Seamen, service men, the homeless and those living in public institutions were well remembered yesterday in the round of Christmas festivities that engulfed the city.

A stockbroker who reads American historical documents with an avidity that many of his colleagues reserve for the ticker tape is completing a fifteen-year study of the origin of the United States flag that may lower the market value of the Betsy Ross legend.
Premier Stalin's Christmas Eve replies to the questions of James Reston were in the main stream of his statements since 1946, in most of which he has sought to appear as the champion of peace.

MIAMI, Dec. 25 (AP) -- There's an air of quiet confidence around the camp of the Syracuse football team as it trains to meet the fierce running attack of Alabama's Crimson Tide in the Orange Bowl on New Year's Day.

BECAUSE of a hemispheric propensity for conducting their weather on an upside-down-basis, the Australians now are enjoying their summer while we shiver in winter's icy clutch. The Davis Cup competition, an August event at Forest Hills when the United States is defending the battered mug, becomes a December affair when the lads from Down Under are the holders.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 25 (AP) -- An Asian-Arab group leader took a wait-and-see attitude today on Premier Stalin's asserted willingness to cooperate in a new diplomatic approach toward ending the Korean war.

The United States Children's Bureau has reported some disturbing facts about juvenile delinquency. It reports that a "junior crime wave" has struck the nation and is threatening to become a "tidal wave." We are told that 94 per cent of our delinquents are between the ages of 10 and 17.
A batch of Christmas Eve contributions brought the forty-first annual appeal for The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund more than $90,000 ahead of its Christmas Day record of last year.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 (UP) -- Christmas 1952 was "the granddaddy of them all" -- dollarwise -- Government economists reported today.

In a year that suffered decline from the standpoint of box-office income and development of talent because of television, Rocky Marciano, world heavyweight champion, has been named "the fighter of the year" by The Ring Magazine, a boxing publication.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 25 -- The whole program of economic development in Brazil may be compromised if the currency is not revalued to stimulate foreign trade, the authoritative monthly Conjuntura Economica has just declared.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 -- Three key members in the new Congress said today they favored budget cuts ahead of tax reductions. A fourth said he would introduce a tax-reduction bill on Jan. 3, the opening day of the Eighty-third Congress.
PARIS, Dec. 25 -- Premier Stalin's answers to the questions of James Reston had the feature position in the Paris press and in the comment of official circles here today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 -- If you're an unmarried city girl looking for a husband -- go rural.

An uneasy feeling is spreading among major charity leaders that the city's voluntary non-profit hospital, health and welfare agencies are facing increasingly hard times in raising funds to keep going. Leaders report strenuous efforts simply to keep pace with rising costs. They find relatively little or no expansion -- outside the hospital field -- to take care of an increasing population, especially in suburban areas, and to meet new and more complex problems.

Take a familiar product, couple it with animal characters praising its virtues and an advertisement is created. That recipe has been used for creating copy ever since the first caveman drew animal pictures on his cavern walls. Often it seems to produce results.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 (AP) -- Andrew J. May, former Democratic Representative from Kentucky who went to prison for conspiracy and bribery, counted a full Presidential pardon among his Christmas presents today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 25 -- The comedy team of Dean Martin and Jerry Lewis may not have all of the professional critics rooting for them all of the time, but they are the fair-haired boys of 1952 in the judgment of several thousand motion-picture theatre operators.

A STUDY of the fined levied during the past season for game law violations reveals that many were penalized for infractions of the law that arose through a failure to read the "fine print," a misunderstanding, or a thoughtless act of omission, rather than through a deliberate intent to commit a violation.

Three hundred and thirty acres of land in the Dix Hills area of Huntington, L. I., have been assembled by the Loshen interests, Long Island home builders, for improvement with one-story and split-level houses in the $14,000 to $20,000 price range.

PASSAIC, N. J., Dec. 25 -- Patrolman Harold Fitzpatrick, a member of the Passaic Police Department for twenty-four years, was held in $15,000 bail today on charges of atrocious assault and battery growing out of an early-morning street argument in which he is said to have fired three shots, wounding a man and a woman.

NASHVILLE, Dec. 24 -- What is described by its founders as the finest observatory in the Southeast and the only graduate research observatory in the region will go into operation near Nashville next spring.
Those who noted an inadequate supply of scrap baskets when disposing of their Christmas wrappings might be interested in some new designs for use in the coming year.
NEW ORLEANS, La., Dec. 25 (AP) -- Two tugs were working their way down the foggy Mississippi River today to aid one of two steamships that crashed in the Gulf of Mexico near the mouth of the river.

A bird lover in Mendham, N. J., wrote a letter to THE NEW YORK TIMES recently, reporting he had sighted a mockingbird on his back porch. Because the mockingbird normally is considered indigenous to the South, the correspondent understandably was excited at seeing one in this area.

President Truman's recent warnings against the loss of civil rights in the prosecution of Communists is but natural. So also is the concern expressed by Governor Stevenson lest we burn down the barn with the rats.

CAIRO, Dec. 25 -- The Arab League Political Committee, in the name of the seven Arab states, issued today a "condemnation of the mere idea of an invitation to the Arabs to negotiate with the Israelis." The committee also expressed the hope, referring to a resolution defeated in the United Nations General Assembly, "that there will be no repetition or these attempts."

Gian-Carlo Menotti's "Amahl and the Night Visitors" was presented over the N. B. C. television network yesterday evening at 6. It was the third televised performance of the work, which was composed expressly for the medium and had been given its world premiere on Christmas Day in 1951.

A tremendous comeback by the New York Knickerbockers, who overcame an early 14-point deficit and conquered the Boston Celtics, 97 -- 84, gave Joe Lapchick's quintet undisputed first place in the Eastern Division of the National Basketball Association last night at Madison Square Garden.

MADRID, Dec. 25 -- The Spanish Government has been asked by labor leaders to take into "urgent consideration" the plight of thousands of Spanish workers living in unhealthy, overcrowded, unsafe dwellings in slum sections of cities and towns throughout the nation.

MINEOLA, L. I., Dec. 25 -- A fatal hit-and-run accident in Wantagh and a fire in the garage of a 35-year-old Bellmore machinist were linked by the police today as the machinist, Charles W. Ellis of 6 Beach Street, was arraigned in First District Court here on charges of third-degree arson and leaving the scene of an accident.

TOKYO, Friday, Dec. 26 -- Japanese sources reflected some skepticism today toward the favorable attitude expressed by Premier Stalin on a proposal for a meeting with President-elect Eisenhower. The Soviet leader's view appeared in answers to questions by James Reston.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 -- The renewed effort which Representative Coudert of New York proposes to make in the Eighty-third Congress for the reform of the system by which Presidential and Vice-Presidential electors are chosen may at last produce a basic change in the method.

HAVANA, Dec. 25 (AP) -- Apprentice Jockey Tony DeSpirito booted home three winners cut of eight mounts at Oriental Park today to raise his year's total of victories to 376, just twelve away from the record.

WASHINGTON, Dee. 25 -- President Truman spent his second and last Christmas at the White House today in a close family group. The day was observed in traditional fashion including the carving of the turkey by the head of the house under the scrutiny of young and old.
Cuba was probably the only country in the world to enjoy complete television coverage in 1952. It also was a hotbed of television receiver smugglers.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 25 (UP) -- Jose Ferrer, the actor, who was boycotted by anti-Communist American Legion pickets at a film premiere Tuesday night, told Legion Commander Lewis K. Gough today that he would be glad to join the veterans' fight against communism.
