Intensive screening of foreign seamen took place yesterday aboard six freighters of four nations under the provisions of the new McCarran-Walter Immigration and Nationality Law, in effect for the second day.

The fair words which Premier Stalin has addressed to the United States in general and President-elect Eisenhower in particular in response to questions submitted to him by our diplomatic correspondent. Mr. Reston, are obviously intended to spread over a troubled world a rosy glow of encouragement that might be further enhanced by the prevailing Christmas spirit and mankind's eternal longing for peace.

There is a footnote that needs to be added to the press report and photograph from Morrisville, Pa., published in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Dec. 12, of the opening of the Fairless Works of the United States Steel Corporation.

TAIPEI, Formosa, Dec. 25 -- Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek assailed today both "Soviet Russian bandits" and nations of the West that, he declared, "kicked us while we were down, encouraged the enemy to knock us out, and rejoiced at our defeat."
A newly revised edition of a guide for parents of pre-school blind children has been issued by the Commission for the Blind of the New York State Department of Social Welfare.

KINGSTON, Jamaica, Dec. 25 (UP) -- Herb McKenley, Jamaica's noted sprinter, scored a resounding victory today in the opening of the Post-Olympic athletic meet when he ran the 100 meters in 10:4 to beat Harrison Dillard and Jim Gathers of the United States.

The Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., asked yesterday for the opportunity to be represented this morning at a special meeting of the Board of Estimate to explain why it plans to strike on New Year's Day against eight private lines for the forty-hour week.

ROME, Dec. 25 -- The replies that Premier Stalin gave to the questions of James Reston interested and excited Italian public opinion as few things have done since the Korean armistice negotiations started a year and a half ago.

ATLANTIC CITY, Dec. 26 (AP) -- The City Commission of Atlantic City today approved an option whereby the Federal Government can purchase Pomona Air Base as the start of a $30,000,000 "master jet base."

Trading was dull on the New York commodity exchanges yesterday, the day falling between two market holidays. The sugar market took an extended vacation. Prices closed irregularly lower with cocoa, lead, coffee and cottonseed oil off. Hides, rubber, wool and soybean oil ended mixed and zinc and potatoes closed higher.

The American Fair Trade Council disassociated itself yesterday from a running battle between Stephen J. Spingarn, acting chairman of the Federal Trade Commission, and the Bureau of Education on Fair Trade. The council represents some 2,000 manufacturers who fix minimum retail prices on their products in forty-five states with fair trade laws.

BAR HARBOR, Me., Dec. 26 -- Year-round residents of this summer resort appeared confident today that ferry service between here and Yarmouth, N. S., would be a reality in a matter of time, despite the protests of wealthy summer residents.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- The incoming Administration of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower promised serious and sympathetic reception today to any "concrete proposals" by Premier Stalin for easing world tensions, but at the same time it discouraged prospects for a face-to-face meeting of the President-elect and the Soviet leader.
LONDON, Dec. 26 (Reuters) -- The Wolverhampton Wanderers were held to a 1-1 tie by Sunderland today, but retained their lead in the First Division of the English Soccer League.
A promising contender for the welterweight title came out of the International Boxing Club's "new talent" fistic carnival last night in Madison Square Garden.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (AP) -- The Air Force said today that it would put ejection seats into its new B-47 jet bombers after February "to improve the chances of the crew getting out" in an emergency. A spokesman, however, denied published reports that the B-47 might be a death trap for its pilot.

Howard Dietz, whose English translation of Puccini's "La Boheme" goes on stage at the Metropolitan Opera this afternoon, has a chip on his shoulder. Normally Mr. Dietz is one of the most mild and equable of men, but these days he is apt to come out fighting at the mention of the English language in relation to opera.

PARIS, Dec. 26 -- With the apparent approval of his party chief, Gen. Charles de Gaulle, Jacques Soustelle conferred tonight with President Vincent Auriol on the formation of a French Cab inet. After the meeting, M. Soustelle said he had told the President that he would sound out various parties on a possible program, and, if he met enough encouragement in those conversations, he would become Premier-designate tomorrow night.
It is welcome news that Attorney General McGranery has ordered the Federal Bureau of Investigation to make a "full-scale investigation" of corruption on the New York-New Jersey waterfront.

Only two books are being published today, Southern Methodist University Press is issuing in two editions a revised and enlarged edition of J. Frank Dobie's "Guide to Life and Literature of the Southwest." The cloth edition sells for $3.50 and the paper edition at $2.50.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Dec. 26 -- Communist anti-Zionism and anti-Semitism expressed at the recent Slansky trial in Prague have brought about a realignment of forces in Israel's fellow-traveling Mapam political party. The near-Communists, who had been gaining a firmer and firmer grip on the party, have been soundly defeated, and the moderates have moved into a commanding position.

Further sharp curtailment of grain handling facilities in the Port of New York is not only a possibility but a probability unless the railroads are permitted to equalize transport rates from Buffalo to New York with those to Baltimore and Philadelphia, Walter P. Hedden asserted last week.
Work by a number of artists on this week's program of art exhibitions proclaimed the artist's freedom to paint what and how they like.

The lovely, fist-sized mourning dove, which is one of birddom's sweetest voices, and the whooping crane which is as tall as a man and sings like a cracked caliope, had something more in common than wings yesterday. Both are threatened with extinction, and this threat has stirred nation-wide Federal and private efforts to protect them.

Silver gifts, untarnished and fresh as the incoming year, are now on hand from many countries to welcome the infants of 1953. In place of the inevitable silver cup, well wishing relatives and friends now have many unusual items from which to choose.

VANCOUVER, B. C., Dec. 26 (Canadian Press) -- The Pacific Ocean, pounding at the freighter Maplecove for more than a week, hurled a final blow tonight as the lights of Vancouver beckoned to the crippled vessel.
BERLIN, Dec. 26 -- Second Lieut. Horace J. Sincore, who reappeared in West Berlin early today after a month in Soviet detention, told this evening of being abandoned on a lonely road last night.
The desirability of amending rules governing boxing in this state to provide three judges instead of two for each bout is being considered by the State Athletic Commission.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 26 -- Enrichment of foods low in vital body-building proteins, eaten by a majority of the world's population, has now become possible as the result of the synthesis of several of the essential building blocks of which the proteins are made, it was reported here today at the opening of the annual meeting of the American Association for the Advancement of Science.

Bureaus and companies specializing in verifying circulation or in measuring readership and listening time are reaping a bonanza in membership because of rapidly rising costs of merchandising. Increasing costs have led to the need for advertisers and their agencies to scrutinize their media lists more closely and revise their procedures of selecting media and to evince more interest in organizations supplying usable services in this connection.

A 15-year-old boy who had been missing since Tuesday evening was found dead of head wounds yesterday at the bottom of an eighty-foot rocky hill in a junk-littered, vacant lot at 175th Street and Carter Avenue in the Tremont section of the Bronx.
Three football games will be broadcast this week-end, beginning at 2:15 this afternoon when WOR and the Mutual Broadcasting System radio network report the annual Blue-Gray game in Montgomery, Ala.

Gerald Barrack and Dick Raskind, sophomores at Cornell and Yale, respectively, paced the field into the round of sixteen yesterday as play in the annual Eastern indoor junior tennis championships started at the Seventh Regiment Armory.

The New Jersey Highway Authority announced yesterday that arrangements have been made to increase the temporary borrowing from banks for the continued development of the Garden State Parkway from $17,000,000 to $28,000,000. Permanent financing is being

There are four operas to which Paris has put her own signature -- Massenet's "Manon," Verdi's "La Traviata," Charpentier's "Louise" and Puccini's "Boheme." Each celebrates quarters and even streets known to American Parisophiles -- the Cours de Reine and St. Sulpice in "Manon"; and perhaps also the rue de Richelieu is where that doomed young lady, in a pretty apartment, sings farewell to her "petite table."

Registering the sixteenth successive weekly increase New York bank loans to business advanced $32,000,000 last week to reach a total of $8,721,000,000 -- another new high. The rise during the week ended on Wednesday brought the expansion since mid-year to $1,051,000,000, compared with a gain of $1,115,000,000 in the similar period last year.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 26 -- Mrs. Ethel Arata, the 52-year-old woman arrested Christmas Eve as Los Angeles' "grandma bank robber,'' identified herself today as a former New Yorker and the daughter of a wealthy Eastern real-estate operator. The police said she had a record of psychopathy and alcoholism.
Senator Pat McCarran, Democrat of Nevada, urged yesterday that the Senate "compel" the State Department to name the department officials who passed on Americans employed at the United Nations.
MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Dec. 26 (AP) -- Two world speed-boat records were set today as the Orange Bowl Regatta got under way with time trials over a mile course.
HAVANA, Dec. 26 -- President Fulgencio Batista said today that the tax law, which has raised a storm of protest, would be modified.
In their "The American Constitution" (Norton, 1948), Kelly and Harbison wrote:
Chares Ufford of Harvard, the defender, entered the quarter-final round of the fifteenth annual intercollegiate invitation singles squash racquets tournament at the University Club yesterday.

The three-story building at 125 Heyward Street, Brooklyn, formerly owned by the City of New York and used as Public School 71, has been sold by Harry, Saul, Morris and Fay Koss to the Bais Yaakov of Williamsburg, Inc. The new owner will occupy the property as a Jewish parochial school.

The general reaction to Premier Stalin's reply to the question of James Reston points up a grim fact in international politics that must be disturbing to the Soviet leader himself. This fact is that Moscow has created a climate of distrust in which no Government that has dealt with Russia believes a word that comes out of the Kremlin.

BELTSVILLE, Md., Dec. 26 (UP) -- Steam hissed into the small "climate chamber," and a six-month-old calf, obviously gasping for air, was led away. Five older animals -- one mature Jersey and four Jersey heifers Sired by red Sindhi bulls from India -- remained in the chamber with the temperature at 105 and the humidity at 60 in an experiment aimed at producing more milk in the South.

CONCORD, N. H., Dec. 26 -- The Suncook Valley Railroad ran its last train last week. After eighty- four years of hauling freight, and occasionally passengers, over the twenty-four miles between Concord and Pittsfield, N. H., the line bowed out in character by leaving two derailed cars along the way on the last trip.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 26 (AP) -- Tony DeSpirito, the nation's leading jockey, failed to gain the winner's circle in eight tries at Tropical Park today, dimming his chances of breaking the record of 388 in a year.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Dec., 26 (UP) -- Harvey Robinson took over the job of whipping Tennessee into shape for the Cotton Bowl game as rumors mounted today that his boss, Gen. Bob Neyland, would retire from coaching.

An active demand for "used" houses in the Passaic-Bergen area of New Jersey is noted by J. I. Kislak, Inc., which reported several recent transactions there. Frank Fulton sold his home at 111 Knollwood Terrace, Clifton, to John F. German, and purchased the dwelling at 47 Windsor Road, Clifton, from Mrs. Edna M. Roemle.
CHICAGO, Dec. 26 (AP) -- Membership in the Methodist Church in the United States and its possessions increased 114,701 this year and now stands at 9,180,428.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- President Truman asserted today that he had worked hard for world peace and the national welfare for nearly eight years and that, looking back, there was no major act of his that he would want changed.

Millions of Roman Catholics in the United States have been called upon to pray tomorrow for persecuted peoples in accordance with a decision Roman Catholic prelates of this country made at their recent annual convention in Washington.
Sturdy and dependable as it is, the Police Information Booth in Times Square is not a place where celebrities would choose to dally on a chill post-Christmas day.

TANGIER, Dec. 26 -- The American colony here turned out practically en masse today for a farewell party in honor of Mr. and Mrs. John Carter Vincent Mr. Vincent was suspended as diplomatic agent and Minister at Tangier after President Truman's Loyalty Review Board found there was reasonable doubt as to his loyalty to the United States Government.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was quiet and barely steady yesterday and closing prices were 22 to 31 points net lower than on Wednesday.

Interest in the health of this nation's families loomed large in the news this month. A little over a week ago the President's Commission on the Health Needs of the Nation urged that complete health services be made available to all as a "basic human right," such services

Mayor Impellitteri refashioned his transit fact-finding committee yesterday into a mediation group and directed it to begin today to find a way of preventing a strike on New Year's Day by the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., against eight private bus lines.
The following is a round-up of new items which might be of use to homemakers during the holiday week as well as in the new year.

Most cases reaching the Supreme Court, and particularly those involving constitutional questions, contain difficult and complex issues of law and policy. At least this is true of the public school racial segregation cases which were just argued before the court.

HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Dec. 26 -- Undefeated Williams College eliminated the Wagner quintet, 84 -- 72, in the opening game of the second annual Hofstra invitation basketball tournament in Calkins Gymnasium tonight. Wagner won the tournament last year.

There was little demand in evidence yesterday on the stock market but even the limited buying gave prices a selective lift Softness in the rails acted as a drag on general gains and restricted the increase in the composite rate of THE NEW YORK TIMES index to 0.28 point.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 26 -- That section of the National Corps of Defense, the elite guard of the Yugoslav Army that included among its tasks protection against armed uprisings, will be dissolved, it was disclosed in Parliament today.

KINGSTON, Jamaica, Dec. 26 (UP) -- Harrison Dillard of Cleveland set a new Jamaican and Caribbean record for the 110-yard high hurdles today and also ran on a United States relay team that set a new Jamaican 400-yard mark, in the second day of the post-Olympic track meet.

WASHINGTON, - Dec. 26 (AP) -- Motions to dismiss indictments accusing E. Merl Young, former Reconstruction Finance Corporation examiner, and three others of perjury have been rejected in Federal Court.

An ending of international allocation of sulphur in the crude state has been considered by the sulphur committee of the International Materials Conference in Washington, it was learned yesterday. However, the group will take no action for the present, with the thought that current improvement in the supply situation might be merely temporary.

JERUSALEM, Dec. 26 (AP) -- Leaders of the Israel bond drive in the United States agreed today to withdraw their proferred resignations after a three-day conference that laid plans for Israeli Government cooperation in the 1953 sales campaign.

SEOUL, Korea, Saturday, Dec. 27 (AP) -- Francis Cardinal Spellman flew along the front Friday, landing nine times and bringing his Christmas message to soldiers, sometimes within range of Communist artillery.

CHICAGO, Dec. 26 -- Grain markets declined sharply today because of sentiment that was prompted by Premier Stalin's comments on the outlook for peace. March and May wheat and all deliveries of corn and oats dropped to new low prices for the season.

The Commerce and Industry Association of New York, on behalf of 121 shipping concerns, has urged the Federal Maritime Board to force twenty-five outbound Atlantic Coast steamship conferences to publish and make available their current tariffs either free of charge or at a nominal price.

The incoming Eisenhower Administration has been quick to reply to Premier Stalin's declared willingness to meet with the new President in an effort to case world tensions and to cooperate in ending the Korean war. The reply, made yesterday by Mr. Dulles, expresses interest in this latest account of Mr. Stalin's views.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 26 (AP) -- Gridiron stars whose collective talents would fire the imagination of any coach clash here tomorrow in the twenty-eighth East-West football game for charity.

A young mugger was shot fatally at 3 A. M. yesterday on a lonely West Side Street by an off-duty policeman in civilian clothes whom the hoodlum and a companion had attacked The second assailant got away.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- A mechanical horse that the business man can gallop in his basement rumpus room is one of the 966 inventions patented in Christmas week.
TOKYO, Saturday, Dec. 27 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,476, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Saturday, Korea time:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (AP) -Calls went out to Republicans and Democratic members of the new Congress today to meet here nex Friday and choose their leader The Eighty-third Congress covenes at noon on the following day Jan. 3.

LONDON, Dec. 26 -- From Chequers, where he spent Christmas, Prime Minister Churchill announced tonight that he would sail next Wednesday for the United States for talks with President-elect Dwight D. Eisenhower and President Truman.

BONN, Germany, Dec. 26 -- The machine tool and machine construction industries, which regulate the rate of expansion and production in every industrial society, reached a post-war peak this year in the Federal Republic of West Germany and provide one of the clues to this country's remarkable economic recovery.

A significant change in the pattern of United States foreign trade has taken place this year. The Department of Commerce reports that in the second and third quarters of 1952 this country's imports have exceeded our exports, thus giving the rest of the world an export surplus in relation to the United States of about $1,100,000,000 for the April-to-September period.
CLEVELAND, Dec. 26 -- An express bus careened out of control toward Lake Erie after the driver suffered a heart attack today, sending the vehicle off the highway and through roadside barriers.

To the criminal mind, the essential climax of any well-regulated payroll robbery is the examination and appraisal of the resulting loot. Now consider what happened yesterday to a tall gunman at 134 West Twenty-fifth Street, near Seventh Avenue.

Chess players of Columbia, City College of New York, Brooklyn, Fordham, Toronto and New York University turned in victories for their respective teams in the opening round of the annual tournament for the championship of the National Intercollegiate League yesterday.

THE allocation of short stretches of five popular streams for fly fishing only came in for considerable discussion during the past angling season, some of it "pro,"some "con" but most of it marked by considerable heat.
MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 26 (AP) -- Forty-eight big, rough-looking Alabama football players arrived today and immediately began drilling for their Orange Bowl game with Syracuse on New Year's Day.

TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 26 -- A sudden dense fog swallowed an Iranian Airways C-47 circling Teheran's airport for a landing Christmas night and it crashed, killing nineteen Iranians and four Americans. Only two persons aboard, both Iranians, survived.

PARIS, Dec. 26 (AP) -- French officials said today that "world peace is not the affair of two men or of two couuntries" in commenting on the possibility that Premier Stalin of Russia might meet Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 26 -- "Storm in the Spring" is the title for the drama of domestic conflict that Bette Davis will make this summer under the sponsorship of Bert Friedlob, independent producer of her current film, "The Star," which opened here yesterday

BONN, Germany, Dec. 26 (AP) -The Republican economy axe is believed certain to fall on what is projected as the largest American diplomatic establishment in the world. Cuts of 25 to 50 per cent in the United States and German staffs of the State Department in Germany are being widely forecast among United States officials here.
The Italians of New York have lost one of their best with the untimely death of Giorgio Di Veroli.

ADVANCE FIGHTER BASE, in Korea, Dec. 14 -- One of the lessons that has come out of Korea is that a war can not be won by air power alone -- especially when a good many of the strategic targets here are off-limits to United Nations bombers.

MOSCOW, Dec. 26 -- Premier Stalin appeared to some Moscow diplomats tonight to have offered Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower an excellent opportunity of making an important and practical test of what so often is referred to by Western diplomats as "Soviet good intentions."

HONG KONG, Dec. 26 -- Two French-Canadian nuns who had been serving five year prison terms in China on charges of "mass baby killing" at a Canton orphanage arrived here today from Canton following an unexpected Christmas Day pardon by Communist authorities in that Kwangtung city.

Mr. and Mrs. Harold Payne Whitmore of Palm Beach, Fla., and Greenwich, Conn., gave a supper dance last night in the St. Regis Roof for their debutante daughter, Miss Vera Lawrence Whitmore. The debutante, who received with her mother, wore a bouffant gown of white tulle, embroidered with pearls, and carried a bouquet of white spray orchids.

A New Yorker in the vicinity of Times Square or Grand Central at 2 o'clock of a holiday morning sees some strange sights, many of them not very edifying. Some, of course, are amusing, some shot through with all the romance and glamour of a big city only 10 per cent awake.
Next Friday, the first day for shopping in 1953, also will be the first time delicacy shops and department stores may display and sell British foods in special tins to commemorate the coronation.
New York arose yesterday, somewhat gasping, from the beribboned debris of another Christmas, and then settled down to enjoy more or less quietly the long holiday week-end.

The news about last night's "Tosca" at the Metropolitan Opera involved Delia Rigal, who was making her first appearance in the title role. Miss Rigal, who previously had sung a variety of other soprano parts, to greater or lesser advantage, found herself on firm ground in her ideas about the volatile, temperamental Floria Tosca.

The favorite argument of those who now oppose raising the transit fare in New York City is to point to the decline in passenger traffic that has occurred since the 5-cent fare was abandoned on July 1, 1948. There is no doubt that there was a decline, but the question opponents of a break-even fare never raise or answer is what would have happened if we had kept the 5-cent fare.

Acting on the assumption that recent violations of the law pertaining to employment of alien performers might be due to ignorance of the measure, Actors Equity Association last week ordered dissemination to Broadway producers and agents of the contents of a Government letter dealing with the subject.

Madison Square Garden's first Holidays Festival basketball tournament will get under way today with afternoon and evening double-headers. This new event, being staged under the joint sponsorship of New York University, Manhattan and St. John's, is an eight-team competition calling for eleven games in five sessions on three playing days.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade state, city and county bonds legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:

EDMONTON, Alta, Dec. 26 (UP) -- Georgie Dunn of Edmonton today enhanced his ranking as a world lightweight contender with a ten-round technical knockout of Carlos Chavez of Los Angeles. Dunn, 131 1/2, and Chavez, 136, fought before a Boxing Day crowd of 3,500.

Bruno-New York, Inc. metropolitan area distributor for radio and television products of the Radio Corporation of America, introduced yesterday twenty-five new television models at a meeting for local dealers in the Park Sheraton Hotel. Suggested-retail prices range from $199.95 to $795.

LA JOLLA, Calif, Dec. 26 -- Evidence that the newest volcano in the Western Hemisphere is a continenttal rather than an oceanic type, despite its appearance on an island separated from the Continental Shelf, was being studied today at the Scripps Institution of Oceanography here.

LONDON, Dec. 26 -- Airman First Class Ervin Williams of Winston-Salem, N. C., and the Atherford family of Hayes End, Middlesex, England, were resting today after a highly successful venture in British-American relations.

Yesterday was Boxing Day in the British Empire and markets in commonwealth countries were closed, among them the London Stock Exchange and the Winnipeg Grain Exchange. Boxing Day for some hundreds of years has been the day in Great Britain when the gentry has made up Christmas boxes for their servants and others of humble station.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., Dec. 26 (AP) -- Yankee coaches snorted at "southern hospitality" today and vowed to make themselves unwelcome guests at tomorrow's Blue-Gray gridiron fiesta.

Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the President-elect, took two hours out of a quiet day at home Yesterday to have a broken porcelain cap on one of his teeth replaced by his dentist. The President-elect had broken the same cap once before, during the election campaign.

NEWARK, Dec. 26 -- Former Chief Supreme Court Justice Clarence E. Case defended today the New Jersey Law Enforcement Council, of which he is chairman, against charges of neglect by Deputy State Attorney General Nelson F. Stamler.

ADELAIDE, Australia, Dec. 26 (AP) -- Indications today were that the Australians will pit their strongest team of Frank Sedgman and Ken McGregor against the Americans in the Davis Cup challenge round beginning Monday.

The last minute spurt in Christmas shopping this week brought sharp increases in sales over the comparative period last year and indicated that December trade here will at least break even with the record 1951 volume.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (UP) -- Senators J. William Fulbright of Arkansas and John J. Sparkman of Alabama, both Democrats and members of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, said today they were sure that the new Congress would extend the reciprocal trade program, even if with some modifications.
LONDON, Dec. 26 (Reuters) -- Hollywood stars captured all ten places in the international section of a poll for the biggest box-office draws in Britain this year.
Congratulations to THE NEW YORK TIMES for giving generous space to the tragedy of the two children in Levittown, L. I.

The Schools Motion Picture Committe, a voluntary organization of parents and teachers, recommends as suitable for children between 8 and 14 the following programs to be shown today and tomorrow unless otherwise noted:

TOKYO, Saturday, Dec. 27 -- United Nations troops turned back four Communist probing attacks along the Korean front yesterday. Allied tanks duelled with enemy armored vehicles on the approaches to the South Korean capital at Seoul.
GLEN COVE, L. I., Dec. 26 -- Notables in the tennis world gathered today at the famous court of Arthur Loew for a match awaited for weeks by residents of Long Island's North Shore.

Trans World Airlines announced yesterday that it was all but finished with the job of equipping a number of its Lockheed Constellations with "sleeper-seat" arrangements for the long trans-Atlantic and international flights. The first of the planes with the more comfortable seating arrangements will go into service on Jan. 5.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (AP) -- Florida Citrus Mutual, a large non-profit marketing association of Lakeland, Fla., was accused by the Federal Trade Commission today of operating outside the anti-trust laws.

Stan Musial, star outfielder-first baseman of the Cardinals, led the National League in slugging last season for the sixth time in his career, according to the official averages announced yesterday. Stan the Man topped the field with a percentage of .538, with second honors going to the Cubs' Hank Sauer, who compiled a mark of .531.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 26 -- A 26-year-old mother today survived the Caesarian-section birth of her fourth child, whom she cherished more than her own life.

ARCADIA, Calif., Dec. 26 (UP) -- Spanish Cream, a 15-1 shot, and Jockey Eric Guerin, getting a break when A Gleam suffered a racing mishap, raced to a three-length victory today in the $22,200 Las Flores Handicap, opening feature of the 50-day Santa Anita Park meeting before a crowd of nearly 45,000.
ALBANY, Dec. 26 (UP) -- The State Commerce Department today, reported the following winter sports conditions:

A hundred thousand former citizens of the Soviet Union have arrived in the United States since World War II and on the whole they are making a good adjustment to American life, Dr. Philip E. Mosely, head of the Ford Foundation's East European Fund, declared yesterday in a report on the fund's work in helping these refugees.

GENEVA, Dec. 26 -- Diplomatic representatives of the Soviet Union and its European satellite countries in Switzerland have been virtually cut off from all contact with the communities in which they are stationed except during office hours or at international meetings.
Clinton Foods, Inc., and its subsidiaries, yesterday reported a decline in sales of 4.3 per cent, but a rise in earnings of 206 per cent for the year ended on Sept. 30.

With reference to your editorial on General Naguib of Egypt which appeared in your paper on Dec. 15 I wish to state that I am in full accord with your expression of hope for a new deal for Egypt under the General.

Shepard H. Spies, chairman of the board of the Security Banknote Company, urged stockholders of the concern yesterday to ignore a stockholders' protective committee's request to remove many of the present directors. The protective committee is led by Sylvester W. Muldowny, president of the company.

At the request of the French Line, the Immigration and Naturalization Service has released the liner Liberte from a "gentleman's agreement" between the company and the Govern ment agency to send an inspector to sea for three round trips to screen crew members under the provisions of the McCarran-Walter Immigration and Nationality Law.

The fifteen-story and penthouse apartment building at 333 West End Avenue, southwest corner of Seventy-sixth Street, has been purchased by M. Robert Steel, who said yesterday that this was the fourth property of its kind he had acquired on the West Side in recent months.

WHISPERING the last enchantments of the middle-aged, a group of donnish and distinguished Oxford authorities gathered in their college's common room on a summer evening in 1949 to discuss the secret of the university. Three imperfectly identified American V. I. P.'s were looming alarmingly as guests at the resolutely antique seat of learning.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, Dec. 26 (AP) -- The touring United States college soccer team, with representatives from Yale, Dartmouth, Cornell and Pennsylvania, defeated Bermuda's National Sports Club, 4 -- 2, before a crowd of 2,000 today.

Contributions pouring into the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund from every quarter of the country added $9,464.27 yesterday to achieve a campaign total of $334,024.95 -- enough to increase the lead over that for the same date last year by $93,459.17. But the forty-first annual appeal needs about $66,000 to surpass the record of $400,012.11 set in 1946-47.
HOLLYWOOD, Dec. 27 -- A cooperative non-profit organization to aid cancer research is being formed in memory of Dixie Lee Crosby, who died last Nov. 1. She was the wife of Bing Crosby.
MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Dec. 27 (AP) -- Tom Von Mello of Wareham, Mass., won both heats of the B stock runabout class today in out-board competition at the Orange Bowl Regatta.

The elm bark beetle, which spreads the fungus causing Dutch elm disease, is no respecter of state or town boundaries. Each year its slow but steady march invades new territory. Maine authorities have reported the first infected tress in that state, making the roll-call complete for the northeastern states.

The first recording of the ballet, "Cakewalk," which had its initial performance in 1951, will be played in its entirety on Wednesday in the noon-to-2 P. M. recorded concert at the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street.

MONSIGNOR SHEEHY'S first novel adapts the "Bridge of San Luis Rey" technique to the story of nine people who regularly attended six o'clock mass in St. Jude's Church in a Midwestern city. The pattern is a crotchety one, and it is no discredit to the modest Monsignor, who in a foreword pleads "literary and intellectual inadequacy," that the novel does not quite come off.

THE modern Olympics are so well organized and widely publicized that it is a little difficult to realize the informal spirit of this international competition back in the early days of the century. In the 1900 games, held in Paris, there wasn't even a cinderpath for the runners, and the American team refused to take part in the opening events because they fell on a Sunday.

THE real key to the drama of "The Deep Blue Sea" lies in the young lover's role. While James Hanley gives an exceptional performance, it taxes the imagination too far to picture him as a decaying handsome hero of the Battle of Britain.

Dr. Joseph E. Johnson, president of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, yesterday attributed the "extremely somber" outlook for world peace chiefly to the "policies, actions and attitudes of the Soviet rulers." He said the Kremlin's definition of "peace" had little in common with the endowment's.

Two new permanent playgrounds may be built soon in a congested section of Greenwich Village under plans announced yesterday by Park Commissioner Robert Moses and Robert F. Wagner Jr., Borough President of Manhattan. Part of the land required already is in use as two small temporary parks.

LONDON, Dec. 27 -- The unexpected decision of Prime Minister Churchill to see President-elect Eisenhower without waiting for the inauguration can be interpreted as an attempt to renew the intimate relationship that existed between Mr. Churchill and the late President Roosevelt.

MANILA, Sunday, Dec. 28 -- A country-wide series of synchronized mass arrests among Chinese residents of the Philippines has cracked two large Communist party organizations having direct connections with Red China and held responsible by Filipino military authorities for supplying and supporting the Hukbalahap rebellion against the Government.

BUFFALO -- The Niagara Frontier, with the help of an ambitious master plan prepared recently by the Niagara Frontier Parks Commission, seems destined to improve its traditional hold on tourists from all parts of this country.

NAIROBI, Kenya, Dec. 27 -- The Mau Mau troubles festering with peculiar savagery in a particularly lovely portion of this crown colony are symptomatic of the deep undercurrent of change that rumbles beneath the surface of Africa.
The commentator James Fassett, talking during the New York Philharmonic intermission about the Waukesha Symphony Orchestra, revealed only half of the story. Here's the other half.

FROM where this observer sits, 1952 appeared to be a year of consolidation in the classical record industry. Disks were issued in a ceaseless flow, with not as many duplications of repertoire as one might expect. The periphery of the repertoire continued to be searched, with the usual ensuing amount of baroque and/or modern esoterica.

Christmas week brought a lull to financial activities in Wall Street. Business was done on only four days, in observance of the holiday, but most of the activity was centered in the first two days of the week. Trading at that time totaled 2,100,000 shares each day as stocks advanced to new highs since 1930.
The "new talent" boxing show idea in Madison Square Garden is a fixture, at least for the remainder of the current indoor season.

The Chicago Black Hawks will tackle the New York Rangers in the National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden tonight. Sid Abel's crew from the Windy City has a decided edge over the Blues this year, with two victories in New York as against one defeat and three successes and a tie in Chicago.

KANSAS CITY, Dec. 27 (AP) -- Two free throws by John Weber, captain, with four seconds remaining, gave Yale a 56-54 victory over Colorado in the final first-round game of the Big Seven Conference pre-season basketball tournament tonight.

CONTRACT bridge is booming as 1952 draws to a close. More books are being sold, more bridge lessons being given, than in any year since 1935. Tournament attendance during 1952 increased for the twelfth consecutive year.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 27 -- Causes and responsibilities involved in the wreck of the 12,500-ton French liner Champollion, which went aground three miles south of Beirut at dawn Monday and later broke up, will be determined by an inquiry conducted in France by the Inscription Maritime, an agency of the Ministry of Merchant Marine.

CATFISH derbies, date and camellia festivals are among a whirl of activities for Southern California's post-holiday season. At Indio, a short distance from Palm Springs, the National Date Festival from Feb. 18 to 23 presents novel entertainment with camel races (the jockeys are local cowboys) and other high jinks.

The medical sensation of 1952 was the remarkable efficacy of isonicotinic acid nydrazid, or isoniazid, in tuberculosis. After months of experience physicians admit its merits but decline to accept it as the miracle-worker it was thought to be at first. The medicos are still in favor of treatment with streptomycin and para-aminosalicylic acid, perhaps in combination with isoniazid.

With Giant players already mulling over their 1953 salary offerings and with the Dodgers braced to receive theirs at any moment -- in fact, several opening bids have been mailed out -- only the world champion Yankees, among the three local major league entries, have yet to make a move in that direction.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 27 -- An unpublished "Passion According to St. John" by the early Italian composer Alessandro Scarlatti will be presented by the Yale University Orchestra, with members of the Choir of St. Thomas' Church here, and the Collegium Musicum of Yale, Monday night in Battell Chapel.

The G. I. in the Korean hills with one ear cocked for a possible alert knows that he can get out of his sleeping bag in a hurry. The slide fastener on the bag looks like an ordinary zipper with one important difference. The slider can be taken off the top and the zipper will fall open with one light pull.
MIAMI, Dec. 27 -- Alabama and Syracuse sweltered under the Florida sun today, more worried about the heat than each other in preparation for their Orange Bowl football game New Year's Day.
In an effort to point up Soviet aversion for modern art, Mr. Barr disposes of Ilya Repin, the greatest Russian nineteenth-century artist, with a few words like "colossal, quasi-photographic."

Education can be more effective than direct financial aid in improving underdeveloped countries, it is held in an extensive study covering fifty-nine nations of the free world. Eighty per cent of these nations were found to have inadequate educational programs.

CHICAGO, Dec. 27 -- Statisticians and economists attending the annual forecasting sessions of their professional organizations here were virtually unanimous today in the belief that business activity would be maintained at high levels through the first three quarters of 1953.

HEADQUARTERS, Eighth Army in Korea, Dec. 27 -- A briefing on the last twelve months of "this mean little Korean war" noted today that the United Nations forces, in the face of a numerically superior enemy, had confined communism in this country to the area north of the battle line.

THIS is the time of year when men and women in the West like to think of gentle and comfortable things -- of families gathered together, of children bright-eyed with the excitement of presents, of candles lit in windows, lights burning before the Christmas crib, of love and unity, and the peace promised to men of goodwill.
Icy northwest winds, which reached fifty miles an hour in gusts, brought the season's coldest weather to the city last night.

Your London correspondent recently wrote of his surprise at finding the opera "Norma" exciting. Is this a testament to his youth or do pre-World War I Teutonic tonic influences still hold sway in England as they do, indeed, in too many places .hereabouts ?

THE sixteenth annual Wright Brothers lecture, given in Washington on Dec. 17, the forty-ninth anniversary of the first flight by the Wright brothers, had much in common with the first hop off the sands at Kitty Hawk, N. C.

Early in 1927, Harold J. Siesel was "let out" of his first and only salaried job in the advertising field. Obtaining another at the time was a difficult proposition, so after several months of fruitless searching he acted on the old maxim, "if you can't lick em, join em."

V.S. PRITCHETT, discussing the merits of T. S. Eliot (Book Review, Nov. 30), refers to London as "the most squalid and disorganized city on earth." He finds it strange that both Henry James and Eliot developed an "unreasonable love of London."

NOT even Lawrence of Arabia knew the sun-blasted land that gave him fame more intimately than Evetts Haley knows the Staked Plains and the territory fringing them; nor did he put more geography into "The Seven Pillars of Wisdom" than Haley has put into "Fort Concho and the Texas Frontier."
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 27 (UP) -- The United States Trotting Association reported today that this has been the best year in light harness racing history.

Correspondents of THE TIMES in ten world capitals were asked last week to summarize the mood in their country as the year draws to a close. Their reports indicate a cautious confidence that the year ahead will bring some improvement in world conditions, and an attitude of watchful waiting to see what the new American Administration will do.

A COSMOPOLITE by inclination, but a Londoner by sentiment, Evelyn Waugh's brother, Alec, has been a consistent and dependable performer in the field of the novel for a full generation now, though he is almost as well-known as a travel diarist.

LIKE the shopper who is currently checking a depleted purse or dolorously contemplating a once gaudily wrapped gift, one is reminded that this is the time for reckoning. And since it is the season for appraisal this annual scanning of the records reveals, as it has in past years, that the hopeful plans of some picture people did not materialize and that, as the noted Irving Berlin ditty goes, "there's no business like show business."

ARCADIA, Calif., Dec. 27 -- De Anza emerged as the top 2-year-old in the West today by scoring a length-and-a-half victory at Santa Anita in the $40,360 California Breeders Championship, top half of a double stakes program.

EVER since the turn of the cenutry American literature has had a habit of falling, sometimes headlong, into convenient decades: realism in the Twenties, naturalism in the Thirties, the war during the Forties. But the midcentury decade, now three years old, has as yet no label.

The possibility of a delay or postponement in the scheduled meeting tomorrow of the executive committee of the Democratic party of Kings County to decide a long- smouldering leadership fight was indicated yesterday.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Dec. 27 -- Premier Stalin's statement this week that he would regard favorably diplomatic steps toward a meeting with Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower has stirred the imagination of the Israelis. Although they are firmry angned with the West.

No lessening of the general business trend is in prospect for the first six months of 1953, according to 55 per cent of purchasing executives reporting in the monthly business survey of the National Association of Purchasing Agents.
Brooklyn Chapter, American Red Cross, has named Hugh R. Cuthrell co-chairman of the Brooklyn Red Cross 1953 Fund drive. Walter H. Rothschild is chairman of the borough appeal.

QUEBEC -- Skiing began a week ago in the region whose headquarters is Quebec City, where heavy snowfall on an average altitude of 1,000 feet produces frequent renewal of the powder-snow surface and a season that often extends up to May in some places.

THE codifier of the French "high cuisine," Auguste Escoffier, informs the chefs for whom he wrote his classic that three kinds of chicory are used in the kitchen. The third is, he says, "Belgian chicory, called endive, obtained from cultivating the root of Flemish chicory in the dark."

I READ recently Olin Downes' article in the Sunday TIMES in which he quoted Floyd A. Blair, president of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, as being against Government subsidy for music and the arts.

THAT master of lightness in both verse and prose, A. A. Milne, calls his latest volume "a calendar of disconnected thoughts and memories." As a calendar, he has divided the book into twelve sections, named for the months.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 27 -- The Yugoslav Parliament ratified today the Government's social plan for 1953. The plan calls for continued heavy sacrifices at a time when, according to official reports, Yugoslavia is entering the new year with only fifteen days' supplies of raw materials.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 27 -- Johnny O'Brien established a new four - year collegiate basketball scoring record tonight as his Seattle University team scored a 90-to-77 victory over St. Joseph's College.

A refinement of Stanford University's widely used Strong Vocational Interest Test now will tell a man not only whether he is likely to enjoy being a doctor, but also what kind -- surgeon, internist, pathologist or psychiatrist. More than 4,000 physicians and nearly 800 medical school seniors were queried in developing the new test.
LONDON, Dec. 27 (AP) -- Londoners coughed and groped their way through lung-stinging fog tonight. It was the second "pea souper" of the month, making this December rough even by London standards.

ADELAIDE, Australia, Sunday, Dec. 28 -- The united States captain, Vic Seixas, drew Australia's top ace, Frank Sedgman, in the opening singles match of the Davis Cup challenge round, beginning here Monday. Today's draw sent Tony Trabert of Cincinnati against Ken McGregor in the second singles tilt.

AS is the annual custom on the final Sunday of the year, this corner today makes its selections of the best films of 1952. And again, as is the custom -- though the reason for it is hard to say -- the number of films which are designated as the all-around "best" is ten.

FIFTEEN years ago this month a soprano completely unknown to America made her debut at the Metropolitan Opera House. Edward Johnson, then general manager, had heard her in Prague in the summer of 1937, had engaged her and had studiously refrained from puffing her before her first appearance.
ONCE again, according to precedent, it is time to count our blessings -- or to discount them, as the case may be -- before we say good-by to the old year.

Whatever may be the make-up of the Eisenhower Administration's Council of Economic Advisers, it is already clear that the new Administration has already made up its mind that the place to go for prime economic guidance is the executive set-up of the long-established Federal Reserve System.

For many years it has been sought to extend the "tax benefit" rule, under Federal income tax laws, to the treatment of depreciation, obsolescence, amortization and depletion. The House of Representatives sponsored such a bill (H. R. 3168) in 1951, which would have been effective as to taxable years beginning after Dec. 31, 1947, but this failed of passage in the Senate.

THE season for New Year's resolutions being upon us, we have been tempted to share these hours of soul-searching and uplifting resolve with our friends in the art world. Lest they are too busy to make up their own lists, we offer some suggestions.

We take exception to the builders' opinion that Pennsylvania's Levittown is "the most perfectly planned community in America." There may be other places better entitled to the designation, but we would nominate Washington, planned by Major l'Enfant 150 years ago, or Garden City, N. Y.

FIFTY years ago Europe enjoyed world leadership which was at once political, economic and cultural. It has declined from that position to a point where today it is weaker and more divided than at any period since the tenth century. World leadership has passed to the U. S. A. and the U. S. S. R., between which Europe plays the dependent role that the Balkans played in the nineteenth century.

At the big Elysee Palace in Paris last week important political figures streamed in to call on French President Vincent Auriol. The President had a job to offer. On Tuesday Antoine Pinay had resigned as Premier. For the eighteenth time since Liberation, France was without a Government.

In his letter of Dec. 7 Harold H. Corbin deplores the drawing of any inference of criminal conduct from the refusal of a public employe to answer questions under oath on the ground that his answers may incriminate him. Any such inference, it is said, makes mockery of the Fifth Amendment to the Federal Constitution.

Retail stocks have been cleared to a greater extent than in many years as the last three days before Christmas saw heavy buying, according to Kirby, Block Co., Inc., resident buying office. Stores will be open to buy more January sales merchandise than normally and many buyers are expected in the market next month.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (UP) -- New foreign aid figures revealed today that United States arms shipments abroad lagged badly in the third quarter of 1952.

CHARLESTON, S. C., Dec. 27 (AP) -- A thirty-foot auxiliary sloop with three New Yorkers aboard, unreported on a voyage from Charleston to Miami for almost two months, became the object of a Coast Guard search here today.

THE combination of wintry winds and closing seasons will send great numbers of sportsmen southward during the next six weeks, and the tone or the inquiries, as well as their volume, indicates that many expect to try the Southern hunting and fishing for the first time.

ANYONE knowing as little about butterflies as I do about birds may find Audubon's lepidoptera as attractive as his bright, active, theatrical birds are to me. Whatever those birds do, I am with them, heartily sharing, for instance, the open-billed wonder of "Green Heron" at the fantastic situation and spurious colors of "Luna Moth" in a famous picture of the "Birds" folio.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Dec. 27 (AP) -- Two seeded players were extended to three sets today to win their third-round matches in the junior boys' division of the sixth annual Orange Bowl junior tennis tournament.

ROSSINI'S "La Cenerentola" will be presented in the spring by the New York City Opera Company. This is the opera buffa Rossini composed the year after "The Barber of Seville." It is based on the Cinderella story, though it replaces the fairy godmother with a visiting philosopher and the glass slipper with an identifying bracelet Its heroine is a contralto.

MOST of us would give a right arm and a couple of wisdom teeth to be able to hear Will Shakespeare read some passages from King Lear, or John Milton intone a few pentameters from "Samson Agonistes" or hear John Keats' somber passion as he reads "Bright Star."

Canada may be considering action to end or curb "loss leader" retail selling within her borders. The American Fair Trade Council last week made public correspondence that indicates "loss leaders" are causing concern to the Dominion Government.

Text of the radio talk by Ambassador Warren R. Austin yesterday in cooperation with the Woodrow Wilson Foundation on the ninety-sixth birthday anniversary of President Wilson, entitled "My Mission to the United Nations":

AT this time of year gardeners alleviate their restlessness somewhat looking at new catalogues and taking heart in rearranging the border for the coming spring. In the meantime, how to soothe the throbbing ache in their green thumbs? The pit greenhouse solves the problem neatly.

There can be little doubt that the conflict over German participation in the European Defense Community has reached a critical stage. It is aggravated but not caused by the constitutional dispute which tests the new German democracy severely and threatens to make the Constitutional Court the football of political maneuvering.
TOKYO, Sunday, Dec. 28 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,477, for Saturday's operations:

SAMUEL CHOTZINOFF, music director for the National Broadcasting Company, ex-music critic, teacher concert pianist, and a man who does not ordinarily lay claim to clairvoyance, foresees the next decade as one in which opera will become as natural to American life as Broadway theatre or the movies.

An end-of-the-year inventory shows that services for the disabled continued to grow in 1952 as the result of the opening of new hospital programs, an expansion in the facilities for crippled children and an increased emphasis on the training of professional personnel.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (AP) -- The American Federation of Labor promised today its honest cooperation in the year ahead to the new Republican Administration.

John Wallenberg, 62 years old, of 476 West Twenty-second Street, an unemployed dishwasher, was ordered sent to Bellevue Hospital for observation after his arraignment yesterday morning in Felony Court on a homicide charge growing out of the fatal beating of an elderly charwoman three weeks ago.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 27 (UP) -- Top-seeded Gardnar Mulloy of Miami advanced today to the semi-finals of the Sugar Bowl tennis tournament by downing Dave Brown of New Orleans, 6 -- 0, 6 -- 1, and Grant Golden of Chicago, 6 -- 2, 3 -- 6, 9 -- 7.

LEONARDO, N. J., Dec. 27 -- The Navy has intensified its already rigid security screening of union longshoremen sent to work at the naval ammunition pier here as a result of recent testimony at hearings by the New York State Crime Commission on waterfront racketeering, Navy spokesmen said today.

BOSTON, Dec. 27 -- A three-year program to advance the study of foreign languages in this country was announced today in connection with the opening of the sixty-seventh annual meeting of the Modern Language Association of America. The program will be aided by a grant of $120,000 from the Rockefeller Foundation.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 27 -- The new anti-TB drug, isoniazid, appears to be more effective than streptomycin against several of the most deadly forms of tuberculosis and is just about as effective as streptomycin against tuberculosis of the lungs, it was reported here today at the annual meeting of the American Association for the Advancement of Science.

Paul Peltz, 15-year-old boy whose battered body was found Friday in a Bronx lot, had "a mania for guns," the police said yesterday as they intensified their search for a missing air rifle the boy took from his home on Tuesday night "to make a trade."

WHEN Joe Pulaski and his parents arrived at the Turner farm in New York State it seemed like paradise after their years in a displaced persons camp. Even when his new schoolmates teased him and the school bully was openly hostile, Joe knew he wanted to stay in America.

MUCH social history has flowed from the press in the last two decades, and much has been written about the importance of the frontier, but the influence of the one on the other has been little discussed. It is well to know how the American colonists lived, but it is more important to know why they lived as they did.

Plans for the construction in this city of a College of Pastoral Work, designed to give Protestant Episcopal clergymen practical experience in ministering to churches in heavily populated urban areas, were announced yesterday by the Rev. Dr. John Heuss, rector of Trinity Church, Broadway and Wall Street.

There are hundreds of millions of tons of high grade bituminous coal in Queensland, Australia. American ingenuity, know-how and private capital are combining in an effort to make this essential source of fuel available to widely-separated parts of the world.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- Among all the problems that frown out upon President-elect Eisenhower, none is likely to be much more difficult than keeping the desperate balance between the Bill of Rights and the security of the United States.
MANILA, Dec. 27 (AP) -- The Philippines took a 2-1 lead in an invitation three-day tennis tournament with Italy by scoring a doubles match victory today, before 3,000 fans.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 27 (AP) -- The background of Mrs. Ethel Arata, 52 years old, who has admitted she is Southern California's "grandma bank bandit," continued to unfold with more surprises today.
In Venezuela censorship blacked out election returns. In Colombia mob action put two newspapers temporarily out of business.

The recent expressions of Premier Stalin of the Soviet Union on the easing of world tensions and an end to the Korean war were discussed "very slantingly" yesterday by Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the President-elect, and Lewis W. Douglas, former American Ambassador to Britain.

Prof. S. Charles Kendeigh of the University of Illinois maintains that "parental care has reached its highest and most elaborate development in birds, since birds must care for their young during the embryo stage as well."
COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Sunday, Dec. 28 (AP) -- Queen Mother Alexandrine, 73, died today after a long illness.
A young thug who crouched in the front seat of a car yesterday while its owner, a costume jewelry manufacturer, was getting a haircut, robbed him of $6,000 when he stepped in to drive away.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- Gordon Dean, chairman of the United States Atomic Energy Commission, predicted today that the first stationary atomic power plants would be designed in 1953.

One of the most unusual of the various channels in which American help is being given to the needy is "Aid to Refugee Chinese Intellectuals." This organization, which enjoys a sponsorship of the highest character, is devoted to helping solve the problems of more than 10,000 anti-Communist Chinese who are stranded in Hong Kong and are a part of the main culture stream of the free world.
The aluminum industry, which has been anxious for a price rise, can have it as part of a rather unusual package arranged by the Defense Production Administration.

TOKYO, Sunday, Dec. 28 -- United Nations patrols clashed yesterday with Communist troops in increasing strength all across the frozen Korean front from "Anchor Hill," near the east coast, to Panmunjom in the west.

IN the last years of the seventeenth century an attempt was made to establish a Scottish colony in Darien. Robert Carse here portrays that brave, futile enterprise through the eyes of Ewen, Laird Laikie, who was 16 when he left his castle in Scotland for the New World.

ONE December night, just fifteen years ago, Robert E. Sherwood, Maxwell Anderson and Elmer Rice stopped at a Madison Avenue bar to relax a little after a long evening at a Dramatists' Guild meeting. Neither Sherwood nor Anderson knew Rice very well, for Rice had quit the Broadway theatre several years before, angered by what seemed to him its shocking indifference to serious playwriting.

BILOXI, Miss., Dec. 27 (AP) -- Mississippi's fifty-two-man football squad arrived by plane today to begin final training sessions for a Sugar Bowl date with Georgia Tech at New Orleans on New Year's Day.

CLIFTON WEBB, a man who wouldn't be caught dead in a pair of overalls, has, nevertheless, a chuckle usually heard in the vicinity of a cracker barrel. Coming from the pride and joy of Twentieth Century-Fox, it invariably underscores some pungent remark by a genial professional who seems to harbor few illusions about what makes actors, including himself, run.

MOSCOW, Dec. 27 -- The Government newspaper Izvestia declared today that Premier Stalin's answers to four questions asked of him by James Reston, diplomatic correspondent of THE NEW YORK TIMES, meant that the Soviet Union was prepared to solve, by means of conferences and other peaceful methods, all outstanding unsettled international questions, including the sharpest issues, such as Korea.

For the first time in more than a decade, high school enrollment is beginning to go up. The next few years will show a reversal of the downward trend that began about ten years ago and reflected the impact of the depression of the Thirties and the educational disruption caused by World War II.

NEW YORK CITY has many praiseworthy qualities but the last and least of these is a feeling of piety toward its own past. Every generation or so its face is drastically redone and what little remains of the old after such operations either crumbles away or is converted to unworthy uses. Only the incomparably elegant City Hall still stands as a monument of humane architecture.

ADVOCATES of liberal education have been on the defensive for a long time. Gordon K. Chalmers, president of Kenyon College, arms them in "The Republic and the Person" for an aggressive attack on their critics.

IN accordance with tradition this is the week for a backward glance at the year in television and radio together with a mention of some of the programs and people making special contributions to the art of broadcasting.

MILLBURN, N. J. AS Frank Carrington, director of the Paper Mill Playhouse sees it, the theatre in suburban Millburn has come full circle. "First, about twelve years or so ago, we operated as a summer theatre," Carrington explained. "Then we expanded our seasons and ran on through the fall and into the early winter.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Dec. 27 -- Dixie All-Stars, led by the brilliant signal calling of Ray Graves of Texas A. and M., and the plunging fullback, Leroy Lebat of Louisiana State, punched the Yankees full of holes today and won the annual Blue-Gray football game, 28 -- 7.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (UP) -- Three officers who served under General Eisenhower in Europe in World War II will be grand marshals of the inauguration parade Jan. 20, Joseph C. McGarraghy, chairman of the inaugural committee, announced today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- The Committee on Un-American Activities of the House of Representatives recommended today in its annual report that the Federal Government's emergency powers to deal with suspected espionage be "placed on a wartime basis."

HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Dec. 27 -- A jump shot from the foul line fifteen seconds before the final buzzer by Edward Cahn enabled Lehigh to score a 58-56 victory over Alfred before an overflow crowd of 1,200 in an opening-round game of the second annual Hofstra Invitation Basketball tournament tonight.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 27 (AP) -- The Fort Wayne Zollners overcame an 18-point deficit in the fourth quarter tonight to beat the New York Knicks, 92 -- 91, in a thrilling National Basketball Association game.

Mayor John V. Kenny of Jersey City will, in effect, be questioned by proxy when he appears tomorrow as a witness at the public hearing of the New Jersey Law Enforcement Council, it became evident yesterday.
MOTORISTS will scramble during the next month for the New Jersey maps that have been revised to unscramble that state's road numbering system.

BY the end of this year an estimated 257,000,000 pocket-sized books will have rolled through the presses, costing the reading public about $65,000,000. This is an awe-inspiring figure for an infant industry which only seven years ago, was struggling along on 66,000,000 copies, a great many of which could be explained by the popularity of Erle Stanley Gardner.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State-designate, has declined with thanks the invitation of a Congressional committee to explain his part in the selection of Alger Hiss as president of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace.

A husband and wife in Begot, Colombia, and a man in Paris joined yesterday the growing list of contributors to the forty-first annual appeal of the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. Their two donations of $25 helped to bring gifts for the day to $6,564.18 from 399 donors.

Standpatters in Wall Street will stagger under another determined attack some time in January. They have given ground this year on Saturday closings, on extension of trading hours and on retirement of New York Stock Exchange seats. This time they will be asked to approve permissive incorporation of Stock Exchange firms.

BOSTON, Dec. 27 -- The appointment of Dr. Joseph M. Hayman Jr. of Cleveland as dean of the Tufts College Medical School was announced tonight by Arthur J. Anderson, president of the board of trustees of Tufts College. Dr. Hayman succeeds Dr. Dwight O'Hara who recently resigned.

AN American returning home after a Government assignment in Europe for nearly three years finds himself -- or every one else -- completely out of step. Old friends may put out the red carpet and entertain him lavishly; the atmosphere is warm but the setting is strange, and values and interests seem to belong to a different world, almost as different as the one you find when you first arrive in Europe.

OFFHAND it would appear that the Columbia Broadcasting System's new $12,000,000 Television City in Hollywood has been snubbed by one of its star producers. Cy Howard, creator of "My Friend Irma" and "Life With Luigi" and a resident of Hollywood in recent years, has arrived here to create a new television program.

Alfred H. Barr Jr. in "Is Modern Art Communistic?" (Dec. 14) writes an apology for extremist art largely on the ground that it was rejected by the Nazis and the Soviets. Representative Dondero bundles all such art together and throws it over the Iron Curtain; the Soviets promptly throw it back, marked "Unfit for use."
Here are offered refresher fashions for girls returning to school or college. They have been selected with an eye to their practicality. Among the fabrics are Orlon, and Orlon and wool jersey.

A Group of color prints by such well-known processes as carbon, carbro, Dye Transfer and Flexichrome, will be introduced as a new feature in the twentieth Wilmington International Exhibition of Photography, which is to be held from Feb. 1 to 23 at the Wilmington Society of the Fine Arts' Art Center in Wilmington.

WE all know the big names of the current investigation into crime and corruption on New York's waterfront. The headlines are hogged by Anastasia, Joe Ryan, Mike Clemente, "Big" Bill McCormack, the polished executives of the great shipping lines and influential stevedores.

George Mandel, second-seeded player from Astoria, Queens, was one of ten contestants to reach the third round as play in the boys' division of the Eastern indoor tennis championships started yesterday at the Seventh Regiment Armory. Mandel drew a first-round bye and then halted Joseph Skowronki of Brooklyn, 6 -- 2, 6 -- 0.

MOST woodchucks are uncooperative creatures -- but not Lonnie's pet. When his master called Chucky came, and when grandpappy started fiddling, Chucky turned somersaults in time to the music. Naturally, such a talented performer attracted attention.

Measuring what business has done in order to figure out what will happen next is no easy task. Production statistics on electric power, paperboard, lumber and a few others tell not only what goes on within the industry itself, but, because of their end-uses, indicate what is happening in the consuming industries.

THERE is a possibility that Carson McCullers, who won a Critics Circle Award for the dramatization of her own novel, "The Member of the Wedding," may be doing another dramatization, this one based on "Anne Frank: The Diary of a Young Girl."

KENILWORTH, N. J., Dec. 27 -- Three persons were killed and two were injured when two cars crashed head-on on Kenilworth Boulevard near the Rahway Valley Railroad crossing here shortly before 2 P. M. today. Police Chief George D. Conklin said it was the first fatal traffic accident here in three years.

THAT strange romance full of swordplay and erotic fire and antique evil, "The Worm Ouroboros," is at last being reissued. Only a handful of people know -- or ever knew -- that it was issued in the first place. Its republication after thirty years, as Orville Prescott notes in his glowing introduction, is "a literary event of the first importance."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (AP) -- The Defense Department identified today 107 casualties of the Korean War. The new list included twenty killed, seventy-seven wounded, three injured in accidents and seven missing. (The following were listed from New York; none from New Jersey or Connecticut):

Graduates of the College of the University of Chicago, which admits students after as little as two years of high school, can more than hold their own with graduates of traditional colleges who have had one or two more years of formal study, according to a current report.

Governor Dewey firmly rebuffed yesterday the efforts by the city to involve the state in the dispute between the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., and eight New York private bus lines, which threatens to result in a strike on New Year's Day.

CHRISTMAS trade is now a matter of history, except for refunds, returns and exchanges. Volume ran ahead of last year in many areas, and probably exceeded that for 1951 by a slight margin for the country as a whole.

WHEN Ti Andre sets out from his Haitian mountain home with his mother he has a secret project in mind. Like little boys in almost any part of the world, he wants to fly and he is sure that in Port-au-Prince he will get his wish.

THE son of a Westphalian blacksmith, Heinrich Oberjohann loved animals from his earliest childhood and grew up to earn a living as a big game collector. "I began working with elephants when I was 19 years old," he writes, "but it was not until I met up with those giants in the wilderness that I really got to know them."

IN recent criticism it has become a commonplace to blame the low estate of literature in general and the novel in particular on society's failure to provide young writers with a "stable order of values" or "common assumptions of value." These phrases appear in recent books on the novel by James W. Aldridge and Edward Wagenknecht.

GALVESTON, Tex., Dec. 27 (AP) -- Don Gottlob, the nation's total offense leader, passed for three touchdowns today as Sam Houston State, which had won only five games during the season, routed Northeastern State of Oklahoma, 41 -- 20, in the Shrimp Bowl football game.

" IF these walls could only talk . . ." A bromide -- but breathes there a man with soul so dead who, on glimpsing some anomalously picturesque old structure, hasn't felt curiosity about the story behind it?

IN this monumental series we are getting the fullest documentation of the activities of an American that has ever appeared in print. The unexampled scope of the work was apparent from the first announcement, but entries of a fresh sort appear in the present volume.

Warren R. Austin, about to retire as permanent United States representative to the United Nations, yesterday counseled the country that it could not stand alone, could not survive without spiritual growth, and "must strengthen its freedom now through fullest participation in and support for the United Nations."
Penn Kimball's "Dream Town -- Large Economy Size" (Dec. 14) omits one important statement: Levittown admits no Negroes.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- The military high command stepped up its call for draftees for the Army today to the highest level reached since early in the Korean war. It asked Selective Service to induct 53,000 men in February.

DALLAS, Dec. 27 (UP) -- Texas and Tennessee, who will renew their Cotton Bowl rivalry New Year's Day, finished practice on their home fields today with only the matter of a little overweight on the Tennessee squad raising any concern among the rival coaches.
SEOUL, Korea, Sunday, Dec. 28 (AP) -- Francis Cardinal Spellman visited Korean air bases yesterday, giving his blessing to thousands of airmen. He is visiting the war front for the second Christmas.

PARIS, Dec. 27 -- Jacques Soustelle, the chief lieutenant of Gen. Charles de Gaulle, decided today to prolong his consultations for the formation of a Cabinet, but with lessening probability that he would ask the National Assembly to approve him as Premier. He said that he would give his final answer to President Vincent Auriol tomorrow.

MILITARY pictures are proving to be good box-office attractions these days. Immediately after the war such films -- along with everything else deemed to be "militaristic," such as toy guns for children -- were prohibited by diligent Occupation authorities.

TO the outsider, Kansas is a hot, dry, wheat-and-grass state that gained fame from John Brown, Carrie Nation, William Allen White and Dwight D. Eisenhower. Some remember that John Steuart Curry lived and painted there, that William Allen White once advised Kansans to raise more corn and less hell.
ALBANY, Dec. 27 (AP) -- The State Harness Racing Commisssion approved today a 452-day program of pari-mutuel racing for 1953 at the seven tracks licensed in New York.

CONCOCTED by the author of "Web of Lucifer," this novel indicates that, on the whole, Maurice Samuel has lost none of his cunning for the proper presentation of an interesting tale, even when, as here, it is an improbable story. It is, in essence, a retelling of the Gulliver opus, and a. com.parison with the original is inevitable. Dean Swift, it must be said, has not his peer in file present realm.

AS 1952 comes to a close, New York bankers may look back on one of the most profitable years since the banking holiday in 1933. Moreover, indications are that the coming year will see a continuation of the high level of loans, interest rates and earnings.

It is no secret around the house that this is the time of the Christmas vacation. From colleges, schools and down to the romping kindergarten, serious-minded students have returned to the house, where they are turning home into a shambles. By now any parent will be inclined to say, as he has said each year before, that the Christmas vacation is far too long.

There used to be a time when people sat down comfortably at the end of the year and measured progress. Nobody, except a few skeptics, doubted the fact of progress. Just as the earth went round the sun, and by a somewhat similar law, so, it appeared, humanity was growing wiser and better.

This writer, with keen expectation, attended the Metropolitan's first performance of Puccini's "La Boheme" as sung in the English translation, or "English version," of Howard Dietz, with decor and costumes by Rolf Gerard, and stage direction by Joseph L. Mankiewicz, yesterday afternoon in the Metropolitan Opera House.

WHEN James Boyd died eight years ago at the age of 56, American fiction lost a very sound and sturdy writer. Quietly, seriously, he had produced a slow succession of novels -- "Drums" and 'Marching On" perhaps most memorable among them -- distinguished by their rich and authoritative understanding of the American past as well as by their simple and deep concern about human beings.

THERE is plenty of gloom in the highway accident research findings presented by the Property and Casualty Insurance Institute of the University of Kansas City as the New Year moves in. A record of failure in insurance coverage and in important elements of road safety is shown, with a warning that perilous conditions have been created that will take years to correct.

The justifiable resentment against the archaic rules of the United States Senate which facilitate filibusters has obscured the problem of democratizing the rules of the House of Representatives. In the Senate the difficulty arises because a minority may ride roughshod over the majority.

Expressing confidence in the near-term outlook, merchants expect a gain in sales of 3 to 10 per cent during the first half of 1953 over the comparative period this year, according to a survey by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

Columbia's chess players, having routed Pennsylvania on Friday, followed with another clean sweep against City College of New York yesterday to retain their lead in the second round of the Intercollegiate Championship Tournament at John Jay Hall.

KEY WEST, Fla., Dec. 27 (AP) -- Five persons aboard the thirty-eight-foot schooner Lilly Dansker completed a leisurely voyage from Corpus Christi, Texas, to Key West this week without knowing the Coast Guard had been searching for them.
In 1952 the American people made The Change.

The connection of doves with peace, referred to in your "Doves (Political)" (Dec. 7) seems really to be wrong. The naturalist, Konrad Lorenz, an expert in animal psychology, found that many animals we usually call cruel live peacefully together in a big and well-organized community.

ONLY a couple of generations removed from the orthodox, semi-medieval ghetto, and in Eastern Europe still steeped in it, they burst into the European literary firmament of the nineteenth century, these highly gifted Jewish writers, with a dazzling display of literary genius that had lain dormant for many centuries before the arrival of their Emancipation and Enlightenment.

An illustrated talk by Alice Chauncey on "Portugal -- Europe's Western Garden by the Sea" on Saturday will inaugurate the winter series of Saturday afternoon programs at the New York Botanical Garden. Ten lectures on varied topics comprise this series.
