WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (UP) -- The United States Weather Bureau, doubtful for years of the validity of "rain-making," announced today it would start experiments early next year to find out if weather can be changed by the "seeding" of clouds.

A 20-month-old Toledo, Ohio, girl who was tempted by the bubbling, colored lights on the family Christmas tree into drinking the contents of one, was apparently recovering yesterday in Riverside Hospital there after the New York police had responded to a call from her doctor and discovered the contents of the ornament.

A FINE book of travel, "The Fon and His Hundred Wives" is also a serious and at the same time a jocular study of life among the Kom tribe of British West Africa. It is a book for ethnologists and housewives, telling how the Fon, the king of the tribe, lived with his many wives and why some of them ran away.

MEXICO CITY, Dec. 27 -- The Mexican Government moved today to counter the effect of a newspaper report that thousands of Mexican workers illegally in the United States had been "kidnapped" by American authorities to serve in Korea.

WARM SPRINGS, Ga. -- More than four years after its opening as a national shrine, the Franklin D. Roosevelt Little White House, on the slopes of Georgia's scenic Pine Mountain here, is attracting an increasing number of visitors from all parts of the world.

I WAS shocked to read the review by Mikhail Koriakov of "Soviet Opposition to Stalin." Mr. Koriakov writes that those 600,000 Russians who at one time or another wore German uniforms must now "under the sheer weight of facts which six years ago were not available" no longer be regarded as traitors.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 27 -- Tommy O'Connell, University of Illinois' gifted quarterback, piloted the East to a 21-20 victory today over the West in a bruising Shrine All-Star classic played before 62,000 fans.

MADE possible by a generous grant from the Foundation for World Government, this book is the quest of an earnest and gifted man into the question of war and peace. Its author is hoping against hope that he can find a peaceful way out of the crisis through some form of Great Society voluntarily and contractually agreed upon -- a universal Social Contract.

ETIENNE GILSON, himself a distinguished Thomist philosopher, has said of Jacques Maritain: "He is growing greater and greater with the years, and I am not at all sure that we, who admire him so much, are fully alive to the lasting significance of his work.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (UP) -A special Congressional committee warned today that an "incredible volume" of filthy literature was flooding the nation's newsstands and called on publishers to clean house before an outraged public demanded that the industry be regulated by the Government.

THE popular American custom of selecting the "ten biggest news stories of the year" has not any exact counterpart in Moscow, although the Soviet editors, like their American colleagues, on Jan. 1, commonly take a quick backward glance at the outstanding events of the last twelve months.

IN a series of nine novels beginning with "The Three Bamboos" (1942), Robert Standish has utilized the colorful field of Asiatic and Far Eastern settings. His books have evoked from reviewers an equal variety of comments: gripping narrative, something lacking, colorful story, characters wooden, adventure-packed, pure corn.

ONLY three weeks ago I mentioned Aaron Marc Stein as 1952's most prolific mystery novelist, with four books under three names. Now he goes and botches up my statistics by publishing, in the last moments of the year, his fifth 1952 novel; and what's even more amazing than the number is the fact that this, like all four of its predecessors, is a thoroughly admirable book.

Mr. Stuart-Linton's explanation in your Dec. 14 issue of the significance of the Lancashire Fusilier's emblem, the red rose, is interesting. I was under the impression that it related to the red rose worn by the Lancashire forces in the war against the House of York.

PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 27 (UP) -- The heavy work was over tonight for both Wisconsin and Southern California in preparation for the Rose Bowl game New Year's Day, and both camps radiated optimism over the condition of their players.

ONE of the best ways to the grasp the significance of the above list of the ten biggest Soviet stories of the year is to compare the list With a similar selection for this country. While opinions may differ, the following would seem to be a reasonable statement of the most important stories in the United States press this year.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (UP) -- Warplanes will roll from the assembly lines at the rate of 12,000 a year during 1953 and "several" new combat types will reach the mass production stage, a spokesman for the aircraft industry forecast today.

NOTHING affords a more striking indication of the evolution of public taste and, indeed, of the constantly changing texture of music itself than a glance over the programs of the year that is passing out and a comparison of these programs with those of even a decade previous.

MR. YEATS was composing. Would I take a seat in the drawing room and wait till he was finished? He must have heard the wheels of the car coming round the gravel sweep, for he was in the room before the servant left it -- enthusiastic, though a little weary.

For the forty-third time in its forty-eight years of history, the National Motor Boat Show will be on display in New York for ten days, beginning on Jan. 9. General Manager Joseph E. Choate, who via Andover and Dartmouth became executive secretary of the sponsoring National Association of Engine and Boat Manufacturers, counted noses yesterday and found he had 248 individual exhibitors this time.

MONTREAL, Dec. 27 (UP) -- Detroit's dynamic Red Wings extended their unbeaten streak through fifteen games tonight as they tied the Montreal Canadiens, 2 -- 2, before 14,474 Forum fans to remain 5 points in front in the National Hockey League race.

THIS effective and unassuming narrative of his first forty years by France's veteran statesman suffers from one regrettable flaw: the translation, apparently done in England, is slovenly. Almost all the words and phrases which refer to the school or university system of France are turned into meaningless would-be English counterparts.

TWO amateur photographers who simply follow the camera and film makers' instructions to learn the craft are paired in a two-man show which opened last week at the Village Art Center, 42-44 West Eleventh Street. The exhibition will continue through Jan. 9. The gallery is open Sunday, Monday and Thursday from 1 to 10 P. M., other days from 1 to 6 P. M.

RADIO'S traditional pursuit of the fading year across the time zones of the country will be a feature of the New Year's Eve schedules on Wednesday night, while television, locally, will be content with brief views of events in Times Square.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Dec. 27 (AP) -- Hungary's Communist economic directors have disclosed that this nation suffered from a severe summer drought and spring frost in 1952. Famine was averted by importing foodstuffs in "considerable quantity" from "friendly countries," an official said.

WHEN the occupants of the Manhattan apartment pictured here moved in last spring, they brought with them literally nothing but a collection of paintings, sculpture and various objets d'art accumulated in many places through the years. After painting the walls white as a suitable background, and distributing the collection through the various rooms, the problem of the actual furnishings remained.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- The career of Theron Lamar Caudle in the Department of Justice was described as an "accurate reflection of decay within the department" in a report issued today by a Judiciary subcommittee of the House of Representatives.

The United States Golf Association has made known the dates and sites for eight major tournaments -- five for men and three for women -- to be held during 1954. The schedule includes the women's amateur championship which will ,be contested over the Allegheny Country Club course at Sewickley, Pa., Sept. 13-18.

The United States faces choosing the McCarran outlook or the spirit of the Point Four program as one of only two ways to use its power, declared Rabbi Bernard J. Bamberger in his sermon yesterday morning at the West End Synagogue, 160 West Eighty-second Street.

LOOKING back over the year now drawing to a close, this observer offers his personal choice of ten outstanding events and developments in the stamp world during 1952. To avoid debate over their relative importance, they are listed as nearly as possible in the order in which they came to light during the year.

NEW HAVEN Conn., Dec. 27 -- The marriage of Mrs. Barbara Wheeler Kirchwey, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Chapin Wheeler, to Philip Livingston Rollin Du Val, son of Mrs. Clive Livingston Du Val of New York and the late Mr. Du Val, took place here this afternoon in the Congregational Church of the Redeemer.

On the basis of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's appointments to major policy offices since his election as President and his campaign speeches, it would appear that the major goal of the new national Administration will be a reversal of the paternalistic trends in domestic and foreign policy that President Franklin D. Roosevelt and President Truman were often accused of fostering.

It is only a few weeks since the November election, yet it seems to us that General Eisenhower has already provided the country with impressive evidence of what the antisepsis of reasonableness, understanding and common sense can do to eliminate what have become areas of chronic inflammation in the body politic and economic.

FAYETTEVILLE, Ark., Dec. 27 -- The chairman of an advisory committee looking for a new University of Arkansas football coach said today that Line Coach Gomer Jones at the University of Oklahoma was receiving "very favorable" consideration.
The City College basketball team defeated Tufts, 81 -- 58, last night in the C. C. N. Y. gymnasium. It was City's fourth victory in six games and Tufts' sixth defeat in nine starts.

FOR THIS WEEK: Mulch buddleia and other half-hardy shrubs as well as all shrubs and perennials set out this fall. . . . Start lily of the valley pips and paperwhite narcissus bulbs in bowls of pebbles and water for bloom next month. . . . Instead of discarding the Christmas tree, lop off the branches and use them as a mulch or as a windbreak for low evergreen shrubs. . . .

Dissident members of the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals have won their first round in court with the refusal of Supreme Court justice to dismiss their suit charging that the society's by-laws were "autocratic and undemocratic."

THE recently elected president of the class of '56 of Barnard College (252 splendid, bouncing girls plus an equally splendid but floating Nepalese named Bhinda Malla) is an amiably disposed and scientific-minded child of 17 named Edith Tennenbaum, part of whose sang-froid is probably the result of having had Kipling's "Stalky Co." recited to her from memory by a second cousin while the whole family was hiding out from the Germans in Poland.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- President Truman expressed today his firm belief that the Soviet Union would welcome a stepped-up war in the Far East to give it a freer hand in Western Europe. During a long "farewell" interview in the series he has given White House correspondents, the President said:
The following article, reprinted from Labour, official publication of Britain's Trades Union Council, is a report on a survey of British holiday habits.

MIAMI, Dec. 27 -- In an intersectional game marked by poor shooting, Columbia's Stan Maratos found the range in the second half last night to guide the Lions to a 65-59 victory over the University of Miami at the Coliseum.
BALTIMORE, Dec. 27 -- Pimlico race track, historic home of the Preakness each spring, changed hands today for $2,213,000.

TORONTO, Dec. 27 (UP) -- Eric Nesterenko, rookie right winger, scored two goals, the first of his National Hockey-League career, to pace the Toronto Maple Leafs to a 3-0 victory over the Boston Bruins tonight before 12,832 fans at the Gardens.

The hydrogen bomb undoubtedly received more attention than any scientific event of 1952. Yet no one knows whether the physicists have succeeded in developing a hydrogen bomb. In referring to the last explosion at Eniwetok, the Atomic Energy Commission said no more than what can be inferred from the technical term "thermonuclear reactions."

HOUSE plants play a dominant role in the ultra-modern decor of the new United Nations General Assembly Building on the East River. This use of plants in public buildings as well as in homes is only one example of a trend which has been developed on the West Coast.

BROADWAY lives on great expectations. If the season so far has been unspectacular, everyone can still hope that next month -- or the month after -- that big, shattering new drama or that big, brilliant new musical will come along to make the critics do all those things no one has ever really seen a critic do -- dance in the streets, toss hats in the air, or dust off a superlative.

LIBERTY, N. Y., Dec. 27 -- Snow was falling today and the spirits of the thousands of winter sports folks who had jammed the Catskills and Shawangunks mountain playlands rose to the sky. While the fall was no more than a dusting of white powder, the cold weather and heavy clouds indicated that perhaps more snow would come and thus start activities on the comprehensive network of trails and slopes.

IT'S a smooth-running mansion into which Mrs. Dwight D. Eisenhower will be moving her household effects as Mrs. Harry S. Truman moves off to Independence, Mo. And Mamie Eisenhower, who learned to travel light as an Army wife, probably will bring along less furniture than did most of the thirty-one families who preceded her.

FOR many years the Dean of the School of Law at the University of California has been collecting specimens of intended humor by judges and lawyers and, occasionally, by men from lesser breeds without the law.

After five and a half years in the Presidential doghouse, the Taft-Hartley Act will move next month into the more congenial custody of an Administration committed to faith in its basic principles. But, even with a friendly President, the controversial labor law is in for months of debate and revision before it gets buttoned down to the satisfaction of the White House and the new Republican Congress.

Turning in one of the slickest individual jobs seen in many a season indoors, Al Parsells, nine-goal star, led his Ramapo Polo Club to a 9-8 triumph over the New York Athletic Club trio in the Metropolitan League match that featured the weekly double-header at the Squadron A Armory last night.

Alighting from a police van with two other prisoners at Police Headquarters yesterday, Peter Mosquera, 22 years old, a burglary suspect, bolted and disappeared in a building two blocks away at 193 Grand Street. He was recaptured, however, yesterday afternoon.

Imports of crude oil and its products into the United States may become a political hot potato next year. A steady increase in imports in the last few years and the loss of a large part of the export outlets are causing concern to the thousands of independent producers in this country who have had to cut back the flow of their wells.

The Great Powers last week appeared to be entering a period of new perspective on the world struggle and -- in the words General Eisenhower used for Korea -- of "new approach." Whether there would be any real change in the world crisis was highly uncertain, but there was speculation over developments on the highest levels of leadership in the struggle.
THE hostess who received a beautiful plant last Thursday is now wondering how to take care of it. "What should I do to keep it looking that way?" is the inevitable query.

CAIRO, Dec. 27 -- The British Embassy here has sent its first secretary, Ronald Burroughs, to Khartum to investigate the stubborn resistance that is arising in the southern non-Arabic and non-Islamic Sudan to the projected British Egyptian agreement, which is intended, from the viewpoint of the Western powers, to clear the way for negotiations with Egypt for the setting up of a Middle East Defense Organization.
LEWISVILLE, Ark., Dec. 27 (UP) -- Eight of the top figures in baseball stood around a derrick near Lewisville today and watched themselves go into the oil business.

SINGAPORE, Dec. 27 -- The year's worst terrorist outrage in Malaya occurred today when a gang of thirty Communists killed ten persons returning from a mosque near Labis in Johore state, the most virulent terrorist area in the entire Malayan Federation.

TO a child there is nothing so exquisitely funny as a non-sense rhyme like "Betty Baker bought some butter," and any well-brought-up adult gets a dreamy look in his eye at the mention of a "chicken in the car and the car won't go."

The final week of Christmas shopping brought heavy gains in retail trade over the comparative week a year ago. Aided by three selling days before Christmas against one a year ago, department stores had increases ranging from 45 to 75 per cent over 1951, with the average put at around 60 per cent, according to estimates by store officials.

Japan and Italy have just signed their first trade agreement since World War II and at the same time Britain and Japan have extended their trade and sterling balance agreements for a full year. The Japanese are thus making strenuous efforts to get back into the world trade picture. The Italian agreement is typical of the sort of thing that Japan needs.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Dec. 27 -- After forty years as a prominent figure in the courtrooms of the East, Supreme Court Justice Lee Parsons Davis of New Rochelle will retire on Wednesday at the statutory age of 70. He will become an official referee.

NEWLY arrived from Vox is a record of American music as performed by European artists. It is a portion of the concert presented on April 22 of this year in the Imperial Theater of Schoenbrunn Palace by the Vienna State Academy Orchestra and Chamber Chorus.

A Marine in Korea, Pvt. Stanley Goldstein, has sent a money order to the Theodore Goodman Memorial Fund in honor of the late City College English professor, it was announced yesterday by Prof. John C. Thirlwall, secretary-treasurer of the fund committee.

THIS is a large, handsome book, a diary kept by a naturalist-illustrator through a long summer -the first of April to the end of September. To accompany the text the author, who lives in Angelsey, Wales, provides dozens of clear, detailed illustrations of terns fishing, drakes fighting. Montagu harriers hunting redshanks mating, ruffs, shags, whimbrels, plovers and many other birds.

LIKE many others, I have done my share of wishing that more novels were written about this or that. Because we feel that certain subjects are important or because they have an exceptional interest for us, we would like them to have the benefit of that basic human appeal which the telling of a story confers.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 27 -- Sagittarius surprised the crowd of 13,764 at Tropical Park today by winning the $15,000 added E. R. Bradley Handicap and Tony DeSpirito, the nation's leading jockey, rode two winners on the nine-race program.

PHILIP II of Spain bears an evil reputation in English-speaking countries. This was the Philip whose Armada menaced Elizabethan England in 1588, whose Inquisition burned heretics, whose conquistadores prolonged the rape of the Americas.

The work week for New York's uniformed patrolmen will be reduced at 12:01 A. M. next Sunday from 45.8 hours to 44.2 hours, according to a general order issued yesterday by Police Commissioner George P. Monaghan.

SOME youngster must have said to Robert West Howard, "Tell me about farms." With the skill of a story-teller he takes the reader outside the usual barnyard into a broad world, pointing out that there are not only the farms of cows, chickens and pigs but also farms of oysters, fish, tung trees, herbs and many other crops.

HANOI, Vietnam, Indo-China, Dec. 27 -- The French Command dropped a large contingent of parachutists to reinforce a strong reconnaissance drive by ground troops southeast of the Thai mountain bastion of Nasan today. The combined ground and air operation was aimed at locating and bringing to battle the Communist-led Vietminh forces that have moved away from Nasan toward the southeast.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (AP) -- Senator Homer Ferguson, Republican of Michigan, urged the armed forces today to "purge their ranks" of known and suspected Communists.

IN a recent issue, David Dempsey (In and Out of Books) quotes from Donald Sheean's "This Was Publishing" to the effect that Marx' "Capital" was turned down by Scribner's in 1877 but published by a Scribner's subsidiary ten years later. Permit me to make some corrections.

In common with most Americans, President-elect Dwight D. Eisenhower and most of the 100 paid and voluntary workers at his Hotel Commodore headquarters put in only a half week last week. These were some of the things the General did:

THE proposal put forward last week by Robert Moses, president of the board of the Jones Beach State Parkway Authority, for a ten-cent toll on Southern State Parkway to finance a $40,000,000 program of highway improvement, evoked lively interest but little neutrality.

WHEN Christmas toys begin to lose their novelty and nothing quite pleases the youngsters, it's time for parents and children to share an outing together. During the holiday week ahead, such excursions will reach their winter peak.

MANY home owners bemoan an outcropping of rock on their property as a blight on the landscape. Actually even a massive rock formation can be turned into a distinct asset. The way to do this is to plant the veins of soil in between the rocks with ferns, mosses and similar native plants that stay green all winter.

LONDON, Dec. 27 -- Prime Minister Churchill is expected to call a special meeting of his Cabinet Monday or Tuesday for a last-minute discussion of his projected visit to the United States to see President-elect Dwight D. Eisenhower and pay his respects to President Truman before taking a fortnight's holiday in Jamaica.
PITTSBURGH, Dec. 27 (AP) -- The University of Pittsburgh's basketball team, paced by Mickey Zernich with 19 points, easily beat Harvard, 72 -- 48, tonight.
LONDON, Dec. 27 -- Dock labor in Britain is controlled by the Dock Labor Corporation under the National Dock Labor Board created by Parliament soon after World War II to eliminate casual labor.

LONDON, Dec. 27 -- The first crescent or scimitar-winged four-jet bomber has made its maiden flight and has been taken off Britain's secret armaments list. Although the Government placed an order for quantity production of the plane "some months ago," no information about it had been released until today.

PARIS, Dec. 27 -- Whatever Cabinet is finally formed to take up the tasks that have been left unfinished by the sudden overthrow of Premier Antoine Pinay will be at once confronted with a wide range of pressing problems in internal policy as well as foreign affairs.

This is a story of a company -- one of the great growth companies of the nation in this generation. It's also a peek behind-the-scenes of an unusual selling operation wherein most of the sales conferences are held in the clouds while on airplane flights from city to city.

SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Dec. 27 -- Led by Walter Dukes, the nation's top scorer, Seton Hall's quintet defeated Iona College of New Rochelle, 67 -- 54, tonight for its tenth straight victory. Iona had won its first seven games.

THE folklore, the myths, and the legends of the past provide particularly rich source material for contemporary writers. Freud and Frazer have disposed both creative artists and critics to regard the oldest stories of the world as also the youngest.

Undefeated Manhattan was the only local survivor of the first round in Madison Square Garden's Holidays Festival basketball tournament, whose afternoon and night double-header sessions attracted a total of 14,374 spectators yesterday.

FORT DIX, N. J., Dec. 27 -With $30,000,000 in construction under way or planned for this sprawling military reservation, Fort Dix is making progress toward fulfilling long-range plans to turn it into one of the "finest and most modern Army posts in the United States."

BY digging back into the archives of eighteen years ago the season has acquired its most trenchant drama. Lillian Hellman's "The Children's Hour" makes all the new plays, with the exception of "The Time of the Cuckoo," seem trifling and irrelevant.

If champagne may be said to have a season, we suppose this is it. For Christmas and New Year's more champagne is sold than at any other one time in the year, retailers say. The pop that signifies the uncorking of the sparkling wine is as much a part of ushering in a new year as horns and noise-makers, and to our ears, at least, more pleasant.

A federal grand jury has filed a presentment urging the National Labor Relations Board to withdraw recognition and certification from four unions because thirteen of their leaders, who had signed affidavits under the Taft-Hartley Act denying Communist affiliations, had refused to say whether their sworn statements were true.
BONN, Germany, Dec. 28 -There are indications that some basic provisions of United States economic aid policy may be modified as a result of West Germany's remarkable recovery.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- A group of Eskimos on Baffin Island tried out the eating tools of the white man last summer aboard the United States Coast Guard icebreaker Eastwind and politely rejected them as unnecessarily elaborate. But they liked the flapjacks and the incomprehensible movies they saw after the meal.
MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Dec. 28 (AP) -- Frank Foulke of Essex, Md., added to his more than 500 motor boat victories by winning the International Grand Prix at the Orange Bowl regatta today.

SOUTHAMPTON, England, Dec. 28 -- Half the crew of the Cunard liner Queen Mary -- about 650 men -- have been examined and cleared for landing in the United States under the McCarran Act, Russell Danielson, United States Immigration and Naturalization Inspector, said tonight when the liner docked here. No crew member examined refused to answer any question or was found unfit to land; he reported.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 28 -- To Detroit's sturdy Lions, who, when they needed it, had the defense to stymie the enemy, went the National Football League title today. A 17-7 victory over the once-mighty Cleveland Browns gave Buddy Parker's outfit what Commissioner Bert Bell persists in calling the "championship of the world."

ADELAIDE, Australia, Monday, Dec. 29 (AP) -- Mighty Frank Sedgman swept to an opening singles match victory, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 3, over Vic Seixas of Philadelphia today and gave Australia a fast start in its second straight defense of the Davis Cup against the United States.

A visual poem that caught the poignancy, frustration and resolution of life on the front lines of Korea was presented last night on "See It Now" by Edward R. Murrow in a special film over the Columbia Broadcasting System's television network. It was one of the finest programs ever seen on TV.

A recent news item announces the formation of a new unit of the Ford Foundation with the stated objective of "eliminating restrictions on freedom of thought, inquiry and expression." All will agree with this noble purpose, but the sweeping nature of this mandate will require hard common sense and realism in its interpretation lest this plea for individual liberty be used by those who would destroy all liberties.

A deficit of one goal midway in the second period left the Chicago Black Hawks unperturbed in their National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night. They were aware of the penchant of their rivals, the New York Rangers, to wilt as time went on, and they just waited for this circumstance to occur.

NEW DELHI, Dec. 28 -- Indian representatives at a United Nations seminar on the status of women in southeast Asia, which began today, sought to dispel a prevalent impression in the West that women in India and other Asian countries were backward and were treated as mere "chattels."

St. Philip's in Harlem, the largest individual parish in the Protestant Episcopal Church, maintained this year its slim but growing membership lead over fashionable St. Bartholomew's on Park Avenue, according to The Episcopal Church Annual for 1953.
Holiday influences dominated the trading in the foreign exchanges last week. Business was light, due to the relatively small commercial demand.

BERLIN, Dec. 28 -- Premier Stalin's statement last week suggesting a willingness to meet Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower was linked by East Germany's Communists today with the broad Communist policy of diverting the Western war potential while the Soviet camp builds up its military and economic strength.

ALBANY, Dec. 28 -- Governor Dewey announced today that he would meet at 11:30 A. M. tomorrow with Republican leaders of the Legislature to discuss his annual message and legislative program. The Governor's message will be delivered in person when the Legislature convenes for the 1953 session at noon Jan. 7.

The vogue for separates continues to be as strong as ever and invades the fashion field for all occasions. For comfortable evenings at home, such as watching television, relaxing with an interesting book, writing letters or settling down to a good sewing or knitting sessiion, Patterns of The Times offers today several ideas for smart at-home separates.

BILOXI, Miss., Dec. 28 (AP) -Fourteen Mississippi football players were stricken with virus infections today and Coach Johnny Vaught said his Rebel's Sugar Bowl chances against Georgia Tech had been handed "a serious blow."
FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Dec. 28 (AP) -- The West continued its mastery of the East today in the swim meet marked the fourteenth annual college swimming forum, scoring a 93-71 victory.

HAVANA, Dec. 28 (AP) -- Tony DeSpirito booted home three winners today at Oriental Park race track to raise his total riding victories for 1952 to 381 and leave him eight short of a new national record.
EAST ORANGE, N. J., Dec. 28 -- A pre-dawn fire ravaged the 85-year-old First Congregational Church here today, causing an estimated damage of $250,000. The church was left a charred shell.

A statement that appeared in a United Press dispatch printed in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Dec. 13 to the effect that the Norwegian Seamen's Union would not allow United States Immigration authorities to board Norwegian ships to screen crew members, was a misrepresentation of the union's policy, Ingvald Haugen, its president, said yesterday.

Those old coffee lovers, McCannErickson, Inc., and Esso Standard Oil Company, have joined the timely hue and cry set up by the Pan American Coffee Bureau and its member coffee advertisers -"When it's 'one for the road' be sure it's coffee!"

The country's problems can be solved if we have "the will and courage to meet issues head-on and forego petty political jockeying," said Charles R. Sligh Jr., president of the National Association of Manufacturers, said in a statement issued for publication today.

Manhattan College Reserve Officer trainees studying military air science and tactics are not getting just nebulous theory. Their professor, Lieut. Col. Michael E. Adams, has hardly brushed the dust of Korea from his uniforms.

The only protection against socialized medicine is voluntary support by the citizenry of non-profit agencies devoted to hospitals, health and welfare, Mrs. Preston Davie, chairman of the 1953 Inaugural Heart Dinner, declared yesterday. The dinner will be given the night of Jan. 9 in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel by the New York and American Heart Associations.

CHICAGO, Dec. 28 -- Billions of dollars in business contracts and obligations are now being based on statistical series that automatically decide the fortunes of millions of citizens, Mrs. Aryness Joy Wickens, president of the American Statistical Association, reported here tonight.

Three worldly wise patrons of an East Side restaurant last night swallowed or sat on their valuables or threw them under the table while two dozen other persons gave up a total of $1,631 and a gold money clip to two theatre-perfect desperadoes who fired a warning shot into the floor as they backed out and made a successful escape.

In the years when this reviewer was still trying to mold a mass of half-digested fact and conflicting theory into the simulacrum of an economic philosophy -- it is still somewhat pulpy -- a defender of high tariffs once shocked him with: "Sure, you can't keep it up forever.

PINE HILL - HIGHMOUNT, N. Y., Dec. 28 -- The song of the ski rang throughout the cold, sharp air of the Catskills today. The temperature was close to zero in the shade and 15 above in the sun as the huge influx of holiday enthusiasts made the best of the limited snow and ski conditions.

The principle of mandatory sharing of all foreign-aid cargo shipments with the American merchant marine is defended in an extensive report filed last week with the Public Advisory Board for Mutual Security.

The 1953 Goodwill Award has been won by Dr. Seth Minot Milliken, New York surgeon and civic leader, it was announced yesterday by Chandler Cudlipp, president of Goodwill Industries of New York. The presentation will be at a reception in Dr. Milliken's honor at the Metropolitan Club on Jan. 26.

A hunch by two radio patrolmen resulted yesterday in the arrest of a postal clerk wanted for armed robbery, passing bad checks, desertion of his wife and two children and the theft of $75 from the postage stamp account he handled.

Swami Pavitrananda, an ordained monk in the Ramakrishna (Hindu) Order of India, discussed "The Hindu View of Christ" yesterday in the regular service of the Vedanta Society of New York, 34 West Seventy-first Street.

General of the Army Douglas MacArthur intimated yesterday that President Truman was using the Korean war for "self-glorification." He termed "inaccurate and misleading" the President's statement that he had relieved General MacArthur as United Nations commander because the general "wanted to involve us in an all-out war in the Far East."

Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the President-elect, named fourteen agricultural experts yesterday as members of an Interim Agricultural Advisory Committee to aid Ezra Taft Benson, Secretary of Agriculture-designate, in shaping national farm policies.

An interview with Premier Ben-Gurion of Israel, reported in THE NEW YORK TIMES on Dec. 15 by C. L. Sulzberger, throws a merciless light on recent developments in the United Nations. It will be recalled that on Dec. 11 the special committee voted twenty-seven to twenty-four to turn over to direct Arab-Israeli negotiation the thorny problems of Palestine, in effect washing out previous U. N. resolutions on that subject.

SWEETWATER, Tex., Dec. 28 -A sobbing young rancher committed suicide today by diving his airplane into the ground after having circled for more than four hours while his friends and the authorities here pleaded with him by radio not to do it.

The ninth week of opera at the Metropolitan, which begins on Monday evening, Jan. 5, will include the first performance in Italian of the new "La Boheme" that has been directed by Joseph L. Mankiewicz. In this performance, on Jan. 7, Hilde Gueden will sing her first Mimi at the house and Regina Resnik her first Musetta. The week also will see the season's first "Aida" on Friday evening.

LONDON, Dec. 28 -- The British cotton industry must undergo a thorough reorganization if it is to survive in the face of growing world competition, according to a report of ten American cotton experts who studied the industry last year.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 28 (AP) -- End Cloyce Box, almost ignored in the jubilant dressing room after the game, and a barbed-wire defense helped the Detroit Lions to their first professional football championship in seventeen years today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- The American Historical Association was asked today to adopt resolutions of alarm at the growth of "anti-intellectualism" in the public schools.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 28 -- Prof. Kirtley F. Mather, internationally known Harvard geologist, charged here tonight in his address as retiring president of the American Association for the Advancement of Science, that the Internal Security Act of 1950 and the McCarran-Walter Immigration Act of 1952, both passed over the veto of President Truman, had "dropped a 'red tape curtain' around the United States."

DETROIT, Dec. 28 (UP) -- Ted Lindsay, Gordie Howe and Marty Pavelich each ripped home a pair of goals tonight as the Detroit Red Wings smothered the Boston Bruins, 7 -- 1, before 12,242 fans at Olympia.
PUSAN, Korea, Monday, Dec. 29 (UP) -- Cardinal Spellman chatted and shook hands with Communist prisoners of war in Allied P. O. W. camps near here today.
AMSTERDAM, Dec. 28 -- The Netherlands Bank unabatedly continues converting dollars into gold.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Dec. 28 -- The Israeli Government in the future will not conscript any American citizen for military service, it was authoritatively learned tonight. Americans who become residents here will be required to perform some other form of national service instead.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., Dec. 28 -- Arthur Knapp, aboard Agony, beat Corny Shields, steering Dainty, by 3 points today, winning the year's final frostbite dinghy championship regatta at the Larchmont Yacht Club.

GUATEMALA, Dec. 28 -- The Government's civil registry has refused copies of documents of the registration of the Communist party under the new name of the Guatemalan Labor party that were requested by the anti-Communist students committee.

CAIRO, Dec. 28 -- Maj. Gen. Mohammed Naguib, Premier of Egypt, hinted in an article published today that British-Egyptian negotiations now under was would result in good feeling but not a joint defense arrangement for the Suez Canal Zone base.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- To Samuel Wagner Anderson, the initial formalities of joining the Eisenhower team will consist primarily of moving his hat from Fifth Street, where he was a member of the Truman team, up to Fourteenth Street where he will be an Assistant Secretary of Commerce under Sinclair Weeks.

This is a good time to begin thinking of resolutions for the New Year. The day upon which these go into effect is a certain distance away, to be sure, but that is all to the good. To be enjoyed, resolutions must be savored, and the longer the savoring, the better.

Malcolm Frager, pianist from St. Louis, made his New York debut in a recital given yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. The young artist, who will be 18 years old next month, gave ample evidence of talent, but as yet his work was not fully mature.

SCARSDALE, N. Y., Dec. 28 -Four fat, white ducks that were apparently too lazy to paddle or get out of the water were rescued by five Westchester Parkway policemen tonight from the Bronx River, where they had become frozen in a thin sheet of ice.

Turned down by Governor Dewey on the city's plea for cancellation of $3,031,081 in state bus taxes, Mayor Impellitteri made it plain yesterday that he had no alternative formula for warding off a New Year's Day strike on eight privately owned bus lines in this city.

The Merchant Marine Act of 1936 holds no bar to the award of a Government operating subsidy to the Bloomfield Steamship Company, despite the fact that it is not an "existing operator" within the meaning of Section 605 (c), Edward Aptaker, counsel for the Federal Maritime Board, ruled last week.

The Health Department is initiating a program to educate parents to the ever-present dangers children face both in and out of the home. That the street and the lot and the field are fraught with potential tragedy is apparent enough from the stories we read day after day in the newspapers.
Toronto University chess players lost to Columbia's champion team in the third round of the national intercollegiate tournament yesterday at John Jay Hall.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 28 -Paramount's sale yesterday of "Rhapsody," its ready-to-shoot screen play, to Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer represents the first application of the former studio's recently announced policy against filming any story that it cannot cast properly or make at a cost deemed to be reasonable on the basis of anticipated box-office receipts.

Ninety-seven patrolmen, chosen early this month to start the Police Department's new three-month training program for detectives, have been promoted after only twelve days of the training because of their "exceptional ability."

In an attack on the McCarran Immigration Law which went into effect last Wednesday, Senator Herbert H. Lehman asserted last night that it had provided "an unfortunate occasion for the free world to note that the United States, in its immigration and naturalization policy, rejects the basic principles of freedom."
LONDON, Dec. 28 -- Sir Harold Spencer Jones, the Astronomer Royal, has offered three possible explanations for the presence of the "star in the east" over Bethlehem at the time of the birth of Jesus.

Smarting from a 1-point setback at the hands of Fort Wayne Saturday night when their seven-game winning streak halted, the New York Knickerbockers turned on the Philadelphia Warriors yesterday afternoon at Madison Square Garden.

The New York Central Railroad announced yesterday that, in an effort to stimulate train travel in off-peak hours, it would sell one-day, bargain-rate, round-trip tickets from suburban counties in New York and New Jersey to New York City. The experiment will begin Thursday.

The Brooklyn Hispanos defeated the New York Americans, 3 -- 1, and the Hakoah Field Club of Brooklyn downed the Brookhattan Galicia eleven, 1 -- 0, in an American Soccer League double-header at Sterling Oval, the Bronx, yesterday.

Plans to remodel the four-story and basement dwelling at 1058 Second Avenue, near Fifty-sixth Street, were announced yesterday in connection with the sale of the property by the Seymour Realty Corporation to the Lusonn Realty Corporation, headed by Louis Iselin.
The Holidays Festival basketball program at Madison Square Garden resumes today, with doubleheaders listed for afternoon and evening. The event will be concluded tomorrow with a tripleheader.
In observance of "Reparation Day," Roman Catholics throughout the United States offered special prayers and services yesterday for the suffering peoples of the world.

A "genuine liking for children" is the foremost requirement of a good substitute mother according to Elizabeth Carter of New York, winner of first prize in a recently conducted essay contest on "What Makes a Good Nursery Mother."

Louis H. Pink, for ten years chief executive of the Associated Hospital Service, New York's Blue Cross Plan, will retire as chairman of the board on Thursday. He will continue with the service in an advisory capacity. Officers and directors of the service will give a dinner in his honor in the Biltmore Hotel Wednesday.
The "Folies Bergere," a Parisian fixture for the tourist trade, will be escorted to Broadway by Arthur Lesser.

In a further expansion move, the Western Electric Company has taken 215,000 square feet of additional space in three units of the group of industrial buildings known as the Bayway Terminal on Myrtle Avenue in Elizabeth, N. J.

NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 28 -Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru was reported to have declared in Trivandrum today that India would not "act under compulsion" of the joint United States-United Kingdom resolution on Kashmir approved by the United Nations Security Council early this month.

We will refrain from putting a jinx upon the chances of Goodhue Livingston Jr. to be reappointed to the City Planning Commission. The best way to hex the renaming of a good man is to urge the Mayor to rename him. To make doubly sure, let a half dozen of the top civic agencies get behind a man, as they have done in this case.

In an expansion move, the Stanwood Oil Corporation has taken a long lease on new and larger quarters in the office building at 79 Wall Street, where it will occupy most of the twelfth floor within a few days.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (UP) -Economy-minded Senators disclosed today they had put a "stop order" on the spending of millions of dollars for military bases in this country and abroad pending a top level review by President-elect Dwight D. Eisenhower.

Warren R. Austin's valedictory address as permanent United States representative to the United Nations must have carried many of his radio listeners back to those deceptively bright days in San Francisco in June, 1945, when the Charter was put into shape and signed.

William W. Barber Jr., headmaster and hockey coach at St. Mark's School, was reminiscing the other day about the first time his Blue and White sextet played in Madison Square Garden. "It was five years ago," he recalled, "and the boys certainly were wide-eyed at the prospect.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 28 -State intervention in trade and industry is increasing in Brazil.

George Shainswit, a member of the United States team that finished fourth at Dubrovnik, won first prize from a field of thirty-two in a speed tournamnet held yesterday as part of the seventy-fifth anniversary program at the Manhattan Chess Club. He defeated Donald Byrne, former Yale star, in the final.
HONG KONG, Monday, Dec. 29 -- The Communists' Peiping Government announced today that an All-China People's Congress would be convened in 1953.
A folksy group of Gramercy Park neighbors threw a farewell party last night for one of their number who is departing to take a new job in Washington.

With the cooperation of Maurice Evans, the American Shakespeare Festival Foundation is planning to set up a tent next summer in Connecticut's Fairfield County for the presentation of Shakespearean plays. The tent will be located on or near the undisclosed site where a replica of Shakespeare's Globe Theatre is to be erected from funds collected by the foundation.

Despite continuance of a world dollar shortage and increased competition from other countries, export sales of appliances by the Westinghouse Electric International Company during 1952 were the highest in the company's history, it was reported over the week-end by C. E. Bitzer, manager of appliance sales.

PARIS, Dec. 28 -- France's deficit with the European Payments Union is expected to be further increased in the month of December. Although the accounts have not yet been completed, it is probable that the increase will be around $40,000,000. This will bring the total French debt to the payments organization, which stood at $554,100,000 on Nov. 30, to about $600,000,000.

Among the 152 contributors who yesterday added $2,871.50 to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund was Arturo Toscanini, who donated $200. Thus far the fund's forty-first annual appeal has received $343,460.63 from 10,111 contributors.
LONDON, Dec. 28 (AP) -- A study of the Donora, Pa., smog of 1948, which killed nineteen persons, may be used to help combat London's disastrous smoke-laden fogs.
New York, in common with other points along the eastern seaboard, felt a touch of real winter yesterday as temperatures reflected a visitation of polar air arriving in a hurry from the Arctic.
The Greater New York Fund has named Benjamin Strong chairman of the private firms division of its 1953 campaign. He is president of the United States Trust Company of New York.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 28 -- In many places throughout the world in 1952 the pattern of life was changed in many ways for many people because of the welfare programs that make up a large part of the activities of the United Nations Economic and Social Council.

After moving moderately but steadily upward during most of last week, cotton prices turned downward following the Christmas holiday to close the period with minor net changes. At the close of trading on Friday active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange were off 1 point to up 10 points from the levels of the previous week.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 28 -- Yugoslavia, Greece and Turkey have completed the main outline of a mutual defense alliance that, although not formalized in a written agreement, goes much further than was contemplated.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 28 (AP) -- Coach Paul Brown, as unruffled losing as winning, held today's loss by his Cleveland team to Detroit proved again that pro football's championship "hinges on little things."
Four rules for finding happiness in the coming year-were offered yesterday by the Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell, pastor of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, at Fifty-fifth Street.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- A current deficit of more than 325,000 schoolrooms in this country was revealed in the second progress report of the school facilities survey, made public today by the Office of Education.

CHICAGO, Dec. 28 -- Independent research workers were urged today by two members of the New York Stock Exchange's research staff to undertake studies which would fill in the gaps in existing information about share ownership.

Thirteen Canadian trust companies administering estates, trusts and agencies with an aggregate value of more than $2,800,000,000 have indicated their preferences as to investments in Canadian preferred and common stocks. These have been tabulated by the magazine Trusts and Estates.
SAN DIEGO, Dec. 28 -- Fishermen who have been operating out of this tuna capital of the world for years are quietly disappearing from familiar waterfront haunts, perhaps never to be seen again.
BOSTON, Dec. 28 -- Earl J. McGrath, United States Commissioner of Education, suggested here today that the study of foreign languages start in elementary school.

MINEOLA, L. I., Dec. 28 -- An Army sergeant was shot twice last night by a Nassau County policeman after an automobile chase of three miles through traffic and red lights on the Jericho Turnpike. The wounded man was Sgt. Glenn Christman, 26 years old, who was home on leave from Camp Rucker, Alabama.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (UP) -Alfred Kohlberg, New York exporter, urged President Truman today to get a secret 1947 report on a State Department investigation before ruling on the loyalty of John Carter Vincent, diplomat. He said in effect, in a letter sent Monday and made public today, that the President should not rely too heavily on the advice of Secretary of State Dean Acheson.

New York University's College of Engineering carried out research projects amounting to $1,758,000 in the last year, an increase of 66 per cent over the previous year's total, according to the annual report of Dr. Harold K. Work, director of the college's research division.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 28 (UP) -- Top-seeded Gardnar Mulloy and second seeded Tom Brown Jr., made easy advances to the final round in the sixteenth annual Sugar Bowl tennis tournament today and will meet tomorrow afternoon for the title.

Jacques Soustelle, secretary general of the Gaullist party, has (by no means unexpectedly) given up his attempt to form a new government in France. However, it is remarkable that he should have even tried to resolve the crisis caused by Premier Pinay's resignation.
NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 28 (AP) -- American Olympic champions set one new Sugar Bowl record and inaugurated two new events today in the annual Sugar Bowl track and field meet.
LONDON, Dec. 28 (AP) -- Eighteen years ago the vicar in the village of Warleggan in Cornwall and his parishioners quarreled because he would not let them use the rectory for a card tournament.

Employment in New York State in non-agricultural fields reached a record total in the current year and unemployment claims touched a post-World War II low in October, while prospects for workers in the coming year are even brighter.

ROME, Dec. 28 -- Wooden frontier posts and a large number of passports were burned publicly today on the bridge of St. Louis between Italy and France, near Ventimiglia, in a colorful ceremony staged by the European Federalists to symbolize the desire of European peoples to unite.

MEXICO CITY, Dec. 28 -- President Adolfo Ruiz Cortines, driving ahead with his ambitious and energetic reform program, has asked Congress for authority to make every Federal employe account for his personal wealth.
Three new films, including an importation from Italy, will open the motion-picture year this week. The programs follow:

Some weeks ago, in the course of defending himself against what seemed a somewhat ludicrous charge that he had been guilty of the offense of "discrediting" official Government agencies, this writer contrived an essay with a theme which was, on the whole, a little on the trite side.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- The Department of Commerce said today it believed that expanding industry could meet the threat of a business depression during the crucial years of 1954 and 1955 when defense spending tapered off.

Anton Webern is one of the trinity of the great twelve-tone composers. The other two are, of course, Arnold Schoenberg and Alban Berg. Of this trio, Webern is by far the most neglected. Last night's International Society for Contemporary Music concert devoted to his music was, according to officials of the society, the first such event given in this city.
TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 28 (AP) -All four legislative members of the Supreme Council of Iran's nationalized oil company have resigned in a dispute over the selection of operating executives.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- The Capitol's authorities on the fine points of parliamentarian and legalistic procedues involved in a change of government have one matter that can, and probably will, preoccupy them until some moment after high noon, Jan. 20.

The volunteer service department of the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies this month realized the success of its first year of educational courses for volunteer welfare workers with the placement of 320 new workers, mostly women but a few men, in 116 affiliated agencies.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (AP) -- The Federal Security Agency said today that early reports indicate this year's state-Federal program for putting disabled men and women into jobs would fall considerably short of the 63,632 rehabilitations reported for 1951-52.

HARRISON, N. J., Dec. 28 -- The Maritimo eleven of Newark beat the Scots-Americans of Kearny, 2 to 1, in a National Challenge Cup match sponsored by the United States Soccer Footfall Association today. Maritimo's second period decided after the teams were tied, 1 -- 1, at the half. Rodriguez and Conty shot a goal apiece for the victors. Gillespie tallied for the Scots.
The term of Goodhue Livingston as a member of the Planning Commission expires Dec. 31. Earlier seven city-wide civic organizations endorsed his reappointment.

Dr. Harold F. Clark of Columbia University has just completed a ten-year study of educational problems in fifty-nine nations of the free world. His complete findings will not be published until next year, but he has already given some of his conclusions. Perhaps the most significant is his conviction that aid to educational programs, properly given, can be far more effective in raising living standards in underdeveloped countries than can simple economic assistance.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Dec. 28 -- The Israeli Government has expressed to the British Government it's alarm concerning the sale of British military jet aircraft to the Arab states and has conveyed a similar message to the United States Government concerning reports that the delivery of arms to Egypt was under consideration.

The waterfront inquiry will shift today to the Essex County Court-house in Newark, where the New Jersey Law Enforcement Council will put Mayor John V. Kenny of Jersey City on the stand to ask him about his relations with racketeers and crooked dock union officials.
MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 28 (UP) -- The Alabama Crimson Tide will be handicapped by injuries in the New Year's Day Orange Bowl game against Syracuse.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 28 -- Despite the Christmas holiday last week, the steel industry was able to maintain an operating rate of 103 per cent of rated capacity. Many steel companies scheduled production so the minimum amount of time was lost while others paid premium work time and carried full schedules.

A peppery little man who races through his work with the energy of a youngster will mark tomorrow night the fortieth anniversary of his election as manager of the Millinery Workers Union, A. F. L., in this city.

THE FON OF BIKOM, sacred and absolute king of the Kom tribe in the British Cameroons, sits in royal and drunken state upon a stone throne on a mountaintop in tropical Africa without an inkling of his world celebrity. When the United Nations Trusteeship Council sent a commission to investigate the Fon's hundred wives the Fon could no more grasp what was going on than he could have read reports about himself in American newspapers.

The number of homes equipped with television increased from 15,000,000 at beginning of 1952 to nearly 21,000,000 at the year's end, a gain of 40 per cent, according to a year-end statement issued yesterday by David Sarnoff, chairman of the board of the Radio Corporation of America.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- The views of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the President-elect, on the question of changing Senate rules to outlaw the filibuster will be sought Tuesday as Senate Republican leaders confer with him in New York.

WARSAW, Poland, Dec. 28 (AP) -- Two alleged spies were quoted in the Warsaw press today as having said the United States intelligence service had paid out more than $1,000,000 for the recruiting of 100,000 agents in Poland, but got "less than a mangy 100 knaves."

At yesterday afternoon's concert of the "New York Philharmonic-Symphony in Carnegie Hall, Bruno Walter turned his attention to two composers -- Richard Strauss and Richard Wagner. Two of Strauss' tone poems, "Don Juan" and "Death and Transfiguration," were on the program, as were Wagner's "Siegfried Idyl," the Prelude to Act I of "Parsifal" and the Prelude and "Love Death" from "Tristan und Isolde."

The number of art exhibitions opening this week is not large, but it includes the showing of new oils and water-colors by John Marin, one of the most prominent contemporary veterans. This exhibition opens tomorrow at the Downtown Gallery.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Dec. 28 -- A corporation with initial capital of 20,000,000 pesos ($8,000,000) has been formed for the production of fertilizers from natural gas from the Government oil fields at Barranca Bermeja. The project is being promoted by the official National Institute of Industrial Development, the Farm Mining and Industrial Loan Corporation, the National Federation of Coffee Planters and the Governmentowned National Petroleum Company.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 28 (UP) -- Coach Paul Brown of the Cleveland Browns, who lost to the Detroit Lions today, 17 -- 7, for the championship of the National Football League, still has two more games to coach before he starts plans for next season.

Echoes of the trial of John T. Scopes for teaching evolution in Tennessee in 1925 enlivened the New York Times Youth Forum yesterday. The setting was pure 1952 -- a television stage at the Adelphi Theatre, Fifty-fourth Street east of Seventh Avenue. But the issue of twenty-seven years ago arose like a good-natured ghost to haunt a discussion of "What Is Academic Freedom?"

LONDON, Dec. 28 -- A spate of financial deals and rumored deals covering a wide range of industries provided the markets with an interest and excitement they would otherwise have lacked because of the imminence of the long Christmas vacation.
TOKYO, Monday, Dec. 29 (AP) -United Nations Command communique 1,478 for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Monday, Korea time:

TOKYO, Monday, Dec. 29 -Waves of United Nations light bombers and fighter-bombers battered a Communist supply and barracks area near the North Korean capital of Pyongyang yesterday in a 200-plane assault that the Far East Air Forces called the biggest raid of the past four months.
Two important store properties in one of the busy business districts of the Bronx figured in sales reported yesterday in that borough.

While party leaders in Paris were going through the familiar motions of trying to patch together a governing majority where no majority exists, several hundred French and Italian students gathered yesterday in Ventimigila and ceremoniously set fire to the post marking the frontier between the two countries.

So long as persons labor under the misapprehension that military might is the key to a stable world -- thereby turning the world into a gigantic arsenal -- the power of Christian love to bring lasting peace and order will be largely ineffectual, the Rev. Dr. Robert J. McCracken asserted in a sermon yesterday morning at the Riverside Church.

PARIS, Dec. 28 -- Georges Bidault, former Premier and Foreign Minister, was summoned today by President Vincent Auriol to try to form a Government after Jacques Soustelle, a Gaullist leader, had failed. M. Bidault, a Popular Republican, began soundings among party groups and said he would report to M. Auriol tomorrow.

An urgent plea for blood was received yesterday by the Red Cross from the armed forces in Korea. In a year-end effort to obtain donations of blood, the Red Cross announced that blood donor centers would be open longer than usual today, tomorrow and Wednesday.
CAMP DRUM, N. Y., Dec. 28 -With Christmas furloughs past, 6,500 Army men of advance units will return tomorrow to their job of preparing Camp Drum for Exercise Snow Storm.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (AP) -- The amount of money available for jobless benefits to workers covered by state unemployment insurance laws has reached a record $8,400,000,000, the Labor Department announced today.

Because proposed higher tariff rates on watches and watch movements were rejected by President Truman last August, the Elgin National Watch Company has adopted a policy of "hedging" against foreign competition by branching out into production of articles other than watches, according to a statement by J. G. Shennan, its president, released over the week-end.
HANOI, Vietnam, Indo-China, Dec. 28 (AP) -- The French Union's double-barreled year-end offensive appeared to have stalled tonight, at least temporarily, for lack of anyone to fight.

CHICAGO, Dec. 28 -- Market influences were of a conflicting character in the grain market last week. Early in the period wheat prices were bolstered by bullish figures on prospective winter wheat yields, and at the close of the week a general selling movement was inspired by a renewal of peace talk.

ROME, Italy, Dec. 28 -- Three hundred and eighty-seven former Communists tore up their Communist party membership cards today and were received into the Christian Democratic party in a public ceremony held at San Severo in Apulia.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 29 -- Two New Jersey manufacturers of pharmaceutical and cosmetic preparations filed suit today in Federal District Court here asking that alleged violations of manufacturer-retailer fair-trade agreements by a Louisiana retailer be declared illegal and that the retailer be enjoined from further violations.

CHICAGO, Dec. 29 -- The antitrust suit that the Department of Justice has been pressing against seventeen investment bankers during the last few years is "unrealistic" and unlikely to yield any significant result, Prof. Paul L. Howell of New York University asserted here today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio, prospective Republican leader of the Senate, left for New York tonight with the avowed purpose of enlisting the aid of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower in a cooperative effort to shorten the work year of Congress.
Simplicity of line distinguishes some practical additions to the Modernmasters group of furniture, designed by Clifford Pascoe and available at Today's House, 53 East Thirty-fourth Street.
Kenneth F. Sutherland was elected yesterday as Brooklyn Democratic leader at a belligerent meeting of the borough's district leaders. He defeated Francis J. Sinnott, the present chieftain, 27 to 21.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- Shipments of arms by the United States to nations around the world sharing in the defense program reached a new high in October and the accelerated rate of aid is likely to be maintain, it was reported at the Pentagon today.

Furniture orders and shipments will reach peak levels by the end of the year, Seidman Seidman, accountants for many furniture factories, predicted yesterday. In its report for November, the accountant concern said most segments of the furniture industry will close 1952 with new highs.

LONDON, Dec. 29 -- Israel, whose Foreign Minister protested yesterday against the proposed sales of British arms to the Arab League states, has been informed that Britain's intention is merely to provide for legitimate self-defense, not to encourage aggression.

" The Member of the Wedding," at the Sutton, is today's lone film newcomer. Ethel Waters, Julie Harris and the child actor, Brandon De Wilde, repeating the roles they created on the stage, head the cast of the drama, which was adapted from the book and play by Carson McCullers and was produced by the Stanley Kramer Company for Columbia release.

LONDON, Dec. 29 -- Dr. Alan Nunn May, 41-year-old British scientist, who gave atomic secrets to the Soviet Union, was released secretly from prison early today. Elaborate precautions taken by officials helped him to go into hiding.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was quiet and lacked a trend yesterday. Closing prices were 2 points lower to 8 points higher than on last Friday.

The steel industry poured 2,133,000 tons of ingots and steel for castings last week, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute. Production remained at a high point in the Christmas week, as new capacity helped to swell the total.

UTICA, N. Y., Dec. 29 -- A petition for an injunction to prevent picketing that has impeded work on an atomic submarine project at the General Electric plant near Schenectady as filed here today by the National Labor Relations Board in the United States District Court.

VIENNA, Dec. 29 -- Austrian pro-Nazis who tried to write an indictment of Austrian justice into an appeal to President Theodore Koerner to grant wholesale amnesty to war criminals were sternly rebuked by their Government today.

DURBAN, South Africa, Dec. 29 -- Prof. J. L. B. Smith, Rhodes University ichthyologist, returned to Durban tonight after a 3,300-mile plane flight with what he described as "one of the most amazing discoveries ever made in science." It was a five-foot-long prehistoric fish called a coelacanth (pronounced SEE-la-kanth), long thought to have been extinct for millions of years.

NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 29 -- Distinguished persons from nine countries will gather here from Jan. 5 to 16 to participate in an international seminar on Gandhian philosophy and to explore the possibilities of evolving some kind of a plan of action designed to lessen prevailing world tensions.

Floyd Patterson 1952 Olympic 165-pound ring champion, scored his fourth straight professional victory and his fourth consecutive knockout when he disposed of Lalu Sabotin, Warren (Ohio) light heavyweight, in the fifth round of their scheduled eight-round bout at the Eastern Parkway Arena, Brooklyn, last night.

Survivors from bygone New Year's Eve festivities in New York who have the stamina, the cash and the taste for more will find conditions here about the same at the end of 1952 as they were when the year was born. Newcomers to the ritual may not appreciate the fact that prices have remained steady.
NEWARK, Dec. 29 -- The following are excerpts from the transcript of today's public hearing of the New Jersey Law Enforcement Council:
ALBANY, Dec. 29 -- New York state, in contrast to the outlook for New York City, is expected to balance its 1953-54 budget without any new taxes or any increases in the current tax rates.

The election of H. Neill Brady and R. George LeVind as vice president of Blyth Co., Inc., investment bankers, was announced yesterday. Mr. Brady is assistant manager of the trading department and Mr. LeVind is manager of the municipal bond department.

Many parties were given at the Post Debutante Tiara Ball, held last night in the main ballroom of the Plaza for the benefit of the Spence-Chapin Adoption Service. The fete, which began with a dinner, was arranged for debutantes of recent seasons and young married couples.

RALEIGH, N. C., Dec. 29 (AP) -Fourth-ranked Holy Cross halted the University of North Carolina, 85 -- 72, and North Carolina State easily disposed of Princeton, 87 -- 63 in today's opening round games of the fourth annual Dixie Classic basketball tournament.

Three hundred eighty-one probationary firemen were sworn in yesterday by Commissioner Jacob Grumet in the Council Chamber in City Hall. Mr. Grumet also promoted fifteen captains to the rank of battalion chief and thirty-five first-grade firemen to lieutenancies.

Stanley Kramer's production "High Noon," released by United Artists, and its director Fred Zinnemann, captured two of the five awards voted yesterday by the New York Film Critics at the eighteenth annual meeting of the organization to decide the top motion-picture achievements during the year.

Fur retailers generally are complying with the provisions of the Fur Labeling Law, which became effective on Aug. 9, and only a small number of comparative price violations have been reported to the Better Business Bureau of New York.

Nothing can be as chilling as cold statistics. Each year Actors Equity Association sets forth the cruel facts on theatrical employment for the twelve months preceding, and in ay business but show business the persons immediately concerned would be thoroughly chilled.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 29 -- Though the United Nations may be losing prestige in political matters, it is forging ahead in economics as the primary means of mobilizing the nations of the world in a concerted attack on want, misery and helplessness.

Mayor Impellitteri appointed Louis Fusco Jr., deputy director of the city's Division of Labor Relations, as a $14,000-a-year magistrate yesterday amid charges by Chief Magistrate John M. Murtagh that the selection was a "wedding present" to the former Miss Eva Giusetti, secretary to Frank J. Sampson. Mr. Sampson is the Mayor's assistant and patronage dispenser.

Following their 3-1 defeat of Brooklyn College in the fourth round, Columbia's champion chess players gained their fifth consecutive victory last night when they defeated the Western Reserve quartet to hold the lead by 4 1/2 points in the annual tournament of the National Intercollegiate Chess League which ends at John Jay Hall today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- Joseph A. Cahil, a New York grand juror, told a Judiciary subcommittee of the House of Representatives today that a member of Congress had helped four or five subversives to get jobs with the United Nations.

LONDON, Dec. 29 (Reuters) -The coronation of Queen Elizabeth II and the headgear worn during the reign of Elizabeth I will set the style for the hats women will be wearing next June 2 when they line the streets for a glimpse of the procession taking Britain's young Queen to Westminster Abbey for her coronation.

World-wide shipbuilding activity complying with the classification rules of the American Bureau of Shipping continued at a high level in November. On Dec. 1, a total of 795 ships, representing 3,402,041 gross tons, were under construction, the bureau's December bulletin reports.

Goodhue Livingston Jr. was reappointed yesterday by Mayor Impellitteri for a full eight-year term in his present $9,000-a-year post as member of the City Planning Commission. Mr. Livingston will be sworn in by the Mayor at noon New Year's Day in ceremonies at City Hall.

HANOI, Vietnam, Indo-China, Dec. 29 -- French columns from the Thai country bastion of Nasan, reinforced by paratroopers from Hanoi, occupied Conoi, a crossroads village eight miles southeast of Nasan, today. Meeting only light scattered opposition, the advancing force took over the junction point of roads leading from Nasan southeastward and branching out from Conoi eastward to the Black River and southwestward to the Laotian village of Samneua.
ALBANY, Dec. 29 -- Governor Dewey will urge the 1953 Legislature in his annual message on Jan. 7 to approve legislation for compulsory semi-annual inspection of all motor vehicles.

One facet of the continuing use of natural materials for all kinds of home furnishings is the appearance of a great variety of accessories sculptured in wood. Far removed from the driftwood objects so popular for a while, these new offerings -- some functional, others purely decorative -- have a finished quality that is proof of the artistry of the craftsmen responsible for them.

Gifts to help the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund continued to arrive yesterday from as far away as Hawaii and from notables as well as ordinary folk. The fund rose to $346,390 as 160 contributors added $2,929 to provide additional aid to the unfortunate New Yorkers helped by the fund.

Negotiations by the Federal Government for lease of the first four floors of Grand Central Palace, which constitute the largest exhibition space now available here, were reported close to completion yesterday.
PANMUNJOM, Korea, Tuesday, Dec. 30 (UP) -- The Communist armistice delegation protested today an alleged series of violations of the Panmunjom neutral zone and warned of "serious consequences."

Objections to hearing aids are that they are bulky, heavy, a nuisance and difficult to conceal. Two weeks ago the Sonotone Corporation brought out a three-ounce device that does the job of a much bigger one.

Commodity markets on the New York exchanges closed higher yesterday with most markets continuing inactive. Wool and potatoes reported more activity than last week. Cocoa, wool, coffee, lead, zinc, cottonseed oil, soybean oil and hides were higher.

CHICAGO, Dec. 29 -- One of the country's top international trade negotiators declared here today that the Eisenhower Administration would have an unusual opportunity to push a "trade, not aid" policy and, at the same time, strengthen United States foreign policy.
Emphasis shifted yesterday to the automotive issues on the stock market and sufficient buying in other divisions was encouraged to raise the price level to new highs.

LONDON, Dec. 29 -- The London Stock Market reopened quietly today after the Christmas holidays with prices generally steady despite small turnover. Weakest spot was Japanese bonds, which fell around two points on confirmation of Japan's reduced sterling balances.

President-elect Eisenhower made good, in spirit at least, another of his campaign pledges over the week-end. In his speech of Sept. 6 in Kasson, Minn., on farm policies he had promised that, if elected, he would establish a bipartisan Federal Agricultural Commission "with power to review the policies and the administration of our farm program and to make recommendations.''

DUBLIN, Dec. 29 -- Prime Minister Eamon de Valera received a tumuitous welcome at Dublin airport tonight on his return by plane from Amsterdam after four months' absence for eye treatment in the Netherlands. The gathering at the airport included President Sean T. O'Kelly and Mrs. O'Kelly, other members of the Government, the papal nuncio, Archbishop Gerald O'Hara, the Archbishop of Dublin, the Most Rev. John C. McQuade, and many members of the diplomatic corps.

NEWARK, Dec. 29 -- Credit for the birth of "independence" among waterfront workers in Jersey City was claimed today by Mayor John V. Kenny in a statement that he submitted to the New Jersey Law Enforcement Council at its public hearing here.

PARIS, Dec. 29 -- The future direction of the French Foreign Ministry, which for the last four years has been in the hands of Robert Schuman, sponsor of a policy of European unity, provided tonight the main obstacle for the formation of a Cabinet by Georges Bidault, like M. Schuman a member of the Popular Republican party.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- The Army announced today that the first Robert P. Patterson Memorial Award, to be given annually to the outstanding graduate of the Infantry Officer Candidate School at Fort Benning, Ga., would be presented on Jan. 16 in a ceremony here.

As a consistent and lifelong anti-Communist I read with utter amazement the incredible grounds on which Hiram Bingham of the Loyalty Board chose to raise doubts concerning the loyalty of John Carter Vincent.

SWEETWATER, Tex., Dec. 29 (AP) -- A Justice of the Peace returned an "accidental plane crash" verdict today in the death of a rich young rancher whose craft dived to earth after he had told pleading friends: "If you had done what I did * * * you wouldn't land."

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 29 (AP) -- Apprentice Tony DeSpirito, driving to break the world riding record of 388, brought in four winners in seven races at Tropical Park today and pushed his total for the year to 385. There are two racing days left.

BERLIN, Dec. 29 -- The East German Government announced today the dissolution of its propaganda office. This left uncertain the future of Gerhart Eisler, the veteran German Communist who has headed the office since its opening.

ALLIE REYNOLDS sat in front of his locker just before he was slated to pitch in the world series last October. The Chief welcomed any conversational distraction and got to talking about his football days with the Oklahoma Aggies. So talented a gridiron performer was he that Steve Owen put in a draft claim for him for the Giants.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Dec. 29 (AP) Five world records fell, and a woman drove a boat better than 100 miles an hour for the first time on record, as the four-day Orange Bowl regatta closed today with a dazzling burst of speed.

MOSCOW, Dec. 29 -- Soviet authorities have notified the British Embassy that it must vacate its embassy building, across the Moscow River from the Kremlin, within three months, and to move to another structure.

MADRID, Dec. 29 -- For the second successive year the United States Navy will pay an official visit to Spain in January with thirty-six units of the Sixth Fleet manned by nearly 20,000 officers and men and under the command of Vice Admiral J. H. Cassady.

Now that Andrew F. Durkin is about to retire after fifty years and ten months with the New York Central System, it seems timely to let the millions of passengers he has served know who he is. He is the tall, friendly, self-possessed fellow who in the last twenty years has supervised the movement of 4,249,000 trains in the New York area, and guided the transportation of 940,000,000 passengers here without fatality or serious injury.

The first Japanese airline providing scheduled passenger service between Tokyo and the United States is expected to begin next spring, Ryohei Itow, general manager of Japan Air Lines Company, Ltd., announced yesterday.

Specialty shops in the New York area enjoyed Christmas sales of almost boom proportions. The smaller retailers in the city and suburbs have cleared their inventories and are prepared, therefore, to buy confidently and in depth for spring.
