WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- Revised regulations governing agents seeking Federal contracts were issued today by Jess Larson, head of the General Services Administration, with the aim of ending influence peddling for exorbitant fees.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- A renewal of the life of the expiring Senate Internal Security subcommittee in the new Republican-controlled Congress became all but certain today amid forecasts of Congressional loyalty investigations among the nation's schools and colleges. There were demands also for new actions against alleged subversives in the labor movement.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (UP) -- Senator Pat McCarran testified today that he had interceded with the Internal Revenue Bureau in 1950 to get a tax reduction for the Flamingo Hotel in Las Vegas, Nev., once described by the Senate crime investigating committee as one of the nation's most lucrative gangster-run gambling houses.

THE arrival of winter weather, which sealed many of the inland lakes and ponds, has pushed numbers of black ducks to the Connecticut coastal waters. Consequently, the last few days of the season, which closes tomorrow, have provided excellent puddle duck shooting.
BONN, Germany, Dec. 29 -- Unification of Europe will become a fact in 1953, Chancellor Konrad Adenauer predicted tonight.
TOKYO, Tuesday, Dec. 30 (AP) -United Nations Command communique 1,479, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Tuesday, Korean time:

SECAUCUS, N. J., Dec. 29 -Three automobiles from Jersey City pulled up here today at the Hudson County Hospital for Mental Diseases. The institution has 2,000 inmates and the daily menu invariably includes "eoffee."

LONDON, Dec. 29 -- Declaring Britain cannot survive as a trading power unless taxation is reduced, Viscount Runciman, president of the Chamber of Shipping of the United Kingdom, said today that "we are moving inescapably to the conclusion that if the state continues to take as much of the national income as it does today then the means of earning that income will progressively decline:"
CHICAGO, Dec. 29 (UP) -- A powerful explosion rocked a retail furniture store in the heart of a large neighborhood shopping area today, killing at least three persons.
BUFFALO, N. Y., Dec. 29 (AP) -- The injunction provision of the controversial Taft-Hartley Act met its first head-on court test today and a Federal judge declared the clause constitutional.

MIAMI, Dec. 29 (UP) -- Coach Ben Schartzwalder of Syracuse hoped today that a six-spigot oxygen system he has hauled out to the Orange Bowl will be the answer for his limited manpower against the reserve-packed Alabama football team on a "hot" New Year's Day.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- The Federal Government moved today to send Serge M. Rubinstein back to his native Russia. Attorney General James P. McGranery signed an order giving the New York financier and draft dodger until 4 P. M. tomorrow to surrender to the Immigration and Naturalization Service in New York.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (AP) -The Air Force now estimates that its air-base build-up to accommodate 143 wings might cost almost $1,000,000,000 less than it expected last spring.

JERSEY CITY, Dec. 29 -- Superior Court Judge Haydn Proctor issued an injunction today against the operation of Jersey City's business license ordinance, enacted earlier this month, until the constitutionality of the measure been decided by litigation.

NEWARK, Dec. 29 -- Mayor John V. Kenny of Jersey City succeeded today in avoiding questioning by the New Jersey Law Enforcement Council about pier evils, and turned that agency's public hearing into an occasion for obtaining publicity for a long defense of his administration and an attack on his critics.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Dec. 30 -- A reinforced company of Chinese infantrymen pushed United Nations defenders off two advance positions on the western front in Korea last night, then pulled back to the Communist lines after having suffered heavy casualties.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (UP) -- The United States put a $17,000,000 steel mill on the block today to convince Communist-dominated Czechoslovakia that the mill would not be used to ransom William N. Oatis, Associated Press correspondent imprisoned on espionage charges.

BONN, Germany, Dec. 29 -- Soviet and anti-Soviet Socialist theorists will soon be faced with the problem of explaining the resurrection of dynamic industrial capitalism in Western Germany since the currency reform of the summer of 1948.

HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Dec. 29 -The Cortland State Teachers and the Flying Dutchmen from the host college reached the final of the second annual Hofstra Invitation Basketball Tournament with victories over Williams and Lehigh, respectively, in the Calkins gymnasium today.

It is a fortunate thing that in our democracy, as in Britain and others of a deeply settled type, there are always men of high caliber willing to respond to the call of governmental duty. They sometimes get little thanks for it, and we are now going through a period -not without its dangers to our institutions -- in which those who have served in our State Department are getting more abuse than appreciation.

A Kerry Blue terrier nearly threw the police off the track of a cat burglar yesterday but the police found their man hidden in a midtown apartment when a detective refused to believe the dog, which had acted as if no prowler could possibly be there.

Members of the Senate Armed Services Committee are right in calling a temporary halt on the cash outlay for the building of military bases, here and abroad. The Defense Department has not protested the action and at the same time there is assurance that really "emergency" construction will not be delayed.

Only one seeded entrant was eliminated as play in both the junior and boys' singles divisions reached the quarter-finals at the annual Eastern Indoor tennis championships at the Seventh Regiment Armory yesterday.
In the report on the result of the Malayan municipal elections an erroneous impression may have been conveyed by the heading: "Malays and Chinese Triumph in Election."

Your most recent editorial "Why Not a 5-cent Fare?" points up the necessity for a candid discussion of the subway fare problem, and the general city financial picture, of which transit deficits are only a small part.
Record sales of $301,695,020 and a net income of $6,083,599 were reported yesterday by the Willys-Overland Motors, Inc., and subsidiaries for the year ended Sept. 30.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 29 -- Israel has initiated conferences with other powers as a preliminary to moving against Egypt through the United Nations over the seizure last October of the Norwegian vessel Rimfrost in the Suez Canal. The ship, which Israeli representatives said today carried a shipment of meat for Israel, was later released, but the cargo was confiscated.
Red Cross officials made another appeal yesterday for volunteer donors to provide a special New Year's Eve shipment of whole blood for Korean forces.

Top executives of sixteen leading corporations in fourteen lines predict that business and industry in 1953 will continue at current high levels or better, barring unforeseen adverse developments in the international situation.

SINGAPORE, Dec. 29 -- A strike of 10,000 workers at the Singapore naval base that began this morning is holding up naval ships being refitted for the Korean war, naval authorities said tonight. Ships here that recently have been in Korean waters include the aircraft carrier Unicorn, two frigates and one submarine.

TULSA, Okla., Dec. 29 (AP) -- Arthur Warren Ambrose, 63 years old, chairman of the board of the Cities Service Oil Company of Delaware, a subsidiary of the Cities Service Company of New York, was killed in an automobile accident last night. Mrs. Ambrose also died.

George S. Kaufman, wit and playwright, has been dropped from the television program "This Is Show Business" because of his pre-Christmas quip, "Let's make this one program on which no one sings 'Silent Night'."

KINGSTON, Jamaica, B. W. I., Dec. 29 (UP) -- Milton Campbell of Plainfield, N. J., upset Harrison Dillard of Cleveland, the Olympic champion, today to set a new Jamaican and Caribbean record of 14.4 seconds for the 110-meter high hurdles.

ATHENS, Dec. 29 -- Foreign Minister Stephan Stephanopoulos announced today that the Yugoslav Legation in Athens and the Greek Legation in Belgrade would henceforth be embassies and their chiefs elevated from ministerial to ambassadorial status.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- A resolution against "anti-intellectualism" in high schools, aimed specifically at the "life adjustment education" movement, was withdrawn at today's business session of the American Historical Association at the request of its chief sponsor, Prof. Arthur E. Bestor Jr. of the University of Illinois.

ROME, Dec. 29 -- The Vatican announced today that the Most Rev. Valerian Gracias, Archbishop of Bombay, would be elevated to the Cardinalate in the secret consistory Jan. 12 in place of Msgr. Carlo Agostini, Patriarch of Venice, who died yesterday.
PHOENIX, Ariz., Dec. 9 (AP) -The Arizona Supreme Court ruled today the Governor did not have the final decision on whether documents in his possession should be withheld from public knowledge.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Dec. 29 -- State, county and municipal highway officials arranged today to close 2.6 miles of the Bronx River Parkway in southern Westchester County for one year, starting about the middle of January, to permit unimpeded work on a $4,300,141 reconstruction job.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- Leadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Dec. 20, totaled 710,358 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- President Truman asserted today that "attempts to control Government decisions by pressure or influence are far more common than by bribery."

TOKYO, Dec. 29 (AP) -- Communist gunfire hit twenty-one United States Navy ships off Korea in 1952, the Navy said today in a year-end report. Sixteen officers and men were killed and fifty-five wounded in the attacks.
A teen-age United Nations explored the financial district yesterday and learned some basic facts about an internationally famous subject -- the American dollar.

The California Toll Bridge Authority sold $62,000,000 of revenue bonds yesterday to finance the Richmond-San Rafael toll bridge. The bonds were sold to a nationwide banking syndicate headed by Blyth Co., Inc.; First Boston Corporation; Harriman Ripley Co., Inc., and Lehman Brothers, a group that represented the merger of several accounts.

Joshua A. Davis and Emmons Bryant, partners in Reynolds Co., have been elected to the executive directorate of the investment banking house of Blair, Rollins Co., H. Theodore Birr Jr., chairman of the board, announced yesterday.

NEWARK, Dec. 29 -- Among the documents submitted today by Mayor John V. Kenny of Jersey City, to the New Jersey Law Enforcement Council was a petition asking that nineteen persons who might be able to throw light on waterfront conditions be subpoenaed as witnesses.

BOSTON, Dec. 29 (AP) -- Georgetown's undefeated Hoyas knocked favored Seattle University and its collegiate scoring king, Johnny O'Brien, out of the Boston invitation basketball tournament tonight, 79 -- 70, in the opener of a double-header at Boston arena.

CHICAGO, Dec. 29 -- A financial policy for the United States Treasury that institutional investors believe would make for monetary and business stability while encouraging sound growth by basic enterprises was presented today by George T. Conklin Jr., second vice president of the Guardian Life Insurance Company of America.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- If Senators Lehman, Ives and others who want to overcome Senate filibustering against "civil rights" legislation pursue to the limit their parliamentary device to get rid of Rule 22 at the opening of Congress this week, a debate is in sight that could block the organizing of that branch by the new Republican majority, hold up confirmation of the Eisenhower Cabinet and otherwise delay the transaction of all other Senate business.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (AP) -Only 11 materials, of which 10 are metals, remain on the "most critical" list from the supply standpoint as 1952 ends, the Defense Production Administration reported today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, received today a Distinguished Flying Cross and an Air Medal with four gold stars for "heroism and extraordinary achievement" as a Marine Corps officer in the Pacific during World War II.

Discussion of possibilities for developing foreign trade, and the appointment of Robert Cutler of Boston as an administrative assistant, dominated Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's activities yesterday as the President-elect returned to his Commodore Hotel office after a five-day Christmas interlude.

CHARLOTTE AMALIE, Virgin Islands, Dec. 29 (AP) -- Howard A. Jackson, retired industrialist of Nashville, Tenn., castigated the administration of Gov. Morris F. De Castro today for not investigating the burning of Mr. Jackson's Virgin Islands residence Dec. 2. He demanded the Governor's resignation.

ADELAIDE, Tuesday. Dec. 30 (AP) -- Frank Sedgman and Ken McGregor wrapped up a third straight Davis Cup tennis victory for Australia today when they defeated Vic Seixas and Tony Trabert of the United States, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 4, 1 -- 6, 6 -- 3, before a crowd exceeding 15,000 in Adelaide's Memorial Drove Stadium.

A union-imposed ban on overtime work by 45,000 civil service employes on the city-owned subway, elevated and surface lines imperiled last night the Board of Transportation's plans for guarding against a breakdown of municipal transit service if the threatened private bus strike materializes at midnight tomorrow.

In spite of all the warnings, and handwriting on the wall that could have been read three or four years ago, the city administration is drifting into a strike on private bus lines on New Year's Day that would inconvenience millions of people and possibly endanger life and limb on overcrowded subways.

Police Commissioner George P. Monaghan appointed twenty-six policewomen to the department yesterday at a ceremony in the trial room in Police Headquarters. He said he was "so satisfied" with the work done by policewomen that he had increased the quota from 240 to 249.
The Comb and Scissors Club will lift the brimming bowl in the Green Room in the Madison Hotel in East Fifty-eighth Street tonight to Robert Hefter, master barber, wit and philosopher.

MINEOLA, Dec. 29 -- J. Russell Sprague, architect of the charter system of government for Nassau County and the first county executive under that charter, presided for the last time today at a meeting of the Board of Supervisors.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 29 (AP) -Paced by Dick Rickett's 32 points, Duquesne romped to a 77-59 triumph over Cornell tonight in the Steel Bowl basketball classic. Pitt downed Dartmouth, 67 -- 61, in the first game of the double-header.

Dissatisfaction with the slowness of Queens sewer investigations burst into the open yesterday when the Central Queens Allied Civic Council, representing thirty groups, and the Laurelton Civic Association, comprising 1,200 home owners, appealed to Governor Dewey to supersede District Attorney T. Vincent Quinn of Queens with a special prosecutor in the case.

ZANZIBAR, Dec. 29 -- As a result of the loss to the Iranian nationalist tide of the huge petroleum installations at Abadan, British oil interests are planning to construct a large refinery at Mombasa, the main port of Kenya and of all East Africa.

The noose of the purge that hangs over the head of every Communist behind the Iron Curtain (Stalin alone excepted) appears to be swinging from Prague to Berlin. One of its potential victims is apparently none other than the well-known Gerhart Eisler.

Shareholders of Foremost Dairies, Inc., will meet on Jan. 28 to consider proposals to increase its authorized $50 par value cumulative preferred stock from 100,000 to 160,000 shares and its authorized common stock, par value 20 cents, from 1,000,000 to 1,950,000 shares.

BALBOA, C. Z., Dec. 29 -- Papers were served today on Brig. Gen. John S. Seybold, Governor of the Canal Zone and president of the Panama Canal Company, in a complaint filed in the United States District Court for the Canal Zone asking for a stay of any discharge of twenty-nine United States citizens employed by the company as chauffeurs.

Letters from 200 scientists, clergymen, educators and union officials were filed yesterday in Federal Court in support of a move by Julius and Ethel Rosenberg, Soviet atom spies, for a commutation of their death sentence.

Unbeaten Manhattan turned back De Paul University of Chicago, 73 -- 64, before 6,579 spectators last night to reach the final of Madison Square Garden's holidays festival basketball tournament. The Jaspers, who now have won six in a row, will face Utah State tonight. The Aggies beat Miami University of Ohio, 79 -- 78, before an afternoon gathering of 2.149.
An underwriting syndicate headed by Allen Co. will place on the market today an issue of 320,000 shares of common stock of the Colorado Fuel and Iron Corporation at $18.75 a share.

AMHERST, Mass., Dec. 29 -Light variations of the smallest planets, the asteroids, have been recorded by one of the world's largest telescopes, the eighty-two-inch reflector of the McDonald Observatory in Texas.

CHICAGO, Dec. 29 -- Another heavy wave of long liquidation hit the grain market today following an early period of strength. The selling for a time found the market bare of support, but later there was enough short profit-taking and buying on resting orders to cause a fair recovery.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 29 -- New Year's will be celebrated hereafter instead of Christmas, it has been decided by the provincial government of Slovenia, which is predominantly Roman Catholic.
OTTAWA, Dec. 29 (UP) -- Trade Minister C. D. Howe predicted today that 1953 would be a good year for Canadians generally, with moderate increases in salaries and employment over the high 1952 levels.

Adolphe Menjou will act as host, narrator and occasional star of a new dramatic series on film to be seen over WNBT on Sundays from 10:30 to 11 P. M. beginning Jan. 11. Entitled "Favorite Story," the show will present mystery, adventure and romantic plays featuring top names in show business.

Net sales and net income of the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company and subsidiaries for the year ended on Oct. 31 declined 1.1 per cent and 11 per cent, respectively, below the volumes achieved in the corresponding period a year earlier.

A minimum of twenty-seven betting parlors for Manhattan alone and 217 such places throughout the state would be required to accommodate "investors" if off-track betting on horse races should be legalized, Ashley T. Cole, chairman of the State Racing Commission, testified yesterday.

Canadian production of the basic types of fine paper (book, magazine, writing, etc.) totaled 13,704 tons in November, or 24.8 per cent less than in the same month of 1951, it was reported yesterday by the Canadian Pulp and Paper Association of Montreal. For the first eleven months of 1952, the output totaled 163,504 tons, a drop of 12.4 per cent from the comparable 1951 period.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 29 -Resumption of filming activities by R. K. O. Radio Pictures will get under way the middle of next month. A minimum of twenty pictures is planned for 1953, C. J. Tevlin, vice president in charge of studio operation, announced today.

SCRANTON, Pa., Dec. 29 -- Federal Judge Albert L. Watson today approved a cash settlement offer of $6,000,000 by the Bethlehem Steel Company to stockholders and former stockholders of the Williamsport Wire Rope Company and at the same time exonerated Bethlehem of any fraud in connection with its purchase of the wire rope concern in 1937 for $3,300,000.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 28 -- Dr. Detley W. Bronk, president of the American Association for the Advancement of Science, praised science writers, newspapers and magazines today for dissemination of the ideas and ideals of science.
Today we reprint the recipes that prompted the greatest response during the year from our readers.

In a statement published yesterday morning Mayor Kenny of Jersey City promised to appear before the New Jersey Law Enforcement Council "as a civic-minded person elected to public office and willing to lend my efforts to the necessary battle that must be fought in the interests and safety of the public."

THE HAGUE, Dec. 29 -- The United States Embassy filed today formal documents requesting the extradition of Harold J. Adonis, former executive clerk of Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll of New Jersey, who is under indictment in that state for bribery.

GENEVA, Dec. 29 (AP) -- Three of Switzerland's major engineering concerns have set up a joint research group to draw up long-range plans for an atomic power project to supply electricity to Swiss industry.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (AP) -Gen. Hoyt S. Vandenberg, Air Force Chief of Staff, said today the Soviet Union had produced five times as many planes as the United States during the last five years.
The following booklet, of interest to parents, was published recently:

ADELAIDE, Australia, Wednesday, Dec. 31 (AP) --Frank Sedgman of Australia defeated Tony Trabert of Cincinnati today in the fourth match of the Davis Cup challenge round, which Australia already has won.

Once again American opinion is intrigued and dismayed by one of France's recurrent crises. Once again, probably, France will find, after due delay, a moderate Premier who will reassure Americans. And solemn articles of predication to the irresponsible French will be replaced by rejoicing that France has at last found a safe Premier.
BONN, Germany, Dec. 30, (Reuters) -- The Allies today put Friedrich Flick, multi-millionaire industrial leader under Hitler, back into business again.

TUSKEGEE, Ala., Dec. 30 (AP) -- The United States went through 1952 without a death from mob violence, Tuskegee Institute reported today, giving the nation its first year without a lynching ever recorded.

BOSTON, Dec. 30 -- Capt. Joe Mitinger of Yale, who saved a Harvard football star from possible serious injury in their traditional game, tonight was announced the seventh annual winner of the Nils (Swede) Nelson sportsmanship award given by the Gridiron Club of Boston.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 30 -- The United Nations has told the United States, in diplomatically polite language, that the world organization has been getting scanty and late information from Washington on Americans on the staff who have been called subversive.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Dec. 30 -- Circumstances surrounding the death on the Hutchinson River Parkway here last night of Sidney M. Alper, national sales manager of the Lily Lake Cheese Company of New York, caused the Westchester parkway police and the county medical examiner's office to start investigations today.

The two-story taxpayer on a plot 152 by 143 feet at 190 Glen Cove Avenue in Glen Cove, L. I., has been sold by the Prone Realty Corporation to a syndicate headed by the Kalmon Dolgin Company L. V. Hoffman Co. were the brokers and the attorneys were Levy Kornblum for the buyer and Margolin Feldman for the seller.
Three teen-age boys received stab wounds and other lacerations in a fight late last night between two organizations of Brooklyn boys.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- Secretary of State Dean Acheson will testify tomorrow morning before a Judiciary subcommittee of the House of Representatives that is investigating charges that the State and Justice Departments tried to thwart a New York grand jury's inquiry on the infiltration of alleged American subversives into high United Nations positions.

BELGRADE, Yugosalvia, Dec. 30 -- Fuad Koprulu, Turkish Foreign Minister, is expected here shortly after the new year to initiate the political exchanges that are required to forge a Yugoslav-Greek-Turkish military entente, the outlines of which already have been discussed and clarified by military leaders.

AMHERST, Mass., Dec. 30 -- The dimensions of the universe are being revised drastically. The 200-inch telescope can now see two thousand million light-years into space, and the Andromeda galaxy is at least as large as ours. The Milky Way system no longer has the unique and scientifically undesirable characteristic of being the largest galaxy.

A large collection of lamps, together with accessories and some furniture, make up a new group of furnishings in a new showroom, Dart Associates, Inc., 39 West Twenty-third Street. The new items, available now through decorators at the showroom, will be on view in retail shops by Jan. 12.

DAR ES SALAAM, Tanganyika, Dec. 30 -- The white population of British East Africa is worried about a "race" question that has nothing to do with the increasing tension between the "European" minority and the indigenous African tribes.

Yields on longer term Treasury securities spilled over the 2.8-percent level yesterday as mixed movements in the year-end market pushed up the price of bills and short-term securities and depressed the price of the long bonds. On what appeared to be but slight offerings in a thin market, prices of three issues of 2 1/2s due in 1972 declined by 5/16 of a point to 3/8 of a point.

" This Is Show Business," a television program dealing facetiously with the problems of performers, had a problem of its own yesterday in locating a replacement for one of its panel members, George S. Kaufman. The wit and playwright was dropped from the program as a result of protests from viewers concerning a pre-Christmas quip.

" Mid-Summer," Vina Delmar's comedy, due Jan. 21, will have the distinction of restoring the Vanderbilt to the legitimate fold after gap of fourteen years. The intimate theatre, seating 716, has been utilized by radio or video since 1939. The last attraction there was the Jack Kirkland-Leyla Georgie play, "I Must Love Some One."

Further delay in the public examination of Mayor John V. Kenny of Jersey City were indicated yesterday by T. James Tumulty, the attorney whose defiance of the New Jersey Law Enforcement Council on Monday caused that agency to postpone its questioning of Mayor Kenny about his alleged connections with waterfront rackets.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 30 -- Glenn Ford and John Farrow, the director, have entered into a partnership deal to produce this summer "Operation NATO," which will be a factual story dealing with the combined sea forces of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization powers in Mediterranean waters. Ford will play the lead role in the film, while Farrow will produce and direct.

Lolita Cabrera Gainsborg, pianist, was last night's recitalist in Town Hall. The principal work on the program was her own composition, "Four Moods on Four Triads," listed as a first performance. The four moods were subtitled "The Valley of Cochabamba" (major triad): "Rumbula" (minor triad); "Of Seagulls and Fog over the Hudson and the Manhattan Skyline" (diminished triad); and "Zortzico" (augmented triad).

ROME, Dec. 30 -- In an encyclical letter addressed to the episcopacy of the Eastern Catholic churches, Pope Pius has severely criticized Communist governments in the Iron Curtain countries for persecuting religion and bringing about a situation that "is for us a cause of grief so heartrending that we cannot restrain our tears."

The New York Rangers will tangle with the Toronto Maple Leafs at Madison Square Garden tonight for their seventh meeting and the Ranger management has announced that "all ladies at tonight's game will be presented with a baby orchid in a plastic vial."

James F. Carty has purchased from Raymond Richards the house at 150 East Garden Road in Larchmont Gardens, Larchmont, N. Y., through Raymond C. Doern Jr., Inc., broker. The house, in the English style, has seven rooms and stands on a quarter-acre plot.

PARIS, Dec. 30 -- Georges Bidault, former Premier and leader of the wartime French Resistance, abandoned tonight his attempt to form a Cabinet because he could not obtain the majority that he considered essential in the present emergency.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (AP) -- A group of Japanese technicians will spend a month in southeast Alaska to look into possibilities of timber development in the Tongass National Forest, an embassy spokesman said today.

HANOI, Vietnam, Indo-China, Dec. 30 (UP) -- French military authorities said today the Communist-led Vietminh rebels were in full rout in the southern Red River delta and that French guns now control key positions in the area
The annual report of Warner Brothers Pictures, Inc., and its subsidiaries, released today, shows that the net profit for the year ended last Aug. 31, amounted to $7,229,000 after providing $7,700,-
DETROIT, Dec. 30 (UP) -- Army Sgt. William E. Pelloski, 33 years old, said today that he would renounce his citizenship if his Austrian wife and son were barred from the United States.

MANILA, Dec. 20 -- Although the next Philippine Presidential elections will not be held until November, 1953, the rival parties and candidates already are maneuvering vigorously for advantage, and all indications point to a feverish campaign year.
Winter vacationists who will bask in the sun on Southern beaches have available to them here a wide choice of accessories created to make a beach costume picturesque as well as becoming.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (AP) -The Government today provided for increased construction next spring of schools, hospitals, streets, highways, and other "essential public services" by allocating a record amount of structural steel for the second quarter of 1953.
Four grants, totaling $97,500, have been made by the Rockefeller Brothers Fund, Inc., to institutions in the field of mental health, it was learned yesterday.

NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 30 -- More than seventy church dignitaries from eighteen European countries and Asian nations are studying at Lucknow current trends of the Christian movement in this part of the world. The conference, which began Sunday, was convened by the World Council of Churches and is being held under the chairmanship of Dr. Henry Van Dusen, president of the Union Theological Seminary of New York.

In an unusual legal move, defense counsel for Minot Frazier Jelke 3d sought and won yesterday a special panel of blue ribbon jurors for the trial of the 22-year-old heir to an oleomargarine fortune on charges of compulsory prostitution.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- There were more man-days of idleness resulting directly from work stoppages in 1952 than in any previous year except 1946, according to a report on preliminary estimates of the year's work stoppages issued today by the Department of Labor's Labor Statistics Division.

An increase in transit fares is a necessity, the New York Chamber of Commerce declared yesterday in releasing a report calling for the establishment of a transit authority to operate this city's transit system with the power to establish new fare schedules.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 30 -- The recording of the television spectrum on magnetic tape has been developed to the stage where it now is possible to record live television entirely by electronic forces and project a clear picture of images on the screen of a home receiving set.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 30 -- The Kelly Clinic, where the late Dr. Howard A. Kelly worked out much of the treatment of cancer with radium and X-ray, went out of existence today with the dismissal of its last patient.

Illegal employment of children on farms in New York State last summer dropped to 2.8 per cent of farm labor, compared with 4.3 per cent in 1951, State Industrial Commissioner Edward Corst reported yesterday.

PARIS, Dec. 30 -- In a singularly pessimistic article Francois Mauriac, French winner of this year's Nobel Prize for literature, argued today that political instability in France was a manifestation of the French character and therefore was unlikely to change.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- Immigration officials temporarily called off their hunt for Serge M. Rubinstein tonight after the United States Court of Appeals here requested a delay in his seizure on a deportation warrant.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Dec. 30 -- The Indonesian Communist party issued a statement last night attacking the Ministry of Defense. It appeared to be a bid to rekindle the crisis in the army over its leadership, which is showing signs of being resolved. Government officials expressed surprise and appeared shocked over the strong tone of the statement.
New Yorkers and other residents of the country were getting ready yesterday to trade the old year in tonight for the new 1953 model.

Outwardly it is over now. It was wonderfully good while it lasted, but outwardly it is over. The bits of tissue paper have been picked from the floor, the excelsior in which fragile things were wrapped has been removed, piece by piece, from the rug.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (AP) -- Government sources disclosed today that the International Nickel Company, Canadian producer and a major exporter of critically scarce nickel to this country, had proposed a price increase of 3 1/2 cents a pound.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- An intensive all-day spy hunt at the Pentagon and the Atomic Energy Commission shifted in the general direction of Hollywood tonight. The "spies," it developed, had been active seven years ago and the freshest part of the cloak-and-dagger intrigue appeared to be a new movie opening here tomorrow.

HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Dec. 30 -- Cortland State Teachers College extended a two - year winning streak to twenty-one games by defeating Hofstra College, 66 -- 58, in the championship final of the second Hofstra invitation basketball tournament in Calkins Gymnasium tonight.
MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 30 -- Tony DeSpirito, an apprentice jockey, broke the world riding record today when he brought in his 389th winner of the year to erase a mark set in 1906.
ALBANY, Dec. 30 -- Frank Dentico, St. Francis sophomore, netted a 20-foot set shot tonight with two seconds remaining in the game to beat Siena College, 57 to 55.

Just to think of the Balkans is to conjure up a long history of storm and strife, of vigor and cruelty and fanaticism, shot through with the glory that was Greece and with all that Byzantium meant. One thinks, too, of the "Eastern Question" which plagued the Western Powers for so many recent generations.

BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N. Y., Dec. 30 -- Philip F. O'Brien, New York importer and exporter of chemicals, rose from a card game here last night in his home on Long Hill Road, went into the cellar and hanged himself. Dr. Victoria A. Bradess, assistant Medical Examiner of Westchester County, ruled today that he had committed suicide while "temporarily mentally disturbed."

MITCHEL AIR FORCE BASE, Dec. 30 -- A conscience-stricken former airman, noting the Air Force's recent economy drive, today returned $75 worth of drafting instruments that he stole from this base when he was separated from the service six years ago.
The election of Edwin J. Fitzpatrick as a director of Johnson Johnson was announced yesterday. Mr. Fitzpatrick is president of the Industrial Tape Corporation, a subsidiary of Johnson Johnson.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (UP) -- Charles F. Brannan, Secretary of Agriculture, today clamped import controls on dried whole milk, dried buttermilk, and dried cream to bolster the domestic market and save the government money in its price support program.

No material change in the present high level of business activity may be expected in the first six months of next year, according to a survey of banker opinion just completed by the American Bankers Association.

Sidney J. Weinberg, national treasurer of Citizens for Eisenhower - Nixon, said last night that a refund amounting to 16 cents on the dollar would be sent to all who contributed to his group in the election campaign.

LONDON, Dec. 30 -- Smiling broadly, Prime Minister Churchill made the farewell V sign to a London crowd at the boat-train platform as he left the British capital tonight for a trip to the United States to see President-elect Dwight D. Eisenhower and President Truman. The onlookers shouted "good luck, Winnie," and "God bless you."

The smoked ham that is traditional for New Year's Day feasting is not the only star feature in food stores today. Turkey, ribs of beef and beefsteaks occupy equally prominent spots in butchers' cases.

Mayor Impellitteri went on television and radio last night and accused both the Transport Workers Union, C. L. 0., and the eight private bus companies faced with a possible strike at midnight tonight of a "squeeze play" designed to force the Board of Estimate to increase bus fares from 10 cents to 15 cents.

SEA CLIFF, L. I., Dec. 30 -- A young stonemason returned to his new home this afternoon to find his wife and two small sons murdered. The killer a wealthy stockbroker's son who had courted the young mother's cousin, was lying dead, a suicide, on the living room floor near his victims.

Top-seeded Gerald Barrack and Dick Raskind, the No. 2 player, moved into the semi-finals in the junior singles division of the annual Eastern indoor tennis championships at the Seventh Regiment Armory yesterday.

Reading the highly informative news stories and editorials of THE NEW YORK TIMES on the bus drivers' threatened strike if fares are not again raised to meet their high-pressure demands, with the city administration against raising fares and the bus companies insisting that they are not able to meet labor's demands unless fares are raised, there is something important sadly missing in the whole performance.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 30 -- Bach, Beethoven and Brahms will have to share their popularity with contemporary Argentine composers, according to a decree issued today by President Juan D. Peron. The decree makes it obligatory for all symphonic orchestras, chamber and choral groups and soloists to present at least one contemporary Argentine composition.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Dec. 30 -- With scarcely concealed irritation, the Netherlands has asked the West German Government to round up and deliver seven Dutch war criminals who broke out of Breda prison last Friday and escaped across the border.

Some of the richest and most influential men in the United States swapped stories and lingered over drinks last night in the softly lighted Green Room of the Madison Hotel in East Fifty-eighth Street. The occasion was a party for Mr. Pumpernickel, their barber.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 30 -- Preliminary factual studies of comparative tax structures in various countries have been released during the past several days by the Fiscal Commission of the United Nations, in line with a resolution of the Economic and Social Council, the objective of which is to promote international trade and investment.
LONDON, Dec. 30 -- The stock markets here started the first bookkeeping period of 1953 cheerfully today and improvements though modest, were fairly widespread.

Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower assured Senate Republican leaders yesterday that there would be "adequate consultation" about future Federal job appointments, and that he also desired to cooperate on legislative and all other matters.

The first positive indication that Rocky Marciano plans to defend his world heavyweight title against the man from whom he won it, Jersey Joe Walcott, came yesterday with the announcement from Manager Al Weill that the titleholder would go into training following the Yuletide holidays.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- Average primary market prices advanced 0.2 per cent in the week ended on Dec. 23, 1952, to 109.5 per cent of the 1947-49 average, according to the United States Department of Labor's Bureau of Labor Statistics.

Churchgoers will watch the old year out and the new year in at devotional meetings tonight. The traditional Protestant Watch Night services will be started just ahead of midnight and continued some time afterward. Holy hours will be conducted for Roman Catholics.

BERLIN, Dec. 30 -- Seldom has a policeman received such a funeral as that given Herbert Bauer today by West Berlin. The intensity of emotion it aroused shows how perilously sensitive is this point of contact between East and West.

NORFOLK, Va., Dec. 30 -- Dade Brothers, Inc., the concern that formerly handled terminal operations at the Army's Claremont, N. J., terminals, will take over similar work at the Hampton Roads Port of Embarkation on Jan. 1.

WEST ORANGE, N. J., Dec. 30 -- Mrs. Frances Madden, 65 years old, was found murdered in the kitchen of her home here, at 160 High Street, at 6 P. M. today by her son, Jeremiah Jr., 24. She had been shot seven times by a shotgun, according to police.
PORTLAND, Ore., Dec. 30 -- Douglas McKay, Secretary of the Interior-designate, pledged today to "continue to promote the Columbia River Basin on its merits, not for votes."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (AP) -- The National Production Authority today revoked, effective Jan. 1, its order requiring paper mills to set aside specified percentages of their monthly paper output to fill Government orders.

In a New Year's message addressed in the first instance to General Ridgway but in reality to all Western Europe General Eisenhower emphasizes two points on which the fate of Europe hinges. The first point, implied in the whole message, is that Western Europe must build up rapidly its defenses against the mounting Soviet menace.

ALL historical reputations are subject to change without notice. Historians disagree among themselves and every few generations historians change the very climate of their thought along with the rest of mankind. Sudden shifts in posterity's opinion are inevitable. But some of the world's most celebrated personages play such controversial roles in their own time that never at any time is there much agreement about their character and achievement.

Caught in a squeeze between State and city regulations, tenants of Stanton Homes, a limited-dividend project at 195 Stanton Street, will have to meet rent increases for the third time in a year beginning next month.

Horace Ashenfelter, whose record-breaking 3,000-meter steeplechase victory at Helsinki gave this country its first Olympic distance-running title since 1908, yesterday was named the 1952 winner of the James E. Sullivan Memorial Trophy.

Alexander Hilsberg, now conductor of the New Orleans Philharmonic Symphony Orchestra, formerly concertmaster and associate conductor of the Philadelphia Orchestra, appeared as guest conductor of that body last night in Carnegie Hall.

CHICAGO, Dec. 30 -- Grain futures and soybeans displayed considerable strength in the early part of the session today, but reacted sharply from the tops, the demand fading on the upturns, while offerings increased. In the late trade there was some evidence of wheat selling to establish losses for tax purposes.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- President Truman today set Jan. 9 as the date for submission to Congress of a budget that is expected to call for slightly less than $80,000,000,000 of expenditures in the 1954 fiscal year, which begins next July 1.

North American Aviation, Inc., in its report yesterday for the fiscal year ended last Sept. 30, showed a net income of $7,820,886 on net sales of $317,198,022, compared with $6,421,612 and $179,443,376, respectively, shown in the previous fiscal year.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Dec. 30 -- In moving large quantities of earth for the construction of the Beit Natufa dam in Galilee, Israeli engineers have uncovered a supply of high-grade iron pyrites. Scientists of the Technological Institute at Haifa are now at work to establish whether supplies are sufficiently extensive to justify commercial exploitation.

Frank J. Carey has been named first deputy manager of The Employers' Liability Assurance Corporation and elected executive vice president of American Employers' Insurance Company and The Employers' Fire Insurance Company.

RALEIGH, N. C., Dec. 30 (AP) -- Brigham Young's classy Cougars caught fire in the last half tonight to rout Wake Forest, 84-58, and move into the Dixie Classic final tomorrow night against the defending champion, North Carolina State.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (AP) -- Farm prices declined 3 per cent in December, ending the year 12 per cent below December, 1951 levels and raising the possibility that the Eisenhower Administration will have a farm problem on its hands.

All 353 crew members of the Cunard liner Ascania, the company's first vessel to arrive since the McCarran-Walter immigration law became effective Dec. 24, were cleared for shore leave when the ship docked at 8 A. M. yesterday at West Fiftieth Street.

Capt. Leonard Frisco will end a seagoing career of forty-one years today when he retires from the Navy with the rank of rear admiral. As well known in the merchant marine, where he spent many of his off-shore years, as in the armed forces, the veteran officer will close his career where he started it -- in Lower Manhatan.

Baseball Commissioner Ford C. Frick yesterday named a six-man committee to make an exhaustive study of radio and television, its effects upon baseball in general and specifically upon the minor leagues.

CHICAGO, Dec. 30 -- There seldom has been a time in the last two decades when economists and business executives were more of one mind on the ways of dealing with this country's economic problems and particularly the problem of business stability than they are today.

MORRISTOWN, N. J., Dec. 30 -- After seventeen hours in the Morris County Jail, Sol Gareth (Garry) Davis, a "citizen of the world," was released under his own protest today when a traffic fine was paid in his behalf by Donald Seawell, a New York lawyer.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- A Congressional subcommittee said today that South Korea could supply most of the men needed to fight the Communists in Korea and sharply criticized the Truman Administration for having failed to train more Korean troops.

Utah State, an outsider in the starting eight-team field, handed previously unbeaten Manhattan its first defeat last night to win Madison Square Garden's Holidays Festival basketball tournament in a hotly contested final witnessed by 9,467 spectators, the largest turnout of the three-day, five-session event.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 30 (AP) -- Hosts Pitt and Duquesne swept past their Ivy League opponents in the Steel Bowl basketball tournament tonight, with the Panthers whipping Cornell, 67 -- 62, and the Dukes trouncing Dartmouth 83 -- 55.

I read with considerable interest the business article last week by reporter William Freeman about the inordinate amount of time a small business man must wait from the time of filing a loan application with either the Small Defense Plants Administration or the R. F. C. until the loan is finally disbursed.

A clemency plea for Julius and Ethel Rosenberg, Soviet atom spies now in Sing Sing Prison under death sentences, was heard yesterday by Federal Judge Irving R. Kaufman, who reserved decision. Judge Kaufman indicated, however, that if defense counsel needed additional time to appeal for Presidential clemency he would grant a stay.

Dr. Grayson Kirk, vice president and acting head of Columbia University, described yesterday "the sense of urgency" he discovered in a recent trip to Europe among cultural leaders invited to participate in the university's bicentennial celebration in 1954.

A series of hearings that could be of decisive influence on the future course of noncommercial video will be opened next week by the New York State Temporary Commission on Educational Television, set up by Governor Dewey to explore the state's role in the use of the medium for teaching purposes both in the school and the home.

Howard C. Sheperd, president of the National City Bank of New York, was formally appointed chairman of the board and chief executive officer of the institution yesterday, succeeding William Gage Brady Jr., who has reached retirement age.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Dec. 30 -- Supervisor George W. Cornell of Scarsdale, head of the town government there, requested and got a $1,000 reduction today in his town salary to off-set an increase of that amount in his new pay from Westchester.
" HEY, Yog," whispered Eddie Lopat in an aside to Yogi Berra, "if you want to see some smart hitting, watch me smash out a dilly of a single off Preacher Roe."

The five-story store and loft building at 145 West Forty-second Street, adjoining the northeast corner of Broadway, has been sold by the heirs of Thomas Scott Fillebrown to the 145 West Forty-second Street Realty Corporation for investment.
WINDSOR, Ont., Dec. 30 (AP) -- The Detroit and Canada Tunnel Corporation is asking $18,000,000 for the vehicle tunnel beneath the Detroit River, the company said today.

EDMONTON, Jan. 30 (Canadian Press) -- Overland Industries, Ltd., of Edmonton, tonight announced completion of arrangements for the immediate development of "what may be the largest potential oil fields o4 all time."

John B. Kapuscienski, a 28-year-old itinerant preacher said to have evaded the draft law twice, was held in $5,000 bail yesterday. He was arraigned before United States Commisisoner Edward E. Fay in Brooklyn Federal Court. Unable to raise the bail, Kapuscienski was taken to the Federal House of Detention to await action of the grand jury.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- Statements from both sides today indicated that the debate on "life adjustment" education in the secondary schools, deleted by mutual agreement from the business session of the American Historical Association yesterday, was nevertheless on.

COLUMBIA, S. C., Dec. 30 -- Aubrey Williams, former National Youth Administrator, told an inter-racial youth conference here today that 10 per cent of Southern children were now attending non-segregated schools and 20 per cent of the college students were in institutions that accepted Negroes.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- President Truman notified Congress today that aid to Britain, France and Italy would be continued despite shipments of strategic materials, valued at $2,500,000, that those nations had sent to countries of the Soviet bloc in violation of the letter of the law.
Northwest Airlines announced yesterday a program by which it would provide 9,200,000 more seat miles a month on its lines in the busy summer season.
The Aluminum Company of America rejected yesterday as "entirely unsatisfactory" a conditional offer by the Government to raise prices on primary and fabricated aluminum.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 30 (AP) -- Skyrocketing to fame in less than a year made no change in little Anthony DeSpirito. He is still the quiet, modest 18-year-old apprentice with strong hands and a big heart. Appropriately, his name is pronounced with emphasis on "spirit."
The cotton futures market in the New York Cotton Exchange was quiet yesterday and closing prices were 3 points lower to 12 points net higher than on Monday.

With six straight victories and a game score of 21 -- 3, Columbia's chess players clinched first place in the annual intercollegiate tournament at John Jay Hall yesterday when Eliot Hearst, 1950 New York State champion, offered a draw to Abe Kaufman, his opponent at board No. 1 in the New York University line-up.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- While President Truman pondered whether to end the diplomatic career of John Carter Vincent, it became known today that a panel of five members of the Loyalty Review Board had split, 3 to 2, in deciding there was reasonable doubt of the loyalty of the diplomatic agent and Minister at Tangier.

Directors of the Socony-Vacuum Oil Company, Inc., yesterday elected as directors Fred W. Bartlett, general manager of the producing department, and George S. Dunham, vice chairman of the company's manufacturing committee.

CHICAGO, Dec. 30 -- Rodney Dee, the stronger of the Brodie Siamese twins, underwent a 2-hour-and-15-minute operation today in Neuropsychiatric Institute to prepare his brain for a new skull covering surgeons plan to build.

QUEBEC, Dec. 30 -- A significantly silent group of newsprint manufacturers walked out of Premier Maurice Duplessis' office today, following their two-hour conference with Quebec's Prime Minister on the subject of newsprint prices.

George Balanchine's fifth new ballet of the season for the New York City Ballet had its premiere at the City Center last night, but if you did not look intently you probably did not see it. It is the merest wisp of pas de trois set to the delicious little "Concertino" of Jean Francaix, called by the same name, and equally delicious -- as far as it goes.

HARTFORD, Dec. 30 -- The Connecticut Commission on Civil Rights reported today in a preliminary finding on a study of college admission practices that there was "still discrimination" against Jewish applicants in colleges in New England outside Connecticut and in the Middle Atlantic states.

A new promotional activity called "Electricity for Better Living" will be undertaken next year under the aegis of the Electric Companies' Public Information Program. A total of eighty-four power concerns in various parts of the country are financing the program but about 150 companies are expected to participate.
The text of the statement adopted by the Board of Estimate on the bus strike situation follows:

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 30 -- For solving an important abstract problem in the realm of pure mathematics that had challenged the world's top mathematical brains for the last half century, Dr. Andrew M. Gleason, a 31-year-old Harvard mathematician, received today the $1,000 Newcomb Cleveland Prize.

Spyros K. Skouras, prsldent of Twentieth Century-Fox, at a press conference held yesterday at company headquarters after a 75,000mile, sixty-nine-day t-rip through twenty-two countries, stressed the tremendous importance of the international market to the American motion-picture industry.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Dec. 30 -- Connecticut's unbeaten basketball team ran its victory skein to seven tonight by defeating Rutgers, 82 -- 73.

Vigorous planning should enable the electrical manufacturing industry to equal or exceed next year its 1952 volume of $12,000,000,000, the National Electrical Manufacturers Association declared yesterday. The statement was made in a year-end report by W. J. Donald, managing director, and A. J. Nesti, chief statistician.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 30 (AP) -- The State Superior Court refused today to delay again a rise in the city's transit fares and the Philadelphia Transportation Company announced immediately that the new rates would go into effect at 3 A. M. tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (AP) -- Edward T. McCormick, president of the New York Curb Exchange, said here today New York State tax laws threatened "to drive the financial community out of New York."

LONDON, Dec. 30 -- From his brother's home in Buckinghamshire, Dr. Alan Nunn May, the British physicist released yesterday after having served a prison sentence for giving atomic bomb secrets to the Soviet Union, issued a statement today defending his action and expressing the hope that he might still be of service to his country and his fellow men.

BOSTON, Dec. 30 (AP) -- Georgetown's undefeated Hoyas staved off a late rush by Rhode Island's Rams tonight to win the Boston invitation basketball tournament, 77 -- 72. Johnny O'Brien of Seattle University eclipsed the collegiate scoring record for the Boston Garden-Arena by tossing in 41 points as his Chieftains whipped Boston College, 99 -- 86, in the consolational final.

Mrs. George F. Baker gave a dance last evening in the St. Regis Roof for her debutante granddaughter, Miss Diana Tailer, daughter of Mrs. Stanley Martineau and T. Suffern Tailer. Miss Tailer is a student at Vassar College.

Some constructive pointers on what a home can offer in the way of creative development for the child may be found in an article of Katherine M. Reeves, Professor of Child Development and Family Relationships at the Cornell University College of Home Economics, Ithaca. Her article on "The Creative Home" appears in the January issue of Your Child's World, monthly bulletin published by the Book House for Children in Chicago.

LONDON, Dec. 30 -- In a New Year's message, former Prime Minister Clement Attlee has called on members of the Labor party to cease feuding among themselves and close ranks against the Conservative foe.
The price of lead was raised a quarter cent yesterday, the third such rise in little more than a week.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Dec. 31 -- Freezing weather, sleet and snow were the worst enemies the United Nations and Communist forces faced yesterday as the fighting in Korea slowed to the lowest level in months.
CAIRO, Dec. 30 (AP) -- Premier Mohammed Naguib said tonight Egyptians are ready to fight and die to prevent a division of the million-square-mile Sudan.
At a special meeting of the National Can Corporation held yesterday in Wilmington, stockholders approved acquisition of all of the outstanding stock of Cans, Inc., of Chicago.

Off-track betting at "unobjectionable places and hours" was held feasible by City Construction Coordinator Robert Moses, who condemned the "hypocrisy" attendant upon legalizing bingo and lotteries, in a letter read yesterday to the Joint Legislative Committee studying horse racing.
TOKYO, Wednesday, Dec. 31 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,480 for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M. Wednesday Korean time:
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- At least half a dozen Republicans will help to lead the fight to outlaw the filibuster Saturday, when the Senate meets to organize.

NEWARK, Dec. 30 (AP) -- The former manager and co-owner of a Newark pharmaceutical concern today was indicted in connection with the shipment of 15,000 defective bandages -- cut so they would have fallen apart in use -- destined for marines fighting in Korea.

LONDON, Dec. 30 -- The value of motion study in increasing production is slowly being recognized in the Lancashire cotton industry, according to an article in Target, a bulletin published by the official Central Office of Information.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (AP) -- The Reclamation Bureau today pictured the West's future power needs being supplied in large part from coal over a revolutionary long distance transmission system. More than half now is supplied by hydroelectric plants.

Mayor Impellitteri declared yesterday that he and the Board of Estimate intended to see that funds were provided to bring the Police Department up to its full budget-allowed quota of 20,372. He said he hoped this would be possible "within the very near future."

PARIS, Dec. 30 -- President-elect Dwight D. Eisenhower expressed the hope today that the European nations would make "decisive progress" next year in increasing their economic political and military unity.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- The Government announced today that allocation controls over pig tin will end Jan. 1 and authorized increased use of tin in toys, jewelry, advertising and other less essential products.

The Federal Government has sent a "letter of intent" signifying its desire to lease the first four floors of Grand Central Palace in behalf of the Bureau of Internal Revenue, it was learned yesterday. The signing of a rental agreement was described as a formality expected to take place soon.

A man now living in Palm Beach who does not wish to have his name published mailed thirty-five shares of common stock to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund as a donation of his seven grandchildren, Robin, Merrill, Peter, Cathie, Stephen, Amy and Bruce.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- A vast expansion of Government lending operations to include Export-Import Bank loans to foreign individuals and corporations without the guarantee of their Governments was recommended today in a private report to the Technical Cooperation Administration of the Department of State.

The Labor Department's estimate that 1952 brought more strikes and more idleness from work stoppages than any period since 1946 will undoubtedly be analyzed from various points of view. Whatever may be said about the causes of this or that stoppage we must agree that improved collective bargaining relations might have eliminated the need for some, perhaps many, of them.

Commodity futures closed irregularly yesterday on the New York exchanges with most markets showing more activity than last week. The coffee volume was larger than at any time this month. Cocoa, coffee, lead, zinc and wool closed higher. Sugar, soybean oil and cottonseed oil were lower, and hides, rubber and potatoes closed mixed.

If a man were to make up a box score on Tony DeSpirito's record-cracking string of race-riding victories, he would not be doing a complete job unless he had a line at the bottom: "389 assists -- the jockey agent."

Frank Cassot, Clerk of Records in Surrogate's Court retired yesterday after more than forty-five years of service in the Hall of Records, Chambers and Centre Streets. He was guest at a farewell party, and presented with a memento by Arthur J. Lennon, chief of the Law Division, in behalf of court employes.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (AP) -- A House of Representatives subcommittee charged today that the multi-million-dollar Alaskan military housing program had been marked by trial and error and considerable lack of expert knowledge.

NEWARK, Dec. 30 -- An unemployed shipping clerk with domestic problems, who was bent on suicide, climbed a sixty-five-foot electric sign atop the twenty-story Federal Trust Company building on Commerce Street this afternoon and resisted the pleas of a fire captain and a patrolman for 1 hour and 10 minutes before he consented to be rescued.
ANKARA, Turkey, Dec. 20 -- In these days of a record economic boom in Turkey, President Celal Bayar tells this story to his people:
More money was bet at the nation's race tracks in 1952 than in any other year in the history of thoroughbred racing, reports collected from twenty-three states by the United Press revealed yesterday.

The Aussies have done it again, which was only to have been expected. So the Davis Cup stays in Australia for the third straight year and nobody can doubt that Frank Sedgman and Ken McGregor are the greatest amateur tennis players alive. The two singles matches coming up today have only academic interest, for the Australians have already won the first two singles matches and the doubles.

" Asia Aflame," by Dr. Ebed Van der Vlugt, an account of Communist infiltration of the entire continent of Asia, is scheduled for Jan. 22 publication by Devin-Adair. The author, formerly a British Intelligence officer and a member of the bar in Amsterdam, The Netherlands, has spent many years in Asia and the Southwest Pacific.

Chief Magistrate John M. Murtagh asserted yesterday that several hours after he had publicly censured the appointment of Louis Fusco Jr. as a new magistrate, Frank Sampson, Mayor Impellitteri's patronage assistant, came to his office and "beat and pounded upon my door" and used "unprintable" language.

Looking back and looking forward is the standard New Year exercise. The turn of the year always appears to be a turning point, when usually it is only another milestone on a continuous road. The human race has a happy knack of forgetting that there is no such thing as a clean break or a start from scratch on that far-stretching highway.

MADRID, Dec. 30 -- Spain's Foreign Minister, Alberto Martin Artajo, in a statement issued to the Madrid newspaper Ya announced that the negotiations between Washington and Madrid for the use of naval and air bases by the United States armed forces had "progressed very much" and that "agreements will be signed when they fully satisfy both parties."

WILMINGTON, Del., Dec. 30 (AP) -- The Atlas Powder Company announced today that it would make another court effort to get the Government to lift its ban on the use of a bread softener put out by the concern.

Kenneth F. Sutherland took over his duties yesterday as Brooklyn Democratic leader, confident that the courts would uphold his victory of 27 to 21 votes over Francis J. Sinnott at Monday's special meeting of the organization's executive committee.

With the largest bus strike in the city's history set to begin at midnight tonight, Michael J. Quill, president of the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., spurned last night a proposal by the Board of Estimate that the stoppage be averted through arbitration.

For the next ninety days the Liberty Avenue police station in Brooklyn will be prepared to turn over to the rightful owners a gold watch worth $100 and a pair of new men's pigskin gloves. The authorities doubt, however, that there will be a claimant for either article.

FOR many years sportsmen have protested the lack of coordination among Federal agencies that has resulted in high and unnecessary tolls in fish and wildlife, and a number of Catskill trout fishermen now are indicating that the lack of coordination among state agencies can also prove costly.

Red Cross officials expressed the hope yesterday that if blood donations continued through today as they have in the last few days, they "might have enough" for a special New Year's Eve shipment of whole blood for soldiers in Korea.

Since my retirement after twenty-eight years of public service as senior inspector of steel construction and bridges in charge of Brooklyn Bridge I have had communications from many public-spirited citizens of Brooklyn, New York and elsewhere. They discuss the fact that the historic old Roebling house at 106 Columbia Heights (which Col. Washington H. Roebling moved into in 1872) was one of the victims of the Brooklyn-Queens Connecting Highway.
The City of Minneapolis, Minn., announced yesterday that it will receive bids on Jan. 22 for $4,945,000 of bonds.

Charles Edouard Jeanneret, otherwise known as Le Corbusier, is an architect who thrives on controversy. He has had plenty of it in his sixty-five years, which is not surprising for a man who is one of the world's most influential exponents of functional design in modern architecture.

VIENNA, Dec. 30 -- Failure to organize the feeding of cities by the countryside has been admitted by Rumania's Communist Government in a resolution by the Cabinet and the Communist party ordering the establishment of vegetable garden zones around urban centers.

MANILA, Wednesday, Dec. 31 -- Two crewmen of a hijacked Philippines Air Lines plane were shot and killed in the sky over the Pacific yesterday by a Chinese gunman who had tried to force the crew to fly the airlines from the Philippines to Red China.

ALBANY, Dec. 30 -- An increase in the fees for motor vehicle driving licenses to provide funds for expanding the membership in the State Police and the eventual re-examination for physical fitness of the 5,606,162 drivers in the state will be recommended to the Legislature by Governor Dewey.
Year-end buying reached new proportions yesterday on the stock market and, although gains again proved selective, the composite rate went to fresh highs for the current upswing.

Novices learning to drive automobiles will have the run of the city under a new regulation announced yesterday by Traffic Commissioner T. T. Wiley. Behind-the-wheel instructions, he said, may be given on all thoroughfares, with the exception of play streets and blocks having entrances to public playgrounds or parks.
ALBANY, Dec. 20 (AP) -- The State Commerce Department today reported the following winter sports conditions at New York resorts:

Oldtimers who contend that "it isn't as cold now as when I was young" got some statistical backing yesterday from the Weather Bureau. This year, according to those who keep the records, has been one of the three warmest in the last 130 years, with an average temperature of 55.2 degrees.
A review of the accomplishments in 1952 of the Maritime Administration and Federal Maritime Board has been issued by A. W. Gatov with evident pride, but his forecast for 1953 was on the gloomy side.

COOPERSTOWN, N. Y., Dec. 30 -- Dr. Linn Fenimore Cooper of this village and of 2222 Q Street, Washington, D. C., announced today the gift of "Fynmere," one of the Cooper family's three estates here, to the Board of Pensions of the Presbyterian Church.

Herbert R. O'Brien, City Civil Defense Director, announced yesterday plans for mandatory civil defense exercises in the first quarter of 1953. Meanwhile, it was explained, no audible air raid warning signals will be sounded, unless prior notice is given.
BONN, Germany, Dec. 30 -- The West German Republic's gold and dollar reserves rose 72 per cent in 1952 -- one of the many indications of the resurgence of this country's economic power.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 30 -- The United Nations received word today of the death in Korea of Jorge Tiongco Teodoro of the Philippines, who was serving as a United Nations information officer there. Mr. Teodoro, who was 40 years old, was killed in an airplane crash on Dec. 27.

An air of mystery surrounded the arraignment yesterday of a United Nations employe and his wife before United States Commissioner Edward E. Fay in Brooklyn Federal Court on charges of leaving the United States without bearing valid passports.

Antonio Medina, chess champion of Spain, Max Blau, four times winner of the "Coupe Suisse" championship of Switzerland, and Jonathan Penrose, 19, former British Boys' champion, were the winners in yesterday's session of the international chess masters tournament at Hastings, England, according to a report from London.

PORTLAND, Ore., Dec. 31 -- Douglas McKay, Secretary of the Interior-designate, said today he was "not worried" about the future of public power in the Pacific Northwest or any other region where the residents themselves might want it.

MANILA, Dec. 31 -- The wild plane ride to China with a dead pilot slumped over the controls and a dead purser lying in the aisle of a Philippine Air Lines plane was described today by the passengers who returned from Taipei, Formosa.

During and after the recent Presidential campaign there were many charges of political bias leveled against the American press. The accusations took two general forms: (1) A "one-party" press exists in the United States because an overwhelming majority of American newspapers editorially favored one candidate (General Eisenhower) and (2) the actual news coverage of the two candidates was unfair in that General Eisenhower received more favorable and fuller treatment than did Governor Stevenson.
KANSAS CITY, Dec. 31 (AP) -- The National Collegiate A. A., today listed the probable dates and sites for its 1953 basketball championship play-offs.
MORGANTOWN, W. Va., Dec. 31 (UP) -- West Virginia staved off a late rally by Cornell to eke out a 70-to-65 victory over the Big Red tonight before 4,000 at the Mountaineer Field House.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (AP) -- The Department of Justice announced today that a "consent judgment" has been entered in the Boston Federal Court ending an anti-trust suit against two New England milk concerns -- H. P. Hood Sons, Inc., and Whiting Milk Company -- and their respective presidents.

LONDON, Dec. 31 -- The steel shortage in Britain has made 1952 a year full of difficulty and frustration for shipbuilders despite an all-time record order book estimated at about 650,000,000 ($1,820,000,000) of which one-third is direct export work, Charles Connell, president of the British Shipbuilders Conference said in a statement issued today.

CHICAGO, Dec. 31 -- Rodney Dee Brodie, 15 months old, born a Siamese twin, was reported making satisfactory progress today in Neuropsychiatric Institute, where surgeons yesterday covered 75 per cent of his exposed brain with a skin graft.

An important indicator of the high level of current mathematical research in this country is the prize awarded this week by the American Association for the Advancement of Science to Dr. Andrew M. Gleason of Harvard. Dr. Gleason solved a problem propounded more than half a century ago by the greatest of modern mathematicians, David Hilbert, and his achievement has been characterized by a competent authority as the most important mathematical advance of 1952.

JERUSALEM, Dec. 31 -- A prefabricated bungalow of the type being built for immigrant families in work villages will be erected in the fashionable quarter of Rehavia in Jerusalem for the official residence of President and Mrs. Izhak Ben-Zvi.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- Attorney General James P. McGranery will be asked to decide whether further evidence regarding the infiltration of alleged subversives into the United Nations is to be presented to another grand jury in New York.

RALEIGH, N. C., Dec. 31 (AP) -- North Carolina State came from behind with a sharp last-half attack to defeat Brigham Young, 75 -- 59, tonight and earn the Dixie Classic basketball tournament crown for the fourth consecutive rear before 12,000 fans.

The biggest bus strike in New York's history came in with the New Year. While holiday revelers welcomed 1953 with songs, shouts and horn blasts, grim pickets started a midnight march outside the garages of eight privately owned bus companies that normally carry 3,500,000 daily riders.

MEXICO CITY, Dec. 31 -- A letter purportedly written by Vicente Lombardo Toledano, president of the Confederation of Workers of Latin America, to Mao Tse-tung, Chinese Communist leader, praising the "high ideals" of the Chinese Communist forces in Korea, was published today in several Mexico City newspapers, stirring anew speculation about what role the Mexican labor leader plays in Moscow's Latin-American activities.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture today called upon Puerto Rican producers to cut their 1952-53 production of sugar 13.3 per cent from the previous season's output.

The New York State Bar Association asked Governor Dewey yesterday to stare a sweeping, statewide investigation of New York's courts and judicial systems with particular attention to policital influence in the selection of judges.
New foods and new home appliances are in prospect for 1953, a year in which people will eat as well as last year and will spend about the same amount of money for groceries and kitchen equipment.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- Serge M. Rubinstein, the Russian-born financier, who is fighting Government efforts to take him into custody on a deportation warrant, may remain at liberty at least until 11 A. M. next Monday under an Appeals Court order issued tonight.

Your editorial "Tito's Tantrums" raises some fundamental questions regarding the relations between the free world and Communist regimes. One can whole-heartedly agree with your denouncing Tito's insolence as well as the "lack of substance" of his "other outcome," since Tire has no other place to go but to return to the Kremlin if he breaks with the West.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (UP) -- The Army reassigned five generals today. Maj. Gen. Robert N. Young, commanding general of the Infantry Center and commandant of the Infantry School at Fort Benning, Ga., was named Deputy Army Assistant Chief of Staff for Personnel. He will supplant Maj. Gen. Bernice M. McFadyen, who previously was assigned to the command of United States troops in Trieste.

ADELAIDE, Australia, Thursday, Jan. 1 (AP) -- Frank Sedgman and Ken McGregor, Australia's top tennis stars, maintained a stony silence today to every question regarding their intentions to turn professional.

M. F. Meissner has been named general manager of the metals division of Olin Industries, Inc., it was announced yesterday. Mr. Meissner succeeds Marshall W. Acker, a vice president and director, who has retired from active service, but who will continue as vice president and a director. Mr. Acker will be subject to retirement under the provisions of the company retirement plan on April 1, 1953.

Your recent report on the appearance of a mockingbird in northern New Jersey quotes Charles K. Nichols of the American Museum of Natural History to the effect that he saw nothing noteworthy in the occurrence of this and certain other species in our area, and that he would not go out of his way even to look at a Carolina wren on Bowling Green.

The average market value of bonds listed on the New York Stock Exchange rose 14 cents a $100 bond in November for an aggregate gain of $201,816,838, according to a report by the exchange. Average value went to $98.19 from $98.05.

Six young French Air Force pilots in New York for the holidays yesterday reported themselves as happy fugitives from Texas, where with eight others they had been taking jet training. Their Gallic zest had been threatened with extinction by the prospect of having to spend Christmas and New Year's at Bryan Air Force Base, which is seventy-five miles from Waco and not gay.

PRINCETON, N. J., Dec. 31 -- Belmont Hill School, Belmont, Mass., has been ranked first among the eight teams entered in the fifth annual Lawrenceville School invitation hockey tournament opening Friday in Princeton University's Baker Rink.

Facts and figures on today's games, giving name of bowl, site, opposing teams, with won-lost-tied records in parentheses, Eastern Standard starting time, estimated attendance, estimated gate receipts; radio and TV schedules, if any, and radio and TV receipts, if any:

Rudolf Bing seems to be in the process of turning an amiable repetition into a happy tradition. Last night, for the third successive year, he presented Johann' "Fledermaus" as the New Year's Eve opera at the Metropolitan.

Bonds called for redemption in December before maturity rose sharply as a result of large retirements in the railroad, state and municipal fields. The month's total of $115,785,000 was the largest since March and compared with only $19,197,000 in the preceding month and $65,359,000 in December, 1951.

Ambassador Loy Henderson saw Premier Mossadegh of Iran yesterday for a second talk on the oil dispute since the Ambassador's return to Teheran last week. Meanwhile, Assistant Secretary of State Henry Byroade has flown to London to discuss the issue with the British.

TAIPEI, Formosa, Dec. 31 -- The dramatic forcing down of a commandeered Philippine Air Lines passenger plane by the Nationalist Chinese Air Force was done after a two-hour-wave-hopping chase along the Communist-held China coast, according to Chinese Air Force Capt. Ku Chung-yu. Captain Ku said he was fired at by the Communists with small arms and anti-air guns during the chase.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (AP) -- The Federal Power Commission today partially reopened the case in which it denied Texas-Ohio Gas Company, Houston, authority to build a 1,406-mile natural gas pipeline. The company had proposed to import its gas from Mexico.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- Henry H. Fowler, director of the Office of Defense Mobilization, saw the country's vast defense build-up program today at a point in "mid-passage" -- permitting some controls to be discarded in 1953. However, new drives are required to hold and broaden the nation's security gains, he said.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- Almost two decades of development under the Tennessee Valley Authority were summarized in the nineteenth annual T. V. A. report issued today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (AP) -- Following are excerpts from the testimony of Secretary of State Dean Acheson today before a House Judiciary subcommittee looking into the employment by the United Nations of Americans alleged to be subversive:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- The Missouri-Kansas-Texas Railroad Company today asked the Interstate Commerce Commission to approve a plan for revamping its capital stock structure to eliminate the effects of $98,049,734 of dividends unpaid on its present preferred stock.
