The security market ended 1952 on a strong and active note with THE NEW YORK TIMES averages at the best levels in more than two decades, but with the volume of business on the New York Stock Exchange the smallest of any year since 1949.

LONDON, Dec. 31 -- The stock markets ended the year today on a rising note with demand broadening and prices higher. An exception was Japanese stocks, which relapsed further on reports of Japan's falling export earnings.
TOKYO, Thursday, Jan. 1 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,481, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M. Thursday, Korea time:
SINGAPORE, Dec. 31 -- Malaya is entering the new year as one relatively bright spot in the anti-Communist front in Southeast Asia.
New York made ready yesterday for the bus strike and its attendant confusion, and Father Knickerbocker was thankful that it was scheduled to break on a snowy holiday interlude.
Two hundred and seventy-one members of THE NEW YORK TIMES Composing Room Chapel of the International Typographical Union presented a New Year's Eve gift of $327 yesterday to the Neediest Cases Fund.

BERLIN, Dec. 31 -- While Western leaders in Germany today hailed West Berlin for its achievements and made optimistic predictions for 1953, Bishop Otto Dibelius of Berlin, head of the German Evangelical church, voiced the discouragement that infects many residents of this city.

BONN, Germany, Dec. 31 -- Opponents of the European Defense Community treaty and the Bonn peace contract are preparing to resume the struggle against ratification of these instruments with arguments that West German rearmament would dislocate current economic prosperity, upset the labor market, and lower the standard of living.

MADRID, Dec. 31 -- Generalissimo Francisco Franco, in his customary New Year's Eve broadcast to the nation, said that the international "anti-Spanish conspiracy of silence" had crumbled everywhere during 1952.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Dec. 31 -- Information Minister Arnold Mononutu said today that Indonesia's acceptance of a long-standing invitation to participate in the Colombo economic plan of British Commonwealth countries "does not and will not obligate Indonesia either politically or militarily."

DETROIT, Dec. 31 (UP) -- Ken Mosdell and Paul Meger scored tonight as the Montreal Canadiens defeated the Detroit Red Wings, 2 to 0, and snapped Detroit's fifteen-game unbeaten string. The victory lifted the Canadiens into second place in the National Hockey League.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio, prospective Republican leader of the new Senate, promised tonight to do all in his power to have the chamber confirm President-elect Dwight D. Eisenhower's Cabinet appointees in the swiftest possible way.

Prices closed irregularly lower yesterday on the New York commodity exchanges with most markets closing early for the holiday. Volume was light except for coffee, where the trading centered on switches. Cocoa, lead, zinc, sugar and cottonseed oil closed lower. Potatoes, coffee and soybean oil were mixed and wool, hides and rubber closed higher.

HONG KONG, Dec. 31 -- The joint Chinese-Soviet administration of the Chinese Changchun railway, backbone of Manchurian economy, ended at 6 o'clock tonight (Peiping time) as the Soviet Union relinquished its rights in the administrative partnership along with its rights to "all property belonging to the railway."

Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower sent New Year's greetings to all the world yesterday with hope for peace in 1953 and a special message to youth behind the Iron Curtain, encouraging them to keep alive the spirit of freedom.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- Long days of hard work on a mass of important legislation faced the Eighty-third Congress as members continued to drift into Washington today for the opening session on Saturday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today rejected demands of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation for refunds of $1,138,000 from railroads on shipments of aluminum ingots made during and after the war period from Canada, and from points in this country, to various aluminum plants.

HONOLULU, Dec. 31 -- Scheduling of a "private informal conference" on Japanese-American relations in Honolulu Jan. 17-20 was announced here today by J. Ballard Atherton, president of the Institute of Pacific Relations of Hawaii, co-sponsor of the conference with the Japan Institute.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (AP) -- Robert Ramspeck resigned as chairman of the Civil Service Commission today -- and received a bouquet from President Truman for his firm defense of government employes.

The traditional religious devotions that mark the passing of a calendar year and the opening of a new one were held last night by Protestants and Roman Catholics. Chimes, carillons and bells rang at midnight. Special music programs, which included many Christmas numbers, were presented and special messages were given by the clergy.

Man attains new speeds in the air, invents new weapons, transforms matter into violent energy, is learning how to turn energy back into matter -- no mean stunt -- and makes new strider forward steadily against disease.

The Magic Chef building at 30-12 Forty-first Avenue in Long Island City, Queens, has been purchased by H. S. Associates, Inc., in a transaction negotiated by Cushman $ Wakefield, Inc., as broker. The four-story structure, vacated when Magic Chef, Inc., moved its offices to East Orange, N. J., also fronts on Skillman Place and Northern Boulevard. It contains 56,000 square feet of space and has a railroad siding.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Dec. 24, the Federal Reserve Board reported today:

Too often we hear the refrain: America must have allies; we cannot survive alone in an unfriendly world. Why? Where do these myths stem from? What prevents our standing alone against any enemy? It is ridiculous and even cowardly to continue to live in fear, compromise our ideals and subordinate our national interests for the sake of perpetuating the selfish, degenerate and worthless ambitions of so-called "brother democracies."
NEW DELHI, Dec. 31 (AP) -- The Indian Government announced tonight a more liberal import policy for the first half of 1953.

CHICAGO, Dec. 31 -- The final session of the Board of Trade for 1952 witnessed a fairly sharp price recovery, reflecting heavy profit-taking by shorts and somewhat more confident buying by commission houses on the theory that recent declines have discounted bearish conditions.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (AP) -- The Government said today the first sizable pilot plant for recovery of ferro manganese from open hearth steel furnace slag will be built at Coxton, Pa., within the next year.

Imposition of import controls on dried milk and butter products by the Department of Agriculture were characterized by a butter company executive as "a farewell grandstand gesture" by the Democratic Administration "of no value to either the dairy industry or the American consumer."

Since 1913 Tuskegee Institute has issued annually a report to the nation on lynching. This year it has no lynchings to report. It is the first year in which no lynchings have been recorded since the keeping of the record on this crime began seventy years ago. It may be too soon to say that lynching has vanished as a nightmare of the American scene, but at least it is a vanishing one.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (UP) -- President Truman moved today to strengthen the nation's defenses against sabotage, espionage and other hostile activities.

Joey Giardello, Philadelphia middleweight, filed suit yesterday in New York County Supreme Court against the New York State Athletic Commission, Seeking an annulment of the board's decision in Giardello's fight with Billy Graham of the East Side.
ATHENS, Dec. 31 -- Italian Premier Alcide De Gasperi's visit to Athens, arranged by the previous Government, will take place Jan. 8, according to an official announcement issued tonight.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- Leaders of conservative Republican and Southern Democratic elements of the Senate, so often dominant in combination in the past, conferred today on the effort to change Senate rules that will touch off the first battle royal in the Republican - controlled Eighty - third Congress.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (AP) -- The six decorations of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy Republican of Wisconsin, entered the realm of controversy today.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 31 (AP) -- Danny Nardico, a fierce young Tampa, Fla., battler, earned a possible light-heavyweight title bout as he scored an eight-round technical knockout tonight over Jake La Motta, former middleweight champion, at the Coral Gables Coliseum.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- The decision of the late Senator Norris and co-authors of the Twentieth Amendment to prescribe a period of seventeen days between the opening of a Congress chosen in Presidential years and the inauguration of the President elected at the same poll probably assured that General Eisenhower's Cabinet can take office with him on Jan. 20, the first day of the new Administration.

AND a Happy New Year to you, too. Let's see. Where are we anyway? Since this is New Year's Day, there must be a lot of bowl football on tap. There usually is, much too much of it as a matter of fact. It's getting to be slightly ridiculous.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- The Baltimore and Ohio Railroad Company was indicted by a Federal Grand Jury today for alleged false statements to Government agencies regarding its cash position in 1943, prior to its filing in bankruptcy and reorganization with an $80,000,000 loan from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.

ATLANTIC CITY, Dec. 31 -- Three former resort patrolmen, dismissed on extortion charges as a result of gambling raids of the so-called "four horsemen," were exonerated today by the New Jersey Civil Service Commission and ordered restored to duty immediately with back pay.

Ill winds blowing no good for holiday-minded New Yorkers drove clouds of fine snow into the city yesterday, iced suburban parkways, slowed down heavy vehicular traffic throughout the metropolitan area and were responsible for countless minor, irritating road accidents.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (AP) -- Investigating Senators said today that $6,000,000 was spent for political broadcasts by national candidates in the 1952 election campaign.

TUNIS, Tunisia, Dec. 31 (AP) -- France's Resident General, Jean de Hautecloque, said today that the Bey of Tunis had been led to believe by American actions in the United Nations that the United States would replace France in Tunisia.
BOSTON, Dec. 31 (AP) -- The Weather Bureau today issued the following forecasts and ski conditions:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (AP) -- The Petroleum Administration for Defense said today the nation's petroleum industry established new records in production, refining, transportation and storage during 1952.
CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 31 (AP) -- Tony DeSpirito, who rode to the cheers of thousands as he broke the world riding record yesterday, was just another jockey at Tropical Park today.

A New Jersey court ordered Mayor John V. Kenny of Jersey City yesterday to show cause why he should not be compelled to answer questions of that state's Law Enforcement Council at a public hearing in Newark on Tuesday.

LONDON, Dec. 31 -- Henry A. Byroade, United States Assistant Secretary of State for Near Eastern Affairs, arrived here today for discussions that will include the oil dispute between Britain and Iran, which the United States is currently trying to settle.

BORDENTOWN, N. J., Dec. 31 A 17-year-old high school junior, who was assistant leader of a Boy Scout troop, was accidentally shot and killed just before 8 A. M. here today while on a squirrel-hunting expedition on the grounds of St. Joseph's Mission. The shot came from the shotgun of his 14-year-old brother.

The American Lutheran Publicity Bureau of the Lutheran Church-Missouri Synod, 1819 Broadway, announced yesterday that Julius F. E. Nickelsburg, its founder and for thirty-nine years an executive officer, would retire today.
Sales in the downtown area featured realty transactions reported yesterday in Manhattan.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (UP) -- Two members of the special House committee investigating obscene literature accused a majority of the group today of expressing ideas "dangerously close to book burning."

The St. Mark's School hockey team from Southborough, Mass., made its Christmas holiday game at Madison Square Garden yesterday a successful one by defeating the Lawrenceville (N. J.) School squad, 2 -- 1, in a hard-fought contest.

Scoring first made little difference for the New York Rangers in their National Hockey League game against the Toronto Maple Leafs at Madison Square Garden last night. Despite the edge that the first goal is supposed to provide, the Blues could do no more than tie their rivals, 3 to 3.

" I BELIEVE in my God, my family, my country and baseball," Babe Pinelli, an umpire with eighteen years' worth of National League hash marks, says in "This I Believe."* In clarity and candor it can't be bettered anywhere among the book's more recondite, erudite avowals of faith, hope and charity. Yet there are in these pages many other approaches to a steady philosophy for a shaky time.

The variegated activities of the United Nations in helping to improve economic and social conditions in many parts of the world are all too often lost from sight because of the attention usually devoted to the organization's more spectacular political controversies.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- President Truman said today that the prospects for world peace were better than a year ago, but that security considerations prevented him from discussing the facts that he knew existed behind the Iron Curtain.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Dec. 31 -- An oldtime cavalryman who found tanks just as easy to tame as horses spent his last day in the Army today wandering around the sprawling old post that was his first assignment thirty-nine years ago.

LONDON, Thursday, Jan. 1 -- Citizens of every degree, from a big industrialist to a master craftsman who makes fishing rods, were among the hundreds of British subjects honored by their Queen today in the New Year's honors list, the first such list for her coronation year.

New Year's resolutions for American women, whereby they can better both themselves and the country, have been suggested by Miss Helen G. Irwin of Des Moines, president of the National Federation of Business and Professional Women's Clubs, Inc.

A new gain was made yesterday by the stock market and trading for 1952 ended with the composite rate at the best levels since 1930. Transactions for cash were fairly numerous but hardly equal to those of previous years. It was the last day, and necessarily on a cash basis, for the legal establishment of gains or profits for tax income purposes.

Larger bond flotations and smaller stock offerings were contrasting features of the new financing in December. Flotations of bonds here were the largest since June and the biggest for a December since 1926, while stock offerings were the smallest for any month since February, 1951, and the least for a December since 1949.

NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 31 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru, in a New Year's broadcast tonight, made an impassioned appeal for a large voluntary effort to join in the "great enterprise" of building a new India through her Five-Year Plan, which is to be completed by 1956.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Dec. 31 -- Several physics, mathematics and history classes at Rutgers will have to finish the semester with new instructors, it appeared last night, as university offices closed without word from two embattled professors who refused to testify concerning their past political affiliations.

ALTHOUGH New Year's resolutions seem to have lost their former popularity, a number of conservation and sportsmen's groups have urged anglers and hunters as well as all others interested in the conservation of our forest and wildlife resources to take a more active part in safeguarding these resources.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Dec. 31 -- The prospect of an intense tussle between labor and employers on wages opens the Swedish New Year, which is the time for renewal of collective agreements. The two camps are wider apart than ever this time.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Dec. 31 -- The United States and Britain, which as members of the United Nations Security Council have denied Egypt's claim to the status of a belligerent, must either prevail upon Egypt to give up belligerency or refrain from giving arms to Egypt, a spokesman of the Israeli Foreign Ministry asserted tonight.

Twenty-two men, women and children, members of eight families, left their homes in their night clothing in near-freezing weather early yesterday when a spectacular fire damaged four two-story frame buildings on Jewett Avenue, Port Richmodn, S. I. No one was hurt.
The United States Court of Appeals refused yesterday to set aside the convictions of three spies who transmitted atom bomb secrets to the Soviet Union.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (AP) -- A score of rail unions with membership totaling 1,250,000 today hailed a decision that might give them a wage increase of several cents an hour.

The dismissal of George S. Kaufman, playwright and humorist, from the television program "This Is Show Business," was assailed yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Truman B. Douglass, chairman of the broadcasting and film commission of the National Council of Churches.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- The coming year should add the fifth to our already accepted four basic freedoms, the freedom "from the fear of economic abundance," Walter P. Reuther, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations said today.

ALBANY, Dec. 31 -- Governor Dewey today announced the appointment of George M. Fanelli of New Rochelle, District Attorney of Westchester County, as county judge. He will succeed Judge Arthur D. Brennan of Harrison who was elected to the Supreme Court in November.

Today, as the old stage directions would put it, we find ourselves in another part of the forest. What we see around us is not greatly changed. The transition from yesterday to today had its dramatic features, but essentially it was not much different from the transition from any yesterday to any today.

Three leading steel executives, in year-end statements yesterday, hailed their industry's production performance during 1952 in the face of the long and costly mid-year strike and predicted that by the middle of 1953 steel capacity should be adequate to meet the needs of defense and civilian users.

The triple murder and suicide in Sea Cliff, L. I., on Tuesday night might have been prevented if relatives of the victims had pressed earlier charges against the murderer, Charles Edwin Weigold Jr. of Plandome, L. I., according to the police and District Attorney's office in Queens.

Hearings on the complaint of the Board of Transportation against the rates recently put into effect by the Consolidated Edison Company for power provided to the city for the operation of the Independent subway system were ordered yesterday by the Public Service Commission.

A strike of three small, but important, locals of the International Longshoremen's Association, A.F.L., set for 8 A.M. tomorrow threatened last night to blossom into a port-wide tie-up in New York, Boston, Philadelphia and Baltimore.
Eight Massachusetts municipal housing authorities have announced plans for borrowing $33,411,000 on state-guaranteed notes maturing variously from July 28, 1953 to July 27, 1954.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- Secretary of State Dean Acheson told a Judiciary subcommittee of the House of Representatives today that the security of the United States was not endangered by the employment by the United Nations of Americans against whom adverse security reports had been made by Federal agencies.

Practised the year-round, and particularly during the holiday weeks, is that pleasant, hospitable custom of serving beverages to visitors. New designs for containers for such liquids, hot or cold, have been executed in a variety of materials.
LONDON, Dec. 31 -- Britain ended the first nine months of her financial year with a deficit of 500,891,067 ($1,402,494,987). At the same point a year ago the budget deficit totaled 209,000,000.
A process that makes "cold rubber" fifty times faster than current methods and does it for less money was announced yesterday in Akron by John L. Collyer, president of the B. F. Goodrich Company.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (AP) -- Representative Russell V. Mack, Republican of Washington, today opposed construction of a transmission line which would virtually link the Bonneville Power Administration with California's Shasta dam system.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 31 -- President Getulio Vargas in a New Year's Eve radio address to the nation promised better times ahead but surprised United States circles by ignoring the questions of foreign exchange, defense cooperation with the United States and other important international issues.

SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Dec. 31 -- Seton Hall University staged a second half comeback last night to register its eleventh straight victory, 87 -- 66, over Loyola College of Los Angeles. The score was tied seven times before Seton Hall pulled ahead for good.

HOBOKEN, N. J., Dec. 31 -- There's a saying among the Welchmen that a Cardiff man is happiest when he's singing or sailing a ship. Capt. Owen C. Morris, 48-year-old skipper of the 8,193-ton Egyptian freight-passenger vessel, Khedive Ismail, who today observed his thirty-fourth anniversary as a sailor, is a typically happy Cardiff man.
OTTAWA, Dec. 31 (Canadian Press) -- Canada had an export surplus of $236,600,000 on her foreign commodity trade in the first ten months of 1952, the Dominion Bureau of Statistics announced today.
I read with deep interest the report of the study made by Dr. Harold F. Clark, director of the Sloan Foundation Project in Applied Economics.
NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 31 (AP) -- Georgia Tech and Mississippi -- the nation's only unbeaten post-season rivals -- match football power tomorrow in the nineteenth Sugar Bowl spectacle.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 31 -- In a New Year's message Premier Marshal Tito appealed to the peasants today to give up whatever hoard of produce they had and sell their surpluses to the Government for distribution to the rest of the population.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (AP) -- Dr. Lewis C. Sorrell, director of research of the Air Transport Association, said today that the country's airlines set new traffic and safety records in 1952. He issued a year-end summary showing that the airline industry as a whole carried more than 27,000,000 passengers, a gain of 9.7 per cent over 1951.

Gilbert Miller, one of Broadway's leading producers, and Donald Oenslager, scenic designer, are combining forces for the production this season of "Horses in Midstream," a new play by Andrew Rosenthal. One of the two major feminine roles already has been assigned to Francoise Rosay, veteran French actress, whom American filmgoers may remember former work in the British film, "Quartet.
The "Metropolitan Opera Auditions of the Air" will return to the American Broadcasting Company radio network for its fourteenth year on Monday evening from 9 to 9:30 o'clock.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (UP) -- The chief Republican tax investigator in the House of Representatives said tonight his group had found no evidence that former Attorney General Tom C. Clark ever intervened in any improper manner in tax fraud cases.

AMHERST, Mass., Dec. 31 -- A theory that harmonizes the expansion of the universe with the clustering of matter into large and small units in space was presented here today at the closing session of the eighty-eighth meeting of the American Astronomical Society.

The sight of heavy snow falling in the metropolitan area last night sent through local ski circles a mid-season restlessness that will start a mass movement northward today for what appears to be an attractive holiday period of sport. Results of the storm, which is a coastal one, will not be fully determined before this afternoon.

All leading domestic and foreign security and commodity markets will be closed today to mark the New Year holiday. Almost all world markets will be open tomorrow. The exceptions are the coffee ring on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange and all the markets and banks in Japan, which will stay closed until Monday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- President Truman today denounced Section 104 of the Defense Production Act, which has required Charles F. Brannan, the Secretary of Agriculture, to impose import restrictions on dairy products.
ALBANY, Dec. 31 -- Governor Dewey will urge the Legislature next week to authorize a uniform state-wide system of traffic tickets designed to make it impossible to get a ticket "fixed."

I find deplorable the recent wave of indiscriminate criticism of the United Nations. It betrays a basic ignorance of the organization and the issues that are derived from it. When something goes wrong the U. N. is to blame. If some good is accomplished the U. N. is praised.

CINCINNATI, Dec. 31 -- The American Educational Theatre Association, in convention here, has adopted a resolution urging a clear distinction between the fields of activity of the association and the National Theatre Assembly.
A crowd officially estimated at 200,000 braved a wet, windy snowstorm last night to fill Times Square and welcome the birth of 1953 with the traditional horn-blowing.

NEWARK, Dec. 31 -- Richard Green, accused in a four-count Federal Court indictment of manufacturing defective bandages intended for the Marine Corps in Korea, pleaded not guilty to the charges today in an arraignment before United States Commissioner Thomas W. Clohosey. He was released in $2,500 bail.

TOKYO, Thursday, Jan. 1 -- Artillerymen of the United Nations Army in Korea sent hundreds of shells screaming across No Man's Land into the Communist lines just at Wednesday midnight. It was the fighting man's salute to the third New Year of the Korean war.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (AP) -- Senator Pat McCarran, Democrat of Nevada and chairman of the Internal Security subcommittee, made public a statement from the office of United Nations Secretary General Trygve Lie saying Mr. Lie encountered lengthy delays in obtaining, data from the State Department on the loyalty of American employes of the United Nations.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today, acting on a petition of railroads serving New York City and Philadelphia, dismissed complaints of fruit and vegetable shippers and receivers seeking elimination of charges at those two cities for unloading fruits and vegetables.

Television could be a powerful force for the enrichment of home life, participants in a radio panel on the subject agreed Tuesday night, but whether it is was a point for much disagreement. Of five speakers on "America's Town Meeting of the Air," three were enthusiastic about television -- "properly used" -- but two held it to be a disrupting, "impoverishing" force in family life.

MIAMI, Dec. 31 -- Some 65,000 sports fans, many of whom were enjoying such "summer" pastimes as swimming, golf, tennis and boating today, expect to watch the Orange Bowl football classic tomorrow between Syracuse and Alabama.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 31 -- All Twentieth Century-Fox now needs to complete the romantic triangle in "Waterhole" is someone to play the role of the errant wife. Richard Widmark today was assigned to portray the wealthy husband who suffers a broken leg on a lonely Arizona mountain top and as left to perish by his wife and by her lover a role for which William Lundigan previously was set.

JERSEY CITY, Dec. 31 -- Officials of the Jersey City Incinerator Authority signed a contract for garbage removal last night only an hour and a half before the present contract, held by another concern, was due to expire.

Police Commissioner George P. Monaghan shook up the Detective Division yesterday and simultaneously announced the formation of a seven-man Youth Squad to deal with the problem of hoodlumism on the upper West Side.

The State Mediation Board sought yesterday to put off until next Tuesday a strike threatened by 11,400 gravediggers and cemetery workers, but the union indicated it might go through with the walkout tomorrow.

ROME, Dec. 31 -- In a rousing appeal to the Roman Catholics of India, Pope Pius called upon them today to "close ranks and stand together" against communism which was attempting to penetrate the minds of Asians.

Dr. Emanuel Neumann, Ameriman Zionist leader and chairman of the Jewish Agency for Palestine's economic department in Jerusalem, asserted yesterday that the inclusion of liberal and conservative elements in the coalition government of Israel "will strenghen the confidence of potential investors" in the infant state.

More inland waterway craft are being built or are on order for 1953 than were launched in 1952, Chester C. Thompson, president of the American Waterways Operators, Inc., said yesterday in his annual report on the barge and towing industry.

The fashion world and a career girl's success are the subjects of a book by Anne Scott-James that Dutton will issue March 27 entitled "In the Mink." Based on her experience as editor of Harper's Bazaar in London, Mrs. Scott-James describes the chic institution of the latest wear, its trade secrets and its suave "uninhibited and yet pretentious life."

ABOARD LINER QUEEN MARY, Thursday, Jan. 1 (UP) -- Prime Minister Churchill, sailing for New York, jauntily raised a glass as the ship's bell tolled in the New Year today and offered a toast to the ties that bind Britain and the United States.

PARIS, Dec. 31 -- President Vincent Auriol called today on Rene Mayer, Radical leader and a former Minister of Finance, to form a Cabinet, and France's crisis entered a new stage. With the withdrawal of former Premier Georges Bidault yesterday, the move for a national union was dropped.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- George Meany, President of the American Federation of Labor, today issued a statement saying that the A. F. of L. would continue to fight for a compulsory health insurance program with universal coverage.

Reporting on operations of the National Pressure Cooker Company, Lewis E. Phillips, president, informed stockholders that a resolution to change the corporate name to National Presto Industries, Inc., will be advanced at the annual meeting on Jan. 20.

ARCADIA, Calif., Dec. 31 (UP) -- Calumet Farm for the second straight day, sent out a speedy filly to annex Santa Anita's feature race, the 2-year-old Lap Full today winning the $17,150 Santa Ynez stakes.
DALLAS, Dec. 31 (AP) -- The greatest offense in Southwest Conference history lashes at the nation's No. 1 defense tomorrow when Texas and Tennessee meet in the Cotton Bowl football game.

PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 31 (AP) -- New Year's Eve celebrations took a back seat to Rose Bowl excitement tonight as the Wisconsin and Southern California football teams awaited the kick-off tomorrow for the seventh game in the Big Ten-Coast Conference post-season series.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- A career diplomat of twenty-seven years' service, in a letter to the unofficial Foreign Service Journal, has strongly opposed the establishment of a foreign economic administration outside the State Department.

Gerald Barrack, the Cornell sophomore from Bayonne, N. J., will try for his third straight Eastern junior singles indoor tennis title at 10:30 this morning when he meets Dick Raskind, sophomer from Yale, at the Seventh Regiment Armory.

Gerald Barrack, the Cornell sophomore from Bayonne, N. J., will try for his third straight Eastern junior singles indoor tennis title at 10:30 this morning when he meets Dick Raskind, sophomer from Yale, at the Seventh Regiment Armory.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (UP) -- Robert A. Lovett, Secretary of Defense, named an eight-man committee today to advise him on defending North America against possible atomic attack.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (UP) -- A House Interior subcommittee recommended today that Congress set up a special commission to determine the "seaward boundaries" of the United States.

An increase last week of 3,408,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end total supplies were 134,425,000 barrels, compared with 131,017,000 a week earlier and 133,070,000 a year ago.
Prices of cotton futures became somewhat irregular on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday, and closing prices on active months were 17 points higher to 12 points lower than on Tuesday.

BURLINGTON, Wis.. Dec. 31 -- The world champion liar of 1952 was announced today by the Burlington Liars' Club, and the winner of the twenty-third annual Ananias award is -- not surprisingly -- a Texan.

In an effort to secure a greater share of the food freezer market, Amana Refrigeration, Inc., Cedar Rapids, Iowa, will launch a $2,225,000 ad campaign next year, it was announced yesterday by Merlin E. Morris, advertising manager.

CINCINNATI, Jan. 1 -- The American National Theatre and Academy will have to disband if it does not soon receive increased financial support from individuals and theatre groups throughout the country, it was reported authoritatively here today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- The Congress of Industrial Organizations already is laying plans for a major role in the 1954 Congressional elections and the Presidential vote of 1956.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- A comprehensive review of the national origins quota system for immigration was offered in the report today of the President's Commission on Immigration and Naturalization. The Commission strongly objected to the system and recommended its abolition.
HANOI, Vietnam, Indo-China, Jan. 1 -- French-Vietnamese drives against Vietminh base areas in the Tonkin Delta are disrupting Communist concentrations, causing heavy Vietminh casualties.
In 1952 the population of this city passed the 8,000,000 mark, reaching an estimated total of 8,053,000, according to the Department of Health.

Three small but important locals of the International Longshoremen's Association, their confidence bolstered by a pledge of full support from Joseph P. Ryan, the union's president, went ahead last night with their plans for a strike at 7:55 A. M. today in the ports of New York, Boston, Philadelphia and Baltimore.
President-elect Dwight D. Eisenhower spent a quiet New Year's Day at his residence at 50 Morningside Drive with Mrs. Eisenhower and other members of his family.

DURBAN, South Africa, Jan. 1 -- In a New Year message, Prime Minister Daniel F. Malan reaffirmed his belief in apartheid (racial segregation) and said that "natural differences" among races would continue for generations to come. "It may be safe to jump over the ditch," but to jump over the gorge would be fatal, he declared.

A destitute mother and her two small children who were befriended on Christmas Eve by an unemployed seamstress who had offerred to share her home and food with them finally had to make a desperate appeal to the police yesterday when the last of the cupboard's meager contents were gone.

KINGSTON, Jamaica, Jan. 1 (UP) -- Mal Whitfield of Columbus, Ohio, and Harrison Dillard of Cleveland set Jamaica records today to pace United States athletes competing in the fourth day of the Jamaica Olympic Association's international track series.
ROME, Jan. 1 (AP) -- A Foreign Office spokesman said today that Italy would bar the entry of Italian-born racketeers who may be deported after denaturalization proceedings by the United States.

Of all the New Year resolutions a conscientious Congressman might make, a resolve to do something about the McCarran anti-immigration act would be among the most useful. But before he can "do something" the Congressman must know what the act is all about -- which we are confident most members of Congress didn't know when they voted for the law last spring and voted for it again in overriding President Truman's veto.
With the opening of the new Congress a few short days away it is important that efforts be renewed to obtain the prompt repeal or amendment of the unfortunate McCarran-Walter Immigration Law.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 (UP) -- The House Small Business Committee in a report tonight said that inflationary pressures had decreased to the point where a price and wage decontrol program should be started.

Dr. Edward Lasker of New York, meeting R. G. Wade of New Zealand for the first time, played to a draw in forty-three moves yesterday in the third round of the international masters' tournament at the Hastings Chess Club in England, according to a report from London.

A soft pinkish cocoa color, called apricot brandy, is invading the fashion departments of B. Altman Co. Shown recently to the press, the tone was originated by the store and planned for all its ready-to-wear departments as well as such related accessory departments as jewelry, lingerie, gloves and handbags.

The snowstorm that covered the metropolitan area with a four-inch blanket failed to make much difference in the over-all Northeastern ski picture yesterday. The local area bore the brunt of the coastal storm, which was expected to bury the Poconos, Hudson Highlands and near-by New Jersey and Connecticut skilands under deep covers and bring several more inches of powdered snow to the Catskills.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Jan. 1 -- Top Indonesian military sources declared today that the Indonesian armed forces, sorely lacking arms and ammunition. were strongly receptive to United States military aid on a payment basis and that the Cabinet discussed this point for the first time last Tuesday.

ROME, Jan. 1 -- Some thousands of former Fascists who had been debarred by law from either voting or standing as candidates in any Italian election regained full use of all their civil rights today. Several of them are likely to run for the Chamber of Deputies in the general elections scheduled for this spring.

The Sterling Engine Company will pay its first cash dividend in years in the form of an initial quarterly payment of 2 1/2 cents on Jan. 26 to holders of the new 5 per cent convertible preferred stock of record Jan. I5, Robert Russell, president, announced yesterday.
That silent helper, the tray, is available in a number of handsome new designs, which might add a decorative note to the serving of drinks, meals or snacks during the near year.

Many passengers on the Lexington Avenue and West Side lines of the I. R. T. division of the subway and on some branches of the B. M. T. expressed puzzlement yesterday when they found that from two to five cars at the end of their trains were kept dark and empty.

After the excesses of the holidays the citrus fruits refresh palates worn out with fruit cake, eggnog and all the other temptations of the groaning board. A salad of chilled sliced oranges or of endive with grapefruit sections may now tempt one, because, in contrast to what has been served, it is so simple.

Negotiations for a new contract covering towboat and barge workers in New York Harbor will open on Tuesday morning between representatives of the boat owners and the wage scale committee of Local 333, United Marine Division of the International Longshoremen's Association, A. F. L.

The development of atomic power has depended thus far upon the needs of the military. The Atomic Energy Commission, the Air Force and the Navy are now working on an atom-powered submarine and an atom-powered aircraft. These projects, when completed, will provide engineering information for stationary power plants.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- Legislation that bars subversive aliens from entry into the United States "must remain on the statute books and be strictly enforced," the President's Commission on Immigration and Naturalization asserted in a report issued today.

ALTHOUGH fishing tournaments seem to be on the wane, a circumstance that will have no effect whatsoever on the popularity of angling, the Metropolitan Miami Fishing Tournament, one of the largest in the point of entries, opened yesterday and will continue to mid-April.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- Following are the excerpts from the report "Whom Shall We Welcome," issued today by The President's Commission on Immigration and Naturalization:

PARIS, Dec. 30 -- French summer fabrics, in the form of embossed or raised weaves, continue to hold interest. Among those fabrics for coats, Rodier offers "grill work" or raised checking of gray fleece on a smooth white wool, Bisville, a white fleece lattice on white or pastel ground.

" Six Weeks in March," a new novel by Constance Robertson, will be issued by Random House on Jan. 19. Set in the period after the Civil War, the story deals with the sons and daughters of an upstate New Yorker, who gather at the family homestead during a March storm to await their father's death and lay hands on his hidden store of wealth.

PASADENA, Calif., Jan. 1 (AP) -- Traveling 73 yards on a victory parade led by second-string halfback Rudy Bukich, the Trojans of Southern California defeated Wisconsin, 7 -- 0, today and finally, in the seventh year, ended the succession of Big Ten triumphs over the Coast Conference in the Rose Bowl.

LONDON, Jan. 1 -- The apparent incongruity of a message from the chief of Britain's organized labor wishing success to Conservative Prime Minister Churchill in his visit to President-elect Dwight D. Eisenhower has perturbed some newspapers here. But Tom O'Brien president of the Trades Union Congress, who sent the message Tuesday on the eve of Mr. Churchill's departure for the United States, said today that he had received no protests.

MIAMI, Jan. 1 -- Alabama's Crimson Tide rolled with such force today that it set records in beating Syracuse by 61 -- 6 in the Orange Bowl football game before a gathering of 66,208, the largest ever to attend the classic.

Golden Hurricane Rally Falls Short When Miner Misses a Late Field Goal JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Jan. 1 (AP) -- Rick Casares got a second chance to kick a conversion because of a Tulsa penalty today and that gave Florida a 14-13 victory over Tulsa in the eighth annual Gator Bowl football game before a crowd of 30,015.
Vigilant inspectors of the city's Bureau of Food and Drugs have thwarted an attempt to palm off horsemeat instead of beef as an ingredient in basterma.

LONDON, Jan. 1 -- If an agreement can be reached on compensation for the nationalization of its concession in Iran, the Anglo-Iranian Oil Company will be prepared to buy up to 10,000,000 tons of petroleum products a year from the nationalized oil industry, it was reliably stated here today.

DALLAS, Jan. 1 (AP) -- Dick Ochoa hammered the heralded Tennessee defense to bits today as Texas defeated the Volunteers by 16 -- 0 in the Cotton Bowl. It was sweet revenge for a 20-14 beating the Vols had handed Texas in the 1951 Cotton Bowl game.

Robert Moses, a personage of undeniable ability and talent, has espoused many meritorious causes in the past. His latest proposal, however, to finance a $40,000,000 highway improvement program in Nassau County by means of the imposition of a ten-cent toll on the Southern State Parkway close to the New York City line lacks the realism and sound judgment one tends to associate with his projects.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 (UP) -- Former Secretary of State James F. Byrnes said today he had ordered State Department officials in 1946 to make no "recommendations" of would-be employes to the United Nations. He added he had not discussed the matter with Alger Hiss.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 1 (UP) -- Leon Hardeman, a stocky, little halfback with a game leg but an even gamer heart, powered Georgia Tech to a 24-to-7 Sugar Bowl victory over Mississippi today to prolong football's longest unbeaten streak through twenty-six games.

ORLANDO, Fla., Jan. 1 (AP) -- East Texas State mixed James Gray's passing with Marvin Brown's running to win its nineteenth straight football game tonight, beating Tennessee Tech, 33 -- 0, in the Tangerine Bowl.

With gross sales expected to exceed $1,250,000,000, the year 1952 was the biggest in automatic merchandising history, and 1953 promises to be even bigger, according to Robert Z. Greene, president of Rowe Corporation, the country's largest manufacturer and operator of vending machines.

A project for determining performance specifications of textile fabrics will be initiated at a meeting in the offices of the American Standards Association, 70 East Forty-fifth Street, next Thursday. More than fifty organizations have been asked to send representatives.
DETROIT, Jan. 1 (AP) -- An aluminum engine for passenger automobiles is a distinct future possibility -- if production costs can be leveled off.

BOSTON, Jan. 1 -- Rabbi Jacob I. Zuber, 54 years old, a Jewish scholar who immigrated to this country from Europe in 1947, died today in Boston City Hospital, apparently the victim of a beating by hoodlums in a lonely public park in the Roxbury district.

THE one quality in man that is universally admired is hustle, a zest for hard work. It's even much more admirable in the other fellow. That's why there is so much appeal in the labor of love that Bob Sieger performs annually for The Detroit News. He is a chap of such appalling energy that he carefully compiles a collection of quotes that sports celebrities were so foolhardy as to utter.

ABOARD THE LINER QUEEN MARY, Jan. 1 (UP) -- Prime Minister Churchill, in fine fettle after a hilarious welcome to 1953, tore into a huge breakfast of lamb cutlets and fried eggs today while most of his fellow merrymakers sipped black coffee.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- Robert A. Lovett, the outgoing Secretary of Defense, notified President Truman today that the National Security Act, the master blueprint for the nation's defense machinery, was an inadequate law that could not stand the strain of emergency. His criticisms included the methods of the Joint Chiefs of Staff.

PARIS, Jan. 1 -- Rene Mayer, fourth hesitating candidate for the Premiership in the eleven-day French Cabinet crisis, conferred today with former Premiers of France and found that he was confronted with all the problems that had faced his predecessors:

HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Jan. 1 -- A. Holly Patterson, former presiding supervisor of the Hempstead Town Board, officially became Nassau County Executive today, succeeding J. Russel Sprague, who held that post since the county charter was adopted in 1938.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- A new Congress controlled by men not close to President-Elect Dwight D. Eisenhower on the Republican side or very close to Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois on the Democratic side, was forecast tonight on the eve of the decisive caucuses tomorrow.
DALLAS, Jan. 1 -- Texas not only got her Brazos River back, but won a Nashville publisher when Texas University's football team whipped the University of Tennessee in the Cotton Bowl today.

ALBANY, Jan. 1 -- Governor Dewey will ask the Legislature next week to approve a controversial plan requiring all owners of motor vehicles in New York to carry a minimum amount of liability insurance.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 (AP) -- Senator Prescott Bush, Republican of Connecticut, announced today he has resigned as a director of seven corporations but is keeping his partnership in the New York banking firm of Brown Brothers, Harriman Co.

A rather gloomy picture of the status of the American merchant marine was presented here yesterday by Walter E. Maloney, president of the American Merchant Marine Institute. In a year-end review of the industry, however, Mr. Maloney granted that the twelve-month period had witnessed significant developments.

While the greatest scientific story of 1952 concerned experiments in connection with the hydrogen bomb, perhaps the world's most potential devastating killer, the second one was field tests of gamma globulin, a potential protector of life and limb, Basil O'Connor, president of the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis, declared last night.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 (UP) -- Senator Milton R. Young, Republican of North Dakota, said today that Ezra T. Benson, Secretary of Agriculture-designate, had assured him that he had a "completely open mind" on extending mandatory high farm price supports.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Jan. 1 -- James B. Moore Jr.'s Lure from the home club finished first in both races completed in the B One-Design Class to lead with two points as the three-day annual frostbite regatta of the Manhasset Bay Y. C. opened today.

In a news item from Tel Aviv published Dec. 22 concerning the participation of the Greek Orthodox Church in a campaign to combat communism among its members, your correspondent makes a statement which is not altogether accurate.

LONDON, Jan. 1 -- A report issued here today by the International Wool Secretariat drew the inference from developments in 1952 that wool textile manufacturers were dropping the practice of mixing other fibers in their wool textile products.

PASADENA, Calif., Jan. 1 (AP) -The sixty-fourth annual Tournament of Roses, a treat in floral and feminine beauty, paraded today for an estimated 1,250,000 cheering spectators here and many more millions watching on television.

Effective today, the firm of Roberts Co., member of the New York Stock Exchange, becomes Cady, Roberts Co. A new senior partner is Everett Ware Cady, once senior partner in Rhoades Co. and more recently limited partner in Carl M. Loeb, Rhoades Co., who left that firm at the year-end.
LONDON, Jan. 1 (Reuters) -- The results of soccer and rugby games played in Great Britain today:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- The President's Commission on Immigration and Naturalization recommended today that the Immigration and Nationality Act of 1952, which went into effect eight days ago, be revised "from beginning to end."

LONDON, Jan. 1 -- A conference of white legislators, ministers and administrators started work in London today on a final plan of federation for three British territories in Central Africa. The native Negroes who comprise 96 per cent of the population of the territories were not directly represented.
TOKYO, Friday, Jan. 2 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,482, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Friday, Korea time:

MINEOLA, L. I., Jan. 1 -- Decentralization of industry, the popular term applied to the post-war industrial revolution that sent hundreds of manufacturers to new plants and factories in suburban areas, has boomed Nassau County, once known as the "bedroom of New York City."
VIENNA, Jan. 1 (AP) -- Czechoslovak President Klement Gottwald complained today Czechoslovakia's industrial production still lagged and food was scarce.

Central Maine Power Company will have to raise about $11,000,000 in capital this year, according to a report made to stockholders yesterday by W. F. Wyman, president. Present plans, he said, are to finance permanently the funds to be raised this year, along with $9,000,000 borrowed from banks in 1952, by the sale of $10,000,000 of bonds in the first quarter of 1953 and the sale of a like amount of new common stock later.

ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 1 (AP) -- Moonrush, a 7-year-old son of Hunter's Moon IV, captured today's sixteenth running of the $27,900 San Pasqual Handicap at Santa Anita. He barely hung on at the end of the mile and a sixteenth to shade the fast-closing Trusting.
CHICAGO, Jan. 1 -- The turning of a spadeful of earth at midnight started the rush task of building a house for a young mother crippled by poliomyelitis.

LONDON, Jan. 1 -- Convertibility is a big word, both in itself and in its implications for Britain and the British Commonwealth. It symbolizes all the Commonwealth's hopes of recapturing its pre-war economic position and will be the key to many a conversation when Prime Minister Churchill and his colleagues go to Washington in the spring for an official visit.

MALE, Maldive Islands, Jan. 1 -- The Maldive Islands, a serene tropical paradise of sturdy brown-skinned fishermen and comely mat weavers whose existence as a free nation has been little known beyond their own untroubled cobalt seas, became the world's newest independent republic today.

The premiere of "Can-Can," the next musical from the atelier of Feuer Martin, is now scheduled for the week of April 20 at the Shubert. To get everything in shape for the event, the Cole Porter-Abe Burrows show will spend four weeks in Philadelphia, starting March 23.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Jan. 1 (AP) -- William G. Williams' Sagittarius, with Sammy Boulmetis in the irons, defeated six other horses in the $10,000-added New Year's Handicap at six furlongs as Tropical Park opened the 1953 racing season with a morning program.

VALPARAISO, Chile, Jan. 1 -- At least forty persons were killed today and 500 injured when twenty tons of blasting powder exploded in a flaming warehouse. Officials said the death toll might reach 100.
DEARBORN, Mich., Jan. 1 -- The multi-million-dollar Ford Motor Company, which was started by Henry Ford with a paid-in capital of $28,000, will celebrate its fiftieth anniversary this year.
A comparison of today's food costs with those of a year ago gives some encouraging news. In many cases prices are lower now than they were as we ushered in 1952.

The University of Southern California scored in the third period to defeat Wisconsin in the Rose Bowl at Pasadena, Calif., yesterday. At New Orleans Georgia Tech swept to victory over Mississippi in the Sugar Bowl to prolong football's longest unbeaten streak through twenty-six games. Alabama drubbed Syracuse in the Orange Bowl at Miami, Fla.

PATERSON, N. J., Jan. 1 (AP) -- Robert Williams Jr., publisher of The Paterson Morning Call, died tonight in Paterson General Hospital at the age of 61. He suffered a heart attack on Christmas Day and had been in in the hospital since that time.

SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Jan. 1 -- Seton Hall University, ranked second nationally, registered its twelfth straight victory tonight, sinking Wittenberg College of Springfield, Ohio, 75 -- 60, before 1,300 at the Seton Hall gymnasium. Walter Dukes led Seton Hall with 30 points.

GENEVA, Jan. 1 -- Many analysts of Europe's economic life are beginning to believe that the end of 1952 will come to be regarded as the close of a fairly well defined period in this region's modern economic history.
TOKYO, Friday, Jan. 2 -- B-29 Superforts from Okinawa made their first air strike of the new year over North Korea last night, bombing close to the Communist capital of Pyongyang.

The public-be-damned attitude of the city administration has had its grave and inevitable consequence, and the most serious local transportation tie-up in a quarter of a century has occurred. It is now up to the Board of Estimate to dismount from its political platform and get these privately owned bus lines to running again, without fail before Monday and sooner if possible.

Two hundred friends, relatives and well-wishers of three new city officials gathered in City Hall yesterday to see them take the oath of office at the outset of the final year for which Mayor Impellitteri was elected in 1950.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Jan. 1 (AP) -- Dr. William Herbert Hobbs, who served as head of the University of Michigan's Geology Department until his retirement in 1934, died at his home here today. His age was 88.

TO distill the essence of more than twenty-five years' turbulent history into one novel is an impossible literary task. Yet that is what Mikhail Soloviev has tried to do in his sweeping fictional panorama, "When the Gods Are Silent."* Like Igor Kravchenko, Alexander Barmine and thousands of other Russians who renounced the Communist faith of their youth, Mr. Soloviev chose freedom and escaped to a better life beyond the Iron Curtain.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- Dr. Martha Eliot, chief of the Children's Bureau of the Federal Security Agency, said today that three groups of children should receive special attention in 1953 -- those in trouble with the law, those born prematurely and those in migrant families.

The members of the vestry at St. Margaret of Scotland (Protestant Episcopal) Church, 193d Street and Horace Harding Boulevard, Flushing, Queens, had a fine time ringing in the New Year on their new bell.

TROY, N. Y., Jan. 1 -- Bill Gall, wingman from Drummondville, Quebec, scored two goals tonight to lead Princeton to a 4-2 hockey victory ever Yale in the opening game of the second annual Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute invitation tournament.

Far from being an outsider in promoting basic research the small producer can make important contributions. This is the view of Dr. Paul Schwarzkopf, powder metallurgist, research scientist and head of a company that has made major additions to the contribution of research in metals.

Garlands of silvered foliage, with myriads of small white lights, frosted branches and Christmas trees, decorated the ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria last night for the thirty-first annual Debutantes' New Year's Ball, which was preceded by many dinner parties.
With 100,000,000 used Christmas cards received in the last two years, United Cerebral Palsy made a new appeal yesterday that no additional cards be sent for therapeutic use by palsied children.

Mozart and Mahler -- admitting that there is a difference -- made up the program of Bruno Walter's concert with the Philharmonic- Symphony Society last night in Carnegie Hall. The G minor symphony, in itself a symbol of incomparable inspiration and impeccable art, might have served as a model of concentration, self-forgetfulness and taste to the Mahler who knew Mozart's symphonies and operas and conducted them so memorably.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 (AP) -- The committee, which is composed of six Democrats and five Republicans, including the incoming Republican Floor Leader Representative Charles A. Halleck of Indiana, also criticized what it called "ineptitude * * * the deterioration in the caliber of personnel" in the government's present emergency control agencies.

PRINCETON, N. J., Jan. 1 -- Dr. Frank Aydelotte "retired" today as American secretary to the Rhodes Trustees, a post in which he has spent thirty-five years in making Rhodes scholarships to Oxford University the most widely sought of all fellowships available to American college students.

CHICAGO, Jan. 1 (UP) -- The president of the American Medical Association, Dr. Louis H. Bauer of Hempstead, L. I., called upon physicians tonight to work for a broad expansion of "voluntary" health insurance programs. He said physicians must "clean our own house" by disciplining those who engaged in such unethical practices as overcharging and accepting kick-backs.

CHICAGO, Jan. 1 -- Net income of Chicago's major banks last year was moderately higher than in 1951, annual reports of the banks disclosed today. In most cases operating expenses and taxes were higher, but these were more than offset by increased revenues.

The bird lover in Mendham, N. J., who hastened to report the sighting of a mockingbird on his back porch should be warned that mockingbirds are not an unmixed blessing. The mockingbird has been hailed in song and made to sound like a very fine fellow; some writers have been guilty of turning him into a romantic feathered figure, something akin to the nightingale, lending sweet melody to the dreamy Southland.
Every four seconds during each working day of 1952 the Bell Telephone Companies added one new telephone to the list of subscribers, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- A Federal Court here will consider shortly the validity of a National Labor Relations Board order that certain labor leaders reaffirm non-Communist oaths that were made under provisions of the Taft-Hartley Act.

A realignment of the American Broadcasting Company's television programs is under way in an effort to improve their competitive position with those of other networks. A "substantial sum" of money has been allotted for new program development both for the A. B. C. network and its local station, WJZ-TV, a spokesman said yesterday.

GRAHAMSTOWN, South Africa, Jan. 1 -- The word coelacanth means "hollow spine," and has stood for a remarkable race of fishlike creatures of almost incredible antiquity. These fish were some of the first to appear in that dim and distant past when life on this planet began.

Despite Arab opposition, Chancellor Adenauer is determined to submit to his Parliament the German-Israeli agreement for $822,000,000 to be paid in compensation for Nazi outrages against the Jews in Germany. Seven Arab League states have threatened to break off economic relations with Western Germany and have already started to boycott its goods.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 1 -- Three of the eleven persons still on United Nations payroll despite adverse comment by the State Department are division directors, one of the top categories in the secretariat hierarchy.

Public and parochial school authorities, cooperating in the city's efforts to minimize the impact of the bus strike, reached a tentative decision yesterday to stagger school hours to keep pupils out of the subways during rush periods and weighed the possibility that some schools might have to close altogether in Bronx and Queens areas where students depend on buses to get to classes.

John B. Hunt has been named production manager of the Borden Food Products Company, a division of the Borden Company. Formerly assistant production manager, he succeeds Carl C. Baldwin, who has retired after nearly forty years of service.

RABAT, French Morocco, Jan. 1 (UP) -- Gen. Augustin Guillaume, the French Resident General, outlined in a New Year's message an ambitious social and economic program to help Morocco "join modern states."

A large majority of the members of the New England Purchasing Agents Association, Boston, believe that production in their area during December was better or the same as in the previous two months and in the similar month of 1951. Twenty-four per cent thought it was better, 66 per cent the same, and only 10 per cent believed it to be worse.

Richard Raskind, Yale sophomore from Forest Hills, yesterday ended the reign of Gerald Barrack as Eastern junior indoor tennis champion. Taking control in the second set, the left-handed Raskind defeated the two-time title-winner from Bayonne, N. J., and Cornell, 3 -- 6, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 1, in the final at the Seventh Regiment Armory.

BOSTON, Jan. 1 (UP) -- In a game featured by a free-for-all and two serious injuries, the makeshift Bruins notched a 5-1 victory, over Toronto tonight in a National Hockey League contest before 8,710 fans.

George P. Moore, an employe of the Cunard Line for twenty-four years and a member of its catering staff here for the last ten years, has been appointed assistant catering superintendent, it was announced yesterday by Harold P. Borer, general manager of the line in this country.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- A new plan for joint participation by the United States and Canada in the construction of the controversial St. Lawrence Seaway will be introduced in Congress by Senator Alexander Wiley, Republican of Wisconsin.
JERSEY CITY, Jan. 1 -- Mayor John V. Kenny assured 4,000 of his friends and Second Ward neighbors here today that he had not changed since he and his "Freedom" ticket were elected in 1949.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Jan. 1 -- Sixty-nine Israelis were killed, seventy-seven wounded and thirty-six kidnapped, while 394 Arabs were killed and 227 wounded, during raids into Israeli territory by Arab infiltrators during the twelve months from Dec. 1, 1951, to Nov. 30, 1952, an official Israeli source disclosed today.

The Federal Maritime Board has put into effect, with the beginning of the year, operating differential subsidy contracts with two San Francisco shipping concerns in the trans-Pacific freight trade, Albert W. Gatov, chairman of the board, announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- A State Department memorandum listing thirty-eight past and present United States employes of the United Nations as persons "believed to be Communists or under Communist discipline" was made public today by the Senate Internal Security subcommittee.

Several major national Jewish organizations and a prominent Protestant leader hailed yesterday the recommendations in the report of the President's Commission on Immigration and Naturalization. They said the report embodied principles that could serve as a strong basis for revision of the immigration laws.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 1 (AP) -- Jack Kramer announced tonight that Frank Sedgman and Ken McGregor, the world's top amateur tennis stars, were turning professional. He said they had accepted his $100,000 offer for a tour of the United States "and other places on which I decide."

On the first day of the New Year the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund received 133 gifts that added $4,651.64 to the forty-first annual appeal. Among them was a $2,000 donation from a contributor who wished to remain anonymous.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 1 -Communist activities in Brazil apparently are as widespread as ever after a year of efforts by authorities to break them up.

Foul weather over most of the country on New Year's Eve yielded some dividends in the relatively low toll of traffic fatalities, it appeared last night. Another contributing factor may well have been cautious driving after the record loss of 556 lives over the long Christmas week-end.

Payment of any further liquidating dividend by the Continental Bank and Trust Company, which has been in liquidation since its banking business was bought in 1948 by Chemical Bank and Trust Company, must await a report of an examining committee of the New York State Superintendent of Banks, John T. Seaman, president of Continental, reported to stockholders yesterday.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Jan. 1 (AP) -- The San Diego Naval Training Center eleven ripped through the bewildered Camp Breckinridge (Ky.) team today for an 81-20 Salad Bowl football victor before a crowd of 14,000.

Formation of the Robert N. Tuller Company to handle business in state, municipal and revenue bonds is announced today, following the dissolution yesterday of the New York Stock Exchange firm of Tuller, Crary Ferris, of which Mr. Tuller was the principal partner.
Kenneth A. Greene, Consul General of Canada in New York City, has sent a message of felicitation to the New York Curb Exchange, which on Monday will change its name to the American Stock Exchange.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 (AP) -- A group of twenty-five rooms in the Statler Hotel has been reserved for the Jan. 20 inauguration in the name of the Vice President-elect Richard M. Nixon, a House of Representatives committee has been told.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's New York agenda for tomorrow will include a discussion of the advisability of reviving, in the Congress convening Saturday, some plan to put universal military training into effect at an early date, according to proponents of the program.
In a generally hopeful review of the work of the welfare agencies of the United Nations during the past year Kathleen McLaughlin reported to this newspaper:
TOKYO, Jan. 1 (AP) -- A Camp Drake Army team today defeated the Yokosuka Navy Base Sea Hawks, 25 -- 6, in the Tokyo Rice Bowl game for the first Far East interservice football championship.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- Should Senator Taft decide, as he says he may, to give up his place on the Finance Committee, just below the incoming chairman, Senator Millikin, for fifth place on the Committee on Foreign Relations, his influence on Congressional action in the field of international policy will increase because he will be more intimately associated with its beginnings.

Referring to your editorial "New Trade Pattern" permit me to say that there can be no solution to the foreign trade problems now besetting the world as long as the Soviet Government survives. We may continue our present policy of patching up here and there, like the shepherd boy in the Russian story who tried to eliminate a hole in the front of his coat by cutting out pieces from other portions of the garment.

ADELAIDE, Australia, Jan. 1 (UP) -- Lewis Hoad, Australia's rising young tennis star, demonstrated today that he may be the logical successor to Frank Sedgman, when he defeated Tony Trabert of Cincinnati, 8 -- 6, 6 -- 4 in the International Club exhibition matches.

WASHINGTON Jan. 1 (UP) -- The American Federation of Labor told its affiliated unions today to exercise "utmost caution" in negotiating 1953 wage contracts pegged to the Government's new cost of living index.

A fire in a crowded Puerto Rican tenement in the Red Hook district of Brooklyn took the lives of a mother and her 4-year-old daughter, caused injuries to seven persons, and drove thirty-nine other tenants to the wet, cold street in their night clothing about 5 o'clock yesterday morning.
THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Jan. 1 -- The Netherlands is likely to be weaned from United States dollar assistance.

THE NEW YORK TIMES of Dec. 23 reported that the New York State Catholic Welfare Committee had issued a public statement opposing the recommendations made by several agencies, including the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith, that the New York State Commission Against Discrimination bar hotel and resort advertising which included the phrase "churches near by" or variants thereof.

Leaders of the city's biggest bus strike served notice yesterday that they would boycott city-sponsored peace talks until Mayor Impellitteri proved or apologized for his charge that the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., and the eight struck bus companies were in collusion to force higher fares.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 1 -- A Kentucky lawyer, Rodes K. Myers, arrived here today after announcing plans to contest the will of Samuel D. Riddle, multimillionaire sportsman who gained fame as owner of the great race-horse, Man o' War.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Jan. 1 -- The rising roll of corporations moving national and regional headquarters from New York to Westchester County carried construction costs of projected office centers today to $51,000,000 and the number of persons expected to be added to local employment lists substantially past the 10,000 mark.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Jan. 1 -- Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson, whose four-year term ends Jan. 12, greeted 2,000 people today at the traditional New Year's open house in the Governor's Mansion.

EL PASO, Tex., Jan. 1 (AP) -- Tom McCormick exploded for three touchdowns today to lead the College of the Pacific to a 26-7 victory over Mississippi Southern in the eighteenth Sun Bowl football game:

HONG KONG, Jan. 1 -- Chang Shun-yu, a Suiyuan cart driver with an obsession that propelled him to and fro over a distance of 9,000 miles in six months and overcame the bureaucrats of twenty-seven Government offices in three North China provinces, finally has received satisfaction.
The striking bus workers are seeking a forty-hour week with no cut in the pay they used to get for working forty-four to forty-eight hours, with five to nine hours of guaranteed overtime.

Charging the United States Department of Agriculture with responsibility for a decline in butter consumption here, the Coordinating Committee, Perishable Foods, Port of New York, estimated yesterday that New Yorkers will consume this year even less than they did in 1952. Last year's consumption here was only half of that in 1940.

Bill Stern, the veteran sportscaster, showed a rare brand of both courage and common sense yesterday. Noted for years as an announcer who practically never stopped talking, he completely altered his technique in giving over the N. B. C. network an account of the Cotton Bowl game between Texas and Tennessee. He was a reporter, not a chattering and artificial expert, and it was an immense improvement.
The Los Angeles Department of Water and Power announced yesterday that it will receive bids on Jan. 13 on $5,000,000 of water works revenue bonds dated Feb. 1, 1953 and due on Feb. 1, 1954 to 1993.
CORAL GABLES, Fla., Jan. 2 (AP) -- The strain of winning 390 horse races last year has tired out Tony DeSpirito.

MEXICO CITY, Jan. 2 -- Vicente Lombardo Toledano, Mexican labor leader, announced today that he had asked President Adolfo Ruiz Cortines to order an inquiry by the Attorney General's office into the origin and publication of a letter that two Mexico City newspapers asserted he wrote to Mao Tse-tung, Chinese Communist leader.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- A special investigating committee of the House of Representatives reported today that Communists, in a Moscow-directed program, had tried for twenty years to infiltrate and control philanthropic foundations in this country, but with little success.

The wheels of trading on the New York Stock Exchange in 1953 were started yesterday with a sale of 200 shares of Goodyear Tire and Rubber common at 54 3/4, up 1/4 point from the final price for 1952. In 1952 the stock showed a gain of 10 1/2 points in market value for the year.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- Reduction of Federal spending to make way for tax cuts and a sound national economy was laid down as the primary aim of the Republicans in the new House of Representatives at a party caucus today.

Federal Judge Matthew T. Abruzzo denied yesterday an application for a preliminary injunction to Theodore F. Otten, a 46-year-old employe of the Staten Island Rapid Transit Company, who sought to restrain the railroad from discharging him because he had refused to join a union.
PROVIDENCE, R. I., Jan. 2 (AP) -- The play "Tobacco Road" appeared destined tonight to become a test case of the right of the Providence Bureau of Licenses to exercise powers of censorship.

St. Francis College of Brooklyn defeated Amherst last night, 68 to 36, as Vernon Stokes, captain of the Terriers, scored his 1,000th point in his third season as a varsity basketball player. The record for a St. Francis performer is 1,028, set by Roy Reardon during the 1949-50 campaign.
New financing will get started in a substantial way next week, with a wide variety of underwriting transactions scheduled.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- A Senate subcommittee, after eighteen months of intermittent investigation of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, issued a final report today in which it declined to offer either conclusions or recommendations as to his fitness to hold office.

LONDON, Jan. 2 -- Although there has been a "change of emphasis" in some parts of Britain's rearmament program there has been no reduction in the scale of rearmament, the British Government declared today.

BONN, Germany, Jan. 2 -- The Soviet Government has again committed the West German Communist party to the destruction of Chancellor Konrad Adenauer's center coalition Government and the resumption of the social struggle for power, although Premier Joseph Stalin recently professed a readiness to meet with Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the President-elect, for the purpose of consolidating peace.

Thirty-five years ago Dr. Frank Aydelotte became the American Secretary to the Rhodes Trust. He has now retired from that post after a third of a century in which he became the best-known American to be connected with the administration of the Rhodes scholarships.

ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 2 (UP) -- Chanlea, Calumet Farm's leading Derby hope at the moment, raced to a length and a quarter victory today at Santa Anita Park in the $16,850 San Vicente Stakes for 3-year-old colts and geldings. In scoring the victory, Chanlea defeated the colt that had beaten him by a nose in the rich Del Mar Futurity last summer, Hour Regards.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed steady yesterday 3 to 21 points net higher than on Wednesday, with a small volume of business.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- Dr. Leonard Carmichael, psychologist and educator, was sworn in today as the seventh secretary of the Smithsonian Institution, the 106-year-old cultural and scientific agency.

There are indications that Lavrenti P. Beria has suffered a demotion in relative power among the top leaders of the Soviet Union. Instead of being the fourth highest ranking personage in the Soviet political constellation, it appears now that he is occupying the number six slot and has fallen behind two individuals whom he formerly outranked.

CROTON-ON-HUDSON, N. Y., Jan. 2 -- Plans for conversion of the historic Van Cortlandt Manor House on the Albany Post Road here into business offices were advanced tonight by village authorities despite protests registered by historians earlier in the day.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands Jan. 2 -- In an angry three-quarter-hour interview Joseph M. Luns, Netherlands Minister without Portfolio in the Foreign Ministry, rejected the demand of the Soviet Ambassador, G. T. Zaitsev, for the release of Lev C. Pissarev, the Tass correspondent who has been under arrest for the past ten days on espionage charges.

Nominations for four of the most important stakes events of the New York turf, two for this year and two for 1954, will close on Jan. 15. The fixtures concerned are the Belmont Stakes, the Coaching Club American Oaks and the two sides of the National Stallion Stakes for 1954.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 (AP) -- The Department of Justice moved tonight to reduce the scope of its multi-billion-dollar anti-trust suit against the wealthy du Pont family by striking several score defendants from the case.

JACKSON, Miss., Jan. 2 (AP) -- Gov. Hugh White of Mississippi today sent a blistering telegram to Southeastern Conference Commissioner Bernie Moore rapping "the worst officiating I've ever seen" at the Sugar Bowl football game.
The complete itinerary for the New York Yacht Club cruise in late July and early August was made public yesterday by Alexander P. Gest Jr., chairman of the race committee.

Mrs. Eulalia Figueiredo of New Bedford, Mass., due to be deported to Portugal on Jan. 20 because of former membership in the Communist party, was arrested yesterday at Immigration and Naturalization Service headquarters, 70 Columbus Avenue, and held without bail on Ellis Island.
Attorney General James P. McGranery announced yesterday in Washington that a new Federal grand jury here would reopen an investigation into the employment of disloyal Americans at the United Nations.

A plan for students of both public and parochial high schools, under which the city's youthful scholars will report at 10 A. M. during the bus strike so as to relieve transit congestion in the morning rush hour, was announced yesterday by Dr. William Jansen, Superintendent of Schools.

Continuation of present savings trends and an increasing volume of funds seeking investment should give a firm underlying tone to the bond market, Halsey, Stuart Co. said in its annual year-end bond survey yesterday.

After 112 years at Park Place and Washington Street, the Gillies Coffee Company, one of the country's oldest coffee merchants, has purchased the property at 89 Water Street from the Estate of Alfred F. Haenlein. The parcel, which is assessed at $43,000 was bought for cash in an expansion move which included the leasing of several floors in the adjoining building at 91 Water Street through Douglas Gibbons Co., brokers.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 2 -- Herman Phleger, San Francisco attorney, slated to be legal adviser to the incoming Secretary of State, is a member of the leading local law firm of Brobeck, Phleger Harrison and served as associate director of the legal division of the Office of Military Government in Germany in 1945.
