Japanese children sometimes sing this little song:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 (UP) -- More money was spent on new buildings in the United States in 1952 than ever before, but the actual amount of building fell below that of 1950 and 1951, preliminary estimates by the Labor and Commerce Departments showed today.

TOKYO, Saturday, Jan. 3 -- United Nations turned back seven Communist attacks along the frozen Korean front yesterday while Allied warplanes flew deep into North Korea and struck at enemy supply concentrations and communications lines.

Year-end pay-offs cut New York bank loans to business $47,000,000 last week. Except during the week ended Sept. 3, when there was a decline of $5,000,000, the latest reduction was the first recorded since last July.

MOSCOW, Jan. 2 -- Pravda published today a letter in which P. Fedoseyev, former editor of the Communist party's theoretical journal, Bolshevik, apologized for shortcomings of articles that he had recently published in Izvestia concerning Premier Stalin's new economic theses.

Mrs. Thomas W. Lamont, who died here last Monday, left $4,115,000 in specific bequests, including $3,950,000 to educational, cultural and civic organizations, and $160,000 to friends and employes, it was revealed yesterday when her will was filed in Surrogate's Court of New York County.

The run-down condition of New York City's public school properties is an old story, but it is useful -- and disheartening -- to get the full picture as presented to the Board of Education in a series of reports by Diedrich F. Lehnert, Superintendent of Plant Operation and Maintenance. Mr. Lehnert finds that there is a "backlog of deferred maintenance in our schools amounting to over $75,000,000."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 (AP) -- Representative Carl Vinson, chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, reiterated today his doubt that an alternative site for the projected air base at Plattsburg, N. Y., would receive "favorable consideration."

ALBANY, Jan. 2 -- Governor Dewey will recommend to the Legislature in his annual message Wednesday that the State Youth Commission and the State Mental Health Commission be continued to 1956. The Youth Commission is scheduled to expire this year and the Mental Health Commission in 1954.

Front-page news is rarely made by the Netherlands. Only twice recently has this steady-nerved and plodding little kingdom, almost literally a manmade land, broken into the headlines, both times with good news. This in itself is remarkable; bad news is so much more sensational and nowadays so much more frequent that it crowds out the good news.

ALBANY, Jan. 2 -- The State Bar Association urged Governor Dewey today to support a proposal for the creation of a commission to study the method of selecting judges in the state and other problems of the judicial system.
Those who have been stumbling over toys on the floor ever since Christmas might be interested in making storage chests for such items.

Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower heard recommendations yesterday from three members and two aides of the National Security Training Commission for the immediate establishment of Universal Military Training, but he refrained from stating any policy to that effect.

LONDON, Jan. 2 -- Zinc was freely traded here today for the first time since the start of World War II in 1939. The price closed about 2 cents a pound cheaper for prompt delivery than the last official price under bulk selling.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 (AP) -- Secretary of the Interior Oscar L. Chapman said today that President Truman had approved the location of the permanent headquarters of the American-administered Pacific Trust territory on Dublon Island in the Truk atoll.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- Roy M. Cohn, who was one of the witnesses Tuesday before the Judiciary subcommittee of the House of Representatives, will take his place soon in the Washington scene on the other side of the table when he becomes chief counsel for the Senate investigating subcommittee to be headed by Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 (UP) -- The Government today shut off potato imports from Spain, the Canary Islands, Estonia and Latvia to prevent spread of the golden nematode, a serious insect pest.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 2 (UP) -- Lloyd Mangrum of Niles, Ill., who won the Los Angeles open two years ago, took a first-round lead today with a two-under-par 69 as darkness was settling over the Riviera Country Club.

PASADENA, Calif., Jan. 2 (UP) -- Southern California's victory over Wisconsin in the Rose Bowl on New Year's Day spurred efforts today toward renewal of the Pacific Coast Conference's bowl agreement with the Big Ten.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 2 -- In addition to the military and political rapprochement among Greece, Turkey and Yugoslavia, Yugoslav sources stress the substantial commercial cooperation that is foreseen in this new Balkan entente with Yugoslavia apparently assuming the unusual role of exporter of industrial goods and equipment.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- Representative Thruston Ballard Morton of Kentucky, who has been nominated by President-elect Dwight D. Eisenhower to be an Assistant Secretary of State, will come to the Eisenhower Administration as yet another political antagonist of Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican of Ohio.

When Pennsylvania's Ernie Beck went on a 27-point scoring spree against Duke in the Dixie Classic basketball tournament -- a feat that earned him a place on the all-star tournament team -- he also went into the lead in the national major college scoring race.

Charles Blount Jr., president and director of the United Piece Dye Works. 132 Madison Avenue, sent his personal check for $750 to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund yesterday to bring the day's gifts to $3,372.71 and the total for the forty-first annual appeal to $370,236.11.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 (AP) -- The Senate Elections subcommittee announced late today that Michigan Democrats had withdrawn their request for a recount of the 1952 Senate election vote in that state. The action ended any contest of the victory of Charles E. Potter, Republican, over Blair Moody, Democrat.

ROTTERDAM, the Netherlands, Jan. 2 (Reuters) -- The American Black Diamond shipping line has quit the North Atlantic Westbound Freight Conference because of dissatisfaction over freight rates, the company's agents said tonight.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- The Equal Rights Amendment, which has been introduced in every Congress for the last thirty years, will be one of the first bills in the hopper at tomorrow's opening session of the Eighty-third Congress.
MUNSAN, Korea, Jan. 2 (AP) -- The United Nations truce delegation "set the record straight" today on a long series of Communist charges that Allied warplanes were flying over neutral Panmunjom.
The following is a round-up of new products that may be of use to homemakers:

BOSTON, Jan. 2 -- A man with a liver disease no longer is doomed to almost certain death. An approach to conquest of cirrhosis of the liver has been achieved, in large part, by a hollow needle through which are taken bits of the victim's liver for diagnosis, study, and proof of proper treatment.
MOBILE, Ala., Jan. 2 (AP) -- Steve Owen's pass-minded South squad was rated an even choice with Paul Brown's North team today for the Senior Bowl all-star football game tomorrow.
BOSTON, Jan. 2 (UP) -- The feud between Henry F. Long, Massachusetts Tax Commissioner, and the state of New Hampshire was on again today.
OTTAWA, Jan. 2 -- Canada ushered out the old year with a record production of minerals, the Bureau of Statistics reported today.

When the Eighty-third Congress convenes today the Republican party will come into full control of the national legislative machinery for the first time since the demise of the Eightieth Congress four years ago. And in less than three weeks from now a Republican Congress will be operating under a Republican Administration for the first time in twenty-two years.

The long-standing and widespread practice of sleeping on trains -- specifically subway trains -- was vindicated yesterday in a prompt and concise ruling by Magistrate J. Irwin Shapiro in Long Island City Magistrate's Court, Queens.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 2 -- A bill to revise and modernize the Ohio General Code, stripping it of such legal surplusage as "and/or," "null and void" and "cease and terminate," will be put before the Ohio Legislature, which convenes here Jan. 5.

CHICAGO, Jan. 2 -- Wheat and corn futures on the Board of Trade today started the new year with an early upturn, but the market encountered free selling on the hard spots, while buying demand was inclined to lag. Other grains and soybeans followed the same general course as the major cereals.

I have been seething for a long time over the deplorable puerility of radio and television, and the news story about the dismissal of George S. Kaufrnan from a TV program has finally caused me to boil over.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 2 -- The Egyptian delegation said today that ships carrying cargoes of meat bound for Israel had been allowed to go through the Suez Canal several times.

Into the semi-vacuum created by the passage of Christmas the purveyors of garden seeds -- flower and vegetable -- very wisely push their catalogues, bright, cheerful, promising of spring and of flowers and tomatoes, radishes and beans.

Preparing for the first major intercollegiate ski meet of the season scheduled to start today at Lyndonville, Vt., Middlebury yesterday disclosed that only one man was lost from the Panthers' 1951-52 Eastern champion team.

VALPARAISO, Chile, Jan. 2 (AP) -- Government officials pressed their investigation tonight into the cause of the New Year's Day blast that rocked this Chilean port city. The toll mounted to fifty-one dead and 348 injured.

LONDON, Jan. 2 -- Dr. John T. Robinson, the South African paleontologist who is continuing the work of the late Dr. Robert Broom, has published a note in the current issue of the British scientific magazine Nature reaffirming that his latest fossil discovery, a few bones of the man-ape, Telanthropus capensis, is "intermediate between one of the apemen and true man."

The January quota for the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program is 20,000 pints, T. Morgan Williams, chairman of the program here, announced yesterday. With the announcement was an appeal to New Yorkers to "start the New Year right" by donating blood.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 (AP) -- Three veteran Senators whose Congressional service totals nearly 100 years are winding up careers on Capitol Hill tomorrow. All Democrats, they are:
WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended Dec. 27 totaled 520,671 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.

PARIS, Jan. 2 -- If he becomes the next Premier of France, Rene Mayer, the Radical leader who has been both Minister of Defense and Minister of Finance, expects to go to the United States in February to seek a new deal for France with the incoming Eisenhower administration.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture today proposed an increase in its fees for reviewing the classifications of cotton stored under cotton futures regulations.

Fifteen Long Island Rail Road trains, eleven of them crowded with commuters, were delayed for periods up to two hours last night when a train bound for East Williston, L. I., struck a stalled oil truck in New Hyde Park, L. I. Earlier, 1,000 passengers were delayed for thirty minutes when the motor of a New York-bound train became disabled in Jamaica, Queens.

HARTFORD, Conn., Jan. 2 -- The New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad found itself in hot water today for a second time over posters in the railroad station here on fluoridation of the Greater Hartford water supply.

PARIS, Jan. 2 -- The attention of the French medical world was centered today on the struggle for the life of a 16-year-old French youth to whose body surgeons had transplanted one of his mother's kidneys a week ago in an operation rarely attempted.

Four titles will be published simultaneously on Jan. 19 in hardbound editions at $1.50 each and paperbound at 35 cents each. Three of them will be issued by Ballantine Books. They are "Tides of Time," by Emile Danoen, translated by Mary Glasgow; "The Red Gate," by LaSelle Gilman, a story of adventure in the Far East, and "Concannon," by Frank O'Rourke, a Western story.

MOSCOW, Jan. 2 -- Writing in Pravda today, Dr. Alexander Nesmeyanov, president of the Soviet Academy of Sciences, made the unqualified assertion that Soviet atomic physicists now occupied the "leading place" in the world and had surpassed the achievements of Western science.

Teddy (Red Top) Davis, Hartford, Conn., lightweight, carried too many guns for Fabela Chavez of Compton, Calif., last night in their ten-round battle at Madison Square Garden. And to the surprise of none in the crowd of 3,120, which paid receipts of $7,958 to see this first fistic carnival of the year in the big arena, Davis received the decision.

The striking bus workers are seeking a forty-hour week with no cut in the pay they used to get for working forty-four to forty-eight hours, with five to nine hours of guaranteed overtime. The old basic wage ranged from $1.66 to $1.73 1/2 an hour.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- During the period ended Dec. 30, member bank reserves decreased $615,000,- 000, the Federal Reserve Board announced today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 (AP) -- The Voice of America said today that Premier Stalin's latest pronouncement on world peace was at least the fifteenth of the same "vague" kind he had been making since 1943.

No contracts have been signed, but the chances are that Walter Matthau and Margo will be enacting two of the important roles in Irving Ravetch's latest play, "Where Late the Sweet Birds Sang," which Kermit Bloomgarden is producing.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 (UP) -- The Senate was asked today to refuse to seat Senators William Langer, Republican of North Dakota, and Dennis Chavez, Democrat of New Mexico, when the Eighty-third Congress convenes tomorrow.

CINCINNATI, Jan. 2 -- Eight suggested objectives for the American National Theatre and Academy were approved here today by the delegates attending the second session of the three-day National Theatre Assembly.
PORTLAND, Ore., Jan. 2 -- A traditional unity in the West Coast employment picture, with the Pacific Northwest and California following the same general labor pattern, now has been broken.
SAN JUAN, P. R., Jan. 2 -- Luis Munoz Marin was inaugurated as Governor for a second, four-year term this morning. He also is the first Governor of the Island on Commonwealth status.

WASHINGTON, Jan 2 (UP) -- Representative Dewey Short, Repulbican of Missouri, the incoming chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, declared today that his group would not consider Universal Military Training now.

BOSTON, Jan. 2 -- The Legislatures of the six New England states will open their 1953 sessions next week with Republican Governors in power in all except Rhode Island. There, Gov. Dennis J. Robert survived the November election that saw Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower carry the state in the first Republican Presidential victory in Rhode Island since 1924.
INDIANAPOLIS, Jan. 2 (AP) -- The 500-mile auto race will be open to turbine-motor cars this year, but none is expected to run until 1954.

Have your children gone back to school, college, into the armed forces? Are you a stranger come to live in New York? Perhaps you are a parttime librarian, or have been a teacher, or a saleswoman in a book shop, or are a housewife with a good reading' background. Have you time on your hands ?

Police Commissioner George P. Monaghan announced yesterday the resignation of fourteen patrolmen and one probationary patrolman, all of whom have signified their intention of joining the Fire Department. This was said to be the largest number of resignations at one time from the force.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- The Republican majority and the Democratic minority of the new Congress, which opens tomorrow. chose almost wholly conservative leadership today and dealt swift successive blows to the avowed liberals in both parties.

St. John's and New York University, out to regain the prestige they lost in suffering first-round defeats in the Holidays Festival tournament, will face formidable opponents in the Madison Square Garden double-header that caps tonight's local college basketball schedule.

CHICAGO, Jan. 2 (AP) -- Union Stock Yards set out on the new year today with the largest run of marketable hogs for a Friday in the more than fifteen years the Department of Agriculture has been keeping such records.
A hold-up man posing as a gas meter reader robbed a restaurant of $4,000 yesterday morning with the greatest of ease, quiet and dispatch.

HARTFORD, Conn., Jan. 2 -- Connecticut political leaders expressed keen interest in a New Delhi dispatch in THE NEW YORK TIMES today that the "influential Times of India" editorially favored the reappointment of Chester Bowles, a Democrat, as United States Ambassador to India.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- Department store sales in the United States during the Christmas week ended on Dec. 27 were 57 per cent above sales in the corresponding period of 1951, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
OTTAWA, Jan. 2 (UP) -- A new subsidy formula, increasing Government assistance to gold mines, went into effect today.
The reported demand of Mickey Mantle, brilliant young center fielder, for a $25,000 contract in 1953 was neither confirmed nor denied by the Yankee management last night.

ROME, Saturday, Jan. 3 -- The Government's electoral reform bill, which has monopolized the attention of the Chamber of Deputies since the first week of December, surmounted its first hurdle early this morning when a motion approving it in principle was passed by 312 votes to 180.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 2 -- Total resources of the Bank of America National Trust and Savings Association now exceed $8,000,000,000, according to a statement of condition for 1952, released today. The statement shows that deposits, loans and capital funds attained records.

The stock market started off the first trading day of the New Year yesterday on a calm but steady note. Business was not impressive and neither the price changes. Improvement all along the line was selective with the steels, coppers, communications and airlines the strongest, while the petroleums and automotives lagged.
Following is the text of the decision of Federal Judge Irving R. Kaufman denying the application of Julius and Ethel Rosenberg for a reduction of their death sentences:

ROME, Jan. 26 -- Deliberate hostility to religion was the real cause of the break with the Vatican announced by Yugoslavia last Dec. 17, the Vatican newspaper L'Osservatore Romano said this afternoon. Yugoslavia is no different from Soviet-dominated "People's Democracies" as far as religion is concerned, L'Osservatore said.

The three teams involved in the see-saw battle for first place in the National Basketball Association's Eastern Division will appear on the same bill at Madison Square Garden this afternoon. A double-header matches the Boston Celtics with the Indianapolis Olympians at 1:30 and the New York Knickerbockers with the Syracuse Nationals at approximately 3:30.

The latest addition to the community of democratic nations is the Republic of the Maldive Islands. The institution of the sultanate has disappeared and one of the heirs to the sultanic throne has been named President in a popular election. The infant republic will continue under the protection of Great Britain, but it is free and independent.

PRINCETON, N. J., Jan. 2 -- Nichols School of Buffalo and Trinity College of Port Hope, Ont., gained the final round tonight as the opening session of the fifth annual Lawrenceville School invitation hockey tournament was completed in the Hobart Baker Rink. Nichols defeated Phillips Exeter, 3 -- 2, while Trinity vanquished Noble and Greenough, 3 -- 0.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- Robert M. Barnett, who was considered one of the outstanding personnel administrators in the Federal Government, had served in Washington as director of personnel of the Federal Security Agency, the Department of Labor, the War Manpower Commission and the Social Security board.

A dock strike of three small locals of the International Longshoremen's Association, A. F. L., got off to a half-hearted beginning yesterday amid growing resentment in the waterfront union against its leadership.

CAIRO, Jan. 2 -- It was learned from an official source today that one of the Government's seven "purge committees" had prepared formal charges of corruption and abuse of power against six former Cabinet ministers and eight lesser politicians active under the old regime.

BALBOA, C. Z., Jan. 2 -- Work on overhaul of the Pacific Locks of the Panama Canal will start tomorrow, and will need a force of more than 700 men, according to announcement by Canal Company officials today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 (AP) -- Following are the leaders the Republican-controlled Eighty-third Congress is expected, to install when it convenes tomorrow:
WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- President Truman paid today what might be his last informal visit to Capitol Hill as President. He went there to have lunch with his old friends in the Senate.
BOSTON, Jan. 2 (UP) -- Two New York racketeers with "connections" in Boston will be questioned by the Federal grand jury investigating the $1,219,000 Brink's hold-up.

Many persons in the advertising business firmly believe that ads not offering entertainment or a promise of material benefits are not read and even if they are they don't do the advertiser any good. The Container Corporation of America feels differently, however, and to prove it is right it cites the experience it has had with its Great Ideas of Western Man series, started in 1950.

Most of the sales of imported machine tools this year will come from orders for replacement machines, to fill some bottlenecks, and for new and economical machines to replace older models, it was asserted yesterday by Eric R. Bachmann, machine tool importer.

Al Parsells' Ramapo Polo Club seeks its second triumph in as many starts in the Metropolitan League championship tournament tonight when it faces the Farmington (Conn.) Polo Club in the opener of a circuit twin-bill at the Squadron A Armory, Madison Avenue and Ninety-fourth Street.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 2 (AP) -- Frank Sedgman, the world's No. 1 tennis player, and his Australian Davis Cup teammate, Ken McGregor, start cashing in on their talents Tuesday when they make their long-expected professional debut at Los Angeles' Pan-Pacific Auditorium.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 (AP) -- American President Lines went to court today in an effort to block Federal subsidies for two competitors on a trans-Pacific shipping route.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- A machine to stretch the human spine was granted a patent this week. Invented by a French woman, Odette Vaquette of Paris, the device can be used also to stretch the neck alone.

The H. J. Heinz Company had a record sales volume in the six months ended last October 29, but earnings declined from the corresponding period of the prior year, according to the semi-annual report issued yesterday by H. J. Heinz II, president.

SUNBURY, Pa., Jan. 2 (AP) -- Daniel M. Coxe of the Coxe Estates announced today that leases for oil and gas exploration are being sought by the newly formed Amgas Corporation for 8,000 acres of land in Northumberland County.

LONDON, Jan. 2 -- A prominent trade union leader made a public protest today against the telegraphed message of "goodwill" that Tom O'Brien, chairman of the Trades Union Congress, sent to Prime Minister Churchill when Mr. Churchill recently departed for the United States.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 2 -- Columbia Pictures moved in so quickly and quietly to snap up screen rights to "The Big Heat" that story editors at other studios didn't get a chance to bid on the current Saturday Evening Post serial from the typewriter of William P. McGivern.

With reference to your recent editorial there is, of course, no valid reason why anyone selected for a Cabinet position at Washington should be excluded for being a Democrat. It happens, however, that Martin Durkin represents the most powerful of all pressure groups that receive special privileges from Congress.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 (AP) -- The Communists have suffered ten times as many casualties as the United States in the Korean fighting, the Defense Department said today in a year-end summary.
This year should prove to be the air conditioning industry's greatest "by a substantial margin," Cloud Wampler, president of the Carrier Corporation, declared yesterday.
Alexandra Trianti, mezzo-soprano, made her recital debut last evening at Town Hall. A native of Greece, she has appeared in recital in Europe and has sung with many European orchestras.

An out-of-state motorist, with a Florida registration and operator's license, was cited yesterday as the city's "No. 1 Traffic Scofflaw" by Chief Magistrate John M. Murtagh, who said the driver has been sought since November, 1951, for evading fifty-seven summonses.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 (AP) -- The Justice Department was asked today to make a full investigation of the removal from Michigan to Alabama Sunday of a man accused of jumping bond. Department officials said that the Federal Bureau of Investigation had been looking into the case for several days.

LONDON, Jan. 2 -- Eight Canadian-built Sabre jet fighter planes, the first of nearly 400 that are coming, were formally handed over to the Royal Air Force today at Abingdon, Berkshire, by Norman Robertson, the Canadian High Commissioner in London.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Jan. 2 -- Foreign Minister Moshe Sharett departed by air for Rangoon today to attend the Asian Socialist Conference at the head of a delegation of leaders of the Socialistic Mapai party.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Jan. 2 -- In an unusual case of intercreedal cooperation Congregation B'nai Israel bought a nineteen-acre tract here and donated 11.7 acres to the Ursuline Community of Roman Catholic nuns. It also deeded one acre free to the city.
William H. Raye Jr. has been elected a director of Saco-Lowell Shops, according to Malcolm D. Shaffner, president.

The National Midcentury Committee for Children and Youth, an organization formed to follow up the recommendations of the Midcentury White House Conference on Children and Youth, held in Washington in December 1950, yesterday issued a report on progress toward the goals set by the conference and suggested eleven important "next steps" to speed further advancement in this field.

Procedures to rid the roads of physically and mentally unfit drivers were suggested yesterday by the Bronx County Medical Society. In a report sent to Governor Dewey the organization urged appointment of a fact-finding board of state legislators and physicians with a view to formulating medical standards for motorists.

Max Blau of Switzerland, winner in the Luzerne Christmas tournament, yesterday moved into first place in the masters' tournament at the Hastings Chess Club in England according to a report from London. He defeated Antonio Medina of Spain in the fourth round and drew his adjourned second-round match with W. A. Fairhurst, former British champion.

The naming of Dr. Seth Minot Milliken for the 1953 Goodwill Award will have the warm approval of all New Yorkers who know Dr. Milliken and are familiar with his works. The award, made by Goodwill Industries of New York, goes annually to some person who has demonstrated courage and fortitude by not permitting a personal handicap to interfere with his civic contribution and service.

Frank A. Duffy has been appointed manager of retail store operations for the General Tire and Rubber Company. Steven J. Pearl and George B. Weiss succeed Mr. Duffy as owner of the Duffy Time Company, Trenton, a distributor for General.

An 18-year-old youth who was taken to Bronx Hospital last night with a critical bullet wound admitted to the police that he was one of five thugs who had held up a Bronx grocer several hours earlier and escaped in a car as an off-duty policeman fired at them. Three of his four companions were picked up later by the police and questioned.

Recommendations of foreign trade groups that Congress repeal the "Buy American" Act are expected to meet strong opposition, but prospects are good for at least some modification of the law, according to trade sources here yesterday.

Trading continued slow yesterday as the New York commodity exchanges. The coffee futures market was closed for a four-day week-end. Prices closed irregularly higher with cocoa, zinc, wool, cottonseed and soybean oils showing increases.

After long delays, proposed amendments to the City Building Code that would encourage the construction of new legitimate theatres moved closer to approval yesterday when two city departments reported that they had found the revised amendments generally acceptable.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- The Agriculture Department set today new standards allowing smaller holes in Swiss cheese -- but the purpose is not to give customers more cheese.

Your editorial of Dec. 30 entitled "Halt on Military Building" is presumably based upon the Dec. 29 news story that the Armed Services Committees were holding up funds for military construction. Both the news story and the editorial draw conclusions which are unjustified.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 2 -- Following is the text of a letter dated 23 December 1952, addressed to Ambassador Warren R. Austin, permanent representative of the United States to the United Nations, by Secretary General Trygve Lie concerning United Nations Secretariat staff matters:
WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- Nicaragua, supported by eight other Latin-American countries, appealed to Spain today to apply for membership in the United Nations.

A research project for reducing waste of cotton fiber in textile production will be undertaken by the School of Textiles at North Carolina State College under joint sponsorship of six Southern textile mills, it was made known here yesterday.

MARSEILLES, France, Jan. 2 (UP) -- Seven seamen were extradited here from Tangier today by international police authorities in a move aimed at centralizing an official attack on piracy in the Mediterranean.

TRENTON, Jan. 2 -- The 361 bus drivers and maintenance employes of the Trenton Transit Company will vote on Tuesday on a pay adjustment that had been worked out by negotiators as a New Year's Eve deadline for a strike approached.

LONDON, Jan. 2 -- The most abused and villified mail box in the British Isles, a new one in Edinburgh, bearing the cipher of Queen Elizabeth II and the only one of its kind in Scotland, was attacked again today, presumably by a Scottish nationalist.

WITH what is described as "many new faces and features," the sixteenth annual National Sportsmen's Show will move into Grand Central Palace on Feb. 21 for a nine-day run. It will provide a midwinter interlude for thousands of sportsmen.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 (AP) -- Senator Olin D. Johnston, Democrat of South Carolina, citing evidence of high life and high jinks among United States Government workers overseas, said today that about half of the 250,000 employes abroad should be dismissed.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- President Truman is worried because President-elect Dwight D. Eisenhower, the next Vice President and the new Speaker of the House of Representatives will be hard hit by the high cost of living and asked Congress today to afford them tax relief.
TOKYO, Saturday, Jan. 3 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,483, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Saturday, Korea time:
Federal Judge Irving R. Kaufman refused yesterday to change the death sentence of Julius and Ethel Rosenberg, unrepentant wartime atom spies, scheduled to be put to death the week of Jan. 12.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 (AP) -- The Federal Reserve Board reported preliminary figures today indicating the nation's business boom continued through November into December, rising to new economic peaks.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- The chances of changing the Senate's rules to make it eaesier to curb filibusters were virtually extinguished this afternoon when a Republican Senate Conference overwhelmingly favored the concept that the Senate was a continuing body and its rules carried over from one Congress to another.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 2 -- The United Nations, making public its side of the case in the loyalty controversy here, disclosed today that the initiative for a security check of United States nationals had come first from the world organization and politely criticized the State Department for supplying only sparse and late information.

In another three or four days all the 530 Arctic-type canvas Jamesway huts will have been set up as winter living quarters for the troops manning anti-aircraft defenses in the metropolitan area, but the 380 steel and plywood prefabricated huts that were ordered originally for the troops are posting a difficult problem for the Army.

The Department of Parks reported yesterday that 141,000,000 visits were made to New York's parks and playgrounds by persons taking part in active recreational activities in 1952. This was an increase of 4,000,000 over 1951.

New York went about limited post-New Year activities yesterday relatively unbothered by a strike of 8,000 employes of eight private bus companies, and the parties to the dispute made no perceptible move toward settlement.

WEST ORANGE, N. J., Jan. 2 -- Michael F. Madden, 29-year-old real estate agent and former mental patient, was held without bail for Essex County grand jury action by Magistrate James A. Degnan this afternoon on a charge of murdering his mother, Mrs. Frances Madden, 65, with a shotgun in the kitchen of their home at 160 High Street, here, on Tuesday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- House farm leaders said today that an investigation was in order to determine why declining livestock prices had not resulted in cheaper steaks and roasts at retail.

Stephen J. Spingarn, acting chairman of the Federal Trade Commission, has been making quite a to-do of late over the criticism of (or, as he puts it, organized campaign against) the anti-trust proceedings of the Government in the so-called international oil cartel suit. Why the acting head of the F. T. C. should be so shocked by these activities is not clear.
ADELAIDE, Australia, Jan. 2 (AP) -- The sixteen big league baseball clubs need not hurry about dispatching any scouts down this way.
LONDON, Jan. 2 -- The stock market began dealings for 1953 with scarcely any change from the quiet confidence that characterized the closing days of 1952.

Today's new film is "Castle in the Air," a British-made comedy featuring David Tomlinson, Helen Cherry and Margaret Rutherford, at the Beekman Theatre. The Hallmark Production was directed by Henry Cass and produced by Edward Dryhurst from a screen play by Alan Melville and Mr. Dryhurst. Barbara Kelly, A. E. Matthews, Patricia Dainton and Ewan Roberts are among the supporting cast of the Associated British-Pathe offering, which is being released here by Stratford Pictures Corporation.

The partly wrecked, four-story tenement at 112 Sullivan Street, Brooklyn, in which two tenants died and six were injured in a fire before dawn on Thursday remained vacant yesterday under police guard.

MADRID, Jan. 2 -- The regular disappearance from the files of the United States Information Service Library here of articles on Spain appearing in foreign publications has forced United States officials to keep a close watch on the library's magazines and newspapers.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Jan. 2 -- The Indonesian Defense Minister, the Sultan of Jogjakarta, has tendered his resignation, the Cabinet announced tonight, bringing the army issue in Indonesian politics to another critical point.

Clergymen at all places of worship in Washington have been asked to keep them open all day Inauguration Day "so persons can go to a place of prayer and ask divine guidance and strength for the new President and his associates," the Rev. Dr. Edward L. R. Elson, pastor of the National Presbyterian Church in the nation's capital, said here yesterday.

Probably this week's largest art exhibition is that at the Village Art Center. This busy downtown headquarters of painting and sculpture, 42 West Eleventh Street, is holding its eighth annual sculpture and drawing exhibition.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed an average increase of 3.5 per cent in December, over the same month a year ago, according to the monthly survey made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES. A late spurt in Yule shopping brought about the increase, following a lag earlier in the month.

It seems to this citizen at least that there has been a profound falling away from our libertarian traditions when a group of our Congressmen can seriously suggest, as the House Un-American Activities Committee has suggested, that the "Government's emergency powers to deal with suspected espionage be 'placed on a wartime basis.'"

BERLIN, Jan. 2 -- The British, French and United States commandants of Berlin told Ernst Reuter, Mayor of the western part of the city, today that they could not allow him to arm his police with automatic weapons, despite a border incident that cost the life of a policeman on Christmas morning.

IN his "Literary Letter About East Germany" (Book Review, Dec. 7) Edouard Roditi writes, "The production of Bert Brecht's drama 'The Trial of Lucullus' as an opera with an interesting near-atonal score by the modern composer Ernst Dessau * * * was banned as 'formalistic' in terms of the orthodox Communist esthetics of 'socialist realism.' * * * 'Lucullus' is now performed only from time to time in Western Germany."

The incoming Republican Administration may have to deal with a difficult surplus problem in some farm products. To satisfy the heavy demand abroad in recent years, the American farmer has stepped up production to record levels.

Staving off a game spurt by the losers in the fourth chukker, the Winged Foot Polo Club, paced by Phil Brady, topped Buddy Combs' Red Bank Polo Club, 11 to 9, in the feature match of the Metropolitan League indoor championship tournament double-header at Squadron A Armory last night.
ROTTERDAM, the Netherlands, Jan. 3 -- A rate war on freight from the Continent to United States ports has started, but reliable informants say it is too early to judge its effects.
ALBANY, Jan. 3 -- A pair of unheralded New Yorkers sparked a last period drive that earned Siena a 61-54 victory over Dartmouth tonight before 4,800 fans.

THE scheduled commercial airlines of the United States had the best year in the history of aviation during 1952 and look forward to an even better year in 1953, the Golden Anniversary of the Wright brothers' first flight.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- Senator Harry F. Byrd, Democrat of Virginia, entered a vigorous negative reaction today to the proposal by President Truman that the President and Vice President-elect and the new Speaker of the House receive income tax relief on their compensation while in office.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- The Rev. James H. Robinson, pastor of the Presbyterian Church of the Master in the Harlem district of New York, has been asked by the Department of State to give up his passport.

LYNDONVILLE, Vt., Jan. 3 -- The Lyndon Outing Club's twenty- second annual intercollegiate skiing meet started today in a driving snowstorm, with Ralph Miller of Dartmouth taking the cross-country event in 49:19, excellent time under the conditions. Cedric Sherrer of Middlebury was a close second.

IN three earlier picture books the Little Red Engine chugged its way to fame with a British gallantry that made it one of the most engaging of the many mechanical heroes in children's stories. This new adventure seems to have been concocted in celebration of the Festival of Britain, and is less exciting and less universal in its appeal.

APPRAISING business prospects for a new year has been a good old American custom. We polish the crystal ball and come up with predictions that frequently are surprisingly accurate. But we often fail because of so-called "imponderables," or events that cannot be foreseen.

Two-thirds of the surface of the earth is covered by ocean. The waters reach a depth of nearly seven miles, which is more than the height of the highest mountains. Down in the deep, pressures are a thousand times greater than they are at sea level and no light pierces the black. From this underworld once was captured the larva of an eel -- a larva six feet long.

The national commander of the Jewish War Veterans issued a statement yesterday praising Federal Judge Irving R. Kaufman's refusal to change the death sentence of Julius and Ethel Rosenberg, wartime atom spies.

ELIZABETH, N. J., Jan. 3 -- Law enforcement authorities on the state, county and municipal levels will confer at the Union County Court House here next Thursday in an effort to iron out jurisdictional conflicts involving the New Jersey Turnpike, it was announced today by Prosecutor Edward Cohn.

IT used to be a commonplace of power politics that Portugal rested securely in Britain's upper vest pocket, and to judge by this book there is at least one Ambassador's wife who thinks it still does. Ann Bridge is not a tactful woman. She may have lived a diplomatic life (her husband was British Ambassador to Portugal) but it didn't take.
BOSTON, Jan. 3 (AP) -- Moose Krause, director of athletics at Notre Dame, tonight indicated he had a long list of television complaints to make during the coming N. C. A. A. meetings.

DEBUSSY'S "Pelleas et Melisande" will be one of Pierre Monteux' chief assignments as guest conductor of the Metropolitan Opera next season. The revival of the opera under a conductor of such distinction will be welcome news for admirers of the work.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (AP) -- Capt. Edward B. Harp Jr. was appointed today Chief of Navy Chaplains and Assistant Chief of Naval Personnel, the assignment to become effective Feb. 1 on the retirement of Rear Admiral Stanton W. Salisbury as Chief of Chaplains.

IN the early years of the century Americans had reason to be proud of discovering a book that has become a classic: Henry Adams' "Mont-Saint-Michel and Chartres." The book could have been called a study in architecture and was, but it was far more than that; it was a reinterpretation of European culture by one of the most discerning minds and best historians America has produced.

The conflict of opinions by the Second and Third Circuits of the United States Court of Appeals on the question of whether losses of later years sustained by transferees of liquidating dividends are capital or ordinary losses has been resolved by a majority decision of the United States Supreme Court, to which there were three dissents.
TOKYO, Jan. 3 -- Japan is in the midst of an orgy of celebrating, fun-making and free-spending bigger than any she has experienced since the beginning of World War II.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (AP) -- Vice President Alben W. Barkley does not plan to retire to his farm in Kentucky Jan. 20. His eyes shine brightly when he declares that he expects to lead a busy life after he leaves the Vice Presidency at the age of 75.

SIR LEWIS NAMIER of Manchester University is one of the most accomplished active historians in the English-speaking world. His knowledge of sources, particularly East European sources, is unrivaled. His ingenuity at piecing fragments and piercing figments is stimulating.

WITH simultaneous releases of Mahler's Fifth Symphony, from Westminster and Columbia, still another major gap in the composer's discography has been filled. Now only Nos. 6 and 7 await recording. Columbia has reissued its five-year-old set, originally on shellac, of Bruno Walter and the New York Philharmonic, and has filled the last side of the two-disk album with another reissue -- eight of Mahler's songs, sung by Desi Halban, with Bruno Walter at the piano.

MONTREAL, Jan. 3 -- A new expedition to Baffin Island will be launched this summer by Canadian and Swiss explorers, the McGill University headquarters of the Arctic Institute of North America announced today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (AP) -- Children in scores of cities are committing more crimes and worse crimes than at any time since World War II.

SOME months ago Frances Horwich was a teacher, less known in Evanston than her two brothers who are distinguished pediatricians in the North Shore suburb. Today she is a television celebrity. And as the two doctors meet their young patients, their mothers besiege them with questions about "Miss Frances," their sister.

SECAUCUS, N. J., Jan. 3 -- Motor traffic was backed up five miles in Bergen County this afternoon after a drawbridge over the Hackensack River between Secaucus and Rutherford failed to close at 2:25 o'clock and stayed up for three hours. The police blamed a faulty pinion gear for the incident.

The machine tool industry will continue to operate at a high rate in 1953, since accumulated replacement demand, at least in part, will offset some of the current lag in defense orders, it is stated in a year-end review by Swan Bergstrom, president of the National Machine Tool Builders Association.

SYDNEY, Australia, Jan. 3 -- Frank Sedgman and Ken McGregor, who signed a $100,000 contract this week for a professional tennis tour of. America, may find themselves persona non grata in their native Australia.
HOUSTON, Tex., Jan. 3 -- Customs collections at the Port of Houston rose to a record $14,248,053 in 1952, according to Sam D. W. Low, customs collector here. The 1951 total was $10,522,729.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (AP) -- Following is the text of an exchange of memorandums between Secretary of State Dean Acheson and President Truman on the John Carter Vincent loyalty case:

THE C. B. S. television network is preparing to refute one of Rudyard Kipling's most famous writings. Television-wise, at least, East is going to meet West in Philadelphia and the union is expected to be a happy one beginning early in February

General Eisenhower has just had an important conference with three members and two assistants of the National Security Training Commission in which they recommended to him the immediate establishment of a plan of Universal Military Training. This commission was set up by law to make such recommendations, not merely to the Chief Executive but to the legislative branch for action.

TOKYO, Sunday, Jan. 4 -- Air fighting flared again over northwest Korea yesterday after almost a week's lapse and United States Sabre jets damaged six of Communist China's Soviet - designed MIG fighters. About fifty of the fast enemy interceptors came south of the Yalu River to clash with Sabres screening photo-reconnaissance planes and fighter-bombers attacking supply concentrations and communications lines in North Korea.

YOU hear increasingly -- and read on this page from time to time -- grim prophecies that live music in this country faces a shrinking market, and there is little doubt that some of the trends are disheartening. But all is not gloom. Let us start the New Year with a glance at a cheerful prospect.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 3 -- Jay Hebert, former star at Louisiana State University who never has won a major professional tournament, moved into the leadership today of the $20,000 Los Angeles open golf tournament. Hebert, 29-year-old professional from the Kahkwa Country Club in Erie, Pa., fired a 2-under-par 69 for a 36-hole total of 140, a stroke in front of Lloyd Mangrum, Al Mengert and Art Wall.
VALPARAISO, Chile, Jan. 3 (UP) -- Mass funeral services were held today for fifty-six victims of a New Year's Day powder magazine explosion.

" The Love of Four Colonels" might be called an actor's dream -- for it gives its two stars the chance to assume, during one evening, many different guises. When the play opens Jan. 15 at the Shubert, Lilli Palmer will be the dream girl of four Army officers in modern Germany -- one American, one British, one French, one Russian.

LONDON, Jan. 3 -- The British Foreign Office expressed its disapproval today of an Egyptian Cabinet minister's endorsement of a threat of "guerrilla warfare" unless British forces withdrew from the Suez Canal zone.

Associated Universities, Inc., which operates the Brookhaven (L. I.) National Laboratory for the Atomic Energy Commission, made public yesterday a report urging the Federal Government to reorganize its civil defense system by adopting a comprehensive new program against atomic, biological and chemical warfare.

After enjoying Harry Gilroy's "Beneficial Exercise, Or Is It?" (Dec. 21), I thought of the glowing picture Celsus gives of good health and how to achieve it. Celsus, Roman physician, living in the reign of Tiberius, writes:

A. P. YORICK: Mr. Dibble, you are the spokesman for the book publishing industry. I am here, this morning, to get the low-down on the book business for 1953. To begin, what do you think will be the attitude of the incoming Administration toward books?

MELBOURNE, Jan. 3 (UP) -- Australia's tennis youngsters will get an inkling of their chances for defending the Davis Cup in 1953 when play begins Tuesday in the Australian national championships at Kooyong Stadium.

EVERY day the central Red Cross office here receives between eighty and one hundred queries about G. I.'s from the folks back home. "Johnny hasn't written for two months -- is he sick -- has he been hurt -- what's happened to him?"

FOR nearly a half-century Manuel Bandeira has charmed Brazilians with crops of poems -- poems that first wore an austere and old-fashioned mood, and then, with the passing of time, took on the purest modern accents.

THE New York City Ballet continues its practice of at least one premiere a week with the presentation on Tuesday of the fifth one this season by George Balanchine. This one is a pas de quatre to be danced by Tanaquil LeClercq, Melissa Hayden, Patricia Wilde and Nicholas Magallanes to Glinka's "Valse-Fantaisie."

IT is wonderful how preposterously the affairs of this world are managed. Naturally one would imagine that the interest of a few individuals should give way to general interest; but individuals manage their affairs with so much more application, industry and address than the public do theirs, that general interest most commonly gives way to particular.

At noon yesterday the Eighty-third Congress came into being, with Republicans taking control on Capitol Hill for the first time in six years. A week from this Thursday President Truman will deliver a swan song on the era of the Democrats with a final broadcast to the nation. Then, on Jan. 20, Dwight Eisenhower will become President.

SHORTLY after the destruction of Hiroshima, Tomikazu Matsui, a printer of that city, began to publish books for children and also a children's magazine, Silver Bells. Since 1952 the magazine has been published in an English edition, and these fifteen stories have been selected from the first eight issues.

GUAYAQUIL, Ecuador, Dec. 29 -- Thor Heyerdahl, Norwegian anthropologist who crossed the Pacific in 1947 on a balsa raft named Kon-Tiki, will soon set out on an archaeological expedition to the mysterious Galapagos Islands, off the coast of Ecuador.

BONN, Jan. 3 -- With the gradual reduction of the pace of European rearmament through the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, the twelve divisions which will be Federal Germany's most significant contribution to European defense become increasingly important to the West.

Dr. Felix R. Labunski, professor at the College of Music of Cincinnati, will speak today at 3 P. M. at the New York Public Library at concert-lecture commemorating the fiftieth anniversary of the death of the Polish composer, Karol Szymanowski. The lecture, a Room 213, will be followed by a program of Szymanowski music, played by Irene Kaszowska-Beck, pianist, and Marilyn Wright, violinist.

FEW careers have demanded the complexity of talents required of an English tea planter in British India. He was lord of his tea estate, the judge, jury and counselor, an agriculturist and an engineer capable of supervising the machinery required to "manufacture" the tea he grew.

Visits of Red Cross bloodmobiles to the central section of Queens will be renewed on Tuesday with union members and other employes of industrial plants scheduled as donors, Mrs. Albert D. Stern, chairman for the Central Queens Chapter of the American Red Cross, announced yesterday.

A TREND toward a romantic look was the most persistent note apparent in the field of interior design during the year just past. In analyzing it one might well refer to a Webster definition of the word romantic -- "freedom of fancy in conception and treatment as distinguished from classical restraint and repose."

MALE, Maldive Islands, Jan. 3 -- After eight centuries of seclusion behind heavy veils and high walls, the petite brown women of this isolated atoll cluster in the Indian Ocean have suddenly become the most emancipated of their sex in the East.

THE motion picture industry has high hopes of catching a glimpse of that elusive silver lining during these next twelve months. Primarily the expectations have been raised by the change in Administration which will take place in Washington.

FOR some eighty years the Post Office of Baltinglass, County Wicklow, Ireland, had been in the Cooke family. When, in 1950, Aunt Katie Cooke, 82, and an invalid, decided to retire, all Baltinglass assumed that her niece, Helen Cooke, who for fourteen years had been acting subpostmistress for her aunt, would succeed her.

STANDARD historical accounts credit one Rodrigo, an Andalusian sailor, with being the lookout who first sighted land on the first voyage of discovery made by Christopher Columbus in 1492. "The Velvet Doublet," then, is Rodrigo's story, told in the form of a journal relating the course of his life from boyhood near Seville, to an old-age conclusion in 1539.

GEORGE LANYI, in his letter to you, suggests that the absence of Kaiserschmarrn from "Luchow's German Cookbook" (an absence I lamented when I reviewed the book) may be due to the fact that it is an Austrian dish. I was well aware of the Austrian origin of this dish but it has been on the Luchow menu as long as I can remember; it is served with Apfelmus.

Stores have ample supplies of merchandise specials with which to open January clearance sales. Wholesale markets here were relatively quiet last week, but more buyers are expected this week than at any time in the last few years, according to Kirby, Block Co., Inc., resident buying office. Buyers will seek to replenish depleted stocks.

Trade observers estimated yesterday that department store sales for the week would show a slight decline from the comparable period of a year before. The decline was attributed chiefly to a change in the Thursday night late opening to Friday because of the New Year's Day holiday and to the bus strike.

PROVENCE -- that part of southeastern France which so long has nourished the sensibilities of Englishmen -- is written of lovingly by James Pope-Hennessy. Today there is hardly an Anglo-Saxon -- or a northern Frenchman -- who is unmoved by that passion for the Mediterranean which stirred the nineteenth century.
An 11-month-old black cocker spaniel with the promising and appropriate name of Bright Future entered the new year with a major dog show victory yesterday.

THE Boeing B-47 Stratojet -- a swept-wing monster which can hit 700 miles per hour with a ten-ton load of atom bombs aboard -- is the backbone of Lieut. Gen. Curtis E. LeMay's Strategic Air Command. It is now coming off the production line at Boeing's Wichita, Kan., plant at the rate of one a day.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (AP) -- A Congressional subcommittee criticized today the dealings of James E. Curry, Washington attorney, with Indian tribes and urged the Attorney General to take Mr. Curry's conduct to the court.

ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 3 -- Calumet Farm's 4-year-old filly, A Gleam, picked up today where she left off last summer in winning five straight stakes as she raced to a head victory in the $28,150 Malibu Sequet Stakes at Santa Anita Park.
One of the nation's leading regulatory authorities -- the New York State Public Service Commission -- has just handed down a highly significant decision involving rate increases.

The appointment of Miss Madeline Dane Ross as executive co-chairman of the memorial fund drive committee of the Overseas Press Club of America was announced yesterday by William P. Gray, president. Miss Ross, who is a member of the club, will devote her full time to a drive to raise $300,000 to create a New York press center at 35 East Thirty-ninth Street.

The Boston Bruins will skate against the New York Rangers in the National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden tonight. The sextets are tied in the season's series to date, each with two triumphs, two defeats and two ties.

THE beauty of the second guess is its utter infallibility. A fellow never misses when he uses hindsight. It's when he tries to make predictions that he gets into trouble. But fools rush in where angels fear to tread even gingerly. So here we go. Gangway, buster!

WHAT the author of this book has done, as I get it, is borrow various plots, characters, and other elements of "The Arabian Nights' Entertainment" with the intention of making them into a humorous novel by doing the thing in modern dress.

MRS. RAWLINGS' grove at Cross Creek, in Alachua County, Fla., earlier yielded books as reliably as oranges: from "South Moon Under" through "The Yearling," so widely and justly loved, to a total of six in its first decade.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- President Truman ordered this evening the appointment of five legal and diplomatic authorities, headed by Judge Learned B. Hand, to restudy the case of John Carter Vincent, a career diplomat suspended last month on the ground that there was "reasonable doubt" of his loyalty.
New York's huge dress industry came through 1952 with a dollar volume gain of 3 to 4 per cent, and possibly a small gain in the number of manufactured units.

Snow was falling throughout the north country yesterday -- the rain that struck the metropolitan area starting Friday turned into swirling flakes in upper New York State and New England -- and the problem of the Salisbury Winter Sports Association in covering its

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Jan. 3 -- Educational television programs for secondary and elementary schools will start here and in near-by Highland Park on Jan. 26, it is announced by Edward C. Rasp Jr., assistant coordinator of audio-visual education for the New Jersey Department of Education.

Guido Cantelli, Italian conductor, completed his first six-week stint with the N. B. C. Symphony late yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Hall. Next week Arturo Toscanini returns and he will lead the ensuing six concerts. Mr. Cantelli's final stint will be the programs of Feb. 21 and 28.

THIS may prove to be an unprofitable discussion, and I begin it simply because the thought which provoked it never occurred to me before, and I am curious to see where it leads. Since it was a thought which has probably entered the minds of many people besides myself, to pursue it may have a more general interest than the satisfaction of my own puzzlement.

The usual list of anniversaries of notable events falling in the year 1953 contains one unusual item. This year, a line reads, is the 500th anniversary of the fall of Constantinople -- an event which shocked and frightened all Western Europe as much as any event since then. Yet the effect was largely symbolical. The Turks, Seljuks and Ottomans had been undermining the old Eastern Roman Empire for four centuries.

KILCHRO was an old highland house, solid and ageless, with fresh white paint and white-railed balconies at the first-floor windows. Standing on a brae looking down to the sea, with the Scottish hills in the background, the MacAlveys' ancestral home had a magic atmosphere all its own.

MINEOLA, L. I., Jan. 3 -- Leone D. Howell will reopen this month the rolltop desk and dust off the sturdy office furniture that he left thirty-six years ago to direct the final business transactions of county residents. His retirement as Nassau Surrogate was effective at midnight Wednesday.

ONE of Beethoven's best known little pieces, the "Turkish March," is from one of his least known longer works, the music he wrote in 1811 for Ernest von Kotzebue's play The Ruins of Athens. Thanks to the Concert Hall Society, that music, catalogued as Op. 113, is now available for the record listener in a first-rate performance, splendidly recorded.
CORAL GABLES, Fla., Jan. 3 -- Elixir, a 23-1 shot owned by Dave J. Schneider of Forest Hills, L. I., easily won the $25,000 - added Robert E. Lee Handicap before 14,116 fans at Tropical Park today.
BONN, Germany, Jan. 3 (AP) -- The German eagle will begin to spread its wings over the world's airways again in 1953, with the revival of Lufthansa, pre-war airline.

IT would be a mistake to exaggerate the influence of music unduly, but it is only fact to note that, following the renaissance of jazz of the old South on the West Coast during the Forties, cotton has become a leading money crop in California. Students of economics, agriculture and music can draw what conclusions they will from this.

Practical ways for teachers and other personnel to plan and carry out effective character-building projects in their own classrooms and schools are presented by the Department of Elementary School Principals, a division of the National Education Association, in a ninety-six-page report entitled "Human Values in the Elementary Schools."

The Ohio Legislature that convenes tomorrow will receive a bill to modernize the State's General Code. Five years of work have gone into the new draft and it will drop 4,500 obsolete and unnecessary sections as well as provide new and simplified arrangement and indexing.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Jan. 3 -- President-elect Eisenhower's appointment of an agricultural advisory committee to help shape national farm policy is being hailed generally as a step toward restoring to farmers a more active role in the formulation of farm programs.

Jewel thieves were at work over the New Year's holiday in hotels on both the East and West Sides of Manhattan, netting an estimated $30,890 in jewels, cash and travelers' checks in two large thefts from visitors to the city.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 3 -- Ambassador George V. Allen will leave for the United States Jan. 15 for consultations on future United States policy toward Yugoslavia. He is expected to remain in Washington three weeks, and will confer with John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State-designate, as well as with Dean Acheson, the present Secretary.

CHICAGO, Jan. 3 -- Industrial management is using statistical techniques on a large scale to get speedy information on which to base quick and intelligent decisions, a conference of the American Statistical Association disclosed here this week.

THE first camellia show of the year will be staged Friday by the Cassina Garden Club of St. Simons Island, Ga. This is one of more than fifty shows featuring this popular flower to be held during the next few months in eleven states across the country.

The five Red Cross chapters of New York have named Albert C. Simmonds Jr. city chairman for the annual March appeal for funds to support the services of the local chapters and the national organization.

The personal responsibilities of citizens of the United States for the welfare of the nation were emphasized in a sermon yesterday morning by Rabbi Leo Jung at the Jewish Center, 131 West Eighty-sixth Street.

TO the unhappy and totally unexpected conditions of this postwar world the American people have reacted, by and large, with courage, imagination and intelligence. In spite of huge taxes, we have moved ahead in association with other nations to strengthen our military defenses.

A scramble for the Democratic nomination for Mayor of New York City in next fall's election is now well under way. At present the struggle centers on the transit crisis, with Democratic politicians seeking to avoid the onus of a fare increase, and Republicans maneuvering to keep the burden of responsibility on Democratic shoulders.

PSYCHOLOGY has come a long way since Freud at the turn of the century startled the medical profession with his thesis that personality, disturbance is related to sexual repressions. The inevitable resistance to this disclosure, fierce and obstinate though it was, served merely to dramatize it, so that by the end of the Nineteen Twenties not only psychology but all the provinces of modern culture were successfuly invaded by it.

The Metropolitan Opera Association yesterday afternoon opened the largest appeal for financial assistance that it has ever addressed to the people of the United States and Canada. In the intermission broadcast between the second and third acts of Ponchielli's "La Gioconda," George A. Sloan, chairman of the board, asked for $1,500,000.

STOCKHOLM, Jan. 3 -- Congressional committee charges voiced by Senator Olin D. Johnston, Democrat, of South Carolina, that United States Foreign Service officers and clerks lead extravagant lives made possible by high salaries, were viewed dimly today at the United States Embassy here.

THE great expansion of the automotive industry over the last quarter of a century or more has been possible largely because of public acceptance of installment buying. By promoting the sale of cars, this method of purchase has provided a sound basis for mass production.

WINTER is the season when any one who has a fire-place keeps it going evening after evening. In spite of modern central heating, the hearth continues to be the focal point of home activities. Constant use of the fireplace, however, diminishes the woodpile rapidly.

HAVING honestly earned its official description as the "Showplace of the Nation," and since it has been doing business at the same stand for twenty years ended Dec. 27, a note or two on the Radio City Music Hall would appear to be in order.

The striking bus workers are seeking a forty-hour week with no cut in the pay they used to get for working forty-four to forty-eight hours, with five to nine hours of guaranteed overtime. The old basic wage ranged from $1.66 to $1.73 1/2 an hour.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's landslide election to the Presidency carried the Republicans into nominal control of Congress, but its precise effect on the traditional voting blocs that have ruled Congress remains to be seen.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (UP) -- Sickness cost residents of the United States $14,200,000,000 in 1951 and about 13 per cent of this was paid for by insurance, the Social Security Administration reported today.

AGAIN displaying her talent for story-telling, the author of the popular Jalna series has incorporated in one volume a group of short stories alternately depicting the doings of small boys and middle-aged women. In these she uses a minimum of characters, unlike the well-populated Jalna books.

IN a Greenwich Village basement, formerly the location of a night club, an interesting, if somewhat risky experiment in theatre economics has been going on since last February. The site, at 100 Seventh Avenue South, is the Originals Only Playhouse, where audiences pay no fixed admission charge, but offer voluntary contributions at the door.

PROVIDENCE. R. I., Jan. 3 -- It is generally recognized that the cost of operating a college, like the cost of living, has just about doubled in recent years. But it is not so well known just how the increased costs have affected the professors, the students and the college administration itself.

The third New Year since fighting started in Korea opened last week with no end in sight. In a Christmas Eve pronouncement Dictator Stalin of Russia said: "The U. S. S. R. is interested in ending the war in Korea." This statement made pertinent the question of the advantages and disadvantages of the Korean war from Stalin's point of view. What follows is a balance sheet:
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (UP) -- Forty-six judges appointed during Republican Administrations are still on the Federal bench, three of them serving in Texas.

LONDON, Jan. 3 -- Faced with the prospect of having to pay higher salaries, the managements of two of Britain's eight permanent symphony orchestras are serving dismissal notices on their musicians. Other orchestras may follow suit. It is hoped, however, that before the dismissals take effect three months hence, the musicians may be re-engaged.

In your Dec. 28 edition of THE TIMES, under the column "From the Mail Pouch," there appeared a note with the headline "Commission," which I think calls for clarification. Chester Kallman, in stating that I did not commission his translation of Bartok's "Bluebeard," is correct.

George S. Kaufman, humorist and playwright, was reinstated yesterday as a member of the panel on the television program "This Is Show Business," but will not return to the screen until after expiration of the American Tobacco Company's contract to sponsor the presentation.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., Jan. 3 -- The Walter Kidde Nuclear Laboratories, Inc., established last spring as the first privately-financed fully integrated research organization devoted primarily to the development of atomic power for commercial and industrial purposes, is scheduled to open its new laboratory building here next Thursday.
I was impressed by your review in your issue Dec. 28 of McCarran's law, as well as your editorial devoted to the detention of nearly 300 members of the crew of the French liner "Liberte."

THE Metropolitan Opera Association reaped one substantial advantage from the new and quite atrocious Englished version of "La Boheme" which it presented to a marveling public Saturday afternoon, Dec. 27. This was the new scenery of Roli Gerard, which in many particulars reflected the quality of the opera itself, and in one scene, that of the Cafe Monus, was a decided improvement over any previous Metropolitan setting of this episode.

STOCKHOLM, Jan. 3 (UP) -- Sweden decided at the last minute today not to compete in a Soviet Union ski meet later this month "because the Russians failed to answer repeated requests for detailed information" about the event.

If there are or have been disloyal American citizens on the staff of the United Nations secretariat, the fault lies primarily with our own Government. The State Department, under Secretaries Byrnes, Marshall and Acheson, has not furnished fully or quickly the information requested of it by Secretary General Trygve Lie.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Jan. 3 -- Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson apparently is prepared today to wait until fall and after an extended trip to the Orient, including Korea, to assess his position as a leader of the Democratic party and his future in politics.

LOOKING at the recent oils and water-colors by John Marin, at the Downtown Gallery, one may well wonder if some of our extreme abstractionists might not learn much from a careful consideration of his work. Or perhaps some of them have learned from it.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Jan. 3 -- Dainty, owned by Cornelius Shields of Larchmont moved into a comfortable lead with 14 points at the end of six races in the B. O. class in the 22nd annual frost-bite dinghy regatta of the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club today.
City College's basketball team staved off a last-minute Rutgers rally to defeat the Scarlet, 86 to 84, at the Beavers' gymnasium last night.

FOR slack-twisted adults it is sometimes hard to see just why stories of Eskimo life hold such a deep fascination for many boys. Perhaps it is because the very starkness of Arctic life with its continuous battle against the elements is in such sharp contrast to our own mechanized civilization.

LINCOLN, Neb., Jan. 3 (AP) -- Nebraska set a new team scoring record tonight as the Huskers overpowered a travel-weary Harvard five, 92 -- 53, in their final warm-up before the opening of Big Seven Conference competition.

OLD hands and many amateurs have come to look forward to January as the month when the All-America awards for the year are announced. This January finds only two new varieties of plants to grow from seed which meet the exacting standards of the Selections Committee for 1953.

EIGHT contemporary Oregon artists -- five painters and three sculptors -- are represented in the present show at the Kraushaar Galleries. It is tempting to look for some general local flavor in such an exhibition, but it is unrewarding.

ALBANY, Jan. 3 -- Governor Dewey will recommend, in his annual message to the Legislature, the setting up of a legislative commission to make a comprehensive study of the state's entire judicial system, including the method of selecting judges and means for making justice less expensive.

WITH THE U. S. SEVENTH DIVISION, Korea, Sunday, Jan. 4 -- Cpl. Robert W. Von Kuznick, who hitch hiked from Fort Knox, Ky., to Korea to fight the Communists, headed for home today with the Army's blessing.
I read with interest Theodore H. White's "Europe's Aching Trouble Spot -- the Saar" (Nov. 23) and would like to express my appreciation of it.

PARIS, Jan. 3 -- Rene Mayer, Radical party leader who is trying to form the new French Cabinet, obtained the permission of President Vincent Auriol today to prolong his negotiations with the party leaders, M. Mayer said that the Gaullist group would meet Monday to decide on whether to give him its support and that in the meantime he would keep on with his efforts for a large majority.

The rapid growth in funds of pension and profit-sharing trusts will give added importance to the role of such funds in the investment market. With trustees of the funds now having a wider field of investments from which to select, the markets for new and old securities should be stimulated through the employment of these funds, it is believed.

THINK what you will about England's present literary climate, it continues to nourish a remarkably hardy and lively crop of younger novelists. Writers, many of them, who can be deft, witty and unpretentious in their profoundest moments -- urbane observers who share Mr. Forster's broad interest in the adjustment of appearance to reality and M. Mauriac's Gallic determination to capture the essence of fictional characters in comparatively few words.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- Some clarification of the whole prospect of investigations in the new Republican Congress has now come, and it appears that they will be more numerous and more inclusive than had previously been supposed.
TOKYO, Sunday, Jan 4 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,484, for Saturday's operations:
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (AP) -- Following is the text of a speech today by Representative Joseph W. Martin Jr., Republican of Massachusetts, after his election as Speaker of the House of Representatives:

FOR a story of best friends, "I will never speak to him again" is, of course, a perfectly natural opening. In easy loose rhyme this small boy goes on thinking "there are lots of things I can do -- and I have other friends, too!" Nothing else, though, comes off quite as well as doing things with Johnny -- but, maybe Johnny's mad and won't make up.

New York savings bankers, busily computing their Federal income tax liability under the regulations just issued, are becoming increasingly bitter over the requirements of the state Franchise Tax Law. Subject to income taxes this year for the first time since their establishment more than 130 years ago, the savings banks, it appears, are determined to "do something" about the impost.

I wish to register a protest at the high-handed treatment by Margaret Sullavan of her public. Back in November, before the opening of "The Deep Blue Sea," I had purchased two tickets for the matinee of Dec. 24, and my companion came from upper Westchester to see the play.

Dr. Harlow Shapley of the Harvard College Observatory reported to the American Astronomical Society meeting this week that the universe appears to be larger than has been generally assumed, that it is expanding at a slower rate than has been believed, and that it is twice as old as earlier estimates said.

ALBANY, Jan. 3 -- Governor Dewey stood firm today behind his plan to require liability insurance for all motor vehicle owners in the state after a ninety-minute conference with thirteen insurance leaders who opposed his compulsory program.

CHICAGO, Jan. 3 -- A Federal report, issued in Washington and covering medical care costs for a four-year period, 1948-51, was termed today "a perversion of statistical information" by Dr. George Lull of Chicago, secretary and general manager of the American Medical Association.

This is the Winter week that belongs to pleasure boating. It is the annual season of the extravaganza known as the National Motor Boat Show, which will come again as it has for forty-eight years to cheer the hearts, eyes and ambitions of New Yorkers and countless visitors.

" NOT long ago I thought to have closed up my little writing-shop for good and all," says Norman Douglas in a footnote to "Footnote on Capri." But a glance at Islay Lyons' photographs made him change his mind, and, shortly before he died last February in his eighty-fourth year, he wrote this final farewell to the Island Where the Sirens Sang.

NAIROBI, Kenya, Jan. 3 (UP) -- Two white women, one of them a star tennis player, fired on a band of Mau Mau terrorists who tried to raid their lonely farm home last night, killing three of the attackers, wounding a fourth and putting the rest to flight.

FORT LEE, N. J., Jan. 3 -- Motivated by their interest in American history, the student bodies of five New Jersey high schools have joined a campaign to persuade the Mayor and Council of this community to preserve Fort Lee Bluff as a national shrine.
ALBANY, Jan. 3 (UP) -- The State Department of Commerce today is sued the following winter sport report:

HOW frightened and susceptible to pressure can television get? The firing of George S. Kaufman from the panel of "This Is Show Business" because of his quip about "Silent Night, Holy Night" is a far greater and more serious mistake than any the playwright may have made.

PRINCETON, N. J., Jan. 3 -- Clinching the game with a four- goal attack in the second period, Trinity College School of Port Hope, Ont., defeated Nichols School of Buffalo, 6 -- 1, in the final today of the Lawrenceville school's invitation hockey tournament. The contest culminated a twelve-game two-day program.

IT is mystery to everyone save a confirmed angler how one fish, insignificant as to size, can capture the imagination and provide an almost irresistable challenge to countless thousands, but the bonefish has managed to do this, and over a period of a very few years has assumed the high status in salt water angling circles that is held by the Atlantic salmon among the fresh water brotherhood.

The start of the new year finds basic investment yields at a crossroads. The next month should tell whether the borrowing cost of the United States Treasury, after zigzagging generally upward through months of record-high bank loan expansion, is headed toward stability at present or possibly lower levels, or is fated to rise still further.
