Mayor Impellitteri proposed last night a seven-point program for settling the strike of 8,000 employes of eight private bus companies, but Michael J. Quill, president of the Transport Workers Union, immediately rejected the plan as "phony" and "too little and too late."

WASHINGTO, Jan. 3 -- The Eighty-third Congress convened today with Republicans in marginal command of both houses and organized in an atmosphere marked by good humor and sportsmanship on the part of the routed Democrats.

Cornell University has set up a special five-year curriculum in agricultural engineering and will grant a new professional degree -- bachelor of agricultural engineering--to students who successfully complete the work. Students will enroll in the agricultural college for the first four years, but during that time they will also be taking courses in the Colleges of Engineering and Arts and Sciences.

CINCINNATI, Jan. 3 -- Three resolutions pertaining to the elimination of the Federal amusement tax on tickets for legitimate theatre attractions were approved here today at the final session of the National Theatre Assembly.

HAROLD LEWIS' analytic report on post-war photography in Italy in "Photography Year-Book 1953" (London: The Press Centre Ltd. and Philadelphia: Rayelle Publications. $6) is a unique and heartening example of contemporary progress in the camera medium.

MELBOURNE, Jan. 3 -- John Landy, the 22-year-old Australian who is confident he soon will run a four-minute mile, came through with a sparkling 4:02.8 performance today on a sun-baked track that was almost as hard as concrete.
The position taken by you in your recent editorial that the conflict in Vietnam must be brought into "global focus" is entirely correct.

YOU will find in the Gospels few more heart-chilling words than the comment of Jesus upon publicly displayed good works: "They have their reward." Father Raymond Bruckberger's parable, "Golden Goat," is both a sermon on that text and a plea for love in a world which finds selfishness respectable and enlightened.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 3 -- Finance Minister Horacio Lafer appeared today to have won the "cotton war" against Ricardo Jaffet, president of the Bank of Brazil, that has been holding the attention of commercial and financial circles for days.
What happened to all the personal wealth, in the way of family fortunes, that existed in the pre-Hitler days in Europe ?

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- The Republicans took control of the House of Representatives today with the election of Representative Joseph W. Martin Jr. of Massachusetts as Speaker and with an implied promise of early relief for individual income taxpayers.
Big Johnny Mize, first baseman of the world champion Yankees, may be under no illusions that his baseball life is beginning at 40 but he should feel that it is by no means ended at that age.
RALEIGH, N. C., Jan, 3 (AP) -- An Air Force transport plane, groping through driving rain and fog, crashed near the Durham-Raleigh Airport about midnight.

JOSE GRECO, the only man ever to keep a dance recital on Broadway for eight week hand running, will bring his company of Spanish dancers back for another, and a more modest, engagement on Jan. 12. Now appearing nightly in the Empire Room at the Waldorf with a smaller ensemble, he will collect the rest of his troupe and move over to the Century Theatre for seventeen performances, ending Jan. 24.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Jan 3 -- Indonesia's press criticized today the resignation of the Defense Minister, the Sultan of Jogjakarta, and indicated that popular feeling was against the Cabinet.

JOHN MASTERS' third novel of India in two years, set in outlands flanking the Northwest Frontier, traces a tenuous trail along devious pathways of psychological harrassment in the mind of his central character.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 3 -- Foreign diplomats here are still a bit rocky Over the way Premier Marshal Tito's Yugoslavia wound up the old year.

DURING the year which ended last Wednesday the world's postal presses printed 2,555 major and minor varieties of stamps. They were produced by 163 governments -- republics, kingdoms, empires, commonwealths, dominions, colonies, dependencies and occupation regimes.

TROY, N. Y., Jan. 3 -- Frank Chiarelli, top scorer in Eastern college hockey, slammed in a goal with 39 seconds of play remaining to give R. P. I. a 5-4 victory over Princeton in the final round of the Engineers' tourney, played before 3,500 tonight.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (AP) -- Representatives Mike Mansfield, Democrat of Montana, and Henderson Lanham, Democrat of Georgia, acting as a two-man subcommittee, today proposed that the entire European foreign aid organization be economically reorganized and placed under the State Department. They said this was necessary to eliminate "duplicate functions" and "excess personnel."

NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 3 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru declared in Lucknow today that he thought that India's resolution on Korea, despite its rejection by the Soviet Union, Communist China and North Korea, could still provide a basis for further efforts by the United Nations to break the deadlock on the exchange of Korean prisoners of war.

A new clearing house of information concerning mentally retarded children and adults has been set up here, Joseph T. Weingold, executive director of the Association for the Help of Retarded Children, reported yesterday.
New York's oddest waterfront strike all but petered out yesterday in its second day as longshoremen toiled on many piers and rank-and-file resentment mounted against union leadership.
American retailers are preparing to share in the bonanza that the coronation of Queen Elizabeth on June 2 will bring for dealers in souvenirs.

SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, Jan. 3 -- Audacious plans to reinvigorate Britain's waning Empire are now being hatched in this Central African boom town, which, with its gaudy big new buildings, daily bustle and bold talk of new developments, is in many ways reminiscent of American Western cities that mushroomed during the last century.

I wonder how many of those who exercised their voting privilege during the past election will now completely wash their hands of any further participation in their Government until the next Presidential election rolls around. It is a sad commentary that this nation required such a tremendous get-out-the-vote drive in order to get millions of habitual non-voters to the polls last November.

A FINE recording of the Brahms First Symphony by Arturo Toscanini and the N. B. C. Symphony is at hand this week (Victor). The Brahms First is one of those works for which the Maestro has a special affinity, and in this new recording his firm hand is evident throughout. It is a noble, unsentimentalized performance characterized by the particular lucidity of musical thought usually found in Mr. Toscanini's interpretations.
NEEDHAM, Mass., Jan. 3 (AP) -- The Carter boys seem to be doing all right running the business their dad started in his kitchen.

BEFORE World War II G. M. Young published, first as a chapter in a cooperative work, then as a book, an essay on the England of a century ago. He called it "Portrait of an Age" and swept away, in that brilliant analysis, a great deal of nonsense that had been written about the Victorian era.

Optimism reigned in financial markets as the old year ended and a new one began. Activities were somewhat curtailed by the New Year's holiday, but traders showed their confidence in the future by pushing stock prices up to new highs for the movement as the year came to a close.

Dr. Maurice N. Eisendrath, president of the Union of American Hebrew Congregations, announced yesterday that The Josephine E. Cordon Foundation of Detroit had presented $5,000 to the union, parent body of, American Reform Judaism, to assist Jewish congregations in low-income areas.

HARTFORD, Jan. 3 -- Connecticut's General Assembly, which meets every two years, convenes here Wednesday at 11 A.M. The five-month session will be given over principally to the state budget and the need for increased taxes.

LEO NIKOLAYEVICH LEONTIEV, a celebrated Soviet writer portrayed in Koestler's "The Age of Longing" escaped from the Soviets in order to write "the one honest book of his life." However, he wrote nothing.

ELIZABETH, N. J., Jan. 3 -- Charging that he had been illegally convicted of drunken driving in South Carolina and that as a result his New Jersey driver's license had been revoked, Lawrence Douglas, a Negro, of 46 Railroad Avenue, Summit, filed notice here today of court action to regain his license.

PARIS, Jan. 3 -- Marshal Alphonse-Pierre Juin of France, commander of the central land forces of the Atlantic pact nations, urged tonight ratification of the European army treaty as a means of rebuilding Western Europe on a basis of "greater solidarity and indissoluble cohesion."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (UP) -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower was elected President last November, but the next order of business for the new Eighty-third Congress is to make it official.

THE indoor gardener who has been growing house plants for some time might consider entering one or two of them in competition. It's not too early to purchase new plants for exhibition at one of the spring shows, for the rules indicate that a house plant must have been in possession of the exhibitor for at least four months.
LAKE PLACID, N. Y., Jan. 3 (AP) -- Northwood School won its annual invitation hockey tournament tonight by crushing Taft, 9 -- 0.

Hemisphere yachting competition between the Old World and the New, with international lines by-passed, is being arranged for a prolonged session on Long Island Sound this year. It will be between six-meter racing craft of Europe on the one hand and those of North and South America on the other.

From a business concern in Detroit yesterday came a check for $500 to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, as the 1952-53 total rose to $374,110.06 from 11,576 contributors on the twenty- eighth day of the forty-first annual appeal.

PARIS, Jan. 3 -- Robert Schuman, the gentle, soft-spoken, idealistic yet canny French Foreign Minister, finds his position somewhat weakened as a result of continued attacks both before and during this week's Government crisis.

PAUL TILLICH, Professor of Philosophical Theology at Union Theological Seminary in New York, is a distinguished German-American scholar who has been in this country since the early Thirties. As Theodore M. Greene of Yale University remarks in his essay on "Tillich and Our Secular Culture" -- one of the essays in "The Theology of Paul Tillich" -- this German emigre thinker is "the most enlightening and therapeutic theologian of our time."

DARIEN, Conn., Jan. 3 -- Peg's Pride, gray gelding from the Hutchinson Stables of Closter, N. J., today won the jumper championship at the twenty-first annual indoor horse show of the Ox Ridge Hunt Club with 20 points.

INSTEAD of a marshal's baton, nearly every American soldier carries a poem or cartoon in his knapsack. From the cartoons appearing almost daily in the Pacific Stars and Stripes in the past two years, the editors have picked nearly two hundred submitted by some fifty different G. I. artists.

OUT in Chicago on Tuesday, they will be celebrating the seventy-fifth birthday of Carl Sandburg. While the events may be such that Mr. Sandburg will be forced to take much of the day off, he will not be among those long looking back.

Last March a Federal grand jury, empaneled to look into espionage and subversion in New York, discovered that an alleged American Communist had gotten himself a job in the United Nations Secretariat. That discovery touched off a series of widely publicized investigations into Communist infiltration at the U. N. -- investigations which seem likely to continue well into the new year.

Five young men were arraigned in Bronx Magistrates Court yesterday, and a sixth lay in Bronx Hospital in critical condition from a policeman's bullet after the $130 robbery of a Bronx grocer Friday night.

Bosley Crowther's article, McBoing Boing, Magoo and Bosustow" (Dec. 21), on a new type of screen cartoon with new characters giving "heavy competition to Mickey Mouse and to Donald Duck for the places they hold in American hearts," was very interesting.

TORONTO, Jan. 3 (UP) -- The Chicago, Black Hawks gained a tie for second place in the National Hockey League tonight by playing a 1-1 deadlock with the injury-depleted Toronto Maple Leafs before 13,220 fans.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (AP) -- The Military Air Transport Service reported today that one of its Alaska-based squadrons had flown snore than 700 missions over the North Pole.

A century ago Ireland's chief "export" was human beings. Today, with freedom to determine political and economic destinies, that part of the country comprising the Republic of Ireland is bending determined efforts toward increasing exports of a kind that will contribute primarily to Irish prosperity and progress at home.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- The State Department took disciplinary action today against Foy D. Kohler, 44-year-old career diplomat, who was arrested for drunkenness following an automobile accident last month. Locked in the trunk of his car at the time of the accident were two secret documents he had taken from his office for study at home.

Whilst reading Charles Stuart-Linton's letter concerning the picture "In Troubled Kenya" on the cover of the Dec. 7 issue of THE TIMES Magazine I was gratified to see that he drew attention to the fact that the guard of honor shown was mounted by First Battalion XXth Foot, the Lancashire Fusiliers, and not by the King's African Rifles.

The New York Knickerbockers rallied to take a 85 -- 77 overtime decision over the Syracuse Nationals yesterday at Madison Square Garden. They came from 11 points behind in the fourth period and wound up regulation time at 72-a11.
The peril of "block obsolescence" hangs heavy over the American-flag tanker fleet and only a Government-initiated and fostered construction program can alleviate the situation.
The last minute rush of Christmas shopping cleared inventories in the men's furnishing field. Shirts and sports shirts were particularly in demand and ties and hats sold well.
WEST POINT, N. Y., Jan. 3 -- Army registered its third successive basketball victory of the season defeating Williams College, 84 to 60, in the Field House today.

The vanguard of 25,000 buyers and home furnishings store owners will visit the Merchandise and American Furniture Marts in Chicago tomorrow for the opening of the winter international home furnishings market. The event, at which thousands of manufacturers will woo retailers with new lines, will run through Jan. 17.

IN his review of Rice E. Cochran's "Be Prepared" (Book Review, Dec. 14) Harry Gilroy states that thirty-five years ago he tried for the Tenderfoot badge and failed, and all because a tyrant of a Scoutmaster refused to let him start a fire out in the woods and take a cooking test.
CAIRO, Jan. 3 -- Premier Mohammed Naguib inaugurated Egypt's five-year economic development plan today at a ceremony in the Royal Opera House.
SEOUL, Korea, Jan. 3 -- During the last week or so the actual fighting became so spotty and scattered that it almost seemed that both sides in the Korean war were waiting for Jan. 20.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (UP) -- Price stabilization officials disclosed today that they planned to survey retail beef ceilings again next week to determine whether they should be rolled back to reflect sharp reductions in cattle prices. A rollback of only a few cents would save housewives and other consumers millions of dollars.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- Senator Herbert H. Lehman, Democrat of New York said today that he might have recommended David Weintraub to the United Nations for employment in its Secretariat, although he had no recollection of having done so.

THERE is a story that Theodore Roosevelt, galled by Senate opposition, burst out that he would like to turn sixteen - lions loose in the Senate. What if the lions ate the wrong Senator, he was asked. "They couldn't if they stayed long enough," Roosevelt replied.
Joseph M. Dodge, Detroit banker, was named yesterday by Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the President-elect, as his Director of the Bureau of the Budget in the new Republican Administration.
SOUTH BEND, Ind., Jan. 3 -- Notre Dame today stepped up its crusade for unrestricted football television by issuing a ten-point explanation of its stand against the N. C. A. A.'s controlled program.

The French Casino, a night club at 235 West Forty-sixth Street, failed to open last night and 130 employes were sent home after the owner had departed abruptly for Paris without leaving enough cash to cover the payroll.

In defiance of the general belief that, under the new basketball rules, the team that trails going into the last three minutes is a sure loser, New York University and St. John5s each rallied in the stretch to win at Madison Square Garden last night.

FOR a good many years now I have turned my back on the Broadway theatre, which in turn has turned its back on me, with no particular profit or gain to either of us. On the one hand, the Broadway theatre has managed to prosper (at times, at any rate) and, on the other, I have managed to write plays.

MR. DOWNES' comments in THE TIMES of Dec. 21 on the latest report of the British Arts Council were of particular interest to me, since I recently returned from a year of study and observation of the musical scene in Great Britain.

IF drama critics, as a year-end custom, can pick the best plays and the worst plays of the year, there seems to be no reason why a bridge critic should not, even though a different kind of "play" is involved and the stage is only a card table without footlights.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 3 -- The first 100,000,000 - ton ore movement on the Great Lakes was predicted today for 1953 by vessel operators, as they closed their books on a profitable 1952 shipping season and drafted plans for the year's operations.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- The Democrats, who were held on downs last Nov. 4, were forced to punt in Congress today, and the Republicans started running the ball back. Because the playing time was short today, the Republicans signaled for a fair catch and the Democrats did not tackle them.

IT is possible to have a civilization with inadequate transportation, but it is difficult, then, to have "prosperity" and impossible to achieve that high degree of highway mayhem in which we have so brilliantly succeeded.

Bit after bit the developments in East Asia have shown in Communist China the character of an international conspiracy rather than a domestic revolution and reform. The tentacles of Peiping have been seen in all of China's neighbors. On the Korean battlefronts, of course, it is not a matter of mere tentacles.

IN her latest romantic novel Betty Cavanna gives us two heroines, both appealing although entirely different. Sixteen-year-old Prue Foster has spent most of her life on a ranch. Her cousin Cissy Rountree -- l7, and a debutante -- is interested mainly in boys and parties.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (AP) -- A special House committee proposed today that the election laws be overhauled and include a provision to allow more money to be spent on election campaigns.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Jan. 3 -- Israel's new broadly-based coalition Government is expected to carry out harsh and basic economic reforms in an effort to make headway against the country's stubborn and fundamental economic problems.

TANGANYIKA. HERE in the heart of the African bush, more than 100 miles from the nearest native village, a Hollywood film unit for the past month has been engaged in a most unusual social and economic experience.
DAYTON, Ohio, Jan. 3 -- Coach Johnny Bach's unbeaten Fordham basketball team ran its victory string to nine in a row by defeating the University of Dayton Flyers, 64 -- 59, before 5,689 fans tonight.

PENZANCE, England -- At this unlikely season of the year, the flowers are beginning to bloom on the Scilly Islands, England's westernmost isles. Starting with the sweet-scented violet crop at about this time, the little bits of land some thirty miles off the Cornish coast are covered by a profusion of spring flowers.

A newspaper man turned advertising executive reluctantly is probably the best description of Bill Small, head of the William J. Small Advertising Agency in Boston. There are many former reporters in the advertising profession but in Bill's case he didn't pursue it -- it pursued him.

IT is possible to have a civilization with inadequate transportation, but it is difficult, then, to have "prosperity" and impossible to achieve that high degree of highway mayhem in which we have so brilliantly succeeded.

Bit after bit the developments in East Asia have shown in Communist China the character of an international conspiracy rather than a domestic revolution and reform. The tentacles of Peiping have been seen in all of China's neighbors. On the Korean battlefronts, of course, it is not a matter of mere tentacles.

WHEN we reviewed covers of record albums for this newspaper's special section on records several months ago it seemed that, from an esthetic point of view, Decca led the field. Although certain covers produced by Victor, Columbia, London, Capitol, Mercury, Vox, Liberty, etc., were noteworthy, Decca appeared to have the most consistent distinction.

ELIZABETH, N. J., Jan. 3 -- The Union County Board of Freeholders today announced it had agreed to place a $10,000 appropriation in the county's 1953 budget for the Union County mental hygiene clinic in Plainfield. Adopting a report submitted by its public welfare committee, the board paved the way for the county's first venture in the mental hygiene field.

The hovering hummingbird consumes about the same amount of energy as does a modern helicopter, weight for weight, according to Dr. Oliver Pearson, Assistant Professor of Zoology at the University of California, in an article in The Scientific American. The hummingbird uses up 726 British thermal units of energy per pound per hour, he calculated.

IN "A Thousand Shall Fall," Hans Habe made a popular attempt at a seemingly surefire formula: if the facts, issues and explosions of contemporary history can be put down fast enough, the older and sterner requirements of fiction will probably take care of themselves.

A CLUSTER of unobtrusive men has attached itself to President-elect Dwight D. Eisenhower. The individuals of which this group is composed will rotate in orderly shifts, but they will be close to him perpetually, day and night, until he retires from the Presidency. They are Secret Service men, responsible for his and his family's safety.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- Though facing certain and crushing defeat, a bipartisan group of nineteen Senators opened today an attempt to harden the Senate's anti-filibuster rule in the thin hope of thus achieving action on the civil rights bills in the new Congress.

MONTREAL, Jan. 3 (UP) -- Sugar Jim Henry gave a scintillating display of net-minding before 14,464 fans tonight and scored his fourth shutout of the National Hockey League season as the Boston Bruins defeated the Montreal Canadiens 1 -- 0 in the Forum.

THERE is something dramatic and inspiring in the spectacle of Winston Churchill, the grand and indomitable old man of British politics setting forth in his 79th year, bundled in his fur-collared greatcoat and wearing his old-fashioned hat, on another mid-winter Atlantic crossing to attempt to renew his close personal relations with General Eisenhower in the interest of world peace and Anglo-American harmony.

IN her annual Christmas message to the students of Barnard College, Dr. Millicent C. McIntosh, the president, contrasted the young people of today with those of pre-World War I days. Members of the earlier generation, she said, were smug in their attempts to improve social conditions because they did not understand the scope or context of the problems they sought to solve.

A WAGON train operator, Whip Bradon, spied a pretty petticoat gently swaying on a clothes line at old Fort Laramie. The gay garment was too slender and shapely for the colonel's wife, so he deduced that there was an interesting guest.

The adoption of a plan for closer cooperation between the New York State Athletic Commission and the National Boxing Association is one of the important matters on the agenda of the N. B. A. meetings here next week-end.
A vigorous auction season reopens this week after the usual lull of the holidays. Most of the New York houses have sales scheduled.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (AP) -- The Senators announced, today their leading pitcher, Bob Porterfield, and best batter, Pete Runnels, have signed contracts for next season. Other contracts, they said, are in the mail.

SCHUBERT: Die Schoene Muellerin; Walther Ludwig, tenor, Michael Raucheisen, pianist (Decca). Mr. Ludwig, who possesses a fine tenor voice, superb technical skill and, seemingly, no imagination whatever, plods through the lovely songs of the cycle as if they were so many Concone vocalises.

THE Italian Film Export Releasing Corporation, a growing organization devoted, as its corporate title proclaims, to getting to the American public top-flight Italian films, is hoping to solve the problem of language barriers by a simple but expensive method.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 3 -- Civil service experts from many of the United Nations are expected to arrive here next month to take part in a debate on the political and legal problems growing out of the staff trouble of the world organization.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 3 (AP) -- La Salle, the 1952 national invitation tourney champion, romped to a 76-59 victory over Wake Forest tonight in the second game of a Convention Hall twin bill. A season's high crowd of 7,223 saw Temple spurt for 10 points in the final period to whip St. Joseph's, 70 -- 64, in the first game.

All economic indicators seem to point to a period of high industrial activity throughout the nation this year. If these indications are valid, it will mean industry will need even more workers than the 62,228,000 persons now employed.

IN a strange and often lovely book, Percy Mackaye continues his "vista of autobiography" begun in "Poog's Pasture." A mixture of mythology, fairy tale and extremely sublimated childhood recollection, "Poog and the Caboose Man" is a fantasy woven about two youngsters at play in a Brattleboro, Vt., pasture.

BONN, Germany, Jan. 3 -- Acting United States High Commissioner Samuel Reber today made the first public move in West Germany on the part of the United States Government to break the deadlock on the ratification of the European Defense Community treaty and the Bonn peace contract.
Fordham University's swimming team yesterday handed C. C. N. Y. its first Metropolitan League loss of the season by a 52-to-32 score at the loser's pool.

MOBILE, Ala., Jan. 3 -- A smooth - functioning squad of Northern All-Stars, paced by passing Harry Agganis and galloping Gene Gedman and Don McAuliffe, defeated the South, 28 -- 13, in the Senior Bowl football game today.

IT would be a real treat to be able to recommend John Brick's latest novel, "Homer Crist." But the author has whittled a set of wooden characters and posed them against a wooden background. The result is a lifeless and completely incredible book.
The World's Team-of-Four Championship, most important tournament in international contract bridge, starts here tomorrow afternoon at the Sherry-Netherland Hotel.

FINAL reports on the recently closed Pittsburgh International lead to some wonder and puzzlement. Gordon Washburn director of fine arts at the Carnegie Institute, rather daringly got together a show which was heavily weighted with abstraction and nonobjective painting from Europe and the United States, a show which he felt represented main currents today.

IN these days when one school of the mystery novel stresses psychology and another emphasizes action, both all too often for their own sakes rather than in relation to any story to be told, it's always a pleasure to read a novel by Seldon Truss, who believes firmly, like his Victorian predecessors, in plot.

LONDON, Jan. 3 -- Prime Minister Churchill, who is on his way to the United States, was advised today to "think again" before discussing with President-elect Dwight D. Eisenhower any "premature steps" toward convertibility of the pound sterling.

WE live for better or worse in a motor age. The wheel, perhaps man's greatest invention, which lifted him from the mud and gave him mobility, now turns by spark and explosion without human sweat but with plenty of blood and tears. Again our genius has outrun our character and control.

Jonathan Penrose of London yesterday wrested the lead from Max Blau of Switzerland by defeating him in the fifth round of the international masters' tournament at the Hastings Chess Club in England, according to a report from the British capital.

While I am fundamentally in agreement with Harold Clurman that a critic or a theatre audience should see a play as a whole, as "one thing," something he says in a parenthesis about the audience's reaction being sounder than the critic's in making "an evaluation which deals with the actor's relation to script" hints at the reason for the critic's failure.

TOM RAINSE, young game warden, and his dog Smoky, who appeared In one of the author's earlier books, "A Nose for Trouble," here face a new wilderness mystery. Tom finds that strange events are taking place in a remote wilderness tract, the object of a struggle between timber interests and the advocates of a new national park.

Winter muffled but did not silence the sounds of war in Korea last week. At several points along the frozen and blasted terrain just north of Parallel Thirty-eight, United Nations and Communist troops launched minor attacks and counter-attacks. Whenever the skies cleared, U. N. planes took to the air.

The minority of those familiar with United States-Latin-American relations, unfortunately small though it be, will applaud your editorial tribute to the departing Assistant Secretary of State, Edward G. Miller. It is a praiseful commentary well deserved by a capable, hard-working public servant.

The Eighty-third Congress, when it has brushed off the dust of organizing itself, faces a gigantic task of legislation. The task is the harder because it has been twenty years and more since there has been a Republican President who would not veto controversial legislation prepared by a Republican-controlled Senate and House of Representatives.

Upwards of 9,000,000 passengers ride the subways and buses in New York City each day, the greatest concentration of mass transportation in the world. About two-thirds of that number use city-owned subways and buses. The remainder normally depend on one or another of the eight privately operated bus lines that represent a vital part of New York's transit system.

Mozart's "Cosi fan tutte," in the English version translated by Ruth and Thomas Martin and directed by Alfred Lunt, will have its first two performances of the season on Jan. 13 and 17 during the tenth week of the Metropolitan Opera.
AMSTERDAM, Jan. 4 -- Three end-of-year decisions reflect the Netherlands' improved external monetary position. They are:

When the Tennessee Valley Authority was set up, twenty years ago this spring, the A-bomb and the H-bomb were unknown and the new agency's initials did not suggest a means of conveying pictures through the unwired air. There was black magic as well as white magic in the making.

HONOLULU, Jan. 4 (UP) -- The College All-Stars, an aggregation of collegiate football luminaries from the States, sparked by the passing of Illinois' Tommy O'Connell and a brace of Oklahoma backs, outclassed the Hawaii All-Stars, 33 to 14, in the Hula Bowl game today.

Amid the welter of the city's efforts to solve its financial problems it is good to learn that here and there are bits of local news that will make life brighter for some persons or groups. Such an item is the one telling us that Park Commissioner Moses and Manhattan Borough President Wagner have completed plans for two new enlarged playgrounds in Greenwich Village.

CHICAGO, Jan. 4 -- More than 750 retailers jumped the gun here today by placing quantity orders at a lamp trade show in the Palmer House. The show began at noon, twenty-one hours in advance of the official market opening in the American Furniture and Merchandise Mart.

Starting 1952 in a pessimistic mood, manufacturers of women's apparel geared their production to actual orders on hand and found that their operation for the year as a whole showed small profits instead of large anticipated losses.

Stephen J. Spingarn, acting chairman of the Federal Trade Commission, has been with the Administration in Washington in one capacity or another (except for an interval during the war, when he was with the Office of Strategic Services) since 1934, or for close to nineteen years.

Following the death of a 15-year-old boy who was knifed Friday in a teen-age gang fight in the Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn, the police have arrested six youths on charges of homicide and seven others for unlawful assembly.

Shoe production last year reached an estimated 508,000,000 pairs, the third time the industry has touched the half-billion mark. The retail dollar volume was about the same as in 1951, the increase in pairage offsetting a 10 to 15 per cent price decrease.

Love, and lovers, may laugh at locksmiths, but these practitioners of an ancient art arouse quite different feelings in, say, a householder who has forgotten his key and discovers that fact only after an evening at the theatre, or in the mind of a follower of another ancient trade when he discovers the safe remains closed despite his persistent manipulation of the dial.

PHILADELPHIA -- The eight-county Philadelphia metropolitan area, fourth-ranking manufacturing center in the nation, entered 1953 with industrial expansion, employment and wages at new peaks and prospects of soaring still further.
WARSAW, Jan. 4 (AP) -- Poland abolished rationing today and at the same time raised prices, wages, pensions and allowances.
TOKYO, Monday, Jan. 5 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,458, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M. Monday, Korean time:
Beneficiaries of private and Government pension programs had their potential pension payments increased in 1952.
The year 1952 ended in the United States with the economy, sustained in a substantial degree by the influence of defense spending, operating at the highest rate in the nation's history.
BOSTON -- New England ended 1952 on an encouraging note of manufacturing activity that gave evidence of extending at least through the first quarter of 1953.

The Board of Estimate has approved by a split vote taken in executive session Mayor Impellitteri's proposed 1953-54 fiscal program to be submitted to the Legislature soon after it convenes next Wednesday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (UP) -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's meeting last week with Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio and other Republican Senate leaders was "not all sweetness and light," but "left no hard feelings or bitterness," Senator Bridges said today.

The site for the new Adath Israel Center in Long Island City, Queens, was consecrated yesterday with the spreading of earth from Israel by Rabbi Jerome Fishman at Thirty-seventh Avenue near Twenty-first Street.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- Republican leaders of the Eighty-third Congress, agreeing that they "cannot promise too much too soon," said tonight that the tax cut they would like must await balancing of the budget.

ATLANTA -- The Department of Labor's regional Bureau of Labor Statistics, noting the strong increase in manufacturing employment in the Southeast in the final quarter of 1952, gave the following state breakdown in peak level employment for the month of October and the percentage of increase over the corresponding period for 1951.

Bonds redeemed before maturity in 1952 rose to $750,989,000 from $589,135,000 in 1951 because of large retirements of Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority bonds in March. The year's total, however, was lower than in 1950, when $1,553,496,000 in bonds was retired.
TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 4 (AP) -Anti-American sentiments were shouted today in a session of the Majlis, lower house of Parliament, which broke up in a row over a new election law.

Manufacturers of clay floor and wall tile have completed the second greatest production year in their history and, on the basis of developments within the industry, forecast excellent prospects in the year ahead.

A 2 l/2-year-old black cocker spaniel from Houston, Tex., Ch. Elderwood Bangaway, became the main winner at the specialty of the American Spaniel Club at the Hotel Roosevelt last night and thereby won national distinction.
ALBANY, Jan. 4 -- Governor Dewey will recommend to the 1953 Legislature a $1,500,000 program to provide more adequate correction facilities for hardened young criminals.

The cigar industry will increase its sales to 6,500,000,000 cigars this year from the 6,000,000,000 sold in 1952, Ernest Eckes, president of H. Anton Bock Company, Inc., maker of hand-rolled cigars, has predicted.
PARIS, Jan. 4 -- French Deputies, preoccupied with local stratagems, have often brought on political crises at times when they did the maximum of damage to France's foreign relations.

Two arguments -- one against increasing the price of gold, as so many Europeans now advocate, and the other for turning the job of making currency convertible back to private hands -- consume almost all the space in the January bank letter of the National City Bank of New York.

The savings outlook this year is for continued large gains, with the public's determination to save "reinforced by the results of the national election," said Robert M. Catharine, president of the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks, in a year-end statement.

The trailer coach industry set a new retail sales record in 1952 with total volume likely to be close to $300,000,000 when final reports are in. E. H. Gubser, president of the Trailer Coach Manufacturers Association, Chicago, says production of mobile homes in 1952 may have exceeded the previous peak, $5,000 units, set in 1948.

NEW DELHI, India, Jan 4 -- Communist China and the Soviet Union have declined Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru's invitation to participate in an international seminar on the Gandhian philosophy of nonviolence that will begin a two-week session here tomorrow.

A second biography of Brig. Gen. William L. Mitchell, whose ideas of air power and military aviation were under fire in the Nineteen Twenties and Thirties is scheduled for publication by Harcourt, Brace on Jan. 22. 'My Brother Bill," by Ruth Mitchell, is a story of the general's life as she knew it.

SALISBURY, Conn., Jan. 4 -- Jon Riisnaes, a 21-year-old Norwegian exchange student of the University of New Hampshire, won his second consecutive American ski jumping title today when he captured the Connecticut State Class A championship.

Once again coffee trading volume went down on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. The estimated figure for 1952 was 4,844,750 bags, against 6,377,250 in 1951, against 12,469,500 in 1950 and against 8,922,750 in 1949. Last year's aggregate is the lowest since the 3,633,750 bags of 1948.
Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower announced the names of three nominees yesterday for key posts as Assistant Attorneys General in the Justice Department.

The value of United States foreign trade in 1952 remained close to the record level of 1951, with increased military shipments serving to offset a decline in commercial exports from the high levels of the preceding year.

The American Can Company expects sales and rentals up to 10 per cent above 1952 this year if can-making supplies remain adequate and if Government controls are removed, said William C. Stolk, president, in a year-end statement.

An application for partial tax exemption for a proposed $20,000,000 cooperative housing project, Riverview Village, at Sound View Park, Clason Point, in the East Bronx, has been placed before the Board of Estimate, Robert Moses, city construction coordinator, announced yesterday.

BERLIN, Jan. 4 -- East Germany's Communists linked a former member of the party's Politburo today with the Slansky group in Prague, and urged the careful screening of all party members who previously had been exiles in the West.

One could hardly say anything more obvious than that Winston Churchill, who arrives in New York this morning, is heartily welcome. The measure of this man's hold on our affections lies in the complete obviousness and naturalness of the greeting he will receive. There was never an Englishman more English than Churchill, but if anyone ever could claim a dual English-American nationality it is he.

WASHINGTON Jan. 4 -- Philip B. Perlman stanchly defended tonight the President's Commission on Immigration and Naturalization, which he headed, against charges by Senator Pat McCarran that it had issued a "leftist" and "absurd" report criticizing the new immigration law.

It had been a favorite winter vegetable in his house for as long as he could remember, Helmut Ripperger wrote us. The author of six highly original cook books had disagreed with our recent observation that salsify was a culinary curiosity.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 4 (AP) -- Frank Sedgman expressed angry surprise today that Australian amateur tennis officials don't plan to extend a helping hand to his professional career.
Modern art was defended, attacked and explained last night by six high school students who spoke with as much authority or bewilderment as might be found in any adult group discussing the subject.

CHINAMORA RESERVE, Southern Rhodesia, Jan. 4 -- The gravest question in all of Sub-Sahara Africa today is the extent of political voice that shall be granted to the native tribesmen who represent a vast majority of the population.

With the full impact of the bus strike due to hit the subways this morning, the national Congress of Industrial Organizations succeeded yesterday in persuading Michael J. Quill, president of the Transport Workers Union, to abandon his boycott of peace conferences under Mayor Impellitteri's auspices.

BOSTON, Jan. 4 (AP) -- The Boston Celtics whipped New York's Knickerbockers, 103 to 100, today to pull within 11 percentage points of the Eastern Division-leading Knicks in the National Basketball Association.

LEONARDO, N. J., Jan. 4 -- Two bodies were recovered this morning from a Marine Corps patrol car that unaccountably went off the pier of the Earle Naval Ammunition Depot here at 6:55 o'clock last night.

American - flag shipping met sharp reverses during 1952 as a result of two inevitable changes in the world maritime pattern. These were the sustained post-war reconstruction program in foreign merchant fleets and the curtailment of the United States foreign aid program.

The construction industry established a new peak of volume of more than $42,000,000,000 last year and may exceed that figure by $l,000,000,000 in 1953, according to Harold R. Berlin, vice president of the Johns-Manville Corporation. Mr. Berlin, general manager of the company's building products division, notes that construction is now in second position, behind defense, as the nation's leading industry.

Quick action by a police sergeant and police emergency crew yesterday morning saved the lives of two babies who had been stricken by escaping coal gas in a rooming house two doors from the East Thirty-fifth Street Police Station.

LOS ANGELES -- Running neck and neck with Philadelphia for the rank of the nation's fourth largest industrial area, Los Angeles continued its phenomenal expansion to new record levels in nearly all industrial and commercial categories in 1952.

Future prices on the New York Cotton Exchange started the New Year on a firm note. Net changes for last week ranged from gains of 60 cents to $1.85 a bale. The near-by deliveries were under slight pressure early last week by tax selling and switches to the more distant positions.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn. -- For the South, the past year was marked by several soft spots and discordances, principally in textile industries and livestock, but in the final quarter an upsurge resulted in record-breaking factory employment and gross cash income for farmers.

OYSTER BAY, L. I., Jan. 4 -- The present Korean impasse is traceable directly to this country's lack of preparedness, Maj. Gen. Charles A. Willoughby, retired, Chief of Intelligence for General of the Army Douglas MacArthur from 1941 to 1951, charged here today.

ALBANY, Jan.4 -- Governor Dewey is expected to take Mayor Impellitteri and other New York City officials to task in his annual message to the Legislature this week for their failure to propose a long-range program for solving the city's budgetary crisis.

Mediators in the dock strike adjourned a meeting early this morning with management and union representatives after failing to end a walkout started last Friday by three small locals of the International Longshoremen's Association, A. F. L.

WASHINGTON -- Federal expenditures in the 1953 fiscal year, which ends June 30, will fall far below the peacetime record of $85,444,000,000 proposed by President Truman in the budget submitted to Congress last January. It is even conceivable now that actual spending will not equal the previous peacetime record of $66,100,000,000, set in fiscal 1952.

Ben Duffy, president of Batten, Barton, Durstine Osborn, Inc., believes that advertising in 1953 will show an over-all increase of 5 per cent above 1952. Basing his prediction on a review of first quarter appropriations already contracted for and scheduled, he says that if the other quarters keep pace with the first, 1953 "will be a banner year."

The furniture industry went into 1952 with mountain-high inventories at all trade levels and prospects extremely dim. Leaders in the industry argued on Dec. 31 whether the record $6,000,000,000 volume of 1951 had been exceeded. They agreed that it had been equaled.

DES MOINES, Iowa -- While 1952 was the second largest crop year in history, milk production fell to a record low in relation to the needs of a rapidly increasing population, the Department of Agriculture reported.

The traffic death toll throughout the country in the four-day New Year's holiday reached a new record at midnight last night when 379 auto fatalities were reported. The previous record of 375 auto deaths was set during the 1952 New Year's holiday period.
WASHINGTON -- A new Congress with a different approach to economic controls is assembling here amid speculation about its attitude toward the continuance of wage and price stabilization.

Her early French training is evident in the beautiful clothes designed by today's creator of the pattern illustrated. Mme. Suzanne, as she is spoken of in fashion circles, is one of New York's leading designers and is known for a very special type of creation, one that is expressed in smart simplicity.
Retail trade set a new mark in dollar volume in 1952 and gains are expected this year.

CHICAGO, Jan. 4 -- The final week of 1952 showed heavy long liquidation in grain futures, especially of wheat and corn, which registered new lows for the crop year. Much of the selling was to establish losses for tax purposes. In addition to this selling there was the usual long liquidation incident to a falling market.

The Griller String Quartet, which played yesterday afternoon in Town Hall, must be ranked as one of the finest string quartets now performing. It has no peer in point of musicianship, sensitivity and finish and balance of tone-quality today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (AP) -- A record attendance was forecast today for the forty-seventh annual meeting of the National Collegiate Athletic Association this week.
Resources of the Manufacturers Trust Company last year rose $182,581,644 and were $2,948,974,541 on Dec. 31 last. A year earlier they had been $2,766,392,897.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (UP) -- A Defense Department spokesman said today that stepped-up draft calls and a tightened rotation policy for United States troops in Korea did not necessarily herald a new United Nations offensive against the Chinese Communists.

TOKYO, Monday, Jan. 5 -- The fighting dwindled almost to a standstill along the frozen Korean front yesterday. The Communist offensive that the Reds' propaganda sources had threat ened for Jan. 4 did not develop.

Lincoln Kirstein, general director of the New York City Ballet, has been chosen to receive the second annual Capezio Dance Award, made each year for outstanding contributions to the dance in the United States. The honor carries with it a cash award of $500. Presentation will be made on Jan. 12 at a luncheon at the Waldorf-Astoria.
Domestic consumption of iron and steel scrap in 1952 was the second highest in history, despite the cutback in usage during the eight-week steel strike in June and July.

The Whitehall Street Ferry Terminal -- a 50-year-old landmark at the tip of the Battery, through which pass 30,000,000 passengers and 2,000,000 vehicles annually -- will receive a $3,000,000 "face-lifting" and reconstruction, it was announced yesterday by Edward F. Cavanagh Jr., Commissioner of Marine and Aviation.

United States industry today is far more than raw materials, intricate machines and annual reports. Industry is alive and human and the finished product always depends primarily on the human element. Never has the human side of industry made such advances as in 1952. Improved industry health programs, health and hospitalization insurance, recreational activities and wiser retirement policies have been included to a greater extent than ever before in labor-management contracts.

MELBOURNE, Jan. 4 (AP) -- Sir Norman Brookes said tonight he had offered to Frank Sedgman and Ken McGregor insurance company jobs with annual salaries rising from 1,500 Australian pounds ($3,367.50) in the first year to 5,000 Australian pounds ($11,225) in the fourth year.

Prettiness as well as comfort is supplied by some of the new bed accoutrements, a group which includes such traditional items as hand-embroidered sheets and such up-to-date ones as blankets made of synthetic fibers.

The change in the national Administration has brought to the forefront a little-known book entitled "United States Government Organization Manual, 1952-53," for sale by the Superintendent of Documents, Government Printing Office, at $1 a copy. This book is the official organization handbook of the Federal Government, describing all Government agencies of the legislative, judicial and executive branches, in addition to the other agencies not so easily classified.
Restive under an economic policy that was half-controlled and half-free, organized labor pushed wages to record heights last year, but lost more than twice as much time through strikes as in 1951.

A floating dice game was taken in tow last night in a Brooklyn tenement by the police and dry-docked at the Grand Avenue station, where thirty men were charged with disorderly conduct. The police also took charge of $5,000 to $10,000 found on the players as well as a portable aluminum dice table.

With all major types of media sharing in the bonanza, advertising expenditures in 1952 ran considerably ahead of those of 1951, when an estimated $6,500,000,000 was spent to promote the products and services of United States industry. Whether this high rate of spending will continue through this year is problematical, though the need for heavy advertising will be greater than ever.

PARIS, Jan. 4 -- Despite the Cabinet crisis the new year is opening in France under conditions of stable prices. Official statistics show that the index for the cost of living on Jan. 1 stood almost exactly where it was one year ago.
Park Commissioner Moses has proposed, and the City Council has disposed of, a measure designed to protect city parks.

Many distinguished non-Communists have been duped into signing the Communist-circulated "appeal for clemency" in the Rosenberg atom spy case, the American Committee for Cultural Freedom declared in a statement issued here yesterday.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 4 -- The year closed with the usual cautious predictions by major steelmakers. However, interpretation of such statements may be in order. All agreed that the first six months of this year would see good demand and high steel output.

CHICAGO, Jan. 4 -- The atomic blast last Nov. 1, which was credited with destroying an island in the South Pacific, was the explosion of a second-stage hydrogen type bomb with more than twice the power of the improved atomic bomb, the Bulletin of the Atomic Scientists concluded today.

Before we condemn that fellow who sandbagged you the other night, let's look into the facts. His primary school teacher made him write with his right hand although he was basically sinister. His grammar school teacher stunted his personality by whamming him whenever he deserved it.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 4 -- The withdrawal of United States and British troops from the Free Territory of Trieste, turning over the entire Zone A, including the port of Trieste to Italy, and by implication leaving Zone B to Yugoslavia, is seriously being considered by responsible United States and British authorities.

Greater confidence in corporate profits has been inspired by improved conditions in recent months and the prospect of more favorable tax, labor and fiscal policies under the new Administration. Other signs, however, point to somewhat lower earnings in 1953 than last year's returns of $17,500,000,000 compared with $18,700,000,000 in 1951.

The spacious Broadway entrance to the Hellinger will be dispensed with, it was learned yesterday from authoritative sources. Supplanting it will be the Fifty-first Street entrance, which has been used occasionally for that purpose in the past.
The paint industry is prospering. Since 1950 sales of paints, varnishes and lacquers for trade and industrial use have been on the rise and 1953 looms as the best year yet.

The travel industry has a rather cavalier attitude toward statistics, which makes it somewhat embarrassing to try to evaluate the 1952 tourist traffic in terms of dollars, miles or tourists. This arises principally from the fact that there is no such thing as a travel industry, in the same sense that there is a steel industry whose products are closely related and whose production can be charted on a graph.

With a marked downturn in prices, United States consumption of burlap from India rose sharply in 1952, according to a year-end statement by Alexander Low, representative in North America of the Indian Jute Mills and president of the Burlap Council of New York. Consumption for the year was estimated at 820,000,000 yards, compared with 531,100,000 last year, an increase of 55 per cent.

BECAUSE the name of Tony DeSpirito does not roll easily off the tongue, a new label suddenly appeared in sports department jargon last week. A fellow would look at the news ticker and announce jubilantly, "Hey, the Desperado won another." Or it might be, "Tony Desperado won another." At no time was there ever any possibility of mistaken identity.

PARIS, Jan. 4 -- Regardless of the outcome his negotiations to obtain additional support, Rene Mayer, the Radical party leader, was thought to have decided today to ask the National Assembly to endorse him as Premier.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- Higher pay and larger expense accounts for all members of the national legislature were advocated in letters sent to each member of the Eighty-third Congress today by the National Committee for Strengthening Congress.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Jan. 4 -- Corny Shields' Dainty, takling two races in the final session today of the New Year's Regatta at the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club, I becam$ the total point winner over I the three days with a score of 26. Second with 43 tallies was Jim Aoore with his craft Lure.

An all-day "clinic" designed to! instruct clergymen on how to make the "maximum" use of tele-J vision will be conducted on Jan. 29 by the Columbia Broadcasting System at the network's Grand Central studios.
The rubber industry, natural and synthetic, made major advances in the year.

PARIS, Jan. 4 -- The expulsion of Andre Marty from the French Communist party after thirtythree years as one of its major heroes has been made final by action of the party's Federal Committee of the Seine Department (Paris), it was announced today.
LYNDONVILLE, Vt., Jan. 4 -- Dartmouth retained its laurels in the Lyndonville ski meet today, although Middlebury College outscored the Big Green in jumping, the final event.

An ending "at the earliest possible moment" of price and wage controls on copper and on brass mill products was called for in a year-end statement issued by James J. Russell, board chairman of Revere Copper and Brass, Inc.
I read in the public press with interest and concern the statement of the twenty Jerusalem rabbis in which they questioned the conviction of treason of the Rosenbergs.

More aluminum was made in the United States during 1952 than in any previous year. Despite the loss of more than 100,000,000 pounds of production caused by drought, the year's output of the light metal ran to approximately 1,870,000,000 pounds.

The new Cadillac, with a soundproofed body and hood fitted for an optional air-conditioning system for summer driving, was described yesterday by the Cadillac division of the General Motors Corporation in an announcement of its 1953 line. The new cars will go on display Wednesday in dealers' showrooms here.

In spite of exceedingly high income tax rates, individual and corporation, business continues at a high level. The most direct cause of this activity is, of course. the forced draft of production generated by Government demands for war and defense material.

HARTFORD, Conn. -- Connecticut's industrial employment and wage figures were the highest on record as 1952 ended and the prospects were that the state's highly favorable economy would continue into 1953.

An investor has purchased for over cash a mortgage of $40,000 the seven-story loft building at 345 West Broadway, near Grand Street, from the Estate of Ray Eisen, Inc., in a deal negotiated by Dwight-Helmsley, Inc., broker. Benjamin Sholomson was the attorney for the seller and Jacob Linett for the buyer of the building, which has a gross income of a little more than $14,000 a year.

WASHINGTON -- John T. Koehler, chairman of the five-man Renegotiation Board entrusted with recovering defense contract profits considered to be excessive, reported that the board received nearly $19,000,000 in prepayments on defense contracts last year.

The American public borrowed more than $23,090,000,000 last year for consumer expenditures. That was the estimate of' total consumer credit--installment and noninst]lment loans -- as 1952 reached its close.
KHARTUM, Sudan, Jan. 4 -- A Socialist leader said today Egypt now was using money in the Sudan in a campaign to bring about the unification of Egypt and the Sudan.

Advocates of a manufacturer's right to fix minimum retail prices of his products scored a telling but not conclusive legal victory last year. In July President Truman signed the McGuire Act, enabling producers to enforce their minimums in the forty-five states having fair trade laws.

DES MOINES, Iowa -- Despite persistent disturbance by weather, prices and costs, American agriculture retained a favorable position in the national economy during 1952, and prospects for 1953 were bright.

Gifts from children as well as donations sent in their names were among the thirty-five contributions adding $621.25 yesterday to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. This brought the total to date to $374,731.31.

The chemical industry has "nowhere to go but up." This is the view of Charles S. Munson, president of the Manufacturing Chemists Association, Inc., and chairman of the board of Air Reduction Company, Inc.

During the first six months of last year shirt inventories were heavy and profits were considerably below 1951 on the retail, manufacturing and mill levels, but by the latter part of the year activity improved and unit sales surpassed the preceding year. While more sports shirts and dress shirts were produced than in 1951, profits were lower due to rising production costs and the holding of price brackets.

Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the President-elect, declaring the need to strengthen American-British relations, announced yesterday his support of the King George VI Memorial Fund to train young people from British Commonwealth countries in the United States.

Railroad issues led in trading on the New York Stock Exchange in 1952, but a diversified list of industrial stocks accounted for a large part of the year's dealings, a study of the twenty most active stocks indicated. Five of the twenty issues were in the railroad category.

The Syracuse and Utica municipal housing authorities have designated for public sale issues of $2,572,000 of notes to finance temporarily low-rent projects being built under loan and subsidy contracts with New York State.

The Salvation Army's 1953 fundraising appeal, with a goal of $1,250,000, will be opened today. The campaign will be continued until March 7 and is designed to provide a third of the $3,211,244 needed to operate the organization's sixty institutions and services in the Greater New York area.

The volume of money in circulation -- currency and coin in the public's pockets and the cash in the vaults of banks and the tills of merchants -- reached a new peak last year, approximating $30,500,000,000. With the start of the new year it is probable that there will be a marked decline, as the post-holiday return flow to banks gets under way, but it is indicated that the volume outstanding will continue large.

The seventeenth annual British Epiphany festival service was con'ducted yesterday afternoon at the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest, Fifth Avenue and Ninetieth Street, by the Rev. Dr. John Ellis Large, rector, with 800 persons in attendance.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 4 -- In response to an announcement by the Egyptian delegation to the United Nations that shipments of food to Israel through the Suez canal were continuing without interruption, a spokesman for the Israeli delegation said today that his Government would insist that Egypt observe a Security Council resolution calling for cessation of seizure and search of ships bound for Israel.

The significance of the "hidden" !thirty years of Christ's life is the "consecration by the God-man to [ . Hxmse,f, of the ordinalH unchrono iicled hours and days and years of his ordinary followers," the Rev. John IV[. Crotty of St. Patrick's Cathedral staff declared there yesterday.

For the tenth successive year truck cargo thefts increased last year, it is reported by the Cargo Protection Bureau of New York. The total reached an estimated record level of $75,000,000 -- two and a half times that of 1945, when crime advanced sharply.

PARIS, Jan. 4 -- Tunisian nationalist leaders will call for a boycott of municipal elections in Tunisia to protest against the grant of voting rights to French colonists and the manner in which the municipal reform program was imposed on the country's ruler, according to nationalist spokesmen in Paris.

The New York Legislature convenes on Wednesday to hear Governor Dewey's annual message and to tackle a collection of problems seldom equaled in number and importance. This heavy calendar makes it imperative that, as the first order of business, the Legislature mend its ways and get down to work at once, avoiding the chaos previously marking the final days of a session.

Ernst Krenek, who was represented by an early work at the New Friends of Music's Nov. 16 concert, was represented by a late work yesterday afternoon when the Friends resumed their concerts after a holiday intermission. This time the composer was present at Town Hall to participate in the program.

Equipment trust certificates aggregating $271,000,000 and maturing serially over fifteen years were sold in the public market by sealed bidding in 1952 to finance acquisition by railroads of equipment costing more than $356,000,000, according to a survey by Salomon Bros. Hutzler.

Spring manufacturing activity in the knitwear and swimwear business this year will far exceed that of a year ago, according to Sidney S. Korzenik, executive director and counsel of the National Knitted Outerwear Association. This expectation, he said, is based on the fact that, although the sweater season has traditionally been the fall, more interest is being shown in spring lines.

The United States and Canada produce approximately one-half of all electric current generated throughout the world. Russia runs a poor second with an annual output equal to only one-tenth of the world's supply.

Prime Minister Winston Churchill is the first to seek a preview, but he is by no means the only world statesman who is impatient to discover the attitude of the incoming Administration on the pressing problems of international policy. In every capital, including Moscow, Governments are waiting with curiosity and concern to see what will happen when General Eisenhower moves into the White House.

SALT LAKE CITY, Jan. 4 (AP) -- The Secretary of Agriculture-designate, Ezra Taft Benson, said here today that farm groups in many parts of the country had sent messages to him urging the removal of Government price controls.

In their first round of the annual competition for the National Challenge Trophy, sponsored by the United States Soccer Football Association at Sterling Oval yesterday, the New York Americans eliminated the Brooklyn Sport Club, 3 to 0, before 1,800 fans.

Volume of the gas appliance industry last year exceeded $1,200,000,000, James F. Donnelly, president of the Gas Appliance Manufacturers Association, said in a year-end report. The showing indicates a remarkable recovery from the slump in which the industry found itself in the first quarter of the year.

CHICAGO -- Industrial and agricultural centers of the Midwest, closing 1952 With confidence, looked to 1953 as a period of expansion, increased production and construction and continued prosperity with comfortable profits, sustained high income and little hope for substantial tax relief.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (UP) -- The Foreign Service Journal today compared the Civil Service Commission Loyalty Review Board's handling of John Carter Vincent, career diplomat, with a Kremlin-type "mock trial."
" Tosca" was performed at the Metropolitan Saturday evening with Mario del Monaco singing Cavaradossi and Sigurd Bjoerling singing Scarpia for the first time at the house.

The recent statement of John J. McCloy, former High Commissioner of Germany, belittling the danger of the resurgence of nazism in Germany, is reminiscent of precisely the same kind of forecasts to which the American people were subjected during the decade following the First World War. The creeping emergence of pan-Germanism then was concealed or ignored.

Bishop Herbert Welch, 90-yearold senior Bishop of the !Vfethodist Church, returned once again from "retirement" yesterday to preach at Christ Church, iVethodist, Park Avenue at Sixtieth Street. In his sermon he examined the purposes of Christian religion.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (UP) -- H. L. Mitchell, president of the National Agriculture Workers Union, A. F. L., said today that some large farm operators in California were trying to hold down agricultural wages by threatening to import cheap labor from Japan. He accused the Ventura Citrus Growers Association of Ventura, Calif., of having made plans for importing thousands of Japanese workers.

WASHINGTON -- The instigation of important grand jury investigations and the filing of several suits against nationally known business concerns were features of the administration in 1952 of the anti-trust laws and other statutes regulating business.

SEOUL, Korea, Jan. 4 -- The United States Army announced today the award of the Distinguished Service Cross to Lieut. Gen. Reuben E. Jenkins and two other officers for extraordinary heroism in combat.

Since C. H. O'D. Alexander, British champion, captured the highest honors in 1946. British players have had to stand aside at the annual Christmas festivals of the Hastings Chess Club of England. In the current international tournament there, however, Jonathan Penrose, former British boy champion, holds a clear 1-point lead after five rounds according to a report from London.
Jerome Lewine Jr. has become a general partner of H. Hentz Co., member of the New York Stock Exchange.

DETROIT -- At the end of a trying year, with earnings and output somewhat higher than most manufacturers had expected, the automobile industry was taking a fairly optimistic view of its prospects for 1953.

" It would indeed be unfortunate if we simply taught people the Kingdom of God and stopped there, rather than helping them find a way to express the love they have learned," the Rev. Lawrence J. Holt, director of social missions of the New York Conference of the Augustana Lutheran Church, declared in a sermon here yesterday.
Churchgoers were urged yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Robert J. McCracken, pastor of Riverside Church, to translate their Christian principles into "practical politics" during 1953.

New domestic freight car deliveries last year approximated 77,000, of which 64,000 were to the Class I railroads, according to C. W. Wright, president of the American Railway Car Institute, in a year-end statement. Retirements by the Class I carriers amounted to about 60,000 cars, making the total number of cars owned by these roads at the end off the year 1,755,000.

Early in 1952 it seemed evident that the decline in industrial failures would be reversed before the year was over. Recession in soft goods lines brought manufacturers and distributors as well as retailers to a point where it was becoming increasingly difficult to meet their bills.
The new age of American industry, when industrial production will be operated by machinery, with a minimum of workers to press the buttons and make repairs, is about to dawn.

The steel industry's big defense expansion program, although a bit behind schedule because of the industry's midyear strike and difficulty in obtaining certain necessary materials, took record strides in 1952 and is due to be completed around the middle of this year.

VIENNA, Jan. 4 -- The Communist-created "Central Committee of Unemployed" has called a conference of Austrian unemployed in Vienna Jan. 25 to "give expression to their demands in connection with the forthcoming general elections."

ROSKILDE, Denmark, Jan. 4 -- The body of Queen Mother Alexandrine was placed this afternoon at the side of the sarcophagus of her husband, King Christian X in the King Christian IX Chapel of Roskilde Cathedral.

A twenty-six page statement of "exceptions" will be filed with the Board of Education today by counsel for eight teachers who were tried recently on charges of insubordination for refusing to answer questions by school officials as to alleged membership in the Communist party. This was announced yesterday by the Teachers Union, of which the eight are members.

The silly indictment of Owen Lattimore may be a fitting prologue to the tragi-comedy which Senators McCarthy and McCarran announce on communism in American colleges and universities. This is an inviting field for Senatorial investigation, for there are in our colleges many faculty members who in their salad days may have joined societies, committees or other bodies now branded by the Department of Justice as subversive.

Child welfare agencies are just beginning to feel the effects of family migration into new industrial areas created as a result of the relocation and expansion of defense industries, Spencer H. Crookes, executive director of the Child Welfare League of America, reported this week-end.

Manufacturers of prefabricated houses will have to abandon their "trial and error" method of marketing and adopt a more effective sales technique if the industry expects to prosper, according to a warning contained in the results of a nationwide survey disclosed yesterday by the Housing Research Center at Cornell University.

An analysis of New York City's labor force, based on the 1950 census, showed an increase of 46,000 persons over the 1940 census and further showed that today four of every five employed individuals were in private industry, the New York State Department of Commerce reported yesterday.
Year-end adjustment of accounts and the influence of the holidays produced an irregular trend of rates for the principal exchanges last week.

The most spectacular event in atomic energy since the explosion of the first atomic bomb in the desert of New Mexico on the morning of July 16, 1945, took place at Eniwetok, in the Marshall Islands, in the Central Pacific, at 7:15 A. M. Eniwetok time on Nov. 1, 1952.

SAN FRANCISCO -- The dollar value of the foreign trade of the Pacific Coast continued to show an upward trend during 1952 and shippers, looking at 1953 through their crystal ball, have reached a consensus that is neither very optimistic nor very pessimistic.

Cautioning against "precipitate action" before the State Crime Commission's hearings are completed and all the facts made known, John V. Lyon, chairman of the New York Shipping Association, reported progress yesterday in his organization's preparation of recommendations for waterfront condition improvements.

Because business is so sensitive to foreign developments and government policy, the possibility of a recession this year depends upon whatever takes place in the world situation and upon the policies of the new administration, according to William White, president of the New York Central System.

The fourth anniversary of the day on which Victor Raul Haya de la Torre took refuge in the Colombian Embassy in Lima, Peru, was reached on Saturday, Jan. 3. One should not let it pass without mention or thought, for his case is a strange one even in our strange times, and his name is still one to stir feelings to their depths in South America.

Leaders of the food industry look forward to 1953 with almost universal optimism, based on the continued high level of expendable income in the United States and the belief that much of it will go for more and better food.

Following all the uproar over George S. Kaufman's pre-Christmas quip about too much singing of "Silent Night, Holy Night," the Columbia Broadcasting System is to be congratulated four reinstating the playwright on its television program "This Is Show Business."
CENTRAL FRONT, Korea, Jan. 4 (UP) -- A wounded Army captain revealed today that a home front racketeer had attempted to extort money from his parents with a promise to get him home from Korea.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 4 -- A losing battle that the concrete mixer has been waging with the automobile for seven years over California's 14,000-mile highway system will be posed to the State Legislature convening tomorrow for urgent solution.

The better terms offered on United States Savings Bonds in May, 1952, improved public response to these prime investments, but redemptions of the "E" series continued to exceed sales by about $750,000,000 during the year. Nevertheless, total sales of all types of the savings bonds showed improvement over 1951.

Gross revenue of the nation's railroads last year was about $10,650,000,000, exceeding the ten billion mark for the second consecutive year. In 1951, the gross revenues were $10,390,610,000. Higher freight rates accounted for the increase, as the traffic volume held below that of 1951.

SAN JUAN, P. R. -- Rafael Carion, president of the Banco Popular de Puerto Rico, of San Juan, which has eleven branch banks, recently expressed the conviction shared by government, business and industrial leaders that the economic progress made by Puerto Rico in 1952 would continue in 1953. He said:
HONOLULU -- Hawaii's 1952 economy kept up a healthy parallel with that of 1951, and the 1953 business outlook is good, according to a leading Honolulu economist.
Stuart Fastovsky, violinist, began his Carnegie Hall recital yesterday afternoon by playing Ravel's "Tzigane," followed by Prokofieff's Sonata in F minor, Op. 80, and Charles Ives' Sonata No. 2.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 4 (AP) -- Lloyd Mangrum, who has won this tournament twice before, clipped two strokes off par for a 69 today for first place at the end of the third round in the $20,000 Los Angeles open golf tournament. His total of 210 was five strokes ahead of the field.

Health insurance benefits account for "more than twice the share of the nation's insurable health bill" than was credited to them by the Social Security Administration, the Health Insurance Council asserted yesterday. The council, representing the accident and health insurance business, has headquarters at 488 Madison Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (AP) -- Senator Pat McCarran, Democrat of Nevada, said today that information from the State Department itself made it apparent that loyalty to the United States was secondary -- if not ignored altogether -- in department security checks on United States employes of the United Nations.

Diversification, key to Florida's rapidly expanding economy, is helping to provide a firm basis for a new industrial outlook for the state. A survey of the current economic scene shows that Florida possesses an assortment of raw supplies important to many chemical and other light operations.
LONDON, Jan. 4 -- Large quantities of ammunition will be sent to Indo-China as part of an increase in British aid to the French forces fighting communism there, the Foreign Office said tonight.

The designation of Eugene F. Bannigan as Minority Leader of the Assembly tomorrow seemed likely last night after Kenneth F. Sutherland, recently elected as, Brooklyn Democratic leader, had conferred with Richard H. Balch, the Democratic State Chairman, at the Biltmore Hotel.

NEW ORLEANS -- The New Orleans area experienced an exceptionally good business year in 1952, and economists here predict that more records will be broken in the first half of 1953 and possibly in the whole new year.

Of all the 1952 developments on the New York Curb Exchange, that which will be remembered longest was the decision of the trading body to take its sixth name -- the American Stock Ex change -- effective today, Jan. 5. Since the name is too long to fit into the one-column headline type of any newspaper in this country, the initials A. S. E. seem destined to become familiar.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- The Council of State Chambers of Commerce made public today an eight-state study that, it said, showed that many manufacturers were cutting back or abandoning expansion plans because of high Federal taxes.

The hosiery industry came through the year on a paradoxical cloud. On one side, the industry registered the highest record of shipments in history. On the other, profits fore most producers were slim, owing to a highly competitive price situation.

SEATTLE -- The Pacific Northwest found 1952 a record post-war year by most economic yardsticks. But as the year ended, a regional power shortage and the softening of the lumber and plywood market cast a shadow likely to extend into early 1953.
