The country's shipbuilding yards must have additional orders for new ships to maintain "reasonable" construction activity and employment during the current year and to preserve a nucleus of shipbuilding skills for the nation.

The stock market underwent some violent movements last year, but each dip only set the stage for higher prices that culminated in a gain for the combined averages of THE NEW YORK TIMES index of 18.89 points. This brought the roving price structure to the best rating in more than 22 years.

With business continuing at a high level, a relatively firm money market is expected to persist in the early months of 1953. As the year progresses, it appears inevitable that there will again be heavy deficit financing by the Treasury, with resultant pressures on the market.

Ned Hall, the new headmaster at The Hill School, came upon a disconcerting item over the holidays. While on a junket through New England and New York, Hall read a report in which a Yale scientist said winters in this hemisphere would be warmer and drier for approximately two centuries.

An eventful if not historic year has just closed for dollar bonds as an instrument of international investment. After distressful decades of depression and war, the concept of the lasting sanctity of international investment contract was confirmed in 1952 by agreements aimed at resuming debt service on the long-defaulted government and corporate dollar bonds of Germany and Japan.

The stock market pattern in 1952 resembled the appearance of a mountain range -- many peaks and valleys. In the first four months, prices alternately rose and declined. For the next four months there was a steady climb from the low of the year made in May to an August peak.

Lumber production last year probably approximated 36,500,000,000 board feet, according to the Lumber Survey Committee. This represented a drop of 772,000,000 board feet from the 37,272,000,000 board feet that streamed out of American mills in 1951.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 4 -- Angry commuters smashed suburban trains and battled the police here yesterday and the day before, and more serious trouble is likely tomorrow as a new working week starts.

Sidor Belarsky, basso, was heard at Town Hall last evening in a program that included arias by Mozart, Verdi, Glinka and Mussorgsky; songs of Salvator Rosa, Tchaikovsky, Dargomijsky, Prozorovsky, Purcell, Thomas, MacGimsey, Sequeira, Shelem-Stuchevsky and Lavri, and traditional l songs.
GLENS FALLS, N. Y., Jan. 4 (AP) -- Ray Blum of Nutley, N. J., streaked to the senior men's championship in the northeastern New York speed-skating meet today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (AP) -- Republican Congressional leaders said today that a system of advance consultation has been worked out to cover appointments and patronage under the Administration of General Eisenhower.

ANKARA, Turkey, Dec. 20 (By Airmail) -- Turkey provides a concrete example of how economic aid increases a country's military strength. As a result of her economic boom, touched off by the Marshall Plan, Turkey will net an additional $100,000,000 or 17 per cent in Government revenues this year.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (AP) -- The value of agricultural products exported by the United States continued a decline during October, 1952, dropping 25 per cent under the level of October, 1951, the Department of Agriculture reported today.

Until Christians "roll up their sleeves" and prove to millions of spiritually destitute in all parts of the world that they sincerely believe in Christian ideals, the fate of mankind will continue to linger in an "ominous twilight zone," the Rev. Dr. John Summerfield Wire, bish declared in a sermon yesterday morning at the Calvary Baptist Church, Fifty-seventh Street near Sixth Avenue.

The New York State Chapter of Americans for Democratic Action announced yesterday that it had sent a letter to Governor Dewey, asking him to support a constitutional amendment to permit an increase in the basic tax rate on real estate from 2 to 2 1/2 per cent.
A worried wife hearing a bowl of hot soup yesterday saved the life of Charles Taffinder, 52 years old, of 53-11 Forty-fourth Street, Sunnyside, Queens.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 4 -- Warner Brothers apparently is aiming to give moviegoers a thrill and a chill with the picture that it is preparing to film with WarnerColor in the stereoscopic three-dimension process called Natural Vision.

While there is a significant shift in the public taste for cigarettes toward king size and filter brands, the total consumption continues to climb. The production last year was about 432,000,000,000 units or about 2,700 cigarettes per person. The 1951 output was 418,000,000,000 units.

An electronic device that "intelligently reacts to numbers" spoken into an ordinary telephone, which some day may make it possible to put through a call automatically by speaking the desired phone number into the mouthpiece instead of dialing it, has been developed at the Bell Telephone Laboratories.

LONDON, Jan. 4 -- While displaying no exuberance, the stock markets ended the year cheerfully and with a feeling of moderate optimism that the new year will witness further recovery in Britain's economic position comparable at least to the progress made in the last year.
The nation's life insurance industry provided more dollars for investment in American business in 1952 than ever before.
Although the production of nylon yarn and staple has increased threefold in the last five years, the fiber still remains under tight ration, according to the National Industrial Conference Board.

This time the Rangers made it. Despite the fact that they scored first in their National Hockey League game against the Boston Bruins at Madison Square Garden last night, the New York skaters managed to win the game, to the mild surprise of a crowd of 10,140. The score was 5 to 2.

JERSEY CITY, Jan. 4 -- An offer by Mayor John V. Kenny to testify before the New Jersey Law Enforcement Council as a voluntary witness rather than under court order was forecast today by a City Hall spokesman.
PITTSBURGH -- Prospects for business and trade for 1953 in this industrial capital appear bright.
Communications, both domestic and international, set new records last year.
NEW ORLEANS -- The port of New Orleans continued to enjoy a balanced import-export trade in 1952, when more cargo was handled over its wharves than in any preceding year.

BONN, Germany, Jan. 4 -- The offices of the United States, British and French High Commissioners have reached an agreement permitting increases in the shipbuilding capacity of West German yards. Five licenses to increase capacity have been granted.

Nationwide closed circuit television broadcasts soon may partly replace the railroad train and the airplane for sales and other conventions of business organizations. Last year an increasing number of companies ranging from producers of hard and soft surface floor coverings to household appliances and lithographers used this method to bring their distributors, salesmen and retailers together.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 4 -- Many advances in the field of human rights were made during 1951 in the United States, according to a comprehensive review prepared by the United States Mission to the United Nations, for inclusion in the Human Rights Yearbook. The text of the survey was released today.

State and city civil defense officials said yesterday that "almost all" of the fifteen general recommendations contained in a report on national defense made public Saturday by Associated Universities, Inc., had been accomplished in this state.

ZURICH, Jan. 4 -- Since the Pinay Cabinet resigned on Dec. 23, scepticism among competent authorities of Switzerland about the feasibility of overcoming the economic monetary crisis of France without another devaluation of the French franc becomes more profound every day France remains without a strong government and has been deepened by numerous statistics on foreign trade and the balance of payments published by official French sources in the last few days.

Although the "separate trousers industry" has been listed in the United Census of Manufacturers for only five years, slacks production in 1952 outran men's suits by about 2 to 1, according to David Lewis, president of Esquire Sportswear, Inc. Last year, his concern turned out its 5,000,000th pair.

The first quarter of this year is not expected to produce significant net change in the level of business loans. Following the holiday season repayment of trade and commodity commitments may be expected, but other factors will tend to offset the normal seasonal liquidation, it is believed.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 4 (AP) -- Renewal of the Rose Bowl football pact between Big Ten and Pacific Coast Conference colleges was foreseen here today following a meeting between presidents and representatives of the two groups.

The radio-television electronic industry last year broke all previous production records, either in peace or war, according to a year-end statement by A. D. Plamondon Jr., president of the Radio-Television Manufacturers Association. He said the industry had demonstrated clearly that it had the capacity for fulfilling national defense obligations and meeting consumer demands simultaneously.
Financial and Business Editor Buffeted by man-made storms the nation's economy ended its journey successfully last year.
JACKSON, Miss. -- Mississippi's $50,000,000-a-year oil and natural gas industry is pouring new wealth into the economic bloodstream of this former onecrop cotton empire of the Old South.

There is better reason than ever why the Metropolitan Opera should make an appeal as it does for financial help. With the enlargement of the media at its disposal through both radio and television it becomes as never before a truly national institution. It belongs not merely to New York and its opera-goers but to the whole people of this country.
LOS ANGELES -- Local boosters are eagerly awaiting Federal statistics expected to confirm indications that Los Angeles has nosed out Philadelphia as the nation's fourth-ranking manufacturing area.

ATHENS -- As a result of last November's elections, held on the majority system, Greece for the first time since the war has a Government with sufficient homogeneous parliamentary backing to enable it to take drastic and even unpopular measures for the nation's rehabilitation.
Rome -- In the first nine months of 1952, Italy had a trade deficit of more than $700,000,000 with the deficit for the whole year projected at more than $800,000,000.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- A State Department aide refused tonight to comment on reports from London that the British Cabinet would meet tomorrow to consider terms of an agreement on the Iranian oil issue worked out between Loy Henderson, United States Ambassador in Teheran, and Premier Mohammed Mossadegh.
The trustees of Columbia University named Dr. Grayson L. Kirk yesterday to succeed Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the President-elect of the United States, as president of the university.

Prices closed lower yesterday on the New York commodity exchanges with most futures showing better volume than during the holidays. Lead, rubber, zinc, coffee, cottonseed oil and soybean oil closed lower. Cocoa was the only commodity to show a gain. Potatoes, sugar, wool and hides closed irregular.

The Reserve Mining Company, an industrial venture owned jointly by Republic Steel Corporation and Armco Steel Corporation and set up to mine the little-touched taconite mother rock of the Mesabi iron range by a new process, has borrowed $148,000,000 privately from major life insurance companies to finance construction of the necessary plant.
PARIS -- France's social security system has improved its position in the past year but shows a deficit of 30,000,000,000 francs, a fact that has motivated a movement for a widespread reform.

The New York Curb Exchange yesterday became the American Stock Exchange amid exhortations from Harry A. McDonald to get out and fight for changes in the Securities Act of 1933 and the Securities Exchange Act of 1934.
Carl Haverlin, president of Broadcast Music, Inc., and chairman of the Young Composers Radio Awards - competition, announced yesterday the national winners of the 1952 awards.

Domestic steel production is continuing to hold the fast pace reestablished following the long strike last summer. Output this week is expected to be 2,213,000 net tons of ingots and steel for castings, compared with actual production of 2,226,000 tons last week, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute.

BEIRUT, Lebanon -- The issue of Lebanese liberalism versus Syrian autarchy will be clearly joined when the plenipotentiaries of Syria and Lebanon meet, presumably within the next few weeks, to renegotiate the one-year trade agreement of Feb. 4, 1952.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Jan. 6 -- Fourteen B-29 Superforts from Okinawa and Japan struck near the North Korean capital of Pyongyang late yesterday, bombing a Communist military staff headquarters and a 100-acre supply storage area on the outskirts of the city.

The fourteenth president of Columbia University, who will be its head for the bicentennial celebration next year, joined the faculty less than thirteen years ago. Until then he was simply Grayson L. Kirk, Professor of Political Science at the University of Wisconsin. Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler named him associate Professor of Government at the restitution on Morningside Heights.

Kansas State, winner of the Big Seven Conference tournament, took over second place yesterday in the United Press college basketball ratings, closing in on Illinois, which was ranked No. 1 for the fifth week in a row.

Republican leaders have agreed, according to Washington reports, that they "cannot promise too much too soon," and that although they would like to reduce taxes any action of that kind must wait on a balancing of the budget.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 5 -- Dr. Andrew M. Gleason, 31-year-old Harvard University mathematician, said today that two other men were entitled to share the credit, widely given him alone, for having solved an important abstract problem in the realm of pure mathematics.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Jan. 5 -- Fourteen of fifteen defendants accused of conspiring to set up a military dictatorship leading to a Communist state were convicted and sentenced today by a special tribunal in Hyderabad.
HACKENSACK, N. J., Jan. 5 -- The special Bergen County grand jury will reopen tomorrow its investigation into political tie-ups with criminals.

NEW DELHI, India -- India's immediate economic situation brightened in 1952 as the Government of Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru, its confidence confirmed by an overwhelming victory in the country's first general elections by universal adult suffrage, attacked its problems resourcefully and with strength.

NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 5 -- Clement Attlee, Labor Opposition leader in the British House of Commons, said here today he did not favor the idea of socialism in Asia developing into a "third force" in international politics.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 5 (UP) -- Lloyd Mangrum fired a 1-under-par 70 today to win the $20,000 Los Angeles open golf tournament, the third time he has captured the event that traditionally opens the winter tournament season.

PARIS, Jan. 5 -- The habitual French fear that any high-level intimacy between London and Washington means that Britain has an axe to grind at France's expense was reflected in comments here today on the visit of Prime Minister Churchill to President-elect Dwight D. Eisenhower.

As pretty a spring collection as one would like to see was offered by Emme yesterday at the Pierre Hotel. Influenced by the coming coronation, she turned to the period of England's first Queen Elizabeth, bringing forth a number of enchanting little shapes adapted from the hats and headdresses of the ladies and gentlemen of that monarch's court.
The 1952 Shelley Memorial Award, which carries a stipend of about $800 a year, has been awarded to Elizabeth Bishop of Rio de Janeiro, it was announced yesterday by the Poetry Society of America.

MADRID -- Favorable weather conditions enabled Spain to attain self-sufficiency for the second successive year in almost all basic agricultural foodstuffs in 1952. As a result, the Government last April abolished ration cards for the first time since the outbreak of the Civil War in 1936.

The first defeat sustained by Jonathan Penrose in the international chess masters' tournament at Hastings, England, came in the sixth round yesterday when he was beaten by Henry Golembek, former British champion, in 44 moves, according to a report from London.

HONG KONG -- After a weak start and a developing depression in the first six months, British Hong Kong's entrepot economy recovered somewhat in the second half of 1952 to complete a spotty year in which the final trade looked reasonably good and the future loomed uncertain as ever.

The visiting British Prime Minister, who has deplored Soviet Iron Curtain policies in Europe, was met here yesterday with a journalistic sally about the screening processes of the McCarran Immigration Act here.
PARIS -- What is called the integration of Western Europe, a cardinal aim of United States policy, made one notable advance in 1952 and some theoretical gains, but also suffered notable setbacks.

CAIRO -- The new regime in Egypt already has begun to encounter economic and financial difficulties, many of which are the legacy of past mismanagement and greed, while others are the result of overpopulation.
The full weight of the five-day-old bus strike descended on the subways yesterday and they swallowed it with no dislocation of their steel plates or the ribs of their longsuffering passengers.

WASHINGTON -- When 1952 ended, President Truman's "bold new" Point Four program for helping under-developed areas was a lusty two-and-a-half-year-old, whose guardians spoke proudly of the past and expected much of the future.
Decorative shoes pointed the way to spring in Delman's new shoe collection shown yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. Their new look emphasized the feminine trend of the coming season.

CHICAGO, Jan. 5 -- Buying at the opening here today of the International Home Furnishings Market was satisfactory, but far below pre - market predictions. There was considerable "shopping" although some smaller furniture stores placed a substantial amount of limited quantity orders.

WASHINGTON -- A decisive Republican victory at the polls and a phrase coined by Britain's Chancellor of the Exchequer have already changed the pattern and extent of United States foreign aid. In a nutshell, there will be less of it from now on and what there is will be tied as closely as can be with Chancellor R. A. Butler's appeal for solvency through "trade, not aid."
JEDDA, Saudi Arabia -- Oil-rich King Ibn Saud, with another year's accumulation of royalty checks in hand, looks forward to the day when his desert kingdom will be as modern as any in the world.
Robert E. Preyor Jr. is serving a fifteen-year term for burglary in the Columbus, Ohio, penitentiary. The bars and gates, however, did not prevent him from stealing again -- this time a book.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 5 -- Twentieth Century-Fox will shoot the works budgetwise on a program of seven big-scale undertakings in Technicolor costing "more than $20,000,000."

Harry Gallatin's rebounding and Carl Braun's outside pop-shooting have earned the New York Knickerbocker players berths on the Eastern All-Star team that will oppose the Western group in the National Basketball Association's third annual classic a week from tonight at Fort Wayne, Ind. President Maurice Podoloff of the N. B. A. yesterday announced the complete personnel of both squads.

MEXICO CITY, Jan. 5 -- With the government of President Adolfo Ruiz Cortines firmly established, the way is cleared for Mexico and the United States to reopen negotiation on five important agreements when the Eisenhower Administration takes office Jan. 20.

Beatrice Martin, a young though firmly established milliner, believes strongly in the youthful flattery of the small silhouette. In her spring collection, shown yesterday at 16 West Fifty-seventh Street, she gave it almost endless variety, turning forth liltingly pretty cloches, pillboxes, bonnets, coifs and sailors, all stamped with her imaginative use of color and trim.
Federal Judge Irving R. Kaufman granted yesterday a "limited" stay of execution to Julius and Ethel Rosenberg, wartime atom spies, to permit them to apply to President Truman for clemency.

VIENNA -- The year 1952 was trying for the Austrian economy and there was every indication at its close that 1953 might be worse. The decline in United States aid, coinciding with a recession in world markets, revealed a number of weak spots in Austria's financial and economic set-up.

With the declaration that he would continue to slide into third base, even in exhibition games, Monte Irvin yesterday signed his 1953 contract with the Giants. It was a fractured ankle, suffered in a pre-season contest against the Indians at Denver last April 2, that kept the hard-hitting outfielder out of action until July 27 of the 1952 campaign.

BRUSSELS, Belgium -- Belgium has set into operation a Bureau for Increasing Productivity, which will try to introduce better human relations, scientific organization, marketing research and psychology in industry. Technical missions sent to the United States under the technical assistance program, say those are the elements responsible for American productivity being two and one-half to three times as high as Belgium's, not better equipment or machinery.

James Wyer of the University Club, seeded fourth, was among the victors as play in the seventeenth annual New York State squash racquets singles championship began last night at the Downtown Athletic Club. Wyer put out C.A. Sullivan Jr., New York A. C., 15 -- 3, 15-9, 17-15.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y. -- Efforts by the United Nations and its affiliated specialized agencies to strengthen and expand the economies of the under-developed countries of the world were stepped up and broadened during the last year.

NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 5 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru stressed today the urgent need for the nations of the world to cultivate a greater measure of "toleration toward one another." The world of today, he declared, has become devoid of the spirit of putting up with one another in spite of disagreement.

BONN, Germany, Jan. 5 -- The West German steel and coal industries are planning post-war production records this year. The goals for steel and coal reflect a determination to give the Federal Republic undisputed industrial leadership in Western Europe in the shortest possible time.

The striking bus workers are seeking a forty-hour week with no cut in the pay they used to get for working forty-four to forty-eight hours, with five to nine hours of guaranteed overtime. The old basic wage ranged from $1.66 to $1.73 1/2 an hour.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden -- After the exceptional export boom and the consequent inflationary repercussions that characterized the Swedish economy in 1951, there was a gradual recession in most fields of activity in the course of 1952. The decline was most conspicuous in exports.

LONDON -- For Britain the New Year began with a slightly improved economic outlook. The huge deficits in her balance of trade with the rest of the world that were draining away the gold reserves supporting sterling had begun to turn by the end of September into small but reassuring surpluses.
Steel-producing capacity in the United States increased by 8,959,800 tons during 1952, the largest gain ever achieved in a year, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

ALBANY, Jan. 5 -- Governor Dewey will have full control over all Federal patronage coming to New York State under the new National Administration. A program to this effect, worked out by William L. Pfeiffer, the Republican State Chairman, will be submitted to the Republican State Executive Committee tomorrow for ratification.
ANKARA, Turkey -- Turkey, which until a few years ago was considered in most senses a backward country, today is a forward-looking, developing nation.

CHICAGO, Jan. 5 -- Carl Sandburg returned today to the city he helped make famous as the "hog butcher for the world." He will celebrate his seventy-fifth birthday here tomorrow. The poet-historian and his wife, Lillian, arrived from their home in Flat Rock, N. C.

RANGOON, Burma -- Government military successes against the Communists and other insurgent groups in Burma during 1952 provided the basis for a general improvement in economic conditions. National production is estimated to have increased by 5 per cent.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 (AP) -- The Bureau of Mines forecast today that domestic demand for gasoline will be 5.5 per cent higher this year than last.

The threat of a port-wide strike by longshoremen receded yesterday as three small locals of the International Longshoremen's Association, A. F. L., removed their ban on the movement of all bulk cargo, except sugar, from local piers.

JAKARTA, Indonesia -- The Indonesian Republic in 1953 faces its most critical economic test since the transfer of sovereignty into Indonesian hands three years ago. "This past year has been critical," Finance Minister Sumitro, a Socialist said recently, "But the new year is the year of crisis."
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y. -- A survey of world production of ten basic raw materials at the end of 1952 has indicated significant shifts in comparison with 1951 records.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 5 (AP) -- Stan (The Man) Musial walked into the St. Louis Cardinals office today, sat down with owner Fred Saigh, named his price and that was it -- his 1953 player contract was signed.

Notre Dame's basketball team, heralded as the best the Fighting Irish have had since 1946, drops in for its annual visit to New York at Madison Square Garden tonight, opposing New York University for the nineteenth straight year. The preliminary game, starting at 7:45, will send Iona of New Rochelle against King's of Wilkes-Barre, Pa.

CAIRO, Jan. 5 -- The eighty-ton Egyptian cargo steamship Samir, valued at 12,000 Egyptian (about $35,000), has been captured by Israeli authorities, according to an announcement today by the Palestine Department of the Egyptian Foreign Ministry.

Because of a lack of coal and oil deposits, Norway has pushed development of hydroelectric power and appliances for its use to the extent that she may soon be able to begin export of all-electric heating units for homes, according to the Norwegian Export Council.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 (AP) -- The Air Force said today its procurement specialists will explain to operators of small businesses at meetings in twenty-seven cities on Jan. 14 how they can get Air Force contracts.

Inspiration buds ever-fresh in the active mind of Sally Victor. For her spring millinery collection she turned to the Fauvists, that noted group of painters recently represented in a showing at the Museum of Modern Art. From them she took their dynamic colorings.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 (AP) -- The Department of Commerce estimated today that United States exports in November totaled about $1,187,000,000, slightly less than the October total of $1,191,000,000 and about 5 per cent below the monthly average of exports in the first three quarters of the year.

OSLO, Norway -- The Norwegian economy retained its high level during 1952, although some industries were affected adversely by the world market price decline -- particularly the important forest industries.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- The State Department said today that this Government was not considering a plan for the withdrawal of American and British troops from the Free Territory of Trieste and for dividing the disputed territory between Italy and Yugoslavia.

TOKYO, Jan. 5 -- South Korean President Syngman Rhee, accompanied by his wife and top military officials, arrived in Tokyo today for a "couple of days" as the guest of United Nations Commander, General Mark W. Clark.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 5 -- One hundred nine of Baltimore's 170 public schools were closed today for lack of heat as the five-day-old strike of city laborers affected the school system at the reopening after the Christmas vacation.

LONDON -- Britain lived throughout 1952 with one of the most baffling political and economic puzzles of the post-war period, the problem of Iranian oil. At the end of the year there was still no solution in sight.

Julius A. Archibald, the first Negro to become a member of the State Senate, was sworn in yesterday by State Supreme Court Justice Benjamin F. Schreiber in a ceremony at the Criminal Courts Building. Senator Archibald, an attorney who lives at 320 Convent Avenue, will represent the Twenty-first District.

GENEVA -- Nineteen fifty-two was a discouraging yearfor all who belieeve the free world's prosperity depends on steady expansion of international trade. It was also an exasperating year for business men who try make goods move despite a constantly changing web of restrictions and unstable conditions generally.

TUCSON, Ariz., Jan. 5 -- A young aircraft worker was rescued today after his first attempt at mountain climbing had left him marooned, thinly clad in sub-freezing temperatures, on a narrow ledge in the Santa Catalina Mountains.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands -- A growing number of American industries are finding the Dutch "industrial climate" highly suitable for the establishment of subsidiaries or for entering into working agreements with Dutch factories.

BAGHDAD, Iraq -- Last year was the most important in Iraq's history in terms of economics. An agreement with the Iraq Petroleum Company for a 50-per-cent sharing of profits before foreign taxes came into effect and the 34-inch Kirkuk-Banyas pipeline went into operation to carry Iraq oil to the Mediterranean.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 (AP) -- The Reclamation Bureau today outlined to Congress a proposed seven-year reclamation construction program estimated to cost $3,870,000,000.

ROCQUENCOURT, France, Jan. 5 -- Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway said today that North Atlantic Treaty Organization ground troops in Europe, including five United States divisions in West Germany, would suffer "grievous blows" if war were to break out with the Soviet Union within the next twelve to eighteen months.

UTICA, N. Y., Jan 5 (AP) -- Federal Judge Stephen W. Brennan today granted a temporary injunction against picketing and striking in a labor dispute at a secret atomic submarine project near West Milton, N. Y.

CHICAGO, Jan. 5 -- Plans to rush the Government's case against the du Ponts to completion in a fraction of the expected time were disclosed today as trial of the anti-trust suit was resumed in Federal District Court.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- It appeared more likely today that the first test of Senator Robert A. Taft's leadership of Senate Republicans might hang on a decision, soon to be forced, on which Senate committee should be assigned to investigate communism broadly.

HONG KONG -- After having completed a preliminary three- year program aimed at restoring its dislocated economy of China and catching up with pre-war production levels, the Peiping Government began preparations in mid-1952 for the introduction of the country's first five-year industrialization plan in 1953.

Exports of meat from Australia during fiscal 1952-53 are expected to have a value approaching three times that of the 1951-52 year, according to the Australian News and Information Bureau in New York. Estimates of the expected 1952-1953 exports of frozen lamb, mutton and beef show a total value of about $41,255,000, compared with $15,944,500 for the preceding year.

Your timely editorial entitled "A Mismanaged City" was a clarion call to all citizens to join ranks and unite in the cause of good government. There will, I believe, be a great response throughout the city by the great majority of our citizens who feel that conditions in our city government have become intolerable.

Western Germany must maintain a "fairly large" balance of payments surplus if it is to meet the terms of the agreements on its external debt obligations, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reports in its monthly Review to be issued today.
BRUSSELS, Belgium -- A struggle, largely successful, against inflationary tendencies characterized Belgium's national finances last year.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- President Truman today made public a letter from Roy V. Peel, Director of the Census Bureau, who submitted data that Mr. Truman said showed "so graphically the wonderful economic conditions of the United States."

Total resources of The National City Bank of New York at the end of 1952 amounted to $6,117,115,200, according to the bank's quarterly statement of condition, to be published today. This compares with $5,888,906,767 on Sept. 30 and $5,909,863,665 on Dec. 31, 1951.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands -- There is no better illustration of the improvement of monetary conditions in the Netherlands than a comparison of the gold and foreign exchange reserves at the beginning of 1952 with those at the beginning of last month.

A high school student who has just taken his first job was among the eighty-six contributors donating $1,096.30 yesterday to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. These gifts brought the fund total to date to $375,827.61 and the number of donors to 11,697.
TOKYO -- Japan's textile industry, once this nation's best hope as an earner of foreign currencies, has entered a slump that has both business and Government circles deeply concerned.

The United States contract bridge team of Howard Schenken, B. Jay Becker, Samuel Stayman, Theodore Lightner and George Rapee, all of New York, with John R. Crawford of Philadelphia, striving for its third successive world title, got off to a strong start yesterday afternoon in the 1953 Team of Four World Championships.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa -- Despite mounting racial tensions, the physical volume of economic activity in the Union of South Africa continued to expand during 1951-52, but the rate of increase slowed down substantially compared with 1950-51 and with the annual rate during the period 1945-51.

VIENNA -- Austria's exports decreased 9 per cent by volume and increased almost 12 per cent by value during the first nine months of 1952 compared with the same period in 1951. The dollar figure was $367,000,000, compared with $328,000,000.

PARIS -- France made a serious effort to clear up her economic and financial situation during 1952, but no decisive action was taken to stabilize prices and the currency. The difficult task of putting France again into step with the modern world was demonstrated by the fall of the Cabinet of Premier Antoine Pinay.

KARACHI, Pakistan -- After a promising beginning with an abundance of exportable cash crops, the five-year-old state of Pakistan in the past year careened onto dangerous economic ground as a consequence of a series of adverse developments.
TOKYO, Tuesday, Jan. 6 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique for the twenty-four hours ended at 6 A. M., Tuesday, Korean time:

LONDON -- There can be no doubt that rearmament has strained Britain's economy in the last two years. The Government's decision to modify the three-year goals set by the North Atlantic Treaty Organization in 1951 for British arms production was a frank admission of the danger of spending too rapidly on armament.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands -- The Amsterdam Stock Exchange was dull and inactive during the greater part of last year. The public and operators continued their stand-offish attitude toward stocks, except for the short period in which United States interests actively bought Royal Dutch on the Amsterdam bourse.

ROME -- Since the beginning of May, 1952, the situation of the Italian Treasury has become appreciably more difficult. In the five months from April 30 to Sept. 30, the net debt of the Treasury to the Bank of Italy increased by 164,700,000,000 lire ($263,520,000).

HELSINKI, Finland -- Business trends in Finland during 1952 were influenced sharply by the severe slump in the export markets for timber, pulp and paper, which account for about 90 per cent of the country's total foreign trade.

Spokesmen for twenty-one railway labor organizations met here briefly yesterday with representatives of the nation's railroads to set the stage for public discussion of wage rises, based on greater output a man-hour, for 1,250,000 operating and non-operating employes.

Representative members of the worlds of society, finance and the arts attended the entertainment known as the Duchess of Windsor's Ball held last night in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria for the benefit of the Hospitalized Veterans Music Service.

THE redhead, which with the canvasback is considered by the gourmet to be something special in waterfowl, with or without special sauces, appeared in greater numbers this season in several northern areas, and a report from the Outer Banks indicates that these birds have staged a real come-back in that area.

ATHENS -- Interest rates on loans in Greece range up to 16 per cent a year, although agricultural credit may be obtained on lower terms. The high rates reflect a lack of savings. The present Government is committed to encourage private business initiative as it is to limitations of credit and to closing the gap between exports and imports.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 (AP) -- The National Labor Relations Board has dismissed the C. I. O. American Newspaper Guild's charges that The Arkansas Gazette Publishing Company at Little Rock had engaged in unfair labor practices.
Lieut. Gen. Withers A. Burress formally took command of Army forces in the eight-state First Army area yesterday in ceremonies on Governors Island.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand -- The year 1952 was one of considerable difficulty in New Zealand because of the need to restrict imports. This country, in common with other British Commonwealth nations, had been living beyond its income, and there had been a rapid dissipation of sterling funds, in spite of swollen receipts from the sale of wool and all other primary products.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 (UP) -- A Federal judge postponed for a week today the enforcement of a National Labor Relations Board ruling requiring eleven officers of three labor unions to reaffirm their non-Communist oaths.

The Minneapolis-Moline Company, manufacturer of agricultural implements and related power machinery, attained the largest sales volume in its history with a total of $92,548,332, but earnings declined, according to the annual report issued yesterday.
BONN, Germany -- The emergence of Federal Germany as a strong and vigorous competitor for world markets probably was the most important economic development in the West German republic last year.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (AP) -- The long - pending proposal for merger of United Paramount Theatres, Inc., and the American Broadcasting Company was finally taken under advisement by the Federal Communications Commission tonight.

JAKARTA, Indonesia -- West Germany, making a strong bid to regain Germany's pre-war Far Eastern trade, is concentrating on Indonesia as its biggest Asian customer. Trade relations in 1952 were strengthened by an agreement to exchange ambassadors.

PARIS, Jan. 5 -- Rene Mayer, Radical party leader, announced tonight that he would seek endorsement as Premier from the French National Assembly during tomorrow's debate, which is expected to hang mainly on the issue of revision of the European Defense Community treaty.

The memory of a generous-hearted American musician, Frederick Jacobi, who died in October, was saluted last night at Town Hall by Thomas Scherman and his Little Orchestra Society. The observance was appropriate and sensitive.

Trade and industry in the metropolitan area appeared yesterday to have emerged virtually unaffected from the first normal work day of the five-day-old strike on the private bus lines. Community life also seemed only slightly disturbed.

BONN, Germany -- Alone among the economies of Western Europe, that of the Federal Republic has been relatively untroubled by either labor disturbances or the convulsions of internal politics. Periodically, there have been predictions that this condition was about to end, and this appears more certain in 1953 than at any time since establishment of West German Government.

The Public Service Commission announced yesterday that it had authorized the Consolidated Edison Company of New York to convert the Riverdale-Marble Hill area in the Bronx and Manhattan from manufactured to natural gas. It is expected that work on the changeover will begin immediately.
ZURICH, Switzerland -- Never since the compilation of statistics on tourism in Switzerland began has the Swiss hotel industry in any summer had so many guests from other countries as in 1952.

MELBOURNE, Australia -- General business and financial activity in Australia during 1952 was influenced by four main factors: drastic restrictions on imports, stabilization of the wool market following sharp price declines, a marked increase in United States investment in Australian industry, and the policy of desocialization pursued by the Commonwealth Government.

Neither the State and Justice Departments nor United States Attorney Myles J. Lane tried to suppress a Federal grand jury presentment that was critical of employment of disloyal Americans at the United Nations, according to one of the members of the grand jury.
TEL AVIV, Israel -- The "new economic policy," unveiled in Israel early in 1952, had an immediate objective of halting inflation and a long-term aim of increasing production.

TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 5 (AP) -- Premier Mohammed lVfossadegh in a fiery broadcast tonight accused recalcitrant Deputies of trying to weaken his Government and demanded a vote of confidence by Parliament tomorrow.

ALBANY, Jan. 5 -- Two units of the New York National Guard -- one of them a crack military police company from Mount Vernon -- will take part in the inaugural parade for Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower in Washington on Jan. 20.

LISBON, Portugal -- Portugal and her colonies will put into operation in 1953 a bold six-year development plan involving the expenditure of 13,500,000,000 escudos ($470,000,000). The plan aims to make Portugal's economy more self-contained.
TOKYO -- Japan's merchant marine, once the third greatest in the world, is restoring itself rapidly after its virtual erasure by Allied air and naval power in the Pacific war.
TOKYO -- Japan's economy in 1952 was heavily bolstered by United States buying for the Korean war, but the country at the year end faced many problems, internal and external.

MANILA, Tuesday, Jan. 6 -- The impatient rejection by President Elpidio Quirino of a Mutual Security Agency report on rural backwardness in the Philippines set off a Congessional movement today for a formal protest to the United States Government.

CHICAGO, Jan. 5 -- Wheat futures prices crashed to new lows today, and influenced sharp declines in other grains. Genera indifference on the part of buyers seemed to be the main reason for lower prices, and support which caused temporary small rallies was attributed mainly to profit-taking by shorts.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 (AP) -- Last month Archie Moore took away Joey Maxim's light-heavyweight title on a decision. Today the National Boxing Association, in its quarterly ratings, dropped Maxim all the way down to a ranking as an "outstanding boxer."

SINGAPORE -- Like most Southeast Asian territories producing basic tropical raw materials, Malaya during 1952 experienced a sharp recession in the value of exports. This caused a generally depressing effect on business activity and likewise confronted Governments with diminished revenues.

While spending billions to prosecute the war against the communists in North Korea, the United Nations may find they are losing a "second war" in South Korea, Dr. Charles R. Joy, minister, author and international relief expert, warned yesterday upon his return from a year's work in Korea.
J. A. Warren, assistant general traffic manager of the Railway Express Agency, has been appointed assistant to the vice president in charge of administration and finance.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- President Truman received and personally congratulated today the members of his Commission on Immigration and Naturalization. At the same time, he deplored what he called the "personal vituperation and slander" aimed at the commission since it submitted its recent report urging a revision of the McCarran Immigration and Nationality Act.

Martin P. Durkin, Secretary of Labor-designate, should be confirmed by the Senate, John L. Lewis said here yesterday upon his return from South America. The president of the United Mine Workers, reminded of the objections raised by Senator Robert A. Taft to Mr. Durkin's selection by General Dwight D. Eisenhower, the President-elect, said that Senator Taft was opposed to any bona fide representative of labor serving in the Cabinet.
TOKYO, Jan. 5 -- During the past few days a considerable number of United States troops have been replaced on the front lines in Korea by soldiers of the Republic of Korea's Army.

WHITE PLAINS, Jan. 5 -- James D. Hopkins, North Castle supervisor, was re-elected chairman of the Westchester Board of Supervisors today at the annual reorganization meeting. He is a Republican and received twenty-eight votes defeating John E. Tobin of Yonkers, Democratic minority leader of the board, who received five.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- A food chain official said today that housewives had only themselves to blame if retail prices of steaks and roasts had not followed the downward trend of the cattle market.

Former Army Sgt. John David Provoo, on trial for treason in Federal Court as a result of his alleged acts after the fall of Corregidor in 1942, was pictured by defense witnesses yesterday as having been a patriotic and gentlemanly soldier, often considerate of his fellow prisoners.

BERLIN, Jan. 5 -- Maj. Gen. Thomas S. Timberman took over today as the United States Commander in Berlin, replacing Maj. Gen. Lemuel Mathewson, who had held the post for two years. General Mathewson left to take a new Army post at Orleans, France.

BONN, West Germany, Jan. 5 -- Final passage of the Allied-German treaties through the Bundestag, an indispensable step in the integration of an armed Germany in Europe, cannot now be expected until the end of February.

When an apparently simple solution of an old and complicated problem comes along it is safe to feel that something is wrong. The story out of Belgrade suggesting that the Allies cut the Gordian knot by dividing the Free Territory of Trieste permanently into Italian and Yugoslav zones along the present lines of occupation, withdrawing American and British troops, looks easy and reasonable.

What is described as the biggest and best grape harvest in half a century is being distilled by the French cognac producers. This is reported by I. M. Bomba, chairman of the special cognac committee of the National Association of Alcoholic Beverage Importers, speaking for the French National Association of Cognac Producers.

Arthur Schwartz, president of the League of New York Theatres, asserted yesterday that the association of theatre owners, managers and operators "stands strongly behind any move" to obtain new theatres for New York. He made the statement after a meeting with Councilman Hugh Quinn in connection with approval of building code amendments that would liberalize construction and operation of Broadway legitimate theatres.

In 1912, the year during which Adolph Ochs instituted the Hundred Neediest Cases, the circulation of the daily TIMES was 220,139, the Sunday TIMES 158,539. This year our daily circulation is over a half million and our Sunday figure over a million. Percentage-wise this represents an increase in one case of more than 100 per cent, in the other of more than 500 per cent.

If the choice of Dr. Grayson Kirk to be the next president of Columbia University is not exactly surprising it is none the less gratifying. The university has availed itself of the opportunity to make even wider use of his distinguished services. His election also recognizes his unusual merit and sets something of a crowning stamp on his splendid career.
AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands -- During 1952 no further progress was made in achieving the Benelux economic union. The difficulties, however, were of a different kind from those of 1951.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- Average primary market prices rose 0.1 per cent in the week ended on last Tuesday, Dec. 30, to 109.6 per cent of the 1947-49 average, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. Farm products advanced 0.1 per cent, largely because of higher prices for fresh fruits (especially citrus fruits), hogs, lambs, live poultry and copra.
CAIRO, Jan. 5 -- The British Embassy in Cairo announced today that another 10,000,000 (28,000,000) of Egypt's blocked sterling balances in London had been released last Friday.
ROME -- The constant progress that the Italian economy has made since the end of the war, and especially since the Marshall Plan went into effect early in 1948, was not continued in 1952.

Overcoming his rival's greater experience with the fury of his attack, Marvin Edelman, 159 1/2 pounds, Philadelphia, last night won his twenty-ninth straight ring victory by outpointing Charley Williams, 155, Newark, in a savage ten-round bout at the Eastern Parkway Arena in Brooklyn.

TOKYO, Jan. 5 -- A United States military court rejected today a challenge to its jurisdiction by defense counsel for an American woman charged with the premeditated murder of her husband, an Army colonel, in Tokyo three months ago.

The Treasury Department in Washington has suggested to R. K. Christenberry, president of the Broadway Association, that there may be, after all, some hope for saving Grand Central Palace, scheduled to be rented to the Internal Revenue Bureau for office space.

PARIS -- French foreign trade in 1952 was marked by a substantial drop in exports, which were lower than in 1951, to the dollar zone, the sterling zone and Western Europe. Although exports attained a higher level than in 1938 ($104,300,000 monthly average), French sales to foreign countries did not reach the monthly level of 1929 ($214,400,000).

TEL AVIV, Israel, Jan. 5 -- Dr. Chaim Yahil, deputy chief of Israel's Reparations Corporation, will depart by air for Bonn tomorrow with instructions from his Government to "see to it that there are no further delays in the ratification of the reparations agreement" with West Germany.
BANGKOK, Thailand, Jan. 5 -- A new effort to increase and improve the production, storage and marketing of the world's rice was launched here today.

A continuation, and even an increase, in the high volume of advertising placed last year is seen for 1953 by the heads of two influential associations in the field, as well as by officials of two of the larger agencies.

JAKARTA, Indonesia -- While many of Indonesia's leaders have publicly come out in favor of allowing foreign investments, the country's press and jingo nationalist political parties have continued a year-long campaign against foreign capital. On four occasions last year the Indonesian Government announced that it was formulating a foreign investment act that would erase fears among foreigners and which would outline protections and inducements for investors.

Undoubtedly the winters now are warmer than they used to be. Anyone in the region of middle age will know this, and will cite as authority his own recollection, naturally unshaded by the passage of time. The long, cold winters of yesterday come through memory with the clear, cold flame of truth, like the equations of an exact science.
PARIS -- The fact that the French Line has regained second place for the number of passengers carried on the North Atlantic is a matter of pride to Jean Marie, president of the company.

JAKARTA, Indonesia -- The specter of a soaring island population is growing in Indonesia. The Republic, the largest Islamic nation in the world, has an estimated population of 80,000,000. Fifty million persons are crowded together on the small island of Java.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Jan. 5 -- Vice Premier Prawoto, in his capacity of Acting Defense Minister, announced today the Government had rejected the resignation of the Acting Army Chief of Staff, Col. Bambang Sugeng, who resigned last Saturday after his appointment of a Seventh Divisional commander had been overruled by the Cabinet.
An East Harlem fruit peddler wound up his business yesterday with the biggest and best plum of all for himself.

DUBLIN -- The most heartening development in Ireland's economy last year was the steady improvement in the country's balance of trade. The big excess of imports over exports gradually has been narrowing, and figures for the first ten months of 1952 give hope that the national account on external trade soon will be leveled.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 (AP) -- Charles E. Shaver, former general counsel of the Senate Small Business Committee, admitted in court today that he had accepted three payments of $500 each from firms seeking loans from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.

VIENNA -- Austria realized $27,253,500 from foreign travel during the first eight months of 1952, or nearly $6,000,000 more than in the same period of 1951. Her total tourist receipts for 1952 may reach $30,000,000, a post-war record.

AMSTERDAM, Netherlands -- Taxation in the Netherlands has apparently touched the ceiling. There is a great controversy whether the surplus on the ordinary budget service is to be used for covering part of the deficit on the extraordinary service and the capital service (as proposed by the Government) or for reducing taxation. The former method will probably be adopted.
ZURICH, Switzerland -- Developments of prime significance occurred in the financial affairs of Switzerland in 1952.

The six-story store and office building at 16 East Forty-first Street has been sold by Mitchel Fein and Jack Nunberg to an investing customer of Douglas L. Elliman Co., brokers in the transaction. The sellers were represented by Walter Scott Co.
SEOUL, Korea -- The national economy of South Korea today might be likened to a flower garden in the wake of a steamroller. There is little left but the roots.

Goalie Chuck Rayner of the Rangers sustained a sprained ligament in his right knee during last Sunday's 5-2 National Hockey League triumph over Boston and will be lost to the team for at least two games, it was disclosed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- The advance guard of some 1,500 delegates to the forty-seventh annual six-day convention of the National Collegiate Athletic Association and affiliated organizations met here today in preliminary sessions preparatory to tackling the major agenda.

A prediction that the Territory of Hawaii would be admitted as the forty-ninth state "at a reasonably early date" was made yesterday by a delegation of four Republican Senators after a conference with Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the President-elect.

Dr. Channing H. Tobias, director of the Phelps-Stokes Fund, was elected chairman of the board of directors of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People at the annual meeting yesterday at 20 West Fortieth Street. Dr. Robert C. Weaver, director of opportunity fellowships of the John Hay Whitney Foundation, was elected vice chairman.

TAIPEI, Formosa -- A new element of stability was introduced into the Formosa economic picture last year as the Chinese Nationalist budget approached balance and rising prices began to taper off in the second quarter.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Jan. 5 (AP) -- How, 5-year-old mare owned by Herman B. Delman, captured the featured Lafayette Purse at Tropical Park today, coming from far off the pace to make the grade under a strong ride by Apprentice Ronnie Wilson.

The five-story store and apartment building at 1045 Union Street, corner of Franklin Avenue, in Brooklyn has been sold by David S. Meister, real estate owner and operator, to a group of investors represented by Saul C. Kaufman. attorney.

In 1952 the economy of the Eastern European satellites of the Soviet Union presented a confused and contradictory picture as boasts of rapid production increases alternated with denunciations of "saboteurs" and admissions of strain and weaknesses. Over all, however, it seemed clear that in 1952 the satellite bloc as a whole set new production records in heavy industry and increased substantially its actual and potential contribution to total world Communist military-economic strength.

Oil production aboard last year set another new peak despite the fact that the wells in Iran remained closed. Outside the Iron Curtain total foreign output in 1952 averaged almost 5,000,000 barrels daily. This contrasted with 4,632,000 barrels a day in 1951.

Shipmasters will be required to supply a record of the movements and ports of call of their vessels for a full three months prior to entering the waters of the Canal Zone under a new set of regulations issued by J. S. Seybold, Governor of the Canal Zone.

DON'T look now, but this is where we came in. Yes, sir. Notre Dame will come whirling into Madison Square Garden tonight to face N. Y. U. for its nineteenth annual appearance in our village. And that brings back basketball to its beginnings at the big arena. A game between the Irish and the Violet in December, 1934, started it all and revolutionized the dribble diversion.

CHICAGO, Jan. 5 -- Traditionalists will get their biggest refresher in many a spring if the offerings at the wholesale International Home Furnishings Market currently in session here are any indication of what is to come. For, in contrast to the overwhelming interest in modern apparent the last few years it would appear there are now more new offerings of period pieces than of contemporary designs.

ALBANY, Jan. 5 -- As a result of election casualties, retirements, deaths and decisions by legislators to run for other offices, the Legislature convening here Wednesday noon for its 176th session will have an unusually large number of new faces.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- The Supreme Court refused today to give an immediate ruling on the constitutionality of the eighty-day strike injunction provision of the Taft-Hartley Act.

Prime Minister Winston Churchill, in a day in which he met Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower as President-elect for the first time, reaffirmed yesterday Great Britain's opposition to any "indefinite extension" of the Korean war into Communist China.

The world has enough iron ore reserves to make 84,000,000,000 net tons of iron, or enough to last 825 years at the current rate of consumption, according to a report on mineral supplies issued recently by the United Nations.
TOKYO -- Japan will wind up 1952 with another whopping, unfavorable foreign trade balance, but with more dollar reserves than virtually any other nation.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa -- On Oct. 8 the first of seventeen gold mines started producing uranium for the United States and British account. The Prime Minister, Dr. Daniel Malan, who set in motion the uranium extraction plant at West Rand Consolidated Mines, said that more than $120,000,000 was being spent in the construction of plants for the extraction of uranium as a by-product of gold mining.
The stock market pushed into new high ground yesterday.

LONDON, Jan. 5 -- Influenced by the dullness of British Government securities, many of the leading industrial shares weakened on the stock markets here today. However, there were several individual good features.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 (AP) -- Representative Sam Rayburn of Texas, dean of all Democrats in Congress, believes his party will be more united now that it is a minority than it was during the almost twenty years it ruled the Government.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands -- The Dutch displayed in 1952 their ability to support their defense burdens without undue economic dislocation. Despite defense spending -- which had not yet reached its peak -- they managed, by constricting public buying power, to end the year with a whopping $525,000,000 surplus in their international payments balance.

ROCQUENCOURT, France -- The year 1952 was one of signal achievement in the creation of collective armed strength throughout the North Atlantic Treaty area -- Western Europe, the Atlantic Ocean and the North American continent.

A warrant is out for the arrest of a former shoe lace peddler who used a Wall Street office to swindle five city street cleaners and their friends and relatives out of nearly $250,000, State Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 (AP) -- Nathaniel Weyl, a confessed former Communist, said today that Alger Hiss was a member of the Communist party in 1933 in a unit composed of various Government officials.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland -- Northern Ireland, hard hit by the slump in textiles in 1952, has strong hopes of a return to an economic equilibrium this year. These are supported by evidence that the industry has passed through the trough of a two-year cycle and, stimulated by the Coronation trade, is about to have another period of relative prosperity.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Jan. 5 -- Dr. W. M. Eiselen, Secretary for Negro Affairs in South Africa's Nationalist Government, announced the broad outline today of a proposal to improve the living conditions and mode of life of Negroes in the urban parts of the country.

The Soviet Union's economy at the end of 1952 was far better prepared for war and stronger in military-economic potential than ever before in that country's history. This was the chief conclusion that emerged last October when Georgi M. Malenkov, one of Premier Stalin's closest colleagues, partially thrust aside the curtain of secrecy that has shrouded the Soviet economy for more than a decade.

The strike against the privately owned bus lines is now in its sixth day. Michael J. Quill has proved what no one doubted -- that he could accomplish a strike as well as threaten one. He has also proved, to his possible dismay, that the public can manage one way or another to get along without the buses.

The Communist party in the United States was depicted yesterday as an independent body working for peace, democracy and economic security, as defense counsel began summing up in the trial of thirteen secondary Communist leaders.

MADRID -- Spain enjoyed last year plentiful crops and greater industrial activity, but the increase in production was not large enough to stem inflation or to redress the continuing deficit in the foreign trade balance.

BOSTON, Jan. 5 (AP) -- Capt. Norbert Lewinski sank two foul shots for Notre Dame with eight seconds left tonight as the Irish gained a 73 -- 71 victory over Holy Cross in the wind-up of a basketball doubleheader witnessed by 12,236 fans in Boston Garden.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- The United States Court of Appeals continued indefinitely today an order restraining the Department of Justice from taking into custody Serge M. Rubinstein, Russian-born financier, against whom deportation proceedings are pending.

Frank Sedgman of Australia, recognized as the world's No. 1 amateur tennis player before he turned professional last week, and Jack Kramer, former United States singles and doubles champion, are to meet in the feature match of next Saturday afternoon's tennis program at Madison Square Garden.

Bill Stern, a sports announcer who has never been heard regularly on any network except the National Broadcasting Company, has been hired as a boxing commentator for a new weekly fight series to be televised over the American Broadcasting Company network beginning Saturday, Jan. 24, at 9 P. M.
REYKJAVIK, Iceland. -- Iceland, striving to carry out a rapid economic development program with the emphasis on diversification, faced three major problems in 1952:

CHICAGO, Jan. 5 -- Homer J. Livingston, chairman of the stock trustees of the Chicago, Indianapolis and Louisville Railway Company (Monon) announced today that "overtures" had been made by the Chicago and Eastern Illinois Railroad Company "looking toward a consolidation" of the Monon and the C. E. I.

Buying activity in New York's wholesale markets went into high gear yesterday with the influx of hundreds of out-of-town merchandise men and women in the second phase of spring apparel purchasing. The peak of spring buying will be reached next week with additional hundreds of retailers coming to New York to attend the annual meeting of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, which begins next Monday.
VIENNA, Jan. 5 -- The largest single project developed in Austria's steel industry under the Marshall Plan was dedicated today by President Theodor Koerner.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- The make-up of the five-man board which Secretary of State Acheson has asked to review the record in the "loyalty" case of John Carter Vincent makes these conclusions reasonably certain:

DUBLIN -- The Republic of Ireland is now prepared to make an all-out effort to earn more dollars through a major drive on exports to the United States, according to an announcement by Sean Lemass, Ministry for Industry and Commerce.
SAIGON, Vietnam, Indo-China -- Tentative moves to achieve some measure of agrarian reform in Vietnam were made by the Vietnamese Government late in 1952.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia -- The economic dependence of the Yugoslav Government on the governments of the United States, Britain and France seems destined to continue.

MANILA -- The Philippines enters 1953 with a balanced budget and an anticipated calendar year surplus in Government revenue now estimated by the Central Bank at $46,500,000. In 1951 the Government had reported a comparative surplus of $39,000,000, turning the corner on a long period of deficit financing.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- President Truman will send to Congress at midday Wednesday his message on the State of the Union. White House spokesmen estimated the message would be 12,000 to 15,000 words and regarded it as one of the longest ever submitted by any President.

BERLIN, Jan. 5 (Reuters) -- A leading official of the Berlin Jewish community said here today that East German attacks on "Zionist agents" had shattered the hope that East Germany would restore Jewish property expropriated under Hitler.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 (AP) -- The Defense Department identified today 95 casualties of the Korean war in two new lists that included 27 killed, 55 wounded, 6 injured in accidents, 3 missing and 4, previously reported missing, now listed as captured by the enemy. The following were listed from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut:

An international business and economic conference, constituting the regular biennial Congress of the International Chamber of Commerce, is scheduled to be held in Vienna from May 18 to 23. One thousand business men from fifty countries, including 150 from the United States, are expected to attend, according to an announcement by the chamber's United States Council.

ROME -- Unemployment, which has been the main Italian problem since the end of World War II has shown signs of recrudescence in the last two years. On Sept. 1, 1952, 2,031,952 men and women were looking for work, compared with 1,880,144 on the same date in 1951, and 1,696,972 in 1950.

The bite taken by a steamshovel out of pavement at the corner of Francis Lewis Boulevard and 130th Avenue, Laurelton, Queens, yesterday afternoon, satisfied hundreds of homeowners who have been the innocent victims of a sewer scandal in that neighborhood.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands -- A year ago the Netherlands was reported to have reached a turning point. Since then it seems as if a miracle has been performed. This has been largely brought about by an orthodox monetary policy, not by quantitative restrictions.

The 1953 national rally of the March of Dimes was officially started yesterday by Mayor Impellitteri on the steps of City Hall with a plea to the public to give the campaign "enthusiastic and generous support."

The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was barely steady yesterday and closing prices were 20 to 45 points net lower than on last Friday on active months, with near months showing the most pronounced weakness.

BONN, Germany -- Some time during the late spring, Federal Germany will become sovereign. Simultaneously the Government will take the first steps toward rearmament within the European Defense Community. The economic consequences of these developments are as important as the political effects.

ROME -- Italian industrial production barely maintained in 1952 the positions it achieved in the boom year of 1951. The index of industrial production in the first nine months of 1952, on the basis of 1938 as 100, was 139 compared with 137 and 116 in the same period of 1951 and 1950, respectively.

In the news item describing the dedication of a Melkite Church in Brooklyn it is stated that the Melkite Church "remained with Rome when what is now the Coptic Church broke away as a result of the Nestorian doctrinal disagreements in 451 A. D."

LONDON -- In the past year a change for the better has taken place in the British Commonwealth's economic circumstances and on the basis of that change an entirely new course for the future has been charted, a course intended to lead the sterling area to new prosperity and stability.

MINEOLA, L. I., Jan. 5 -- Nassau County's District Court system tackled its long calendars of civil and criminal cases today unhampered by the usual overflow of traffic law violators. The new Central Traffic Bureau opened for business in the still uncompleted administration building on Courthouse Drive to handle ticket holders and the fines mailed in by first offenders.

ROME -- Foreign trade was, in previous years, the sector of the Italian economy that furnished the most comforting symptoms of post-war recovery. In 1952, instead, exports showed a sharp drop, accompanied by an increase of imports and a consequent large increase of the trade deficit.

LANSING, Mich., Jan. 5 -- A trend in the automotive industry to the manufacture of robot cars that will relieve drivers of almost all manual effort was indicated here today. A summary of construction improvements showed that ease in driving, steering, starting and stopping had been greatly advanced.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands -- Dutch foreign trade developed favorably last year. For the first eleven months imports were covered by exports for nearly 94 per cent. There even were months with an export surplus (April with a "cover" of 102 per cent and September with a "cover" of 114 per cent.)

JAKARTA, Indonesia -- The Indonesian Government, in a drastic move to slash foreign exchange expenditures, has listed twenty-seven items for which foreign exchange will not be granted. In effect, this bans them from importation.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands -- Evidence has been accumulating in the past year that the Dutch economic position is slowly being sapped away in Indonesia, the colony to which the Netherlands granted independence three years ago.

The visit of Korean President Rhee to Japan is at the personal invitation of General Clark, but Mr. Rhee has offered a friendly hand to the Japanese. His Government, he says, is willing to meet Japan halfway if Japan is ready to reciprocate.

International advertising, despite many obstacles, made considerable progress last year and is expected to continue to increase through 1953, according to executives of the advertising agencies most active in that field.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 5 -- Negotiations between top-level representatives of the Philadelphia Transportation Company and the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., broke off an hour after they were resumed today.

ROME -- Foreign trade was, in previous years, the sector of the Italian economy that furnished the most comforting symptoms of post-war recovery. In 1952, instead, exports showed a sharp drop, accompanied by an increase of imports and a consequent large increase of the trade deficit.

LANSING, Mich., Jan. 5 -- A trend in the automotive industry to the manufacture of robot cars that will relieve drivers of almost all manual effort was indicated here today. A summary of construction improvements showed that ease in driving, steering, starting and stopping had been greatly advanced.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands -- Dutch foreign trade developed favorably last year. For the first eleven months imports were covered by exports for nearly 94 per cent. There even were months with an export surplus (April with a "cover" of 102 per cent and September with a "cover" of 114 per cent.)

JAKARTA, Indonesia -- The Indonesian Government, in a drastic move to slash foreign exchange expenditures, has listed twenty-seven items for which foreign exchange will not be granted. In effect, this bans them from importation.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands -- Evidence has been accumulating in the past year that the Dutch economic position is slowly being sapped away in Indonesia, the colony to which the Netherlands granted independence three years ago.

The visit of Korean President Rhee to Japan is at the personal invitation of General Clark, but Mr. Rhee has offered a friendly hand to the Japanese. His Government, he says, is willing to meet Japan halfway if Japan is ready to reciprocate.

International advertising, despite many obstacles, made considerable progress last year and is expected to continue to increase through 1953, according to executives of the advertising agencies most active in that field.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 5 -- Negotiations between top-level representatives of the Philadelphia Transportation Company and the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., broke off an hour after they were resumed today.

The forthcoming establishment of the Henry Ittleson Center for Child Research at 5050 Iselin Avenue, Riverdale, the Bronx, as a project for treatment and research for emotionally disturbed children was announced yesterday. It is expected that the building will be renovated in time so the program may be started in the spring.
SINGAPORE -- From the trade and production point of view the Communist rebellion in Malaya was not a serious hindrance during 1952.
The Navy's Military Sea Transportation Service paid commercial ship repair yards $70,000,000 last year to keep its ships fit for sea duty.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Jan. 5 -- A twin-engine British airliner from London [1 on map] crashed and burst into flames while landing near Belfast [2] tonight, killing at least twenty-seven of the thirty-five persons aboard and injuring seven.

Guaranty Trust Company of New York showed gains in deposits, loans and total resources for the quarter ending on Dec. 31, according to its statement of condition to be published today. Although loans and resources were also higher by comparison with the previous year, deposits showed a slight decline.
ROME -- The Italian tourist industry had a record year in 1952 and expects to do even better in 1953.
WASHINGTON Jan. 5 (AP) -- Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican of Ohio, indicated tonight that he favored continuation of the reciprocal trade agreements program in about its present form.
THE HAGUE, the Netherlands -- This country reaped the rewards of low prices in 1952 with the greatest tourist boom in its history, and this year is expected to be even better.

A proposal that the city immediately order 13,000 parking meters, in addition to the 13,000 ordered last Dec. 9, and sell commercial advertising space on the entire 26,000 was advanced last night by Rudolph Halley, President of the City Council.

" A Tale of Five Women," a comedy-drama filmed in London, Paris, Berlin, Rome and Vienna, has been booked into the Sixtieth Street Trans-Lux where it is slated to have its local premiere on Thursday, Jan. 15, it was announced by United Artists, the distributors.

NEWARK, Jan. 5 -- Mayor John V. Kenny of Jersey City gave his promise in court today that he would testify at tomorrow's public hearing of the New Jersey Law Enforcement Council, but his attorney declared later that he would "start fireworks" if any "loaded" questions were put to the Mayor.
ROME -- The development of defense appropriations and spending in Italy is shown by the following table:

The city's school children, exhibiting an enthusiasm for their classes that amazed teachers and principals, took the bus strike in their stride yesterday as they flocked back to school after the holiday recess.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 5 -- Allal El Fassi, one of seven Moroccan nationalists whose passports have been rescinded by the International Administration at Tangier, left New York yesterday by plane for Cairo, his associates here said today. He had been in New York since the debate in the United Nations General Assembly over French policy in Tunisia and Morocco.

MONTREAL, Jan. 5 (AP) -- The police said today that discovery in a rooming house of a pistol, a knife and documents containing information on Communist activities might prove "one of the most important caches of subversive data found in Montreal."

The predominant feature of the concert given last night by the National Orchestral Society, Leon Barzin conductor, in Carnegie Hall, was the whirlwind performance by young Philippe Entremont of a highly modern and exciting piano concerto of Andre Jolivet, heard for the first time in this country.
Traffic deaths throughout the nation were the highest in its history over the Christmas and New Year week-end periods, The Associated Press said yesterday on the basis of available figures.

An agreement among New York City's Democratic leaders yesterday cleared the way for selection of Assemblyman Eugene F. Bannigan of Brooklyn and Senator Francis J. Mahoney of Manhattan as Minority Leaders of the 1953 Legislature.

CHICAGO, Jan. 5 -- The affiliation of seven Negro newspapers as Defender Publications was announced yesterday by John H. Sengstacke, editor and publisher of The Chicago Defender, who was elected president of the new organization.
TEHERAN, Iran -- Helped by the collection of tax arrears estimated at more than 1,000,000,000 rials ($30,300,000) Finance Minister Bagher Kazemi plans a "more or less balanced budget."

PARIS -- A sharp rise in the number of United States tourists last year helped to maintain the French tourist industry at a high level of activity comparable with that of 1951, when 5,200,000 visitors came to France.

Today is the feast of the Epiphany, of the Magi, of the Three Kings, of Little Christmas, of Twelfth Day. However one calls it, it is the celebration twelve days after Christmas that commemorates the visit of the Wise Men to the Christ Child.

It is hard to disagree with the main thesis of Professor Schwartz' letter of Dec. 30, in which he takes issue with the Loyalty Board's statement on John Carter Vincent -- namely, that "correctness of judgment" can be a "criterion of loyalty" only in a totalitarian country.

PARIS -- Reorganization and the clean-up of French nationalized industries continued throughout 1952, but a good deal remains to be done. The sectors of these industries that have most improved are the nationalized banks and the electric power system.
