SANTA MONICA, Calif., Jan. 5 (AP) -- Judy Garland's mother, Mrs. Ethel Milne Gilmore, who helped her daughter along the path to film fame, but more recently was reported estranged from her, was found dead today on the Douglas Aircraft Company parking lot nearly four hours after she was due to report for work.

CARL SANDBURG is 75 years old today. To celebrate the occasion a dinner is being given in Chicago tonight at which a number of celebrities will make formal speeches honoring one of the most versatile of American writers. The world will little note nor long remember what is said in Chicago, but in all probability it will not soon forget a book which is published in New York today, Mr. Sandburg's "Always the Young Strangers."*

" Discovery," an anthology of original writing, will be published in the standard Pocket Books format on Feb. 3. The book, which contains contributions by such authors as William Styron, Norman Mailer and Hortense Calisher, presents three writers who make their literary debuts.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 7 -- The Hashemite Kingdom of Jordan, its tottering economy shored up by British grants, by British subsidies for the Arab Legion and by United Nations expenditures for refugee relief, was still looking in 1952 for a better basis for survival.

Carl Sandburg, reaching the age of 75 today, can have no doubt of the affection in which his countrymen hold him. He is more than a poet, biographer, historian, more than a man of infinitely entertaining and moving words. Child of Swedish parents, son of the Middle West, epic interpreter of Abraham Lincoln, poet laureate of Chicago, he has been a kind of literary Liberty Bell ringing across the prairies and the decades.

Those Third Avenue habitues who are normally accustomed to seeing pink elephants were startled more than usual last night when they saw a real luxury cruiser posing right in the middle of the thoroughfare under the elevated structure at Ninety-sixth Street.
BERLIN -- Because the Communists apparently decided that German unity was no longer a possibility to be reckoned with, 1952 was a turning point for the Soviet zone.

Eugene G. Grace, chairman of the board of Bethlehem Steel, will be among those honored at the Metropolitan Golf Writers Association dinner at Toots Shor's on Jan. 29. The scribes have named Grace as the person who has "contributed the most to golf over the years."

PARIS -- With the official end of the Marshall Plan effort for European recovery, the economy of Western Europe has been considerably improved, but there remains a serious imbalance in European trade relations, shown by the standings of the countries in the European Payments Union, and a continued imbalance in Europe's relations with the United States as manifested by the problem of the dollar gap.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark -- The improvement in the basic situation of the Danish economy that began in the second half of 1951 continued through 1952. Despite some recession, marked by a decline in industrial production of around 7 per cent compared with 1951, the inflationary crisis appears to have been overcome and there has been a decisive betterment in the balance-of-payments situation.

Eastern Air Lines' traffic and revenues for 1952 were the highest in the company's history, Capt. E. V. Rickenbacker, president and general manager, said yesterday. In view of the growing industrialiaztion of the South and the development of all-year vacations in Florida, he predicted highly favorable conditions for the line in 1953.

ROCQUENCOURT, France, Jan. 6 -- Senior Allied commanders from throughout the North Atlantic Treaty area conferred in succession today with General Matthew B. Ridgway, the Supreme Allied Commander in Europe, as the latter began the new year with an exhaustive military stocktaking of defense forces available to him.

Allegations that the Communist party in the United States was committed to a policy of force and violence were attacked as preposterous yesterday by the defense at the Federal court trial of thirteen second-team Communist leaders accused of conspiring to teach and advocate the forcible overthrow of the Government.

The city's long-range financial program, as submitted yesterday by Mayor Impellitteri to the Legislature for consideration at its 1953 session, opening today, calls for new net revenues in 1953-54 of $126,500,000 exclusive of rapid transit financing.

SAN JUAN, P. R. -- Sugar production for 1951-52 was 1,359,840 tons compared with 1,228,000 for the previous fiscal year. However, the quantity shipped to the United States dropped from the 1950-51 total of 1,064,475 tons valued at $134,870,000, to 904,438 tons valued at $113,250,000 in 1951-52.

WASHINGTON -- The Good Neighbor policy, a standard fixture of United States relations with Latin America since its pronouncement nearly twenty years ago, finally in 1952 began to run into criticism from both sides of the Rio Grande.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Jan. 6 -- Navy, the nation's scoring leader, ran its victory string to seven today by defeating a stubborn Johns Hopkins five, 77 -- 50.

Mal Whitfield, whose most cherished goals are sole possession of the world 880-yard record and a third straight Olympic 800-meter title in 1956, yesterday received the green light from the Metropolitan A. A. U. registration committee to compete for the first time in the local association's indoor track and field championships.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- Two more major aluminum producers, the Reynolds Metals Company and the Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation, today rejected the Government's conditional offer of a ceiling price increase for their product. The offer had already been turned down by the Aluminum Company of America.

MEXICO CITY -- Mexico's face is changing rapidly. Already her portrait must be removed from the section of the world gallery devoted to backward areas and re-hung in the middle, developing group. The heart of the change is an industrial revolution.

Nineteen fifty-two marked the twenty-fifth anniversary of commercial air transport between the United States and the Good Neighbor republics to the south. What began with a precarious ninety-mile flight from Key West to Havana on Oct. 27, 1927, has now grown to one of the great sky networks of the world.
CHICAGO, Jan. 6 (AP) -- A slightly discordant note was sounded today amidst the general prediction of optimistic business and economic forecasts for 1953.

CINCINNATI, Jan. 6 (AP) -- Officials of the National Cash Register Company, Dayton, Ohio, are to appear in U. S. District Court tomorrow to request the court's permission to buy controlling interest in the Computer Research Corporation, Hawthorne, Calif. Judge John H. Druffel is to preside.

MEXICO CITY -- Negotiations looking toward more foreign capital participation in the Mexican petroleum and gas industries were conducted spasmodically through 1952, but without reaching any definite agreements.

Directors of the American Express Company have elected Albert R. Cotterill, assistant secretary, and Richard A. Taylor, personnel director, to be vice presidents, Ralph T. Reed, president, also announced yesterday the election of George M. Shirey as vice president and general manager, London; H. Wybrand de Jong, vice president and general manager, Amsterdam; Gerard J. Gilmore, assistant vice president and sales manager, travel, and Charles A. Cuccineloo, assistant vice president, investment department.

OTTAWA -- There are today about 3,500,000 families in Canada compared with 2,500,000 before the war. This rapid increase has called for a tremendous effort to provide new housing and in the seven years since the end of the war 570,000 housing units have been built.

Near-record production levels were achieved by the gypsum industry in 1952, along with the national building boom, it is reported by Lloyd H. Yeager, general manager of the Gypsum Association. He said the industry expected its markets to hold firm in 1953.
In 1953 many United States business leaders gave increasing emphasis to the importance of developing new sources of raw materials in Latin America to meet this country's future needs.

MEXICO CITY -- Responding to continued high prices in the world market, Mexican mining and metallurgical output showed a slight rise last year over 1951 and minerals took first place on Mexico's list of exports.

In a press interview on his arrival in New York Mr. Churchill made two statements which give a clue to his motives in coming to this country before the new Administration is installed. One was on Korea and reflected the nervous feeling on the other side of the Atlantic that General Eisenhower means to make a new and perhaps risky attempt to break the deadlock in that dragging war.

MONTREAL -- Although the continuing surge of business expansion has been accompanied by an increase in freight tonnage hauled on the Canadian railways, net revenues have declined steadily in percentage terms since 1946 except for one year, Donald Gordon, chairman and president of the Canadian National, said in a yearend review. During that period each year has seen new records set in gross revenues.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 6 -- The production readjustment program under way at Paramount Pictures for the last several months has reached the lower salary brackets. Five out of the studio's staff of seven story analysts and nine stenographers have received dismissal notices.

MARTINS CREEK, Pa., Jan. 6 -- A new $1,000,000 railroad bridge designed to open up the Martins Creek section of the Delaware Valley for future industrial development was formally opened this afternoon by the Pennsylvania Railroad.

SUMMIT, Miss., Jan. 6 (UP) -- Mrs. Mary D. Cain, whose weekly newspaper was padlocked by the Government after she had refused to pay Social Security taxes on herself, reopened her plant today with a hacksaw.

OTTAWA -- The Canadian Government Travel Bureau spent an estimated $917,123 for newspaper, magazine and film advertising during 1952, mostly in the United States, and serviced 275,426 individual tourist inquiries.

BUFFALO, Jan. 6 -- A placid hearing of the Temporary State Commission on the Use of Television for Educational Purposes was stirred suddenly here today when a labor union official declared that some members of the commission were prejudiced against educational television.

BERLIN, Jan. 6 -- The United States was charged today with anti-Semitism in its sentencing Julius and Ethel Rosenberg to the electric chair. At a mass meeting in East Berlin the passions of several thousand persons were aroused by a procession of clergymen and other speakers at a Communist-backed rally to urge the pardoning of the American couple.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 6 -- In addition to the resumed session of the General Assembly in February, arrangements have been made for eleven meetings to be held at United Nations Headquarters between now and the end of March.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 (AP) -- A vast expansion of production and competition in the nation's aluminum industry was reported by a Senate-House committee tonight with a suggestion that the Government follow "a hands-off policy" on future development.

SANTIAGO, Chile -- Year-end indications tend to show a healthier outlook for Chile's copper production than that of a few months ago. Sales continue strong, with virtually all now going to the United States at the price fixed by the Central Bank of Chile of 35 1/2 cents a pound.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Jan. 7 (AP) -- An Army nurse today testified at the murder trial of Mrs. Dorothy Krueger Smith that the attractive daughter of a general told her "I stabbed my husband with a 10-inch Japanese knife -- he was asleep when I did it."

PARIS, Wednesday, Jan. 7 -- Rene Mayer was voted Premier of France at 3 o'clock this morning after he had promised to subordinate ratification of the European Army Treaty to an agreement on the Saar and to new negotiations to modify the treaty.

HONG KONG, Jan. 6 -- Communist China's state trading companies, which now dominate the commercial economy, have been instructed to give greater retail leeway to the private merchant while increasing their own profit margins in the wholesale business.
LONDON, Jan. 6 -- The stock markets here remained quiet today but closed on a firm note after a recovery had eliminated early losses. One or two British Government securities closed with gains.

There should be widespread support for the measures aimed at increasing safety on the road which our Albany correspondent reports Governor Dewey will recommend to the Legislature. The Governor will undoubtedly drive hard for enactment of compulsory periodic inspection of motor vehicles. He also favors the re-examination of all drivers for physical fitness and periodical examinations thereafter.

JERSEY CITY, N. J., Jan. 6 -- The holdover Hudson County grand jury handed up two perjury indictments today against Edward J. Florio, 57-year-old former Hoboken waterfront boss, who started serving an eighteen-month Federal prison term for perjury yesterday.

RIO DE JANEIRO -- United States and Brazilian experts in the last year have completed drafts for nineteen high-priority projects to develop Brazil's economy at a cost of $493,400,000. Of that, $231,300,000 is to be in loans from the Export-Import Bank and the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development. Loans totaling $93,900,000 already have been granted by the banks.

RANGOON, Burma, Jan. 6 -- More than 200 representatives of Asian, European and African Socialist parties assembled today in Municipal Hall for the opening session of the world's first Asian Socialist Conference.
CARACAS, Venezuela -- Venezuela enjoyed another boom year in 1952 and -- barring unforeseen developments -- promises to repeat the performance in 1953.

Picketing in labor-management disputes, except in certain cases, is a legitimate activity. But union picketing union for the purpose of forcing an employer to assign particular work to employes in a particular organization, trade, craft or class would seem to be barred under the Taft-Hartley Act.

The Latin American nations have been cautioned that free enterprise offers a better road than statism for reaching the economic goals they are seeking. They were told this is because the free enterprise system is the best way to increase production and national wealth without sacrificing individual liberty and private initiative. Also, they were told, it is the system under which foreign capital is most likely to seek investment within their boundaries.

Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower yesterday summoned his top appointees to meet with him here next Monday and Tuesday for "a general discussion of problems confronting the new Administration, both domestic and foreign."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- Senator Everett M. Dirksen, Republican of Illinois, warned today that "hell will pop" in Congress if the talks between Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower and Prime Minister Winston Churchill produced any scheme for United States financial aid to Britain in restoring convertibility of the pound sterling.

The Peiping radio has announced that in line with the agreement of last September Soviet Russia has relinquished, as of Dec. 31, all its rights to joint administration of the Manchurian railway system and has returned that lifeline of Manchurian economy to Communist China without compensation, together with "all property belonging to the railway."

BOGOTA, Colombia, Jan. 5 -- Venezuela will insist on changing the name of the Flota Mercante Grancolombiana (Grand Colombian Merchant Fleet), if the Government remains as one of the principal stockholders in the company largely financed by the Governments of Colombia, Venezuela and Ecuador; it was learned today.

HAVANA -- A sugar surplus and a feeling of uncertainty as to the country's political future have brought Cuba to the verge of an economic recession despite the prosperity of 1952. Whether the recession develops in 1953 will depend to a great extent on world conditions, according to financial circles.
MEXICO CITY -- Steady but not soaring inflation has kept the cost of living on the rise in Mexico, and it moved upward a little faster in 1952 than it had in previous years.

Only 249 pints, well below the quota, were donated to the American Red Cross blood donor program on Monday, officials reported yesterday. All the contributions were made at the city's three donor centers.

HAMILTON, Bermuda -- With a current annual intake of $28,000,000 to $30,000,000, United States and Canadian Bermuda was described by a semi-authoritative source here recently as the largest dollar earner per capita in the sterling pool.

Before an audience of 1,250 buyers and merchandise executives, the Millinery Stabilization Commission unfolded its spring 1953 showing last night at the Astor Hotel. The Millinery Stabilization Commission is composed of New York hat designers and manufacturers; forty-five of the members exhibited their designs.
An unexpected pause took place yesterday in the stock market.

RIO DE JANEIRO -- Foreign exchange was the pivot of Brazil's problems all through 1952, and the situation was only partly cleared up by the adoption of a law allowing "free" exchange near the end of the year.

QUITO, Ecuador -- Business was better in Ecuador in 1952 than in 1951 and prospects for 1953 appear to be favorable, at least for the first six months. The trend in 1953 will depend largely on the action taken on new economic measures that may be passed by a special session of Congress called for Jan. 8.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 6 -- The closing of 107 of the city's 174 public schools by a labor dispute gave Baltimore an opportunity today to conduct one of the country's first mass experiments in television school teaching.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 6 -- Premier Marshal Tito of Yugoslavia has let it be known here he favors a personal meeting with Premier Alcide De Gasperi of Italy to seek a settlement of differences between the two countries.
HAVANA (AP) -- The Cuban Government is trying to run one of the most difficult businesses in the world -- growing henequen for foreign markets.

KANSAS CITY, Jan. 6 (AP) -- A Federal grand jury today indicted the Kansas City Star Company, Roy A. Roberts, president, and Emil A. Sees, advertising director, on two counts of violating the Sherman Anti-Trust Act.
SAN JUAN, P. R. -- In August, 1952, 63,400 persons were employed in industries in Puerto Rico, against 58,800 in December, 1951. Close to half the employes in August, 30,200, were women.

MONTREAL -- Canada's aluminum industry last year achieved a marked increase in production and made substantial progress in its big expansion program under the sustained pressure of demand for the light metal.
